title: DR. AARON GOLDBAUM
description: Dr. Aaron Goldbaum, an obstetrician and gynecologist who helped establish the gynecology department of Harlem Hospital, died here yesterday at the age of 66. He lived at 12 West 96th Street.

title: Rivals at Paris Trade Charges But Will Continue Peace Talks
description: PARIS, Aug. 31Delegates to the Vietnam peace talks here blamed each other's sides today for the unending war and agreed to meet again next Thursday.

title: It's All Greek
description: The public justifications given by the Administration for its expanding military entanglements with the dismal Greek regime of Premier George Papadopoulos comprise an unconvincing series of contradictions, vagaries and evershifting rationalizations.

title: 262,807 ABORTIONS IN STATE IN 1971
description: ALBANY, Aug. 31A total of 262,807 induced abortions were performed in New York in 1971, the majority of them in New York City, the State Health Department reported today.

title: Primary Appeals Are Set
description: ALBANY Aug. 31 (UPI)The State Court of Appeals will hear challenges to results of the June 20 primary on Sept. 12, it was announced yesterday. It will be the only special session before the court's regular term begins Sept. 25.

title: Joseph T. Dineen Dies at 62; Former Investment Banker
description: Joseph T. Dineen, a retired investment banker, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Sea Island, Ga. He was 62 years old and also maintained a residence in Summit, N. J.

title: Executive Changes
description: Frederick R. Einsidler, 47 years old, has been elected president, chief executive officer and a director of Butler Aviation International, Inc. He formerly was president of Consultants and Designers, Inc.

title: 3 Jewish Groups Ask for Investigation of Fuentes
description: Three Jewish organizations announced yesterday that they had filed a formal petition with Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner calling for an investigation of the appointment of Luis Fuente as superintendent of Community School District 1, on the Lower East Side.

title: Experts Forecast Fischer To Win Chess Title Today
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 31Experts who watched Boris Spassky seal his 41st move tonight felt certain that a new world chess champion would be crowned tomorrow. Bobby Fischer, playing the black pieces in the 21st game of the series, had a very strong edge in the adjourned position, and little hope was offered for Spassky.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Eugene V. Rostow insists (letter Aug. 22) that the real issue about Vietnam in the campaign is that responsible leaders of opinion should not rewrite history. Ironically, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, 196669, who served with Secretary of State Rusk, does indeed rewrite history when he contends that the nation committed itself to the Vietnam policy through the SEATO Treaty.

title: 2 U.S. SPRINTERS SHUT OUT IN MIXUP
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 31 (UPI)The opening day of track and field competition in the Olympics turned into a calamity for the United States team today, partly because of an apparent mixup in the time schedule for the 100meter dash. In quick succession:

title: Alcoa and Amax Sign Deal
description: Alcoa of Australia, Ltd., and American Metal Climax, Inc., announced in Perth, Australia, yesterday that they had signed a supply contract under which Alcoa will initially supply Amax with 400,000 tons of alumina a year beginning in 1975.

title: Auto Production for Week Shows Gains, Led by G.M.
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP)Auto production continued to rise this week as General Motors built up to full strength after a lengthy changeover, Automotive News reported today.

title: Premier, 71, Loses In British Columbia
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 31  In a stunning political upset, 71yearold W. A. C. Bennett was defeated as Premier of British Columbia yesterday, after 20 years in office.

title: Knicks Sign Riker, Scoring Star
description: The Knicks, looking to the future when their aging, talented front line is phased out, signed Tom Riker, their 22yearold No. 1 draft choice yesterday. Riker, a high school allAmerican at St. Dominic's in Oyster Bay, L. I., and a 19.6 scorer last season at South Carolina, received a threeyear nocut con tract.

title: Books of The Times
description: Rage is the fuel that makes Sol Yurick's fiction burna revolutionist's rage at the urban bureaucratic machine that flattens people into forgotten file drawers. Rage was in his novel Fertig, about a man avenging himself on random people because a skip in the machine had destroyed his child. Rage spilled out of The Bag,

title: 2 Killed in Texas Blast
description: FREEPORT, Tex., Aug. 31 (AP)An explosion in two box cars at the Rhodia, Inc., petrochemical plant tonight killed two persons, injured 10 others and started a fire, the poice said. The plant, on Texas 332. is next to the Dow Chemical Company complex.

title: Advertising:
description: A series of publicservice radio spots is being planned on a subject that may never have been broadcast on a nationwide scale before: consumers use of smallclaims courts.

title: Screen: 'Money Talks':Film by Allen Funt Is in Familiar Pattern
description: "Money Talks," which opened Wednesday at neighborhood theaters, is Allen Funt's second movie in a format familiar to anyone who has seen his television show, "Candid Camera." It is an in-offensive, mostly innocuous film, and as such must represent a giant step up from "What Do You Say to a Naked Lady," Funt's first movie, virtually an essay in the immortality of inviting people to make fools of themselves.It is also a film somewhat short of material, for although it is only 81 minutes long, it devotes conspicuous amounts of time to the image of Allen Funt enjoying his work and to a kind of thematic filler material: bowls of free money on the sidewalk; girls trailing clouds of money down a busy street.There is one potentially good interview(scene near the Harvard Yard; "About your father's money  how can you keep taking it?" "Now, that's a really complicated question . . .")but it doesn't go anywhere. And there is one distinctly pleasant sequence in which a man without money tap-dances for a bouquet of flowers, for his groceries, for a shoeshineand everyone seems to feel he's been well enough paid.Indeed, the distinctive feature of "Money Talks," whether by accident or by the filmmaker's selection, is that almost nobody it deals with is very much obsessed with money. There are moments of petty cheatingon the level of a taxi driver's not turning on his meterbut there is much more personal honesty. Almost everybody returns to the pretty girl the bills that keep dropping from her coat pocket. I assume that they are small bills."Money Talks" avoids major temptations, just as it avoids extremes of poverty or wealth. Its rewards are a certain amount of temperate humor, a few middling insights and the inconsequence attendant on a small subject casually pursued.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON CAPITAL PIPPIN
description: An agreement reached yesterday between a musicians union local and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington will permit Pippin, the Stephen SchwartzRoger O. Hirson musical, to open Sept. 20 at the Center's Opera House for a fourweek engagement as originally planned.

title: Ohio Dentist Is Charged In Unregistered Stock Case
description: An Ohio dentist accused of selling unregistered stock while board chairman of a former New York securities firm known as the Midwestern Securities Corporation, has been directed by the State Supreme Court to show cause why he should not be permanently barred from the securities business in New York State.

title: Beef Stew and a Dessert With Fresh Blueberries
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Merger Plans Postponed
description: Thu U.S. Life Corporation) and the Old . Line Insurance Company of America, which have announced plans to merge, said yesterday that a stockholders meeting to vote on the proposal has been postironed because of problems with state and Federal regulators. They did not elaborate further although one source close to the situation said that the Securities and Exchange Commission had taken an interest. A spokesman for Old Line declined comment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Is the real world of President Richard Nixon and the Republican party represented by the picture we saw on television of the thousands of multicolored balloons descending upon the happy delegates at the Republican National Convention celebrating the nomination of their candidate? Or is another picture of over 3,550,000 tons of explosives descending upon the people in the lands of Indochina in the three and onehalf years of his Administration?

title: Birth Shelves Rights Case Of a Pregnant Teacher
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 31 (UPI) The planned court hearing for a pregnant schoolteacher who wanted to begin teaching this fall was postponed indefinitely here today.

title: Officials Testify in Favor of Mayor's Graffiti Bill
description: The Lindsay administration presented some highranking city officials yesterday in support of its bill to curb graffiti, before a poorly attended session of a 15member City Council committee.

title: CANDIDATES AIDES SPAR OVER TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Spokesmen for President Nixon and Senator George McGovern traded criticisms today on the subject of the Senator's new tax reform and welfare programs, and the Senator challenged the President to debate the issues on network television.

title: Nixon Stalls Raises For U.S. Employes From Oct.1 to Jan. 1
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 31 (UPI) President Nixon today postponed from Oct. 1 to Jan. 1 the automatic pay increases established for Federal employes.

title: Alternatives to Reformatories Hailed Amid Controversy in Massachusetts
description: BOSTONWhen Dr. Jerome G. Miller became commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Youth Services three years ago, an official asked him where he stood on the binding and gagging of children, an established punitive practice at one of the states six reform schools.

title: NonMoslem Builders Visit Meccaby TV
description: In Mecca, the holy city where only Moslems may tread, closedcircuit television is allowing 20 French and West German technicians to supervise the construction of the Mecca InterContinental Hotel.

title: Peking to Head U.N. Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP)Peking's delegate to the United Nations, Huang Hua, will become president of the Security Council Friday for the first time since the Communist Government was seated in the United Nations last October. Mr. Huang succeds Edouard Longerstaey of Belgium in the post, which rotates every month among the 15 Council members in alphabetical order.

title: Turner to Split His Dare to Be Grpat
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 31 (AP)Glenn W. Turner said today that he would split his legally embattled Dare To Be Great selfmotivation concern into 500 companies and give them away if necessary.

title: A NEW TOWER DUE IN FINANCIAL AREA
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced plans yesterday for a $60million, 24story office tower to stand atop four steel columns adjacent to the bank's headquarters in the financial district.

title: U.S. Aides in Vietnam See an Unending War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31Two weeks after Henry A. Kissinger's surprise visit to Saigon, highranking American officials here are talking privately not of a breakthrough in the peace talks, but, rather, of the possibility of unending war.

title: Thai Is Accused in Plane Blast Fatal to 81, Including His Child
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 31 (AP)A Thai police lieutenant was arrested today in connection with a June 15 plane explosion over South Vietnam that killed his 7yearold daughter and 80 other persons. Police spokesmen said that he had heavily insured the child before the flight.

title: Stranded Tourists Back From Britain And Irked at U.S.
description: With caustic words for American Embassy officials in Britain, whom they accused of failing to help them, some 140 tourists returned to New York yesterday after having been stranded, many without money, at London's Gatwick Airport for four nights.

title: LIFTER FROM IRAN BARRED ON DRUGS
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 31On the fifth day of competition the Olympic Games doping control officials caught their first offenderan Iranian weight lifterand disqualified him retroactively today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Senator George McGovern continued today to attempt to allay the fears of the United States allies that if he was elected President he would weaken the country's commitments abroad.

title: Man in the News
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 31Premier Kakuei Tanaka may do most of the talking for the Japanese side during the summit conference here. But if President Nixon and his adviser for national security, Henry A. Kissinger, have been well briefed, they will not overlook the man at Mr. Tanaka's side, Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira, whose silence and sleepy look could be misleading. It has been Mr. Ohira, rather than Mr. Tanaka, who has been the architect of Japan's new China policy. The Foreign Minister is the planner of Japan's China strategy, the executor of her diplomatic tactics and the builder of the consensus required of all national decisions before they are put forward.

title: STOCK PRICES RISE ON AMEX AND QTC
description: Stock prices edged ahead yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market. The upturn was the first in eight days on the Amex.

title: FAVORED WOMEN ADVANCE EASILY IN TITLE TENNIS
description: Billie Jean was intimidating, Evonne was mesmerizing. Chris proved relentless. Rosemary was demoralizing, and Margaret looked overwhelming. That's how the girlwatchers rated the top five women players yesterday at the United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Yanks Top Rangers, 70, On Peterson's 5Hitter
description: The New York Yankees unseeded and unloved earlier in the summer  charged out ??? August yesterday with a 7.0 victory over the Texas Rangers and headed into the homestretch of the baseball season in a fourway race for the American League's Eastern championship.

title: Woman Named Dean At the Cooper Union
description: John F. White, president of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, yesterday announced the appointment of Mrs. Marilyn Gore as dean of students.

title: Manila Shanty Dwellers Protest Eviction From City Waterways
description: MANILA, Aug. 31  Eviction as a floodprevention measure of more than 100,000 squatters who live in shanties erected over the many waterways of Manila is proving to be a difficult and politically awkward operation for both the city and the national Government.

title: Weekly Store Sales Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $895million, up 8 per cent from the year earlier $832million in sales. Total retail store sales were about $8.42billion up 7 per cent from the year earlier $7.85billion.

title: 2 HELD WITH KEYS, GUNS AND JEWELRY
description: Two men were arrested in the Bronx last night after the police said that the stolen car in which they were riding contained two loaded handguns, 2,000 keys, including master keys for hotels, and assorted jewelry.

title: N.B.C TO EXPAND INTO TOMORROW
description: The Natonal Broadcastng Company, which has televised the popular Today show for the last 20 years and The Tonight Show for 18 years, plans to introduce a new, onehour program, Tomorrow, that will go on the air at A.M., following The Tonight Show.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Artaud's theater of cruelty is tame compared to the spectacle which was emitted from Miami this week. Each slanted phrase was punched at the audience with devilish glee; each young person was exploited for theatricality.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: When a near majority of youth vote for Richard Nixon in November, it will not be particularly for the personality of the President nor for his policies. Rather, it will be part of the inexorable conservative turn by the youth of this country during the past two years.

title: Revenues Climb 12%
description: UAL, Inc., the parent of United Air Lines, continued its upward climb in earnings with a 24.8 per cent increase in July net to $8.508,000 for its airline subsidiary from 86,817,000 in the yearearlier month, the company reported yesterday.

title: BELMONT FEATURE TO COLD COMFORT
description: Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, always unflappable, had a few anxious moments during the running of the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. His 5yearold mare, Cold Comfort, odds on in a field of seven fillies and mares competing in the sevenfurlong turf event encountered the sternest and most obstinate opposition from Fred Hooper's Mainzier, the complete outsider in the betting.

title: Derailment on IND Forces A Rerouting of D Trains
description: A southbound IND train was derailed just south of the stattion at 53d Street and Seventh Avenue late yesterday afternoon, forcing the Transit Authority to reroute D trains well into the evening.

title: Turning on the Heat in Vietnam
description: LELAND, Mich.In two previous Vietnam articles on this page, I discussed the options open to President Nixon. Briefly they were: (1) get out of Vietnam, (2) continue stalemate, (3) escalate the war, (4) Vietnamization. After a visit to Vietnam, I discussed Mr. Nixon's adoption of the Vietnamization program. It has succeeded exceptionally well, to the extent that its objective is about to be reached with withdrawal of practically all U.S. ground forces from Vietnam and the assumption of their responsibilities by the South Vietnamese.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON. Aug. 31 (AP)World economic growth, led by the United States and Japan, will continue expanding next year and major industrial nations with the exception of Britain will curb price inflation.

title: CHARLES MERINOFF
description: Charles Merinoff, chairman of Charmer Industries, Inc., wholesale distributors of liquors and wines in the metropolitan area, died Wednesday at his home in Atlantic Beach, L.I. His age was 71.

title: GIANTS GET SET TO PLAY EAGLES
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 31It was defensive day at the New York Giants camp today and Coach Alex Webster put in all of his defenses in preparation for Saturday's game against the Philadelphia Eagles in Princeton.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP)A Federal antipollution commitee will be headed for three years by a scientist from the State University of New York at Albany. Harry L. Hamilton, associate professor of atmospheric science, has been appointed to the Meteorology Advisory Committee of the Environmental Protection Agency. The committee's mission is to improve air quality.

title: Notes on People
description: George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, is unlikely to remain in his post long after the November election, according to knowledgeable H.U.D. officials. Mr. Romney has said he will stay on to work for the reelection of President Nixon. But the H.U.D. officials note that he failed to win White House support for a combined urbansuburban approach to city problems and say he is now considering a return to private industry.

title: Kennedy Center Opens Music Series
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31If it were customary to see thousands of people seated on a broad red carpet more than a block long, no one would have been surprised at the opening of The Old and the New music festival at Kennedy Center last night. But since even the festival planners had not anticipated such a sight, they were startled by the first glimpse of it.

title: Labor Day Is a Day for Anything But
description: Labor Day, the holiday for the nation's gainfully exhausted, beckons just ahead.

title: Williams Back in Play
description: Tennessee Williams once aagin is playing Doe in his current Small Craft Warnings at the New Theater. The playwright is expected to remain with the show for three weeks. The play's new leading lady is Peg Murray, who spent the last four years as Guide in Fiddler on the Roof.

title: Reprieve for Voters
description: A threejudge Federal court in Brooklyn has issued a temporary restraining order that will assure continuation of sidewalk voter registration at least until September 15th. Without the judicial reprieve, tomorrow would have been the last day for this convenient form of registering new voters.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I have just read the delightful letter written by Mary Torr Rehm, and published in The Times of Aug. 22.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK SELECTS PRESIDENT
description: Donald C. Platten was elected president of the Chemical New York Corporation and its principal subsidiary, the Chemical Bank, it was announced yesterday.

title: MRS. JACOB VINER
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 31Mrs. Frances K. Viner, widow of Prof. Jacob Viner, who for 40 years was an economic adviser to Government agencies, died Saturday at Princeton Hospital after a long illness. Her age was 75.

title: Personalities: Maglie in Hospital
description: Sal (The Barber) Maglie, the former majorleague pitching star, was in fair condition yesterday at Mount St. Mary's Hospial in Niagara Falls, N. Y., where he was admitted Wednesday following an apparent heart attack. Maglie, 55 years old, posted an outstanding record of 119 victories and 62 losses during his career with the New York Giants, the Brooklyn Dodgers, the Yankees and the Cardinals.

title: J. DONALD MULVEY
description: CHATHAM, N. J., Aug. 31 J. Donald Mulvey, who retired as a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company in 1968, died today at his home here. His age was 66.

title: Price Changes
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it would raise prices of methanol and formaldehyde beginning Oct. 1.

title: GEOFFREY ROLLASON, METALS EXECUTIVE
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 31Geoffrey M. Rollason, for many years an executive in the metals industries, died yesterday in the Muhlenberg Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 935 Belvedere Avenue.

title: For Homosexuals, It's Getting Less Difficult to Tell Parents
description: In 1970 Chuck Ortleb had been leading a double life as a homosexual posing as a heterosexual  for more than two years. Finally, he couldn't stand the deception any longer. So one evening, after he had attended a Gay Liberation meeting at the University of Kansas, where he was a student, he telephoned his parents long distance.

title: Fireman, 2 Sisters And 2d Man Killed In 3 Blazes in City
description: A fireman, two young sisters and an unidentified man were killed in three separate fires in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan yesterday.

title: QUEENS BALL FIELD BEING BUILT BY CITY
description: Construction was started yesterday on a $45,000 ball field for children and young people of Hamilton Beach, Queens, along the shore of Jamaica Bay.

title: JOHN G. STEIN DIES; LOCATED MISSING
description: UNIONDALE, L.T., Aug. 31 John G. Stein, who as acting captain commanded the Missing Persons Bureau of the New York Police Department from 1934 until his retirement in 1943, died yesterday in the Holly Patterson Home. He was 93 years old and lived at 1:3 Malverne Avenue, Malverne, L.I.

title: POLL ON ABORTIONS SCORED BY PRELATE
description: ALBANY, Aug. 31 (UPI) A recent Gallup poll claiming that 64 per cent of the public is not opposed to legal abortions used an ambiguous question that did not consider the rights of the unborn, a national spokesman for a Roman Catholic group said Wednesday.

title: Rail Ton Mileage Up 5.8%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 15.7 billion tonmiles, 5.8 per cent above the corresponding 1971 week. The A.A.R. also reported carloadings last week totaled 526,135 cars, 2.3 per cent above the comparable week a year ago. The American Trucking Association, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 1.6 per cent above last year.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.6 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 122.0 from 120.4 last week.

title: Steak Dishes, Korean Style
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and ddcor (four triangles to none).

title: Ulster Police Find Victim Of 49th Sectarian Murder
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 31 (Reuters)The police found the body of a man, hooded and shot in the head, slumped in an alleyway today, apparently the latest victim of sectarian killings that have claimed 49 lives here in the last two months.

title: Mako Shark Sets Record
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (UPI) Joe Gorgita, a commercial fisherman using a harpoon, killed the biggest mako shark ever seen, the County Museum of Natural History said today. The shark, an old female 11 feet 5 inches, long and weighing 1,030 pounds, set a world record, Dr. Shelton Applegate, the museum's paleontologist, said. The mako shark swims in oceans around the world and is feared as a maneater.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: BASF Wyandotte Concern Agrees to Job Rights Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) A Michiganbased chemical company with plants in 10 states has agreed to end discriminatory hiring and promotion policies, the Justice Department said today.

title: Petite Russian Glamour Girl Is Big Winner in Gymnastics
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 31 (UPI)  Everything about Olga Korbut of the Soviet Union is tiny except her talent as a gymnast, and that was big enough to win her two gold medels and one silver in individual competition at the 20th Olympics tonight.

title: HIRING BIAS CITED IN LABOR AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The Department of Labor said today that it was taking steps to correct what its own investigation last year found to be pervasive and substantial underutilization of minorities and women in the department.

title: Dodgers Beat Cubs, 53
description: CHICAGO Aug. 31, (AP) Claude Osteen checked the Chicago Cubs on seven hits and singled to score what proved to be the winning run today as the Los Angeles Dodgers won a 53 National League baseball victory.

title: Astros Beat Phils, 51
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 31 (AP)Doug Rader's tworun single capped a fourrun uprising in the third inning and Larry Dierker scattered seven hits to lead the Houston Astros to a 51 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

title: Brewers Trim Royals, 73
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 (AP) Dave May's tworun single sparked a threerun uprising in the second inning tonight as the Milwaukee Brewers recorded a 73 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Kresge Sales Gain 20%
description: The large retail sales advance in August was underscored yesterday by reports of sizable gains in the month by three additional retail chains.

title: GEORGE B. TEPPER
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 31  George B. Tepper, a City Court judge here, died of a heart atack yesterday at the Long Beach Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: Devoted Audience for Street Theater
description: Every day for the last two weeks Lincoln Center's plaza has been filled with 500 to 1,000 people participating in the free Community/Street Theater Festival. There have been senior citizens basking in the sunshine, young mothers with infants, people in wheelchairs, teenagers of all descriptions and large groups of black children as young as 5.

title: Court Ruling May Restrict Florida's Beach Buildings
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 31 (AP)In a decision that may establish a precedent involving the use of Florida's beaches, the First District Court of Appeal ordered today the dismantling of a 176foot observation tower that it said interfered with the public's right to use Daytona Beach.

title: DR. DAVID DU BOW
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 31Dr. David T. Du Bow, who served from 1951 to 1965 as chief medical officer at the JohnsManville plant at Manville, died today at his home, 222 Stelle Avenue. He was 71 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: City Council President Garelik is to be congratulated for charging O.T.B. with engaging in medicineshow huckstering when it opened its Harlem office on 125th Street earlier this month. Exhibiting a trotter, complete with trainerdriver answering questions, distributing shopping bags and awarding lottery prizes was a vulgar appeal to the basest instincts of people who can ill afford to gamble.

title: U.S. TOLL IN VIETNAM LAST WEEK PUT AT 5
description: SAIGON, Aug. 31The United States command said today that five Americans were killed in action and three wounded last week, in the lowest casualty toll of any week since recordkeeping began on Jan. 1, 1965.

title: Contracts With City U. Expire With 2 Sides Still Miles Apart
description: The threeyear contracts between the Board of Higher Educution and the faculty and professional staffs of the City University of New York eypired last night, with both sides reporting little progress toward a new comprehensive agreement.

title: O'BRIEN REPROVES MOVERN STAFF OVER LAX EFFORT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Evidence of dissension and disarray in the campaign organization of Senator George McGovern came to light today after Lawrence F. O'Brien made a veiled threat to quit as campaign chairman unless remedial action is taken by Monday.

title: Delay in Corona Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (AP)A delay was ordered today in the opening of the Juan V. Corona murder trial until arguments can be heard on a prosecution demand for a sample of his handwriting. The trial was scheduled to begin next Tuesday. The state Court of Appeal scheduled a hearing Sept. 12. The 38yearold defendant was charged last year with murdering 25 intinerant farm workers.

title: Mrs. McGovern Tours Garment Area
description: Eleanor McGovern, the wife of the Democratic Presidential nominee, campaigned in the city yesterday.

title: Internal Problems Beset American Track Team
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 31The incredible foulup that cost two American sprinters an opportunity to chase a gold medal in the 100meter dash today was the latest in a series of strange circumstances that have stalked the United States track and field team at the Olympics.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The campaign debates on the economy and the war sound as if the two sides disagreed about almost everything, but you look at the human side of these two great questions, the fact is that they agree on a great many disagreeable facts.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Envoy Accuses McGovern Of Bad Manners to Thieu
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Tran Kim Phuong, Ambassador of South Vietnam, accused Senator George McGovern today of bad manners and a gross violation of international courtesy because of a statement he made yesterday about Nguyen Van Thieu, South Vietnam's president.

title: Chaparrals Drop Two Blacks in Order to Get More White Players
description: DALLAS, Aug. 31 (UPI)The Dallas Chapparrals, citing the need for a white face, have dumped two black allstars, Donnie Freeman and John Brisker, in an attempt to bolster fan support by luring more white customers.

title: Festival Rises on What 6 Weeks Ago Was a Dump
description: PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 31 The Great Falls Festival, a fiveday fair, opened today on what, six weeks ago, was a dump covered by 60 feet of debris.

title: PLAYS FOR DANCING OLIVER JAZZ BAND
description: The idea that a good jazz band is usually also a good dance band has been buried for so many years under the concept of jazz as concert music that attempts to revive the connection between jazz and daming have, until this summer, been hesitant and unconvincingat best, a short medley for dancers tacked on to the end of a show.

title: U. S. Officials Say Soviet Is Delivering Oil to China
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31United States intelligence sources said today that a number of Soviet tankers had been unloading fuel and other petroleum products in Chinese ports in recent weeks, apparently to replace some of China's deliveries in North Vietnam through two new pipelines.

title: A Labor Day Calendar For the StayatHomes
description: Many dyed  in  the  wool New Yorkers feel the Labor Day weekend is the best of all possible times to stay in the city. The streets, movies and museums are empty, there is hardly any traffic, and the metropolis takes on the appearance of a small town.

title: 2 Held in Watergate Case Tied to Film of Party Data
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31A photographic processor in Miami said today that two men arrested June 17 in the breakin at Democratic party headquarters had asked him to develop pictures of party documents a week before the breakin occurred.

title: Crangle Accuses State G.O.P. OP Surrender to Radioal Right
description: Joseph F. Crangle, the Democratic state chairman, accused Governor Rockefeller and the state Republican party yesterday of selling out to the radical right by agreeing to Conservative party endorsement of President Nixon.

title: Cambodia Reports Raids
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 31 (UPI)The Cambodian command reported that Communist commandos killed 28 people and wounded 35 others early today in three raids aimed at the military petroleum storage depot at Prek Pnou, nine miles north of Pnompenh, and at two bridges the raiders destroyed about 15 miles north.

title: Traces of Fungicide Derivative, Tied to Cancer, Found in Food
description: A Canadian scientist reported yesterday what was apparently the first evidence of contamination of food by a chemical that has been shown to cause precancerous changes in rats when fed to the animals in levels 50 times higher than that found in some foods.

title: CITY MARKET AIDE IS SEIZED AS THIEF
description: The manager of the city's Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx, whose anticorruption vows were featured this week in a thieves market TV expos6, was arrested yesterday on charges that he stole $1,827.75 in toll receipts at the market.

title: Alcan in Aluminum Deal
description: Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., announced yesterday that it had signed a contract to sell 5,000 tons of aluminum ingot worth more than $2million in Canadian currency to the China National Metals & Minerals Corporation, an agency of the Government of mainland China.

title: LOU GREENBERG
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Aug. 31 (AP)  Lou Greenberg, assistant sports editor of The Hudson Dispatch in Union City, died at his home here yesterday. He was 58 years old.

title: From Cleaning Woman to Entrepreneur
description: MT. KISCO, N. Y.Last year, Betty Hawkins earned $23 a day scrubbing other women's floors. Today, she still scrubs many of those same floors, but she's doing much better financially.

title: The Newark News Ceases Publication
description: NEWARK, Aug. 31The Evening News, which announced on Tuesday that it was ceasing to publish, shut its doors today, printing its final afternoon editions after 88 years of publication?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I believe that William V. Shannon's column in the Aug. 17 edition on Nixon wooing the Catholic vote contains a significant misunderstanding. In commenting on the Administration's support for the provision in the CareyMills Bill (H.R. 16141) which would provide a tax credit of $200 per pupil for tuition paid to private schools, he states that a $200 tax credit is not going to save foundering parochial schools. He argues that since the average cost of educating a child is $930 a year, a credit would have to be four times larger than what the President has endorsed to be of decisive help.

title: External Reserves Of Japan Advance To a NearRecord
description: TOKYO, Aug. 31 (Reuters)Japan's external reserves at the end of August rose to a nearrecord $16.37pillion, the Finance Ministry said today. The yen is currently quoted at about 0.3323 cent.

title: Sanford J. Smith Is Dead; Women's Fashion Executive
description: Sanford J. Smith, a manufacturing executive in the women's fashion field, died here Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 57 years old and lived in Woodmere, L. I.

title: JETS SAID TO RAZE MUNITIONS DUMP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday. Sept. 1 (AP)American air strikes against North Vietnam destroyed a huge ammunition dump Wednesday and set A fuel depot ablaze, the United States command reported yesterday.

title: Laos Holds 3d Soviet Plane
description: LAOS, Aug. 31 (AP)A third Soviet cargo plane loaded with war material for North Vietnam has been diverted to the airport at Vientiane because the Hanoi airport was closed down by American bombing, Laotian officials said today. The plane, like the others, had been temporarily grounded by Laotian authorities because its manifest did not list arms.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: The American Jewish Committee, which brought intense pressure on behalf of the recent Presidential proclamation eliminating minority quotas from all Federal hiring, has itself come under pressure to pull back from its initial stand.

title: Merger News
description: Pasco, Inc., a 52 per centowned subsidiary of StudebakerWorthington, Inc., has made a cash offer to the Atlantic Richfield Company for several oilfields in Wyoming, the Sinclair Wyoming refinery and some 2,500 Sinclair service station retail outlets together with varying interests in pipelines.

title: Spitz Takes 5th Gold Medal
description: Mark Spitz, the California swimmer, made more Olympic history at Munich, West Germany, yesterday, winning his fourth and fifth gold medals with his fourth and fifth world records of the current Games. Only one other athlete has ever won five gold medals in a single Olympics. An Italian fencer, Nedo Nadi, did it in 1920 at Antwerp, Belgium.

title: Fort Dix Soldiers Face Ban On Drinks Before 4:30 P.M.
description: FORT DIX, N. J., Aug. 31 (UPI)The soldiers of Fort Dix will no longer be able to down a midafternoon drink. As of tomorrow the officer and N.C.O. clubs will be forbidden to serve hard drinks until after 4:30 P.M. on duty days.

title: Worden Is Transferred From Astronaut Office
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 31 (AP)Lieut. Col. Alfred M. Worden, one of the three spacemen involved in the Apollo 15 stampcover dispute, has been transferred out of the astronaut office, officials said today.

title: Labor Bloc for McGovern
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) Labor unions representing half a million workers in Illinois announced the formation today of the Illinois Labor Committee for McGovernShriver. Ken Holland, administrative assistant to the general vice president of the International Association of Machinists and one of the group's cochairmen, said the 30 unions represented on the committee would work together to bring their influence to bear. Our job will be to do everything possible to help George McGovern become President.

title: Advertising:
description: The Advertising Club of New York wants it known that it approves the concept of one major creative award for advertising, as proposed by the Art Directors Club, the Copy Club of New York and the independent board of directors of the Andy Awards. But the Ad Club, which controls the Andy Awards, also wants it known that something more definitive is needed before it can make a firm decision.

title: Rent Strike Easing
description: BELFAST, Aug. 31About 1,000 Roman Catholic families have ended their rent and tax strike In Londonderry, Northern Ireland's second largest city, the Londonderry Development Commission said today.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Aug. 31 (UPI)The Shell and Esso oil companies announced today that they had struck oil in new North Sea oilfield. Oil experts predicted it would be mother major oil field.

title: CITY GETS ORDER AGAINST A HOTEL
description: Another hotel became a target yesterday in the city's drive against prostitution, obscene films, socalled massage parlors and other illegal sexoriented activities in the Times Square and midtown theater districts.

title: Penn Central Refund Due Stranded Riders
description: Regular Penn Central commuters who were forced to find other means of travel last Monday when a power failure cut all service from Grand Central Terminal will be able to get their money back.

title: Olympic Personalities: Avery in Love?
description: A romance for Avery Brundage?

title: Wickes to End Production Of Modular Housing Units
description: SAGINAW, Mich., Aug. 31 (AP)The Wickes Corporation, a diversified company that has considerable interest in lumber and allied fields, said today it would discontinue manufacture of modular housing units but would continue producing the individual components for sale through its network of 285 lumber and building supply houses across the country.

title: NIXON AND TANAKA CONFER IN HAWAII ON TROUBLED TIES
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 31President Nixon and Premier Kakuci Tanaka of Japan began a twoday meeting here today in an effort to revitalize the United States troubled alliance with Japan.

title: A Man Who
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Labor Day marks the traditional opening of intensive campaigning for the Presidency. Although no candidate of either party ever meets a voter's every expectation, I will tell you the positions I wish the candidates would espouse in the next sixty days. I would want a man who:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., Aug. 31 (UN)  Senator Thomas F. Eagleton said today that he thought it would have been preferable if Ramsey Clark had not gone to Hanoi and Pierre Salinger had not met with the North Vietnames delegation to the Paris peace talks.

title: Clock Stopped to Avert Coffee Pact Collapse
description: LONDON, Aug. 31With no agreement in sight on quiotas for the coming year, delegates to the International Coffee Council recessed what was supposed to be their final meeting tonight to go into a round of private consultations between producing and consuming countries.

title: 3 Shot and a 4th Stabbed In Reputed West Side Feud
description: Two men and a 15yearo1d girl were shot and a third man was stabbed late yesterday afternoon at West 106th Street and Columbus Avenue in what the police said was a flareup of animosity between Puerto Rican and Dominican residents of the area.

title: Murder Made Easy
description: No matter how deftly the latest statistics on the national crime rate are manipulated to give the appearance that this law and order Administration has crime on the run, two closely related facts simply cannot be covered up: violent crime increased sharply last year, and gunfire is responsible for most of the increase.

title: Attention, Drivers: Some Tips on Just Where Not to Go
description: The last long summer weekend will have millions of metropolitan area drivers facing an assortment of highway problems.

title: Credit Markets
description: The steep climb in shortterm interest rates that dominated capitalmarket activity in the second half of August, slowed to a crawl yesterday in light preholiday dealings. Bond rates, meanwhile, halted their more moderate advance.

title: 12Inch Water Main Breaks
description: A break in a 12inch water male caused the collapsed of a 12by12foot section of Nostrand Avenue between Avenue V and Avenue \V in the Sheenshead Bay section of 13rooklyn, about 2 A.M. yesterday, the police reported.

title: Books of The Times
description: Blacks usually expect that their heroes have style as well as talent, which explains why Willie Mays is deified and Henry Aaron simply respected or why Earl Monroe is the idol of street basketball players when Oscar Robertson is the more consummate athlete or, perhaps, why the late Adam Clayton Powell Jr. was returned to office long after his political effectiveness had been exhausted. It certainly explains why the title of Budd Schulberg's sociopolitical essay on boxing and the Ali era is based firmly on sentiments held by the majority of blacks in America. But Schulberg, a novelist (The Harder They Fall), screenwriter (On the Waterfront) and sports buff, here views Muhammad Ali in another contextas mythic protagonist in the turbulent morality play that was the nineteensixties in the United States.

title: U.S. WRESTLERS CAPTURE 3 GOLDS
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 31 (AP)  Tough Soviet wrestlers won five gold medals in the freestyle finals today, but the United States made its best showing in Olympic history with three gold medals, two silvers and a bronze.

title: Mayor Visits Bronx To Talk With Police And Local Leaders
description: Mayor Lindsay spent part of the day in the Bronx yesterday, looking into police manpower problems, drug treatment (as exemplified in a small ambulatory center for former addicts) and the plight of elderly people.

title: Danger on the Job
description: When President Nixon vetoed the appropriation bill for the Departments of Labor and of Health, Education and Welfare, he inadvertently provided Congress with an opportunity to correct an injustice to millions of American workers.

title: Business Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (UPI)A suit was filed Federal court today in an attempt to nullify a $255million refinancing plan approved by stockholders at the Penn Central Company's annual meeting last week.

title: Hope for Welfare Reform
description: Recent comments by President Nixon and Senator McGovern revive hope that a bipartisan push for welfare reform may yet achieve success in this Congress. The Republican platform adopted an ambiguous attitude toward welfare reform, praising the President's initiative but denouncing the principle of a guaranteed minimum income which underlies that initiative. Mr. Nixon, however, in his acceptance speech and again in his news conference before departing for Hawaii reasserted his devotion to the basic concept.

title: MRS. ANDREW KALMYKOW
description: ARDSLEY, N. Y., Aug. 31Mrs. Helen Dolores Kalmykow, wife of Andrew Kalmykow, counsel to the American Insurance Association, died yesterday in St. Agnes Hospital, North White Plains. She was 60 years old and lived at 11 Park Avenue here.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP)Robert H.. Finch, counselor to President Nixon, said today that the White House was bemused by the breakin at the Democratic National Committee headquarters office.

title: RICHARD COTTER SR., A JUDGE IN VIRGINIA
description: MATHEWS, Va., Aug. 31Richard C. Cotter Sr., presiding judge of the county courts of Gloucester, Mathews and Middlesex Counties since March, 1962, died last Thursday after a brief illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Tigers Acquire Rangers Howard
description: Frank Howard, one of the leading sluggers in baseball for most of the last 14 years, was sold by the Texas Rangers to the Detroit Tigers yesterday in the latest bit of pennantmaneuvering in the American League.

title: Navy Accepts Change in Litton Ship Pact
description: The Navy announced yesterday that it would permit major revision of its controversial contract with Litton Industries for the construction of $1billion worth of ships.

title: DANIEL C. CAREY
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 31Daniel C. Carey, who retired as business manager of the Riverdale Country School in 1955, died Thursday at his home here. His age was 89.

title: L' Express vs. Le PointParis Awaits a Press War
description: PARIS, Aug. 31A magazine war is about to start in France. Ostensibly, it is a fight between publishers, but in fact it is an intricate round in the hidden struggle here between the existing power structure and its challengers.

title: BARNYARD WASTE TURNED INTO FEED
description: In an expanding effort to make the most out of barnyard wastes, two corporations reported this week experimental successes in recycling cattle manure into a highprotein food supplement for livestock.

title: Bay Shore Girl, 17, Found Stabbed to Death in Woods
description: A 17yearold girl was found dead of stab wounds in a wooded area near Oakwood Boulevard and Adams Avenue in Bay Shore, L. I., yesterday afternoon.

title: Sports of The Times
description: AUGSBURG, West Germany, Aug. 31The canoe bucked like a bronc with a burr under his tail as Tom Southworth and John Burton steered through the concrete gorge past the boulder called Brundage's Noseit is a bard nose, not a soft noseplunged headlong into the Washing Machine and brought up against the rock in the middle of that maelstrom. The canoe rolled over once, rolled again, righted itself with both men still aboard and lurched on, burying its nose in white water diving down the Zoom Flume, twisting, careening, whirling through the SpinDry Cycle to surge past the finish line where the torrent empties into the river Lech.

title: Great Southwest Elects
description: Shareholders of the Great Southwest Corporation yesterday elected six outside directors at the company's annual meeting in Los Angeles. The new directors are M. Colyer Crum, George P. Keeley, John Marin, Howard B. Miller, Harvey S. Perloff and Richard F. Vancil.

title: Fire Destroys 500 Acres In Montana National Forest
description: MISSOULA, Mont., Aug. 31 (UPI)A forest fire destroyed 500 acres of brush and timber in the Lolo National Forest yesterday and was still out of control today.

title: TIGERS LOSE, 40, TO ANGELS RYAN
description: ANAHEIM, Aug. 31 (AP) California's Nolan Ryan fired his third straight shutout and ninth of the season as he stopped Detroit on three hits, 40, tonight and knocked the Tigers out of a firstplace tie in the American League East.

title: Film of His Dallas Penalties Brings Praise for Jets Jackson
description: HEMPSTEAD. L. I., Aug. 31 They say that the camera doesn't lie, a fact that Joey Jackson, the sixthround draft choice of the New York Jets can be thankful for this week.

title: Bridge: MinorSuit Game Requires An Appreciation of Timing
description: Choosing the right moment to play in a minorsuit game is seldom easy. There must be a good reason to avoid three notrump, which may be the absence of a stopper in the opponents suit.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Senator George McGovern, who freely admits that he could not have been nominated without a strong media campaign, will open his fall television drive a week before the first Nixon political commercials begin appearing.

title: About Pro Football
description: A pair of nationally televised games feature the National Football League's nexttolast weekend of preseason contests. Tonight in Tampa, Ha., the Baltimore Colts play the Detroit Lions, beginning at 8:30 over Channel 4 here. Tomorrow night two potential Super Bowl rivals, the Dallas Cowboys and Kansas City Chiefs, meet in Kansas City. Watch it on Channel 2 starting at 9 P.M. Both Lion quarterbacks, Greg Landry and Bill Munson, have performed well this summer while playing for one half each in Detroit's previous games. The Lions will show two new receivers, the fleet Ron Jessie who has replaced the slumping Earl McCulloch, and Al Barnes, who is in for injured Larry Walton.

title: A Smart Approach to Dope
description: URBANA, Ill.Why is so little said about the possibility of supplying drug addicts with the stuff they need, bought by official clinics at uninflated, normal pharmaceutical prices? I am not suggesting that we legalize dope or let the corner drugstore go into the heroin business. I am not suggesting that supplying legal heroin to an addict will be good for him. The addict will still be his own victim, but innocent people will not be victimized by him. A clinic system, utilizing pharmacies, exists now in Britain, a country which has a drug abuse problem, but nowhere near the addictcaused fear and violence we have.

title: BROOKLYN HOLDUP TOTALED $213,000
description: Two bank robbers whose bizarre behavior during a holdup of a Chase Manhattan Bank branch in Brooklyn on Aug. 22 attracted 3,000 onlookers were charged yesterday with stealing more than $213,000 in the robbery.

title: Harlem Staff Bars All Weekend Surgery
description: Angry staff surgeons at Harlem Hospital announced yesterday that they would no longer perform operations on weekends, even in emergency cases.

title: African Congress Meets
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 31 (UPI)The second international conference of the Congress of African Peoples convened here today for five days of workshops designed to unify organizations and people who relate to Africa.

title: L.I. SCHOOL CHIEF GIVEN COURT DATE
description: Dr. Marie L. Fetsch, founder and president of the Sands Point Country Day SchoolFetsch Academy in Sands Point L. 1,, was ordered yesterday to appear this month in State Supreme Court in Queens in connection with a $600,000 damage suit involving alleged fraud on the part of the school.

title: JOHN BRANT, 59, DIES, TAX DIVISION LAWYER
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., Aug. 31John Myers Brant, a senior trial attorney in the appellate section of the tax division of the Department of Justice, died at Annapolis on Sunday. He was 59 years old.

title: Theater: Roman Plays
description: STRATFORD  ON  AVON, England, Aug. 31Ten years ago, the Royal Shakespeare Company, under Peter Hall, artistic director, made history by producing a group of Shakespeare's histories under the title The Wars of the Roses. The idea was to expose the political undercurrent of Shakespeare's plays and to show Tudor England's view of English medieval history. It was a great and successful project.

title: REALTY MEN LIE, LEICHTER ASSERTS
description: Assemblyman Franz S. J. Leichter of Manhattan denied yesterday that the Democratic Legislative Task Force on Housing, which he heads, had failed to invite real estate spokesmen to its hearing last Tuesday.

title: Liza Minnelli Makes a Rare Stage Appearance
description: Can a girl who grew up in a steamer trunk, with a movie star for a mother and a director for a father, find success in the glittering, glossy world of Show Business? If her name is Liza with a z, as she specifies in one of her many bits of special material  Minnelli, you bet she can.

title: U.S. Said It Offered Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (Reuters)  A State Department spokesman, Charles Bray, commenting on the charges, said that the department's impression is that our embassy in London did what it could to be of assistance to these passengers.

title: India Decrees Outlawing Of Nagaland Rebel Groups
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 31 (Agence FrancePresse)India announced the outlawing today of all underground organizations of rebel Naga tribesmen on her northeastern border with Burma.

title: Files Disclose More Army Snooping Under Johnson
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Army files show that military electronic eavesdropping on civilians was far more extensive during the Johnson Administration than previously disclosed. They show it included monitoring of private radio transmissions during the 1968 Republican National Convention and during the trial that year of Huey Newton, the Black Panther leader.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Detroit Edison Company announced yesterday it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed offering of 4 million shares of common stock. The public offering, to be managed by Morgan Stanley, Blyth Eastman Dillon and Lehman Brothers, is expected on Sept. 30. Net proceeds will be used for the utility's construction program. The company's stock was down  at 20 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Prospects for Fishing and Boating This Weekend
description: AREA A  The usual late summer lull prevails at Surf City with a few small stripers, weakfish and blues being taken. Farther north at Bernegat, good fluke and weakfish to six pounds are reported along the beach. Four miles offshore many small bluefish are being caught by trawlers, and the chum fishermen are still doing very well on large blues and school tuna at Barnegat Ridge. The ridge is offering its best bluefishing at night. In the interior waters, fluke have moved to the lower end of the bay.

title: Redskins Def eat Dolphins, 27 to 24, On Kick by Knight
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Curt Knight's 24yard field goal gave the Washington Red skins a 2724 victory over the Miami Dolphins in a National Football League preseason game tonight.

title: Union Threatens a Strike at Polyclinic Hospital
description: Local 144 of the Service Employes Union threatened a sitdown strike by 450 members at 9 A.M. today at Polyclinic Hospital as a result of a representation dispute.

title: ILLUSTRATED WORLD IN LITIGATION PACT
description: The Illustrated World Encyclopedia, Inc., has made a settlement with Kenneth R. Cunningham anti Robert D. Tomlinson, former officers of the Associated American Corporation that was purchased by Illustrated World Encyclopedia in November, 1971.

title: FUTURES OF CORN AND SOYBEANS UP
description: Export brokers bought heavily in the corn and soybean pits yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, sending futures for both commodities up sharply. Observers expressed the belief that the exporters were hedging against recent sales to foreign countries, possibly Russia again.

title: PROTEST MOVE SET ON SOVIET EXIT FEES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Jewish leaders from more than 10 countries plan to meet in London next Monday to form a united front against the payment of the high fees asked by the Soviet Union for the emigration of educated Jews to Israel, a spokesman for the National Conference on Soviet Jews said today.

title: Spassky Begins Enterprisingly, But Loses Initiative at End Game
description: The 21st game was interesting and absorbing. Boris Spassky played enterprisingly, sacrificing the exchange and obtaining a good position. But he later mishandled the end game and, at adjournment, Bobby Fischer stood better.

title: Urban Coalition Elects Senior Vice President
description: The New York Urban Coalition announced yesterday the election of Jack John Olivero as its senior vice president.

title: Stradivarius a Bargain At $42,000 on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (AP)A Stradivarius violin dating from the 1730's was auctioned here yesterday for $42,000, but its owner thinks the price was too low.

title: U.S. COURT ORDERS STATE EXTENSION OF REGISTRATION
description: Voter registration in New York State was extended yesterday to Sept. 15. A threejudge Federal Court in Brooklyn signed a temporary restraining order barring enforcement of the current state law that mandates an end to registration tomorrow, except for a brief period next month, on Oct. 5, 6, 7 and 10.

title: London Pleads for Calm In Face of Influx of Asians
description: LONDON. Aug. 31The Government sought tonight to mollify rising resentment against the expected influx of thousands of Asians from Uganda by appealing to the British people to show traditional calm and resource.

title: Market Place.
description: One of our wise friends in Wall Street believes that the best way to make money in the stock market is to buy quality and hold it indefinitely.

title: Swiss Official Quits in Dispute Over Buying U. S. Warplanes
description: GENEVA, Aug. 31  The Swiss Government announced today the resignation of its top arms procurement official in protest over the delay in approving the purchase of Americanbuilt fighterbombers in preference to French ones for the Swiss Air Force.

title: Amex Names Vice President
description: J. Hamilton Crawford Jr., 42, has been named a vice president of the American Stock Exchange, to work on legal and regulatory matters, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Crawford has been associated since 1965 with the Glass Container Manufacturers Institute, Inc., where he served as executive vice president and counsel.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE AS TRADING DIPS
description: Despite an absence of bullish economic developments the stock market yesterday scored its second consecutive modest advance in continued dull trading.

title: MISS BOWDEN SEEN IN RHYTHMIC DANCE
description: Sally Bowden's current dance interests are in musical interpretation. The impulse is so guttraditional among dancers and has been ignored for so long that her presentations have an air of welcome revolution. Wednesday evening at the Construction Company Studio, 542 La Guardia Place, she created a playfully rhythmic cluster of dances around thirteen rock and Latinrock songs.

title: State Bank Board Reverses Denials Of 2 Acquisitions
description: The New York State Banking Board announced yesterday its reversal of two previous denials of acquisitions of two small upstate banks by major New York City bank holding companies. It acted on the recommendation of State Superintendent of Banks Harry W. Albright Jr.

title: Miss Bernstein Wed
description: EAST HILLS, L. I., Aug. 31 The marriage of Miss Barbara Ellen Bernstein to Dr. Stuart Allan Levy took place here this evening at the home of the bridegroom's hrotherinlaw and sister. Mr. and Mrs. Itaymond Taylor. Rabbi Ralph Silverstein of Brooklyn performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Ruben Bernstein of Forest Hills. Queens, and the late Mr. Bernstein. Dr. levy a dentist, is a son of Mr. mil Mrs. william Levy of Brooklyn.

title: 39 Box Cars Pass Over Man
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 31 (AP)Dearl Joe Wilson escaped with minor cuts and scratches today after 39 cars of a Missouri Pacific freight train had passed over him as he lay between tracks at a Little Rock crossing. He was taken to a hospital for treatment.

title: REV. G. C. BRADDOCK, VICAR FOR THE DEAF
description: LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Aug. 31The Rev. Guilbert C. Braddock, retired vicar of the Protestant Episcopal Church mission for the deaf, died today. He was 74 years old.

title: The Sweet Life Fading From Troubled Rome
description: ROME, Aug. 31  A pizza that was a dollar last spring now costs $1.20. Suddenly there is a black market in meat and vegetables. The unseasonable weather wraps the traffic jams in a wet blanket and even the Colosseum is crumbling.

title: Policeman Killed in Chile
description: CONCEPCION, Chile, Aug. 31 (AP)A policeman was shot dead and two others were wounded during a street demonstration in this southern Chilean city last night. Witnesses reported that: the shooting broke out when an antiriot squad tried to disperse a demonstration by supporters of President Salvadore Allende Gossens.

title: COMPANY ACCUSED IN TWINE DISASTER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)An Interior Department investigation of a Blacksville, W. Va., coal mine disaster that claimed nine lives places the blame on the mine operator, the Consolidation Coal Company, department sources said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The arrest of nine suspects accused of conducting a large gambling operation in the New York suburbs was announced here yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Sept. 1, 1972
description: Intergovernmental Panel of specialists on the U.N. water Conference10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: RAPID EXPANSION REPORTED BY FED
description: Monetary expansion has continued at a rapid rate in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday, despite a decline in the nation's money supply in the week ended Aug. 23.

title: School Blast Kills One
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 31 (UPI)Leaking gas exploded in a high school laboratory today killing one person and injuring eight. No one was in the lab at the time

title: SAMUEL J. SPECTOR
description: Samuel J. Spector, retired president of the Insuline Corporation of America and American Geloso Electronics, Inc., electronic products, died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 20 0Central Park South.

title: GILES LEADS BY 1 IN AMATEUR GOLF
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 31 (AP)  Vinny Giles, who has finished second three times in recent years, shot a 68 today at the United States Amateur golf championship and took the 36hole lead at 141.

title: TIMES TO PUBLISH A JERSEY EDITION
description: The New York Tines will begin publishing a daily New Jersey edition on Sept. 14.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In a nation that prides itself upon free speech, it is incumbent that all leaders and their supporters be permitted to express opposing views in an unintimidated, nonharassed atmosphere. It is greatly disturbing when delegates to the Republican convention are physically assaulted and public vehicles are destroyed in an effort to inhibit free discussion and embarrass the President.

title: 10 CHINESE DOCTORS TO VISIT U.S. IN FALL
description: An American physician has returned to Peking to lay plans for a delegation of 10 Chinese physicians to visit the United States this fall.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Bell Aerospace Company, a division of Textron, Inc., received a $66million Air Force contract for the production of rocket engines for Minuteman III propulsion systems, it was announced yesterday.

title: Crosswalk
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.It was late afternoon on a grey November day, with the east wind bringing the smell of wharves and ocean into the Boston streets. I walked southward on Boston Common down the Long Path quartering the sloping fields between Beacon Street and Boylston. My mind wandered to the palimpsest the Common is. Here Ben Franklin tethered the family cow. Here the Boston schoolboys threw snowballs at the Redcoats. Here Boston hanged Mary Dyer, the Quakeress, and perhaps Mary Glover, convicted of witchcraft, who could answer the court only in Irish, and who had difficulty saying the Lord's Prayer. Down this Long Path Emerson walked with Whitman, while Concord tried to persuade Brooklyn not to publish Leaves of Grass.

title: Town to Mark Attica Day
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 31 (AP)Mayor Edward Stockton of Bloomfield today became the state's first Mayor to agree to proclaim Sept. 13 A Day, for the first anniversary of the uprising at Attica prison in New York State. The proclamation was requested by Edward Coll, director of the Revitalization Corps in Hartword, who also asked town officials to tour local prisons on the anniversary day.

title: DR. EDWARD GLASER OF U. OF MICHIGAN, 53
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 31 Dr. Edward Glaser, professor of Spanish and Portuguese Literature in the Department of Romance Languages at the University of Michigan, died at his home on Tuesday after a long illness. He was 53 years old.

title: Pope Officiates at Funeral For Cardinal Dell'Acqua
description: ROME, Aug. 31Pope Paul VI interrupted his summer vacation at the nearby lakeside town of Castel Gandolfo to officiate at a solemn funeral rite for the late Angelo Cardinal Dell'Acqua, his vicar general for the Diocese of Rome, who died at the age of 68 in Lourdes, France, on Sunday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In speaking of the Viet vet, President Nixon has said, America isn't going to turn her back on them, We are not going to make a mockery of their sacrifice and devotion by talking of amnesty for deserters. In Jon Nordheimer's brilliant news article about the returning vet [Aug. 28], The Times has shown how the Administration has made a mockery of the vets sacrifice and devotion by discharging them into a program of benign neglect.

title: Spitz Captures 4th and 5th Gold Medals
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 31  Mark Spitz won his fourth and fifth gold medals of the current Olympic Games tonight and equaled the record output for a single athlete in one Olympics.

title: CONSTRUCTION IS SET BY PRESS INSTITUTE
description: The construction of the American Press Institute's new building in Reston, Va., is expected to begin this month, the institute announced yesterday.

title: THOMAS F. PARSHLEY
description: Thomas F. Parshley, a woodwind musician who had performed with the Alfred Wallenstein Sinfonietta, died on Monday at his summer home in Shinnecock Hills, L. I. He was 60 years old and lived at 575 Grand Street in Manhattan.

title: M'GOVERN DENIES RIFTS ARE MAJOR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. Senator George McGovern acknowledged today some difficulties within his campaign organization but joined with his senior advisers to try tominimize reports of chaos and dissension.

title: Democratic Disarray
description: Senator McGovern, who has been having plenty of trouble lately straightening out his campaign policy positions, now has an even more troublesome task of straightening out his campaign organization. He has received what amounts to an ultimatum from his campaign chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, to establish some clearcut lines of headquarters authority before the end of this holiday weekend or face chaos in the fragmented apparatus on which the Democrats pin their hopes for victory next November.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Former Presidential aspirant Eugene J. McCarthy's concept of the Vice President as a crown prince in a monarchy (OpEd Aug. 17) gives an insight as to the kind of President he would have made had he been elected and perhaps as to why he was not nominated. What's he been reading lately, The Prisoner of Zenda?

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) The Democratic VicePresidential candidate, Sargent Shriver will make campaign trips to Syracuse and Albany next Monday and Tuesday, his office announced today. The schedule calls for Mr. Shriver to tour the state fairgrounds at Syracuse at noon Monday. He planned to spend Monday night in Boston, then make jaunts to Portland, Me., and Springfield, Mass., on Tuesday, ending with a 6:30 P.M. rally at the Albany County Airport.

title: Merger News
description: A courtapproved plan for the acquisition of the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Company properties of the El Paso Natural Gas Corporation has been announced by the APCO Group, comprising the Alaska InterJlate Company, the Apco Oil Corporation, the Gulf Interstate Company and the Tipperary Land and Exploration Company. Final details for the properties deal, with a book value approximating $300million, will not be determined until the United States Supreme Court rules on an appeal made by the Colorado Interstate Corporation. A Federal District Court in Colorado on Wednesday reversed its earlier decision to award the pipeline properties to Colorado Interstate and substituted the APCO Group.

title: GROSS PAYS A FINE ON LESSER CHARGE
description: Ted Gross, Commissioner of the city's Youth Service Agency, pleaded guilty in Criminal Court yesterday to charges of disorderly conduct and paid a $250 fine after felony charges against him were dropped.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Barbara Harrison recently defended the women's movement from its enemies (For Decter and Friedan Op.Ed Aug. 5) with such animosity that she confounded her own argument and missed the opportunity to make an important point.

title: HANOI SET TO FREE 3 AMERICAN PILOTS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 2The Hanoi radio announced this morning that three American pilots held as prisoners of war would be released on the occasion of North Vietnam's National Day today.

title: Bally Consent Judgment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) The Justice Department filed a proposed consent judgment today prohibiting the Bally Manufacturing Corporation of Chicago from allocating customers Or territories among the distributors of its amusement and gaming equipment.

title: Olympic Personalities: Bikila, the Hero of 2 Games, Returns in a Wheelchair
description: The first black African ever to win a medal in Olympic Games competition, Abebe Bikila of Ethiopia, was greeted with cheers and applause yesterday as he visited the Olympic Stadium in wheelchair.

title: 130 Hurt at Kennedy in Making Emergency Exit From 747 Jet
description: About 30 people were reported injured last night at Kennedy International Airport after making an emergency chute exit from a Trans World Airlines 747 jet that developed a small fire in its right landing gear prior to takeoff, the police and airline officials reported.

title: Merger of J. J. Newberry Into McCrory Corp. Voted
description: In one of the largest mergers of retailers in recent years, shareholders of the McCrory Corporation and of the J. J. Newberry Company yesterday overwhelmingly approved the merger of Newberry into McCrory.

title: RELIEF THEFTS LAID TO 2 CITY WORKERS
description: Two city employes were accused of grand larceny yesterday in separate cases involving welfare money.

title: 71 Concerns Ask Indonesia To Speed Project Clearance
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 1 (AP)A group of 71 major companies from the United States, Western Europe and Japan have called on the Indonesian Government to eliminate discoordination among government departments in implementing investment projects.

title: PRICE RISE SLATED BY FALCONBRIDGE
description: Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., announced in Toronto yesterday that it was raising the price for refined electrolytic nickel by 20 cents a pound, to $1.53 a pound, effective immediately.

title: Rape Suspect is Trapped by. Screams Over Phone
description: A telephone operator traced a call from a frantically screaming woman early yesterday and alerted the police in time to seize an alleged rapist as he fled from his victim's apartment building in Flushing, Queens.

title: A Priest Here Loses 30 Pounds in Antiwar Fast
description: The Rev. Paul Mayer said yesterday that he had lost 30, pounds since Aug. 6 on a wateronly fast and was prepared to lose more if it helps to bring an end to the war in Indochina.

title: Viscountess Weymouth: She Leads Three Lives
description: LONDON  She is a viscountess in England, an actress in France, and a journalist wherever her restless curiosityleads her.

title: NIXON AND TANAKA ANNOUNCE PLANS TO CUT ES. DEFICIT
description: KUILIMA, Hawaii, Sept. 1President Nixon and Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan reached agreement today on shortterm measures to reduce the United States huge trade deficit with Japan, and voiced hope that Mr. Tanaka's forthcoming visit to Peking would ease tensions in Asia.

title: JOHN F. O'BRIEN
description: John F. O'Brien, who retired in 1970 as an assistant vice president of the Hudson Trust Company in Union City, N.J., died Thursday in St. Raphael Hospital, New Haven. He was 67 years old and lived at 33.70 168th Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: See the U.S.A.
description: AURORA, Ind.My 1957 Chevrolet was more dependable, in better condition, and safer to drive after 130,000 miles than my 1971 Impala custom coupe was the day I got it. My 1957 Chevrolet required no repairs except ordinary maintenance.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: As the wooing of Jewish voters by campaigners for President Nixon and Senator George McGovern becomes more intense, eight prestigious national Jewish groups joined yesterday in deploring appeals to Jews based on the single issue of United States support of Israel.

title: Better Chutch Art Is Aim of Editorial Wai.
description: The editor, advertising manager, subscription department and fileclerk of Liturgical Arts magazine Maurice Lavanouxaused in his oneman office at 43d Street and Fifth Avenue the other day to talk about his dreams.

title: Women Deputies Widen Role
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (AP) Women deputies are going on patrol in Los Angeles County. A sheriff's department spokesman said that 20 women began yesterday a oneyear program to test the feasibility of placing more women in: the field, each woman deputy is joined in a patrol car by a male deputy for routine patrol duty, he said.

title: Protestants Attack Soldiers in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 1 (AP)  Rioting Protestants hit army and police units with rocks, bricks and bottles early today when the security forces moved in to protect a Roman Catholic family complaining of intimidation.

title: MRS. HEINRICH ARNHOLDI
description: Mrs. Lisa Arnhold, widow of Dr. Heinrich Arnhold, a prominent financier in Germany, died Monday of a heart attack in Hmburg. She was 82 years old. Her husband had been a partner of Gebreuder Arnhold of Dresden, one of the largest private banking institutions in Germany.

title: Hired Killer Sought
description: RELFAST, Sept. 1 (UPI)British security sources said today that they believe they know the identity of a professional Swedish killer hired by the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army to kill British soldiers for a price.

title: MARKET ADVANCES IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market advanced for the third consecutive session yesterday in slow trading.

title: Man in the News
description: REYKJAVIK, IcelandBobby Fischer has fulfilled his destiny by becoming the chess champion of the world, and nobolly is particularly surprised.

title: Pert Notes
description: All manpower and equipment under the jurisdiction of the Third Coast Guard District were being prepared Thursday for the Labor Day weekend and the 100,000 to 125.000 pleasure boats expected to be in operation during the threeday holiday. A service spokesman said that about 3,200 officers and enlisted men would be available during the threeday weekend for search and rescue duty.

title: COTTON FUTURES POST SHARP GAINS
description: Reports that Japan would increase her purchases of United States cotton under a new agreement being discussed by President Nixon and Japanese. Premier Kakuei Tanaka sent cotton futures here soaring yesterday.

title: Violent Incidents Spread in Chile As Allende Anniversary Nears
description: SANTIAGO. Chile, Sept.1 (AP)AntiMarxist students took to the streets of downtown Santiago tonight to protest ag'inst Chile's leftist Government and gangs of young Marxists confronted them in clashes that paralyzed the area.

title: Borzov Gives the Soviet Union Its First Olympic Sprint Crown
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 1Valery Borzov, a 22yearold sprinter from the Soviet Union who said he wasn't even running at full speed, won the Olympic gold medal today in the 100meter dash, long a symbol of the United States pride in track and field.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP) Three former Philadelphia Mayors, all Democrats, have pledged their support for the Democratic Presidential candidacy of Senator George McGovern.

title: Champion Fischer
description: Bobby Fischer finally became world chess champion yesterday. He won the title fairly after summerlong combat across the chess board against his predecessor, Boris Spassky. Even to get to the championship table, Fischer had to defeat the world's other top chess players in a series of crushing matches where his brilliant performances plainly foreshadowed the outcome at Reykjavik.

title: Letters to the Editor
