description: My class is really two classes in one. One class is made up of Englishspeaking pupils. The other is made up of Puerto Ricans who do not speak English. Because I have to divide my time, both groups suffer.

title: Beating the Light
description: The flashing Don't Walk sign or the yellow light indicates that the signal is about to turn red. An elephantine truck, a lumbering bus or a covey of cars and taxis take this as a challenge to beat the lightand predictably find themselves stuck in the middle of the intersection. Accompanied by a crescendo of blaring horns, traffic in all directions comes to a halt and backs up several blocks deep. Pedestrians must run an obstacle course of bumpertobumper automobiles.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Overseas Shipholding Group, Inc., yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed offering of 1,000,000 common shares, half of which will be sold by the company. Kuhn, Loeb & Co. will head an underwriting group. The company will use its share of the proceeds for future opportunities to expand its shipping business. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange, was down  at 24 yesterday.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Canada Faces Soviet Six Today
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 1Ast Frank Mahovlich unloaded a slap shot during a workout today, Vadislav Tretiak, the Soviet Union's top goalie, watched from the stands. Throughout the 30 minutes of shooting he had been impassive, but when that shot spun in after hitting the crossbar, the goalie coughed.

title: U.S. Bids Court Dismiss Suit on Steel Import Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The Justice Department asked a Federal district judge here today to dismiss a suit filed earlier this year by Consumers Union seeking to end the current voluntary controls on imports of steel on the ground that the agreement with foreign steel companies constitutes violation of the antitrust laws.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Opera:Mefistofele Back
description: Mefistofele, one of the grandest operas that ever hung around the fringes of the Italian repertory, seems to have established itself on the New York City Opera's greatest hit list. Julius Rudel conducted the Boito work Thursday night in its first performance of the young fall season, and the score's extraordinary qualities shone through as brightly as in the past.

title: Joy Baker Is Married
description: LONDON, Sept. 1  Miss Joy Elaine Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hensley Baker of Crystal City, Mo., was married here today to John Laurence, a correspondent with the London bureau of the Columbia Broadcasting System. The ceremony was performed at the Kensington registry office by H. G. Williams, superintendentregistrar. The bride worked as executive secretary on the C.B.S. Evening News with Walter Cronkite from 1967 to 1971.

title: Market Place Wankel Heartens Curtiss  Wright
description: For supporters of Curtiss Wright, this was a week of vindication. The company, with over 100 patents on the Wankel, or rotary engine, has been a highflyer on prospects that this radical departure from the internal combustion engine will soon power the American automobile.

title: 7 Firemen Are Hurt in Midtown Blaze at Rush Hour
description: A total of 120 firemen and 22 pieces of equipment battled a threealarm blaze in an unoccupied eightstory brick building at 318 West 57th Street yesterday afternoon, closing the block and slowing holiday weekend traffic on nearby Eighth Avenue to a trickle.

title: GanglandSlaying Suspect Surrenders to the Police
description: The man wanted for the murder of Bruno Carnevale, a reputed Mafia soldier, surrendered to the police last night in Queens.

title: Striking Construction Union Votes for 3Year Contract
description: Building contractors prepared for a general recall of sheetmetal workers after a twomonth strike as a vote on new contract plans met initial approval yesterday from the union.

title: DESEGREGATION PLAN FOR AUGUSTA UPIIELD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell, in a decision that blunted a key Congressional antibusing weapon, refused today to delay a school desegregation plan for Augusta, Ga.

title: Ben Duffy of B.B.D.O. Dead; Office Boy Became President
description: Dernard C. Duffy, president for 10 years after World War, LI; of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, Inc., one of the world's largest advertising tgencies, died yesterday of a stroke in St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains. He was 70 years pld and lived in Rye, N. Y.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 1Communist China is not saying whom it favors in the American Presidential election but North Vietnam is backing Senator George McGovern.

title: RICHARD O. A. PETERSEN
description: BARNEGAT BEACH, N. J., Sept. 1Richard 0. A. Petersen, a management consultant and president of the Kestrel Corporation of Rainelle, W. Va., died of a heart attack yesterday at the Appalachian Regional Hospital in Beckley, W. Va. He was 61 years old and lived on Marine Drive here.

title: ALBERT BEYER DIES; MANUFACTURER, 71
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 1 Albert O. Beyer, a director and former senior vice president of the Coleman Company, Inc., manufacturers of camping gear, died yesterday in Southwestern Baptist Hospital after a week's illness. He was 71 years old and had lived here since his retirement in 1966.

title: Victory by Giants Today Needed for Reassurance
description: Mission: confidence. That's the theme of today's exhibition game for the New York Giants, who square off against the Philadelphia Eagles at Princeton's Palmer Stadium at 2 P.M.

title: Pakistan Considering Ties With Dacca, Indian Reports
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 1 (UPI)India's Foreign Minister Swaran Singh told the upper house of Parliament today that Pakistan has indicated to India she is seriously considering the recognition of Bangladesh.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Officials of Senator George McGovern's state campaign announced yesterday that its headquarters would be moved Sunday. It will occupy six floors of an eightstory building at 19 East 53d Street.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1A nuclear reactor has been designed for the Atomic Energy Commission. Including mechanical attachments, it is about the size of an average man. Carroll B. Mills, a physicist, and Robert L. Brasier, an engineer, at the University of Cali fornia scientific Laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M., were granted patent 3,687,804 this week.

title: A ROBBER IS KILLED BY INTENDED VICTIM
description: An unidentified gunman was shot and killed yesterday by the 58yearold owner of a Brooklyn truckrenting concern that he was attempting to rob, the police reported.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 1When the race was over, not one tan hair in the winner's wavy coiffure was out of place. As befits a cleancut citizen of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the coiffure was parted the left.

title: Fischer Captures Chess Title As Spassky Resigns by Phone
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 1 Bobby Fischer, who for years has been saying he is the greatest, proved it today by becoming the chess champion of the world, the first American ever to hold the title.

title: Working for Welfare
description: The yearold program to let welfare recipients work out their benefits in service for the public good has proved its worthto the relief clients themselves, to the hardstrapped municipal government and to the community at large.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: According to Chief of Patrol Donald Cawley, the New York City Police Department has 15,740 men assigned to the patrol force. A very impressive figure, but what does it reveal?

title: JOSEPH FITZSIMMONS OF INVESTMENT FIRM
description: LONGVILLE, Minn., Sept. 1 Joseph M. Fitzsimmons, who had been a director of the Allegheny Corporation and president of Inveitors Diveisified Services Inc., until hit; retirement 10 years ago, died of a heart attack at his home here Wednesday. His age was 70.

title: El Quneitra (Pop. 10): Ghost of a Town Amid the Lively Bustle of Golan Heights
description: EL QUNEITRA, IsraeliOccupied Syria, Aug. 27I prefer it here, said the aging woman, patting her brown head scarf with a gesture more elegant than the cloth. It's so quiet, so calm. Usually I have only cat visitors.

title: Executive Changes
description: Charles F. Baird has been appointed senior vice president of International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd.

title: TAMBOURINE BAR LOSES ITS LICENSE
description: The liquor license of the Tambourine Bar, a Yorkville tavern that has drawn the fire of local residents because of excessive noise, rampant drug use and offensive sexual behavior, was revoked yesterday by the State Liquor Authority.

title: Drug Raids in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Ma., Sept. 1 (UPI) State and local policemen have made 25 arrests in a crackdown on Maine's summer drug trade. The largest single move against drug trafficking in Maine was the climaxraidsyesterday in five counties.

title: COLUMBIA PASSES U.S. TEST ON JOBS
description: Columbia University's plan to increase the number of women and minoritygroup members it employs will be accepted by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare early next week, ending a threeyearold dispute.

title: Philharmonic Board Adds 2
description: Luis QueroChiesa and Anthony P. Terracciano have been elected to the New York Philharmonic board of directors. Mr. QueroChiesa, artist, writer and civic leader, is chairman of the Board of Higher Education and vice president in charge of art for Roy Blumenthal International Associates, Inc. Mr. Terracciano is senior vice president and director of corporate planning for the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: RICHARD S. BARNES, EXECUTIVE OF BACHE
description: Richard S. Barnes, first vice president of Bache & Co., Inc., and a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1951, died Thursday at his home in Englewood, N. J., after a long illness. His age was 49.

title: Butchers in Rome to Strike Against Freeze on Prices
description: ROME, Sept. 1 (AP)The butchers in Rome today called a weeklong strike, beginning Monday, to protest against the city's price freeze on food.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Uniformed Fire Officers Association elected their financial secretary to the post of president yesterday to replace Raymond W. Gimmler, who resigned to become national chairman of Firefighters for Nixon. The new president, Capt. Alfred Benway, 43 years old, was a policeman for eight years before he joined the Fire Department in 1959.

title: Holiday Weekend Starts With Crush And Rainy Outlook
description: The Labor Day weekend, that last fling of summer when New Yorkers search for solitude in the country and visitors find it on the deserted byways of the city, began yesterday with crushes of humanity at air, rail and bus terminals and bumpertobumper traffic on the metropolitan highways.

title: State Rights Unit Names Panel To Check Case Against Fuentes
description: Jack M. Sable, the State Commissioner of Human Rights, appointed a special committee yesterday to investigate charges of racism and bigotry brought against Luis Fuentes, the recently appointed superintendent of Community School District 1, by several Jewish organizations.

title: SHANE GOULD WINS THIRD GOLD MEDAL
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 1 (AP)Shane Gould's third Olympic gold medal dangled from her neck as the 15yearold Australian said, I reckon I'm fit enough to do another good one.

title: A HOSTAGE FREED, HOLDUP MAN SLAIN
description: A 19yearold robber who held a woman employe of a Brooklyn checkcashing agency at gunpoint for more than two hours yesterday morning was shot and killed by the police after he had been lured out by a ruse.

title: Unfortunately, I Do Not Identify With The People
description: ELIZABETH, N.J.The People is very much in the day's news. Last year, it was Ecology, and the year before that, Youth, so The People had better enjoy its moment while it lasts and the television networks, magazines, and, of course, political parties are celebrating its life style and charisma.

title: Blind Junkie Presented At Street Theater Fete
description: In his rock musicals Choices and, particularly, The Blind Junkie, Peter Copani reveals an intuitive grasp of the heartbeat and the idiom of the city's streets. The plays also have a firmly antidrug point of view.

title: Purse Money Hits $127,500 Total On Yonkers Card
description: YONKERS, Sept. 1A total of $127,500 in purse money, well above the average for harnessracing card on which no stakes races are listed, was disbursed tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The nineevent program was studded with a pair of $25,000 preliminaries in the Maggie Counsel pacing series for fillies and mares, a $22,500 handicap pace and a $20,000 trot.

title: Lowenstein's Charge of Fraud In Brooklyn Primary Dismissed
description: State Supreme Court Justice Charles R. Rubin yesterday dismissed a suit brought by former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein charging that fraud and voter irregularities were responsible for his loss in the June 20 Democratic primary to Representative John J. Rooney in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District.

title: 500 JAZZ ARTISTS FORM NEW GROUP
description: The New York Musicians Organization, Inc., a cooperative of more than 500 jazz artists that temporarily coalesced just before the Newport Jazz Festival to produce an alternate jazz festival in July, has become a permanent organization.

title: Johnson Interests Are Forced to Sell Austin TV Station
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 1 Forced by Federal regulations to sell either their television station or their interest in a cable TV operation, the Lyndon B. Johnson interests announced today that they would sell their television station in Austin to the Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Put a flock of girls in shorts on the street to hand out balloons and invitations to a free lunch. Add Walt Frazier, star of the New York Knicks, to sign autographs. Sit your customers on grandstand benches and wrap the whole thing up in blaring rock music. Now that's the way to change your image. Shoppers on 34th Street were startled the other day. Whatever happened to good old A. S. Beck at 49 West 34th Street, one of the chain of stores that was an institution in New York for inexpensive shoes? Well, it's changed its name to The Grand Stand, added a decor to matchbleacher seats and gymnasium lights, for instanceand is stocking some of the craziest platform shoes in town.

title: Suffolk County Police Still Hunt For the Killer of Phone Operator
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Sept. 1Suffolk County homicide detectives continued an unsuccessful search today for the murderer of a 17yearold telephone operator whose badly mutilated body was found behind a farmer's market parking lot shortly before:2 P.M. yesterday.

title: Miss Thomas Has Nuptials
description: DETROIT, Sept. 1  Miss Christine Louise Thomas, an assistant treasurer in the corporate banking department at the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, was married here this evening to George Harold Denniston Jr., a vice president and area manager in the international department at Chase. The Rev. Bernard Karasewicv performed the ceremony in Our Lady Queen of Heaven Roman Catholic Church.

title: Kodes Upset by Amateur In Tennis at Forest Hills
description: The initial shock of last year's United States open tennis championships came when Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia beat the defending champion, John Newcombe, in the first round. Yesterday, the first shock of this year's tournament in Forest Hills. Queens, occurred when Kodes lost in the second round to Alex Mayer Jr. of Wayne, N. J.

title: HOLY LAND FIRST IN BELMONT RACE
description: The goat of the 1970 Kentucky Derby, Holy Land, and the hero of the 1971 Derby, Canonero II, were in the same race at Belmont Park yesterday, and the glory went to Holy Land.

title: ASTROS TOP METS FOR 6TH STRAIGHT
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 1The magic charm that loquacious Leo Durocher is said to have brought here as the new manager of the Astros still seemed ager of the Houston Astros still seemed to be effectively infecting his players tonight as the home team rolled over the New York Mets, 80.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 1 (UPI)The European Common Market has passed the United States as the world's leading auto maker, a European Economic Community report said today.

title: Storm Heading North
description: MIAMI, Sept. 1 (UPI)The tropical storm Carrie moved slowly northward in the Atlantic today, skirting the North Carolina coast with 55mileanhour winds.

title: Housing Patrolman Hurt Shooting Alleged Prowler
description: An offduty Housing Authority patrolman and an alleged prowler exchanged 15 shots on an Upper Manhattan street last night, with each suffering minor wounds, the police said.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) AMF, Inc., today received a $20.9million addition to a previously awarded Navy contract for Mark 82 bomb bodies. The North American Rockwell Corporation received a $9.8million Air Force contract for prelaunch computer data for missiles.

title: Christine Marie Armbrust Is Wed
description: WARWICK, R. I., Sept. 1 Miss Christine Marie Armbrust, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Armbrust, was married here this evening to Stephen Atherton Rooks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Webster Rooks. Both families reside in Warwick.

title: Yancey Cards 63, to Lead Wethersfield Golf by One
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 1Many people take a week off from business to play golf. But Bert Yancey, after leading in the $125,000 Greater Hartford open today with a 63, said that he took a vacation from the pro golf tour last week so he could relax.

title: Germans Protest the Behavior of Arrogant Americans
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 1  The West German hosts of the Olympic Games assorted today they were unhappy with what they regarded, as inconsiderate behavior by leaders of the 584member United States delegation.

title: Roundup: Reynolds Finally Wins, 111
description: Ken Reynolds of the Philadelphia Phillies evidently took the old adage to heart, If at first you don't succeed, try, try again.

title: Nigeria Moves Boldly to Gain Control of Her Economy
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 31Nigeria is making bold moves toward controlling her own economyfor the first tine.

title: WIDER AID PROPOSED IN BLACK LUNG CASES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) Coal miners and survivors of miners disabled by black lung disease will receive $1billion more than before in benefits under new rules proposed today to implement the Black Lung Benefits Act of 1972.

title: Pioneer 10 Passes Mark
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif, Sept. 1 (AP)The spacecraft Pioneer 10 is almost onethird of the way through its 620millionmile journey to the planet Jupiter, officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Ames Research Center here said yesterday. The spacecraft is expected to reach Jupiter on Dec. 3, 1973.

title: Chicago Gang Figure Held With 2 Others in 63 Death
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (UPI) Sam DeStefano, a reputed crime syndicate leader and his brother and another man were arrested yesterday and charged with the 1963 murder of Leo Forman, a syndicate loan collector.

title: Thousands Line Streets For Funeral of Chichester
description: PLYMOUTH, England, Sept. 1 (AP)Sir Francis Chichester, pioneer aviator and lone yachtsman, was buried among the seafarers of his native Devonshire today.

title: Israel and the Election
description: The fate of Israel and of Jews seeking to leave the Soviet Union are matters of concern to the United States and to free men everywhere, but the impression recently created that they are the overriding issues confronting American voters and the Presidential candidates themselves in the 1972 elections distorts reality.

title: Bid to Put Wallace on Ballot Ruled Invalid by the State
description: ALBANY, Sept. 1 (AP)Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo today ruled invalid petitions to place the name of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama on the ballot as a Presidential candidate for the Courage party in New York State.

title: TWO SUBURBS GET A SALES TAX RISE
description: A, sales tax of 1 per cent in Westchester County and an increase to 3 per cent in Suffolk County went into effect yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The attorney for five men arrested in the June 17 breakin at the Democratic National Committee's headquarters filed motions today in Federal court seeking, the dismissal of a $1million civil suit by Lawrence F. O'Brien, former Democratic national chairman.

title: A Bookkeeper Is Wounded Refusing to Yield to Robber
description: A 47yearold bookkeeper for an importing company on the Lower West Side was shot three times yesterday when he refused to give up a payroll to a gunman.

title: 2 HELD IN CLEVELAND IN EXTORTION CASE
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (UPI)Two men weer arrested tonight by the Federal Bureau of Investigation after allegedly trying to extort $200,000 from United Air Lines by threatening to blow up the line's freight depot at Cleveland's Hopkins International Airport.

title: COFFEE COUNCIL IN POSTPONEMENT
description: LONDON, Sept. 1After two marathon negotiating sessions today failed to produce an agreement on coffee export quotas for the coming year, delegates to the International Coffee Council said tonight that there seemed to be little purpose for further talks.

title: Purfield Kent of C.C.N.Y., Led an EarthScience Unit
description: Purfield Kent, summer session supervisor for the. City College department of earth and planetary sciences, a lecturer in the regular session and a student adviser in the evening session, died yesterday while returning from San Diego, Calif., after an illness of several months. He was 58 years old and liyed at 5331 Francis Lewis Boulevard, Bayside, Queens.

title: EXPERTS DESCRIBE AID TO MISS DAVIS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 (Reuters)A group of black psychologists have described how they helped Angela Davis's defense attorneys to pick the allwhite jury that acquitted her of murderconspiracy charges.

title: Books of The Times
description: FREDERICK, LAW OLMSTED AND THE AMERICAN ENVIRONMENTAL TRADITION. By Albert Fein. 180 pages. Braziller. $10.

title: Why George Meany Did It
description: WASHINGTONLooking back now at the MeanyMcGovern contretemps one gets this flavor: An arrogant and geriatric cabal of labor bosses and Meany henchmensenile, hawkish, old men out of touch with American workingmen and searching for Commies under their bed, ensconced first in a pleasure palace in Miami and then in a marble palace in Washington, chomping on frayed cigarsconspired irrationally and vindictively to deprive an honest patriot of a prized endorsement that he richly and rightly deserved.

title: Students Back Nixon
description: MARIETTA, Ohio, Sept. 1, (UPI)  Students at MariettaCollege cast 649 votes for President Nixon and 479 for Senator George McGovern in a poll conducted during registration this week.

title: 3 Were Visited in Captivity
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Sept. 2The three Americans whose imminent release was announced today were previously known to have been prisoners of war in North Vietnam all three of them had been seen by American antiwar activists during visits to North Vietnam.

title: RATE OF JOBLESS FIRM IN AUGUST; EMPLOYMENT UP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The nation's unemployment rate remained essentially unchanged last month despite a resumption of growth in jobs generated by the expanding economy, the Labor Department reported, today.

title: New President Is Elected At Asian Development Bank
description: MANILA, Sept. 1 (AP)The Asian Development Bank has elected Shiro Inoue, a Japanese banker, to succeed Taskeshi Watanabe as president, it was announced today.

title: Teacher, Urging Harmony, Still Holds Views That Led to Ouster
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP, N. J., Sept. 1The president of the Brick Township Education Association, who was dismissed as a teacher for her criticism of the Superintendent of Schools, called today for harmony between teachers and administrators.

title: Business Briefs
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press)A surge in personal spending and a heatlhy trend in foreign trade raised the gross national product past the $102billion mark in the second quarter of this year. Statistics Canada reported today.

title: WISE SHOE COMPANY TO HALT OPERATION
description: EXETER, N. H., Sept. 1 (AP) The Wise Shoe Company announced today it was closing (down its factory here with loss of about 250 jobs.

title: 2 Killed in Chemical Blast
description: FREEPORT, Tex., Sept. 1 (UPI)Chemicals being used to make perfume exploded in a factory and killed two workers yesterday. Eight other persons were injured, two critically. Fifteen workers of the Rhodia, Inc., plant were in the room when the chemicals were mixed to form an ingredient used in making the perfume.

title: Notes on People
description: Pope Paul VI will make his first major trip outside Rome in almost two years when he visits Venice and Udine in Northern Italy in midSeptember. In Udine, the Pontiff will attend the Italian Nittional Eucharistic Congress. In. A7enice, where the city's bells pealed at the Vatican announcement of the trip, the Pope is expected to take a tour in a gondola cortege. His last major trip, late in 1970, was to Southeast Asia, Oceania and Australia.

title: Montreal Night Club Blast Kills 22, Injures 60 to 75
description: MONTREAL, Saturday, Sept. 2A bomb explosion followed by a flash fire in a Montreal night club filled with about 200 people killed at least 22 persons and injured 60 to 75 others last night, the police said.

title: Subway Changes Called Not Imminent
description: In the wake of criticism from Mayor Lindsay for allegedly proceeding too far with plans to change subway schedules, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority repeated yesterday its earlier assertions that no such changes were imminent.

title: DRAFT NO. 95 SET AS HIGHEST IN 72
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The Selective Service announced today that about 15,900 young men holding lottery numbers 95 and below would be drafted during the OctoberDecember period. They may be the last American men conscripted into the armed forces.

title: L. WALTER SCHAEFER SR.
description: NEW HYDE PARK) L. I., Sept. 1L. Walter Schaefer Sr., a senior vice president of the National Bank of North America in charge of the Westchester division, died yesterday of a heart attack in Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 7 Summit Lane.

title: CITY ADDICT AIDE RESIGNS IN ANGER
description: The city's coordinator of drug addiction programs for veterans quit his job yesterday, charging that the Nixon Administration had largely ignored the problem except for cynical, political references by the President.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The promotion of bilingualism for our city is, as far as I know, meeting with no overt opposition. The movement seems to be generated by men and women of good will in response to generous impulses.

title: Texts of NixonTanaka Communique and Announcement on Trade in Honolulu
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 1Following are the texts of a joint communiqu issued here today after the meetings between President Nixon and Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan, and of an accompanying announcement on JapeneseArnerican trade issued after tallzs between Ambassador Robert S. Ingersoll and Deputy Vice Foreign Minister Kiyohiho Tsurumi:

title: SULLIVAN TO MAKE DEBUT AS FALCON
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 1  The New York Jets and the Atlanta Falcons are not scheduled to meet in their first for real game until next season, but tomorrow afternoon at Georgia Tech's Graht Field, they will come as close as they ever have, meeting in their third preseason contest beginning at 4 P.M. (WNEWTV Channel 5, WOR Radio 710).

title: British Bill Rate Gains
description: LONDON, Sept. 1 (Reuters)Average rate at today's tender of treasury bills rose to 5.8872 per cent from 5.8260 per cent last week. This week's 1:60million offer of 91day bills met applications of 199,525,000. Applicants for bills dated Monday to Friday at 98.53 received about 65 per cent. Next week 200million bills will be offered replacing E200million of maturities.

title: Canadian Mayor Battles the Developers
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, Aug. 27This Pacific seaport has decided to battle the builders of highways and highrise apartments, in the face of what it sees as a threat to its graceful mood.

title: installment Credit Gains Slowed Somewhat in July
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The steep increase in consumer installment credit slowed somewhat in July, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Personalities: Quick Ski By Brown Stirs Wave
description: Coach Paul Brown of the Cincinnati Bengals violated the spirit of the waiver season in sports by placing claims on Bubba Smith of the Baltimore Colts and Bob McKay of the Cleveland Browns. He got neither, because their teams promptly withdrew them from the injured waiver list and restored them to the active roster. But he did get plenty of heat, he says, for not letting the two stars slide by. It's within the rules, Brown insisted with a straight face. Wouldn't you claim Bubba Smith if you had the chance?

title: Mother Held in Drowning Of Girl, 9, in Kitchen Sink
description: A 9yearold girl was drowned by her mother in the kitchen sink of their East Harlem apartment, the police of the East 119th Street station reported yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Sept. 1 (AP)Japanese and British electronics industry representatives agreed today not to take any immediate steps to curb Japan's rapid increase of electronics exports, particularly of color television sets, to Britain, officials said.

title: Casting Call for Children
description: A limited number of children are needed to take part in the first two performances today at the Lincoln Center Community/Street Theater Festival, officials of the festival said. Those interested should appear at the Lincoln. Center fountain at 11 A.M. The first play is Drams, by the Young People's Theater from the Riverdale Theater Company. The second is a happening presented by the Children's Video Theater.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1 (UPI) Edward J. Hayes, special agent in charge of the F.B.I. office here, said today that his office had some good leads in the attempt to extort $100,000 from Milwaukee County in a bomb plot.

title: Nation's Campers at Dawn:. Squirm, Stretch, Move On
description: WAPITI, Wyo.The chill comes first, attacking in the bluegray of dawn.

title: 84Pound Powerhouse Thrills Munich Fans
description: 84Pound Powerhouse Thrills Munich Fans

title: Modern Marquee Due At Carnegie This Month
description: Carnegie Hall will get a new marquee with 18inch high illuminated letters by the end of the month.

title: Reporter Receives 6Month Sentence In Contempt Case
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 1Paul Brandburg, a former Louisville CourierJournal reporter now working for The Detroit Free Press, was sentenced to six months in jail today for contempt of court for refusing to tell a grand jury the identity of two men he observed making hashish in Louisville in 1969.

title: Joseph Schmalacker, Newsman, An Aide of Cashmore and Stark
description: Joseph H. Schmalacker, al newspaperman who retired as public information officer for the Brooklyn Borough President in 1969, died yesterday of pleurisy while returning from a vacation trip aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2, which sailed from Southampton Thursday. His age was 70. He lived at 175 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: P.&G. in Japanese Venture
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it had signed a contract with two Japanese concerns to establish a joint venture in Japan to make detergents. The Japanese partners are the Nippon Sunhome Company and C. toll & Company.

title: Jersey Jobless Rate Drops
description: TRENTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) Unemployment dropped from 7.8 per cent in July to 7.1 per cent in August in New Jersey, the state Labor and Industry Department reported today. Commissioner Ronald M. Heymann said that while the August decline was the sharpest monthly drop since last September, it followed the seasonal pattern. The number of people on unemployment rolls dropped by 22,300 to 227,550, the department said.

title: Fischer Had a 20 Victory Streak In 2 Year Trek to Championship
description: The match that catapulted chess into the public consciousness began, not in Reykjavik on July 11, 1972, but, in Moscow, on June 17, 1969.

title: Oil Profits Found To Be Insufficient
description: The petroleum industry is not earning enough to permit growth art a rate that will satisfy global energy demands, the Chase Manhattan Bank asserted yesterday.

title: WINE TALK
description: When Mrs. Edward Brooks of Forest Hills began to plan her son Lewis's bar mitzvah earlier this year, she promised herself she would avoid all the cliche guest souvenirs, such as cigars with the boy's name on them.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: Daniel Ellsberg appeared in Miami Beach during the Republican convention, an unwelcome ghost. He produced for the press copies of a memorandum prepared at the end of 1968, at Henry Kissinger's request, for Presidentelect Nixon. The paper, done by a private group of experts under Ellsberg's chairmanship, set out the possible options for a new administration in Vietriam.

title: Godfather a Hit in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 1 (Reuters)The Godfather, which has shattered boxoffice records in the United States, has started doing the same in Britain. During the first six days of its London run, the film took in $165,000, earning record boxoffice receipts at all four houses where it is showing here.

title: INTERSTATE LOSS GREW IN 13 WEEKS
description: Operations of Interstate Stores, Inc., in the 13 and 26 weeks ended July 30 resulted in deep losses, according to yesterday's report by the 173 retailstore chain.

title: GILES, WITH 214, KEEPS SHOT LEAD
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C. Sept. 1 (UP1)Vinny Giles of Richmond, Va., shot a 72 today to hold his onestroke lead after the third round of the United States amateur championship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your recent editorial on the urgency of island conservation hit right where we live, here in Norwalk, Conn.

title: What Could Have Been Had the Play Resumed
description: The adjourned position of the final game, the 21st, between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky was extremely interesting.

title: DR. ALBERT DUNCAN, TAUGHT CHEMISTRY
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 1Dr. Albert B. F. Duncan, professor of chemistry at the University of Rochester for many years, died Tuesday at the University of Virginia Hospital after a brief illness. He was 69 years old.

title: Free Music Classes Set
description: Free music classes to train boys for the children's chorus of the New York City Opera will be offered by the company Monday afternoons and Saturday mornings at the New York State Theater from Sept. 9 through May 26. Boys between the ages of 8 and 12 will be chosen through auditions. No previous musical training is necessary. An audition may be requested by writing to the Children's Chorus Director, New York City Opera, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, New York, N. Y. 10023.

title: City's Largest Sewage Plant Is Going Upon the Hudson
description: To most people driving by on an elevated section of the Henry Hudson Parkway near 125th Street, it is a half mile of construction cranes jutting into the sky from somewhere below eye level.

title: Saigon Thrust to Retake Queson Post Is Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 2 (AP)A South Vietnamese task force set out yesterday to recapture a former regimental command post in the Queson valley south of Danang, but reportedly ran into heavy enemy fire about 400 yards outside it.

title: Bridg: A Lesson on How to Succeed With a Hopeless Contract
description: One of the ironies of tournament bridge arises when a player in a hopeless contract finds himself hoping that bad, breaks will make the penalty he suffers even bigger.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW ADVANCES
description: Prices edged ahead in light preholiday trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market.

title: Hijacking Accord Is Proposed By U.S. and Canada for Parley
description: The United States and Canada made public yesterday an updated version of an antihijacking treaty that would establish the first machinery outside of the United Nations Security Couhcil for applying sanctions against individual countries.

title: Raise Due Soon at G.M.
description: DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP) Starting Monday, more than half a million employes at the General Motors Corporation will receive costofliving pay allowances, it was announced today. The Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company are expected to make similar announcements. Costofliving allowances will be increased by three cents an hour for more than 400,000 hourly employes covered by union contracts with G.M., a company, spokesman said.

title: YANKS TURN BACK WHITE SOX BY 40
description: In defeating the pennantminded Chicago White Sox, last night, the pennantminded Yankees celebrated the birth of a potential star and the rebirth of an established star.

title: Harold Callaway, Golf Pro At Skytop, Pa., Resort, 72
description: EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., Sept. 1Harold J. Callaway, golf professional at Skytop for 40 summers, died yesterday in Monroe County General Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Skytop and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Emergency Service At Harlem Hospital Promised by Aides
description: Patients requiring emergency operations at Harlem Hospital this weekend will be treated and operated upon there, despite an announcement by the hospital's staff surgeons Thursday that they would turn the patients away, officials reported last night.

title: Soviet Union to Help Iraq
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 1 (UPI)The Soviet Union has agreed to help Iraq build an oil refinery capable of producing one and a half million tons annually, the Tass news agency said today. Tass did not specify where the refinery would be built or when, but did say part of the economic program of cooperation between the two countries provided for expanding the oil fields of northern Rumeila to increase its productivity from five to 18 million tons of oil a year by 1974.

title: RENT INCREASES ARE UPHELD HERE
description: A panel of five Appellate Division judges yesterday threw out a challenge to a 15 per cent rent increase ordered last May for tenants in 400,000 rentcontrolled apartments in the City.

title: SETTLEMENT SET IN WESTEC CASE
description: HOUSTON, Sept 1 A Federal judge today approved a $1.6million partial settlement of a civil suit accusing 93 defendants of manipulation of Westec Corporation stock prior to the company's collapse in 1966.

title: Turner Group Cut From 70 Concerns To 10, Aide Says
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 1 (AP) Once a 70company group, the business empire of Glenn W. Turner today is made up of only 10 concerns, a company inventory shows.

title: Antiques: Of Salt Glaze
description: Eighteenthcentury British saltglaze ware, which began as an inexpensive substitute for porcelain, has come into its own with collectors. In just a few years prices have increased fivefold, with saltglaze plates selling for $125 and the rarer teapots in the thousands. A good place to see this thin white pottery, often called stoneware for its hardness, is at the special exhibition of it now in the ceramics galleries of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The State Department took issue today on two counts with statements by Senator McGovern concerning the Jewish issue.

title: Miss O'Neal Senior's Bride
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 1Miss Margaret Tierney O'Neal and Thomas Rockwell Shepard 3d were married here this afternoon in Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Joseph Meehan.

title: Greece's Sprint Star Hisses Start of Race
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 1 (Reuters)  Another Olympic sprint star was scratched from the 100meter event today for failing to arrive on time for a heat.

title: U.S.Company Ties On Grain Exports Stir House Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) The chairman of a House agriculture subcommittee plans to hold public hearings soon on the controversy over relations between the Agriculture Department and private grain concerns in handling massive wheat sales to the Soviet Union, Congressional aides said today.

title: LABOR DEPARTMENT DENIES UNFAIRNESS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson, commenting on a report indicating that his department discriminated in its hiring practices, declared today that the Labor Department leads, not lags in the employment of minorities.

title: Nixon Returns From Talks
description: EL TORRO MARINE BASE, Calif., Sept. 1 (Reuters)President Nixon returned here tonight from talks with Premier Tanaka in Hawaii.

title: Lindsay Proffers Honors Of City to New Champion
description: All the prematch shenanigans were forgotten or forgiven yesterday as chess players and chess officials from one end of the country to the other expressed great delight in the fact that Bobby Fischer had become America's first world chess champion.

title: Queens Couple Charged With an Opium Shipment
description: A Queens man and his wife were arraigned in Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday on narcotics charges after they allegedly accepted delivery of two toy pink elephants stuffed with four pounds of crude opium.

title: Happy Birthday, Big Brother
description: It is hard to believe that as we approach the 200th anniversary of this country's founding the F.B.I. and the Justice Department are compiling lists of contributors to a church and it is again necessary to worry about religious freedom, freedom of association and freedom of the press. However, when one considers the actions of the Justice Department against the Unitarian Church and its small bookpublishing arm, The Beacon Press, one feels both dismay and outrage. Briefly, this is what has happened.

title: Business Briefs
description: BAD MUENSTEREIFEL, West Germany, Sept. 7 (UPI) Helmut Schmidt, Economics and Finance Minister, today gathered his top cabinet officials for a secret meeting here to discuss the international economic and monetary situation, ministerial sources said.

title: 2Star General Favored for No. 2 Post
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1Pentagon civilian leaders are seriously thinking of reaching into the White House for a relatively junior twostar general to fill the secondhighest military post in the Army.

title: George Grosz Exhibition Shows Early to Late Art
description: Art criticism has generally tended to favor the early work of the expressionist George Grosz, the mordacious, bitter satires he produced of the decadent German morality and militarism between World War I and his departure for the United States in 1932. It has been frequently maintained that his art in America, where he lived until his return to Germany in 1958 (he died a year later), lost its sting and much of its significance. His affectionate, sometimes sentimental, and almost awesome notion of a utopian America has not been considered congenial to his angularly brittle style or to his apparent need for an execrable subject matter.

title: Paraguay Decides to Extradite A Key Drug Figure to the U.S.
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 1 (UPI)The Foreign Ministry announced today that it had decided to extradite Auguste Joseph Ricord to the United States to stand trial there on charges related to a major narcotics smuggling operation based in Latin America.

title: ADOLPH W. ROESCH.
description: Adolph W. Roesch, who had been employed in the picture department and the mail room of The New York Times for many years, died on Thursday. He was 60 years old and lived at 1130 123d Street, College Point, Queens. Mr. Roesch left The Times in December of 1970 after having suffered a broken hip. He had been a fulltime laboratory assistant in the picture department from 1930 to 1947 and then moved to a parttime job in the mail room.

title: Police in Buffalo Suburb Stage Massive Sick Call
description: LACKAWANNA, N. Y., Sept. 1 (AP)The police in this Buffalo suburb staged a massive sick call today. Only three of the department's 70 members were on duty, Chief Joseph V. Deren said.

title: Trudeau Calls Vote In Canada Oct. 30
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 1  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau tonight called a Canadian general election for Oct. 30. It will give Canadians their first opportunity to vote on Mr. Trudeau's Government since its election in June, 1968.

title: Iceland Pushes Out Her Fishing Limits, Risking Cod War
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. (UPI)Iceland extended her fishing limit from 12 to 50 miles today despite threats of a new cod war with Britain.

title: Passing of Landry Turns Back Colts; Lions Win, 2417
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 1 (AP)Greg Landry, Detroit's quarterback, hurled touchdown passes of 9 and 46 yards tonight to lead the Lions to a 2417 victory over the Baltimore Colts in a National Football League exhibition game.

title: HOWARD C. MEYERS
description: Howard G. Meyers, who retired as marketing director of Sinclair Refining Company in 1968, died Thursday in Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, Patchogue, L. I. He was 62 years old and lived at 5301 32d Avenue, Woodside, Queens, and in Patchogue.

title: Korea Conferees Reported Listing Families to Reunite
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 1 A South Korean red Cross official reported today that his organization had begun making lists of divided Korean families in preparation for the second round of NorthSouth Red Cross talks in Seoul on Sept. 3. The talks have the objective of reuniting these families, many of thett divided since World War II.

title: Gas Rate Increase Asked
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 1The Elizabethtown Gas Company filed a request with the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners today for an average 12.3 per cent increase in the rate for natural gas. The adjustment, which probably would not go into effect until early next year if approved, would apply to 183,000 users of natural gas in Union, Middlesex, Hunterdon, Warren, Sussex and Morris Counties.

title: Moscow Is Melancholy, But Some Hail Fischer
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 1  The mood at the Central Chess Club of the Soviet Union tonight was about as joyful as Mudville when the Mighty Casey struck out.

title: Radburn, a Planned Community, Still Living Up tolts Plan
description: FAIR LAWNIn the Radburn section of this North Jersey borough, a youngster can run around for blocks and blocks and feel secure that a car won't cross his path.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Monserrat Reports Negotiations With Teachers Are Progressing
description: Contract talks between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers continued yesterday, with the president of the board reporting that some progress was being made in efforts tb head off a teachers' strike threatened for the opening of the fall term on Sept. 11.

title: Myrth Yorkis Wed To David B. Green
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 2The Morrow Memorial Methodist Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Myrth York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto H. York. of Maplewood, to David Bryan Green. He is the son of the late. Mr. and Mrs. James Dennis Green of Jacksontille, Tenn.

title: NEW BENCHES SET AT GRANT'S TOMB
description: The burly artist from Chile waved a hand toward Grant's Tomb and said, almost possessively: There it is.

title: Travel Notes:
description: NEW type of bus ticket will be offered by Greyhound and Continental Trailways starting Sept. 15. Called Ameripass by Greyhound and Eaglepass by Trailways, it will cost $149.50 and permit almost unlimited bus travel in the United States and Canada for 60 days. Aimed primarily at stimulating offseason travel by the elderly and others with leisure time, it will nevertheless save money for anyone who boards btis in New York and travels at least as far west as Denver and back since the regular roundtrip New YorkDenver fare is $150 (the tariff to the West Coast and back is $194.60).

title: Mailbox: Elementary, Watson
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS REPORT DECLINES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) Although private elementary and secondary schools not affiliated with the Roman Catholic school system have shown dramatic increases in enrollment, pew Government statistics show that the overall private sector is shrinking.

title: The Nation
description: ITEM: John Scriven of London bought a roundtrip charter flight ticket on a nonscheduled airline to New York for only $175, about $140 less than it would cost on a scheduled airline. But when he tried to fly home last week he discovered the 42nd Street charter flight agency that was supposed to honor his return ticket had closed its doors.

title: Even to Montoya, Guitarist, Rock Is Music to His Ears
description: WAINSCOTT, L. I.The potato fields stretch seaward by the acre in this quiet and secluded hamlet, a place where the ocean roar breaks the stillness even more often than that of the traffic on Montauk Highway, to the north.

title: Where 4H'ers Learn Their ABC's
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.Learn by doing is the 4H motto. And that is what a lot of Nassau County boys and girls did this summer at the Dorothy P. Flint 4H Camp, hard by Long Island Sound.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The securities markets, as last week clearly showed, are constantly shifting, never behaving quite the same way twice. The week before last, stock prices declined, depressed largely by the prospect of higher interest rates and tighter money conditions. Last week, by contrast, interest rates kept rising but stock prices rose, too.

title: Fischer vs. Spassky
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland: At first, Boris Spassky did not want to use the duplicate of the swivel chair that Bobby Fischer had ordered from New York. He was perfectly comfortable with the big, clothupholstered chair that the Icelandic Chess Federation had supplied. Spassky would sit in it, motionless, elbows on the handsome but impractical table that the Icelandic organizers had built for the worldchampionship chess match, chin supported by both palms, his leonine head expressionless, his eyes moving from the king rook 1 square to the queen rook 8 square, assessing, balancing, weighing, anticipating, planning. Across from him sat Bobby Fischer, lolling back, gently swiveling to and fro, feet jigging in that nervous habit of his. But one day shortly after the match started Spassky, without any comment, was also using a Fischertype chair, a $500 (U.S.) black, leatherupholstered, chrometrimmed beauty flown in from New York courtesy of the manufacturer. There was one difference. Fischer sat directly facing Spassky, in profile to the audience. But Spassky played much of the fivehour sessions with his back to the pieces, the chair swiveled at right angles to the chessboard.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer Fun Is CostlybutWorth It
description: HACKENSACK  Summer culture may not be a big moneyearner, but two New Jersey organizations have decided that their 1972 programs were successful enough to warrant consideration of return engagements.

title: Gallup Finds 29% Want Regime Of South Vietnamese in Saigon
description: A new Gallup poll shows that 29 per cent of the people questioned in a recent survey favor a government in South Vietnam run solely by South Vietnamese after the United States troop withdrawal is completed.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Fontaine Fox's Toonerville Trolley
description: For a nice, native, naive American art form that has been keeping company with a crowd Grandma Moses never dreamed of, the newspaper comic strip has proved its durability. It's been going ever since Richard Outcault trotted out the Yellow Kid 78 years ago, and if some New York newspaper readers think the field is withering, let them stop by the Times Square outoftown newspaper stand. The medium is alive and burgeoning.

title: Larry Ree Puts On The Grand Manner In Role of Ballerina
description: The art of Larry Ree is expressed in the name and performing personality of a mythical ballerina, one Ekatharina Sobechanskaya. Mr. Ree has made cameo appearances at the Judson Church and Allice Tully Hall, and he was the only bright spot in the Cockettes disastrous season. Now, with his Trockadero Gloxinia Ballet Company, he made an appearance Friday evening at the Jean Cocteau Theater at 43 Bond Street.

title: INFLUX OF LABOR WORRYING ITALY
description: ROME, Sept. 2  Italy, leading supplier of manpower for Western Europe, is herself experiencing a mounting influx of workers from North Africa and, other underdeveloped areas.

title: Fascist Office Is Bombed
description: MILAN, Italy, Sept. 2 (AP)Two bombs exploded before dawn today, wrecking the printing plant of Candido, a rightist weekly publication and the headquarters here of the neoFascfst political party. Four residents of nearby buildings were hurt and damage was estimated at nearly $250,000.

title: Police SickCall Ends
description: LACKAWANNA, N. Y., Sept. 2 (AP)A massive sickcall by this city's 70member police department apparently ended today as dayshift officers reported for work as scheduled. The policemen, most of whom called in sick yesterday, have been working without, a contract since Jan. 1. Erie County deputy sheriffs provided police protection last night in this city

title: The World
description: SEOULThe meeting was mostly atmospheresmiles, handshakes, friendly gestures by delegates of both sides. The only concrete result of the threehour meeting in Pyongyang last Wednesday was the adoption of a fivepoint agenda for a second session to be held Sept. 13 in Seoul. Yet the fact that Red Cross officials of North and South Korea met at all, as the first step toward normalizing relations between the two halves of the divided country, showed that a new era had begun.

title: Coast Guard Keeps Boatmen Shipshape
description: BAY SHORE, L. I.The United States Coast Guard began enforcing five new boating regulations the other day, and found violations on just about every vessel it inspected. The violations carry fines of $50 or $100, which may be reduced if the irregularities are corrected within a reasonable time.

title: EXPOLICE REFLECT ON CLASS OF 1925
description: Fifty men who were sworn in as New York City policemen 47 years ago gathered the other dayas they have almost every year since their days at the Police Academyto eat, drink, talk of the good old days and the bad new ones.

title: MERGER PLANNED BY MILLS COLLEGE
description: Mills College of Education, a 63yearold private teachertraining institution noted for its pioneering work in early childhood education, is letting its faculty members go and handing over all of its teaching functions to two large neighbors this fall.

title: Nixon Aide Hails Plan to Curb Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2A top Adminstration official has privately disclosed that many of the Democratic social welfare programs started in the nineteensixties would be cut, back or eliminated if Congress enacts the ceiling on Federal spending that President Nixon has requested.

title: First Two Finishers Are Timed in 1 : 45.9Seagren Defeated
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 2Dave Wottle, who felt he was running for second place, won a gold medal today in the closest 800meter finish in Olympic track and field history.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: BOSTON, Sept 2 (AP)It may come as a surprise to the pigeons, which sometimes outnumber the people, that Boston's South Station, a proud relic of another era, is destined for demolition soon. But hardly anyone else will feel that way when the wrecker's ball starts to destroy the building, which covers a city block.

title: Hogan Sailing Victor
description: Tim Hogan of the Newport Harbor (Calif.) Yacht Club captured the North American match racing championship and the Prince of Wales Bowl at the Kaneohe Yacht Club in Hawaii Friday. The runnerup was John Kolius of the Texas Corinthian Yacht Club.

title: Old Color to Return To Brooklyn Bridge
description: The 89yewold Brooklyn Bridge will be repainted in its original colorssilver and two shades of buffCity Hall sources said yesterday.

title: Movies
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Reshaper of Trade Policies
description: WASHINGTON  After only six months of being Secretary of Commerce, Peter G. Peterson seems well on the way to becoming the second holder of that office whose name and work may leave a lasting impression.

title: Dodgers Top Cards, 51
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 (AP)Doug Rau, a rookie lefthander, pitched a threehitter in his major league debut today as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 51.

title: Rose Mary Liguori Is Wed in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 2Miss Rose Mary Francessca Liguori, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfonso Liguori of Mount Lebanon, Pa., was married here this afternoon to Michael Kenneth Dahood, son of Mrs. Michel Dahood of Holmes I3each, Fla., formerly of Hillsdale, N. J., and the late Mr. Dahood. The Rev. Garrett Barton performed the ceremony in St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Energetic Optometrist, 90, Not Ready to Slow Down
description: Dr. Harry H. Nathan has the proverbial twinkle in his eyes. His face is cheerful, his voice is tangy. He jokes and laughs a lot, and walks not lopesseveral miles to work six days a week.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Street Crime Cut by Disguise Artists
description: Gulls calmly stroll the lawns of the low brick building as though it were still what it was meant to be a pleasure pavilion for visitors to Randalls Island.

title: U.S. Eight Gains Silver Medal Behind New Zealand in Rowing
description: OBERSCHLEISSHEIM, West Germany, Sept. 2Catching a boatload of East German cops in a photo finish, the United States eightoared crew went second to New Zealand in a rousing race for America's only rowing medal in these Olympic Games. It was the second consecutive time the Yanks went without victory in a sport where they used to excel. But the hardwon silver eased the memory of 1968 when the United States eight finished last.

title: The Nation
description: For months now, in growing numbers, letters have been pouring into airline headquarters and Federal agencies saying, either in anger or bewilderment: Why don't you do something about hijacking?

title: The resale of the resident
description: MIAMI BEACH: Thursday evening, Aug. 24, and it is over now. The massive apparatus required for the renomination of Richard Nixonor, as some would have it, the coronation of King Richardhas been dismantled. Delegates, convention workers, media personnel have mostly gone; the unsold Richard Nixon emery boards, playing cards, coffee cups, sun visors and Tshirts have been packed into cartons, along with leftover felt elephants and partisan cookbooks (Culinary Achievements by Republican Senators and Congressmen), and shipped to wherever it is that such things go. And the blanket of tear gas that lay over the city through much of last night has disappeared, the air cleansed by the hot breeze that blew lightly across this sunny day.

title: HOUNART VICTOR ON TWO MOUNTS
description: SUFFERN, N.Y., Sept. 2Paul Hounart did double duty in both the hunter and jumper divisions at the Catamount Hunt Club horse show today and when he finished the day he had ridden two champions.

title: Athens Bars Autos From Its Old Quarter
description: ATHENS, Sept. 2Plaka, the picturesque old quarter of Athens, is being sealed off to traffic following a police order that was hailed by many Greeks as a victory of man over machine.

title: Bergen Prosecutor Sworn In
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Sept. 2 (AP)Judge Sherwin D. Lester, 46 years old, of Englewood Cliffs was sworn in yesterday as a deputy state attorney general to handle prosecution in Bergen County. Mr. Lester resigned as judge of the Bergen County District Courft to accept the post, which must he confirmed by the state Senate when it convenes in November.

title: NixonTanaka Success
description: Honeyed homilies are the stockintrade of diplomacy, but they have an importance and legitimacy in the NixonTanaka communique that dwarfs even the meeting of minds the two leaders announced on their broad objectives toward China and trade. The old bromides the statement about warmth and mutual trust and the opening of a new chapter in relations between the two countries are what the Hawaii meeting was all about.

title: President is Pleased
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 2 (UPI)President Nixon is pleased to learn that North Vietnam is planning to release three prisoners of war, it was announced last night.

title: International Fete Drawing to Close
description: After a. month of plays, block parties, dance and music events, movies, children's theater and community happenings, the first International Festival, an undertaking of the Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association, will culminate tomorrow with a massive West IndianAmerican parade down Eastern Parkway.

title: Tigers Defeat A's, 31, on Homers by Freehan and Stanley in 11th Inning.
description: OAKLAND, Sept. 2 (AP)Bill Freehan and Mickey Stanley hit home runs in the 11th inning, giving the Detroit Tigers a 31 victory over the Oakland A's today.

title: Mets Score 7 in 8th, 4 in 9th, Win, 118
description: H OUSTON, Sept. 2  The magic that Leo Durocher, the new manager of the Astros, seemed to have brought to this space capital of America, went up in a cloud of smoke tonight as the Mets pulled out an 118 victory to snap Houston's six game winning streak.

title: The Ogre
description: I've just read over what I've written, says the narratorprotagonist of this novel. My name is Abel Tiffauges. I run a garage in the Place de la Porte des Ternes and I'm not crazy. I've just read the whole of the story of Abel Tiffauges. My own perceptions and pretensions have been stripped so bare by this strange, rich, terrifying book that I cannot stand with Tiffauges and proclaim my sanity.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 2 (AP)A dispute over how many striking Northwest Airlines pilots would be recalled immediately after their strike ends has broken up contract talks between the nation's seventh largest air carrier and its 1,600 pilots.

title: A Holiday Spot With History
description: TITUSVILLE  On Christmas night, 1776, despite fiercely adverse conditions, George Washington crossed the Delaware River from Pennsylvania, with his army of 2,400 men, his horses and his cannons. Mounting a surprise attack against the Hessian mercenaries quartered at Trenton, Washington won his first great victory, thereby turning the tide of the American Revolution.

title: Ellen B. Fishwick Is Married To Isaiah Guyman Martin 3d
description: ROANOKE, Va., Sept. 2Miss Ellen Blair Fishwick and Isaiah Gummi Martin 3d were, married in St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony, assisted by the Right Rev. William H. Marmion, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Southwestern Virginia.

title: Recordings
description: SOME months ago there appeared a perfectly respectable Die Zauberflote on Eurodisc, an East German label. It moved to be a performance ably conducted by Otmar Suitner but most compelling for the fine Pamina and Tamino of Helen Donath and Peter Schreier. Now the same company has issued a Cosi fan tutte (80 405 XR, 3 disks), again with Suitner directing, but here using the chorus and orchestra of the Berlin Staatsoper instead of the Leipzig. Radio Chorus and the Dresden Staatskapelle. Many of the same soloists also participate: Schreier, Theo Adam, Gunther Leib And Sylvia Geszty, but whereas only Schreier among them managed to make Success in Zauberflote, the others all appear in a mostly flattering light in Cosl fan tutte. tutte.

title: Astros Recall 4 Players
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 2 (UPI)The Houston Astros recalled four players today from their Oklahoma City team in the American Association. They were Mike Cosgrove, pitcher; Cliff Johnson, catcher; Gary Sutherland, infielder, and Rich Chiles, outfielder.

title: A Kidney Patient Can Live Normally...
description: TEANECKOver the last three years, the Holy Name Hospital Regional Hemodialysis Center here, which takes patients from Bergen, Passaic, Hudson and Sussex Counties, has treated 95 persons suffering from chronic kidney failure and put more than 40 of them on hometreatment programs.

title: Mobutu Bids Priests Use Zairian Names in Baptism
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept. 2 (UPI)President Mobutu Sese Seko. has signed a decree providing jail terms of up to five year for priests baptizing Zairian children with foreign names, officials report.

title: World News Briefs
description: BILBAO, Spain, Sept. 2 (UPI) Spanish policemen today shot and killed two suspected members of a Basque separatist organization, officials here reported.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIt was the kind of announcement rarely heard herea Government agency, in this case the Postal Service, telling the citizenry it had saved so much money on its own that it was canceling its request for an increase of onecent an ounce in the firstclass mail rate.

title: State Scans Corruption Allegations In 3 Towns
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP  The state appears to be ready to move ahead on a corruption investigation involving three municipalities and one of the largest developers in New Jersey.

title: Nuptials in Suburb For Challen Heaney
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 2In the Presbyterian Church of White Plains this afternoon, Miss Challen Williston Heaney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Heaney, was married to Daniel Edward Armstrong of Rye, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George G. Armstrong of the Bronx, New York. The ceremony, written by the couple, was performed by the Rev. Frank N. Watson,

title: Chiefs Score Twice in First Period, Then Hold Off Cowboys to Win,2010
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 2The Dallas Cowboys, champions of the National Football League, lost their winning streak tonight and acquired the pains of anxiety two weeks before the start of the regular season. After 15 straight victories, the Cowboys were beaten soundly by the Kansas City Chiefs, 2010, before a capacity crowd of 79,592 in the new Arrowhead Stadium.

title: Harlem Store. Owner Slain, Worker Wounded in Holdup
description: The owner of a small grocery store in Harlem was shot and killed last night and one of his workers was wounded during an attempted robbery.

title: Abigail Bradley Becomes Bride Of Duke Senior
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 2Miss. Abigail Alexandra Bradley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Worcester Bradley of New Canaan and Key Biscayne, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Scott Nelson Ledbetter, son of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Ledbetter 3d of Greenwich. The ceremony was performed in St. Aloyshis Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Francis X. McGuire, the pastor.

title: Broncos Rout Patriots, 4924
description: DENVER, Sept. 2 (AP)Steve Ramsey fired two touchdown passes, staking Denver to a 3510 halftime lead, and the Broncos went on to defeat the New England Patriots, 4924, tonight.

title: Sullivan County Show To Start on Friday
description: The seventh Sullivan County Sportsmen's Show will begin Friday morning and through Sunday at the Fairgrounds in Grahamsvine, N. Y.

title: CITY UNDERTAKES EXTENSIVE STUDY OF HELP FOR POOR
description: Mayor Lindsay's administration plans to name a blue ribbon panel to study the oftencriticized antipoverty prograin here, in part responding to complaints that the Jewish and Italian poor have been largely overlooked.

title: World News Briefs
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 2 (AP) President Chiang Kaishek has been ordered by his physician not to officiate at the ceremony tomorrow honoring Nationalist China's war dead, official sources said today.

title: Red Sox Triumph, 53
description: BOSTON, Sept. 2 (AP)Sonny Siebert singled home a run in a decisive, threerunsecond inning to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 53 victory over the Kansas City Royals today.

title: The Glamour of Forest Hills
description: Every year at this time, a 12%acre site in Forest Hills becomes the world capital of tennis. It is the West Side Tennis Club, scene of the United States Open championship, in which more than 200 players from 33 countries are now vying for glory and $160,000 in prize money.

title: There's No Magic Lullaby for B'way
description: RECENTLY, in these pages, producer Alexander H. Cohen detailed the problems of the Times Square area and proposed radical new zoning restrictions to rid Broadway of peep shows, prostitutes, massage parlors, and other unseemly enterprises.

title: HIJACKING CURBS WIDENED BY F.A.A.
description: In a new move to tighten airport security, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it would notify 54 foreign airlines operating in this country that they will, have to meet the same antihijacking regulations as United States airlines.

title: Faye and Zeppole Mean Feast Days
description: FAIRVIEW The Italian festival season is reaching its peak in Bergen and Hudson Counties this weekend, with thousands of visitors enjoying religious processions, band music and delicacies such as fave, clams, chick peas, torroni and zeppole.

title: A Year of Textile Quotas
description: Alms a year has gone by since voluntary quotas were placed into effect by Japan, Hong Kong, South Korea and Taiwan on apparel and fabrics of manmade fiber and wool exported to the United States. These quotas promised some measure of relief to manufacturers here whose markets had been disrupted.

title: CHRISTIANS SEEK PAKISTANI PLEDGE
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 2After a week of street demonstrations and some violence, Pakistan's Christian minority appears resigned to accept a compromise with the Government over the nationalization of its colleges.

title: 6 Dead in Filipino Ambush
description: MANILA, Sept. 2 (UPI) Members of the Communist New Peoples Army ambushed a Philippine Army supply team today, killing six persons including a lieutenant, the Philippine national police reported. The lone survivor of the sevenman team, a sergeant, was seriously wounded, the police said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Possibly I'm an ecofreak. Long before the energy crisis became a fashionable topic, I shunned airconditioning as much as I could.

title: Crackdown on Soring Embroils WalkingHorse Show
description: SHELBYVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 2 A I9man Federal crackdown against alleged cruelty to animals at the big Tennessee Walking Horse National Celebration here has caused controversy and consternation among breeders and trainers.

title: Butler Time, $6.60, Wins $8,000 Pace at Freehold
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 2 (AP)  Butler Time won the $8,000 Dunellen Pace at Freehold Raceway today pacing the mile in 2:01

title: Talk of Forest Hills
description: With the world's best tennis players competing together for the first time this year, Forest Hills has taken on a linguistic flavor. The streets around the West Side Tennis Club are buzzing with dialects. Thirtythree countries are represented in the Open, and the stores on Continental Avenue, a main thorough fare near the club, are showing a substantial in crease in business. French, German, Spanish and Italian are heard inside and outside the spacious club. A newsdealer on the corner of Continental Avenue and Queens Boulevard is ordering batches of foreign papers. I don't know much about tennis, he said, but a lot of differentlooking people are buying ray papers.

title: SAFETY BOARD ASKS RULES FOR CAMPERS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board has proposed the adoption of specific safety standards for recreational vehicles such as slight trucks, camper bodies for pickup trucks, travel trailers, motor honies, dune buggies and snowmobiles.

title: For the French there is a serious way to do everything
description: A person who has lived for 12 years in France may still, after that length of time, not realize that there is anything more seriously wrong with his adopted country than an inadequate telephone system and an unusually unresponsive government bureaucracy. Indeed,, this hypothetical expatriate, who cleverly returned to the States just as the dollar sank to the level of the boliviano in French estimation, may quite honestly and cheerfully believe that the good life, happily, continues in an... undiminished state.

title: Prospective U.S. Steel Cleanup Pact Is Near Collapse
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 2After months of negotiations involving the United States Steel Corporation, the State of Pennsylvania and Allegheny County, a prospective agreement on a plan to clean up air polution by the concern's huge coke plant at Clairton is in danger of coming apart.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE trend toward the use of the natural or outdoor look on interior surraces, as well as on exteriors, has created a strong resurgence in the use of brick  especially artificial bricks or materials that look and feel so much like the real thing that even an expert would have difficulty in determining whether or not they were actual bricks made of baked clay.

title: Movies
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Trevino and Beman Share 36Hole Lead at 132 in Greater Hartford Open
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 2Subpar golf was typical of play today as Lee Trevino and Deane Beman shared the 36hole lead in the $125,000 Greater Hartford open at 132, 10 under par.

title: Hencken and Miss Carr Break World MarksMiss Belote Victor
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 2  East Germany's Roland Matthes became a double gold medalist for his second straight Olympics tonight, and American swimmers won the other finals, Melissa Belote, Cathy Carr and John Hecken getting the victories. Hencken and Miss Carr beat world records.

title: Miss Alexander to Wed
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 2Mrs. Charles Truman Alexander has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Linda Alexander, to Glenn Orris, son of Mrs. Patricia Guerin of Marbella, Spain, and William Orris of New York. The couple will be married here Sept. 16. The future bride, a, graduate of Tennessee Technological University, is a stewardess with Eastern Air Lines. Her fianc, a senior marketing consultant with Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., in New York, graduated from the University of Colorado. His father has his own law firm in New York.

title: Anne Ludlow Plans Bridal
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 2  The engagement of Miss Anne Lincoln Ludlow to Wendell Wallace McLendon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Jones McLendon of Oakboro, N. C., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James M. Ludlow: A late fall wedding is planned.

title: Anderson's Contract Renewed Two Years
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 2 (UPI)The Cincinnati Reds, announced today that Manager Sparky Anderson, who is shooting for his second pennant in three years, had been rehired for two more seasons.

title: C. Harvey Bradley, Headed Battery Concern in Indiana
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 2 (AP) C. Harvey Bradley, honorary chairman of P. R. Mallory & Co manufacturer of batteries, capacitators and electronic equipment, died yesterday in Methodist Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: The Last Word
description: Time was when the Central Intelligence Agency was accused of some particularly dirty trick by the press it would reply blandly, The C.I.A. neither confirms nor denies the charge. Recently, however, the agency has departed from its customary inscrutability; it has doffed the cloak, drawn the dagger and intervened openly in the bookpublishing process. The most publicized of these interventions has been its demand to examine, prior to publication, the manuscript of The Politics of Heroin in Southeast Asia, by Alfred W. McCoy, which as the review in this issue points out, makes some serious allegations about the C.I.A.'s inadvertent involvement in the heroin traffic. In another less publicized case, the agency enjoined a book by former agent named Victor Marchetti which had been contracted for but not written.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Sam Posey, an auto race driver whose business base is in San Juan Capistrano, Cal., has returned to Connecticut, his home. Connecticut is his home two ways. His residence is in Sharon, and his home track is at Lime Rock, where he first learned about cornering and drafting. His return is not for reasons of nostalgia. He has a big business commitment at Lime Rock tomorrow.

title: CLEMENTE BREAKS WAGNER'S RECORD
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 (AP)Roberto Clemente passed Honus Wagner as Pittsburgh's career hit leader with a third inning double, and then slammed a threerun homer in the fourth to spark the Pirates to a 63 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight.

title: Basketball Hall of Fame Displays Barry's No. 24
description: The famed uniform No. 24, worn by Rick Barry of the New York Nets, has been added to the Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: Mrs. Chapman Rewed
description: HARWICHPORT, Mass., Sept. 2Mrs. Linda H. Chapman and William F. Robinson Jr. were married here today in the Pilgrim Congregational Church by the Rev. Charles Monbleau. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Cecil Brown and the late Kemp Huss. Her first marriage ended in divorce. The bridegroom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robinson of Greensboro, N.C., is an attorneyfinancial advisei with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington.

title: ATHENS BECOMES A U.S. HOME PORT
description: ATHENS, Sept. 2Athens today became the United States Navy's largest home port in the Mediterranean as a squadron of six American destroyers pulled into Phaleron Bay and anchored near this capital.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: The classroom on rails, an idea that has proved successful on several commuter lines, will be tried on the New Haven Division of the Penn Central, beginning Sept. 25.

title: Geraldine? She Isn't So Flip
description: THERE are many questions that could or should be asked of the ubiquitous imagemaker, television. But I would like to ask these for starters: Who is Geraldine? What is she, that all America loves her?

title: Pamela C. Schaeffer Is Affianced
