description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 2  Mr. and Mrs. Peter Schaeffer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Cady Schaeffer, to G. Nicholas Buffington, son of Mrs. George N. Buffington of Quissett Harbor, Mass., and the late Mr. Buffington.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Heartworm in Pet Dogs Is Found Spreading
description: Heartworm, a lifethreatening but treatable infection of dogs that until recently has been found mostly in Southern states, is moving into other sections of the country for reasons that mystify veterinarians.

title: Carole J. Ferguson to Wed Dec. 23
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Sept. 2 Miss Carole Jane Ferguson, a school psychologist with the Bureau of Child Guidance in New York, and Dr. Paul David Brodsky, who is on the attending staff of the Optometric Center of New York, will be married Dec. 23 in Lawrence.

title: 80 Guards at Essex Jail Stage A. Job Action Over ConditiOns
description: NEWARK, Sept. 2The day shift of 80 guards at the Essex County Jail staged a twohour job action today in protest over conditions in the jail.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS REPORT DECLINES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) Although private elementary and secondary schools not atfiliated with the Roman Catholic school system have shown dramatic increases in enrollment, new Government statistics show that the overall private sector is shrinking.

title: Travel Notes:
description: Relatives of American servicemen buried in World War I and World War II cemeteries abroad are eligible to receive a passport freethat is, minus the usual $10 processing charge  if they declare they are planning to visit one of the cemeteries. However, they represented only a small percentage of the record five million visitors to the overseas gravesites in the fiscal year just ended. The American Battle Monuments Commission reported that more than three million foreigners were included among the five million, and that the cemeteries that drew the most visitors were Margraten in the Netherlands, Omaha Beach Cemetery in France on the site of the DDay landings in Normandy in 1944, the Luxembourg City Cemetery, where Gen. George S. Patton Jr. lies buried, and Nettuno,Italy, near Anzio Beach. The most visited World War I site is the cemetery at Flanders Field in Waregem, Belgium.

title: 3 Cambodian Posts Hit
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 2 (UPI)Enemy gunners today lbombarded t hrec besieged Cambodkin garrisons south of 1Pnomponh, the Government command reported.

title: Long Live Vidor, A Hollywood King
description: PASO ROBLES, Calif.

title: Dance
description: BACK in the thirties, when the old Theater Arts Magazine was a cozy reading habit, I always found myself particularly attracted to a feature called Tributary Theater. It had to do with a new world outside New York. It seemed so varied; the actors were intriguingly unfamiliar. There was excitement in the stage sets, too. They had a look of vaulting imagination unfettered by Broadway economics.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: MUHLHEIM, West Germany Seventytwo years after Count Ferdinand von Zeppelin surprised the world with his first zep, a new West German dirigible, its plastic hull studded with 10,000 bulbs advertising a local beer, may Well usher in a renaissance of airship aviation.

title: Movies
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: A GYPSY CAB DRIVER IS KILLED IN HOLDUP
description: A gypsy cab driver was shot and killed, in the Mordsania section of the Bronx last night by three holdup men who fled on foot, the police reported.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  In the group of mainly industrial countries that make up the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the share of government expenditure in the gross national products rose from 27 per cent in the late nineteenfifties to 32.5 per cent in the late nineteensixties.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: RALEIGH, N. C. Sept. 2For the last two weeks, while national attention has been fixed on the efforts of the Committee for the Reelection of the President to account, or not to account, for certain campaign contributions, the attention of North Carolinians has been fixed on similar problems of their Democratic Governor, Robert W. Scott.

title: More Than 13,000 in Africa Died of Cholera in 2 Years
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, Sept. 2  More than 13,000 people have died of cholera in Africa in the last two years, the African office of the World Health Organization said this week, in its annual report.

title: The Good Word
description: Of Ezra Pound, as of Bobby Fischer, all that can decently be said is that his colleagues admire him. There is no special reason for anyone else to. Pound belongs to an allbutextinct priesthood which believes that Art is God, that kindness to other artists exhausts Charity and that the outside world is slightly unreal. Does one honor him? Daniel Bell asked recently in a letter to The Times. But what kind of honor could he possibly want from us, who are not of his faith? A heathen's blessings are wasted on a priest.

title: Susan Swords Plans To Marry Next Month
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 2Mr. and Mrs. Gerard S. Swords, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Swords, to Carleton Hickox Stevens 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens Jr. of Branford,

title: CHICANOS OCCUPY A CALIFORNIA ISLE
description: AVALON, Calif., Sept. 2 (UPI) After the war between the United State and Mexich, California and its offshore islands, including Santa Catalina Island, were ceded to the United States.

title: Technology
description: DETROITOnly five years ago the rotary engine, also, known as the Wankel, was considered a curiosity by the auto industry and largely dismissed as, a polluting, inefficient engine with a bleak future. Today, companies that have even a remote connection with the Wankel have seen their stock jump, and many industry experts predict that it will replace the present piston internal combustion engine by the end of the decade.

title: Uzbeks Honor Angela Davis
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (UPI)Angela Davis, the American Communist who was acquitted on a gunsupplying charge in California early this summer, was awarded an honorary degree today by the University of Tashkent, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. Miss Davis arrived in. Moscow Monday and went to Uzbekistanof which Tashkent is the capital three days ago.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) Amtrak, the Governmentoperated passenger railroad system, inaugurated improved mail service between the Midwest and the Northwest this week when the Chicago to Seattle Empire Builder started carrying mail over the entire route.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Movies
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Giants Extend Regulars And Top Eagles, 2712
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 2Using their regulars for almost the whole game and getting a satisfying touchdown out of their second set of running backs in the closing moments, the New York Giants poste their second straight exhibition victory today, beating the Philadelphia Eagles, 2712.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 2Dave Wottle is so used to going bareheaded that he didn't even realize he was wearing his goodluck cap when the Star Spangled Banner was being played while he stood on the victory podium today with the apparent insensateness of a bump on a log. He was so dreadfully embarrassed by his thoughtless gaffe that it robbed him of much of the exultation he should have felt at his spectacular triumph in the 800meter run. I'm so embarrassed about the cap, he kept repeating.

title: Movies
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: How School Works Is Up to Its Students
description: MONTCLAIR  When Classes resume here, students at one of the public schools will not know whether they may smoke in the classrooms, whether they will receive traditional ABC grades or whether their afternoon schedules will involve cabinet making or the writings of Cicero.

title: Difficult to explain to infidels
description: Jean Renoir remains to this day the only notable film director with a hereditary claim to artistic eminence. His childhood features have been immortali7ed in four of Papa Auguste Renoir's most famous paintings. Le Chasseue (1910), the last of these paternal tributes, forms the background against which an elderly Jean Renoir poses, more than 60 years later, on the dust jacket of Leo Braudy's thoughtful book. How visually eloquent and characteristically direct of Renoir to counterpose his youth in one medium (painting) with his old age on another (photography).

title: JACQUES LE CLERCQ, TEACHER OF FRENCH
description: Jacques Georges Clemenceau Le Clercq, retired professor of French literature and Romance languages at Queens College, died Tuesday of cancer at Lenox Hill Hospital. He Was 73 years old and lived at 340 East 74th Street.

title: COMPUTER ADVANCE OBSERVED IN CHINA
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 2 (UPI)A computer science expert from Harvard University who visited China last month said this week that Chinese computer science was more advanced than American experts had thought.

title: Music
description: HALF of being an artist today lies in promotional skill, yet to accept this condition is to be half an artist.

title: Music: A Little Ham to Go Along With the Fish
description: ROSLYN, L. I.One August night in 1959, Walter Ahrens, a pianist, reached one of those momentous decisions that can be the turning point in someone else's life. He had been playing on Friday and Saturday nights at the Jolly Fisherman, a local restaurant noted for its seafood, and seemed to be a permanent fixture. But on this fateful night 13 years ago, he declared, I've been here long enoughand left.

title: Art
description: AT a Society for Photographic Education conference some time ago, a parent addressed a question to the two panel members most involved with the psychology of photography, Ralph Hattersley and myself. He asked passionately, What right do you have to meddle with the inner workings of our children? At that moment passel of college children burst into the room shouting, The scheduled discussion is so much! We have our thing. You must see that!

title: If No One Asked, What's Next?
description: THE composer Frank Loesser used to have a theory that, if ever it had been taken seriously, would have ended drama overnight. It was Mr. Loesser's contention that all of our troubles in this world come from our narrative sense.

title: Every Play Was Interesting
description: THIS was the third summer I've been to the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center at Waterford, Conn. The first time was in 1967 when I was 21. Now I'm an oldtimer at 26. Since I've grown old along with the O'Neill, it seemed fitting at this time to write my memoirs of three summers (that's not a bad title). Here goes.

title: 5 ARE ARRESTED AT TAMBOURINE
description: Five Tambourine Bar employes were arrested early yesterday, less than 24 hours after the Yorkville tavern had its license revoked by the State Liquor Authority for being a disreputable place.

title: Archery Devotees Aim to Aid Young
description: There are those who shoot arrows in the air, but know not where they land. And then, of course, there are those who also shoot like weapons aloft and know exactly where they are going.

title: Art Mailbag
description: In a recent article on these pages, The War Against the Good in Art, artist. Walter D. Bannard contended that the art world had abandoned standards of quality in new art, and was attempting to displace traditional forms by aping the spirit of innovation with such substitutes as pop art, minimalism and conceptualism. Great art, he concluded, new or old, will not compromise but is always there, waiting for us to come to it. Here are seine responses from readers.

title: Ramapo Is Trying to Be Accommodating
description: MAHWAH  With Ramapo College starting its second year of operation next week many students who had planned to move into the school's first oncampus housing find themselves, Ihring in the homes of professors, deans, and even, the college president.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: America the Flabby
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2With the arrival of Labor Day, summer is over for most of us and so is our fleeting encounter with physical exercise. Once home from the beach, we will have done for another year with physical effort except running for the bus. We are a nation of sportsmad spectators growing steadily slower of step and thicker around the middle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.; Does Apparel Center ear Well?; New York Struggles To Retain Visitors
description: Can business and government working jointly to elevate New York City's image surmount the basic social problems that have stained that image?

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: The Jaws of the Whale
description: PRINCETON, N. J.Advocates of a moratorium to stop killing whaleswhich was urged by the United Nations Conference on the Environment at Stockholmwere disappointed by results of the recent International Whaling Commission meeting at London. But the moral imperative of the Stockholm decision, persistently voiced by Russell E. Train, leader of the U.S. delegation, did contribute to a number of positive actions.

title: One Air Route at 11 Prices
description: At 9 A.M. one day next week, 57 American Legion members from New Jersey will board Eastern Air Lines Flight 9 at Kennedy International Airport and fly to Miami for a week's holiday. Other economyclass passengers on the same plane will pay as much as $170 for the round trip, but the Legionnaires will pay only $91.

title: 21,819 FANS WATCH SAMMARTINO WIN
description: The return of Bruno Sammartino to New York helped draw 21,819 people to Madison Square Garden last night for a card of professional wrestling exhibitions. Sammartino defeated George (The. Animal) Steele in 12 minutes 29 seconds in only his third Garden appearance in 18 months.

title: Draft and Election
description: President Nixon's pledge to eliminate the draft, if reelected, may go down in historyalong with his vow to E. id the Vietnam waras the twentieth century's most ingenious contribution to the art of electioneering: the twocampaign promise. Mr. Nixon ran successfully on that platform in 1968. Now, with the target date for draftfree army set for July 1973, he is campaigning on the same promise again.

title: Horse Show News
description: Jack Le Goff, coach of the United States Equestrian Team's threeday squad, said in Munich yesterday that he was pleased with the silver medal won by his riders in the Olympic Games Friday.

title: Virginia Schilling Wed
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Sept. 2Miss Virginia Owen Schilling and Michael Kendrick Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kendrick Clark Smith of Huntington, were married here today in St. John's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Carleton Lee, the rector, , performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John McGeever of St. Patrick's Roman. Catholic Church in Huntington. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Scott Owen Schilling of Northport.

title: Bridge
description: Every expert would like to have 100 per cent concentration. None of them has it, but a few come close. In Europe the Concentration Champion is Benito Garozzo of the Italian Blue Team, whose mind virtually never wanders from the business in hand.

title: The Nation
description: Leukemia is one of the most mystifying cancers affecting man. In recent years, doctors have made significant progress in treating the disease, particularly the childhood types, with, drugs. But cures are exceptional.

title: World News Briefs
description: SINGAPORE, Sunday, Sept. 3 The ruling Peoples Action party made a sweep of all parliamentary seats in a general election yesterday to extend its 13year rule of the Southeast Asian island state for five more years.

title: Auto Price Freeze
description: The Price Commission has now concluded that under its rules neither General Motors nor Ford qualifies for any price increase on its 1973 models to cover the extra cost of Governmentordered safety and antipollution improvements. Welcome as that decision is to car buyers and to others interested in holding the line against inflation, confidence in the order's detachment from political pressure would be greater had it not been preceded by the Cost of Living Council's jawboning on higher auto prices earlier this month.

title: GILES TRIDMPHS IN U.S. GOLF BY 3
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 2 (AP)Vinny Giles ended several years of frustration today by shooting a 72 for a 285 total and a threeshot victory in the United States amateur golf champion ship.

title: Hanoi Premier Is Adamant On Terms for Settlement
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2  Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam has made a major speech that American analysts here describe as uncompromising in its insistence that the fight continue for a settlement of the war on the Communists terms.

title: Herbert Macdonald Dead; Artist at Bloomfield College
description: GLEN RIDGE, N. J., Sept. 2  Herbert MacDonald, artistinresidence at Bloomfield College, known for paintings of nature and Biblical subjects, died of a heart ailment here Thursday. He was 73 years old and lived at 173 Stonehouse Road.

title: URBAN CRISIS
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: DEATH OF L.I. MAN, 20, LAID TO METHADONE
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2 The police are investigating the death of Richard J. Andrews, a 20yearold electrician's helper of 220 Elm Street, Southampton, who died at 1:15 P.M. today in Southampton Hospital. They said Mr. Andrews swallowed methadone last night, and then spent the rest of the night drinking, beer at a party. Detectives have tentatively ruled that his death was caused by the methadone, a synthetic narcotic used for treatment of heroin addicts.

title: Dust Is Piling Up on Old Coins in Library
description: JERSEY C1TYHidden in messy storerooms and windowless crevices, a museumquality collection of coins, paintings, furniture, dolls and other pieces lies untouched and unseen here, gathering dust with each succeeding year.

title: Emily Tate Betrothed
description: The engagement of Miss Emily L. Tate, production manager of elementary school textbooks at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc., publishers, to Frederick H. Rudolph, Jr. vice president of the Maple Press Company in York, Pa., has been made known. Miss Tate is a daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. William J. Tate of Deep. River, Conn. Mr. Rudolph is a son of the late Mt. and Mrs. Rudolph of Roseland, N.J.

title: Colleges Are Slow to Act on Reform of Admission Procedures
description: PRINCETONIn June, 1971, two top Princeton University admissions officials resigned in the hopes of getting a foundation grant, starting their own educational institute and reforming the college admissions process.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Unlike many rosepetalstrewn projections into 1974, I think we are already headed toward a series of economic collisions. I will list them in the order in which I expect them to occur.

title: UNION AIDE SLAIN IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2A union drive to organize health care employes here was marked by protests this week after a union organizer was shot to death outside Metropolitan Hospital, allegedly by a private security guard.

title: COCKER SPANIEL IS BEST IN SHOW
description: BRANCHVILLE, N. J., Sept. 2 A silverbuff cocker spaniel, who, according to her handler, is the topWinning dog, in the Country, was named best in a field of 1,330 at the annual Newton Kennel Club show on Sussex County Farm and Horse Show grounds today.

title: U. S. and Venezuela Arrest 14 and Seize 70 Pounds of Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) The seizure" of 70 pounds of heroin and cocaine with an estimated street value of $12.6million and the arrests of 14 persons in Caracas, Venezuela, and Miami have broken up an international drug ring, the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs said today.

title: Daughter to Parishes
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Charles Parish on Aug. 17 at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. The child has been named Jennifer Leigh

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Man, His Wife and Son, 3, Shot to Death in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 2A man, his wife and their threeyear old son were shot and killed tonight in their home on Wakefield Avenue in the Filmore section here.

title: Injured Ram on Waivers
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 2 (UPI)  The Los Angeles Rams placed Kermit Alexander, safetyman, on the injured, waiver list today. He suffered a broken elbow against Oakland two weeks ago.

title: Sale Begins Tuesday For Knicks Tickets
description: Tickets for the New York Knickerbockers two preseason games at Madison Square Garedn will go on sale at the Garden box office Tuesday at 10 A.M.

title: Wing Is Named Chairman Of Colonial Cup Committee
description: The Colonial Cup executive committee has officially named the Colonial Cup race committee for the third running of the Colonial Cup races at Camden, S. C., on Nov. 18.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2In the 1968 Presidential election, Richard Nixon got only 14 per cent of the labor vote, but at the Labor Day opening of the 1972 Presidential campaign, the pollsters were indicating that he would get over half the labor vote in November. What explains this extraordinary shift?

title: Mammoth Found in Siberia
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (Reuters) A oneandahalfton mummified elderly female mammoth complete with worn teeth, pieces of skin, wool, muscle and the remains of undigested food in the intestines has been found frozen on the Siberian Arctic ocast, Tass reported.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Efforts to make employers and employes more conscious of industrial safety have been under way throughout the country since the passage of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, which went into effect in April, 1971.

title: ROW ON DEFENSE EMBROILS BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 2The Lebanese political scene is dominated these days by an issue known as the Crotale Affair. It has brought the entire defense policy of this country of two and a half million people into question.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article on the changeover in ownership of builditigs on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx ["As Change Intrudes, the Concourse Sells, Aug. 13] contains a quote by Borough Engineer Leonard Piekarsky: The Bronx does not have a single major cultural institution, not even a museum.

title: The English Hamburger in an Elegant Setting
description: LONDONFans of P. G. Wodehouse will recall Drones as the ultraestablishment men's club where doublebarreled names communed on overstuffed settees.

title: The girls in the gray flannel dresses
description: Gray flannel is finally back in fashion. Its even turning up in long dresses to brighten those long winter evenings at home. (And isn't that where everyone's hanging out these days?) Although some of the flannel that's around is actually knitted. it still has that elegant look and it still makes for pretty and glamorous gamesmanship. An added attraction: the dresses shown here are all long. which means that they can easily go out on the town if the mood strikes.

title: Linda Loehr Wed To William Gerdts
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 2  The marriage of Miss Linda Mary Loehr, daughter of. Mr. and Mrs. William R. Loehr, to William Ernest Gerdts took place this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Rosary. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest L. Gerdts of West Islip, L. I. Msgr. James J. Hart. performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Andrew J. Christensen.

title: Inquiry Into Democratic BreakIn Strips General Accounting Office of Some of Its Anonymity
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2A lot of people wish they would go back to checking expense vouchers and others grumble that they do not always dig deep enough, but the General Accounting Office just goes on some call it investigating, the G.A.O. prefers auditing" and still others say it is prying.

title: Montreal Police Seeking 3 ht Club Fire That Killed 36
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 2  The police issued coroner's warrants for three men today in connection with the fire that swept a crowded midtown nightclub last night, leaving at least 36 persons dead and 54 injured.

title: Music: Tex Gives A Bluegrass Bash
description: MADISONThe big silver bus with the Tennessee license plates that was parked in the driveway of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Logan's house on Green Avenue Tuesday evening was all that anyone in the neighborhood needed to know what was going on there. And if the bus did not carry the message, the sound of fiddles, banjos and high, lonesome singing coming through the windows indicated that Tex Logan's annual Bill Monroe party was going on.

title: Holding of High Holy Days Rites At Resorts Is Deplored by Rabbi
description: Rabbi Louis Bernstein, the president of the Rabbinical Council of America, called on worshipers last week to pray in their regular synagogues on the High Holy Days instead of the flimsy attractiveness of resort places.

title: Education
description: The unionization of college professors spread from a few isolated campuses jot() a serious movement in the late 1960's with strongholds throughout the country. But this campaign for faculty power was largely overshadowed at the time by the headlinewinning drive for student power.

title: Movies
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: RushSeat Chair Still Made
description: WESTWOODYears before Lambert Hitchcock began massproducing his famous caned and rushbottom chairs in Connecticut, a branch of the Bogert family was busy turning out similar designs in Bergenfield. This was in the early 1800's.

title: W. A. Davis Weds Christina M. Tree
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 2Miss Christina Marie Tree was married here this afternoon to William A. Davis in the Mount Holyoke College Chapel by the Rev. William Van Etten Casey, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is The Boston Globe's travel writer and her husband is the travel editor.

title: The World
description: MONTREALOn a ferry boat winding its way along the rugged British Columbia coast one afternoon 10 days ago, a top adviser to the provincial government mused for a moment about the forthcoming provincial election and what might happen if David Barrett, a former social worker, happened to become Premier of British Columbia in an upset victory.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: WAR FOES TO BRING 3 PRISONERS HOME
description: PARIS, Sept. 2Two leaders of the American peace movement said today that they would fly to Hanoi soon to escort three American prisoners of war back to the United States.

title: E. J. Christiansen Jr. Weds Evelyn Tatum
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 2Miss Evelyn Vance Tatum, a graduate of Wellesley College, was married at the home of her grandmother, Mrs. John Coleman Cowan, here this morning to Edward John Christiansen Jr., who attends the Harvard Law School. The Rev. William F. Shouse performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: The World
description: MUNICHBefore the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City, Mark Spitz, a Santa Clara, Calif. student, brashly predicted that he would win six gold medals for swimming. Things didn't turn out that way. He collected two golds as a member of victorious United States relay teams, but he won none of the individual events.

title: Key Drug Figure Flown to New York
description: Under tight security, Auguste Joseph Ricord. who is believed by the United States Government to control about onehalf of the heroin smuggled into this country from South America, landed at Kennedy International Airport last night aboard a chartered jet after being extradited from Paraguay.

title: Sheryl Gillin Bride Of Jeffrey Wagner
description: WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 2 Miss Sheryl Claire Gillin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Gillin of Westfield, was married here at noon today to Jeffrey Robert Wagner. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Wagner of West Covina, Calif.

title: Gardiner Lehigh Coach
description: J. Bruce Gardiner, 26 years old, of Port Chester, has been named head swimming coach at Lehigh. He also will serve as an assistant in the intramural and recreational programs.

title: Miss Felix Bride of Law Student
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 2 Miss Carolyn Patricia Felix, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Thomas Felix of Ridgewood, N. J., was married here at noon today to Russell Norman Fairbanks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fairbanks of Moorestown, N. J.

title: Italy to Show Chinese A Spaghetti Machine
description: PEKING, Sept. 2 (Reuters) Italy is to reintroduce spaghetti  complete with cheese and tomato saucein China, where it is believed to have originated. It is supposed to have been bought back to Europe 700 years ago by Marco Polo.

title: Sarah Abernethy Bride of John Snyder
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2Miss Sarah Hamilton Abernethy was married here this afternoon in St. Albans Episcopal Church to John Edward Snyder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Philip Snyder of Baltimore. The Rev. Robert W. Estill performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. William B. Abernethy a cousin of the bride.

title: Welfare Mothers Taking to Jobs
description: TRENTON  More than 1,300 welfare mothers have been working in a variety of public jobs in a fourmonthold program that state officials say proves they are willing and capable workers.

title: MISSISSIPPI PATROL GETS FIRST BLACKS
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 2 (AP) Mississippi's, first three black Highway Patrol cadets have been graduated in what Gov. William Waller termed a significant step for the state.

title: WALL STREET
description: Does the average investor follow stocks listed on the Big Board, a few on the Amex and nothing else? Certainly householdname companies are listed companies by and large.

title: The Dutch Face Unexpected November Election With Doubts About Political Structure
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 30The unexpected, and unwelcome, fall election campaign in the Netherlands has begun to convince increasing numbers of the Dutch that their political structure requires broad and basic overhaul.

title: Karen Taylor Is Bride Of Christopher Collins
description: FREEPORT, L. I., Sept. 2In the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration here this afternoon, Miss Karen Rene Taylor and Christopher Allen Collins, seniors at Michigan State University, were married by the Rev. Robert Pierce.

title: Law
description: Last Tuesday, police In plainclothes and uniform raided three Times Square movie houses exhibiting sex films that the authorities considered obscene. The police arrested six employees of the theaters and pulled down and carried off signs describing the films as adult entertainment and best porno ever. A police official announced that the public response to the raids] has been overwhelmingly favorable. The raids have alerted the people to realize it is being subjected to visual pollution by pornography.... We will not stop this drive.

title: AUSTRALIA BALKS ON UGANDA ASIANS
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept 2 The Government's recent refusal of a British request to lift longstanding color bars for the sake of Asians facing expulsion from Uganda has renewed the national debate over Australia's racially restrictive immigration practices.

title: 1,200,000 at Olympics On the First Six Days
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 2 (UPI)More than 1.2 million people watched the first six days of Olympic sports, officials said today.

title: Gloomy Skies Shroud the Labor Day Scene
description: Melancholia descended on metropolitanarea resorts and on the city's tourist attractions yesterday as gray skies and intermittent rain marked the opening of the Labor Day weekend.

title: The Soviet Press Steps Up Attacks on U.S. After Lull
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2The tempo of antiAmerican propaganda in the Soviet press has risen sharply in recent days from the restrained period of President Nixon's visit here, when the mining of Haiphong harbor went unmentioned for 21 days.

title: Prices for Movies Dropping
description: TEANECK  In this age of spiraling costs, a refreshing trend is growing among many northern New Jersey movie theaterslower admission prices.

title: ROBERT B. BAXTER
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 2Robert B. Baxter, a former president of Baxter, Kelly & Faust, Inc., New York textile manufacturers, and a trustee of the Dime Savings Bank of New York, died yesterday at Princeton Medical Center.

title: DRUNIMERS'
description: If drumming isn't one of your favorite things in all the world, then the Schaefer Festival in the Park was no place to be Friday night. In a lengthy program of sturm and drang bellicosity and bombast, were the groups of two of the rock world's premier percussionists: Ginger Baker of Britain and Buddy Miles of the United States.

title: Detroit Housing Coalition Fails After 6Year Effort to Aid Poor
description: DETROIT, Sept. 2An urban coalition group here founded by the city's most prestigious business and labor leaders and aimed at building, housing for the poor collapsed finally this week.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Food, Fun, More Food at Hellenic Picnic
description: The annual Shish KeRab Picnic of the Greek Orthodox Church of the Assumption in Port Jefferson Station attracted more than 4,000 GreekAmericans and other lovers of Greek food. In between trips to the amply stocked tables, the picknickers were able to dance to a Greek orchestra and swim in a nearby pool. The picnic was held on the grounds of the church.

title: Big Talk at Munich Is the Big Cost of Big Roof
description: MUNICH, Sept. 2To local skeptics, and there seem to be several hundred thousand of them, the huge acrylic glass roof spanned above Munich's main Olympic Games buildings looks like a dropped handkerchief, or even a fallen cleaning rag.

title: G. D. HOFE, EXHEAD OF CARTRET SCHOOL
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 2  George D. Hofe, a former cosmetic manufacturer and former beadmaster of the Carteret School for Boys in West Orange, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years, old and lived at 301 West South Orange Avenue.

title: September
description: September is not really a separate season, though sometimes seems so. It isn't full autumn yet, though there is a ripeness about the fields and woodlands that has an October look and odor. It isn't really summer any longer, though hot days and warm nights often linger. But there is no mistaking it for any other month.

title: How to Get List of Publications
description: To receive a free list twice a month of new Government publications for sale, write: Selected List, Superintendent of Documents, Washington, D.C. 20402, giving your name, address and zip code.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Penn League Selects 3 For Awards
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 2 (AP)Dave Fanning, Bill Nahorodny and George Case have been voted special baseball honors in the New YorkPennsylvania League.

title: Susan E. Hiat, Andrew Tisch Plan to Marry
description: The Rev. Dr. Philip Hiat, rabbi of Mount Neboh Congregation, and Mrs. Hiat of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Ellen Hiat, to Andrew H. Tisch, son of Laurence A. Tisch, chairman and chief executive officer of the Loews Corporation, and Mrs. Tisch of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Rohiner Film to Open Fete
description: Chloe in the Afternoon, the last of Eric Rohmer's moral tales, will have its world premiere as the openingnight film for the 10th New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall on Sept, 29.

title: Television
description: IN any industry, structure is important. In television, it is crucial. Be hind the relatively simple matter of what you see on the screen there is the complex mechanism of how you got to see itwho made the decision, who created the product, who has what share m the potential profits. These are the aspects of the TV industry that are being questioned in the Justice DepartMent's antitrust suit against the three commercial networks.

title: Phils Win, Gain Split
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 2 (AP)Dave Downs pitched an eighthit shutout in his majorleague debut and singled home a run as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Atlanta Braves, 30, to gain a split of a doubleheader tonight.

title: Humphrey Wants to Curb Health Experiment Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that he would introduce next week a bill to guard against abuses of humans subjected to health experiments.

title: Norwegian Wins Lift
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 2 (AP) Jenssen of Norway won the Olympic lightheavyweight weightlifting gold medal today after two Soviet favorites were eliminated. His threelift total was 1,118.83 pounds.

title: Miss Moore Sets Nuptials
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 2  Miss Caroline Daniels Moore and James Todd Baldwin Tripp plan to be married here nest month. Their engagement has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Francis Daniels Moore, parents of the bridetobe. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Vandervoort Tripp Jr. of Chestnut Hill. Miss Moore, a Sarah Lawrence College graduate, has a master's degree. in urban planning from Columbia Uni versity.. She is with the Mayor's Office of Midtown Planning and Development in New York City. Her father is Moseley Professor of Surgery at Harvard Medical School and surgeon in chief at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston.

title: Red Sox Acquire Veale From Pirate Farm Club
description: BOSTON, Sept. 2 (AP)Bob Veale, a 36yearold southpaw who spent more than nine years with the Pittsburgh Pirates, was purchased by the Boston Red Sox today from the National League club's organization.

title: Roger B. DouTens Is Dead; ExPan Am Executive, 57
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 2 Roger B. Doulens a former assistant vice president of Pan American World Airways, died today of cancer. He was 57 years old.

title: The World
description: RIO DE JANEIROIn the heady days two years ago when Senator Salvador Allende had just won the Presidency and brought the MarxistLeninist left to power in Chile, his followers were euphoric. They danced and chanted in the streets at the drop of a slogan. They painted city walls with heroic.murals of revolutionary triumph. They were the future and the future had arrived.versity in Santiago, he said: I am horrified to hear people talking irresponsibly about a possible civil war. I will fight with all my strength to maintain normalcy in the country, for if there were to be a civil war, even we were to winand we would have to winit would mean the destruction of the Chilean economy and brotherly coexistence for several generations.

title: The World
description: LONDON  The great cod war was on again last week.

title: What's It Like To Be an Actor? I'll Tell You...
description: WHAT is it like being an actor? asks your little cousin Mimi from Maywood, Illinois. I bet it's real glamorous.

title: The World
description: REYKJAVIKRobert James Fischer, the new chess champion of the world, is not going to be any less ornery than he was as Bobby Fischer, the challenger. He has done it all by himself, and from now on it is going to be brand new chess game.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Chinese on Tour
description: They stood together eyeing endless rows of corn that spanned the flat Illinois horizon, a slight Chinese from Peking in baggy pants and a tall, heavyset American farmer in blue jeans.

title: BUTTERFLY GIVEN BY THE CITY OPERA
description: Puccini's Madama Butterfly was given its first performance in the New York City Opera's fall season at the New York State Theater on Friday night, and although summer is still with us, the house was sold out. It seems that the appeal of Puccini, of the company and, probably, of opera itself disproves the old view of opera in New York as coldweather fare.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: CLEVELAND  Ohioans, like most people, have been inclined to take their banking services pretty much as they find them.

title: FEW GOOD PLAYS
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: SEX AT OLYMPICS: A GREAT DEBATE
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 2 (AP)Olympians found themselves involved with a delicate question today: Can sex rob you of a gold medal?

title: Pupils Build Classrooms
description: MONMOUTH JUNCTIONFor Dennis Biddle, a South Brunswick High School sophomore, it was more than what I did on my summer vacation"; it was a practical application of some of the theories he has been taught en route to his chosen study of architecture.

title: Photography
description: THE New York University's School of Continuing Education is again offering a lecture series as part of The Concerned Photographer Program this fall. The program will also include three advanced workshops.

title: SUFFOLK SEEKING TOM ITS FARMS
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 2Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein announced a program last week directed toward the preservation of farmlands in Suffolk.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Coins
description: THE Eisenhower dollar will be added to the United States proof proof sets next year, it was announced by Mrs. Mary T. Brooks, Director of the Mint during a luncheon address before the Young Numismatists at the American Numismatic Association's convention in New Orleans.

title: Consuelo Hutton Fiancee Of Henry SeherrThoss
description: The engagement of Miss Consuelo Virginia Hutton to Henry White SeherrThoss has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Langdon Hutton of New York and East Hampton, L. I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Henry O. H. Frelinghuysen of Far Hills, N. J., and Hans Christoph SeherrThoss of Litchfield, Conn. A February wedding is planned.

title: Penn State, as Usual, Looms as No. 1 Team in Eastern Football
description: The seven major independent Eastern college football teams scrap among themselves on and off the field and meet more intersectional opponents than any seven conference teams in the nation. They know one another's strengths and weaknesses thoroughly and compete with one another in the recruiting wars.

title: Fran Ashley Plans Bridal
description: Mrs. Constance Sitomer Ashley of New York and Ted Ashley of Beverly Hills, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Fran Ashley, to Thomas F. Curtis. He is the son of Luther Curtis of Allentown, Pa., and the late Mrs. Curtis.

title: U. S. Suit Filed to Set Aside Lowenstein Primary Loss
description: A group of nine black, Hispanic and other supporters of former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein have begun a suit in Federal Court, in Brooklyn, seeking an order setting aside the June 20 Democratic primary election in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN

title: Jets Defeat Falcons, 93, On3HowfieldFieldGoals
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 2  Bobby Howfield, the Jets leading preseason scorer, picked up 9 more points today by kicking field goals of 12, 29 and 32 yards to account for all the points in the Jets 93 victory over the Atlanta Falcons.

title: The Nation
description: Auto theft up 2 per cent... burglary up 9 per cent... aggravated assault up 10 per cent... rape, robbery and murder each up 11 per cent.

title: Hungary Turns Back U.S. in Water Polo, 53
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 2  Hungary's water polo team defeated America's Californiarecruited team, 53, today for the Americans first setback in the Olympics. That all but ended the American hopes for a gold medal.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2  A Federal judge ruled today that the five defendants in a $1million civil suit arising from the breakin on June 17 at the Democratic national headquarters here could not be called for questioning by lawyers for the Democrats, pending the outcome of a Federal grand jury investigation that is also under way.

description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 2A United Nations committee's resolution aimed at showing that Puerto Rico is a colony of the United States has caused deep division in political circles here.

description: To the Editor:

title: CARDS TURN BACK PACKERS BY 3110
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 2 (AP)  Jackie Smith, a tight end, scored two touchdowns and set up a third with a 23yard pass reception tonight to spark the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3110 victory over the Green Bay Packers in an exhibition game.

title: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE? ADVT.
Minsk to Munich Via Baldwin, L.I
description: BALDWIN, L. I.When Tanya Adamovich talks, her hands are continuously moving. Every now and then, she will stand erect and move forward, as though thrusting an imaginary foil before her.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Aug. 6 article on the city's housing court plan leaves out one of the quaint examples of the Lindsay administration's Incompetence.

title: British Say Icelanders Harassed a Trawler
description: LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP)The British Trawlers Federation said that an Icelandic gunboat tried to wreck a British trawler's fishing gear today. It was the first reported move by Iceland against about 100 British, West German and Belgian trawlers defying Iceland's new 50mile territorialwaters limit.

title: News of Dogs
description: Of more than a million dogs registered with the American Kennel Club last year, onefourth were poodles. So it is fitting that the nation's most popular, breed has, produced America's No. 1 canine hero for 1972.

title: Montreal Toll Now 36
description: The toll in the fire that swept a downtown Montreal nightclub Friday night has mounted to 36 dead and 54 injured, the police said yesterday. One man is being held and two are being sought. The police said the blaze may have been started by a group who were refused admission to the club shortly before the fire started. Details, Page 3.

title: More Money to the Politicians
description: For many Americans party politics seems pointless and closed. Still our political parties, for all their current limitations, offer citizens the best potential for redirecting American politics. The unprecedented changes that have occurred in the representative structure and procedures of the Democratic party since 1968 are clear indications that extensive party modernization is an entirely feasible goal for the nineteenseventies.

title: Ratings for Sale
description: When a number of newspapers announced earlier this year that they would no longer accept advertising for Xrated films, the Motion Picture Association of America quite properly condemned such a policy as an act akin to censorship. While the number of pornographic sexploitation films in the X category was steadily increasing, the M.P.A.A. pointed outrightly, in our viewthat a blanket prohibition on advertisements for films carrying that label constituted a misuse of the code.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: With the election campaign heating up, a little drama is being played out with regard to its financing. The scene is the nation's capital and the players are politicians, fatcats and assorted hangerson.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  It is regularly called the Watergate caper, and certainly the breakin at the offices of the Democratic National Committee on June 17 has been colored from the start by touches of slapstick, by an air of unreality, and by lots of empty explanations. Examples abound.

title: The Nation
description: NEWARKIt once was the largest newspaper in New Jersey, and was widely regarded as the state's most prestigious. In its heyday it could make governors knuckle under and legislatures quake. But in the end, the Newark Evening News couldn't even save itself.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: PECOS, N. M. Sept. 2 A lawsuit challenging the proposed construction of a 33mile mountain road deep inside the Santa Fe National Forest is posing an important legal test for the 1969 National Environmental Policy Act.

title: A movie natural, with a part for the C.I.A.
description: It looks as though Papaver somniferum, the rather beautiful opium poppy, is going to provide us with a new genre of film, fiction, journalism and, even, scholarship. This is understandable. Heroin addiction is savaging our cities. Any nation that moves down the road to addiction, that nation has something taken out of its character, President Nixon observed last March shortly after his return from China, once the most addicted of nations. Mr. Nixon has declared war on heroin at homeand galvanized his emissaries abroad. In certain parts of the world, American diplomats now give almost monomaniacal attention to persuading frequently indifferent or corrupt officials to do something about poppy cultivation, heroin refining and heroin trafficking.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nominee, called yesterday for the release of the five IrishAmericans imprisoned in Fort Worth, Tex., for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury.

title: Messed over and generally maligned but in vogue
description: Linguisteducator J. L. Dillard of the University of Puerto Rico has produced a highly readable, usable and extremely timely discussion of the language system and habits of African Americans in previous and current times. Readable in that he doesn't go off on the reader about phonemes and dental fricatives and all them other things linguists be running off at the mouth about doin their professional number. Usable in that he opens up the discussion of language in general, doesn't stalk language with grim thoushaltnot schoolmarm prescriptions or towho and towhom trivia or engage in the hierarchal madness of labels like proper or substandard. He comes at language as langdagea network of cultural loyalties, group outlooks, verbal games, perceptual modes, lore, structure, music.

title: A Russian Paradox
description: Yachting is surely the most paradoxical of all the sports on the 1972 Olympic program caught up in SovietAmerican rivalry. It is always referred to as a rich man's sport. Yet the major stronghold of the world proletariat has developed a team of yachtsmen capable of threatening Western supremacy at Kiel.

title: AROUND THE
description: You all deserve some fun.... Have it.... The garden can do without you til next week.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 2 (UPI) Three snipers opened fire on British troops in the Roman Catholic Falls Road area of Belfast today and the army said that soldiers wounded two of the gunmen.

title: Proposed Housing Project For Aged Gets State Loan
description: The initial step in the development of a 547unit housing project for the aged in Far Rockaway, Queens, was taken yesterday when the project obtained a $288,167 loan from the State Division of Housing and Community renewal.

title: Steelers Rout Saints, 567
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 2 (AP)Terry Bradshaw passed for three firsthalf touchdowns and the Pittsburgh defense kept New Orleans in its own territory most of the time as the, Steelers routed the Saints, 567, tonight.

title: Fiction: From Las Vegas to Wall Street, the Caribbean and an East Prussian castle
description: Ignore the flap copy. This is a lovely, gutsy, brilliant book completely free of the pose, the cuteness and the graduateschool sniggering it would have you believe is the sum total of M. E. White's talent. If it was really meant to be a con, it fails; if it was meant to reveal the wild, baffling coherence of life in the tinny towns and fruitless fields on both sides of the Mississippi, it succeeds in a manner stunning enough to chill the bone.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2A new Democratic reform commission, designed to meet some of the complaints leveled against the commission that so radically changed this year's Democratic National Convention, is to be appointed next week.

title: Fischer Celebrates Winning of Crown By Playing Chess
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. After becoming chess champion of the world yesterday, Bobby Fischer returned to his hotel room and celebrated: He played chess.

title: RICHARD A. FEIGE
description: HARRINGTON PARK, N.J., Sept. 2Richard A. Feige, an administrative assistant in the program department of Care, Inc., of New York, died today at his home, 25 Columbus Avenue. He was 44 years old.

title: Fischer 11th to Hold Official World Title
description: Bobby Fischer is the 11th man to hold the official world chess championship since 1886, when Wilhelm Steinitz of AustriaHungary, who had been unofficial titleholder for 20 years, won the first recognized championship match.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: JAPAN'S CURRENCY RESERVES rose $488million in August to $16.37billion, highest since March when it hit $16.63billion.... General Motors says it will produce the Wankel rotary engine and may offer it in the Vega... Auto production last week totaled 173,000 units. So far this year the industry has produced 5.63 million cars, against 5.75 million by this time last year.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: KINGS POINT, Sept. 2 (UPI)  The Merchant Marine Academy's class iof 1976 was sworn in today. The plebes, who reported to the academy here on July 19, were formally accepted into the 1,000man regiment by Rear Adm. Arthur B. Engel, the academy's superintendent.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE SPEAKER originally scheduled for last Tuesday's meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts was a man from the Chase Manhattan Bank. It would have been a routine affair, neither more nor less crowded than most of the other sessions that the society stages every day in its ordinarysize meeting room down in the financial district. But the man from the Chase was bumped by the Senator from South DakotaGeorge McGovern, the Democratic nominee for Presidentand the room was packed.

title: WELCOME TO NEW YORK
description: THE 747 was still lounging around in a dramaticlooking thunder storm an hour after it should have touched American soil, and, like the plane, my mind circled back to an Incident that had occurred the last time I arrived at Kennedy International Airport. It ought to have been a pleasant memory. because it centered on a whole, deliciouslooking smoked salmon.

title: BOTH SIDES MEET AT SUEZ BRIEFLY
description: QANTARA. IsraeliOccupied Sinai, Aug. 29  Boats were sailing across the Suez Canal and Egyptian seamen were casting for fish from the Israeliheld eastern bank.

title: Japanese Feel Nixon Accepts Their Policy of Ties With China
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 2  A senior Japanese official said today that President Nixon had assured Premier Kakuei Tanaka during their twoday meeting here that the United States would not try to interfere with Japan's plans to establish formal relations with China even though the President was concerned about the diplomatic repercussions of the move.

title: Simmer it in coffee
description: Pot roast will never be the same Good old pot roast becomes a new experience with the two recipes given below. They turn relatively inexpensive cuts of beef (brisket or blade or bottom round) into culinary happenings. One garlicrich pot roast is marinated in vinegar for a day and a night and then simmered for hours in brew of black coffee; the other is flavored with horseradish, cranberry sauce, a stick of cinnamon and cloves.

title: $4Million in Injury Suit
description: RENO, Sept. 2 (UPI)Nearly $4million, believed to be the largest judgment ever awarded to a personal injury victim, was deposited in a Reno bank yesterday on behalf of Keith Bush and his family. Mr. Bush was hurt Oct: 19, 1969, while helping reassemble a giant vehicle used in openpit mining. A bolt broke and dropped a 1,130pound electrical control cabinet on him. Mrs. Bush filed suit against the Westinghouse Air Brake Company and the General Electric Company.

title: Young Conservationist Has Total Faith in Nature sWays
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I.  To 19yearold Lynne Mehalick, ecology is more than Just a stylish sevenletter word. She has been interested in the outofdoors since her Girl Scout days, she is planning for a future centered around some aspect of nature and she spent the summer working for the Smithtown Conservation Advisory Council.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon's celebrated but never really stated fouryear plan to resolve the nation's agony in Vietnam was, in fact, a threetiered strategy aimed at that pivotal day of reckoning, Nov. 7, 1972. As Election Day nears, only one of those tiers has actually been reached, but the President appears to have been right in calculating that this would suffice to mollify the voters.

All of a sudden we must refocus our thinking about the dicethrowing, I Chingconsulting composer, mushroom authority, mystic and philosopher. Can you imagine Huck Finn with a gray beard? Puck as an elder statesman? Peter Pan on Geritol?

title: Photography

Nevertheless, it conceals beneath its bland and cautious surface enough explosive material to rock modern painting to its very foundations, if not to blow it sky high.

description: ROSLYN, L. I., Sept. 2The engagement of Miss Ellen Schwartz to John W. Wolff has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schwartz. Mr. Wolff is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hans Wolff of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Cox Upsets Rosewall in Tennis
description: Two lefthanded Britons provided the major excitement yesterday at the $160,000 United States Open tennis championships. One was Mark Cox, who ousted Ken Rosewall, the secondseeded player, in four sets. The other was Roger Taylor who carried the fourthseeded Ilie Nastase to a tie breaker in the final set before bowing.

title: New Law School for St. John's
description: What is believed to be the first law school in Queens is scheduled to begin fulltime operation on Tuesday. That is the day when 800 day and 300 night students will start to attend classes in St. John's University's $6million Fromkes Memorial Hall.

title: Fiction: From Las Vegas to Wall Street, the Caribbean and an East Prussian castle
description: Louis Auchincloss is the only writer of our time who has done something interesting with something like the novel of manners. An admirer of Henry James and a discriminating critic of James's principal American disciple, Edith Wharton, Auchincloss has deliberately limited his scope. He has set aside as his particular provincehis Yokapatawpha County, so to speaka small part of the population of New York City, made up of people of some means but not rich in the Hollywood sense of the term and usually but not always belonging to old families. They constitute, in short, what is still called in some quarters good society.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Keeping the nuclear peace:
description: A vital detail relating to the armscontrol agreements signed in Moscowand now on the verge of winning Congressional approval  has been withheld by the Governments of both the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. This is the specific means to be used to police the agreements and how effective it will he in detecting violations. The agreements state simply that compliance with the terms will he assured by national technical means of verification.

title: Jane Hardesty Wed to F. Harrison Poole
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Sept. 2 The marriage of Miss Jane Frances Hardesty of New York to F. Harrison Poole of Wilson Point, South Norwalk, director of planning for Philip Morris Inc. in New York, took place here today.

title: Stamps

title: If You Come...
description: ... to New York City from abroad, leave your smoked salmons at home, but bring your potential for awe, for wonderment and for absorbing experiences you are not likely to have elsewhere. Most Americans won't speak your language, but in New York City there will be someone who does, if you can find him.

description: Is it a chair or a stool? Should it be straddled, leaned against or sat in? Will an accidental shove topple the pedestalbased design or dislodge its occupant?

title: Lettars
description: To the Editor:

title: A SixHour Voyage Back Into Time On a C. &
description: MIILWAUICEE  There's a time warp on Jones Island. It's not marked by any sign, but it's there and you can see it while driving out Lincoln Memorial Drive from the scrambling, trafficchoked heart of this city. An early morning fog boiling off Lake Michigan enhances the timelessness. Jones Island, at the Milwaukee harbor entrance to the lake, is a remnant of the era when industry spread across the nation leaving bleak, dreary scabs of concrete, gravel and steel on the landscape. Telephone and power poles, gray and weathered, loom out of the mist, and rusting chainlink fence, protecting nothing, stretches by on either side of the road. It's a flat and desolate scene, without trees or grass. In the nineteenthirties and forties this was a place of beauttf to bankers and businessmen; now its a dying memorial to a false god, a place worth visiting for the eerie sense it conveys of what used to be.

title: Theodore Riehle 3d, Teacher, Marries Helen H. Scheidecker
description: SOUTH HERO, Vt., Sept. Miss Helen Hardy Scheidecker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Instone Scheldecker of Mountainside, N. J., and West Dennis, Mass., was married here this afternoon to Theodore Martin Riehle 3d, son of Mrs. Sumner RulonMiller Jr. of New York and Mr. Riehle Jr. of South Burlington and Savage Island.

title: The World
description: MOSCOWIt's almost Impossible to find enough good potatoes these days, a Moscow housewife complained while standing in line in state store last week. Whenever potato shipment arrives the queues are terrible. A man in line chimed in When it's this bad now, you can expect it will be worse in winter.

title: METHADONE CARE CUTTING ARRESTS
description: The arrest rates for drug addicts enrolled in the city's methadone treatment program have dropped by as much as 82 per cent, according to data released yesterday.

title: Heavy Toll Reported in Battle North of Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Sept. 3 (AP)North and South Vietnamese troops fought north of Saigon Friday and yesterday, and preliminary reports from the field indicated that there were heavy casualties on both sides.

title: College Names 2 Trustees
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 2 (AP)Hedley Williams Donovan, editor in chief of Time, Inc., and Charles Philip Price, a professor at Virginia Theology Seminary, have been elected trustees of Mount Holyoke College, the school announced this week.

title: Terry Joins Nixon Campaign
description: Governor Rockefeller, who is chairmaii of the New York Committee to Reelect the President, yesterday announced the appointment of Representative John H. Terry of Syracuse to head the committee. In the fivecounty area there Mr. Terry, who is retiring this year from the House, will direct the Nixon campaign in Onondaga, Oswego, Jefferson, Cayuga and Chenango counties.

title: In Germany: The End Of Assimilation
description: ITHINK of myself as an assimilated Jew. I say that without any particular pride or passion, but merely to provide a perspective for what follows. It was because I consider myself assimilated that I was able to plan a business trip to West Germany last fall without ever thinking twice. It was a trip of more than 2,000 miles through much of the country and I can honestly say that I regarded it as just another. job. I left New York on the first night of Rosh Hashanah. 5732.

title: SHOP TALK
description: COLTS NECKWhether or not this township's name came from its resemblanceeither real or fanciedto a colt's neck, there's no doubt about the influence of horses on its lifestyle.

title: THEY'RE LEGAL
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: FRANK SCHOONOVER, ILLUSTRATOR, DEAD
description: WILMINGTON. Del., Sept. 2 (AP)Frank E. Schoonover artist illustrator and a contemporary and friend of the late N. C. Wyeth and Howard Pyle, died yesterday at. the Wilmington Medical Center.. He Was 95 years old.

title: Divorce JuvenileStyle
description: It's little wonder that some children think they are the ones being di vorced when their parents split up. No one, of course, wants to tell them what's really going on. So, when confronted by eight children's books on the subject I asked myself, first of all, if the writers were letting kids in on what is happening. Have they, as adults, joined the side of parental resistance? Are they providing a glimmer of positive thinking for the young reader? Or are they perpetuating a sad fantasy they could help the child be rid of?

title: The Nation
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Committee on Colonialism was established in 1961, after most of the West's African and Asian colonies had been granted independence. The committee's role was to speed up the elimination of the last vestiges of colonialism. In the view of the American and some other Western governments, however, it has been acting with more zeal than fairness.

title: R. H. Hughes Fiarice Of Lauren Marcus
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 2Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Marcus have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lauren Gail Marcus, to Raymond Howard Hughes of New York. The wedding is planned for Sept. 16.

Potter's Equation, a 68foot ketch out of SeawanhakaCorinthian Yacht Club at Oyster Bay, L.I., today became the first trophy winner on the 38th annual Stamford Yacht Club Vineyard Race which, for the passage eastward, was a wild thresh that was taking a heavy toll of the record fleet.

title: The Nation
description: Florida millionaire Glenn W. Turner has an ample assembly. of criticsinchiding the attorneys general of most of the 50 statesbut even his detractors agree he is something of a phenomenon. The man, said one assistant attorney general who tangled with him, is incredible. Absolutely incredible.

title: Fiction: From Las Vegas to Wall Street, the Caribbean and an East Prussian castle
description: The strengths and idiosyncracies evident in Sol Yurick's novelsespecially the overwhelming, exasperating, and unforgettable The Bagare all here in this collection of 13 short stories. The book begins with a brutal piece called The Annealing, in which a young black woman's miscarriage is probably the least of the brutalities recorded. It ends with a curious fantasy of a communal birth, And Not in Utter Nakedness.... Throughout, Yurick manages an easy relationship with his very contemporary, very urban and exotic subject matter; despite frequent explorations of sordid events, in which the body has horribly come into control of the spirit, he shows a sympathy for his many misguided, illfavored, unhappy people.

title: Rain Defers Senior Net Play
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 (AP) Semifinal play in the United States senior grasscourt tennis championship was postponed by rain today. Matches pitting last year's winner, Torsten Johanson of Sweden, against Gardner Mulloy of Miami, Fla., and Bobby Riggs of Newport Beach, Calif., against Richard Heath of New Canaan, Conn., will be held today.

title: Pocket Sundial Is Found In Jerusalem Excavations
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 2 (Reuters)  Archeologists here have found a 2,000yearold pocket sundial made of stone, described by one expert as the equivalent of a pocket watch.

title: Susan Speers, R. L. Herrmann Have Nuptials
description: KILLINGWORTH, Conn., Sept. 2Miss Susan Archer Speers and R. Leith Herrmann were married here this afternoon in Emmanuel Episcopal Church by the Rev. E. Perren Hayes Jr., who was assisted by the Rev. William Patten Reed.

title: The fashionable view of man as a naked ape is: 1. An insult to apes 2. Simplistic 3. Malemoriented 4. Rubbish
description: Last fall, C.B.S. Television broadcast a National Geographic special, in prime time, called Monkeys, Apes and Man. This was an attempt to demonstrate how much studies of primates can tell us about our true biological selves. And in a recent Newsweek article, Stewart Alsop, while discussing problems of war, stated that nations often quarrel over geopolitical real estate when national boundaries are poorly Oefined: his examples were culled from areas as diverse as the Middle East, Central Europe and Asia. One of his introductory paragraphs included the following:

description: There's a basic human instinct, a fundamental urge that Sigmund Freud never properly acknowledged. Joseph Hirschhorn, the uranium tycoon, has it and so does Michael Lewis, a 15yearold schoolboy from Chappaqua, N. Y.

title: Brewers Beat Rangers, 62
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 2 (UPI)  Bill Parsons scattered seven hits and drove in two runs with a pair of hits today as the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Texas Rangers, 62, before the smallest crowd ever to see a major league game at Arlington Stadium.

title: Soviet Union Sextet Downs Canada, 73
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 2In a shock to Canada's nervous system, the remarkably controlled Soviet Union national team tonight trounced the National Hockey League's finest players, 73, in the first meeting between the world's top professional and amateur hockey teams.

title: Letters:
description: In Facing Major Dental Work? Take Your Teeth to Europe (Travel section, Aug. 20), Bynum Shaw described how members of his family had spent two weeks abroad, had dental work done and saved money. Many American dentists have written to deride the idea. The following letters are a representative sample.

description: HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 2  Miss Beverly Winslow Cutler and James Wesley Masland, son of Mrs. John Wz Masland of Hanover and the late Professor Masland, were married here this afternoon. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Norton Cutler of Washington.

description: Although the city has been urging citizens to conserve electricity this summer, there are plates where its street lights continue to burn by day as well as at nightsometimes, apparently, for periods as long as a month.

Baldwin of Greenwich, Conn. Miss Kugel, daughter also of the late Mr. Kugel, is a staff nurse at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn. She is a 1972 graduate of the Greenwich Hospital School of Nursing.

title: Art
description: THE dictionary, which is my favorite book, gives five definitions for efflorescence, ranging from the must pleasant, time of flowering, hence a peak or fulfillment, to rather awful, an eruption on the skin. Hence it is safe to refer to the profusion of community art centers that continue to spring up across the land as the cultural efflorescence that, unquestionably, they are.

title: Rice Named to Fitness Board
description: SALT LAKE CITY. Robert L. Rice, chairman and president of Health Industries, Inc nationwide operator of the European Health Spas, has been appointed by President Nixon to serve as a member of the Conference on Physical Fitness and Sports. Rice succeeds A. J. Foyt Jr., whose resignation the President recently accepted with regret.

description: TRENTON  The volatile rentleveling controversy in New Jersey began quietly enough last year in Lakewood, where the first rentcontrol ordinance was adopted in the state.

title: Gardens
description: SOMEWHAT involved as I am with the museums of the Dukes County Historical Society on Martha's Vineyard, I have come to know of the strong attachment people have to things old, rare and beautiful. Which brings me to wonder, who is going to become the curator (or curators) of the oldfashioned quality plants in the United States or other countries? For the fact of the matter is that the increasing demands for quickly effective landscape plants and the corresponding growth of big nurseries to supply them, lessens the opportunities for the interested gardener to secure unusual plants for special spots, or to fill in collections of one or another

title: Government Bookstore Is Full of Advice for Your Health, Education and Welfare
description: Whooping Cranes and Puddle Ducks roost in harmony here. Both brochures are on sale at the United States Government Printing Office bookstore at 26 Federal Plaza.

description: RINGWOODIf you like visiting important old houses full of beautiful things and with a lot of historyand some legends, including stories of ghosts  Ringwood Manor is the place to go.

title: White Sox Defeated, 21, As Kline and Allen Excel
description: The old pennant fever kept rising in the Bronx yesterday as the Yankees scored a 2.1 decision over the Chicago White Sox for their fourth straight victory and the seventh in their last eight games.

title: Travel Notes:
description: Steering clear of a politically sensitive issue in an election year, the Nixon Administration has extended the right of Aer Lingus, the Irish international airline, to land in New York. Earlier in the year the Civil Aeronautics Board recommended that the line's authority to land at Kennedy International Airport be revoked on Aug. 18 unless the Irish Government permitted United States carriers to land at Dublin rather than terminate their flights at Shannon Airport in the west of Ireland.. The Administration's reprieve for Aer Lingus came in the form of an assurance from the State Department that no final decision would be made before the end of the year. As if in celebration, the line promptly offered a series of tours designed to lure more vacationers to the Emerald Isle, among them a $305, twoweek Autumn in Ireland package and, starting in November, a weeklong honeymoon special for $289 a person. Both include roundtrip air fare from New York, accommodations and free use of a car.

description: WEST HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 31  Born, brought up in this town. Never did notice that stadium much till this summer, said the cab driver. I stay away from all that traffic on game nights. They draw some damn fine little crowds.

title: Criminals At Large
description: There is no mystery as such in Patricia Highsmith's A DOG'S RANSOM (Knopf, $5.95). A sick, warped old man in New York's West EndRiverside Drive area sends poisonpen letters to a prosperous couple, then kidnaps their dog, holding it for ransom. He gets the money, is apprehended, and starts a chain of events leading to the breakup of various lives.

title: If...?
description: An article I wrote for the Jan. 9 issue of the Book Review (Not Science Fiction but If...? Fiction), demonstrating the difficulty of any satisfactory definition of the genre, drew some interesting responses. The most pleasurable was an assignment, by the Encyclopedia Americana, to define science fiction for the new edition. I was able, at least, to describe it. To this description, I added several appropriate examples. One was AGAIN, DANGEROUS VISIONS, edited by Harlan Ellison (Doubleday, $12.95).

title: Fastest US AC Field in History Poised for California 500 Today
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Sept. 2The 33 cars in the California 500 here tomorrow, with an average qualifying speed of 187.766 miles an hour, constitute the fastest field in the history of the United States Auto Club. But the combination of Southern California's mid90's heat and the immense wearandtear of a 500mile grind makes it likely that victory will go not to the swiftest, but the strongest.

title: The Nation
description: HONOLULU  The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a leading Japanese newspaper, said in an editorial the other day: The relationship between Japan and China is like opening up a road where there is no road. The relationship between Japan and the Soviet Union is like paving a road that has already been opened. And the relationship between Japan and the United States is like repairing a highway.

description: To the Editor:

title: Gardens
description: THE preparation, many garden plants can make a late summer migration indoors as miniature trees.I became interested in cultivating these twoway plants when friend showed me what ceauld be done by trimming and training an ordinary variegated coleus. While neither a balllike standard nor a bonsai, the coleus had been effectively shaped and maintained so that it had the qualities of both.

title: Miss Kennedy Wed To Robert Gilbert
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Sept. 2 Miss Mary Elizabeth Kennedy and Robert Snowden Gilbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Adrian Gilbert of Garden City and West, Gilgo Beach, were married here this afternoon.

description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 2 A history of racial problems dating from 1967 has culminated in a state investigation of the Waterloo, Iowa, school district to determine whether allegations that it practices racial discrimination are true.

description: The Atlantic salmon is probably the world's most highly regarded game fish.Certainly, no other species has attracted the international attention accorded the lordly salmon during the last few years when it was finally realized that overharvesting by commercial interests, dams, pollution, poaching and disease had made questionable the salmon's survival.

description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 2 (AP)Hal Breeden and Ken Singleton hit home runs as the Montreal Expos downed the Cincinnati Reds, 72, tonight.

description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2Porter Lee Harris Jr., 5 years old, was playing with his toy fire engine here the other day when a convertible sped by, its tires squealing and its three occupants firing an assortment of weapons in his direction.

description: DETROIT, Sept. 2  The United Automobile Workers has asked the Chrysler Corporation to begin talks on how to humanize jobs on the assembly line.

title: Uzbeks Honor Angela Davis
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (UPI)Angela Davis, the American Communist who was acquitted on a gunsupplying charge in California early this summer, was awarded an honorary degree today by the University of Tashkent, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. Miss Davis arrived in Moscow Moniday and went to Uzbekistanof which Tashkent is the capital  three days ago.

title: Conciliation: Is It Worth a Try?
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  Despite the conciliation called for under the state's fiveyearold divorce law, the majority of Long Islanders now seeking divorce win their decrees without any conciliation attempt.
