Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, would visit the Soviet Union Sept. 10 to Sept. 13 for talks with Soviet leaders, including the Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin.

title: Court Backs Connecticut Vote On Lines Fought by Democrats
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 5 (AP)The State Supreme Court refused today to call a halt to the process of choosing General Assembly candidates for tbe Nov. 7 elections.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Most of the world Is saddened and shocked by the reprehensible violence that erupted at the Olympic Games, and calls are already being heard for something to be done about such unconscionable terrorism. But the question is, what can be done?

title: Lolich Wins 20th, 43
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 6Earl Weaver received a contract to manage Baltimore again next season, but Mickey Lolich gained his 20th victory of this season tonight and that gave Detroit more of a reason to celebrate.

title: Tokyo Offers Soft Loans Of $170Million to Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 6Japan promised today to provide South Korea with $1701 million in soft loans in a continuing program to help this country's economic development.

title: BEANIE DECLINES FUNDS FOR CAMP
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame refused yesterday to approve a $67,974 request by the city's Youth Services Agency for its summer camp program for underprivileged children from the South Bronx Model Cities area.

title: Talley to Halt Operations Of 85%Owned Discom
description: Talley Industries, Inc., Mesa, Ariz., announced yesterday that it has decided to discontinue the operations of Discom, Inc., an 85 per cent owned sudsid iary which manufactures components for data.processing. The company said that the move will result in a charge of $500,000 against Talley's fiscal 1973 earnings.

title: SOUTH KOREA PLANS A VIETNAM PULLOUT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Sept. 7. (UPI) South Korea will withdraw all of its 37,000 soldiers from South Vietnam starting in December, a highranking Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: 16 Crewmen Feared Dead As Ship Sinks Off Finland
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 6 (UPI)  A 60yearold dredging vessel capsized and sank early today during a storm in the Gulf of Bothnia, trapping most of the sleeping crew of 20 below decks, the Finnish Coast Guard said.

title: KUNSTLER LOSES BID OVER ATTICA QUERIES
description: WARSAW, N. Y. Sept. 6 (UPI)  State Supreme Court Justice Carmin F. Ball rejected today a bid by the civil rights attorney William M. Kunstler, for a protective order to stop the state from questioning him about inmate actions during last September's rebellion at Attica State Correctional Facility.

title: Roundup: Phils'
description: Ken Reynolds, who had lost his first 12 games of the season, appears to have made a turnabout.

title: Neutercane a Meteorological Rarity
description: There is a new but rare beast in the meteorological menagerie of storms. It is called a neutercane, and it is a cross between the tropical hurricane and the temperate zone's common frontal, or intertype storm.

title: Red Sox Down Yankees, 20
description: BOSTON, Sept. 6The Boston Red Sox emerged with a 20 victory over the New York Yankees tonight in a clash between the American League's two principle miracle seekers.

title: SILVER TUMBLES IN FUTURES TRADE
description: Profittaking sent silver ands copper futures tumbling yester1 day on the Commodity Exchange here.

title: Baltimore Jack Dies
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 6 (AP)Baltimore Jack, a 20yearold, 300pound gorilla, died today of pneumonia.

title: Rockefeller Aide Named
description: ALBANY, Sept. 6Governor Rockefeller's office today announced the appointment of John P. Harcourt Jr. of Menands, N. Y., as. assistant secretary to the Governor at a salary of $30,000 a year. Mr. Harcourt, who is 30 years old, joined Mr. Rockefeller's staff in June, 1970, as special assistant for appointments and assumed his new position today. In his new post, Mr. Harcourt will assist Dr. T. Norman Hurd, who is secretary to the Governor.

title: Cultural Boom Brings Urbanity to the Nation's Suburbs
description: MANASSAS, Va., Sept. 2 The Kennedy cultural center, Washington's new marble monument to the arts, is 27 miles away. The Great White Way is an era away. But out here, where the new rows of townless townhouses curl ever farther across the fields, stands a symbol of a new form of American cultural life, culture in the suburbs.

title: Growth of Politics in Future Games Seen
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 6The tragic events that interrupted the 20th Olympic Games yesterday may have a profound effect on all, large international athletic events in the future, including the 1976 games in Montreal.

title: Dotson Feels Confident Of Making Knick Squad
description: WEST LONG BRANCH N.J., Sept. 6Is there room on the New York Knicks basketball roster for a 6foot4inch. backcourt man who can play defense?

title: What's in a Name? For Nixon Committee, Confusion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Senator George McGovern's campaign staff, embarrassed by recent reports of organizational confusion in its ranks, can take some solace from a bit of bureaucratic befuddlement in President's Nixon's campaign.

title: Books of The Times
description: I can't remember reading a more inconsequential volume of stories than Gabriel Fieding's New Queens for Old. The author is a man of considerable reputation especially in his native Englandand so, instead of dismissing the book as it seems so richly to deserve,.I feel a professional obligation to rummage through it, to, search its pages for the secret of that reputation. There has been enough praise for Mr. Fielding's work to give pause to a philosopher, and indeed we may require a philosopher to account for this phenomenon, since I don't see how literary criticism can. Even the casual reader is familiar, by now, with the doctrine of large signifiin small detail. in the starlet of certain contemporary authorsthe NeW Yorker magazine comes to mindthe reader ,sled into tiny, exquisitely furnished room (I like to think of it as a Morning room) and left to brood on the fraying of the carpet. Everything conspires to create a mood: an ironically elegiac awareness of the disappearance of grace front our lives. We are reminded of the tightrope balance of sanity, the cruel inconsistencies of the passions, the terrible difficulty of simply, being.

title: Lumber Price Inquiry Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) Complaints about rising lumber prices have caused the Internal Revenue Service to begin an investigation into pricing practices in the lumber industry. The Price Commission chairman, C. Jackson Grayson Jr. said yesterday that the inquiry would include random audits of companies to determine compliance with price regulations.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The season for suntans and swimsuits is waning and stores are naturally concerned with what women will wear when it snows. Many of the new fashion offerings have foreign labels, preferably French.

title: RALLY BY SOVIETS TIES CANADA, 44
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 6 (AP)  The Soviet Union hockey team rallied for two goals late in the second period tonight to tie Team Canada, 44, in the third game of an eightgame exhibition series.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: The Storm Over Agnes
description: WASHINGTONThe unprecedented destruction wrought by Tropical Storm Agnes across a sixstate area late in June left thousands homeless, necessitating a temporary and permanent housing program unequaled in scope and urgency.

title: Nuptials Here for Katherine Silberblatt
description: Miss Katherine Robin Silberblatt and Marvin A. Wolfthai, both of Milan, Italy, were married here last evening at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, by Rabbi David Seligson.

title: Britain Offers Parley a Modified Proposal for Treaty on Aircraft Hijackings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Britain offered a partial formula today for drafting a new international treaty on hijacking. United States officials said that it might help overcome some of the most difficult diplomatic hurdles to a new treaty.

title: Steingut Sees a $550Million Surplus
description: ALBANY, Sept. 6Some of the 150 members of the Assembly came to the State Capitol today for a minisession that consisted mainly of partisan rhetoric and closed meetings on how best to get reelected.

title: SAIGON DECREES END OF ELECTIONS ON HAMLET LEVEL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 6The South Vietnamese Government, by executive decree; has abolished popular democratic election of officials at the most basic levelin the country's 10, 775 hamlets.

title: Times Mirror 2for1 Split
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 (AP) Directors of the Times Mirror Company, a diversified corpora lion that publishes Los Angeles Times, approved a 2for1 common stock split today. If approved by stockholders the split is expected to become effective Nov. 14.

title: Forest Hills Compromise To Get a Hearing Sept. 20
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday scheduled hearing for Sept. 20 on the proposed Forest Hills publichousing compromise that has been endorsed by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Rev. William Weber, Ecumenist Who Led Lutheran Parish on L.I.
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Sept. The Rev. William R. Weber, pastor of the Lutheran Church of Our Savior, and long active in ecumenical work, died today after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

title: Donegan Officiates at Marriage Of Alyce L. Brookfield in Rye
description: RYE, N.Y., Sept. 6Christ's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Alyce Lee Brookfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lord Brookfield, to James Rafferty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ward Rafferty. The ceremony was performed by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, retired Episcopal Bishop of New York and godfather of the bride, who officiated at the marriage of the bride's parents in the same church 35 years ago. The Rev. Wendell Phillips, rector of Christ's, also took part in the service.

title: Health Department Cites Food Outlets For Violating Code
description: Ten more restaurants and other foodprocessing establishments were cited by the Health Department yesterday for serious violations of the city's Health Code.

title: Last of Stake Offered
description: The Cities Service Company, a leading domestic integrated oil company with interests in minerals and chemicals, yesterday sold the last of its holdings of Atlantic Richfield Company stock, totaling 730,400 shares, for $48million.

title: Kotite Dropped by Giants, But Tight End Is Used to It
description: Dick Kotite, the Brooklyn boy from Wagner College who, in his pro football career, has been cut more times than a chopped steak, felt the knife again yesterday. The Giants, who first, signed him as a free agent in 1967, dropped the tight end as they cut their squad to the mandatory 44 players. Others waived by the Giants were Dave Roller, a defensive tackle; Joe Green, the safety; Jack Protz, a linebacker from Colonia, N. J., and Jack Rizzo, the rookie running back from Lehigh.

title: TRADING IS SLOW ON AMEX, 0TC
description: The OKC Corporation announced that it had abandoned a wildcat oil well in Ecuador and its shares plummeted 5% points to 337/8 yesterday for the sharpest drop, of the day on the American Stock Exchange. The company said that after testing it had decided the well would not yield enough oil for commercial development.

title: Autumn Yields Rich Harvest of Verse
description: The season in poetry, the chamber music of the book world, is, usually more intense than spectacular, and It is hard to predict how any single season will turn out. Most results are delayed. Very few, for instance, in 1922 foresaw the impact of T. S. Eliot's.. The Waste Land, just as few anticipated the excitement that was to be provoked by Allen Ginsberg's Howl when it was published in 1956 orin spite of some early alerts by Sylvia Plath's Ariel, when that was published 10 years later.

title: DRAFTEE ON TRIAL
description: FORT ORD, calif., Sept. 6A black draftee went on trial In a courtmartial here today, accused of premeditated murder in the deaths of two white officers killed by a hand grenade as they slept in their bunks at Bienhoa Army base in South Vietnam.

title: Law Firms'
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Government, broadening its network of price controls, imposed today. a 2.5 per cent ceiling on increases in the fees of law firms with more than 60 employes.

title: Teachers Threaten to Strike Unless City Makes Satisfactory Contract Offer
description: The teachers union warned the Board of Education yesterday that unless it presented a satisfactory final contract offer by 9 A.M. today it would be too late to avert a teachers' strike on Monday, the first day of the new school year.

title: Arthur Daley
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept 6The athletes of the world stepped into the Olympic Stadium today through the same portal they had used when they took part the pageantry and hoopla of Opening Day. Bands played and people cheered then, but that was 11 days ago, when they were brimful of hope and joy as they paused on the threshold of their great Olympic adventure.

title: Bloomingdale's Is 100 and Is Still Looking Up
description: Bloomingdale's yesterday celebrated a century of growth from a little store that grossed $3.68 on opening day to its present eightstory building, a block square, that has taken in more than $2million a day.

title: Savings Bond Record Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) A record of $57billion in Series E and H Savings Bonds and Freedom Shares were outstanding in August, the Treasury reported today. Series E and H sales of $562milion exceeded redemptions, at cost and H sales of $562million exalone totaled $534million, highest for any August since 1945, it was reported.

title: CHARLEY BERRY, UMPIRE 20 YEARS
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 6 Charley Berry, former American League catcher and umpire, who was also a football star, died today of a massive coronary attack in Evanston Hospital. He was 69 years old and had been hospitalized since suffering a stroke in June.

title: 2 SENATORS OFFER TRANSIT FUND PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Lowell P. Weicker introduced today legislation designed to permit use of $2.4billion from the Federal highway trust fund for mass transit.

title: Pathmark Seeks to Advertise Prices of Prescriptions
description: Pathmark, one of the largest supermarket and pharmacy chains on the East, announced yesterday that it had filed suits in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in an attempt to overturn laws prohibiting the advertising of retail prescription drug prices.

title: SPITZ HAS NOTHING TO SAY ON RETURN
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 Mark Spitz made a noncommittal return to the United States tonight.

title: ARAB GUERRILLAS WARNED BY ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 6Israel warned the Palestinian guerrilla organizations and indirectly the Arab nations today that they would be held accountable for the murders of 11 Israeli athletes and coaches in Munich.

title: The Storm Over Agnes
description: KINGSTON, Pa.As I was growing up I never paid too much attention to the river that flows near my home in Kingston. I used to wonder if would sink if I stepped on one of the grassy islands which grew out of the river in the summer. I remember wishing that it could be used for boating and swimming, but the Susquehanna was just too polluted for that. Only once a year, on the evening of July 4, was the river bank a meeting place for excited children who gathered for the fireWorks. But then; of course, we were enchanted with the streaks and sparks of color explosions high in the sky, and forgot all about the river.

title: Wood, Field and Stream : Tuna in Hiding
description: YARMOUTH, N. S., Sept. 6There wasn't a solitary bluefin sighted yesterday as Nova Scotia's 23d International Tuna Cup Tournament started. And, it was small wonder. Tropical storm Carrie passed through Sunday and Monday and the storm had such fury that even the citizens of this busy tourist community went into hiding. The electrical power in town was cut for three hours. The Prince of Fundy, the automobilepassenger ferry that makes a daily 10hour trip here from Portland, Me., arrived three hours late. The big blow had churned up the sea's bottom round Cape St. Mary.

title: Diversion From Pulling Canine Teeth
description: Westchester,the East's most prestigious outdoor show, takes place Sunday in Sterling Forest, Tuxedo, N. Y. A huge affair, with an entry of 2,486, it is produced by a 17man kennel club, one of the smallest in the country. No. 17 joined six months ago. He is Dr. Bernard (Bud) McGivern, an oral surgeon from Staten. Island. He has been active in the sport since his days at Notre Dame. The official mascot of the football team was an Irish terrier, Shannon View Rudy, he recalled. I showed him at International in Chicago in 1958 We took second place in a twodog class.

title: Foe Is Reported Repulsed Near Pleiku
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 7 (AP)More fighting was reported yesterday in the Central Highlands, with North Vietnamese troops attacking within seven miles of the city of Pleiku.

title: De Mont Told to Return Medal; Alexeyev Takes Lifting Crown
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 6 (Reuters)  America's victorious Olympic swimming team, ready to go home with 18 gold medals, was told tonight that 16yearold Rick De Mont would have to return the one he won in the 400meter freestyle event. De Mont was found to have violated Olympic rules when he took an antiasthma medication that was on a list of forbidden drugs.

title: Keep Moving
description: In San Francisco, as the daily rush hour approaches, uniformed officers temporarily take over the task of moving the trafficthe same traffic which, when left to automatic signals, winds up in nowin jams, as New Yorkers know all too well. The San Francisco officers look like unarmed police, but their shoulder patches identify them as traffic controllers. They receive several weeks of special training at the Police Academy, and their salary is about a third less than that of the regular patrolmen.

title: The Greening of China Is Reported by Historian
description: The two most striking physical features of China today are the new tree planting and the old transportation by animaldrawn and mandrawn cart.

title: Job Violations Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  The Department of Labor said today that it had found violations of Federal job safety and health regulations in 70 per cent of the 32,700 such investigations it made in the last year.

title: City Seeks to Double Number of Centers for Elderly
description: The city is seeking to more than double the number of public and private centers, for the elderly, aiming at a target of 231 centers, under Federal and state funds now held available. There are now 111 such centers.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Many persons who admire President Nixon have objected to the antiNixon bias in the Nixonian history. of America which was published here the other day. They demand, in the name of fair play, an equally biased American history according to Senator McGovern.

title: American Fails to Test Soviet Strongman
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 6 (AP)  The tragedymarked Olympic Games resumed today and both finals on the program went to Eastern Europeans.

title: The Theater: Long Day's Journey
description: LONDON  There is no doubt that the National Theater's production of Eugene O'Neill's Long Day's Journey Into Night is one of the greatest achievements of its nineyearold history. First given at the end of last year at the Old Vic, it has now been revived with its original cast, Constance Cummings, Laurence Olivier, Ronald Pickup and Denis Quilley.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI)A record $57billion Series E and H savings bonds and Freedom Shares was outstanding in August, the Treasury reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The appointment by the Governor of a State Deputy Attorney General as recommended by the Knapp Commission is an unjustified reflection upon the New York City District Attorneys, and is wasteful.

title: $115MILLION SUIT ATTACKS INSURER
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 (AP) A $115million classaction civil suit has been filed against the Pennsylvania Life Insurance Company by three of its policy holders who claim fraudulent and deceitful tactics were used by the company in its sale of disability insurance policies.

title: Wesleyan Opens a $23Million Drive, First Major Effort in Half a Century
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 6  Wesleyan University today began a major fundraising effort, its first in more than half century.

title: WILLIAM FRAZIER SR., PHYSICIAN 47 YEARS
description: YONKERS, Sept. 6Dr. William H. Frazier Sr., a member of the medical staff of Yonkers General Hospital and a general practitioner, died at the hospital on Sunday after a brief illness. He was 72 years old and lived at 204 Warburton Avenue.

title: Personalities: Jobs With No Escape Clause
description: Prisoners who show promtie as boxers will be among those permitted to take outside jobs in Massachusetts next month. Tom McNeeley, who once attempted to take the heavyweight crown from Floyd Patterson and now is a member of the state's boxing commission, explained yesterday that there are quite a few convicts who look good enough to box as professionals. Massachusetts has a new law that permits certain convicts to leave the prisons for outside work under supervision. There are some talented fighters in jail, added Paul Pender, the former middleweight champion who is a prison recrea tional director.

title: Robeson Will Receive Whitney Young Award
description: Paul Robeson Sr., the 74yearold former actor, singer and pioneer activist in the civil rights movement, was named yesterday as the recipient of the second annual Whitney M. Young Jr. National Memorial Award.

title: AUGUSTA, GA., GROUP SEEKS A BUSING TEST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI)A group of Augusta, Ga. parents seeking the first full judicial test of the new Federal antibusing law, asked the Supreme Court today to delay a lower court order for massive additional busing in their city's school system.

title: New Yorkers Grieve Over Israeli Dead
description: It ends, the Negro spiritual, with these words: Thank God, thank God, they got peace at last.

title: The Real School Issue
description: With the opening of the city's public schools only five days away, the United Federation of Teachers appears to have decided once again to, move into the war of nerves routine in its contract negotiations with the Board of Education. Union president Albert Shanker's public display of pessimism is clearly intended to put pressure on the board to surrender to unreasonable demands in order to avert a strike.

title: A Primary to Watch
description: Colorado is a long way from Manhattan, but what happens in the Democratic primary of that state's Fourth Congressional District next Tuesday is of keen interest to New Yorkersas well as Kansans, Alabamians and all other Americans. The incumbent, Representative Wayne N. Aspinall, is the extremely potent chairman of the House Interior Committee, a oneman roadblock to sound environmental legislation and a baneful influence on the uses of the public domain. After 24 years in Congress he is in political danger thanks to some redistricting, to advanced age and to a dynamic conservationist opponent named Alan Merson.

title: Despicable Act Decried at Arena Rites
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 6The 20th Olympic Games resumed this afternoon, five hours after 80,000 persons gathered in the huge Olympic Stadium to mourn the 11 Israelis killed in the battle, with Arab terrorists.

title: METS LOSE BY 73, FALL 16 BEHIND
description: Groping their way toward the finish line of the season, the Mets dropped a 73 decision to the Montreal Expos last night at Shea Stadium while the medical reports kept piling higher and higher.

title: S.E.C. Rebuffs Utility
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today a proposal by the American Electric Power Company, Inc., that the commission make an immediate decision on the'. company's revised plan for acquisition of the Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company.

title: Hijacker Profile Leads To Seizure of Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) The Federal Aviation Administration said today that its hijacker behavioral profile led to the discovery of a small arsenal in a violin case at the Cleveland airport.

title: Birth of Male Gorilla Is Pleasant Surprise for Zoo
description: A fivepound male gorilla with a wise and wizened face was born Sunday at the Central Park Zoo to the delight of two dozen onlookers and several surprised zookeepers, who reported yesterday that they did not even know that his mother, Lulu, was pregnant.

title: FlameProof Line Offered
description: M. Lowenstein & Sons, Inc., announced yesterday a new flameproof line of polyester knit goods as well as polyester plain and printed woven fabrics. Robert Bendheim, chairman, said the company was ready to offer to the trade what it termed a complete line of year round fire retardant knits and woven goods in a wide range of colors and prints.

title: BATTLE DEFENDED
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 6  West Germany began a fullscale inquiry today into the Arab terrorism and German police action that left 17 persons dead and. disrupted the Olympic Games yesterday.

title: ExLabor Aide Bids Nominees Back Plan for Minority Hiring
description: Arthur A. Fletcher asserted yesterday that the Philadelphia Plan was not likely to be enforced unless President Nixon and Senator George McGovern took clear supportive stands on the minority hiring program.

title: MISS EVERT GAINS OPEN SEMIFINALS
description: The Soviet Union's top woman player, who studies tennis psychology when she's not competing, nearly found the secret to beating Chris Evert yesterday but America's teenage wonder survived, overcoming, Mrs. Olga Morozova, 36, 63, 76. Her victory put her into the semifinals of the United States Open championships at Forest Hills, Queens, along with Mrs. Billie Jean King, Mrs. Margaret Court and Kerry Melville.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If Mr. Peterson's mission was, as you have, I think, correctly deduced in a recent editorial, to make it clear to the Soviet Government that the chief political precondition to any major expansion of SovietAmerican trade and any major extension of U.S. credits to the Soviet Union is genuine Soviet aid in ending the Vietnam war, i.e., on the disingenuous terms proposed by President Nixon, which have been totally rejected by the. Government of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam and by the South Vietnamese National Liberation Front; it is not surprising that it has proved a failure.

title: REVENUE PLAN URGED BY PANEL OF MAYORS
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 6  Members of a bigcity mayors committee today urged Congress to approve pending revenuesharing legislation.

title: CHOU AND A THAI ARE SAID TO MEET
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 6China reported today that Premier Chou Enlai had talked with Thai official who is accompany ing a Thai table tennis team now visiting Peking.

title: I.M.F. DIRECTORS DIFFER ON REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The executive directors of the International Monetary Fund issued today a report on reform of the world monetary system containing numerous points of disagreement.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Addressograph Multigraph Corporation has promoted John C. Martin to executive vice president in charge of United States operations; William J. Ledbetter, executive vice president, administration and finance; and Timothy C. Cronin, executive vice president responsible for plans and administration and corporate staff functions.

title: 8 POLICE INDICTED IN ADDICT ARRESTS
description: Three detectives and five patrolmen have been indictedfor stealing money from addictswhile making narcotics arrests in the last two and a half years.District Attorney Burton B. Roberts of the Bronx announced yesterday.

title: Michael V. Rubino, ExBoxer Who Trained Youths Here
description: Michael V.Rubino, who lived for most of his 75 years in Greenwich Village, where he was a boxer, trainer and recreational director, died yesterday of a heart attack at St. Vincent's Hospital. His home was at 64 Bedford Street.

title: Common Cause Suit Asks Names of Donors to Nixon
Net Up Sharply at Utah International
Jersey Trooper Charged In Pedestrian's Death
description: WALL TOWNSHIP, N. J., Sept. 6 (AP)A state policeman was charged here today in a hitrun traffic death.

title: McGovern Asserts Nixon Is Neglecting Domestic Ills
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (Reuters)Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential candidate, accused the Nixon Administration today of neglecting problems at home for more glamorous, headlinemaking actions abroad.

title: Clearing Unit Joins Service
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the Midwest Stock Exchange Clearing Corporation had joined, the New York exchange's Central Certificate Service, where ownership of securities is transferred through bookkeeping entries and the physical movement of securities is eliminated.

title: Munich, 1972...
description: Are medals and commercial contracts more important than human lives? That question rises inevitably in the wake of the incomprehensible decision to continue the 1972 Olympic Games. The bodies of the eleven Israeli athletes and coaches killed by Arab terrorists were still unburied when the games resumed yesterday.

title: CHARLES S. ROSS
description: Charles S. Ross, motionpicture advertising manager for Variety, died Sunday in the Lenox Hill Hospital, following a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 39 years old and lived at 308 East 79th Street.

title: A BRITISH FRIGATE SAILSFOR ICELAND
description: LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP)The British frigate Aurora sailed for Icelandic waters today to back up the British fishing fleet in the dispute over Iceland's territorial limits.

title: Opponents of State Housing Plan Sound Off at Hearing in Bedford
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Sept. 6An angry demonstration against the Urban Development Corporation erupted here tonight as opponents of plans for. 200 lowincome and moderateincome apartments jammed a public hearing.

title: Jersey City Council Backs Study for New Waterfront
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 6 The City Council today approved a study of the city's waterfront by private developers, who will draft a master plan for a $2billion project with 20,000 units of housing and varied industry.

title: Rhode Island Schools Shut
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 6 (AP)  Teacher contract disputes in nine districts in the state kept 52,000 pupils out of school today.

title: U.S. Promoting Excursions Down on Farm
description: STROUD, Okla., Sept. 1Claud Earp squatted happily on the damp, manuresplotched bank of his farm pond, watching Mrs. Thelma Newnam and her married daughter pull little bluegill from the murky water.

title: Amnesty Group Accuses Brazil Of Torturing Political Prisoners
description: LONDON, Sept. 6The organization Amnesty International, in a report alleging torture of Brazilian political prisoners, has named more than 1,000 Brazilians it says were illtreated, and asserted it has names of 472 Brazilians responsible for their sufferings.

title: Ah, to Sleep In a Real Bed Of Fake Fish
description: Enter the willowy woman in the bodyclinging, pink wool dress. She strides right up to the 9footlong rhinoceros, pats its smooth skinned snoot and, with a toss of her blonde hair, announces:

title: Democrats Urge Legislation to Make President Disclose His TaxReform Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Senator Edward M. Kennedy and three other liberal Democrats proposed today legisla, tion that would force President Nixon to disclose his plans for tax reform before the election.

title: Warner Wins Court Order To Bar Waling of Old Film
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 (AP) Warner Brothers has won temporary restraining order preventing an eightyearold movie starring Mamie Van Doren from being redistributed as The Candidate, the title of a current Warner Brothers movie starring Robert Redford. Clinton Rodda, Superior Court Commissioner, issued the order against Maurice Duke and his Cosnat Productions of California and set Sept. 22 for a further hearing on the civil suit.

title: Soviet Cadets Visit Kings Point for First Time
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Sept. 6 Relations between the merchant marines of the United States and the Soviet Union took a turn for the better here today during the first visit of Soviet merchant marine cadets with their United States counterparts.

title: Regret on Resignations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) President Nixon accepted today with deep regret the resignations of Robert Cahn and Gordon J. MacDonald as members of the Council on Environmental Quality. The White House said their successors would be announced very soon.

title: U.S. Uses Taxes as a Weapon in Its War on Drugs
description: More than 866million in taxes and tax penalties have been assessed, against illegal drug traffickers in the last 14 months, Assistant Treasury Secretary Eugene T. Rossides announced yesterday.

title: Ricord. Brought to Jail Here
description: Auguste Joseph Ricord, charged with heading a massive heroin smuggling operation, was transferred yesterday from the Nassau County Jail to the Federal House of Detention on West Street in Manhattan. Nassau Sheriff Michael P. Seniuk had demanded that the prisoner be removed because he was a high security risk. Ricord had been brought here from Paraguay last Saturday after a long extradition fight. A bail hearing is scheduled later this week.

title: Most Arab Governments Keep Silent on Slayings
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 6 (Reuters)  A subdued Arab world today heard the news of the slayings at Munich with little public or official emotion. Most governments kept silent, and spokesmen of most of the main Palestinian guerrilla groups refused to comment on the deaths of 11 members of ?? Olympic team.

title: CONRAD B. LEWIS
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., Sept. 6Conrad B. Lewis, who retired in 1958 as assistant treasurer after 44 years with the Bankers Trust Company of New York, died yesterday at his home. He was 79 years old and lived at 406 Acacia Road.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Officials of the Borough of Edgewater, on the west bank of the Hudson River, reluctantly agreed yesterday furnish by next Wednesday an updated schedule for abatement of the borough's pollution of the river.

title: Firestone Tire President To Take Early Retirement
description: Robert D. Thomas,62 years old, president of the Firestone Tire & Rubber Company, is taking early retirement because of illness. Mr. Thomas has been with the company for 40 years and has been a member of the board since 1966 and president since 1970.

title: Denunciation on West Bank
description: JERUSALEM,. Sept. 6 (AP)The slaying of the Israeli athletes and coaches was condemned by Sheik Mohammed Ali Jaabari, Mayor of Hebron, on the West Bank of the Jordan River, and the town council. Israel occupied the Jordanian territory in the 1967 war.

title: TEACHER UNITS URGE WORK AGAINST NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) For the first time, the nation's 2.1 million elementary and high school teachers are being urged by their national organizations to take an active role in a Presidential electionto oppose President Nixon and donate funds to the campaign of Senator George McGovern.

title: Threat in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Sept. 6 (UPI)  A guerrilla radio station known as the Voice of the Palestinian Revolution tonight accused the Munich police of brutality and thirst for Palestinian blood, and said West German interests would become a principal target for future action.

title: Nixon Seeks Aid to Cubans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) President Nixon asked Congress today to shift $161million in Government funds to cover costs of transporting Cuban refugees to the United States. The funds would be transferred within the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and would involve no increase in the budget, the White House said.

title: Business Briefs
description: Net earnings of the trust departments of 10 large New York City banks declined 22.6 per cent in 1971, dropping to their lowest level since 1965, a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed yesterday.

title: Killings Expected to Spur Debate on Police Structure
description: BONN, Sept. 6Yesterday's violence in Munich is likely to increase Public pressure for basic reform of West Germany's decentralized police strueture.

title: DOUGLAS DOWNS, 51, N.B.C. CAMERAMAN
description: Douglas J. Downs, a news and documentary cameraman with the National Broadcasting Company, died in an accident on Tuesday while vacationing in Grenada, West Indies. He we 51 years old and lived at 1064 Hunter Avenue in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:As a grandmother, I would like to suggest that the defeat of Richard Nixon can come even more from the senior citizens of this country than the new eighteenyearold vote.

title: 48 PUBLISHERS FINED BY COURT IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 6The South Vietnamese Government announced today that a Saigon court had fined 48 newspaper and magazine publishers for violations of the press law.

title: BORROWING COSTS CLIMB FOR STATES
description: The late summer rise in interest rates has pushed up borrowing costs for cities and states to the highest level since the end of spring. The cost of shortterm funds for public housing hit the highest level since July, 1971. In the keystone financing of the taxexempt bond market this week, Connecticut yesterday sold $100million of bonds that underwriters subsequently priced to give in vestors the highest yields for such securities since midJune. Yields on these bonds were set to range from 3.10 per cent on those maturing next year to 5.10 per cent on those scheduled to come due in 1991 and 1992somewhat more generous yields than offered on other topquality state bonds earlier this summer.

title: COLORADO TO WEIGH DEATH PENALTY BILL
description: DENVER, Sept. 6. (UPI)The Colorado legislature will be presented with a bill that would require a mandatory death penalty in certain murder convictions, a state legislator said yesterday.

title: Market Place: Rays of Hope For Little Guy
description: Remember those dark days of yesteryear when small investors throughout the land suddenly discovered they were getting the cold shoulder in Wall Street?

title: STRIKES HAMPER SCHOOLS IN AREA
description: Scattered strikes marred reopening day for some suburban public schools yesterday.

title: RETAIL CHAINS LIST MORE AUGUST GAINS
description: Several more leading retail chains reported yesterday increased sales for August over the yearearlier levels.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I was amazed as well as appalled by District Attorney Hogan's statement criticizing the verdict of not guilty in the trial of the three inmates charged in the 1970 rebellion at the Tombs as a hideous miscarriage of justice!

title: Lawyer Arrested in Theft Of $10,000 in Art Prints
description: A 34yearold lawyer who two years ago was convicted of trying to sell personal letters of Mrs. Aristotle Onassis was arrested yesterday and charged with grand larceny in the theft of art prints from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: McGovern Bloc Merges With Regulars in Jersey
For City Schools, a Change From SoupandSandwich Lunches
description: Community School District No. stretches from Yorkville to the Battery. It includes all the public schools of east Midtown and Clinton and Chelsea and Chinatown. Its students are an incredibly diverse, polyglot and polyethnic population of 16,000. But what really sets them off from other youngsters getting ready to go back to school next week is that their district will soon be the first in the city to take over its own lunch program.

title: 50 PrimeTime C.B.S. Specials Will Run 70 Hours for 197273
description: A total of 50 primetime entertainment specials, adding up to more than 70 hours of television, will be presented on the Columbia Broadcasting System network during the 197273 season.

title: DUKE OF ALBA, HEAD OF SPANISH INSTITUTE
description: MADRID, Sept 6 (UPI)Don Luis Martinez de Irujo y Artazcoz, the Duke of Alba, died today in Houston, Tex., spokesman at his home said. He was 52 years old.

title: Court Actions Cite Turner In Mississippi and Georgia
description: JACKSON, Miss. Sept. 6 (UPI)Mississippi and Georgia took steps today to prevent Glenn W. Turner, the Florida millionaire from operating his Dare to Be Great corporation within their states.

title: Notes on People
description: New Zealand's Ambassador to Washington, Frank Corner, is returning to the Foreign Ministry in Wellington after 10 years of assignments in this country. Asked what impressions he was taking home with him, Mr. Corner said: The main thing I go back with now is a sense of the enormous creativity, adaptability and energy of Americans. At times I wondered if the United States was a country on the decline, but now, on balance, I think it is a country that is bursting into something new, rather noisily and argumentatively, but something new.

title: Satellite Is Gathering Data To Aid in Florida Planning
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 6 (AP)  An earth resources satellite began yesterday the first of three days of sweeps over Florida, gathering data 4aid urban and regional planning in the east central part of the state, including the impact of Walt Disney World.

title: ... Hijacking Uncurbed
description: A consummate example of the fuzzy governmental thinking that leaves ordinary people vulnerable to fanatic terror the world over is now unfolding at a seventeennation conference in Washington. Thanks to diplomatic footdragging by the Soviet Union and France, a joint United StatesCanadian proposal for establishing legal machinery to deal multilaterally with air hijackers is danger of disappearing into the morass of good ideas that might have been.

title: HAROLD RUBENSTEIN, B'NAI B'RITH LEADER
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Sept. 6Harold Rubenstein, president of Oberman Fabrics, Inc:, 469 Seventh Avenue, New York, died yesterday in South ShOre Hospital, Far, Rockaway, Queens. He was 63 years old and lived here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Faced with the coldblooded demagoguery and hypocrisy of this great President who is so confident, of his reelection, one is left with a sense of utter despair. Not only is he arrogantly claiming to be on God's side, but he is also exploiting, for his demagogic purposes, the deep anguish and suffering of a little Russian girl with shameless false sincerity. She was a beautiful child. Her name was Tanya. I read her diary. It tells the terrible story of war.... And finally, these were the last words in her diary: All are dead, only Tanya is left. Let us think of Tanya and of the other Tanyas and their brothers and sisters every. where in Russia and China and in America as we proudly meet our responsibilities for leadership in the world in a way worthy of a great people.

title: Limit Set on Legal Fees In Black Lung Miner Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) Fees for lawyers representing coal miners and survivors of miners disabled by black lung disease will be limited to no more than 25 per cent of the amount due in benefits under rules announced today by the Social Security Administration.

title: PUERTO RICO'S CHIEF BARS U.N. INQUIRIES
description: Gov. Luis A. Ferrd of Puerto Rico said yesterday that he would refuse to cooperate with any United Nations committee looking into the status of the island territory.

title: Economic Strength, But More Inflation, Foreseen for 1973
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 6 (UPI)  Leading business economists are looking forward to continued economic strength in 1973 but also predict no letup in inflation, a survey showed today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator McGovern's proposal to tax longterm capital gains in the value of stocks at the same rates as shortterm gains or earned income would be a serious blow to thousandi of senior citizens. To them, the tax credit allowed on stock held over six months is not a loophole, but a means of maintaining a decent living standard often not provided by Social Security and their private pension plans.

title: 8 Slain by Robbers On Virgin Islands
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, V. I., Sept. 6  Eight persons were slot to death and three others were injured when robbers invaded the clubhouse of a golf course in St. Croix today and opened fire in the pro shop and bar.

title: Report Accuses Mine of Laxity In West Virginia Dam Disaster
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Sept. 6A state investigatory commission accused the Pittston Company today of flagrant disregard for the people of Buffalo Creek, a narrow valley that was flooded after the callapse of a companyowned dam last Feb. 26.

title: Jersey Vote Officials Told To Register All Transients
description: TRENTON, Sept. 6  Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. told county election officials today that they must register all transients who desire to vote in the Nov. 7 election as long as they reside in a New Jersey municipality at the time they register.

title: Return Here Halted For Man Convicted In 70 Murder Plot
description: LONDON, Sept. 6 (AP)The British Government says it will give a man convicted of plotting to murder Chiang Kaishek's son a chance to contest his extradition to the United States.

title: Film Festival Will Include 21 New Productions
description: Films by Francois Truffaut, Robert Altman and Bob Raphelson are among the final programs announced yesterday for the 10th New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. The festival, which opens Sept. 29 with Eric Rohmer's Chloe in the Afternoon and closes Oct. 14 with Bernardo Bertolucci's Last Tango in Paris, with Marlon Brando, will include 21 films, all of them new. There are no retrospectives in the festival.

title: ALLENDE AND FOES AYOID OPEN CLASH
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 6President Salvador Allende Gossens and his major opponents, after three weeks of almost daily clashes in the streets, have backed away from kind of allout confrontation that they feared could lead civil war.

title: News of Olympic Drama: 22 Hours of Uncertainty
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 6 (AP)Uncertainty over what was: taking place persisted through the 22 hours of the Olympia tragedy.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)The Interstate Commerce Commission today denied a request by the nation's railroads to impose Interim Increases in protective service charges on the shipment of fresh and frozen commodities, effective Oct. 7.

title: A Robber Who Frightened Ailing Widow, 75, Is Found Guilty of Murder
description: A 21yearold robber was found guilty of murder here yesterday after the city's Chief Medical Examiner testified that the elderly victim, who had sufered from advanced heart disease, died because fright and exertion from the robbery hastened her death.

title: Many Events Are Planned Here For Mexico Week, Sept. 11 to 15
description: With a figurative tip of his sombrero, Mayor Lindsay proclaimed the period of Sept. 11 to 15 as Mexico Week in New York City.

title: Act Dishonors Our Time, Pope Says
description: From Castel Gandolfo, summer residence of Pope Paul VI, to Canberra, political and spiritual leaders used strong and direct language in expressing outrage, horror and revulsion at the events in Munich.

title: JapaneseIndonesian Talks
description: TOKYO, Sept. 6 (AP)Three Japanese trading companies are negotiating with P. N. Pertamina to supply a $130million oil refining plant to Indonesia, Mitsui & Co. said today.

title: RED REALITY WINS WITH TRACK MARY
description: Red Reality of the Cragwood Stable came along at, the last instant to register the triumph in the $28,650 Brighton Beach Handicap before 18,452 at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: TRIAL OF FRIEND OF GALLO BEGINS
description: The prosecutor at the first trial to result from the recent rash of gangland killings said yesterday that crime figures, their associates and others are reluctant to talk because they're afraid of being killed.

title: Iceland Rejects Protest
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 6 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Einar Agustsson of Iceland rejected tonight a British protest over the cutting of a British fishing boat's trawling lines saying that Iceland reserved the right to protect her new 50mile fishing limit. The minister was replying to a protest by the British Ambassador, John McKenzie.

title: Caltex Introduces Rig
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 6The search fiat oil in South Africa is being extended with the introduction of the Caltex Petroleum Corporation's offshore drilling rig, Sedco 135, for exploration near the Cape of Good Hope.

title: CORONA PROVIDES WRITING SAMPLES
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif. Sept. 6 (AP)  After two contempt citations, Juan V. Corona has bowed to prosecution demands, for samples of his handwriting. The way was thus cleared for his murder trial to begin Monday.

title: House Kills a Bill to Push Sales of Wheat Products
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI)1 The House today killed on a 235122 vote a bill to promote wheat products that critics said amounted to a bread tax on the consumer. The measure would have created a Wheat Industry Council to conduct a promotion and research program of wheat products, costing $2.6million the first year and climbing to $6million later to be paid for by farmers and wheat processors. Representative Leonor Sullivan, Democrat of Missouri, charged that the cost of the program would be passed on through higher prices to consumers.

title: NEW HEARINGS SET IN STIRLING HOMEX
description: Frank G. Raichle, trustee of the Stirling Homex Corporation, in bankruptcy, has obtained a court order in Rochester authorizing him to question former officers to determine what has become of funds and other material and records of the company.

title: Advertising: Youths Do TV Spots
description: At the request of Group W (Westinghouse Broadcasting Celhipany), four Massachusetts youngsters have each created animated TV spots that knock some major advertisers  candy, soft drinks, snack products and toys.

title: Auxiliary Bishop Is Named To Head Diocese of Buffalo
description: BUFFALO Sept. 6 (AP)The Most Rev. Bernard J. McLaughlin, an auxiliary bishop, will preside over the Roman Catholic Diocese of Buffalo until Pope Paul VI selects a new bishop.

title: Soviet Aide, in U.S., Sees Tool Trade Gains
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 6  The head of a 116man engineering team from the Soviet Union today described the Commerce Department's recent action in decontrolling 90 per cent of all machine tools from expert limitations as inevitable progress.

title: U.S. Moves for Campaign To Counter Political Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 6 The. United States embarked today on diplomatic efforts throughout the world and new security measures at home to try to curb international political terrorism following yesterday's killings of members of the Israeli Olympic team at Munich in the attack by Palestinian guerrillas.

title: Personal Finance: AirTrip Insurance
description: If you're planning to fly somewhere soon, you may be interested in buying airtrip insurance.

title: 2 MUSICALS SET THEIR PREMIERES
description: Two new Off Broadway musical ventures, Lady Audley's Secret and Smith, have been announced for presentation this season.

title: Hearings on Polls Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI)House Administration subcommittee will hold hearings later this month on the reliability and influence of public opinion polls, Representative Lucien N. Neclzi, Democrat of Michigan, announced today.

title: Southern Governors Elect Wallace as Chairman
BUSING CURB GOES ON SENATE AGENDA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Legislation designed to prevent longdistance busing for school desegregation officially went on the Senate calendar today, but there was no indication of when the measure would be called up for a vote or of how much support it would receive from the Nixon Administration.

title: DEATH OF INMATE LAID TO 3 IN JAIL
description: Three inmates of the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men were charged yesterday with the murder, of a fellow inmate who refused to participate in a boycott of courtroom appearances earlier this summer.

title: Thieu Foe in Exile Suggests New Regime
description: PARIS, Sept 6A former Saigon legislator who escaped after being sentenced to prison, said here today that antiThieugroups would form a nonCommunist provisional governmentif the United States withdrew support for President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: Paul Shoots a 77 to Pace U.S. Senior Golf Qualifiers
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 6James Paul of Piping Rock shot a sixoverpar 77 over his home course today to pace six qualifiers for the United States Golf Association senior amateur championship.

title: Mrs. Thorne Wed Upstate
description: KEENE VALLEY, N. Y., Sept. 6The marriage of Mrs. Helen Ellis Thorne of Hamden, Conn., and Keene Valley, widow of Dr. Lewis Thorne, to Charles Newton Prouty 3d, a widower, of Woodbridge, Conn., took place here today. The Rev. Van Santvoord MerleSmith Jr. performed the ceremony in the Congregational Church.

title: Sergeant Says 200 Men Helped Falsify Bomb Data
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept: 6A Young Air Force sergeant who first reported the unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam took issue today with the Air Force contention that Gen. John D. Lavelle acted alone and said more than 200 Men were involved in falsely reporting the raids.

title: Year'sPay Benefit Backed For Transit Police Widows
White House Tied to Arms Pact Delay
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Senator Mike Mansfield, the majority leader, accused the White House today of contributing to the Senate's delay in approving the interim agreement with the Soviet Union freezing offensive nuclear weapons.

title: NIXON SEEKS TO CUT PENSION PROPOSALS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  The Nixon Administration has asked the Senate Finance Committee to drop several Social Security benefits from its welfare reform bill; the committee chairman, Russell B. Long, DemoCrat of Louisiana, reported today.

title: Rock Colors Sound of Portrayal, a Jazz Quintet
description: A new quintet that is basically, jazz but with some of the rock coloration that is almost inevitable in the playing of young musicians today made its debut Tuesday night at the Clark Center for the Performing Arts in the West Side Y.W.C.A., 840 Eighth Avenue. The group, which is called Portrayal, is a tightlyknit ensemble that wanders in and out of several jazz influences but has not yet found its own identity.

title: HODGSON SCRAPS STATE LABOR TALK
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 6The. New York State A.F.L.C.I.O. preserved its neutral posture in the Presidential election campaign today after Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson scrapped a strongly partisan proNixon speech that might have precipitated an explosive reaction from supporters of Senator George McGovern.

title: Comment by Arafat
description: BEIRUT, Sept. 6 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Palestinian resistance leader, Yasir Arafat, declared today that Palestinian fighters have taken up arms to defend their civilization, their culture and their landnot to cause bloodshed.

title: A SOVIET DEBATE ON ECONOMY SEEN
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 6  Western diplomats, assessing the economic and political impact of this year's poor Soviet harvest, believe that the Soviet leadership may have to trim back its fiveyear economic plan at meetings later his month because of heavy hard currency expenditures for foreign grain.

title: Yield, Volume Increase At Auction by Fanny May
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (Reuters)Average yield and volume increased at the Federal National Mortgage Association's auction today of fourmonth commitments for Governmentbacked mortgages.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The President stresses the point that he is getting us out of Vietnam. From Pearl Harbor to VJ Day, the United States fought and won World War II. That took three years, eight months, and one week. Mr. Nixon has been President for three years, seven months, and one week. The Nixon disengagement has taken over 20,000 American lives and tens of billions of dollars.

title: Munich's Chief Is a LawandOrder Man
description: BONN, Sept. 6Dr. Manfred Schreiber, Munich's police chief who led the police last night as they tried to cope with the events that finally led to the deaths of nine Israeli hostages and four Arab terrorists, took office in 1963 with a firm resolution to play it cool. Nevertheless, he has reacted to rapidly rising crime rate with increasing toughness.

title: McGovern Aide Calls Nixon Era Worst Crime Years in History
Illinois Ballot Ban Upheld
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 6 (UPI)  The Illinois electoral board voted without dissent to bar Communist party and Socialist Worker party candidates from the ballot in November. The board upheld objections raised last month when the parties, backed by a Federal judge, filed nominating petitions without signing an antiCommunist loyalty oath re. quired by state law.

title: Bridge: With Great Hand, He Can't Believe He Blew the Etc....
description: Since the riverboat victims of whist sharpers in the last century there have been no more disappointed and incredulous cardplayers than a small group at the Westchester Bridge Center in White Plains. They had held the West hand in a recent duplicate game, with 31 highcard points and 12 very probable tricks. This was not too dissimilar from the Mississippi heart hand, on which the victims usually held something like:

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The HewlettPackard Company announced yesterday it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed secondary offering of 297,000 shares of common stock, all of it being sold by selling shareholders who are beneficiaries of gifts by Mr. and Mrs. David Packard and the W. R. Hewlett Foundation. White, Weld & Co. will head an underwriting group handling the public sale. The company's stock was down 2 at 67 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator McGovern is undoubtedly an idealistic man and I wonder if that isn't his personal albatross. Tax incentives are a reasonably efficient means of persuading less idealistic people to do worthwhile things, such as ,build housing or search for energy sources or invest in jobproducing new enterprises. Perhaps, cynically, I feel that the possibility of making money is a stronger lure for doing good than all the appeals to conscience which have ever been made. The record suggests that faith doesn't really move very many mountains.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the. Editor: It is high time that the now infamous and, much overworked Watergate Caper were put into proper perspective as a potential campaign issue. It is alleged that this abortive and bungled political spying foray into Democratic National Committee headquarters was planned by some faction of the opposition party.

title: Personalities at Olympics: Carlos Challenges Borzov
description: Those American sprinters, past and present, can't stop talking. about Valery Borzov, the Ukrainian who won gold medals in the 100meter and 200meter dashes at Munich.

title: Dorothy Day's. Group Wins U. S. Tax Exemption
description: Dorothy Day and her Catholic Worker movement have won a $296,359 tax battle with the Federal Government.

title: OILFIELD IS FOUND OFFSHORENORWAY
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 6 (UPI)An AmericanEuropean consortium has discovered a new oilfield in Norwegian waters, Petrofina, the Belgian oil company, announced today.

title: MinorityHiring Dispute Perils Newark Airport Terminal Job
description: The Port Authority said yesterday it would suspend all construction work on a new terminal at Newark Airport, effective next Monday unless several nonunion black workers were hired by the Iron Workers Union as trainees.

title: LOST REMBRANDT BAFFLES SLEUTHS; Where Can You Co With It? Is Question in Montreal
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 6  Detective Sgt. Gerald Viau received 30 telephone calls this morning from Canadian and American police officials offering help in a painstaking search he is conducting. What he is looking for is a Rembrandt.

title: Firemen Draw Line on Job
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 (UPI)Six more firemen who refused to wash windows at their stationhouse have been suspended. Eight others, all members of Engine Company 33, were suspended for two days last Friday for the same reason. The firemen contend that washing windows goes beyond their duties.

title: CAR SALES SOARED AT END OF AUGUST
description: DETROIT, Sept. 6Sales United States car producers the final third of August set record for that period, and sales in thee full month were the highest for any August since 1955.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  The Communications Satellite Corporation and the MCI Lockheed Satellite Corporation announced today they have signed a memorandum of understanding looking toward a jointlyowned, mutipurpose domestic satellite system.

title: Civil Liberties Unit Scores City's Drive On Times Sq. Films
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union yesterday denounced Mayor Lindsay's campaign against Times Square movie houses that show allegedly obscene films as a flagrant vioation of the Constitution and an outrageous waste of police and judicial resources.

title: Protocol Aide Promoted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) President Nixon announced today that he would nominate Marion H. Smoak, Deputy Chief of Protocol, to the personal rank of Ambassador. Mr. Smoak, 56 years old, a former South Carolina legislator, has been Deputy Protocol Chief since March, 1970. He has been serving as acting chief since the resignation on June 30 of Emil Mosbacher Jr.

title: JANE GRIFFIN DEAD; AIDED SCHOOLBOUND
description: Jana Griffin, an educational counse??, died Tuesday at the Neurological Institute of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 75 years old and lived at 1000 Park Avenue.

title: Moscow Police Seize 30 At the Lebanese Embassy
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 6  The Moscow police detained about about 30 persons today, most of them militant Jews, who tried to demonstrate outside the Lebanese Embassy over the slaying of Israeli athletes by Arab guerrillas near Munich.

title: SOVIET WHEAT SALE FACES G.A.O. INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The General Accounting Office said tonight that it had agreed to investigate questions of profiteering raised by a Delaware Congressman in the big United StatesSoviet wheat deal.

title: McGovern Blames Egypt. and Lebanon in Slayings
Arthur Hill, Former Chairman Of Resources Board, Is Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Arthur M. Hill, former chairman of the executive board of the Greyhound Corporation, who was chairman of the National Security Resources Board in the late 1940's, died yesterday at Clifton Forge, Va. He was 80 years old.

title: Regents'
description: Stressing the need for coordinating all of New York State's postsecondaryschool educational resources, the Board of Regents released a development plan yesterday that for the first time spells out the roles of private colleges and universities and trade, business and other proprietary schools.

title: Kansas City Janitors Strike
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept6 (UPI)A strike by 680 maintenance men, janitors and truck drivers has forced the closing of Kansas City schools for the rest of the week, the school board said today.

title: Philadelphia Delays Opening of Schools As Teachers Strike
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP)  The opening of Philadelphia's 280 strikebound public schools was pushed back indefinitely today, leaving 285,000 children to learn on their own.

title: Party for London School of Economics Benefits Institution's Own Economics
description: A millionaire once asked Beatrice Webb, cofounder of the London School of Economics, how he could best put his riches to work for mankind.

title: TV: Real World Proves to Be Curiously Elusive
description: During a special daytime report Tuesday on the tragedy unfolding in Munich. the American Broadcasting Company switched from the Olympic Village site of Israeli hostages and Arab terrorists to the closing moments of a volleyball game. As the television picture returned quickly to Olympic Village, Jim McKay, A.B.C. sports announcer, observed that it was returning back to the real world.

title: FRED DOOLITTLE, 62, OF CEMENT CONCERN
description: Fred L. Doolittle, former president and chief executive officer of the PennDixie Cement Corporation, died yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he lived. He was 62 years old and had a summer home at Laconia, N. H.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange issued this week its latest report on trading by directors, officers and major stockholders of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange made no such report available this week.

title: DONALD M'LEAN
description: MONTAUK, L. I., Sept. 7Donald McLean, who retired in 1965 as a purchasing agent for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., after 37 years with the company, died today of a heart attack at his summer home here. He was 72 years old.

title: Executive Changes
description: Richard A. Riley, 56 years old, has been elected president of the Firestone Tire & Rubber Company. He succeeds Robert D. Thomas, 62, who has retired because of illness. Associated with the company for 33 years, Mr. Riley had been executive vice president since February, 1971, and a member of the board since January, 1970. During his career he has been in sales manufacturing and financial management positions in five Firestone divisions, including the presidency of four. He was named a vice president of the parent company in 1968. Raymond C. Firestone, and chief executive officer, said that an internal realignment of executive responsibilities would make it unnecessary to fill Mr. Riley's previous post as an executive vice president. There are three other Firestone executive vice presidnts.

title: AN EXTENSION SET ON REGISTRATION
description: A threejudge Federal Court yesterday extended central voter registration in New York State to Sept. 23 and ruled unconstitutional a provision of the State Election law that terminated such registration earlier.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Matthews Wins in 400; Munich Fans Boo Him
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 7Vince Matthews, who climbed 10foot fences in Brooklyn after work to train for the Olympics, stepped down from the victory platform to a chorus of boos and whistles tonight after a goldmedal performance in the 400meter run.

title: Harrisburg Vengeance
description: In the incredible saga of the Federal Government's abortive case against the Harrisburg Seven, once again the quality of mercynot to mention justicehas been badly strained. Father Philip Berrigan has been sentenced to two years in jail and Sister Elizabeth McAlister to a year and a day for smuggling letters in and out of a Federal penitentiary. What makes this cruel sentence of the Catholic antiwar activists amount to political harassment is that they are being punished for an act committed in 1970 that would no longer be illegal if it were committed today. Even in 1970 the law then making such letters a technical violation was widely disregarded without official rebuke.

title: Personalities: A Chin Is Exposed
description: Curtis Cokes of Dallas, the former world welterweight boxing champion, will be working without his goatee and his regular manager, Charlie Dietz, when he fights Elijah (Tap Tap) Makathini in Durban, South Africa, tomorrow night. Cokes must shave off his goatee to conform with South African boxing rules. Dietz will not be allowed to work in Cokes's corner because of the country's apartheid laws, which forbid a white man to act as a second for a black boxer.

title: ShortTerm Rates Show More Stability
description: Shortterm interest rates made a stab at stabilizing yesterday. The Federal Reserve did not intervene in the money market to push rates higher, although Federal funds traded well below 5 per cent. Since midAugust, the central bank's money managers have come into the market virtually every day. to sell Treasury bills or to absorb reserves from the banking system through matched salepurchase transactions. Both actions tend to make Treasury bill rates rise.

title: Mariner 9 Chief Honored
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 7 UPI)Dan Schneiderman, manager of the Mariner 9 project. which orbited a spacecraft around Mars, was presented with the highest award of the space agency today. Mr. Schneiderman was cited for leadership of a team that achieved all objectives of the most scientifically productive mission to Mars. The Mariner 9 spacecraft, launched May 30, 1971, went into orbit around Mars last Nov. 13 and has photographed the entire planet. It still continues to gather scientific data.

title: McGovern Aide Quits in a Rift Over Voter Registration Drive
Mrs. Christie Wins Trophy In MatchPlay Against Par
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 7Mrs. Robert E. Christie of Winged Foot won the Jane Robbins Memorial Trophy today by finishing 3 up on par at the Country Club of New Canaan in the annual match playagainstpir tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association.

title: U.S. Trade Envoy in Eonn
description: BONN, Sept. 7 (UPI)President Nixon's special trade envoy, William Eberle, today discussed problems connected with an expansion of world trade with West German Government officials, a BOnn spokesman said.

title: Williams Proposes Plan For Wall Street Reforms
description: The broad outline of a major legislative reform for Wall Street was unfolded here yesterday by Senator Harrison.A. Williams, chairman of the Senate Securities subcommittee, who characterized his proposals as harsh.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Bank lending to consumers under bank credit card plans is continuing to rise but the rate of growth has slowed, a member of the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: 1,500,000Share Offer Set By General Public Utilities
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation plans to issue 1,500,000 common shares later this year.

title: Festivities Mark Brazil's 150 Years Of Independence
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil Sept. 7 (AP)he world's fifth largest nationonce known as Latin America's sleeping giantcelebrated 150 years of independence from Portuguese colonial rule today with ceremonies and expressions of hope that a prosperous future finally is drawing near.

title: MRS. CHARLES DIBNER
description: Mrs. Anna Schwam Dibner, widow of Charles W. Dibner, a Brooklyn builder, and mother of Martin Dibner, a novelist, died Tuesday at the Jewish Home for the Aged in Portland, Me. Her age was 86.

title: Dakotan Says Nixon Seeks To Downgrade the Farmer
U.S. NOT CONSULTED ON SAIGON ELECTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The State Department said today that the United States had been neither consulted nor informed by South Vietnam of its decision to abolish popular elections for officials in countryside hamlets.

title: Its Hors d'Oeuvres Rate With the Best
description: Le Madrigal, 216

title: Harvard Study Disputes Impact Of Schooling on Future Income
description: Contrary to popular wisdom, efforts to provide better schooling for poor children would have surprisingly little effect on their prospects for economic success as adults even if such efforts were successful, Christopher Jencks of Harvard University said here yesterday.

title: Palestinians Said to Plot Spectacular Act in the U.S.
description: Charles Collingwood, the television news commentator for the Columbia Broadcasting System, reported last night that he had been warned by a reliable Palestinian that other Palestinians were plotting some spectacular act of kidnapping or bombing against prominent American Jews and/or businesses.

title: Witter Is Ordered To Drop Seminar On Tax Shelters
description: Dean Witter & Co., Inc., the investment banking house, was ordered here yesterday to cancel a seminar it had planned to conduct on taxsheltered investments.

title: Roundup: Carlton Subdues. Cards for 23d Victory
description: Steve Carlton, who has known the tension and the glory of World Series competition, has had to provide his own star status this season with the futile Philadelphia Phillies.

title: CITY YOUTH PAYROLL PUT AT $1.6.7MILLION
description: A total of $16,785,000 in wages was paid to about 56,000 boys and girls who participated in New York City's Neighborhood Youth Corps summer job program, Industrial Commissioner Louis L. Levine said yesterday.

title: Tropical Storm Dawn Becomes a Hurricane
description: MIAMI, Sept. 7 (AP)The tropical storm known. as Dawn became a hurricane tonight as it mustered 80mileanhour winds in the Atlantic Ocean about 250 miles east of Cape Hatteras, N. C.

title: Arms Talks, Recess in Geneva Without Progress
description: GENEVA, Sept. 7The 25na tion disarmament conference today ended its sessions for this year with no progress to report on its search for, agreements to scrap chemical weapons and to ban all testing of nuclear armaments.

title: AUSTRALIA BAGS TWO LARGE TUNA
description: YARMOUTH, Nova Scotia, Sept. 7Well aware that tales about fish that get away are all too common among anglers, Australia's tuna, team made doubly sure it had a success story to tell today by capturing two giant bluefins after watching one escape.

title: CHARLES P. BERDELL JR.
description: Charles P. Berdell Jr., a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday at his home, 137 East 66th Street, after a long illness. His age was 86.

title: WEAYER, ON A 65, LEADS BY STROKE
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 7 (AP)DeWitt Weaver, playing despite an infected left ear, carded a 65 today and took the firstround lead in the $100,000 Southern, open golf tournament.

title: Safety Board Presses for Rules On Vehicles Used in Recreation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The National Transportation Safety Board is pressing other Federal agencies to identify and reduce hazards in what it calls the explosively growing use of recreational vehicles.

title: Not Reprisal, Israel Says
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 7  Israeli military sources said today that the Israeli patrol action in Lebanon was in no way a reprisal for the Munich shootings.

title: POLICEMAN CIRCLED BY 250 IN ARRESTS
description: BABYLON, L.I.,Sept. 7 (UPI) An angry crowd of about 250 youths surrounded and assaulted a Suffolk County patrolman as he attempted to arrest two youths on drug charges at a park here last night, the police said.

title: Bicentennial Group Accused by Rivals Of a Political Role
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The American Revolutionary Bicentennial Commission was accused of political and commercial impropriety today by a counter group offering alternative commemorative programs to mark the nation's forthcoming 200th anniversary.

title: HOUSE PANEL PLANS GRAIN DEAL HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) A Congressional subcommittee plans to investigate how the Nixon Administration dealt with the private grain trade in negotiating the multimilliondollar United StatesSoviet wheat deal.

title: Mexico Eliminates Canada In Soccer Preliminaries
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 7 (AP) Canada has been eliminated from the 1974 soccer World Cup after losing, 21, to Mexico last night.

title: Olympic Personalities: Golden Future
description: Mark Spitz's seven Olympic gold medals will be worth $5million to him. Sherm Chavoor, Spitz's coach, said on the West. Coast yesterday.

title: Israel Honors Her Dead At Tel Aviv Airport Rite
description: LYDDA, Israel, Sept. 7Ten of the slain members Israel's Olympic delegation came home today, their coffins met by a cortege of army command cars. All but one the victims of the battle with Arab terrorists in Munich were honored at a formal state funeral under a broiling sun at the Tel Aviv airport. It was an emotional and, at moments, even angry ceremony that typified the reaction in this country to the Munich shootings.

title: 3 Lawyers Seek Grand Jury Study Of Hogan's Malice
description: A group of three lawyers) called yesterday for a special, grand jury to investigate District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's qualifications for office in light of what they called his recent incredible and outrageous attack on the jury system.

title: Envoy to E.E.C. Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) The White House announced today that President Nixon had accepted the resignation of J. Robert Schaetzel as United States.Ambassador to the European Common Market. The brief announcement did not give a reason for Mr. Schaetzel's resignation, from the post, he has held since 1966 but said it would be effective upon a date to be determined.

title: BIack Switohes G.0.P.
description: BOSTON, Sept. 7 (AP)Jack E. Aobinson, president of the Boston chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, announced today that he was switching from the Democratic to the Republican party. Outlining his reasons, Mr. Robinson mentioned Senator Edward W. Brooke. We have the only black Senator in the country, and he's a Republican, Mr. Robinson said.

title: Washirigton: For the Record
description: Activities. President Nixon met with Republican Congiessional leaders and with police association representatives. He received diplomatic credentials from several new Ambassadors. He also met with. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz.

title: GUNMEN HUNTED IN VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: ST. CROIX, V. I., Sept. 7The largest manhunt in the history of the Virgin Islands today combed the brushcovered hills surrounding the Fountain Valley Golf Club where gunmen shot eight persons to death yesterday on a terrace overlooking the fairways.

title: STRICT NOISE LAW PREDICTEDIN CITY
description: Theodore S. Weiss, chairman of the City Council's Committee on Environmental Protection, predicted yesterday that the Council would pass the most comprehensive and advanced noisecontrol legislation in the country next Tuesday.

title: MONTREAL WEIGHS ITS 76 OLYMPICS
