description: MONTREAL, Sept. 7 (UPI) Security will be tight when the Summer Olympics are held here in 1976. but Montreal hopes to avoid the image of the army, Mayor Jean Drapeau said last night.

title: Military Medical Academy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP)  An armed forces medical academy and a scholarship program to train military doctors were approved by Congress today. The House completed action by approving a bill for the two programs, 309 to 13, and the legislation went to President Nixon.

title: Reserve Proposes Simplified Deals For Eurodollars
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The Federal Reserve Board proposed today to simplify its system of reserve requirements against bank borrowing of Eurodollars.

title: Aftermath of Munich
description: At the most poignant moment of Israel's grief, facing the flagshrouded coffins of its dead Olympic athletes, Deputy Premier Yigal Allon showed courage in cautioning his outraged countrymen that the crimes of extremists do not warrant extremist reprisals. Denouncing the terrorists of Munich as an untouchable sect, Mr. Allon declared, I am happy to say that most Arabs are not like that.

title: 5 Firemen Taken to Hospital Following a Brooklyn Blaze
description: Five firemen were treated for smoke inhalation at Brooklyn Hospital yesterday after fighting a twoalarm blaze that heavily damaged a twostory frame building in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, fire officials reported.

title: Edward R. Murkland. 53, IndustrialFilms Writer
description: ROXBURY, Conn., Sept. 7Edward R. Murkland, a writer of industrial and educational films, died of cancer in Waterbury Hospital Sunday. He was 53 years old and lived here.

title: CONCERT BY PRESLEY TO BE SHOWN ON N.B.C.
description: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that the 102 hours of special primetime prOgrams it will televise this season would include a 90minute concert by Elvis Presley, the singer, his first TV appearance since 1968.

title: ARTHUR TOBOLSKY, CHEMIST, WAS 53
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 7 Dr. Arthur Victor Tobolsky, an authority on rubber research and a member of the Princeton University faculty, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage in St. Luke's Hospital, Utica, N. Y while attending a conference at Raquette Lake, N. Y. He was 53 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor,
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR POWER UNIT IN VERMONT BACKED
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. (AP)  The Atomic Energy Commission has cleared the Federal path for operation of the Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power Corporation's generating station at Vernon.

title: LEBANON IS RAIDED BY ISRAELI PATROL
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 7An Israeli armored patrol supported by helicopters struck across the Lebanese border today in search of Arab commandos.

title: Balanced Justice
description: With Governor Rockefeller showing no eagerness to act on the Knapp Commission's call for a special superprosecutor to root out official corruption, it is encouraging to see some signs of intensified cleanup activity among the city's regular prosecutors.

title: Notes on People
description: Bobby Fischer sent Boris Spassky a friendly letter and a gift camera as the defeated Soviet chess master prepared to check out of his hotel in Reykjavik, Iceland. For his part, Mr. Spassky got these remarks off his chest Fischer is a man of art, but he is a rare human being in the everyday life of this century. I like Fischer and I think that I understand him.

title: LIBRARY OFFERED $750,000 BY U.S.
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities, which last year gave a matching grant of $500,000 to the New York Public Library for its deficitplagued research libraries, offered $750,000 yesterday for the coming year.

title: MIDEAST EVENTS DEFLATE STOCKS
description: Investors seemed reluctant to make commitments yesterday because of developments in the Middle East as the stock market registered its third consecutive decline in dull trading.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RED SOX WIN, 104, FROM YANKEES; TAKE LEAD IN EAST
Digest Making Movies Fit for Its Readers
description: HOLLYWOODAre dirty movies on the way out? The Reader's Digest, which asked this question a few months ago, has decided to give sex and violence films a push out the studio door by making family movies that reflect a wholesome American life instead of la dolce vita.

title: Kissinger Off Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's nationalsecurity adviser, will fly to Munich on Saturday, a day later than previously scheduled, and will meet with West German leaders over the weekend before traveling to Moscow for three clays of discussions there.

title: Court Rejects Nader's Request on I.T.T.
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 7 (AP)A Federal Court judge today retused a request by Ralph Nader to open the case against the completed merger of the Hartford Fire Insurance Corn pany and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: 60 Tennis Pros Unite With Kramer as Head
description: Jack Kramer was named yesterday executive director of a new organization of tennis pros.

title: WEST SIDE GIRL, 11, IS SLAIN IN HOME
description: An 11yearold girl who had been left home alone by her working parents was found dead in her apartment on Riverside Drive at 152d Street yesterday, the apparent victim of a strangler.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: De Mont Has Medal; Ruling to Be Reviewed
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 7 (AP)The American swimmer, Rick De Mont, flew home today, presumably with the gold medal he won in Olympic swimming, while the International Olympic Committee prepared to take an other look at its decision that he must give it back.

title: FUTURES PRICES END IRREGULARLY
description: A rally in, the afternoon sent soybean, corn and wheat futures prices up yesterday after a dismal opening on the Chicago Board of Trade; The net result was that they closed on anirregular tone.

title: J. GRANT TYLER
description: ST. THOMAS, V. I., Sept. 7J. Grant Tyler, a former New York advertising executive, died of complications following surgery on Friday. He was 43 years old and had lived here since 1969.

title: Six Arab Countries Remain in the Games
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 7 (AP)Athletes from six Arab countries competed in the Olympics today after three other Arab teams withdrew in the wake of the Arab terrorist attack on Israel's team Tuesday.

title: Supply of Money Showed Advance In the Latest Week
description: A wild and woolly week in the money markets produced a marked acceleration in monetary expansion, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: City Is Widening Its Help To Many Ethnic Groups
description: The city's manpower agency has been striving to reach ethnic group in the city other than black and Puerto. Rican, both to help their poor and to gain their communities support for antipoverty programs.

title: RUEFELD ORDERS BEEF PRICE WATCH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) The Cost of Living Council ordered today a close watch on retail meat prices in chain food stores and urged the Price Commission to consider tighter moves to bring retail prices down faster after wholesale prices decline.

title: 2 Polluters Assail Lag in Plan For a Regional Sewage System
description: NEWARK, Sept. 7Two ac knowledged polluters of the waters of New York Harbor the Jersey City Sewage Au thority and the Town of Kearny insisted today that their anti pollution efforts were being for by the lagging plan for a regional sewer system in Hudson County.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON SCHOOL PACT, AVERTING A STRIKE;Monserrat Says the Value of Increases Is $300Million and Within 5.5% Limits
description: The Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers announced agreement last night on a new threeyear contract, averting a citywide school strike threatened for Monday, the opening day of the fall term.

title: Expos'
description: Far from the peak they reached three months ago, and disappearing fast, the New York Mets lost their third straight game last night when they were stopped by the Montreal Expos, 40.

title: Business Briefs
description: The National Steel Corporation said in Pittsburgh yesterday that it had ordered a fully continuous fivestand tandem rolling mill for its Weirton Steel division that the company said would provide distinctly greater productivity in the cold reduction of thin steel sheet coils.

title: N.A.A.C.P. SEES END OF JOB RIGHTS PLAN
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that despite denials by the Department of Labor, the Nixon Administration has for all practical purposes ended the daytoday administrative enforcement of the Philadelphia Plan.

title: BROOKLYN DIOCESE MAY FACE STRIKE
description: Edward Corcoran, president of the Lay Faculty Association of the Brooklyn Diocese, said yesterday that his union might strike the 12 diocesan high schools in Brooklyn and Queens next Monday if current contract negotiations failed to settle problems of job security, layoffs and due process.

title: CHARLES H. DODSON
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Sept, 7Charles H. Dodson, who retired in 1970 as vice president of Texaco's Midwest operations, died of emphysema today at his home here. He was 67 years old and also lived in Evanston, Ill.

title: Queens Woman, 86, Is Slain
description: An 86yearold South Jamaica, Queens, woman was found strangled to death early yesterday morning in her bedroom in a twostory rooming (house she owned at 10731 171st Street. The police said that the body of the woman, Edith Chandler, was found by roomer who was returning after midnight.

title: Birtha, New Group, Rocking the Cradle Of Musical Myths
description: Allwoman rock groups have not had an easy time of it in the pop world. Sexism of the sort that would have ? believe, for example, that women just can't play good lead guitar, or women aren't strong enough to play rock drums, has built an extremely impenetrable wall of music prejudice.

title: Bid Is Made to E.E.C. Members
description: BONN, Sept. 7West Germany asked today its partner countries in the European Economic Community to recall funds they had invested in the socalled international Eurodollar market. The appeal is contained in a list of antiinflationary measures that the Bonn Government proposed to its Common Market partners in advance of next week's meeting in Rome of the community's foreign and finance ministers. The meeting is to prepare a summit conference of Common Market government chiefs in Paris next month. The other Common Market members are Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands.

title: ORIOLES WIN, 90, DROP TIGERS TO 2D
description: BALTIMORE Sept: 7Few funs show up for Baltimore baseball games these days, but those who do are learning to arrive in time to watch the frSt inning, lest they miss the best part.

title: 2 Aides Say Nixon Pledges Not to Ask for a Tax Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 President Nixon, through two subordinates, promised today not to ask for any Federal tax's increase for the rest of his Administration, whether that turns out to be five months or four and a half years. ,

title: Lockheed Loan Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) The EmergencY Loan Act passed last year by Congress to rescue the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has succeeded in preventing a financial collapse of the company and enabled it to begin delivering its first Tristar jetliners, the Government said today.

title: U.S. OLYMPIANS GLAD THAT GAMES WENT ON
description: The first contingent of American athletes and officials re awned here from the Olympic Gaines yesterday, shocked by the deaths of 11 athletes and coaches from Israel, but pleased for the, most part that the games had continued.

title: Munich Police Ordered 5 To Ambush 8 Terrorists
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 7  The Munich police, strongly defending their unsuccessful attempt to rescue nine Israeli hostages from eight Arab terrorists Tuesday night, reported today that five sharpshooters had beep assigned to the task.

title: Murphy Names Civilian As Personnel Director
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday the appointment of Seymour Bernstein as director of police personnel.

title: 2 Civilians Killed in Clahes in Belfast
Metropolitan Briefs
description: The captain of the New York Knicks basketball team, Willis Reed, was found not guilty yesterday in Queens. Criminal Court of four chargesreckless endangerment, harassment, menacing and a traffic violation. The charges stemmed from an altercation between Mr. Reed and an offduty patrolman, Joseph Guarino, last July 20 on street in Rego Park, Queens, along which both men had been driving.

title: Death Penalty. Backed In California, 66241
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 (AP)  Californians favor retention of the death penalty by 66 to 24 per centthe biggest margin in 16 years it has conducted public opinion polls on the issue, the California Poll said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mills Sees Weakness In McGovern Staff And Urges Changes
description: Representative Wilbur D. Mills, the Arkansas Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said last night that he was quite disturbed over some staff weaknesses in the Presidential campaign organization of Senator George McGovern.

title: 25 U.S. GENERALS TOLD TO RETIRE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The Army moved today to. open its top posts to younger men by notifying 25 generals that they must resign short of the normal retirement time.

title: LowIncome Units Get First Tenants
description: Symbolic gold keys and pieces of a welcome cake were handed out yesterday to tenants moving into a new lowincome public housing tower in the central Bronx.

title: MODERN SCREENING KING VIDOR'S FILMS
description: The film director King Vidor, whose career spans most of the history of American sound and silent cinema, is the subject of a, current retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. The retrospective, which runs through Nov. 13, includes 38 films, from The Jacknife Man (1920) through Solomon and Sheba (1959), Mr. Vidor's last major commercial work, and Truth and Illusions, a personal film made in 16 mm. in 1964.

title: Dean Who Was Shot by Student Returns to Duties at Columbia
description: Six weeks after he was shot six times by a disgruntled student, Columbia College's dean of students, Henry S. Coleman, was back at his desk yesterday as classes resulned at Columbia University.

title: Hoff a Plans a Hanoi Trip; U.S. Later Cancels Permit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7James R. Hoffa, the former president of the teamsters union, planned to leave tonight for Hanoi to try to bring about the release of American prisoners of war, but he canceled the trip, at least temporarily, this morning.

title: Nixon Campaign, Minus Nixon, Spends a Day Here
4 ANTIWAR G.I.'S FREED IN FLORIDA
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. Four antiwar veterans, jailed last month for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury, were released on their own recognizance today.

title: Red Smith
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 7This time surely, some thought, they would cover the sandbox and put the blocks aside. But no. The Games must go on, said Avery Brundage, high priest of the playground, and 80,000 listeners burst into applause. The occasion was yesterday's memorial service for 11 members of Israel's Olympic delegation murdered by Palestinian terrorists. It was more like a pep rally.

title: Advertising:
description: The creators of the best graphics in 1971 were honored last night by the Art Directors Club at a dinner in the Plaza Hotel.

title: Cairo Says Bonn Seeks To Evade Responsibility
description: CAIRO, Sept. 7The Egyptian Government accused West. Germany today of trying to evade responsibility for the killing of nine Israeli hostages and five Palestinian guerrillas by making false charges against Egypt and other Arab countries.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: N.B.A.A.B.A. BILL RECEIVES BACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Al bill that would permit the National and American Basketball Associations to mergebut only at the expense of giving up the reserve clausewas passed today by a Senate subcommittee, and may be enacted into law before this session of Congress ends.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Retail sales in July were up 2 per cent from June and were 11 per cent above a year earlier, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Enemy Troops Reported Holding Most of Key Town Near Danang
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 8North Vietnamese troops have reportedly taken control of most of the key district town of Tienphuoc in Quangtin Province about 35 miles south of Danang.

title: U.S. Reports One Killed In the War During Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 7 (UPI)One American was killed in action last week, the lowest death toll since single United States soldier died in the week ended last Christmas, the United States command said today.

title: Letters to the Editor,
description: To the Editor: Now that Mr. McGovern has laid his forwardlooking economic program on the line (and the words money made by money should be taxed at the same rate as money made by men constitute just about the most democratic utterance since the days of F.D.R.), perhaps the press can leave off maligning Mr. McGovern long enough to get around to questioning some of R. M. Nixon's financial gimcrackery.

title: TEACHERS CONTINUE SUBURBAN STRIKES
description: Teacher strikes continued yesterday in some schools in Nassau, Dutchess and Rockland Counties.

title: Books of The Times
description: One of the dividends of the cultural revolution, along with the increase in museum attendance, museum tours of Europe and the like, has been the proliferation art books for popular consumption. The coffeetable book, though a subject for small jokes, is a steady seller in the bookstores, and a $25 item of Great Treasures... is as common in middleclass homes today as the Van Gogh print was in the thirties. That in some of these books there is less than meets the eye is not surprising. But that some are more enduring is also true, as the titles below indicate. In this felicitous blend of word and picture, Claude Marks has managed a chort course in the history of art. He has done it by considering the sketchbooks, usually the working sketchbooks, of great artists and some lesser ones from the Middle Ages to the present. Though he talks about drawing he is really talking about changing styles, changing techniques, changing ideals. He is colloquial without being chatty, learned without being pedantic., Biographical material, technical matter, the thoughts and assumptions of an age are united in a formula that is the author's own. But his remarks are so pithy, the language so right that they provide the layman a new way of seeing or of under?? what he has seen or often both.

title: PHILLIPS SCREW DELISTED BY AMEX
description: The Phillips Screw Company can no longer be, found among American Stock Exchange listings.

title: U.S. Drafts New Rules On Handling of Cargoes
description: The Federal Maritime Commission has taken another step toward improving the lessthansatisfactory system of truck deliveries and pickups of freight at local steamship piers.

title: U.S. and Soviet Arms Rated
description: LONDON, Sept. 7The international Institute for Strategic Studies says in a report to be published tomorrow that the armslimitation accords signed in May leave the Soviet Union with more missile launchers and heavier bombs than the United States but give America a lead in weapons flexibility and the ability to hit more targets.

title: Wreck Kills 2 Jersey Men
description: ALBANY, Sept. 7 (UPI)Two New Jersey men were killed last night when their car was struck by another on an Interstate Highway here, the police said. The men were identified as Kenneth Strangeway, 21 years old, and Gregory Breslin, 23, both of Wayne, N. J. James J. McCarthy, 33, the driver of the other car, faced arraignment in Police Court today on charges of drunken driving. He escaped with minor injuries in the crash.

title: Federal Aid Urged for Losses on Cyclamaie Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Advocates of a Housepassed measure that would permit Federal compensation of food companies and growers that lost money as a result of the Government's ban on cyclamates pleaded at a Senate hearing today for ourday in court,

title: Vietnamizing Democracy
description: The abolition of popular elections in South Vietnam's 10,775 hamlets by the stroke of an executive order from Saigon once again underscores the futility of the war and the fatuousnessin today's contextof professed American war aims. The blood of hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese and American soldiers and the suffering, of millions of civilians have been rationalized by lofty commitments to assure for the South Vietnamese people the right to democratic selfgovernment. In explaining his war policy, President Nixon has insisted that when the United States leaves Vietnam, it must be in a way that gives the South Vietnamese a reasonable chance to survive as a free people.

title: Senate Takes a Small Step Toward Approving Accord on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The Senate took a small forward step today toward approving the United StatesSoviet agreement on limiting offensive nuclear weapons by going on record in favor of mutual restraint and equality in relations between the two countries.

title: Giants, Jets Get Final Preseason Tests
description: For their final preseason games the New York Giants play the Cleveland Browns, who have lost five in a row, at Yankee Stadium on Sunday afternoon and the Jets meet the Chargers in San Diego on Saturday night. The Chargers have won four of five games, all against National Conference teams. The Jets cut their squad to the mandatory 44 men, yesterday, by trading Chuck Hinton, a defensive tackle, to Baltimore for a draft choice, and by dropping Scott Palmer, Grant Guthrie, Ken Gamble and Rocky Turner.

title: Peking Eulo gizes ExKuomintang Aide
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 7Peking has reportedly paid a warm tribute to Ho Hsiangning, who represented a link with the Nationalist Chinese and with modern China's revolutionary beginnings at the turn of the century. Miss Ho died in Peking at the age of 95.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Of the last five Presidential elections; the Republicans have won three, mainly on foreign policy issues. General Eisenhower won in 1952 and 1956, not only because he,was immensely, popular but because he was regarczed as man of peace, and experience in the foreign field. Richard. Nixon won in 1968 largely because of Vietnam, and this helps explain his strategy for reelection.

title: Painted Furniture: New Interest in an Old Art
description: Generations of collectors scorned it. Antiques dealers Ignored or stripped it. But due to the pioneering efforts of a score of enthusiasts, painted American furniture has finally acquired respectability, an avid following and the inflationary prices that usually accompany such revivals.

title: Possible Dream Auction Planned to Help the Arts
description: Opportunities to conduct major symphony orchestra, partake of a Chinese dinner prepared by Danny Kaye and lunch with Neil Armstrong, the astronaut, are among the enticements promised in The Possible Dream Auction, new project to promote community arts in the city.

title: And for Dessert, NectarineStuffed Puffy Crepes
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by recipe.

title: Levitz Shareholders, After Trouble, Hear Profit Margins Will Recover
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7The Levitz Furniture Corporation, a dramatic growth company that has recently been troubled by profit erosion and regulatory investigations, is looking ahead to a profitmargin recovery, stockholders were told here today.

title: Mark Longman Dies at 55; Head of British Publishers
description: LONDON, Sept. 7  Mark Longman, president and former chairman of the Longman Group of publishing companies, died yesterday at his home in Salisbury. He was 55 years old.

title: Matthews Takes a Stand and It Brings Him Trouble
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 7For the second time in less than a week, conduct on the victory stand became a controversial issue at the Olympic Games. Once again the athlete or athletes involved were Americans.

title: Business Briefs
description: Housing starts during the second quarter failed show another seasonally adjusted gain, signaling the peak of the current housing boom has been reached, according to George Christie, F. W. Dodge economist.

title: A Rice Shortage in Cambodia Provokes Clashes With Police
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 7An increasingly serious rice shortage, induced partly by the Communist forces closing of key roads leading to Pnompenh, brought scuffles today between crowds and troops in some areas of the Cambodian capital as people demanded rice at reasonable prices.

title: U.S. Gains Expansion of Working Group's Size as Hijacking Treaty Is Pushed at Global Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Delegates to an international conference here created a smaller working group today to search for avenues of agreement on a new antihijacking treaty after a debate in which France attacked the United States with unusual bluntness.

title: Smith Toppled by Ashe In 3 Sets
Market Place: Big Board Lifts Some of Secrecy
description: A governing committee of 28 men was created at the New York Stock Exchange on May I, 1869. Its purpose was to rule on policy matters for the Big Board, and for 103 years the group and its successors have met in secrecy.

title: 64 Correction Officers Are Cited for Heroism
description: After two yeari of postponements because of jailhotte tensions and disruptions, the city finally celebrated the heroism of its correction officers yesterday.

title: Protecting the Missions
description: Inevitably in an international city that is the home of the United Nations and 200 foreign embassies and consulates, an outrage somewhere else in the world has its repercussions here. Special details of New York City policemen have now been provided to protect the Lebanese and Egyptian missions, where demonstrators have been protesting against the Arab terrorist slaying members of the Israeli Olympic team in Munich.

title: ...Tying Up Building
description: Two unions with more muscle than good sense are, the chief obstacles to final settlement of the nineweek strike of construction workers in this city. Most of the dozen other crafts that walked out :last. July 1 are back on the job under contracts that stretch the 5.5 per cent antiinflation guidepost but make minimal concession to the union's original featherbedding demands.

title: Letters to the Editor,
description: To the Editor: Your editorial on Senator. McGovern',s revised tax plan (McGovernomics, Aug. 30) attempts to condone the Senator's fast switch from his earlier $1,000 a person payments to. his new updated proposals. This bold switch, you say, is the same as President Nixon's breaking of the chains to his original Economic Game Plan on Aug. 15, 1971.

title: RAIL LOANS VOTED BY SENATE BODY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The Senate Commerce Commits tee approved today a bill authorizing Federally guaranteed loans of up to $3billion to railroads and other surfacefreight handlers.

title: Books of The Times
description: Please don't get me wrong: I know an ongoing problem when I see one, and I can deplore the deplorable as well as the next guy. Some of my very best friends have furrowed brows. And I really share Vance Packard's latest concernwith the rootlessness that is spreading its feeders into our social fabric. I think he's really put his finger on what's wrong again (if he has any fingers left over after putting them on the pyramid climbers, the waste makers, the status seekers, the hidden persuaders and the sexual wilderness of our naked society). It's awful what's been going on lately. High corporations packing up their personnel and sending them off to nasty places like Houston. Rubber companies in Akron, Ohio, switching to threeshift and fourshift workdays (to keep the machinery running round the clock), so that next door neighbors can't bowl with each other any more. Aerospace towns springing up like ABM silos and messing up the lifestyle of the old village green. Shopping malls in Paramus; youngsters running off to dear old MultiU; old folks toddling off to cities in the sun. Snowbirds centrifugating! Ethnics churning in peopleimploding cities! Urbs and suburbs sprawling! It's all very distressing, it really is.

title: China. Parts Its School Curtain
description: PEKING, Sept. 7 (Reuters)The Chinese have agreed for the first time to allow children of diplomats and residents of Peking to attend kindergartens with preschool age Chinese children, sources said here today.

title: Bridge: Tournament World Depends On Enthusiasm of Amateur
description: Bridge administrators are of two main species: the fulltime professional, rare in the United States and almost unknown elsewhere, and the sparetime amateur, on whose unselfish enthusiasm the organization of the tournament world largely depends.

title: VIETNAM DEMANDS REPEATED AT PARIS
description: PARIS, Sept. 7William J. Porter, the chief United States representative at the Paris peace talks, warned Hanoi once more today against hoping to achieve political ends in Saigon by military means. The Communist side once again took the position that continued American; bombing of North ?? Proof of American ?? to end the war.

title: Generator Is Ordered
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 7 (UPI)The Combustion Engineering Corporation has won a contract to supply a 500megawatt steam generator to the Mississippi Power Company for an electric generating plant to be built on the Pascagoula River near Cumbest Bluff. The price was not disclosed.

title: Feliciano Program At the Palace Mixes Hits and New Disk
description: Jose Feliciano, perched on a high stool, plucking his guitar, stomping out the beat with booted foot against a rung of the stool, can do great things with a song. One song. Maybe two. Even possibly three. But after that, monotony begins to set in because Mr. Feliciano turns all his songs into the same song with a delivery that stays at one level, projected as a fervent, nasal wail.

title: Dutch Troubled by Hints of Bias In Fights With Turkish Workers
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 31Shocked and startled, Dutchmen are beginning to figure out the unhappy meaning of street fights that raged for a week recently between Dutch and Turkish workers here.

title: Foreign Currencies Are Sold
description: The Federal Reserve System sold $31.5million in foreign currencies during July and August to help defend the value of the dollar in international dealings, Charles A. Coombs, senior vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday. This intervention, which occurred on nine separate occasions during the last two months, helped to improve market confidence that the pattern of currency values agreed to at the Smithsonian Institution last December would be maintained, Mr. Coombs said.

title: LAZAR ASSAILED BY 9 COUNCILMEN
description: Michael J. Lazar, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, was accused yesterday by nine City Councilmen of usurping legislative powers by creating regulations that have diminished rather than improved taxi service in the city.

description: To the Editor:

title: Askew Backing McGovern But Rules Out Campaigning
Huge Art Show on View at Olympics
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 7Amid the pall that hangs over the Olympic Games as a result of this week's tragic events there are attractions aside from the competitions themselves that continue to draw attention. One of these is an extravaganza of an art show mounted in the House of Art by the West Germans.

title: Compromise Limits on Exhaust Established by Pollution Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency adopted today new exhaust standards for heavyduty vehicles. The, standards are more stringent than present ones but somewhat weaker than E.P.A. proposed last, year.

description: To the Editor:

title: Prisoners'
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 7A few days after James Riddle Hoffa was released from a Federal penitentiary last Dec. 23, he was on the phone ordering suits and. hoes with the concentration and energy that he once used in negotiating contracts.

title: O'Brien Says His Phone Was Tapped Before Raid
Louis Lurie, 84, Dies on Coast; Realty Man and Theater Angel
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. (UPI)Louis R. Lurie. a millionaire real estate developer and a financial angel for many Broadway stage hits, died last night on his 84th birthday.

title: Threats Compel Norwegians to Play
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 7 (AP)Norway's Olym pic handball team returned to action today after boycotting members bowed to pressure and permitted three members to play.

title: BETTER SERMONS URGED ON CHURCH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Roman Catholics heard today that the time has come to upgrade the Sunday sermon.

title: Buttering Up Labor...
description: The Administration's quest, for labor support is mowing down one Republican tradition after another. It is also getting increasingly expensive for the taxpayer.

description: CLEVELAND, Sept 7, (UPI) Four officials of the United Mine Workers union, who: were indicted by a Federal grand jury here, in connection with, the slayings of Joseph A. YablOnski, his wife and hid daughter pleaded not guilty today to conpsiracy charges in, Federal District Court.,

title: TV: A Glossy Smattering of Nostalgia in a Tribute
Heroin Sale Is Laid to Daughter Of Convicted ExI. S.M. Official
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 7 The 18yearold daughter of Lawrence A. Tate, the former International Business Machines executive who is appealing two drugrelated convictions here was arrested today by local policemen, who charged her with selling an undisclosed quantity of heroin to an undercover agent.

title: Historian Tells How a Spartan China Has Banished the Old Squalor
description: After transportation; housing is the most backward aspect of China. Although given to drastic street widening and bursts of Sovietstyle gigantism in public squares and buildings, the authorities have preferred to let new housing adjoin new industry in the new sectors of provincial capitals rather than attempt urban renewal of the old inner city.

title: Acting F.B.I. Leader, Unlike Hoover, Speaking in Support of White House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 L. Patrick Gray 3, the acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has departed from the nonpolitical practices of his predecessor, J. Edgar Hoover, by making a series of speeches that follow key points in the political line of the incumbent Administration.

title: BAPTISTS GET ADVICE ON BLACKSIN POLITICS
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 7 (UPI)The president of the 6.3 million memzer National Baptist Convention today urged 20,000 black delegates to the group's 92d annual convention not to vote for any man for the Presidency who did not seek the black vote.

title: Weekend Fishing Reports for Nearby Waters
description: AREA ABlues are continuing in good numbers, especially on the Barnegat Ridge, and fishermen are taking them with diamond jigs or squid. In a fivemile stretch of New Jersey coast from Bay Head to Mantoloking, sea bass and porgies of good size are plentiful. Weakfish have been caught in impressive numbers along the coast. Crabbing is reported excellent in Barnegat Bay, where fluke else have been pulled in:

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.4 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 122.4 from 122.0 last week.

title: SCHOOL SEGREGATION DENIED BY CARDINAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI)  Cardinal Cooke, the Arch bishop of New York, testified today that Roman Catholic schools had never fostered racial or religious segregation and urged approval of a bill to provide tax credits for priyate school tuition.

title: Rosh haShanah Starts at Sundown With Prayers for Israelis Slain in Munich
description: Special prayers will be recited in synagogues and temples at sundown today for the slain Israeli Olympic athletes as the observance of Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year of 5733, begins.

title: Road Funds for Transit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP)  The Nixon Administration gave its support today to a plan to provide an additional $800million from the Federal Highway Trust Fund for use on mass transit systems. The endorsement came in testimony by Secretary of Transportion John A. Volpe before the Senate Subcommittee on Housing and.Urban Affairs.

title: Jersey Official Reports Old Horrors Of Parkway Restaurants Are Ended
description: TRENTON, Sept. 7  The head of the New Jersey Highway Authority announced to day that he had finally cleaned up what he described as the horrors in the Garden State Parkway's restaurants and service stations after a 19 month upgrading campaign.

title: Coal Order Is Placed
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 7 (UN) The Wisconsin Power and Light Company has contracted to buy 300,000 tons of low sulphur steam coal yearly for 20 years from the Westmoreland Resources Company of Billings, Mont, for its Cassville, Wis., generating station.

title: HOUSING HEARING BECOMES UNRULY
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 7 Telling a small, unruly crowd that we do not propose to turn, over the question of housing in Westchester to the frenzy of mob rule, Edward J. Logue, president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, adjourned a public hearing late tonight until next Tuesday for discussion of a proposed apartment project in nearby Greenburgh.

title: Pentagon Knew of Unauthorized Lavelle Raid in 71
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Congressional sources reported today that the Joint Chiefs of Staff had detected at least one of Gen. John D. Lavelle's unauthorized bombing missions against North Vietnam in 1971, well before the series of raids ended.

title: COURT NULLIFIES ROONEY VICTORY; NEW PRIMARY SET
description: The Appellate Division yesterday set aside the renomination of Representative John J. Rooney and ordered a new primary election between the Brooklyn Democrat and his opponent, former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein.

title: Harlem Doctors and Nurses Protest Appalling Medical Care at Hospital
description: Harlem Hospital physicians, nurses, orderlies, citizenadvisers walked together in an extraordinary picket line yesterday to protest what they called appalling medical care there.

title: Boston Schools Get Funds Held Up Under U.S. Rules
description: BOSTON, Sept. 7 (AP)The State Department of Education has decided to release $6.6 million in Federal aid to Boston schools.

title: BRIGADIER BENTON OF SALVATION. ARMY
description: Brigadier William Benton, newly appointed men's social service secretary for The Salvation Army's Eastern Territory, died yesterday in West Hempstead, L. I. He was on the way to New York for what was to have been his first day in his new office on 145 West 15th Street. He was 59 years old and lived at 78 Sycamore Setreet, West Hempstead.

title: Board Counsel Appointed For New York Exchange
description: The appointment of Charles M. Mattingly Jr., to the newly created post of counsel to the board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange was announced yesterday by James J. Needham, the new fulltime chairman of the Big Board.

title: PATRICK J. MURPHY
description: Patrick J. Murphy, a linotype operator who retired from The New York Times last year and who had been chairman of the typographical chapel in the composing room, died Wednesday. He was 65 years old and lived at 5940 Queens Boulevard in Woodside, Queens.

title: Dutch Central Bank Cuts Its Rate to 3% From 4%
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept 7 (Reuters) The Netherlands cut the bank rate to 3 per cent from 4 per cent, the Dutch central bank said today. The cut takes effect tomorrow.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Warner Communications, Inc., said yesterday it was filing a registration statement With the Securities and Exchange Commission for the proposed sale by certain shareholders of 791,247 shares of common stock. The company said the registration is required in connection with its agreement to acquire the.Cypress Communications Corporation, a cable television business. The company's stock was down  at 38 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: AMEX VOLUME UP FOR INSTITUTIONS
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that, while individual investors continued to generate most of the public trading volume on the Amex, institutional activity had increased 11 percentage points since 1966.

title: STATE LABOR TOLD TO ELECT FRIENDS
U.S. Cardinal to Attend Martyr's Rite in Poland
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP)John Cardinal Krol of Philatrelphia will visit Poland Oct. 14 and 15 to concelebrate a mass marking the end of the year of beatification for a Polish martyr, the Rev. Maximilian Kolbe.

title: Troops Raid 100 Rice Stores
description: PNOMPENH, Sept. 7 (Reuters)Cambodian troops raided more than 100 stores to find cheap rice here today as the Government announced that it was requisitioning all lowquality stocks of rice in the face of a national food shortage.

title: KENNECOTT SETS CHILE WRITEOFF
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation announced yesterday that it would write off the $50.3million book value of its equity investment in Chile following the refusal by the Chilean Special Copper Tribunal to review a, $410million retroactive profit deduction decreed by President Allende.

title: Corsaro Directs City Opera Rehearsals Con Brio
Black September Guerrillas'
description: Fervent young Palestinians, convinced that the Arab commando movement must go completely underground, have swelled the yearold Black September organization's ranks to about 300 men, wellplaced Arab informants reported in Beirut yesterday.

title: PUBLISHERS UNIT TO DROP SUBSIDY
description: The Association of American Publishers has decided to withdraw its subsidy from the National Book Committeewhich annually makes National Book Awards.

title: LOWENSTEIN ASKS A FAIR ELECTION
description: Allard K. Lowenstein yesterday praised an Appellate Division decision ordering a new primary election between him and Representative John J. Rooney, but declined to blame the city's Board of Elections for the irregularities in the June 20 primary that were cited by the court.

title: And What Would Henry Thoreau Have Thought?
description: To the Editor: It struck me while reading Joseph Farkas One Small Life [OpEd, Aug. 29] that Thoreau would never have stood around and allowed another man to kill a woodchuck 200 feet away from him.

title: Finland, Still Wary of Moscow, Covets World Role at European Security Parley
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 5A Helsinki newspaper reported a change this week in the way Finnish students are to be selected for advanced training in Soviet universities. In addition to relying on academic levels and test scores, the newspaper said, political views will also be considered.

title: PENN LIFE MERGER BEING CALLED OFF
description: The National General Corporation, a company with extensive interests in insurance, book publishing and movie theaters, disclosed last night that a $244million merger it had planned with the Pennsylvania life company had been broken off.

title: DOG SHOW HONOR WON BY TERRIER
description: TUXEDO, N. Y., Sept. 8 A 20monthold smooth fox terrier, Ch. Boreham Baranova, competing in a final that included the topwinning performer in America, Mrs. Peggy Westphal's silverbuff cocker spaniel, Ch. Sagamore Toccoa, walked out of the ring at Sterling Forest as best of 1,341 dogs at the Tuxedo Park Kennel Club show tonight.

title: KLEINDIENST SCORES CHARGE BY O'BRIEN
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. S Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was not inVestigating the charge of Lawrence F. O'Brien, former Democratic party chairman, that his office telephone was tapped before the June 17 breakin attempt at the party's Watergate Hotel headquarters.

title: Slain Israeli Athlete Is Buried In His Home Town of Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 8David R. Berger, one of the 11 Israeli athletes slain by Arab terrorists at Munich, was buried here today.

title: Ryun Falls and Fails to Qualify in Olympics
description: The United States had one of its most frustrating and embarrassing days in Olympic history at Munich, West Germany, yesterday. The fastest miler who ever lived fell and failed to qualify, two of the world's best quartermilers were barred for life from the Games and a gold medal in swimming was lifted.

title: Market Place: Merrill Lynch Sets Secondary
description: The stock market has been unkind this year to shareholders of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Wall Street's biggest brokerage house and one of the handful that are publicly owned.

title: Screen: A Rootless Life:Film About Veterans Is At Neighborhoods
description: Richard Compton's "Welcome Home, Soldier Boys," which opened very modestly at neighborhood theaters yesterday, is a largely unsuccessful, occasionally grotesque, but by no means dishonorable attempt to deal with some of the texture of rootless American life at the present time.It goes wrongquite dreadfully wrongin its more mechanically spectacular moments. But it seems right when it is content to roam around the towns and highways of the West and Southwest, moving all but aimlessly toward what should have been a small-scale doom.The soldier boys in question are four veterans, Green Berets, who are discharged from the Army in Arkansas, jointly buy a big black second-hand Cadillac, and set off for California to start raising cattle on land that one of them is supposed to own, but that is in fact no more than a photograph on a picture postcard. Along the way they alternately victimize and are victimized.They pick up, use, and possibly kill a tough girl hitchhiker (they never bother to see what happens when she falls out of their speeding car). They visit one boy's home, and move on, growing more desperate, and poorer. Finally, out of money and out of gas, they erupt into violencetotally destroying a tiny New Mexico town that is all too obviously a surrogate Vietnamese villageand absurdly simplifying a movie that could have taken something better.Each of the boys has a certain edgy individuality, and their leader, Danny (Joe Don Baker) seems genuinely complex with his imposing slouch, his defiant eyes and mumbled speech. Indeed, I am not sure but that what impressed me most about him was my being unable to make out more than a third of his dialogueand feeling that all that inarticulate talk was an expressive part of a characterization.But it is as a road movie that "Welcome Home, Soldier Boys" really comes into its own. Five minutes here, 10 minutes there, motel scenes at night, or driving through the early morningscenes that don't finally co-here but that do stand out for a kind of lyricism and reticence and subtlety of observation. There is a quality of emptiness and random pathos to the film that is ultimately rather lovely, and that belongs as much to the spirit of American movie making as it does to the spirit of American life.This doesn't add up to a good movie, but it adds up to a sporadically interesting onein which the failure of the whole is no measure of some of the parts.

title: BISHOP JAMES ROBERTS
description: Bishop James P. Roberts, founder of the St. Thomas Liberal Catholic Church, 147 West 144th Street, died Sunday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 70 years old.

title: Military Womanpower
description: The Pentagon has found a logical possible solution the manpower shortage arising out of the drive for an allvolunteer forcewomanpower.

title: MacGregor Warns Staff To Keep Problems Quiet
Red Smith
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 8These questions were asked today in these words: In view of Israel's experiences with Arab terrorists in recent years, did the Israeli delegation to the Olympic Games ask for special security measures in Olympic Village? If so, were such measures provided? What form did they take? Why did they fail?

title: RETAIL CHAINS SALES MIXED FOR AUGUST
description: Several large retail chains yesterday reported mixed sales results for August.

title: And What Would Henry Thoreau Have Thought?
description: To the Editor: I would certainly distinguish between woodchucks and human beings, yet I wonder why Mr. Farkas when in no real danger himself would not act to save the woodchuck. I doubt we could count on him when there might be real danger to his own life to re sist a wrong to another human being. The point is not whether woodchucks are good or bad animals, nor that those men chose to kill the animal. The point is that Mr. Farkas chose not to act but to watch, record what he saw, and no doubt receive a fat fee from. The. New York Times for his trouble.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: One troubling aspect of the i972 campaign is the vulgar courting of the Jewish vote. President Nixon's strategists, say happily that many more Jews will vote Republican this year, and the proNixon announcements of some Jewish leaders support that claim. Senator McGovern, for his part, has countered by telling Jewish audiences that he can do better for them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I would like to commend your recent editorial on registering the voters. Your readers might be interested in some further details: (1) More than 43 per cent of all eligible New York City residents are not registered to vote, compared to the national average of 28 per cent; (2) Three boroughsManhattan, Bronx and Brooklynnow have lower registration ratesbthan Mississippi and most Southern states; (3) New York City's percentage of all.registered voters in the state has dropped below 39 per cent, while we still constitute the majority of the state's pop. ulation.

title: Some Women in Business for Themselvesin Man's Domain
description: Cheryl Eule is a carpenter. Millie Marglotta is a printer. Florence Alexander is a house painter. Aside from the fact that all three follow occupations traditionally considered male preserves, they also share a common achievement: Each has established a successful business with other women.

title: Matthews: I'm an Athlete, Not a Politician
description: MUNICH, Sept. 8I just hope that people in the United States don't get the wrong impression about what happened on the victory stand after the 400meter run last night.

title: British Payments Surplus Up
description: LONDON, Sept. 8 (Reuters)  Britain's payments surplus widened to 77million in the second quarter from a revised 58million in the first, the Treasury said today. The estimates are on the currentaccount basis and are seasonally adjusted.

title: Top Fillies and Mares Awaiting Showdown in Today's Beldame
Killing of Six Laid To ExNazi Guard
description: Aaron Kaufman, a 71yearold veteran of eight Nazi concentration camps, told a Federal hearing here yesterday that he had seen Hermine Braunsteiner, a former SS prison guard and now Mrs. Russell Ryan of Maspeth, Queens, whip five women and a child to death at the World War II concentration camp at Maidanek, Poland.

title: Venereal Disease an Epidemic in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 8Gov. Thomas J. Meskill's task force on venereal disease reported , today that syphilis and gonorrhea had spread to epidemic proportions in Connecticut.

title: Waldheim Asks a Debate On Terrorism in General
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 8  Secretary General Waldheim asked the General Assembly today to consider measures to prevent terrorism. The move opened the way for a fullscale United Nations debate on the killing of 11 Israeli athletes at the Olympic Games in Munich by Arab guerrillas.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 8 (Reuters)Oakley Hunter, president and chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Association, announced today that the Fanny May would begin issuing commitments to buy 95 per cent conventional home mortgages in November.

title: HOWARD M. LESOURD, MINISTER, EDUCATOR
description: CHRISTMAS COVE, Me., Sept. 8The Rev. Dr. Howard M. LeSourd, former dean of the Graduate School of Public Relations and Communications at Boston University, died today at his summer home. He was 82 years old and lived at 685 West End Avenue, New York.

title: Woman in Queens Is Killed When Struck by Bulldozer
description: A Woodhaven, Queens, woman was killed yesterday when she was run over by a small bulldozer driven by Joseph Ferranti of Ferranti Constructors.

title: Sanford Bates, 88, Who Headed Federal Prison System, Is Dead
description: TRENTON, Sept. 8 (AP) Sanford Bates, who served as director of the Federal prison system from 1930 to 1937, died here today at Mercer Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: Laos Setback Reported
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 8 (AP)  Informed sources said today that elements of Americansupported Laotian irregular forces were forced to withdraw under heavy fire last Tuesday, abandoning an offensive operation against the North Vietnameseheld Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos.

title: Jews Picket Israeli Office
description: Some 500 Hasidic Jews from Brooklyn and lower Manhattan picketed the Israeli Government offices at 800 Second Avenue for two hours yesterday morning to protest the jailing without bail of two religious students who were charged with setting an explosion in a Tel Aviv sex boutique on June 21. The demonstrators, who did not meet with consular officials, said they hoped the Israeli Government would free the two, Samuel Weisenstern and Yisroel Bernath; both 18 years old, on the eve of Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year, which began at sundown last night.

title: Mrs. Shana Kreingold, 83 Golda Meir's Older Sister
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 8 (AP)Mrs. Shana Kreingold, older sister of Israel's Premier Golda Meir, died yesterday after long illness. She was 83 years old.

title: ANOTHER DISPUTE VALDEZ DEFEATED
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 8 (AP)Jesse Valdez, the United States team's flashiest fighter, lost a disputed split decision tonight as the Americans moved only one man into the Olympic boxing finals.

title: UTILITIES TO TEST ELECTRIC VEHICLE
description: The Electric Energy Association announced yesterday that 55 utilities had agreed to participate in a program to test ontheroad electric vehicles in various parts of the country beginning, next year.

title: Hurricane Loses Strength But Flooding Is Predicted
description: CAPE HATTERAS, N. C., Sept. 8 (UPI)The hurricane, Dawn, dwindled in strength to a tropical storm today and headed for the Outer Banks of North Carolina, causing predictions of some flooding during the night.

title: Despite Rise in Syphilis, Many Hospitals Drop Tests
description: Until 1969, every hospital in the country was required to perform routine blood tests for syphilis on every patient in order to be approved by the Joint Commission on Hospital. Accreditation.

title: Fate of Embattled Tienphuoc Is in Doubt
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 9The Saigon command reported yesterday that South Vietnamese troops had abandoned an embattled district capital south of Danang, but a spokesman said early today that fighting apparently was still under way inside the town.

title: Hoffa Lawyer Sought Deal On Trip, Kleindienst Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that James R. Hoffa's lawyer had suggested a deal under which Hoffa would be allowed to return to union activities if he won the release of someAmerican prisoners of war from North Vietnam.

title: McGovern's Campaign
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 8 As seen from Washington, Senator George McGovern's Presidential campaign is an amalgam of money problems, organizational confusion, disastrous showings in state and national polls and the gloom of party professionals. From the perspective of the Democratic nominee's campaign plane, there are a few mildly hopeful signs: reasonably good crowds at many stops during this first week of allout campaigning and excellent ones in Akron and Seattle; a sense that Mr. McGovern, undiscouraged, has found his primary theme, that of Richard Nixon the fixer, Richard Nixon the enemy of the little man: hints that many of the oldline Democrats who are nervous about Mr. McGovern have not yet decided to vote for the President.

title: Notes on People
description: Alf M. Landon, the Republican candidate for President in 1936, celebrates his 85th birthday today at his home in Topeka, Kan. Asked in prebirthday interview if he thought Senator George McGovern would replace him as the candidate who made the worst showing in a Presidential election, Mr. Landon laughed and said, I wouldn't predict anything like that. If you ask me the Saturday before the election, I might answer you, but it's too early to tell.

title: Frustrating Terrorists
description: Numerous inquiries are now under way probing the deficiencies in logistics and communications that contributed to this, week's tragedy in Munich. Since the attack on the Olympic village was unprecedented, the West German Government was unprepared and had to improvise as events unfolded. The terrorists had the advantage of surprise, and of the nearchaos that surprise produced.

title: Teachers Here Postpone Vote On New Pact 48 Hours
description: Voting by the city's 60,000 public school teachers on tentative threeyear labor contract was postponed yesterday for more than 48 hours because of a delay in getting the agreement into final form for printing and distribution to the United Federation of Teachers membership.

title: Brennan Reports Labor Leaders Favoring Nixon A re Organizing
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 8Peter J. Brennan, president of the New York Slate Building and Construction Trades Council, said today that he had found widespread support for President Nixon among delegates to the convention here of the states's American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organizations.

title: Business Briefs
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 8 (Reuters)The Dutch Government announced today measures to stimulate the economy of the Netherlands.

title: Egypt's No. 1 Diplomat Mohammed Hassan elZayyat
description: Those who know him say that Mohammed Hassan elZayyat is one of the most moderate of the Arab diplomats on the question of Israel. Indeed, they say he cannot be as moderate in public as he indicates in private that he would like to be Still to look at him or talk to him, it would be hard to consider him as anything but moderate, for he is a large man who sham bles along like a great friendly brown bear.

title: Books of The Times
description: The pattermof events in Thomas Kenea ly's novel about aboriginewhite relationships in Australia at the turn of the century will be familiar. It is the same as that of Indians and white men in America and later of whites and blacks. The natives of Australia had the distinction of being the Indians and the blacks of their land. If the novel is authentic, and the facts do ring true, then the behavior of white men in Australia was simply a copy of our own: There was the same cultural blindness, the same indifference to the natives as human beings, the same arrogant use of brute strength. It was a downward spiral. They degraded and humiliated the natives, and then cited the condiwhich the natives ,lived as proof of native inferiority. Yet mixed in with these aspects of their dealings with each other was a linger ing sense of guilt on the part of the whites. Especially at those times when the cliches about native intelligence, industry or moral quality did not prove, out. When the Jimmie Blacksmith in the title shows himself to be a trustworthy worker and an able one, he finds that he seems to threaten the whites more than if he were merely shiftless and irresponsible. He never did understand it. And the white men did not either.

title: Upstate Teachers Strike
description: Public school teachers in Falconer, N. Y., a suburb of Jamestown, in the southwestern part of the state, struck yesterday in a contract dispute with the board of education. The 120 teachers picketed six schools that normally are attended by 2,200 pupils. Meanwhile, teachers continued on strike in the PlainviewOld Bethpage school district in Nassau County, in the Clarkstown, Pearl River and Ramapo District No. 1 of Rockland County and in the Dutchess County city of Beacon.

title: Roundup: Fryman and Tigers Put Orioles 2 Back
description: Woodie Fryman held Baltimore hitless for 5 innings last night in Memorial Stadium and finished with a twohitter as Detroit posted a 21 victory, its second in the socalled crucial threegame series.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 8 (Reuters)The average rate today's tender of British Treasury bills rose to 6.3427 per cent from 5.8872 per cent last week. This is its highest level since March, 1971, banking sources here said.

title: Marathoner Suggests Victory Ceremony Ban
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 8 (UPI)  Ken Moore, a marathon runner from Lowell, Ore., said today the victory ceremony at the Olympic Games should be abolished.

title: Daniele Maury Wed in France
description: Miss Daniele Marie Olga Maury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Maury of l'Aiguillon sur Mer Vendee France was married there yesterday to Stephen Frederic Robert Beekman son of the Rev. Garadus Beekman, retired rector of St. Paul's American Church (Episcopal) in Rome, and Mrs. Beekman of Cap d'Antibes, France. The ceremony was performed in St. Nicola Roman Catholic Church by the Rev Gabriel Berthome.

title: SOVIET STAR SETS DECATHLON MARK
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 8 (AP)  I am really tired, Nikolai Avilov of the Soviet Union said tonight after setting a world record in winning the Olympic decathlon. I am really beat.

title: Hubert Long. Talent Agent In Country Music, Is Dead
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 8 (AP)Hubert Long, a talent agent who represented some of the top names in country music for two decades, died here yesterday, several months after undergoing surgery for removal of a brain tumor. He was 48 years old.

title: MANSFIELD SEES NIXON DUPLICITY ON KEY PROBLEMS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8.Senator Mike Mansfield accused President Nixon today of duplicity in attempting to blame Congress for what the Senator called the Administration's own failings in dealing with the nation's economy, environmental problems and social needs.

title: Acupuncture Used in Houston To Help Woman Avoid Surgery
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)The M.D. Anderson Cancer and Tumor Institute disclosed today that doctors there had treated a patient with the ancient Chi nese art of acupuncture with apparent success.

title: Merchants Assist Cleanup Drive Here
description: Six bright blue litter baskets purchased by local merchants were placed along Broadway between 82d and 86th Streets yesterday as part of a cleanup project sponsored by the city's Environmental Protection Administration and the Vera Institute of Justice.

SMALL POINT, Me.  What about this solution? The President should choose his successor after and not before his election. Let the Constitu tion be amended to require that the elected President shall choose as his successor that one of his Cabinet whom he deems best qualified to carry on the aims and aspirations of his office.

title: Pnompenh Residents Riot, Looting Markets for Rice
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 8Angered by an acute shortage of rice, residents of Pnompenh rioted today, looting nearly every food market in the city.

title: The New Body Snatchers
description: Look, gang, does anyone here mind if I make a proposal? Not a modest one, like Dean Swift's about Irish babies, or an immodest one of the sort every redblooded boy in my youth longed to make to Aileen Pringle, Nita Naldi and Billie Dove, but more of a petition, as it were. I'd just like to borrow, for purposes of this diatribe, a nickname applied by the British Expeditionary Forces to themselves after Kaiser Wilhelm had dubbed them contemptible"to wit, the Old Contemptibles. I've been poring through my stock of pejoratives all morning, hunting for a phrase rancorous enough to describe some characters who set my teeth on edge, and that seems to be the only one that fits. Of course I could use the fourletter word that Kenneth Tynan, Britain's master showman, so deftly resuscitated that it brought the privy into the parlor, but it's become so shopworn by now that it's practically a term of endearment.

title: Italy Bids Six Revise System of Linking Currency Rates
description: ROME, Sept. 8 (Reuters)The Common Market's system to tie the currencies of its members tightly together should be revised, Italian monetary authorities feel.

title: Panel in Senate Votes to Divert Road Funds to Transit Systems
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 8  In a significant breakthrough, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee approved today bill that would use part of the Highway Trust Fund to build subways and other rapid transit systems in urban areas.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Recent news stories suggest Olt close former associates of Robert kennedy are unenthusiastic about Sargent Shriver for Vice President. This is just not so.

title: BID BY ANACONDA DENIED BY CHILE
description: The Anaconda Company announced yesterday that the Chilean Special Copper Tribunal had denied a petition for reconsideration of the deduction of socalled excess profits from any compensation to be paid Anaconda for its expropriated assets in Chile.

title: U.S. to Approve L.I. Plan For MinorityHiring Quota
description: The Nixon Administration is planning to approve the Long Island Plan for integrating the construction industry in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, despite the fact that the plan contains a 6 per cent quota for employment of members of minority groups.

title: JUDGE DENOUNCES EXHUDSON AIDES
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 8 Five former members of the Hudson County Employes Pension Commission heard themselves denounced today as traitors to the public by Superior Court Judge Theodore I. Botter as he sentenced them to terms of up to two years in prison for awarding undeserved disability pensions.

title: Plunge in Colombia Kills 5
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. (UPI)Five soldiers were killed and 12 injured when a troop carrier in which they were riding plunged into the Obita River, 190 miles north of here, officials said.

title: And What Would Henry Thoreau Have Thought?
description: To the Editor: It is quite apparent Mr. Farkas was not brought up on a farm else he would know that the woodchuck is rodent capable of much damage to crops.

title: Secret Burial for Arabs
description: MUNICH, Sept. 8 (AP)West German authorities today ordered a secret burial for the five Arab guerrillas killed in the airport battle Tuesday, and early Wednesday and ?? sued formal arrest warrants charging the three commandos who were captured with murder and kidnapping.

title: Age of NeoClassicism Displays Art to London
description: LONDON, Sept. 8A comprehensive exhibition of neoclassical art, sponsored by the Council of Europe, opened here yesterday. The most ambitious of a series, according to the council, it is intended to remind Europeans of the rich cultural heritage which is theirs and of the artistic trends in Europe through the ages.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: John Moran, in his Aug. 31 letter, describes the imposition of emigration fees by the Soviet Government as a neutral or even appealing policy aimed at retaining for the motherland skills acquired at the expense of society. But if retaining such skills is the true purpose of this policy, why, Professor Moran, does the Soviet Government choose to forgo the benefits derivable from these skills, as happens when people who apply to emigrate to Israel are commonly dismissed from their jobs? BERNARD JOSHUA KABAK New York, Aug. 31, 1972

title: De Mont Appeal Loses; He Must Return Modal
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 8 (AP)  The International Olympic Committee's Executive Board rejected today a United States appeal of the I.O.C.'s decision ordering Rick De Mont, an American swimmer, to give up his gold medal. It was not immediately clear how the I.O.C. would go about recovering the medal if De Mont, already back in the United States, balked at surrendering it.

title: FELICIA SOREL DIES; A DANCER, TEACHER
description: Felicia Sorel, choreographer, dancer and teacher, died Thursday of cancer in Las Vegas, Nev where she lived. Her age was 66.

title: Speeding Conviction Is Upset As Traffic Law Is Held Unfair
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ruled unconstitutional a section of the state's Vehicle and Traffic Law on the ground that it discriminated against residents of New York City.

title: Cairo Appoints a New Foreign Minister
description: CAIRO, Sept. 8Mohammed H. elZayyat, former Ambassador to the United Nations and Minister of State for Information, was named Foreign Minister today in a Cabinet shuffe announced by Premier Aziz Sidky.

title: And What Would Henry Thoreau Have Thought?
description: To the Editor: Little moments, at times; are beyond themselves, and can be lifetimes in miniature. Joseph Farkas called the woodchuck his friend and yet watched the man destroy him. How could he?

title: WHOLESALE PRICES UP SHARPLY AGAIN, SPURRED BY FOOD
description: WASHINGTON,, Sept. 8Wholesale prices continued to rise sharply in August, largely because food prices did not come down as much as usual during the month, the Government reported today.

title: Japan Set to Curb Exports to Britain If Industries Don't
description: TOKYO, Sept. 8 (AP)The Japanese Government has promised Britain that it will exercise administrative guidance to curb excessive shipments of goods to the British market if the industries concerned are unable to work out satisfactory restraints on a voluntary basis.

title: AustraliaChina Rod Deal
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 8, (Reuters)China has agreed to buy 150,000 tons of pig iron and 2,000 tons of steel rod from Broken Hill Proprietary, the Australian concern announced today.

title: Messmer Opens French Campaign in Alsace
description: STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 8On his first provincial tour as Premier, Pierre Messmer has promised Alsatians mere money and more local power from the central Government.

title: 9 Arab Guerrilla Organizations Said to Be Active in Germany
description: BONN, Sept. 8The attacks by Arab guerrillas in West Germany have focused public attention on the fact that the country's liberal immigration laws have made it a favorite arena for Arab underground activities.

title: PATROLMAN CITED FOR DRUG FORUMS
description: A patrolman who for six years has conducted narcotics education and rehabilitation programs on his own time in the community where he lives and in the precinct where he works received yesterday the top annual award of the 100 Year Association of New York $1,000.

title: FED TAKES ACTION IN MONEY MARKET
description: The Federal Reserve, in an unusual action yesterday, sopped up some reserves from the commercial banking system that resulted from the Treasury's running down its cash balances instead of borrowing.

title: Thanks to Mi. Lowenstein
description: The ordering of a new Democratic primary election to settle the contest between Representative John J. Rooney and former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein is notable on several levels. The immediate effect of the Appellate Division's unanimous decision is to make official what had hitherto been only a defeated candidate's contention that the June election in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District was so ridden with irregularities that its declared outcome should not be allowed to stand. In the longer view, the judges served notice that court intervention could be expected not merely elections won by a hair or allegedly won by fraud, but in those woneven by an appreciable marginwhere simply bad management may have dictated the outcome.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: State Senator Roy Goodman's wellintentioned review of the laws and rules governing building construction with the object of repealing those that are unenforceable and graftprovoking will be going too far if it advocates repeal of the current regulations governing street cranes and street obstruction by building materials.

title: WINE TALK
description: For anyone who likes Italian food and dining out, there are times when it seems that the entire metropolitan region must surely, one day, sink slowly in a turgid sea of tomato sauce. Nowhere, unless perhaps in Italy, are there so few good Italian restaurants and so many bad ones.

title: SCORES OF ISRAELI PLANES STRIKE 10 GUERRILLA BASES IN A REPRISAL FOR MUNICH
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 8In a sweeping reprisal for the terrorist shooting of 11 Israelis at Munich, Israeli Air Force planes struck simultaneously today at 10 Arab guerrilla bases and naval installations deep in Syria and Lebanon.

title: Senate's End War Amendment Is Dropped From Military Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  A SenateHouse conference committee today scrapped an endthewar amendment that the Senate had attached to a military procurement bill requiring the withdrawal of all American forces from Indochina in four months.

title: FUTURES OF SUGAR CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Sugar futures continued to drop yesterday after having fallen sharply the day before.

title: Campaign Will Finance Nixon Family's Travels
And What Would Henry Thoreau Have Thought?
description: To the Editor: The account of the killing of the woodchuck and the earlier account of the poodle standing guard over his collie friend killed on the highway [OpEd, July 11] are sad commentaries on man's destructiveness. But implicit in both stories is an increasingly frequent, linked observation: the passivity in the face of violence of men of better instincts. Could not Mr. Farkas have done more than just watch the pitchforking of the woodchuck?

title: RENTAL RISES STAYED IN CONTROLLED UNITS
description: Rent increases of up to 15 per cent for more than 400,000 tenants of rent controlled apartments in the city were stayed for a second time yesterday.

title: JAPAN APPROVES SAYER PROPOSAL
description: TOKYO, Sept. 8The Govetnment's Foreign Investment Council today approved the acquisition by Oscar Mayer & Company of the United States of a 25 per cent stock ownership in Prima Meat Packers, Ltd., of Tokyo, Japan's largest meat processing company. Under the program sanctioned by the council, Oscar Mayer will purchase 20 million shares of Prima stock, valued at $10 million. To meet the growing domestic demand for meat, the Japanese meatprocessing company will expand and modernize its existing plants and build a new factory with the new funds to be obtained from the American company through sale of its stock.

title: Mills Is Optimistic on Chances For Approval of Budget Ceiling
Decision for Democracy
description: In extending the period of voter registration yet again to Sept. 23, a threejudge Federal court has brought New York State more fully into compliance with the basic requirements of the Voting Rights Act of 1970. Noble as this feat is, it was achieved only over the active opposition of state officials who still seem stoutly dedicated to restricting the franchise.

title: PROSECUTOR SEEKS ATTICASTUDY FILE
description: The special state prosecutor preparing criminal cases in connection with last year's prison rebellion at Attica has subpoenaed the records of 3,000 confidential interviews conducted by the state's factfinding commission on the uprising.

title: Reforms Approved By Panel Planning U.S. Bicentennial
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) The American Revolution Bicentennial Commission adopted reforms today in an effort to satisfy Congressional critics who are holding up appropriations for the panel, which is planning the nation's 200th anniversary celebration.

title: Judge Orders Jail For Balky Veteran In Florida Inquiry
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 8 Federal District Judge David L. Middlebrooks Jr. ordered today the jailing of another recalcitrant witness on contempt charges for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating an alleged plot by antiwar veterans to disrupt the Republican National Convention last month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: William vanden Heuvel's statement on the prison riot prosecutions, as reported in The Times of Aug. 20, suggests a serious misunderstanding about the proper workings of the criminal justice system. Referring\ to the fact that guilty pleas to lesser Charges had been offered to some but not all of those indicted, he asserts that this is unequal treatment as well as needless burdening of the courts.

title: Cambodia Elevates Minister
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 8 (UPI)Cambodia's Information Minister, Long Boret, will also head the Foreign Ministry, the Government announced today. He will lead Cambodia's delegation to the United Nations next week. The Foreign Minister's. post had been held concurrently by the Chief Minister, Son Ngoc Thanh.

title: Mrs. King Gains Final But Chris Evert Loses
description: The plot in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday was for Mrs. Billie Jean King and Chris Evert to win and face each other today in a rematch for the women's singles title of the United States Open tennis championships.

title: Evie Robert, Political Hostess In Washington, Is Dead at 63
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Mrs. Evelyn Walker Robert, who as Evie Robert was for many years a leading political hostess in this city, died of a kidney ailment in George Washington Hospital on Wednesday. She was 63 years old and made her home in the Mayflower Hotel here and in Atlanta.

title: Matthews and Collett Banned From Olympics
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 8  The International Olympic Committee barred today two United States track and field athletes, Vince Matthews and Wayne Collett, from all future Olympic competition, including the remainder of the current Games, for what it termed a disgusting display on the victory stand following last night's 400meter run.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
