description: The Community School Board for District 1, on the Lower East Side, yesterday protested the proposed state investigation into the appointment of Luis Fuentes district superintendent as an unwarranted and possibly illegal intrusion into community educational affairs.

title: 1,000 ATTEND RITES FOR BISHOP M'NULTY
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 8 (AP)A funeral service was held today for the Most Rev. James A. McNulty, Bishop of the Buffalo Roman Catholic diocese for the last nine years.

title: Black Panthers in Algiers Halt Operations in Rift With Regime
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 6The international section of the Black Panther party, which established itself here in 1969, appears to have virtually ceased operations following an open break with the Algerian authorities.

title: Colombo Family Aide Is Slain at Miami
description: A longtime member of the reputed Mafia family of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. died early yesterday morning after being shot six times by an unknown assassin near Miami.

title: Olympic Personalities: The Next Hurdlel
description: Rod Milburn, who achieved his first lifetime goal by winning an Olympic gold medal, starts next week on his next goala football career that will lead to the pros. Milburn, 22 years old, of Opelousas, La., said he ran the best race of his career when he won the 110meter high hurdles at Munich.

title: After You're Mugged
description: The worst thing about a mugging is the shock of itthe sense of personal outrage. I was mugged recently in the elevator of a twelvestory loft buildingnow used for officesat 5 P.M. on a weekday by four young blacks. Normal building traffic was still moving in and out at that hour and it simply did not occur to me that should not step into the elevator with these rather cleancut appearing young men. I was so surprised that I could not believe it when they slammed me against one wall of the elevator and demanded my wallet.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION OFF FROM WEEKAGO
description: DETROIT, Sept. 8 (UPI)Despite some overtime scheduled this week to compensate for the Labor Day holiday, United States car production was held to 147,749, compared with 168,627 cars turned out last week.

title: At Least 30 Dead, Arabs Say
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 8The Israeli attack on Palestinian guerrillas and refuge camps in Lebanon and Syria today left at least 30 dead and scores wounded, according to Arab sources.

title: Antiques: Elaborate Designs in Chinese Enamels
description: There are Chinese enamels to suit almost every taste turning up at the antiques shows these days.

title: Stock Sale Negotiated
description: Canadian Cablesystems, Ltd., Torontto, is negotiating to sell its 3,506,724 shares of 48.8 per cent of Famous Players, Ltd. to Gulf & Western (Canada), Ltd., a subsidiary of Gulf & Western, Inc., for more than $27million.

title: WEAVER IS LEADER IN SOUTHERN GOLF
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 8 (AP) Dewitt Weaver, the long hitter from Atlanta, scrambled to a threeunderpar 67 today to take a threeshot lead at the midway mark of the $100,000 Southern Open golf tournament.

title: SISTER MARY JOSEPHINE
description: Sister Mary Josephine Enright of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd, who was superior and administrator of its Euphrasian Residence here from 1965 to 1970 and of its Villa Loretto in Peekskill, N.Y., from 1959 to 1965, died Wednesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived in the Mount Florence House in Peekskill.

title: MRS. MEIR OUTLINES JORDAN SETTLEMENT
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 8 (UPI)GoIda Meir proposed a peace settlement with Jordan on the eve of the Jewish New Year today but said Israel would never return to the pre1967 war borders. At the same time Foreign Minister Abbe Eban said it would be futile to discuss treaty with an Egypt that supports guerrilla activities.

title: SAUCY WAVE WINS PACE AT YONKERS
description: YONKERS, Sept. 8Romalie Hanover, and those among the 16,544 fans who backed her in the $35,000 Maggie Counsel pacing final at Yonkers Raceway tonight paid the penalty for the overland journey taken by the 1to5 favorite.

title: Upgrading An Eyesore
description: The letter scale, that ugly duckling of the desk accessory field, has been redesigned for 20thcentury tastes by Marco Zanuso, the Italian architect, for Terraillon, the French scale manufacturer. Mr. Zanuso's streamlined version is a flattened cylinder topped by a circular weighing tray.

title: BIAGGI ENDORSES OTTINGER'S RACE
description: Dismissing political labels as perilous, Representative Mario Biaggi, DemocratConservative, yesterday endorsed the campaign of former Representative Richard L. Ottinger, a liberal Democrat, to return to Congress by way of the new Bronx Westchester County district.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of Aug. 17 on Ramsey Clark's visit to Hanoi exhibited the poor judgment that you attribute to him. As any visitor to North Vietnam will confirm, the experience is a compelling one in human terms. To turn aside in silence from such desolation would require the most callous and selfinterested state of mind.

title: Fishes Good Deed Over, Now It's Texas Threat
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 8 (UPI) The grass carp, an aggressive freshwater fish imported from Asia to Arkansas to eat water plants choking reservoirs, have completed their task and are beginning to cat all the other fish, wildlife experts say.

title: Executive Commission Meets to Consider Possible Moves
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 8 (UPI The European Economic Community took its first steps today to control an inflation galloping upward in member nations at about 6 per cent a year.

title: Mrs. Harriet B. R. McCormick's Nuptials
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 8 Mrs. Harriet Binney Richmond McCormick of New Hope, Pa., widow of Brig. Gen. Gooderham L. McCormick, U.S.M.C.R., retired, was married here at noon today to David M. Freudenthal, widower, of New York and Solebury, Pa. The Rev. George W. Wickersham 2d performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: WARD RIDES CHUMBO TO JUMPER VICTORY
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 8Barney Ward rode Jerome A Denberg's Chumbo to victory in the open jumper stake at the North Shore horse show today and in the process beat out his archrival, Rod Jenkins.

title: DR. SAM BEISER, MICROBIOLOGIST
description: Dr. Sam M. Beiser, acting chairman of the department of microbiology of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, died Thursday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 49 years old and lived at 92 Pleasant Street, Dumont, N. J.

title: POVERTY PROGRAM IS INVESTIGATED
description: NEWARK, Sept. 8Federal investigators told a Congressional task force examining Model Cities procedures here today that they had found evidence of more than 8200,0001 being spent on items that are questionable at best.

title: Business Briefs
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 8 (UPI)The average Canadian paid in excess of $1.02 in August for food he was able to buy for a dollar in July.

title: Personalities: Wells in Limbo
description: The Oakland Raiders announced yesterday the retirement of Warren Wells, their 29yearold wide receiver. Wells, who is on probation following a year in prison for attempted rape, starred as a. receiver for the Raiders from 1967 to 1970.

title: Brandt Says Bonn Wants Ruthless Inquiry Into Olympic Killings
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 8  Chancellor Willy Brandt said today that his Government wanted a frank and ruthless inquiry into the 17 killings touched off last Tuesday by an Arab terrorist raid on the Israeli Olympic team here.

title: Global Resources Deal Sett
description: Stockholders yesterday approved the sale of the main assets and liabilities of Global Natural Resources Properties, Ltd., to Property Resources, Ltd. a new Bahamian company controlled by Norman P. Leblanc, a former officer of I.O.S., Ltd., after a Colorado court refused to block the annual meeting yesterday in Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: METS LOSE, 94, TO CARDS IN 13TH
description: The New York Mets and St. Louis Cardinals held a miserylovescompany meeting before 28,422 persons at Shea Stadium last night, dividing a doubleheader and sharing in both the company and the misery.

title: SLAIN 11 MOURNED AT HOLY DAY RITES
description: New York's Jewish community mourned the victims of the Olympic Village massacre at Rosh haShanah services at sundown yesterday, and the solemnity of the ancient ceremonies was heightened by the tragedy in which 11 Israeli athletes lost their lives.

title: ActorDirector Is Robbed Of $11,620 at Hotel Here
description: Rossani Brazzi, the Italian actor and director, was robbed early yesterday of $11,620 in jewelry, cash and traveler's checks while he was away from his room at the SherryNetherland Hotel for four hours with his wife.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times certainly has the right to disagree with George McGovern's positions on the issues and to publish editorials outlining its disagreements. However, it has a responsibility to avoid misleading innuendos, something which occurred in your Aug. 26 editorial, Striking the Schools.

title: Supercharged Wankel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Felix Wankel of Lindau, West Germany, inventor of the rotary combustion en gine bearing his name, was granted a United States patent this week for a modified form of the engine that is supercharged. Patent 3,688,749 is assigned to two German companies, Audi NSU and Wankel G.m.b.H. The CurtissWright Corporation holds exclusive North American rights and has granted the General Motors Corporation a license to develop the new form if it desires.

title: Virgin Island Police and F.B.I. Continue Search for Slayers of
description: ST. CROIX, V. I. Sept. 8The investigation into the slayings of eight persons at the Fountain. Valley Golf Club slowed today as the state and Federal authorities hunted for the armed black men who gunned down the victims on Wednesday.

title: EAGLES CONQUERED BY BILLS, 34 TO 17,
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 8 (AP)The Buffalo Bills struck for 24 points in the middle two periods tonight and recorded 3417 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in a preseason game.

title: And What Would Henry Thoreau Have Thought?
description: To the Editor: At the end of the article, Mr. Farkas wonders if the woodchuck's murderers truly appreciated the beauty of the day. I would wonder if Farkas ever questioned his moral responsibility in this matter. Surely Thoreau, whom the author apparently admires, would have acted differently. Assuming that he wanted to avoid a physical confrontation, could not Farkas have been more forceful in his verbal exchange with the workmen? At the very least, he could have chased the animal while the men were choosing their respective weapons.

title: After 112 Years, Store Makes Final Sale
description: YELLOW HOUSE, Pa.They auctioned off groceries by the bagful at The Yellow House last Monday. The general store here at the junction of rural routes 662 and 562 in the heart of Pennsylvania Dutch country is shutting down after 112 years.

title: Bridge: Many Errors Go Unpunished Because of Rivals Failure
description: On a strictly quantitative basis, errors are far more important in bridge than brilliancies. Most players do not realize how many errors they make, simply because many of them go unpunished. If the declarer makes a slip in dummy play, it may take a brilliant effort by the defense, to take advantage of the situation.

title: Bank Regulators Back Bill in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) The three Federal bankregulating agencies told Congress today that they prefer a Senatepassed bill giving them enforcement authority over banks acting as transfer or clearing agents, or depositories for securities.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Philippine Communist Movement Reported Growing
description: MANILA, Sept. 4Though still on a small scale, Communist activity in the Philippines has grown to the level where it produces incidents of violence every few days somewhere in the country.

title: Litton Industries Earnings Fell Sharply in Fiscal 72
description: Litton Industries, Inc., which has been one of the most spectacular of the nation's private industrial enterprises since its inception in November, 1953, experienced its sharpest setback in fiscal 1972, when profits plummeted to $1,118,000 from $50,003,000 in the preceding year ended July 31, 1971.

title: FOLK CITY RETAINS SOME OF ITS JAZZ Two Groups Excel With Opposite Approaches
description: Folk City, which became Jazz City during July while it switched to a jazz policy to tie in with the presence in town of the Newport Jazz Festival, has reverted to its original name but it has not entirely given up jazz. This week it is featuring two unusually good jazz groups, the Pat Martino Quartet and the Richard DavisClifford Jordan Quintet, which take almost diametrically opposed approaches to making music.

title: Stamps Offered for Safety
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 (AP)The Golden Gate Transi District, which transports Mar in County commuters to Sar Francisco and home again, is encouraging its bus operators to drive safely by offering then trading stamps. For even month that a driver operates without an accident he will be given 600 trading stamps.

title: REV. WILLIAM HAEGER
description: The Rev. William E. Haeger, pastor since 1948 of St. John's Lutheran Church, Lindenhurst, L.I., died Thursday in Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Lindenhurst.

title: Official Denies Any Drugs Were Given Chinese by U.S.
description: A Manhattan prosecutor denied yesterday charges that American agents had drugged a Chinese man convicted of trying to kill the son of Chiang Kaishek.

title: STOCKS END WEEK IN ANOTHER DROP
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange, which have been declining all week, dropped a little further yesterday. Declines outnumbered advances in continued slow trading.

title: Bank Acquisition Cleared
description: The Federal Reserve Board has approved the applications of Shorebank, Inc., of Quincy, Mass., to acquire indirectly the Mechanic National Bank of Worcester Mass., and to acquire directly the First Agricultural National Bank of Berkshire County, Pittsfield, Mass.

title: The Dance: Lively and Varied Fare
U.S. IS PROTESTING SOVIET EXIT TAXES
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 8The United States has lodged an official protest with the Soviet Union over the imposition of a high education tax against two persons seeking to emigrate to the United States, diplomatic sources disclosed today.

title: Uruguay Devalues Peso
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 8 (Reuters)The Uruguayan central bank said today it had devalued the peso. A communiqu from the bank set the rate for importexport transactions at 627 pesos per United States dollar to sell and 621 to buy. The financial rate Friday was 860 to sell and 855 to buy, while on the black market it was 1,000 pesos per United States dollar.

title: Red Sox Top Yanks, 42, to Hold Lead
PAUL D. GRAVES, 64, OF SUPREME COURT
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., Sept 3 (UPI)  New York State Supreme Court Justice Paul D. Graves of Gouverneur, N. Y., died yesterday at Methodist Hospital, where he had been patient since undergoing surgery Tuesday at the Mayo Clinic. He was 64 years old.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Clorox Company filed for a proposed public offering of 400,000 shares to be issued on conversion of its $10million of 7 per cent convertible subordinated notes by two institutions. Reynolds Securities, Inc., heads the underwriting group.

title: Rhode Island Revenue Up
description: PROVIDENCE, Sept. 8 (AP)State sales tax revenue exceeded estimates for the fourth straight month during August, with collections indicating that $20million more was spent in Rhodes Island last month on retail goods than during the same period in 1971. Finance officials said today that slightly more than $8 million was collected from the tax last month.

title: 4 Women Seek Jobs as Miners, And Man's World Is in Conflict
description: CLEVELAND, Va., Sept. 7 In the working creed of the underground coal miner, two of the most enduring beliefs are these: Women are bad luck in a mine, and a miner can always rely on his buddy in a time of crisis.

title: SHRIVER CRITICAL OF NIXON ON GOALS
U.S. Ship May Have Hit Mine Off North Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)  The first victim of the minefields placed around North Vietnam by United States Navy planes may have been a United Navy ship, a Pentagon spokesman indicated today.

title: Executive Changes
description: Alfred J. Moccia has been elected vice president and chief financial officer of the Sperry Rand Corporation.

title: U.S. Sets Up Intelligence Group to Combat Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 8 The Government announced the formation of an intelligence committee today to deter international political terrorism in cooperation with intelligence services of friendly foreign countries.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The revolution is on, but don't be alarmed. It's only in men's clothes, and the thrust is conservative. Elegance is what Alexander's called it in its fall showing of its men's wear collection yesterday and it's true there wasn't any fringe around. Nobody strolled out in a Bedouin robethe ethnic rage has subsided.

title: And What Would Henry Thoreau Have Thought?
description: To the Editor: I sat for a long time mulling over this story of brutality to a small creature and wondering what prompted Mr. Farkas to write

title: FLOOD VICTIMS SEEK JOBS BY ADVERTISING
description: LEWISTOWN, Pa., Sept. (UPI)More than 3,000 families whose income was wiped out by the tropical storm Agnes have placed their hopes on photograph and an advertising campaign.

title: Yellowstone Visits Rise
description: YELLOWSTONE PARK, Wyo., Sept. 8 (UPI)Park officials report that 3.5 per cent more people have visited Yellowstone this year than last year. The park announced yesterday that 1.9 million persons visited Yellowstone through August of this year, compared with 1.8 million through August of 1971. However, more than two million persons visited the park during the same period of 1970.

title: And What Would Henry Thoreau Have Thought?
description: To the Editor: What man would not at least have frightened the animal away with sound  a stone  something that would have given the animal a chance against the executioner?

title: SENATE DEFEATS TAX REFORM BID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8A group of Senate Democratic liberals was decisively beaten back today in an attempt to force President Nixon to take a preelection stand on tax reform.

title: Theme for Tools: Think Metric
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 8  An important theme emerges from the hundreds of exhibits of machine tools and the crowds at the 10day 1972 International Machine Tool Show here. It is: Think metric.

title: DR. HUGO R. RONY, 84, INTERNIST, IS DEAD
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 8  Dr. Hugo R. Rony, who retired several years ago as a specialist in internal medicine and a researcher in endocrinology and metabolism in Chicago, died today at his home here. He was 84 years old.

title: BEEF PRICES STAY UNCHANGED HERE
description: Despite pressure from the Cost of Living Council, which thinks retail beef prices are too high in relation to their wholesale prices, chain and independent food stores in the New York area are maintaining their prices for beef items.

title: NO LEADS APPEAR IN GIRL'S SLAYING
description: Groups of children played noisily yesterday in front of the building at 745 Riverside Drive, where an 11yearold girl was strangled and apparently sexually molested in her thirdfloor apartment Thursday.

title: FiveAct Opera by Bussotti Opens Festival in Venice
description: VENICE, Italy, Sept. 8Sylvano Bussotti's eagerly awaited fiveact opera Lorenzaccio opened the 35th international festival of contemporary music here last night.

title: I.R.A. Says Gifts From U.S. Dry Up In Wake of Terror
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 7 (AP)Sources close to the Irish Republican Army said today that American contributors have cut their donations drastically because they have been repelled by bombing in the last few weeks.

title: Miss Joan Pendleton Is Married
description: BRYN ATHYN, Pa., Sept. 8 Miss Joan Pendleton was married here this evening to Christopher Willoughby Lynch. The bride's father the Right Rev. Willard Dandridge Pendleton, Bishop of the Bryn Athyn Swedenborgian Cathedral (Church of the New Jerusalem), performed the ceremony in the cathedral, of which the late Raymond Pitcairn, the bride's grandfather, was the architect.

title: STOCK PRICES DIP ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Shares on the American Stock Exchange ended week as they began it, declining prices. The index to 26.46, down 0.03. In the thecounter market industrial shares were moving the way, with the N.A.S.D. index ending at 131.24, down 0.13.

title: Teacher Pact: A Victory for All
description: Late last Thursday night weary Board of Education negotiators met with two dozen representatives of the city's 31 decentralized community school boards.

title: Jim Ryun Falls and Fails to Qualify in 1,500
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 8 (AP)Jim Ryun's long, uphill climb to Munich to defend his reputation as the world's fastest miler ended today in the longest loneliest walk of his career.

title: Air Force Accused Of Raid CoverUp
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Senator William Proxmire made public a letter today from four Air Force intelligence sergeants who asserted that officers of the Seventh Air Force made a concerted effort early this year to cover up all traces of an accidental bombing of civilian targets in Cambodia.

title: New Outlook in Schools
description: The new teachers contract provides the first substantial evidence of the constructive role decentralization can play in improving the city's troubled school system.

title: 5 Arab Martyrs Mourned in Mosques, But Munich News Hasn't Stirred Cairo
description: 5 Arab Martyrs Mourned in Mosques,

CANAAN, Conn.  In recent years with the absurdities of the balanced ticket becoMing apparent a new method of choosing the VicePresidential candidate has come into being. The Presidential nominee designates his choice of a running mate for pro'forma approval of the convention. This practice in effect amounts in case of vacancy to selecting a President of the United States by appointment, a procedure flagrantly at odds with the republican spirit of the Constitution.

title: HEAD OF COLLEGE QUITS IN JERSEY
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 8  Thomas H. Richardson, president of Montclair State College since 1964, announced his resignation today in a protest over excessive central control of individual college policy by the State Board of Higher Education.

title: Bibby Scores 22 Points In Knick Intrasquad Game
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 8Led by the scoring of Henry Bibby, the No. 3 college draft choice from University of California, Los Angeles the Blue team defeated the Reds 122102, here today in an intrasquad game staged by the New York Knickerbockers. Bibby scored 22 points.

title: Defector Tells of Massacre by Enemy at Quangtri
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 8A defector from the North Vietnamese Army said today that his unit had gunned down civilian men, women and children and South Vietnamese soldiers without discrimination as they fled south from Quangtri City in late April and early May.

title: Freight Volume Increases
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 16.2 billion tonmiles, 6.2 per cent above the 1971 levels. Carloadings in the same week totaled 541,398, 2.8 per cent above last year's. The A.A.R. also reported both loadings and tonmiles reached weekly highs for the year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 2.8 per cent above last year.

title: Union at City University Says Negotiations Are at an Impasse
Woman Economist Backs PartTime Work
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 8A Federal Reserve economist counseled business today that by creating more parttime jobs it could recruit women of exceptional ability, reduce absenteeism, cut overtime costs and increase efficiency.

title: Bus Cuts Due in Connecticutl
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 9 (UPI)The Connecticut Company said yesterday that it plans to implement courtauthorized reductions in bus service on Sept. 16 in Hartford and New Haven. A ruling Wednesday in Hartford Common Pleas Court said the cutbacks were justifiable, and certified a decision of the Public Utilities Commission permitting the discontinuance of holiday and Sunday service and other changes.

title: All's Casual on McGovern Plane
description: DALLAS, Sept. 7There was no lettuce aboard Dakota Queen 2 when the chartered United Air Lines 727 jet lifted off the runway of Love Field here today, but there were plenty of martini makings and, to the relief of 57 of the 58 passengers, no signs of bologna sandwiches.

title: Pinch on Profits Seen
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. S (AP)  Alan Greenspan, the economist, said today American industry should expect lower profit margin over the next decade, but predicted profits would oe high enough to support investments and technological advances.

title: FAULKNER ATTACKED BY A MOB IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 8  Angry crowds attacked Northern Ireland's former Prime Minister Brian Faulkner, in the Protestant Shankill Road area of Belfast today during a protest against the killing of two men last night by British soldiers.

title: SOVIET SIX DOWNS TEAM CANADA, 53
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Sept. 8 (AP)Boris Mikhailov scored a pair of firstperiod powerplay goals and Ladislav Tretiak turned in some dazzling goaltending as the Soviet Union dominated Team Canada to score a 53 victory tonight.

title: Long Beach State Is Upset
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Sept. 9 (AP)  Larry Cates and Dave Myers scored two touchdowns each today to lead Western Michigan to a 2820 victory over the defending Pacific Coast Athletic Association champion, Long Beach State.

title: No Resting Place By Eugene Mirabelli. 243 pp. New York: Viking Press. $6.95.
description: The characters in No Resting Place all come from a genteel stratum of middleclass society. They are well educated, liberal, they all have good safe jobs, and they're all in their own way profoundly discontented. Marco, the central character is an editor in an academic publishing house. He has vague longings to escape the confines of the life he leads with his wife and three children. So he nurtures strange psychotic dreams and has an affair with his secretary. Afterward he rushes back home to confess to his wife.

title: Mailbox:
description: To The Editor:

title: STATE AIDE REPORTS RATS RESIST POISON
description: ALBANY, Sept. 9 (AP)Dr. Hollis S. Ingraham, state health chief, said yesterday that some rats in urban slum areas of at least eight Eastern cities had become immune to the poisons most widely used to control them.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe Federal Aviation Administration keeps a list of the 157 American planes that have been hijacked during the past decade and a record of what has become of the 211 persons involved.

title: The Nation
description: LOS ANGELES  Lorraine Egger sells candy for a living, belongs tounion and believes in the Democraticparty. But this year she might vote Republican. As she sat under a treeat the. Alameda County Labor Day picnic, surrounded by children and grandchildren, Mrs. Egger explained why:

title: New &NOVEL
description: What in hell had we done? an artist named Blane Peterson wonders, awakening in a strange motel in Texas. What he has done is to marry, on impulse, an inmate of the redlight district of Nuevo Laredo, then take her home to meet his American Gothic folks. Aunt Lona and Uncle Lem, on their farm near Des Moines; Cousin Jack and Cousin Carol, Dad and Mom, sister Alice and little brother Mike in Illinois.

title: GIRLS ADMITTED BY BOSTON LATIN
description: BOSTON, Sept. 9Marshall Gallagher and his five teammates stare proudly into the ancient hallways from the picture labeled: 1899 1900 Golf Champions. Ralph Waldo Emerson composed his first verse in one of these classrooms. Joseph P. Kennedy, the former ambassador and father of John, Robert. and Edward, played first base on the 1908 baseball team.

title: Ullman Accuses Nixon Aides Of Poor Policy on Forests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP)  Representative Al Ullman, Democrat of Oregon, accused the Nixon Administration today of poor leadership and lack of directions in national forest management.

title: The World
description: The modern Olympics were born, raised and promoted on nationalism and controversy. The founder, Pierre de Coubertin, hoped to stimulate French moral and physical comeback after the 1870 defeat in the FrancoPrussian War. His fifth set of Games, at London in 1908, became known as The Battle of Shepherds Bush to commemorate the charges of prejudiced officiating, improper equipment and professionalism. Americans and Swedes complained that their flags were not prominently displayed. Finns and Irishmen were sullen over being made to compete under the colors of Russia and Great Britain.

title: Mrs. Striver, in Indiana, Calls Administration Cold
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 9 (UPI) Mrs. Sargent Shriver, wife of Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, said today that the Nixon Administration had showed again and again that in matters of the human heart it simply did not care.

title: Caroline Richmond Wed To Peter Arpin Orgain
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 9Miss Caroline Heywood Richmond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Thacher Richmond, was married this afternoon to Peter Arpin Orgain, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Orgain of Hackettstown, N.J., and Chippewa Bay, N.Y.

title: PROXMIRE CHARGES PRICE DISTORTION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, accused the Administration today of distorting its latest report on wholesale prices to make President Nixon's antiinflation program look better.

title: ELECTION IS DUE IN NEW ZEALAND
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sept. 9New Zealand too has an election in November and the result is far from a foregone conclusion.

title: Pravda Discloses Stoppages in Bread Supply to a Region East of Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 9  The Communist party newspaper, Pravda, disclosed in an unusually frank report, today that there had been stoppages in bread supply to a number of towns in the Gorky Region, 250 miles east of Moscow.

title: Roots of Inequality
description: The American people chronically expect too much their schools. When society is in trouble, education asked to furnish the cure, instantly and without much cost in money or reform. These high hopes spring in part from an ingrained idealism; but they are also raised deliberately by those who want to avoid the hard questions involved in effective social, political and economic change.

title: This time the aim is different The return of the quota system
description: Who, these days, has a kind word to say for quotas? Not Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman New York City's Commission on Human Rights. Not J. Stanley Pottinger, head of the Office for Civil Rights of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. Not Ken Bode, lately director of the Center for Political Reform. Yet they, and others, are being accused of attempting to insinuate into their several areas of activity, quota systems based on race, sex, age and, by inference, on religion well.

title: U.S. Amateur Plans Match Play in 73
description: Talk of ??oif

title: Cities Adopt Tougher Lock Laws in Effort to Curb Burglaries
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 9Milton Washington arrived to open his service station recently and found his office door knob bashed in and the wood chipped around the door's dead bolt lock.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Designers call the tune in the nation's multibilliondollar fashion industry and, peculiarly enough, they all sing in harmony with each other, although each in his or her way may be indulging in individual phrasing. Most of the leading designers are artists in their craft, but their success depends on keeping an ear to the ground where they get similar drum beats, a feedback of what women want and will wear.

title: A Public Vote On Composers I Like Least
description: ONE of the enduring delusions of our mythspangled society is that a social scientist can ask people what they think ar4 people will tell him. T.n season of polls and polling, it helps to remember that primitive societies have always consulted oracles and entrails, and sometimes have acted as foolishly we do on the advice. Contrary to what one might gather from looking around at the world, we are probably not inherently any dumber than CroMagnon Man.

title: PENTAGON ASSAILS PROXMIRE ACTIONS
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 9The Pentagon took issue today with Senator William Proxmire. Democrat of Wisconsin, who yesterday made public a letter accusing Air Force officers of covering up the accidental bombing of civilian targets in Cambodia.

title: Gallant Knave Rallies From 9th in Backstretch to Win at Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 9 (AP)Arthur I. Appleton's Gallant Knave rallied from ninth in the backstretch to win by 1 lengths in the $29,775 World's Playground Stakes at Atlantic City today.

title: Aging Paper Mill Playhouse May Be Reborn as Arts Center.
description: MILLBURN  The Paper Mill Playhouse, an aged New Jersey institution, is hoping for a second childhood.

title: Buyers Renovating Homes Revive InnerCity Areas
description: TRENTONCan rundown, innercity streets in New Jersey be transformed into neighborhoods as attractive as Washington's Georgetown or Society Hill in Philadelphia?

title: 1943 O.S.S. Study Called Hitler Weak and a Bully
description: Late one night in October, 1943, a psychoanalyst in Boston stuffed a secret manuscript into his briefcase and boarded the Federal Express for Washington. He had just completed one of the more cerebral intelligence assignments of World War II: six months of probing the strange psyche of Hitler.

title: U.S.Soviet Deal on Grain Becomes Campaign Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The question of whether a few large grain companies reaped windfall profits from the grain deal between the United States and the Soviet Union evolved today into a Presidential campaign issue.

title: Reported Cases of Smallpox Rise 38% in World in 1972
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 9 (UPI)The National Center for Disease Control reported today a 38 per cent increase in the number of reported smallpox cases around the world.

title: Freedom is not happiness
description: The Politics of Authenticity appears to be written out of a commitment to rediscover the roots of radical liberalism, the origins of that search for a politics of personal value and selfrealization so intensely renewed in the past 10 yearsthe dream of an ideal community in which individuality will not be subsumed and sacrificed, but fully developed and expressed. From a perspective influenced by contemporary revisionist Marxism (Herbert Marcuse, R. D. Laing), Marshall Berman examines the tradition in Western political thought that insists on the primordial importance of the individual's existential freedom, his ability to expand the potential of selfhood, and on the need to make a society a medium for the full free growth of man. What he discovers in his path is mainly Rousseau, still the fountainhead of all we think of as peculiarly modern, the first consciousness we recognize as wholly ours.

title: City Gains in Securities Jobs, With 132% Rise From 195870
description: Despite recurring threats that the securities industry might leave the city, New York has not only held its share of jobs in the often spectacularly growing industry but has also shown moderate gains.

title: TIGERS THROTTLED BY GARDNER, LYLE
description: DETROIT, Sept. 9The New York Yankees tightened up the American League's Eastern Division pennant race again tonight by beating the Detroit Tigers, 31, before a crowd of 41,624 at Tiger Stadium in chilly weather.

title: Letters
description: Thomas Meehan's precious assessment of the Elks (The Other July Convention, Aug. 13) is another reminder of how much today's socially sensitized liberalism smacks of what is plainly a quite fascistic, elitist conceit parading as humanitarianism.

title: The World
description: ROMETo protest a Government decree freezing the retail price of food products, Rome's butchers and grocers shuttered their stores last Monday and Tuesday. Outdoor markets were deserted by hawkers. Police protected housewives lining up at the few supermarkets that had remained in business.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONBy a coincidence, two international reports were published last week that disclosed the great depth of disagreement among otherwise friendly nations on the organization of the world trading and monetary system.

title: D'Aulaires Trolls; By Ingri and Edgar Parin d'Aulaire. 62 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $5.95. (Ages 8 to 11)
description: There are children whose drawings of even the most ferocious monsters still reflect a quality of their own innocence and sweet temperament. The same is true of the artwork of the d'Aulaires. No matter how fierce their subjects, they can endow them with a kind of vulnerability that is both touching and  especially in the case of trollsridiculous. Seeing these great ugly creatures beset with problems related to health, hygiene and domestic tranquillity reduces their power to horrify considerably.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The National Rail Passenger Corporation has won a Federal court injunction ending a twomonth prohibition of liquor on its trains through Oklahoma.

title: BADILLO TO SEEK. M'GOVERN PARLEY
description: Representative Herman Badillo of the Bronx and other Spanishspeaking New York Democrats have decided to seek a meeting with Senator George McGovern to resolve financing problems in the city's voterregistration drive and what they ?? as inadequate hiring of Latins in the local campaign apparatus.

title: Don Juan as a blend of sex and history
description: Of all the discarded masks in the steamer trunk of cultural history, none seems less promising to wear or to meditate on than that of Don Juan. Every popular psychology book for years has minutely explained that under the Don's omnivorous sexuality lurks impotence and death, the objectification of human relations, and a childish ego forcing the world to make up for not being an extension of himself. Especially in 1972, when no one wants to be treated as an object, Don Juan would seem to be the archvillain, his sexual pride an index of his emptiness.

title: Does big business really do us any harmor good?; Economic Concentration; Structure, Behavior and Public Policy. By John M. Blair. 742 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.
description: Calvin Coolidge once remarked that the man who builds a factory builds a temple. But Americans have not always agreed, particularly when they had to pay the tithe. The New England merchants who chose the patriot side in the Revolution were less concerned with the rights of man than the tribute exacted by British trade monopolies. A century later impoverished Midwestern farmers rebelled against Eastern robber barons who in good years gouged them on railroad rates and when times were bad foreclosed on their mortgages. While few truly populist reforms were ever enacted, attempts to pacify antimonopolist sentiments left the nation with a tangle of regulatory commissions, alphabet agencies and antitrust laws officially intended to extract the common man from the of Mammon.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Two Gentlemen of Verona is thoroughly enjoyable: It has talented performers, good voices, good linesthey came from a fairly wellqualified writer.

title: Orioles Capture Pair From Brewers, 21 and 80, With Home Runs
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 9 (AP)Don Baylor and Dave Johnson hit home runs to back Doyle Alexander's twohit pitching as the Baltimore Orioles downed the Milwaukee Brewers, 80, to complete a sweep of a doubleheader tonight.

title: Future of the Fair Site Still Debated
description: On June 3, 1967, the city officially dedicated what was heralded as the Central Park of the 20th century.

title: LEHIGH TOPPLES HOFSTRA, 4413
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 9 Three Lehigh quarterbacks threw scoring passes today as the Engineers opened their football season with a 4413 rout of Hofstra before 7,200 spectators.

title: SUSAN'S GIRL, 31, BELDAME VICTOR
description: Susan's Girl flashed a thrilling stretch rally to beat the favored Summer Guest in the $112,800 Beldame at Belmont Park yesterday. Fred Hooper's fine Floridabred filly enjoyed the margin of a length over the Rokeby Stable's color bearer at the end of the 1mile test for fillies and mares 3 years old and up.

title: The World
description: SANTIAGOThe kids in clean blue jeans and blue blazers blocking late rush hour traffic last Wednesday morning in Santiago could have been massing for a high school pep rally or vacation trip. Two or three thousand strong, they chanted occasionally in tenor, alto and soprano voices. Stray dogs and women with trays of sugared doughnuts for sale made their way through the milling, gleeful crowd.

title: Dead Whale Removed
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass., Sept. 9 (AP)  A dead whale that floated up on the beach at Mussel Point was towed back to sea today, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: IN THE NATION
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Sept. 9  The end of a vacation is a time to realize that you have not done the things you had planned to do. Packing the bags, loading the car, cleaning the rented house these familiar chores do not consume enough time or energy to blot out the sense of missed moments, lapsed opportunities, of the curtain coming down long before the play should have ended.

title: This Lab May Have Tested the Miracle Drug You Used
description: MAPLEWOOD  If you have benefited from some of the socalled miracle drugs or from medical technology, the chances are that a team of pharmacologists and technicians working in this Essex County suburb has had hand in your wellbeing.

title: MOOD OF WORKERS IN BRITAIN DIVIDED
description: BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 9 Delegates to the weeklong annual congress of Britain's trade unions began drifting homeward from this seaside resort city today in an ambiguous mood that combined unabated anger against the Conservative Government with a readiness to continue talks with Prime Minister Heath to work out an antiinflation policy.

title: The dirty thirty at large in the Texas State House
description: If the Democratic nominee for Governor of Texas, Dolph Briscoe, appeared to be a trifle petulant at the national Democratic convention at Miami Beach last month, he had reason. The woman he beat for the nomination, Mrs. Frances (Sissy) Farenthold, became the darling of the convention and constantly upstaged him. While Mr. Briscoe was reduced to reporting the fragmented Texas vote on roll calls, Sissy was being consulted on the platform, was helping plan strategy, and in the end getting the second largest number of votes for nomination for Vice President. She became a symbol of the spirit of reform which is abroad the United states.

title: Robinson Endorses Peace
description: MUNICH, West Germany. Sept. 9 (Agence FrancePresse) Arnie Robinson, bronze medalist in the men's long jump at the Olympics today, wore an anti Vietnam War armband when he stepped up to receive his medal. The United States jumper's track suit carried an emblem of three bombs with a red line through them, a symbol seen on several United States track suits at the Games.

title: Schools Open Smoothly With Disputed Busing Plan
description: MONTCLAIR  A controversial reorganization of schools in this Essex County town that includes formation of socalled lowerschool clusters and three middle schools, as well as the busing of 1,714 of the 7,500 pupils in the school system went into effect smoothly last week despite earlier instances of community friction.

title: Tennessee Strikes for 28 Points in 2d Half and Defeats Georgia Tech, 343
MISS DAVIS HAILS SOVIET'S POLICIES
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 9Angela Davis, the American black militant and Communist, has been given the keys to the ancient city of Samarkand and been made an honorary professor of Moscow University on a triumphal tour of the Soviet Union since her arrival here two weeks ago.

title: The Last Word
description: Finishing one of the latest books on rock musican interesting diversion if your stereo speakers are not functioning and you're curious about what is supposed to be happening in pop and counterpop cultureI was left with the definite sense that something was askew. I mean, I dig the music, I know a Beetle from a Stone, a Zircon from a Diamond, or for that matter an Impression from a Main Ingredient. But it seemed to me that the book I'd finished had little to do with the output of my F.M. radio, so began browsing through some of the recent rock books, among them: R. Meltzer's Aesthetics of Rock (Straight Arrow), Carl Belz's The Story of Rock (Oxford), Michael Lydon's Folk Rock (Dial), David Dalton's Janis (Simon & Schuster), Jon Landau's It's Too Late to Stop Now (Straight Arrow), and Jonathan Eisen's Age of Rock, 1 and 2 (Random). That convinced me that someone should take exception to the fifties proverb, Don't knock the rock, at least as

title: For a casual evening (that's kind of special); Slip into a slinky, slithery, sexy long jersey
description: When the occasion is too special for pants, but not quite special enough for a ballgown, slip into a long, slithery jersey dress with a casual air or a gray flannel jumper with a pale jersey blouse or a slink of white with its own builtin sweater or... There are variations on this fall's casual, longskirted theme to suit every tasteand every figure.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: Having returned from a vacation in Israel and Greece, I would like to allude to a disconcerting experience which occurred on arrival at Athens International Airport last month. Before departure from the United States, I was informed by the Automobile Club of New York, Trans World Airlines and the United Nations World Health Organization that certification of having been inoculated for smallpox was not necessary for travelers entering the two countries on my itinerary. However, at the passport control center at the Athens airport, 15 other passengers and myself had our passports confiscated, since we failed to produce documentation of a recent smallpox vaccination. Our pleas to the officials proved to no avail. After a considerable wait we were rudely led to the airport's health station where, like cattle, we were each given a smallpox vaccination. I was delayed in the airport for three hours, necessitating the cancella tion of a reservation I had for a threeday cruise of the Greek Islands commencing that evening. Subsequently experienced considerable discomfort and swelling as a result of the vaccination, and, therefore, for fear of further complications, decided to terminate my vacation and return home.

title: National Campaign Chief For Shriver Is Appointed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) Lee C. White, 49 years old, a Washington lawyer and former Presidential special counsel, was named today as national campaign manager for the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, Sargent Shriver.

title: Education
description: The opening of the new school year and of the official phase of the Presidential election campaign has put the spotlight on the busing controversy in the education debate. But paradoxically, though the issue has been prominent for many months, there seemed little indication last week that there would be significantly more busing this year than last. There may even be lessSan Francisco and Nashville are trying to reduce busing.

title: New &NOVEL;A Marriage Of Convenience By Elizabeth Rossiter. 255 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $6.95.
description: When Janey Carter marries Matthew Neal, they feel the brunt of Murphy's Law. (If anything can go wrong, it will.) Both parties have been recently widowed, and between them they have five children to add instant stress to the marriage bonds. The breaking point seems near when Paula, Matthew's exmotherinlaw, comes to live with them. And it seems even nearer when Maggie, Paula's sisterinlaw, settles in.

title: Mrs. Irving Out of Detention As Swiss Inquiry Continues
description: ZURICH, Sept. 9 (Reuters)Mrs. Edith Irving, Swiss wife of Clifford Irving, was released from preventive detention here last night on condition that she did not leave Switzerland, the District Attorney's office said today.

title: ALEX R. GRYLACK
description: PATERSON, N. J., Sept. 9Alex R. Grylack, a lawyer and business figure here for the last 30 years, died today of a heart ailment at Barnert Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived here.

title: Jennifer Beard Is Bride of Lawyer
description: NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Sept. 9In the Unitarian Church of Newburyport this afternoon, Miss Jennifer Beard, daughter of Mrs. Dorothy Plumer Beard of New York and Newburyport, and Francis D. Beard of Jacksonville, Fla., was married to Vincent Mills Badger. son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Bradford Badger of Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Burt Steeves, assisted by the Rev. Raymond Webster.

title: SOVIET FIVE TOPS U.S. IN OLYMPICS
description: United States supremacy in Olympic basketball was ended early today at Munich, West Germany, when the Soviet Union scored on a disputed basket and took the gold medal with a 5150 victory.

title: Salinger Charges Nixon Manipulates U.S. News Media
description: BOLTON LANDING. N.Y., Sept 9 (AP)Pierre Salinger, cochairman of Citizens for McGovernShriver, charged today that the Nixon Administration has been manipulating the news media.

title: Gardens
description: SOMEWHERE in southern Asia, early man first popped a stem of sugar cane into his mouth and found it pleasant to chew. Thus began man's sweet tooth, In the United States we cat our body weight in sugar per year.

title: Hearing Urged on Charges Of Sex Bias in Little League
description: NEWARK, Sept. 9 (AP)The New Jersey Division on Civil Rights recommended yesterday that a public hearing be held on charges of sex discrimination filed against Little League Baseball, Inc. by the Essex County chapter of the National Organization for Women.

title: Money in Short Supply for L.I. Schools
description: Money is very much on the minds of Long Island school board members and educators as they begin a new academic year, a year featuring heavily trimmed budgets and fewer new programs than usual.

title: Descendants Sell Off Last Remnants Of Old Homestead on Fireplace Road
description: THE SPRINGS, L. I. ,It's a genuine threecornered hat. The kind they wore during the Revolution. Who'll start at $10? One? Two? Three? Four? Five? Six? Who'll give me seven? Six? Going once, twice. Gone at six.

title: WHITE DAWN WINS PACE AT YONKERS
description: YONKERS, Sept. 9Arthur Hult, a 31yearold reinsman who visits this area only occasionally, rarely fails to make a strong impression on local harness racing fans.

title: Miss Haslarn Has Wedding
description: Miss Deborah Page Haslam, an officer of the First National City Bank of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Eric Walker Peniston Jr., a vice president of real estate and insurance firm of Cushman & Wakefield, Inc.

title: DETECTIVE HELPS FRESH AIR CAMP
description: Many changes can be seen in the Fresh Air Fund's summer camps and even in the underprivileged city children who attend them, according to a police detective who was once a camp counselor and who returned this summer to work with children again.

title: Brian Carty Weds Miss Mary McGrath
description: EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Sept. 9Miss Mary Virginia McGrath, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John F. McGrath of Pleasantuille, N.Y., was married here this afternoon to Brian Thomas Carty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Carty of Belmont. The Rev. Salvatore Matarazzo performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Russell Sage Chapel of the Northfield School.

title: Bridge
description: It is somewhat surprising that artists and architects rarely make good bridge players, since bidding sometimes requires paintingin technical senseand an effort of creative imagination to react correctly to partner's artistic performance.

title: Pair Charged in Murder of Eight in Virgin Islands
description: ST. CROIX, V.I., Sept. 9The police tonight charged two men already in custody with the murder of eight persons earlier in the week at the Fountain Valley Golf Club owned by Laurance S. Rockefeller.

title: Rough Tunnel Trip Is Getting Smoother
description: WEEHAWKENSince the start of August, commuters and others riding through the center tube of the Lincoln Tunnel may have thought they were riding on a graveled country road, for the going became a little bouncy.

title: A Lawyer Is Ousted at a Hearing On Station's Bid to Keep License
description: PUYALLUP, Wash., Sept. 9A small radio station of conservative viewpoint, fighting to retain its license, suffered a setback yesterday When its lawyer was ejected from a hearing.

title: Mrs. Don Orton Has Son
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 9A son was born Aug. 29 to Dr. and Mrs. Don A. Orton at the Boston LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Orton is the former Miss Leslie Ellen Feuer of Teaneck. N.J. Her husband is president of Lesley College here. Their child has been named Andrew Jason.

title: Daniel Salvatore Jr. Marries Pamela Clark
description: CORNWALL, N. Y., Sept. 9Miss Pamela Clark, daughter of Lieut. Col. Chester H. Clark, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Clark of Tampa, Fla., was married here today in St. John's Episcopal Church to Daniel Anthony Salvatore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore of Carmel. The Rev. Robert Butt performed the ceremony.

title: A New Fire Truck Arrives In. Freeport: Color It Green
description: FREEPORT, L.L.After an eightyear wait, the citizens of Freeport are finally getting a look at the village's controversial new $112,000 fire engine. Contrary to their expeotations, they aren't seeing red. It's more like chartreuse.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: The article about San Miguel left us nodding in agreement and a little shaken, While living as a family on the Mexican island of Cozumel, we watched the native boys ogle the American tourist girls (often braless) and serve tourists paying $50 a day for a room at the El Presidente Hotel while the boys parents were probably earning 80 cents a week on the mainland or in the roadless interior of the island. Mexicans, with some exceptions, are gentle, kind, generous and filled with selfpride. The exceptions appear most often in those who serve the tourist. If United States citizens traveling south of the border would be sure to pack their manners, fewer dollars and a sense of humility along with their clothes, perhaps the Mexicans would not feel toward us what they do, and events such as those described in the article might

title: KANSAS BEATEN BY WASH. STATE
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 91 (UPI)Washington State, thoroughly beaten for three quarters, scored all its points in the last period today to defeat Kansas, 1817. A twopoint conversion by Ty Paine with 1:39 left was the decisive score.

title: Russians Dominate Kayaks
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 9 (UPI)The Soviet Union put on an awesome display of power and rhythm today to win six of seven Olympic gold medals in canoe and kayak racing. In the men's Canadian canoe singles the gold medal went to Ivan Patzaichin of Rumania. No country before had won more than three gold medals in the finals.

title: REV. DR. HENRY J. WAHL
description: The Rev. Dr. Henry J. Wahl who retired from the ministry in 1958 after 40 years as pastor of the Second Reformed Church of Flatbush, Brooklyn, died Thursday at a nursing home in Syosett, L.I. He was 97 years old.

title: How now, Dick Daring?
description: The aging Irving Thalberg Building looks like a branch bank that might have been built by the W.P.A. among the tacky Edward Hopper storefronts and withered palms of Culver City, Calif., an unfashionable suburb of Los Angeles. But the building, the production office and since 1969 the corporate headquarters of MetroGoldwynMayer, Inc., was a good deal more splendid the first time Jim Aubrey saw it.

title: The Tarnishing of Reynolds Aluminum
description: We abandon the chilly caverns of caution. If we are missing you will find our bones out yonder in the sun with our arms outstretched toward the great tomorrow.

title: Spock to Get Protection
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The Treasury Department announced today that Dr. Benjamin SpoCk, Presidential candidate of the People's party, has accepted an offer of Secret Service protection.

title: G. C. Thayer Weds Carol L. Edgerton
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Miss Carol Lytle Edgerton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Edgerton, was married here this afternoon to George Chapman Thayer Jr., son of Mrs. Franklin H. Nicholas of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Mr. Thayer, who was a partner in Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Beane in Philadelphia.

title: Lieut. Gen. George Simler Killed In Jet Crash at Texas Air Base
description: RANDOLPH AIR FORCE BASE, Tex., Sept. 9Lieut. Gen. George B. Simler, the outgoing commander of the Air Force's Air Training Command, was killed today when his T38 jet trainer crashed and burned. He was 51 years old.

title: Voting Splits a P.O.W.'s Family
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 9 (UPI)Rob Risner was 17 years old when his father, a hero of both the Korean and Vietnamese wars, leaped from a flaming fighterbomber into Communist hands.

title: The World
description: JERUSALEMEven before the full dimensions of the Munich massacre became clear, many Israelis had begun to consider how and in what measure Israel should take her revenge.

title: Music: Garden State Bluegrass Festival Survives
description: BRICK TOWN  The Garden State Bluegrass Festival, which has been an annual event for the last four years, appeared to be about to lose out this year. But last weekend, Jim Murphy, the originator, producer, MC and parttime performer on the festival, arranged to sneak in the fifth annual festival on what must be the tag end of outdoor music season in New Jersey  Oct. 29.

title: Bermudians in Cricket Lead
description: A United States cricket team, replying yesterday to Bermuda's 238 runs for nine wickets declared on Friday, was dismissed for 143 on the second day of the threeday match at Walker Park, Staten Island. Then Bermuda in its second innings scored 149 for seven.

title: Fiction: Irony, elitism, Babbitt updated, Africa, civil rights
description: The writer of the following reviews lectures at Princeton University on contemporary Third World literature and is the author of Black Midas.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I now know that Gene Thornton's reviews have nothing to do with photographic impact or artistic judgment. I took his critical review literally and almost missed the David D. Duncan show at the Whitney. Fortunately, your mailbag made me curious enough to step off the Whitney elevator into an exhibition of visual excitementa stunning display of black and white and color blowups.

title: Sara Jane Feakins Bride in Brussels
description: Miss Sara Jane Feakins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hayes Feakins of New Vernon, N. J., was married in the Roman Catholic Church of Notre Dame de l'Annonciation in Brussels yesterday to Xavier Jean Monteil, son of Col. and Mrs. Henri Rene Monteil of Paris and Brussels.

title: Dean of Mayors, 78, Plans Others Fall Races
description: UNION, N. J.At an age when many of his surviving contemporaries are content merely to be alive, F. Edward Biertuempfel, the 78yearold Mayor of this township, is spending his summer planning the fall campaign for local Republicans.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WHARTON A boomtown during the 1800's, when ore was mined and iron manufactured in Morris County, this industrial borough is today well into another cycle of growth. Wharton's population remained constant from 1930 to 1950about 3,800 residents. Today there are 6,000 people, a housing development and an apartment house. And a new shopping center is in the offing.

title: SEAT BELTS URGED FOR THE PREGNANT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Pregnant women should wear seat belts in automobiles, according to a new study by the American Medical Association's Committee on Medical Aspects of Automotive Safety.

title: MUMMY REMOVED FROM PUBLIC VIEW
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. After being displayed for years in a glass case in the garage of a funeral home in Laurinburg, about 100 miles east of here, the embalmed body of an Italian carnival worker has been removed from public view.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Michael Feingold, in his review of the American Shakespeare Festival production. of Shaw's Major Barbara, remarks that this Dlay has not been seen professionally La this area for 15 years.

title: First Front Wins Mile Pace With 1:59 at Freehold
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 9For the second time during the Freehold Raceway meeting the sub2minute mile was turned in when First Front, owned by Michel Bisson and Marquis Lafleur of Buckingham, Quebec, won the $10,000 Guttenberg Pace in 1:59 3/5. Driven by Denis Filion, First Front was up on the outside to win by half a length.

title: Gardens
description: THIS summer 26 garden plots on private land in Toronto were tilled, planted, water, weeded and harvested by tenants of nearby high rises. To the north and east of this metropolitan area of 2 million people, other city dwellers rented plots of land which they visited and tended on weekends.

title: Consumer Advocate Named For U.S. Postal Service
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) Thomas W. Chadwick, longtime postal official and former South Carolina newspaperman, has been named consumer advocate of the United States Postal Service.

title: The World
description: Let us export oarsmen, runners, fencers; there is the free trade of the futureand on the day when it shall take place among the customs of Europe, the cause of peace will have received a new and powerful support.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: In an article entitled Lights Out by Ada Louise Huxtable the Shell Oil Building in Houston is cited as an example of ignorance or arrogance as regards dwindling resources, wood being one of those cited. Since our firm was the primary supplier of both the woods mentioned, I would like to present a more balanced picture.

title: LEGENDARY PEACE DEFEATS JUMPERS
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 9 Frank Andrea's Legendary Peace won his first open jumpier class at the North Shore horse show today in a tense contest with three other speedy mounts.

title: Caribair Workers Back Sale of Airline
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 9About 600 employes of Caribair, a Puerto Rican airline, have appealed to President Nixon to override a Civil Aeronautics Board decision blocking the sale of the airline to Eastern Air Lines.

title: Miss Griswold, Gibbs Alumna, Wed
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 9Miss Pamela Post Griswold, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Henry Feuerborn of Carmel, Calif., and Henry Bridgman Griswold of Greenwich, was married here this afternoon to Langdon Payne Clarke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Warner Clarke Jr. of Greenwich. The ceremony was performed in the Round Hill Community Church by the Rev. Dr. Jesse Thomas.

title: Anne Trafford Has Nuptials
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., Sept. 9Miss Anne Trafford and Peter Ellis Gordy were married here this afternoon in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Arthur W. Hargate.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The headline, A Sort of Monastic Supermarket, on your article about the monastery called New Skete in Cambridge, N. Y., was misleading. It tended to emphasize the commercial aspects of our existence and ignore the real reason we are up on this mountain. The Brothers of Sl. Francis here are not monastic checkout girls. We are small contemplative community with small variety of quality meats, icons and German Shepherd dogs. Calling us a supermarket gave people the wrong impression; they are even disappointed when they do not find pushcarts and crowded aisles. Thanks for the cover. age, at any rate!

title: MADISON AVE.
description: If the future of the business lies in multinational marketing then Don Johnston of the J. Walter Thompson Company is truly the right man in the right place at the right time.

title: South African Reports A Rescue by Dolphins
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 9  A 23yearold South African woman, who swam for 25 miles in the sharkinfested Indian Ocean after a shipwreck off Lourenco Marques, MOzambique, says that she owes her life to two dolphins.

title: Only Jet, $13, Wins
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Sept. 8 (AP)Only Jet, a 2yearold hay colt, covered six furlongs in 1:13 4/5 today to win the 10th running of the New York Breeders Futurity at Finger Lakes Race Track.

title: Gen. Davis Sees Gains In Fighting Hijackers
description: GROTON, Conn., Sept. 9 (AP)  The United States is winning the battle against plane hijackers and aerial extortionists, according to the nation's director of civil aviation security, Benjamin O. Davis Jr.

title: TOKYO PREPARES FOR TANAKA TRIP
description: TOKYO, Sept. 6Preparations for Premier Kakuei Tanaka's visit to China moved ahead today as an airliner left here for Peking carrying television technicians, legislators, airline officials, a medical team, two chimpanzees and a pair of black swans.

title: Hearings Scheduled By City Council Units
description: Following are hearings scheduled for this week by City Council committees:

title: Son to Mrs. Grant. Jr.
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Grant Jr. of Cedarhurst, L.I., on Aug. 22 at the LyingIn Hospital. The child has been named Michael. Donald 3d. Mrs. Grant is the former Miss Elizabeth Lawall, daughter of Frederick Lawall of New York and the late Mrs. Lawall. M. Donald Grant, chairman of the board of the New York Mets baseball club, and Mrs. Grant are the paternal grandparents.

title: COLORADO DOWNS CALIFORNIA, 2010
description: BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 9 (UPI)Ed Shoen, a linebacker, ran 48 yards with an interception midway through the third quarter today to pace sluggish Colorado to a 2010 victory over California.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: T. D. Allman, author of the article about the Ngorongoro Crater in Tanzania (Travel section, Aug. 6) is misinformed about the use of African elephants in warfare. The overwhelming evidence is that both the Carthaginians and the Ptolemaic rulers of Egypt used African elephants for war, since the Seleucid Empire controlled the supply of Indian elephants. The Egyptians got theirs from Eritrea and the Sudan; the Carthaginians from the now extinct Moroccan race of the African elephant. Of the 36 elephants that Hannibal brought over the Alps, one is thought to have been Asiatic, the rest African. The article said he used Indian elephants.

title: First Rutgers Coeds Arrive
description: NEW BRUNSWICKMorris Selzer sat down and said: When I went to school in Czechoslovakia some years ago, you had to walk a mile to see a woman; now look what you've got.

title: Cynthia Ratsey Attended by 5 At Rye Bridal
description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 9Miss Cynthia Ratsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Colin Ernest Ratsey, was married this afternoon to Thomas Flynn Young Jr., son of Mr. Young of Islip, L. I., and Mrs. Wilton H. Marvin of Hampton Bays, L. I.

title: All that's left of grandmother's place
description: For three generations the Hendrick family had summered in the Hamptons, ever since 1902, when grandmother's big house, with its caretaker's cottage and carriage house, was completed. But, as is often the way with big estates, the large house was sold. And the carriage house, inherited by grandsons Arthur and Robin, had become a storehouse for castoff furniture. The tumble of furniture in the before picture (top left) is exactly what confronted designer Dick Ridge, who had been asked by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hendrick to reclaim the picturesque building (top of opposite page). Searching through the accumulation, Ridge found many usable pieces. Lamps were the only new things we had to buy, he reports. Chairs were freshened with paint and bright cotton prints and plaids. The walls were painted chocolate, the ceilings white and the exposed pipes were boxed in. Sanding the wide oak floor boards brought out a glorious honey color that underscored the new yellow, white and brown scheme. The Hendricks added a kitchen, which opens onto a new terrace. And the Hamptons are once again a summer

title: Sarah W. Davis Becomes Bride Of Francis Geer
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 9 Miss Sarah Whitney Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Shippen Davis Jr. of Shrewsbury, N. J., and Plymouth, was married here this afternoon to Francis Hartley Geer. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis George Geer of New York and Rumson, N. J.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: In a recent photography column A. D. Coleman asked rather pointedly why the new, younger generation of photographers has not had a fair showing at the photographic galleries in New York City. This question, coming from Coleman, seems very odd indeed. Many of the photographic galleries have made a point of showing the work of exciting new photographers.

title: Jersey Nuptials For Miss Early
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Sept. 9Miss Elizabeth Collins Early, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Early of Madison, was married here this afternoon to David Henry Mortlock Jr., son of Mr. Mortlock of New York and Quogue, L. I., and the late Mrs. Margery Boyce Mortlock. The Rev. S. Hughes Garvin performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: Observatory at Union College Lets the Public See Into Space
description: CRANFORDFor a number of years now, we've been getting a close look at disstant space through the television cameras of astronauts. And for years before this, planetariums reproduced, on domed screens, the full range of galaxies and constellations known to the scientific world.

title: Anniversary of Prison Riot Passes Unnoticed in Attica
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 9This quiet village took no public notice of the first anniversary today of the outbreak of last year's fiveday riot that resulted in 43 deaths at the tSate Correctional Facility.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I am left wondering whether the brilliantly written article on the Elks by Thomas Meehan (The other July convention, Aug. 13) doesn't reveal their simplicity and lack of sophistication rather than the bigotry Mr. Meehan emphasizes.

title: RUSSIANS REPORT ROCKS ON VENUS ARE LIKE EARTH'S;Says Spacecraft Also Found Dome Sunlight Penetrates Planet'Dense Clouds
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 9The Soviet spacecraft that reached Venus in July found that the planei s surface resembles the earth's granitic rocks and that some sunlight does penetrate through the dense cloud cover to the surface.

title: Mrs. Vest Has Daughter
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Vest on Aug. 25 at the New York LyingIn Hospital.

title: Evidence Found That Fluoride Is Vital Element in Diet of Mice
description: Scientists at the University of Minnesota have found evidence that fluoride, the controversial chemical that some groups oppose as an additive to water to prevent tooth decay, is an essential trace element in the diet of mice.

title: The Polygamist By Ndabaningi Sithole. 178 pp. New York: The Third Press. $6.95.
description: Sithole's novel reminds one of Camara Laye's The Dark Child. Both of these essentially autobiographical first novels reveal through austere prose some of the inner tensions, the ritual and the magic that still survived in African tribal life as their central characters set out on journeys into the mid20th century. Sithole, who comes from Zimbabwe (Rhodesia), writes in English, while Laye, a Guinean, wrote in French. The Polygamist and The Dark Child also differ in content and style. Laye's novel about an idyllic childhood and youth comes as close to perfection as any writer can hope to get; while Sithole uses dialogue brilliantly, the descriptions, at the beginning of the novel, border

title: ALABAMBA DEFEATS DUKE ELEVEN, 3512
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 9 (AP)  Terry Davis and Paul Spivey led Alabama to a 35.12 victory over Duke tonight in the opening football game for both schools.

title: Rene Leibowitz 191372
description: COMPOSER and conductor Rene Leibowitz, who died in Paris on August 28 at the age of 59, remained virtually unknown to all but a small circle of now middleaged composers. Yet he left an indelible Mark on 20thcentury music: Leibowitz is the man who revived 12tone writing in postwar Europe, where it had gone underground during Hitler's war on decadent art.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Of all the people to defend DDT, the president of the Montrose Chemical Company is hardly the most unbiased critic; and his essay is a distressing example of smooth and misleading statements.

title: Maryland Rallies to Tie N. Carolina State, 2424
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 9 (AP) Maryland's Terps, behind 2410 in the third period, roared back on the running of Louis Carter and the passing of Al Neville to gain a 2424 tie with North Carolina State in an Atlantic Coast Conference football game tonight.

title: Effort to Save Barnegat Bay Will Pit Rock Against Sea
description: WARETOWNA project under way offshore of this small settlement on Waretown Creek is fighting the slow but inexorable effort by nature that would fill in much of Barnegat Bay.

title: HANOI NEGOTIATOR ARRIVES IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 9Le Duct Tho, North Vietnam's chief negotiator in a series of secret talks with Henry A. Kissinger, flew into Moscow tonight on the eve of Mr. Kissinger's scheduled arrival here for talks with Soviet leaders.

title: Talented Children Have a Place to Play
description: RIDGEWOODA group of 5yearolds examines different rocks to determine which is hardest and which is shiniest; 8yearolds divide into teams to play tictactoe with coordinate geometry  using negative and positive numbers, they plot their position on a grid, trying to prevent the other team from lining up three numbers while doing so themselves.

title: GIANTS BEAT REDS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 (UPI)  Dave Kingman hit a tworun homer with one out in the ninth inning today to give the San Francisco Giants a 21 victory over Don Gullett and the Cincinnati Reds.

title: W. T. Thompson Weds Sally Richardson
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Sept. 9 The marriage of Miss Sally Payson Richardson to William Thomas Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Thompson of Menlo Park, Calif., took place here this afternoon. The Rev. James E. Annand performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Payson Richardson of Greenwich and the late David Rait Richardson Jr.

title: Science/ Medicine
description: Activated charcoal is an odorless, fine black powder. When mixed in water it turns into a tasteless soup. In recent years this substance has been hailed by some physicians as the most valuable single antidote and home remedy against poisons and drug overdoses that one could put into medicine cabinet.

title: No Free Lunch
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Neither candidate in this campaign has yet addressed himself to the environmental issue. That is not surprising inasmuch as the 1968 campaign also passed without any of the candidates devoting speech to this critical concern.

title: Former Chomsky Disciples Hurl Harsh Words at the Master
description: Sigmund Freud revolutionized understanding of the unconscious and founded the psychoanalytic movement. But then disciples, many of them professing loyalty to his insights, founded rival schools.

title: Oil Negotiations in Lebanon Recess for Computer Study
description: BELT MERI, Lebanon. Sept. 91 (AP)  International oil talks here were adjourned today until the middle of next week to permit experts to conduct computer studies of some of the issues involved, a spokesman for 10 Western oil companies announced.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I appreciate Peter Schjeldahi's review of my piece, INTROSPECTION I. EVOLUTION", which he calls an eyepopper in his article on the Outsized Drawings and Multiples show at New York University. Unfortunately he misquotes me when referringto a section called RELATIONS, thus changing con, siderably the meaning of this philosophical investigation.

title: Warren County Incomes Low for Area
description: On the fringe of the northeastern New Jersey metropolitan area, Warren County, still nearly halfrural, ranks in the lower half of New Jersey's counties in family income.

title: Alice Thayer Bruchhausen Married
description: WHITEFIELD, N. H., Sept. 9Miss Alice Thayer Bruchhausen and Robert Maynard Schenck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Maynard Schenck of Brooklyn, New York, were married this afternoon in the Whitefield Community Baptist Church by the Rev. Dr. Harry H. Kruener.

title: The World
description: OTTAWAThe comely young Ottawa housewife was atwitter with anticipation. She was about to meet Pierre Elliott Trudeau, Canada's swinging Prime Minister, a man whose picture, she blushed to admit, was pasted to her refrigerator door, for inspiration.

title: Hungary Wins Fencing
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 9The defending champion, Hungary, won the Olympic gold medal for team epee fencing tonight by defeating underdog Switzerland, 84. Dr. Csaba Fenyvesi, the Olympic gold medalist in individual epee, scored two victories.

title: The World;I.R.A.:
description: LONDONMaria McGuire, a dark, slightly built, 24yearold graduate, of University College, Dublin, for some time had been the most prominent female member of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army. She attained this status even though she held no important post in the Provisional? command structure, apart from a brief stint as publicity director for Sinn Fein, the I.R.A. political wing in Dublin.

title: Home Improvement
