description: HOME craftsmen and rabbyists who enjoy wuo:"..og with Plexiglas, the acrylic plastic that conies in sheets cit. various sizes and thicknesses, and that is now widely available in lumber yards, hardware, paint and department stores, should find that constructing a small table like the one illustrated here will prove to be an interesting and worthwhile project that can he easily completed in a few evenings. Only simple hand tools that even an apartment dweller would normally have available are required. The finished table can be used as a night. table, as an end table next to a sofa or chair, or as an occasional table that will also serve to support a record player, radio or small television set.

title: JETS, CHARGERS END IN 2020 TIE
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 9Bob Davis, Joe Namath's understudy, fired up the New York Jets in the final minute and a half tonight to lead the New Yorkers to a 20.20 tie with the San Diego ChargerS. Bobby Howfield's 33yard field goal with seven seconds left produced the tie.

title: Arabs Mourn Dead in a Bombed Village
description: RAFID. Lebanon, Sept. 9A visit early this morning to this hillside town in southern Lebanon, one of the targets of Israeli jets in raids yesterday, found women wailing in the Moslem fashion for their dead while the men, including many from neighboring villages, dug in the wreckage in search of the missing.

title: PERIL TO BEACHES FEARED IN TEXAS
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Sept. 9Several years ago, an attorney for a concessionaire seeking a permit to build a stand on a beach here had a novel way of trying to skirt the Texas law that guarantees the public's unrestricted access to the seashore.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The unrestricted and unregulated growth of travel agencies in the United States calls for the establishment of a national licensing board to set and maintain standards of service and ethics, similar to the Federal Trade Commission or the Securities and Exchange Commission. Reputable agents belong to the American Society of Travel Agents, a selfpolicing society. Countless others operate on individual inclination, as tales of luckles clients attest,

title: $14,632 Median Income Found in Nassau County
description: in 1970, nearly half of NasSau County's 360.000 famiues had an annual income exceeding $03,000, the best record by far of any connty in the tristate metropolitan

title: Roberto (Baeza) Will Race Against Hard To Beat (Piggot) Today
description: PARIS, Sept. 9For students of classic racing form, breeding and jockeymanship, the $45,000 Prix Neil, to be run over a mile and three eights at Longchamp tomorrow, holds the promise of a real treat.

title: U. S. and Saigon Dispute Defense of Capital
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 9The American military command and South Vietnamese headquarters are conducting a lively debate about how best to contend with the possibility that the Communists will initiate new military moves in the Saigon area.

title: Airport Plan Is Killed
description: ALBANY, Sept. 9 (UPI)The State Transportation Department has killed plans for a, new western New York airport, at Batavia. Transportation Cornmissioner R. T. Schuler, rejecting a consultant's recommendation, sa'd yesterday that the Batavia site was too far removed from Buffalo. Rochester and Niagara Falls.

title: John B. Hansbury Weds Miss Wenzel
description: Miss Elizabeth Patricia Wenzel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Wenzel of Yonkers, Stony Hollow, N. Y., and St. Thomas, V. I., was married at noon yesterday to John Brian Hansbury. He is the son of Mrs. John Brian Hansbury of Armonk, N. Y., and the late Mr. Hansbury.

title: PAUL HEUDUCK DIES; DID MOSAICS AT U. N.
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (AP)Paul T. Heuduck, a mosaic artist whose works are displayed at the United Nations building and Rockefeller Center in New York, died yesterday in a St. Louis hospital. He was 90 years old.

title: Miss Carole Prentice Andrews Married to Fredrick L. Miley
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 9In the Round Hill Community Church here this evening. MiSs Carole Prentice Andrews was married to Fredrick Lee Miley by the Rev. Jesse Thomas.

title: Law
description: HARRISBURG  The contraband letters went in and out of the Lewisburg Federal Penitentiary copied into the lines of a spiralbound Bucknell University notebook.

title: STEERS RALLY TO TIE REDSKINS
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9The Pittsburgh Steelers and Washington Redskins, both contenders for division titles this season, ended rehearsals tonight by playing to a 1010 tie. Each finished the preseason campaign with four victories, one loss and one tie.

title: Roxanne C. Hammer Is Betrothed
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 9Miss Roxanne Catherine Hammer plans to be married Nov. 25 to Thomas Eugene Brydges, son of Earl W. Brydges, State Senate Majority Leader, and Mrs. Brydges of. Niagara Falls. married Nov. 25 to Thomas Eugene Brydges, son of Earl W. Brydges, State Senate Majority Leader, and Mrs. Brydges of. Niagara Falls.

title: Vietnam Veterans in Seoul Protest Against Japan
description: SEOUL South Korea, Sept. 9About 100 disabled South Korean veterans of the Vietnam war demonstrated at the Japanese Embassy here today, rigorously protesting a recent supplement or a Japanese newspaper that they said had defamed them.

title: Detergent Ban: No Regrets
description: Eighteen months ago, Suffolk County banned the sale of almost all detergents, a move designed to protect its water supply. Today, officials are still happy that, they made that move, despite the fact that, to date, the ban has not yet produced any measureable results.

title: Music
description: PIERRE BOULEZ'S recent Times article on his functions as music director, and his musings on the appropriate way to bring foes of contemporary music into a positive relation with it, produce countermusings on the orchestra as medium and institution. Naturally, what I have to say is unabashedly compositorial. I cannot adopt the neutrality of tone that Boulez would use to statesmanlike advantage. But my lack of neutrality proceeds from what I think rational conviction: though it may take long time to have effect, what composers do determines everything about the world of music.

title: A talk with Eleanor Mc Govern
description: Eleanor McGovern was midway through one the more hectic days of her year. She and the children were leaving for Miami the next day, and there were still a million things to be done. Phone calls, shopping, packing. Steve needed shoes and Mary needed stockings and someone had to take Atticus to the vet.

title: The World
description: Starting with his own reelection as an unopposed candidate last October, President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam has taken a series of steps to centralize power in his handsthus diminishing the democratic processesat a time when the United States is pulling out troops and, correspondingly, losing influence there. The major steps are shown below.

title: NO. CAROLINA BEATS RICHMOND, 28 TO 18
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Sept. 9 (AP); North Carolina's Tar Heels struck for two quick touchdowns and went on to defeat Richmond, 2818, today in the football opener for both,

title: 7 Clubs Combine in E.M.R. A. To Hold. Amateur Road Racing
description: Members of the British Sports Car Owners Association will be busy next Saturday inspecting Corvettes and several other makes of cars at Bridgehampton Raceway. The procedure is not for the purpose of comparing American and foreign machinery but as a part of the conduct of an Eastern Motor Racing Association competition program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In its Aug. 25 editorial Call to Fear The Times takes an extremely critical view of President Nixon's acceptance speech at the Republican Convention in Miami Beach. You were especially dissatisfied with the attack on the Democratic ticket, implying that the President should have stressed the achievements of his Administration.

title: F.A.A. Pronoses Standards For Model Plane Flights
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The Federal Aviation Administration recommended operating standards today for the nation's 500,000 hobbyists who fly model aircraft.

title: Primary Season Stretches On, With 9 More Tuesday
ARAB AIDES WARNED OF FURTHER ATTACKS
description: CAIRO, Sept. 9 (UPI)The Arab League Secretary General, Mahmoud Riad, opened a conference of Arab foreign ministers tonight with a warning that Arabs should expect further Israeli attacks, and with call for a joint Arab plan of action.

title: Report by Syria
description: BEIRUT, Sept. 9Syrian fighterbombers inflicted heavy damage and casualties today on Israeli positions in the occupied Golan heights. a Syrian military spokesman said.

title: HANOI INVITES KIN TO GREET P.O.W.'S
description: Family members of the three American prisoners who arc being released by North Vietnam will be flown to Hanoi on ednesday night to pick them up.

title: Stamps
description: BEGINNING on Thursday; and continuing through Sunday, New Haven will be host to the 86th annual convention of the 27000member American Philatelic Society, the country's oldest and largest national organization of stamp collectors. Since the American Philatelic Research Library at State College, Pa., will also be dedicated this Tuesday, this week will be a double celebration for the society, for it is the founder of the library and the new building that houses the library and the central office and sales division of the organization.At New Haven, in association with the sponsors, the New Haven Philatelic Society and the Cheshire Philatelic Society, A.P.S. members will share in the SONEX 72, the Southern New England Stamp Exhibition, the convention and show both being booked at the Sheraton Park Plaza Hotel. Henry W. Houser and Otto G. Schaffling are cochairmen of the fourday philatelic weekend.

title: YACHT RACE WON BY RABEN'S SLOOP
description: GREENWICH, conn., Sept. 9 La Forza del Destino, a black 51foot aluminum sloop owned by Norman Raben of Loudonville, N. Y., won the third race in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's cruising yacht series for the Whitmore Trophy today. The final race will be sailed tomorrow.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONWhen lawyers and their fees are discussed, the storyundoubtedly apocryphalis often toldof Clark Clifford, the suave Washington counselor, who is said to havebeen telephoned by a businessmanseeking advice on a complicated problem. According to the story, Mr. Clifford told him to say nothing and do nothing. And then sent a bill for $10,000.

title: Tampa Ends Toledo Streak At 35, Winning by 210
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 9 (AP)Led by two quarterbacks, Buddy Carter and Freddie Solomon, Tampa defeated the University of Toledo, 210, tonight to end the secondlongest winning streak in modern collegiate football history at 35 games.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Samuel Rotrosen, president of the Montrose Chemical Corporation of California, states that DDT substitutes are slow in being developed and he alludes to the current issue of the M.I.T. Technology Review that a suitable substitute to DDT may not be attained before the end of the century.

title: Solzhenitsyn: Writer Caught Between
description: Alexander Solzhenitsyn, now 53, is a man caught in a bind between the Communist and capitalist worlds. In his Russian homeland he is a nonperson, a writer whose works no publishing house will touch, whose books must be circulated surreptitiously in typescript. For the past three years he has been supporting his wife and small son in the frugal style to which he became accustomed while an obscure highschool teacher, dependent on the hospitality of friends and a legacy left him by the grand old man of Russian children's literature, the late K. I. Chukovsky.

title: SMOOTH FOX TERRIER IS BEST AT FAR HILLS
Reservists Find the Big Time in Watertown
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y.Most summer weekends, the streets of this upstate city were thronged with young men who walked from one movie showing skin flicks to the other theater showing skin flicks to one gogo bhr where fully clad teenaged girls were gyrating to another gogo place where older women were dancing in bathing suits.

title: S.I. Dean Plans to Fly a Flapping Machine
description: James L. G. Fitz Patrick has spent a good part of the last 38 years trying to fly like a bird. And now the countdown is about to begin on Staten Island, after what Mr. Fitz Patrick estimates has been 9,0000 hours of experiments, the dissection of 300 birds and an expenditure of $40,000 of his own money.

title: Gary Player Gains Edge By 2 Shots in Akron Golf
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 9Jack Nicklaus underwent a new golfing experience today. Although he had dominated the world series of golf in his first previous seven appearances, he was in fourth or last place after an opening round of 75 today. He was four strokes back of Gary Player, the leader.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market moved through its postLabor Day week:the first week of the economy's new yearin a depressed state of mind. Prices declined every day, dropping quite sharply on Wednesday.

title: Two on Motorcycle Killed. Car Driver Hurt in Crash
description: Two Brooklyn motorcyclists were killed early yesterday and the driver of an auto was seriously injured when a car going west on the Belt Parkway at the northbound exit leading to Cross Bay Boulevard in Queens and the motorcycle, also westbound, collided.

title: A Boycott On Wines Apparently Fizzling Out
description: HICKSVILLE, L.1.  Nine months after a boycott of French wines was declared by a Long Island trade association, the topic engenders less ferment than ,a glass of fresh grape juice.

title: BARNARD COLLEGE LISTS INVESTMENTS
description: Barnard College has released a detailed report listing all of its stocks and bonds held as of last June 30. This move, made at the request of the student newspaper, The Columbia Daily Spectator, apparently marks the first time that Barnard has made its stock portfolio available for publication.

title: Counseling Service Set For Families in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I.County Executive Ralph G. Caso has announced the appointment of Roland H. Davis as head of the newly created Family Bureau of the Nassau County Department of Social Services.

title: TV Series Planned As Aid in Teaching In 4 Jersey Areas
description: TRENTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)Students in four New Jersey areas will he spending their time this year watching televisioneducational television designed to fit their school curriculum.

title: Train Derails at Utica
description: UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 9 (AP) A westbound Penn Central freight train jumped the tracks just west of here this morning, spilling lumber, fruits, vegetables and diesel fuel along the main line. W. J. Sparks, diVision superintendent at Utica. said no injuries were reported and the cause of the accident was under investigation.

title: Man Held in Father's Death Found Hanged in the Tombs
description: A 30year old inmate of the Tombs apparently hanged himself with a bedsheet last night. the police said.

title: A wild stallionand an actor manqu
description: The only review Richard Burton professes to remember is the one that appeared in New Statesman after his debut on the London stage in 1944: In wretched part, Richard Burton showed exceptional ability.

title: The Mendelssohns
description: To the Editor: I have no quarrel with your brief but sensitive comment on my book, The Mendelssohns. However, it contains an error that does some injustice to the memory of Felix Mendelssohn.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Shaun Herron, now living in Canada, was born in Ireland and thus has an idiomatic feeling for Irish sport, politics and dialect. All of this stands him well in his latest book, THROUGH THE DARK AND HAIRY WOOD (Random, $5.95). Nominally this is novel of espionage, but there are things in it that far transcend the genre.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In reference to Mel Gussow's The baadasssss success of Melvin Van Peebles (Aug. 20), Mr. Van Peebles's intentions appear good to me but unfair. I am a young black from a middleclass family and welleducated. I am lightskinned and am not considered by the accepted standards set up by blacks such as Mr. Van Peebles (including many whites) as a typical black. I am an actor and am finding it an additional hindrance in struggling to make it in the theater.

title: 11 ARE SEIZED HERE IN NARCOTICS RAIDS
description: Raids by narcotics policemen in Brooklyn and Manhattan resulted in the Seizure Friday night of heroin and marijuana worth about $115.000, and the arrest of nine men and two young women.

title: U.S. Gives Loan to Finance BotswanaZambia Road
description: GABORONE, Botswana, Sept. 9 (Agence FrancePresse)The American Ambassador, Charles J. Nelson, has signed on behalf of the United States a formal loan agreement providing Botswana with nearly $12stone in Zambia.

title: Nasson College Names Aide
description: SPRINGVALE, Me., Sept. 9 (AP)Nasson College has announced the appointment of Gurth I. Abercrombie as assistant to John S. Bailey. the college's president. Mr. Abercrombie has served for the last five years as dean of Pratt Institute's School of Continuing Professional Studies.

title: Art
description: THE rhinoceros in my life stands ten inches high with his tail up and inhabits an ecological vacuum at the Metropolitan Museum, a glassfronted case that he shares with four musicians, two soldiers on horseback, two male dignitaries, one jar, one plate, and four dragons engaged in supporting a bowl. His vital statistics are given on a label that reads: Rhinoceros. Pottery. Chinese, Late Han Dynasty, 25 A.D.220 A.D. or Six Dynasties, 220589. Bequest of Florence Waterbury, 1968, in memory of John I. Waterbury. 68.149.15. That last figure is his accession number, the museum equivalent of a dogtag.

title: EXSENATOR RUNS FOR COUNTY POST
description: MIAMI, Sept. 9A former member of the United States Senate is campaigning here for the office of County Commissioner, convinced that the post offers as much challenge as any other job I have held, public or private.

title: Stamps
description: Tom Sawyer! What memories the name recallsthe adventures with Huck Finn, Becky and the cave, Injun Joe, that fencepainting adventure, Aunt Pollyfaded memories now; but how much a part of growing up his adventures were... the tattered book that rested atop Dad's handcrafted bookcase that stood in majesty against the wall next to a window that let in the clear Virginia light, and the many times that book was pored over (and how Mom wished that I had put in as much time on my school books). I guess I read Tom Sawyer a zillion times. I'm going to read it again... and wonder how many young folk today have found the lives of Hannibal lads and lassies exciting, or is it too dull matched against the mayhem of television?

title: New &Novel
description: Jim Bower is an advertising man who sees huckster. ing as an art, then suddenly finds himself working for a new agency president who thinks it is a science. Bower relies on his knack for creating word magic. His boss relies on market surveys, copy testing, the whole bag of motivational research. This classic professional conflict becomes the mainspring of a really good novel about mayhem on MadiAvewe.

title: Ewell Bowdle Stewart Is a Bride
description: WAYNE, Pa., Sept. 9The marriage of Miss Ewell Bowdle Stewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bowdle Stewart of Bryn Mawr, to Alexis Felix du Pont 4th took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Richard W. Hess performed the ceremony in the chapel of Old St. David's Episcopal Church.

title: Dog Kennel Here Accused Of Keeping Sick Animals
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday charged the operator of a dog kennel here with keeping sick animals.

title: Opposition for Nixon
description: DALLAS, Sept. 9  The National Baptist Convention of America, representing 3.5 million black Baptists across the nation, approved resolutions here this week in favor of school busing and against an allvolunteer army and the reelection of President Nixon. allvolunteer army and the reelection of President Nixon.

title: Arthur Daley
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 9One crisis after another has been besetting these illstarred Olympic Games. It's almost as if they were accursed, and the point has now been reached when even their most ardent supporters are reluctantly wondering whether they haven't started to come apart at the seams. Alarming cracks and fissures have appeared since the start of this greatest of all international sports spectacles, and the tragic assassination of Israeli athletes by Arab terrorists was an extra outside blow of staggering impact. The end of the Games of the XXth Olympiad is approaching, though, and it can't come a moment too soon. Even the finale has been jostled out of the place that had been originally scheduled for it by those paragons of precision planning, the Germans. According to the Grand Design, track and field would produce a glittering smash finish today and then the carnival of muscle would make graceful exit on the morrow with the glamorous closing ceremony.

title: Patricia Joyner Fiancee
description: Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Exum Joyner of Snow Hill, N. C., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Anne Joyner, to Warner King Babcock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Nash Babcock of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Rehabilitation Hospital Administrator in Wheelchair Is Symbol of Victory for North Brunswick Patients
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK From his wheelchair, Maurice Dorsen supervises the Middlesex Rehabilitation Hospital. in North Brunswick, and is deeply involved in every phase of its current expansion plans.

title: The Private Life of the Louvre
description: PARIS  Some of the most interesting things about the Louvre are also the least known. Few people are aware, for instance, that the great museum was first opened to the public during the French Revolution. That immortality, as far as Louvre officials are concerned, begins 60 years after an artist's death, at which time it is decided whether the artist's work will be shown. That the Louvre's policy is to give each painting a frame of the period in which the painting was done. That some people have asked for permission to give gala dinners and balls at the Louvre. That the museum has been called a noble exercise in confusion. That it is quite useless to speculate how the (armless) Venus de Milo held her arms. That the Louvre's main problem is not money, but space; owns far more art treasures than it can show at one time. That a hundred years ago most paintings were hung quite high but have gradually descended until today most hang at eye level because people want to he close to great paintings and analyze them. That current policy is to try to hang a painting so that it is lighted by its neighbors and,

title: Long George Alley By Richard Hall. 214 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $6.95.
description: This first novel is stripped down to its barest and most lucid essentials. It brings the civilrights struggle back to life for us. It is uncompromising in its search for truth, and yet because the author is able to make the meanest and the most timid of his characters human, one is left with the feeling that the tragedy, the farce, the banality, the idealism of the bid to confront a decaying, stubborn and unjust system was finally vindicated.

title: Hughy Takes Tire Race
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Sept. 9 (AP)Driving a Ford Pinto, Lanny Hughy of Bethesda, Md., today won the B. F. Goodrich Radial Baby Grand race for streettire subcompacts. He covered the 30 laps around the 3.37mile course at an average speed of 77.8 miles an hour.

title: Teacup Full Of Roses;By Sharon Bell Mathis. 125 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $4.50. (Ages 12 to 15)
description: Everybody black got a heavy need, Joe says. His older brother, Paul, needs heroin to help him forget he can't make it as an artist. His younger brother, Davey, a crack athlete and A student needs encouragement and a piece of money for college. Joe has needs, too: the night school diploma that will get him away from the inner city's dreary poverty, and will open doors to higher education, security, success magic life with his girlfriend, Ellie, in a place where trouble never comes. In... a teacup full of roses.

title: Dodgers Down Astros, 4.0
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 (AP) Steve Garvey singled home two runs for Los Angeles in the first inning and Claude Osteen made them stand up with a threehitter in the Dodgers 40 victory over Houston tonight.

title: For Some, Trade Is a Big Favor
description: A number of factors are involved in a trade and Tom Landry, coach of the Dallas Cowboys, cited one last week: I think one season and a summer is time enough that if the player doesn't deliver what you want, then you do him a favor by trading him.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: One of the largest private estates in the metropolitan area, the 475acre Woodland and Oak Hill Farms, in Middletown, N.J., has been sold for almost $2million.

title: 7 Gang Members Arrested In Attack on Policewoman
description: Seven members of a youth gang called the Immortals were arrested in Central Park yesterday after they threw stones at a plainclothes policewoman on horseback.

title: MoreEfficient Paper Work Speeding Pace of Justice in Court in Middlesex
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Middlesex County has taken action in furtherance of what the Bill of Rights has assured Americans"the right to a speedy and public trial.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR: With regard to Take Your Teeth to Europe (Travel section, Aug. 20), Americans with medical problems do not fly to Europe only to visit a dentist  our 2yearold daughter was born in East Germany. When my wife, who comes from Rumania, was told that the overall minimum cost of the delivery, of her baby in a New York clinic would be about $1,200, she insisted on flying to Europe to have the baby there. I had serious reservations about the proposal, but the financial consideration prevailed. At first, my wife started corresponding with two hospitals in West Germany; then we learned that East Berlin's clinics were even cheaper. Their charge for full service, including the cost of room for five days, was less than $100. After writing to the Charite Hospital in East Berlin, my wife flew to West Berlin and from there to the Eastern sector where a room in a maternity house connected with the hospitalas well as a visawas waiting for her. Four days later a telegram from a father and that my wife was fine. Ten days after that my wife and our baby arrived at Kennedy Airport. The whole operation, including the roundtrip ticket, cost us $747.60. My wife was so pleased that she is now insisting on having her next child, expected in January, at the Charite Hospital. A final note: twice a year we receive form from East Berlin with questions about the physical and general condition of our daughter.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Just as the tobacco industry refuses to recognize the health hazards of cigarette smoking, so also will the makers and distributors of DDT apparently not be convinced by overwhelming scientific evidence that their product is an environmental and human health hazard.

title: Kennedy Scores Farm Policy During Iowa Campaign Trip
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. (UPI)  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, accused the Nixon Administration today of juggling the books to make the national farm program more attractive to rural voters.

title: TAIWAN SAID TO PLAN AID FOR STOCKPILING
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 9 (UPI)The Chinese Nationalist Government will lend $100million to private industry to stockpile materials that normally conic from Japan, the newspaper China News reports.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: FRED M. HECHINGER'S incisive article on Portnoy's Complaint masterfully points to one aspect of what has become a growing concern of the American Jewish community since the late 1960's antiJewish slurs from new and unexpected sources.

title: Ogden Phipps's Boucher Triumphs in $131,482 St. Leger by a HalfLength
description: DONCASTER, England, Sept 9 (UPI)American domination of English horse racing's oldest classics continued today when Boucher won the 3131,482 St Leger.

title: Black Baptists at Two Conventions Indicate Opposition to Nixon
description: FORT WORTH, Sept. 9Clergy and lay leaders for six million black American Baptists united here this week in support of the politics of cooperation between the races but indicated a split with their leader over his support of President Nixon's bid for reelection.

title: Mrs. Sorensen Has Son
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 9A son was born Aug. 27 to Mr. and Mrs. Andrew A. Sorensen at the Tompkins County Hospital.

title: Injunction Is Defied By 2,000 Festival Fans
description: OAKTON, Va., Sept. 9 (UPI)More than 2,000 fans of blues and country music gathered at the Timberlake Blue Grass Festival today despite a court order aimed at banning the event.

title: GIANTS, BROWNS CLASH HERE TODAY
description: The New York Giants will attempt to end their National Football League preseason schedule on a victorious note this afternoon at Yankee Stadium when they play the Cleveland Browns in their sixth contest.

title: Cubs Defeat Phillies, 74
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 (AP)  Rick Monday and Carmen Fanzone hit runproducing doubles to break a sixthinning tie and spark the Chicago Cubs to a 74 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

title: DETECTIVE HELPS FRESH AIR CAMP
description: Many changes can be seen in the Fresh Air Fund's summer camps and even in the underprivileged city children who attend them, according to a police detective who was once a camp counselor and who returned this summer to work with children again.

title: SOVIET SAID TO ADD FORCE NEAR CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Wellplaced officials in the Administration report that the Soviet Union has recently added three mechanized divisions to the already major buildup of troops along its long border with China.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: READING Loften Mitchell's article, Time to Break the Silence Surrounding Paul Robeson?", brought to mind memory I have had since was a small boy. I do not believe I will ever forget watching Robeson sing OI Man River in the movie Showboat.

title: Orthodox Priest Asks Removal Of Patriarchate From Turkey
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. A Greek Orthodox priest here has started a campaign to move the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Eastern Orthodoxy out of Istanbul.to a friendlier site.

title: W. and M. Wins, 317
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 9 (AP)  William and Mary's Indians scored the 300th victory in their 77 years of football today. The running of Doug Gerhart and the passing of Rip Scherer led them to a 317 Southern Conference victory over Furman's Paladins.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 9  The Eastern Cruiser Associations 20th annual predicted log contest for the Commodore William Edgar John Memorial Trophy was won today by Rear Commodore Ray Kirchmyer in his 40foot ShangriLa. Kirchmyer completed the fiveleg, 32 mile course from Execution Rock to Lloyd's Point and back with 0.7281 per cent error.

title: Congo Aide to Visit China
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic. Sept. 9(Agence FrancePresse)Health Minister Dieudonne noun will visit China Starting Friday to discuss Chinese medical assistance it was announced here.

title: Photography
description: REGISTRATION is now going on at the School of Visual Arts, 209 East 23d Street, New York, N. Y. 10010, for a group of 16 evening courses in photography, as well as seven in film making.

title: The unborn and Right to Life
description: Regarding 'Right to Life has a message for New York State Legislators by Fred C. Shapiro (Aug. 20): While there are those who feel that the fetus has the right to life, I myself have seen too many children who are unwanted, unloved and uncaredfor. The assertion that the bare fact of physical birth makes a woman into a mother is not borne out by fact, as most social workers could tell you. How will the advocates of a less liberal abortion law ensure unwelcome babies more than mere physical existence?

title: Coins
description: WITH many club activities, major international auctions and conventions crowding the early fall calendar, the new numismatic season in this city promises to be the busiest and best in the annals of coin collecting.

title: Study of Coastal Currents To Aid Sewer Placement
description: STONY BROOK, L. I.The Marine Sciences Research Center of the State University here is conducting a study of the ocean's coastal currents so as to help determine the best place to locate an outfall defuser sewer system for parts of Babylon and Islip.

title: White Sox Win, 32
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (UPI)Carlos May's single scored Pat Kelly with the winning run in the bottom of the eighth tonight and gave the Chicago White Sox a 32 victory over the California Angels.

title: The Nation
description: Voter registrationthe political combat tactic that is about as exciting as trench warfareis assuming an ever larger role in the Presidential campaign.

title: Auburn Triumphs, 143
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 9 (AP) Randy Walls guided Auburn to a 14.3 victory over Mississippi State tonight in the first Southeasern Conference game of the season.

title: How to talk with Barbara Walters about practically anything
description: Each weekday morning between the hours of and 9 more than eight million Americans switch on their television sets and accept the National Broadcasting Company's chatty initiation into another round of human events. The show is appropriately called Today. It is now in its 20th year; the most familiar face belongs to a wellgroomed, 40yearold woman with a curiously rigid upper lip and an accent that seems to have foundered somewhere between Boston and the Bronx. She is Barbara Walters, for eight years a prominent if supportive member of the Today cast and the only woman in television to occupy such an exalted position on a regular network program of news and commentary.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9'My Uncle Antoine is the most extraordinary movie. It is almost impossible to explain why. There are no boa constrictors being petted by any of the charactersthat's undoubtedly part of the explanation. As for rapegood old rape, what would movies be without you these days?well, rape has been omitted, which is rather pleasant for a change. There isn't even any rape off camera, or any suggestion that rape may be imminent. When we got home, we talked about that, and we all agreed that leaving out rape would not have been so unusual if, to compensate, someone had been savagely beaten, or an ingenious mass homicide had been thrown in, or even if just one of the characters had been cut in two by an airplane propeller or beaten slowly by a giant crab.

title: Education
description: It was a familiar situation. The deadline for a new contract was approaching fast and the New York City Board of Education and the teachers union seemed far apart on some key issues, despite virtually aroundtheclock negotiations. With memories of teachers strikes in 1967 and 1968 hanging over the talks, the possibility loomed large that another strike would be in force at the start of the new school year tomorrow for the system's 1.1 million students.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times characterization of President Nixon's Republican Convention acceptance speech as an exercise in partisan demagoguery (Call to Fear Aug. 25) seems to smack of sour grapes. Mr. Nixon hardly could be expected to echo.the familiar litany of the doctrinaire liberal. He spoke instead for the decisive majority of Americans who quite plainly are fed up with an elitist minority which seeks to reshape America in its own image.

title: SISTER MARY JOSEPHINE
description: Sister Mary Josephine Enright of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd, who was superior and administrator of its Euphrasian Residence here from 1965; to 1970 and of its Villa Loretto in Peekskill, N.Y., from 1959 to 1965, died Wednesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived in the Mount Florence House in Peekskill.

title: Long Strike Swells Welf are Rolls
description: EDISON  A halfyear strike against the FeddersNorge Corporation here has swelled the Middlesex County Welfare rolls by 700 families.

title: Olympic Personalities: Is Flame Going Out?
description: Bitter and disappointed because her efforts to stir a peace movement in the Olympic Village have been thwarted, Mrs. Olga Connolly said, No Olympic spirit is allowed to flourish among the athletes. We are kept on the level of children at play.

title: Nuptials for Eileen Pond
description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 9Miss Eileen Pond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Pond of Southbury, was married here this afternoon to Juri Keerdoja, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henno Keerdoja of Bridgeton, N. J. Msgr. Thomas V. McMahon performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection. The bride, a graduate of Connecticut College in New London, is an editorial assistant for Newsweek magazine. Her husband, a Northwestern University alumnus, is a realestate administrator for the Supermarkets General Corporation in Cranford, N. J.

Larkin of Greenwich, was married here this afternoon in the Round Hill Community Church to James Windsor Hubbell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubbell Jr. of Des Moines, Iowa. The Rev. Jesse Thomas performed the ceremony.

title: The World
description: PARIS  The French involvement in a sevenyearold civil war in Chad, a former French colony in the heart of Africa, has been a bitter personal affair for French Gen. Edouard Cortadellas. He has served as overall commander of French and loyalist Chad forces in the conflict and his son was one of 50 French soldiers who died helping the Chad Government put down the insurgency.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Clayton Riley's article concerning Black films Shaft Can Do Everything  I Can Do Nothing, was the straw that broke this camel's back. I'm so sick and tired of reviewers  Black and white  who continually knock these films.

title: TopsyTurvy Olympics
description: Even without the unspeakable horror of the Arab guerrilla raid on the Israeli Olympic squad, the 1972 Games in Munich have added no luster to the Olympic tradition.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONAt the Smithsonian conference last December, the United States agreed with its nine chief trading partners to begin negotiations promptly to construct a new monetary system for the free world. The postWorld War II Bretton Woods structure, shattered in August, 1971, by the suspension of the dollar convertibility into gold, had only been patched together temporarily by the Smithsonian currency realignment, pending permanent reform.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WITH THE PASSAGE of Labor Day, a new season started in the business world and the annual economic forecasting derby for the year ahead has hit full stride. Business, abounding with optimism, is certainly primed for continuance the boom that was renewed about 19 months ago. Nothing that happened during the summer suggested any significant easing in the fast pace of overall economic activity.

title: 20% of the Nation's Aluminum
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, founded to supply foil to the tobacco industry and nurtured by Government loans and contracts during World War II, has grown into major factor in the world aluminum industry, outranked only by Aluminum Company of America and Alcan Aluminium, Ltd.

title: Cahill Surveys Tocks Island Dam Site by Helicopter
description: NEWTON, N.J., Sept. 9Govt William T. Cahill closed his investigation of the proposed Tocks Island Dam project today with a helicopter flight over the Delaware River site and a meeting with Warren and Sussex County officials.

title: An itchy Parasite Not New. to Island
description: A tiny parasite that makes people itch was reported last week at the beaches around City Island, and it now turns out that this creature has been in Long Island waters for many years. If you have been digging for clamsor wading or swimmingand then discovered clusters of itchy red welts on your skin, that may be the culprit.

title: LUTHERAN LEADER PRESSURES SCHOOL
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept 9The Rev. Dr. Jacob A. O. Preus, president of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod, this week renewed pressure on church authorities to stop alleged doctrinal errors by professors at Concordia Seminary here.

description: DENVER, Sept. 9 Representative Wayne N. Aspinall, 76 years old, a 12term House member who is chairman of its Interior Committee; faces the first major primaryelection challenge of his career next Tuesday.

description: They called him Slavery Brundage or Avery Umbrage, and the titles they gave him ranged from America's common scold to world's leading shameteur.

title: Soviet Elevates Young Generals in Army Shuffle
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 9The son of a famous World War II marshal has been appointed commander of the prestigious Moscow Military District in a continuing rejuvenation of key command posts in the Soviet armed forces.

title: Entries Due for L.I. Fair Oct. 79
description: OLD BETHPAGE, L. I.  Farmers, horticulturists, home gardeners, craftsmen and hobbyists from Nassau, Queens and Suffolk Counties have until Friday to enter the Long Island Fair, which will be held Oct. 69 at the Old Bethpage Village Restoration.

title: PACKERS DEFENSE STOPS CHIEFS, 200
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 9 (AP)The Green Bay Packers, sparked by Scott Hunter's passing and a defense that held Kansas City without a first down for almost the first 28 minutes, beat the Chiefs, 200, in an exhibition game tonight.

title: The revolution in haute cuisine
description: On a gloomy street in the suburb of Asnieres to the west of Paris, Michel Guerard presides over Le Pot au Feu, an already legendary center of the revolution taking place in French cooking. Chef Guerard is typical of the new chefs in that he traces his revolutionary roots to Fernand Point of Vienne and is pushing still further in the direction of the sophisticated simplicity at table that the late Monsieur Point began. The Guerard recipe for duck fricassee with vinegar descends from the Point recipe of the same name. It is not a dish that requires the time and talents of a quartermaster general. Stock must be made ahead, but, apart from that, the process, like the end result, is a paradigm of purity. There is nothing heavy here; no fussy garnishings of artichoke bottoms, carved truffles and piped potatoes. A chef of an earlier generation might scoff and say: You've got nothing but duck pieces and a vinegar reduction. The modem answer is that no one wants all those edible curlicues on the side any more. What the young French chefs are about is exactly this kind of plat, one that emphasizes the major ingredient, cooks the duck magnificently, and distills a subtle

title: Mailbox:
description: To The Editor:

title: Spock to Get Protection
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The Treasury Department announced today that Dr. Benjamin Spock, Presidential candidate of the People's party, has accepted an offer of Secret Service protection.

title: NEBRASKA UPSET BY U.C.L.A., 2017
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 (AP) Efren Herrera kicked a 20yard field goal with 22 seconds to play as unranked University of California, Los Angeles stunned topranked Nebraska, 2017, tonight before 67,702 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

title: Aquarium Names Director
description: BOSTON, Sept 9 (AP)John H. Prescott of Palos Verdes, Calif., will assume his duties as managing director and vice president of the New England Aquarium Oct. 15. He is currently general manager for operations at Marineland of the Pacific.

description: CHARLES BAUDELAIRE began an essay on contemporary philosophic art, written around 1860, with a general criticism of the genre:

title: Movie Mailbag

This film is only one of a long line in which Judaism and Jews have been treated with contempt and in which the Jewish tradition is seen as a burdensome appendage to be cut off as soon as possible.

title: DR. MORTIMER D. DROSIN
description: Dr. Mortimer D. Drosin, podiatrist, died at the New York Hospital on Friday evening. He was 57 years old and both lived and had his office at 302 West 86th Street.

title: Maria K. Bacalakis Is Bride Of Lawrence Rodman in Jersey

Rodman, president and chief executive officer of the Grand Union Company and Mrs. Rodman. Both families are of Ridgewood.

description: The Lindsay administration, one of the last public holdouts, has decided to support the state's $1.15billion environmental bond issue that goes to the voters Nov. 7.

description: A special commission of the Synagogue Council of America has urged the council to oppose quotas but support affirmative action strategies to raise the number of disadvantaged minority groups in employment and higher education.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: Who is Paul Robeson? This is a question that can be answered with great pride by Rutgers students. Last year, a small group of black students on the Newark campus of Rutgers University started a movement to honor Robeson, a Rutgers alumnus, by naming the new campus center The Paul Robeson Campus Center. This was part of a larger movement in the Newark community to honor prominent blacks who present a positive image to black young people.

title: JAMES W. FARRELL
description: James W. Farrell, who retired from the Bell Telephone Laboratories as attorney and secretary in 1952. died yesterday. He was 85 years old and lived at 16509 85th Avenue, Jamaica, Queens.

title: Scott F. Sturges Weds Diane Pendleton

Pendleton and the late Major Pendleton, U.S.A.F., was married here this afternoon to Scott Forsbrey Sturges, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Sturges of Oberlin, Ohio, and Twitchell Lake, N. Y. The Rev. Albert O. Judd performed the ceremony in St. George's Episcopal Church.

title: FLA. STATE AERIALS TOP PITTSBURGH, 197

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: I was shocked to read, after my return from a vacation in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, Helen Epstein's sensational article about the girl who was shot by an intruder in that lovely town (Travel section, Aug. 27). The story's tone implies ominous and unspeakable violence at every turn. Yet I fail to get the point of the article. That lust and passion explode, even in San Miguel? That American neighbors there act no differently than in Queens, refusing to become involved when there is trouble? That the town's little hospital does not compare favorably with Massachusetts General? That Americans are not always universally beloved by local residents? what

title: Missouri Tops Oregon
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 9 (UPI)Greg Hill booted a 31yard field goal with six seconds left today to give Missouri 2422 football decision over Oregon.

title: Rangers Defeat A's, 32
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 9 (AP)  The Texas Rangers scored three early runs and held on to defeat the Oakland A's, 3.2, tonight in a game held up for 67 minutes by rain and an electrical storm.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: RICHARD C. GERSTENBERG, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, predicted record car and truck sales of 13.5 million to 14 million for 1973, up from the 13.2 million expected this year... Car sales in the final third of August set a record for the period at 273,080.

title: Textile Manufacturer Raises Donkeys
description: LEBANONWilfred Weppler leads a double life. To his 35 employes in Weehawken, he is president of Mechanical and Felt Textiles, Inc., fabricators and importers of textiles for industry; to a growing number of children, horseowners, parents, zoos and elderly, he is the man from the Box Hill Farm who raises that unique breed of docile pet, the miniature Sardinian donkey.

title: Bayer's 70 Sets Golf Pace
description: DAVISON, Mich., Sept. 9 (AP) Five birdies helped George Bayer take the firstround lead by two shots today with a twounderpar 70 in the $10,000 Michigan Professional Golf Association championship.

title: Senate Supports Measure On Retired G.I.'s Pension
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The Senate has passed a bill that would allow up to 55 per cent of a retired serviceman's pension money to go to his widow and family when he dies.

title: Susan Revile Is Wed
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 9The marriage of Miss Susan Curry Reville and William Michael Friedrich, both graduates of Union College, took place here this afternoon. Msgr. William J. McCormack, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony in the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Philip Curry Reville of Scarsdale and Mr. and Mrs. William E. Fredrich of Babylon, L. I.

description: NORTHPORT, L. I.  Nearby _residents are preparing to file still another suit, their second, against a villageapproved plan for a cluster housing development on the banks of Northport Harbor.

title: Cordelia Exton Becomes Bride Of Leslie Carter
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 9Miss Cordelia Wheeler Exton, a descendent of Gov. William Bradford of the Plymouth Colony, was married here this evening to Leslie Stuart Carter. The Rev. Francis X. Cheney performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Rice Beats Houston, 1413, As Collins Is a Standout
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 9 (AP)Edwin Collins caught touchdown passes of 30 and 5 yards to lead the Rice Owls to a 1413 upset over crosstown rival University of Houston in the football opener for both teams tonight.

description: Communications difficulties should not be compounded by confused terminology. It is not the schoolmarm in me that objects to the misuse of slum, but my interest in the urban scene, its ills, causes and cures.

Nassau Jail Needs Godfather or Two
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I.The best seller around here is The Godfather. If we had 500 copies, they'd be off the shelf in a week.

description: Horse Show

title: Tropical Storm Wanes
description: CAPE HATTERAS, N. C., Sept. 9 (UPI)  A diminishing tropical storm, called Dawn, remained stalled off the North Carolina coast today, but weathermen said it would soon move out to sea and lose more strength. Forecasters kept smallcraft warnings flying along the coast from Cape Fear, N. C., to Cape May, N. J.

title: CHARTER AT ISSUE IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept.  A longdiscussed constitutional amendment to reduce the size of the Pennsylvania legislature may come up for showdown vote in the State Senate before the end of this month.

title: On the Mill Outlet Route, You Need Uncle Stanley's Measurements

For a supPly or these it is hard to surpass a tour of factory stores in Connecticut and Massachusetts, mill outlets in great fluorescentlighted factory lofts, many of them with working mills next door and even an occasional waterwheel to look at. Best of all, you can buy things.

Loud of Lattingtown and the late Mrs. Kathryn Jane Douglass Loud.

title: British Museum Expert Fined In $2,280 Stamp Robbery
description: LONDON, Sept. 9, (Reuters) James Mackay, who was in charge of a $75million collection of stamps at the British Museum, has been fined $2,500 for stealing stamps.

title: Air Force Captain Gets 5th MIG to Become Ace
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Sept. 10 (UPI)An Air Force fighter bomber crewman from Louisiana became America's fourth air ace of the Vietnam war yesterday, shooting down his fifth MIG in a dogfight near Hanoi, the United States command reported.

title: A new departure for a master
description: Alexander Solzhenitsyn's current position as the foremost living Russian writer is so selfevident and so unassailable on any imaginable literary grounds that it is hard to remember he made his debut in print 10 When Nikitayears Khrushchev authorized, for reasons of party policy, the publication of One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich in November, 1962, he could hardly have realized what he was doing for Russian literature. In society where for the past 40 years the Government had determined what reality was and just how much of this reality literature was to reflect and in what manner, Solzhenitsyn's short novel of prisoncamp life came as a shattering reversal of all previous taboos and canons.

title: Pirate Homers Beat Expos
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 9 (AP)Al Oliver and Richie Hebner hit tworun homers and Rennie Stennett hit an insidethepark home run, powering the Pittsburgh Pirates to an 82 triumph over Montreal in a National League baseball game tonight.

title: 3 TIED FOR LEAD IN SOUTHERN GOLF
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 9 (UPI)George Johnson of Atlanta, bidding to become the first black player ever to qualify for the Masters, and Frank Beard ended in a threeway tie with DeWitt Weaver today in the third round of the Southern open golf tournament.

title: Rosh haShanah Sermons Note Munich Murders
description: The shadow of the murders of 11 Israeli athletes in Munich continued to dominate in a large measure sermons and messages yesterday on the first day of Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year, 5733.

title: The Nation
description: PHILADELPHIAThis city of nearly two million persons is a working man's town, and although more than onethird black, political power lies with bluecollar whites. They control the labor unions whose support is deemed essential for political success here.

title: Americans Overseas Face Denial of Vote Under Law
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 9Thousands of Americans living abroad are apparently being denied the right to vote in the 1972 Presidential election, despite a new Federal law intended to provide for the first time absentee ballots for all citizens living or traveling overseas.

title: Presidential trivia
description: Questions

title: Woman Dies in Plane Crash
description: SKANEATELES, N.Y., Sept. 9 (AP)  A Massachusetts woman died last night when a singleengine airplane piloted by her husband crashed near this Finger Lakes community southwest of Syracuse. The state police identified her as Margaret J. Roberts, 32 years old, of Hanover, Mass.

title: $52Million Suit Faces Mine in Flood Disaster
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Sept. 9 (AP)A $52million lawsuit against the Pittston Company in connection with the Feb. 26 flood disaster in the Buffalo Creek hollow was filed in United States District Court here yesterday.

title: Youths Compete for Trophies inAsphalt Olympics
description: It wasn't the Olympic Stadium. There was no spectacular panoply. There weren't 80,000 fans.

title: That Rare Painting Can Get New Life in Newark Studio
description: NEWARK  Just a few steps off a busy downtown ??reet, an art lover has created a placid studio where he labors to preserve the world's art treasures, only slightly sealed off from the hubbub of the city.

title: Nuptials for Sandra Farah and Abdillahi M. Arr
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 9  Miss Sandra Farah, daughter of Abdulrahim Abby Farah, Permanent Representative of Somalia to the United Nations, and Mrs. Farah, was married here this afternoon to Abdillahl Mohammed Arr. Sheikh Soliman Donia, director of the New York Islamic Center, performed the ceremony at the Farah home.

title: Mailbox:
description: To The Editor:

title: VATICAN SUSPENDS SACRAMENT MOVE
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 9 A move by the Most Rev. Robert E. Tracy, Bishop of the Baton Rouge Diocese, to allow Roman Catholics who have divorced and remarried to return to the sacraments has been suspended on orders from the Vatican.

title: Austrians to Play in U.S.
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University's basketball team will play a touring Austrian basketball team Sunday, Dec. 17. The Austrians will play eight games in the United States. They will also play Rider, Cheyney State, Mansfield (Pa.) State, East Stroudsberg State, the University of Scranton, Brockport (N. Y.) State and Lafayette.

title: That Championship Director
description: Go see A. J. Antoon, they say. He's a terrific new director. He's only 27 years old. Sure. Why not? I'm not bitter. Just because I've been 17 for more than 17 years, and haven't made my mark yet. (My mark is not an X, no matter what rude people suggest.) A couple of weeks ago, The Times sent me to see Academy Awardwinning director Billy Friedkin. He was an old guy of 33 Next month they'll probably dig up this sensational little chap in nursery school. Only four, but what perceptions, they'll tell me. His recreation of Fanny Hill is being moved to Broadway as soon as his mother gets her driver's license.

title: U.N. Council to Meet Today at Syria's Call
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 9 (Reuters]The Security Council is to meet in, emergency session tomorrow morning on the Middle. East situation at the request of Syria, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Recovery of the nation's railroads cannot be obtained through institution of the monopoly conditions of 1910, but only through an entirely new departure.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Unlike New York City (with which Ms. Epstein seems to hint comparison), San Miguel did not have four to five murders a day in the first six months of 1972. Violence in San Miguel, especially acts involving Mexicans toward Americans, is extremely rare. That the author's larger impression of Mexico should have been acquired through this sole, negative act by an isolated criminal is regrettable, as is the fact that you chose to expose it.

title: Alden P. Johnson, 58, Built Barre Book Publishing Co.
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. (AP)  Alden Porter Johnson, who developed Barre Publishers into a leading regional book publisher, died here yesterday at Memorial Hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: BOLIVIA UNCOVERS DRUG FACTORIES
description: SANTA CRUZ DE LA SIERRA, Bolivia, Sept. 9 (Reuters)A sizable part of the international narcotics trade can be traced back to this landlocked South American country, which has almost no drug problem of its own.

title: MISS STONE, ON 140, LEADS DALLAS GOLF
description: DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 9 (AP)Beth Stone, from Oklahoma, hit 17 of 18 greens and went on to post a 70 for a 140 total today for the secondround lead in the $33,000 Dallas Civitan golf tournament.

title: WASHINGTON WINS FROM PACIFIC,136
description: SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 9 (UPI)Peter Taggares, a fullback, scored from the 3yard line with 5:11 remaining today to give favored Washington 136 victory over University of Pacific and spare the Huskies an embarrassing tie in its season opener.

title: FLORIDA COMMUTES 40 DEATH SENTENCES
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 9 (UPI)  The Florida Supreme Court, fearing that a state law taking effect next month might prompt a rash of prisoner escapes and murder of guards, has issued a blanket commutation of death sentences for 40 convicted killers and rapists.

title: HOUSING DEBATED IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 9 The Urban Development Corporation got a convincing demonstration last week that local opposition has not disappeared in the five weeks since the agency agreed to a moratorium on most of its activity in nine Westchester County towns.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent news of the capture of Raul Sendic, the Tupamaro urban guerrilla leader in Uruguay, may lead some to imagine that at last law and order is returning to that small Latin American nation. Such is not the truth. It may be that the Tupamaro rebellion is disintegrating, but the major reality in today's Uruguay is a massive Government repression which violates basic human rights in a most brutal manner.

title: Mall Rescues Downtown Santa Cruz, Calif., From Paralysis
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Sept. 9Dan Reis and Laurie Bliss wanted to rest while shopping the other day, so they stretched out on the lawn in the middle of downtown Santa Cruz.

title: DETAILS PROVIDED ON MUNICH DEATHS
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 9An interim report on the autopsies performed on the 11 Israeli athletes and coaches killed Tuesday during an Arab terrorist raid reportedly shows that all were struck by bullets.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., Sept. 9 (UPI)Kansas State scored twice within 50 seconds of the fourth quarter today to defeat Tulsa, 2113.

title: Kissinger in Germany
description: MUNICH West Germany, Sept. 9 (Reuters) Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security affairs, arrived here tonight from Washington for talks with West German leaders on an 18hour stopover on his way to Moscow for talks with Soviet, leaders.

title: West Va. Routs Villanova
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Sept. 9 (UPI)  Frank Nester tied a modern National Collegiate record today by kicking six field goals to lead West Virginia to a 256 football victory over Villanova.

title: Robert MM. Smith. Head Of Travel Agency, Is Dead
description: Robert McNeal Smith, president of Travel Desk of New York, Inc., a travel agency, died yesterday in the Lawrence and Memorial Hospital, New London, Conn. He was 64 years old and lived here at 133 East 80th Street.

title: Serenity and Respect Mark SexTherapy Project at Hospital on Long Island
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I. In co??rast to the Masters and Johnson clinic in St. Louis, where desperate couples fly in for a twoweek crash course of treatment, a moreleisurely sextherapy programbut one still patterned after the Masters and Johnson techniquesis being offered to Long Islanders.

title: Nutrition Centers Prove a Boon to the Elderly in Chicago
description: CHICAGOMrs. Margaret Falckenberg, 61 years old, was seated at the piano and beside her was her husband Otto, 63, leading the audience in singing German Lieder.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Anybodyman, boy, or Times Book Reviewerwho calls Topsy a he is a male chauvinist pig.

title: Hole in the Shopping Bag
description: The Administration's acknowledgment that wholesale prices rose faster in the first year of controls than they did in the year before represents something more than confirmation that inflation is still rampant. It underscores the need for plugging the one big gap in the control programthe exemption from regulation of the price of meat and other raw foods.

title: ULSTER PROTESTANTS ACCUSE PARATROOPS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. (UPI)A British paratroop battalion, a target of Protestant resentment after gunbattle in which two civilians were killed, has been ordered to maintain a low profile, a security source said today.

title: Meskill Seeks to Legalize Ads on Prescription Drugs
description: Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut has called for state legislation to legalize the advertising of prices of prescription drugs, to promote competition. A bill that would allow price ads was passed by the House this year but died in the Senate. The present ban on price ads is being challenged by court suits in Connecticut and several other Northeastern states.

title: CHECK WITH STATE, FUNDRAISERS TOLD
description: NEWARKCharitable organizations and their professional fundraisers have been reminded by the State Division of Consumer Affairs that they must register their activities with its charitable registration section or face legal action.

title: R. J. Kerrigan Marries Catherine R. Delany
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 9The marriage of Lieut. Catherine Rose Delany, Nurse Corps, U.S.N., to Corpsman 1/C Richard Joseph Kerrigan of the Navy Medical Corps, took place here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary. Msgr. Joseph P. O'Brien performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Egyptian Women to Pray In Mosques on Fridays
description: CAIRO, Sept. 9 (Reuters)Egyptian Moslem women have gained access to one of the oldest and most exclusive preserves of menthe inside of a mosque during prayers on Friday, the day of rest.

title: Blind Man Donates Eyeglasses To Special School in Paraguay
description: Melvin A. McCollom smiled and spoke of his planned tour of South America. It would be his first visit there. he said, and the trip would take him to Asuncion, Paraguay, and then to Cordova, Argentina.

title: The escalation of Soviet dissent and of Soviet repression
description: Almost a dozen years agoon Oct. 27, 1961, to be exact the head of the Soviet Communist party and Government, Nikita Khrushchev, stood before the party's 22d Congress and talked about the Yakir family, father and son. Khrushchev knew both well. The father, Red Army Gen. Iona Yakir, had been shot in 1937 under Stalin's ruleunjustly, Khrushchev made plain. As a result, the son, Pyotr Yakir, had himself spent long years in prisons and forcedlabor camps before being freed and rehabilitated under Khrushchev's deStalinization program. He had become a historian and Khrushchev honored him as such.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The community of nations must not treat the tragedy in Munich as just another isolated incident to be mourned and condemned for a few days and forgotten. The barbaric madness that cost seventeen lives is but the most recent in a series of terrorist actions against the people of Israel and as such against decent people throughout the world. Have we all forgotten that it is barely three months since Arabpaid terrorists murdered 28 innocent people and wounded 72 more at Lod International Airport in Tel Aviv?

title: Barthes vs. Einstein
description: To the Editor: Edward Said's review of Roland Barthes's Mythologies quotes an estimate I find disturbing.

title: Friend; The Story of George Fox and the Quakers. By Jane Yolen. 179 pp. New York: The Seabury Press. $5.95. (Ages 12 to 15)
description: Biographies of famous men can be written to amuse, instruct or edify, to glorify or debunk their subjects. The best biographies, perhaps, do a little of each. And the worst, on the same grounds, pursue only one of these purposes.

title: Schools Face New Challenges
description: With the threat of a citywide teachers strike over, public schools in Brooklyn and Queens will reopen for the new year tomorrowa year that promises to be filled with challenges, changes and, almost inevitably, some conflicts.

title: Science/ Medicine
description: For centuries the logs of ships crossing the Atlantic have carried notations along this line: Storm encountered; unlike anything previously seen. And until the advent of the highorbiting weather satellite with its God's eye view of the complete lifecycle of the storms, such reports remained a mystery.

title: Ryan Concedes Career In Track May Be Over
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 9 (Reuters)Jim Ryun, the American middledistance star who crashed out of the Olympics yesterday, said tonight he was considering retiring from competition.

title: Seizure of Porpoises Is Center Of Dispute on the Florida Coast
description: NAPLES, Fla., Sept. 9 The capture of 10 porpoises off the coasts of Naples and Marco Island has resulted in a formal protest by several residents to the Collier County Commission.

title: Talking Back to The New York Times
description: Every day The Times mailroom man dumps on Kalman Seigel's desk anywhere from 100 to 150 lettersover 40,000 a year. Seigel is the Letters editor of The Times and compared to my daily take of Con Ed bills, pleas for money and rejection slips, he has a very rich postal life indeed.

title: AROUND THE
description: Bring house plants indoors.... Feed lawns... Plant new ones; repair old ones.... Order bulbs. Divide and replant thick clumps of perennials. Spray roses.... Keep up with vegetable harvests.... Dry flowers.

title: Mayor Gets and Rejects Transport Chief's Memo Urging Veto of Noise Code
description: A confidential memorandum from the City's Transportation Admiinstrator urges Mayor Lindsay to oppose and veto, if necessary, the sweeping new noise control regulations to be voted on Tuesday by the City Council.

title: Twins Defeat Royals, 3.2, With Run in 13th Inning
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 9 (UPI) Doubles by Jim Nettles and Danny Thompson produced the winning run in the 13th inning tonight, lifting the Minnesota Twins to a 32 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Fittipaldi, 25, Verges on World Driving Title
description: Jackie Stewart dropped out with mechanical trouble, Pedro Rodrigez ran out of gas, and the spectators at the 1970 United States grand prix at Watkins Glen, N. Y., saw an unknown driver with the improbable name of Emerson Fittipaldi win fluke race.

title: Seattle's Elusive Recovery
description: SEATTLE  Downtown Seattle bustles. The clamor of iron worker crews is cohstant as new office towers rise about the city. Department stores are full of shoppers and retail sales are up sharply. Boeing is hiring.

title: Summer: It's Gone The Way Of All Flesh
description: POINT LOOKOUT, L.I.Well, it's gone. The Summer of 72  long and lazy for the kids and much too fast for their aging parents  is good for nothing but memories now. And among the notsoyoung marrieds on the beach here, there was general agreement that this summer had been much, much shorter than most.

title: DR. HUGO R. RONY, 84, INTERNIST IS DEAD
description: STONY BROOK. L. I., Sept. 8  Dr. Hugo R. Rony, who retired several years ago as specialist in internal medicine and a researcher in endocrinology and metabolism in Chicago, died Friday at his home here. He was 84 years old.

title: The American Wife
description: To the Editor: If I understand Rona Jaffe's summary, Natalie Gittelson's The Erotic Life of the American Wife can have only the vaguest connection with reality.

title: The Campaign:
description: WASHINGTON  Mr. Nixon's relatively light schedule from Wednesday on gave political observers here chance to digest the President's first two weeks of formal campaigning since the Republican National Convention. One conclusion seemed instantly permissible: Namely, that Mr. McGovern is going to catch it.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Our songbirds and butterflies disappear in myriads; man has come face to face with an indestructible poison of his own making, and Mr. Rotrosen continues to battle in favor of our ingesting the fatal hemlock.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: The Landmarks Preservation Commission of New York City has engaged my firm to mak, a detailed report on the hitt Ty and architecture of th9 :h. Nicholas Historic District. The District consists of four rows of houses on West 138th and West 139th Streets between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. They were built by David H. King, Jr., from the designs of the firms of McKim, Mead and White, Clarence Luce, Bruce Price, and James Brown Lord.

title: VIETNAM KILLINGS LAID TO KOREANS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 9 (AP)Two South Vietnamese legislators have called for a Government inquiry into what they charge was the massacre of 29 civilians by South Korean troops on July 31.

title: Chess: Anderssen, First Champion, Master of Combinative Play
description: Although there have been chess champions for a long time, formal recognition of the world championship title did not start until 1948. Before then, champions were acclaimed by public recognition, and when a challenger defeated a recognized champion, he was acknowledged as the successor.

title: From Munich to NixoninChina
description: In the grim, unsettling days when Hitler was conquering Europe piece by piece, first by threat of war and then by war itself, an iconoclastic voice emerged in 1939 from that bastion of good taste and classical music, WQXR, to taunt and reassure his listeners. It was a peculiarly New England voice that defied a classification. More Down East and nasal than that of a Kennedy, I can only say that it was most fitting for man named Quincy Howe. Even though he, like the Late George Apley, was a native of Boston and attended Harvard, he transcended (one of his favorite words) the Apley atmosphere to become one of the most trenchant radio commentators of his day. (He left WQXR for C.B.S. in 1942.)

title: They're Off in Australia Racing Mice, That Is
description: PERTH. Australia, Sept. (Reuters)You name it and Australians will he on it. The latest enthusiasm is mouse racing and it is expanding rapidly in popularity.

title: Susan Bass Engaged
description: ABINGTON, Pa., Sept. 9Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Jerome Bass have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Ellen Bass, a student at Barnard College, to Joseph Barry Jacobs, who is attending the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Jacobs of South Orange, N. J.

title: AUSTRALIAN BOWS
description: Neither rain nor wind nor the speed of Kerry Melville's forehand could stem the aggressive Mrs. Billie Jean King from remaining the queen of women's tennis yesterday at Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Theft by Design
description: From an interior decorating point of view, the thieves made interesting selectionsa pair of Corots, a pair of Breughel landscapes, as if each pair might be hung together in a room somewhere.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: I was disappointed by the San Miguel article. I spent three months in the town last summer with my three teenage children. We attended the Instituto Allende and met all kinds of friendly, lovely people, Mexican as well as North American. My oldest daughter is a typical 17yearold American girl, braless, outgoing and independent. She came and went freely in the evenings, met and socialized with respectable Mexican boys in The Jardin, the social center of town, and I never felt concerned about her safety.

title: HUMANIZING ROLE OF RELIGION EYED
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 More than 3,000 Biblical scholars and theologians spent five days at an international congress here this week discussing Religion and the Humanizing of Man.

title: Mailbox:
description: To The Editor:

title: Treasury Bond Market Learns to Love the Computer
description: Two years ago, after the stock market limped away bruised from its backoffice battle with paper, the securities industry vowed to modernize into the certificateless society.

title: Pop
description: STEPHEN STILLS: Manassas (Atlantic SD 2903). Poor Stephen Stills! Over and over again on this doublerecord set we hear how his lady love won't come away with him. You'd think that after writing Love The One You're With, Stills would find another woman. But the tight country and rock music of his new band, Manassas, is too often spoiled by the selfpitying cry of wounded male chauvinist.

title: Miss Wisconsin Is Miss America
description: ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 9Terry Anne Meeuwsen, Miss Wisconsin, was chosen Miss America 1973 in the 52d Miss America Pageant here tonight.

title: The World
description: SAIGONI abide by democratic principles, President Nguyen Van Thieu told a military audience here recently, but the more open is democracy, the more disorderly it is, and the more fissures it will leave open to Communist penetration.

title: Ring Lardner And the Portrait Of Folly; By Maxwell Geismar. 166 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell Company. $4.50. (Ages 12 to 16)
description: Like the girl was saying: Ma, what have they done to my song? To anyone or his reasonable facsimile who was there at the time, the 1920's and 1930's were no more than a way of life, needing no analysis. The expositors have been after them, however. Now even the intermediate grades have been told more about the age than was known by Scott and Zelda, Dottie, Alec and the dwarf who sat on J. P. Morgan's knee.

title: Januskiewicz, Praetorius Score Touchdowns as Syracuse Beats Temple, 17 10
Abortion Referendum Put On Massachusetts Ballots
description: BOSTON, Sept. 9 (UPI)The Abortion Referendum Committee, a coalition of six women's rights and abortion repeal groups in eastern Massachusetts, has filed petitions to have an abortion referendum placed on the Nov. 7 ballot.

title: HIGH MINORITY RATE SET IN COAST HIRING
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 9 (UPDA Federal district judge ordered yesterday that twothirds of all employes hired by the Imperial Irrigation District must be MexicanAmericans or blacks.

title: Phi Beta Kapa Receives Grant to Aid Humanities
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities announced yesterday an outright grant of $602,171 to Phi Beta Kappa in support of its National Hutnanities Faculty.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONFor several years, an embittered controversy has been, building regarding the use of quotas as a means of bringing discriminatedagainst minorities into jobs. In the past few days it has flared into the open in the Presidential campaign.

title: Act Two Is Spattered With Ted's Tears
description: TODAY, September 10, is a very important anniversary in my life. It is exactly three years since I finished first version of my first play, a comedydrama entitled 'More News in a Moment, which is set in Belfast at the height of the troubles  yes, those same troubles that plague Northern Ireland right now. At the start of the new Broadway season you might care to brood with me on a budding playwright's fate as the new season opened three years ago.

title: Wendy Leyser Becomes Bride
description: ROWAYTON, Conn., Sept. 9Miss Wendy Barrell Leyser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Doremus Leyser of Darien, was married in the Rowayton Methodist Church this afternoon to E. William Weyeneth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene E. Weyeneth of Westport and Hilton Head Island, S.C. The Rev. John Cole performed the ceremony.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: WEDGEPORT, Nova Scotia, Sept. 9  Well aware that giant tuna go for herring the way Broadway theater devotees go for fifth row center seats, captains of this famous fishing port have been taking the recent failure of local waters to attract bluefins in good grace.

title: Students in India Attack Rail Stations and Police
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 9 (UPI)Railway stations were burned, police outposts stormed and contingents of policemen stoned today by mobs of students in several parts of the northeastern state of Bihar.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Walter D. Bannard's The War Against the Good In Art was so inspiring that wish you had given it a full page spread. Art, as, Bannard pointed out, should be the flower of our civilization and, ultimately, its salvation. For the past ten years the art world establishment hag been less than inspiring.

title: How to turn $2,000 into $70 millionon paper
description: Ever wonder how those tycoons really do itI mean, starting out with tiny firm A and building it up into corporate empire Z? This book shows you stepbystep how it was done at LingTemcoVought by the biggest conglomerator of them all, James J. Ling.

title: Blind Youth Scared At Rare Acceptance By a Medical School
