description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 (AP) David W. Hartman begins his freshman studies next week in Temple University's medical school scared but excited, knowing he is an educational experiment.

title: What World War II and its aftermath were all aboutsome new reappraisals
description: Gaddis Smith treats Dean Acheson as the dominant figure in American foreignpolicy making for most of the period 194553. Acheson emerges not so modestly as present at the creation, as his memoirs suggest, but as principal creator of the period termed the cold war. One senses that Acheson was de facto President for foreign affairs, and Truman served as a vehicle, referring reporters to the Secretary of State's pronouncement. (The one exception in the volume is Truman's impromptu remark that the United States might use the atomic bomb in Korea.)

title: Rootless Americans
description: Beginning with The Hidden Persuaders in 1957, Vance Packard has written a series of successful books in which he has served both as a popularizer of the social scientists and as a muckraker. Both jobs need doing. Although the sociologists, psychologists, anthropologists and other social scientists deal constantly with subjects of broad public concern, few of them try to communicate with even highly intelligent laymen.

title: German Press Raises Questions About Taste
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 9 (UPI)German newspapers complained today that the program for the Olympic closing ceremony Monday did not take sufficiently into account the massacre of Israeli athletes by Arab guerrillas less than a week ago.

title: And Now for Something Truly Funny
description: THERE Is a resemblance between satire and Indian summer. For good satire has the ability to make its victim roast in canicular agony, while providing the innocent with the tang of an applerich autumnal morning. It has youthful intransigence and the wry knowingness of maturity; it can make the most irritating insight irresistible. It sticks by its unpopular opinions and does not ask for permission, pardon, sympathy. It is the only really dangerous art form, much so for its creator as for its butt. And yet only old, mellow cultures know how to produce it.

title: The Name They Share Is Part of Each
description: When Charles Edwin Hambrick Stowe went into bank to cash a check not long ago, the teller expressed a friendly interest in his signature.

title: Key Town Reported Lost By MALCOLM W. BROWNE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 9The political crisis in Cambodia's capital deepened today as news was received that North Vietnamese forces had captured the important district capital called Kampong Trabek.

title: Disputed Basket Halts Streak
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sunday, Sept. 10In a chaotic finish unparalleled for the sport of basketball, the Soviet Union snapped the 63game winning streak of the United States, 5150, early this morning and won the Olympic gold medal.

title: Swedes Organize To Build Coops
description: TABY, SwedenIn housing, the Swedes have phrase for itH.S.B.; the National Association of Tenants Savings and Building Societies, a 350,000member group dedicated to the development of more and better nonprofit cooperative housing. There are other cooperative building associations in Sweden, but none compares with H.S.B.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Candidates for the Presidency make certain assumptions about the condition of the nation and the world, and particularly about what kind of people we are, and what we think, or at least what we will swallow.

title: The World
description: BELGRADE  Amid the pine forests of Yugoslavia's highland area of Zlatibor, clusters of attractive, redroofed chalets create an impression of a resort for the welltodo. And that is what it is  Yugoslavsocialist style. Mercedeses, Volvos and Peugeots purr along the highways, outnumbered by small Fiats and Volkswagens but in sufficient quantity to cause wonder where such money comes from in country where the monthly average salary is only $100.

title: Card Errors Help Mets Triumph, 31
description: Gary Gentry hurled one of his strongest games for the New York Mets yesterday at Shea Stadium, but the unpredictable righthander needed excellent relief help from Tug McGraw and some erratic work in left field by Lou Brock of St. Louis before the Mets topped the Cardinals, 31.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Americans are not bringing violent crime to Mexico. Northern and central Mexico long have shared the high crime rates of the southern and southwestern portions of the United States which they adjoin. Kate Simon, in her excellent Mexico: Places and Pleasures, dwelt upon Mexico City's extraordinary homicide rate. It is comnon in that city for each block of homeowners to hire their own nighttime guard. And the state of Guerrero in which Acapulco is located is famous even among Mexicans for its violence. During the last full year for which F.B.I. statistics are available, 134 American cities, most of them in the South and Southwest, had had more criminal homicides capita than New York City.

title: The Hessian By Howard Fast. 192 pp. New York: William Morrow &
description: This novel finds Howard Fast in familiar territory (the American Revolution) and at his storytelling best. A Hessian drummer boy is captured by Connecticut militia and tried for what might now be called a war crime, in which he had no direct part. While in hiding, he had been befriended by a family of Quakers and attended by a maverick Catholic surgeon. But the Continental Establishment apprehends the boy, and puts him in the dock of a kangaroo court. The theme of the book is synopsized by the testy surgeon, who asks after the trial: Is war merciless... Or merciless?

title: The World
description: LONDON  Mrs. Indira Gandhi awaits Sheik Mujibur Rahman's arrival in New Delhi this week with a red carpet and a diplomatic hope chest.

title: Lindsay Miller Bride of E. G. Colson Jr.
description: STONINGTON, Conn., Sept. 9The marriage of Miss Lindsay Robinson Miller to E. Garrett Colson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Colson of Canton, Mass., took place here this afternoon. The Rev. C. Pendleton Lewis of Calvary Episcopal Church performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of the bride's parents, Comdr. Thomas Lloyd Miller, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Miller of Stonington and Coconut Grove; Fla. parents, Comdr. Thomas Lloyd Miller, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Miller of Stonington and Coconut Grove; Fla.

title: To the Editor:
description: As a reader who has still not made up his mind on the abortion issue, I want to congratulate Fred Shapiro for doing the impossible nowadaystreating fairly a viewpoint diametrically opposed to his own. The Right to Life groups, as well as representatives of Women's Lib, have every right to lobby and pressure their legislators in an effort to have their own particular philosophies on this subject made into law.

title: 63,917 See Grambling Win by 60
description: Richard Paul, a junior from Greenwood, Miss., booted two field goals from medium range to give Grambling a 60 victory over Morgan State in the aniual Whitney M. Young Jr., Memorial classic at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

title: Education
description: If poor children are provided better schooling, will they get better jobs when they grow up? Most education reformers have said yes in pushing such efforts as racial desegregation in schools, compensatory education, preschool programs and increased school spending.

title: CITY TO PURCHASE 273 NEW BUSES
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday announced the approval of contracts for 273 new airconditioned buses for delivery to city lines by next summer.

title: McGovern Says Attempt To Bug Office Was Foiled
TRANSPORTATION
description: The Board of Estimate this week will again consider a request from the Transit Authority for $3.5million to convert a Hudson River pier into a bus garage.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: ALBANY, Sept. 9The war against illegal and unsightly billboards in New York is proceeding slowly, steadily and satisfactorily, according to reports this week from the State Department of Transportation.

title: President Flies to WilkesBarre With Funds and Encouragement
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Sept. 9 (UPI)  President Nixon made a surprise visit to this flooddamaged community today with g $4million check for a local college, an offer of free picnic hot dogs and a promise that WilkesBarre would 'come back better than ever.

title: Americans Dwindle on the London Scene
description: LONDON  The London season is over. That unrelenting calendar of social events, which classically starts with the opening of the Royal Academy in May, has churned out another summer.

title: The Growing Love Affair Between Poles and Polonia
description: WARSAW  The scene at Warsaw's International Airport was unusual enough for airline representatives and cafeteria personnel to join the hundreds of onlookers craning for a better view from the crowded balcony above the customs hall. What everyone was looking at on this sunny day not long ago was a line of more than 500 patiently waiting PolishAmericans; a line so long that it extended into the flight service area. The PolishAmericans, some of whom were visiting Poland for the first time since emigrating many years ago, had just arrived on three charter flights that had touched down within a few minutes of one another and were wait ing to go through customs inspection.

title: Platitude Wins at Somers
description: SOMERS, N. Y., Sept. 9Platitude, who ran up a dozen straight championships last year, scored 11 points to capture the regular working hunter title today in the first of the Primrose Farm's fallwinter horse show series.

title: Television
description: I WANT to be in the human race, not the rating race. Is that a good answer? What do you think? Joe Franklin delivers the three sentences as one, pausing for a response if not quite a full answer. The host of WORTV's Joe Franklin Show (weekdays 1 to 2 P.M. with a nightly repeat following the Late Movie) is expounding on the Numbers, TV's deadliest game.

title: Princess Visits Michigan
description: HOLLAND, Mich., Sept 9 (UPI)  Princess Margriet of the Netherlands arrived here early today to help the city celebrate its 125th anniversary. The Princess and her hushand. Pieter van Vollenhoven, were greeted by 200 persons as they stepped off the plane at Tulip City Airport.

title: To Survive, Bookstores Move to Malls
description: NEWARK  New Jersey's bookstores have moved out of local communities to shopping centers in recent years in order to survive.

title: Plates Fly as Onassis Gives Party in Athens
description: ATHENS, Sept. 9 (AP) Aristotle Onassis gave party at a seaside night club and a guest reported record plate smashing.

title: Winfield James, Reporter, Weds Patricia Barrett
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 9Miss Patricia Hope Barrett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dirk K. Barrett, was married in the Central Presbyterian Church here at noon today to Winfield Scott James, son of Mr. and Mrs. Winfield H. James of Larchmont, N. Y. The ceremony, written by the bridal couple, was performed by the Rev. Dr. Robert Stephens.

title: CHARLES J. BRODY
description: Charles J. Brody, superintendent of the Lenox Hill station of the United States Postal Service, 221 East 70th Street, died of cancer in Montefiore Hospital on Friday. He was 55 years old and lived at 3656 Johnson Avenue, Riverdale, the. Bronx.

title: Faleons Rout Bengals, 4414
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 (UPI)Bob Berry threw for two touchdowns and Joe Profit ran for another pair as the Atlanta Falcons overwhelmed the Cincinnati Bengals, 4414, tonight.

title: Al Unser Again Takes Hoosier Hundred Race
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 9 (AP) Al Unser won the Hoosier Hundred auto race for the third straight year today. making the Indiana Fairgrounds dirt track an even friendlier place than the Indianapolis Motor Speedway across town.

title: Harness Race Drivers To Honor Track Group
description: The Harness Tracks of America, comprising 47 parimutuel tracks in the United States and Canada, has been voted the 1972 Winner's Circle Award for distinguished service to the sport by the National Association of Harness Drivers.

title: Indians Beat Red Sox, 21, For Perry's 20th Victory
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 Graig Nettles's home run with one out in the 10th inning today gave the Cleveland Indians a 21 victory over the Boston Red Sox and enabled Gaylord Perry to score his 20th victory.

title: Laurence S. Ross Marries Emily Lanier
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 9 Miss Emily Caroline Lanier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Lanier, was married here this afternoon in St. Francis Episcopal Church to Laurence Seton Ross, son of Dr. and Mrs. H. Justin Ross of Montrose, Pa., and Ringoes, N. J. The Rev. Robert M. Dresser performed the ceremony.

title: Cahill Says Efficiency and New Income Give StaM $40.8Million
description: TRENTON, Sept. 9 (AP) Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that his administration's efficiency program, coupled with new sources of income, had provided the state with a neL dividend of $40.8million.

title: The Only Dope on the First Bad Trip Was the Passenger
description: No one likes to travel quite as much as an Englishman. You have only to tell him that there is some spot on the globe that is distant, difficult or forbidding and he will have his luggage packed within the hour and be off, dressed in sturdy tweeds and stout walking shoes.

title: DELAY IS EXPECTED IN TEACHERS VOTE
description: The United Federation of Teachers said yesterday that voting on a new contract by the city's 70,000 public school teachers was expected to be delayed at least a day.

title: Fiction: Irony, elitism, Babbitt updated, Africa, civil rights
description: Institutions, in West Indian society, were created by slavery and colonialism, for a small elite. When a new Elite, however, began to emerge, the peasant majority began to understand their former white rulers through the black imitators who succeeded them. The peasant at this stage also recognized that the institutions sustaining the black elite were even more vulnerable than the ones that had upheld the white one; that these borrowed institutions could be coopted, transformed and finally destroyed if necessary. A mass demonstra

title: Letters
description: The sale of properties does not necessarily mean going backward. Many realestate brokers in the area believe it is a healthy step. On the Concourse have recently been built Executive Towers Apartments and a new building for the Telephone Company.

title: 2,000 Old Car Bodies Pose Honolulu Problem
description: HONULULU, Sept. 9 (AP)A drive to tidy up the island of Oahu has left Honolulu with 2,000 junk cars and no place to put them.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Fred M. Hechinger's article, An AntiJewish Joke? has highlighted a grotesque situation whereby Jewish gag writers in Beverly Hills and New York are busily creating the impression of selflacerating hatred reaching paranoid proportions. Through the efforts of these miserable scribes we have come to a pass where the mere mention of the word Jewish is bound to provoke gales of laughter, particularly in situation comedies on TV.

title: Virginia Eleven Wins, 2416
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 9 (AP)Virginia used two fumble recoveries and, a blocked punt to defeat the University of South Carolina, 2416, tonight.

title: Cousteau searches for his whale
description: REDHOOK, St. Thomas, V. I.: All afternoon people poke along the road above Cowpet Bay, looking for Capt. Jacques Yves Cousteau. Word has passed through the community of expensive, new condominiums that the captain is arriving to join members of his team, who are living in an apartment overlooking the beach while shooting a film about humpback whales.

title: M.I.T. to Raise Tuition
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 91 (AP)  Massachusetts Institute of Technology has announced that it is increasing its tuition by $200, beginning with the summer session of 1973. Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, its president, said Wednesday that the school had cut its budget this year, but there was no respi Bible alternative to an in crease. Tuition, beginning next summer ,will he S3,100 a year.

title: Court Hearing Slated On Rockaways Fare
description: The longstanding controversy over the double fare on the Rockaway subway line will reach a new stage on Sept. 27, when the case will be considered by the State Supreme Court.

title: Notes: 7/8Day Hops Resume in November
description: AMERICANS are expected to fly to Europe in record numbers this winter, taking advantage of lowcost oneweek tour packages again being offered by airlines and tour operators. The packages will be in effect from Nov. 1 to Dec. 15 and from in. 4 to March 31.

title: State Breeds Quail as Quarry
description: JACKSON TOWNSHIP When the hunting season opens Nov. 11, sportsmen will find 82,000 game birds waiting for them on public hunting grounds.

title: Carolyn Paladino Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rocco L. Paladino of Whitestone, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Paladino, to Lieut. Jeffrey A. McNally, U.S.A., son of Richard McNally of Des Plaines, Ill., and Mrs. Robert Oster of Chicago. The future bride is a graduate of Marymount College.

title: Deputy Assistant Fire Chief Gets Fire Prevention Post
description: Joseph A. Flynn, a 51yearold deputy assistant chief in the Fire Department, was promoted to assistant chief in charge of the Division of Fire Prevention, Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery has announced.

title: Aster Days
description: September brings starry days as well as starry nights. The asters, which began to bloom here and there almost a month ago, now come into their own, fields of them, acres, roadsides and hillsides frosted with asters. And, in fortunate places, purpled with them, those big New England asters that make such a spectacular display against a background of goldenrod. If they weren't so many and so everywhere, the autumn asters would be one of our natural spectacles, like the dogwood, the mountain laurel or the October maples. But they are in every fencerow, every pasture lot, on every village refuse dump. They even invade the city and try to beautify the rubble and the alleyways of the slums.

title: Pop
description: WITH the establishment of rock as the dominant stylistic force in American pop music, it was only a matter of time before a new group of young interpretive performers, raised and weaned on folk, blues, rock a roll, etc., would arrive on the scene. Since the earliest rock musicians were primarily concerned with the personal exploration of hard rhythms, highdecibel electronics and riffbased, bluesstyled melodies, it has taken a while for a reasonable number of songs with interpretive potential to emerge. But they've been coming, and from the Beatles to Don McLeanwith stops in betweena neardecade of new pop song has become available for the new young interpreters.

title: Get 10 or 20 Playwrights Into a Room...
description: I HAVE long had a dream that is also a conviction. Perhaps it is a conviction that is also a dream. It's just this. If I0 or 20 playwrightsmen and women who have done work at the tradewere gathered in a single room, and if one manager or a representative of a cabal of managers were to point his tinger around the room, saying You have a play for the Barrymore by October, you have a play for the Broadhurst by November, you have one for the Morosco by suchandsuch a time, all of the plays would get Written.

title: 2,486 Dogs Slated at Westchester Show
description: A hardy oldtimer on the dogshow circuit has a brand new location for its 55th event. It's the Westchester Kennel Club fixture and it is being held today on the beautiful grounds of Sterling Forest in Tuxedo Park, N.Y. There are 2,486 dogs, representing 122 breeds or varieties. Judging starts at 9 A.M., with the groups at 3 P.M. After having been at Croton Point Park for four years, Westchester had to seek a new location in a hurry. rieties. Judging starts at 9 A.M., with the groups at 3 P.M. After having been at Croton Point Park for four years, Westchester had to seek a new location in a hurry.

title: Many Players Missing or Gone as N.H.L. Camps Open
description: Training camps, decimated by defections and the loss of star players to Team Canada, open for the National Hockey League this weekend.

title: U.S. Opposes Trips
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The spokesman for the Department of Defense, Jerry W. Freidheim. issued a statement today opposing travel by families of prisoners of war to North Vietnam.

title: Caroline Wins on Coast
description: SAN MATEO, Calif. Sept. 9 (AP)  A. L. Diaz rode Caroline to a twolength victory over the favorite, Our Madam Lucky, in the $20,000 Hillsborough Handicap at Bay Meadows today.

title: More Words Of Science; By Isaac Asimov. Illustrated 267 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $5.95. (Ages 12 and Up)
description: In More Words of Science, Isaac Asimov exhibits, as he did in his 1959 Words of Science (to which this book is a sequel), the same deep attention to the science of words as he does to science. Dr. Asimov's knowledge of his subjects embraces their etymology, lending, in most cases, a simple clarity to even the more complex definitions.

title: Undercover Men Hired For Resort Drug Raids
description: DOVER  More than 50 persons have been arrested on charges of selling drugs, and others are.being sought in the wake of annual narcotics raids conducted by resort municipalities in the northern part of Ocean County.

title: Cowboys Top Raiders, 1610
description: DALLAS, Sept, 9 (UPI) Charlie Waters's 61yard interception runback and three field goals by Tony Fritsch carried the Dallas Cowboys to a 1610 victory over the Oakland Raiders tonight..

title: Editor Urges Halt In Aid After Arson Destroys His Shop
description: MADISONVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 9After Dan Hicks Jr. stood in the fire ruins of his weekly newspaper shop Aug. 23 and said it was another act of arson, he began to get offers of help.

title: Mary A. Halbarth Married in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 9  Miss Mary Ann Halbarth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred W. Halbarth, was married here this afternoon to L. James Phillips, son of Mrs. Lloyd J. Phillips of New York and the late Mr. Phillips. The ceremony was performed in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Thomas P. Byrne.

title: Photography
description: IT'S a playground, is all it is, says Ed Ruscha. Photography's just a playground for me. I'm not a photographer at all.

title: Miss Chisholm, Smith Alumna, Wed to Doctor
description: The chapel of St. James Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Cynthia Wisner Chisholm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Field Chisholm of Laurel, Miss., to Dr. Nathan Emile SaintAmand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Emile SaintAmand of Gaffney, S.C. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John B. Coburn, assisted by the Rev. Clarke K. Oler.

title: 5 Die as Storms Hit Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 9 (Reuters)At least five persons were killed. eight injured and five others reported missing in floods and landslides after rainstorms lashed southeast Japan today.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Cascade Airlines, Air Wisconsin or Pilgrim Airlines are not the household words in airline circles occupied by the big trunk carriers on the order of Pan Am, United or Eastern.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two Southampton, L. I., policemen found a break in the Long Island Rail Road tracks late Friday night at Water Mill a halfhour before a MontauktoNew York passenger express was due.

title: John Kirshon Weds Barbara Steinmetz
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 9Miss Barbara Jean Steinmetz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Steinmetz of North Stamford, was married here this morning to John William Kirshon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Kirshon of New York and Southampton, L. I. The Rev. John Moertz performed the ceremony in St. John's Lutheran Church.

title: Movies
description: ON AN unusually hot and humid day in London, a man of severe mien, with downcast eyes, small mustache, and stocky build, keeps a luncheon appointment with me at a new, posh restaurant. As he walks in, something about the movement of his neck, the curt, staccato pace of his walk, instantly translates into the image of one of the most hated men who ever livedAdolf Hitler.

title: Attack on Refugee Camp Near Danang Is Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Sept. 10 (AP)  A Vietcong demolition squad reportedly attacked South Vietnam's biggest refugee camp yesterday, taking a heavy toll in life and property.

title: 1973 Autos Will Stress Control Over Pollution
description: DETROIT, Sept. 9In a few days the 1973 cars go on sale and most of them will not look much different from the old 72's. But these cars represent major accomplishments in Detroit's efforts to satisfy the consumerenvironmental revolution.

title: WELFARE CLIENTS SEEKING DAMAGES
description: Legalservices lawyers who won a Federal Court order against the state's workrelief law as applied to welfare family cases are seeking retroactive damages for cases terminated for noncompliance.

title: Hubert Long, Talent Agent In Country Music, Is Dead
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 8 (AP)Hubert Long, a talent agent who represented some of the top names in country music for two decades, died here Thursday, several months after undergoing surgery for removal of a brain tumor. He was 48 years old.

title: For Aged, Handball Still Packs Wallop
description: They were old men, but their bodies were trim and they flailed at the hard rubber ball with great gusto.

title: U.S. WILL AIRLIFT RICE TO CAMBODIA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The United States is preparing to fly! supplies of rice from Saigon to Pnompenh, the Cambodian capital, State Department officials said today.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: WE read with great interest John Canaday's article on the Romare Bearden mural in Harlem and were particularly taken by his comment that the work had actually been improved by the graffiti added to it. The problem of the apparently inevitable spread of graffiti on any available space in this town is of great interest to us because one of our gallery artists, Arnold Belkin, has been working, under the auspices of the City Arts Council, on a large mural at a playground in the Hells Kitchen

title: Pier Gets Name: Pier
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 9 (AP)Joseph E. Duffy won a $25 savings bond Thursday in a contest to name the city's new fishing pier. His entry was among 1,500, which were narrowed down to 15. The final selection was made by a drawing. His entry: The Pier.

title: POLL FINDS YOUNG SHIFTING TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Younger voters appear to be switching from Senator George McGovern to President Nixon, according to the newest Gallup Poll.

title: Riot Follows Football Game
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga., Sept. 9 (UPI)Rioting involving white and black spectators broke out at a high school football game here last night and the police used tear gas to restore order. Two persons were stabbed, one seriously enough to require hospitalization, aro at least 12 per. sons were arrested.

title: Tennessee Race May Turn on Busing.
HOUSING DEBATED IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 9 The Urban Development Corporation got a convincing demonstration last week that local opposition has not disappeared in the five weeks since the agency agreed to a moratorium on most of its activity in nine Westchester County towns.

title: The United States And the Origins of The Cold War 19411947
description: The Moscow summit suggests that much of the cold war is history, but that history remains a battleground. The terms of the conflict are increasingly set by the revisionists, who generally maintain that American efforts to guarantee an open door for an expansionist capitalism led Russia to clamp an admittedly repressive but defensive regime on Eastern Europe.

title: Algeria's 3 Revolutions
description: ALGIERSRevolution is a much used word in Algeria these days. Two are under way and a third is promised in a country that celebrated in July the 10th anniversary of her independence from France, which followed a bloody eightyear revolution.

title: Laurie Brill Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Brill of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laurie Jay Brill, to Dr. Bernard R. Klein, an ophthalmologist at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Klein of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Miss Bogash Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving A. Bogash have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Bogash, to Dr. Dennis M. Sivak, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Sivak of Louisville.

title: New Medical Students at N.Y.U. Oriented by Peers
description: In addition to the words of greeting from faculty members and administrators, the incoming class of firstyear medical students at the New York University school of medicine were asked some weighty questions during their orientation last week.

title: Alley Jaggers plays Proteus
description: This jest book, a grabbag of graffiti, japes, capers, doggerel, slapstick and random ruminations, brings Paul West's Alley Jaggers trilogy to a conclusion. Well, to a conclusion of a sort. During the course of Alley Jaggers (1966), the British plasterer rides from place to place on his Honda, quarrels with his wife Dot, puts up with his widowed Mam, builds a glider, indulges himself with a phony Irish brogue, runs off with a gogo girl, strangles her to death (without meaning to), and makes love to her corpse (without much meaning to). He ends that novel penned i,) in the madhouse, a fit place for a man of effects rather than causes. Alley was, and is in this last fiction, a victim of West's relentless appetite for novelty. Putting his chip always on the outlandish incident, he divides and subdivides Alley's character into a bricabrac of what the burlesque comics call bits: the workingman bit, the Walter Mitty bit, the rambling lunatic bit, the horny husband bit, the poet manque bit...there is no end.

title: Miss Stevens, J. R. Polk Jr. Plan to Marry
description: JERICHO, L.I., Sept. 9Mr. and Mrs. Byam Kerby Stevens Jr. of Kirby Hill here have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Lucas Stevens, to James Robert Polk Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Polk of Creve Coeur, Mo.

title: JUDGE SENTENCES 2 YOUTHS TO TEACH
description: MIAMI, Sept. 9 (AP)A judge who thinks illiteracy is one of the major causes of crime has given two white teenagers chance to teach black prisoners to read and write instead of going to jail.

title: 3 SYRIAN PLANES DOWNED IN CLASH WITH THE ISRAELIS 4th Arab Aircraft Reported Struck in Battle Over the Golan Heights
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 9Israeli Air Force jets intercepted four Syrian warplanes over the occupied Golan heights today downing three of them and hitting the fourth, an Israeli military spokesman announced.

title: Donors to Baldwin Fair Share Common Interest
description: BALDWIN, L. I.  The handsewn, handknit, handwrought, handcarved and handpainted works of 73 men, women and children will.be offered for sale at home crafts fair that will be held here on Sept. 23.

title: News of Boating
description: It will be Dynamite vs. Mirage today in the opening race of the Canada's Cup sailing competition at Toronto.

title: Namero Uno, the jetset's matador
description: Luis Miguel Dominguin is rarity among toreros. He is a sophisticate, capable of articulating the details of what is essentially an instinctive craft. His brain was both his greatest asset and his greatest liability during the years when he was the bullring's outstanding performer. It is also the greatest asset in the hands of his biographer, Keith Botsford  but, once again, it is a liability to its owner. What ultimately emerges from this book is the portrait of a vain and petulant man, fascinating but selfcentered, intelligent but not wise, whose existence is curdled by the sour aftertaste of a life too greedily lived.

title: Television
description: IT'S a brand new television season and, if you pay any attention to publicity being generated by the networks, the operative word is special. That, at least for the moment, describes quantity rather than quality.

title: F. C. Losen Weds Marjorie Neppel
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I, Sept. 9Miss Marjorie Joan Neppel and Frederick Cyril Losen, a pilot holding the rank of first officer with Pan American Airways, were married here this noon. After a reception at the Centerport Yacht Club, the couple left under sail to Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard aboard the bridegroom's 34foot boat.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Along with Loften Mitchell. I, too, am not oniy In awe of Paul Robeson's vast and extraordinary gifts but heartsick that since 1949 we in American have been deprived of seeing and hearing him perform.

title: Shriver Assails President On Reaction to the Poor
Landfills Take Toll of Marsh Birds
description: NORTH ARLINGTONThe aluminum boat turned in from the Hackensack River and pushed its prow between the thick cord grass and the sinuous waving reeds into an allbuthidden creek in the Meadowlands salt marshes here. In the marshes, the reeds hide the shallow rivulets that cut through the Meadowlands estuary, creating hidden sanctuaries for ducks, mudhens, egrets and herons.

title: Poignant, contemporary, innovative
description: Penelope Gilliatt has been for some time very well known on both sides of the Atlantic as a film critic, and this year earned universal fame as the author of the script of Sunday, Bloody Sundaya script which was voted best of the year by the New York Film Critics Circles She has written two novelsOne by One and A State of Changewhich seem to me to be of great originality and whose peculiar flavor is recalled, like a rarely consumed but classic dish, in this, her second volume of stories.

title: Obeah Is a Fact of Life, and Afterlife, in the Caribbean
description: Caribbean travel notes:

title: Soviet Physicist Quits Human Rights Group
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 9  Dr. Valery N. Chalidze, a physicist whose civil rights campaigning the secret police have sought to stop, has resigned from the Committee on Human Rights, an unofficial group headed by Andrei D. Sakharov, reliable sources disclosed today.

title: Many Upstate Communities Ponder Mergers as Costs Rise
description: ALBANY, Sept. 9Can the vrillages towns and cities ofupper New York State achieve economy, efficiency and taxsavings by merging into bigger governmental units and consolidating their services?

title: If You Go...
description: on a factory store and mill outlet outing in Connecticut and Massachusetts, the first day's stop could be at Bridgeport, Conn.: the American Fabric Company, the Levine Coat Company (women's and children's clothes) and Mitchell Brothers (women's nightgowns). Head north to Shelton for the B.F. Goodrich store (sneakers and boots) and Shelton Hosiery Mills, then west to Danbury for a call at John B. Stetson (men's clothing), then on to nearby Brookfield Center's County Calicoes, Inc. (ask for Obtuse Road South).

title: Ann Strother Bride Of John P. Streb Jr.
description: DOBBS FERRY, Sept. 9The marriage of Miss Ann Ramsdell Strother, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Corneille 0. Strother, to John P. Streb Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Streb, took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Charles Colwell performed the Episcopal ceremony on the grounds of the Masters School, of which the bride is a graduate.

title: BYZANTINE TOMBS FOUND IN ISTANBUL
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 9 (AP)A new discovery has confirmed the suspicions of archeologists that tombs and cemeteries of the Byzantine period are buried under much of Istanbul.

title: Ivy League Football Prospects: Dartmouth Rated Top Choice to Take Crown
description: Three of the best running backs in the Ivy League, who were expected to help their teams considerably, will not return this fall.

title: To the Editor:
description: Fred C. Shapiro's article on abortion is the first truthful article I have read on the subject. He rightly pinpoints the matter as political. Abortion has never been the moral issue of saving babies vs. killing babies that some people would have us believe it is. It is purely a political issue of who is the legal guardian of American uteri.

title: Gang's Activities Expose Ways of Organized Crime
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP"Wall safe, read the scrawl next to the name of a doctor from Ellenville, N. Y. The notation was followed by his office hours, when he and his wife were likely to be away, and the warning he had frequent house guests during the summer.

title: Gun Discharge Hurts 5
description: REDMOND, Ore., Sept. 10 (UPI)  A 30caliber machine gun discharged yesterday while it was being cleaned and five National Guardsmen were injured. The accident occurred while the men were cleaning the weapon after completing tank gunnery exercise.

title: Red Smith
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 10So now the gasman cometh, to take the last 10 pfennig out of the meter and turn off the Olympic flame. In Israel there is a week national mourning. From Syrian and Lebanese villages rises the smoke of vengeful bombs. In Olympic Stadium tomorrow the band serenades Avery Brundage with For He's a Jolly Good Fellow. Six days too late, the Games of the XX Olympiad creak to a close, the happy Games, the freundlichspiel that became a carnival of blood and bitterness.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:I read with some unhappiness William E. Farrell's Aug. 30 news story. Mr. Farrell writes again on the subject of the Port Authority and he continues to make the erroneous statement, which your paper has carried for some time, that I and other members of the Port Authority have stanchly resisted pressure for it to become more involved in mass transportation projects.

title: Aiken Poloists Triumph Over Huntington, 5 to 4
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Sept. 10Pete Bostwick's goal with two minutes left in suddendeath overtime gave Aiken a 5.4 victory over Huntington in a Long Island Polo League match today at Bethpage State Park.

title: Fire Destroys Pier Here
description: Fire destroyed an abandoned East River pier and a floating drydock in College Point, Queens, early yesterday, Fire Department officials said, Two fireboats were called to the foot of 125th Street near Fifth Avenue, together with 10 pieces of ground apparatus. There were no injuries, and the blaze, which was repOrted at 1:35 A.M., was declared under control at 3:28 A.M.

title: StripMine Pretense
description: Two days before the Johnson Administration left office, Stewart L. Udall, then Secretary of. the Interior, approved regulations to control strip mining for coal on public and Indian lands in the West.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:The Soviet Government's attempt to capitalize on Jewish emigrants is a dehumanizing and unconscionable act. Moralhumanitarian consideration aside, it is essential to examine objectively the Soviet claim that persons emigrating from the U.S.S.R. should repay the state for the costs of their education.

title: Varied Texas Cultures Disprove Stereotypes of State at an Ethnic EatIn
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 9A tall, skinny woman eating a German sausage on a stick stood eying a big iron washpot that was giving off rich smells of cooking beef. What's in it? she asked a sweating cowboy who was stirring up a fire under the pot of stew.

title: Impartial City Election Board?; Rooney Case Raises Basic Questions of Political Integrity
description: Last woek's judicial decision setting aside the primary election victory of Representative John J. Rooney over Allard K. Lowenstein pointed up the fact that the Board of Elections, which is charged with insuring the integrity of elections, is actually a creature of the politicians involved in those elections. Some relationship between the board and politicians was built into the law that requires that board members be recommended by the two major parties, but insurgents, reformers and minor parties have long protested that this relationship is overly close.

title: Colts Conquer Broncos As Unitas Stars, 2013
description: Is life beginning at 39 for Johnny U.?

title: Opening in Panama Today Of First Elected Assembly
description: PANAMA, Sept. 10  Panama's first elected assembly is scheduled to begin a monthlong session Jere tomorrow.

title: Lung Cancer Found More Often In Cities Than in Rural Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)A scientific panel said today that lung cancer was twice as common among those who breathed the polluted air of cities as it was among country dwellers.

title: Thousands View AfricanAmerican Parade in City
description: Tens of thousands of blacks lined the northbound lane of Seventh Avenue in Harlem yesterday to watch the fourth annual AfricanAmerican Day Parade and to enjoy the warm weather.

title: Lawyers Charge Argentina Lied on Guerrilla Deaths
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 10Six Argentine lawyers have charged here that naval guards opened fire suddenly and without the slightest incident on imprisoned leftwing guerrillas who had been paraded at 3:30 A.M. on Aug. 22 at Patagonian naval base.

title: 3 MEN ARE CHARGED IN ASSAULT ON GIRLS
description: The president and vice president of a Manhattan recording company and a rock drummer were arrested yesterday and charged with having kidnapped, assaulted and sexually abused three teenaged girls.

title: South Africa Bids For Deal to Lift Steel Production
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 10The South African Iron and Steel Corporation (ISCOR) is in an advanced stage of negotiations with the Austrian Voest steel combine to put up a plant to produce some 150,000 tons a year of semiprocessed steel that could earn South Africa well over $500million a year in foreign exchange.

title: With the Dave Brubeck Family, The Stress Is on Togetherness
description: WILTON, Conn.One day recently a man and a woman sat in a parked car in nearby New Canaan and went over some contracts, planned some itineraries and did other paper work. They were waiting while their youngest child, 11yearold Matthew, took cello lesson.

title: Weaver Southern Victor On First Playoff Hole
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 10 (AP)DeWitt Weaver of Atlanta, faltering on the final two holes of regulation play, captured the $100,000 Southern open golf tournament today, by beating Chuck Courtney on the first hole of a playoff.

title: The Environment Of Politics
description: With President Nixon and Democratic Congressional leaders vying with each other as champions of the environment, this election year should have produced a spate of programs to clean up the nation's air and water, preserve its Natural resources and protect its scenic beauty. But it has so far yielded more acrimony than achievement, with both sides apparently content to blame each other for the paucity of legislation on the subject,

title: Jeweler Hangs Himself in Cell; Jail Suicide Is 10th Here in '72
description: A 30yearold jeweler hanged himself in his jail cell yesterday afternoon, the police said, little more than an hour after being arrested on charges of being drunk and disorderly.

title: U.S. Bows in Soccer, 21
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  Mexico today became the unbeaten victor in the North American zone of the world soccer competition by defeating the United States, 21, for the second time. Mexico must still play the Central American winner to gain place in the World Cup finals in Germany in 1974. The United States was eliminated earlier.

title: Milton Cruz's Piano Program Is Fluent Though a Bit Cautious
description: Concert managers, idealistic or otherwise, are constantly trying to find new auditoriums where they can get better exposure for their artists. Less expensive halls in a hospitable neighborhood and suitably sized may be some of the qualifications they are looking for.

title: 2 Die in Greenwich. Fire
description: GREENWICH, Sept. 10 (AP)  An Old Greenwich mother and her son, 2&3x00BD; years old, died of asphyxiation this morning in a house blaze that her husband and another son managed to escape, the police said. Bryce Ructon, 34, awoke shortly after 5 A.M., discovered hit house in flames, and fled the house with Bryce Jr., 3, according to the police. The police said Mr. Ruxton was unable to reenter the house in search of his wife, Jacqueline, and another son, William.

title: FASHION TALK
description: More than any other designer of this century, Coco Chanel changed the way women looked the world over. She also, 40 years ago, changed the way they perfumed themselves.

title: Nixon Enables Wisconsin To Receive U.S. Flood Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) President Nixon today designated parts of northwest Wisconsin a national disaster area.

title: ARABS IN PERUGIA MEET HOSTILITY
description: PERUGIA, Italy, Sept. 10This ancient hill capital of Umbria, host to a fluctuating body of more than 2,000 Arab cstudents, has suddenly become tense with suspicions, rumors and fears.

title: Bermuda Cricketers Win
description: The Bermuda cricket team defeated a United States team by 162 runs yesterday at Walker Park, Staten Island. In the second innings the Americans scored 157 runs.

title: Bilingual Curriculum Is Broadened by City
description: A steppedup program in bilingual education heads the list of new offerings and improved services that the New York City public school system plans to offer the 1,161,500 pupils who begin classes today.

title: Antoinette Cavuoto Wed
description: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J., Sept. 10The marriage of Miss Antoinette Theresa Cavuoto, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pasquale E. Cavuoto, to William Robert Meyer, son of Mrs. Robert Meyer of Rivervale and the late Mr. Meyer, took place here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady Mother of the Church. The Rev. Dominic Fucille performed the ceremony. The bride is with the public relations department of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, the New York advertising agency, and her husband is with the guest relations department of the National Broadcasting Company.

title: School Workers End Strike
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 10 (UPI)Public school maiintcnance workers and custodians voted today to accept an agreement ending their threeandahalf week strike against city schools.

title: Shoulder Pin Removed, Staubach Mending Well
description: DALLAS, Sept. 10 (UPI)Doctors removed the pin from Roger Staubach's right shoulder yesterday and said the Dallas Cowboys quarterback could be throwing footballs again in 10 days.

title: Joe Cocker Sings Familiar Hits on L.I.
description: When Joe Cocker appeared at Madison Square Garden last spring it sounded as if it was all over for the jerkylimbed, gravelvoiced English rock singer. His backup band was erratic and unsupportive, the trio of accompanying singers was just this side of amateurish, and Cocker himself looked bloated and sounded listless.

title: New Norton Co. Product
description: The Norton Company announced yesterday that it had developed a new abrasive belt, made with a zirconia alumina alloy, that cuts up to 40 percent faster than conventional belts.

title: CORONA TRIAL OPENS IN CALIFORNIA TODAY
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Sept. 10 The trial of Juan Corona, a farm labor contractor accused of killing 25 men, is scheduled to begin here tomorrow after being delayed for more than 10 months.

title: Petty Triumphs in 500
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 10 (AP)Richard Petty of Randleman, N. C., driving the last 25 laps with a tire on his battered 1972 Plymouth going flat, won the Capital City 500 Grand National today. It was his sixth victory of the season in the, National Association of Stock, Car Auto Racing series.

title: Ireland Fails to Settle Traveling People
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 8Despite the fitful efforts of the Irish Government to change their colorful lifestyle and settle them down, the traveling people of Ireland persist in, their nomadic existence and their numbers seem, to be swelling rather than declining.

title: Retail Census Says Number of Stores Declined by 12,400
description: An annual, private census of the retail industry reported over the weekend that the number of American stores declined by 12,400 in the last year. The loss in the last five years has been 60,000.

title: Boeing Confirms Accord
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 10 (Reuters) The Boeing Company tonight confirmed that an agreement has been signed in Peking for the sale of 10 Boeing 707 passenger jets to China.

title: Jane Ward Bride Of Stephen Waller
description: CENTERVILLE, Mass., Sept. 10  Miss Jane Ballard Ward was married here this afternoon to Stephen Glenn Waller. The Rev. Robert Sargent performed the ceremony in the South Congregational Church.

title: GEORGE V. KENDALL EXWABASH DEAN, 91
description: DUXBURY, Mass., Sept. 10 George V. Kendall, dean emeritus of Wabash College in Crawfordsville, Ind., died yesterday at his home here. He was 91 years old.

title: BILL SEEKS A REIN ON MEAT LABELING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) Legislation about to emerge from the House Agriculture Committee could result in a costly Federal penalty for cities and states that try to enact meat packaging and labeling rules stronger than those of the Federal Government.

title: HIGH LIVING COST VEXES ALSATIANS
description: PULVERSHEIM, France, Sept. 8A group of some 30 potash miners here sounded the one discordant note in Premier Pierre Messmer's preelectoral tour of Alsace.

title: 4POUND DOG BEST AT WESTCHESTER
description: TUXEDO, N. Y., Sept. 10A tiny fourpouneer proved to be the biggest dog of 2,498 at the Westchester Kennel Club's 55th fixture tonight in Sterling Forest, N. Y. For Ch. MiLo's Mischief Gold Pat, a Pomeranian owned by Lady Florence Conyers of Bermuda was chosen best in show by James A. Farrell Jr., making Westchester history. It was the first time Porn had taken the top prize at this prestigious event.

title: Hard To Beat Defeats Roberto By a Length in Prix Neil Race
description: PARIS, Sept. 10Junzo Kashiyama's Hard To Beat lived up to his name again today by defeating John W. Galbreath's Epsom Derby winner, Roberto, over 1 miles at Longchamp in the $45,000 Prix Neil.

title: GREEK PRIMATE BARS MOVE FROM TURKEY
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 10 Archbishop Iakovos, Primate of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America, said today that he was not in agreement with a suggestion by a prominent Charlotte priest that the center of Eastern Orthodoxy be moved from Istanbul, Turkey.

title: Fittipaldi, in Lotus, Wins Monza Race
description: MONZA, Italy, Sept. 10 (UPI) Emerson Fittipaldi toasted his gold and black Lotus to victory in the Italian Grand Prix today and became the first Brazilian to win the world drivers championship as well when Jackie Ickx of Belgium dropped out in the 46th lap.

title: Many Flee India Floodwater
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 10 (Agence FrancePresse)Thousands of people evacuated lowlying areas and others perched on roofs today as tidal waves lashed the eastern Indian coast in Orissa Slate. No reports had been received here of loss of life.

title: U.S. TRADE GROUPS LAND IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10The arrival of two United States business delegations in Moscow day signaled a new round of intensive trade talks here this week, coincident with discussions between Soviet leaders and Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser.

title: Bridge:
description: One could debate the proposition that the man who finishes last in a marathon is much more tired than the winner because he has been running for a much longer time.

title: U.C.L.A. Ends Nebraska Streak
description: Nebraska's supposedly punctureproof Cornhuskers failed their very first test in defense of their No. 1 college football preseason rating.

title: Spassky Flies Home On 2dClass Ticket; Finds the Air Chilly
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10 (AP) Boris Spassky, the man who let the world chess championship slip from Soviet hands for the first time in 24 years, returned home to a loser's welcome tonight. The only concession authorities made to him was that he did not have to open his bags for customs inspection.

title: Fort Lee Council Bans Rezoning To Stem Long HighRise Boom
description: FORT LEE, N. J. Sept. 10Along the crest of Fort Lee's Palisades and back along the quiet side streets, the ranks of highrise apartment buildings shoulder up through the trees like monolithic symbols of prosperity.

title: WORLD GOLF GOES TO GARY PLAYER
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 10Gary Player won the world series of golf today with its $50,000 first prize, then flew home to South Africa, ending his campaign for the year in the United States.

title: State TakeOver of Funding Inevitable, Nyquist Says
description: It is inevitable that the state will assume the financing of local school systems, the New York State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.The series of articles by your staff writers Linda Charleton and Iver Peterson did a public service by spotlighting one of the more fraudulent areas of malpractice in the mental health field, the granting of diplomamill degrees which are used by unscrupulous individuals who set themselves up as selfstyled mental health practitioners.

title: U.S. CASTS A VETO IN U.N. ON MIDEAST, CITING TERRORISM
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 10The United States tonight vetoed a Security Council resolution that would have called for an immediate halt to military operations in the Middle East but that did not mention the terrorist acts that led to Israeli air strikes against Syria and Lebanon.

title: CATHOLIC TEACHERS ACCEPT A CONTRACT
description: A strike authorized by 558 Catholic lay teachers against 12 Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens was averted last night when the teachers voted to accept a contract containing no salary increases and virtually no new benefits.

title: GIANTS SET BACK BROWNS BY 2821
description: The Giants completed their first winning exhibition campaign in over 13 years yesterday as Charlie Evans scored four touchdowns to beat the Cleveland Browns, 2821, before 60,152 fans at Yankee Stadium.

title: ACTION BY EGYPT SEEN AS UNLIKELY
description: CAIRO, Sept. 10  The Egyptian Government, though angered by the Israeli air raids on Palestinian camps in Lebanon and Syria, is determined to avoid involvement in military action against Israel unless the Israelis attack Egyptian territory, political sources here said today.

title: Israel Denies Cairo Report
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 10 (Reuters) The chief spokesman of the Israeli Defense Ministry dismissed tonight as utter rubbish an Egyptian press report that Defense Minister Dayan was at Munich when the Israeli athletes were killed. The report had been carried by the official Egyptian Middle East News Agency.

title: Cork Eleven Beats Cypress
description: CORK, Ireland, Sept. 10 (AP) The Cork Hihernians beat Paizoporicos of Cyprus, 21, in the first leg of a firstround European soccer cup winners cup match before 8,000 fans today. The second leg of the match is scheduled here Wednesday.

title: Jockey Hurt in Spill
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 10 (AP)Steve Valdez, a promising rookie rider, was injured in a threehorse spill in the final race at Del Mar yesterday. The 16yearold jockey suffered three broken ribs, a lung laceration and a ruptured spleen. He will be out about two months.

title: Retribution and Justice
description: It was predictable and understandable that Israel should retaliate for the murders in Munich by striking hard at centers of Palestinian guerrilla operations Syria and Lebanon. The danger now is that indefinite prolongation of the retributive attacks on the scale last Friday's operations will help defeat, rather than advance, the legitimate objectives of Israel and the whole civilized world in regard to Palestinian terrorism.

title: Pressure Is Put on Cahill To Modify Tocks Is. Plan
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10Gov. William T. Cahill, facing one of the most crucial decisions of his administration this week, is coming under increasing pressure to modify the plan for the proposed Tocks Island dam and national park.

title: M'GOVERN SILENT ON BUGGING SPY
description: ESPANOLA, N. M., Sept. 10 Senator George McGovern refused today to confirm or to deny published reports that the Democratic party had a highly placed informant at the Committee for the Reelection of the President or the Republican National Committee.

title: Personal Finance: Guidelines for Insurance Ads
description: Herbert S. Denenberg, Pennsylvania's increasingly influential Insurance Commissioner, shook up the health insurance business earlier this year after he spotted an ad he didn't like.

title: DOLPHINS 21, VIKINGS 19
description: Miami overcame a 12point Minnesota lead in the final minutes with Mercury Morris's diving 6yard touchdown with 52 seconds left and Bob Griese's earlier passing. Fred Cox kicked four field goals for the Vikings from 40, 30, 24 and 17 yards. But he missed one with two seconds left from 44 yards. It fell short.

title: Aliens in Cambodia Fear New Purge
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 10The Cambodian nation is in deep trouble and once again its nonCambodian residents are living in dread lest they be blamed for everything and become targets of a new pogrom.

title: Economic Future Clouded By Virgin Island Slayings
description: ST. CROIX, V. I., Sept. 10The slaying of four American tourists and four workers at a golf course here last Wednesday has clouded the economic future of the Virgin Islands and has raised fundamental questions about the future race relations on an island that had prided itself on its tropical serenity.

title: $27Million Sale Is Planned For Canadian Theater Chain
description: TORONTO, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press)  Canadian Cablesystems, Ltd., of Toronto has entered an agreement to sell its 48.8 percent interest in Famous Players, Ltd., a Toronto theaterchain operator to an unidentified buyer for more than $27million.

title: DANIEL AUSLANDER;
description: Daniel Auslander, president of the United Pension Corporation and a leading agent of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, died Saturday on a vacation in Venice, Italy, after a short illness. He lived at 785 Park Avenue.

title: Rabbis Here Urge All Nations To Prevent Further Terrorism
description: Rabbis called on the nations of the world yesterday to develop security measures to prevent incidents like the slaying of Israeli athletes at Munich.

title: False Alarm Halts Effort To Calm a City in Georgia
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga., Sept. 10 (AP)Firemen investigated 14 firebombing reports tonight shortly after a false alarm interrupted an emergency meeting of city officials and black leaders in this northeast Georgia community.

title: Jerome Weinstein Is Dead; Lawyer and Tax Specialist
description: Jerome Weinstein, a lawyer and authority on tax policy, died yesterday at his home, 14 Fifth Avenue. He was 71 years old.

title: Olympic Personalities: Belated Bronze for U.S.
description: Tom McBreen of San Mateo, Calif., salvaged some solace for the United States yesterday when he was awarded an Olympic bronze medal for third place in the controversial 400meter freestyle swimming final held Sept. I.

title: Manila Areas Blacked Out In Latest Bombing Attack
description: MANILA, Monday, Sept. 11 (UPI)At least two explosions early today hit the main office of the Manila Electric Company and a power substation less than five miles away, causing a blackout in scattered residential and commercial areas. No casualties were reported.

title: GROUP WORSHIPS WITHOUT A RABBI
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Sept. 10The Eisenbergs and the Karels and about 40 of their friends joyfully ushered in the Jewish New Year at sundown Friday without benefit of clergy or sermon.

title: I. M. F Sees Gradual Gain From Parity Realignments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The currency realignment of last December should eventually do the job of straightening out the big, maladjustment in the balances of payments of the industrial countries, the International Monetary Fund concluded today.

title: Mrs. Cox at Polish Fete
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Sept, 10 (AP)  Mrs. Edward F. Cod heard Polish music, ate Polish food, and learned a Polish phrase during an hourlong weekend visit to a PolishAmerican festival 25 miles north of Philadelphia. The President's daughter was serenaded in Polish and deluged with gift yesterday during a stop at the Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa. Sto Let, or live 100 years, the crowd sang out to her. Sto Lat, she replied into a microphone, receiving enthusiastic applause.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame asserted yesterday that a dual set of records had been kept by the former management of the Pioneer Bus Corporation, and those submitted to the city had failed to show $108,033 in revenues between April 1, 1969, and last Jan. 13.

title: White House Treats 1,500 at WilhesBarre
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Sept. 10 (UPI)About 1,500 residents of this flood damaged community ate White House hamburgers and played games today at a, picnic served up by President Nixon's cooking staff.

title: Dayan Reported in Munich on Day of the Killings
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 10West Germans said tonight that Moshe Dayan, the Israeli Defense Minister, flew to Munich from Tel Aviv Tuesday night as the police here were making plans to rescue the Israeli athletes held by Arab terrorists.

title: OILERS 14, SAINTS 14
description: A standingroom crowd of 44,571 in Houston's Astrodome got its chance to cheer when Ward Walsh scored with 52 seconds left to give the Oilers the tie. Walsh, a running back, went round left end from 10 yards out for the score.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Tom Buckley in his fine news story (Aug. 30) stated that Senator Kennedy is attempting to protect the lonely moors and magnificent shoreline of the Vineyard, Nantucket and the Elizabeth Islands from the relentless pressure of real estate development. A noble gesture indeed.

title: Attica a Year Later: Calmer. but Grievances Persist
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 10I don't want to be a puppet just to prevent a riot, said Edwin Temple, one of 28 prisoners elected by fellow inmates to speak for them to administrators of the state prison here.

title: CITY ACTS TO DROP WELFARE ADDICTS
description: About threefourths of a first group of drug addicts to whom the city sent letters asking about their treatment programs failed to respond, and the city is moving to take them from the welfare rolls.

title: The Stage: Crazy Now
description: Stop the season, I want to get outl Well no, not really, but the little show Crazy Now that somewhat apologetically opened at the Eden Theater last night hardly got the 197273 New York theater off to a running start. At least from now on, everything should be up.

title: VITAL KOPECK COIN SCARCE IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10Imagine New York City with only a few thousand subway tokens in circulation at rush hour and you can appreciate how relieved Muscovites will be if the Government keeps a new pledge to end the chronic shortage of 2kopeck pieces here.

title: Chopped Liver Poisoning
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (UPI)About 100 elderly persons were stricken with food poisoning last night, apparently after eating chopped liver at a dinner celebrating the Jewish new year. The victims, residents of a West Side apartment building, were taken to area hospitals for treatment of food poisoning.

title: REFORMS REPORTED IN STATE'S PRISONS
description: The State Correction Commissioner, Russell G. Oswald, reported yesterday that changes in the state prison system in the year since the Attica rebellion constitute a creditable record of accelerated penal reform.

title: Army Orders a Worldwide Crackdown on Routine Granting of Discharges for Misfits and Malcontents
description: FORT ORD, Calif., Sept. 10The Army has ordered a crackdown on Chapter 10 discharges, a process by which misfits, malcontents, goldbricks, drug addicts, those who have been AWOL and others who may merely loathe the military system can escape to civilian life without facing courtmartial.

title: Advertising:
description: When the word got out in early July that the Buckingham Corporation was toying with the idea of moving its Cutty Sark Scotch out of Clyne Maxon, Inc., after 11 years, some people didn't take it seriously.

title: West's CentralBank Governors Discuss Basic Monetary Reform
description: BASEL, Sept. 10Governors of leading Western central banks meeting here today to discuss basic reform of the International Monetary System and further development, of economic and monetary union within the European Economic Community, appeared to give some support to a review of the community's narrowerband currency system.

title: L.I. Youth Shot and Robbed Outside an East Side Bar
description: A Long Island youth was wounded yesterday morning after an argument with a companion in front of an East Side bar was broken.up by two men who then robbed the couple, the police reported.

title: Classic LaborOrganizing Drive Splits El Paso
description: EL PASO, Sept. 10A classic labororganizing struggle in one of the nation's biggst pants factories has polarized this border city with its large Chicano labor force.

title: MICHIGAN TO VOTE ON ABORTION ISSUE
description: LANSING, Mich., Sept. 10Michigan voters will decide In the November election whether to legalize abortion..

title: China's Cloudy Outlook
description: In the wake of recent upheavals, the internal politics of Communist China appear to be even more of an enigma than those which characterized Stalin's Russia. The real issues behind the latest struggle for powerand subsequent purgeare far from clear. Did the struggle center on personalities or substantive disputes? Were foreign as well as domestic policies at the heart of the matter?

title: TRADE EXPANSION WITH EAST URGED
description: A panel of 200 business leaders and university presidents has urged the removal of virtually all restrictions on nonmilitary trade with the Soviet Union, China and other Easternbloc countries, except North Vietnam, North Korea and Cuba.

title: Juli K. Hensley, Denver Student, Is Jersey Bride
description: GLADSTONE, N. J., Sept. 10Miss Juli Kay Hensley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart K. Hensley of Far Hills, was married here today in St. Luke's Episcopal Church to Leslie Cole Schreiner, son of Mrs. Hobart Early of Atlanta and the Rev. Charles Schreiner of Mercer Island, Wash.

title: WAGNER DISCOUNTS DISSENSION'S IMPORT
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, the state campaign manager for the Democratic Presidential nominee, George McGovern, yesterday conceded that dissension in the McGovern camp sets us back.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:The bilingualism discussion in your letters columns Sept. 2 offers much needed service for your reading public.

title: The Continuity of Life
description: CALIFON, N. J.The liberatibn of the young from the oppression of their elders makes no sense. A question can initially be raised whether is compatible with the nature of man and his development. Human creatures have a long childhood and adolescence when the young need their elders to survive and to acquire the knowledge needed to maintain the continuity of life. The two ages are segments of one existence and cannot be separated into contradictory parts.

title: Main Opposition Newspaper In Saigon Halts Publication
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 10 (Agence FrancePresse) Dien Tin, the main opposition newspaper, announced today that it was suspending publication.

title: SCHOOLS OPENING TODAY WITH FORCE OF SECURITY AIDES
description: Freed from the threat of a teachers strike, the city school system will start the new academic year this morning with a sigh of relief, a record enrollment, a number of new programs and a determination to do something about an old problem  violence. in the schools.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:I have recently returned from London, surely one of the cleanest of the world's supercities.

title: PENSION COLLAPSES LINKED TO MERGERS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)  Most pension plans that collapse do so when one company is taken over by another, two Senators sponsoring corrective legislation said Sunday.

title: MRS. CHAIM BIALIK
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 10Manya Bialik, widow of Chaim Nahman Bialik, one of the most revered Hebrew poets of the century, died here this morning at the age of 97.

title: White Harlem Dentist Will Teach Black Studies
description: Daniel Jay Perlman, a 52yearold dentist, stood in the drab green office where he maintains his practice as his father did before him, one flight up over the Blue Note Tavern, overlooking the grimy intersection of 135th Street and Eighth Avenue in central Harlem.

title: Nastase Wins Tennis
description: Ilie Nastase of Rumania became the United States Open tennis champion yesterday by defeating Arthur Ashe of Miami, 36, 63, 67, 64, 6.3, at Forest Hills. (Page 49).

title: Kissinger Arrives for Talks in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser, arrived here tonight for talks with the Soviet leadership, as Moscow gave renewed though routine assurances of support for Hanoi to North Vietnam's top negotiator.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:The Times otherwise excellent obituary of C. Suydam Cutting (Aug. 25) opened with the statement that he was the first white Christian to enter the forbidden city of Lhasa (in 1935).

title: Books of The Times
description: What is happening in Africa now is like the shattering of an enormous diamond in order to make working parts for thousands of industrial machines. Of course, a diamond is useless, in a sense. Its only virtue is its rarity and beauty, but it is precisely these two qualities that our homogenized world can least afford to lose. Watching Africa change is like seeing our children grow up, allowing their pure egoism and astonishing creativity to be curbed ,and cramped into practical patterns. The very idea of Africa had always been a sort of psychological escapevalve: Its darkness had helped absorb the harsh light of reason. Halfway between hell add the Garden of Eden, it affected many whites like feverproduced delirium, a germ that never gets out of your blood. Men who have lived in Africa always talk of it with extremes of emotion: love, hatred, or both.

title: 13Hour Blaze Damages I.B.M. Plant at Hawthorne
description: HAWTHORNE, N.Y., Sept. 10 A 13 hour fire heavily damaged one wing of a twostory concrete building of the International Business Machines Corporation here today.

title: Credit Markets
description: People in the credit markets can't make up their minds about how tight they think the Federal Reserve wants the money market to be. It's no wonder. Last Thursday, the Federal Reserve reported that the money supply expanded at an annual rate of almost 11 per cent during July and August while bank reserves that support nongoVernment deposits increased at a 12.5 per cent rate.

title: Lebanon Urges an Effort To Solve Refugee Problem
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10President Suleiman Franjieh of Lebanon has begun a diplomatic effort to get major powers that are interested in the Middle East to tackle the Palestinian refugee problem, which underlies much of the violence in this region.

title: Bay State Tax Gain Seen
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Massachusetts wil get back more money from Washington this year than its residents sent to Washington in taxes, a state official predicted today. Peter Goldmark, secretary of the state Human Services agency, said that in 1971 Massachusetts residents paid $781.6million in Federal taxes and got back $734.9million, equal to 97 cents on the dollar. The 1972 return will be equal to $1.06 for each dollar of Federal taxes paid, he said in a radio inter, view.

title: Olympic Village Shots May Have Been Corks
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept, 10, (Agence FrancePresse)  A combination of high spirited athletes and jumpy guards led to a false report of shots fired in the Olympic Village tonight. The police, with the results of last week's guerrilla raid fresh in their minds, reported that an unidentified man had fired five shots but that there were no victims.

title: A RISE IS INDICATED IN STEEL SHIPMENTS
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10, 1972 A decisive rise in steel shipments was indicated last week. Orders for October pointed to shipments as high as 8.5 million tons in the month. That would compare with an estimated, 7.9 million tons in September and would exceed the previous 1972 high of 8.1 million tons in May.

title: Edwin Fairfield, 48, Dies; Architect Designed Hospitals
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J. Sept. 10Edwin E. Fairfield, a principal in Crow, Lewis & Wicks, a New York architectural and engineering firm, died last night in Morristown Memorial Hospital, after having been injured in an automobile accident here. He was 43 years old and lived in Harding Township.

title: MISS BLALOCK WINS GOLF IN A PLAYOFF
description: DALLAS, Sept. 10 (UPI) Jane Blalock sank a birdie putt on the first hole of a playoff today to edge Kathy Whitworth and win the $33,000 Dallas Civitan golf tournament.

title: Subversive Activities Panel Takes 33 Groups Off List
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The Subversive Activities Control Board has decided that 33 groups named on the Attorney General's list of subversive organizations no longer exist.

title: Kissinger Sees West Germans
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 10Henry Kissinger spent today talking to Chancellor Willy Brandt and other West German political leaders about the future of Europe and its relations with the United States.

title: PATRIOTS 34, LIONS 30
description: Jim Plunkett passed for three touchdowns last night and Carl Garrett ran for two as the New Englanders won their second of six preseason games. Plunkett threw two touchdown passes to his former Stanford University leammate, Randy Vatara, and one to Reggie Rucker. The loss was Detroit's second in six games.

title: Navy Drug Unit Termed A Disgrace by Rep. Aspin
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)The Navy's Drug Rehabilitation center at Jacksonville, Fla., is a disgrace because it has correctly identified only 44 per cent of heroin samples tested, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: New Boston Center: Skillful Use of Urban Space
U.S. Wins Its First Olympic Marathon Since 1908, Loses on Basketball Protest
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 10  Frank Shorter, an American who was born in this Bavarian capital 24 years ago, ran through its crowded streets to an Olympic gold medal in the marathon today, one day, before the Games of the XX Olympiad close.

title: Top Israeli General Calls Raids OnlyPart of a Continuous War
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 10 (AP)Israeli troops were placed on alert status today after the heaviest Israeli air action against Arab guerrillas since the six day war of 1967.

title: CITY OPERA'S COSI IS SMOOTHLY STAGED
description: Cost?? fan tuttle reentered the City Opera repertory yesterday afternoon with a practiced cast drawn from the company's regulars. Needless to say, the performance at the New York State Theater went smoothly under the watchful eye of the conductor, Charles Wilson.

title: U. S. Protests Invective By Saigon on McGovern
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 11The United States Embassy here has found attacks on Senator George McGovern on the South Vietnamese national television and radio so offensive that it has protested to the Saigon Government, according to an embassy spokesman.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Staging Parties for a Party Is Their Business
description: WASHINGTONA cartoon cocktail party for campaign contributions? Well, there's more than one way to raise money, so why not sell original art from the New Yorker or Playboy?

title: 2 Soldiers Are Killed in Ulster As Armored Car Is Blown Up
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 10 (UPI)A bomb placed on a country road blew up British Army armored car today, killing two British soldiers and seriously injuring three others, the army said.

title: Nepal Slaughters Goats, Puts Blood in New 727
description: KATMANDU, Nepal Sept. 10 (UPI)  Nepal slaughtered two goats today to mark its entry into the jet age.

title: Merrick Takes Ad To Report Switch To Nixon Support
description: Hello, Dolly!, the title song from David Merrick's hit musical, became Hello, Lyndon! donated royaltyfreeas the Democrats 1964 Presidential campaign song. That was after the theatrical producer had threatened to sue for $10million when the Republicans proposed to use the tune as Hello, Barry!

title: HENRY J. LEADER, 63, EXUTICA PUBLISHER
description: UTICA, N. Y., Sept. 10 (AP) Henry J. Leader, former publisher of The Utica ObserverDispatch and Press, died here today. He was 63 years old and had been in hospitals most of the last eight years since an automobile accident in 1964.

title: Nixon and McGovern Square Off on Economic Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10President Nixon and his challenger, Senator George McGovern, are heading for a sharp ideological confrontation over economic issues, according to campaign strategists for both candidates.

title: RANGER33 SLOOP FIRST IN SAILING
description: Michael Lichtenstein's Beaver, a.Ranger33 sloop out of Knickerbocker Yacht Club at Port Washington, L. I., was the overall winner of the 37th annual City Island Yacht Club overnight race, which ended yesterday off Big Torn Rock in Eastchester Bay.

title: Advertising:
description: The U. S. Home Corporation, builders, has brought lots of happiness to Foote, Cone & Belding/New York. It was easy enough to do, too. Just gave the agency its national advertising account, that's all.

title: South's Textile Producers Woo Japanese
description: TOKYO, Sept. 10A year ago I would have been whistling Dixie if I thought of coming to Japan to sell textiles, he said with a slight Southern drawl.

title: TV Review
description: Nearly buried in this season's ambitious plans for television specials is the fact that primetime TV will continue to rest on a foundation of regular series. The season begins officially this evening as two new series take first nervous steps along a path that could lead to the success of an All In the Family or the disaster of the Bearcatsl

title: MacGregor Says Nixon Aides Were Not Involved in BreakIn
