description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)Clark MacGregor, President Nixons campaign director, said today that he was convinced that top officials in the reelection effort, past and present, are wholly innocent of involvement in the June 17 breakin at the Democratic national headquarters.

title: South Vietnamese Airports Are Attacked
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 11 (AP)Two of South Vietnam's biggest air bases, the Tansonnhut field just, outside Saigon and the base at Bienhoa, 15 miles northeast of the capital, came under attack yesterday.

title: Miss Davis in East Berlin
description: BERLIN, Sept. 10 (UPI)Angela Davis, the American militant, received a turbulent welcome from thousands of East Berliners today, according to the official press agency A.D.N. Miss Davis flew in from Moscow after two weeks in the Soviet Union in which she visited Tashkent, Samarkand and Leningrad.

title: Edwin C. Wilson, 79, Is Dead; Ambassador to Turkey in 1940's
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Edwin C. Wilson who, as United States Ambassador to Turkey in 1947, administered $100million in and under the Truman Doctrine, died today at his home here. He was 79 years old.

title: Bears'
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP)Gale Sayers of the Bears, considered by many the greatest halfback ever to carry a football, today announced his retirement from pro football.

title: Mets Beat Cards, 32, as Seaver Wins 17th Despite Leaving Game in Fifth
description: A leapingonehanded catch in front of the leftfield fence by Clean Jones on Luis Melendez's long drive with the bases loaded yesterday saved a 32 victory for the New York Mets over the St. Louis Cardinals at Shea Stadium.

title: Chicanos Halt Kennedy Talk
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (UPI)  A group of Chicano activists broke into chants today, preventing Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Masachusetts from continuing a campaign speech for the Democratic Presidential candidate, Senator George McGovern, to a gathering of MexicanAmericans.

title: Strike to Close 12 Schools In L.I. District for 3d Day
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I., Sept. 10The PlainviewOld Bethpage School Board announced tonight that the district's 12 public schools would remain closed tomorrow for the third day.

title: New Wealth Expected to Foster Big Shift in Fischer's LifeStyle
description: Bobby Fischer is planning to change his lifestyle substantially now that he is the world chess champion, Life magazine says in its issue out today.

title: Berta Gersten, a Leading Lady Of Yiddish Stage, Is Dead at 78
description: Berta Gersten, a leading lady of the Yiddish stage here for more than half a century, died yesterday in Montefiore Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived at 50 West 97th Street.

title: Pope Condemns Terror In a Sorrowful Address
description: CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 10  Pope Paul VI said in a sorrowful address to pilgrims today that terrorism, revenge and war did not resolve anything and were selfdefeating.

title: The Central American Market is Near Collapse in Trade Rifts
description: GUATEMALA CITY, Sept. 10The fraying Central American Common Market is in serious danger of collapse. The free trade group, which originally was composed of five members, now has only three.

title: MANY IN QUEBEC BACK SEPARATISM
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 10Two French Canadian diplomats stationed at an embassy thousands of miles away from here sat in a tavern, sipping beer and talking fondly about Montreal, their hometown.

title: A Guest Is ColorBarred, To Rhodesian Discomfort
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 10Officials of the Rhodesian Government's Information Department found themselves unhappy victims of the country's colorbar practices last week.

title: Three Bizarre Seconds End a 36Year Reign of U.S. Quintet
description: ARCHERY  Nineteenyearold John Williams of Cranesville, Pa., and 42yearold Mrs. Doreen Wilbur of Jefferson, Iowa, gave the United States a goldmedal sweep, Williams, who led all four days, won by points. Mrs. Wilbur triumphed by 17.

title: Record U.S. Deficit Seen By Chambers of Commerce
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) The Council of State Chambers of Commerce says that this year's Federal budget deficit may be a record $37billion, $10billion more than predicted.

title: I envisioned my career involving deathdefying rescues
description: Fire alarm box 1459 stands sentrylike, imbedded in concrete on the northwest corner of 123d Street and Lexington Avenue in East Harlem. It. is neither unique nor impressive.

title: New Horse, Old Blinders
description: The welcome news that the city of New York will acquire its largest group of new subways cars ever752under a contract just signed with the PullmanStandard Company holds overdue promise of improved service. These will be longer, roomier, quieter and faster cars, all with airconditioning. They will replace the preWorld War II relics that now rattle along the IND and BMT lines sometimes breaking down, sometimes catching fire, as did an IND car in Queens the other day, inconveniencing and endangering passengers.

title: Adviser on Aide Named
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP)The Massachusetts Board of Education has appointed Dr. Harold C. Hunt of Lexington to advise it in seeking a state education commissioner to replace Dr. Neil V. Sullivan. Dr. Hunt was named to assist a threemember subcommittee of the board, which will recruit and screen candidates for the state's top education job. Dr. Sullivan resigned from the post in July.

title: El Mundo Pact Accepted
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 10 (AP) Members of the Puerto Rico Newspaper Guild ratified yesterday a threeyear contract that ends a sevenmonth strike at the big Spanishlanguage daily El Mundo. It provides for increases of nearly 50 per cent. El Mundo's editor, Tom Harris, said he hoped to be publishing again by Sept. 18. The minimum for journeymen reporters, photographers and editorial researchers goes to $180 a week,, retroactive to July 1 and to $250 over the next three years. Their minimum now is $168.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: An Associated Press dispatch from Saigon Sept. 3 included this passage:

title: Thomas Edward Knudsen Weds Miss Laura Wilkinson Bucknell
description: MIDDLETOWN, R. I., Sept. 10Miss Laura Wilkinson Bucknell was married here this afternoon to Thomas Edward Knudsen. The Rev, Robert R. Hansel, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. George's School where he is chaplain. He was assisted by the Rev. Thomas Liggett of Portsmouth Priory, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: New Sargent College Dean
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP)Dr. Bernard Kutner, professor of social science at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, has been named dean of Boston University's Sargent College of Allied Health Professions. Sargent College specializes in rehabilitation and preventive medicine. Mr. Kutner, a graduate of City College of New York, received a doctorate in social psychology from Harvard University.

title: Denial by McGovern Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Abram L. Chayes, a Harvard professor and chairman of Senator George McGovern's foreign policy advisory panel, has denied controversial views attributed to him in the Sept. 11 issue of Newsweek.

title: Nastase Turns Back Ashe in U. S. Open Final
description: Ilie Nastase of Rumania won the United States Open tennis championship yesterday at Forest Hills, a top prize of $25,000 and the right to be called the world's best player on grass.

title: Mrs. Susan Warburg Is Married
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 10  Mrs. Susan MacDonald Warburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Keith MacDonald of Jamesburg, N. J., was married here this evening to Richard Z. Chesnoff of New York, an author and journalist and son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis J. Chesnoff of Sea Cliff, L. I. Rabbi Herbert Freed performed the ceremony at the bride's home.

title: MRS. GEORGE M. COHAN
description: Mrs. Agnes M. Nolan Cohan, widow of George M. Cohan, the actormanager and playwright, died Saturday at her home in Forest Hills, Queens. She was 89 years old.

title: China Purchasing 10 Boeing Liners For $150Million
description: PEKING, Sept. 10  China has signed a contract believed to be worth $150million for 10 Americanbuilt Boeing 707 airliners, usually reliable diplomatic sources said here today,

title: FUTURE OF H.I.P. STILL IN DISPUTE
description: One month after the administrative and financial problems of the Health Insurance Plin of Greater New York becattie public, the fate of the planthe nation's second largest prepaid group practiceis Still in dispute.

title: DAVID DULNY
description: David Dulny, former president of Empire Credit Cornmany, a finance concern, and Private Credit Service Corporation, died Friday at his home, 45 Sutton Place South. He wasi 75 years old.

title: REID BIDS U.S. HELP BRITISH IN ULSTER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Representative Ogden R. Reid warned today that the situation in Northern Ireland threatened to become a British Vietnam and urged the United States to offer its good offices in some area.

title: A NEW HALL OPENS WITH BACH SERIES
description: A new concert hall was inaugurated Saturday night the Center Cinema in Madison Square Garden.

title: Roundup: Red Sox Sweep Two
description: The Boston Red Sox drive for the American League Eastern Division title continued to move forward yesterday with Carlton Fisk and John Curtis, the chief members of a good rookie brigade, the key contributors.

title: HOWARD HYDE, 71, OF GOODYEAR DIES
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 Howard L. Hyde, who retired in 1966 as vice chairman and a director of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, died today of a heart attack at his home in Waite Hill Village. He was 71 years old.

title: ROBERT H. RETTEW
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 10 Robert H. Rettew,a member of the financial staff of the International Business Machines Corporation's headquarters, died of cancer yesterday at. his home, 21 Dunham Road. He was 53 years old.

title: A Distant Marathoner
description: When Frank Shorter dropped out of medical school in 1970, he explained that he just wanted to go to work and see how good a runner he could really be.

title: COIN PUP DECIDES VICTOR IN SOCCER
description: The flip of a coin determined the winner of a soccer exhibition at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday afternoon between Barcelona of Ecuador and Nacional of Colombia, with. Nacional declared the winner.

title: Theatrics Sweeping Pop Music Scene
description: Theatricality is the Idea whose time has come for pop music this season. Theatricality in dress, in manner, in presentation and in attitude will be one of the newest energizing elements in the fall's substantial number of scheduled concerts.

title: Yanks Beat Tigers, 50, On Stottlemyre 3Hitter
description: DETROIT, Sept. 10  Mel Stottlemyre's threehit shutout and Horace Clarke's wideranging offense brought the New York Yankees a 5.0 victory over the Detroit Tigers today, and solidified their position in the American League's Eastern Division pennant race.

title: STOCKS DECLINE FIFTH DAY IN ROW
description: The stock market posted its fifth consecutive loss yesterday as declines outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 in continued light trading.

title: MAX FLEISCHER, CARTOONIST, 89
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 (AP) Max Fleischer, creator of the Out of the Inkwell cartoon series and inventor of more than 20 motion picture production devices, died today at the age of 89.

title: Sun Oil Is Expanding
description: The Sun Oil Company, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Sun Oil Company announced in Toronto yesterday that it planned a $32million expansion of its refinary at Sarnia, Ontario, to increase capacity from 38,000 barrels to 80,000 barrels a day.

title: Technical Accord Reached
description: Combustion Engineering, Inc., and Siemens, A.G., of West Germany announced yesterday an agreement for technical cooperation in pressurized water nuclear reactor engineering. Future extensions of the agreement are expected to include more advanced reactor types such as the liquid metal fast breeder reactor.

title: East Bloc Aides Assemble
description: BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 11 (Agency FrancePresse)Defense ministers of the Warsaw Pact countries arrived today to attend military maneuvers, the official C.T.K. press agency reported. The maneuvers will last from Sept. 12 to 16.

title: Panama Assembly Charges U.S.Holdi Zone Arbitrarily
description: PANAMA, Sept. 11 (AP)Panama's newly elected Assembly of Community Representatives today charged that the Panama Canal Zone was being occupied arbitrarily and voted to reject the $1.93million the United, States pays annually to use it.

title: Artificial Dollar Prop Shunned
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Paul A. Volcker told Congress today that intervention by the Federal Reserve and Treasury in foreignexchange markets would not be used to artificially prop up the dollar counter to any basic balanceofpayments trends.

title: ATTICA INMATE DIES, AN APPARENT SUICIDE
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 11 (AP)An Attica prison inmate from Buffalo died today in his cell, an apparent suicide by hanging, according to Superintendent Ernest L. Montayne.

title: A PhoneCall Trap
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 11  An Israeli diplomat was lured to a cafe here last night and critically wounded by gunfire as he waited for information he had been promised on plans for a terrorist attack on his embassy.

title: inco Increases Prices
description: The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., said yesterday that it had increased its price for two types of nickel oxide sinter, a granular material used in the production of wrought or cast stainless and alloy steels

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Within five short blocks of my apartment on. East 52d Street, there are about ten squirrels, a bevy of moles and a large assortment of sparroWs, starlings, swallows and wrens.

title: POLICE CHIEF KILLED AT BERMUDA HOME
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 11 (UPI)One or more gunmen broke into the home of the police chief of Bermuda, George Duckett, Saturday night, shot him to death and wounded his 17yearold daughter, the police reported yesterday.

title: BOND RULE EASED AT GERMAN BANKS
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 11 (Reuters)The West German Bundesbank announced today modifications to the June ruling subjecting the sale of mark fixedinterest securities to nonresidents to specific Bundesbank permission.

title: Gains in Income
description: Examples of major gains in family income in Manhattan between 1960 and 1970 are shown below:

title: 5 ACTS PERFORM ATDANCEFESTIVAL
description: Some would not only walk a mile to see Carmen de Lavallade dance but also regularly endure the hurly burly at the New York Dance Festival at the Delacorte Theater to enjoy her artistry. The programs presented each year under the wing of the New York Shakespeare Festival happily find place for her in her ever rarer New York appearances. Sunday evening she shared a program with Ballet Hispanico of New York, Bottom of the Bucket, But.. Dance Theater, The Theater Dance Collection and Peter Gennaro.

title: ASSEMBLY CHIEFS BEGIN STATE TOUR
description: The Republican leaders of the Assembly began an eightcity election campaign trip here yesterday asserting that the Republicancontrolled Legislature had met the needs of the city end its administration.

title: MAN SHOT IN HEAD FOUND IN BROOKLYN
description: The body of a man apparently slain in gangland fashion was found shortly before last midnight on an isolated street in the Bergen Beach section of Brooklyn.

title: China's Growing Airline
description: China's purchase of 10 Boeing jets and her conditional order in July for three supersonic Concordes herald the entry of the last of the world's major powers into the big leagues of commercial aviation.

title: 20,000 in Jerusalem Ask Death in Guerrilla Cases
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 11 (Reuters)More than 20,000 people in Jerusalem have signed a petition organized by Hebrew University students calling on the Government to institute the death penalty for guerrillas found guilty of killing civilians.

title: Night Staker, $6.40, Takes Belmont Dash After Stablemate Sets Early Pace
description: The entry representing Sigmund Sommer cooperated perfectly in the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. Night Staker, with Eddie Belmonte riding, won the sevenfurlong sprint, after Aqua Belle, with Bobby Woodhouse up, carried out the pacesetting assignment in the early stages.

title: Ali and Patterson Prepare for Bout in Genial Way
description: Muhammad All and Floyd Patterson continued yesterday to approach their 12round heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden Sept. 20 with congeniality, not controversy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: How' interesting that in The Times coverage of the unsuccessful efforts of Wit and Bir'im Arabs to, return to their former villages near the Lebanese border, no mention was made, of the most significant aspect of the protest that Israeli Arabs have reached the political maturity to demonstrate publicly.

title: Laotian Victory Reported
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 11 (Reuters)Laotian troops drove North Vietnamese soldiers from the town of Khong Sedone in southern Laos over the weeknd, a Government spokesman said here today. Gen. Thong1phanh Knoksy said that the Government troops had recaptured the town after fierce fighting. He did not say how many casualties the Laotian force suffered. Khong Sedone lies at the foot of the Boloven Plateau, 30 miles north of Pakse.

title: Shriver Says Union Man Would Be in Cabinet
Letters to the Editor
description: Senator George McGovern would have us pull out of Vietnam immediately, and hope that the North Vietnamese would be good boys, and release our P.O.W.'s, as he claims they did with the French. The sad truth is that the North Vietnamese only released 11,000 out of the 37,000 French P.O.W.'s they held.

title: The Great Necktie Gap Grows Wider in Soviet
description: MOSCOWIn the quiet process of borrowing fashions from the bourgeois West, Soviet men feel they are falling behind their women. The women are getting an increasing, though still modest, flow ol chignons, patterned panty hose and pants suits. But men complain they can't find a decent wide tie.

title: Rumanian Defects in Munich
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 11 (AP)A member of the Rumanian volleyball team has asked for political asylum in West Germany, becoming the first Olympic athlete from an Eastern European country known to have defected during the games, which ended today. A spokesman for the West German Interior Ministry confirmed the defection. The name of the athlete was not given.

title: Law Firms Question FeeIncrease Limit
description: Amid a chorus of no comment for the record, senior partners and other spokesmen for major law firms here have privately expressed surprise and resentment over the decision of the Price Commission last week to impose a ceiling on the fee increases of big law firms.

title: MONEY DOMINATES DIPLOMATIC TALKS
description: PARIS, Sept. 11After a long spell of twosided summitry, the Western diplomatic calendar is crowded again with conferences. But the emphasis has changed.

title: Advertising:
description: Previously confidential documents have been obtained that reveal the story of a small agency's unsuccessful sevenyear effort to get on the roster of one of the country's top advertisers.

title: Chess: Rapid Transit Gains in Appeal Among More Advanced Players
description: Rapid transit is a popular form of chess among more advanced players. One way of playing it is to limit the game to five minutes, which requires fast thinking and immediate decisions, and which can be extremely strenuous when the competition is strong.

title: A Tiny Bug Gives San Francisco Sourdough Its Special Taste
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Its taste is tart, the crust is hard, and it's difficult to eat without showering crumbs all over one's clothes.

title: Public Broadcasting Post
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) A former Representative, Thomas B. Curtis of Missouri, was confirmed by the Senate today as a member of the board of directors of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. He served in the House from 1950 through 1968.

title: Agnew Says McGovern Takes Strange Positions
Black Movies
description: Most movies with allwhite casts have nothing to do with the issue of race, but the same does not seem true for current movies and plays in which black actors predominate. Of the black movies now on viewShaft, Shaft's Big Score, Super Fly, Come Back Charleston Blue and othersall seem to be commenting in one way or another on what it means to be black in America. Unquestionably there are gains in lifting black faces out of the obscurity of their usual unheroic roles and including them in the fantasy life on the screen. Yet sadly, in quality and social imagination, the black movies are only on a par with the usual Hollywood features. Some seem merely to be variations in reverse of the anachronistic white man vs. Indian theme.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: According to the Republican National Committee (RNC) and the Committee to ReElect the President (CREEP), their files do not support the widespread belief that candidate Nixon in 1968 claimed a secret plan to end the Vietnam war. Inasmuch as they are better known for rummaging around in other people's files than producing facts from their own, gladly offer the following to save the locks on my doors.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. READY TO ENDORSE CASE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 11New, Jersey's American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations is preparing to endorse Senator Clifford P. Case, a liberal Republican, for reelection to a fourth term. The endorsement would be the first ever accorded in New Jersey to a statewide Republican candidate by the A.F.L.C.I.O.

title: San Francisco Transit System Opens
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept, 11One leg of the Bay Area Rapid Transit district's new system opened to paying passengers today in a nearly flawless display of what electrified rails can provide in what may be their last stand against the automobile.

title: HEARING IS RECESSED ON BROADCAST ISSUE
description: PUYALLUP, Wash., Sept. 11  Administrative Judge. Ernest Nash of the Federal Communications Commission recessed today the hearing on Radio KAYE's application for the continuation of a broadcast license, and announced that he would enter an order to end the hearing.

title: No Treasury Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The Treasury had no comment today on the court decision in San Francisco involving the Bank Secrecy Act because the meat of the decision has not yet been received here.

title: 10Year Rise in East Side Affluence Noted
description: In a farreaching spread of affluence on Manhattan's middle East Side, family income levels rose by $12,000 to $18,000 between 1960 and 1970 in numerous areas.

title: Business Briefs
description: The President's National Commission on Productivity is sponsoring a comparative study of work attitudes and job satisfaction, it was disclosed yesterday at a productivity conference conducted by the American Management Association at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Terence Jackson, assistant to the executive director of the commission, said that it was involved in a joint project with Japan, West Germany and other industrial nations to study attitudes on work under conditions of automation.

title: Police Seek a Bronx Man In Killing of Estranged Wife
description: A Bronx man allegedly shot and killed his estranged wife yesterday morning and fled with the couple's fiveyearold son.

title: A.M.A. OFFERS PLAN ON EMERGENCY CARE
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (UPI)The American Medical Association has proposed legislation that would establish an emergency medical services administration as a branch of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Helene Lovings Slaght, 78, Advertising Representative
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 11 Mrs. Helene Lovings Slaght, a newspaper and magazine advertising representative, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived at 1225 Midland Avenue.

title: H.E.W. Study Hints Misuse of School Aid for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11A confidential, internal report by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare says that school districts across the country have been using inaccurate figures and unreliable estimates in accounting for billions of dollars in compensatory education funds.

title: AT LEAST 28 DIED IN SYPHILIS STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) Reports written by doctors in charge of a Federal syphilis experiment show that at least 28 of the Alabama black men used in the study died as a direct result of untreated syphilis, and it is possible that the toll could be close to 100.

title: A Game That May Decide Race In East Is Still Not Scheduled
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11  A game that may decide the American League pennant race remains unscheduled by Joe Cronin, the league president, for no discernible reason except that it may not have to be played.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Aug. 29 editorial assumed, without even bothering to argue, the truth of what in fact is a novel and pernicious doctrine: that the cruelty and racism of Uganda's antiAsian expulsion order was mitigated by the failure of Asians to integrate with the African community in which they have lived for several generations.

title: TV: Maude, a Comedy, Will Make Debut Tonight
description: The new television season, cont'd:

title: Books of The Times
description: The trouble with Philip Roth's new novella reminds me of a playwriting teacher I once hada courtly old gentleman (long since deceased) named Lemist Esler, whose modest claim to immortality was the authorship of a movie called Whistle at Eaton Falls, which used to show up on The Late Late Show from time to time. Mr. Esler was a strong believer in certain fundamental rules of storytelling he felt he had discovered in a long career of writing and teaching, and one of the most fundamental of them was that you couldn't make your hero too passive. I once proposed to him the idea of a play about a young man who decides, in Act One, to spend the rest of his life In bed. Too passive, was Mr. Esler's carefully considered response. What are you going to do with your man after he goes to bed? I bring up this recollection here because you might say that the hero of Philip Roth's story is just as passive.

title: Baby Gorilla's Debut Brings a Surprise
description: Lulu, the gorilla who has been in a state of euphoria since giving birth nine days agoto the first gorilla born in this area  swung into an outside cage at the Central Park Zoo yesterday and showed her baby off to the public.

title: PYRAMID SALES TARGET OF S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The Securities and Exchange Commission asked Congress today to enact swiftly legislation that would give the commission clearcut authority to regulate pyramid sales ventures similar to Glenn W. Turner's Dare to Be Great. Most such programs amount to nothing but a cruel hoax, according to the commission's chairman, William J. Casey.

title: Hundreds Pay Tribute At Khrushchev Tomb
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (Agence FrancePresse)Hundreds of Muscovites and Soviet and foreign tourists today filed past the tomb of the former Premier, Nikita S. Khrushchev, on the first anniversary of his death.

title: To Save the Delaware
description: Governors Cahill and Rockefeller will have a rare chance to strike a blow for environmental integrity when the Delaware River Basin Commission meets tomorrow in Philadelphia. The New Jersey and New York executives will in effect decide whether or not to block the potentially devastating Tacks Island Dam project, which has been studied, restudied and studied again for seventeen years.

title: Retail Sales Last Month Rose Strongly to Record
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Retail sales rose strongly again in August to a record $38billion, the Commerce Department reported on a preliminary basis today.

title: LAW GROUP ASSAILS ATHENS DETENTION
description: ATHENS, Sept. 11The International Commission of Jurists has accused Greece of violating legal practices accepted among civilized nations by holding a woman political prisoner incommunicado for four weeks without charge or trial.

title: Democrats Open TV Campaign With Old Message
A REPAIR GUARANTEE INTRODUCED BY FORD
description: DETROIT, Sept, 12  The Ford Motor Company announced today a new guarantee program for automobile repairs. It called the plan the most extensive improvement program in automotive history.

title: PLATINUM PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Uncertainty over the future of platinum futures sent prices down sharply again yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Cornmission in connection with a proposed public offering of 600,000 common shares. Net proceeds will be used to repay outstanding domestic shortterm indebtedness with the balance to be added to working capital. Lehman Brothers will manage a banking group which is expected to make the offer later this month. The company's stock was down 3 at 86 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Taiwan Importers Told To Use Western Sources
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 11The Board of Foreign Trade has directed Taiwan importers to turn to American or European sources rather than. Japanese for orders of machinery or industrial Materials exceeding $20,000.

title: In Ocean Hill, Usual Woes Ate Made More Intense
description: Carrie Jones figured that Warren MacArthur would be a difficult case the minute he.walked in the door for his first day in the first grade at Public School 155 yesterday.

title: Air Chief Against Plan
description: BERNE, Sept. 11 (AP)The Swiss Air Force Chief, Brig. Eugen Studer, said today that he opposed the idea of buying 24 reconditioned Hunters from Britain.

title: RIGOLETTO RETURNS TO CITY OPERA STAGE
description: The City Opera's Rigoletto returned to the State Theater Sunday night, the leading singers in fine voice, the production just a bit rusty after its summer layover.

title: JOB DISPUTE HALTS WORK AT AIRPORT
description: Construction was ordered halted last night on two new terminals in the $400million redevelopment project at Newark Airport after negotiators failed to resolve a dispute over the hiring of six black men as ironworker trainees.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Yields on United States Treas ury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Gen. Lavelle Now Asserts He Committed No Wrong
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle, in what some Senators considered a change of testimony, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that he had committed no wrong in connection with the unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam for which he was dismissed from the Air Force.

title: BOMBING OF NORTH IS BACKED IN POLL
description: A Louis Harris poll of voters made public yesterday showed that 55 per cent supported con, tinued heavy bombing of North Vietnam, while 32 per cent opposed it.

title: U.P.I. Names Boston Chief
description: BOSTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)James F. Wieck has been named Boston Bureau manager of United Press International, the news service announced today. Mr. Wieck, 28 years old, succeeds Paul Robbins, who joined the public relations department of the Sheraton Corporation of America.

title: Cairo Replies to Bonn Critics
description: CAIRO, Sept. 11Egypt today dismissed as unacceptable and illegitimate a West German Government statement criticizing Arab nations for failing to condemn publicly the Palestinian guerrilla attack on Israeli athletes in Munich.

title: I KILLED, 2 INJURED IN TAVERN SHOOTINGS
description: One person was killed and three were injured early yesterday morning in shootings at taverns in the Bronx and Manhattan.

title: Lederle Sets Expansion
description: The Lederle Laboratories division of the American Cyanamid Company said yesterday that it would build a major facility for the production of polyglycolic acid sutures at Manati, 30 miles west of San Juan, Puerto Rico. The plant will cost in excess of $10million.

title: The Library's Future
description: The $750,000 grant to the New York Public Library by the National Endowment for the Humanities underscores both the library's precarious finances and the growing realization that a national rather than a local resource is at stake.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Sept. 11 (AP)Three harness racing figures pleaded guilty today to charges in connection with alleged fixing attempts at Pocono Downs in 1971.

title: 37,000 Cadillacs Recalled For Defect in Axle Shafts
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation announced today that it was recalling 37,000 Cadillacs produced at the end of the 1972 model year to find 5,000 defective left rear axle shafts.

title: Swiss.Decide Not to Buy U.S. or French Planes
description: BERNE, Sept. 11 (Reuters)Switzerland has dropped plans to buy either American or French fighterbombers to modernize her air force, Defense Minister Rudolf Gnaegi said today.

title: A Silent Prayer for 11 lsraelis Observed
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 11With a moment of silent prayer as a somber reminder, the XX Olympic Games ended tonight after two weeks of tumult and tragedy.

title: Personalities: Fittipaldi Gets a Scare
description: Emerson Fittipaldi, the 25yearold Brazilian, who became the world drivers champion on Sunday by winning the Italian Grand Prix at Monza, Italy, disclosed yesterday that he almost failed to make it to the starting line. Just 20 minutes before the start, we found the left fuel tank was leaking, he said at his home on Lake Geneva in Switzerland. The mechanics worked a miraclean hour of work in 15 minutes to change the tank. My title was a team affair and everyone had a share in it, but especially the mechanics. Fittipaldi will leave today for Canada to prepare for the Canadian Grand Prix in three weeks and then the American Grand

title: Granite Is Set to Acquire Mortgage Bank Company
description: Granite Management Services, Inc., a diversified real estate Ewd computerleasing concern based in Garden City, L. I., announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the InterIsland Mortgage Corporation, a mortgagebanking company also based on Long Island, for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes. Last May, in an appearance before the Antitrust and Monopoly Sub committee of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Stanley Sirote, president InterIsland, refused to answer questions on the ground that his replies might tend to incriminate him. cash and notes. Last May, in an appearance before the Antitrust and Monopoly Sub committee of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Stanley Sirote, president InterIsland, refused to answer questions on the ground that his replies might tend to incriminate him.

title: Football Cardinals Sold
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP)The football St. Louis Cardinals today became the sole property of William V. Bidwill, previously vice president and halfowner of the team.

title: Hogan Charges Greed and Not Fear Prompts Builders to Brie Inspectors
description: Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday dismissed as obscene, intolerable and unacceptable charges by constructionindustry spokesmen that if they blew the whistle on shakedownminded inspectors, there would be reprisals from colleagues of the inspectors.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES A $43BILLION CUT IN DEFENSE FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The House Appropriations Committee approved today a $4.3billion cut in the defense budget. Despite the reduction, the $74.6billion measure represents the largest defense appropriations bill to be recommended by the committee since World War II.

title: Ship Traffic Last Month Was Up Over Year Ago
description: A funny thing happened to the port last month. For the first time in several years, according to traffic data furnished by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, there was an increase in both ship arrivals and ship departures over the previous year. There were 1,701 ship movements last month, an increase of 27 over August, 1971. There were 26 more ship arrivals and one more sailing. According to Customs sources, three factors were responsible for the traffic increase, an increase in cruise ship travel, more traneAtlantic cargo ship arrivals attributable to the end of the British dock strike and more tanker traffic.

title: Bavarian Art Exhibition in Munich Is a Tour de Force
description: MUNICH, West Germany The notion of an exhibition devoted exclusively to Bavarian art might seem somewhat specialized, perhaps provincial and even dull. This is by no means the case of the Bavarian Art and Culture exhibition that the Munich State Museum mounted as a special treat for visitors to the Olympic Games as well as for the forthcoming October festival. The show is nothing less than tour de force.

title: GREECE OUTLINES GROWTH PROGRAM
description: ATHENS, Sept. 11The Greek Government unveiled today a summary of a 15year master plan for economic and social development that promised to achieve material prosperity without sacrificing the nation's spiritual values.

title: FRANK O'BRION
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 11 (AP) Frank O'Brian, president of the Tradesmen's National Bank of New Haven until it was acquired by the Connecticut Bank & Trust Company in 1969, died yesterday at St. Raphael's Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: STRIKES PREVENT SCHOOL OPENINGS
description: Schools remained closed in a number of suburban areas yesterday as striking teachers continued to press their demands.

title: Extradition Asked In 70 Plot to Slay Official of Taiwan
description: The United States applied formally to Britain yesterday to extradite a Taiwanese convicted here of plotting to murder the son of Chiang Kaishek.

title: U. S. Has Not Acted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 State Department officials said today that no formal request for the extradition of Meyer Lansky had been transmitted to the Israeli Government.

title: Advertising:
description: The Theodore Hamm Company, a subsidiary of Heublein, Inc., and one of the 10 largest brewers in tne country, will stop using the J. Walter Thompson Company as its advertising agency Dec. 15.

title: City Sees Winter Electricity Squeeze
description: Consolidated Edison's peak demand for electricity in the coming winter will exceed output from its efficient plants by 2 million kilowatts, forcing the utility to use costlier and obsolete units, the city administration said yesterday.

title: Festival Adds Bunuel Film
description: Luis Bunuel's French comedydrama, The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie, has been added to the 10th annual New York Film Festival. It will be shown Oct. 13 at 11 P.M. The festival will present 22 feature films at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center from Sept. 29 through Oct. 14.

title: Attica Prisoners Have Gained Most Points Made in Rebellion
description: In the tortured days before the final bloodshed at the State Correctional Facility at Attica a year ago, the rebel inmates made many demands for changes in the conditions of their confinement. It is a measure of the fever for reform in the state prison system that all but four of those demands have been at least partially met in the ensuing 12 months.

title: Roundup: Red Sox Bow, 65, to Indians
description: The race for the American League's Eastern Division continued on its merrygoround last night. But one contending team, the Boston Red Sox, was undone by a sacrifice fly fin Cleveland's Municipal Stadium and lost to the Indians, 65.

title: FILM SERIES TO OPEN AT WHITNEY SEPT. 21
description: Five independently made feature films will have their premieres during the Whitney Museum's third annual New American Filmmakers Series, which starts on Sept. 21.

title: City Adopts Skin Test in TB Screening
description: The city's Department of Health is changing its tuberculosis screening procedures, substituting the skin test for the routine use of the chest Xray.

title: Bridge:  Husbands and Wives Team To Make Exceptions to Rules
description: Bridge authorities are sometimes asked two apparently unrelated, questions: Should husbands teach their wives to play? And can the unorthodox bids and plays of an inexperienced player so confuse an expert that he will go astray? The answer to both questions is very rarely, but the diagramed deal happens to illustrate exceptions in both areas.

title: Tug Mishap Spills 3,000 Gallons of Oil In a Suburban Creek
description: Three thousand gallons of flammable No. 2 diesel oil spilled into Eastchester Creek at the foot of Canal Street in Mt. Vernon early yesterday, the Coast Guard reported.

title: Graham Bell, Stockbroker, Diesi Former Amex Vice President, 51
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 11 Graham Bell, a vice president of Thomson & McKinnon Auchincloss, Inc., stockbrokers, and a former vice president of the American Stock Exchange, died today of cancer at his home, 93 Prospect Avenue. His age was 51.

title: Wagner's Son Plans to Run For the Council in 1973
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr., 28yearold son of New York's former Mayor, said last night that he plans to run for the City Council next year.

title: Brooklyn Fireman Honored
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 (UPI)  Capt. John T. Dunne, a Brooklyn fireman who died while trying to rescue four children he believed were trapped on the third floor of a Brooklyn tenement but who had been rescued moments before, was posthumously awarded today Ward Lafrance's first annual fire industry award for heroism. The award was jointly announced by Curtis W. Volrkamer, president of the International Association of Fire Chiefs, and Don Alvin, president of Ward Lafrance, Inc., manufacturer of fire engines.

title: Music: The Sarah Lawrence Chorus
description: The Sarah Lawrence Chorus stopped off at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night in the way home from its seventh European tour and gave a concert that at its frequent best did the collegians honor. Harold Aks, the director, put the 32member mixed chorus through a program that ranged from music by Orlando di Lasso, Palestrina, Orazio Vocchi Vittoria and Schutz to some fetching but neglected works by Hindemith, Bartk and Irving Fine.

title: MUNICH SECURITY FOUND DEFECTIVE
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 11An Israeli Government report on security arrangements during the Olympic Games in Munich has uncovered glaring deficiencies in precautions taken by West German and Israeli agencies, reliable sources said today.

title: Kissinger Begins Talks
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 11Henry Kissinger began three days of wideranging talks with the Soviet leadership today without making any contact here with the North Vietnamese negotiator, Le Duc Tho.

title: Some Arithmetic Problems and the G.O.P. Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11After months in which it was Senator George McGovern who kept using tax and other economic statistics that, no one else could add up the way he did, it is now President Nixon and his staff who are having trouble with their arithmetic.

title: ExRep. Robert Ramspeck Dies; Led Civil Service Commission
description: CASTOR, La., Sept. 11 (AP)  Former United States Representative Robert Ramspeck died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while visiting friends here. He was 82 years old.

title: IN THE NATION
description: President Nixon has taken American ground combat troops out of the war and therefore American casualties are down, but American war prisoners are nowhere near freedom, Vietnamization has never looked more dubious, the Thieu regime has never seemed a less attractive ally, and neither lethal bombing nor mining of its harbors has ended North Vietnam's ability to carry on and perhaps intensify the war.

title: Indiana U. Gets $500,000
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 11 Nelson P. Poynter, chairman of the board of The St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times and president of the Congressional Quarterly, has awarded through the Poynter Fund $500,000 to Indiana University for a pilot project aimed at bridging the credibility gap between citizens and American institutions.

title: Reid and Rival Exchange Charges in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 11Representative Ogden R. Reid and his opponent, District Attorney Carl A. Vergari, today filed formal charges of unfair campaign practices against one another.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday plans for restarting about 30,000 tons of annual operating capacity at its Rockdale, Texas, primary aluminum smelter about Oct. 1. The company said that increasing need for sheet ingot brought about the restoration of the potline that has been idle since May.

title: U.S. Studying Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 White House and State Department spokesmen said today the Administration was studying the Vietcong statement. But, speaking privately, Administration officials said they saw no new elements in the declaration.

title: ADDS TO LINE OF DICTATION ITEMS
description: The International Business Madhines Corporation announced yesterday that its office products division has introduced five new models of input word processing equipment, better known in the past as dictation equipment.

title: W. German Riders Take Championship In Olympic Finale
description: MUNICH., West Germany, Sept. 11 (AP)American riders lost the last gold medal of the Olympics Games tonight to the host West Germans by the narrowest possible margin quarter of a pointbut they were happy to get so close.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: WASHINGTONThe Old Guard dies, but never surrenders. Those ringing words were supposed to have been said by Gen. Pierre Etienne de Cambronne, commanding Napoleon's Imperial Guard at Waterloo, when called upon to surrender.

title: Kennedy Helps McGovern Stir Big Minneapolis Rally
Letters to the Editor
description: Secretary of the Treasury George Shultz has attacked Senator McGovern's proposal for phasing out the depletion allowance and other favorable tax treatments which permit businesses and individuals in the oil industry substantially to reduce their Federal income tax bill. Secretary Shultz argument for not disturbing the preferential treatments given by the Government to this industry is: It is well to be sure you know what you're doing before you throw away something that works well. [News story Sept. 1, 1972.]

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If history is any guide, the recent bombings of North Vietnamese dikes must be considered as harbingers of largescale dike destruction in the future. Previous escalations of the war, dtiring both the Johnson and Nixon Administrations, were signaled by smallscale attacks of the kind being planned. Like the current, dike bombings, those attacks were denied at the time they occurred, were somehow excused, or were kept totally secret from the American people.

title: 3 Dead as Mexican Gunmen Fire on Crowd at Church
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 11 (Reuters)Gunmen fired at crowd leaving a church in Santa Cruz near here last night, killing three people and wounding 12, the police reported today.

title: Cooperative Climate Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) Any new law to increase speed and efficiency of securities handlers should retain a climate of cooperative regulation, a New York Stock Exchange official told Congress today.

title: Alfred A. Knopf, at 80, Recalls His Life and Career
description: Mrs. Alfred A. Knopf wanted to invite 80 people to a birthday dinner for her husband tonight  one for each of his years. But the Cosmopolitan Club cannot handle quite that many, so he will be victim of a slightly short count.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Cesar Chavez' call for a nationwide lettuce boycott is being met by legislation prohibiting use of this tactic, the only effective strategy for the migrant farm worker.

title: Jews in Moscow Protest On Access to Synagogue
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (Reuters) Ninetyfour Jews have protested to the Moscow City Council over restrictions on access to the city's main synagogue during Rosh haShanah, the Jewish new year, usually reliable sources said today.

title: Alexander's Seen Adding Use of Master Charge
description: Alexander's, Inc., a chain of 11 stores in the New York area that has been operating strictly on a cash basis, is expected soon to adopt use of the Master Charge bank credit card in all its stores, following a limited testuse in its new Menlo Park, N. J., store.

title: Jersey Crime Unit Planning Inquiry Into Zoning Cases
description: TRENTON, Sept. 11  Municipal corruption in the handling of planning and zoning decisions will be the subject of public hearings conducted by the State Commission of Investigation starting Sept. 19.

title: Top Physicists Meet at Biggest AtomSmasher to Assess Gains
description: BATAVIA, III., Sept. 11In a cavernous, vaultlike auditorium within the world's largest experimental device, leading explorers of the innermost nature of matter met here today to assess the prospects for success in that ageold quest.

title: BEN B. MUSLIN
description: Ben B. Muslin, former president of the Surgical Supply Corporation of America and hospital management consultant, died yesterday. in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 3530 Henry Hudson Parkway, the Bronx.

title: MUCH ADO OPENS RUN HERE NOV. 11
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival's production of Much Ado About Nothing, one of its three presentations this summer at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, will open at the Winter Garden Nov. 11 for a run of 10 weeks.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)President Nixon reviewed today forthcoming European trade negotiations with his Cabinetlevel Council on International Economic Policy. Ronald L. Ziegler, White House press secretary, said the onehour meeting was in the nature of a review of ongoing negotiations that will be taking place in the next six months with the European Economic community based on a spirit of goodwill.

title: Woman Gets 4Year Term In Police and Fire Bombings
description: CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 11 (AP)Kathryn Holt, 21 years old, of Boston, was sentenced to up to four years in Federal prison today by United States District Judge Hugh Bownes for her role in the bombings of the Manchester police and fire headquarters in February.

title: Rites of Abraham Moscowitz, Lawyer, Will Be Held Today
description: A funeral service for Abraham Moscowitz, a lawyer here 50 years, will be held today at 1 P.M. at Sigmund Schwartz's Gramercy Park Chapel, Second Avenue and 10th Street. Mr. Moscowitz died Aug. 20 on vacation in Bergen, Norway. He was 75 years old and lived at 304 West 75th Street.

title: New S.D.R. Issue in Doubt
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) The International Monetary Fund reported today that the matter of a further distribution of Special Drawing Rights, the created reserves sometimes called paper gold, remained in doubt.

title: HARRY E. COLLIN, 86, A RETIRED BROKER
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 11Harry E. Collin, a financial leader here and a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died today at the age of 86.

title: An Apology for Munich By Terrorists Reported
description: CAIRO, Sept. 11 (Reuters) A will, in which the Palestinian terrorists who attacked the Israeli Olympic team at Munich last Tuesday apologized to the athletes of the world for interrupting their games, was reported by Palestinian sources here to have been made public by the Black September organization, to which the terrorists belonged.

title: American Party Candidate Asserts Bremer Had Help
description: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11Representative John G. Schmitz, Republican of California, the American party's candidate for President, charged here today that Arthur H. Bremer, the man convicted of shooting Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, did not act alone.

title: Japan and the U.S. Begin Talks On Antidumping Enforcement
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) The United States and Japan held the first of a twoday policy level meeting today aimed at clarifying the Treasury's plans in enforcing the American antidumping law.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial of Mass Murder Suspect Opens on Coast
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Sept. 11The trial of a husky MexicanAmerican farm labor contractor, charged with committing the largest mass murder in American history, opened today in crowded courtroom here.

title: British Military Instructors Ordered to Leave Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 11 (Reuters)  President Idi Amin tonight ordered the expulsion of a 12man British military training mission by midday Friday.

title: Musicians'
description: A musicians' strike that would have darkened New York's legitimate theaters was temporarily averted yesterday when union and management agreed to extend for a week the threeyear contract that expired at midnight Sunday and to continue negotiations for a new pact.

title: CITY'S LOBBYIST RESIGNS POSITION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Noel H. Klores, New York City's chief Washington lobbyist for the last two and a half years, is resigning to enter private law practice here.

title: Schmitz Ballot Plea Denied
description: PROVIDENCE, Sept. 11 (AP) The Board of Election rejected today an appeal from the American party to get John C. Schmitz on the November ballot in Rhode Island as a Presidential candidate. Supporters of Mr. Schmitz failed to produce sufficient valid signatures on nominations to win a ballot spot, the board said.

title: Officials Chagrined Bylloffa's Lawyer In P.O.W. Incident
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Government officials were scratching their heads today over the exploits of William L. Taub, the mysterious New York lawyer who represented James R. Hoffa in his abortive effort last week to go to Hanoi to negotiate for the release of American prisoners.

title: $3MILLION TRESTLE SERVES CITY DETOUR
description: A specially built $3million trestle, opened yesterday for detoured traffic while a decayed section of the BrooklynQueens Expressway is being rebuilt, is up for sale if the buyer will wait a year or two for delivery.

title: Policy Shift by U.S. at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11  By its veto in the Security Council yesterday, the United States signaled a fundamental change in strategy with regard to the Middle East.

title: Pasarell Beats Stilwell, Lutz Is Toppled in Tennis
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 11 (UPI)  Charlie Pasarell of Puerto Rico and Terry Addison and John Alexander of Australia were winners today in the $50,000 Montreal tennis tournament for contract pros.

title: 9 More Food Places Cited in Health Violations
American Standard Ends 2 MoneyLosing Operations
description: American Standard, Inc., announced yesterday that two of its subsidiaries had ceased some operations as part of the company's program of asset redevelopment.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The children are going back to school again. Time for the old false sentimentality. Time for the tired pieties about education. Roll them out. Send the newspaper feature writers over to P.S. 17 for one more rewrite of every editor's favorite backtoschool story: Little 6yearold Adolf Hitler, leaving home for the first day of school, weeps for mother; finds compassion among schoolmates.

title: Service Held in Cleveland For Slain Olympic Athlete
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 (AP) John J. Gilligan, the Governor of Ohio, and representatives of 15 foreign countries attended a memorial service at Cleveland City Hall today for David Berger, a slain Olympic athlete.

title: Satellite Takes a Portrait of. New York Area
description: Despite some technical problems, the first Earth Resources Technology Satellite is transmitting a steady stream of panoramic portraits of the earth, including the first published picture of the New York metropolitan area taken from space.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A Pleasant Pond to Visit While in Maine
description: FRYEBURG, Me.Shortly after dawn, acres of white water lilies on Pleasant Pond opened to the light and warmth of the sun, and as white as the blossoms of the lilies was a herring gull that had made this remote inland lake its summer home.

title: Executive Changes
description: Lewis W. Gillenson has been elected president of the Thomas Y. Crowell Publishing Company, succeeding Robert L. Crowell, who was appointed chairman, Mr. Gillenson was named last November as president of Funk & Wagnalls Publishing Company, also a subsidiary of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., and will now serve as chief executive officer of both companies.

title: Senate Rejects Two TaxReform Proposals to Help Pay for Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. II (AP) Efforts to adopt two taxreform amendments to help pay for the $34.8billion revenuesharing bill failed in the Senate today.

title: MARTIN KAPP, 48, A CIVIL ENGINEER
description: Martin S. Kapp, chief engineer of the Port Authority New York and New Jersey, died yesterday while being taken Somerset Hospital, Sorrierville, N. J., after suffering a heart attack at a meeting of the Associated General Contractors in Lamington, N. J. He. was 48 years old and lived at 195 East Chestnut Avenue, Metuchen, N. J.

title: Groups Backing Inmates To Hold Attica Service
description: Two committees supporting inmates at the State Correctional Facility at Attica, N. Y., announced yesterday that a 'dignified, peaceful memorial service would be held outside the prison walls tomorrow.

title: Soviet Five Allowed To Keep Gold Medal
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 11 The International Olympic Committee ruled today that Russia should have the basketball Told medal but, left open the possibility of revoking it if a United States protest is upheld,

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The number of complaints about telephone service New York State dropped sharply for the first half of 1972, the State Public Service Commission said yesterday. total of 10,676 complaints were received during the first six months of this year, compared with 17,072 in the same period of 1971. At the same time, the number complaints in the upstate area served by New York Telephone rose from 537 in the first six months of 1971 to 675 in the first half of 1972.

title: Yanks Beat Tigers, 42, In RainShortened Game
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11Aided by a timely rainstorm, the New York Yankees completed a threegame sweep of the Detroit Tigers tonight with a 42 victory ended after 500BD innings by a steady downpour.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Arnold Scaasi, the last of the bigtime couturiers in New York, isn't terribly worried about his clients dashing off to buy all their clothes from plain pipe racks. They like the special attention, the chance to choose their fabrics, the advice from the designer on what neckline is right for them, what outfit to wear for what occasion.

title: Power Workers Walk Out
description: BELFAST, Sept. 11Workers walked out of two Belfast power stations today in a protest against the British Paratroop Regiment's killing of two Protestants in riots here last week.

title: World Monetary Reform
description: To no one's surprise, the longawaited International Monetary Fund study on reform of the world's ailing monetary system reflects inability on the part of the fund's twenty executive directors to agree on a new structure. But the study does help illuminate the major issues that must be decided by governmentsissues that can no longer be ignored. They will be on the table when 123 finance ministers and central bank governors assemble in Washington at the end of this month for the I.M.F.'s annual conference.

title: YIELD UP TO 7.58% FOR UTILITY ISSUE
description: The yield on highgrade electric utility bonds the most widely used measure of the corporate bond marketrose yesterday to 7.58 per cent, its highest level since late June.

title: New Plan for Dallas Site
description: DALLAS, Sept. 11 (AP)A citizens committee was formed here today to raise money to buy the Texas School Book Depository and donate the building to the city for a school, a park, a memorial or a museum., The committee seeks to rescind a city council resolution asking for Federal funds to buy the building. The School Book Depository is the building from which Lee Harvey Oswald fired the shots that killed President John F. Kennedy in 1963.

title: GEN. WILLIAM J. SUTTON
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 11 (AP)Maj. Gen. William J. Sutton, former chief of the Army Reserve, died yesterday in Washington. He was 64 years old.

title: Du Pont Contract to End
description: E. I. du Pont de. Nemours & Co., Inc., said yesterday that it would not bid for renewal of its Government contract for the manufacture of black powder. The current contract expires in March. Du Pont said it would sell its blackpowder plant in Moosic, Pa., the company's only blackpowder operation, when the contract ends. The Moosic plant employs 45 persons.

title: METS BEAT PHILS AND CARLTON, 42
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 The New York Mets salvaged something from a sinking season tonight when they defeated Steve Carlton, the 23game winner of the Philadelphia Phillies, 42.

title: NIXON FUND DATA SHOW $5MILLION IN AUGUST INCOME
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11President Nixon's main campaign treasury took in and spent nearly $5million during the last three weeks of August, campaign finance disclosures showed today.

title: Petrie Names President; Martin's Chief Resigns
description: In the fastpaced women's fashion field, two leading retailers that have made no change in their presidencies for many years announced yesterday new appointees to that post. The companies are the Petrie Stores Corporation, New York, a 240store concern, and Martin's, Brooklyn, a familyowned chain of quality fashion stores.

title: Vietcong Restate Peace Terms
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 11South Vietnam's Communists today issued what they called an important statement of their terms for a peace settlement.

title: Buffalo Man Killed in Crash
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 11 (AP)Daniel J. Jamieson, 34 years old, of Buffalo, was killed and nine persons were injured last night in a twocar crash on Route 20 in nearby Hamburg.

title: E.E.C. Moves to Set Up Reserve Fund
description: ROME, Sept. 11  Finance ministers of the European Common Market nations took a modest, although important, step today toward establishing a Federal Reserve System for Europe. They agreed to all but minute details of a European Monetary Fund that would help members of the European Economic Community out of temporary financial difficulties.

title: $50Million Virginia Plant Dedicated by ICI America
description: A $50million polyesterfilm complex was dedicated yesterday by ICI America, Inc., at Bermuda Hundred, near Hopewell, Va. The plant will produce Melinex polyester film, a material whose applications range from magnetic tape and photographic films to packaging films.

title: 6 WORKS SCHEDULED FOR MUSIC SOCIETY
description: Six works, commissioned by the Koussevitzky Music Foundation, will be performed by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center this season and next. One of them, Barbara Kolb's soever for winds and strings, will be given its premiere in the society's opening concerts on Oct. 27 and 29 in Tully Hall.

title: Bonus Lottery Drawing To Take Place Thursday
description: AUBURN, N. Y., Sept. 11 William H. McKeon, former state Democratic party chairman, has a chance at winning $109,234 in the bonus drawing of the state lottery.

title: GEORGE M. MILLER, ARTIST, DIES AT 85
description: George Macculloch Miller, an artist and a member of the architectural firm of Noel & Miller here from 1930 to 1948, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 10 Gracie Square.

title: Notes on People
description: The former Lynda Bird Johnson said that her 2yearold daughter, Catherine Robb, almost drowned on Labor Day in the swimming pool at the LBJ ranch in Texas when the child apparently crawled under a safety rope around the pool.

title: Big Marijuana Field Found
description: GRAND ISLE, Vt., Sept. 11 (AP)A state trooper on routine patrol during the weekend discovered a field of wild marijuana said to be one of the largest found in the state. The plants, estimated to weigh neara ton, were removed yesterday for later destruction.

title: 11 Pakistanis Are Banned Forever in Field Hockey
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 11 (AP)  The International Olympic Committee today banned 11 Pakistani field hockey players from Olympic competition for life, charging they were disrespectful at the final awards ceremony.

title: U.S., Citing Hijacking Rift, Cancels Talk With France
description: The United States broke off discussions with France yesterday for a new bilateral treaty on reciprocal air service because of what State Department officials called Paris's unbending resistance to a proposed new international treaty against hijacking.

title: Dynamite of U.S. Triumphs In Canada Cup Sail Opener
description: TORONTO, Sept. 11 (Canadian Press)  The American challenger Dynamite captured the opening race of the Canada's Cup sailing series today by 1 minute 52 seconds in light winds.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Sept. 11 (UPI)  Philadelphia announced today that Gary Gregor, who played out his option with the Portland Trail Blazers, had agreed join the 76ers.

title: MAIN HANOI BRIDGE REPORTED BOMBED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 12  United States Air Force jets have bombed the major railroad and highway bridge in downtown Hanoi, the American military command said yesterday.

title: MOORING OF JETS ON CENTER STAGE
description: Weeb Ewbank, the coach of the New York Jets, spent several hours yesterday viewing films of his team's 2020 tie with the Chargers at San Diego on Saturday night and most of what he saw pleased him.

title: DEMOCRATIC SUIT CHARGES SPY PLOT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The Democratic party today accused Maurice H. Stans, finance chairman of the Nixon campaign, and three other campaign aides of conspiring to commit political espionage against Democratic officials and candidates.

title: Dr. lonel F. Rapaport Is Dead; Psychiatrist at Willowbrook, 63
description: Dr. Ionel F. Rapaport, senior psychiatrist at Willowbrook (SI.) State School for the mentally retarted and a practicing psychoterapist here, died Saturday in Staten Island Hospital, after an illness of several months. He was 63 years old and lived at 69 Sherman Avenue, Tomkinsville, S.I.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 11 (AP)The runner who fooled more than 80,000 fans into thinking he was the leader in the Olympic marathon was identified yesterday as Norbert Suedhais, a 16yearold German, who said he wa's protesting the resumption of the Games after last week's killing of 11 Israelis.

title: BODIES OF 5 ARABS FLOWN TO LIBYA
description: TUNIS, Sept. 11 (Reuters)The bodies of five Arab guerrillas killed in Munich, West Germany, last week arrived tonight in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, the Libyan radio re. ported.

title: Sayers's Last Carry: A Sense of Rigid Pride
description: A rigid sense of personal pride was the force that carried Gale Sayers out of professional football. The Chicago Bears' running back, who announced his retirement Sunday, gave up $75,000 in salary for this season when he packed in after a dismal effort during a preseason game against St. Louis on Saturday night.

title: REPAVING IS BEGUN ON JAMAICA AVENUE
description: Repaying of more than a mile of Jamaica Avenue between Woodhaven and Lefferts Boulevards in Richmond Hill, Queens, began yesterday.

title: Princeton U. Balances Its Budget After Two Years of Deficits
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 11 Princeton University, by reducing its expenses and increasing its income, has balanced its budget after two years of deficits that ran as high as $1.5million.

title: BUTZ ASKS M'GOVERN TO SUPPORT CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)  Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz challenged George McGovern today to produce a shred of evidence that any grain dealers had got inside information enabling them to profit at the expense of United States consumers and farmers in a massive grain sale to Russia.

title: Indiana Aide Hints Criminals Are Behind Rock Festivals
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 11 (AP)Attorney General Theodore L. Sendak of Indiana has called for a Federal grand jury investigations to determine whether organized crime has an interest in large rock music festivals.

title: Mexico Honored Here
description: Mexico's independence was marked at City Hall yesterday with a colorful ceremony attended by about 500 people. Gaily costumed members of the Ballet Folklorico Paloma Bernal performed outside the building as the city began its celebration of Mexico Week.

title: Classes Resume Smoothly In All But Two City Schools
description: The new school year got off to a generally smooth start yesterday for most of the city's 1.1 million pupils and their 60,000 teachers.

title: Barker Admits Raid Role But Won't Involve Others
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The accused leader of the Watergate raid admits his role in the breakin but says he would endure a long prison term rather than implicate others or disclose the reasons behind the affair.

title: 3d British Soldier Dies in Ulster From Wounds Received in Blast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 11 (Reuters)A British soldier died in a hospital today, the third victim of a landmine that blasted an armored vehicle off a country road yesterday.

title: Amex Price Drop Continues; Counter Stocks Are Also Down
description: Prices of American Stock Exchange shares slumped yesterday, pushing the index down 0.14 to 26.32. The drop continued a decline that began last week.

title: Smallpox Cases Up 38%
description: Atlanta, Sept. 11 (UPI)The number of smallpox cases around the world has gone up 38 per cnt, according to figures from the National Center for Disease. Control. Some 47,872 cases of smallpox were reported to the World Health Organization for the first 700BD months of this year, compared with 34,697 cases reported for the same period in 1971. The center attributed the increase to improved reporting and surveillance in all eight countries where smallpox is endemic.

title: Troop Strength in Vietnam Drops by 300, to 36,700
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 11 (AP)United States troop strength in South Vietnam decreased by 300 men last week, and 100 United States sailors were also withdrawn, leaving 36,700 American servicemen in the country, the United States command reported today.

title: Israel Refuses Citizenship to Lansky, But Offers Him Special Travel Papers
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 11Israel's highest court ruled today that

title: Sports News in Brief
description: COOPERSTOWN, N. Y,, Sept. II (AP)Lyndon Wilson, a 57yearold corporation executive from Hamburg making his first appearance in the New York State senior men's golf tournament, led the firstround field today with a fouroverpar 76, His margin was two strokes.

title: Marriott Corporation's Earnings Rise 29% in Year on 20% Sales Gain
Arthur Daley
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept, 11It was raining when Closing Day dawned and the day was to remain damp, dark and dolorous. It is difficult to envision a more appropriate setting for these unhappiest of Olympic Games than the gray, funereal backdrop that the weatherman provided. The usual partingissuchsweetsorrow motif was missing and these Olympics dragged their way into history with their honest achievements shunted aside by the mishaps and controversies that kept demanding attention.

title: Police Chase Train Through Bronx, Catch Pair
description: In a chase scene like the one that highlighted the movie The French Connection, two policemen  commandeering trucks and cars in the street belowpursued an elevated train in the Bronx for five stops yesterday before heading it off and seizing two armedrobbery suspects who had boarded it.

title: MRS. NIXON TO AID CANVASS IN QUEENS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, Lionel Hampton and George Romney will be among a group of 50 Presidential surrogates who will spend Saturday as volunteer canvassers, pushing doorbells in major cities to mark the start of the Republican canvassing effort.

title: San Francisco Opera Begins Week of Gala
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept, 11 The San Francisco Opera began celebrating Opera Week today, with Joan Sutherland singing before a noon crowd in Union Square.

title: COURT OVERTURNS PART OF BANK LAW
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11A threejudge Federal Court ruled today that provisions of the Bank Secrecy Act permitting the Government to examine individual bank accounts were an unconstitutional invasion of privacy.

title: 2 HELD IN ATTEMPT TO BRIBE THE POLICE
description: Two Manhattan men were arrested on bribery charges early yesterday in connection with an alleged attempt to fix a traffic ticket in the Flushing, Queens, station.

title: Wachovia Plans New Unit
description: The Wachovia Bank & Trust. Company, one of the largest banks in the Southeast, announced yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had approved its application to open an international banking subsidiary in New York.

title: Chaos, Tragedy Haunt Games
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 11Long after the memories of who won and lost have been absorbed, analyzed and forgotten, the Games of the XX Olympiad will be remembered for their chaos, confusion and tragedy.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Boys'
description: Although fall is just around the corner, boys' wear retailers are beginning to plan their purchases for the spring, 1973, season. Talks with a group of them yesterday indicated that they were looking for a big one.

title: New Teacher Enjoys Introduction to Job in Corona, Queens
description: My name is Mrs. Friedman and I'm your teacher. And I'm new here, like you are, said the slim, smiling 2yearoldwearing bellbottoms, a knit pullover and thong sandalsto each new arrival yesterday for her kindergarten class at Public School 14 in Corona Heights, Queens.

title: Business Briefs
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 11 (Reuters)The United States dollar is still grossly overvalued in terms the Japanese yen, the West German mark and the French franc, and should be adjusted, Wilbur D. Mills, the chair man of the House Ways and Means Committee, said in an interview with a German news magazine, Der Spiegel, published today.

title: Hanoi PeaceTalk Adviser Is Back in Paris
description: PARIS, Sept. 11 Le Duc Tho, chief adviser to Hanoi's delegation at the Paris peace talks, returned to Paris today, creating speculation that he might meet again with Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security.

title: Yearling Brings $28,000 As Keeneland Sales Open
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 11 (AP)Keeneland's fall sale of thoroughbred yearlings got off to a good start today when the average per horse was $1,437 more than last year's record sale.

title: Mayor Denies Jobs Serve as Payoffs For Political Aides
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday described as utter nonsense the charge that provisional appointments to city jobs were political payoffs, saying that provisionals are essential in order to run the city better.

title: United Fund Begins Fall Drive With Aid of Business Leaders
description: Dozens of board chairmen and corporate executives took time off yesterday to inaugurate the 1972 Fall Campaign of the United Fund of Greater NO* York.

title: Murder Suspect Arraigned; St. Croix Presses Search
description: ST. CROIX, V. I., Sept. 11 (UPIOne of the seven suspects charged with murdering eight persons last week at plush Rockefellerowned golf course on the island of St. Croix was arraigned today on burglary charges.

title: Raytheon and National Data Report Litigation Is Settled
description: The Raytheon Company and National Data Communications, Inc., said yesterday that litigation between the two companies had been settled.

title: PONTIAC REDESIGNS ENGINES OF 73 CARS
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11  The Pontiac Motor Division said today that it had redesigned 1973 model car engines to provide better performance and economy while still meeting the stricter Federal antipollution rules.

title: Heck, Baker Among Four Giants Put On Waivers in Roster Trim
description: The New York Giants cut their roster to 40 players yesterday, as required by National Football League rules, when they asked waivers on Ralph Heck, a linebacker with 10 years of professional experience; Ed Baker, a quarterback, who has spent two years on the Giants' taxi squad; Dick Kotite, a tight end, and Bart Buetow, an offensive lineman.

title: Market Place: Trading Planned In Stock Options
description: Most investors are about as familiar with the putandcall market as they are with the mating habits of the porcupine.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GAZA, Sept. 11 (AP)An Israeli military court in occupied Gaza sentenced two Arab guerrillas today to life imprisonment. They were convicted of killing two Arabs and blowing up bridges and railway lines in the Gaza Strip. Both pleaded innocent.

title: Wisconsin Editor Retires
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 11 (AP)The retirement of Lawrence H. Fitzpatrick, 65yearold executive editor of the Wisconsin State Journal, was announced yesterday by, J. Martin Wolman, publisher.

title: Scientist to Speak in Soviet
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11 (UPI)Dr. Abraham Nemeth, a blind professor of mathematics and computer sciences at the University of Detroit, has accepted an invitation to address an international conference of the Russia Society for the Blind in Moscow Nov. 1317. Dr. Nemeth, 53 years old, developed a 64character code that transcribes mathematical symbols and digits into Braille so that blind students can study the abstract reaches of astronomy, nuclear physics and higher mathematics.

title: A HEALTHY REED SIGNS KNICK PACT
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 11  A healthy Willis Reed, the ingredient the Knicks must have to challenge for the championship in a stronger National Basketball Association, signed a multipleseason contract today.

title: LATHERS HERE AGREE ON FOUR 35C RAISES
description: Metallic lathers and building contractors in the city reached agreement yesterday on a twoyear contract, leaving three other unions still on strike against the construction industry here.

title: $392,000 Paris Art Theft
