description: PARIS, Sept. 11 (UPI)The police said today that thieves broke through a wall into the Amenage Art Gallery on Avenue Matignon overnight and took 11 paintings whose value was estimated at $392,000. The paintings were said to be four Vlamincks, three Utrillos, one Derain, one Picasso, one Sisley and one Pissarro.

title: Hijacker Who Got $303,000 Pleads Guilty to Air Piracy
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 11 (AP)  Frederick W. Hahnemann, 49yearold Pennsylvania electronics engineer, pleaded guilty in United States District Court today to a charge of air piracy. Sentencing will take place Sept. 29.

title: Control Data Is Completing Development of Disk System
description: The Control Data Corpora. tion confirmed reports yesterday that it was completing development of a new pluginterchangeable disk storage subsystem to be offered later this year as a replacement for the IBM 3330 disk subsystem.

title: Olympic Partygoers Undaunted Despite the Shootings
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 11The social Olympics that got under way in connection with the 1972 Olympic Games resumed in this sprawling city after only a oneday pause last Tuesday following the Arab terrorist attack in which 17 persons died. By the weekend, the partying was in full swing again.

title: Commuter Who Balked At Fare Denies Guilt
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 12 A Penn Central commuter arrested last month after refusing to pay his fare on a hot, crowded train to Brewster pleaded not guilty today to theftofservice charges brought by the railroad.

title: Aline Saarinen Memorial
description: Governor Rockefelle will pay tribute to Aline B. Saarinen, the late art critic and TV commentator, at a memorial service tomorrow at 5 P.M. at the Forum Theater in Lincoln Center. Others who will speak at the service are John Chancellor, correspondent for the National Broadcasting Company, Tom Hess, art critic, and Daniel Schwarz, Sunday Editor, of The New York Times. Mrs. Saarinen was for many years associate art editor of The Times and, at her death on July 13, was chief of the N.B.C. news bureau in Paris.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: To the Editor: The dastardly attack in Munich against the Israeli athletes is justly condemned throughout the world, and engendered Increased sympathy for Israel in its fight for continued independence.

title: Tragedy in Munich, 1972
description: To the Editor: Citizens of this nation rightfully view with outrage the Palestinian guerrilla actions at the Olympic Games in taking hostage and killing Israeli athletes. Certainly such actions can do nothing for the guerrilla cause except to coalesce world opinion against it.

title: Man Dies in Plunge Here
description: A 38yearold Manhattan man jumped or fell to his death yesterday mottling from the window of his sixthfloor apartment at 245 East 35th Street, the police said. The police said the man, identified as Jay Gentry, had been despondent over family problems. The incident occurred shortly after 6 A.M.

title: LEFKOWITZ SEEKS STOCKSALE DATA
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz disclosed yesterday that he had obtained a court order requiring seven Individuals, Including the president of a Wall Street brokerdealer finn, to testify on the sale of $1million in stock that had not been cleared with the state.

title: UNIVERSITY RECTORS QUIT POSTS IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, Sept.12 (AP)The heads of Madrid's two big state universities have resigned to protest a Government order suspending their ,schools autonomy, the newspaper, Informaciones reported today,

title: CHASE BANK CLEARED IN SHARE TAKEOVER
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, announced yesterday that the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati had dismissed the challenge by Donald H. Parsons of Chase's formal takeover of roughly 40 per cent of the shares of the troubled Bank of the Commonwealth, Detroit.

title: Santiago, on Long Shot, Completes $207 Double
description: Angel Santiago, the latest Panamanian to arrive at New York's big wheel, is making it evident that he has learned to ride at Belmont Park much faster than he has been able to add to his English vocabulary.

title: A.B.A. Trustees Veto Undergraduate Draft
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 12 (AP)The trustees of the American Basketball Association unanimously voted today against holding a draft of undergraduate players.

title: PRICEFIXING LAID TO 4 BREADMAKERS
description: A Federal grand jury filed an indictment yesterday charging that four major baking companies had conspired to fix the price of bread in the New York region.

title: 2 Soviet Planes Reported Flying Off U.S. East Coast
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) The Pentagon reported today that two Soviet longrange aircraft operating from Cuba carried out a 12hour reconnaissance flight yesterday off the East Coast of the United States.

title: A New Plague
description: JERUSALEMThe liberators are on the march. They write the headlines with the blood of their slain victims. Their tenet of faith is brutal Violence, their business is bloodshed, their sentiment is savage hatred, their method is stealth, their strength is extortion and the weakness of society. They kill and maim, they hijack and kidnap, they boobytrap and dynamite.

title: Levitt Reports Strengthening In Financial Position of State
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt repcirted a brightening state financial picture yesterday, and urged that a possible surplus be used to finance highway repairs that the Legislature had planned to pay for through borrowing:

title: SoHo Residents Split on Sports Center
description: Spokesmen for artists living in the SoHo district of lower Manhattan clashed sharply with older residents of the area yesterday over proposals for the construction of an $11million 21story public sports. center.

title: Notes on People
description: Marc Chagall has agreed to create a 70footlong outdoor mosaic structure in Chicago's Loop, a few blocks from Picasso's Colossus. The work is expected to take form next year on an open landscaped terrace at the First National Plaza. Made of ceramic murals designed by the artist, the work will be 14 feet high and 10 feet thick, covering more than 3,000 square feet.

title: Boeing Expects 6Million From Chinese in a Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The man who negotiated the sale of 10 Boeing 707 jets to China indicated today that down payment of $6million or more was expected to be turned over within the week.

title: Saving Banks Deposits Up
description: Savings banks in New York State had a net deposit gain of $104million in August, up 50 per cent from the $69million gain in August last year and the best deposit performance for the month since 1967, the Savings Banks Association of New York State reported yesterday.

title: Chile's Shopkeepers Challenge Allende
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12Chile's socialist revolution in slow motion, approaching its second anniversary, has come up against the little man, the home or store owner, organized and fighting to survive in an increasingly state controlled economy.

title: Western Plans Drilling Rig
description: The Western Company of North America announced yesterday plans for construction of a second semisubmersible offshore drilling vessel, costing an estimated $20million. It will be built in the Bethlehem Stdel Corporation's Baltimore yard and is scheduled for delivery in late 1973. Another rig is now under construction at Bethlehem's Beaumont, Texas, yard.

title: Letter to the Editor 9  No Title
description: To the Editor: All Americans are shocked, and rightly so, at the killing of the Israelis at the Olympic Games, and yet most of us seem to be unmoved by the daily slaughter, maiming and burning of Vietnamese by our bombers. The Arabs have a grievance (though it does not excuse terrorism); they have been dispossessed and their lands occupied; but what harm have the Vietnamese done to us that we should destroy them and their land?

title: REVIEW ORDERED ON JOB PROGRAM
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered a review of a special job program for Vietnam veterans and the poor, following charges by City Councilman Robert I. Postel that the program has been misused to create patronage havens for favored appointees.

title: Letter to the Editor 8  No Title
description: To the Editor: Where are the aroused voices of the black athletes who threatened to boycott the Olympics on the Rhodesiaapartheid issue (and rightfully so) and are so deafeningly silent at the murder of fellow athletes? Does color and/or religion make the great difference as to the righteousness of a cause or the concern to be accorded?

title: U.S. Court Upholds a Ban On Alabama Traffic Refunds
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled yesterday that Alabama did not have to refund $1.2million in traffic fines to 50,000 violators.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)President Nixon today sent to the Senate for ratification a treaty designed simplify the filing of patent applications on the same invention in different countries. He recommended early and favorable consideration of the Patent Cooperation Treaty signed in Washington on June 19, 1970.

title: Rockwell Receives Order
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 (UPI) The Rockwell Manufacturing Company received today a $19million order from PullmanStandard to supply truck assemblies for the 752 transit cars under order by the New York City Transit Authority.

title: TAX EVASION LAID TO DRUG SUSPECT
description: A selfstyled racingcar driver who was indicted last year by a Kings County grand jury as a major heroin dealer pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal indictment charging him with evading payment of nearly $172,000 in income taxes..

title: Executive Changes
description: William G. Kuhns, president of General Public Utilities Corporation; has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of two of its subsidiaries, Jersey Central Power & Light Company and New Jersey Power & Light Company. Dr. Shepard Bartnoff, who had been director of environmental affairs at the G.P.U. Service Corporationanother company in the G.P.U. systemwas named president and chief operating officer of the two New Jersey organizations.

title: New Light on Venus
description: Several years ago, before the first men stepped on the moon, American scientists landed instruments there which radioed back directly measured information on the chemical composition of the lunar surface, later confirmed by analysis of rock samples brought back by Apollo astronauts. Now the Soviet Union has announced a similar but even more impressive, feat.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
description: Another drop in stock prices took the American Stock Exchange index much lower yesterday to 26.17, down 0.15.

title: SENATE CHIEFS MOVE TO END SALT DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) Leaders of both parties moved monthlong Senate debate over the new United StatesSoviet nuclear arms control agreement.

title: MEDIATORS ENTERING MUSICIANS DISPUTE
description: City and state mediators yesterday entered the stalemated contract negotiations between Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and the League of New York Theaters. There was no announced progress in the day's bargaining.

title: Treasury Terms Decision On Bank Secrecy Limited
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 The scope of yesterday's Federal Court decision in California relating to the Bank Secrecy Act of 1970 was far narrower than most reports of the decision implied, Treasury and banking industry spokesmen said here today after examining the decision.

title: Woman to Be Chamber Chief
description: MT. SNOW, Vt., Sept 12 (AP) Another traditional bastion of male dominance crumbled with the election yesterday of Mrs. Madelyn Davidson as president of the Greater Vermont Association. She is believed to be the first woman in the nation to head a statewide chamber of commerce.

title: Equatorial Guinea Bids U.N. Deal With Invasion Charge
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 12 (Reuters)  Equatorial Guinea called today for an immediate meeting of the Security Council to deal with what it charged was.an invasion of all its coastal islands by neighboring Gabon.

title: Suspect in Wife Slaying Surrenders in the Bronx
description: William Ronson, a Bronx man wanted on charges of slaying his estranged wife, June, reportedly in the presence of his 5yearold son, Mithael, surrendered yesterday at the Washington Avenue Station.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: To the Editor: The callous refusal of the Big Powers to help in curbing of international terrorism is dramatized on the front page of Sept. 6 Times. Side by side with the story of the Munich killings is the report that France, Britain and Russia rejected a U.S.Canadian proposal for an antihijacking treaty.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: To the Editor: Premier Golda Meir's expression for the West German Government's decision to take action for the liberation of the Israeli hostages and to employ force to this end is almost as incomprehensible as the decision of the International Olympic Committee to resume the Games even before the victims of the Arab terrorists were buried. This increasingly evident intransigence on the part of many governments is but a reflection of their diminishing respect for the rights of the common man who, by chance, becomes the pawn in these all too frequent power plays between heads of state and outlaws.

title: Indian Panel on Alcoholism Is Moving Office to Denver
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 12 (AP)  The American Indian Commission on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse announced yesterday it was moving from Salt Lake City to Denver, alleging a lack of local cooperation that included a brushoff from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints.

title: Ripon Society Challenges G.O.P. on Delegate Plan
Walter J. Bergman, 68, Is Dead; ExPresident of LilyTulip Corp.
description: Walter J. Bergman, who built the LilyTulip Cup Corporation into a giant in its, field, died Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived at 1185 Park Avenue and in Rye, N. Y. Mr. Bergman, a native New Yorker, went from DeWitt Clinton High School, where he was captain of swimming for two years, to the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Business Briefs
description: New York State Controller Arthur Levitt, a champion of competitive bidding on bonds, stepped up the pressure yesterday to get state agencies to stop selling their issues by negotiating with one underwriting network at a time.

title: Oldsmobile's Omega Is 1973's Only New Model Auto
description: (AP)The Oldsmobile Division of General Motors unveiled today the industry's only brand new model offering of the 1973 runa compact called the Omega.

title: Giants Rehire Fox
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 (AP)Charlie Fox, who managed the San Francisco Giants to the National League Western Division title in 1971, has received a new contract for 1973, the club president, Horace Stoneham said tonight. The Giants are struggling in fifth this season.

title: An Anniversary for Attica
description: Elliot Barkley died a year ago today. He died in the yard of D block at Attica. Barkley was 21 years old and black. He was in Attica for violation of parole. He had violated parole by being unemployed, and he was unemployed because he was fired when his boss discovered he was an excon.

title: El Al Drops Security Man At Rome After Bomb Blast
description: TEL AVIV, Sent, 12 (Agence FrancePresse)The Israeli airline El Al has dismissed its Rome airport security officer on charges of neglect after an Arab attempt to blow up an Israelbound El Al aircraft last month, it was disclosed here today.

title: Suffolk Judge Fines Toiletries Concern $70,000 in Fraud
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 12 (UPI)A Mount Vernon toiletries manufacturer was fined $70,000 yesterday in Suffolk County District Court after being convicted in a charity swindle.

title: 9 More Dead Miners Found
description: FARMINGTON. W. Va., Sept. 12 (AP)  The bodies of nine of the 78 men lost when explosions ripped through Consul No. 9 coal mine in 1968 were found this afternoon by recovery crews, officials of the Consolidation Coal Company said, This brings to 33 the number of recovered bodies.

title: Decisionon Madison Ave.Mall Put Off
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he would announce soon his decision on a proposed mall on Madison Avenue between 42d and 57th Streets.

title: Letter to the Editor 10  No Title
description: To the Editor: I am appalled and incensed by the tragedy at Munich in which several of my fellow Jews were brutally and senselessly slaughtered by Palestinian terrorists. Equally distressing is the yesterday news treatment which these mishaps are too often given several days following the event.

title: New Art Season Focuses on the Media
description: The New York art scene, which for a quarter of a century has been notable for its obsessive concern with the new  new movements, new reputations, new ideas and new pricesis due for change. This season, to judge by announcements of forthcoming exhibitions, the emphasis will no longer be on esthetic novelty. If there is a new direction to be discerned, it is to be found in the plethora of shows devoted to certain media, especially crafts, or decorative arts, and photography, which formerly ranked low on the scale of esthetic values and that are now apparently due for an upward revaluation.

title: Nets Open Season At Coliseum Oct.13 Against Colonels
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 12 The New York Nets will play the bulk of their 42 home games on weekends, according to the club's 197273 schedule.

title: Man of La Mancha Opens in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  Nearly seven years after the birth of its brilliant New York run, Man of La. Mancha has found a new world to conquer with a successful opening here.

title: Ulster Catholics Meet Heath; Say They Won't Attend Parley
description: LONDON, Sept. 12  Prime Minister Heath, in his first formal meeting with representatives of Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic minority, failed tonight to persuade them to attend an important peace conference on Ulster set for later this month.

title: Walter J. Stern, an Editor Of JournalAmerican, Dies
description: Walter J. Stern, former Sunday editor of The New York Journal American and later makeup editor of The WorldJournal Telegram, died of heart attack yesterday at his home, 5445 Netherland Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 69 years old,

title: ASPINALL IS LOSER IN COLORADO RACE
description: Two veteran House committee chairman, Representatives Wayne N. Aspinall of Colorado and John L. McMillan of South Carolina were defeated yesterday in Democratic state primaries.

title: TRADE SUSPENDED IN 13 PREFERREDS
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would suspend trading in 13 Preferred issues of 10 companies, including the General Tire & Rubber Company and W. T. Grant Company, effective Sept. 25.

title: It May Contain Soy Flour, But Just Call It Macaroni
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12After a threeyear battle to placate opposing lobbies and pressure groups, the Food and Drug Administration today finally  maybesettled the question of the definition of the word macaroni.

title: Gleason. Mrs. Holub Lead Jersey ProWoman Golf
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 12 Jim Gleason, an assistant pro at Shackamaxon, and Mrs. Seymour Holub today combined for a 343367 to take the firstround lead in the New Jersey Professional Golf's Association section prowoman tournament at the Woodlake Country Club.

title: Excerpts From Report of Commission Studying Origin and Aftermath of Attica Riot
description: In prison, inmates found the same deprivation that they found on the street: Meals were unappetizing and not up to nutritional standards. Clothing was old, illfitting, and inadequate.... To get along in the prison economy, inmates resorted to hustling, just as they had in trying to cope with the economic system outside the walls. Above all, for both inmates and officers, correction meant an atmosphere charged with racism. In the end, the promise of rehabilitation had become a cruel joke. If anyone was rehabilitated it was in spite of Attica, not because of it.

title: TV: A.B.C.'s 2 New Comedy Series
description: The new television season, cont'd:

title: RONALD J.PERMAN, HERTZ CHAIRMAN;Chief Officer of Car Rental Concern Stricken at Golf
description: Ronald J. Perman, chairman and chief executive of the Hertz Corporation, died yesterday of a heart attack while playing golf at the Latrobe (Pa.) Country Club. He was 52 years old and lived at 10 Forest Lane, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: TeachIn Scheduled Today On Need for Prison Reform
description: Charging that the nation's academic community had failed dismally to tackle the issue of prison reform, Edward T. Co the director of the Revitaliiation Corps, announced yesterday that a series of teachins would be held today in Attica and in schools and colleges in many major cities across the country.

title: Camden Burglar Gets $900 Plus Watchdog
description: CAMDEN, Sept, 12 (UPI)A burglar did a thorough job at a tavern here.

title: Books of The Times
description: What Theodore Roszak offers us in Where the Wasteland Ends is nothing less than a State of the Union Message on the condition of the human soul. He begins it by saying that most of us hardly have anything resembling a soul left, that we have matured under the influence of science to a point where the very word soul has a childish and sentimental connotation. Our religious feelings, as we once knew themwhat the author calls our transcendent energieshave been exiled from the social order, except, he points out, where they have taken refuge in psychedelic experiences, sensory awareness groups and oriental philosophies, all of which are looked upon as either crimes, fads or lunatic fringe activities.

title: Westchester Hearing on U. D. C. Is Held Under Strict Controls
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 12There was no less bitterness but decidedly more order tonight as the Urban Development Corporation held the second night of a public hearing on its proposed lowincome and moderateincome apartment development in Greenburgh.

title: Monzon to Defend Title
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 12 (AP) Carlos Monzon of Argentiria will defend his world middleweight championship here against Benny Briscoe of Philadelphia Nov. 4, Juan Carlos Lectoure, a promoter,.announced today.

title: Enterprise Sails for Vietnam Despite a Protest Blockade
description: ALAMEDA, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI)  The Enterprise, the world's largest warship, sailed for Vietnam today despite fleet of a half dozen small boats blockading the Golden gate in a war protest.

title: Market to Seek Action
description: ROME, Sept 12 (UPI)Foreign ministers of the Common Market countries agreed today, at West Germany's urging, to prepare a joint European initiative in the United Nations for the control of terrorism.

title: Wallace and Humphrey Still Owe for Air Travel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)The Hubert H. Humphrey and George C. Wallace political organizations failed during July to pay anything on their pastdue transportation hills to Texas International Airlines, the Civil Aeronautics Board disclosed today.

title: Court Nominee Picked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) President Nixon intends to nominate Frederick Pierce Lively, a Danville, Ky., lawyer, to the U.S. Court of Appeals, for the Sixth Circuit, the White House said today.

title: KENNEDY PRESSES M'GOVERITS DRIVE
description: DETROIT, Sept. 12Senator George McGovern, the onetimeevangelist of Democratic partyreform, stumped across the crucial Great Lakes states todaypreaching party regularity as the gospel of his Presidential campaign.

title: Oilmen Bid $586Million For Tracts Off Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 (AP) Oilmen offered more than $586million for 74 tracts of sea bottom off Louisiana's oilrich shore today, including one bid of $77.3million for a prime 5,000acre area.

title: Business Briefs
description: Three steel companies and a leading coal producer announced yesterday the signing of a construction contract for an experimental cokepellet processing plant that could cost as much as $37million. The participantsthe Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the National Steel Corporation, the Republic Steel Corporation and the Consolidation Coal Companysaid the plant would have a 500tonaday capacity and was expected to be completed by 1974 with blastfurnace tests,in 1975.

title: Waldheim Bids U.N. Act on Terrorism
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12  Secretary General Waldheim declared today that the United Nations could not remain a mute spectator to the acts of terrorism that were plaguing the world.

title: Iowa Corn Crop Warning
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 12 (UPI)State Secretary of Agriculture L. B. Liddy said today that between 5 and 7 per cent of: Iowa's corn crop Might be lost because of rain, flooding and expected frost.

title: Athlete, 14, Electrocuted
description: WEST COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 12 (AP)Charles E. Derrenbacher, 14 years old, a member of the BrooklandCayce High School junior varsity football squad, was electrocuted and five teammates were injured today as the goalposts they were leaning against hit a high tension wire. The police said the boys made the goalposts sway, and the posts hit a wire.

title: For Migrant Family There's Little Chance For a Moment of Fun
description: GOSHEN, N. Y.  A light bulb hanging from the ceiling illuminates the kitchen in the gray predawn light as Lupe Ortiz starts her day, cooking breakfast for her husband and their nine children. One of about 2,000 migrant workers in Orange County, she is the hardest working member of a hardworking family. Her sturdy figure bends over the stove while Victor, her husband, and their children,

title: Motion Dismissed To Lift News Curb In I.B.M. Lawsuit
description: A Federal judge here yesterday dismissed a motion to withdraw a pretrial order restricting the dissemination of news by laWyers involved in the Government's antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: $410 Raised in Harlem to Bury Girl Allegedly Slain by Mother
description: A 9yearold girl whose mother allegedly drowned her in a kitchen sink to save the child from hunger will have a decent burial today because neighbors in the East Harlem slum where she lived raised $410 in a doortodoor collection.

title: Hanoi Held Able to Fight 2 Years at Present Rate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12This country's two principal intelligence agencies have concluded in recent reports submitted to the White House that Hanoi can sustain the fighting in South Vietnam at the present rate for the next two years despite the heavy American bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Sinking Ship's Crew Saved
description: BOSTON, Sept 12 (AP)The United States Coast Guard,rescued the sixman crew of the 83foot lobster boat Mardi Gras before she sank at 5 A.M. today 23 miles south of Block Island, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: Head of Democratic Group Says G.O.P. Tapped Phone
description: RUMFORD, Me., Sept. 12 (AP)  The Democratic state chairman, Severin Beliveau, says that his Washington telephone was tapped and that he is considering filing an invasion of privacy suit against the Committee for the ReElection of the President because of it.

title: INQUIRY ON ATTICA SCORES GOVERNOR OVER 1971 REVOLT;Report Says He Should Have Visited Site Before Order Was Given for Assault
description: The New York State Special Commission on Attica concluded in its final report released yesterday that Governor Rockefeller should have gone to the upstate prison before ordering an armed assault on rebel inmates.

title: Russians Gloat Over Gold Medals, Chide Americans
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 12Cold war competitiveness may be mellowing in other fields, but it still runs strong in sports.

title: 21,000 Get Flood Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)Labor Secretary James D. Hodgson said today that. Government programs had put more than 21,000 persons to work in floodstricken areas of the East Coast, cleaning up, repairing damage and providing services in the wake of the tropical storm Agnes. Mr. Hodgson said that the jobs were provided in the first six weeks of a $30million program ordered by President Nixon to provide swift assistance to victims of the most widespread flooding in the nation's history.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: To the Editor: Egypt and its Olympic team cannot escape responsibility for the massacre in Munich. While the Cairo radio broadcast the bulletin of the Black September Group, which claimed responsibility for their feat in Munich, the Egyptian Olympic team packed And fled from Munich for their own protection without any attempt to free the surviving Israeli athletes.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN HIRING DISPUTE
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12  Work will resume tomorrow on the $400million terminal construction project at Newark Airport following an agreement by the Iron Workers Union to hire six black trainees.

title: TIGERS TRIUMPH OVER ORIES,32
description: DETROIT, Sept. 12  John Hiller, Woodie Fryman and Ed Brinkman blended their varied talents and backgrounds tonight to bring the Detroit Tigers a 32 victory over the Baltimore Orioles and a further tightening of the American League's Eastern Division pennant race.

title: Credit Prices Retreat As Early Trend Changes
description: The credit markets made an effort yesterday to push interest rates lower for the first time in a month but the attempt was not successful.

title: Outlook for Monetary Union Is Clouded
description: BERLIN, Sept. 12The outlook for European monetary union is still clouded by a lack of harmony between the French and the West Germans. The West Germans cling tightly to their American relationship. The French, under President Pompidou, continue their basic Gaullist line of seeking political

title: ElectionLaw Suit Brought By Conservatives Dismissed
description: Federal Judge Milton Pollack dismissed yesterday a suit by the state's Conservative party challenging the constitutionality of certain provisions of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971.

title: ALFRED ROTHSCHILD, SHAKESPEARE EDITOR
description: Alfred Rothschild, whose lifelong fascination with the works of William Shakespeare gave him a second career as a scholarly editor after his retirement as a business executive, died Monday at his home, 315 West 70th Street. He was 83 years old.

title: Chafee Aid Exceeds Pell's
description: PROVIDENCE, Sept. 12 (AP) The Senatorial campaign of Republican John H. Chafee received more than $300,000 by the end of August, exceeding by about $60,000 contributions to the reelection effort of Democrat Claiborne Pell, according to reports filed at the State House.

title: Assist for Shoplifting Drive
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 12 (AP)  The Montpelier Area Chamber of Commerce has received a donation to its antishoplifting campaign from an unexpected source. An anonymous letter arrived from Detroit along with a $10 bill and a variety of small items. Dear Sirs, the letter read, I am sending back some of the things that I stole from the stationers and the dime store. I am also sending money because you cannot use them again. I apologize for taking them.

title: Impeachment Group Wins a Stay of Injunction
description: The United States Court of Appeals here granted a stay yesterday of a weekold injunction against political activities by the National Committee for Impeachment, which seeks to impeach President Nixon for his conduct of the war in Vietnam.

title: Letter to the Editor 5  No Title
description: To the Editor: In answer to those who are so quick to condemn to death the fact and spirit of the Olympic Games, I wish to say:

title: DOUGLAS REJECTS APPEAL ON BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Justice William O. Douglas refused today to block a Las Vegas school desegregation plan that involves busing.

title: Number 7 Looks Like New Version of Old 98
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12Mark Harmon, son of Tom old 98 of Michigan fameis off and running and passing for the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: Upset by Miss Schallau
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 12 (AP)Mona Schallau of Iowa City turned in the only upset today as the $40,000 Four Roses women's tennis tournament completed its first round.

title: Lester W. Bentley, Painter Of Eisenhower and Dodglas
description: MADISON, Wis.,Sept. 12 (AP)Lester W. Bentley, a portrait painter, died of cancer today at a hospital here. He was 64 years old and lived in nearby Ephraim and in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Red Smith
description: There used to be an advertising slogan for a chewing gum: The flavor lasts. For a gum manufacturer, this is a proud boast. When it is said of the 1972 Olympic Games, it is an unhappy truth. It would be a relief to forget the fortnight just concluded, to pretend it never happened. Perhaps an ostrich could manage this, or a member of the Olympic hierarchy. For everybody else, those sorry days must be remembered always as a time of bloodshed, bungling and bitterness. Neither the Games nor the governing heads of the International Olympic Committee were in any way responsible for the bloodshed. On the ground of common decency, however, the brass is faulted for blundering on with the frolic while the world stood aghast. As to conduct of the sport, never since these global clambakes got started in 1896 has there been one remotely comparable with this for official misfeasance, incompetence and stubborn arrogance. Chances are it would never be possible bring together thousands of young people from widely dissimilar backgrounds and cultures and throw them into competition for two weeks without creating some friction. Even so, by comparison with past gatherings, Munich was a disaster.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Halston is doing for fashion in the 1970's what Rticli Gemreich did in the 1960's. Or what Mainbocher did in the 1930's.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 12  Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr. of the Larchmont (N. Y.) Yacht Club and B. H. O'Connor of the Corinthian Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass., were separated by a  point today after the first two races in the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup on Long Island Sound. Both are previous winners.

title: Leningrad Visit Canceled
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 12 (AP)Henry A. Kissinger canceled scheduled sightseeing trip to Leningrad tonight and extended his secret meetings with the Soviet leadership through tomorrow.

title: Jets Cut Four, Including Foley, Who Then Becomes $100 Bill
description: At 4 P.M. yesterday, when time ran out on claiming players placed on waivers the day before, there were 104 fewer jobs in the National Football League as the 26 teams settled on their 40player rosters. The result was a number of unhappy or disappointed athletes, like John Mackey of the Baltimore Colts, Tom Woodeshick of the Philadelphia Eagles and Hank Bjorklund of the New York Jets.

title: The Facts of Attica
description: It was one year ago today that the bloodiest prison uprising in all American history ended in a haze of tear gas and hail of gunfire at Attica. The fiveday rebellion left 32 inmates and 11 correction personnel dead and scores more injured in the final, desperate police charge to rescue hostages and retake an inmateheld portion of the upstate facility. Confused, conflicting and demonstrably untrue official accounts of what happened prompted the formation of an impartial citizens panel to determine the factsthe Neld York State Special Commission on Attica, which releases its findings on this anniversary date.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP)A circuit court judge today extended until Sept. 30 a temporary restraining order barring Bobby Hull, the former Chicago Black Hawks star, from joining his new club, the Winnipeg Jets of the World Hockey Association.

title: ... Soviet Methods
description: Expansion of SovietAmerican trade will require major effort by Moscow as well as Washington, course. As the C.E.D. report points out, the economic institutions and practices of Communist countries create special problems both for trade and joint enterprises with the marketoriented business firms of the West.

title: North Koreans in Seoul as Red Cross Talks Open
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Sept. 13  A meeting of South and North Korean Red Cross delegations, opened here this morning with the chief South Korean delegate warning the North Koreans to stick to the humanitarian objectives of the conference and not turn it into a political forum.

title: Lavelle Is Reported to Tell Senators Abrams and Moorer Approved Raids
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle has told the Senate Armed Services Committee that he received permission from Gen. Creighton W. Abrams and Adm. Thomas H. Moorer before ordering series of attacks on North Vietnamese airfields In November, 1971, wellplaced sources said today.

title: Personalities: Erving No Squire
description: The American Basketball Association suffered a damaging blow yesterday, when Ernest Tidwell, a Superior Court judge in Atlanta, ruled that Julius Erving could play for the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association. Erving, a 6foot6inch forward, was the A.B.A. rookie of the year in 197172, scoring an average of 27.2 points for the Virginia Squires.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept 12 (AP)Jim Ryun, who suffered a severe disappointment in the Olympics, and Dave Wottle, who won a gold medal, are scheduled compete in the 800meter run at a meet here Thursday.

title: SOVIET STIFFENS LAWS ON ADDICTS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 12The Soviet Union published stringent legislation on drug addiction today, indicating that the abuse of narcotics might be becoming a matter of concern to the authorities.

title: Rizzo Seeks to Help Nixon
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP)Democratic Mayor Frank L. Rizzo says he is going to the White House Thursday to find out what I can do to help reelect the President.

title: Saigon Says Its Marines Fought Way Into Quangtri's Citadel in 2d Attempt to Capture City
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 13 South Vietnamese marines fought their way into the walled. Citadel in Quangtri city Monday night, a South Vietnamese military spokesman said. The marines reportedly took up where paratroopers left off July 28, after the first attempt to recapture the. town from the North Vietnamese.

title: Travelers Aid Got Director
description: The appointment of John James Ryan as general director of the Travelers Aid Society of New York was announced yesIterday by John M. Perkins. president of the 67yearold voluntary social agency. Mr. Ryan had previously been executive director of Irvington House, which serves children affected by rheumatic fever and allied diseases.

title: 3 MORE CAPTURED IN MURDERS OF 8
description: ST. CROIX, V. I., Sept. 12 (AP)Acting on an anonymous tip, law officers raided Frederiksted house today and captured three of five fugitives charged with murdering eight persons at the Fountain Valley Golf Course last week. The three suspects surrendered without a fight.

title: Sales Nearing $4Million, Record Pace, at Keeneland
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 12 (AP)The Keeneland fall sale of thoroughbred yearlings approached the $4million mark today after three of the eight sessions had been completed.

title: Safety Board Study Cites Perils Of Jet Engine Blasts at Airports
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board said today that jet blasts, particularly from new, extremely powerful airplane engines, were causing a disturbing number of accidents on the ground at airports.

title: Disaster Area Declared
description: BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP)Massachusetts has been declared an agricultural disaster area because of the wet, cold growing season, and Federal aid is now available through the Farmers Home Administration. Myron Maiewski, Assistant State Commissioner of Agriculture, said today that United States Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz notified the Federal agency about the designation yesterday.

title: Israelis Report Arabs Fired Bazookas at Golan Heights
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 12 (Reuters) Arab forces struck back at Israeliheld territory today for the first time since the Israeli Air Force's heavy reprisal raids on Syria and Lebanon last Friday.

title: SEATBELT WARNING IS CALLED FAILURE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)The autosafety research arm of the insurance industry said today that the buzzerandlight warning on new cars does not stimulate seatbelt use.

title: 25% RERUN LIMIT ON TV IS DECRIED
description: Robert D. Wood, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System television network, yesterday branded as completely cockeyed proposals that the networks be prevented from presenting reruns during more than 25 per cent of the evening prime viewing time in any given year.

title: HEROES'BURIAL HELD FOR 5 ARABS IN LIBYA
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 12 (UPI)Libya gave a heroes burial today to five Palestinian guerrillas killed at a military airfield near Munich, West Germany, Sept. 5 as they were trying to escape with nine Israeli hostages taken in a raid on the Olympic Village.

title: Nan Riley Dies in Air Crash; Aide at Carl Byoir Was 39
description: Nan Riley, director of women's news for Carl Byoir & Associates, public relations concern, was killed Sunday in the crash of an Ethiopian Airlines plane near Gondar, Ethiopia. She was 39 years old and lived at 340 East 74th Street.

title: DYNAMITE TAKES 20 LEAD IN SAIL
description: TORONTO, Sept. 12 (AP)The American challenger, Dynamite, again exhibited superior boat speed in light air today, beating Mirage on the Lake Ontario course and taking 20 lead in the Canada Cup sailing series.

title: OFFICE OF EDUCATION BAcKS FUNDS REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The Office of Education said today that it agreed with a study indicating widespread misuse of compensatory education funds but added that it was making every effort to correct the situation.

title: SLIGHTED MUMMY GOING ON DISPLAY
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y. Sept. 12 (AP)  Tothmea  the Schenectady Museum's longneglected Egyptianwill bask again in the public admiration through the graces of modern media.

title: NEWSMAN IS CITED IN HOSPITAL INQUIRY
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 12 (UPI)A state legislative committee investigating reports of child abuse at a staterun hospital for the mentally retarded ended its inquiry today after ordering a newsman to show cause why he should not be held in contempt.

title: DR. JOHN P. RIESMAN
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 12Dr. John Penrose Riesman, a surgeon and clinical associate at the Yale University School of Medicine, died Friday after a heart attack in Maine Medical Center, Portland. He was 60 years old and lived in Branford, Conn., and Damariscotta, Me.

title: Hrs. Knauer Criticizes Quality of U.S. Autos
description: DETROIT, Sept. 12 (UPI)Virginia H. Knauer, President Nixon's director of consumer affairs, attacked the automobile industry today on its home ground contending that it fails to build cars right the first time and then does not provide adequate and honest repair service.

title: Senate Drug Inquiry Starts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee opened a study of worldwide drug traffic today to find a cure ofr the epidemic of illegal narcotics in the United States. Unless America can conquer drugs, drugs will surely conquer Arrierica, the committee chairman, Senator James O. Eastland, Democratic of Mississippi, said at the outset of a fiveday hearing.

title: METS GET 4 HITS, DEFEAT PHILS, 43
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 They picked some sweet time to do it, with the season nearly over, but the New York Mets continued their 11thhour revival tonight by defeating the Philadelphia Phillies again, 43.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Another letter carrier has discarded undelivered mail into the trunk of his automobile, postal authorities charged yesterday. It was the second such incident uncovered the last 16 days.

title: Meetings Arc Held Here To Protest Munich Deaths
description: More than 3,000 members of District 65, Distributive Workers of America, stopped work yesterday shortly before noon and held a 90minute meeting in Astor Place to protest the killing of 11 members of the Israeli Olympic team in Munich last week.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: To the Editor: In the anger, frustration, sorrow and sadness expressed by our leaders and by most civilized nations over the shootings in Munich, we find true mankind.

title: Bitie Cross Rate Rise Backed
description: BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP)An average rate increase of 18.7 per cent for nongroup Blue CrossBlue Shield subscribers has been approved by State Insurance Commissioner John G. Ryan.

title: Salute to a Bookman
description: For an author fame is commonplace and often unearned; for a publisher the esteem even of the literary world is unique and can only be deserved. Alfred A. Knopf, at 80, enjoys that admiration.

title: Bayh Asks Parole Change
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Legislation to revise the Federal parole system was introduced today by Senator Birch Bayh, Democratic of Indiana. The bill would remove the Fed, oral Board of Parole from the Justice Department and give it independent status. It would give parole applicants the rights to counsel at parole hearings, and require publication of criteria for granting, denying and revoking parole.

title: N.H.L. Islanders Start Getting to Know One Another
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Sept. 12Fiftynine strangers have gathered here on the shores of Lake Kawartha, 90 miles northeast of Toronto, for the impossible task of molding a National Hockey League team in less than a month.

title: COCOA CONTRACTS DECLINE SHARPLY
description: The removal by Brazil of minimum prices on export sales of cocoa caused heavy selling of bean futures here yesterday and prices dropped the daily limit of 1 cent a pound. In London, prices fell half a cent a pound.

title: Elizabeth F. Martin Wed to Erno F. Bolan
description: Miss Elizabeth Fontaine Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fontaine Martin of Darien, Conn., and Landgrove, Vt., was married in London last Friday to Ern Ferencz Belan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erno BeIan of London, formerly of Budapest. The ceremony at the Office of the Registrar of the Borough of Brent was performed by E. T. Shrimpton, the superintendent registrar.

title: Meter Maid Arrested; Ticketed a Police Car
description: A meter maid was arrested yesterday afternoon when she placed a parking ticket under the windshield wiper of a police car. A passersby who protested the arrest was also taken into custody.

title: LIE DETECTORS USED FOR KLAN INFORMERS
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 (AP) An official of the Ku Klux Klan says the organization is using lie detector tests to root out government informers.

title: Rod Stewart and Faces Show Full Artillery, of Rock n Roll
description: Rod Stewart and Faces have been bouncing around the States this summer buoyed by their reputationat homeas one of the best rock bands in all of England. Yet despite their obvious selfassurance and respectable record sales, the reputation somehow hasn't quite managed to survive the ocean crossing untarnished.

title: Yanks Win, 32 From Red Sox
description: Fiveyearold Gregg Peterson reaffirmed his belief last night that Sparky Lyle is the best team in the American League and 30yearold Fritz Peterson has plenty of reason to believe it.

title: British Say Iceland Gunboat Put Fishermen in Danger
description: LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) Britain issued a stiff protest to Iceland today over an incident between three British trawlers and an Icelandic gunboat.

title: DROP IS FORECAST IN U.S CORN CROP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)The nation's corn crop, a key to consumer meat supplies next winter, will be 5,124,425,000 bushels, down 8 per, cent from the record harvest in 1971 but 4 per cent more than forecast in August, the. Agriculture Department estimated today.

title: $25,000 to Shave?
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI)Mark Spitz said today he had been flooded with contract offers, requests for personal appearances and fan mail since winning seven Olympic gold medals in swimming.

title: 2 CAR MAKERS ASK FOR RISE IN PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The nation's two smaller automobile manufacturers said today they would raise the prices on their 1973 models if possible even if the prices on other new cars remained frozen.

title: Black General Takes New Post As the No. 2 Man at Fort Dix
description: FORT DIX, N. J. Sept. 12 Brig. Gen. Julius J., Becton Jr. today became the first black deputy commander of Fort Dix, the Army's largest basictraining base.

title: Market Place: A Random List Posts 200% Rise
description: It may come as a surprise to many investors to learn that a random selection of big, broadly capitalized growth stocks purchased at the market peak in December, 1968, Would have created a portfolio whose value today would be up some 200 per cent.

title: London Delays Extradition Of Convicted Taiwan Man
description: LONDON, Sept. 12 (UPI)A Taiwanese architect convicted of conspiring to assassinate Gen, Chiang KaiShek's son at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan was ordered held in custody in London for another week today.

title: ENVY DUKE, 17I, WINS AT YONKERS
description: YONKERS, Sept. 12It long has been acknowledged that the most hazardous gamble at a harness track is a wager on the outcome of a race involving 2yearold trotting fillies.

title: G.M. Displays LowPrice Car It Hopes to Sell in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 12 (AP)A specially designed lowcost automobile produced by the General Motors Corporation and called the Bedford Tiger was unveiled today for demonstration purposes.

title: RICHEY TRIUMPHS IN STRAIGHT SETS
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 12 (Canadian Press)Two Americans and a South African advanced to the second round of a $50,000 tournament for contract pros.

title: Textile Sales Expected to Rise 7% in 1972
description: Textile sales this year are expected to exceed the 1971 level by 7 per cent, H. W. Close, president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, said yesterday. He estimated domestic mill volume at $24.5billion, up from $22.9billion last year.

title: Forest Payments a Record
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)  A sharp increase in United States Forest Service receipts has brought the agency's payments to states to record total of $85.1million for the year, the Agriculture De partment announced today. Officials said that the service collected nearly $339million from timber sales, grazing fees, recreation, minerals, power and other uses in the year.

title: Court Upholds Lowenstein And Orders New Primary
description: ALBANY, Sept. 12  The state's highest court tonight ordered a new primary election in Brooklyn's 14th CongressionalDistrict next Tuesday between Democratic Representative John J. Rooney and his opponent in the. June 20 primary, former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein.

title: HOUSE UNIT SCANS FUND GIVEN G.O.P.
A Fifth of Expected Total, It Stirs Credibility Fears
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 12A miscalculation in Yale's budget estimates has resulted in a 197172 deficit that is less than onefifth of the $5.7million originally predicted.

title: Israel Vows Wide Fight on Guerrillas
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 12Premier Golda Meir warned today that Israel has no choice but to strike at the terrorist organizations wherever we can.

title: Syphilis Study Went On After Its Apparent Success
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) After only four years of a 40year Federal syphilis experiment in Alabama, doctors had apparently gained the specific knowledge they initially sought.

title: Connally Names Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) George Killion, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee from 1945 to 1947, was appointed today as a national vice chairman of Democrats for Nixon, the group's chairman, John B. Connally, announced. Mr. Killion worked in the campaigns of former Democratic Presidents Roosevelt, Truman, Kennedy and Johnson.

title: Roundup: Expos Laboy Swings Hot Bat
description: Coco Laboy, who spent most of the season recovering from a knee operation, almost beat the St. Louis Cardinals singlehandedly in Montreal's Jerry Park last night.

title: MALL TUNNEL PLAN OPPOSED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Sept. 12 (AP) State Senator Walter B. Langley of Albany said today he had asked the Office of General Services to halt plans for construction of a multimillion dollar tunnel linking the State Capitol Building and the Legislative Office Building at the new South Mall.

title: KILLANIN ASSUMES TOP OLYMPIC POST
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Sept. 12 (AP)Lord Killanin of Ireland took over as president of the International Olympic Committee today and stated his support of efforts to deflate ultranationalism, which had marred past Olympic Games.

title: GOV. KERNER LINKED TO A $45,000 BRIBE
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP)Federal prosecutors say that former Gov. Otto Kerner of Illinois took a $45,000 bribe from a race track operator just before his election in 1960.

title: FundSharing Bill Passed By Senate on 6320 Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The Senate passed the revenuesharing bill today, after rebuffing repeated attempts by Senators from large, urban states to shift more of the Federal financial aid provided by the bill into their states. The vote was 63 to 20.

title: H.I.P. Says It Is Solvent In Spite of Its Problems
description: The head of the fiveman committee that is running the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York said yesterday that the prepaid group medical plan was not bankrupt and should be operating at a profit by July.

title: U.S. Doctor Says Herbal Remedies will Be Next Medical Import From China
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12A prominent American physician said today on the return from his second trip to China in two years that he expected herbal remedies would follow acupuncture as the next medicinal import from China.

title: CHILEAN COPPER UNIT ASSAILS KENNECOTT
description: The Chilean Government Copper Corporation yesterday termed as open aggression a statement made last week by the Kennecott Copper Corporation that it would look for remedies in other countries for the expropriation of its Chilean copper properties.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Two major outdoor fashion shows will highlight the city's first fall fashion festival, a weeklong celebration that Mayor Lindsay will help launch next Tuesday with a walking tour of the garment center.

title: Trade With the East..
description: It was of course by pure coincidence that a major report urging liberalized rules for EastWest trade was released on the same day this week that China was revealed to have bought ten Boeing 707 airliners in $150million deal. The contract concluded in Peking only emphasizes the great possibilities of EastWest trade and will further sharpen the interest of American businessmen in this type of commerce, which had already received a huge boost with the U.S.S.R. agreement to purchase large quantities of grain from the United States.

title: CALIFORNIA INDIANS SUE FOR $15BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) A coalition of Indians has sued the Federal Government for $15billion in damages, saying that tribes were deceived in settlement of their claim to twothirds of California.

title: TWO STOPS ADDED TO KISSINGER TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon'a adviser on national security, has expanded his overseas tour to Include talks with Government leaders in London and Paris.

title: NEW AID PLANNED FOR CITY ADDICTS
description: A new city program for drug additts, designed to provide proper medical treatment for all and to find jobs for those who are employable, was announced yesterday by officials of the Addiction Service Agency, and the Department of Social Services.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: To the Editor: The world is rightly outraged by, what happened in Munich and before at Tel Aviv's airport and many other places.

title: Plan Dropped to Form A National Daily Paper
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Plans to establish a national daily newspaper based here have been dropped.

title: COTS FEARED HERE IN AID TO THE POOR
description: Mayor Lindsay and Human Resources Administrator Jule IV Sugarman declared last night that a Senate action yesterday  if sustained would force the city to slash existing prOgrams designed to help welfare mothers into jobs, as well as other social services.

title: 4 More Women at F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (Reuters)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has hired four more women to train to be F.B.I. agents, raising the total to six. A bureau spokesman said today that fewer than 50 women had applied to be agents, fewer than expected.

title: Crangle Calls Rockefeller's Record a Key Issue
LUCAS OF KNICKS GETS 3YEAR PACT
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 12A new threeyear contract for Jerry Lucas with the New York Knicks was announced today with the opening of training camp at Monmouth College. Twentythree players were on hand, 11 more than New York will be able to carry when the season opens Oct. 10.

title: The Smoke Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The Nixon people watching their thirtypoint lead in the opinion polls, their swelling campaign coffers, and the dissension among the Democrats have only one nervous fear as they count the days until Nov. 7. They dread that one or another of the scandals smouldering around them may break into open flame before the election.

title: Bridg: Impact of Unexpected Result Can Prove Pitfall for Expert
description: The emotional impact of a triumph or disaster often carries forward to the next deal. Even the greatest players are not immune, as the diagramed deal demonstrates. In a Spingold Knockout match in the recent Summer Nationals in Denver, Lew Mathe of Los Angeles held the South cards.

title: Munich Autopsies Show Shots Killed 10 of 11 Israelis
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 12 (AP)All but one of the 11 Israelis who were killed last Tuesday after an Arab guerrilla raid on the Olympic Village here died of gunshot wounds, according to autopsy reports made public today.

title: GUSTAVUS ROBINSON OF CORNELL LAW, 91
description: Gustavus H. Robinson, William Nelson Cromwell Professor of International Law Emeritus at the Cornell Law School, died Monday at his home in Ithaca, N. Y. He was 91 years old.

title: Genesco Cuts Dividend To 17 Cents From 42
description: Directors of Genesco, Inc., Nashville, yesterday reduced the quarterly common stock dividend to 17 cents a share from 42, cents a share paid in previous quarters. The dividend is payable Oct. 31 to shareholders of record Oct16.

title: Organ Transplant Dies
description: ROYAL OAK, Mich., Sept. 12 (UPI)Charles E. Mundy, who received a new kidney in a 1968 triple organ transplant, died in Beaumont Hospital here today. Mr. Mundy, who was 25 years old, received the kidney of woman auto accident victim at the Cleveland Clinic on Sept. 4, 1968. A second man reeeivea the woman's heart and a third received her other kidney. Both died within months of the operation.

title: F.H.A. AIDE PLEADS GUILTY TO FRAUD
description: A former appraiser for the Federal Housing Administration pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of conspiracy and fraud in connection with multimilliondollar mortgagefraud scheme.

title: McGovern's Position on Foreign Policy: A Broad Pattern Seems to Be Emerging
Talks on Widened Common Market to Go On
description: FRASCATI, Italy, Sept. 12The foreign and finance ministers of the Common Market's six present and four prospective member nations removed today the final doubts over the holding of the proposed European summit conference to chart the Course of the enlarged market.

title: LAW TO CURB NOISE VOTED BY COUNCIL
description: The City Council, in spite of heavy opposition from the construction industry, last night passed, by a vote of 31 to 5, the city's first comprehensive noisecontrol code.

title: MRS. GALLO HEARD IN TRIAL OF AIDE
description: Mrs. Joseph Gallo, widow of the gangland leader who was shot to death April 7, testified yesterday in Supreme Court in Manhattan that when gunmen burst into the downtown resfaurant to kill her husband, his first instinct was to protect the people sitting with him.

title: Waterfront Concern Is Charged With Infiltration by 2 Criminals
description: Criminal infiltration and control of a company doing cleaning and maintenance work for waterfront concerns, mainly at Port Elizabeth, N. J., was charged yesterday by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

title: Passionist Fathers Elect A Leader for First Time
description: NORTH PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 12 (AP)Ending a tradition that lasted 251 years, the Passionist Fathers have elected their own religious leader in an open vote.

title: Manhattan Life Appoints
description: The Manhattan Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the appointment of Raymond S. Olinsky as senior vice president for sales and marketing.

title: NEWSPAPER WAGE CUT BY PAY BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 The Pay Board today ordered Washington's two daily newspapers, The Post and The Evening StarDaily News, to reduce wages and salaries they pay to their mechanical employes. The Post was also told to cut the pay of its news and commercial employes.

title: RAPIDAMERICAN SHOWS PROFIT UP
description: The RapidAmerican Corporation, which operates retailing and consumergoods companies, reported yesterday higher operating net income in the second fiscal quarter ended July 31 of $4,605,000, or 30 cents a share, against $3,434,000, or 26 cents a share, in the comparable 1971 quarter.

title: Research Unit Seeks Green Revolution in Nigeria
description: IBADAN, Nigeria, Sept. 8 Sunday Adepoju looked out over a cornfield and called to several workers marking off the rows: Make certain the lines are straight! They must be straight!

title: STOCKS DECLINE FOR THE 6TH DAY
description: The stock market slumped again yesterday, showing its biggest loss for one day, in almost three weeks as measured by the DowJones industrial average. Trading volume increased.

title: BROOKLYN SCHOOL IS SHUT FOR 2D DAY
description: The Meyer Levin Junior High School, on the border, of the East Flatbush and Canarsie sections in Brooklyn, remained closed for a second day yesterday after local school officials continued to refuse to admit about 90 youngsters from a predominantly black housing development in the Brownsville) section.

title: New Carmen Awaits Call To Open Met's 88th Season
description: The scene is the Metropolitan Opera House, a few days ago. The stage is set with the scenery for the last act of the new production of Carmen, which will open the Met's 88th season on Tuesday night.

title: G.O.P. Charts Plans for Last 8 Weeks of Drive
Mrs. Mitchell Identifies Official She Says Tore Phone Off Wall
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Mrs. John N. Mitchell has identified the man who allegedly tore the telephone from the wall during her conversation with a reporter last June as the new head of security for the Committee for the Reelection of the President.

title: Reasoner's Wife Gets Post
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 12 (AP)Mrs. Kathleen Reasoner, wife of the American Broadcasting Company newscaster Harry Reasoner, has been appointed to the Board of Trustees of the state Training School for the Mentally Retarded in Southbury.

title: DR. T. N. BURBRIDGE, COAST RIGHTS FIGURE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 (UPI)Dr. Thomas N. Burbridge, a civil rights leader and a medical expert on alcoholism, died at the University of California Medical Center Friday after a long illness. His age was 51.

title: STEVENS CONFIDENT ON BOOK UNIT FUNDS
description: Roger L. Stevens, chairman of the National Book Committee, which was told last week that it was losing an annual subsidy of $80,000 from the Association of American Publishers, said.yesterday that he expected the committee to be able to solicit enough contributions to make up the difference and perhaps more.

title: HOUSING PROJECT ATTACKED ANEW
description: Seven hundred Forest Hills residents turned out last night for a public hearing held by Community Board 6 in Queens on the controversial public housing project being built off the Long Island Expressway at 108th Street.

title: Property Crimes Decline in City, But Crimes Against People Rise
description: Serious crimes against: people in New York City rose in JUly, while crimes against property dropped.

title: Canada's Peking Fair Adding Up to Success
description: PEKING, Sept. 12While a final judgment on Canada's first trade fair in China must await the maturing of contacts made between participating companies and the Chinese trading corporations, enough contracts have been signed already to indicate that it was worth the price.

title: U.S.,Canada, Britain Back Compromise on Hijacking
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The United States, Canada and Britain agreed today on a cornpromise formula for a new antihijacking treaty.

title: UNITED NATIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y:, Sept. 12 Beginning next week, the representatives of most of the nations of the world will convene here for the 27th General Assembly of the United Nations. Nobody is paying much attention to the event, but somebody has to pay attention to the present violence and anarchy in the world, and maybe the United Nations is the place to do it.

title: HoffaLawyer, Despite Dossier, Presented Film at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 William L. Taub, the mysterious figure who acted as legal counsel for James F. Hoffa, was able to arrange and attend the showing of a film on China at the White House last February, even though the Secret Service had a thick dossier on him.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Daley Calls on Chicago to Back McGovern, the Next President
Counsel to Attica Study Group
description: For Arthur L. Liman, general counsel to the New York State Special Commission on Attica which released its report yesterday, the personal sense of a job well done is shadowed by a mood of doubt.

title: Small Quake Hits Coast
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI)  A small earthquake rippled along the San Jacinto Fault, a branch of the San Andreas Fault, through Riverside'and San Bernardino Counties yesterday. There were no reports of damage or injuries.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: The former world lightweight champion, Ken Buchanan of Scotland, was named yesterday to substitute for injured Roberto Duran of Panama against Carlos Ortiz next Wednesday night in a semifinal to the Muhammad AliFloyd Patterson main event.

title: FRANK J. MEISTRELL OF U.S. FLOOD AGENCY
description: Frank J. Meistrell who held Federal posts in flood and housing agencies and in recent years was director of receivership in the city housing administration, died Monday of a heart attac15, at Cedarhurst, L. I., wheie he lived. His age was 70.

title: AMIN PRAISES HITLER FOR KILLING OF JEWS
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 12 (Reuters)Uganda's President, Gen. Idi Amin, has suggested that all Israelis be moved from the Middle East to Britain, adding that he understands why Hitler killed six million Jews.

title: Advertising: Memories of L. &
description: The once bustling offices on the sixth and seventh floors of 380 Madison Avenue were tomblike yesterday morning.

title: Buffalo Creek Flood Inquiry Is Off Until After Election
description: LOGAN, W. Va., Sept. 12 (UPI)A special grand jury will not begin its investigation of the Buffalo Creek Valley flood, which killed at least 118 persons on Feb. 26, until after the Nov. 7 general elections, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Outbreaks of Mob Violence in Various States Plague New Delhi
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 13 For many weeks, mob violence has been erupting in various parts of India, set off by seemingly smallscale incidents that officials say political foes of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi have inflated to national proportions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATORS ASSERT ABRAMS DISPUTES LAVELLE ON RAIDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Gen. Creighton W. Abrams was reported to have given the Senate Armed Services Committee testimony today that conflicted with the version of Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle on the unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Consular Aides Tour Port Facilities As New Foreign Business Is Sought
URBAN LEAGUE CHIEF ASSAILS CANDIDATES
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the executive director of the National Urban League, accused both the Democratic and Republican Presidential candidates in an open letter yesterday of alienating black citizens by skirting such issues as racism and urban revitalization.

title: 4 INDICTED UPSTATE IN SLAYING OF CLERK
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 13 (AP) An Onondaga County grand jury indicted four young men today in the slaying of a motel clerk two weeks ago.

title: CAHILL WITHHOLDS TOCKS IS. SUPPORT DEMANDS CHANGE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13Gov. William T. Cahill said here today that he could not support the controversial Tacks Island Dam project unless it was drastically modified and reduced in scope to spare New Jersey from what he warned would be an adverse environmental and financial impact.

title: Market Place: Why Little Guy Is on Sidelines
description: Why is the small investor out of the stock market? Why is he glued to the sidelines, while most of the action is accounted for by such big market players as mutual funds, insurance companies and pension funds?

title: Brezhnev's Cadillac Not Being Recalled
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13 (AP)The $9,600 Cadillac Eldorado that President Nixon gave to the Soviet.Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, is not being recalled.

title: A Sitter for Almost Every Purpose
description: There have been baby sitters and even dog and cat sitters for quite some time. But now it is possible to have someone sit with the plumber, the telephone installer or even to just sit and wait for a delivery man.

title: Roundup: Pirates Smell World Series
description: Old baseball players seem to perform better than ever when the smell of fresh moneyWorld Series money assails their nostrils.

title: Ghana Abolishes Top Court; Get New Jobs, Judges Told
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)  Ghana's eight month old military regime has abolished the country's Supreme Court and told the Justices to look for other jobs.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: BUZZARDS BAY, Mass., Sept. 13 (UPI)John Havlicek became an official holdout today when he failed to show up for the Boston Celtics opening preseason workout at the Massachusetts Maritime Academy. Havlicek was in camp yesterday for a physical examination, but a spokesman for the club said he left immediately afterward. The 31yearold Havlicek's previous threeyear contract expired at the end of last season and he is reported to be seeking a new one for five years.

title: MRS. CRERAR HARRIS
description: Mrs. Mildred Cook Harris, wife of Crerar Harris, a retired member of the foreign news staff of The New York Times and former desk chief in its London bureau, died of cancer yesterday in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 68 years old and lived at 226 East 59th Street and in North Truro, Mass.

title: Ferry Capsizes in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 13 (AP)A ferry carrying mainly school children capsized today in the Krain River in the north Malaysian state of Perak and more than 30 persons were missing, the police reported.

title: Syria Said to Agree To Soviet BuildUp At 2 of Her Ports
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Administration officials said today. that Syria and the Soviet Union had just negotiated a security arrangement that would allow the Russians to build up naval facilities at two Syrian ports in return for supplying advanced air defense missiles and jet fighter planes.

title: SLATTERY IS LOW IN BID ON SUBWAY
description: The Transit Authority opened bids yesterday on construction work for the first section of the proposed Second Avenue subway, from 99th to 105th Street. The low bid of $17,480,266 was submitted by Slattery Associates of Maspeth, Queens.

title: Redskins Brown Paying Price as Top N.F.L. Back
description: Pro football's Monday night telecasts will open next week with an interesting match, the game's best running back against the game's best defense. Larry Brown, the Washington Redskins rubberized runner, will be going against the Minnesota Viking Purple Gang, the defense that gave up the fewest points (139), the fewest touchdowns (14) and the fewest touchdowns by rushing (2) in the National Football League last season.

title: House G.O.P. Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)  House Republicans today unanimously picked Representative Jack Edwards of Alabama as their secretary. He succeeds former Representative Richard H. Poff of Virginia, who resigned from the House to become a State Supreme Court justice in Virginia. The job of secretary of the party conference, or caucus, carries no major responsibilities, but its holder is included in the House Republican leadership team.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept 13The State Board of Education ordered all public school districts today to take part in a new, longrange state testing program to determine student achievement in reading and mathematics.

title: Advertising:
description: If you consider a cigarette pack an unlikely advertising medium for all but the Surgeon General, wait till you hear what Liggett & Myers has in mind for its Chesterfield brand.

title: Shriver Borrows From a Comedian And a Catechism
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 13Sargent Shriver's speeches these days are drawing on both the Roman Catholic catechism and the wit of one of Danny Thomas's gag writers.

title: Simple Rites for Drowned Girl Are Attended by 500 Neighbors
description: There were no eulogies at Shirley Rohinson's memorial service in East Harlem yesterday, no funeral music, no displays of deep grief.

title: 31% Fewer Turkeys Raised
description: ALBANY, Sept. 13 (AP)Turkey growers in New York are raising 31 per cent fewer turkeys this year than in 1971, according to the State Department of Agricultiire and Markets. The number of heavybreed turkeys raised was estimated at 154,000, down 32 per cent; Light breeds were estimated at 28,000, down 24 per cent.

title: Tokyo Envoy Due in Town
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  The Nationalist Chinese Government agreed today to a visit by a Japanese envoy to explain Tokyo's new China policy. Etsusaburo Shiina, vice president of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic party is expected here on Sept. 17.

title: Sports of The Times
description: DEER LAKE, Pa., Sept, 13On a wooded hill here about 25 miles north of Reading, an oiled dirt road led up towhere two acres of trees had been leveled. In the clearing, Muhammad Ali stood outside a low log cabin, his gym. Not far away was a larger log cabin near a wooden stable with four horses. Behind the gym another log cabin was being built near the long, yellow and white mobile home where he is living.

title: Roving ArtistStory Program Gains A Following Among Children in City
description: The setting is several streets in Harlem one day, a playground in East Harlem another day and a park in Chinatown on a third day.

title: Jersey Board Orders New Tests For Students in Every District
description: TRENTON, Sept. 13  The State Board of Education or tiered all public school districts today to take part in a new, longrange state testing program to determine student, achievement in reading and mathematics.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Installed in Error, Parking Sign Stays And Provokes Ire
description: Four months ago the Traffic Department admitted posting in error a noparking sign on Walton Avenue near the Bronx County Courthouse and promised to remove it in the very near future.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TENAFLY, N. J. Sept. 13Her white tennis shirt ruffles underneath and she wore sunglasses, though there is never any sun inside the Tenafly Racquet Club.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)  The Democratic National Commitee said that a small, black implement, described as a listening device, was found today in a telephone that had been previously tapped at party headquarters.

title: War Veteran in Plot Case Freed of Marijuana Charge
description: GAINSVILLE, Fla., Sept. 13 (AP)Scott CamiI, an antiwar activist, was acquitted yesterday of two marijuana charges and said that he had overcome a bigger obstacle than the Federal conspiracy charge he faces next month.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BAL HARBOR, Fla., Sept. 13 (AP)  The United Rubber Workers, representing 184,000 members, announced today its support of the Democratic Presidential ticket after 900 delegates to the union's annual convention here voted unanimously to endorse Senator George McGovern.

title: Moves to Curb Terrorists Are Discussed in Bonn
description: BONN, Sept. 13The West German Cabinet and the Interior Ministers of the 11 state governments held separate meetings here today on measures to control terrorist organizations in the country.

title: Personalities: Miss Gould Visits
description: Shane Gould, the 15yearold Olympic swim champion from Australia, was in New York yesterday with her parents, and she did the expected. She took in the sights, conversed with taxi drivers and toured the United Nations.

title: YONKERS MARK SET BY SWEET O'BRIEN
Article 3  No Title
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass., Sept. 13 (AP)Schools were closed here today for the third day this week and City Solicitor William Jerome went to court to seek a contempt citation against the striking Somerville Teachers Association. The main issue is an increase in the number of classes teachers would be required to conduct a day.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J. Sept. 13Jim Gleason and Mrs. Seymour Holub of Shackamaxon carded a 75 for 142 today to win the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association prowoman championship by three strokes at the Woodlake Golf and Country Club.

title: Relatives Are Flying To Hanoi to Escort P.O.W.s Back Home
description: Relatives of American war prisoners to be freed by North Vietnam, accompanied by three peace activists, left for Hanoi last night to escort the liberated pilots back home.

title: BRIBERY INQUIRY WIDE IN CHICAGO
