description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13A Federal grand jury continued this week its investigation of the alleged bribing of officials in communities along the route of a natural gas pipeline.

title: The Proceedings In theU.N. Today
description: Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Frank Wickhorst Is Dead; Navy AllAmerican in '26
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 13 (UP1)Frank Wickhorst, former football coach at.the University of California, Berkeley, died today at the age of 67.

title: With Barry in Limbo, Nets Look to George Carter
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Sept. 13The New York Nets opened training camp today at the United States Merchant Marine Academy while Rick Barry, their scoring star, was househunting on the North Shore of Long Island.

title: Land Hustlers in Las Vegas Thrive On PropertyHungry Vacationers
description: PAHRUMP, Nev.  Las Vegas not only has casinos, it also has Pahrump.

title: For Attica Townfolk, the Very Scars Hurt
description: ATTICA, Sept. 13Several weeks after last year's prison riot here, the principal of the local high school, Alfred L. Feeney, was amazed to see some of his football players weeping during game. He questioned them on the bench.

title: Peace Fasters,Demonstrate At Headquarters for Nikon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)  Seven antiwar protesters, observing the 39th day of a wateronly fast, demonstrated today at a busy Nixon reelection headquarters and left empty rice bowls as a memento.

title: Italian Keeps Ring Title
description: CAGLIARIA, Italy, Sept. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)  Antonio Puddu of Italy retained his European lightweight boxing title when he beat a compatriot. Enzo Petriglia, on a technical knockout tonight. The champion won when the referee stopped the bout in the 11th round of a scheduled 15rounder at the Sant'Elena Stadium.

title: For This Chef, the Taste of Success Is Indeed Sweet
description: Most people turn sugar into cavities. Maurice Bonte, an outgoing, mustachioed French pastry chef of 37, transforms the little white granules into flowers and shooting stars by pulling and spinning and blowing. This arcane talent vaulted him to the highest pinnacle of his high caloric profession recently when he was named Meilleur Ouvrier de France in the pastrycandy category.

title: MOSCOW UNIT ASKED BY DRESDNER BANK
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 13The Dresdner Bank of West Germany has applied to open an office In Moscow. If accepted, it would be the first Western bank to be represented in the Soviet Union.

title: 4 Electrocuted in Malaysia
description: BUTTERWORTH, Malaysia, Sept. 13 (AP)  Four persons were electrocuted today, one after the other, by a streetlight cable that fell during rains in this northern Malaysia town.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rites at Attica Mark the Day of Tragedy
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Sept. 13A pounding rain, like the rain on Sept. 13, 1971, drenched 200 people who gathered today in front of the walls of the Attica State Correctional Facility to commemorate the deaths of 32 inmates and 11 prison employes in last year's convict rebellion.

title: JOHN P. SMITH
description: BABYLON, L. I., Sept. 13John P. Smith, general superintendent of the Long Island State Park Commission, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip after suffering stroke on Friday. He was 60 years old and lived on the grounds of Belmont Lake State Park where the commission has its headquarters.

title: Haifa Lawyer, in Paris, Won't Talk About Past
description: PARIS, Sept. 13 (AP)  William L. Taub, who acted as legal counsel to James R. Hoffa during the former union leader's attempt to travel to North Vietnam, declined today to answer direct questions about his background.

title: 3/4 of Construction Finished On State's 1st Nuclear Plant
description: OSWEGO, N. Y., Sept. 13 (AP)The State Power Authority's first nuclear generating plant, scheduled to begin producing electricity next year, is more than 75 per cent through its construction phase, officials have reported.

title: Noise Bureau Chief Named
description: ALBANY, Sept. 13 (AP)Dr. Fred G. Haag of Burnt Hills has been named director of the New York Statb Environmental Conservation Department's Bureau of Noise Control. Commissioner Henry L. Diamond said Mr. Haag, 41 years old, would receive $23,599 a year in the post. He has taught noise control and acoustics for the last five years at Union College in Schenectady.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)Television blackouts of major sports events will be investigated by a Congressional subcommittee, Representative Harley O. Staggers, Democrat of West Virginia, said today.

title: School Dispute Continues In a Brooklyn District
description: A Brooklyn junior high school, closed for the first two days of the new school term, opened yesterday, but a nearby elementary school was shuta casualty of the same bitter controversy.

title: News Analysis
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 13The official week of mourning for the 11 Israelis slain in Munich came to a close today, but it seems clear that the impact of the shootings and Israel's retributive air strikes will be felt here and throughout the Middle East for a long time. A new element of tension has been injected into the area, just at a time when many people here were coming to believe that some sort of de facto accommodation between Israel and the Arabs might be possible.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The notion that. Republicans wear cloth coats became a quaint bit of history yesterday when Republicans, as well as RepublicansturnedDemocrats and Democrats, took to the runway of the Plaza's Grand Ballroom, enveloped in all manner of fur.

title: High Treasury Aide Hails Dumping Findings by U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The Treasury's chief trade official took pride today in a (record number of findings of foreign dumping in the United States market in the last fiscal year and rejected foreign complaints that the more vigorous enforcement of the antidumping law constituted protectionism.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ROME, Sept. 13 (AP)Lee Evans, who failed to qualify for the United States Olympic team in the 400meter dash, got a small measure of revenge tonight when he beat the Olympic gold medalist, Vince Matthews, at the Zauli memorial track and field meet.

title: The Stage: Improvisation
description: Last night The Proposition opened the third new edition of its improvisational show, which has been running since March, 1971, currently at the Mercer Arts Center. Since The Proposition suposedly improvies an entirely new show every evening, this actually should be about the 550th edition.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 13 (UPI) Cliff Drysdale of South Africa and Torn Okker of the Netherlands advanced to the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Montreal international tennis tournament today.

title: MARKET CLIMBS ON TRADE REPORT
description: News of a possible $5billion SovietUnited States trade agreement sent the stock market higher yesterday after six consecutive days of declines.

title: Syria Said to Agree To Soviet BuildUp At 2 of Her Ports
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Administration officials said today that Syria and the Soviet Union had just negotiated a security arrangement that would allow the Russians to build up naval facilities at two Syrian ports in return for supplying advanced air defense missiles and jet fighter planes.

title: Personal Finance: Social Security
description: Men and women planning ahead for retirement in 10 to 20 years will find the newly enacted Social Security laws a strong anchor to windward in their financial planning.

title: EVANS WINS 400; MATTHEWS IS 2D
description: ROME, Sept. 13 (AP)Lee Evans, who failed to qualify for the United States Olympic team in the 400meter dash, got a small measure of revenge tonight when he beat the Olympic gold medalist, Vince Matthews, at the Zauli memorial track and field meet.

title: SYRIANS CASUAL ON ISRAELI THREAT
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 13 Even while military men and officials voice concern over Israel's threat to strike again, the lively tempo of city life in the marketplaces and mosques of Syria's capital does not miss a beat.

title: Merger News
description: Barclays Bank, Ltd., an nounced yesterday in London, that it had sold its 2S.33per cent holding in United Dominions Trust, Ltd., a leading British finance company, for 41.9million pounds. Based on yesterday's closing exchange rate, of $2.4474, the transaction would be worth more than

title: U.A.W. Head Says Car Price Hearings Are Politically Inspired
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The Price Commission's hearings on the automobile industry's requests for price increases were called politically inspired today by the United Automobile Workers.

title: Dance: Brief, Attractive Program at the Delacorte
description: The program given by the New York Dance Festival at Central Park's Delacorte Theater on Tuesday night was brief and attractive. It had real quality and seemed just Tight for a light autumn evening.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANT IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: ARMY SEEKS HALT IN R.O.T.C. DECLINE
description: FORT MONROE, Va., Sept. 13 (AP)The Army is contemplating dynamic changes in the structure of its Reserve Officer Training Corps in an effort to reverse steadily declining R.O.T.C. enrollment on college campuses, a spokesman for the Department of the Army said today.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Outboard Marine Corporation said yesterday that 35horsepower Wankel rotary engines would be available this autumn on two of its dines of snowmobiles. The company did not disclose the price of the engine nor the number of engines to be manufactured. Outboard Marine said it had developed its own 35horsepower engine under license from the CurtissWright Corporation and N.S.U. Wankel of West Germany.

title: Advertising:
description: The League of Women Voters is doing to try to reach the conscience of the electorate through its collective funnybone.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: In competitive bidding on a 1.7 million share offering of American Natural Gas Company, underwriters led by White Weld & Co. won on a bid of $36.965 a share. The winning bid was about $2.03 below the stock's closing price of $38 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. The utility will use proceeds for construction programs, a spokesman said.

title: G.O.P. Countersuit Says O'Brien Is Abusing Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13President Nixon's campaign organization, accusing the Democratic party of using the Federal courts as an instrument for creating political headlines in the Watergate breakin case, filed today a $2.5million countersuit against Lawrence F. O'Brien, former Democratic national chairman.

title: SCHOOLS ROLLS UP BUT LESS SHARPLY
description: School and college enrollment across the country increased this fall by onehalf of 1 per cent over last year, the smallest margin in 28 years, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare reported yesterday.

title: Koreans End Parley Without Accord
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Sept. 14A meeting of North Korean and South Korean Red Cross delegations concluded here yesterday without an expected agreement on progress toward reuniting families separated when this peninsula was divided at the end of World War II.

title: LAWMAKERS TOlD OF FEAR BY AGED
description: Elderly Bronx residents, talking yesterday with touring state legislators at five institutions for the aged, said they lived in constant fear for their personal safety.

title: Goal Post Touches Wire; Football Player, 14, Dies
description: WEST COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 13 (UPI)A 14yearold member of the BrooklandCayce High School football team was killed and five others were injured yesterday when a goal post came in contact with highvoltage wire.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U. S. Won't Prosecute Times on Impeachment Ad
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The Justice Department announced today that it would not press criminal charges under Federal election laws against The New York Times for publishing a twopage advertisment by a group advocating the impeachment of President Nixon.

title: House Panel Supports Agency For Consumer Product Safety
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)The House Rules Committee overrode its chairman today and cleared the way for House action on a bill creating a commission to. protect consumers from unsafe products.

title: Music: Bel Canto Bellini
description: The world is full of good singers, but singers such as Stefan Zucker appear only at great intervals, like total eclipses of the sun. Mr. Zucker is not only general manager and artistic director of a group of enthusiasts named the Association for the Furtherment of Bel Canto but also its leading tenor. He led the organization at Town Hall on Tuesday night in a concert version (with piano accompaniment) of Adelson e Salvini, Bellini's first opera. Or, rather, of a drastically revised version of that work that seems never to have been perforMed before Mr. Zucker and his friends brought it to light.

title: SIDNEY DOUGLAS
description: Sidney Douglas, controller of the Flatbush Medical Group, died of a heart attack Tuesday outside his home at 485 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 68 years old.

title: Military Court in Israel Dooms Guerrilla in Bombing of a Bus
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 13 (UPI)A military court sentenced an Israeli Arab to death today for a bomb explosion on a bus that wounded two persons in Tel Aviv nearly a year ago, the military command said. Israel has never carried out an execution of a guerrilla sentenced to die.

title: Primary Defeats Portend Big Shift Of House Power
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13With their defeat in Democratic primary elections yesterday, two elderly committee chairmen joined what will be a mass exodus of aging and powerful members from the House of Representaitves at the end of the year.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 13  The New Jersey Supreme Court ordered an indefinite stay today of a lowercourt order that had struck down as unconstitutional the state system of financing public school education.

title: Notes on People
description: In Tel Aviv, Meyer Lansky, the reputed American underworld figure, sounded philosophical as he discussed Israel's decision that he must leave the country. The 71yearold Lansky was denied permission to stay, in Israel because his presence could prove a danger to public safety. In an interview published in The Jerusalem Post, Lansky said he did not'know where he would go now. That's life, he said. At my age it's too late to worry. What will be will be. Lansky, who has been living in Israel for 26 months and sought citzenship there, also reportedly said, A Jew has slim chance in the world.

title: Ossining Prison Marks Day
description: OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 13Thirtytwo small black flags hung in the rain over a prison ballfield here today as six inmates who survived the Attica riot memorialized their dead brothers and called for an end to the racism, bigotry and oppression that took their lives a year ago today.

title: Spook Says He's Hopeful That McGovern Will Win
description: Benjamin Spock, Presidential candidate of the People's party, said yesterday that he hoped Senator George McGovern wins the November Presidential election.

title: SOVIET UNEARTHS AN ANCIENT TOWN
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13  Soviet archeologists have reported the discovery of the remains of a 5,000yearold town with a probable population of 20,000, described as the largest Stone Age settlement yet excavated in Eastern Europe.

title: A CHANGE IS ASKED IN WESTERN UNION
description: Charging that Western Union was not providing adequate service in its message and Moneyorder deliveries in New York, an investigator for the state's Public Service Commission called yesterday for the Federal Communications Commission to investigate these services with a view to having someone else perform them.

title: ...Rerun Against Rooney
description: As a ranking member of the House Appropriations Committee and chairman of its important subcommittee on State, Commerce and Justice Departments, Brooklyn's John J. Rooney has for years been an aggressively reactionary force in Congress. Now, by the grace of a court decree, Democratic voters in the city's heavily Democratic Fourteenth Congressional District will have an opportunity to replace him with a far more enlightened nominee. Proving massive irregularities that invalidated the results of June primary balloting, in which Mr. Rooney emerged with a narrow victory, former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein will meet Mr. Rooney again in a special election next Tuesday.

title: William Shields Duncan, Expert in Surrogate Law
description: William Shields Duncan, a specialist in surrogate law, whol had offices at 175 Fifth Avenue, died Sunday at the United States Veterans Hospital, Beacon, N. Y. He was 82 years old.

title: Addressograph Adds Unit
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 (UPI) The Addressograph Multigraph Corporation announced today the formation of a data systems division to pursue emerging opportunities in electronic transaction systems. The new organization was formed to effectively mobilize our expanding strength and resources in advanced information systems technology in one unit and focus its efforts on the fastestgrowing segments of the business data systems market, the company said.

title: Boston U. Dean Is Named
description: BOSTON, Sept. 13Peter P. Gabriel, a 43yearold New York management consultant who is a specialist in international business, was named today as dean of the Boston University College of Business Administration.

title: PHILADELPHIA PAPER NAMES CHIEF EDITOR
description: Eugene L. Roberts Jr., national editor of The New York Times, was named yesterday as executive editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer.

title: UgandaThreatens to Intern Banned Asians After Nov.8
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 13 (Reuters)Uganda said tonight that any of the 55,000 unwanted Asians who were still here after President Idi Amin's 90day expulsion deadline would be rounded up by the army and put into military camps.

title: Price Changes
description: Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it would hold published prices of stainless steel sheet and strip until next April 30. The materials are widely used by the automobile and appliance industries. Allegheny Ludlum, the largest domestic producer in this area, said that it would not raise its present book prices on these major specialty steel product lines on orders booked for shipment before May 1 next year. This was being done, the company said, despite the rising costs of labor and nickel scrap.

title: Three Prisoners Escape From Rockland County Jail
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Sept. 13 (UPI)Three inmates at the Rockland County jail here escaped early this morning when one man obtained the key to his cell and freed the other two.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Aging. The President sent a memoradum to the heads of all Federal departments urging them to guard against discrimination against older people in employment.

title: Squires Seek Erving Injunction
description: The Virginia Squires have filed suit in Federal District Court in Virginia seeking an injunction to prevent Julius Erving from playing for another basketball team, Robert Carlson, commissioner of the American Basketball Association, said yesterday.

title: Schmitz Says He'd Dispatch Marines to Free P.O.W.'s
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Sept. 13 (AP)The American party's Presidential candidate, John G. Schmitz, said here yesterday that, if elected, he would order Green Berets and a Marine division into North Vietnam to rescue American prisoners of war.

title: TV: Varying Programing Norms With Family Entertainment
description: The new television season, cont'd:

title: Chamberlain, Havlicek Missing as Camps Open
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (AP)  Wilt Chamberlain, who wants to renegotiate his contract, missed the Los Angeles Lakers opening practice session today.

title: Accord Ends Dow Strike
description: FREEPORT, Tex., Sept. 13 (AP)The Dow Chemical Company and representatives of eight unions agreed on terms of a new threeyear contract today. The tentative settlement, subject to ratification by rankandfile members, will end strike that began June 23. It was the longest strike in the history of Dow's plant here.

title: 2 NEGROES ELECTED MAYORS IN ALABAMA
description: MONTGONERY, Ala., Sept. 13 Negroes were elected Mayor in two moderatesized Alabama cities this week, becoming the first of their race to hold the top municipal office in other than allblack cities.

title: $1.5Million Won in Suit
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)David N. Standefer, 53 years old, a real estate salesman whose arms and legs were paralyzed because a Veterans Administration hospital student jerked his neck during an Xray session after a traffic accident has won $1.5million in damages. Federal District Judge John V. Singleton ruled that the attendant's rough handling had caused the paralysis.

title: Crumbling Hierarchy...
description: There is far more than local political significance in the defeat of Representatives Aspinall of Colorado and McMillan of South Carolina in Tuesday's Democratic primaries. Both are pillars of the Old Guard that has for decades dominated the House of Representatives. And each has in his own way been a barrier to progressMr. Aspinall, as chairman of the House Interior Committee, to improving the physical environment of the country; Mr. McMillan, as chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia, to improving the social and political environment of the nation's capital.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 13 (Reuters)Tests made at Britain's new undersea Brent oilfield, 100 nautical miles off the coast of northern Scotland, have confirmed earlier assessments that it has reserves of up to a billion barrels of oil, it was announced here today. In a joint statement, the AngloDutch Shell group and the American Esso group, who are exploiting the field, said intensive tests carried out by their experts had provided scientific data to show that the oilfield would have a production rate of 300,000 barrels a day and recoverable reserves of up to a billion barrels.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The Government's top decisionmaking body of international financial affairs has decided to retain the present 6 per cent interest rate on loans by the ExportImport bank, it became known today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The population of the Willowbrook State School on Staten Island has dropped below 5,000 for the first time in 14 years, the State Department of Mental Hygiene reported yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: EDISON, N. J. Sept. 13About 80 per cent of the faculty members at Middlesex County College went to union meetings instead of classes today, forcing filie cancellation of many Classes and leaving confused students waiting around the campus.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  One of the few things in Washington that really works well is President Nixon's campaign organization for squelching Senator McGovern.

title: OTB to Open 90th Office
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation said yesterday its 90th branch office would open today at 6967 Grand Avenue in Queens.

title: Chief of Tax Unit Named
description: Whitney North Seymour Jr., announced yesterday the appointment of Milton Sherman, an assistant United States attorney, as chief of the tax unit in Mr. Seymour's office. The 30yearold Mr. Sherman succeeds Michael Saltzman, who recently returned to private practice.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CAHILL WITHHOLDS INKS IS, SUPPORT, DEMANDS CHANGE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13Gov. William T. Cahill said here today that he could not support the controversial Tocks Island Dam project unless it was drastically modified and reduced in scope to spare New Jersey from what he warned would be an adverse environmental and financial impact.

title: Rites at Attica Mark the Day of Tragedy
description: ATTICA, N.Y. Sept. 13A pounding rain, like the rain on Sept. 13, 1971, drenched 200 people who gathered today in front of the walls of the Attica State Correctional Facility to commemorate the deaths of 32 inmates and 11 prison employes in last year's convict rebellion.

title: Uncoordinated Justice
description: The proper administration of justice requires the collective efforts of persons and agencies far beyond the traditional court system, with its judges, clerks, attorneys and probation officers. If that seems obvious, perception of its implications has been painfully slow taking hold in the quarters where it would count.

title: Executive Changes
description: Peter W. Brengel has been named treasurer of Pan American World Airways, Inc. and will join the airline next month. He is presently assistant treasurer of the Mobil Oil Corporation's international division.

title: Mrs. George M. Cohan, a Dancer In Her Husband's Act, Is Buried
description: Stagestruck and auburnhaired, Agnes Nolan and her sister Alice arrived here from Brookline, Mass., in 1905 and were hired as $22 a week chorus girls in George M. Cohan's first musical, Little Johnny Jones.

title: South Vietnam's Medical Care Found to Deteriorate
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 8Shortcomings in the medical care provided by the South Vietnamese Government to its people are becoming more apparent as American medical support is phased out along with American combat troops.

title: PEYOTE CHARGES FILED AGAINST 3
description: Two Queenshoro Community College students and a 19yearold typist were charged yesterday with possession of nearly 70 pounds of peyote, a hallucinogen derived from a cactus plant and widely used as stimulant by Mexican and Southwest American Indians.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The McKay Commission has concluded that Governor Nelson Rockefeller should have gone to Attica before permitting the armed assault that recaptured the prison last September. But the commission also observed that this question has tended to overshadow all other issues as a subject of public debate, and that is both true and too bad. Had the Governor gone to Attica, the deaths of 39 persons killed in the assault might, or might not, have been avoided; no one will ever know. As the commission stated, at least Mr. Rockefeller's presence might have acted as a restraint on the attackers; as some of the special observers committee believed at the time, personal exposure to the lethal atmosphere of tension and hatred prevailing at Attica just before the attack might have altered his view on how to proceed.

title: Powell's Grand Slam Offset by Rally
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13Scoring the tiebreaking run on a balk by Doyle Alexander, the Detroit, Tigers got four perfect relief innings from Fred SchermanI tonight to nail down a 6.5 victory and a sweep of a twogame series with the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Atlanta Banker Criticizes Liberal LongTerm Loans
description: A leading banker sharply criticized yesterday the recent trend among major moneycenter banks to make longterm business loans on substantially more liberal terms than were characteristic only a few months ago.

title: Trailer With Copper Hijacked
description: MARLBORO, Mass., Sept. 13 (AP) Three men hijacked a trailer truck with a 30,000pound load of copper tubing worth $100,000 yesterday when the driver stopped on Interstate 495 to fix a flapping canvas, the police said. The driver, James Connors of Somerville told the police that he was released unharmed in Salem, N. H. He is a parttime employe of the Darcey Transportation Company of Everett.

title: Airline to Scan Customers
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept 13 (AP) Handheld scanning devices designed to detect metal on airline passengers will be employed as an antihijacking measure at all airports serviced by Western Airlines, Ron Hammer chief of security for the Los Angelesbased airline, said yesterday.

title: HOUSE VOTES, 33643, FOR ARMS MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) A $20.9billion weapons authorization bill that would prohibil any spending this year on a Safeguard antimissile site for Washington, D. C., was approved today by the House on a 336to43 vote and sent to the Senate.

title: Stolen Stock Is Left at Bank While Manager Checks It Out
description: TORONTO, Sept. 13A cautious bank manager in suburban Toronto is , still holding onto $44,000 in United States securities after an effort here to dispose of them.

title: Pollution From Autos Expected To Dip to Safe Level in 5 Years
President's Brother Campaigns for Him In the Nutmeg State
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 13 (AP)Edward C. Nixon, 42yearold brother of President Nixon, opened a campaign visit to Connecticut today by describing his brother as someone who leads with his ears, not his mouth.

title: Football Group Denies Fraud
description: A spokesman for the National Football Foundation denied yesterday that there was anything fraudulent about the organization's financial activities.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Legislative candidates  both incumbents and challengersgathered in the faded elegance of the National Democratic Club here yesterday to listen to prominent Democrats hammer away at a common theme the necessity for unity among, all the party's factions to win, the November elections.

title: NIXON MEETS AIDES TO MAP STRATEGY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13President Nixon spent a second straight day in political planning today, meeting with some of his top strategists for dinner and discussions at his Camp David retreat.

title: Time to Come Clean
description: President Nixon's campaign machinery is increasingly compromised as more and more details emerge concerning the outrageous burglarizing of the Democratic National Committee headquarters last June. The accused leader of the band that broke into the party's offices in. Washington's Watergate Building has admitted his role in the crime while refusing to offer explanations. Two of the arrested men had connections with the President's election committee, and a recent White House assistant has been dismissed for refusing to answer questions put to him by the F.B.I.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13Henry Ford 2d, a strong supporter of the Democrats in the nineteensixties, says he is going to vote for President Nixon this year.

title: H.U.D. IS FACING CURB ON MORTGAGE ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) The House Banking Committee voted today to repeal the authority of the Department of Housing and Urban Development to set maximum real estate settlement costs for Federal Housing Administration and Veterans Administration loans:

title: NANCY SHADE SINGS LEAD IN SUSANNAH
description: Nancy Shade, one of the New York City Opera's newer leading sopranos, took over the title role of Susannah in Tuesday night's performance at the New York. State Theater. As those who have seen Miss Shade shattering glass with her amplified voice on a television commercial know, she is very pretty, and she made a seductivelooking heroine in Carlisle Floyd's bit of operatic Americana.

title: Syracuse Teachers to Get Pay Raises Averaging 6%
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 13 (AP)Publicschool teachers here will get raises averaging 6 per cent under a new twoyear contract hammered out by school officials and leaders of the Syracuse Teachers Association.

title: Annual Meeting Postponed
description: The Data Technology Corporation announced yesterday at San Jose, Calif., postponement of its annual stockholders meeting to Nov. 14 from tomorrow to allow directors time to choose a new president. A. S. Huson, president and chief executive officer since last Feb. 1, resigned late last month. M. E. Hickson is serving as interim president. A company spokesman cited differing longterm management philosophies between Mr. Huand the board.

title: Drysdale Routs Rosewall, Okker Tops Lutz in Tennis
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 13 (UPI) Cliff Drysdale of South Africa and Tom Okker of the Netherlands advanced to the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Montreal international tennis tournament today.

title: SOVIET TELLS PUBLIC OF EMIGRATION TAX
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13  The Soviet Union told its people tonight, for the first time, about its new high emigration taxes, publishing the rules in the controlled domestic press.

title: Chiefs of 2 Teacher Groups Join in Backing McGovern
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)  Leaders of the nation's two biggest teacher organizations today endorsed Senator George McGovern for President.

title: A CYANAMID PLANT CALLED POLLUTER
description: An American Cyanamid Company plant in Buchanan, N.Y., was indicted yesterday, charged with having discharged wastes harmful to marine life into local waters.

title: Times Subsidiary Plans To Buy Tennis Magazine
description: An agreement in principle was announced yesterday by The New York Times Company between its wholly owned subsidiary Golf Digest and Tennis Features, Inc., for the purchase of Tennis magazine. The agreement, subject to a formal purchase contract, was made by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president of The New York Times Company, and Asher J. Birnbaum, president and principal stockholder of Tennis Features.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (AP)  Wilt Chamberlain, who wants to renegotiate his contract, missed the Los Angeles Lakers opening practice session today.

title: LEFKOWITZ SEEKS A THAW ON ATTICA
description: The State. Attorney General,) Louis J. Lefkowitz, said yesterday that he had requested Robert E. Fischer, the special prosecutor preparing criminal cases arising from last year's Attica prison rebellion, to postpone court action against the civilian eommission that on Tuesday released its study of the uprising.

title: H.D.A. Aide Ousted for Failing to Disclose Holdings
description: A realestate manager for the Housing and Development Administration has been discharged for failing to disclose that he owned a slum building in which a welfare tenant was housed.

title: 59,000 on Welfare Face Cutoffs Over I.D. Cards
description: The Human Resources Administration announced yesterday the start of the largest single welfare caseclosing operation in the city's history, with 59,900 cases to be mailed notices that they face being dropped fom relief rolls for twice failing to get photo identification cards.

title: TV FILM FOCUSES ON ATTICA REPORT
description: A 90minute television version of the official report of the New York State Special Commission on Attica was seen last night in New York and more than 200 other cities interconnected by the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: BUZZARDS BAY, Mass., Sept. 13 (UPI)John Havlicek became an official holdout today when he failed to show up for the Boston Celtics opening preseason workout at the Massachusetts Maritime Academy. Havlicek was in camp yesterday for a physical examination, but a spokesman for the club said he left immediately afterward.

title: Fine Words, Slim Cut
description: The House Appropriations Committee asked some the right questions and made some of the right criticisms of Pentagon extravagance in debating the nation's defense needs for this fiscal year. It had the good judgment to cut $300 million from the Safeguard antiballistic missile program and eliminate all funds for a useless ABM system around Washington.

title: SCHOOL STRIKE ISSUE TO GO BEFORE COURT
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 13 (AP)With teachers in several communities out on strike, the Rhode Island Supreme Court has agreed to reconsider the question of whether public school teachers should have the right to strike.

title: Auto Volume Slumps for 10Day Period
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13Sales of new cars slumped to 103,697 in the period Sept. 110, the lowest 10day total of the year and the worst performance for the early September period since 1967.

title: Sugar Quotas Revised
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today that Haiti would not be able to provide 6,812 tons of its United States quota this year and that, the deficit has been prorated among 14 other Western Hemisphere countries.

title: $400Million Suit Filed Over Rates At Hawaii's Hotels
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 13 (AP)A law student has filed a $400million class action lawsuit against a number of travel agencies and every hotel in Hawaii.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHERE THE WASTELAND ENDS: POLITICS AND TRANSCENDENCE IN POSTINDUSTRIAL SOCIETY. By Theodore Roszak. 492 pages. Doubleday. $10.

title: Israel to Observe Independence With Festivals Here
description: Israel will send some of her leading cultural attractions to the United States over the next 12 months to mark the 25th anniversary of the Jewish State.

title: THOMAS J. WILLIAMS
description: BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N. J., Sept. 13,Thomas J. Williams; Mayor here in 196263, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit. His age was 66.

title: Hearings Due Here On Land Complaints
description: Officials from the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development will hold public hearings in the city next week to hear complaints about abuses in interstate land sales.

title: Times Starts Publication
description: The New York Times begins publication today of a daily New Jersey edition.

title: Trudeau and Rival Off and Running
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 13 The leaders of Canada's two major parties formally began their political campaigns last night at hometown rallies that reflected their differences and set the tone for the weeks between now and the national election on Oct. 30.

title: Gary Hall Wins 2 Events In Slovak Swimming Meet
description: BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 13 (AP)Gary Hall of Garden Grove, Calif., scored victories in the 100meter butterfly and the 400meter individual medley at the 10th International Grand Prix of Slovakia Swimming Meet today.

title: Neoclassical Art Surveyed in London
description: LONDONAt a time when museums are finding it increasingly difficult to present original exhibitions, London has come up with two, The Age of NeoClassicism and Caspar David Friedrich.

title: Lindsay Pays Visit to New Factory at Flatlands Park
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday described San Francisco's new regional mass transit system as a Toonerville Trolley in comparison with New York City's plans for renewing its subway system.

title: FOOTBALL GIANTS ACQUIRE ORDUNA
description: The New York Giants acquired Joe Orduna, a running back, from the San Francisco 49ers yesterday for the $100 waiver fee. The exNebraska star will replace Vince Clements, formerly of Connecticut, who was placed on waivers.

title: Sale of 2 Parcels of Land Brings the City $800,000
description: The city yesterday gaiued $800,000 from two parcels of surplus property at a public auction at the Roosevelt Hotel.

title: Construction Worker Shot
description: A 39yearold construction worker was struck in the thigh by a bullet yesterday while he was renovating a building at 710 East Ninth Street in the East Village, the police said.

title: HEARINGS URGED ON ATOM. PLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13A coalition of environmental groups asked Congress today for fullfledged, indepth hearings on the safety of the nation's nuclearpowered electric generating plants.

title: Pope Paul Asserts Sensual Pleasure May Lead to Drugs
description: ROME, Sept. 13Pope Paul VI, in an uncharacteristically blunt speech today, condemned sexual permissiveness and warned that it might lead to drug addiction.

title: POTATO TRADING IS HECTIC HERE
description: The latest Government report on the Maine potato crop resulted in hectic trading yesterday in potato futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: British G.E. Earnings Up
description: The General Electric Company, Ltd., has recorded profits in the first four months that are usefully ahead of last year, Lord Nelson, chairman, told yesterday's annual meeting at London. He added: There remains much scope for improvement and expansion in our operations. There are both advantages and disadvantageous factors at work and no quantitative evaluation can be made. The British company has no connection with the General Electric Company of this country.

title: TREND IRREGULAR IN U.S. PAYMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Two key measures of the United States balance of international payments moved in opposite directions in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: News of Dogs
description: During the week, the Rev. Thomas V. O'Connor teaches at St. Peter's Prep In Jersey City, where he heads the chemistry department. On Saturday and Sunday, he is engaged in parish work at St. Cyril and St. Methodius Roman Catholic Church at Deer Park, L. I. Then, as an avocation, he is busy with dogs, either judging the educated setthe obedience performers  or extolling and working with softCoated wheaten terriers. The wheaten is a labor of love. The breed has yet to be accepted for registration in the American Kennel Club stud book, so it must be shown in the forgotten classthe miscellaneous.

title: Thieves Kill Horneless Man at Church
description: An 86yearold man, sleeping with his clothes and shoes on because he did not have the strength to undress himself, was bound and suffocated by thieves early yesterday in the rectory of a church on West 40th Street. The man had been given sanctuary there because he did not have a place to live.

title: Amex Shares Higher at Close; Counter Prices Also Advance
description: After six sessions of declining prices the American Stock Exchange index met enough buying resistance to push it up a notch to close at 26.18, or.01 above Tuesday's close.

title: All 31 Aboard Are Killed As Nepalese Plane Crashes
description: DHULIKHEL, Nepal, Sept. 13 (UPI)All 31 aboard a Royal Nepalese DC3 were killed today when the plane crashed near this town 18 miles east of Katmandu, the capital.

title: F.D.A. PLANS ORDER ON CHILD POISONING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration said today that it would order that pesticides and similar household poisons be sold only in childproof containers.

title: Soviet Gold Survey Released
description: LONDON, Sept. 13 (Reuters) The Moscow Narddny bank, the Sovietowned bank based here, released a financial survey today estimating that the commercial gold price that should prevail if all South African gold output was sold is about $50 an ounce.

title: Plane Downed, Syria Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 13 (AP)Syria said that its forces shot down an Israeli jet that penetrated Syrian airspace today, but an Israeli military spokesman denied it.

title: Rights Suit on Illinois Voting
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UPI)The Rev. Jesse Jackson, a civil rights leader, filed suit In Federal Court today charging that provisions of the Illinois election code are unconstitutional. Similar suits will be filed within the next 10 days in seven other major cities, including Los Angeles, Denver, Miami and Memphis, Mr. Jack son said.

title: Antipoverty Clerk Seized On Charge of Larceny
description: A senior clerk in the Human Resources Administration's Community Development Agencythe city's antipoverty program operating armhas been arrested on charges of collecting $2,439 in welfare grants from last November until last month while being paid a city salary of $6,250 a year.

title: Ann Margret in Surgery For Fractures of Her Face
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (AP) AnnMargret, who was seriously injured in a fall from a stage platform, underwent facial surgery today at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center.

title: MIKHAIL NESTEROV, SOVIET TRADE AIDE
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (UPI)Mikhail V. Nesterov, a former chairman of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce and a leading figure in promoting Soviet foreign trade, died today, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported. He was 79 years old.Mr. Nesterov, who attended the Moscow Commercial Instiitute, had visited manyforeign countries to lay the foundations for expanding trade. Among them were India in 1951, Turkey. and Japan in 1957, Egypt in 1958 at the Cairo AsianAfrican economic conference, Great Britain in 1959 and the United States in 1962.

title: Lowenstein Predicts Victory Over Rooney Tuesday
description: Former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein predicted yesterday that he would win his primary election rematch with Representative John J. Rooney if enough voters went to the polls next Tuesday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 13 (UPI)Mrs. Billie Jean King trounced Betty Stove of the Netherlands today as the favorites continued to dominate the $40,000 Four Roses women's tennis tournament.

title: GROSHAWK TAKES STAKES AT DEL MAR
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 13 (AP)  Stretchrunning Groshawk wore down favored Lucky Mike for a 1length victory today in the $112,785 Del Mar Futurity, richest race in Del Mar history. Bill Shoemaker guided the chestnut son of Graustark by Songster over the 7 furlongs on turf In 1:28 35, a stakes record.

title: MAINLAND CHINA REPORTED BUYING FIRST U.S. WHEAT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz is expected to announce tomorrow the first sale of American wheat to China.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13Senator George McGovern and Senator Edward M. Kennedy brought what has unquestionably been the most successful act of the developing Democratic Presidential campaign to Philadelphia today and were rewarded by a thunderous reception at an outdoor rally in the shadow of City Hall.

title: G.O.P. Countersuit Says O'Brien Is Abusing Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13President Nixon's campaign organization, accusing the Democratic party of using the Federal courts as an instrument for creating political headlines in the Watergate breakin case, filed today a $2.5million countersuit against Lawrence F. O'Brien, former Democratic national chairman.

title: Gleason's Team Captures Jersey Golf by 3 Strokes
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 13Jim Gleason and Mrs. Seymour Holub of Shackamaxon carded a 75 for 142 today to win the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association prowoman championship by three strokes at the Woodlake Golf and Country Club.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major shareholders, directors and officers of its listed companies.

title: A Boy, 10, Accidentally Shoots Cousin, 12, on Lower East Side
description: The argument started during the lunch hour on a playground next to Public School 20 at 166 Essex Street. The victim was identified as Azem Muhametaj. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where he underwent surgery and was later reported in satisfactory condition. The 10yearold, whose name was not disclosed, was charged with juvenile delinquency.

title: Ten Food Concerns Cited for Violations After 2d Inspection
description: The Health Services Administration cited 10 more foodprocessing establishments yesterday for failing, after a second inspection, to correct violations of the city's Health Code.

title: Sex Bias Found in Baker's Dismissal for Long Hair
description: A rare finding of sex discrimination suffered by a man was announced yesterday by the city's Commission on Human Rights as it ruled in favor of a longhaired doughnut maker who refused to go to the barber when his boss demanded it.

title: U.S. UNIT SETS PRICE FOR FISCHER TO PLAY
description: SKOPJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 (Reuters)The American chess federation has asked a big price to recruit the world champion, Bobby Fischer, for the American team at the 20th Chess Olympiad opening here Mondayall proceeds of United States television rights.

title: Earl of Strathmore Dead;, Cousin of Queen Was 54
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, Sept. 13 (UPI)The Earl of Strathmore and Kinghorne, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, died at his home today. He was 54 years old.

title: Nastase Doubles Victor
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 13 (AP)The United States Open singles champion, Ilia Nastase of Rumania, and his partner, Richard Russell of Jamaica, scored a firstround doubles victory last night over Onny Parun and Jeff Simpson of New Zealand, 63, 67, 76, in the $25,000 Rainier international tennis tournament.

title: Kling Wins Senior Golf
description: COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 13 (AP)Burt Kling of Rochester carded a finalround 82 in a driving rain to beat Nick Fritz of Utica today in the New York State Golf Association's senior championship. Kling ended with a 54hole total of 237, one stroke better than Fritz, who carded an 81 today.

title: AntiDefamation League Seeks U.N. Censure of Amin
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith called upon President Nixon yesterday to direct the United States representative at the United Nations to seek a resolution censuring Uganda for an outrageously obscene statement by its President, Gen. Idi Amin.

title: Oilman Joins Global Shareholders Fight
description: A former conductor of the St. Louis Symphony who has been waging a fight to protect his investment in an offshoot of the oncepowerful I.O.S. mutualfund complex got strong new support here yesterday. John M. King, the Denver oilman and former board chairman of the King Resources Company, disclosed in a news iconference at the Plaza Hotel that he had reached an agree! ment in principle to help the conductor, Edouard van Remoortel.

title: 6,000 New Guinea Warriors Said to Attack Rival Tribe
description: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea, Sept. 13 (Reuters) About 6,000 warriors from one of the biggest tribes in the New Guinea highlands attacked rival clan near Mount Hagen in the western highlands district today, a police spokesman said.

title: Bridge :German Expert Shows Skill In Escaping From a Squeeze
description: New York clubs are often visited by prominent European players. A recent visitor to the Mayfair Club was Dirk Schroder, a German internationalist who demonstrated his skill on the diagramed deal. In a standard squeeze position the declarer has lost all the tricks he can afford to lose, but on this occasion South lost no less than three tricks after the squeeze.

title: Chairman Also Sees Increase in Hiring
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13  Henry Ford 2d said today that he looks for record sales of morel than 11 million cars by the United States auto industry in the 1973 model year and that he expects the Ford Motor Company to hire another 3,000 workers in the coming year.

title: 72 Loss Puts New York 1 Games Back
description: It was as if the Yankees were newlyweds trying to impress their new neighbors with a lavish dinner party only to have everything go wrong. There was first place a grasp away and there was a collection of celebrities watching the Yankees go for it.

title: J. W. SMALLWOOD, EXSTOCKBROKER, 79
description: J. William Smallwood, retired senior partner in Carl H. Pforzheimer & Co., stockbrokers, died Tuesday in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Redington Beach, Fla.

title: SCIENTISTS CAUTION ON ATOM MATERIALS
description: OXFORD, England, Sept. 13 (Reuters)Fears were expressed at an international conference of scientists here today over the security of growing stockpiles of nuclear materials.

title: Mexican Seized in Smuggling Of Drugs Arrested a 2d Time
description: A Mexican alien arrested last May for allegedly being part of an international heroinsmuggling ring has been arrested on a new narcoticssmuggling charge.

title: Campbell Soup Posts a 14% Gain in Earnings
Credit Markets
description: The late summer's rise in interest rates pushed yields yesterday on bonds to finance pubfi lic housingsecurities backed by the Federal Government that pay interest exempt from income taxesto the highest levels since July, 1971. In a sale announced by George Romney, Secretary of Housing

title: Mrs. King Advances
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 13 (UPI)Mrs. Billie Jean King trounced Betty Stove of the Netherlands today as the favorites continued to dominate the $40,000 Four Roses women's tennis tournament.

title: 50,000 Gallons of Jet Fuel Spilled Near Alaska Airport
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Sept. 13 (AP)An automatic valve apparently malfunctioned during fueling operations today at a Standard Oil tank farm near Anchorage International Airport, spilling 50,000 gallons of jet fuel.

title: MAORISDUE OCT. 16 FOR PALACE SHOWS
description: In line with its policy of flexible booking, Nederlander Productions has rented its local legitimate playhouse, the Palace, for a twohour Maori entertainment, Pacific Paradise, during a twoweek engagement starting Oct. 16.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PRINCETON, Sept. 13New Jersey is no hotbed of theatrical activity, and already that is an overstatement. There are community theatersamateur groupsin New Jersey, and a few theaters offering shelter to modest bus and truck tours of Broadway shows. But at present there is no genuinely innovative or imaginative indigenous theater in the state.

title: Stockton Advances, Coody Bows in Match Play Golf
description: RICKMANSWORTH, England, Sept. 12(AP)  Dave Stockon, the 1970 United States Professional Golf Association champion from Westlake, Calif., beat England's David Snell, 1 up, today to advance in the $47,500 Benson and Hedges match play golf tournament.

title: Chinese Denounce Israelis For Raiding Syria, Lebanon
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 13 (Reuters)China denounced Israeli air strikes into Syria and Lebanon today but maintained official silence on the Munich massacre of Israeli athletes by Palestinian guerrillas.

title: J. ROBERT DOYLE, 49, OF SECURITIES UNIT
description: J. Robert Doyle, vice chairman of the board of governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers, died of a heart attack Tuesday at a board meeting in Pebble Beach, Calif. He was 49 years old, the president of Doyle, O'Connor & Co. of Chicago, and a resident of Winnetka, Ill.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: BROWNFIELD, Me.Logs, tree roots and other debris had helped form a deep black hole where the Tenmile River enters the Saco, and my first cast to that spot produced a sharp strike.

title: Opposition Denies Charges
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 13, (Reuters)Four Indian oppoiltion parties today denied charges by the ruling New Congress party that they were behind violent demontrations in New Delhi in the last week.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 13 (AP)The United States Open singles champion, Ilie Nastase of Rumania, and his partner, Richard Russell of Jamaica, scored a firstround doubles victory last night over Onny Parun and Jeff Simpson of New Zealand, 63, 67, 76, in the $25,000 Rainier international tennis tournament.

title: Strip Mining Bill Is Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)The Senate Interior Committee today approved a bill to provide for Federal regulation of strip mining. The bill would apply to surface mining of all minerals, not just coal, and the surface effects of underground mining.

title: Murder Witness Says Gallo's Guard Was Armed
description: A witness at the trial of Peter Diapoulas, alleged bodyguard of Joseph Gallo, testified yesterday that he had seen a man who resembled the defendant with what looked like a gun in his hand in Umberto's Clam House in Little Italy immediately after Gallo was gunned down there last April 7.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Allows Occidental To Open Office in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (Reuters) The Los Angelesbased Occidental Petroleum Corporation has gained Soviet permission to open an office in Moscow, Tess the Soviet press agency, reported today.

title: Keeneland Yearlings Sale Passes $6Million Mark
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 13 (AP)The Keeneland fall sale of thoroughbred yearlings passed the $6million mark today as G. B. Blackwell topped the fifth session with a $30,000 bid for a bay son of Nearctic.

title: Fund for Peace Here Gets A $330,000 Danforth Grant
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 (AP)The Danforth Foundation has awarded a $330,000 grant to a group called Fund For Peace in New York City.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: WASHINGTONGeorge McGovern has called for the enactment of a $22billion income tax reform program that would treat all taxpayers alike no matter how they make their living.

title: SCHOOLS ROLLS UP BUT LESS SHARPLY
description: School and college enrollment across the country increased this fall by onehalf of 1 per cent over last year, the smallest margin in 28 years, the Department of Health Education and Welfare reported yesterday.

title: Cards Acquire Brumm
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 (AP)The St. Louis Cardinals reacquired Don Brumm, a defensive end, from the Philadelphia Eagles today.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP)Britain's world trade, bit by a threeweek dock strike, showed a deficit of about $464million in August, the Department of Trade and Industry said today.

title: 2 Island Dependencies Seeking More Home Rule After Australia Moves to Effect Administrative Changes
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 13Two tiny island dependencies of Australia have started separate agitations for home rule following moves by the. Canberra Government to effect drastic changes in their local affairs.

title: Man Is Slain by Ulster Gunmen; Another Is Killed by Policemen
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 13 (AP)Two men were shot dead in Belfast bars today.

title: Arrest of Meter Maid Fosters MurphyKaragheuzoff Dispute
description: The city's Police Commissioner and its Traffic Commissioner differed sharply yesterday over an incident Tuepday in which, a meter maid was arrested after giving a summons to a police car parked in a nostanding zone.

title: RICHARD KHMER, MARRIAGE EXPERT
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Sept. 13 (AP)Dr. Richard Hudson Klemer, a psychologist who was a writer and teacher on marriage and thefamily, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at the campus here of the University of North Carolina. He was 54 years old.

title: NIGERIAN URGES USES OF THE PAST
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 13 Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe, a chief architect of Nigeria's independence from Britian, believes that former colonial rulers in Africa unintentionally laid viable foundations for black African unity.

title: Brooklyn Expressway Due For Nighttime Resurfacing
description: Nightime repairs and resurfacing of more than a mile of the eastbound roadways of the BrooklynQueens Expressway between Fulton and Tillery Streets, Brooklyn, will start today, Highways Commissioner Vincent J. Gibney announced yesterday.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 13 (UPI)Eleven former stars, three of them deceased, have been named to the Pennsylvania Sports Hall of Fame and will be officially inducted Nov. 4.

title: Welfare Assistance in May Drops, but Rolls Show Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The number of persons receiving welfare increased by 20,000 nationally between April and May, but the amount of money spent on public assistance dropped by $22million in the same period, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today.

title: Newspapers Fill Post
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 13 (UPI)Edward B. Skinner, production manager for The Augusta Chronicle and The Augusta Herald, has been appointed business manager for the newspapers. The announcement was made today by William S. Morris 3d, president of Southeastern Newspapers, Inc., and Paul S. Simon, executive vice president.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: The widespread skepticism which originally greeted Senator McGovern's economic program was often followed by a prediction that most of the proposals would surely be softened or repudiated after Mlaink From an economic adviser, James Tobin, it now appears that McGovern intends to keep most of the new spending, abandon some of the proposed revenue sources, and obscure the resulting tax burden on the middle class.

title: Chinese at U.N. Assembly To Be Led by Chiao Again
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 13 (AP)Deputy Foreign Minister Chiao Kuanhua will head China's delegation to the United Nations General Assembly session that starts Tuesday, the Chinese delegate, Huang klua, said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rodgers, Nebraska Back, In Trouble With Law Again
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 13 (AP)A Nebraska football star, Johnny Rodgers, has been cited by Lincoln police for a traffic violation following a twocar accident.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 13 (AP)Tidewater, Va., the new champion of the International League, became the last team today to join the Kodak World Baseball Classic, the roundrobin tournament to determine the king of TripleA baseball. The Tides first opponent will be the Venezuelan AllStars, who have a 11 wonlost record in the poorly attended tournament, which has yet to attract more than 2,000 fans in an evening.

title: STATE SUES LOEWS OVER KENT CONTEST
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz challenged in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday the legality of a Kent cigarette wordmaking contest that paid off a reported $150,000 in prizes including a holiday in Britain for two.

title: Chess:
description: Chess. interest displayed by women in the past has been negligible. Many women, as well as many men, believed erroneously that chess was way above their heads  that the game required a great mentality. Nothing could be further from the truth. Anyone can learn to play and enjoy the game.

title: Founder of JobTraining Centers Hails Savings
description: The Rev. Dr. Leon H. Sullivan, the Philadelphia Baptist minister who founded a jobtraining program known as Opportunities Industrialization Centers of America, said yesterday that the training had resulted in an estimated saving of $86million that might otherwise have gone toward welfare payments.

title: UNSAFE WET TURF CANCELS 5TH RACE
description: Because of the slippery condition of the turf course, the fifth race on the program at Belmont Park yesterday was canceled. A refusal to ride on the part of many of the jockeys was responsible for the action, which was prompted by a fall suffered by Jorge Velasquez, one of the country's leading riders in the previous event on the card.

title: Business Briefs
description: Paris, Sept. 13 (Reuters)France's, foreigntrade surplus dropped in August to 33 million francs from 1.188 billion in July, the Finance Ministry said today. The franc is currently valued at 19.5 American cents.

title: Islanders Rich Rookie Gets an Icy Reception
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Sept. 13  The wealthiest rookie in the history of hockey, whose $100,000ayear income is five times what Bobby Orr earned in his debut, finally reported to the New York Islanders training camp this morning.

title: SENATORS REPORT ABRAMS DISPUTES LAVELLE ON RAIDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Gen. Creighton W. Abrams was reported to have given the Senate Armed Services Committee testimony today that conflicted with the version of Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle on the unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Mexican Rodeo at Garden
description: The National Mexican Festival and Rodeo, costarring Antonio Aguilar and Flor Silvestre, opens a sixperformance run tonight at Madison Square Garden. Ticket prices range from $3 to $6. Children under 12 are admitted at half price for all performances.

title: OKLAHOMA INDIANS SEIZE U.S. OFFICE
description: PAWNEE, Okla., Sept. 13 (AP)  About 40 Oklahoma Indians seized the Bureau of Indian Affairs office in Pawnee for more than two hours today and then left after presenting a list of demands to Federal and state officials.

title: Koscot and Turner Cited in Complaint Filed by the S.E.C.
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 13, (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a complaint in the United States District Court here today against Koscot Interplanetary, Inc., and Glenn W. Turner of Orlando, Fla., seeking to enjoin the cosmetics company from future violations of Federal securities regulations.

title: BIG GAIN INIACATED IN MOSCOW TALKS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13  A wellPlaced Soviet source reported tonight that Henry A. Kissinger and the Soviet leadership had made a breakthrough in the deadlocked negotiations over expanding SovietAmerican trade.

title: MAINLAND CHINA REPORTED BUYING FIRST U.S. WHEAT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Secretary of Agriculture Earl L Butz is expected to announce tomorrow the first sale of American wheat to China.

title: 4 HELD IN YORKERS IN NUMBERS RAID
description: A raiding party of eight New York City policemen crossed the city line into Yonkers last night, broke into an apartment and arrested four men they said were running one of the biggest policy banks in Harlem and East Harlem.

title: GOVERNOR SCORES BILL ON SHARING
description: Governor Rockefeller declared yesterday that the Federal revenuesharing bill voted by the Senate failed to provide desperately needed funds that a Housepassed version would give New York State.

title: S.U.N.Y. WILL AWARD NEW KIND OF DEGREE
description: ALBANY, Sept. 13 (AP) The first external degrees awarded by the State University of New York will be presented here in ceremonies (Sept, 27 at Chancellors Hall at the State Education Building.

title: William Boyd, Hopalong Cassidy, Dies
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 13 (AP) William Boyd, who rose to stardom as Hopalong Cassidy, died last night at a South Laguna Beach, Calif., hospital of complications from Parkinson's disease and congestive heart failure. He was 74 years old.

title: BIG GAIN REPORTED IN MOSCOW TALKS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13  A wellplaced Soviet source reported tonight that Henry A. Kissinger and the Soviet leadership had made a breakthrough in the deadlocked negotiations over expanding SovietAmerican trade.

title: Mrs. Nixon to Campaign In Jersey Visit Tomorrow
description: NEWARK, Sept, 13  New Jersey's importance to President Nixon's reelection plans was outlined today in a campaign program released by the state committee to reelect the President.

title: U. S. to Help Rumania Finance Offshore Oil Drilling in the Black Sea
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The United States has agreed to help Rumania finance an offshore oil drilling venture in the Black Sea.

title: FIRING AT CITADEL REPORTED HEAVY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 14 (AP)As the battle for the Citadel of Quangtri continued, the Saigon command reported yesterday that heavy enemy artillery fire and stiff ground resistance prevented reinforcements from reaching the fortress.

title: Texaco and Sun Oil Plan To Increase Size of Plants
description: Texaco, Inc., and the Sun Oil Company announced yesterday plans for increasing the size of I plants in Washington and Ontario, Canada, respectively.

title: Bar Association Upheld On Building Tax Status
description: State Supreme Court Justice Amos E Bowman ruled yesterday that buldings on West 44th Street owned by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York qualified for taxfree status because they are used exclusively for charitable and educational purposes.

title: FRENCH CORRUPTION CHARGED BY EXAIDE
description: PARIS, Sept. 13 (Reuters)A former French Government official threatened today to expose what he called corrupt links between the French business world and Government circles unless France immediately halted the supply of Mirage jet fighters to Libya.

title: F. Patrick Shannon,38, Dies; 1WTENTV General Manager
description: ALBANY, Sept. 13 (AP)F. Patrick Shannon, general manager and vice president of WTENTV here, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 38 years old.

title: The Talk of Fort Collins
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Sept. 13Mrs. Sandra Murray is a refugee from the sprawl and smog of California and a supporter of Alan Merson for Congress. As she pushed a grocery cart down a supermarket aisle yesterday, she explained the connection:

title: Primary Defeats Portend Big Shift Of House Power
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13With their defeat in Democratic primary elections yesterday, two elderly committee chairmen joined what Will be a mass exodus of aging and powerful members from the House of Representaitves at the end of the year.

title: WILLIAM S.HAYES
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 14William Saeger Hayes, a re tired advertising representative, who had been for many years with Conover Mast and Dana Chase Publications, died today at his summer home here. He was 56 year old and lived at 107 East 82d Street, New York.

title: Brandt Is Reported Seeking Elections in Parliament Test
description: BONN, Sept. 14Chancellor Willy Brandt plans to put his Administration to the test of parliamentary vote of confidence next Wednesday as means of getting new elections scheduled for. Nov. 19, reliable sources said today.

title: Estimate Board Reverses Itself, Votes to Halt Brooklyn MidIncome Project
description: The Board of Estimate reversed itself yesterday and voted to stop the Harbor Village subsidized cooperative project in Brooklyn, despite warnings from city officials that the action would mean the end of the MitchellLama housing program in the city.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 14 (AP)A Canadian who admitted in court that he planned to fix horse races using a laser beam was sentenced yesterday to a fourmonth jail term and placed on probation for two years.

title: LEGISLATORS GET HOSPITAL ADVICE
description: State legislators, seeking ways to control rapidly escalating hospital costs, heard a broad range of advice yesterday on how to resolve a clash of monumental egos among physicians, hospital administrators and providers of health insurance.

title: Times Names Jones National Editor
description: The appointment of David R. Jones as national editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor.

title: Iraqi Leader Arrives In Moscow for Talks
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14President Ahmed Hassan alBakr of Iraq arrived here today on an official visit that symbolizes an apparent shift of Soviet influence in the Middle East away from Egypt and toward Syria and Iraq.

title: FUNDSHARING BILL ALTERED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14A joint SenateHouse conference committee liberalized considerably today the severe limitations on spending for the Government's social services programs that are contained in the revenuesharing bill as passed by the Senate.

title: Port Authority Plans Expansion in Newark
New Jersey Sports
description: FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept. 14A robot that swung at golf ball and flashbacks to traditions of the game marked the official opening of the United States Golf Association headquarters here today.

title: 62 Bids Accepted On U.S. Oil Leases In Gulf of Mexico
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14 (AP)All but 12 of the high bids, submitted earlier this week for oil leases in the Gulf of Mexico, were accepted by the Interior Department today, putting a $586million bonus into the Federal Treasury.

title: ULSTER BOMB KILLS MAN AND INJURES 50
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 14 (UPI)  A powerful bomb wrecked a crowded Roman Catholic pub tonight, killing a passerby and injuring scores of people, many in the elderly patients wing of a nearby hospital, the army said.

title: Stricken Umpire Improves
description: The condition of Ron Luciano, American League umpire who collapsed from internal bleeding before Wednesday's YankeeRed Sox game, was listed as improving yesterday by Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 14 (UPDDave Schneck hit three home runs and drove in six runs to. lead the Tidewater Tides to a 97 victory over the Venezuelan allstars in the Kodak world baseball classic at Honolulu Stadium last night.

title: WHITLOCK HEARD AT KANSAS CITY
description: Rock musicians, like jazz musicians before them, are beginning to fall prey to the blandishments of wanting to lead their own groups. Too many, chiefs, not enough Indiansan old story, and one that is flooding the market with superfluous disks and filling the clubs and concert halls with competent, but mediocre music.

title: Back to School in France
description: PARIS, Sept. 14 (Agence FrancePresse)Some 12 million French children went back to school today. It was the first time in the history of republican France that school was held on Thursday. The Thursday holiday is being replaced by a longer weekend.

title: KOREANS REPORT DEAL RI VIETNAM
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 14Informed Korean sources report that President Park Chung Hee has agreed to a requent by President Nixon to delay the withdrawal of South Korean troops from South Vietnam.

title: Rail Council Backs Nixon
description: The Long Island Rail Road Labor Council announced yesterday that its 12 member unions had voted to endorse President Nixon for reelection. Anthony F. D'Avanzo, general chairman of the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen, said that the 12 nonoperating unions, representing 5,000 workers on the railroad, had arrived at their decisions unilaterally and had then joined in making, a group statement of support.

title: Exterminator Is in the Red
description: WARREN, Mich, (AP) Nancy Rutkowski, 19 years old, a parttime Wayne State University student, is employed as an exterminator by a pest control firm. While on the job, she wears a red jump suit, redbrimmed hat, and drives a red jeep.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Briefs
description: GENEVA, Sept. 14 (Agence FrancePresse)Experts of the Genevabased General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade predicted today a gradual reduction of the American basic payments deficit by the middle of the nineteenseventies, barring a new spell of inflation. In a report on United States foreign trade released here, they expressed the view that America would less and less have to rely on a visible trade surplus in order to achieve a surplus on current account.

title: Symphony Seats On Sale
description: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra announced the sale of subsCription tickets to 16 concerts, throughout the state during the 197273 season. The series will be performed in 10 New Jersey counties and will be the most extensive schedule the orchestra has played. The musical director, Henry Lewis, will conduct all the concerts. Subscriptions are being sold by the symphony's office in Newark.

title: Maspeth Finds Its OTB Branch Is a Winner
description: Women with baby carriages were getting curb service to play the horses yesterday in the Maspeth section of Queens. The gala opening of the newest OffTrack Betting Corporation storefront introduced horse betting, family style.

title: HARRY KIPKE DIES; MICHIGAN COACH
description: PORT HURON, Mich., Sept. 14 (AP)Harry Kipke, former University of Michigan head football coach, who was a threetime AllAmerica halfback there, died today at a hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Communists on Ballot
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (UPI)  United States District Judge John M. Davis ordered Commonwealth Secretary C. Delores Tucker today to certify Communist party candidates for the November ballot in Pennsylvania.

title: Market Place: Car Issues Hurt In Price Dispute
description: Despite what some pessimists may tell you, just about everything seems to be coming up roses in Detroit these days.

title: LEADERS GLOOMY ON WELFARE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 14Two top Congressional leaders suggested today that welfare reform is all but dead.

title: UNE DE MAI NO.1 IN FILION'S BOOK
description: YONKERS, Sept. 14This is not intended as a knock against Cadillacs, Herve Filion said today, but the difference between driving Une de Mai and any other horse is like the difference between driving RollsRoyce and a Cadillac.

title: HOGAN REBUFFED INEXTRADITION BID
description: LONDON, Sept. 14Efforts by the Manhattan District Attorney's office to extradite Theodore Ratnoff, a wiretapping specialist who worked with the Knapp Commission's investigation of corruption among New York City policemen, collapsed in a Magistrate's Court today.

title: S.E.C. Adopts New Rule On Assessment Reviews
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had evidence that some bro kers were not paying the full assessment they are supposed to turn over to the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.

title: 50,000 FINNS SEE VIREN SET RECORD
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 14 (UPI)Lasse Viren, the 23yearold Finnish policeman who won both the 5,000 and 10,000meter events in the Olympic Games at Munich, established a world record tonight in the 5,000meter run at an international track and field meet at Helsinki's Olympic Stadium.

title: Nations Offer Entry to Asians
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 (Reuters) More than a dozen countries, including Canada, New Zealand and Sweden, have responded,. favorably to a British request that they accept some of the Asians being expelled from Uganda, a Government Minister said today.

title: Oswald Declares Skilled Planning Led to Outbreak
description: The State Correction Commissioner, Russell G. Oswald, in a book to be published next month entitled AtticaMy Story, disputes a central conclusion of the New York State Special Commission on Attica that the violent outbreak at the prison was spontaneous.

title: Dance Festival Sunday
description: Wednesday's program of the Dance Festival at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, which was rained out, will be presented Sunday at 8 P.M. The performers will be Twyla Tharp and Dancers, Joffrey II Company, and Bonnie Mathis and Dennis Wayne. Admission is free.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Corinthian Y.C. Captures Cup Series
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 14Robert H, O'Connor, 40yearold sailmaker challenging for the Corinthian Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass., today won the 73d Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup series on Long Island Sound.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CASTER AND BAKER DRILL WITH JETS
description: The New York Jets hopes for a top showing against Buffalo on Sunday were strengthened yesterday when Rich Caster, the tight end, and Ralph Baker, the linebacker, engaged in their first full practice sessions in five weeks.

title: MONEY EXPANSION CONTINUES GAINS
description: Despite stubborn resistance from the Federal Reserve System monetary expansion is continuing at a rapid. rate, the central bank's weekly statement showed yesterday.

title: Jets Expected to Get Off Winging, but Not the Giants
description: The Jets are favored and the Giants are not for their opening games Sunday. They are road games and thus will be on television here.
