The Jets are the choice by 6 points over the Bills at Buffalo (Channel 4, 1 P.M.) and the Lions are 9 over the Giants at Detroit (Channel 2, 2 P.M.). Also on television is the MiamiKansas City game (Chan1 nel 4, 4 P.M.) and Washington Min

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MUJIB FIRM ON TERMS FOR MEETING BHUTTO
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 14The Prime Minister of Bangladesh, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, insisted again today that Pakistan must recognize his coiuntry before he would meet with the Pakistani President Zulfikar All Bhutto.

title: Shriver in Iowa, Pledges Switch to Peace Economy
CON ED IS OPPOSED ON RATE INCREASE
description: Ann Shoenstein is a New York City resident whose Consolidated Edison hills average more than $25 a month. Milton Musicus is Municipal Services Administrator for the city, whose Con Ed bills average almost $4million a month.

title: McGovern's Lag in Polls Continues in Latest One
A.T.&T. STUDYING PRIVATELINE RATE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday it was studying a possible replacement plan for existing rates for private line interstate telephone services, including Telpak.

title: Brazil's Export 72 Sells New Image
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 14 (AP)One of the biggest and most concerted government efforts at selling the image of a new Brazil came to a close today on the final day of the Brasil Export 72 trade fair.

title: Requiem for Contender: Mets Dismantling Due
description: The New York Mets, who somehow pieced tdgether a fivegame winning streak, will open a series with the Cubs in Chicago this afternoon with one immediate prize at stake: second place in the National League's East.

title: Auto Officials Raises Called Biggest
description: Pay increases for corporate chief executives soared in a number of industries last year according to a study by McKinsey & Co., a management consulting firm.

title: EXCHANGE IS URGED TO AID ACUPUNCTURE
description: Increasing numbers of pa, tients in the nation could receive acupuncture treatment if a largescale exchange program between Chinese and American doctors were undertaken, it was suggested yesterday.

title: Lack of Players Cancels Football at Haverford
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Sept. 14 HaverfordCollege, which has played varsity football since 1879, dropped the sport today only nine, days before it was scheduled to open the 1972 season. There were not enough players on the team to make it safe to continue, according to officials of the small Quaker college in this Philadelphia suburb.

title: U.S. PROFIT RULE HELD INEFFECTIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14A survey made confidentially for the Federal Reserve Board has shown that the Price Commission's profitmargin rule has had little effect in restraining price increases by big manufacturing and mining companies.

title: Cocaine Seized on Coast
description: MIAMI, Sept, 14 (UPI)Customs agents arrested Mrs. Aura T. de Serrate, a 28yearold Colombian woman, at Miami's InternatiOnal Airport last night after finding 3.3 pounds of cocaine in three falsebottom suitc'ses. Agents said that the cocaine had a sale value of nearly $370,000.

title: Stage: That Championship Season
description: Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival, with all the laconic grace of a Wilt Chamberlain, last night scored the first hit of the Broadway season. The Shakespearean brotherhood brought uptown to the Booth Theater its remarkable downtown hit of last spring, That Championship Season.

title: COURT VOIDS ORDER FOR HIRING BLACKS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (UPI)A Federal District Court order directing Philadelphia to hire one black policeman for every two whites was vacated today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

title: Bloomingdale's Opens in Garden City
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 14 In an unusual night opening, Bloomingdale's, the centuryold departmentstore chain based in Manhattan last night, moved into the shopping hub of this affluent community. A 250000square foot, fourlevel store is the concern's largest branch and its first complete department store in Nassau County.

title: MRS. JOHN DE SAUSSURE
description: SHIPPENSBURG, Pa., Sept. 14Mrs. Mary Waller de Saussure, a greatgranddaughter of President John Tyler, died Tuesday at the Episcopal Home here. Her age was 92. She was the widow of John de Saussure, former cashier of the Associated Press, who died in 1945.

title: Prof. Burgess, Your Humble Narrator of Joyce
description: Mott 112green walls, prison hospital decor; gloomy acousticscould haVe been a set for A Clockwork Orange. But the 24 droogs and ptitsas smecked softly in tbeir biblios as the Visitprof Warbled Ulysses.

title: Dining Out: Bravos For Venice Outpost
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday, are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The New York Jets' hopes for a top showing against Buffalo on Sunday were strengthened yesterday when Rich Caster, the tight end, and Ralph Baker, the linebacker engaged in their first full practice sessions in five weeks.

title: Rangers a Club With No Holes
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 14  The archconservative, Emile Francis, considered the question for a long time today. Did he think this was the best chance his Rangers had to go all the way?

title: Puerto Rican Named To U.S. Delegation For U.N. Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 14President Nixon has nominated Puerto Rico's Secretary of Labor to serve as one of 10 United States representatives at the 27th General Assembly of the United Nations, which convenes here Tuesday.

title: BLACK SEPARATIST GUILTY IN SLAYING
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 14A second member of the Republic of New Africa, a black separatist organization, was convicted tonight of murder in the shooting death of a white Jackson policeman last year.

title: Oyster Bay Republican Accused Of Harassing Newspaper Chain
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 14The publisher of eight weekly newspapers on Long Island charged today that the Oyster Bay Republican town leader, Angelo Roncallo, was attempting to put him out of business by withholding Republican political advertising, the town's legal advertisements and by other forms of harassment.

title: New Jewish Group Set Up to Manage Contributions Here
description: Two major philanthropic organizations, in an unusual collaboration, announced yesterday the establishment of Jewish Communal Fund to expedite charitable contributions.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The Orient, as far as department stores are concerned, seems to be a good deal more inexhaustible than it is mysterious.

title: Protest in Panama
description: Panama's newlyelected Assembly has no genuine legislative power, and its demand that the Government spurn the $1.9 million paid annually by the United States for use of the Canal Zone is thus merely an expression of popular opinion. However, this is no reason to take lightly the resolution, which charges that the Canal Zone is being occupied arbitrarily, particularly when this action is viewed in context with other recent events in Panama.

title: 250 LateFiling Groups Warned To Report on FundRaising Data
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Officials monitoring campaign spending disclosures issued formal warnings today to 250 Democratic, Republican and labor fundraising. committees that failed.to. meet the Monday filing deadline for financial report.S. Democratic committees led the list of violators.

title: Bohack Lays Quarter Loss to a Price War
description: The Bohack Corporation reported yesterday a loss in the July quarter and attributed the reversal from a profit last year to a cutthroat price war started by an industry giant, the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company.

title: Univac Plant to Close
description: ILION, N. Y., Sept. 14 (UPI) The Univac plant here, which once employed several thousand, will close in November. The SperryRand subsidiary announced today it would move the customer engineering training school to Princeton, N. J., in a consolidation effort. The school has a staff of 20, and teaches 50 people a year how to use the company's products.

title: News Analysis
description: TRENTON, Sept. 14When Gov. William T. Cahill announced yesterday that he could not support the Tocks Island project on the Delaware River unless it was substantially modified, the immediate reaction of many was that his conditions were so sweeping that they would kill the dam outright.Today, however, a number of Federal and state environmental authorities took the view that Mr. Cahill's objections were not presented to kill the project but to show that his demands were necessary if New Jersey was going to reap any benefits from the proposed dam and park.

title: Text of Joint Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Following is the text of the joint statement issued by the United States and the Soviet Union on the talks between Henry A. Kissinger, the White House adviser on. national security, and Soviet officials:

title: ZOEL PARENTEAU, STAGE COMPOSER
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 14 Zoel Parenteau, a composer of songs and stage scores and a music, director and arranger, died yesterday. He was 89 years old and lived at the Actors Fund Home here.

title: Governor Vows War on Graft to P.B.A.
description: TANNERSVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 14 Warning that corruption among the police, prosecutors and judges must be confronted openly and squarely, Governor Rockefeller today told the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of New York City that he would move to root out this corruption.

title: Bonn and Warsaw Agree to Establish Embassies
description: BONN, Sept. 14The Governments of West Germany and Poland agreed today to open embassies In each other's capitals rand to take further practical steps toward Improving relations between their two peoples.

title: Panama Grants License To Trade Bank Overseas
description: PANAMA, Sept. 14  The Panama Banking Commission has granted, a Class I license to the Trade Development Bank Overseas, Inc., an affiliate of the Republic National Bank of New York and the Trade Development Banks of Geneva and France. The new bank is a subsidiary of Trade S.A. Luxemburg.

title: Beman's Fine Iron Play Gains Shot Edge on 64
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 (AP)Deane Beman hit his irons with great accuracy today and craded a sixunderpar 64 that gave him the firstround lead in the inaugural Greater St. Louis Classic.

title: Anthony Hauck Jr., Prosecutor In Lindbergh Kidnap Case, Dies
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., Sept. 14  Anthony M. Hauck Jr., the Hunterdon county prosecutor in the Lindbergh baby kidnap trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann in 1935, died early this morning of a heart attack at Hunterdon Medical Center. His age was 71 and he lived in Lebanon.

title: George C. Scott Marries
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 14 (Reuters)  George C. Scott and Patricia Van Devere, actress, were married today in a private ceremony. It was his fourth marriage and her third. The ceremony was performed by Superior Court Judge Laurence J. Rittenband in the judge's chambers. The couple met two years ago in Spain while they were filming The Last Run.

title: Bus Service Still Limited Months After Strike's End
Metropolitan Briefs
description: The rate of insured unemployment in Connecticut dropped to 4,6 per cent during the week ended last Saturday, the State Labor Department said. The rate for the previous week was 4.8 per cent.

title: Property Tax on Elderly Is Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14A group of experts who are advising the White House on the issue concluded today that the property tax is so burdensome for many elderly home, owners that it constitutes a national scandal.

title: 71 Nets Victory for Hooper, Mrs. Goldzier in L.I. Golf
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., Sept. 14Mrs. Sanford Goldzier of Cold Spring and Robert Hooper of Wheatley Hills posted a winning gross of 71 today in the annual Women's Cross County Golf Association tournament for the Long Island Caddy Scholarship Fund. Mrs. Norman Simon and Dr. Ruegg Quibell of North Hills were low net winners with 66 over the 6,366yard Island Hills course. Par is 71.

title: Mrs. Gunter Triumphs
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 14 (UPI)Mrs. Nancy Richey Gunter put on a late surge today and defeated Wendy Overton as quarterfinal action began in the $40,000 Four Roses women's tournament.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Sept. 14 (Reuters)Japan had a $560million balanceofpayments surplus in August, against a surplus of $402million in July, the Finance Ministry said today. Receipts from exports in August totaled $2.37billion, almost the same as the $2.39billion in July, it added.

title: Resettler for Asians
description: LONDON, Sept. 14For 40 years, Sir Charles Cunningham has worked away m quiet Government corners as an obscure civil servant whose name and face were known to few.

title: COUNCILMEN FIGHT CABGARAGE PLAN
description: Eight City Councilmen, challenging the right of the Taxi and Limousine Commission to license limousines for hire, moved in Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday to block the city from purchasing, renovating and equipping, for $1.9million, a Long Island City cabinspection garage.

title: President Backs Coast Unions In Fight to Limit Reruns on TV
description: President Nixon yesterday placed his Administration firmly behind the efforts of Hollywood unions to force the three television networks to cut back on the number of reruns programed in prime evening time.

title: Bay State Editors Honored
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) Thomas L. Winship, editor of The Boston Globe, and Thomas J. Murphy, managing editor of The Waltham (Mass.) Newstribune, were named recipients today of the 1972 Yankee Quill Awards. The awards are sponsored by the New England chapter of Sigma Delta Chi, the national journalistic society. They were established in 1960 to honor persons who have made significant contributions to New England journalism.

title: DALEY OPPONENTS. ORDERED TO TRIAL
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 14  The 59 insurgent Democrats who replaced Mayor Richard J. Daley and other organization delegates at the Democratic Nationat Convention in July were ordered today to stand trial for contempt in disobeying a Cook County Circuit Court order barring them from being seated at the convention.

title: Dune to Be on Screen
description: Dune, a science fiction novel by Frank Herbert set 8,000 years into the future, has been acquired for filming next year by APJAC Productions. APJAC, which is shooting a musical film version of Tom Sawyer in association with United Artists and Reader's Digest, also announced it will film a musical adaptation of Huckleberry Finn, with a script and songs by Richard M. and Robert B. Sherman, the team that did the adaptation and music for Tom Sawyer.

title: 3,000 Mark Lowered
description: AARHUS, Denmark, Sept. 14 (AP)Emiel Puttemans of Belgium shattered Kip Keino's sevenyearold world record for the 3,000meter run in an international track and field meet here today with a clocking of 7 minutes 37.6 seconds.

title: Worms Clog Runway; Big Broom Clears It
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 (UPI) The longest runway at Cleveland's Hopkins International Airport was closed for 30 minutes today while a motorized broom swept the concrete clear of hundreds of thousands of earthworms.

title: Oosterhuis a Big Winner
description: RICKMANSWORTH, England, Sept. 14 (UPI)Peter Oosterhuis of England dominated the second day of the $50,000 Benson and Hedges matchplay golf tournament today with a sevenunderpar 30 for nine holes as he ousted another Briton, Peter Ward, 7 and 6, in the third round.

title: Kidnapping Suspect Sought
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that Steyen Ivan Ross, 31 years old, was being sought for the 23dayold kidnapping of a Mexican girl who was ransomed for $105,000. Two and one half yearold Diana Canedo Carrion was found yesterday in a Biloxi, Miss., motel after her father, Raphael Canedo Benitez, a Mexican lawyer, had given her abductor a brown paper bag containing $105,000 in $100 bills, the F.B.I. said.

title: City Seeks to Close Hotel As a Place of Prostitution
description: The city moved in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday to close the Mack Hotel, 301 West 47th Street, on the ground that it constituted public nuisance in violation of laws barring prostitution and lewdness.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP)Bronze Heir, the 11yearold wonder horse, remained unbeaten for the year today by winning a halfmile special by 2 lengths at Sportsmans Park, for his fifth victory. He returned $9 straight.

title: Dr. Howard J. Curtis Is Dead; Biologist and Expert on Aging
description: UPTON, L.I., Sept. 14Dr. Howard J. Curtis, senior biologist and former chairman of the, biology department at Brookhaven National Laboratory who was known for his research in neurophyslology, radia,tion biology and the causes of aging, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Shoreham. He was 65 years old.

title: First Lady Will Open National Parks Fete
Vatican Abolishes the Tonsure, 1,500 YearOld Clerical Rite
description: ROME, Sept. 14Pope Paul VI today ordered the abolition of the tonsure, the circular, shaving of the crown of the head that has marked preliminary steps on the way to priesthood.

title: Residents of East Flatbush Struggle to Preserve Ethnic Identity
description: Dennis Waschitz was leaning over the grill in his luncheonette, watching the bacon sizzle.

title: Union Head Reelected
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 14 (AP)Thomas Murphy of Potomac, Md., was reelected today to head the 160,000member International Union of Bricklayers, Masons and Plasterers.

title: Mel Torme Takes 47 at Easy Tempo
description: Mel Torme's 47th birthday was made memorable for him Wednesday evening when he stepped out onto the floor of the Maisonette of the St. Begis Sheraton Hotel and started singing. The amplifying system went its own way, making his voice sound as fuzzy as a rabbit's coat. As it turned out, the event Was not as disastrous as it threatened to hethe gremlins were exorcised after the first three numbers. But it provided an unexpected emphasis for the overall excellence of the singer's program. and the solid professionalism bf his delivery.

title: La Mancha Film Dec.11
description: The film version of the hit Musical Man of La Mancha, starring Peter O'Toole and Sophia Loren, will have its world premiere at the Rivoli Theater here Dec. 11. Proceeds of the opening performance will go to the Will Rogers Memorial Fund

title: Business Briefs
description: BONN, Sept. 14 (Reuters)West Germany's Economics Minister, Helmut Schmidt,. today formally rejected raising the official price of gold as a solution to international monetary problems. Raising the gold price, as proposed by France, would lead to a sudden increase in international liquidity that would be distributed among countries in proportion to the gold content of their reserves, Mr. Schmidt said in answer to a parliamentary question.

title: $250,000 Landfill Scandal Is Charged to 11 in Hudson
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 14A special Hudton County grand jury today indicted 11 persons, including the former county Democratic chairman, on charges of converting more than 100 acres of county parkland into a landfill operation that netted them better than $250,000 between 1967 and 1970.

title: U.S. Delays Uganda Loan Over Amin Note on Jews
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The United States is holding up a projected $3million loan to Uganda as a sign of displeasure over a recent statement by President Idi Amin supporting Hitler's slaughter of 6,000,000 Jews in World War II.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:; Why do those people who warn of the danger of a blood bath by the Vietnamese Communists at the end of the war approve the colossal blood bath created by our past and present bombing of civilians?

title: U.S. Scrutinizes Charges of Job Abuses by the City
description: The United States Labor DeI partment has begun an investigation into allegations that the Lindsay administration has abused a federally financed job program to provide employment for administration favorites, a department spokesman said yesterday.

title: Teledyne Will Buy a Million of Its Shares at $20 Each
description: Teledyne, Inc., the big Los Angelesbased manufacturer of electronic equipment and engines, announced yesterday that it would repurchase one million of its common shares at $20 a share Teledyne closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 16, down  on a volume of 15,900 shares. Earlier in the year, Teledyne sold as high as 28. The offer would be effective immediately, the announcement said, and would expire Oct. 16.

title: Handicapped Week Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)President Nixon signed today an annual proclamation designating the week of Oct. 1 as National Employ the Handicapped Week. Noting that 1972 marked the 25th anniversary of an effort to encourage greater job opportunities for the handicapped, Mr. Nixon wrote, Although much has been done, there is more that must be done.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Sept. 5

title: Responsibility Is Denied
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept, 14 (UPI)The executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization said in a statement made public here today that the Palestinian guerrilla leadership was not responsible for the activities of the Black September group that was involved in the Munich violence last week.

title: Advertising:
description: The last major new product success in the candy bar field, as far as Jim Hanlon is concerned, was the Caravelle in 1966. And it, he said, was the hottest thing to come along since the debut of Almond Joy in 1948.

title: Roundup: Cards Gibson Wins No. 16
description: The St. Louis Cardinals earned a split in the battle of Montreal last night at Jarry Park, taking the fourth game of the fourgame series, 6.2. The Cardinal victory settled, momentarily, fourth place in the National League's Eastern Division standing.

title: Polish Jews in Denmark Find New Life Difficult
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 10More than three years after Poland's Jewish community began an exodus under charges of Zionist sympathies, a thin stream of refugees continues to arrive here, ostensibly on the way to Israel.

title: Jersey Senators Back Cahill Stand On Tocks Project
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ISSUES 1972
description: In 1972 veterans have become a political issue. None too soon. Official statistics indicate the veteran unemployment is twice the national average, and three times as high among racial minorities. According to a poll conducted for the Veterans Administration, 5 per cent overlooked by the official count have given up even looking for work. Estimates drawn from the same poll put the number of veterans with a drug problem at 700,000.. Only onequarter of those eligible have resumed schooling under the present G.I. Bill, although 50 per cent did so after the last two wars. Throughout the country mental health professionals are disputing the official claim of a record low psychiatric casualty rate in Vietnam by citing innumerable cases of veterans suffering from a postVietnam syndrome.

title: U.S. Views Japan Trade
description: TOKYO, Sept. 14 (Reuters)United States Ambassador Robert Ingersoll has called for Japan's continued cooperation in reducing the American trade imbalance with Japan to less than $2billion by 1974.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  When Government decisions directly affect the economic welfare of an industry or an interest group, policymaking officials have a delicate problem in political judgment. As realists, they recognize that a favorable decision may pay off in the next election in votes or campaign contributions.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Federal Reserve Board offered today to make the Reserve discount window available to nonmember banks that might be pinched by the new rules on immediate collection of checks that will go into effect next week.

title: Korean Delegates Set the Dates For 2 More Red Cross Parleys
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 14The North and South Korean Red Cross delegates agreed today to hold their next meetings in Pyongyang on Oct. 24 and in Seoul on Nov.22 to start substantial discussions on how to reunite divided Korean famdies.

title: Stiff Antigraffiti Measure Passes Council Committee
description: A broad, tough bill to combat the graffiti that are defacing public buildings, subways and buses was voted out of the City Council's General Welfare Committee yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Review
description: The new television season, cont'd: For some time, the Columbia Broadcasting System has been on the verge of putting together a blockbuster lineup of situation comedies for its Saturday evening schedule. The network just may have succeeded this season.

title: Horse, 11, Stays Unbeaten
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP)Bronze Heir, the 11yearold wonder horse, remained unbeaten for the year today by winning a halfmile special by 2 lengths at Sportsmans Park, for his fifth victory. He returned $9 straight.

title: COAST BANK EXPECTS RISE IN LOAN LOSSES
description: The Security Pacific National Bank, Los Angeles, the nation's eighth largest commercial bank, expects to have a rising level of loan losses in the years ahead, Frederick G. Larkin Jr., chairman, warned the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

title: RISE IN BOGUS BILLS REPORTED IN REGION
description: The counterfeiting of Federal Reserve notes has shown a big increase this year in the New York area, officials of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and of the United States Secret Service said yesterday.

title: Red Smith
description: This was how it used to be when excitement was New York's daily bread. There was a time when the town wouldn't have seemed the same without the Yankees and Red Sox at the top of the league, going for the jugular; Ralph Houk would remember Sept. 26, 1949. In Yankee Stadium that day, Johnny Pesky slid home on a squeeze play, Willie Grieve called him safe, and Boston took over first place with one week to go. Houk, the Yankees catcher, was sure he had tagged Pesky out and he told

title: BLAND WEEK IS SEEN AT THE BITTER END
description: Let's be generous and just say that it will be a bland week at Paul Colby's Bitter End. The two featured acts, Randy Burns and the Sky Dog Band and the Sam Neely group, seem to have some enthusiastic fans, and neither group can be faulted on musical values alone. But for this listener, they simply sounded dull.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14No President in over 100 years has ever won a national election by as large a margin as Richard Nixon now holds over George McGovern in the polls, yet Gary Hart, McGovern's 33 year old national campaign director, still thinks his man can win.

title: Advertising:
description: Bowing to pressure from within, the National Advertising Review Council  the sponsoring organization of the National Advertising Review Boardhas voted to allow the board to disclose publicly its decisions under certain conditions.

title: Books of The Times
description: These innovative volumes are not for every taste. Try them and you may very well not like them. But, they seem to me, to have a function other than that of providing entertainment. They are exciting and challenging, annoying and irritatinga combination that makes us defend or at least define our literary likes. Reading them is much like listening to the music of Harry Partch or Stockhausen or Richard Trythall. We may not like the sounds they make, but we come back to the conventional tonalities with sharper and more attentive ears.

title: Repairmen Face Curbs By the City
description: The city has taken steps to make it harder for unscrupulous repairmen to cheat their customers.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Pennsylvania Power & Light Company yesterday announced it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering of 2 million shares of common stock. The First Boston Corporation and Drexel Firestone will manage the underwriting group. Proceeds will be used to retire part of the utility's outstanding shortterm debt. The company's stock was up  at 24 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Waldheim Aide Responds
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 14Referring to President Amin's message to the Secretary General, a United Nations spokesman said that while Mr. Waldheim did not comment on messages from heads of state, he condemned all forms of racial discrimination and genocide.

title: Doctors Unlicensed Clinic Ordered to Halt Abortions
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 14The State Supreme Court here has ruled that the Dobbs Ferry Medical Pavilion, Inc., is an unlicensed abortion clinic and has ordered it to stop performing abortions.

title: Kosygin Meets Industrialist
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14In the wake of the talks between Mr. Kissinger, and Soviet leaders, Premier Alexei N. Kosygin met for 90 minutes today with Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, to discuss a string of industrial projects, including $70million hotel and trade center in Moscow.

title: Conferees Vote '85 Goal To End Water Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14A HouseSenate conference committee approved today legislation that would set the goal of eliminating all pollution of water in this country by 1985:

title: DEBT CEILING RISE ASKED BY SHULTZ
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Nixon Administration fired the first shot today in what promises to be an intense political battle in the next six weeks over the ceiling on the national debt and Government spending in general.

title: Changes in Executive Pay Listed
description: Following are the changes in chief executive compensation of 587 large companies in 31 industries reported the McKinsey & Co. 1972 top executive compensation survey:

title: PHILIP W. BRISK
description: Philip W. Brisk, a retired New York printing executive, died yesterday at his home in Rossmoor Village, Jamesburg, N. J., at the age of 73.

title: A Drug Addict, 24, Survives Removal Of 2 Heart Valves
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 14 (AP)4 24yearold drug addict who had two of his four heart valves removed three months ago appears today to enjoy normal health, the doctor who performed the operation said today.

title: ELECTRONICS GEAR SEIZED, MARCOS SAYS
description: MANILA, Sept. 14 (Agence FrancePresse)President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today the seizure by the internal s6curity forces of electronic equipment from a Chinese trading concern here.

title: GOVERNOR EULOGIZES MRS. SAARINEN HERE
description: Memorial services for Aline Saarinen, the art critic who died July 13, was held yesterday afternoon in a theater that her late husband, the architect Fero Saarinen, had helped design.

title: Dr. George B. Morris Dead; Dentist Taught at N.Y.U.
description: Dr. George B. Morris, a retired Manhattan dentist and former associate professor at the New York University College of Dentistry, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital, Newburgh, N.Y. He was 80 years old and had been living at a retirement home in Plattekill, N.Y.

title: MRS. DAVID J. MARTIN
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I,, Sept. 14Mrs. Helen Mayer Martin, widow of David J. Martin, a hotel executive who was acting chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority at his death in 1957, died early today at her home, 32 Crestwood Road. She was 76 years old.

title: Lyle B. Womack, a Member Of Byrd Expedition to Pole
description: PRINEVILLE, Ore., Sept. 14 (UPI)A memorial service is planned Saturday for Lyle B. Womack, a member of Adm. Richard E. Byrd's first expedition to the South Pole, who died Sunday as a result of a kick from a pet burro.

title: A Brooklyn Priest Robbed of $2,000 In Church Rectory
description: A Roman Catholic priest who has been active in lowincome housing causes and as a leader of community control of the public schools was robbed at gunpoint yesterday of $2,000 by two women and a man in the rectory of his church in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

title: Washington: ?? the Record; ,Sept. 14, 1972; THE PRESIDENT
description: Activities. The President saw Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton and Mrs. Nixon to plan the 100th anuiversary celebration of national parks. Later in the morning the President saw Mayor Frank Rizzo of Philadelphia and youngsters of the Police Athletic League dedicated to law and order. He also saw Governor Rockefeller of New York.

title: Executive Changes
description: Virgil E. Boyd, vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, retired yesterday from its board. Mr. Boyd, who was president of Chrysler from 1967 to 1970, has recently been in charge of its office of public responsibility. He was succeeded as a director by Robbin W. Fleming, president of the University of Michigan.

title: Fishing Report for Nearby Waters
description: AREA A  Bluefish are responding in large numbers at Manasquan Ridge to boats chumming with moss bunkers, and using butterfish, smelt and bunkerbacks on the end of their lines. The sizes are running from 5 to 15 pounds. Numerous school tuna and albacore are being taken by the same anglers, using the same methods. Along the shore, from Bay Head to Seaside Park, considerable fluke and weakfish are interested in squid. Both also are being captured in Barnegat Bay.

title: 14 ExAddicts Celebrate Success of Their Gas Station
description: The celebration of the opening of a Bronx service station featured pastelallos (spicy chicken) and music by an electric piano and conga drums. The event represented the takeover of a failing business by former narcotic addicts who have turned it into a thriving enterprise.

title: House Panel Backs Slash In Lead Allowed in Paint
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)  The House Banking Committee approved legislation today to reduce the amount of lead allowed in paint to half of 1 per cent.

title: Sisters Win Top Laurels In Long Island Golf Event
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 14  Mrs. Justine Cushing of Meadow Brook won low gross laurels today in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 18hole event. She posted a 36, 3975, three over par, over the 5,480yard Links Club course. Her sister, Mrs. Gordon McGrath of Piping Rock, captured the low net prize with a score of 69. Mrs. William Eakins of Creek was the putting winner with 28.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $839,000,000, up 12 per cent from the yearearlier $750,000,000. Total retail store sales were about $7,890,000,000, up 6 per cent from $7,423,000,000 a year earlier.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Colonialism 10:30 A.M.

title: STATE BANK BOARD APPROVES MERGERS
description: Harry W. Albright Jr., New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday that the State Banking Board, acting on his recommendation, had approved a series of four proposed bank holding company acquisitions.

title: Toronto Exchange Appoints
description: TORONTO, Sept. 14 (Canadian Press)The Toronto Stock Exchange announced today that Harold Gibson, 57 years old, will succeed John L. Lyndon as director of market operations.

title: Sharing or Paring?
description: Now you see it; now you don't.

title: EMERSON, RIESSEN ADVANCE IN TENNIS
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 14 (AP)  Roy Emerson of Australia and fifthseeded Marty Riessen of Chicago advanced to the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Montreal international tennis tournament today with secondround singles victories.

title: Landfill Case Is Newest In 2 Years of Indictments
Sports News in Brief
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 14 (UPI)Team Canada held its first two workouts today during its oneweek stay Sweden, which also will include games on Saturday and Sunday against the Swedish National Team.

title: Assemblyman Is Held In Gypsy Cab Protest
description: Assemblyman Armando Montano was among eight persons arrested last night in a melee involving more than 500 persons that grew out of a demonstration by gypsy cab drivers at Southern Boulevard and the Bruckner Expressway in the Bronx.

title: Researchers Hopeful of Grand Synthesis in High Energy Physics
description: A number of practitioners in the most fundamental field of atomic research1 that dealing with the basic forces and constituents of the universebelieve a new level of understanding in that realm may be within reach.

title: MRS. WILLIAM KARLIN
description: Mrs. Ida Beck Karlin, widow of. William Karlin, a labor lawyer and former Assemblyman who was a leader in the Socialist and later the American Labor and Liberal parties, died Wednesday at her home, 444 Central Park West. She was 82 years old.

title: U.S. Fears Raids Will Empty Danang Refugee Camps
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 11"We are confused and afraid, a disabled veteran said as he told of an attack on two refugee camps here over the weekend in which his son was among 28 persons killed. More than 90 other people were wounded.

title: Butz, Aide Deny Knowing Of Any Grain Export Tip
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz and his Assistant Secretary for International Affairs told a House subcommittee today that they had no knowledge of any telephone calls by a department official telling exporters about an impending change in export subsidies on sales of wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: The Risk to Gateway
description: Apparently no one in Congress is out to scuttle the proposal to grace New York Harbor with the country's first urban national park. But the project is in serious danger of being lost in the scramble to recess in time for members to do their necessary, electioneering.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mirage Ties U. S. Yacht
description: TORONTO, Sept. 14 (APIMirage, the Canadian defender, won the third race of the Canada's Cup yacht series today by 5 minutes 22 seconds from the United States challenger, Dynamite of Detroit.

title: Nastase Wins Opener
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 14 (AP) Ilie Nastase, the favorite from Rumania, posted 64, 64 victories over Glenn Gerstnar of Honolulu last night in the first round at the $25,000 Rainier International tennis tournament here.

title: SILVER FUTURES TUMBLE IN PRICE
description: Late profit taking sent silver futures tumbling yesterday in commodity trading here.

title: MRS. MIKHAIL SUSLOV
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14 Mrs. Yelizaveta A. Suslov, wife of one of the principal figures in the Soviet leadership, died yesterday after a long illness. She is believed to have been about 70 years old.

title: For These PreSchoolers There's No Time to Be Homesick
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y.In the workshed at the Ramapo Anchorage Camp here, five small boys are making toy boats to sail later on Lake Sepasco. One of the five counselors helping them starts a song. Rickticktickety ding dong, they all sing, keeping time with Rammer&

title: 71 Wins for Mrs. Hooper Mrs. Goldzier in L.I. Golf
Notes on People
description: Retired Lieut. Col. Anthony Herbert, who left the Army when he was relieved of his Vietnam command after attempting to report alleged war crimes, told a conference in Washington how he felt the Army would react to criticism by military men of certain members of Congress. The conference, held in a Senate hearing room, was to examine the role of the military in American society and was sponsored by former Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee.

title: Crowds Turn Out, but for Whom?
A.M.A. Recommends Ban On CrossBody Blocking
description: CHICAGO, Sept, 14 (UPI)An American Medical Association Committee said today that the crossbody block should be eliminated on downfield blocking to lessen knee injuries in football.

title: POLLUTION CURBS RULED TOO HARSH
description: The city's effort to impose airpollution curbs on landlords of rentcontrolled apartments were set back yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: Inventories Rose in July As Business Sales Gained
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Total business inventories rose $730million in July, more than in most months of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Pollution Foe Cuts Red Tape and Gets to Lake Bottom
description: If city officials are wondering where many of their wire mesh trash cans have gone, they might do well to check the bottom of Crocheron Pond in the Bayside section of Queens.

title: Irate City Councilmen Vote Out Bill on Registering of Lobbyists
description: A bill to regulate paid municipal lobbyists, which has languished in a City Council committee for two years, was voted out yesterday by 15 angry Councilmen..

title: Books of The Times
description: Never mind the wittiness of Jack Dillon's dialogue (She: Do you know how to boll an egg? He: I guess so. It's like giving it a bath, isn't it? She: God.). Forget the skill with which Mr. Dillon paces his. story of two weeks in the decline and fall of an advertising copywriter. What's most impressive about The Advertising Man what makes it the I sort of book that is the best thing about whatever day you happen to have read it; one of those books you can hardly wait to get back to even if the weather, is golden or your favorite movie is on TVis that Jack Dillon gets you concerned about his man with the gray flannel Pentel pen. You can be as big a snob about the advertising business as Hershey chocolate once was, and you'll still watch Jim Bower's slide into the martini pitcher with something like pity and fear. This is no mean accomplishment. There are few clichs as solidly entrenched or as deeply contemptible as the one of the advertising copywriter complaining that his creativity is being thwarted by the demands of the agency. It's normally enough to make you drip crocodile tears in his swimming pool or strangle yourself with his love beads. Indeed when Mr. Dillon's hero starts defending creative independencewhen you begin to sense that the battle lines of The I Advertising Man are being drawn over whether the copy department of Gibbs & Wilson will be left alone by the new boss to go on creating those marvy concepts that the agency has come to stand foryou feel downright antsy.

title: The Grain Game
description: America's amber waves of grain seem to be on their way to feeding the (Communist) world, a far better use for them than rotting away in heavily subsidized silos. The sale of almost 20 million bushels of wheat to China, plus the much larger $750million grain transaction with the Soviet Union announced in July, represent important breakthroughs in EastWest trade.

title: U.S. SEES SIGNING OF TRADE ACCORD WITH SOVIET IN 72
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The White House said today that it expected the signing of a comprehensive trade agreement with the Soviet Union before the end of the year and possibly within weeks.

title: Earnings of B.P. Plunge; Dividend Is Cut 2c to 12c
description: The British Petroleum Corporation, Ltd., buffeted by weak prices, reported yesterday that, despite a rise in sales, its earnings declined sharply in both the second quarter and first half. As a consequence, it added, it was trimming its dividend by 2 cents a share to 12 cents.

title: Personalities: Shorter and Petersons Feted
description: Many members of the United States Olympic team are being honored this week in communities all over the nation. Frank Shorter, who won the marathon, received a hero's welcome on Wednesday in Middletown, N. Y., where he spent the first 20 years of his life. He jogged through several sections of the city, then attended a luncheon where he received the keys to the city. In an address to 400 people, Shorter said that winning the 26mile 385yard race was not as easy as it appeared. Referring to Pheidippides, the Greek soldier who ran the distance in 400 B. C. to proclaim the Athenians victory over the Persians and then dropped dead, Shorter observed, I wish he had dropped after the 22d mile. A crowd estimated at 4,000 turned out in Cornstock, Wis., on John and Ben Peterson Day. A victory parade honored John, who won the silver medal in the 180.5pound wrestling division, and Ben, who took the gold medal in the 198 pound division.

title: CORPORATE BONDS SHOW FIRM TONE
description: The corporate and governmerit bond markets were quiet yesterday, with prices firm in the former and easier in the latter.

title: Daughter Tricia Stumps for the President in State
McGovern Charges President is Hiding; Again Asks Debate
description: Senator George McGovern accused President Nixon yesterday of being afraid of the people.

title: Middle America Finds The Campaign Boring
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 13If there is such a thing as a typical American voter in middle American community, he/she strolls or drives through this Middle Western manufacturing city. And if there is big Presidential campaign this year, he/she Isn't sure whether it is all over or has yet to to begin. He/she expects President Nixon to be reelected, but does not necessarily want him to he.

title: GARLAND OF ROSES WINS AT BELMONT
description: The condition of the turf at Belmont Park yesterday was satisfactory enough to attract a field of 10 for the main event, the Summer Festival Purse. Most satisfied in the crowd of 16,053 were those customers who made the Hobeau Farm's Garland of Roses the favorite in the 1 116mile grass event for fillies and mares,

title: YANKEES RESUME A FORGOTTEN JOB
description: While the people who are responsible for winning the Eastern Division title took the day off, some lessglamorous Yankee employes continued working yesterday on autumn ticket plans that once were part of an annual routine.

title: SENATE APPROVES PACT WITH SOVIET ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 After more, than a month of debate, the Senate approved today the United StatesSoviet agreement to freeze a major part of their offensive nuclear arsenals for five years. However, it stipulated that there should be equality in the number of weapons in any future treaty governing strategic intercontinental arms.

title: Mrs. Julia Hotton Is Appointed To New Brooklyn Museum Post
description: The appointment of Mrs. Julia Hotton, a specialist in educational communication, as the next assistant director for interpretation at the Brooklyn Museum, was announced yesterday by the museum's director, Duncan Cameron, who said he believed Mrs. Hotton was the first black woman to assume such a high position in any major museum in the country.

title: Stocks Seesaw on Amex; Average off 0.01 Point
description: The American Stock Exchange continued yesterday its seesawing action of the last two sessions. The Amex index dropped yesterday 0.01 to close at 26,17, after rising 0.01 Wednesday.

title: Schmitz Says U.S. Hides. Data on Plot to Slay Wallace
Kennedy Called a Crutch for McGovern
description: Herbert G. Klein, President Nixon's director of communications, said here yesterday that Senator.George McGovern had resorted to tactics of desperation, by turning to Senator Edward. M. Kennedy as a crutch for what he called Mr. McGovern's faltering Presidential campaign.

title: GEORGE H. DAVIS, 61 , INSURANCE OFFICER
description: George H. Davis, who retired in 1970 as actuary and senior officer of the Life Insurance Association of, America, an industry group, died Wednesday night at a meeting of the New York Actuaries Club at the Harvard Club, 27 West 44th Street. He was 61 years old and lived in Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS HOUSING MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The House Banking and Currency Committee tentatively approved today a $10.5billion housing bill that would make new initiatives in aid to urban mass transit and in community development grants to cities.

title: Railroad Traffic Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The Association of American Railroads reported freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 13.8 million tonmiles, 8.2 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Loadings last weekwhich included the Labor Day holidaytotaled 460,145 cars4.6 per cent above the corresponding holiday week a year ago. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week as 6 per cent above last year.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: WASHINGTONConcerned Vietnam Veterans for Nixon is an organization that exists to give a voice to the prevailing but often unnoticed views of the vast majority of Vietnam veterans. We oppose Senator. McGovern's election because, while he accurately pinpoints some of this nation's problems, his solutions are totally counterproductive. With regard to the many problems of returning Vietnam veterans, Senator McGovern has often expressed concern for us but fails to recognize that his false characterization of the typical veteran as both drug addict and a psychopath is perhaps our biggest hurdle in the transition to meaningful and productive civilian lives.

title: MRS. AMOS J. PEASLEE
description: CLARKSBORO, N.J., Sept. 14 Mrs. Dorothy Quimby Peaslee, widow of Amos J. Peaslee, a former United States Ambassador to Australia, died yesterday in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. She was 81 years old and lived here.

title: Blitz of Dance Companies on the Way
description: A blitz of at least 23 Amerlean moderndance companies and 16 foreign dance troupes  from Toronto to Timbuktuwill swoop down through the 1972.73 dance season here.

title: AUTOTHEFT RAIDS BRING 20 ARRESTS
description: In a series of raids that beI gan before dawn yesterday, the Police Department's auto squad broke up a group of auto theft rings reported to have stolen 1,500 airs in Nevir Jersey and New England in the last three years for sale here, a police spokesman said.

title: Clorox and Kiwi End Merger Talks Australia Opposed
description: The Kiwi brand of polishes will apparently remain Australianowned. Spokesmen for the Clorox Company in Oakland, Calif., and for the Kiwi International Company in Melbourne said yesterday that merger negotiations had been terminated by mutual agreement. Clorox said the decision stemmed partly

title: Recount for McMillan
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 14 (AP)The South Carolina Democratic Executive Committee, acting in response to a request from Representative John L. McMillan, today ordered a recount of votes in the runoff primary in the state's. Sixth District. The 74yearold Representative, who has served in Congress for 34 years, lost by about 1,000 votes to John Jenrette, a 36yearold state legislator.

title: Ward Foods Chief And Five on Board Quit in Policy Split
description: Six of the 12 directors of Ward Foods, Inc., including the chief executive officer, have resigned following what a company spokesman described as a policy difference between two factions.

title: LETHARGY SHOWN IN STOCK MARKET
description: The stock market continued its lethargic pattern yesterday showing no decisive trend in continued slow trading.

title: NADER, AUTO MAKER CLASH OVER PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The General Motors Corporation and Ralph Nader disagreed at a Price Commission hearing today on whether the auto maker was justified in reeking price increase.

title: BediordStuyvesant Vote Pitting Two Black Forces
description: The special primary election scheduled in Brooklyn's 18th Senatorial District for next Tuesday pits two factions of that borough's black political structure against one another and could result in a realignment of the black leadership there.

title: Saigon Reports Fierce Fighting In Quangtri City, but No Gains
description: eight buildings and cut lines in attacks on the Kep railroad yard 40 miles northeast of Hanoi, military spokesmen said.

title: Art: Bierstades Large and Small Work
description: The Whitney. Museum's opening attraction for the season, an Albert Bierstadt exhibition that originated last January at the Anion Carter Museum in Fort Worth, has a curious air of rattling around in the galleries. This is no fault of the Whitney's installation, since ordinarily it is a treat to find paintings as widely spaced as Bierstadt's biggest ones are in this case. The trouble is that the big Bierstadts turn out to be not very good paintings after all. Each one in its splendid isolation has room to fall to pieces. Jammed together frame to frame they might have. held their own, supporting one another, but it takes better pictures than these to withstand the careful inspection they invite.

title: Pnompenh Unit Falls Back
description: PNONIPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 14 (UPI)Government forces retreated from their positions around Pnom Bat early today under heavy enemy pressure and artillery fire, the command reported.

title: New Painting Kit Developed
description: General Mills, Inc., announced yesterday a new paintbythenumbers kit that is based on a computer process developed for the company's Craft Master division by the Itek Corporation.

title: NIXON SEES RIZZO, AND ROCKEFELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 President, Nixon met today at the White House with political supporters from two politically vital states. His visitors were Governor Rockefeller of New York, a Republican, and Mayor Frank L. Rizzo of Philadelphia, a Democrat.

title: Peking's Purchase of American Wheat Is Confirmed by Louis Dreyfus Corp.
description: The Louis Dreyfus Corporation, the New York branch of a big Parisbased commodities trading organization, confirmed yesterday that Peking had bought about 500,000 metric tons of United States wheat, the first such purchase by the mainland Chinese in more than 20 years.

title: Bridge:An Ordinary Looking Deal Proves Difficult to Bid
description: Any listing of suit combinations that are commonly misplayed should include the NorthSouth diamond holding in the diagramed deal. It was played in the recent Olympiad Fund game, a continentwide effort that helps to finance North American teams in international competition and netted some $21,000. The winners with a magnificent score of almost 75 per cent in a field of 3,000 tables, were Dr. Armin Docter of New York and Robert True of Newburgh, N.Y.

title: Net Loss Deepens For Collins Radio
Maine Tops Boston U., 257
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP)  Maine spotted Boston Univer sity a touchdown in the first 52 seconds and then came back to upset the Terriers, 257, to night. The firsthalf running of Steve White and Mike Porter and the secondhalf passing of Ron Cote and Rich Prior sparked the victory.

title: Sports of The Times
description: As if it were a huge computer blinking information, the big scoreboard rises above the Yankee Stadium bleach ers. Normally, it's inanimate. But now, in the American League East, it's alive. During a pennant race, scoreboard watching is half the fun. According to one of baseball's most dignified myths, the players involved in a pennant race never peek at the outoftown scores. They're too busy to look back. Except that it doesn't work that way with most of them any more than it did with Lot's wife.

title: MAN AT L.I. COLLEGE SETS HIMSELF ON FIRE
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept. 15 (UPI)A young man doused himself with a flammable liquid today and set himself afire in the middle of the soccer field at the State University here, a university spokesman said.

title: A. B. Hancock Jr. Dead at 62; Claiborne Farm Horse Breeder
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 15 (AP) A. B. (Bull) Hancock Jr. of Paris, Ky., owner of Claiborne Farm, the world's largest breed er of thoroughbred race horses, died yesterday at Vanderbilt University hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: Pitt Eyes KingoftheHill Role
description: Carl DePasqua, Pittsburgh's football coach, was sad enough last Sunday morn ing when he sat down to breakfast. His team had dropped its opener to Florida State, 197, the day before after missing many chances.

title: Butz's Agency Confirms Day's Notice to Exporters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Department of Agriculture acknowledged today that on Aug. 24 one of its officials called the six principal compa nies selling wheat to the Soviet Union and gave them 24hour advance notice of a change in the Nixon Administration's pol icy on export subsidies.

title: MONTANO PAROLED ON RIOT CHARGES
description: Assemblyman Armando Mon tano was arraigned in Bronx Criminal Court yesterday on charges that he had started a riot Thursday night during a demonstration by gypsy cab drivers in the Bronx.

title: RAIDS APPROVED, LAVELLE INSISTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle told the Senate Armed Services Committee during testimony this week that one month after staging his first unauthorized bombing raids on North Viet nam, he was criticized by high erranking officersnot for a violation of rules, but because his planes missed their targets.

title: RYUN RUNS MILE IN 3:57.4, LOSES
description: LONDON, Sept. 15 (AP)The world mile recordholder, Jim Ryun, who fell during a prelim inary heat of the 1,500meter race at the recent Munich Olympics and failed to qualify for the final, failed again today, finishing second to New Zea land's Tony Polhill in an invi tation mile at London's Crystal Palace.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: The measure of George McGovern's failure so far as a candidate for Presi dent is a poll just taken by Louis Harris. It shows what should be an enormous reservoir of sympathy for the McGovern position on Vietnam: By a majority of 76 per cent to 21, Americans want to bring home all U.S. military, naval and air forces from Vietnam. But the poll finds:

title: Lord Fisher, ExArchbishop of Canterbury, Dead
description: LONDON, Sept. 15Lord Fisher of Lambeth, a former Archbishop of Canterbury and a leading advocate of Christian unity, died last night at Sher borne, Dorset. He was 85 years old.

title: BISHOP M'CARTY OF RAPID CITY 83
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., Sept. 15 The Most Rev. William T. McCarty, retired Roman Catho lic Bishop of Rapid City, former military delegate for chaplains under Cardinal Spellman and former superior of the Redemp torist Order in the Eastern sec tor of the country, died of cancer yesterday at his home here. He was 83 years old.

title: Pierson, Mrs. Burati Take Bergen County Golf Honors
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 15Howard Pierson of River Vale and Mrs. Phyllis Burati of Haworth took honors in the third Bergen County golf tour nament today.

title: Public Cleanliness Theme as Mayor Visits Queens
description: Mayor Lindsay sternly told the public to shape up their cleanliness habits in public places yesterday, as he spent most of the day on sundappled streets and parks in Queens.

title: Executive Changes
description: Martin B. Clark has been appointed president of Gold Circle, the discount store division of Federated Department Stores, Inc. He was formerly president of Burdine's the Miamibased division of Federated, the nation's largest department store group. Hal W. Field has been promoted from president to chair man of Gold Circle and will continue as its chief executive officer.

title: Victor Romano, vice pres ident of the festival.
description: The 46th annual festival of San Gennaro, a conglomerate of happy, jostling throngs, aromatic foods, lively music in the narrow streets of Lit tle Italy, seems the same as ever since it opened Thurs day night. But behind the scenes a virtual revolution has taken place.

title: 8 Colleges Told to Shy at Tenure
description: NEWARK, Sept. 15 The State Board of Higher Educa tion ordered the eight state colleges today to hold down the number of faculty members who are tenured.

title: Personalities: Keino Nearing Finish Line
description: Kenya's Kipchoge Keino, who won a gold medal in the 3,000meter steeplechase and a silver medal in the 1,500 meter run during the Olympic Games at Munich, announced yesterday in Nairobi that he would retire from interna tional competition in January. He said his final appearance would be in the AllAfrica Games at Lagos, Nigeria. The 32yearold police inspector said: I will run in the Africa Games and then call it a day. I have had a wonderful career in international athletics and I am afraid it must come to an end. There are a number of youngsters in Kenya who need the chance and I cannot continue forever. Keino is reported planning to resign as police inspector and take a job in the sports equip ment business.

title: Israeli Jumbo Jet Disabled
description: ROME, Sept. 15Israel's first Boeing 747 jumbo jet, on a scheduled flight from Tel Aviv to New York via Rome and Paris, was forced into an emergency landing here today after losing oil from two en gines. None of the 218 passen gers and crewmen aboard the El Al Airlines flight were in ured. Rome airport officials said that they found no evi dence of sabotage.

title: EARLY START SEEN ON FUND SHARING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  The SenateHouse conference committee completed work to day on the revenuesharing bill.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 15 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King of PalmAire, Fla., the No. 1 seed ed player, was extended for the first time in a threeset victory over Mona Schallau, 62, 67, 61, in one of two quarterfinal matches today in the $40,000 Four Roses women's tennis classic.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 George Gordon Liddy, the second former Nixon Admin istration aide named today in the Watergate indict ments, acquired a reputation for legal brilliance along with stubborn independence dur ing his rapid ascent from lo cal government official to White House staff member. After graduating from Ford ham University Law School, Mr. Liddy served for five years as an agent with the Federal Bureau of Investiga tion before joining the Dutch ess County, N. Y. district attorney's office in 1965.

title: Butz's Agency Confirms Day's Notice to Exporters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Department of Agriculture acknowledged today that on Aug. 24 one of its officials called the six principal compa nies selling wheat to the Soviet Union and gave them 24hour advance notice of a change in the Nixon Administration's pol icy on export subsidies.

title: Enemy Soldiers Seized
description: QUANTRI, Sept. 15 (Reu ters)Clouds of mud were flung into the air this morn ing as enemy artillery shells landed in the eastern part of the Citadel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The failure of the seventeen principal airtransport countries to arrive at an antihijacking agreement is on a par with the tawdry record of the U.S. Senate in refusing a gunlicensing act there is nothing like a selfish mi nority. However, in the case of anti hijacking there is still a method of procedure which can circumvent the duplicities and specious arguments of those countries whose politicians will not face up to this desperate issue.

title: Antiques: 18thCentury Ironstone Dinner Set Is Sold to Collector for $1,500
description: English ironstone means $10 or $20 plates and bowls to most people but this week one avid collector was de lighted to pay $1,500 for an 181520 49piece dinner serv ice at a ParkeBernet auc tion.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  The White House and the State Department denied today pub lished reports that South Korea had agreed to delay the with drawal of its troops from South Vietnam in exchange for a commitment that American forces would stay in Korea until the middle of 1973.

title: Inmates Back McKay on Private Data
description: Lawyers for five inmates of the Attica Correctional Facility moved in State Supreme Court last night to back the McKay Commission's attempt to quash a grand jury subpoena of panel records of 3,000 confidential in terviews.

title: Venezuela in 3d Place in Oil Sales
description: CARACAS, VenezuelaTwo years ago Venezuela was the world's leading petroleum ex porter. Today, she is in third place, behind Saudi Arabia and Iran. The causes of her decline are supply, demand and price, and there is no immediate pros pect for improvement.

title: U. S. Restates Stand on Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  State Department officials re iterated today that the decision to indefinitely delay the loan to Uganda was linked to Presi dent Amin's remarks on the Jews.

title: Signs at S.I. Ferry Announce New OneWay Toll Collection
description: Signs were posted in the Staten Island Ferry terminals yesterday announcing that effective Oct. 10 a double fare10 centswould be collected in Manhattan, but that passengers embarking at Staten Island would ride free.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  Environmental activists are demonstrating again that, al though their numbers and war chests may be small, they can exert significant influence in the nation's politics.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 15 (AP)Long Beach State, Southwestern Louisiana, Oral Roberts and Brigham Young, among the nation's top basketball teams last season, are included on the first intercollegiate schedule to be played at the Nassau Coliseum this season. The inaugural Nassau Classic, involving Long Beach State, Oral Roberts, Jack sonville and Hofstra, will be played Dec. 1920.

title: Chrysler Announces Recall Of 39,333 Dodge Trucks
description: DETROIT, Sept. 15 (UPI)  The Chrysler Corporation an nounced today the recall of 39,333 lightduty Dodge trucks, sold in the 1972 model year, because of a possible brake defect.

title: MRS. WALTER SANBORN
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 15 Mrs. Yvonne Ducos Sanborn, widow of Walter Sanborn, the founder of the Juniorgraphic Company of Little Neck, Queens, died yesterday in Stam ford Hospital after a short ill ness. She was 76 years old and had lived for many years in Great Neck, L. I.

title: 2 SHIPS SEPARATED OFF CAROLINA COAST
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Sept. 15 (AP)Two cargo ships locked together since they collided late yesterday off the North Caro lina coast were separated to night, the Coast Guard said.

title: 2 NIXON EXAIDES AMONG 7 INDICTED IN RAID IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  Two former White House aides and the five men seized by the police inside the Watergate com plex on June 17 were indicted today on charges of conspiring to break into Democratic na tional headquarters at the com plex.

title: Aid for Dock Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Senate passed a bill yes terday that would more than double compensation for dock workers injured on the job. The measure was sent to the House.

title: Whitehead at Meeting
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 15 (UPI) President Nixon's adviser on the television industry con ferred today with union leaders about the White House cam paign to reduce the number of TV reruns.

title: Felicia Romano Bride of Peter J. Jones
description: WESTPORT, N. Y., Sept.15 Miss Felicia Frances Ro mano, daughter of Maj. Jo seph F. Romano, U. S A. F., retired, and Mrs Romano of Rutland, Vt., was married here this evening to Peter Jeffrey Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. John. Haydn Jones. The Rev. David S. Langdon per formed the Episcopal cere mony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: MARINACCIO TROUPE IN DANCE DEBUT HERE
description: Three groups  Gene Mari naccio's American Concert Bal let from Los Angeles; Manola Asensio and Tanju Tuzer of the Harkness Ballet, and the Luis Rivera Spanish Dance Company shared the free Dance Festi val program Thursday night at the Delacorte Theater in Cen tral Park.

title: TULANE UPSETS BOSTON COLLEGE
description: NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 15 AP)Steve Foley came off the bench for his varsity debut and directed a 67yard scoring thrust in the second period, sparking Tulane to a 10.0 upset victory over errorplagued Bos ton College tonight in a 1972 football opener.

title: Hijackers Hold Plane in Sweden, Forcing the Release of Croatians
description: MALMO, Sweden, Saturday, Sept. 16Three gunmen advo cating Croatian independence from Yugoslavia hijacked an airliner yesterday and won from Sweden a promise to release seven Croatian prisoners.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: MADRID, Sept. 13  Spain and the Soviet Union, estranged for more than 30 years today signed a commercial agreement, their first major treaty since the Spanish Civil War brought Generalissimo Francisco Franco to power in 1939.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: QUANTRI, Sept. 15 (Reu ters)Clouds of mud were flung into the air this morn ing as enemy artillery shells landed in the eastern part of the Citadel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Representative Edward Koch's sug gestion that we open our doors to 5,000 Asian Ugandan expellees does not go far enough. A North American committee should be formed with rep resentation from Mexico, Canada and the United States to find openings with business firms that could prob ably use the expertise developed by these unfortunate people over the last halfcentury. Uganda's loss could be our gain.

title: Should Gold Reserves Go to Free Market?
description: ROME, Sept. 15On both sides of the Atlantic support is growing for a new idea that would deal with the nettlesome problem of gold as an asset frozen in the vaults of central banks that might outflank the French in their demands for an increase in the official price of $38 an ounce.

title: Vietnamese Cleric Says Allied Planes Bombed His Church
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15 (AP)  A Protestant minister said today that Ameri can or South Vietnamese planes wrecked a church last month in the fighting for the Queson Valley south of Danang, but a spokesman for the United States Seventh Air Force said later that no American planes had been involved in the in cident.

title: 14 Saigon Papers Close, Muffling Opposition Press
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15South Vietnam's op position press was virtually silenced today with the perma nent closing of 14 daily news papers and 15 other periodicals that failed to pay large bonds demanded by the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: 19Story Building Emptied By Smoky Midtown Fire
description: A smoky fire in the grease duct of a groundfloor coffee shop sent smoke throughout the 19story Scandinavian House building at 505 Fifth Avenue, near 42d Street, yesterday.

title: U.S. Bars Renaming Schweitzer as Head Of Monetary Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  The United States has, in ef fect, vetoed the reappointment of PierrePaul Schweitzer as managing director of the In ternational Monetary Fund.

title: 14 ARE ENTERED IN U.N. HANDICAP
description: ATLANTIC, CITY, Sept. 16 The United Nations Handicap, which has produced 13 grass, champions in its previous 19 runnings, has attracted a field of 14 entrants for the 1972 re newal tomorrow. An invitation test of 1316 miles, the United Nations will have a gross value of $100,000, with the winner earning $65,000.

title: Quarter Horse Track Licensed for Yaphank
description: The New York State Quarter Horse Racing Commission has approved sites for two new race tracks, the first to be licensed in the last quarter cen tury, according to the office of Governor Rockefeller.

title: Scott to Aid Nixon Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)The Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott of Pennsyl vania, announced today that he would campaign in 12 states for President Nixon's reelec tion and for other G.O.P. can didates.

title: Scratch the Graffiti
description: The handwriting is on the wall  and the ceiling, floor, seat, door, window. It is dayglo bright and multicolored, sometimes obscene, always offensive. The marvel of modern technology that took paint from a can and gas from a cannister and combined them to make spraypainting a possibility for every Saturday doit yourselfer also armed youthful vandals with a new tool of defacement. They use it on sidewalks, buildings, monu ments, subways, buses.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In its otherwise excellent reporting of the current meeting in Washington of a legal subcommittee of the Inter national Civil Aviation Organization (I.C.A.O.), The Times has more than once treated as factual an argument against imposing sanctions to deter hijacking of aircraft: that the United Nations Security Council is the only international organ authorized to impose sanctions.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)  Vice President Agnew said today that he was increas ingly suspicious of a Federal valueadded tax, which is under consideration by the Nixon Ad ministration as a means of re ducing local property tax bur dens.

title: Moscow and Madrid Sign a Trade Pact
description: MADRID, Sept. 13  Spain and the Soviet Union, estranged for more than 30 years, today signed a commercial agreement, their first major treaty since the Spanish Civil War brought Generalissimo Francisco Franco to power in 1939.

title: QUANGTRI CITADEL REPORTED TO FALL TO SAIGON TROOPS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, Sept. 16South Viet namese marines recaptured the Citadel in the heart of Quangtri City yesterday, American and South Vietnamese officers re ported. It was the most sig nificant victory for the Saigon Government since the North Vietnamese launched their of fensive March 30.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 15The way was cleared today for the dis bursement of $7million in state aid to 13 independent colleges and universities in New Jersey.

title: Soviet Jewry: A Just and Justified Measure
description: MOSCOW  A decree has been adopted in the Soviet Union on reim bursement by Soviet citizens taking up permanent residence abroad, of state expenses on their education. This decree has caused a preconceived attitude in some countrles. What then is the meaning of this measure?

title: MRS. HAGGE PACES GOLF BY 2 SHOTS
description: WACO, Tex., Sept. 15 (AP) Mrs. Marlene Hagge called a birdie at the 18th hole today on a fourfoot putt and finished with a fiveunderpar 67 for the firstround lead in the Quality First Classic She gained a twostroke edge at the Lake Waco country Club.

title: F.P.C. DENIES NEED FOR ENERGY CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  The Federal Power Commission declared today that conserva tion of resources did not re quire limitations on growth of energy use in the United States.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The Inner Circle, a 50 yearold organization of past and present political writers and City Hall newsmen, has voted overwhelmingly to ad mit qualified women report ers into its ranks.

title: 2 NIXON EXAIDES AMONG 7 INDICTED IN RAID IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  Two former White House aides and the five men seized by the police inside the Watergate com plex on June 17 were indicted today on charges of conspiring to break into Democratic na tional headquarters at the com plex.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15 (AP)  A Protestant minister said today that Ameri can or South Vietnamese planes wrecked a church last month in the fighting for the Queson Valley south of Danang, but a spokesman for the United States Seventh Air Force said later that no American planes had been involved in the in cident.

title: U.S. Embassy Is Silent
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 15 (UPI)The American Em bassy here declined comment on the Uganda Government statement.

title: Art: Executive Order 9066 of 1942
description: Thirty years ago a wartime President who was also a lib eral heroFranklin D. Roose veltsigned an order con demning 110,000 Japanese Americans, nativeborn citi zens and aliens alike, to Mili tary internment in what have often been described as the first American concentration camps. Now an extraordinary exhibition of documentary photographs recalling this grim episode in public hys teria and the abrogation of Constitutional rights has come to the Whitney Mu seum of American Art.

title: A Speech, Free, For McGovern
description: CORNWALL BRIDGE, Conn.I have no connection with the McGovern campaign organization. I met the can didate the year before he became one, when he came to my house to make a plea for a Democratic candidate for the Senate (who was subsequently defeated) but I had a chance to talk with him then and was impressed by his character and common sense. He was a guest in my house a second time when he came to speak for himself not long after he had announced his candi dacy and when he was in desperate need of funds to go into the New Hampshire primary.

title: LINDSAY WILL AID M'GOYERN'S DRIVE
description: Mayor Lindsay has been named cochairman of a na tional Mayor's committee to help the Presidential campaign of Senator George McGovern, aides of the Mayor said yesterday.

title: 2 Antiwar Activists Are on Way To Hanoi for P.O.W. Escort
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)Mrs. Cora Weiss and David Dellinger, the American anti war activists, arrived here by plane today on their way to Hanoi to escort home three American prisoners of war who are to be released by North Vietnamese authorities.

title: Clash Among Inmates Reported At Green Haven State Prison
description: STORMVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 15  A state of emergency was imposed at the Green Haven Correctional Facility here to night, after a clash among in mates that was reportedly quelled by tear gas.

title: Equity Financing
description: UMC Industries, Inc., said yesterday it had purchased 377,323 common shares at $21.25 per share from White, Weld & Co. and Salomon Broth ers, managing underwriters in the company's recent secon dary offering of 2,394,953 com mon shares. The company said it will use the shares for its stock option and stock pur chase plans. The company's stock was up 1 at 22 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Canonero In Drill
description: King Ranch's Canonero II, weighted at 110 pounds for next Wednesday's $25,000 add ed Stymie Handicap at 1 miles, worked out on Belmont's main track yesterday. He was clocked for seven furlongs in 1:26 2/5. He went the first quarter in 25 1/5, the half in 492/5 and six furlongs in 1:13 4/5.

title: Annabelle W. Giellerup Married
description: Miss Annabelle Wynne Giellerup was married yester day to Denis P. Coleman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cole man of New York and South ampton, L.I. Christopher C. McGrath, Bronx County Sur rogate, performed the cere mony at the home here of Mrs. Eleanor Wynne Giellerup of New York and Lake Placid, N.Y., mother of the bride. A reception followed at the Colony Club.

title: MedicaidFraud Scheme Laid to Psychotherapist
description: A Queens psychotherapist was indicted in both Manhat tan and the Bronx yesterday in what was described as an elaborate scheme involving forged Medicaid bills that bilked the city's Department of Social Services of at least $36,000.

title: Business Briefs
