description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (Reuters)The average yield of subsidized 7 per cent Federal Housing Administration home mortgages auctioned by the Government National Mortgage Association was 7.61 per cent, compared with 7.59 per cent at the first such auction on July 28, Ginny May said today.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Hamilton College announced yesterday that the school was unsuccessful in attempting to schedule a football game to re place Haverford, which dropped football on Thursday. The school's football team will play seven games instead of eight. Oberlin will be the homecoming opponent.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Msgr. James P. Mahoney, 42yearold vicar general of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, was ordained as titular bishop of Ipagro, a small town near Seville, Spain, and auxiliary bishop of New York in a two andahalfhour rite at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

title: FRANK HARDART, 87, OF AUTOMATS CHAIN
description: Frank Hardart, a former executive vice president of the Horn and Hardart Company and a son of the cofounder of the automat restaurant chain, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 15 Sargent Shriver is a Roman Catholic candidate or an un familiar sort, a man who slips quietly out to mass many mornings of the campaign and works a little harder because of the thought that a good day's effort can be a form of prayer.

title: Heavy Auto Output Set
description: DETROIT, Sept. 15 (AP) Domestic auto production of 47,000 units is set this week with overtime scheduled at two Ford, two Chrysler and seven General Motors plants, accord ing to Automotive News.

title: SECRETARIAT 25 AT BELMONT TODAY
description: It was elementary. Meadow Stable's Secretariat was named the oddson favorite for this afternoon's 83d running of the $75,000 added Futurity at Bel mont Park. The son of Bold Ruler is to be faced by six rivals in the 6furlong event for 2yearolds.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 15  The unregistered voter in New Jer sey will have a difficult time maintaining his independent status this fall in the face of the most ambitious round of registration drives in the state's election history.

title: RED SOX SURGES TOP INDIANS, 43; FIRST PLACE HELD
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Reggie Smith doubled home the deciding run tonight with two out in the ninth inning as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Cleveland Indians, 43, and maintained their hold on first place in the torrid American League East race. The Red Sox had trailed by three runs.

title: Hijacking Is the Latest Croatian Action
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 15The hijacking of a Scandi navian Airlines plane in Swe den today was the latest in a growing series of violent ac tions by Croatian migrs in a long campaign to win inde pendence for Croatia, one of six republics in Yugoslavia.

title: M'GOVERN OFFERS WAGEPRICE PLAN
description: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 15 Senator George McGovern pro posed today establishing a system of wage and price, guidelines to replace the Nixon Administration's inflation con trols, which, he charged, are unworkable and radically dis honest.

title: Senate Backs Outlay for Denver Winter Olympics
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. Senator Gordon P. Allott of Colorado tilted today with Sen ator Fred R. Harris of Okla homa over whether the Govern ment should put up $3million for a refrigerated luge course at the 1976 Winter Olympics in Denver.

title: Theodore Bennahum Dies at 66; Financier Was Active in Israel
description: MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 15  Theodore Bennahum, an inter national financier, died today of cancer in Mount Sinai Hos pital here. He was 66 years old and lived in New York and Paris.

title: Beryozka Tour to Stress Folk Dances
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15The serene domes of the old Petrovsky Monastery gave no hint of the vitality within. Yet behind the redbrick walls lithe young bodies glided and kicked their way through traditional Russian folk dances.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Magnetic bubbles, in millions to the square inch, promise reliable and inexpensive stor age for the vast quantity of information that computers hold. Four staff members at the International Busi ness Machines Corporation's Thomas J. Watson Research Center in York town Heights, N. Y., were granted Patent 3,691,540 this week for sensors to detect the bubbles. The presence or absence of a bub ble at a given location may represent the zero or one of computer language and pro vide a bit of informaition.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 15 (AP) The hometown hero, Tom Gor man, and the topseeded player, Ilie Nastase of Rumania, each won secondround matches last night as they headed for a showdown in the $25,000 Rain ier international tournament.

title: RAIDS APPROVED, LAVELLE INSISTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle told the Senate Armed Services Committee during testimony this week that one month after staging his first unauthorized bombing raids on North Viet nam, he was criticized by high erranking officersnot for a violation of rules, but because his planes missed their targets.

title: U.S. Joins Jersey in Citing 14 Towns as Sea Polluters
description: TRENTON, Sept. 15  New Jersey environmental protection authorities joined with their Federal counterparts today in legal action against 14 Mon mouth and Cape May County communities that they said were polluting the state's coastal waterways.

title: Uganda Denies Statement By Amin Delayed U.S. Aid
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 15 A Uganda Government state ment tonight said that the United States Ambassador, Thomas P. Melady, had met President Idi Amin and had de nied Washington reports that a $3million American loan had been frozen because of General Amin's recent statement prais ing Hitler's liquidation of Eu ropean Jews.

title: Books of The Times
description: MEMOIRS: 19501963. By George F. Kennon, 368 pages. AtlanticLittle, Brown. $12.50.

title: ISRAELIS ATTACK BASES IN LEBANON
description: TEL AVIV, Saturday, Sept. 16 An armored Israeli task force early today crossed into Leba non and began searchand destroy operations against Arab guerrilla bases in the Ainata area, a military, spokesman an nounced here.

title: Business Briefs
description: The First National Batik of Boston announced yester day that it would enter the consumerlending business in Britain by establishing a chain of money shops that would offer personal loans, homeimprovement loans and unsecured revolving personal credit accounts. According to the announcement, the offices will also offer savings and checking accounts.

title: HOOT MON TROT TO FLOWER CHILD
15Nation Hijacking Parley Ends Without a Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  A 15nation conference ended today without reaching an agreement on terms for a new treaty calling for joint inter national action, against coun tries that provide havens to aircraft hijackers and sabo teurs.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Faced with the threat of imprisonment under an 18thcentury law, 15 New Jersey residents said yesterday that they planned to post future bail and pay possible fines with 18thcentury barter: chickens, pigs, cows and horses.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 15 Peter Poor scored with only 10 seconds elapsed in sudden death overtime to give Myopia (Mass.) a 54 victory over the Greenwich Pitchforks today in a semifinal round game of the Governor's Cup fivegoal polo championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club. Myopia will meet Monroe (Conn.), the defending cham pion, in the final round at Ox Ridge on Sunday. Poor scored three of Myopia goals and Kurt Miller, playing at No. 1, got the other two. Adie von Gontard scored twice in the second chukker and also scored the tying goal at the end of the fourth period for the Pitchforks.

title: OUTPUT CUTS SET BY CITIES SERVICE
description: The Cities Service Company made public yesterday a plan to get out of its agricultural chemicals operations, to sell about 175 marginal producing leases and to streamline other operations, particularly gasoline stations. The result is expected to improve earnnigs by more than $15million a year.

title: Science and Magic Join to Spur Nigerians' Output
description: OSHOGBO, Nigeria, Sept. 4 A flock of weaver birds flew over a tangled growth of jun gle, then swooped gracefully toward 30 acres of upland rice, bright green in the noonday sun and ripening for harvest.

title: Mrs. Lombardo Wed on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 Mrs. Helen Healey Lom bardo of San Francisco was married here today to Roger Fawcett, president of Fawcett Publications, Inc., of New York and Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Fred Stripp per formed the nondenomina tional ceremony at the Fair mont Hotel.

title: CITY AIDE DEFENDS PROGRAM'S HIRING
description: Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton said yesterday that city officials had found only a handful of people who had apparently falsified their home addresses to qualify for jobs under the Federal Emergency Employment Act of 1971.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) New Jersey Citizens for Bal anced Transportation, the group seeking to win passage of the transportation bond issue on the November ballot, announced today it had organized a bureau to provide speakers on the sub ject.

title: Taiwan Planning Measures If Japan Recognizes Peking
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 15 (UPI)A Government spokes man said today that Nationalist China had worked out a num ber of measures which it might take against Japan in the event Premier Kakuei Tanaka's Gov ernment establishes diplomatic relations with Peking.

title: Prostitution Scandal Involving the Police and a Gaullist Deputy Shocks Lyons
description: LYONS, France, Sept. 5 This staid city is in the throes of a scandal involving police profits from prostitution under the allegedly benevo lent eye of a Gaullist deputy.

title: Canada's Election
description: Relations with the United States are certain to figure prominently in the election campaign now getting under way in Canada; but probably in a political climate much calmer than that prevailing north of the border just a year ago. At that time, Canadian resentment at Presi dent Nixon's import surcharge, the heavyhanded pres sures of Treasury Secretary Connally, and the under ground nuclear test at Amchitka Island was at its peak.

title: Roundup: Carlton Struggles for His 24th
description: Even Steve Carlton is be ginning to find it difficult to win games for the futile Phila delphia Phillies. The southpaw pitching star struggled to a 53 triumph over Montreal with the aid of Willie Mon tanez and Greg Luzinski.

title: 3 CUB HOME RUNS SUBDUE METS, 93
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15A trem or rocked the Chicago area early this morning, but the Mets did not feel the full effects until this afternoon when three Cub homers, including a grand slam by Jim Hickman, jolted them into a 93 defeat. The loss dropped New York 2 games behind Chicago in the battle for second place in the National League's Eastern Division.

title: A CREDIT SQUEEZE DOUBTED BY BURNS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today he thought the Reserve could avoid a credit crunch in the months ahead but said the best in surance against such a squeeze would be enactment of a $250billion ceiling on Gov ernment spending.

title: DOUGLAS ORDERS 5 IN TEXAS FREED
description: FORT WORTH, Sept. 15 United States Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas or dered today that bail be grant ed five IrishAmericans jailed here for refusing to testify in an international gunsmuggling investigation.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: In close elections, Joe Nemeth and Larry Grantham were chosen as offensive and defensive captains of the New York Jets yesterday. Nameth, who had been captain in 1969 and 1970, won by a narrow margin over Winston Hill, who served as cocaptain last year with John Schmitt. Namath, injured in the first exhibition game last season, was not in the running then. Grantham won over the incumbent, his fellow linebacker, Al Atkinson, who had been defensive captain the last three seasons. Grantham, now in his 13th year with the team, has been on it ever since it set up shop as the Titans in 1959.

title: African Racist
description: When Gen. Idi Amin, dictatorPresident of Uganda, abruptly ordered the expulsion of over 50,000 Asians from that African country, his apologists angrily rejected charges that the callous action was motivated by racism. General Amin's recent statement in praise of Hitler for murdering six million Jews should suffice as indisputable proof of something even worse than virulent racism.

title: 220 YACHTS FINISH RACE TO SALT POND
Wagner Tops Hofstra, 107
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 15 Despite a 93yard rushing performance by Jim Pugh, the Hofstra Flying Dutchmen dropped their home football opener tonight to Wagner Col lege, 107.

title: White House Mystery
description: Since so much of the case for reelecting President Nixon is being built on the supposed efficiency of his Administration, it is instructive to examine the dents put in that businesslike image by the strange shenani gans surrounding James R. Hoffa's effort to become a diplomatic courier to Hanoi.

title: Beman Cards 67 for 131, Raising Lead to 2 Shots
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 (AP) Deane Beman fashioned a threeunderpar 67 today and stretched his lead over Lee Tre vino to two strokes in the second round of the $150,000 Greater St. Louis Golf Classic.

title: Boy, 8, and Dog Survive Night on Capsized Boat
description: PATCHOGUE, Sept. 15 An 8yearold boy and his Husky dog sat on a capsized sailboat in Great South Bay here for six hours last night and today before being rescued.

title: TREASURY STUDY OF ACCOUNTS SET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Treasury announced today a new restudy of its long standing practice of keeping tax and loan accounts in commercial banks.

title: Personal Income Showed Solid Increase in August
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) National personal income showed a solid increase of $6.9billion last month, the Commerce Department said to day.

title: KISSINGER MEETS WITH HANOI AIDES
description: PARIS, Sept, 15Henry A. Kissinger met with North Viet nam's senior negotiators here today in their 17th secret ses sion aimed at ending the war.

title: M'GOVERN OFFERS WAGEPRICE PLAN
description: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 15 Senator George McGovern pro posed today establishing a system of wage and price guidelines to replace the Nixon Administration's inflation con trols, which, he charged, are unworkable and radically dis honest.

title: Business Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Sept. 15 (UPI)Oilparticipation talks be tween Western companies and five Persian Gulf states resumed in Saudi Arabia yesterday, the official Saudi press agency said today.

title: Hijacked Vehicle Found
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass., Sept. 15 (AP)The tractor that was pulling a trailer with $45,000 worth of copper tubing alleged ly hijacked on Interstate 495 Tuesday was found abandoned here today. The cargo was not found.

title: Waldheim Insists on Safety Of Diplomats at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15  Secretary General Waldheim asked today that the public be made to understand that the personal safety of United Nations diplomats and their families must be main tained.

title: City Ballet Ready For Soviet Tour
description: The New York City Ballet is leaving Monday for a five week tour of the Soviet Union and Poland and the company is in the midst of quiet frenzy. They are tak ing more than 100 members of the company, 5,000 ballet slippers, 60,000 pounds of scenery and costumes and enough tuna fish to keep a ballet company going for a month.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 15 (AP)A St. Paul attorney representing the New York Islanders of the National Hockey League has filed a showcause order against Ted Hampson, a center, and the Midwest Saints Inc., owners of the Minnesota Fighting Saints hockey team. Attorney Robert R. Weinstine said he had been retained by the Islanders to get injunctive relief and money damages from the Saints for interference with Hampson's contract.

title: CURTIS WILL DIRECT BROADCASTING UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The Corporation for Public Broad casting today named its newest member, Thomas B. Curtis, as chairman of the board of di rectors.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon and Ray Charles, the blind singer and jazz pianist, met in the White House and compared their impressions of life abroad. Mr. Charles talked about the differences he encountered in Europe and the Far East. Mr. Nixon observed that the Jap anese have become very Europeanized, but you don't see that in China. I think that's a good thing, added the President. We don't want everyone to be alike.

title: Elderly Japanese Seeking More Government Help
description: TOKYO, Sept. 15About 15,000 elderly Japanese and their friends gathered today in the Budokan, or Hall of Martial Arts, and chanted a poem that began:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As for the old fogies you mention in your Sept. 5 editorial Seven for Spitz, I might say: If all the young people were being as constructive and were of the same piece of goods as Mark Spitz and Bobby Fischer  non of us old fogies would have any complaints.

title: Rooney and Lowenstein Step Up Pace In Brooklyn as New Primary Day Nears
description: The issue in this race is who can do what for whom, Rep resentative John J. Rooney, the veteran Brooklyn Democrat, said yesterday of the new pri mary election next Tuesday in which he will again face former Representative Allard K. Low enstein.

title: Dutch Genre Drawings at the Morgan
description: Drawing fanciers, as any honest one will admit, are subject to a special form of chauvinism having nothing to do with sex, country or race, but only with the kind of drawings they prefer. As an unregenerate 16th17thcen tury Italian in this respect, 1 found the Pierpont Morgan Library's new exhibition, Dutch Genre Drawings, a bit on the stolid side, just as the Dutch fan club thinks my Italians somewhat flighty. But any exhibition that in cludes 11 Rembrandts, as this one does, has something for everybody.

title: Clean Water Ahead?
description: A compromise bill to curb water pollution has emerged from a Congressional conference committee with provi sions that are surprisingly strong in view of the bill's history. The proposal that passed the House of Repre sentatives in March was a weak effort, product of inten sive pressures from industrial interests which have used the country's rivers as a free disposal system and from an Administration timorous about the financial cost of enforcementnot to mention its political price.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I was profoundly disturbed at your news report (Sept. 1) that the Ameri can Jewish Committee has come un der pressure to pull back from its ini tial stand (against use of quotas as a means of carrying out affirmative action programs) and had approached leading Nixon Administration officials in an effort to carry out such a with drawal.

title: Section on Spray Can Sales is Deleted From Graffiti Bill
description: A regulation calling for sell ers of aerosol spray cans and other marking devices to list sales and identities of pur chasers with the Police Depart ment was deleted from the anti graffiti bill voted out Thursday by the City Council's general welfare committee, a council spokesman said yesterday.

title: Elderly Japanese Seeking More Government Help
description: TOKYO, Sept. 15About 15,000 elderly Japanese and their friends gathered today in the Budokan, or Hall of Martial Arts, and chanted a poem that began:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am a supporter of President Nixon, and have been one for the last four years. However, I do have some ques tions which I would like to have an swers to. (1) The Watergate bugging affair, (2) the secret $10 million in con tributions, (3) the violations of the campaign law disclosed by the Gen eral Accounting Office.

title: Neurotics Seeking Help Among Themselves
description: They sat nervously in a circle, and they told only their first names: Mildred, Ann, David, Joe, Gertrude, Monroe, among others. Then, for 90 minutes, they took turns pouring out their prob lems.

title: 2 Are Killed in Ulster Bombing, Another Dies of Sniper Wounds
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 15  Three persons died today as terrorists continued a steppedup bombing and shooting campaign that gave Belfast its worst night of vio lence in three weeks.

title: EARTHQUAKE JOLTS MIDWESTERN STATES
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (UPI)A rare earthquake shook five Mid western states today, startling thousands of persons but caus ing no serious damage or in juries.

title: Gold Prices Drop Sharply
description: LONDON, Sept. 15 (AP) Gold prices dropped rather sharply on London and Euro pean bullion markets today amid rumors that the Soviet Union had started selling the metal in some volume in West ern markets to cover foreign exchange costs of grain im ports.

title: DISSIDENTS PICKET TAXI DRIVERS UNION
description: About 20 youthful members of the dissident Taxi Rank and File group picketed yesterday outside the Park Avenue offices of the Taxi Drivers Union. They were protesting a recent pro posal that fleet owners and drivers submit their twoyear old contract dispute to arbi tration.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 15  The State Board of Higher Educa tion ordered the eight state colleges today to hold down the number of faculty members who are tenured.

title: SOVIET HIJACKERS DRAW LONG TERMS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15  Two young Soviet students who hi jacked a small plane to Turkey in 1970, and were returned a year later, have been sen tenced to prison terms of 10 and 13 years.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) Black Onyx, the favorite, rallied today to win the $6,500 Dr. Pager purse by 3 lengths at sportsman's Park. The winner, ridden by Jeff Anderson, paid $3.20 for $2.40 win.

title: Yale to Build 2 StoreCollege Centers
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 15In a compromise with the city of New Haven, Yale University an nounced today that it would build two additional residential colleges with streetlevel shops and offices that would remain on the city's tax rolls.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 15 Robert H. Finch, counselor to President Nixon, shook hands and posed for pictures with local candidates today as he opened ReelectthePresi dent headquarters for central New York and Onondaga County.

title: ADM. HEWITT
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Sept, 15 Adm. H. Kent Hewitt, U.S.N. retired, one of the last surviving naval leaders of World War II, died today in Porter Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Orwell since his retirement in March, 1944, after 46 years of naval service.

title: Smuggling Suspect Seized
description: MIAMI, Sept. 15 (AP)Some 1,652 American gold coins worth $30,000 on the collectors market were seized when a man was arrested as he stepped off a flight from Curacao, United States Customs agents said today. The agents said that Salvador Abrams, 46 years old, an American citizen who lives in Mexico City, had at tempted to smuggle the 30 pounds of coins into the coun try inside a homemade vest.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: MORRISTOWN, Sept. 15 Mrs. Richard M. Nixon toured Morris Township today in sup port of her husband's campaign for reelection.

title: Where the Citadel Stood, 50 Acres of Devastation
description: QUANGTRI, South Viet nam, Sept. 15 (AP)  Five South Vietnamese marines crouched behind a shell battered brick wall, hurling grenades at snipers on the other side.

title: Theater: Jacques Brel Lives Again
description: So far the Broadway sea son has been outstandingly successfulby courtesy of Off Broadway. The Thursday cheers for That Champion ship Season had scarcely abated when last night an other Off Broadway hit swept into 45th Street at the Royale Theater. This was the longlongrunning musical Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris. And from now on he is liv ing in 45th Street as well.

title: Stocks on Amex Fall in Quiet Trading
description: Stocks fell slightly in sub dued trading yesterday on the America Stock Exchange.

title: Bridge: A Good Player on the Attack May Upset a Passive Course
description: Military men who dislike passive strategies, preferring the French dictum toujours l'attaque, do not make good bridgeplayers, at any rate in the area of opening leads. They constantly present the declarer with a trick and help him on the road to success.

title: Black Onyx, $3.20, Wins
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) Black Onyx, the favorite, rallied today to win the $6,500 Dr. Pager purse by 3 lengths at sportsman's Park. The winner, ridden by Jeff Anderson, paid $3.20 for $2 to win.

title: A CREDIT SQUEEZE DOUBTED BY BURNS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today he thought the Reserve could avoid a credit crunch in the months ahead but said the best in surance against such a squeeze would be enactment of a $250billion ceiling on Gov ernment spending.

title: Cuba Black Market Ring
description: HAVANA, Sept. 15 (Reuters) A group of men have been convicted of operating a black market in grain and slaughter ing cattle and have been sen tenced to 15 years in prison, the official radio reported here. The radio did not say how many were involved.

title: FASHION TALK
description: For years, Dorothee Bis has been one of those pace setting shops in Paris where the young fashionables con gregate to deck themselves out in whatever the less knowledgeable will be wear ing a few months later.

title: South Korean Floods Kill 101
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 15  The police said today more than 100 persons had been killed by torrential rains and floods that hit the southern part of the Korean Peninsula yesterday, the toll was put at 101 dead, 29 missing and 59 injured. Last month's heavy rains in the central part of the country killed 467.

title: BURCH SAYS F.C.C. CAN LIMIT RERUNS
description: Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Com mission, said here yesterday that he believed the agency had the authority to order a limit on the amount of prime evening viewing time the tele vision networks may devote to reruns.

title: Defendant in the Extortion Plot To Blow Up QE2 Pleads Guilty
description: A man arrested last June 21 and accused of trying to extort money by threatening to blow up the liner Queen Elizabeth 2, as well as American Airlines terminals and planes, pleaded guilty to the charges in Federal court yesterday.

title: Nixon Bids Senate Act
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)President Nixon asked the Senate today to approve a treaty aimed at deterring per sons from committing acts of sabotage or otherwise endan gering international air travel.

title: Kissinger and Top Hanoi Aides Hold 17th Private Talk in Paris
description: PARIS, Sept. 15Henry A. Kissinger met with North Viet nam's senior negotiators here today in their 17th secret ses sion aimed at ending the war.

title: MARKET DECLINES IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market failed to generate any enthusiasm yes terday mainly because of an absence of bullish economic news. Stocks finished Slightly lower in continued dull trading.

title: Yankees Beaten, 31, by Orioles
description: Jim Palmer celebrated his 20th victory with champagne, but all the Yankees could do was cry in their beer about the slippery pitcher's mound after they lost to Baltimore, 31, last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: 15 May Pay Tax Fines With Cows and Horses
description: Because they allegedly have not paid Pennsylvania wage taxes, 15 New Jersey residents who work in Phila delphia are faced with the threat of imprisonment under an 18century law. However, the 15 said yesterday that if they had to pay the fines it would be with such barter items as chickens, pigs, cows and horses.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The announcement by the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, William Ruckelshaus, of a ban on DDT in this country will expose Americans to the likelihood of instant death and disabling paralysis through the wider use of the highly toxic family of organo phosphor pesticides.

title: Market Place: Hazards Exist In Growth Pitch
description: One of the pet projects of security analysts is to create theoretical investment port folios and put them into a time frame to prove or dis prove a point.

title: Soviet Said to Transfer Writer to Moscow Prison
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15 (AP) Andrei Amairik, a Russian whose writings have become widely known in the West, has been transforred to Lefortovo prison in Moscow from a Sibe rian labor camp where he was serving a threeyear term, friends of the family reported today.

title: Message Impossible
description: Holding hearings about Western Union's message delivery service is like giving artificial respiration to a corpse. Theoretically, Charles Kraft of the state's Public Service Commission is quite right in suggesting that the only way to get those stalled messages moving again is to let somebody else do it. To wait for Western Union to transmit a money order might well deliver the addressee to debtor's prison.

title: Opposition Press In Saigon Muffled As 14 Papers Close
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15South Vietnam's op position press was virtually silenced today with the perma nent closing of 14 daily news papers and 15 other periodicals that failed to pay large bonds demanded by the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: QUANGTRI, South Viet nam, Sept. 15 (AP)Five South Vietnamese marines crouched behind a shell battered brick wall, hurling grenades at snipers on the other side.

title: Secret of Flea's Jumping Ability Is Found
description: For most people, fleas have little to recommend themthey bite and bother, spread ghastly diseases and give the unwary host a bad reputation.

title: NASA Says 15 Astronauts Signed Stamps for Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The value of the commer cial exploitation of the Apollo program passed $1million to day with the announcement by the space agency that 15 astro nauts had been paid $37,500 for signing more than 30,000 stamps and postcards.

title: WINE TALK
description: The big push is on. The world over, anyone who can grow grapes and squeeze them is out to crack the American wine market. Ar gentines, Bulgarians, Greeks, Yugoslavs, even Turks and Moroccans are trying to el bow past the French, Ital ians, Germans, Spanish and Portuguese who have been here for years.

title: Thousands Join in March Protesting Allende's Rule
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 14 (Reuters)Thousands of young opponents of President Salva dor Allende Gossens marched through Santiago tonight in protest against inflation, food shortages and what they call restrictions of freedom under his Marxist leadership.

title: PALMER HARMAN, 85, A FREELANCE WRITER
description: NEWTOWN, Pa., Sept. 15 Palmer Harman, a freelance writer, died here today at a nursing home. He was 85 years old and had lived in Bucks County for the last 30 years.

title: Merger News
description: The 10th United States Court of Appeals at Denver up held yesterday a Federal Trade Commission order requiring the divestiture of the Peabody Coal Company by the Kenne cott Copper Corporation.

title: Evaluation Office Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Senate has passed a bill to create an Office of Technol ogy Assessment to assist Con gress in evaluating scientific projects. The bill was returned to the House for consideration of Senate changes.

title: Big Money Good for a Man's Incentive, Tkaczuk Says
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 15In deference to the very valuable and very outof shape muscles of most of the regulars, who skated today for the first time, the Rangers merely exercised this morn ing, forgoing their scrim mages.

title: Soviet Jewry: We Want Moral Outcry
description: Even in normal times, for a Soviet Jew to apply for an exit visa is an act of courage. As soon as his inten tion becomes known he suffers re prisals. First, he usually loses his job. Next, his movements are checked by the police. Then, impediments of every kind are placed in his way. Finally, he must sell his belongings at a fear ful loss in order to pay $480 for his visa and $600 for permission to re nounce Soviet citizenship, a require ment of Soviet law.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Everette Howard Hunt Jr., the former White House con sultant who was indicted to day in connection with the Watergate breakin, has de voted most of his sometimes romantic career to spying on people.

title: PODGORNY DEPLORES MUNICH, REPRISALS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15Presi dent Nikolai V. Podgorny sought last night to dissociate the Soviet Union from the group of terrorists involved in the killings of the Israeli ath letes at the Olympic Games, but he contended that the slayings did not justify Israeli reprisal raids against Palestinian camps in Syria and Lebanon.

title: ExAide to Wallace Is Guilty of Evading U.S. Tax on Bribes
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 15 Seymore Trammell, who was manager of Gov. George C. Wallace's thirdparty cam paign for the Presidency in 1968, was convicted today in Federal District Court of evad ing income taxes on bribes and kickbacks received while he was Alabama's chief financial officer.

title: Hijackers Hold Plane in Sweden, Forcing the Release of Croatians
description: MALMO, Sweden, Saturday, Sept. 16Three gunmen advo cating Croatian independence from Yugoslavia hijacked an airliner yesterday and won from Sweden a promise to re lease seven Croatian prisoners.

title: DEVELOPING NATIONS WEIGH S.D.R. ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (Reuters)The group of 24 developing countries holding monetary reform discussions here at deputy ministerial level has agreed that the next issue of Special Drawing Rights should be for two years, mone tary sources said here today.

title: Riessen Loses to El Shafei, 76, 76, in Montreal Tennis
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 15 (AP) Ismail El Shafei of Egypt upset Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., today and advanced to the semifinals of the $50,000 Mon treal international tennis tour nament.

title: Britain Tightening Curbs on Cigarettes
description: LONDON, Sept. 15New re strictions on the promotion of cigarette sales are being phased into practice in Britain, and by the end of the year there will be no form of cig arette advertising that will not be coupled with a Government health warning.

title: U.S. Joins Jersey in Citing 14 Towns as Sea Polluters
description: TRENTON, Sept. 15 New Jersey environmental protection authorities joined with their Federal counterparts today in legal action against 14 Mon mouth and Cape May County communities that they said were polluting the state's coastal waterways.

title: Before Tackling the 3 R's, They Go on a Shoe Hunt
description: Understated mothers date on them, overachieving fathers work hard to pay for them and selfrespecting East Side youngsters wouldn't dare set foot in Buckley or Brearley without them.

title: SHELLFISH BANNED IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Gov. Francis W. Sargent de clared a public health emergen cy today and the State Depart ment of Public Health banned the sale and marketing of fresh and frozen shellfish on the wholesale and retail level and in restaurants because of red tide algae in the sea.

title: King of Islands in Indian Ocean Relinquishes Rule to Australia
description: COCOS ISLANDS, Sept. 15 (Reuters)  The neofeudal rule of Cocos Islands in the In dian Ocean ended suddenly today when the islands' un crowned king, John Clunies Ross, relinquished his power to the Australian Government in a 44word statement.

title: Paris Issues a Formal Call For Oct. 19 Market Meeting
description: PARIS, Sept. 15  President Pompidou announced tonight that he had issued a formal call for a 10nation European meet ing in Paris on Oct. 19, the first full toplevel session between the four nations scheduled to join the Common Market next Jan. 1 and the six present mar ket members.

title: QUNANGTRI CITADEL REPORTED TO FALL TO SAIGON TROOPS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, Sept. 16South Viet namese marines recaptured the Citadel in the heart of Quangtri City yesterday, American and South Vietnamese officers re ported. It was the most sig nificant victory for the Saigon Government since the North Vietnamese launched their of fensive March 30.

title: Rabbi Julius Price, Chaplain At Bronx County Jail, Dies
description: Rabbi Julius J. Price, chap lain for many years of the Bronx County Jail and spiritual director of Sinai Temple, the Bronx, from 1921 to 1931, died Thursday at his home, 1560 Grand Concourse, the Bronx. His age was 85.

title: 8Cent Tom Sawyer Stamp
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) A new 8cent Tom Sawyer commemorative stamp will go on sale for the first time Oct. 13 at Hannibal, Mo., the Postal Service said today. Collectors may submit requests for first day cancellations to the post master at Hannibal. The re quests must be postmarked no later than Oct. 13. The new stamp will be sold at other post offices starting Oct. 14.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: They're called midgets, but don't let their size fool you. Turn them loose on a big enough track and they can hit 150 miles an hour or better.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that its hearings on hot issues and how to regulate them would resume Wednesday.

title: NIXON SEEKING RISE IN FLOOD BENEFITS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)Prodded by record flood losses this year, President Nixon said today that he would ask Congress to increase by 400 per cent the authorization for Federally subsidized flood insurance and to encourage more homeowners to partici pate in the program.

title: HARLEM SCHOOL TO END BOYCOTT
description: More than 1,000 pupils re mained out of classes for the third day yesterday at a Harlem elementary school where parents were protesting the dismissal of four substitute teachers.

title: Film: 'Bewitched Love':Cadiz Is Background For Spanish Musical
description: One problem with mounting poetic fantasy in film, a problem that essentially doesn't exist for live theater, is that the medium itself makes such strong claims upon its audience's belief in photographic reality.The problem plagued several of the more ambitiously imaginative American movie musicals of the 1940's and early 1950's. And to a degree it plagues "Bewitched Love," a film loosely based on the ballet, and utilizing de Falla's popular music for, "El Amor Brujo."Candelas, the heroine of "Bewitched Love," fears that her former lover, the evil Diego, is following her, even though she has seen him dead, killed in a fight. She has good reason to fear. Diego is not dead; he has dressed a body in his clothes and escaped to a hiding place from which he does pursue Candelas, hoping to win her back and take her away with him.He is opposed by Antonio, a shipyard worker, a good man, truly in love with Candelas. The drama of "Bewitched Love" develops mainly from the contest between Antonio's gentle love and Diego's bitter passion, with the tormented Candelas between them.It all sounds like a plot for ballet (which it partly is), with much emotion and not too much substance, but with good occasions for dancingof which there is some, but not enough. The cast, led by Antonio Gades, La Polaca, and Rafael De Cordova, does of course dancebut mostly in a few isolated set pieces. And except for one long and quite fine nightmare dream dance by Candelas, the film is at pains to make everything seem naturalistic.To a large degree this works. Aided by locations in Cadiz, a very picturesque old city wonderfully full of television antennas and littered streets, "Bewitched Love" achieves a kind of uneasy plausibility. But at the same time it seems to fall prey to its own commitment to filmed realitybegging, and not always finding, a poetry in dark twisted alleys and rain-soaked squares that are real enough, but also more neutral than a film of passionate feeling might care to allow."Betwitched Love" opened yesterday at the Cine 2.

title: NASA Says 15 Astronauts Signed Stamps for Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The value of the commer cial exploitation of the Apollo program passed $1million to day with the announcement by the space agency that 15 astro nauts had been paid $37,500 for signing more than 30,000 stamps and postcards.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BURBANK, Calif., Sept. 13 People who work in and around the Lockheed plant here have very few good things to say about Senator George McGovern when they talk about pocketbook issues such as jobs and prices. And many of them have a lot of angry things to say about President Nixon's handling of the economy.

title: Prices Up Sharply In Wheat Futures; Soybeans in Gains
description: A reported purchase of wheat by East Germany coupled with continued export demand for the grain for other Communist nations pushed wheat futures up sharply yesterday. In most wheatcontract months the gains were around the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel. The distant deliveries set new life ofcontract highs.

title: Jobs Under Federal Act Are Meant for Cross Section of Unemployed as Well as the Poor
description: New York City is one of 600 communities throughout the nation participating in a $1 billion program under the Fed eral Emergency Employment Act, passed by Congress in August, 1971.

title: Tigers Win
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 15 (AP) Norm Cash hit a runscoring single with two out in the ninth inning tonight as the Detroit Tigers nipped the Milwaukee Brewers, 21.

title: PETER G. KELLER, 77, STAMP DEALERS' AIDE
description: TAPPAN, N. Y., Sept. 15 Peter G. Keller, for 25 years a director and executive officer of the American Stamp Dealers Association, died of a heart at tack today at his home here. His age was 77.

title: Fare Along Mulberry St. Varies From the Sublime
description: The orgy is off and run hing again on Mulberry Street. The Feast of San Gen naro is 11 days of wallto wall Neapolitan food, 11 days of al fresco gorging from booth to booth down a seem ingly endless tunnel with white lights on top and sweet sausage on both sides.

title: The Munich Olympics:
description: The decision of the Inter national Olympic Committee to bar Vince Matthews and Wayne Collett from further participation in the Olympics for their socalled disgust ing display once again reaf firms the absurdity, not of the games, but of the manner in which they are conducted.

title: Politics May Play a Part in China's Wheat Purchases From U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 16Pe king's surprise purchase of wheat from the United States is not due to a bad domestic wheat crop this year and has to be explained on other grounds, Chineseaffairs special ists here say.

title: M. K. Furman, Susannah Buck Are Wed on L.I.
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 16  Miss Susannah Buck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Porter Buck, was married here this afternoon to Mitchell Kenneth Furman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Furman of Farmingdale.

title: Notes: It's Time To Leave
description: FROM now until the leaves fall, the Northeast's hills will be alive with colorhungry tourists, and from New England down through the Middle Atlantic states there will be no limit to the enticements offered by resort areas noted for their autumn extravaganzas of brilliantlyhued foliage.

title: Mets Routed, 185, for Worst Loss Ever
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16  The Cubs walloped five home runs and took advantage of 15 bases on balls today to saddle the Mets with an 185 trouncing, the worst defeat in their 11 years. Chicago's total was the most runs scored by a team in the National League this sea son.

title: SHOP TALK
description: I didn't think that meas uring 6 feet 3 inches tall and weighing 225 pounds was equivalent to being a freak. That is, until I started looking for places to buy clothes.

title: Framingham Votes Curb On Building Apartments
description: FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP)The town meeting has taken a step toward curbing population growth here, voting 100 to 12 to ban further con struction of apartment houses.

title: Lords Of Power
description: Here's a political novel so timely it includes a Presiden tial candidate who considers re signing because of something murky in his portfolio. Its pro tagonist is a Governor of the Empire State who is a rich, magnetic, handsome, unscru pulous dreamer. Roman a clef? Mmm hardly, al though Mr. Weissman, a News week and C.B.S. reporter, knows a lot about how strings are pulled, influence peddled and patronage dispensed.

title: oss
description: Ever since the Greeks filled a wooden horse with soldiers and pre sented it to the Trojans, the world has been fascinated by the deceptive methods of espionage and counter intelligence. The craft of intelligence, by its very nature, is so secret that clandestine activities are cloaked either in the ridiculous and the ab surd or the sublime and the practical. In this book, R. Harris Smith, who worked briefly as a research analyst for the C.I.A. and now lectures in po litical science at the University of California's Extension Division, seems to have discovered only the first two. Perhaps that's all he was meant to find. It would appear that old O.S.S. men never die; their stories simply get better while their secrets remain intact.

title: 9 Croatians Are Held in Spain After Hijacking
description: MADRID, Sept. 16  Nine Croatian extremists turned themselves in to the Spanish police today three hours after their arrival at Madrid Airport aboard a hijacked Scandinavian Airlines jetliner.

title: Miss Robin E. Brown Is Bride Of Christopher Tuthill Linen
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I. Sept. 16Miss Robin Eliza beth Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Brown of Mill Neck, was married here this afternoon to Christopher Tuthill Linen, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Linen of Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Linen is chairman of the executive committee of Time Inc.

title: McGovern Drive Falters Here
description: The Presidential campaign here covers a gamut as wide as the territory between Bay Ridge and Montauk.

title: SurroundedBut Not Afraid
description: THERE we were, Joan MacIntosh and I, sur rounded by a swift, great, circling dance of 1,200 New Guinea warriors armed with spears, bows and arrows, and clubs; their bodies and faces glistening red, yellow, blue, and black; their headdresses magnifi cent fourfoot plumes of cas sowary and birdofparadise feathers. In the air, the in credible stench of 300 freshly slaughtered, just barely cook ed pigstheir meat and bones piled threefeet high in a jumble of muzzles, hoofs, flanks, and ribs around an altar decorated with fresh cut red flowers and 300 pig jawbones.

title: Stamps
description: CONTINUING the ever growing proliferation of stampissuing enti ties (not always coun tries), the Isle of Man, as was the case with the islands of Guernsey and Jersey in the Channel Islands, will be is suing stamps next year. The Isle of Man32 miles long and 12 miles broadlies in the Irish sea between Ireland and Scotland and was under Scandinavian rule some cen turies ago.

title: New Rochelle Honors Fatt Calfe Tradition
description: A 284yearold agreement was observed in the southern Westchester city of New Ro chelle yesterday when its Mayor, Frank J. Garito, pre sented a live, purebred Jersey calf to a direct descendant of Sir John Pell.

title: 12 on Georgia Police Force Suspended in Theft Cases
description: THOMASVILLE, Ga., Sept. 16 (UPI)Twelve Members of the Thomasville Police Department, representing about half the uni formed division, were sus pended today and Chief R. T. Alley said that charges of theft and burglary would be placed against them.

title: The Munich Olympics:
description: The reaction of both spec tators and the International Olympic Committee to the be havior of Vince Matthews and Wayne Collett on the victory stand after the 400meter run demonstrates the inflated sense of importance and the appalling lack of perspective which have marked the 1972 Olympics.

title: Polo, Now a Spectator Sport, Draws Varied Crowds on L.I.
description: This is the polo season on Long Island. On every fair Sunday afternoon from now until midOctober, the fa mous Meadow Brook Polo Club is sponsoring matches, just as it has since it was organized by North Shore sportsmen in 1881.

title: Diane Biondi Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Biondi of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Prescent Biondi, to Richard Robert Welsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Welsh of New York.

title: North Vietnam Will Teach Four Foreign Languages
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 16 (Agence FrancePresse) Four foreign languagesEng lish, Russian, Chinese and French  will be taught in North Vietnamese schools, ac cording to a decision by Pre mier Pham Van Dong reported here.

title: GA. TECH ROUTS SO CAROLINA, 346
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 16 (UPI) Randy Rhino, an 18yearold sophomore, set a Georgia Tech record with a 95yard punt re turn for a touchdown and he set up another touchdown with a 41yard punt return today as the Yellow Jackets crushed South Carolina, 346.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To my surprise and very much to my disappointment, the article AirConditioners Blow Minds as Well as Fus es [Aug. 13] confined itself to discussing the problems of tenants and homeowners in connection with the faulty operation of these nefarious mechanisms and difficulties in getting them repaired.

title: U.S. BOAT VICTOR IN CANADA'S CUP
description: TORONTO, Sept. 16 (AP) Dynamite, the American chal lenger from Detroit, defeated Mirage, the Canadian defend er, today by 1 minute 7 seconds in the deciding sailing race for the Canadia's Cup on Lake On tario.

title: Egypt to Get Antibird Aid
description: CAIRO, Sept. 16 (Reuters) Egypt is importing a sonic boom gun from the Netherlands to combat millions of sparrows destroying crops and devour ing grain stocks.

title: Meskill to Propose Cut of 0.5% In Sales, Capital Gains Taxes
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 16Gov ernor Thomas J. Meskill said today he would propose to the General Assembly, when it con venes in special session Tues day, that it trim both the state's sales tax and the capital gains tax by onehalf of 1 per cent.

title: Thoreau's Concord Is Willing to Leave Nature's Work Alone
description: ALTHOUGH Concord, Mass., was 182 years old when Henry David Thoreau was born there in 1817, and is 337 years old now, it has the rage for life of a youngster, the reverence for life of a poet and an urge for life's renewal that rivals the late Rachel Carson's. When Thoreau was asked whether he had made his peace with God, he answered, We have nev er quarreled. The entire town of Con cord, because of its respect for life, could say the same.

title: The World
description: BUENOS AIRES  Every television screen throughout Argentina flickered with the same images for half an hour last Wednesday night. All stations had been ordered to join a nationwide link up over which an army general was explaining, with dramatic background music and film sequences, how 25 ter rorists had escaped from Rawson max imum security prison in Patagonia on Aug. 15.

title: Television
description: IF you still can't find a cop when you need one, it may be because he's at the station house watch ing his idealized image on tele vision. The policemandetectivelaw en forcer genre has existed on TV since the early days of the electronic me dium. This year, with several new en tries, it seems to be prevailing.

title: Edwin Mullhouse; The Life and Death of an American Writer. (19431954). By Jeffrey Cartwright. A novel by Steven Millhauser. 305 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $6.95.
description: We all know Fats Waller's reply to the welldressed woman who leaned over his piano to ask him to define jazz. His answer applies to similar questions about art. If you have to ask you'll never know. Yet people go on askingand, though the answer will never come, occasionally, like whacks from the Zen master's cane pointing the way to satori, unexpected clues are illuminated. Steven Mill hauser's deft first novel (which takes the form of a biography of an 11 year old artist by his scholarly best friend) offers a substantial amount of truth disguised as elegant artifice.

title: Miss Mary Fitzhugh Stewart Bride of Ronald HunterBlair
description: The Madison Avenue Pres byterian Church was the set ting here yesterday after noon for the marriage of Miss Mary Fitzhugh Stewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Stewart Jr. of Far Hills, N. J., and Nan tucket, Mass., to Ronald Pat rick HunterBlair of London. He is the son of Mrs. Ron ald HunterBlair of Charles town, Fife, Scotland, and the late Commander Hunter Blair of the Royal Navy.

title: Excerpts From Park Study
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16Following are excerpts from the recommendations in the federally sponsored Conserva tion Foundation study National Parks for the Future:

title: K. J. Fishman Fiance Of Barbara Dalton
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 16Mr. and Mrs. Stanley F. Dalton of Oyster Bay and Shelter Island have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jean Dalton, to Kenneth J. Fishman, son of Mr. and Mrs. George N. Fishman of Lat tingtown. A June wedding is planned.

title: Meet Mr. Nice Gun
description: The National Rifle Association is like the American Medical Association, says Lou Levine. A bunch of old fogeys out of touch with today's realities. I belong be cause they're a necessary evil, somebody who represents us. But I don't subscribe to many of their ideas.

title: U.S. AND MEXICANS COMBATING PEST
description: DALLAS, Sept. 16Ranchers in the southwestern United States and in Mexico, who have suffered widespread finan cial and livestock losses be cause of a disastrous screw worm epidemic, have been en couraged by a cooperative eradication program just started by the two nations.

title: Mrs. Anne Hutton Is Married To Peter Trowbridge Cook
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 16Mrs. Anne Blind Hutton was married here this after noon, to Peter Trowbridge Cook of New York. The Rev. Almus M. Thorp Jr., an Epis copal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William Charles Blind, parents of the bride.

title: Letters:
description: An elderly couple who need space and convenience, we find, upon plan ning a West Coast trip by train, that we cannot get a bedroom suite without paying an additional adult fare. So we have had to resort to the airlines. The rule that requires three adult fares for two passengers in the Pullman accom modations is, in my opinion, nothing less than blackmail. As a railroad buff, I had hoped for a revival of rail travel under Amtrak, but I am disillusioned.

title: Fly Air Chance, Costly Bargain
description: Continued From Page 1

title: Sterling Forest Makes Plans For Bigger, Better Dog Shows
description: News of Dogs

title: Mrs. Judith Rollinson Davis Rewed
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 16 Mrs. Judith Rollinson Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Harrison Rollinson Jr. of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, was married here this afternoon to Patrick RulonMiller, son of Sumner RulonMiller Jr. of New York and Mrs. Lindley W. Tiers of Princeton.

title: Letters:
description: The flaw in the End of Assimilation article was the simplistic viewpoint that only a Jewish religionist is a Jew. Was it their Jewish religion or their. Jewish genes that sparked so many Jewish Nobel Prize winnersa number quite disproportionate to their percentage of the world's population?

title: Education
description: Enrollments in the nation's schools and colleges have grown steadily for nearly three decades. But figures re leased last week indicate a tapering off that could bring better teaching conditions and less pressure on tax payers but harder times for college faculties.

title: SIXKILLER RETURNS; HUSKIES WIN, 14 TO 6
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 16 (Ap) Washington's quarterback, Son ny Sixkiller, returned to action today and hit Tom Scott with a 45yard scoring pass to lead the Huskies to a 146. victory over Duke in an intersectional football game.

title: Eddie Waitkus, First Baseman Who Was Shot in 1949, Is Dead
description: BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP) Eddie Waitkus, a former major league first basemen for 11 years and one of the Philadel phia Phillies Whiz Kids who won the 1950 National League pennant, died last night at a Veterans Administration Hos pital. He was 53 years old.

title: Nixon, Agnew Net Worth
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Following are statements of the net worth of President Nixon, as of June 30, 1972, and Vice President Agnew, as of Aug. 31, 1972, as issued today by the White House:

title: GANG MEMBER SLAIN IN BROOKLYN FIGHT
description: A Brooklyn tenement hall way battle early yesterday morning, involving members of the Young Barons, a Puerto Rican gang, ended with one youth stabbed to death, another with his nose cut off, and a 37 yearold man charged with homicide.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market's September song continued this week as a slowgaited dirge, with prices drifting lower. The DowJones industrial average dropped every day but one, losing a total of 13.92 points. It closed Friday at 947.32. Average daily trading since Labor Day has slumped from 16.30 million shares to 11.80 million.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON Every morning, seven days a week, the White House receives over the signature of Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird a detailed report on the bombing of North Viet nam in the preceding 24 hours.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: LOS ANGELESTransit leaders here will try soon to entice motorists out of their cars by giving them a chance to race past rushhour traffic jams on the San Bernardino Freeway in a bus.

title: The novel as biography, as memoir, as fantasy
description: On its simplest level Runner Mack is the story of Henry Adams, a naive, aspiring professional base ball player who leaves his small, Southern home town and, with his wife Beatrice, comes North to find fame and riches. He gets his chance to try out with the Stars, a bigleague team, but before he is told whether he has made it he is drafted and sent to Alaska where his outfit is fighting a capricious war with an unseen enemy. There he meets Run nington Mack, a wouldbe black rev olutionary, who leads Henry to an awareness of himself as a black man and involves him in a plot to bomb the White House and take over the country.

title: Letters
description: The lead quotation in Martha Lear's article Save the spouses, rather than the mar riage (Aug. 13), is inaccur ate. I was quoted as saying, We know that somehow mar riage stinks. We don't know why. We used to make jokes about marriage and stay mar ried and kill each other. Now, for the first time, we feel free enough to say that it stinks, and to ask why.

title: A major minor poet
description: Randall Jarrell's poetry will probably always discomfort his fondest readers. All the ancil lary matters of his life and work arouse in us an almost painful wish to see him, to accept him, as a major con temporary poet, a fit compan ion, say, to Lowell and Roethke and Plath in a pantheon of postwar voices. He was a writer of unbelievably catholic intereststhe collected poems are a tour of things from Freud to German Romanticism to middlecentury supermarket Americaand of unerring crit ical taste.

title: Harbor Polluters Are Resentful at Being Singled Out
description: NEWARK  Officials of seven New Jersey govern mental polluters of the wa ters of New York Harbor, called to account by the Federal Government at hearings in the last two weeks, were puzzled and re sentful at being singled out to take action to stop the polluting.

title: U.S. TO HELP POLES COMBAT POLLUTION
description: WARSAW, Sept. 16A $2 million waterpollution control program sponsored by the Unit ed States Environmental Pro tection Agency will begin in Poland next month. It is one of several measures undertaken here recently that represent a drastic change in this country's attitude toward environmental problems.

title: Jonrob Wins Hiscoe Cup
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 16  John Storck's Jonrob, an Ericson39 sloop out of Lloyd Harbor Yacht Club at Hunting ton, L.I., won the Hiscoe Cup today on the Belle Haven Club's annual cruising yacht race on Long Island Sound.

title: INNIS O'ROURKE
description: MILL NECK, L. I., Sept. 16 Innis O'Rourke, founder of the Concrete Conduit Corporation and Precast, Inc., died yester day at his home here. He was 81 years old and lived on Frost Mill Road and in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Down With Din!
description: Garbage trucks will be quieter. So will sirens and horns and air conditionersand those carsplitters that tear into streets and side walks. For last week, despite loud opposition from the construction in dustry, the City Council passed New York's first comprehensive law to control noise. Mayor. Lindsay is expected to sign it shortly and the program will go into effect over the next two years.

title: Board Given Approval To Review Colley Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froehlke has au thorized the Air Force and Army Clemency and Parole Review Board to consider a clemency petition filed on be half of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., convicted of murder in the Mylai massacre case.

title: PONITFF, IN VENICE, WARNS OF DECAY
description: VENICE, Italy, Sept. 16  Pope Paul VI told the Venetians today that he knew how seri ously their city was threat ened in its physical stability and warned that Venice, city of ideal beauty, must never be corroded by manifestations of aesthetic and moral decadence.

title: New &Novel
description: Poetic imagery fortifies this unusual regional novel  but the story's the thing, and the people in it, and their village in the Orkneys, off the north east coast of Scotland. Fused by a touch of the poet, these ingredients come as close to being a work of art as anything you will find in many a season.

title: Tasters Trained In Testing Foods
description: FAIR LAWNThe subject was Frenchfried onion rings. There they were  small, palegolden mounds in code labeled styrofoam bowls, ready for a texture test in the kitchen of the National Biscuit Company's research center in Fair Lawn.

title: And don't forget the pickled green beans
description: Cooking, like music, lends itself to many variations on a theme. In this case, Salad Alaska (its name is based on the state's salmon riches) is a variation on the salade Nioise of southern France. Red salmon and pickled green beans, redolent with garlic and spicy with hot red peppers and mustard, are responsible for its distinctive flavor. The green beans can also stand on their own as an ap petizer. This hearty salad is appropri ate for lunch or supper. When fresh salmon is not available, canned sal mon makes an excellent substitute.

title: Busy Man: But Not Too Busy To Help
description: While I was on vacation and talking to my fellow Point Lookouter Bob Rickard, he said, Nothing exciting ever happens to me.

title: CRAFT WILL STUDY COSMIC RAY ORIGIN
description: An investigation of where cosmic rays are produced, how long they last and how fast they travel will be conducted by an American spacecraft scheduled for launching next Friday from Cape Kennedy, Fla.

title: Miss Cathleen E. Moran Is Bride
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 16Miss Cathleen Eliz abeth Moran, a descendant of Michael Moran, who founded the Moran Towing Corpora tion of New York in 1860, was married here this noon to Peter Reynes Vermylen, who is descended from An toine Zerega, founder in 1848 in Brooklyn of A. Zerega's Sons, manufacturers of maca roni.

title: The novel as biography, as memoir, as fantasy
description: Better the banal than the apoca lyptic, Prof. David Alan Kepesh saysthe central character in Phil ip Roth's new novella, The Breast. For reasons not altogether clear to his doctorsthe assault (some say) of a volcanic secretion from the pi tuitary of mammogenic fluidKe pesh has turned into an enormous breast, round at one end like a watermelon, at the other end a nip ple that can hear and talk and feel sexual stimulation but never reach orgasm, forever howling more! Per haps it's a dream, Kepesh hopes. Perhaps madness, an effect of hav ing taught too much Swift, Kafka and Gogol. But it's not; the trans formation is real. So the professor rants and reasons, or tells banal jokes to himself and those who visit him.

title: Wattiker's 3 Touchdowns Lead Fordham to a 3418 Victory Over Manhattan
description: Fordham University took a few quick strides on its road back to football glory yester day, defeating Manhattan Col lege, 3418, before 8,322 fans at Jack Coffey Field.

title: Hospital Additions Face Hurdles in State Survey
description: TRENTONThe New Jer sey Health Department plans to modernize its medical censustaking this month, eliminating obsolete data and arbitrary criteria that may have blocked at least one needed hospital addition.

title: Milwaukee Beaten, 21
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 16 Woody Fryman and Chuck Seelbach combined on a seven hitter and Ed Brinkman knock ed in the deciding run with a fourthinning single today in leading the Detroit Tigers to a 21 victory over the Milwau kee Brewers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Is it too much to ask that the Olym pic Committee be composed of mem bers who understand that the Olym piad is truly international and that the personal behavior of participants should not be judged by accepted European standards? Since when do Americans have to stand at attention to display pride or respect?

title: Shorter Reviews
description: We are coming to recognize as never before the right of the nation to guard its own future in the essential matter of na tural resources, President Theodore Roosevelt wrote in 1908 in a statement reprinted as the introduction to these 13 essays by as many contempo rary writers. The two most im pressive of these thoroughly documented pieces deal with is sues not thought of as environ mental  a chapter on trans portation by Bob Waldrop of the Sierra Club and one on The Workplace Environment, in which Franklin Wallick of the United Auto Workers de nounces the Nixon Administra tion's industrialsafety pro grams.

title: QUEEN ELIZABETH 2 HIRED BY TEXANS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 16The Queen Elizabeth 2, one of the world's largest luxury ships, has been booked for an un accustomed 1974 journey by businessmen from Texas.

title: Lowenstein Says Rooney Wages Scurrilous Attack
description: Allard K. Lowenstein charged yesterday that supporters of Representative John J. Rooney were circulating scurrilous campaign literature accusing him of being antiSemitic and antiCatholic.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It seems that a representative of the United States Olympic Committee or at least the coach of malcontents such as Vince Matthews should stand by while Olympic medals are being handed out in order to see that a modicum of respect is given to Olym pic traditions and the United States national anthem.

title: New Headmaster at Buckley
description: Cornelius Brett Boocock Jr. has succeeded James M. Hub ball as headmaster of the Buck ley School, the school's Board of Trustees announced last week. Mr. Hubball is retiring after 32 years as headmaster of the private elementary school at 113 East 73d Street. Mr. Boocock previously was head master of the Chadwick School in Palos Verdes, Calif,

title: Son Born to Levys
description: A son was born Aug. 29 to Mr. and Mrs. James L. Levy of White Plains in Beth Israel Hospital here. Mrs. Levy is the former Miss Leslie Bernstein of New York. Her husband is a real estate ap praiser and vice president of the Estates Management Com pany, Inc. The child has been named Samuel Lewis.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 (AP)Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshore men's and Warehousemen's Union, says that the union's international board, meeting here Monday, quite probably will endorse Senator, McGovern for President.

title: Shipyard Hiring 300
description: BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP)The Boston Naval Shipyard is hiring more htan 300 mechanics and helpers as a result of an in creased workload at the yard, according to a union spokes man.

title: Idaho Upsets Ohio U.
description: MOSCOW, Idaho, Sept. 16 (AP)The Idaho Vandals upset the Bobcats of Ohio University, 1714, toda in 35mileanhour winds. The victory margin came in the fourth quarter when Steve Tanner kicked an 18yard field goal.

title: Alcorn Tops Grambling, 96
description: GRAMBLING, La., Sept. 16 (AP)Alcorn A. and M. opened its 1972 football season today with a 96 victory over Gram bling in a southwestern athletic conference game. A sophomore quarterback, William Wooley, hit on 12 of 26 passes for 163 yards for Alcorn.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: According to George Danger field's review of Walter Lord's The Dawn's Early Light, not only was General Winder (com mander of the American troops at the battle of Bladensburg) a Virginian  but that fact was a major cause of the debacle preceding the British occupation of Washington in the War of 1812since the Secretary of War disliked Vir ginians and therefore gave Winder absolutely no help.

title: U.S. AMMUNITION AIDS CAMBODIANS
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 10  The United States is manufacturing Soviet  style cartridges for the Communist made weapons still used by the Pnompenh Government's forces.

title: So. Conn. Beats Wesleyan On Jaskot's Passes, 31.21
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 16Tony Jaskot's touchdown passes of 33 and 16 yards in the second half today led Southern Connecticut to a 3121 football triumph over Wesleyan University before 4,000 fans on Bowen Field.

title: Ball State Wins, 30 to 12
description: MUNCIE, Ind., Sept. 16 (AP) Phil Donahue threw a pair of scoring passes and ran for an other touchdown today as Ball State trounced Central Michi gan, 3012,in football.

title: Robins Wins 2 Races
description: WESTHAMPTON, N. S., Sept. 16Sam Robins of Greenwich, Conn., who does his sailing mostly in Tiana Bay, captured both races today to take the lead in his defense of the Celeb rity Class National champion ship. Three more races are scheduled for tomorrow.

title: WISHBONE CLICKS
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16Tom Harmon, former star Michigan running back and father of Mark, the young University of California, Los Angeles quarter back, credited the Bruins with playing just about a perfect nine with only one noticeable mistake when U.C.L.A. upset Nebraska a week ago.

title: MIAMI PROSECUTOR SURE OF 5TH TERM
description: MIAMI, Sept. 16  Richard E. Gerstein, Dade County (great er Miami) State Attorney, has been assured of a fifth four year term in a post that is gen erally regarded as second only to the governorship in impor tance in Florida.

title: They Started Out as Real Farm Shows
description: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP State fairs initially were live stock and agricultural affairs. It was only near the end of the 19th century that elements of the midway be gan to creep in.

title: LIBERALS' PLATFORM IS CRITICAL OF NIXON
description: The Liberal party unveiled its 1972 political platform yes terday calling on voters to re ject the Nixon Administration and its policies. The party had endorsed the Presidential can didacy of Senator George Mc Govern of South Dakota in June.

title: Letters:
description: Mr. Birnbaum's story recounts, in es sence, our feeling toward the Germans. Although we are Americanborn, we lost many relatives in Hitler's concentration camps. We are not religious and live a pleasant assimilated existence in America. Yet on our many trips to Europe, both on business and for pleas ure, we have never gone to Germany, nor do we ever expect to. Further, we have felt uncomfortable whenever Ger man tourists crossed our path; our distaste for the Germans has even led us to avoid Germanspeaking Zurich in favor of Geneva and Lucerne.

title: Science Academy Assails Nation's Emergency Care
description: The National Academy of Sciences has charged that thou sands of Americans die need lessly each year because of in adequate emergency medical services.

title: Cabbies to Give 48c a Day To Keep Company Afloat
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (UPI)Drivers for the Yellow Cab Company of Philadelphia have agreed to give their finan cially troubled company 48 cents a day in a move designed to keep the concern afloat and Save their jobs.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: In his review of Allen Man delbaum's translation of the Aeneid, Erich Segal may be right in finding its protagonist antiwar. But he is unfair to T. S. Eliot.

title: DICKINSON MARKS 200TH BIRTHDAY
description: Dickinson College in Carlisle, Pa., the 10th oldest college in the United States, began cele brating its 200th anniversary this weekend.

title: Twins Triumph, 111
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 16 (AP)Harmon Killebrew drove in five runs today, the first three with his 29th homer of the year, in leading the Min nesota Twins to an 111 vic tory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Red Tide Moving North Along New England Coast
description: BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP) A toxic red tide, which Massachusetts officials blame for at least seven cases of ill ness from shellfish poisoning, moved up the northern New England coast today.

title: COCKER SPANIEL GAINS TOP AWARD
description: EMMAUS, Pa., Sept. 16Ch. Sagamore Toccoa, a buff cock er spaniel owned by Peggy Westphal of Bedford, N.Y., took her 30th bestinshow award today in a field of 1,924 at the 44th annual Lehigh Val ley Kennel Club event at the Emmaus Community Park.

title: ALABAMA OFFICIAL IS TOLD TO RESIGN
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 16The Alabama Board of Mental Health called this week for the resignation of the state's Commissioner of Mental Health in the wake of two years of litigation and contro versy over the treatment of the retarded and the mentally ill in Alabama.

title: The 2 Faces of the Fair
description: HAMILTON TOWNSHIPIn the colisuem, a rather dubiously named dull stucco building with vacated wasps nests still clinging to creosoted beams, the judging of dairy cattle was beginning.

title: Civilian Control
description: The secrecy that surrounds the Senate hearings into charges that highranking officers were aware of Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle's unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam makes it impossible and improper at this point to judge the behavior of those who have appeared before the panel. It is clear, however, that, in the words of Senator Stennis, chairman of the Armed Services Com mittee, a conflict exists between the testimonies of General Lavelle and Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, prospec tive Army Chief of Staff.

title: Nuptials for Jane Wilson
description: PARK RIDGE, N. J., Sept. 16Miss Jane Wilson, a pro fessional tennis teacher in the Bergen County area, was married here this morning to James Wheeler Eoff, assistant golf professional at the Mon tammy Country Club in Al pine. The Rev. James Turro performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Ro man Catholic Church. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Wilson of River Vale. Mr. and Mrs. James B. Eoff of Carrollton, Tex., are the bridegroom's parents.

title: The Nation
description: MOSCOWOn the surface, the Kremlin appears to have gained more than the White House from Henry A. Kissinger's talks with the Communist party leader, Leonid Brezhnev, here last week, but only timeand the Vietnam negotiationswill show whether that impression is valid.

title: Art
description: As the New York art world enters its sec ond straight season without even the pre tense of a dominant new art movement, the closest thing to a trend in sight may be less esthetic than social and economicinvolving, among other things, the return to respectability of the coop gallery. The coop, in which members share expenses and duties, flourished briefly in the semiunderground 10th Street scene of the 1950's, then lost out to the new big time entrepreneurial galleries of the sixties with their well groomed stables of art stars. A sixties artist who had to pay for his own show was judged an embarrassment to his family and friends.

title: J. D. McKee Jr., Janine Brockie Wed in Jersey
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 16The sanctuary of the First Presbyterian Church of Englewood was the setting this afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Janine Nash Brockie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Simmons Brockie Jr., to Julien Davies McKee Jr., son of Mr. McKee of Dublin, N.H., and Mrs. Fitz Eugene Newbold of Englewood. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John W. Van Zanten.

title: Lions Look Too Tough For Giants
description: DETROIT, Sept. 16After a winter of almost ludicrous pessimism and a training sea son of perhaps excessive op timism, the New York Giants open their National Football League season here tomor row against the Detroit Lions.

title: U.S. BIDS NATIONS CURB TERRORISM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  The United States is mobilizing its influence, publicly and pri vately, to focus world attention on the growing menace of polit icalespecially Arabterror ism.

title: Ole Miss Wins, 3429
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn Sept. 16 (AP)Norris Weese ran for two touchdowns and passed for three more tonight, leading Mississippi to a 3429 victory over Memphis State.

title: PACIFIC PHONE SEEKS NEW RATE INCREASES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 (AP)  The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it was asking the state Public Utilities Commis sion for an interim rate in crease of $103million annually and a permanent increase of $225million, for a total of $328million a year.

title: Art
description: WITH its current (September) number, the magazine Artforum is observing its 10th anniversary. To mark the occasion, the editor (John Coplans) has brought together a number of essays that attempt, either through disinterested analysis or per sonal confession, to give us a sense of the problems and impasses currently dominating certain sectors of the art worldthe sectors where art is con cerned to be advanced. The problems felt to be most acute on this occasion are social rather than esthetic, how ever. The impasses acknowledged and analyzed in these essays are likewise social and intellectual. A sense of breakdown is everywhere apparent in these essaysa sense of anxiety and dissatisfaction over the ways in which art has lately been thought about and written about and experienced.

title: Home Improvement
