description: ALL metal hardware around the inside and outside of the house, as well as the gutters, railings, windows, furniture, tools, toys and other items made of metal, are being con tinually subject to attack by rust or corrosion wherever they are the least bit exposed to a combination of both air and moisture. This attack can never be stopped entirely, but it can greatly be in hibited, and its costly effects minimized, by a program of regular preventive mainte ance which every homeowner should follow.

title: TV Drive to Tell Nonresident Alaskans About Claims Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  The Bureau of Indian Affairs plans to conduct a television and radio campaign to inform native Alaskans living in the continental United States about benefits they are entitled to under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act.

title: Religion
description: Missouri Synod Lutherans have al ways marched to their own distinct Germanic drum. Their 2.8 million member denomination, founded in the mid19th century by immigrants seek ing haven from the liberal rationalism that dominated religion in Europe, has lived in virtual isolation from the so cial and theological winds that have affected most Protestant churches.

title: Mailbox:
description: The most salutary result of the visit of the Russian hockey team may be the return of the National Hockey League to hockey. It is now evident that the game has been deterio rating into slap shots and junk goals with enough violence thrown in to keep the custom ers happy.

title: The Guest Word
description: As a friend of Alexander Solzhenitsyn and as the sister of his first wife N. A. Reshetovskaya, I would like to protest against the publication of the book Solzhenitsyn.  The book is being published against the will of the novelist, it is written in an irresponsible manner, and it can bring him direct harm.

title: Toledo Beats E. Michigan As Schwartz Excels, 160
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., Sept. 16 (AP)Joe Schwartz, the Toledo quarterback, ran for two touch downs today as the Rockets shut out Eastern Michigan, 160, to even both school's football wonlost records at 11 for the season.

title: Letters:
description: The beautifully written articles by Stephen Birnbaum and Thomas Glynn have had a powerful effect on me and my family. To read them at this season of the Jewish High Holy Days, and of the Munich Olympics, made the experi ence that much more poignant.

title: Dream Lives as Art Center
description: RICHMONDTOWN, S. I. For more than a quarter cen tury, the Jacques Marchais Center of Tibetan Art has served as a memorial to one woman with a dream.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: LONDONThe gulf in un derstanding between the American and the Western European sides in the current controversies about the fu ture shape of world economic relationships is probably wider than at any time since World War II.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: TORONTO, Sept. 16  China will begin its first reg ular shipping service to North America next year.

title: Pleads for Church Unity
description: UDINE, Italy, Sept. 16Pope Paul, addressing a huge crowd during the Italian Eucharistic Congress in this city near the Yugoslav frontier tonight, made an impassioned plea for world wide unity of the Roman Cath olic Church.

title: Suskie Ride Stalled Again
description: HACKENSACK  A dem onstration train ride to il lustrate the need for restoration of commuter service to New York on the Susquehanna Railroad has been postponed for a second time while the sponsoring or ganization incorporates as a nonprofit organization.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Sports of The Times

title: HOLY CROSS TOPS RUTGERS, 24 TO 14
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP)Joe Wilson, a fullback, set three Holy Cross rushing records and scored all three touchdowns as he led the Cru saders to a 2414 football vic tory over Rutgers today.

title: Israelis Report That Armored Force Is Holding Its Ground Within Lebanon
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 16  An Israeli armored force was re ported to be holding its ground several miles inside Lebanon tonight after a major assault north of the border.

title: YOM KIPPUR RITES SET FOR SUNDOWN
description: Yom Kippurthe Day of Atonement and the most sa cred day on the Hebrew re ligious calendarwill begin at sundown today with services in temples and synagogues.

title: After Heart Attacks, Rx in Bergen Is Gym Course
description: HACKENSACKWatch a gym full of middleaged men at the Bergen County Y.M. Y.W.H.A. and you would never suspect that they are all coronary patients  not until they pause to check their pulse rates.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 16 The North Korean Red Cross delegation left here for home today after attending the sec ond formal session of the North South talks to search for and reunite families separated by the division of Korea.

title: New &Novel
description: The hero of The Dis tant Laughter is a movie director which tips you off that this is a bitter, sardonic book. I can't remember a motion picture novel since Merton of the Movies that wasn't bitter and sardonic, un less it was Richard Condon's The Ecstasy Business  and that was sardonic but not bit ter.

title: MAGAZINE OFFERS A JEWISH FORUM
description: In the current issue of Sh'ma, a wellknown Orthodox rabbi accuses most of his colleagues of indifference to moral is sues like the suffering of vic tims of American bombing in Southeast Asia.

title: Letters:
description: I can only wonder at the tact and taste you demonstrated in publishing two articles, one warning all Jews to stay clear of Germany, the other provid ing a scenic tour through a Baltic con centration camp on the front page of the Travel and Resorts (!) section. And this while Germany was hosting the American team, among others, during the Olympic Games. One could further marvel at Mr. Birnbaum, the totally assimilated Jew, whose first meeting with a middleaged German provoked apocalyptic visions of the past. How indignant the American media would be if the West Germans expressed distaste for hosting the perpetrators of genocidal actions in Vietnam, or if the Japanese should see fit to print exhaustive articles on Hiroshima and Nagasaki the next time Americans participate in the Olympiad in Japan. One senses that the author was relieved he found nothing likable in West Germany, although, as he was a supposed businessman, this is hard to believe.

title: Nixon Has Edge Among Catholics Here
description: President Nixon's edge over Senator George McGovern in their race for President is greater among Roman Catho lics in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey than among Roman Catholics nationally.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A stepup in inspections of movie theaters in the city to end the widespread and growing violations of the nosmoking laws was announced yesterday by Fire Com missioner Robert O. Lowery. Mr. Lowery pointed out that smoking in theaters, except in designated sections, was a violation of the city's administrative code and punishable by a $500 fine, up to six months in jail, or both.

title: Lord Parker, 72, Chief Justice Of England 12 Years, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Sept. 16  Lord Parker, England's former Lord Chief Justice, died yesterday at his home near Shaftesbury in Dorsetshire. His age was 72.

title: BROOKS C. MARTIN
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 16 Brooks C. Martin, a director of the First Savings and Loan Association of Bloomfield and a former building inspector of Bloomfield, died yesterday in the Van Dike Nursing Home. He was 75 years old and lived at 334 Grove Street.

title: U.S. School Official Links Local Defeat To Black Minister
description: FORT DODGE, Iowa, Sept. 16 The president of the National School Board Associ ation, defeated for reelection to the Fort Dodge school board, attributes his defeat to the can didacy of a black minister who also lost in last week's election.

title: Princess Graustark Is Left at the Gate
Clifford P Senkpiel Weds Deirdre Poste
description: HASTINGS, N. Y., Sept. 16 Miss Deirdre Poste and Clifford P. Senkpiel, both of whom were graduated from Knox College, were married here this afternoon The Rev. George Kuhan performed the ceremony in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Shipyard Hiring 300
description: BOSTON, Sept. 18 (AP) The Boston Naval Shipyard is hiring more htan 300 mechanics and helpers as a result of an in creased workload at the yard, according to a union spokes man.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: The South is changing, ac cording to the child psychia trist Robert Coles (as quoted by reviewer Jonathan Yardley, in his comment on Coles's lat est book, Farewell to the South). Frankly, I don't think it is.

title: Reds Defeat Padres, 63

title: Letters:
description: As a Jewish Vietnam veteran, I read The End of Assimilation with an acute sense of anguish. The article so vividly reproduced in my mind one of my war experiences that, just as Birnbaum con cluded, I  sat back and cried. I offer you this experience in the hope that Jews across this country who agonized with the author will agonize with me and do something.

title: Mailbox:
description: Ilie Nastase hardly sets a good example in tennis court etiquette for budding champion ship tennis players, who are advised to watch matches. His conduct is in poor taste and dis tracting to his opponent, as well, who, in the contest exem plified the highest quality of good manners and sportsman ship. Cheers to Arthur Ashe!

title: Honey Jay Triumphs
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) Honey Jay, ridden by 52year old Robert Lee Baird, won the $33,2000 Snaro Handicap to day by a neck before 17,831 fans at Sportsman's Park.

title: The right to raise his voice
description: Certain critics, I. A. Richards says, treat us like Gulliver, first in the land of Lilliput, tied down by countless silken threads, and then suddenly a wondering dwarf in the palm of a giant Brobdingnagian. Patrick Cosgrave does that in his book on Robert Lowell. He offers at once a strong, even hostile, statement about modern poetry (Literature has been in general decline for a very long time.) and a network of minute and interesting, most often sympa thetic, discriminations about Lowell's verse. The two disposi tions, naturally, do not always support one another; the critic's instinctsit's an old story lead him down more interesting garden paths than his narrower prescripts allow him. As far as principles are concerned, Cos grave judges that the best po etry is public poetry, and that Lowell, almost uniquely among modern poets, has been moving toward a mastery of it. By pub lic poetry he means verse which analyzes and assesses the es sential quality and characteris tics of the life of [its] time. So, Lowell burns to judge men and affairs against an immuta ble and objective standard. The work is public, too, in a more obvious sense, in that much of it deals with the world of poli tics and public affairs.

title: Swedes Lose, 41, As Team Canada Preps for Soviet
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 16 (Reu ters)Team Canada, the Na tional Hockey League profes sionals, posted a 41 victory over Sweden's amateurs in their opening match in Europe tonight.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, Sept. 16A rickety wooden bridge jammed with Roman Catholic women and children celebrating the fes tival of their patron saint collapsed today, crushing to death or drowning at least 100 persons.

title: Love and violence, play and lust
description: The Rivers of Eros is a strange haunted novel based on a very old idea of how sin and damnation work. If you accept the idea it is also an effective novel. Colter is a skillful writer and his characters, even the minor ones are as vivid as any fictional people I have met lately.

title: Natase Gains Semifinal
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 16 (UPI) Ilie Nastase of Rumania will meet Jaime Fillol of Chile in the semifinals of the $25,000 Rainier international tennis classic.

title: WASHINGTON RACE LED BY GOV. EVANS
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 16Gov. Daniel J. Evans appears cer tain to be renominated on the Republican ticket in Washing ton primary election on Tues day. Mr. Evans, 46 years old, is seeking a third term.

description: LINCOLN CENTER, Mass., Sept 16Miss Priscilla Whit ney Scott, daughter of Mr. Mrs. Hermon Hosmer Scott, was married here this after noon to William Henry Coch rane Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cochrane of Lake Wales, Fla. title: F.B.I. Aide Demoted In a Mustache Dispute
description: EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 16 (UPI)  The special agent in charge in Los Angeles  the bureau's second largest field office  has been suspended for 25 days and demoted to head of the El Paso office for refusing to obey the order of L. Patrick Gray, acting di rector, to let agents wear mustaches, an F.B.I. spokes man says.

title: Few in Poll Back Weaker Controls; Many Dissatisfied
description: Although there is widespread dissatisfaction with the applica tion of President Nixon's wage and price controls, only a small percentage of the voting public favors weakening them, accord ing to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: Mich. State Beats Illinois
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 16 (AP)Bill Simpson, a corner back, scored touchdowns on a 48yard punt return and a 20yard pass interception run to lead Michigan State to a 240 victory over Illinois in a Big Ten football opener today.

description: The longplanned and contro versial Madison Avenue Mall will got a threemonth test, starting next March, as the first step toward an expected per manent mall, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., Sept. 16 (UPI)Don Taylor, a freshman who has not yet attended his first class, kicked a 29yard field goal in the fourth guar ter today to give Bowling Green a 1714 upset over Pur due.

The cardtable variety, though more quickly forgotten than the others, can be quite embarrassing at the time, especially in a team event. What is the best response in the post session discussion when one of your teammates challenges you in this fashion:

description: In the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Amanda Belknap Maugham was married to Thomas Ran dall Richards by the Rev. Dr. Victor L. Baer.

description: WASHINGTON  Probab ly it is naive to hope that issues will ever be debated in a political campaign in a way that will add to public understanding.

title: Miss Saylor Wed in Rye
description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 16The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Fyfe Saylor, assistant per sonnel manager with D'Arcy McManus International, an advertising agency in New York, to Thomas Nelson Erb, manager of budgets with the National Broadcasting Com pany, took place this after noon. The Rev. Dr. Joseph Bishop performed the cere mony in the Rye Presbyterian Church.

description: ON television recently I saw Alfred Hitchcock's film thriller set on a train, The Lady Vanishes, and as I had to travel to Los Angeles on business anyway, I thought why not via Amtrak? Here's the way Am trak and I went:

title: Books:
description: The merits of the adage to have and to hold are considerable, and appropri ately they come in for con siderable praise in this new book by Thomas W. Phelps. He is a former investment counselor, financial journalist and economist, so he brings fine credentials to his dis cussion of the stock market.

title: GRIFFITH DEFEATS DENUCCI ON POINTS
description: BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP) Emile Griffith, campaigning for another title shot at the age of 34, rallied after a cautious start to win a divided 10round decision from Joe DeNucci of Newton tonight.

title: Foe Reported to Open New Offensive South of Danang
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Sept. 17  Communist forces have begun an offensive in southern Quangngai Prov ince, south or Danang, with seven simultaneous attacks, American officials in Danang said yesterday.

title: A mirror held up to confusion
description: For half its length The Making of Black Revolution aries is a confident work, se cure in form and tone, com manding in its address to its materials. It opens with a suc cess story. A black youngster pressing his way up through hard times, bad breaks, down andout in Chicago and Missis sippi, surviving a beating by cops (on campus at the Univer sity of Southern California), a rejection letter from Chicago University's law school, grime and sweat among Fayette County sharecroppers, even an unpublished novel. The man has guts, application, aspira tion, and charm. (Forman was strongly built, Howard Zinn recalls in his SNCC (1964), handsome, with a big shock of curly hair, brown skin, an easy smile, and the features of an Indian.) He stays at his books, labors ceaselessly at selfdevel opment, and in his early thirties his people turn to him, recog nizing strength, and appoint him executive secretary of a new movement (the Southern NonViolent Coordinating Com mittee, S.N.C.C.). The reader applauds, grateful that talent gets what it deserves; a life story's first chapter is done.

title: Iona Beats St. Peter's, 257, As Crucet Scores Twice
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 16 Iona posted a 257 victory over St. Peter's College tonight. Al Crucet scored two touchdowns and Richie Paulis and Jim Wil liams one apiece for the Gaels.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The history of a nisei who became a nonperson, poised between the America of his birth and the Japan of his ancestry. At the age of 19, in 1941, Yoshida and his family went to Japan to deposit his father's ashes. Relations be tween Japan and the U.S. worsened, and they were unable to get a ship back. Two years later Yoshida was conscripted into the Japanese Army and served in China. His memories of the brutal treatment enlisted men received as a matter of routine are painfully vivid. After the war he returned to Japan, worked for the Occupation forces, and when the Korean conflict broke out volunteered to serve with an MP outfit as a kind of penance for having fought on the side of his coun try's enemy. After a long legal battle his American citizenship was restored in a precedent setting case. This is a touching story about one man's love of country.

title: Recordings
description: IT was noted last week that either because of a process of getting accus tomed to the sound prob lems of the Seraphim Der Ring des Nibelungen (derived from a series of Rome broad casts Wilhelm Furtwngler made in 1953) or because of all ?? improvement as the end of Die Walkre nears, one is gradually less and less put off by the set's tech nical limitations, especially if lengthy listening sessions are the chosen way of experienc ing this Ring. But I think there can be no doubt that Siegfried and Die Gtterdm merung are definitely more acceptable.

title: Videotape Is Used For Traffic Safety
description: MORRISTOWNSix mem bers of the Traffic Safety Bureau here have been refin ing their moviemaking tech niques this summer by taking videotapes of youngsters jaywalking and committing safety violations on bicycle and foot.

title: the traveler's world
description: A FASCINATING phenomenon of trav el is the way, after being away from home and office for a month or so, you expect everything to be different, and every year at sum mer's end there comes the shocking realization at the end of the first day back at work that nothing has changed. The first few breaths of Manhattan air proved not acceptable to my lungs but in my absence no one had devised a practical alternative to breathing un acceptable air.

title: Susan Cyr Married
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 16 Miss Susan Cyr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Paul Cyr of Plainfield, was married here this afternoon to John F. MacLaren, a commercial air lines pilot serving as chief corporate pilot for Medcom, Inc. He is the son of Mrs. Marie MacLaren of Teaneck. The Rev. John McGovern per formed the ceremony in St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Given adversity, women can do anything
description: It is hard to think of a work at once more encouraging and depress ing than this collection of some thir teenhundred life stories. The stories prove that women can do practically anything; and they prove that so far, they tend to be pushed to do it only by awful adversity or, on the other hand, by spinsterhood.

title: New &Novel
description: Murgatreud's Empire is one of those little satires that might have been written in the 1930's, when the merchants ofdeath theory was a popular simplification of the nature of war. Bamber Gascoigne recon stitutes a microcosm of histor ical dialectic in the jungles of New Guinea, where a mons trous, gumchewing superspiv named Murgatreud crashes his airplane in pygmy territory. Forthwith, the unspeakable en trepreneur introduces his tribal hosts to the escalating require ments of an arms race.

title: 2HITTER BY BLUE WINS FOR A'S, 40
description: OAKLAND, Sept. 16 (AP) Vida Blue pitched his first vic tory since Aug. 13 today, yield ling two hits as the Oak land A's beat the Texas Rangers, 40.

description: BOMBAY, Sept 16 (Canadian Press)A survey is under way in India to find forgotten he roesthe man who took an active part in the fight against British colonial rule.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Service on the New Yorkto Boston turbotrains will be increased from one to two roundtrips a day starting Oct. 1, Secretary of Trans portation John A. Volpe an nounced yesterday.

title: The Munich Olympics:
description: The disgusting, insulting display of vulgarity and dis courtesy put on by Matthews and Collett was a discredit to America. The request by Clifford Buck for the I.O.C. to rescind its ban is also a discredit to America.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: In the pitiably small number of admirable books about New York City's past, Bruce Bliven Jr.'s The Battle of Manhattan, published in 1956, stands out like a little gem. This longer, more ambitious volume covers the 13 months preceding that, critical military engagement June 1775 to July 1776, when New Yorkers were trying to make up their minds whether their grievances against George III were galling enough to just ify independence. With British warships cruising the harbor capable of burning the town with a few fire bombs, with an amiable governor named William Tryon holding the line for the British and an overly ambitious, ineffectual Con tinental general named Charles Lee trying to strengthen the Rebels' military position around Manhattan, New Yorkers had good reason to be irresolute.

title: Linda Kaznova Wed To David H. Johnston
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16Miss Linda Christine Kaznova, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) Davis and Elkins opened its soccer season here today by losing, 21, to the defending National Collegiate champion, Howard University.

title: Feed Mix Order Protested
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) Three companies are seeking a Federal court review of a Food and Drug Administration order withdrawing approval of a compound that promotes growth in sheep and cattle. The companies said yesterday they had petitioned the United States Court of Appeals in Washington to determine whether the withdrawal of ap proval to manufacture animal feed premixes containing die thylstilbestrol (DES) was legal and scientifically sound. The three companies are Cheme tron Corporation, Chicago; Hess & Clark, a division of Rhodia, Inc., Ashland, Ohio, and Dawes Laboratories, Inc., Chicago.

title: Atamps
description: STAMP  ISSUING pro grams for 1973 are shaping up in a num ber of countries. Post master General E. T. Classen has revealed several items for the United States Postal Service. Britain, Canada and New Zealand, among others, have projected plans for next year, and there will be a newcomer, toothe Isle of Man (see below).

title: Chromosome Passports For All Forecast by Experts
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 16 (Agence FrancePresse)Scien tists here forecast this week that before long every person would carry a chromosome passport issued at birth by a computerized machine.

title: ExF.B.I. Agent Named As Bugging Case Witness
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Government's chief witness in its justcompleted investiga tion of the Democratic head quarters bugging is reported to be a former agent for the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation who transcribed tape record ings of bugged telephone calls while working as a security guard for President Nixon's re election committee.

title: Photography
description: IT may seem farfetched, to compare the photographs of Ansel Adams (on view at the Witkin Gallery through Oct. 8) with the paintings of J. M. W. Turner. But it is not farfetched to compare them with the paint ings of the 19th century American landscapist Thomas Moran, whose avowed am bition was to paint Turner's from nature.

title: Heroin, Weapons and $164,000 Seized in Two Raids in Brooklyn
description: The New York Drug Task Force seized $164,000 in cash and more than $300,000 in uncut heroin and an assortment of weapons in two raids late Fri day night in Brooklyn apart ments, Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts reported yes terday.

title: At last, the French catch up
description: Parisian Marc Held, whose furniture will be shown in this country late this month, is one of the significant inno vators on the French design scene. Held and others like him who are com mitted to modern design have had more difficulty gaining acceptance for their work than Italian designers (whose government takes an active in terest) or Scandinavians (who have a public predisposed to contemporary design). Held, however, seems to thrive on resistance. When he was 11, he ran messages for the World War II Re sistance. In 1964, he encountered an other sort of resistance when he opened a boutique for modern design called l'choppe. Everyone had ad vised against the venture. But he was vindicated. Parisians soon crowded into the tiny shop, which is well es tablished today. (Held chats with a passerby out front, right.) Unfortunately, the fight to popularize good de sign brought Held close to bankruptcy. He had to move into a lowincome housing project and dodge creditors for months. All to realize his vision: to search out new materials and shapes, to simplify construction and manufacturing, to bring modern design into everyone's reach by low ering costs. Typical of Held's simplify ing is his bed, which incorporates bed, night table and lamp in a single unit, and his chairs, which swivel and rock without any mechanism or moving parts. New design, he says, comes only from a new concept of function or a new technology. The beanbag chair is one of the few true innova tions in years. And what is France's role in the design of the future? After the neorusticism of Scandinavia and the Italian plastic fantasia, perhaps there is a need for French equilibrium, Held speculates confidently.

title: School Bells Ring
description: SATURDAY morning class es begin this week at the New York Botani cal Garden, Bronx Park, N.Y. Winterizing Your Gar den taught by Frederick Marshall will start at 10 A.M. in the administration build ing. The fee is $15, for three morning lessons.

title: If You Go
description: from New York to Los An geles by train in a through car, you have two route choices: by way of Kansas City, Mo., which is how the author did it, or by way of New Orleans. Until last Sunday the Kansas City route offered the advantages of daily service and a layover of only 35 minutes when schedules were met. Now there is still daily service, but the layover is nine and one half hours, during which time pas sengers can, in the words of an Amtrak spokesman, use the rail road car as their hotel or go into town for a Kansas City steak.

description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 16 Haynes V. Huffard, who retired as director of purchases for Union Carbide Corporation in 1957, died today at his home, 9 Stephen Mather Road. He was 78 years old.

title: ACCLIMATIZATION WINS U.N. STAKE

With Carlos Barrera riding the Nelson Bunker Hunt representa tive, Acclimatization negotiated the firm turf course in 1:54 while beating his nearest rival, Dubassoff, by 1 lengths. A field of 13 competed.

title: A radio station with real hair, sweat and body odor

After playing an excerpt from Mozart's Magic Flute, Josephson pulled off his earphones and bent to the floor, explaining to his audience, I am on the floor, good people, search ing for a news clipping about the Pope's opposition to the notion of a human Jesus.

title: The Munich Olympics:
description: In view of an Olympiad marked by the obscenities of nationalism, which infected almost every aspect of these socalled games and which culminated in the hideous murder of the Israeli athletes, I wish to express my revul sion of the boorish huck sterism of commercial tele vision in which everything that happened at Munich be came links of sausage to be dangled for the ultimate goal of selling cars, insurance, shaving cream, etc.

Each class or workshop will meet for 12 weeks, and reg istration will be conducted at the school on Mondays through Thursddys from 7 to 9 P.M. For more information call (212) GR 56200.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: After reading To Live Rent Free, Be a House Sitter [Aug. 27] one can merely marvel at the gullibility of homeowners. Eric Broudy is certainly not reticent about detailing the disasters that followed in his wake. Why this horrendous record had no appreciable effect as he sought out other locations (which, in turn, also became disaster areas) puzzles me. Has it become oldfashioned to demand references of those who seek to occupy one's premises?

title: Harvard's Peabody Museum Establishes Its Own Press
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP)Harvard University's Pea body Museum of Archeology and Ethnology has established the Peabody Museum Press for its Publications Department, the museum's director, Prof. Stephen Williams, announced today.

title: A model, clockworkorange prison
description: JESSUP, Md.: The Patuxent Institution for Defec tive Delinquents is widely considered a model rehabilitative prison and a showplace of enlight ened penology. At Patuxent (named for a nearby river), inmates are called patients, which means that they are here not to be punished but to be cured. Patuxent's director, Dr. Harold M. Bos low, a properly benign gentleman with a soft pink face, sweptback white hair and glasses that slide down his nose, is a psychiatrist. Two of the three associate directors are behavioral scientists, and for a prison population of about 400, there are more than 40 psychiatrists, psychologists and social workers on the staff. To use a phrase I heard there frequently in interviews, Patuxent is more a thera peutic community than a prison.

title: Navy Beats W. and M.
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 16 (AP)  Fred Stuvek, a quarter back capped an 81yard Navy drive today with a twoyard run for a touchdown that de feated William and Mary, 139. The score came with 34 sec onds of play remaining.

title: BUSING BOYCOTT SET IN LAS VEGAS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 16 Elementary schools will open here Monday amid a contro versy over a $1.5million busing plan.

title: Typhoon Kills 13 in Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 16 (UPI)A typhoon struck Japan's Pacific coast today, killing at least 13 persons, the national police said. One person was missing and 13 were known to be seri ously injured by the typhoon, which hit the main island of Honshu.

title: NO. CAROLINA TOPS MARYLAND, 3126
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 16 (AP)Dick Oliver's 1yard touchdown with six mniutes re maining today provided the winning margin for North Carolina as the defending At lantic Coast Conference football champions barely held off un derdog Maryland, 3126.

title: SPANISH COLLEGES RESIST DISCIPLINE
description: MADRID, Sept. 16Tough Government measures to re store discipline in universities in Madrid and other Spanish cities are beginning to backfire with mass resignations of uni versity officials.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Jesus Christ Superstar tells the story of Christ from the point of view of Judas. Sup pose a Dead Sea scroll is found and authenticated as be ing the words of Judas him self. And suppose it presents a somewhat different story from the Authorized Version. Suppose Peter, not Judas, was the traitor, and that Peter had framed Judas, and that Jesus was, in a way, not unlike the leader of a hippie commune as described in Superstar.

title: FUTURITY IS WON BY SECRETARIAT
description: Meadow Stable's Secretariat, a 2yearold son of Bold Ruler, triumphed in the $144,200 Fu turity at Belmont Park yester day in an easydoesit per formance that lived up to the expectations of chalk players in the crowd of 34,248. They had sent the colt off as the $2.40 for$2 choice.

title: Art
description: AT the turn of the cen tury, many Americans mistakenly believed that a major work of art had to be large, on canvas and painted in oil. Conse quently, drawings, especially those by U.S. artists, became the Cinderellas of a collec tion, remaining hidden and ignored. But as tastes broad ened, Americans began to realize the wisdom of that great draftsman Ingres who said, The integrity of art lies in drawing.

title: Social Announcements
description: Confirmations

title: Theater: Bread and Puppet Troupe
description: Revenge of the Law, an eightact play by The Bread and Puppet Theater, is an eightpanel tragicstripa se quence of pictures framed in a box set. Wearing bulbous masks, the actors may look like cartoon figures (there are also a few peoplesize puppets on strings), but the play they are performing is as earnest and as mournful as a dirge.

title: Yale Names Bettendorf
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 16 (AP) Ed Bettendorf, Yale's swimming captain three years ago, was appointed an assistant swim ming coach today.

title: FULLBACKS PACE BUCKEYE ATTACK
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 16 (AP)Ohio State overcame ear ly mistakes and resorted to a bruising fullback attack today to whip stubborn Iowa, 210, in a Big Ten football opener.

title: Love and violence, play and lust
description: In addition to being a very good novel, The Heart's Grown Brutal is an excellent primer for those who've forgot ten and for others who never knew how the present bloody struggle in Northern Ireland began. It is complexed enough to satisfy those who never real ly believed that mid20thcen tury Europeans were taking their Protestantism and Cath olicism seriously enough to kill each other over. What we learn here is that any news report that gives the lineup as Cath olics on one side, Protestants on the other and British troops in the middle as peace keepers and targets is terribly over simplified.

title: Composer Looks Back on Life
description: LONG BEACH, L. I.When a man is 79 years old, he has more of life to look back on than to look forward to. There are exceptions, of course, and Elmo Russ, a 79 yearold bachelor, is one of them.

title: Housing Units Dip in Brooklyn
description: Despite a scattering of new housing projects, there was an overall loss of 2,000 dwelling units in the last dec ade in three sprawling Plan ning Districts south of Atlan tic Avenue in Brooklyn.

title: Miss Wear Fiancee Of Peter M. Farrell
description: UNION CITY, N. J., Sept. 16Mr. and Mrs. James S. Wear have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Prudence Hartzler Wear, to Peter Michael Far rell, son of Eugene Farrell of Bloomfield, and the late Mrs. Farrell.

title: Girls to Fashion Scouting Plans
description: FAIRVIEWTwentyseven thousand Bergen County girls will put a new concept of Girl Scouting to a test when their congress, the only one of its kind in the country, meets next month.

title: The Munich Olympics:
description: In the final Olympic bas ketball game between the United States and U.S.S.R., did Coach Hank Iba call time out to remind his team of the long thrownin pass? If not, why not?

title: Love and violence, play and lust
description: The Trial of Christopher Okigbo is the story of Hamisi, a Kenyan Muslim, who is killed in an automobile accident and finds himself in a place called AfterAfrica, a world beyond the grave that combines the best of Christian, Muslim and traditional African versions of heaven. Though we get only suggestions of what it is like there, this setting remains the most memorable feature of this fine little novel.

title: Davidson Triumphs, 1814, Over Va. Military Institute
description: LEXINGTON, Va., Sept. 16 (AP)Two fumble recoveries by a defensive end, Jack Stultz, and a 67yard punt return by Dave Ingold set up 16 points today and they were all David son's Wildcats needed to hold off Virginia Military Institute's Keydets, 1814, in a Southern Conference football game.

title: Beef Prices Steady Except for Sales
description: Many beef items were sold at reduced prices in special sales last week in food stores in the New York and Hartford areas, where state price re porters check week by week on food prices.

title: The Nation
description: It was Attica Week, perfectly or chestrated: The final factfinding re port published on the first annivers ary of the slaughter; simultaneous publication of a paperback version re plete with gory photos; a 90minute television report broadcast nationally. Other commissions had released their findings quietly only to have them ignored; the McKay Commission, ap pointed by the state's ranking judges and charged by Governor Rockefeller with sorting out what happened in the bloody fiveday prison rebellion last September, wanted its findings remembered.

title: Elaine Mattie Has Nuptials
description: BRAINTREE, Mass., Sept. 16Dr. Elaine Marie Mattie, a resident in pediatrics at St. Christopher's Hospital in Philadelphia, and Capt. Peter Reist McCombs, U.S.A. title: Yes, There Are Sacred Cows And Yes, There Should Be
description: LATE next month the new Uris Theater building will be opening on the site of the old Capitol, and somewhere along its in terior walls there is going to be a Theater Hall of Fame, a roster of distinguished per formers, writers, directors and producers whose individ ual careers, one way or an other, spanned a period of 25 years. A committee was formed a while back to win now out the presumed greats from the presumed near greats; it came up with a list of 95, a list which, needless to say, satisfied no one.

title: Returns to Rome
description: ROME, Sept. 16Pope Paul returned here from Udine by air tonight after a 16hour, 600  mile journey through northern Italy.

title: Fall Planting
description: ALTHOUGH I have grown roses for more than half a century, I con tinue to be surprised by their resilience. Too often thought fragile and demand ing, roses are actually tough, surviving most vicissitudes and producing, in proportion to time required, more bloom than any other plant.

Ham mond, assistant general manager of the Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) District, which last week put into service 28 miles of the first new mass transit system in the United States in more than half a century. After, all, Mr. Hammond went on to ex plain, We want people to know that the train has come into the station.

Kennedy today of setting up the Democratic Presidential nominee, Senator George McGovern, by appearing with the South Dakotan in campaign stops earlier this week. Mr. Scott, who partici pated in a Republican voter canvassing drive here, added that Senator Kennedy was working for his own candidacy in 1976.

Henry Ford 2d predicted sales of more than 11 million cars for the 1973 model year. Auto sales in the first 10 days of September fell to 103,697 units from 165,010 a year before.

title: Fashion's higher mathematics
description: Mix and match and doyourown thing are the rules of this game. The woman with a clever eye for line and color can turn three cos tumes into ninewithout even trying. For instance, that yellow topper cut like a smock (at the far left on the facing page) is strik ing with its own oxford gray pants. It would be equally dramatic with the black pants (center) and take on a fresh look with the gray checked pants. A clutch of ac cessories will increase the varia tions to a mindboggling infinity.

description: SINGAPORE, Sept. 16 (AP) Ramanathan Krishnan of India beat Somparn Champisri of Thailand, 60, 61, 60, today in a semifinal match of the Asian invitation tennis cham pionship. In the other semifinal Eduardo Cruz of the Philippines upset Condo Widjojo of Indo nesia, 61, 64, 64.

title: New York
description: Now it's instant campaigns. Repre sentative John J. Rooney and Allard K. Lowenstein will be doing a second take, Tuesday, on their contest for the Democratic Congressional nomin ation in Brooklyn's 14th District. The campaign will have lasted a full seven days.

title: Grow Some Nut Trees For a Ripe Crunchy Harvest
description: TREES that bear edible nuts have a place in the home orchard, the large home landscape or the ancestral acres on which you pay taxes and retreat to on weekends. They provide snacks in flavors not avail able at your local super market and are attractive for shade and ornamental.

title: Pirate Magic Number 3 as Cards Win on Santorini 8Hitter, 40
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (UPI) St. Louis erupted for four runs in the fifth inning today to back the eighthit pitching of Al San torini en route to a 40 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Meanwhile, Boy Scouts Are Training Future Leaders
description: MENDHAMFor poten tial executives of the Boy Scouts from the world over, all roads wind initially to ward the Schiff Scout Res ervation  508 acres of gentle, wooded hillsides sur rounding this Morris Coun ty town.

title: Letters:
description: The gratitude and good wishes of every serious Sherlockian must be ex tended to Leslie Magoon for her de lightful and accurate article on the Holmes Museum at Chateau de Lucens in Switzerland (Travel section, Aug. 20).

title: Peter O'Toole, From Lawrence To La Mancha
description: I WAS sort of the Van essa Redgrave of the fifties, says the slightly disheveled man slouching Into a hotel chair. True, he's tall, good looking, and has blue eyes, but you'd never in a million years mistake him for yan essa Redgrave. And there's another performer you'd nev er mistake him for: sporting a graying beard, shaggy dark hair, drably casual clothes, and nonmoviestar glasses which fail to conceal the bags beneath his bleary baby blues, he bears scant resem blance to that golden matinee idol of a few seasons back, Peter O'Toole.

title: LEGAL AID GROUP BACKS PEDDLERS
description: The constitutionality of the city's regulations of street ped dlers, who are the target of a new crackdown by the Police Department, is being chal lenged by the Legal Aid Society in a suit defending the right of a 30yearold artist to sell his works on the city's side walks.

title: Jewish Workers Backed
description: OAKLAND, Calif, Sept. 16 (UPI)Jews working for the State of California can take off Yom Kippur on Monday and may get paid for it. Alameda County Superior Court Judge Robert L. Bostick made the rul ing yesterday and said he would hear arguments Oct. 19 on whether Jewish employes are entitled to a paid holiday on Yom Kippur as Christians are on Good Friday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 16 Joseph F. Stautner registered a 5minute Luders16 Class vic tory with Undine on Long Is land Sound today, in the sea son's 37th championship re gatta for Yacht Racing Associa tion fleets based EastofRye. Undine finished the 5.1mile course a quarterofamile ahead of the second place craft.

title: Chess: Olympics Offers a Chance For Lively Experimentation
description: The number of entries in the biennial Chess Olympics has grown steadily in the last 20 years and, in the last Olympics, in Siegen, Ger many, in 1970, 60 countries were represented. There prob ably will be more than 60 countries in the event that starts tomorrow in Skopje, Yugoslavia.

title: Queens Nine Splits Pair
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 16Sal Rizzo pitched a 70 fourhitter for New York Tech against Queens College in the opener of a doubleheader to day. Richie Miner drove in three runs with two hits. In the second game, Queens won, 92, on the strength of a grand slam homer by Ron Vassil in the sixth inning.

title: The Munich Olympics:
description: If American athletes, their coaches, trainers doctors and managers can't be good los ers (Bob Seagren), can't tell time (Coach Wright and his sprinters), can't be bothered complying with medical rules that other nations' teams adapt themselves to (the De Mont case), and can't bring themselves to meet the ex pected standards of deport ment (Matthews and Collett), then what are they doing at the Olympic Games?

title: Letters:
description: I did not expect the emotional shock I received from the two accounts. I am not a strictly practicing Jew, but I do hold a sense of Jewish pride and an innate fear that it can happen again. Reading Mr. Birnbaum's description of the everpresent Germanic psyche and the feelings he underwent in today's new Germany, I felt renewed com munion with all my Jewish sisters and brothers. To assimilate is to finish the job Hitler's ovens again. Both articles served as a reminder that the Holy Days are not merely holidays but days for thought, pride and atonement.

title: Miss Butler Is Wed on L.I.
description: ISLIP, L. I., Sept. 16Miss Marianna Linda Butler, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Butler, was married this afternoon to Anthony Steven Kaufmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kaufmann of Brookville and New York. The Rev. Oscar Daley per formed the ceremony in the Islip Presbyterian Church.

title: Miss Linda Margaret Hiddemen Is Bride of Nils Hartley Wessell
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 Miss Linda Margaret Hid demen was married here to day to Nils Hartley Wessell. The bride has chosen to be known from now on as Mrs. HiddemenWessell.

title: Toni Kruman Plans Bridal
description: DEAL, N. J., Sept. 16 Mayor and Mrs. Daniel Kru man have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Toni Kruman, to Bruce Rubin of Jamaica Estates, Queens, New York. The wed ding is planned on Dec. 23.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe long awaited indictments in the Watergate raid were handed up last week by a Fed eral grand jury in Washington. As President Nixon and various other Republicans had forecast, no one presently employed by the Admin istration was mentioned.

title: Meryl Cohen Engaged
description: JERICHO, L. Sept. 16 Miss Meryl Paula Cohen, a sophomore at Johns Hopkins University, and Bruce T. Gardner, a junior at American University in Washington, plan to be married in Decem ber of next year. Mr. and Mrs. Cohen have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Gardner. Mr. Cohen is a partner in the New York law firm of Langer, Beaudet, Cantor & Cohen. Mr. Gardner is treasurer of Rocke feller Center in New York.

title: GREENWICH BEATS NEW CANAAN, 100
description: The experts had picked Stam ford and New Canaan High Schools to be the two strongest teams again in Fairfield County. Stamford, defending state and Fairfield county interscholastic association champion, won 266 fr omDarien yesterday as pre dicted, but Greenwich proved the expert wrong by upsetting New Canaan, 100.

title: American Pianist Wins Leeds Fete
description: LONDON, Sept. 16Murray Perahia, a 25yearold pianist from New York City, playing in the final against two fellow Americans, won first prize to night at the Leeds International Piano Festival.

title: What's In The Cards For Carmen?
description: THE elevated orchestra pit, a mismatched mess of music stands and swivel chairs, virtually eclipses the chaotic proceedings on stage, where choris ters listen to the piercing, accented voice of the gaunt, longhaired director: Leaping about like a chor eographed demon, he attempts to show them where and how to stand. It is a tedious and repetitive busi ness, but tempers are under control. Even the mighty principals are patient and goodhumored.

title: GEORGIA DEFEATS STUBBORN BAYLOR
description: ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 16 (AP) A reserve quarterback, James Ray, threw a 55yard third period touchdown pass and ig nited a sluggish Georgia offense as the 16thranked Bulldogs struggled to a 2414 victory over the Baylor Bears in a foot ball opener for both teams today.

title: Rerun of N.F.L.'s Longest Day
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 16A few minutes past 1 o'clock tomorrow, New York time, there will be kickoffs in Foxboro, Mass., Buffalo, Cleveland and Pittsburgh. The National Football League's 53d season will be under way. Three hours later they will start game here between the Kansas City Chiefs and Miami Dolphins, matching the teams that played for 82 minutes 40 seconds last Christmas Day in the longest and one of the best pro foot ball games of all time (won by Miami, 2724). This one will be telecast nation ally and can be seen in New York over Channel 4 (4 P.M.).

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Sept. 16  About a dozen volunteers sat around a nar row table in a cavernous room that still bore the signs of its former function, a shoe store, Whites from the sub urbs of Menlo Park and blacks from the ghettos of East Palo Alto, they sipped coffee from plastic cups and plotted how to elect Senator George McGovern as Presi dent.

title: GROMYKO BIDS U.N. DISCUSS ARMS BAN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16 (AP)The Soviet Union has proposed that the United Nations General As sembly discuss the permanent prohibition of nuclear weapons and the renunciation of force in international relations.

title: A RISE IN U.S. HELP TO AGED FORESEEN
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept, 16 Wilbur J. Cohen, who helped draft the original Social Se curity Act of 1935, predicted here this week that poverty can, should and will be elimi nated among our senior citizens within the next five to 10 years.

title: Kentucky Routs Villanova
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 16 (AP)Kentucky, behind the brilliant quarterbacking of a junior college transfer, Dinky McKay, defeated stubborn Vil lanova today, 257.

title: F.B.I. Police Symposium
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation will sponsor a na tional symposium on police community relations starting tomorrow at the new training facilities in Quantico, Va.

title: Charlie and the Great Glass Elevator
description: Charlie and the Chocolate Fac tory turned out to be one of those things children have in common, like Silly Putty or Plastic Goop. Some librarians, I'm told, took a dim view of Charlie. They thought it was disrespectful of the old, or the poor'or something. But, of course, children love breathless, runon stories that have the air of being improvised on the spotRoald Dahl started writing for children by making up bedtime stories for his own kidsand so Charlie became a triumphant best seller, an integral part of the lore and language of this generation of chil dren. Justice was served. Millions and a moviewere made. And a sequel was inevitable.

title: Music
description: AND now, once againPrelude, and curtain up on A square in Se ville Enter, wearing a hope ful smile, the Metropolitan Opera, to begin its 197273 season on Tuesday night with a new Carmen, the pro duction that was to have been Goeran Gentele's artistic debut in New York. No matter how many new seasons or new Carmens we have sat through, we find ourselves itchingly curious, like King Shahriyar in the grip of Sche herazade, to know what comes next. Triumph? Disaster? Orworst of all something in between?

title: New York
description: For the first time since she gave birth Sept. 3, the proud mother showed off her baby to visitors last week. Pho tographers were welcomed  in fact, whenever one walked away, the mother rewarded him with an angry glare. Though she kept the infant close to her, she was obviously de lighted by any attentions it received  to the point of lying on the floor and kicking her legs with joy.

title: Oakland to
description: THIS is the view from the train, en route from Oakland, Calif., to Denver: A small boy building a shack with tarpaulin and wood  a onestory house on pilings, north of Rodeo, Calif., with a sign in white paint: Scow Town, Pop. 2  the bay, which we skirt as we snake north.

title: Books: How Many Miles to Camelot?
description: HOW MANY MILES TO CAMELOT? by Jerry Izen berg, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, Inc., 227 pages, $6.95.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: Advertising to children much resembles a tug of war between 200pound men and 60pound youngsters.

title: REGISTRATION BID DENIED IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16  In another skirmish in his battle to register more black voters, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson yes terday lost his first attempt to keep special registration places in Chicago's 50 wards open for 10 more days.

title: Why Jacques Can't Write
description: When French children go to school they learn they are the heirs of a culture every foreigner envies, and speak a language that has no civilized equal. A notion of cultural superior ity gradually enters their minds from about the TinTin age level, and often becomes an assurance barbar ians find rather tiresome. However, it is all very innocent, for it will seldom be put to a test, particular ly by any extensive reading of for eign literature.

title: Barker Takes Title
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Sept. 16Bob Barker of Sands Point, L. I., captured the East ern tennis championship for men 35 years and over today by overwhelming Bob Greene of New York in the final, 61, 61.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: D. Keith Mano's dismissal of B. Traven's novel, The Rebel lion of the Hanged, is most provoking to readers like my self  who are familiar with Traven's stark books dealing with the feudal peonage of the Amerindians.

title: Freshman Passer Plays Key Role for Wolfpack
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 16 (AP)  A freshman quarterback, Dave Buckey, scored one touch down, passed for another and set up a third with a 57yard run tonight as North Carolina State routed Syracuse, 4320, in an intersectional football game.

title: Looking for the Family Tree in Wales, and Getting Stumped
description: HAVERFORDWEST, Wales  The taxi driver who took me from the station to my hotel was as gray as the weather but much, much drier. Have you lived in Haver fordwest long? I asked, anxious to get right into my tickertape welcome.

title: Ship in Crash Being Towed
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Sept. 16 (AP)The disabled freighter Republica de Colombia, her midships gouged out when the freighter TransHawaii rammed her Thursday off the North toward Norfolk, Va., today. The TransHawaii, under her own power, arrived in Balti more about 6 P.M. today and berthed at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation Key Highway yard.

title: Phils Top Expos, 31
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP)A rookie third baseman, Mike Schmidt, hit a threerun homer in the seventh inning to night to snap Balor Moore's scorelessinning streak at 25 and give the Philadelphia Phil lies a 31 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: 31 TEAMS TO PLAY P.S.A.L. FOOTBALL
description: Public Schools Athletic League football, once a steadily declining sport in New York City because of the lack of playing fields and the high cost of maintaining teams, has made a turnabout. It has become just about the fastest growing sport among the 13 P.S.A.L. sponsors.

title: Face to Face With the Junkies
description: IN America, Black art grows and grows. Goes through changes and whatnot. Is a schizophre nic form in Its continuing ability to be alternately a conformist and an outlaw ex pression, as with the work of Leontyne Price on the one hand and that of Charlie Park er on the other. (Which is not about better and worse, just about difference.)

title: Tulsa Downs Wichita State On Late Field Goal, 109
description: TULSA, Okla., Sept. 16 (UPI) Sam Henry booted a 36yard field goal with five minutes to go today that gave Tulsa a 109 victory over Wichita State. The Wheatshockers' attempt to re gain the lead on a field goal, with 20 seconds left, failed.

title: WALL STREET
description: It's no secret that mutual funds are big swingers in the stock market and that their buying and selling can have an important influence on the trend in stock prices  especially for individual issues.

title: Town's Police Come and Go
description: PINE BEACH  This tiny Ocean County municipality may get its first fulltime po lice force soon, the aftermath of a dispute that led to the resignation of the entire part time force.

title: DIVERSITY MARKS VENICE MUSIC FETE
description: VENICE, Italy, Sept 15It's not a contemporary opera, it's a personal statement, said Mauricio Kagel the Cologne based composer, following the world premiere of Sylvano Bus sotti's opera, Lorenzaccio.

title: U.S. Buys Finnish Device To Detect Arms at Airfields
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 16 (AP)A Finnish mining firm has sold 100 weapons detector devices to the United States Federal Aviation Administra tion, according to company of ficials.

title: Horse Show News
description: In the Olympic Games of 1960, 1964 and 1968, the United States Equestrian Team's Prix des Nations (jumping) squad was regard ed as a serious contender for the gold medal.

title: Puppeteer, At 16, Pulls Strings Like Old Hand
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.  Peter is a very unusual per son. He has a dedication and singularity of purpose that is really amazing.

title: Two Ways to Win a Race
description: Aesop's fables are fair game for people who write children's books: no copyright; no cries of pain from the author if you twist his meaning.

title: Wittenberg 197 Loser
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 16 (AP)Two bad snaps from center and a fumbled punt re turn undid Wittenberg Univer sity today as it lost a 197 Ohio Valley Conference football con test to Western Kentucky.

title: WILLIAM M. WILLY
description: ROSENDALE, N. Y., Sept. 16 William Mladek Willy, ban quet manager at the RitzCarl ton, WaldorfAstoria and Pierre Hotels in New York for more than 50 years, died here Thurs day at the age of 78. He lived at Stokes Point.

title: Letters:
description: In the article on locomotive spotting (Travel section, Aug. 13) you mentioned that Amtrak had recommended our book From Zephyr to Amtrak as being of interest to railroad enthusiasts. Its cost was given as $7.50, but that was the prepublication price. Its cost now is $9.50.

title: Jewish Workers Backed
description: OAKLAND, Calif, Sept. 16 (UPI)Jews working for the State of California can take off Yom Kippur on Monday and may get paid for it. Alameda County Superior Court Judge Robert L. Bostick made the rul ing yesterday and said he would hear arguments Oct. 19 on whether Jewish employes are entitled to a paid holiday on Yom Kippur as Christians are on Good Friday.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A detailed account of how 12 volunteers from the 1st Mar ine Division helped the South Vietnamese liberate the village of Binh Nghia from the Viet cong during 17 months of 1966 67. The author, formerly a Marine captain, went along on night patrols during the action and recorded actual dialogue. He also did extensive in terviewing with villagers and surviving American partici pants. As he himself says, this is not a political book or a critique of national policy; it is rather a story of dedicated, courageous men  American and Vietnamese  undergoing the rigors of guerrilla warfare.

title: N.C.A.A. BARS 2 IN SOCCER RULING
description: The National Collegiate Ath letic Association last week de clared two Hartwick College soccer players ineligible for the 197273 season because they participated in unauthorized competition. About a dozen other players from various col leges in New York may be penalized under the same rule.

title: Eileen C. Shields To Marry Dec. 16
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Albert Shields of Jamaica Estates, Queens, of the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Catherine Shields, to Bruce Lincoln Whyte, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln Dodge Whyte of New York.

title: Postel Disputes City's Contention That Only a Handful Got City Jobs Illegally
description: City Councilman Robert I. Po stel charged yesterday that there were dozens of people illegally employed on city jobs under the public employment program for assitance to the un employed and underemployed.

title: YUGOSLAVIA BANS SERBIAN JOURNAL
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 16  The Serbian Philosophic Society's quarterly journal, Filosofija, ordinarily does not stir much excitement when it appears in its full circulation of only 1,500 copies. But a court ban imposed on the latest issue, which was accused of false and alarming statements, has aroused more than usual inter est in the journal, assuring attentive reading of copies that have eluded the authorities.

title: PRIESTHOOD STUDY DENIED PUBLICATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  The National Conference of Catholic Bishops has decided not to publish a controversial theological study of the priest hood because its administrative committee could not agree with some of the study's conclusions.

title: SECURITY IS TIGHT AT GREEN HAVEN
description: STORMVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 16 Inmates of the Green Haven Correctional Facility here were kept under tight supervision to day following a clash among inmates yesterday that left seven of them injured before it was quelled with tear gas.

title: Elizabeth du Pont Bayard Married
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 16 Miss Elizabeth du Pont Bayard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Bayard 3d, was married here this after noon to Sgt. John Idell Tall man, U.S.A.F., in Trinity Epis copal Church. The Rev. Rob ert MacLeod Smith performed the ceremony.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 519; Arms Observation Hinted.
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16The So viet Union today launched the unmanned spacecraft Cosmos 519, believed to be a military observation satellite. It was placed into an orbit of 130 to 213 miles at an angle of 71.3 degrees.

title: Relatives and Antiwar Leaders In Hanoi to Get 3 Freed P.O.W'.s
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 16 (AP)Four American anti war leaders and the relatives of two American prisoners of war arrived here today to es cort home three United States pilots scheduled to be freed by the North Vietnamese.

title: Man Lost in Welland River
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Ont. (AP) Sept, 16Firemen were search ing the Welland River for one of six men after a 24foot boat sank early today. Missing and believed drowned was Michael Dundas, 18 years old, of Niagara Falls, Ont. The other five swam to safety.

title: A gynecologist looks at love
description: It is a personal insight, and a pivotal one, that the universal quest for stability takes two formsthat of the pyramid builder, who stakes out his ter ritory, measures it, and plans course after course toward a definite goal, or apex; and that of the gull, whose stability is dynamic, who must be ever in motion to remain stable, and who has equipped and trained himself to tilt and recover, to adjust to direction and temp erature and density and what ever else he may encounter. And by and large, gulls outlast pyramids, for flex and bend and change are the very essence of life, while pyramids, however impressive, are doomed to dust for the lack of ability to cope with the lifeforces, the sun beam, the raindrop, which will them.

title: The cool war
description: When President Roosevelt returned from Yalta in 1945, there was hardly a dissenting voice. We really believed in our hearts that this was the dawn of the new day, wrote Harry Hopkins. We were absolutely certain that we had won the first great victory of peace. And the Soviet press announced that Yalta was a memorable milestone on the road to ensure world peace and security. Ten years later, at the height of the Cold War, Yalta had become a synonym for a sellout. Today we take a more balanced view of Yalta: It was not a betrayal because most Western concessions were probably inevitable; but neither was it a page of glory in the annals of American diplomacy.

title: Music
description: There is a bright paint splattered door at the cor ner of Bedford Avenue and Lincoln Place in Brooklyn that leads into a long, curv ing, tunnellike corridor that takes one from Africa to New Orleans into the varied worlds of jazz, displayed in pictures, words and music.

title: Louise Arner Boyd Dies at 84; Led Expeditions to the Arctic
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 (AP) Louise Arner Boyd, a former debutante who achieved world renown as an Arctic ex plorer, died Thursday night after an extended illness. She would have been 85 today.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)A $2.7million pur chase of 1,090 walkthrough passenger  screening devices and 1,200 handheld units for added airport security was announced today by the Transportation Department.

title: MOTHER ACCUSED OF KILLING BABY
description: A Queens woman was charged yesterday with the murder of 2yearold Korean orphan she and her husband had adopted six months ago, the police said.

title: Social Announcements
description: Anniversaries

title: Green Thumb Beautifies Burlington
description: MOUNT HOLLY  Walter Harrison, who retired 10 years ago at the age of 65, could have spent those years watching the numbing quiz programs on television and getting old.

title: AROUND THE
description: Buy new evergreens; transplant old ones. Con tinue planting perennials and dividing thick clumps.  Control insects on shrubbery. Take cut tings of border plants. Start cleanup.

title: Blam! Blam! Blam! Not gun nuts, but pistol enthusiasts
description: The powerful reports from the 9mm. Luger and the 41caliber Magnum penetrate the shooters' soundabsorbing oversized earmuffs, and the odor of gunpowder laces the air of the Remington Arms Co pistol range in the Bridgeport, Conn. suburb of Lordship. The revolver that fired the shots at Alabama Gov. George Wallace, the bullets that paralyzed him, all were manufactured in Bridgeport. It is a handgunconscious community in a gunloving state. In a time when antigun forces have finally won a modest victory in the Senate banning cheap snubnosed handguns, the Lordship range seems to be a logical place to begin interviewing some of America's pistol enthusiasts, more commonly called gun nuts by their numerous detractors.

title: Television
description: ACTORS for whom the sun rises and sets on a film studio grow like bananas in large bunches and are just as in distinguishable. But an actor who earns a Ph.D. in com munications, writes a book about blacklisting, lectures against the war in Vietnam, and debates with William Buckley on TV is a different kind altogether and may well be one of a kind.

title: Alaska LandUse Panel Studies Disposition of 190 Million Acres
description: ANCHORAGE, Sept. 16Rep resentatives of the Federal Gov ernment, the State of Alaska, conservation and native groups have begun formal discussions on the disposition of about 190 million acres of land.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Prince Georges County, Md., is a sprawling suburban area outside Wash ington, D. C., that contains acre after acre of lowtomiddleincome housing, and which operates the tenth largest school system in the nation. Twenty four per cent of its 163,000 pupils are black; but four years ago, in 1968, only 15 per cent were black.

title: ASHE VANQUISHES OKKER BY 75, 64
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 16 (Cana dian Press)  Arthur Ashe of Miami and Roy Emerson of Australia won semifinal matches today in the $50,000 Montreal international tennis tournament.

title: Letters
description: Much of the furor re To scoop or not to scoop emanated from a bill I intro duced into the City Council (Intro. No. 493, 12171) which would ban dogs from multiple dwellings in the City of New York.

title: McGovern Accuses Nixon Of Whitewash on BreakIn
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  Senator George McGovern ac cused President Nixon today of having ordered a whitewash in the Federal grand jury in vestigation of the alleged bug ging on June 17 of the Demo cratic national headquarters at the Watergate complex.

title: QUEEN ELIZABETH 2 HIRED BY TEXANS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 16The Queen Elizabeth 2, one of the world's largest luxury ships, has been booked for an un accustomed 1974 journey by businessmen from Texas.

title: Elmhurst Triumph
description: ELMHURST, Ill., Sept. 16 (AP)Dale Renner ran for two touchdowns to lead Elmhurst to a 3226 football victory over Milliken today.

title: The World
description: JERUSALEM  The fastest selling book in Israel today is a 483page proposal by a leading Member of Parliament for the establishment of a sovereign Palestinian state on the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan. And the fact that the book, entitled Glory in the Land of the Living  a Biblical reference to Israelcan generate such excitement is a barometer of the passions aroused here by the debate over how Israel should cope with the Palestinian prob lem.

title: F. and M. Triumphs, 220
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Sept. 16 Franklin and Marshall held Carnegie Mellon to 13 yards rushing today and the Diplo mats triumphed, 220.

title: SHOP TALK
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS  This urban borough, today one of the many small, pros perous communities that make up Bergen County, was the Polify area General Wash ington and his troops passed through on their retreat from Hackensack. Polify became Corona, then, because of the confusion with Corona, N.Y., the town changed its name to Hasbrouck, after the gen eral manager of the N.J. and N.Y. Railroad. Heights was added later when it was dis covered there was also a Hasbrouck, N. Y.

title: Dumping of Bluefish In Sound Is Charged By Niantic Residents
description: NIANTIC, Conn., Sept. 16 An unusually bountiful run of bluefish off this shore town has led to charges that some fish ermen, after catching more than they can use or give away, are dumping hundreds of dead fish into Long Island Sound.

title: LETTERS
description: Your article Tax Shelters Coming Under Scrutiny (Aug. 27) reported that in vestors using tax shelter schemes were often milked by the operators who put to gether the tax shelter deals. So far, so good, but no one reading the article would have learned that there is more to tax shelters than who gets what share of the profits.

title: The Watergate Case
description: From the outset of the Watergate case in June, when five agents of the Nixon campaign organization were arrested in the Democratic National Committee head quarters while engaged in espionage, the White House and Republican party leaders have steadfastly denied that anyone of senior status was involved. The indict ment of the five arrested men plus two other individuals fails to resolve this larger, more serious question of who was ultimately responsible. Meanwhile, the denials be come less and less convincing.

title: Texas Tech Wins, 452
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept, 16 (AP)  Texas Tech, led by George Smith, recorded a 452 football victory over Utah to night.

title: Paperback Rights for Crichton's Camerons Sold for $700,001
description: The Camerons, a novel by Robert Crichton that will be called oldfashioned, has just brought a price that is strictly newfashioned: $700,001.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Only one element of the benefits equation is highlighted in The Times' Sept. 8 story, Harvard Study Disputes Impact of Schooling on Future In come.

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Sept. 16Prime Min ister Heath of Great Britain ar rived here this afternoon for discussions next week with Premier Kakuei Tanaka on Ja pan's new policy toward China, trade issues, monetary reform and a prospective visit to Japan by Queen Elizabeth II.

title: The Munich Olympics:
description: The sign of a true cham pion is to be poised and dig nified in any given situation, but Vince Matthews and Wayne Collett did nothing to make the people of the United States proud of them. Their actions were disgraceful and their explanations further de tracted from the cause they espouse; whereas they could have been such a progressive influence had they acted as real champions.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 Shortly after 10:30 this morning, the director of President Nixon's reelection campaign pushed the doorbell at 4063 Brownsville Road in suburban Brentwood and then stood on the awninged porch, waiting for a response.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: In Newgate Callendar's re cent review of my novel, The Chickens in the Airshaft, he remarks that presumably, there is a larger social purpose un der the farce.

title: Education
description: We have no recourse except to indict the Nixon Administration for its failure to provide leadership in solving the nation's educational ills.

title: LETTERS
description: I agreebut to a limited extentwith E. Spencer Mil ler's views (Sept. 10) regard ing railroad consolidation. It is, clear that savings and economies, not to mention improvements in service, can be accomplished through con solidations of railroads.

title: ISRAELI RAID INTO LEBANON SETS OFF HEAVY FIGHTING; TANKS AND PLANES CLASH
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 16 The Lebanese Army said to day that Israeli armored forces had swept across a large part of southern Lebanon and en gaged in heavy fighting with Government units and Pales tinian commandos.

title: The New York Times Magazine
description: The gimmicks are gone, the more flamboyant styles have fled, the confusion and fashion frenzy which followed the new sartorial permissiveness has abated. For the fall and winter ahead a gentlemanly look has once again been buttonholed. In clothing, the twobuttoned, waistandshoulderexpressed suit is still top favorite, but the excessive detailselaborate pocket treatments, fancy backs and suchhave been banished. What does give spirit to suits and sport coats are the patterns. Bold, showy plaids and checks predominate: exemplifying the new breed of plaided jacket is the one, on this page, of tweeded Scottish wool. Waistshaped, twobuttoned, centervented, its by Stanley Blacker and $90 at Bloomingdale's. Robust woolens are being appreciated anew, often in tweedier, beefier country looks not seen around in some time, while knits after the big pitch that they were about to replace most other fabricshave taken their rightful place as a wardrobe extra. Those old favorites, the gray flannel and striped blue suits, have been taken out of mothballs and rejuvenated with seventies spirit. In clothing, green has gotten the go signal, too. And it's an appreciation of yesteryear's classics, rather than nostalgia, that accounts for the return of the stalwart storm coat, the rugged lumberjack shirt, the flight jacket, the Navy peacoat. The whitegrounded peacoat on the cover takes on another rediscovered favorite, the lusty mackinaw plaid. The allwool coat is clovercollared, zippocketed, quiltlined. By Robert Chernin for Aljac. $89 at Alexander's. The turtleneck is by Barclay; the brushed cotton jeans, Shelby Slacks for Robert Bruce. The report continues.

title: Air Force Routs Wyoming On Passing of Haynie, 4514
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Sept. 16 (AP)Rich Haynie threw two touchdown passes to Frank Murphy and Joe Carl son ran for two more today as Air Force opened its foot ball season with a 4514 vic tory over Wyoming.

title: JURY CHARGES 6 IN BOND PETITIONS
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16Instead of going out for fun as planned, a group of suburban teenagers accepted an invitation to make $5 each by working one July night in the 11thfloor offices of one of the city's top adver tising concerns.

title: Sara Osborne Wed To Stephen Batty
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 16Miss Sara Anna Osborne was married here this afternoon to Stephen Mathewson Batty, son of William R. Batty of Bristol, R. I., and Mrs. George Costa of Lincoln, R. I. The cere mony was performed at the home in Llewellyn Park of Mr. and Mrs. Foster S. Os borne, parents of the bride, by the Rev. Richard Dannen felser, a Presbyterian min ister and assistant chaplain at Brown University.

title: Weissbuch Leaves Post
description: Bill Weissbuch of Great Neck, L. I., has resigned as president of the Eastern Professional Tennis Association for business and health reasons. The associ ation, a group of teaching pros, has named George Bacso of Westfield, N. J., to succeed him.

title: The Girl from Storyville
description: Frank Yerby's career certain ly qualifies as a legend in American publishing. Since 1946 he has written 24 novels, many of them bestsellers with total sales of more than 21 mil lion copies. From his bastions in Spain and France he has poured them out, almost one a year and, in its turn, each has been called a flaming story a story of passion, violence, cruelty, lust and hateten sionpacked fastmoving  eventfilled stormy ro bust. It makes no difference which description is applied to which novel. Any of the adjec tives will fit all of them.

title: Today's Sections
description: (Part 2) Report on Men's Wear

title: Washington U. Wins, 307
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (AP) Washington University used its new wishbone offense today to record a 307 football Victory over the University of the South (Sewanee).

title: CITY MAN
description: Seven trafficstoppers with citysized plaids. Big photo, near right: a richly shaded glen plaid is brightened by a blue overplaid on a wool suit by Hardy Amies. The twobuttoned jacket, has gently curved lapels, hacking pockets, deep side vents. $125 at Whitehouse & Hardy. Eagle shirt. Reis of New Haven tie. Churchill hat. Center, a triplestriped windowpane plaid, centered with diamondwoven squares. The highspirited wool suit is waist shaped and twobuttoned; the pockets are angleflapped, the back is sidevented. Traditionally  pocketed, sidevented. By Hart Schaffner & Marx. $175 at Wallachs. The shirt: John Weitz for Excello. The knit tie by Eros. Far right, subtlybox plaided suit of doubleknit polyester. The twobuttoned coat is styled with straight flap pockets and center vent. By Eagle. $150 at B&B Lorrys. Gant shirt. Tie: Churchill hat.

title: 7 JUDGES DIFFER OVER GRAFT UNITS
description: The judge who runs the New York City Criminal Court be lieves that while the machinery to investigate judges should be strengthened, there is no need for new agencies to prosecute official corruption, as proposed by the Knapp Commission and by State Senator John H. Hughes, Republican of Syra cuse.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONOn Jan. 25, 1971, Wilbur D. Mills, following a meeting at the White House, announced that he would hold hearings on the Ad ministration's plan for revenueshar ing but not for the purpose of promoting the plan  for the purpose of killing it.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIt was first heard in midAugust, the charge that some large grain exportersCargill, Con tinental, Huge, Cook, Dreyfus, Gar nackhad made windfall profits from the $750million U.S.Soviet grain deal announced by President Nixon on July 8.

title: Mailbox:
description: I found the conduct of Ilie Nastase in his recent [U.S. Open final] match against Arthur Ashe appalling.
