He should be reprimanded for directing a towel and tennis ball at a lines man who called a fault against him. It was an affront to Ashe, who is a most gracious and dignified player. The American team may be in for an un pleasant defeat in the Davis Cup finals in Rumania, where Nas tase should be particularly irascible. Nobody enjoys play ing against Nastase at any time.

title: Movies
description: SUDDENLY, Ron O'Neal is it. Playing the role of Priest, the cocaine hus tler in Gordon Parks Jr.'s surprise hit Super Fly, he has become one of the hottest actors in the country. Up in arms as so many Black people have become about the effect his sympathetic por trait of a pusher might have on Black youth, most Black women simply want to be up in the arms of Ron O'Neal. He makes Shaft look like Little Jack Homer, said one girl who has, seen the film three times because O'Neal is so yummy. The men dig him too, and shout out their approval of his fur coat, his customdesigned Cadillac and his machismo. Right on! That is one mean dude!

title: SemiTough
description: The setting for this novel is at the very heart of contemporary American culture. It is the week of the Super Bowl: the Giants, still playing in New York thanks to a new Commissioner of Football (who has foiled a plan by the Mara fam ily to move the team to Bermuda), are about to play the dogass Jets for the championship. All America watches. Since the memoirs of great athletes, particularly great white athletes, are of no small commercial value, Billy Clyde Puckett, the great Giant fullback (Jimmy Brown's abil ity, Tucker Frederickson's cosme tology) is tape recording his pre game experiences for his book. (He has been persuaded to do this by friends, since it could presumably have a beneficial influence on kids. People, he notes, keep saying that kids are the hope of the world and maybe even Texas.)

title: Letters
description: In The Resale of the President (Sept. 3), author Joe McGinniss states that I, along with Osborn Elliott and Shana Alexander, attended a $500aplate political gala at the Republican National Con vention in Miami Beach. Mr. McGinniss writes of his ost racism from Republican social events like this one, com pared, he implies, with re porters like myself who, ob viously less outspoken, were favored by the Nixon Ad ministration.

title: BOB SMITH VICTOR IN N.Y.A.C. SAILING
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 16Bob Smith sailed Viking to a second straight International Class victory on Long Island Sound today during the New York Athletic Club's annual re gatta for the Yacht Racing Association. Arthur Frimmet won his first Shields Class race of the season with Persephone.

title: Blast Hits Philippine Plane
description: MANILA, Sept. 16An ex plosion aboard an Air Manila aircraft flying to the southern Philippine city of Illigan today tore a hole in the plane's bag gage compartment, but none of the 42 passengers and crew members wag injured. Cause pf the explosion was not immedi ately known.

title: Kissinger Says Accent Extends to German Too
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)Henry A. Kissinger, Preident Nixon's adviser on national security, struck back at the jokes aimed at his German accent today when he opened his news conference by noting:

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The 1972 Presidential campaign is the best thing that has happened to America since Joe DiMaggio. After years and years in which everything seemed to be going wrong, the campaign began and, ever since then, the world has been getting better every day.

title: Delaware Beats Lehigh
description: NEWARK, Del., Sept. 16 (AP) Delaware held off a late surge by Lehigh today and tri umphed, 2822, on the strength of a strong ground attack.

title: S.M.U. Triumphs, 5610
description: DALLAS, Sept. 16 (AP) Southern Methodist led by Al vin Maxson, who turned in four touchdown runs, and Wayne Morris, who ran 50 yards for a score, routed Wake Forest to night, 5610.

title: ShapeUp: Islanders Spare None
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario Sept. 16Everyone at the New York Islanders' train ing camp walks the half mile from the Holiday Inn to the rink. That includes the general manager, Bill Torrey; the coach, Phil Goyette, and the publicity man, Hawley T. Chester 3d.

title: Let's not talk about love
description: Much of the turmoil now dis turbing the Roman Catholic es tablishment originates in the demand for a reappraisal of its authoritarian structure. Rad ical reformers are calling for a return to the Law of Christ, by which they mean the New Testament commandment of love. By an ironic twist of ec clesiastical development, the one area where historically the law of love seems to have received least consideration is in Chris tian marriage. In the document concerned with matrimony pre pared for discussion at Vatican Council II, the word love was relegated to an appendix. In John Noonan's impressive study The Power to Dissolve, love appears perhaps a dozen times, one of which is in the index. The author is professor of law and chairman of reli gious studies at the University of California, Berkeley.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Stanley Hoffmann's sympa thetic review of Frances Fitz Gerald's extraordinary book (Fire in the Lake, Aug. 27) ends with a misleading inter pretation of her title. He says we must not simply get out but create the conditions for the independent, national Government of South Vietnam that could begin the cleansing of the lake.

title: Selfpity
description: So many of us are positive that the record of our experience, if we could just get it in print, has ines timable value for the world. We rea son that, quite simply, no one has suffered so much. No one has had so much bad luck. No one has worked so hard without enjoying the fruits of that labor. It's a common fallacy. Reading Piri Thomas's second book, Savior, Savior, Hold My Hand re minds us that most of our experiences are not that interesting to others. Accordingly, the bulk of Thomas's autobiography just doesn't grab us or even pinch us.

title: 45% in Bergen Are From Elsewhere
description: Close to half of the resi dents of Bergen County were born outside of New Jersey. Thus, Bergen has a higher proportion of migrants than any other New Jersey county in the metropolitan region close to New York City.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is distressing to find in The Times (Aug. 28) an article about Japan and Asia captioned and written in termi nology so reminiscent of the 1930's: Japan Tightens Her Economic Grip on Nations of East and South Asia.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  I re ceived your letter asking me (and probably several million others) how much I would like to contribute to the reelection of President Nixon, and what I regard as the main issue of the election.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, lead ing state Republicans, several thousand Queens residents, and hecklers for a dozen assorted causes were on the scene for an election rally for the President in Flushing yesterday.

title: CHINA ASSAILS SOVIET ON USE OF ALCOHOL
description: PEKING, Sept. 16 (Reuters) China has accused Soviet lead ers of using alcohol to poison the will of the Soviet people who, Peking says, are resisting Moscow's attempt to restore the capitalist system.

title: Tracy & Hepburn The Potato And the Dessert
description: T RACY and Hepburn, subtitled an inti mate memoir, is the autobiography of Garson Kanin limited to those moments in his life when Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn played supporting roles as old friends and as coworkers in two very funny movies writ ten by Kanin and his wife, Ruth Gordon. The book is chatty and fidgety, qualities that are punishable at an Olympics and apparently the stuff of a surefire best seller here.

title: Lottery Income Adds College Space for 28,556
description: TRENTON  When state supported colleges began their fall term, places for an additional 28,556 students were available through funds provided by the New Jersey State Lottery. And by next June 30, it is expected that another 15,802 students will be accommodated, thanks to the public's gambling in stinct.

title: Buckley Warns Against Apathy, Calls for a Mandate for Nixon
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Sept. 16Warning against apa thy because of President Nixon's good showing in the polls, Sen ator James L. Buckley called for a dramatic defeat of all McGovernites, in a speech to night at the Westchester Coun ty Conservative party dinner at the Briar Hill Country Club.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The Roman Catholic Church is in a state of emergency, with the result, according to Hans Kng, of the University of Tubingen, that 25,000 priests, curates and bishops have taken their leave in a recent period of eight years. The trouble, he says, is that it is no longer clear what or why a priest is. In this controversial book Kng proposes not ways of patching up traditional concepts to fore stall priestly defection but a new ministry of leadership.

title: Light Shed on Affluence
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 16 (AP)  George Romney, Secre tary of Housing and Urban De velopment, was discussing af fluent teenagers with P.T.A. members at a Portland high school Wednesday when he was interrupted by a public address announcement. The announcer wanted to notify a student that the lights on his ?? were on.

title: STATE CRITICIZED ON PENAL REFORM
description: Members of a joint legislative and citizens committee yester day sharply criticized what they called inadequate reforms made in the last year in the state's prisons, characterizing the im provements as minuscule and mainly cosmetic.

title: Soviet Hockey Gets Start in Kindergarten
description: The Soviet goalie, Vladis lay Tret'yak, proved to be a very fine hockey player dur ing the Team CanadaU.S.S.R. allstar hockey games in Can ada earlier this month. Prav da, the Communist Party newspaper, modestly termed his performances good; the Canadian and American press rated them sensational.

title: City Opera Lifts the Curtain on Its New Don Giovanni
description: When the curtain descend ed on the New York City Opera's new production of Don Giovanni on Friday night, the singers came forth to receive a spattering of ap plause. They were followed by Frank Corsaro, the direc tor, and Bruno Maderna, the conductor. Then there was action. Both got as lusty a collections of boos as has en livened the New York State Theater since it was opened.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: John P. Young in a Sept. 3 letter deduces from a statement by a bank holdup man that reinstating the death penalty will save lives.

title: Stormy Hearing Ahead On Fluoridating Water
description: TRENTON  It seems that New Jersey has never had to wait very long for one burn ing state issue to follow an other. During the last few years, the State House has witnessed angry hearings on guncontrol, legislative con troversies involving school busing, abortion, organized crime and political corrup tion, and of course this year's taxreform debate. Now wa ter fluoridation is the issue whose time has comeagain.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Could I have a few lines to suggest possible unfairness in the reporting of the early stages of Senator McGovern's Presidential campaign? May I note that, although I am a warm partisan of McGovern's, these are not matters with which I have been in any appre ciable way associated.

title: OUSTERS DISPUTED IN RAINBOW GIRLS
description: AUBURN, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP)One year after Laurie Chester became a Rainbow Girl in October, 1968, her local chapter was suspended from the national Order of Rainbow Girls for no stated reason, the local adviser says. Laurie Chester, 18 year old, is black.

title: Mayor Indicates Freeze on Hiring May End as City job Output Nears Its Peak
description: Mayor Lindsay has been tell ing concerned neighborhood leaders that the city may be very close to the point where increasing productivity can no longer compensate for the freeze on hiring policemen and other uniformed services work ers.

title: New Attitude Seen In Ecology Battle
description: Robert Arbib, a distin guished conservationist who grew up on the South Shore of Long Island, believes that 1972 may be Year No. 1 in the Environmental Revolu tion.

title: Mississippi State Crushes Northeast Louisiana, 427
description: STARKVILLE, Miss., Sept. 16 (UPI)  Melvin Barkum, a sophomore quarterbach, passed for one touchdown and ran for anther today to lead the Mississippi State Bulldogs to a 427 victory over Northeast Louisiana.

title: Go West, old man
description: Rancho Paradise is a trailer park in Yucaipa, Calif., in the foothills of the San Bernardino Mountains. It is a community of retired people, living com fortably on small incomes. It is situated just above and be yond the circle of smog, roughnecks, blacks, kids, high taxes and futureshock surrounding Los Angeles. The sun shines 300 days of the year. Yucaipa's population has gone up 75 per cent since 1960. Its median age is 56. Rancho Paradise is not one of the showier parks, where widows are excluded and anybody in a mobilehome more than five years old is liable to be evicted; the decencies are observed. Novelist John Deck brought his tape recorder here and for some months, with generous good sense and perspicacity, collect ed quite an array of memories and situation sketches.

title: The World
description: When Hitler was the Prime Min ister and supreme commander, he burnt over six million Jews. This is because Hitler and all German people knew that the Israelis are not people who are working in the interest of the people of the world.

title: Letters
description: Edward R. F. Sheehan's ar ticle (A Visit With Hussein, the Palestinians and Golda Meir, Aug. 27) states that Mount Scopus has been  radically altered to make way for the new buildings of the Hadassah Medical Center and other structures.

title: Union Approves Pact Preventing Dismissal of 20 Columbia Maids
description: A contract approved yester day by a union representing buildings and grounds workers at Columbia University will prevent the dismissal of 20 uni versity maids whom the uni versity had been trying to lay off since January.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: ITALIANspeak, write Italian and English fluently? See Classified ad under Italian, Secretary Executive Suite in today's issue. Advt.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The textile industry is meeting the challenge of producing nonflammable fab rics and fibers and is actively engaged in turning out goods that will meet the rigorous standards set by the Com merce Department.

title: Innovations Mark Dances in Air at Museum
description: The MultiGravitational Ex periment Group, whose self proclaimed purpose is dancing in air, presented four pieces for one scaffold, five inner tubes, several humans and some trapezes in the Summer garden series at the Museum of Modern Art Friday night.

title: New &Novel
description: Two Americans named Tom and Caroline Hutton spend a month on Malta with Tom's small son by a previous mar riage. Tom is a partner in a variety store in the Midwest, and he is undergoing a mild crisis at reaching 39. Caroline, an exschoolteacher of 30, is in the psychological aftermath of a miscarriage.

title: Letters:
description: There is little public discussion about a medical problem that appears to af flict a minority of passengers on jet aircraft. Some people get very severe pain in their ears when the plane de scends. The pain may persist after the flight for a few minutes, for several hours, or, in some cases, for weeks. The stewardesses and some doctors ad vise chewing gum, mouth breathing, etc., during the descent, but I have heard of a number of people who, be cause of the pain they have experi enced, will not fly again under any cir cumstances. I have tried without suc cess to get information about this con dition and wonder if you could furnish any details.

title: Area Bombing Suspended
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16 (AP)The immediate Hanoi area was placed off lim its to United States fighter bombers today for the arrival of a group of Americans invited by North Vietnam to pick up three captured pilots, United States military sources dis closed.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: A 49yearold entrepreneur who admittedly likes to con duct himself with flair sometimes it make me look like a smart aleck and this upsets people  Meshulam Riklis is apparently doing it again.

title: Dodgers Down Astros, 100
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 16 (AP) Willie Davis stroked four hits, including a threerun homer to night, to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 100 triumph over the Houston Astros.

title: LETTERS
description: At the risk of prolonging the debate over DDT the let ters of Dr. Charles Wurster and Otis Kidwell Burger in your Sept. 10 issue require response to set the record straight.

title: President Lists Net Worth at $765,118
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  The White House made public today a financial statement showing that President Nixon has a net worth of $765,118, an increase of $168,218 while he has been in the White House.

title: Northport School Opens Despite Insurance Fight
description: NORTHPORT, L.I.  Stu dents are attending classes in a rebuilt section of the Ocean Avenue Elementary School here, which was sev erely damaged by fire 18 months ago, but it is still not known whether the structure was covered by insurance.

title: Which War Was Not Won By John Wayne?
description: BY popular demand, The Times presents an other of the quizzes from the Cinema 101 course at Vera Vague Uni versity. Score 10 points for each correct answer, along with special bonus points as indicated. Answers will be published when  and if  classes resume this fall.

title: Dance
description: NOWADAYS the New York dance season seems to be starting earlier and ending later. American Ballet The ater shut up shop at the New York State Theater on Au gust 13, and Antonio Gades and his Spanish Dance Com pany opened at the New York City Center on September 6, while the very day after the New York Dance Festival opened at the Delacorte The ater in Central Park. There is now hardly any respite in New York's dance season. Fur thermore the season ahead, from say now until next Au gust, is shaping up to be the biggest ever in New York. There will on occasion he three or even four companies playing the town at the same time, not to mention individ ual concerts.

title: Blue Cross Acts to Cut Double Claims
description: Through a littlenoticed pro vision in its last rate increase, Greater New York Blue Cross, the nonprofit insurance plan for hospitalization, is trying to cut down on payments to Blue Cross subscribers who also carry commercial health in surance plans.

title: Bizarre End in Sight
description: The finish of the American League's Eastern Division pennant race can turn out to be even more bizarre than most peopleincluding the playershave yet realized.

title: New York to
description: THERE was a time when Ameri cans, like young Eugene Gant, took the longdistance train. Per force. And the journey itself was meaningful, an Experience, not simply the fastest means of transportation be tween two points.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: CREDIBILITY GAPS are not confined to the world of politics. A kingsized one can be discerned at the moment in the economic realm. Quite clearly, there is a distinct difference in the attitude of various elements of American society on some key as pects of the business outlook.

title: NEBRASKA ROLLS TO 377 VICTORY
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 16 (AP) Nebraska's defending nation al football champions, stung by U.C.L.A. last week, retali ated today by crushing Texas A. and M., 377. David Humm, a quarterback, and Johnny Rodgers, a flanker back were the stars.

title: Wilson's Yacht, Vamoose, Wins In E. B. Standish Trophy Sailing
description: SALT POND, Block Island, Sept. 16W. Ronald Wilson's Vamoose extended its lead over competing Class A1 yachts in the second day's sailing of the twoday 35th annual Fall Off Soundings competition today and won the E. Bradford Standish Trophy.

title: President at Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) President Nixon flew by heli copter today for a weekend at Camp David, the Presidential retreat in Maryland. He was ac companied by Mrs. Nixon and their younger daughter, Julie Nixon Eisenhower.

title: Mexican Gangsters Wage Bloody Narcotics War in Border City of Nuevo Laredo
description: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico, Sept. 16 (AP)Mexican gang sters are in the midst of a violent narcotics war in this border city.

title: HOUSTON BEATEN BY ARIZONA STATE
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 16 (AP) Danny White Jr. threw first quarter touchdown passes of 55 and 52 yards to Steve, Holden as Arizona State de feated Houston, 3328 today in a college football game in the Astrodome.

title: Miss Murtagh, Edward Byrne Plan Marriage
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 16Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Murtagh have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Mary Murtagh, to Edward Thomas Byrne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald T. Byrne of Douglas ton, Queens. The wedding is planned for next June.

title: Fall Planting
description: IT'S fun to team up hardy bulbs and shrubs for si multaneous bloom in the spring garden. Whether spring comes early or mean ders along as if it had all the time in the world, bulbs, shrubs, perennials and flow ering trees are programmed to bloom in a certain se quence. This builtin timing means that lilacs are right in step with midseason tulips. Forsythias bloom along with those big trumpet daffodils.

title: Converser with men of the future
description: For the modern reader with some sense of history Diderot's appeal is very strong. First, the brillance, te nacity and steady courage of his editorship of the great Encyclopdic, which gave him his central position in the Enlightenment. Then his own thought: labile, multiform  essays, aphorisms, dramas, novels, dialogues, art criticismthought which opened new paths in the philosophy of sci ence, in esthetics and inspired some of the beginnings of romanticism. But above all, Diderot's life, which seems to prefigure in unselfconscious and rudimentary ways some of the typi cal dilemmas and preoccupations of modern bourgeois intellectuals: de pendence on, yet uneasiness with, es tablished powers; a secularism that commits them to an empirically given world but simultaneously to a better one; and the search for a social definition of reason that will endow the intellectual with an eman cipatory function within the human community. To the extent that 20th century conditions force us to com pare alternative modes of social exist ence, to take society as the most serious object of thought, we are linked to the Enlightenment and pre eminently to Diderot.

title: A Community Welcomes New Retirement Villages
description: MANCHESTER TOWNSHIP This may soon be one of the few localties in New Jersey if not the only onewith a majority of elderly people. The 11,000 residents here are about evenly, divided between the old and the young. But the recent open ing of the township's fifth retirement community seemed destined to change that.

title: Institute's Enrollment Up
description: ROSWELL, N. J., Sept. 16  Enrollment at the New Mexico Military Institute is the highest in three years and has in creased 20 per cent over the record low of 592 cadets reached at the opening of school last year, Dr. C. Robert Kemble, president, said today.

title: German and Japanese Get World Church Council Posts
description: GENEVA, Sept. 16 (Agence FrancePresse)A German and a Japanese have been appointed assistant directors of the Ecu menical Institute of the World Council of Churches here and an Austrian will become emi gration secretary for the Coun cil, it was announced today.

title: Westminster Wins, 286, For 22d Victory in Row
description: LOCK HAVEN, Pa., Sept. 16 (AP)Westminster won its 22d straight regularsea son football game today, top ping Lock Haven, 286.Lock Haven, held to only 95 yards total offense, scored its only touchdown on an 80yard interception return by Steve Glass. The losers picked off three other passes, but suffered six interceptions of their own.

title: Prosperity On Tobacco Trail
description: WILSON, N. C.Wilson, the nation's largest tobacco market, remembers with tol erant amusement an entre preneur who tried to exploit the lungcancer issue a few years ago.

title: Colette Sebrell Woods Is Wed To David Cudahy Wilhelm Jr.
description: Miss Colette Sebrell Woods and David Cudahy Wilhelm Jr. were married here yester day afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. David H. C. Read.

title: Letters:
description: I have the dubious distinction of hav ing been a prisoner at Stutthof, the concentration camp near Danzig de scribed by Mr. Glynn. At this time of year, near the High Holidays, I am never far from tears. But, I am always told, you live for today; and with three beautiful children to raise and a won derful husband, I find it easy at most times to forget. But we never forget. On reading the article, I could smell and feel all the things I try not to think about: the ankledeep sand and dust, our lice, filth, the lack of water, and peeling rotten, frozen stinking po tatoes for our soup. And the bodies piled high outside those barracks, strip ped naked like so much kindling wood for the trucks and the ovens. Somehow, by the grace of God, I never saw the inside of an oven. I was so small, so ugly, crosseyed from an ear infection, and stuttering from constant fear that I was just passed over.

title: India Yields to Liquor Demand Despite Her Ideal of Prohibition
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 16 (Reu ters)India's states have re laxed the nation's dry laws de spite constitutional disapproval of alcoholic drinks.

title: Letters:
description: Please convey to Giulo E. Miranda my family's appreciation of his article about the pitfalls of the Grand Reunion in Italy (Travel section, Aug. 6). We had been hurt by the unkind statements made by the three men in Rome who were interviewed about the impres sions left behind in Italy by Americans (Travel section, May 14) and would have responded bitterly. Instead, Mr. Miranda replied lovingly and with humor, reminding us all that the human race is one big family with both virtues and frailties.

title: LAWYERS CLASH AT CORONA TRIAL
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Sept. 16 The first week of the search for a jury in the trial of Juan V. Corona, the accused mass murderer, ended here with the prospects for a swift, quiet pro ceeding having all but van ished.

title: Miami of Ohio 347 Victor; Hitchens Tallies Four Times
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Sept. 16 (AP) Bob Hitchens ran for four touchdowns, tying a Miami of Ohio record, and paced the Redskins to a 347 victory over Dayton today.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: In 1949 V. O. Key published Southern Politics in State and Nation, a scholarly study of Southern political viewpoints, their historical, economic and cultural basis. Now William C. Havard has edited a similar study to bring Key up to date. There have been considerable changes since Key's study, notably in the position of the blacks, and the flight from the Democratic party in favor of Wallace or the Republicans. Editor Havard contributes sen sible opening and closing chap ters; there are charts, graphs and maps. This is a book main ly for students of the subject, but of special value now that the election is coming up.

title: Contracts to Grumman
description: The North American Rock well Corporation announced yesterday it was awarding $8million in subcontracts to Long Island's Grumman Cor poration for engineering work on the space shuttle, a move expected to save the jobs of some 300 top Grum man engineers. This was the first subcontracting in the $2.6billion spaceshuttle pro gram. Details, Page 24.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: ROME, Sept. 16  Chaos at Fiumicino Airport, wor sened by long delays in the takeoff and arrival of sev eral recent transAtlantic flights, is becoming a major Roman worry with interna tional overtones.

title: THIRD PARTY SLATE OFF TEXAS BALLOT
description: SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Sept. 16Texas laws requiring the filing of petitions by June 30 for third parties to obtain a place on the November election ballot were held constitutional yesterday by a threejudge Fed eral Court.

title: SUPER BOWL FIRST IN COLONIAL TROT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept 16  Eased through the stretch, Super Bowl won the $100,000 Colonial Trot as comfortably as Stanley Dancer, the colt's trainerdriver, desired tonight at Liberty Bell Park. The time for the eightfurlong stakes test for 3yearolds over the five eighthsmile track was a com paratively slow 2:02.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: PARIS: On Friday, Feb. 25, Pierre Overney, a young Maoist demonstrating and distributing po litical tracts at the gate of the stateowned Renault factory in suburban Billancourt, was shot dead by one of the socalled volante company cops in ci vilian clothes who work on the assembly lines minding the company's business. Renault claimed that Pierre Overney had fired first. Unfortunately for Renault, Agence Liberation, the Reuters of the underground, had a photographer on the spot, and Overney was shown to have been unarmed. The in cident occurred in the Government's own plant, in the exercise of a political freedom to which even the Gaullist Government pays lip service; it was at the hand of a company cop, during a time of politi cal and industrial unrest; and it happened to a Maoist, the one uncontrollable factor in the French political spectrum. As if this were not enough, the Government had been gauche enough to lie about it and then be caught in the act.

title: Ios Odyssey: A Day's Hike In Quest of Homer's Tomb
description: IOS, GreeceI had been living on this small, mountainous Aegean is land for months, and one day I decided to try to find the burial place of Homer. In the island's only port and village, also called Ios, a sign in Greek, French and English bears the words Homer's Tomb, and next to it is some unknown artist's crude drawing of the legendary poet. Now, I knew that no one really knows where Homer is buried, or even if he was a single individual or a collection of bards. The sign itself gave no indication of the alleged tomb's location, and the Greek Government is totally noncommittal on the subject. Yet I decided I would try to find it.

title: If You Go
description: to Concord and wander over to the Visitor Center near the Old North Bridge any Saturday or Sunday afternoon from now to Oct. 15, you can watch the Con cord Company of Minutemen in full regalia, playing their fifes and drums and firing their flintlocks. Some of the original minutemen who had British musket balls in their hides on April 19, 1775, were taken to the Colonial Inn, which is in the town center and dates to 1716. Part of the inn was the home of Thoreau's family while he attended Harvard College. Today the Colonial has old charm, modern plumbing and dinners from $5. There are three motels on the fringes of town.

title: First Bloom Triumphs
description: MIAMI, Sept. 16 (AP)Lucien Chens' First Bloom outran heav ily favored Hickory Gray today to win the $10,000added Holly wood Handicap by two lengths at Calder Race Course. The Re publican finished third and Gran Sport was fourth.

title: St. John's Wins, 16 to 7, From Brooklyn in Football
description: St. John's scored 9 points in 1 he last quarter to defeat Brook lyn College, 167, yesterday in football.

title: Fall Planting
description: PLANTS are the living palette with which the landscape architect de signs outdoor compo sitions. Unlike the painter who works in two dimensions on paper or canvas, the land scape architect is an artist in three dimensions, more close ly allied to the sculptor who works in the round. He can rest on his laurels, once the die is cast, secure that his creation is safe for eternity.

title: Michigan Triumphs, 70
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 16 (AP)Dennis Franklin, the first black quarterback ever to start for the University of Michigan, threw a 21yard touchdown pass to Bo Rather in the second quarter today as Michigan downed Northwestern, 70, in the season and Big Ten football opener for both teams.

title: Misunderstanding
description: We are faced this year, Presi dent Nixon said in his Labor Day message, with the choice between the work ethic that built this na tion's characterand the new wel fare ethic that could cause that American character to weaken. The one, he argued, represents the tra ditional American ethic of striving and sacrifice and the other represents a new and alien ethic of indulgence and passivity.

title: Coins
description: TWO coins to commem orate the 100th anni versary of the Royal Canadian Mounted Po lice will be struck for 1973 by the Royal Canadian Mint, it has been announced by Mint Master, Gordon W. Hunter.

title: If You Go
description: .. Ios, you can take a ship from Piraeus harbor or from Crete, via Santorini. Service is frequent. The trip from Piraeus takes roughly 10 hours and costs about $3.25, deck class, From los there is motorlaunch service, on alternate days, to the islands of Amorgos, Syconos and, occasion ally, Pero.

title: Everyone in Wee TavistockGolf ParadiseHas City Job
description: TAVISTOCKOn election day, the polls here will stay open all day, as the law requires. But the entire pop ulation will have voted by 9 A.M. or earlier.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Those unaware of the imprecision of warfare even in present times, with modern facilities, and therefore in clined to be unduly critical of the oper ations of the United States in Vietnam, might do well to recall the way in which the United Nations forces con ducted their operations in the Congo in 196061. PaulHenri Spaak, the Bel gian statesman, was very critical of these operations.

title: Letters:
description: This is in reply to the reader who suggested that supplemental, or non scheduled, airline flights at Kennedy Airport be transferred to Newark Air port, where new terminal facilities are under construction (Travel section, Aug. 20). As a matter of fact, about 30 per cent of all domestic supplemental flights do use Newark. The international flights must use Kennedy, of course, because that is where U.S. Customs and other Federal inspection services are available. Plans are under way to de velop temporary facilities for interna tional flights at Newark Airport as early as 1974. Permanent Federal clearance facilities will be incorporated into one of the three new terminals scheduled to open in 1976. In developing plans for international flights at Newark, we are discussing the matter of both scheduled and nonscheduled carriers; but, at this point, it is too early to determine which international flights should be serviced there.

title: Tool Show's Top Exhibit: Turnaround
description: The recession in the ma chine tool industry seems to be over. That appeared to be the overriding conclusion of observers at the 10day In ternational Machine Tool Show, which ended Friday in Chicago.

title: COLORADO ROUTS CINCINNATI, 5614
description: BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 16 (AP)Colorado's running game  sparked by Charlie Davis, Bo Matthews and Ken Johnson ultimately predominated in a game of giveaway today, as the nationally ranked Buffaloes posted a 5614 football victory over Cincinnati.

title: Children's Day Slated At Yonkers Raceway
description: Yonkers Raceway will stage a Children's Day program Saturday, beginning at 10 A.M. with free admission to the grandstand.

title: STUDY GROUP ASKS BAN ON VEHICLES IN NATIONAL PARKS
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16A panel of citizen specialists, after a yearlong study, today recommended radical changes in the national park system as it enters its second century.

title: The Munich Olympics:
description: Four years ago, at the time of the Mexico City Olympics, you printed my let ter questioning the fairness of the expulsion of two black American athletes who had raised clenched fists during the playing of the national anthem while a Czechoslovak gymnast's bowed head at the playing of the Russian an them was ignored by officials.

title: Columbia Eleven Defeats Rhode Island in Scrimmage
description: Columbia, showing a strong defense but somewhat shaky offense, defeated Rhode Island, 127, in a preseason game yes terday at Baker Field.

title: and Bombing Fiasco
description: How purely military judgment can miscarry even from a strategic standpoint is all too sharply illustrated by the bombing of North Vietnam that was authorized.

title: LIONS TRAIL, 210, AFTER FIRST HALF
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 16 (AP)  Seventhranked Ten nessee piled up 21 points in the first half and then out lasted sixthranked Penn State in the second half tonight for a 2821 victory.

title: Bethany Team Wins, 2514
description: BETHANY, W. Va., Sept. 16 (AP)A 53yard run by Dem rey Brandon sparked Bethany to a 2514 triumph over Case Western Reserve in a Presi dent's Athletic Conference foot ball game today.

title: Mary Makrides to Wed
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L. I., Sept. 16Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Malcrides of the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Joy Makrides, to George Constantin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Con stantin of Brooklyn.

title: David Jones
description: The Welsh painter, engraver, essayist, poet and novelist now living in England  best known for his widely exhibited watercolors, is studied here for the first time as chiefly a lit erary experimenter in the tra dition of Joyce, Eliot and Pound. Mingling prose and free verse, his earliest major work, In Parenthesis, (1937) is a kind of epic novel that distils his experiences of World War I. Written some twenty years after the event, it replaces the subjective lyricism of a Rupert Brooke with a cosmic con sciousness of what war means; in the course of the narrative, the modern soldier becomes identified with traditional Welsh heroes and the knights of the Arthurian legends.

title: Robert Lansing, Kathryn S. Hart Plan Marriage
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Sept. 16Miss Kathryn Stuart Hart, a descendant of John Hart, a signer of the Dec laration of Independence, plans to be married next month to Lieut. (jg.) Robert Ten Eyck Lansing, U.S.N., whose ancestor, John Lan sing, was a delegate from New York to the Constitu tional Convention in Phila delphia in the late 1780's.

title: Books:
description: The author of this new guide to efficient estate plan ning worked for 18 years for Investors Diversified Services the huge Minneapolisbased mutual fund complex. Conse quently he speaks loudly in favor of mutual funds and stresses that banks often are overly conservative in their investments. He fails, how ever, to say much about the heavy charges usually in volved in buying mutual funds, plus the annual man agement fee the fund re ceives before it figures divi dends for stockholders.

title: Fordham Dean to Resign
description: Dr. Harry N. Rivlin will re sign, effective next Aug. 31, as dean of the Fordham Uni versity School of Educition, the university has announced. Dr. Rivlin, who came to Ford ham in 1966, said that he wanted to take time to examine new directions in educational training. At Fordham he has concentrated on developing training programs for urban teachers.

title: LAFAYETTE BEATS KINGS POINT, 2013
description: EASTON, Pa., Sept. 16Tony Giglio, a junior halfback, ran 70 yards early in the fourth quarter today for a touchdown that enabled Lafayette to beat Kings Point, 2013.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: IF YOU MISSED OUR AD LAST WEEK CALL 5335350 AND WE'LL SEND YOU A COMPLETE BROCHURE. HUNTER COLLEGE CONCERT BUREAU.ADVT.

title: British Soldiers Kill a Gunman In Londonderry Catholic Area
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  British troops shot and killed a republican gunman during a battle in a Roman Catholic dis trict of Londonderry today, an army spokesman reported.

title: POOR LANDS FOUND GROWING POORER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The World Bank reported today that despite billions of dollars of foreign aid and impressive economic growth in the poor countries, it is probably true that the world's burden of pov erty is increasing rather than declining.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE IRRELEVANT ENGLISH TEACHER. By J. Mitchell Morse, 142 pages. Temple Univer sity Press. $6.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: MANILA, Sept. 17 (UPI) Fiftytwo prisoners at the pro vincial jail in the southwestern City Naga overpowereded their guards and escaped yesterday in the confusion following a mass drowning tragedy. The guards at the jail had been re duced to two when others rushed to help in the disaster that killed as many as 140 people in a religious river fes tival.

title: PLAN IS OFFERED ON MONEY REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17A group of leading Americans offered today a fairly detailed plan for world monetary re form, including an interim arrangement to keep the sys tem stable during the inter national negotiations on reform.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Striking Steamfitters Reject Pact

title: Confusion Is Delaying Federal Student Loans
description: The Federal Government's $1.3billionayear guaranteed student loan program, the larg est single source of financial aid for the nation's college stu dents, is in a state described by virtually everyone concerned as uncertain, confused, and sometimes chaotic.

title: Wheat Subsidy Debacle
description: As every student of elementary economics soon learns, one function of prices is to reflect the changing relations of supply and demand for different commodities. The Nixon Administration has now learned the hard way how expensive politically and economically it can be to try to prevent a basic pricein this case the price of wheatfrom performing its natural function. Like a latterday King Canute, the Administration sought to keep the world wheat price in the area of $1.64 this summer. It failed, and in the process cost the taxpayers more than $200 million in subsidies and provided the makings of what may turn out to be a serious scandal.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: NEW HAVENThe degradation of Public discourse is the heaviest blow Korea and Vietnam have inflicted upon the American spirit. Our leaders seem almost derailed by the stress of events and the lure of peace. As a result, foreign policy is discussed in an Or wellian language, according to the Red Queen's rule that words mean what she says they mean.

title: Credit Markets
description: The credit markets, which seemed last week to be show ing some signs of stabilizing following a dismal month marked by steadily higher in terest rates and lower prices, face more than their usual quota of uncertainty this week.

title: Port Notes
description: SeaLand Service's new highspeed North Atlantic containership service, sched uled to start at the end of the month, will be the first such operation to depend sub stantially on coastwide water borne feeder service.

title: DUNNE URGES USE OF FORMER JAILS
description: The conversion of three abandoned or only partially used correctional institutions in and near New York City to accommodate prisoners near ing release was urged yester day by State Senator. John R. Dunne, chairman of the Sen ate Committee on Crime and Correction.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Don't throw away your blazers or give your battle jackets to Goodwill Indus tries, but Bill Blass has come up with still another topping for pants.

title: 2 Slain in Bronx As Gangs Wield Guns and Knives
description: Two young men were slain early yesterday and two teen agers were wounded in the Bronx in two fights that the police said grew out of friction between street gangs.

title: $200,000 in Art Works Found In 2 Lockers at Grand Central
description: The police, acting on an anonymous telephone tip, re covered $200,000 worth of stolen museum prints and books last night from two coin lock ers in Grand Central Terminal.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  After a week of hearings into unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam, the Senate Armed Services Committee is far from resolving what some Senators consider the most pressing question raised thus far  did any of Lieut. Gen. John D. La velle's superiors know what he was doing? The hearings will con tinue tomorrow with testimony from Gen. John D. Ryan, the Air Force Chief of Staff, who in March dismissed General Lavelle as commander of the Seventh Air Force.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: City Councilman Robert I. Postel said yesterday he would seek both a state investigation of the city's Civil Service Com mission and a councilmanic interrogation of Mayor Lindsay for allegedly permitting dozens of people to be employed ille gally on municipal jobs.

title: Tanaka Gives Details of Trip
description: TOKYO Sept. 17 (AP) Premier Kakuei Tanaka said today that he would make his planned visit to Peking around Oct. 1 and would spend four or five days there for talks with Chinese leaders on nor malization of relations. He made the statement in Yama gata, northern Japan, during a visit to support his Liberal Democratic party's candidates in a byelection.

title: Chinatown Dispute Stalls EnglishClasses Opening
description: A complex dispute that in volves the Board of Education, state funding agencies and various Chinatown factions is holding up the opening of the second year of a highly praised experimental program to pro vide Englishlanguage instruc tion to Chinese immigrants.

title: No Delaware Dam
description: Governor Cahill of New Jersey, supported by Governor Peterson of Delaware and Governor Rockefellee's repre sentative, has taken the action needed to remove immediate danger of a dam and vast lake on the Dela ware River. Theoretically at least, the longthreatened project at Tocks Island is still a possibility, but for the most compelling reasons Mr. Cahill has now made construction of a dam and reservoir even in the future most unlikely.

title: World's Players Gather For the Chess Olympiad
description: SKOPJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 17 Riding on a wave of interest in chess generated by the re cent world, championship match between Bobby Fischer and Bo ris Spassky  players from throughout the world were gathering in this Macedonian city today amid tight security fit for the fortress headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: STANLEY J. HERTZIG
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 17Stanley J. Hertzig, general manager of the Metro politan News Company, died yesterday of a cerebral hemor rhage in Middlesex General Hospital, New Brunswick. He was 42 years old and lived at 18 Neal Drive.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: UDINE, Italy (AP)John Wil liams of Cranesville, Pa., the Olympic gold medalist retained the world archery championship today. He totaled 1,086 points out of a possible 1,120. Dennis McComak of Columbus, Kan., placed second with 1,053 points. Williams had won the title in England last year.

title: For Hearty Appetites, It's All You Can Eat And a Night Out, Too
description: Howard Johnson's has a customer who has become a legend in the com pany. He comes into one of the Long Island restaurants every Monday night and manages to consume an entire case (72 pieces) of barbecued chicken.

title: 180 Asians Leave on Flight
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 17 (Agence FrancePresse)  The first charter flight carrying ex pelled Asians left Entebbe airport tonight. More than 180 persons were aboard.

title: FARM OUTPUT UP IN NORTH AMERICA
description: ROME, Sept. 17 Farm pro duction in North America last year achieved the largest in crease8 per centsince 1958 and probably reached the high est level in history.

title: GUARDSMEN HELP AREAS IN JERSEY
description: MARLBORO TOWNSHIP, Sept. 17The New Jersey Na tional Guard, troubled by re cruiting and its public image, is moving its men in increasing numbers out of the armories and into the local communities for training.

title: Dolphins Dominate Chiefs in 2010 Victory Before 79,829 at Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 17 Everything is O.K. in Kansas City except the Chiefs. Open ing the season in their magnif icent new stadium, Arrowhead, before 79,829, the Chiefs were beaten thoroughly today by the Miami Dolphins, 2010, who were an alive, aggressive foot ball team.

title: TREVINO, ON 269, WINS BY A STROKE
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP) Lee Trevino passed Deane Be man with birdies on the first two holes and held on for a onestroke victory today in the $150,000 Greater St. Louis golf tournament.

title: Miller Boein's Man in Peking
description: Byron H. Miller has been travelling the world for the last 13 years selling Boeing airlin ers. Last week he returned from Peking with the biggest coup of alla $125million order for ten 707 jets.

title: The Companies We Keep
description: THETFORD CENTER, Vt.In the last ten years a good many Amer icans have begun to feel surrounded by a few monster corporations. I.T.T. is only one example. It is quite an ex ample, I admit. I.T.T. owns Sheraton Hotels, Avis cars, Morton Frozen Foods, Who's Who in America, the City Window Cleaning Company of Central Ohio, Bobbs Merrill, Levitt and Sons, and something over four hundred other companies. You almost can't live in the United States and not too easily in Europe without sooner or later being an I.T.T. customer.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: AMHERST, Mass.A curious sense of ?? ?? hovers over Mr. Nixon's at tack on Senator McGovern and the Democratic party. This, we feel, is where we came in, in 1946, in 1950, in 1954.

title: VERSATILITY LIFTS BLUEGRASS SHOW
description: A bluegrass purist might quibble about the choice of the Strange Creek Singers as the opening attraction in this sea son's monthly concert series of the Bluegrass Club of New York. Bluegrass, after all, is only one element In the Singers' reper tory, which includes oldtime country music, blues, vaude ville songs and original ma terial in a variety of veins.

title: Fatah Reports Beirut Ultimatum To Evacuate Southern Villages
description: CAIRO, Sept. 17 Lebanon early this morning ordered Palestinian commandos to evac uate all villages in southern Lebanon, the Palestinian resist ance organization Al Fatah reported here tonight.

title: CEVERT CAPTURES 210MILE CONTEST
description: BRAINERD, Minn., Sept. 17 (AP)  Francois Cevert of France overtook George Foil mer on the last lap today and won the 210mile Donnybrooke Speedway CanadianAmerican Cup road race that was marred by two spectacular crashes.

title: Arts Abroad
description: PARISThe current talk of Paris is Paris. Its people are awakening to the fact that lack of planning, absence of imagination, greed and in difference to the conditions that make urban life endur able are fast turning one of the last humane capitals of the world into one more infernal megalopo lis.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: ADULTERY AND MARRIAGE. UNLIKE OPEN MARRIAGE DISCUSSES ADULT ERY IN DEPTH. BOOKSTORES. (ADVT.).

title: Terrorists Kill 4 in Danang
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 17 (AP)Terrorists riding on motorbikes hurled hand gre nades at two coffee shops and an intersection in separate sec tions of Danang tonight, killing four persons and wounding 14, reports from the area said.

title: Rep. William Ryan, West Side Liberal, Is Dead of Cancer
description: Representative William F. Ryan, a founder of the Demo cratic Reform movement and a liberal hero for more than a decade died last night in Memorial Hospital at the age of 50.

title: President Arthur Kept Illness a Secret
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 16A shadow of death from kidney disease fell upon Chester Alan Arthur after he became the nation's 21st President, and he served the rest of his time in the White House with the secret knowl edge that he was a dying man, a conference of his torians was told today.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: Violence, less and less embarrassed by the limits imposed by centuries of lawfulness, is brazenly and victorious ly striding across the whole world. The world is being inundated by the brazen conviction that power can do anything, justice nothing.

title: Personal Finance: Bargaining in Cars
description: With the season for new car models at hand, many Americans are thinking of a new automobile. But, is there a price advantage for wait ing a few months?

title: Korean Singer In Debut Here
description: Under the auspices of three KoreanAmerican cul tural organizations, Young W. Hong made her New York debut Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. No biographical information was circulated about the Korean soprano, but Miss Hong's confident stage manner sug gested that she is no stranger to concert audiences. Her substantial voice has a pleas ing timbre, sweet in the low and midranges, and her sing ing has considerable musical ity, too.

title: LUCY JARVIS FILMING INSIDE MING TOMBS
description: Lucy Jarvis, a prochicer for the National Broadcasting Com pany television network, is filming the interiors of the heretofore forbidden and sacred Ming Dynasty tombs near Peking, she informed the network last week. A docu mentary featuring the tombs, and other historic Chinese sites titled The Forbidden City, will be televised some time in December on N.B.C.

title: U.S. Reports Planes Bomb Targets Near Hanoi
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 18 (AP)United States jets set fire to fuel, am munition and storage facilities in raids near Hanoi, but stayed away from the North Vietnam ese capital itself, the United States command announced yesterday.

title: Los Angeles Rivals Build Early Interest for Meeting
description: John McKay, who has coached such running backs as O. J. Simpson and Mike Gar rett in 13 years at Southern California, said his Current Trojans were the quickest team I've ever had, shortly after they trounced Oregon State, 516, at Los Angeles Sat urday night.

title: Ashe Withstands Emerson's Rally, Wins at Montreal
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 17 (Ca nadian Press)  Arthur Ashe fought off a comeback bid by Australia's Roy Emerson today to win the singles championship of the Montreal tennis tourna ment.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEPTUNE, N. J., Sept. 17 State Assemblyman Sylvio J. Faille was shot and killed last night in a lowermiddleclass residential neighborhood three miles west of Asbury Park.

title: A NIGERIAN STATE BATTLES EROSION
description: KANO, Nigeria, Sept. 7The forestry commissions of Nige ria's 11 other states are preoccupied with cutting trees down, but here in Kano State we are concerned with plant ing them, said the state's com missioner for forestry and co operatives, Alhaji Tanko Ya kassai.

title: Weicker Scores McGovern
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)  Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, charged today that Senator George McGov ern's policies would cost thou sands of Connecticut workers their jobs. Calling the Demo cratic Presidential nominee George, the jobkiller, Mr. Weicker said that Mr. Mc Govern was proposing policies that could produce depression conditions in Connecticut.

title: SECURITY IS TIGHT FOR U.N. OPENING
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17Security at United Nations headquarters, where the 27th annual session of the General Assembly opens Tues day, is the tightest this year since 1960, when many heads of government includig Nikita S. Khrushchev and Fidel Cas tro, were here.

title: End of a Charade
description: Little remains of the myth, carefully nurtured by the policymakers of three successive Administrations, that the United States is engaged in protecting a burgeoning democracy in South Vietnam. With every passing day the evidence mounts that the thin veneer of popular government was nothing more than a facade presented to the naive Americans in return for unlimited and unquestioning support.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT 60 ARABS KILLED AS RAID IS ENDED
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 17 ?? Israeli Army units com pleted their withdrawal from southern Lebanon today after encountering heavy resistance that delayed the return of some elements for at least 12 hours.

title: Dollar's Gains Calm Currency Markets
description: LONDON, Sept. 17Two months ago, the dollar was under such heavy attack in the foreignexchange markets that only heavy intervention by the European central banks kept it from breaking through its floor.

title: Flowers and Music Help People Enjoy the Summer's Last Sunday
description: Yesterday was the last Sunday of summer and it set a record, 92 degrees, for the date. It was a lovely remnant that begged New Yorkers to ignore the haze in the air and the first leaves underfoot and to turn the day into some thing special.

title: Reynolds and Japanese Tall On Uranium Plant Venture
description: TOKYO, Sept. 17 (UPI)A consortium of nine Japanese electric power companies has opened talks with the Reynolds Metal Company of the United States on construction of a $2.5billion uranium enrichment plant in Wyoming, a spokow man for the Japanese concerns said today.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: OAKLAND, Sept, 17More than 5,000 people jammed Mul ler's Park over the weekend to view fiery dances, songs and handicrafts of 1,700 American Indians, many in lavish cos tumes.

title: Snead Wins W. Va. Golf
description: PARKERSBURG, W. Va., Sept. 17 (AP)Sam Snead, 60 years old, shot a par 70 today for a 54hole total of 206 to capture his 16th West Virginia open golf championship.

title: Poland Leading Bloc's Efforts To Expand Scandinavian Links
description: WARSAW, Sept. 17When Poland's current leaders came to power nearly two years ago they said that whatever else needed changing at home, Po land's foreign policy would re main unchanged. In fact, it has changed.

title: ALBERT WOODRUFF JR.
description: GREENS FARMS, Conn., Sept. 17Albert C. Woodruff Jr., co founder and president of Fun wood, Inc., which operates the Calico Corners decoratorfab rics stores, died yesterday in Bridgeport Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived on Turkey Hill Road.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: DOVER, Del., Sept. 17 (AP) David Pearson broke out of an early leadswapping duel with Bobby Allison, Buddy Baker and Richard Petty today and captured the Delaware 500 at Dover Downs Raceway.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Issue of Duchess's Title Raised Anew in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 17The editor of Debrett's, the guide to the British peerage, as serted today that the British Parliament had acted uncon stitutionally and illegally in withholding the title Her Royal Highness from the Duchess of Windsor.

title: Sports of The Times
description: On the color screen, Joe Willie Namath drifted back into the pocket and threw with no apparent effort. Those expensive knees looked all right and there never was any question about the $400,000 arm. The pass gave the New York Jets first down on the Buffalo 16yard line. Joe Willie slouched out of the huddle, walking on the heels of his white shoes. He lifted the towel that John Schmitt, the center, wears as a curtain concealing his bottom, stooped to take the snap, pivoted and handed off to John Riggins, who slanted left for a touchdown. Joe Willie is a roundshouldered sex symbol but Riggins is built like Secretariat, the big kid in Rive Ridge's stable who won the Futurity at Belmont.

title: RURITANIA CHOICE AT BELMONT TODAY
description: Ruritania of the Greentree Stable, the 31 favorite in to day's 80th running of the Law rence Realization for 3year olds, will attempt to end a string of 12 stakes races with out a victory.

title: POOR LANDS FOUND GROWING POORER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The World Bank reported today that despite billions of dollars of foreign aid and impressive economic growth in the poor countries, it is probably true that the world's burden of pov erty is increasing rather than declining.

title: Bigelow Is OverAll Victor In Trenton Midget Car Race
description: TRENTON, Sept. 17Tom Bigelow of White Water, Wis., edged Wally Dallenbach of East Brunswick, N.J, by one foot today and captured the overall honors in the A.R.D.C. U.S.A.C. Midget Indy 100 at Trenton Speedway. Mel Kenyon of Lebanon, Ind. had won the first heat.

title: Jersey Lawmaker Slain; Robbery Termed Motive
description: NEPTUNE, N. J., Sept, 17 State Assemblyman Sylvio J. Failla was shot and killed last night in a lowermiddleclass residential neighborhood three miles west of Asbury Park.

title: Spain Considers Trial of 9 Held in Swedish Hijacking
description: MADRID, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  A Spanish military judge began interrogating nine Croa tian extremists today to decide if they should stand trial here in the hijacking, in Sweden of a Scandinavian Airlines System airlineror be sent back to Sweden.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT 60 ARABS KILLED AS RAID IS ENDED
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 17 Weary Israeli Army units com pleted their withdrawal from southern Lebanon today after encountering heavy resistance that delayed the return of some elements for at least 12 hours.

title: Reason on Guns
description: To me, calling for the confiscation of handguns jibes with the overreaction to hijackers.

title: MRS. F. SCHWEITZER
description: PENNINGTON, N. J., Sept. 17 Mrs. B. Dora Page Schweit zer, wife of the Rev. Dr. Fred erick Schweitzer, a retired Presbyterian minister who was president of Bloomfield College and Seminary from 1945 to 1959, died today at their home, 217 Hale Street. She was 87 years old.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: EAST ORANGE, Sept. 17 (UPI)  Upsala College an nounced a program today to encourage minority students to study for careers in the sci ences, especially medicine. The program is expected to train 20 college students and 120 high school students from the New ark area in mathematics, Eng lish, biology, physics, chemis try and geology over the next four years.

title: Alouettes Beat Lions, 2217
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 17 (Cana dian Press. The Montreal Aloucttes parlayed a nass in terception and a fumble into two secondhalf touchdowns and went on to defeat the Brit ish Columbia Lions, 2217 today in a Canadian Football League game.

title: Uganda Reports Invasion by Tanzania; It's a People's Revolt, the Latter Insists
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 17 Fighting reportedly broke out today in the already troubled East African nation of Uganda, and neighboring Tanzania said that a people's army was marching to overthrow Ugan da's controversial President, Maj. Gen. Idi Amin.

title: Family Income Rise Noted Here Even With a Recent Recession
description: Newly available census sam plings indicate that the incomes of New York City families kept rising despite the recession that started late in 1969, the Center for New York City Affairs of the New School for Social Re search reported yesterday.

title: Petition on Pennsy Loan Taken Under Advisement
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP)A Federal judge took un der advisement Friday a peti tion to block the Penn Central Company from initiating a plan to refinance a $64million loan.

title: Driver Hurt as Collision Spills 13 on Ball Team
description: A green panel truck, carrying 13 amateur ballplayers to a baseball game, sideswiped an automobile and overturned on the BrooklynQueens Express way yesterday, the police re ported. All who were injured in the accident were taken to Cumberland Hospital, where only the driver of the truck, Albert Alexander, 49 years old, of 651 Greene Avenue, Brook lyn, was admitted with multi ple fractures of the ribs. The ballplayers, who ranged from 9 to 16, were treated for minor injuries and released. The acci dent occurred near the Man hattan Bridge exit and tied up traffic for miles.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: An Israeli Briefing on Raid: No Looting I Repeat, No Looting
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 17 (AP) We are not thieves, we are fighters. No looting, I repeat, no lootingour mission is to kill or capture terrorists.

title: Fischer Is Back Home From Scene of Victory
description: America's new world chess champion, Bobby Fischer, slipped off an Icelandic Air lines plane at Kennedy International Airport last night, and said It's great to be back in America and added that he did not know whether he would participate in the Chess Olympiad in Yugoslavia this week.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SKOPJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 17 Riding on a wave of interest in chess generated by the re cent World championship match between Bobby Fischer and Bo ris Spassky  players from throughout the world were gathering in this Macedonian city today amid tight security fit for the fortress headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: EXGOV. L. C. STARK OF MISSOURI DEAD
description: CLAYTON, Mo., Sept. 17 (UPILloyd C. Stark, who helped shatter machine politics in Missouri in his one term as Governor and then saw his na tional political ambitions dashed by Harry S Truman, died today at his home in this St. Louis suburb. He was 85 years old.

title: Cambodia Names Staff Chief
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 17 (Agence FrancePresse) Maj. Gen. Sosthene Fernandez, commander of the southeastern military region, has been named Chief of Staff of Cambodia's armed forces, it was announced here today. The post had been held until now by Marshal Lon Nol, concurrently with the presidency. Marshal Lon Nol continues to be the Supreme Commander.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 17 (Reuters)The Prime Minister, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, was attacked bitterly here today at a leftwing rally attended by 50,000 people. Abdur Rab, a student leader and a veteran of the guerrilla forces that fought Pakistan, warned the Prime Minister: You have used in your speeches the metaphor of weapons. But have you even used a weapon? We know how to use weapons.

title: Bridge: Imaginative Bidding Makes A Worthless Hand Pay off
description: A preliminary step toward the selection of the 1973 North American international team was taken Friday and Saturday in Memphis. A group headed by Curtis Smith of Houston, Edith Kemp, Cliff Russell and Dingy Weiss, all of Miami, Pat Brennan of Amarillo, Tex., and Byron Greenberg of Tulsa, Okla., qualified for the semifinal playoff stage with a 141international matchpoint victory over Jack Blair of Tulsa, Paul Swanson of Morgantown, W. Va. Fred Hamilton of ?? Mich., and Howard Perlman of Southfield, Mich.

title: Third Straight Loss to Cubs Makes It Official: Mets Out of Pennant Race
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 17The pennant race that began with so much promise for the Mets last April ended for them to day when a 64 defeat by the Cubs marked their official elim ination.

title: Lyle Keeps Orioles 1 Out as New York Wins, 21
description: The New York Yankees bounced back into the race again yesterday when they ended a threegame slide and defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 21, before 30,072 fans at Yan kee Stadium.

title: Summit in Paris
description: MILAN, Italy Next month the heads of the ten governments of the enlarging European Economic Commu nity will gather in Paris for a summit meeting that will symbolizeor sim ulate  a strengthening of the Euro pean union.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: English Instruction Delayed by Dispute

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Newark Presses Search for Arsonist

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 17 (AP)Jim Ryun, the world recordholder from Kansas, again failed to win today, placing third in 3 minutes, 42.2 seconds in the 1,500meter race at an international track and field meet.

title: A Minor Major Causes Some Major Confusion
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 16A man named Minor W. Major was seated among the guests at the Tarrytown Conference of Six Empire State Presidents. Mr. Major teaches English at California State College in California, Pennsylvania. His wife, Catherine Delano Major, ex plained the name.

title: Laser Video Is Intriguing, but Is It Useful?
description: What was billed as a striking demonstration of one of the most exotic twentieth century technologies may not have been quite that. But it was a nifty trick nevertheless.

title: Miss Haynie Registers 68 For 206 to Win at Waco
description: WACO, Tex., Sept. 17 (AP) Sandra Haynie of Fort Worth shot a fourunderpar 68 today and finished 10 under at 206 ?? win the $20,000 Quality golf tournament, Mrs. Marlene Hagge slumped to a 73 and took second place at 210.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Hoyt Ammidon, who retired recent ly as a Commissioner of the Port ?? thority, complains in his letter of Aug. 30 that your newspaper con tinues erroneously to report that he and other Commissioners have stanchly resisted Port Authority in volvement in mass transportation. The difficulty, he explains, is not any lack of enthusiasm on their part for mass transportation but the problem of avoiding violence to the 1962 pact wherein Port Authority bondholders must be protected.

title: London Protests Arrests
description: LONDON, Sept, 17  The British Foreign Office an nounced tonight that a protest had been made to Uganda over the reported arrests of about 20 Europeans, most of them British. Officials said they had been assured that there was no question of Britons' being singled out, but that, in a pe riod of great tension, foreign ers were being required to es tablish their identities.

title: Rep. William Ryan, West Side Liberal, Is Dead of Cancer
description: Representative William F. Ryan, a founder of the Demo cratic Reform movement here and a liberal hero for more than a decide, died last night in Memorial Hospital at the age of 50.

title: MUSICIANS RESUMING TALKS ON CONTRACT
description: Negotiations are expected to resume tomorrow in an effort to head off a strike by members of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians against the League of New York The aters.

title: Clubhouse Is Hive of Rooney Workers
description: Singe 1904 it has been the district Democratic club  a our  story red  brick building, brownstone stoop, onetime carriage house in back now oc cupied by a caretaker  314 Clinton Street at Kane Street, Kane named for James Kane, who was district leader for 52 years.

title: Curbs on Foreign Capital Are Expected in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 16 Financial circles here expect the Government to act soon to curb foreign investment.

title: MRS. W. F. COGSWELL, OF CENTER FOR BLIND
description: Mrs. Estelle O'Brien Cogswell, a prominent Roman Catholic laywoman and widow of Wil liam F. Cogswell, lawyer and shipping executive, died yester day in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived at 141 East 72d Street and in Southampton, L. I.

title: Smith Beats Dibley
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP)Topseeded Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., defeated Colin Dibley of Australia, 64, 57, 64, 64, today in the sin gles final at the Central Cali fornia tennis championship.

title: Critics Find State's Program For Addict Care Is in Disarray
description: At a time when some fearful citizens and harried politicians are calling for compulsory re habilitation of heroin addicts, the nation's most ambitious ad dictcommitment and aftercare programrun by the New York State Narcotic Addiction Con trol Commissionis in disarray, according to its critics.

title: GUN TO SIMULATE DEPTHS OF EARTH
description: The fastest gun in the West, when completed, will not ride a sheriff's knee or an ?? hip. It will be in a subbasement of the California Institute of Technology.

title: GypsyCab Driver Shot to Death In 2d Such Slaying in 2 Weeks
description: A 58  year  old gypsy  cab driver was shot to death, ap parently by robbers, in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn early yesterday.

title: Myopia Riders Turn Back Monroe Cup Final, 54
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 17 Peter Poor scored on a 30yard shot with 10 seconds remaining in the game to give the Myopia Hunt Club of Hamilton, Mass., a 54 victory over the Monroe (Conn.) Polo Club today in the final of the Governor's Cup 5goal polo tournament at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Republicans could win con trol of Congress if President nixon is reelected by 60 per cent of the popular vote, a party spokesman said yester day.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Tarzan might have found Marilyn Meltzer's woven swings a bit tame. But in the Allan Meltzers' home, and several other Pittsburgh dwellings, Mrs. Meltzer's swings are the most popular place to read a book, carry on a conversation, or simply think.

title: Thompson Contributes 92Yard Kickoff Return
description: DETROIT, Sept. 17The of fense sputtered and the defense tired today as the New York Giants opened a new National Football League season by los ing to the Detroit Lions, 3016.

title: Maine Coast Closed
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 17 Spencer Apollonio, Commis sioner of a Mine's Department of Sea and Shore Fisheries, today ordered the state's 2,500 milelong coast closed to the digging of many types of shell fish, because of the spread of the toxic red tide algae.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 17Tom Bigelow of White Water, Wis., edged Wally Dallenbach of East Brunswick, N.J, by one foot today by one foot and capture the overalll honors in the A.R.D.C.U.S.A.C. Midget Indy 100 at Trenton Speedway. Mel Kenyon of Lebanon, Ind. had won the first heat.

title: Arnold Aron, Manufacturer Of Plastic Laminates, Dies
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Sept. 17Arnold Aron, presi dent and chief executive of the Pioneer Plastics Corpora tion of Auburn, Me., died here Friday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: DR. CHARLES A. SWEET
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Sept. 17Dr. Charles A. Sweet, who practiced medicine in Yonkers for 58 years, died yesterday in the Northern Westchester Hos pital. He was 92 years old and lived at 2 Turner Drive in Chappaqua.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: John McKay, who has coached such running backs as O. J. Simpson and Mike Gar rett in 13 years at Southern California, said his current Trojans were the quickest team I've ever had, shortly after they trounced Oregon State, 516, at Los Angeles Sat urday night.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 17 (AP)The possibility of Bobby Orr playing for Team Canada against the Soviet Union the fourgame windup of their eightgame series in Moscow later this month is remote, his agent said today.

title: JOB INVESTIGATION SOUGHT BY POSTEL
description: City Councilman Robert I. Postel said yesterday he would seek both a state investigation of the city's Civil Service Com mission and a councilmanic interrogation of Mayor Lindsay for allegedly permitting dozens of people to be employed ille gally on municipal jobs.

title: Israelis Leave Much Damage Behind
description: BINT JBAIL, Lebanon, Sept. 17Israeli armored forces pulled out of southern Lebanon today after a major search anddestroy mission against Palestinian commandos.

title: Advertising:
description: The effects of the child on the marketplace and of the marketplace on the child are getting a fair share of atten tion, both in the private sec tor and in the halls of gov ernment, not to mention cocktail parties.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 17The world Les Cason has taken a complete turnabout. Then again, maybe it moved too quickly for the 19yearold former high school allAmerican, who placed East Rutherford, one of New Jersey's smaller schools, on the national basketball map.

title: Hanoi Frees 3 P.O.W.'s; Wife and Mother Greet 2
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 17  An American mother ciasped her son, and an Ameri can wife embraced her husband here tonight in a room hot with television lights, at the release ceremony for three American prisoners of war, pilots shot down over North Vietnam.

title: DDay Minus One for Rivals in Brooklyn
description: The cars outside the Lowen stein for Congress offices at 383 Pearl Street in downtown Brooklyn have mostly outof State plates, and their worn bumper stickers pretty well identify the kind of people who have come to work to defeat Representative John J. Rooney in the courtordered rerun pri mary tomorrow.

title: JESS H. DAVIS, LED STEVENS INSTITUTE
description: Jess Harrison Davis, presi dent, emeritus of the Stevens Institute of Technology in Ho boken, N. J., died of cancer yesterday at his home in Char lottesville, Va., where he had moved after his retirement last June. He was 66 years old.

title: TOKYO ENVOY STIRS PROTEST IN TAIWAN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 17 Student demonstrators protest ing the arrival of Etsusaburo Shiina, the special envoy of Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Ja pan, broke through a phalanx of armed military policemen to surround some of the cars in Mr. Shiina's motorcade at the airport today.

title: Mrs. King Tops Mrs. Court
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 17 Topseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King of Palm Aire, Fla., play ing nearly perfect tennis, de feated Mrs. Margaret Court, 62, 62, today to win the $40,000 Four Roses women's tennis tournament.

title: President Arthur Kept Illness a Secret
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 16A shadow of death from kidney disease fell upon Chester Alan Arthur after he became the nation's 21st President, and he served the rest of his time in the White House with the secret knowl edge that he was a dying man, a conference of his torians was told today.

title: Kampala Takes News Calmly
description: KAMPALA, Sept. 17 News reports of an invasion were re ceived calmly here.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: A green panel truck, carrying 13 amateur ballplayers to a baseball game, sideswiped an automobile and overturned on the BrooklynQueens Express way yesterday, the police re ported. All who were injured in the accident were taken to Cumberland Hospital, where only the driver of the truck, Albert Alexander, 49 years old, of ?? Greene Avenue, Brook lyn, was admitted with multi ple fractures of the ribs. The ballplayers, who ranged from 9 to 16, were treated for minor injuries and released. The acci dent occurred near the Man nattan Bridge exit and tied up traffic for miles.

title: North Stars Lose Barrett
description: BLOOMINGTON. Minn.. Sept. 17 (AP)Fred Barrett suffered a broken bone in his right hand today, and will be lost to the Minnesota North Stars of the National Hockey League for an indefinite period.

title: PEARSON TRIUMPHS IN 500MILE RACE
description: DOVER, Del., Sept. 17 (AP) David Pearson broke out of an early leadswapping duel with Bobby Allison, Buddy Baker and Richard Petty today and captured the Delaware 500 at Dover Downs Raceway.

title: Tidewater Downs Hawaii To Gain in World Baseball
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 17 (AP) Tidewater edged Hawaii, 21, in 10 innings yesterday, com pleting the roundrobin seg ment of the Kodak World Base ball Classic.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: BRAINERD, Minn., Sept. 17 (AP)  Francois Cevert of France overtook George Foll mer on the last lap today and won the 210mile Donnybrooke Speedway CanadianAmerican Cup road race that was marred by two spectacular crashes.

title: POLLUTION STUDIES TERMED DEFICIENT
