description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Far too little has been done toward assessing the impact that pollution and other degra dations of the environment have upon mental health, a fed erally sponsored study has con cluded.

title: Confusion Is Delaying Federal Student Loans
description: The Federal Government's $1.3billionayear guaranteed student loan program, the larg est single source of financial aid for the nation's college stu dents, is in a state described by virtually everyone concerned as uncertain, confused, and sometimes chaotic.

title: Penn Central Disappoints Ronan
description: In the last 20 months the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has taken over three Penn Central commuter lines here in an effort to rescue pas senger service, but the agency is unhappy with the way it says the railroad, which re tained operational control, has carried out its part of the agreement.

title: Appeals Court Supports C.I.A. In Blocking Article by ExAide
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit has upheld a lower court ruling restraining a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency from publishing books or arti cles about his former employer without prior authorization from the Director of Central Intelligence or a designated representative.

title: SaveaWatt? No, Replies G.E.
description: Some of the country's power companies  including New York City's Consolidated Edison are urging donsumers to Save A Watt by cutting back on their use of electricity. But Vernon A. Rydbeck, on the other hand, is touring the country exhorting utility executives not to let up on their selling ef forts.

title: YOM KIPPUR RITES URGE DEDICATION
description: Yom Kippur began at sun down yesterday as rabbis in crowded temples and syna gogues called on Jews to re dedicate themselves to Juda ism's religious meaning and play a stronger role in furthering social justice for all peoples. The 24hour period of fasting and selfevaluation capped the 10 High Holy Days.

title: $7,700 for a Rembrandt
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (UPI)A Rembrandt drawing, Study of an Aged Woman, valued at $10,000 three years ago, was sold at auction today to an engineer, Jan Kolar of Laguna Beach. The sale price was $7,700.

title: A State Unit Examines ExAddict Hiring Bias
description: The temporary State Com mission evaluating drug laws is looking into the problem of discrimination by employ ers against former drug ad dicts. It has scheduled a hearing for 10 A.M. Wednes day at 270 Broadway.

title: MRS. WILLIAM HUDGINS
description: Mrs. William R. Hudgins, a prominent golfer and wife of the president of the Freedom National Bank here, died Satur day afternoon, apparently of heart attack, while playing golf at the Knob Hill Golf Club in Freehold, N. J.

title: Stage: Pinter Homecoming at CSC
description: The CSC Repertory is up and away at its Greenwich Village home on West Third Street with what promises to be its most ambitious sea son yet. The repertory of eight plays ranges from Shakespeare and Buechner to John Whiting and Tom Stop pard. In addition, and With an eightplay subscription priced at $15, this may be one of the last theatrical bar gains in New York City. Fur thermore, this year the com pany is also offering, in ad dition to its classics, a new play series, which will pro duce 8 to 10 new plays dur ing the season.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP)John Havlicek signed today with the Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Asso ciation, after holding out for one week, a team spokesman said.

title: 9 Die in Alberta Car Crash
description: GUNN, Alberta, Sept. 17 (Reuters)Nine people were killed and another was critical ly injured early today in a headon collision of two cars on Route 43 near this town, about 45 miles northwest of Edmonton.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 17 (AP) Phil Esposito of the Boston Bruins scored with 47 seconds left in the game today, giving Team Canada a 44 tie with Sweden.

title: Krishnan Wins in Singapore
description: SINGAPORE, Sept. 17 (AP) India's Ramanathan Krishnan won the second Asian invita tional tennis singles title today beating Edwardo Cruz of the Phillippines, 62, 119, 61.

title: Arab Guerrillas Are Reported to Get Direct Shipments of Soviet Weapons
description: GENEVA, Sept. 16The So viet Union has recently begun to supply weapons directly to the Arab guerrilla organization Al Fatah, sources close to the Fatah leadership reported this week.

title: INNOCENT PASSERBY DIES IN KNIFE FIGHT
description: A youth who the police said was an innocent passerby was fatally stabbed Saturday night in a knife fight in Washington Heights that left seven other youths seriously injured.

title: 4 Policemen Close DirtyBook Stores In Impromptu Raid
description: Four rookie foot patrolmen in Times Square who tired of apol ogizing to tourists for the sex ually oriented material for sale on their beats got together yes terday and raided four dirty book stores in the area.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PARSIPPANY, N. J., Sept. 17 The Democratic leaders of Essex. County gave Sargent Shriver a hearty welcome to day, fully aware that the fate of their local candidates de pends heavily on the success of the national ticket.

title: New England Puts Curbs on Shellfish As Red Tide Gains
description: BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) Clam digging was banned in Maine, New Hampshire and Massachusetts as the red tide, a poisonous algae in the water, spread along the northern New England coast today.

title: J. Geils Band Brightens the Rock Scene
description: What a pleasure it was to go to the Academy of Music Saturday night and hear some good old foot stompin', energycharged rock n roll music. After a week that had been dominated by disap pointing appearances from such alleged rock heavies as Rod Stewart with Faces and the T. Rex band, it was beginning to look as if the heavily scheduled fall pop music scene might end with a whimper instead of a bang.

title: Tunnel Under Park Ave. Is Closing for 7 Months
description: The 100yearold, sevenblock tunnel under Park Avenue south of Grand Central Ter minal is to be closed to traffic this week for the start of seven months of construction and re pair work.

title: Johnson Says Change Keeps America Strong
description: TEMPLE, Tex., Sept. 17 (UPI)Former President Lyn don B. Johnson, in his first public speech since his heart attack earlier this year, said yesterday that the United States would continue to be strong so long as it accepted change.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)The Presidential candi date of the American Party said today that President Nixon wanted to surrender South Vietnam to the Communists on the installment plan while his Democratic opponent, Senator George McGovern, wanted to surrender immediately.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, Sept. 17 (AP)Gary Player of South Africa will face the challenge of Lee Trevino of the United States and Britain's Tony Jacklin in defending his World Match Play golf championship next month.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)Mrs. Sargent Shriver, speaking to a Jewish rally on the eve of the Yom Kippur re ligious observance, pleaded to day for love, wisdom and compassion in the world. The wife of the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee spoke to a rally of 2,000 Washington area Jews gathered on the El lipse behind the White House to protest a stiff emigration tax levied by Russia against Jews desiring to leave the country.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Sept. 17Senator George McGovern began the second straight two week swing of his Presidential campaign here today by calling for the suspension of a Cabi net member and declaring the failure of Richard Nixon's war on drugs.

title: The Last Month
description: With Congress well into the final month of this session before probable adjournment in early October, the risks are high that hasty, politically motivated decisions will be made on several major issues.

title: Schools Closed Today To Mark Yom Kippur
description: Because of the Jewish holy day, Yom Kippur, the city's public schools and the Board of Education headquarters and decentralized district of fices will be closed today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP)  Philadelphia Orchestra members approved a new three year contract today, hours be fore the old, one expired. The agreement calls for a $330 minimum weekly salary, includ ing recording guarantees.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP)John Havlicek signed today with the Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Asso ciation, after holding out for one week, a team spokesman said.

title: Service Station Man Killed, 2 Customers Shot in Illinois
description: MORTON GROVE, ILL., Sept. 17 (UPI)  A gunman walked into an allnight service station early today, took $400 from the cash register and then killed the service station attendant and seriously wounded two customers, the police said.

title: Shelly Rouda Wed to John Rosen
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 Miss Shelly Ann Rouda, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl R. Rouda of Hillsbor ough, was married here yes terday to Dr. John David Rosen, son of Dr. and Mrs. John N. Rosen of New York and Gardenville, Pa. Rabbi Sanford Rosen performed the ceremony at the Stan ford Court Hotel.

title: Monticello Superfecta Is Under Investigation
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Sept. 17An $822 superfecta won by a long shot at the Monti cello Raceway Thursday night is under investigation by New York, State harness racing officials. The race was won by Greg Scott, who paid $59.40.

title: Residents of East 81st Street Celebrate Closing of Tambourine Bar on the Block
description: They strung colored lights on their balconies, and some Yorkville residents put out flags, and still others fes tooned their windows with flowers.

title: 1 IN 7 ROAD DEATHS MAY BE A SUICIDE
description: A significant proportion of automobile fatalitiesperhaps as high as one out of seven may be suicides and not acci dents as they are almost al ways listed, a team of Houston doctors has found.

title: Roger D. Blanc Weds June Ku
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 17Miss June C. Ku, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. P. M. Ku, was married here this after noon to Roger David Blanc, son of Mrs. Are P. Blanc of Manhasset, L. I., and Robert S. Blanc of Plandome, L. I.

title: Steel Price Rise Expected To Occur Gradually in 1973
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17, 1972 Until recently it was assumed that the prices of most steel products would go up in Janu ary.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read with considerable surprise the letter in the Aug. 28 Times from Tom Jorling, former minority counsel to the Senate Committee on Public Works, which criticized the national land use legislation presently pending before Congress (S. 632) because of its failure to establish Federal rules controlling the use of land. I am afraid Mr. Jorling apparently misconceives the purpose of the legislation.

title: Nixon Aide Named in State
description: Bradford J. Race Jr., a law yer, will be executive assistant to R. Burdell Bixby, the general campaign director of the New York Committee to Reelect the President, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Governor Rockefeller, the chairman of President Nixon's campaign in the state, made the announce ment, Mr. Race, 27 years old, is a Yonkers resident. He worked in Mr. Rockefeller's 1968 Presi dential campaign and his 1970 reelection campaign.

title: Nastase Triumphs
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 17 (AP) Ilie Nastase of Rumania beat a hometown favorite. Tom Gor man, 64, 36, 63, today to win the Seattle tennis tournament.

title: Carol A. Molloy Married
description: WANTAGH, L.I., Sept. 17 Miss Carol Anne Molloy and Anthony Philip Geraldi were married here this after noon in St. Francis de Chan tal Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Michael McLoughlin, who also celebrated the nup tial mass. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Thomas P. Hawkes of Wantagh. The bridegroom, a graduate of Rider College, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Ger aldi of Valley Stream.

title: Jersey Restaurants
description: Colligan's Stockton Inn, Bridge and Main Streets, Route 29, Stockton, N. J., (609) 3979864, 3971250.

title: Jersey Notes
description: For more than a year there has been considerable contro versy over whether the State House dome would ever be gold again. In 1971, state engineers discovered that the dome was covered with rust and filled with cracks, and ordered its restoration. The first change the public saw with the restora tion was a dome the color of rust, which reflected a temporary, pri mer coating ap plied as a preservative to the copper dome base. But the color made a few legislators grumble, more so when it appeared after nearly a year that the color might be there to stay.

title: Throngs Turn Minnesota Hamlet Into a Global Center of Plowing
description: VERNON CENTER, Minn., Sept. 17This quiet fanning hamlet in southern Minne sota, normally the home to 347 souls, entertained a quarter of a million visitors last week for the 19th world plowing champlonships.

title: Uganda: Lush but Troubled Nation
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 17 (Reuters)Uganda, a lush African land of 10 million people on the shores of Lake Victoria, gained independence from the British in 1962. It was governed by Milton Obote until January of last year, when Maj. Gen. Idi Amin ousted him.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: With a sense of shock I realized, as I read S. J. Perelman's The New Body Snatchers (OpEd Sept. 9], that he was, degrading one of the most revered nicknames in Britain, that of The Old Contemptibles, by applying it to pia giarism by commercial artists in this Country.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MITCHELLVILLE, Md., Sept. 17 (AP)President Nixon made an unexpected visit to an Italian American picnic today and he toured a Roman Catholic nurs ing home for the elderly.

title: Opera Alfresco Battles Clamor
description: Bucking the familiar dis tractions that are making outdoor music in New York a grisly prospect (in this case roving bands of noisy chil dren and the roar of the nearby Met Opera aircondi tioning), the Interstate Opera Association ventured into Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park Saturday night for a double bill of The Friend by Terrence Hammond and Pagliacci.

title: California's Rate of Growth Drops Sharply After 7 Decades of Rapid Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Reversing a trend that began in 1900, California's striking rate of population growth has dropped sharply in the last two years, according to a new Census Bureau study.

title: BASIC CHANGE DUE FOR TAXEXEMPTS
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 17The taxexempt bond mar ketthe normal place where states and cities raise millions of dollars for schools, streets, sewers and other such uses is soon going to change dras tically. For example:

title: Penn Central Disappoints Ronan
description: In the last 20 months the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has taken over three Penn Central commuter lines here in an effort to rescue pas senger service, but the agency is unhappy with the way it says the railroad, which re tained operational control, has carried out its part of the agreement.

title: Davis Wins City Tennis
description: Wilbert Davis defeated Steve Gottlieb in the City Public Parks tennis tournament final yesterday, 36, 61, 75, 30 (re tired) at the Central Park courts. The men's senior di vision went to Joe Turoczy, who defeated Tom Hirsch, 36, 62, 63. The women's crown was won by Valerie Sitkopp by default from Sheila Maroshick.

title: 2 SPACE MISSIONS CHARTED BY U.S.
description: Two new projects of plane tary explorationone for Ju piter and Saturn, the other for Venusare being organized by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: TEAM CANADA GAINS 44 TIE WITH SWEDEN
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 17 (AP) Phil Esposito of the Boston Bruins scored with 47 seconds left in the game today, giving Team Canada a 44 tie with Sweden.

title: Women in All Key Roles During Ordination Rites
description: NORTHFIELD, Conn., Sept. 17The first religious service of ordination ever held by a Major denomination in which women assumed all the princi pal roles was held here this aft ernoon in a white frame coun try church about 20 miles north of Waterbury.

title: Football Season Opens
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 17It isn't very often that something nice happens to the New York Jets in War Memorial. Stadium, but it did today as they opened their 1972 National Football League season by defeating the Buffalo Bills, 4124, before a sellout crowd of 46,206.

title: Pressure Mounts For Prison Reform in Mississippi
description: PARCHMAN, Miss., Sept. 17 The Mississippi State Peniten tiary, long a place of killing, homosexual rape, beating, knif ing and varied other forms of violence to the body and the spirit, has come under the greatest pressure for reform in its 69year history.

title: Indians Top Boston, Detroit Climbs .001 From First Place
description: Boston's firm ?? on the top spot in the American League's Eastern Division broke momentarily yesterday and the pennant health of the three other contenders suddenly was blooming again.

title: 6 Die in Crash on Coast
description: TOPPENISH, Wash., Sept. 17 (UPI)Six teenagers and young children were killed last night when their car overturned and landed on its top in a canal east of Toppenish. Three other es caped. A stale patrol spokesman said that the vehicle had failed to make a lefthand curve, went off the road, crossed a canal and struck an embankment, falling into the canal on its top.

title: POLICE SAY DANCER WOUNDED BURGLAR
description: An alleged burglar was shot and seriously wounded early yesterday by a Greenwich Vil lage man he had stabbed re peatedly with a screwdriver when he was caught ransacking the man's apartment, the police said. Both the apartment dwell er and the alleged burglar were charged.

title: Williams Wins Archery Title
description: UDINE, Italy (AP)John Wil liams of Cranesville, Pa., the Olympic gold medalist retained the world archery championship today. He totaled 1,086 points out of a possible 1,120. Dennis McComak of Columbus, Kan., placed second with 1.053 points. Williams had won the title in England last year.

title: Advertising:
description: There is a longstanding bias among advertisers and agency people against maga zines that readers receive free. They don't think they're being read.

title: Campaign Letter
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16  Where have all the issues gone?

title: Huntington Halts 2 Rivals To Take L. I. Polo Tourney
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Sept. 17 Huntington defeated Aiken, 53, and edged Bethpage, 32, today to win the Long Island Polo League roundrobbin championship tournament. Bethpage defeated Aiken, 53, in the other threechukker match.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The Board of Education will hold a hearing tomorrow on the controversial appointment of Luis Fuentes as superin tendent of School District 1 on the Lower East Side. Mr. Fuentes, who has been accused of making antiSemitic re marks three years ago, when he was the city's first Puerto Rican school principal, has aroused the ire of Jewish groups who have been seeking his ouster. The hearing at the board's headquarters at 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn, at 8 P.M., will, however, be concerned with his method of appointment last July 19.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 Senator George McGovern's field organization is like an automobile on a cold winter morning. It had a lot of trouble getting started in the chill of despondency that followed Senator Thomas F. Eagleton's ouster from the ticket seven weeks ago. Now the operation is running well but the road is icy and it is still not going at full speed.

title: Football Season Opens
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 17It isn't very often that something nice happens to the New York Jets in War Memorial. Stadium, but it did today as they opened their 1972 National Football League season by defeating the Buffalo Bills, 4124, before a sellout crowd of 46,206.

title: New JERSEY
description: BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP)The Cape Cod Planning and Eco nomic Development Commis sion will soon begin a three tofour year study of water availability that could deter mine future patterns of popu lation growth on the cape. The study is expected to cost $700,000. Norman H. Cook, executive director of the com mision, gave the cape's sum mer population as 400,000 and said that the present water supply might not be capable of serving more people.

title: Judge Listens, Soothes A Musician's Neighbors
description: A French horn player in Stuyvesant Town whose practice sessions allegedly drove at least one neighbor up the wall was ordered by a judge yesterday to confine her playing to specified hours or face eviction.

title: Chimpanzee Raised To Be a Best Pal
description: What's a magician to do when he tires of pulling rabbits out of his hat?

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The General Electric Company yesterday received a $21million Navy contract for continuation of research and development on the nuclear propulsion plant for the Trident submarine pro gram.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION UNCHANGED IN WEEK
description: Domestic steel production was unchanged last week at 2,496,000 net tons, the Ameri can Iron and Steel Institute re ported yesterday.

title: 2Year Pact Approved
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass., Sept. 18 (AP)Teachers here approved a new twoyear contract today by a 2 to 1 margin, ending a strike that had closed Somer ville schools since Sept. 8, a school spokesman announced.

title: Contract Signed on Offshore Nuclear Plant
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18 The potential of offshore floating nuclear power is lands moved a step nearer reality today at a point just under three miles off the Jersey coast.

title: A.T. & T.'s Earnings Rise in Quarter
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday that thirdquarter profits climbed to $641.2million from $531.5million in the year earlier period.

title: National Securities Cites Resignation of President
description: The resignation of Walter E. Auch as president of the Na tional Securities and Research Corporation, which has in ex cess of $900million in mutual fund assets under management, was announced yesterday.

title: Suit for Ballots in Spanish
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP)  A Puerto Rican organization asked the United States Dis trict Court today to require that Spanishspeaking voters be provided with ballots and voting instructions in their lan guage at the Nov. 7 election. The suit, filed by the Puerto Rican Organization for Politi cal Action, contends that with out such an order Spanish speaking voters will be sub ject to a de facto English literacy test outlawed as un constitutional by the United States Supreme Court.

title: COMPLAINT NAMES GRAPHIC SCANNING
description: The Western Union Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had filed a complaint in Federal District Court here charging the Graphic Scanning Corporation with violation of the Federal Communications Act.

title: STEADY LEVEL SEEN FOR CAR PURCHASES
description: Consumers are unlikely to in crease their outlays for automo biles substantially in the months ahead, according to an analysis published by the Commercial Credit Company of Baltimore.

title: WARPROTEST FAST MARKED BY 100 HERE
description: Six youthful Vietnam war protesters who said they had fasted on water for 40 days gathered with about 100 friends last night to mark their absti nence and discuss future anti war action.

title: 2 TOP $50,000 MARK, A FIRST IN L.P.G.A.
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 18 (AP) Kathy Whitworth and Jane Bla lock have passed the $50,000 mark in earnings this year, the first players in the history of the Ladies Professional Golf As sociation to reach that figure.

title: Colorado's Cornerback Quick To Get Award With His Speed
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 18 (UPI)  Cullen Bryant, who used his speed to perform two Outstanding plays for Colorado on Saturday, was named today the Big Eight's defensive play er of the week.

title: ATHEISTS WAVER, MOSCOW WARNS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 18Pravda has sharply attacked Commu nist party members for taking part in religious ceremonies.

title: Imperial Oil Strikes Well
description: EDMONTON, Sept. 18 (Cana dian Press)Imperial Oil Ltd., announced Monday it had struck medium crude oil at the 8,100foot level of its explora tory well, Ivik J26, in the Mackenzie Delta.

title: Air Chief Defends Policy Of Punishing Lavelle Only
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Gen. John D. Ryan, the Air Force chief of staff, defended today his decision to punish only Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle for unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam and told Senate investigators that he couldn't guarantee that such incidents wouldn't hap pen again.

title: Sports of The Times
description: John Mackey joined the San Diego Chargers yester day after a week of intrigue and infighting. It's as much a part of the National Football League as the games them selves, but seldom as obvious. And seldom as demeaning. To most N.F.L. aficionados, John Mackey is remembered for being selected two years ago as pro football's all time tight end. When he ran with a completed pass for the Baltimore Colts, he dragged tacklers with him. The lucky ones fell off, it was said. As the president of the N.F.L. Players Association, he had the same drive. To the consternation of the club owners, he held 1,300 players together two years ago during pro football's only strike. And he did it his way. At one of the bar gaining sessions, he appeared in a purple jump suit, Why are you wearing that thing? an owner asked.

title: M'GOVERN URGES STRIPMINING BAN
description: LOGAN, W. Va., Sept 18 Senator George McGovern came to West Virginia's coal country today to assert that the Gov ernment should put an end to the strip mining that is de stroying much of this beautiful state.

title: Private Investment Director
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) President Nixon today desig nated Willis C. Armstrong, As sistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, to serve on the board of directors of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. He succeeds Na thaniel Samuels, who resigned as deputy Under Secretary of State May 31. The corporation was established in 1969 to mobilize participation of United States private capital and skills in the economic and social prog ress of lessdeveloped friend ly countries.

title: M'MANUS TRIUMPHS IN TENNIS ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP) Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., beat Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico, 46, 63, 76, today as the $60,000 Pacific South west open tennis tournament opened.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 18  A motorvehicle agent and another man have been indicted on charges of using the agent's 13yearold son in a scheme to obtain and collect on $4,960 in unsigned winning lottery tickets.

title: Margaret Mead Studies Her Own Life in Latest Book
description: On one of the walls in a small, cluttered room under the redtiled roof and be tween the gingerbread tur rets of the American Museum of Natural History are seven closets running from the wall to the ceiling. On the opposite wall is another book case, equally jammed. These shelves hold nothing but the books, articles, monographs, scientific essays and other publications written or edited by Margaret Mead.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: That The Times should find the cur rent wave of black movies a subject worthy of an editorial [Sept. 12] is interesting enough, but more inter esting is your assertion that...mov ies with allwhite casts have nothing to do with the issue of race.... In deed, such movies more often than not have everything to do with race.

title: Car Hits Paraders in Italy
description: BERGAMO, Italy, Sept. 18 (Reuters)  Fourteen people were injured when a car struck a religious procession in the nearby village of Calcinate in northern Italy. The police said the car hit the procession at high speed, knocking over members of the municipal band. The 19yearold driver was attacked by the crowd, but escaped. He later gave himself up.

title: Newburgh Man, 29, Is Held In Slaying Outside His Home
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 18 (AP)A man was arrested and charged with murder this morn ing, shortly after another man was gunned down in front of a house in this Lower Hudson Valley city, the police said.

title: Woman Rabbi, in First Yom Kippur Sermon, Calls for Individual Thought
description: The first woman ordained to the rabbinate in this country preached her first High Holy Day sermon yesterday and called on her congregation to face the coming national elec tions and other current issues as individuals and not as a Jewish community.

title: LEO BAUER, 59, DIES; A BRANDT ADVISER
description: BONN, Sept. 18 (Reuters)  Leo Bauer, one of Chancellor Willy Brandt's closest advisers and a leading member of the Social Democratic party, died last night after a long illness, the party reported today. He was 59 years old.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: WASHINGTONThe North Viet namese launched their massive inva sion of South Vietnam last Easter weekend. What have been the results of that invasion? In a word, failure.

title: Mrs. Nixon, on Her Own, Begins Campaign Swing
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18  Mrs. Richard M. Nixon began her first and longest political swing on her own for the 1972 Pres idential campaign today by de claring: I'm taking, the White House to the people.

title: F.D.I.C. WILL APPEAL BANKMERGER RULING
description: The Federal Deposit Insur ance Corporation will appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit a lower court decision that would significantly limit the discretion of Federal bankreg ulatory agencies to deny bank merger applications, it was announced yesterday.

title: Rooney, Lowenstein Face New Primary In Brooklyn Today
description: Seeking to avoid the chaos at the polls that marred the June 20 primary, the Board of Elections is taking special pre cautions to assure that today's rerun of the Democratic pri mary in the 14th Congressional District in Brooklyn is conducted smoothly.

title: Sanitation Officers Report Ratifying of New Contract
description: Frank Sisto, President of the 1,400member Sanitation Offi cers Association, announced yesterday the ratification of a 30month contract retroactive to the start of last year.

title: Personalities: Miss Gould's Aim
description: With the Olympics over, at least two medal winners are trying to pick up nonathletic life styles that were shelved in preparation for the Munich Games. Shane Gould of Au stralia, the 15yearold swim mer who won three gold medals, a silver and a bronze, said upon returning to Sydney yesterday: I'm tired and looking forward to school. I wish to be an ordi nary teenager.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Nobody, except the tax dodger, is rationally opposed to closing tax revenue loopholes, including loopholes through which phony organizations conceal what otherwise would be taxable income.

title: Morton Hesitant on Car Ban
description: BUTTE, Mont., Sept. 18 (UPI) Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton hesitated yesterday to endorse a ban on automobile traffic in the nation's national parks as suggested in a report by the Conservation Foundation on National Parks. Mr. Morton declined comment on the report until he reads it, but he said that cars were the only feasible mode of transportation for some people to see the scenic areas.

title: ... Alliance Policy...
description: While building bridges to the Russians and Chinese, Mr. Nixon has been burning bridges to America's allies in West Europe and Japan. The Democratic platform opened this issue and it has been carried further by the head of the McGovern foreign policy task forces, Prof. Abram Chayes of Harvard, in visiting Europe to combat fears about Mr. McGovern's alleged isolationism. Mr. Chayes argued that President Nixon has already iso lated the United States. We have affronted our friends here in Europe as well as in Japan, he said. We have dealt with them as adversaries. This is a question the Democratic candidate himself needs to address, along with the alternative policy he would propose.

title: JOB QUOTA CONFLICT DENIED BY HODGSON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson said today that the Labor Department's equalem ploymentopportunity programs did not conflict with President Nixon's caution against racial job quotas.

title: ... The Essential Choice
description: But America's European allies fear a McGovern admin istration even more than they dislike the Nixon one. The Democratic candidate has said that he is a con vinced internationalist. Withdrawal from Vietnam and his Come Home America call, Mr. McGovern has said, are intended not as moves toward disengagement every where but as steps that would enable the United States to concentrate on really vital interests abroad, Western Europe and the Mediterranean first of all. This assurance, however, remains vague. What is concrete, in European minds, is the McGovern proposal to withdraw 170,000 of America's 300,000 troops from NATO's front lines.

title: WIRE TAP EVIDENCE IN U.S. CASE BARRED
description: DETROIT, Sept. 18A United States District judge here ruled today that wiretap evidence in a huge gambling case was inad missible because officials in the Department of Justice had sought authorization improperly for the wiretap.

title: Apollo 15 Stamps Sale Linked To NASA and ExHughes Aides
description: COCOA, Fla., Sept. 18 (AP) The manager of a printing com pany said today that the en velopes carried to the moon aboard Apollo 15 and later sold to stamp dealers had been or dered by a NASA official and billed to a businessman who then worked for the Hughes Enterprises.

title: School Player, 16, Dies
description: HARLETON, Tex., Sept. 18 (AP)Terry Ray Muse, 16 years old, a quarterback for Harleton High School, died last night in a Shreveport, La., hospital fol lowing his collapse while play ing in a football game against ComoPickton last Friday.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Senator John Stennis of Mississippi is not likely, to be elected man of the year by the N.A.A.C.P., but he may be the ideal person to investigate the strange case of Gen. John P. Lavelle and the unauthorized bombing of North Viet nam. Not only is the Senator a man of unquestioned personal integrity and one of those Southern patriarchs who command exceptional respect in the Senate; he also has been active and effective for so long as a member of the Armed Services Committee that he knows as well as any man can where the bodies are buried in the Pentagon and the boondoggles are buried in the defense budget.

title: Seabee Memorial Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) President Nixon signed today legislation authorizing construction of a memorial to the Navy Seabees. A Washing ton site for the memorial will be chosen by the Secretary of the Interior.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Sept 18 (AP)  Bill Screws, Western Michigan University's junior quarterback, will be lost for the rest of the season. A team spokesman said today that Screws, 20, suffered a knee in jury in last Saturday's 4114 loss to Fresno State.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Lee Trevino, winner of the $30,000 top prize in the St. Louis golf classic Sunday, has moved closer to a second straight $200,000 season on the pro tour.

title: Dawdle Starts Gas Search
description: The Dowdle Oil Corporation, Midland, Tex., announced yes terday it had begun drilling operations on the first of a planned 50well natural gas program on 2,712 acres of oil and gas leases in West Central Pennsylvania. The company ac quired the leases from the Peo ples Natural Gas Company of Pittsburgh, which will take all the full production under long term contracts with Dowdle.

title: UGANDA INVADERS REPORTED HALTED BY AMIN'S TROOPS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 18 A small army that reportedly invaded Uganda from neighbor ing Tanzania yesterday in an attempt to depose the contro versial President of Uganda, Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, appeared today to have been outfought and pushed back.

title: Terror at Turtle Bay
description: The problems of the world come to roost at the doorstep of the United Nations in an exceptionally urgent sense today as the representatives of 132 nations gather under extraordinary security precautions for the 27th session of the General Assembly at Turtle Bay.

title: Canonero II on Tap
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 18 (UPI)Canonero II, winner of the Kentucky Derby and Preakness in 1971, will be en tered Wednesday in the Stymie Handicap at Belmont Park, the King Ranch owner, Robert J. Kleberg, said today. Riva Ridge also is entered.

title: Future of Philadelphia Plan for Minorities in Doubt
description: PHILADELPHIAThree and a half years ago, Andrew Free man was excited over the resurrection by President Nixon of a Johnson Administration plan to open up this city's tough but highpaying skilled construction jobs to minorities.

title: Akim Tamiroff, Actor, Is Dead; Had Screen Career of 35 Years
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Sept. 18 (AP)Akim Tamiroff, who played hundreds of roles in a movie career of more than 35 years, died yesterday at the age of 72, a family spokesman said today.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: WHAT DOES QUALITY LIFE INSURANCE COST? $250,000 Yearly R&C Term, an nual premium, age 33, $662.50. Full details, rates your age, call or have your agent call North Atlantic Life, Jericho, N. Y. (516) 9356900,ADVT.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 18 (AP)Coach Chuck Fairbanks said today that Leon Cross white, Oklahoma's hardhitting senior fullback, should be ready to play in the Oct. 14 game with Texas in the Cotton Bowl.

title: State Scores City Schools On Sabbatical Practices
description: A state audit charged yester day that the City Board of Edu cation had spent $28million in the last five years on sabbatical leaves for teachers who did not return to work or retired short ly after they did return.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Anaconda Brass Company, a subsidiary of the Anaconda Company, said yesterday it was increasing prices on all nickelbearing products by 20 cents a pound of nickel content. Tinbearing products will be raised 7.5 cents a pound of tin content. Scrap purchase prices for nickel and tinbearing metals will be adjusted accord ingly, the company added.

title: RooneyLowenstein Battleground Is Diverse
description: The Brooklyn constitu ency that will decide today whether Representative John J. Rooney or his challenger, Allard K. Lowenstein, gets the Democratic nomination for Congress is one of the most exciting and varied ethnic, racial and religious agglomerations in the nation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Tom Wicker, states in his Sept. 12 column, The Issue of 1972, that the American people do not seem to re alize that their air power is carrying out one of the most terrible mass ex terminations in history....

title: DR. ALVIN TILLMAN, EXPERT ON TOXEMIA
description: Dr. Alvin J. B. Tillman, who specialized in the field of preg nancy complications, died yes terday after a long illness in the Harkness, Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 68 years old and had lived and practiced at 5 Rivercrest Road, Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: California Official Sues to Bar Balloting on Farm Labor Curb
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 18Secretary of State Edmund G. Brown Jr. filed a suit in the Sacramento County Superior Court last week asking that a controversial farm labor initia tive be removed from the Nov. 7 California election ballot.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Sept 18 (AP)  Bill Screws, Western Michigan University's junior quarterback, will be lost for the rest of the season. A team spokesman said today that Screws, 20, suffered a knee in jury in last Saturday's 4114 loss to Fresno State.

title: Charge That Policemen Threw Man Off Roof Is Investigated
description: The death of a Bronx man last week is being investigated by the police and officials of the District Attorney's office following statements by local residents that two policemen threw him off a roof during a nearriotdemonstration by gypsy cab drivers in the South Bronx.

title: Three Astronauts Will End 8 Weeks in 20Foot Chamber
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18 (UFI) Three astronauts will leave on Wednesday a 20foot long chamber that has been their home for the last eight weeks during tests and experiments for future Skylab missions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Gerald E. McGuirk's letter (Sept. 9) reads as though it had been written by the Nixon Administration. The his torical backdrop to the Vietnam con flict is quite distorted and inaccurate and appears to be the usual line of fered from Washington.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Sept. 18 Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk criticized as in Sane today the defense posture advocated by the Democratic Presidential nominee, Senator George McGovern.

title: Splinter School District Dispute In Texas Reaches a U.S. Court
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18A two yearold effort to establish a splinter school district here with an enrollment that would be 90 per cent white has sur vived a legal path through local and state channels and now has moved into Federal Court.

title: Nixon Intends to Nominate Alternate I.M.F. Governor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)  President Nixon announced today he intends to nominate John N. Irwin 2d of New York City to be the United States al ternate governor of the Inter national Monetary Fund and related organizations.

title: Chinatown Dispute Ends Over Classes in English
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that special English language classes for Chinese immigrants, financed by the state and administered jointly by the Board of Education and a Chinatown organization, would start this week.

title: City Told Revenue Sharing May Peril Social Services
description: Parts of the revenuesharing bill scheduled for passage by Congress this week threaten cuts of 37 to 55 per cent in current federally funded social services programs here, ac cording to city estimates given to Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

title: U.S. Protests to Uganda Over Arrests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The United States has expressed strong concern to the Uganda Government about the arrest of several Americans, some of whom are being held incommu nicado, State Department offi cials said today.

title: Acupuncture Status Urged
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Sept. 18 (UPI)The Missouri Medical Association suggested today that acupuncture be classed as part of the medical practice.

title: BENCH DRIVES IN 2 AS REDS TOP GIANTS
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 (UPI) Johnny Bench drove in one run with his 34th homer of the season and another with a bunt single leading the Cincinnati Reds toa 20 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight.

title: Apostle of Change
description: In a way that few public figures have been able to do, Representative William F. Ryan took positions ahead of his time and patiently persuaded his constituency and elements of the larger society to follow him, win ning the warm affection of an increasing circle of friends in the process. He was loved as an immensely sensitive and decent man.

title: Credits for Survival
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 18 (UPI)  The University of Hawaii, which once offered for gradua tion credit a course in surfing, now offers Survival 494. To pass and earn OAT' credits, stu dents must attend classes all semester without using a car.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOWELL, Mass., Sept. 18 The brother of John F. Kerry, an antiwar candidate for the Democratic nomination to the House in the Fifth Massachu setts District, was arrested with another Kerry campaign worker early today and charged with breaking into the building housing the headquarters of a Kerry opponent.

title: Nine Food Outlets Are Cited by City As Code Violators
description: The Health Services Admin istration released yesterday the names of nine more restaurants and food establishments that had violated the citys' Health Code.

title: Business Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP)The final contract was signed today for the manufacture and sale of International Harvester construction equipment in Poland.

title: Executive Changes
description: Walter E. Auch has been appointed executive vice president of duPont Glare Forgan, Inc. He will also be on the firm's board and a member of its executive committee.

title: Advertising:
description: To improve its communi cation with minority groups, American Telephone and Telegraph has hired Zebra Associates, a blackowned andoperated ad agency, for a special advertising cam paign.

title: Clothing Union Wins a Pay Rise in Shirt Industry
description: The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and major producers in the shirt industry announced yesterday agreement on a new threeyear contract that will provide wage in creases for 20,000 workers.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: East Coast waterfowl hunt ers will not be able to shoot redhead or canvasback ducks this season, and the Atlantic brant, a small sea goose, also will be fully protected.

title: Nets, With Staub, Top Pirates in 9th On Hit by Dyer, 10
description: New York Mets fans got a taste of how sweet it might have been when Rusty Staub returned to the lineup for the first time in two months last night. He scored the winning run in the ninth inning in a 10 victory over the pennant bound Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: HARLETON, Tex., Sept. 18 (AP)Terry Ray Muse, 16 years old, a quarterback for Harleton High School, died last night in a Shreveport, La., hospital fol lowing his collapse while play ing in a football game against ComoPickton last Friday.

title: 50 Richest Counties Are in Suburbs
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 18  As in suburban shopping centers everywhere, the pen nies of youthful wishmakers glint on the bottom of the fountain in the Montgomery Mall. But here, in the Mont gomery County, Md., suburbs of Washington, D.C., there are dimes and even quarters. For Montgomery County, as certified today by the Census Bureau, is the richest county in America.

title: Pickets Close TNT Plant
description: CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 18 (UPI)The Volunteer Army Ammunition Plant, the world's largest supplier of TNT, ceased operations today after chemical workers set up picket lines. Company spokesmen said the pickets were members of the International Chemical Workers Union sympathizing with strik ing workers at Volunteer's sis ter plant in Charleston, Ind.

title: U.S. Cut 200 Men Last Week From Its Force in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 18 (AP)United States troop strength in Vietnam dropped officially by 200 last week, to 36,500, the United States command reported to day.

title: Troubled Cambodians Miss the Monarchy
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 10  With Cambodia's military, economic, and political situation sliding into deeper trouble daily, many of her people are express ing a nostalgia for the good old days two years ago when this land was a well fed, peace ful kingdom and not a thread bare and wartorn republic.

title: Burch Is Pleased
description: Key to the Mint, whose next start is the $100,000added Woodward Stakes Sept. 30, had a workout which was must sat isfactory to Elliott Burch, who trains him for Paul Mellon's Rokeby Farm. On the main track between the first and second races, Key to the Mint stepped a mile in 1:34 4/5, and went out 1 miles in 1:47 4/5.

title: POLLUTION TALKS IN MOSCOW BEGIN
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 18A new United StatesSoviet committee on the environment opened its first session today.

title: GIANTS CONSIDER BENCHING SNEAD
description: Whether to change quarter backs for the next game, against Dallas at Yankee Sta dium Sunday, was the main question facing the New York Giants yesterday as they gath ered for their first regularsea son Monday workout, a major change from their traditional working week. The players will have today off.

title: Edward C. Marsh, Officer Of Union Service Corp.
description: Edward C. Marsh, vice presi dent for investment research of the Union Service Corporation, died in his sleep on Sunday at his home in Westfield, N.J. He was 65 year sold.

title: INDUSTRY OUTPUT RESUMES GROWTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Industrial production resumed its brisk rise in August follow ing two months of sluggishness, partly caused by the effects of tropical storm Agnes, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: BONN PANEL PRAISES HANDLING OF MUNICH
description: BONN, Sept. 18 (UPI)A committee of the West German Bundestag, the lower house of Parliament, said today that the federal police and other author ities handled the Palestinian terrorist's attack on Israel's Olympic team appropriately and that there was no need for a parliamentary investigation.

title: Britain Welcomes U gandans Warmly, But Warns of Rebuffs They May Face
description: LONDON, Sept. 18 The first Indians and Pakistanis to be airlifted out of Uganda arrived here this morning and were met by a chilly rain, hot tea, an official wel come, and a reminder that to many Britons they were not so welcome.

title: Sunny Plans for Giants if Court Clouds Lift
description: NEWARK, Sept. 18 (AP) A sun root providing cover for 6,000 fans will be installed at the proposed New Jersey home of the football Giants.

title: Homosexuals Allowed Own Columbia Lounge
description: Peter Pouncey, the new dean of Columbia College, yesterday officially recog nized a student lounge for homosexuals, reversing a de cision of his predecessor, Carl. Hovde, who had denied recognition for the lounge. The move is believed to mark the first time that a college administration has recognized a facility for homosexuals, according to sources at the Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: LOOMIS IS NAMED TO SUCCEED MACY
description: Henry W. Loomis, deputy di rector of the United States In formation Agency, was appoint ed yesterday to head the fed erally chartered Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: EUGENE A. VALENCIA, NAVY ACE IN PACIFIC
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 18 (AP) Eugene A. Valencia, a Navy fighter ace in the Pacific thea ter in World War II, died Satur day after a heart attack. He was attending the convention in San Antonio, Tex., ot the American Fighter Pilots Asso ciation, of which he was a founder and vice president. He was 51 years old and lived in Chula Vista.

title: Merger News
description: The General Signal Corpora tion announced yesterday an agreement in principle to ac quire the Mixing Equipment Company, Inc., for 480,000 shares of General Signal com mon stock, which would have a cur rent market value of $24.66million. Mixing Equipment, a closely held Rochester, N. Y., concern, makes fluid mixing equipment for industrial companies and aerator equipment for munici pal and industrial wastetreat ment units. Mixing Equipment's consolidated sales in 1971 were $32million.

title: Incredible Prices for Fruit and Vegetables Follow a Poor Growing Season
description: ALBANY, Sept. 18A sharp reduction in fresh fruits and vegetables reaching market in New York State was reported here today by state and Feder al agriculture officials, indicat ing that prices for consumers would be soaring in the near future.

title: In a Way, She's Still a Farm Girl Farming Her English Estate
description: LONDON  When Marcia Brockle bank moved into her husband's family house, her motherinlaw jotted down a few notes that might help her take care of the place. They came to 58 typed pages.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Like a cornucopia at harv est time, New Jersey's au tumn promises a cultural feast of opera, music, art, dance and drama and an assertion of greater inde pendence from the state's historical cultural orientation toward New York and Phila delphia.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Charging the Democrats with hypocrisy and the Republicans with bias, a Washington law yer filed a series of legal mo tions today to have the Federal courts appoint a special prose cutor to investigate the alleged attempt at bugging the Demo cratic national headquarters in the Watergate complex on June 17.

title: LISTLESS STOCKS WEAKEN FURTHER
description: A dispirited stock market, locked in a slump since Labor Day, drifted downward yester day in one of the slowest trad ing sessions of 1972. The Dow Jones industrials, firming near the close, ended 1.96 lower at 945.36.

title: Senator Scores Cigar Ads
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (UPI)  Television advertising of cigarettesized cigars was assailed today by Senator Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, as an attempt to circum vent Federal law. Mr. Moss, who was chief sponsor of legis lation which eliminated ciga rette commercials from tele vision, said I think we're go ing to have to change our defi nition so that it will include these little cigars.

title: Husband Given Tickets For the Colder Half
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 18 (UPI)The Lancaster County District Court ruled today that each party in a marriage dissolution case would have the use of University of Nebraska football tickets half the season.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18This is Phil Chivy, America, and as a public service to the nation in this vital Presidential election campaign, this noisecaster will periodically present interviews with the indispensable men who make government and politics in America the great farce we have all learned to love and sneer at.

title: Field, of 61 Countries, a Record Start Play at Chess Olympics
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 18  A field of 61 countries, a record, is entered in the Chess Olympics, which started today at 4 P.M. (11 A.M. New York time.) The competition is for the team championship of the world, held generally every two years.

title: PILLSBURY RAISES QUARTER PROFITS
description: The Pillsbury Company had a net income of $3,243,000, or 61 cents a share, up from $2, 666,000, or 50 cents a share in the first quarter ended Aug. 31.

title: U.S. AND RUSSIANS OPEN SEA PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  SovietAmerican maritime ne gotiations, the first step toward a planned comprehensive trade pact between the two coun tries, opened here today with the United States facing com plex domestic and international issues.

title: UGANDA INVADERS REPORTED HALTED BY AMIN'S TROOPS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 18 A small army that reportedly invaded Uganda from neighbor ing Tanzania yesterday in an attempt to depose the contro versial President of Uganda, Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, appeared today to have been outfought and pushed back.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) The Senate ratified today, 69 to 0, a revision of a 90nation treaty on narcotics. The change is designed to strengthen inter national control of drugs.

title: More Dentists Sought
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP)The University of Penn sylvania says there is a shortage of dentists and an overabundance of biologists, engineers and physics profes sors. So the school is offering the nation's first federally fi nanced program to make den tists out of unemployed scien tists.

title: Shultz Warns of Tax Rise Unless Spending Is Curbed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz qualified today the pledges recently made by two other Administration officials that President Nixon would not propose any tax increases throughout a sec ond term in office.

title: HALO TAKES FIRST ON BELMONT TURF
description: Fighting off successive chal lenges by a pair of determined opponents, the Cragwood Sta ble's Halo registered an im pressive victory in the $58,800 Lawrence Realization at Bel mont Park yesterday. Although the charts show that Halo had the lead from start to finish of the 1mile turf event, the colt yielded the spot twice be fore scoring.

title: Trawler Protection Pledged
description: LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) The Government pledged today to protect British trawlers if Iceland's patrol boats con tinued to harass vessels fishing in waters claimed by Iceland. The pledge was made after the Minister of Agriculture, James Prior, met with representatives of the deepsea fishing industry, who asked naval protection should incidents involving the cutting of trawler wires con tinue.

title: Market Place: Grarin Railroads For Railroads
description: Sudden and unforeseen bo nanzas are eagerly awaited in Wall Street, They usually seem to involve technology companies with new prod ucts, mining companies with big ore strikes or other equally exciting vehicles.

title: ELWOOD M. WAGGONER
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 18Elwood M. Waggoner, su pervising engineer for the Charles J. Cooke architectural firm here, died after a heart attack today in Vassar Brothers Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 61 Old Post Road.

title: PRODUCE COSTS UP SHARPLY IN STATE AS OUTPUT LAGS
description: ALBANY, Sept. 18A sharp reduction in fresh fruits and vegetables reaching market in New York State was reported here today by state and Feder al agriculture officials, indicat ing that prices for consumers would be soaring in the near future.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 18 (AP)Bobby Unser, Indianapolis 500 winner in 1968 who only occasionally drives stock cars, will compete against the top stock drivers in the National 500 race at the Charlotte Motor Speedway next month.

title: Removal of Judge Asked
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 18 (AP)Six Vietnam Veterans Against the War today sought the removal of United States District Court Judge David Mid diebrooks from hearing their conspiracy case and asked to be allowed to examine grand jury testimony against them. They are charged with plan ning to disrupt the Republican National Convention at Miami Beach last month.

title: Stadium Thieves Score $27,000 Hit, No Errors
description: Sparky Lyle saved the game in another relief pitch ing appearance, but he could do nothing about thieves who made off with $27,000 from the Stadium Club at Yankee Stadium some time after Sunday's New York Yankee victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Port Notes
description: The Port of New York ap pears to be more than holding its own in the constant and often fierce competition with other Atlantic ports that serve as terminals for con tainerships.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: BEAUTIFUL singing is easy as talking. Individual instruction 663??ADVT.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 18 (AP)  Andy Lowe, a starting defensive end for Texas Tech who was injured in Saturday night's game with Utah, was lost for the year following knee surgery. Lowe suffered the injury while attempting to block a punt.

title: Man In the News
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18The responsibility for protecting the 8,000 men and women, including scores of controversial political leaders, inside the 16acre United Nations enclave falls on the square shoulders of a retired Canadian Army offi cerLieut. Col. Harold Allen Trimble. For the 13 weeks of the General Assem bly session that opens here to morrow, Colonel Trimble has drummed the motto Prevention rather than apprehension into his 230 guards in their grayblue uniforms. Some admit priv ately it sound a bit corny but it does not diminish the seriousness with which they approach their jobs.

title: YANKS WILL VISIT WHERE IT BEGAN
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18  It was right here, six weeks ago, that the whole pennant idea really ignited in Yankee minds, and it will be here the next two nights that the Yankees must win to keep the idea from turning into a memory.

title: Fuentes Hearing, Scheduled Today, Is Closed to Public
description: A closed hearing on the ap pointment of Luis Fuentes as superintendent of Community School District 1 will be held today at an undisclosed loca tion, Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner said yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 18 (AP)  Andy Lowe, a starting defensive end for Texas Tech who was injured in Saturday night's game with Utah, was lost for the year following knee surgery. Lowe suffered the injury while attempting to block a punt.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company yesterday filed with the Securities and Ex change Commission 2 million common shares for sale through the First Boston Corporation and Drexel Firestone, Inc, The utility said it would use pro ceeds to retire a portion of its shortterm debt. The company's stock was up  at 24 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Stolen Art Owners Sought Here
description: The police were seeking yesterday to identify the last of 45 art prints and books found Sunday night in two coin lockers in Grand Central Terminal and presumed stolen from museums, the Public Li brary and, perhaps local art dealers.

title: Russian Roulette Kills Yotith
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Sept. 18 (AP)An 18yearold youth killed himself while play ing Russian roulette in front of his sister and brotherinlaw, the police said. They reported that Stanley Eugene Johnson, holding a .22caliber revolver to his head, had spun the bar rel and fired. The chamber was empty. On the second chance, they said, the gun fired, killing the youth.

title: Classical Disk View: New Life Signs
description: The people who make clas sical recordings are pinching themselves, cautiously but happily, as they look forward to the 1972.73 season. Since their darkest days, some three or four seasons ago, they have been slowly but steadily returning to life. Although much of the quality in the forthcomingrecord lists cen ters on foreignbased labels, the domestic brands are also beginning to sit up and take nourishment.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 18 George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O, bitterly assailed the Democratic party that nom inated Senator George McGov ern for the Presidency as elitist and antilabor.

title: Rooney, Lowenstein Face New Primary In Brooklyn Today
description: Seeking to avoid the chaos at the polls that marred the June 20 primary, the Board of Elections is taking special pre cautions to assure that today's rerun of the Democratic pri mary in the 14th Congressional District in Brooklyn is conducted smoothly.

title: PARLEY ON ULSTER IS SET NEXT WEEK
description: LONDON, Sept. 18  The British Government announced today that a conference on the political future of Ulster would be held next week despite a boycott by the Roman Catholic opposition parties of Northern, Ireland.

title: Lima Prostitution Deplored
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 18 (UPI) The Roman Catholic Church here today denounced plans to legalize prostitution. The church authorities in Lima and in Callao, a port seven miles to the west, said the proposal of the Lima police to license houses of prostitution and es tablish red light districts would turn women into mer chandise and would degrade women instead of promoting women's dignity.

title: Irrationality in Uganda
description: President Idi Amin has cried invasion too many times in twenty months of power to be persuasive with his charge that a thousand Tanzanian troops have attacked Uganda. It is more likely that Ugandan exiles loyal to former President Milton Obote have launched guerrilla raids from Tanzania in the hope of exploiting discontent and provoking a coup against General Amin.

title: Yom Kippur Divides Jerusalem for a Day
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 18 Jerusalem became a divided city again today, with barri cades separating its Arab and Jewish quartets much as they did for the 20 years before the 1967 war.

title: MERGER OF SCHOOLS IS TO PROCEED HERE
description: The State Education Commis sioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, said yesterday that the New York University Engineering School should go ahead with its planned merger with Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute even though most of the N.Y.U. en gineering faculty has refused to be transferred to the Brooklyn campus.

title: Credit Markets
description: Interest rates moved nar rowly in light activity yester day, extending a period of rela tive stability that began early this month after a siege of sharply escalating rate levels.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 18 (AP) Kathy Whitworth and Jane Bla lock have passed the $50,000 mark in earnings this year, the first players in the history of the Ladies Professional Golf As sociation to reach that figure.

title: SHOP TALK
description: For the last six months Christopher Darway has been working on a system to link pieces of jewelry, taking a basic unit or modular element and adapting it to rings, bracelets and necklaces. What he has done is on exhibition and sale through Sept. 29 at Amulets and Talismans, 740 Madison Avenue.

title: Bridge: Overcall of One NoTrump Gets Theorists' Attention
description: A competitive bidding sit uation that has received some attention from theorists in re cent years arises when one notrump is overcalled by the next, opponent. One highly ambiguous development is the following:

title: Gold Price Slides; Dollar Holds Firm
description: LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP)The price of freemarket gold fell sharply in Europe's main bul lion centers today in the biggest wave of selling this year.

title: Senate Bill Would Aid Victims of Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) In an effort to speed Con gressional approval, the Senate twice today approved a $15 million measure to set up a system to compensate victims of crime and persons who try to help them.

title: Brandt Will Ask a Parliamentary Test This Week
description: BONN, Sept. 18 Chancellor Willy Brandt said today that, to open the way to federal elections on Nov. 19, he would ask parliament for a vote of confidence Wednesday.

title: Dollar Firm
description: FRANKFURT, Sept. 18 (Reu ters)The dollar closed higher here today, at 3.1975 marks bid compared with the opening of 3.1926 bid.

title: ROLE OF UNDERDOG SUITS PATTERSON
description: Floyd Patterson rested yes terday and hoped that Muham mad Ali would be made a strong favorite for their fight tomorrow night. Meanwhile, Ali continued to train and said he expected the fight to go all the way.

title: Murphy to Reward Police Who Arrest BribeGivers
description: Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has told his policemen that those who make bribery arrests will be considered for higher paying jobs and more desirable assignments. Mr. Murphy, urging his com manders to support their men in the war against bribery, said that any attempt by a su perior officer to discourage a proper arrest and the inclusion of all legitimate charges in these cases will be considered a serious violation of depart ment policy.

title: Oklahoma Star to Return
description: NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 18 (AP)Coach Chuck Fairbanks said today that Leon Cross white, Oklahoma's hardhitting senior fullback, should be ready to play in the Oct. 14 game with Texas in the Cotton Bowl.

title: Civil Rights Leader Freed
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 18 (AP)  Hosea Williams, the civil rights leader who was arrested last week while picketing a nursing home, was released from jail today against his wishes. An Atlanta businessman, Charles Williams, signed a $1,500 prop erty bond for Mr. Williams, who had said he wanted to remain in jail until his trial on charges of assault, inciting a riot and creating a turmoil.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18 (AP)The Houston Rockets of the National Basketball Association sold Dick Cunningham, center, to the Milwaukee Bucks and bought centerforward Don Smith from the Seattle Sonics in straight cash trans actions today.

title: Kennecott Unit in Colombia Coal Pact
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 18 The Kennecott Copper Cor poration has shown $60million worth of fresh faith in Latin America, despite Chilean dis couragements.

title: U.S. Sees Threat to Pact Limiting Imports of Steel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Administration has sudden ly become alarmed at the im plications of an amendment in the big defenseappropriations bill that may threaten the agreement with European and Japanese steel producers to limit their steel exports to the United States.

title: Nixon Picks Ambassador
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) President Nixon announced today that he will nominate C. Robert Moore of Seattle, a career minister in the Foreign Service, to be Ambassador to the Republic of Equatorial Guinea, Mr. Moore has been Ambassador to the United Re public of Cameroon since July 6 and will serve in the new position concurrently and with out additional compensation.

title: U.S. DROPS CURRENCY OVER NORTH VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The Air Force is dropping sim ulated North Vietnamese cur rency printed on propaganda leaflets over North Vietnam to drive home to the population woes caused by inflation, State Department officials said today.

title: Suit to Recover a $100,000 Fee From Biaggi Filed Here by State
description: State officials have taken ac tion to recover some of the substantial legal fees paid to Representative Mario Biaggi, a Bronx Democrat, by an ailing insurance company that unsuc cessfully fought to remain in business.

title: 44 in Japan Hurt as Police Battle 6,000 at U.S. Depot
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan, Tuesday, Sept. 19 (AP)At least 44 peo ple, most of them policemen, were injured early today in clashes between riot policemen and about 6,000 student demon strators in front of a United States Army supply depot.

title: NIXON INCREASES OILIMPORT LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)  President Nixon acted today to increase sharply the flow of oil imports into the United States because lagging production of petroleum prod ucts has not kept pace with ris ing demand.

title: Psychologist Faces Molesting Charges Involving 2 L.I Boys
description: A 35yearold psychologist who works with children at state institutions was arraigned yesterday on charges that he enticed two brothers, 11 and 13, into deviant sexual acts.

title: Red Sox Lose, 52, to Orioles and Drop to 2d
description: BOSTON, Sept. 18The Bos ton Red Sox dropped a 52 de cision to the Baltimore Orioles tonight and also dropped out of first place for the first time in 12 days as the American League's fourteam race for Eastern honors turned, into the final 2 weeks.

title: Mine Safety Lags Despite Federal Efforts
description: OAKWOOD, Va., Sept. 16 Beatrice is a popular coal mine; Federal inspectors visit her three times a day.

title: Met's Standees Maintain Overnight Vigil
description: The Metropolitan Opera's most rugged patrons the standees  began their tradi tional vigil last night for tickets to this evening's openingnight performance of Carmen, But like Don Jose, they wondered if the Met was really about to return their love.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Mixed at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Yields on United States Treas ury bills were mixed in the Government's weekly competi tive sale today of those short term securities.

title: Alabama Puts U.S. on Defensive With Suits Against Federal Agencies Over Environmental Damage
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 18The state of Alabama has become embroiled In a series of encounters with the Federal Government over environment al protection issues.

title: Business Briefs
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 18 (Reuters)The Argentine central bank restricted today the sale of foreign exchange to tourists traveling abroad.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: We the Jews, by will of a chance living in the U.S.S.R., Jews by birth and conviction, address all the people of goodwill all over the worldpeople in large and small states, people of all religions and faiths, all the people for whom principles of morality and jus tice are not an empty shell. Our firm desire to unite with our people in our historical homeland, in the State of Israel, meets now obstacles from the Soviet authorities all over again.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 18 (AP)  A broken engine yesterday in the Dela ware 500 at Dover Downs In ernational Speedway could cost Bobby Allison the 1972 NASCAR Winston Cup Grand National driving championship.

title: Police Will Shoot to Kill
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 18 (AP)A plainclothes police unit known as the felony action squad was given shoot to kill orders here today in a crack down on street crimes. Super intendent of Police Clarence B. Giarrusso said that when squad members closed in on a suspect they thought was armed, they would give a three word order Police. Drop it. Then, if the suspect has something in his hand, Mr. Giarrusso said, members of the squad will shoot to kill.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Former Gov. Richard J. Hughes said yesterday that he was too busy to take a leading role in Senator George Mc Govern's campaign in New Jersey.

title: Cigarette Consumption Up Along With Production
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) Both consumption and pro duction of cigarettes is increas ing in the United States, the Government reported today.

title: Theater: At La Mama
description: For Everything for Any body, the intimate down stairs theater at La Mama has been transformed into a pastoral park in the middle of the city. Trees filled with glistening lights are placed around the stage and even occupy a few of the seats in the audience.

title: Strike by Sanitationmen Affects 40,000 on L.I.
description: VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Sept. 18  Sanitationmen went on strike against this village today, leaving 40,000 residents here without refuse pickup and with out some municipal services.

title: Louis Sigaud, Lawyer, Dies; Wrote on Military Subjects
description: GREENWOOD LAKE, N. Y., Sept: 18  Louis A. Sigand, a retired lawyer and author, died yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hospital in Lyons, N. J. He. Was 79 years old and lived in Forest Knolls.

title: Egypt and Libya Agree on Cairo as Joint Capital
description: CAIRO, Sept. 18President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan leader, today agreed that Cairo would be the capital of the proposed union between their two countries.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (UPI) President Nixon, fondly re membering the 12course gourmet meals that he had in Peking this year, asked his elder daughter, Mrs. Ed Ward F. Cox, to cook a Chi nese supper for him tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Two comments on your Aug. 31 editorial entitled McGovernomics: First, ignoring his change of mind on specifics, he is wrong in assuming he will raise additional revenue by re pealing depreciation allowances. Sec ond, he should pledge to increase the investment tax credit, from 7 per cent to 10 per cent.

title: U.S. MINERAL NEEDS CALLED ALARMING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (AP)The United States has demonstrated alarming de pendency on the mineral re sources of other nations since 1950, the American Mining Congress was told today.

title: Shultz Warns of Tax Rise Unless Spending Is Curbed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz qualified today the pledges recently made by two other Administration officials that President Nixon would not propose any tax increases throughout a sec ond term in office.

title: Wider Medicaid Due in Newark in New Thrust at Help to Poor
description: TRENTON, Sept. 18A $54 million Medicaid program for Newark, announced here today, places the Federal Government in the new role of guarantee ing the delivery as well as the payment of medical care.

title: Food Consumption Up for Sixth Year; Prices 3% Higher
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) The Agriculture Department says that per capita food con sumption rose in 1971 for the sixth consecutive year but the yearly advance did not match the record gain in 1970.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW SHARP RISE
description: Commercial interests, includ ing exporters, bought wheat fu tures heavily yesterday, push ing prices up the 10centsa bushel daily limit in the case of some deliveries, with result ing new lifeofcontract highs.

title: Millions of Dead Fish Float Along Oyster Area in Florida
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 18 (AP)Millions of dead and dying menhaden continued to whiten the waters on a section of Escambia Bay today in what threatens to become Florida's worst fish kill of the year, a state Marine Patrol officer said.

title: European Reaction Is Mild To U.S. Schweitzer Stand
description: PARIS, Sept. 18  The Euro pean reaction to reports that Washington opposes the re appointment of PierrePaul Schweitzer as managing direc tor of the International Mone tary Fund was considerably softer than might have been expected.

title: Queens Playhouse Will Present Pygmalion at Opening Oct. 25
description: The Queens Playhouse, the newly established nonprofit, professional resident theater in the former New York State Pavilion building of the 1.964 65 World's Fair, will open its first season with Shaw's Pyg malion on Oct. 25.

title: James Hughes, 74, Headed Theatrical Press Agents
description: James T. Hughes, former chairman of the board of the Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers, died of cancer yesterday in his home at 124 East 92d Street. He was 74 years old.

title: Thermodyne in Chapter XI
description: Thermodyne International, Ltd., said yesterday it had be gun proceedings for reorganiza tion of the company under Chapter XI of the Federal Bank ruptcy Act. Thermodyne also said it was negotiating an agreement, subject to court ap proval of certain lending insti tutions, to provide operating capital upon settlement with creditors.

title: College Sports Notes
description: Most major college foot ball coaches frowned upon the use of freshtnan players when the National Collegiate Athletic Association approved varsity football for them this season. But Don Taylor of Bowling Green in Ohio, and a number of other freshmen across the country, played important parts in their teams' victories last Saturday.

title: Effort to Curb Bison Disease Perils Herds and Splits Ranchers and Park Officials
description: YELLOWSTONE NATION AL PARK, Wyo.  The fa mous bison herds of Yellow stone face a new threat of extermination  not from hunters this time but from ranchers who fear that the huge, shaggy animals will stray from the park and in fect their livestock with bru cellosis.

title: F.D.A. Recalls Seafood Infected By Red Tide Off New England
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) The Food and Drug Admin istration today began a recall of potentially lethal soft and hard clams and mussels re cently distributed throughout New England and possibly other sections of the country.

title: Trevino, 2d on Money List, Nearing 2d $200,000 Year
description: Lee Trevino, winner of the $30,000 top prize in the St. Louis golf classic Sunday, has moved closer to a second straight $200,000 season on the pro tour.
