title: Redskins Set Back Vikings, 2421
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 18A blocked punt and two lost fumbles, all at the wrong time in the wrong place, cost the Minnesota Vikings dearly tonight as the Washington Red skins beat them, 2421, in the first Monday night televised game of the pro football season.

title: Democratic Ticket Backed By Longshoremen's Union
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (UPI)The executive commit tee of the International Long shoremen's and Warehouse men's Union endorsed the Dem ocratic Presidential ticket to day.

title: 2 BLASTS INJURE 26 IN CITY NEAR MANILA
description: MANILA, Sept. 18Two ex plosions rocked the new city hall in Quezon city today, in juring. 25 people and destroy ing several rooms and part of the auditorium in the commu nity just east of Manila.

title: JETS ARE RUSHING TO EVEN OFFENSE
description: Someone asked Emerson Boozer, who had just scored three touchdowns in a game for the third time in his New York Jets' career if this reminded him of the good old days.

title: Suit to Recover a $100,000 Fee From Biaggi Filed Here by State
description: State officials have taken ac tion to recover some of the substantial legal fees paid to Representative Mario Biaggi, a Bronx Democrat, by an ailing insurance company that unsuc cessfully fought to remain in business.

title: Wider Medicaid Planned To Reach Newark's Poor
description: TRENTON, Sept. 18A $54 million Medicaid program for Newark, announced here today, places the Federal Government in the role of guaranteeing the delivery as well as the payment of medical care.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
3 Win in Drag Racing
description: ROCKINGHAM, N. C., Sept. 18 (AP)Carl Olson, Richard Tharp and Ronnie Sox won titles in championship events in the United States open drag racing championships today.

title: Air Chief Defends Policy Of Punishing Lavelle Only
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Gen. John D. Ryan, the Air Force chief of staff, defended today his decision to punish only Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle for unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam and told Senate investigators that he couldn't guarantee that such incidents wouldn't hap pen again.

title: SAINTHOOD URGED FOR MISSIONARY
description: MARQUETTE, Mich., Sept. 18 The first step toward achieving sainthood for the Most Rev. Frederic Baraga, a 19thcentury Roman Catholic missionary, is being completed here as the findings of a spe cial tribunal are being pack aged for review and action by the Vatican.

title: Corona Trial Citation Asked
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Sept. 18 (UPI)Richard Hawk, defense attorney for Juan V. Corona, accused as a mass murderer, sought to have the prosecution team cited for contempt of court today. Mr. Hawk asked Superior Court Judge Richard E. Patton to stop the trial to give him time to prepare a brief for dismissal of the charges.

title: 3 More Deaths in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 18Three more persons died today as a result of sec tarian violence in northern Ireland. One was a woman, aged 53, who was injured in a Belfast hotel blast last Thurs day. The others were a 26 yearold soldier who was shot while on patrol in Londonderry yesterday, and a man who was killed tonight in a bomb blast in County Down.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: LYNDHURST, Sept. 18A re port released today on the wa ter quality in the Hackensack meadowlands said that hun dreds of acres of the marsh lands adjoining the Hackensack River were not as polluted as had been expected.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE APPROVES AID BILL FOR $42BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  A foreign aid bill calling for the appropriation of $4.2 billion, or nearly $1billion less than the Administration had requested for the fiscal year that began July 1, was ap proved today by the House Appropriations Committee.

title: Mobil Unit Makes Gas Strike
description: Mobil Oil Indonesia, Inc., a subsidiary of the Mobil Oil Corporation, yesterday con firmed that it has a gas dis covery in its Lho Sukon A1 well in the onshore B block of North Sumatra. The company said an open hole test from 8,500 feet to 8,700 feet flowed 27 million cubic feet per day of natural gas through at 48/64inch choke.

title: Mrs. Abzug Rated a Leading Contender To Succeed Rep. Ryan in 20th District
description: Representative Bella S. Ab zug emerged yesterday as a leading contender to succeed Representative William F. Ryan, who had died Sunday. However, there apparently were considerable misgivings about Mrs. Abzug among many Democrats who had backed Mr. Ryan in his primary fight with her last June.

title: Advertising:
description: Detroit, that bountiful well spring of autumnal advertis ing, is once more bringing happiness (and dollars) to medialand.

title: INDUSTRY OUTPUT RESUMES GROWTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Industrial production resumed its brisk rise in August follow ing two months of sluggishness, partly caused by the effects of tropical storm Agnes, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 18 (AP)The underdog and under manned Venezuelan AllStars scored two upset victories and moved to a semifinal against Tidewater in the Kodak World Baseball Classic.

title: AUSTRALIAN FISH CHANGES ITS SEX
description: As long as the male wrasse, a family of fish inhabiting Australia's Great Barrier Reef, stays alive, he dominates his harem of three to six females, keeping each in her place in the wellordered hierarchy be low him. But, when he dies, an extraordinary transforma tion takes place in the top ranked female.

title: Notes on People
description: Prime Minister Edward Heath of Britain met in Tokyo with Premier Kakuei Tanaka and urged closer eco nomic ties between their countries, which was more or less expected. Before that, the Prime Minister visited the 300yearold Toshogu shrine, in the mountain resort of Nikko and found Japanese walking slippers difficult to walk in, which wasn't entire ly expected.

title: U. S. Hails Westchester's Cleanup Action
description: Westchester County had been due back in Federal Court this week to learn what it would have to do next to clean up the Croton Point dump.

title: Billiard Match to Begin
description: Jimmy Cattrano, who has won 32 consecutive games this year, will open a twoday, 240 point, threecushion billiards challenge match against Larry Johnson today at McGirr's Billi ard Academy, Eighth Avenue and 50th Street.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation, in an effort to cut costs and save jobs at its Bethpage, L. I., plant, is trim ming the amount of work it subcontracts to other com panies.

title: M'GOVERN URGES STRIPMINING BAN
description: LOGAN, W. Va., Sept 18 Senator George McGovern came to West Virginia's coal country today to assert that the Gov ernment should put an end to the strip mining that is de stroying much of this beautiful state.

title: Job Possibility for Calley
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 18 (AP) Ronnie Thompson, Republican Mayor of Macon, Ga, says that if he is elected to Congress he will offer First Lieut. William C. Calley Jr. a job on his Wash ington staff Lieutenant Calley is under house arrest in Fort Banning, Ga., awaiting a deci sion on appeals on a court martial conviction of murder in the 1968 Mylai slayings.

title: Kashmir Leader Says Vote Shows Need for SelfRule
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Sept. 18Heartened by his party's landslide victory in last week's municipal elections, Sheik Abdullah, the Kasmiri Moslem leader, warned yesterday that his, people would revolt if any one trampled on their right for selfdetermination.

title: Beacon Teacher's Strike Goes On as Schools Close
description: BEACON, N. Y., Sept. 18 (UPI)Both sides in the Beacon teachers strike marked time to day as schools in this Dutchess County city were closed in ob servance of Yom Kippur.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 18Fifty years after winning her first tournament, New Jersey's most durable golfer can still belt a tee shot 215 yards. That's about 35 yards shorter than Maureen Orcutt used to hit, but she's managed to compensate for loss of distance by improving other areas of her game.

title: Bills Lose Two Players
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 18 (UPI) The Buffalo Bills lost the serv ices of a middle linebacker, Ed gar Chandler, and a center, Bruce Jarvis, for the remainder of the season because of knee injuries suffered in the club's 4124 loss to the New York Jets yesterday.

title: Cat Finds Long Way Home
description: CONCORD, Calif., Sept. 18 (AP)Owners of a 5yearold tom cat say that the animal was lost in Oregon, then wan dered 400 miles through moun tains and desert to its suburban ?? here. Mr. and Mrs. Mack Kitchen said that their cat turned up Sept. 8, some 60 days after he vanished at Central Point, Ore.; near the California border.

title: NEW BEIRUT MOVE IN SOUTH DEPICTED
description: KANA, Lebanon, Sept. 18 Highly placed Lebanese sources said today that the Lebanese Army was setting up new roadblocks and otherwise building up its presence in southern Lebanon to restrict the activities of Arab comman dos along the Israeli front.

title: FRANCE IS BRACED FOR NEW SCANDAL
description: PARIS, Sept. 18Another ser ies of scandals about corrup tion in high places has begun to break in France. The cumu lative political impact is be coming intense, provoking some calls for quick national elections without awaiting the end of the Assembly's mandate next March.

title: Fighting in Laos Stepped Up
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 18 (UPI)United States and Lao tian spokesmen today reported an upsurge in fighting around the Plaine des James in north ern Laos and near the town of Khong Sedone in the south ern part of the country.

title: MILITIA REPORTED AIDED IN VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 19 (AP)South Vietnamese reinforcements re portedly pushed into an embat tled district capital in the Cen tral Highlands yesterday to re Have a militia force that had been under siege for three days.

title: Ahmanson Plans Year's Biggest New Issue
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Co., the nation's largest privately held concern, filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell its shares to the public for the first time.

title: S.E.C. Seeks Aids for Small Investors
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking ways in which individual investors of relatively modest means can get somewhat personalized in vestment advice at reasonable cost, William J. Casey, chair man, said today.

title: FRITZ GLARNER, 73, PAINTER, IS DEAD
description: Fritz Glamor, the Swiss art ist best known here for his murals in the lobby of the TimeLife Building and in the Dag Hammarskjold Library of the United Nations, died yes terday in Locarno, Switzer land. He was 73 years old.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 18Four New Jersey countiesBergen, Somerset, Morris and Union are among the nation's top 25 in family income, according to a Census Bureau announcement today.

title: HEARINGS ON TENURE RESUME IN FLORIDA
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 18 Tenure hearings for a Univer sity of Florida wildlife ecology instructor, Dr. George W. Corn well, resumed today after a threeweek recess.

title: Typhoon Killed 50 in Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 18 (AP)Ty phoon Helen killed 50 people, destroyed 399 houses and dam aged or sank 75 ships over the weekend, the police said today.

title: Adm. Thomas L. Sprague Dead; ExCommander of the Intrepid
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 18 (AP) Adm. Thomas L. Sprague, U.S.N., retired, who won the Legion of Merit in World War II for sailing the crippled air craft carrier Intrepid to safety, died yesterday in suburban Chula Vista at the age of 77.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: Just as important and useful drugs are found on occasion to give rise to untouched reactions, so there are alarming rumors of unexpected, long range and even lethal consequences to some of the specific new chemicals of war. The tale of a fivefold increase in the incidence of a liver cancer in man is a case in point.

title: ANCIENT LINE WINS IN STRETCH DRIVE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18 (UPI)Ancient Line turned on the heat in the stretch today to cap a harddriving advance from fifth place with a victory by a nose in the $7,500 feature for fillies and mares on the turf at the Atlantic City Race course.

title: MASSAGE PLACES FACE CRACKDOWN
description: Mayor Lindsay and the City Council leaders joined yester day to support proposed city legislation that would require licensing of all socalled mas sage parlors that do not belong to recognized medical institu tions.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PHILADELPHIA, (AP)  The National Hockey League filed a countersuit in United States District Court today against the World Hockey Association, ask ing the court to prohibit any N.H.L. players from jumping to the W.H.A. in any of the next three seasons.

title: Ryan's Colleagues Suggest Naming Gateway for Him
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Representative William F. Ryan who was treated as an outcast when he first came to Congress in 1961, was eulogized for one andonehalf hours on the House floor today as a man who had fought lonely political battles before they became fashionable.

title: Navy Sued on Pollution
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 18 (AP)The California Regional Water Quality Control Board sued the Navy today, contend ing it was intentionally dump ing some 380,000 gallons of in dustrial wastes a day into San Francisco Bay. The board seeks to enjoin the Navy from further dumping and asks $6,000aday damages.

title: Tickets on Sale Today For Six Knick Games
description: Tickets for the first six games of the New York Knickerbockers' 1972  73 home schedule will go on sale tomorrow at 10 A.M. at the Madison Square Garden Center box office and over 150 Ticketron outlets throughout the metropolitan area.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI)The House Interior Committee today scheduled a Sept. 25 hearing on proposed legislation authorizing Federal participation in the 1976 Winter Olympic Games, scheduled for Colorado.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Floyd Patterson rested yes terday and hoped that Muham mad Ali would be made a strong favorite for their fight tomorrow night. Meanwhile, Ali continued to train and said he expected the fight to go all the way.

title: Foreign Affairs Void...
description: As the Presidential campaign evolves, it is becoming clear that the two candidates are talking past each other on the subject that President Nixon asserts is the central issue: the foreign policy needed to assure a generation of peace.

title: Federal Reserve Decided July 6 To Bolster Treasury Bill Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee acted in early July to prevent the then existing international monetary turmoil from driving down in terest rates on United States Treasury bills, it was disclosed today.

title: WALDO F. OPERER
description: Waldo F. Operer, executive director of the Thread Institute, an industry association, from 1960 to his retirement last May, died Saturday at his home, 22 Cambridge Court, Larchmont, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: Coal Research Group
description: A team, headed by the West inghouse Electrfc Corporation, and including Public Service Indiana, Bechtel Inc., and the Amax Coal Company, has been authorized by the Office of Coal Research of the Department of Interior, to proceed with de velopment of a process to con vert highsulphur coal into syn thetic gas for electric generat ing stations.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two New Jersey men have been indicted on charges of using the 13yearold son of one of the men in a scheme to collect on $4,960 in winning lottery tickets that were not theirs, the Attorney General's office in Trenton an nounced yesterday.

title: U.S. TEAM TO JOIN CITY JOB INQUIRY
description: A special team from the Labor Department in Washing ton today will join in the in vestigation of alleged irregu larities in the city's administra tion of the emergency employ ment program, Edward W. Aponte, the department's Re gional Manpower Administra tor, said yesterday.

title: Rockefeller May Act Today in War on Corruption
description: Governor Rockefeller report edly plans to take action today to supersede the five New York City district attorneys in mat ters involving corruption in the criminal justice system.

title: FARMERS CRITICAL OF U.S. GRAIN DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Representatives of three farm organizations and several Democratic members of a House Agriculture subcommit tee sharply criticized the De partment of Agriculture today for the way it had handled the United StatesSoviet grain deal.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  President Nixon, in another quick response to charges raised by his Democratic oppo nent, defended today his rec ord on narcotics control and pledged to cut off aid to any foreign government whose leaders protect international drug traffickers.

title: Klippstatter Is Conductor Of Memphis Opera Theater
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 18 (AP)  Kurt Klippstatter has accepted the post of resident conductor of the Memphis Opera Theater.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 18 (UPI)  Cullen Bryant, who used his speed to perform two outstanding plays for Colorado on Saturday, was named today the Big Eight's defensive play er of the week.

title: NEW BEIRUT MOVE IN SOUTH DEPICTED
description: KANA, Lebanon, Sept. 18 Highly placed Lebanese sources said today that the Lebanese Army was setting up new roadblocks and otherwise building up its presence in southern Lebanon to restrict the activities of Arab comman dos along the Israeli front.

title: U.N. SCIENTIST WARNS AGAINST MARIJUANA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) A United Nations scientist told Congress today that re searchers were becoming pro gressively more suspicious of the possible dangers of mari juana and hashish.

title: BedfordStuyvesant Leadership Is at Stake in a Primary Rerun
description: If it wasn't for Congress woman Shirley Chisholm's sup port of Assemblyman Vander Beatty, there would be no con test, said State Senator Wald aba Stewart, who faces Mr. Beatty today in a courtordered rerun of the primary vote for the State Senate and district leader seat of BedfordStuyve sant's 18th Senatorial District.

title: U.S.C. KEEPS LEAD IN FOOTBALL POLL
description: Southern California contin ued to lead yesterday in The Associated Press college foot ball poll while Oklahoma, last season's runnerup, moved back to No. 2 with an impressive opening victory.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: George McGovern has now changed his mind on every domestic proposal he's made, and half the staff and cam paign personnel he initially supported; so he seems to be starting on foreign policy. At least this is what can be inferred from the statements of Har vard professor Abram Chayes, now traveling in Europe as McGovern's personal envoy.

title: Petty Widens Point Lead On Grand National Circuit
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 18 (AP)  A broken engine yesterday in the Dela ware 500 at Dover Downs In ernational Speedway could cost Bobby Allison the 1972 NASCAR Winston Cup Grand National driving championship.

title: Ex Aide to Nixon Offers Monetary Plan
description: A former senior White House adviser on international eco nomic policy called on the Nixon Administration yesterday to take the initiative in the negotiations for basic world monetary reform, which are due to open formally in Wash ington next week.

title: Books of The Times
description: NECESSARY OBJECTS. By Lois Gould. 271 pages. Random House. $6.95.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN SLOW TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market continued to ease yesterday in very light trading.

title: FARMERS CRITICAL OF U.S. GRAIN DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Representatives of three farm organizations and several Democratic members of a House Agriculture subcommit tee sharply criticized the De partment of Agriculture today for the way it had handled the United StatesSoviet grain deal.

title: Washington Teachers Threaten to Strike Today
description: About 4,500 teachers in Washington vowed to go on strike this morning for higher pay and in protest against in creases in the size of their classes. Government officials sought a temporary restraining order to block the threatened walkout.

title: Capital Teachers Close Schools; Philadelphia Bargaining Pushed
description: More than 3,500 Washington, D.C. teachers ignored a court order and walked off their jobs yesterday in protest against job cuts and a stalled pay rise. Their action forced the closing of 54 of the 184 public schools in the nation's capital.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: NEWTOWN, Conn., Sept. 19 (AP)A group including Jackie Robinson, the former baseball star, announced plans today to build a thoroughbred and harness race track in Newtown.

title: ERNEST WASSING
description: DANVILLE, Va., Sept. 19 (AP)Ernest Wassing, a retired Austrianborn cellist who per formed with several of the world's major symphony or chestras, died here Sunday. He was 81 years old.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH, DRINK DEWAR'S William Lawson's 86.8 Proof Blended Scotch Whiskies. Imported by Palmer & Lord, Ltd., Syosset., N.Y.Advt.

title: McGovern For Tax Credit To Aid Parochial Schools
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 19Senator George McGovern endorsed to day a taxcredit system of pro viding Federal aid to parochial and other nonpublic schools.

title: Advertising:
description: If you run Into one of those local boosters who try to hand you the line that New York has everything, just ask him, What about com mercials in movie houses? You'll really have him there.

title: TWO L.I. BOYS SEIZED IN FATAL SHOOTING
description: EAST MEADOW, LI., Sept. 19 (AP)Two Hempstead boys were in custody today at the Children's Shelter here in con nection with the fatal wound ing of a man and the shooting of his wife during a robbery at their home last Saturday.

title: Rev. Charles A. Matthews, ExHead of Fordham Prep
description: The Rev. Charles A. Mat thews, a member of the Ford ham University faculty since 1941 and principal of Fordham Preparatory School from 1946 to 1952, died Tuesday in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, L.I., of cardiac congestion. He was 61 years old.

title: Capacity Set in Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 19The Texas Railroad Commission to day set allowable oil produc tion for the state in October at capacity for the seventh month in a row.

title: 12 Are Disciplined By Stock Exchange On Rule Violations
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that it had taken disciplinary actions against 12 present or former registered renresenta tives of member firms for various infractions of exchange rules.

title: Venezuela Cites Oil Find
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 19 (UPI)Venezuela's state oil company announced today it had struck oil in a wildcat well drilled in a new basin on the Continental Shelf off the north west coast of the country.

title: U.N. Assembly Opens and Chief Assails Vietnam War
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19The General Assem bly convened today for its 27th annual session amid tight antiterrorism measures and heard its new President, Stan islaw Trepczynski of Poland, declare that the war in Viet nam should be stopped once and for all.

title: ANACONDA LOSES INSURANCE CLAIMS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 19 The Overseas Private Invest ment Corporation, the govern ment agency that insures American private investment abroad, announced today that it had denied insurance claims from the Anaconda Company of $154million connected with Anaconda's nationalized cop per investments in Chile.

title: WNET TO PRESENT A BRITISH SERIES
description: Coronation Street, the longestrunning and most popu lar television serial in Britain, will begin a 26week run here Nov. 13 on WNETChannel 13. as it is in Britain, the serial will be presented here in twice weekly episodes, on Mondays and Thursdays at 10 P.M.

title: Mideast: Soviet Exodus From Egypt
description: JERUSALEMWith the passing of Egypt's President Nasser, Premier Kosygin's hasty visit to Cairo, which outlasted the normal requirements of protocol, indicated Russian apprehen sion as to relations with Egypt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is ironic that one day after pub lication of F. M. Esfandiary's A Plague on Both Your Tribes [OpEd Sept. 4], a tragic event developed in Munich, breaking the monumental boreas Mr. Esfandiary described it of the ArabIsraeli quarrel.

title: LandDevelopment Company Acknowledges Ills of Industry
description: One of the largest land de velopment companies in the country acknowledged yester day that many Federal charges against the industry, of wide spread unscrupulous practices have been justified.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITEWASH SEEN FOR MSG ADDITIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 An outspoken scientific crit ic of use of the chemical ad ditive MSG in foods charged before a Senate committee to day that the food industry, aided by the National Academy of Sciences, had whitewashed the harmful effects of the arti ficial flavorenhancer.

title: WHEAT FUTURES TAKE A TUMBLE
description: After rising sharply by the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel on Friday and another 10 cents again on Monday, wheat futures reacted yesterday with a sharp decline on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is quite regrettable that you found fit to print on the Aug. 26 OpEd page a column by a patent lawyer [I. Jordan Kunik] against the Grand Central Building.

title: Air Force Honors Civilian
description: BEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 19 (AP)Dr. Sylvia R. Mayer, a research psychologist at the Air Force Electronic Systems Divi sion at Hanscom Field, has been awarded the Air Force Civilian of the Year award. She won the award for develop ment of a computerbased on thejob training system.

title: Arab League Acting as Mediator Between Lebanon and Commandos
description: HASBEYA, Lebanon, Sept. 19 The 18member Arab League moved today to forestall open conflict between the Arab com mandos and the Lebanese Gov ernment while commandos and Lebanese troops maintained a wary coexistence here near the Israeli border.

title: RAMIREZ OUSTS LUTZ IN TENNIS
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP) A Mexican teenager, Paul Ramirez, eliminated the United States pro champion, Bob Lutz, from the $60,000 Pacific south west open tennis tournament in straight sets today.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Rooney Beats Lowenstein In Close Primary Runoff
description: Representative John J. Rooney defeated Allard K. Lowenstein early today in the courtordered special Democra tic primary in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District.

title: Business Briefs
description: DALLAS, Sept. 19 (UPI)A New York executive told an American Bankers Association meeting today that, despite overcoming blatant prejudice against blacks in business, there was a scarcity of minority banking execu tives because of an unconscionable tradition of exclu sionism.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CEDAR GROVE, N. J., Sept. 19while the bulk of the track and field world takes a postOlympic training reprieve, Marty Liguori has started double workouts aimed at resuming his competitive career.

title: Increase in Income Limits On Social Security Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)A bipartisan bill was introduced in the Senate today to increase by $1,320 a year the amount that Social Security pensioners may earn without cutting into their government benefits.

title: Complaint by Tanzania
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 19 (Reuters) President Julius Nyerere warned tonight that Uganda's bombing raids into northern Tanzania consti tuted a real and urgent dan ger to peace.

title: HOUSE FUNDS VOTE CHALLENGES NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The House challenged Presi dent Nixon to a new veto to day by approving an appropri ations bill for the Department of Labor and the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare that provides $836million more than requested by the Ad ministration.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ALBANY, Sept. 14 (AP)  New York State has been studying for the last six months the possibility of starting a daily state lottery, state Tax Commissioner Norman F. Gall man said today.

title: SENATE BACKS BILL FOR LANDUSE AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  The Senate approved today a major environmental bill de signed to meet a developing land crisis by authorizing the Federal Government for the first time to help states de velop longrange plans for use of land. The vote was 60 to 18.

title: Philathea College Agrees to Change Name to Seminary
description: Philathea College, an unac credited Canadian Bible school that has been criticized for awarding degrees too freely, has agreed with the Canadian Government to change its name to Philathea Theological Semi nary.

title: About Pro Football
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 19Of the players on the Washington Redskins' 40 man roster, Ted Vactor and Bill Malinchak rank about No. 29 and No. 36. Yet these two littleknown members helped tip last night's game to Washington over Minne sota, 2421, as George Allen's special teams on kicking plays clearly outper formed those of Bud Grant, the Viking coach Grant's offensive and defen sive teams clearly outper formed their Redskin coun terparts, but lost because of goofups.

title: Ranger Tickets on Sale Tomorrow for Six Games
description: A limited number of tick ets for the first six home games of the New York Rangers will go on sale to morrow at the Felt Forum Box Office at Madison Square Garden Center and at more than 150 Ticketron outlets.

title: N.Y.U. Cutting Its Faculty By 217 in Austerity Move
description: New York University plans to lay off or retire 217 faculty members and impose a strict payyourownway or perish rule for its member schools and colleges under a plan to stave off bankruptcy.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell of the Supreme Court denied today an appeal by the American party of Texas to overturn a threejudge Federal court ruling that the party filed too late to get on the ballot in Texas.

title: Admiral Moorer Comments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) Adm. Thomas C. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that the Lavelle affair had been over played, but had not hurt the military.

title: News Analysis
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 19 The grim succession of terror ist acts against Israeli targets in recent months has set Is raelis, and Arabs of various po litical stripes, to addressing themselves to two questions: Why should Arab militants have recourse now, more than 20 years after the birth of Is rael, to such spec tacular terrorist gestures? And why should they do so largely outside the Middle East? A traveler in the area hears many shades of opinion on the ques tion, but there is a surprising degree of agreement between Israelis and Arabs on one point.

title: TV: N.B.C. Presents Two New Series of TriplePlay Routine
description: This Fall, proclaim the ads, N.B.C. week has it all. Well, let's not look at that one too closely. But Wednes day evenings the National Broadcasting Company cer tainly comes close to having all the policeman  detective private eye action in televi sion town.

title: 10 PARENTS HELD IN SCHOOL PROTEST
description: Ten persons were arrested yesterday at the Meyer Levin Junior High in Brooklyn as Brownsville parents continued to demand the admission of their children to the East Flat bush school.

title: Cornell's Ithaca Campus May Get Biology Complex
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 19 Cornell University may con struct a multimilliondollar complex for biological studies at its campus here, university officials disclosed today.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  The Senate approved today a major environmental bill de signed to meet a developing land crisis by authorizing the Federal Government for the first time to help states de velop longrange plans for use of land. The vote was 60 to 18.

title: AGNEW SAYS NIXON BADE F.B.I. LOOK INTO WHEAT SALES
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 19 Vice President Agnew said to day that the F.B.I. had been ordered to investigate the $750 million sale of American wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: Fighting in Uganda Is Reported Continuing as Kampala Claims Victory
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 19 Fighting appeared to continue in southern Uganda today be tween troops loyal to President Idi Amin and a force of Ugan dan exiles who reportedly in vaded the country on Sunday from neighboring Tanzania.

title: Four New Trustees Named At Long Island University
description: The election of four new trustees to the board of Long Island University in Brooklyn was announced yesterday by John P. McGrath, board chair man.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Crowds at 13 games on Sunday and Monday night set a National Football League attendance record for open ing games, the league announced yesterday.

title: Rise in Housing Starts Ends Downward Drift
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Housing starts rose strongly in August after an irregular downward drift in previous months, the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: Issues at U.N. Session
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19Following is a summary of issues that are expected to figure promi nently in the 27th annual General Assembly session, which opened today. Some of the issues are formally inscribed on the agenda; others, are expected to be raised in the general debate or at committee meetings during the course of the 13week session.

title: LAWMAKERS MEET IN CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, Sept 19 The General Assembly met in spe cial session today, summoned by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill to stave off a bus crisis and pos sibly to formulate a compre hensive, longrange approach to Connecticut's worsening public transportation problems.

title: CoOp City Tenants Charge Fraud in Sale of Units
description: A group of 50 tenant share holders of the CoOp City housing development in the Bronx charged a state agency and two corporations with fraud yesterday in the sale of apartments in the cooperative which opened three years ago.

title: Mideast: A Canvass for Fairness
description: Arabs who live in the United States have been fed with a recipe which is extremely alien to their taste. Since Munich's tragedy, the Arabs have been depicted as bloodhounds, fleshmon gers, a species with an unquenchable appetite for bloodspurting.

title: District Attorneys Noncommittal On the Appointment of Nadjari
description: The city's five District At torneys, who had been opposed to the appointment of a special prosecutor to ferret out official corruption, either acquiesced or remained silent yesterday when Governor Rockefeller named Maurice H. Nadjari to fill that newly created post.

title: U.S. Protested Sept 10
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The United States protested to Syria nine days ago the arrest of Major Barrett, but he remains detained without known charges, the State Department said today.

title: New Giant Defense Not New to Landry
description: For two months, the Giants have been talking about their new rover defense. Now along comes Tom Landry, the Dallas coach, to explode that illusion with one swipe of the tongue.

title: ALI HEAVY CHOICE OVER PATTERSON IN BOUT TONIGHT
description: With an anticipated sellout throng of 19.000 expected to produce more sympathy for his 37yearold opponent than idol atry for him, Muhammad All will oppose Floyd Patterson to night at Madison Square Gar den in a 12round bout.

title: Yankees Beaten, 7 to 2, By Brewers' Parsons
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 19 Spurning opportunity so thor oughly as to be absolutely rude, the New York Yankees were never in the game tonight as they lost to the Milwaukee Brewers, 72.

title: Front Page 4  No Title
description: 2 LB. LOBSTER DINNER $10.95THE LOBSTER RESTAURANT 5820400 145 WEST 45th ST.ADVT.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I feel compelled to ?? the blatantly racist posters of the I.L.G. W.U. which many subway cars are now exhibiting. Their appeal to xeno phobic and racist feelings against the Japanese people deserves a thorough denunciation from our public leaders and the media.

title: Mrs. Forbes Hawkes Dies; A Women's Suffrage Leader
description: COCONUT GROVE, Fla., Sept. 19  Mrs. Alice Silliman Belknap Hawkes, widow of Dr. Forbes R. Hawkes, a New York surgeon, died today at her home here. She was 94 years old.

title: Federal Housing Reform Unlikely Despite Scandal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Despite widespread scandals and failures in Federal housing programs, Congress appears to be on the verge of enacting voluminous new legislation that would continue the controver sial programs for another two years without major reform.

title: Lindsay Attends Start Of Fall Fashion Festival
description: Mayor Lindsay toured the garment area, unveiled a sign temporarily renaming part of Seventh Avenue, Fashion Avenue, and had lunch with leaders of the garment indus try at The Daily News yester day as the city began its first annual Fall Fashion Festival.

title: Show Business for Spitz
description: 19 (UPI) Mark Spitz, who swam to a record seven gold medals at the 1972 Olympics, yesterday signed a contract with the William Morris Agency to handle his potential show business career. Meantime, the California Milk Advisory Board said that it would film Spitz on Thursday for one of its Every Body Needs Milk commercials.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19Gover nor Cahill signed into a law today a bill that will allow New Jersey's 21 counties to modernize their operations by selecting a form of government that puts greater power into the hands of an elected or ap pointed county executive.

title: FED'S CHECK RULE DELAYED BY JUDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 19A Federal judge issued today a temporary restraining order that will probably delay two major new regulations of the Federal Reserve Board that were scheduled to take effect on Thursday.

title: 3 RELEASED BY HANOI TOUR BOMBED AREAS
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 19 (Agence FrancePresse) Three American prisoners who were released at a ceremony Sunday left the capital at dawn today for a tour of heavily bombed areas of Namdinh and Ninhbinh 60 miles from Hanoi.

title: BOOBY TRAP KILLS ISRAELI IN LONDON
description: LONDON, Sept. 19  An Israeli diplomat was killed and another injured today when an envelope sent through the mail exploded in the embassy.

title: COAST F.B.I. AIDE DEMOTED BY GRAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)David L. Kinley, execu tive assistant to L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation, said today that the former chief of the Los Angeles office of the bureau had been suspended for a second time and demoted to the Minneapolis office.

title: Vesco Resigns Positions At International Controls
description: Robert L. Vesco, the former power behind I.O.S. Ltd., the Swissbased mutualfund group, resigned yesterday as board chairman, chief executive of ficer and a director of the International Controls Corpo ration.

title: Albatross Sets Pacing Mark Of 1:55 for Mile in Ohio
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 (AP)  Albatross established a world pacing record over a halfmile track today in regis tering a time of 1:55 35 for the mile at the Delaware Coun ty Fairgrounds.

title: Notes on People
description: The United States Supreme Court did not want to discuss the disclosure that for the first time in its 182year his tory the Court has appoint ed a girl page14yearold Deborah Gelin of Rockville, Md. Miss Gelin, a highschool sophomore, was not permit ted by her mother to discuss her new job on the telephone. Among the things the Court and the Gelins declined to disclose was Deborah's sal ary, which she begins to earn on Monday. But her father, Jacques Gelin, a lawyer for the Justice Department, said Deborah was quite a bit above average and a player of the saxophone and bas soon.

title: SOVIET ADMITS LAG ON POLLUTION CURBS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 19  The Soviet Government conceded today that despite the advan tage it has claimed for Com munism in protecting the en vironment, heavy industrial pol lution was still causing serious damage to the nation's econ omy.

title: Tire With Flaw Recalled
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP)  The Montgomery Ward Com pany said today that it was recalling 435 passenger car tires to recover 220 tires sus pected of inadequate vulcani zation. A company spokesman said Ward's supplier, the Fire stone the and Rubber Com pany, had said the tires were shipped from Firestone's plant in Des Moines, Iowa, to loca tions in the Midwest and South east.

title: EARLY STRENGTH OF STOCKS FADES
description: The stock market opened yesterday with a mild show of strength, but it gave ground later in another spiritless ses sion to finish with a loss. The DowJones industrials, dipping 2.18 points, ended at 943.18.

title: Antiques in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19  A rakish bowbacked Wind sor, a Jenny Lind callabash bottle and a porcelain coffee pot boasting a dogshaped spout are all part of the mixed and surprisingly rich legacy that two centuries of this state's craftsmen have left for today's antiques en thusiasts to mull over or merely enjoy.

title: Beryozka Dancers to Glide In Tonight
description: The Beryozka Dance Com pany, making its first visit to the United States in 13 years, opens tonight at the City Center almost as a new company. The formerly all women Soviet folk ensemble has gone coed and is three times its original size.

title: JERSEY TO START A DAILY LOTTERY WITH $2,500 PRIZE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19New Jersey will offer bettors a daily 50cent lottery beginning Nov. 29, to meet increased compe tition to the weekly lottery from surrounding states and to cut into receipts of the illegal numbers racket.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)Trimming the 10 per cent tax on telephone calls by half was recommended today by Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Con necticut, to show that the Viet nam war is winding down.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: PETERSBURG, Ind., Sept. 19 (AP)Above all, he was dedicated to God, family, country and the game of baseball.

title: New Haven Sheriff Queried on Picking Of 20 Grand Jurors
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 19The 76year  old High Sheriff of New Haven County, questioned today about his selection of a grand jury to consider a triple slaying indictment, said that he had chosen three or four of the jurors after being intro duced to them at an Elks club.

title: Pole, Obscure in '71, U.N. Assembly Chief
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19Who is Trepczyn ski?

title: Whistler's Sketches Limn Early Years
description: The Metropolitan Museum's latest miniature exhibition in the gallery devoted to airing American drawings and wa tercolors from the storage bins, is given over to James Abbott McNeill Whistler, the expatriate firecracker. Unlike its predecessors, the new show, which opened yester day, is composed largely of familiar (and even overfamil iar) material, but it opens with a group of early sketches never before exhibited.

title: I.B.M. Is Seeking a Listing On Tokyo Stock Exchange
description: TOKYO, Sept. 19 (AP)The International Business Machines Corporation, said today it would like to have its shares listed on the Tokyo Stock Ex change.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Just about every style a fashionable women would want to wear this winter is in the Donald Brooks fur col lection for Bonwit Teller, which was shown yesterday. There are smocks, battle jackets, blazers, pants suits, caftans, fireside skirts, trench coats, cardigans, youname it.

title: A Degas, Not Missed, Is Recovered by Museum
description: A valuable Degas print has been returned in a brown paper package to the Brook lyn Museum, which, a spokes man said, did not know it was missing.

title: BOOBY TRAP KILLS ISRAELI IN LONDON
description: LONDON, Sept. 19  An Israeli diplomat was killed and another injured today when an envelope sent through the mail exploded in the embassy.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 19Despite lower enrollments and mount ing costs the Catholic schools of New Jersey are facing a new year with optimism.

title: JERSEY TO START A DAILY LOTTERY WITH $2,500 PRIZE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19New Jersey will offer bettors a daily 50cent lottery beginning Nov. 29, to meet increased compe tition to the weekly lottery from surrounding states and to cut into receipts of the illegal numbers racket.

title: Market Place: Discipline Data For the Public
description: For years the New York Stock Exchange has been ac cused of acting as a private club strictly for the benefit of its members.

title: Coaches Have a Day Oct. 6
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  President Nixon, a self described sports enthusiast, signed a proclamation today designating Oct. 6 as National Coaches Day.

title: Senate Votes Transit Aid From Fund for Highways
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The Senate voted today to allow the states to use part of their Federal highway money to build mass transportation sys tems in urban areas.

title: A Sense of Proportion
description: Robert Marcel Casadesus was generally considered a musician in the best French traditiona tradition known for clarity of expression, a sense of propor tion and elegance of phrasing. In reviewing one of his earlier recitals here in 1937, Noel Straus wrote in The New York Times that of the many striking mer its of his playing, sanity and continence were preeminent and few pianists possessing Mr. Casadesus's strength refuse as consistently to indulge in overstatement.

title: The Politics of Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19It is ironic but unsurprising that policemen's or ganizations have endorsed President Nixon for reelection. Ironic because Mr. Nixon has done nothing to help policemen but not surprising since he plays upon the negative, defensive, inwardlooking attitudes which pre vail in the police community.

title: SHERMAN GRAFF
description: Sherman Graff, a proofreader on The New York Times for 26 years, died Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 15 Clare mont Avenue.

title: Substantial Progress Reported in Jobs Inquiry
description: The city's Investigation Commissioner, Robert K. Rus kin, reported yesterday that there had been substantial progress in his department's investigation of alleged irregu larities in the emergency em ployment program here but that he was not ready to an nounce any conclusions.

title: Executive Changes
description: Jerome H. Holland, former United States Am bassador to Sweden and president of the Hampton Institute, was elected a director of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and its parent company, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. Dr. Holland was recently named a public director of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Merger News
description: The Justice Department yes terday sought to block the ac quisition of the Columbus & Southern Ohio Electric Compa ny by the American Electric Power Company, a large utility holding company, on the ground that it would seriously curtail competition in the sale of elec tricity in Ohio. In a brief filed with with the Securi ties and Exchange commission, the Justice Depart ment said there is a serious risk that approval of this acquisition would have the direct and rapid effect of transforming a seven firm industry structure in Ohio into a twocompany industry structure.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LAKE CHARLES, La., Sept. 19 (AP)The Southland Conference has barred McNeese State University from participating in basketball championships and recruiting prospective players, because of irregularities in college entrance exams taken by two athletes, school officials announced today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Warning Issued on Clams and Mussels

title: 9 CONVICTED HERE IN NARCOTICS CASE
description: Joseph (Jojo) Manfredi, a reputed Mafia captain, and eight other defendants were found guilty in Federal District Court here last night of con spiring to distribute narcotics.

title: Personalities: Knicks Obtain a 610 Forward
description: The Knicks, looking to the future when they will have to rebuild their talented, but aging front line, obtained the negotiation rights yesterday to John Gianelli from the Houston Rockets. The 22 yearold Gianelli was the na tion's second leading college rebounder last season at the University of Pacific and was named to several allAmerica teams. The 6foot10inch Gianelli, primarily a center in college, was Houston's sec ondround pick in last April's National Basketball Associa tion draft. The Rockets had no first round pick because they had traded it to the Mil waukee Bucks.

title: Perelman, Sated With British Couth, Is Reveling in His Gotham
description: S. J. Perelman, the man without a country home, has returned to his native New York City.

title: New Jersey Women Repeat Intersectional Golf Victory
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Sept. 19New Jersey, which won the Myra D. Patterson Cup last season for the first time in 15 years, made it two straight today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association intersectional matches at Rock ville Links. The Garden State team scored 44 points, to 25 for Long Island and 20 for Westchester.

title: Distillers CorporationSeagrams, Ltd., Sets Earnings Records
Stage: Rumanian Troupe's Dybbuk
description: There is a special curios ity due to a Jewish dramatic company originating today in Eastern Europe, where Jews do not seem particu larly welcome. However, Ru mania clearly does not slav ishly follow Moscow's party line and it is therefore a par ticular pleasure to welcome to the United States the Jewish State Theater of Ru mania, which last night opened a twoweek engage ment at the Brooklyn Acad emy of Music.

title: JUSTICE STREIT PLANS TO RETIRE
description: Manhattan Supreme Court Justice Saul S. Streit an Inounced yesterday that he was retired after more than 36 years on the bench.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A nonregistered secondary offering of 64,700 shares of Carolina Freight Carriers com mon stock at 13 was offered yesterday by Bache & Co. The company's stock closed at that price, up , on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SAMUEL KLEIN DEAD; A CHOCOLATE MAKER
description: Samuel Klein, who spent 55 years in the chocolate business, died Sunday at his home, 137 Riverside Drive, after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Opera: A New Carmen, Daring and Provocative
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened its season last night with what Lowell Wadmond, in a precurtain speech, called Goeran Gentele's new Car men. Mr. Wadmond, chair man of the board of the Metropolitan Opera, was of course referring to the late general manager and his pro jected debut. When he met his death last July, Mr. Gen tele was full of ideas about this Carmen, which he him self was going to direct.

title: Theater: A Baraka Trio
description: The three oneact plays that opened Monday as the first installment in a two part Imamu Amiri Baraka (LeRol Jones) festival at the AfriAmerican Studio are an gry indictments written from a highly moral position. It is not only the white world that Baraka is criticizing but also blacks who passively accept oppressive white judgments.

title: Man in the News
description: The question was long and a bit convoluted but it boiled down to this: Would you be reluctant to bring a judge or district attorney before a grand jury as part of an in vestigation of corruption in the city's criminal justice system?

title: EXRACEWAY AIDE IS INDICTED HERE
description: A former director of Monti cello Raceway was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday. Jerome Ehrlich, 41 years old, of South Fallsburg, N.Y., was charged with devis ing a fraudulent tax scheme in connection with raceway winnings.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Tenants of Coop City in the Bronx filed a $110mil lion suit alleging stock fraud against the state; the United Housing Foundation, the de veloper; Community Serv ices, Inc., the contractor, and eight officers of the two cor porations. The suit was filed in Federal Court by 50 ten ants on behalf of Coop City's 15,273 families. The suit charged that the defendants had circulated a false and de ceptive prospectus and also that they had wasted assets of the project.

title: Cambodians Hit Sampans
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 19 (Reuters)Cambodian air craft caught and attacked about 300 North Vietnamese sampans in the waterlogged Mekong River Valley, 26 miles south west of here, the military com mand reported today.

title: SPOTTSWOOD WHITE OF KUHN, LOEB DIES
description: H. Spottswood White, a former general partner and since 1968 a limited partner in Kuhn, Loeb & Co., investment bankers, died early yesterday in New York. He was 70 years old and a resident of Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Inland Systems Decides To Take Bankruptcy Step
description: M. K. Miller, chairman of In land Systems, Inc., announced that the company yesterday was in Federal Court in Springfield, Ohio, seeking an arrangement with its creditors under the Bankruptcy Act.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  The seven men charged on eight counts each in the Water gate bugging conspiracy case all pleaded not guilty today and were released an bonds ranging from $10,000 to $50,000.

title: Grain Giveaway
description: A picture of incompetence or worse in the Department of Agriculture has emerged from the current House subcommittee hearings on the strange events attending large wheat sales to the Soviet Union last summer. At the end of July it was common knowledge in Moscow that the U.S.S.R. grain harvest was very disappointing.

title: Still a Pared Share
description: Conferees representing the House and Senate have managed to combine many of the best elements in the divergent versions of revenue sharing adopted by the two chambers, thus clearing the way for passage of a bill that will represent a major advance in intergovernmental fiscal relationships.

title: New Singer With Old Ways at Plaza
description: Last season, by booking acts such as the poprock Kenny Rogers and the First Edition, the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel began to move away from the posh Image it had maintained since It opened in 1934. However, it still kept such vestiges of its past as a stiff cover charge and an expensive menu.

title: NEW HABITS URGED TO CONSERVE FUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19A Government study suggests far reaching changes in the habits of Americans, particularly in transportation, that might mod erate the soaring demand for fuels and electric power.

title: House Backs Bear Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 19 (AP) A directive for the President to seek an international mora torium against killing polar bears was passed by the House today and sent to the Senate. Some 1,300 polar bears are be ing killed every year, mostly by hunters seeking trophies, ac cording to a report accompany ing the House bill.

title: U.N. Assembly Opens and Chief Assails Vietnam War
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19The General Assem bly convened today for its 27th annual session amid tight antiterrorism measures and heard its new President, Stan islaw Trepczynski of Poland, declare that the war in Viet nam should be stopped once and for all.

title: Senate Votes Transit Aid From Fund for Highways
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The Senate voted today to allow the states to use part of their Federal highway money to build mass transportation sys tems in urban areas.

title: Convention Plot Suspects Gain Trial Postponement
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 19 (AP)  United States District Judge David L. Middlebrooks ordered an indefinite postpone ment today in the conspiracy trial of six antiwar veterans charged with plotting to dis rupt the Republican National Convention.

title: New York Studies Proposal
description: ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 19 (AP) New York State has been studying for the last six months the possibility of starting a daily state lottery, State Tax Commissioner Norman F. Gall man said today.

title: Buck to Seek U.S. Pullout From Olympic Basketball
description: Clifford H. Buck, president of the United States Olympic Committee, said yesterday he would recommend that the United States suspend indefin itely any further participation in Olympic basketball as a protest to the unconscionable injustice done to the U.S.A. bas ketball team in Munich.

title: Schlitz to Expand Plant
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company plans to expand its newest plant at Memphis to an annual capacity of 6.2 million barrels from 4.4 million barrels. Robert A. Uihlein Jr., chairman of the board, said the $17mil lion project, scheduled for com pletion in 1974, would give the company a total production at its nine plants of more than 24 million barrels a year.

title: THEATER IS PLANNED FOR WESTCHESTER
description: A group of private investors announced plans yesterday to build a 3,200seat theater in Westchester County near the intersection of the State Thru way and the Cross Westchester Expressway.

title: Role in Talks Is Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Clarence D. Palmby, a former Assistant Secretary of. Agricul ture, denied categorically to day that he had had any part in negotiations between the Continental Grain Company and the Soviet Union after he had left the Government to join the in negotiations between the Continental Grain Company and the Soviet Union after he had left the Government to join the company as vice president.

title: Books of The Times
description: CHIMERA, By John Barth. 308 pages. Random House. $6.95,

title: U. S. Gets Reassurances
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The State Department said to day that the American Embas sy in Kampala had been in touch with President Idi Amin and other top officials to secure the release of six Americans detained by Uganda.

title: Aide Says Lavelle Ordered Bombings
description: DENVER, Sept. 19 Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle's former top aide told a Senate commit tee today that the general per sonally ordered him to stage unauthorized bombing missions into North Vietnam and also demanded that official post strike reports be falsified.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 19 (UPI)J. M. Hewgley Jr., for mer Mayor of Tulsa, inched ahead of former United Staes Attorney Robert Rizley tonight in a runoff for a Republican berth in Oklahoma's 1st Con gressional District. Mr. Hewgley led with 12,096 votes to Mr. Risley's 11,658 with 351 of 356 precincts reporting.

title: Young Pop Musicians Given Chance to Win 4Week Gigs
description: A pop music contest for young New York musicians, with two prizes of fourweek engagements at two wellknown local restaurants, was an nounced at a news conference yesterday at the Riverboat res taurant, Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, by Phyllis Robinson, Deputy Commissioner of Cul tural Affairs.

title: Business Briefs
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday it was reorganizing its data processing product group along lines integrating product development with manufacturing.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 19Gov. Dan Evans won renomination on the Republican ticket today and former Gov. Albert D. Rosellini pulled into a strong lead for the Democratic nomi nation.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: NEW SCHOOL NEWSLINE  Call 741 0707. 24hr service for listing of special events you'll want to attend. Advt.

title: $500,000 BAIL SET FOR FORT WORTH 5
description: ABILENE, Tex., Sept. 19 (UPI)United States District Judge Leo Brewster today set bail at $100,000 each for five men jailed without bond since June for refusing to tell a Fed eral grand jury what they know about an alleged plot to run guns to Northern Ireland.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 19 Dr. George Gallup, the dean of American political pollsters, said today that Senator George McGovern had as good a chance of closing the gap with President Nixon as he did in winning the key primaries.

title: Hijack ?? Protested at U.N.
description: More than 150 pilots and other airline employes demon strated quietly near the United Nations Building yes terday to campaign for tougher international treat ment of hijackers.

title: Miss Durr Is Upset
description: ALBANY, Calif., Sept. 19 (AP)Kris Kemmer of Santa Monica upset Francoise Durr of France today in the first round of the $20,000 Pacific Coast tennis tournament.

title: G.E. Wins Nuclear Deal Valued at $875Million
description: The Potomac Electric Power Company announced yesterday the award of a contract valued at about $875million to the General Electric Company for two 1.1millionkilowatt nuclear power units and transmission lines. The total cost of the proj ect, which will be built on a 1,400acre site near Douglas Point on the Potomac River in Charles County, Md., 34 miles south of Washington, D.C., has been put at $1billion, including nuclear fuel.

title: Foe Now Holds Large Part Of 5 Northern Provinces
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 19The other side is building a nation in the hills, a high American officer said, ruefully summing up developments in the last six months in the five northern provinces of South Vietnam, known as Military Re gion I.

title: Sperry Rand Reports Sales
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation said yesterday that more than $90million in its Univac Ser ies 70 computer equipment has been shipped to customers since last Jan. 1. Shipments through Aug. 31 included 66 central processors.

title: Robert Casadesus, French Pianist, Dies
description: PARIS, Sept. 19Robert Cas adesus, French pianist and com poser, died in a hospital here today after an operation for cancer of the pancreas. He be came ill three weeks ago. His age was 73.

title: ROCKLAND WEIGHS OWN 2% SALES TAX
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Sept. 19 A 2 per cent Rockland County sales tax, designed to reduce the tax burden on real prop erty owners, was proposed to night to the County Legislature.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Shortly after the Democratic Na tional Convention nominated Senator George McGovern for President, The Times carried a dispatch stating the Democratic nominee had been en dorsed by the executive board of The Newspaper Guild. A dispatch froth Washington quoted Charles A. Perlik, national Guild president, announcing the endorsement at McGovern head quarters, as stating the union had de cided for the first time in its forty year existence to endorse a Presi dential candidate.

title: Syria Is Detaining a U.S. Aide Despite Protest by Washington
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 19 (Reuters)A United States Em bassy spokesman said today that Syria had detained an American military attach and that the United States had pro tested the action.

title: Preview of Beryozka Canceled: No Costumes
description: Last night's performance of the Beryozka Dance Com pany, billed as a preview, was canceled when two costume shipments failed to arrive on time from Europe. Columbia Artists, which is presenting the group, said the official opening at the City Center would take place tonight as scheduled.

title: Roundup: Reds Triumph, Cut Magic Number to 4
description: The Cincinnati Reds broke a 44 tie and spoiled Juan Marichal's relief pitching to beat the San Francisco Giants, 54, last night in Riverfront Stadium.

title: ExF.B.I. Man Becomes N.B.A.'s Security Chief
description: A fourth major sports league went to the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday for a security director when the Na tional Basketball Association appointed an agent as its se curity chief.

title: PRICES ON AMEX AND OTC DROP
description: Stocks continued to decline yesterday in slow trading the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter mar ket.

title: Heath Warns Japanese on Trade
description: TOKYO, Sept. 19  Prime Minister Heath of Britain cau tioned the Japanese today to balance their trade with Britain and other European nations or be confronted with protection ist measures.

title: Saigon Reports Heavy Fighting at Towns
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 20  Heavy fighting was reported yesterday in the central coastal province of Quangngai, with four of its 10 district capitals under con tinuing attack.

title: HENRY NUNN DEAD; LED SHOE CONCERN
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Sept. 19 (AP)Henry L. Nunn, cofoun der of the NunnBush Shoe Company of Milwaukee and its president until 1960, died Fri day at his home here. He was 94 years old.

title: Cleveland Policemen Held In $316,500 Brink's Theft
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (UPI) Patrolman Wallace E. Cow per, 31 years old, was arrested today by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a police precinct rollcall room and charged with participating in the $316,500 larceny of a suburban Mentor bank.

title: Fund Partners Will Part Ways
description: The dissolution of one of the oldest partnerships in the mu tual fund industry was an nounced yesterday.

title: Israel's Risks
description: Only by daring to take risks for the sake of our country and our rights can the danger be overcome and eliminated, Premier Golda Meir told her Parliament last week. Subjected to continuing terrorist onslaught, Israel has now launched a campaign of direct military action focused on the training and command centers of Pales tinian guerrilla activity in Lebanon and Syria.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 19 Dr. Arnold D. Grobman, dean of Rutgers College, announced today he was leaving Dec. 31 to become vice chancellor for academic affairs at the Chicago Circle campus of the University of Illinois.

title: TALKS BROKEN OFF ON MUSICIANS' PACT
description: Contract talks broke off yes terday between Local 802 of the American Federation of Mu sicians and the League of New York Theaters.

title: Biessinger Suffers Attack
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP)  Howard Biessinger, a harnessrace driver, was re ported in good condition at Lower Bucks Hospital today after suffering a heart attack early this morning. Biessinger, 64 years old, had driven in races last Saturday night at Liberty Bell.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 President Nixon will fly to New York next Tuesday to kick off the second tour of his reelec tion campaign.

title: TIGERS LOSE PAIR TO INDIANS, 32, 64
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (AP) Steve Dunning's pitching in the first game and Graig Net tles's hitting in the second powered the Cleveland Indians to a 32, 64 doubleheader sweep over Detroit tonight that knocked the Tigers out of first place in the American League East.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The chairmen of the Re publican and Democratic na tional committees solemnly promised today to conduct a clean and fair political cam paign. Minutes after they signed the pledge, they traded accusations of personal abuse and espionage.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On a matter of accuracy regarding the plebiscite held in Puerto Rico in 1967, you have stated twice in your news columns that the independence movement leaders asked the people to boycott the election as rigged. (Aug. 29 and Sept. 3.)

title: Midwives Carry New Image Into Hospital Delivery Room
description: The greatest joy is to become a mother; the second greatest is to be a midwife.

title: Citizens Committee Set Up Here To Aid McGovern's Campaign
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, state chairman of the Presidential campaign of Sena tor George McGovern, an nounced yesterday the forma tion of a citizens committee of nearly 200 persons to help carry the state for the Senator.

title: Strike of Valley Stream Sanitatiorimen Continues
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Sept. 19Garbage and refuse piled up in front of homes here today as sanitationmen continued their strike for the second day to protest the village's docking them two weeks' pay for al leged violation of the state's Taylor Law, which prohibits strikes or slowdowns by public employes. The village accuses the workers of starting a slow clown on July 14 during con tract negotiations.

title: BAHAMAS LEADER APPARENT VICTOR
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Sept. 19Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling, promising the 180,000 residents of the Bahamas their freedom from Britain next sum mer, apparently led his Pro gressive Labor party to victory at the polls today.

title: Senate Panel Approves Revised MilitaryAid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a revised $1.5billion military authoriza tion bill today to replace the one that the Senate killed in July.

title: JAPAN'S ENVOY ENDS HIS TALKS IN TAIWAN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 19 Etsusaburo Shiina, the special envoy sent by Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan, ended a three day visit here today, apparently without having softened the Taipei Government's strong op position to Tokyo's plans for normalization of relations with the Chinese Communist Government.

title: Fanny May Yields Go Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (Reuters)The average yield for fourmonth commitments on Governmentbacked mortgages at the latest Federal National Mortgage Association auction was 7.658 per cent, compared with 7.635 per cent at the pre vious sale on Sept. 5, Fanny May reported.

title: Advertising:
description: With the new year, 34 yearold Warwick & Legler will become Warwick, Welsh & Miller. I feel strongly that an agency's name should re flect the people who are heading up the key areas, said John P. Warwick, presi dent and chairman, who is also the son of the cofound er, H. Paul Warwick.management, while John F. Welsh, vice chairman and executive vice president, handles account services, and Robert D. Miller, also an ex ecutive vice president, heads the creative area.

title: Sports of The Times
description: They could bill it as an evening in the Old Soldiers' Home with the soldiers still at war. Madison Square Garden, where fistfighters have been winning and losing cham pionships since the ring stood in an abandoned railroad station on Madison Square offers The Fancy a curious and interesting confection tonight, a boxing card topped by four exchampionsFloyd Patterson and the man he calls Cassius Clay, who have fought each other once and other people 22 times for the heavyweight championship of the world and have held it three times between them: Carlos Ortiz, once junior welterweight and twice lightweight cham pion, and Ken Buchanan, who lost in June the lightweight title Ortiz first won 10 years ago. Has there ever been a show presenting four exchampions in the same ring? We prefer to call them past champions, said the Garden's Tommy Renville, like the past grand exalted ruler of the Elks or past boxing commissioners, who always get the best seats ringside.

title: Eagleton Would Not Accept Post in McGovern Cabinet
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 19 (UPI)  Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, campaigning in Illinois with the Democratic candidate for State Attorney General, Thomas Ly ons, ruled out yesterday any post for himself in a McGovern Administration.

title: BEATTY IS VICTOR IN BROOKLYN RACE
description: Assemblyman Vander L. Beatty defeated State Senator Waldaba Stewart last night in a special Democratic primary electtion in Brooklyn's 18th Senatorial District that pitted two factions of the black politi cal structure in BedfordStuy vesant against each other.

title: Filly's Debut Will Be Tough Act to Follow
description: Arlene Francis not only can act and talk and serve on panels, she can also fly. The filly, that is.

title: WILSON & CO. PLANS TO MERGE 4 UNITS
description: Directors of Tour publicly held subsidiaries of Wilson & Co., Inc., approved yesterday in principal a proposal to con solidate into one new company. The proposal will be submitted to shareholders of the four con cerns.

title: Federal Housing Reform Unlikely Despite Scandal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Despite widespread scandals and failures in Federal housing programs, Congress appears to be on the verge of enacting voluminous new legislation that would continue the controver sial programs for another two years without major reform.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: A woman in San Francisco couldn't decide which of Adolfo's furtrimmed knitted suits to buy, so she bought all four. Typical price: $725 each. Another customer, in Chevy Chase, Md., is collecting Adolfos with a passion.

title: EXPERT DESCRIBES LONG CAVE DAYS
description: A French specialist in cave research, after remaining iso lated underground for 205 days in Texas, has found that, for reasons unknown, his body rhythm sometimes doubled its rate.

title: Jamieson, Weiskopf to Represent U. S. in Cup Golf Starting Nov. 8
description: Jim Jamieson, the Western open champion, and Tom Weis kopf were named yesterday as the team that will represent the United States in the World Cup golf matches in Melbourne, Australia, Nov. 8 through 12.

title: GROUPS ARE SPLIT ON AIRPORT THEFT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)The Justice Department and Governor Rockefeller yes terday urged a Senate subcom mittee to approve a compact between New York and New Jersey extending the jurisdic tion of the Waterfront Commis sion to airports.

title: Role in Talks Is Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Clarence D. Palmby, a former Assistant Secretary of Agricul ture, denied categorically to day that he had had any part in negotiations between the Continental Grain Company and the Soviet Union after he had left the Government to join the company as vice president. Mr. Palmby accompanied Sec retary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz to Moscow last April for preliminary discussions on Gov ernment credits for the pur chase of American grain. The discussions came to nothing at that time because the Soviet Union wanted a long term, low interest loan, and under the law, the Commodity Credit Corporation could give credits for only three years at 6 per cent interest.

title: Toxic Paint Chemical Is Found in 17 of 39 States
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)  A toxic chemical used in plastics and paints has been found in unexpectedly large amounts in 17 of 39 states sampled, according to Govern ment scientists. The chemical appeared especially prevalent in newly developed real estate lakes.

title: Boston Shorty Meets The Cat in Billiards
description: By 2 o'clock yesterday af ternoon the dank subterra nean hall that is McGirr's Billiard Academy was filling with men who broke into groups and talked excitedly about the imminent headto head threecushion billiard confrontation between Jim my (the Cat) Cattrano and Larry (Boston Shorty) John son.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: DON'T be the last one to find out about the new TICKETRON ENTERTAINMENT MAGAZINE. 178.000 readers in metro N.Y. are already ahead of you. Call today for advertising info: 8381652.ADVT.

title: N.Y.U. Cutting Its Faculty By 217 in Austerity Move
description: New York University plans to lay off or retire 217 faculty members and impose a strict payyourownway or perish rule for its member schools and colleges under a plan to stave off bankruptcy.

title: THWARTED VOTERS BACKED BY COURTS
description: The rerun Democratic pri mary race between Represent ative John J. Rooney and Al lard K. Lowenstein was compli cated late last night because of a decision reached by four State Supreme Court justices and a court order from a Fed eral judge.

title: 2 ExportPromotion Plans Ended by Bank of Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 19 (Reuters) The policy board of the Bank of Japan announced today the abolition of two measures de signed to promote exports with preferential treatment. They are the system of making loans on the security of export trade bills and the system of dis counting export advances de nominated in yen.

title: Bridge: Some Uses of the Familiar Are Strictly for the Experts
description: The unusual notrump, promising length in the minor suits is wellknown to stu dents of the game, but some of its more sophisticated ap plications are marked for experts only. An example occurred in the diagramed deal, played at the Mayfair House of Bridge.

title: Super D.A.
description: Governor Rockefeller's response to the Knapp Com mission's call for a special prosecutor to root out official corruption holds promise of effective reform. The Gov ernor has instructed State Attorney General Lefkowitz to create such a special Deputy Attorney Generala request with which Mr. Lefkowitz has naturally complied and assurance has also been given that this new office will have an adequate staff and essential finances.

title: Aide Says Lavelle Ordered Bombings
description: DENVER, Sept. 19 Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle's former top aide told a Senate commit tee today that the general per sonally ordered him to stage unauthorized bombing missions into North Vietnam and also demanded that official post strike reports be falsified.

title: Highway Patrolman Slain
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 19 (UPI)A state highway patrol man, Robert E. Akes, 28 years old, was shot and killed late yesterday, apparently by a motorist he stopped just east of here. The police were seek ing three suspects. The motive for the shooting was not de termined.

title: PAN AM IS HOPING FOR PROFIT BY '73
description: Pan American World Air ways has set its sights on re turning to profitable operations in 1973 but it is too early to assess its chances of success, the company's chairman, Wil liam T. Seawell, said yesterday.

title: McGovern Would Hold Regular News Sessions
description: Senator George McGovern says that if he is elected he will hold Presidential news conferences twice a month, open Cabinet meetings to the press except in rare cases where the national security poses a secrecy requirement and end background briefings in which information is sup plied on the condition that the source is not disclosed.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Alarm Broadcast in Failla Slaying

title: Hospital Is Upheld In Ban on Abortion For L.I. Woman, 20
description: Federal District Court Judge John F. Dooling Jr. yesterday dismissed a contempt charge against Nassau County Medical Center brought by a 20year old woman who had been re fused an abortion.

title: Survivors Get $865,000
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 (UPI)The widow and the son of a lawyer who was killed in a light plane crash 2 years ago were awarded $865,000 yesterday by a Superior Court jury. Mrs. Sandra Dedina, 36 years old, of San Rafael, Calif., and her 5yearold son, Steven 4th, had sought $3million for the death of Steven Dedina 3d.

title: PIRATES WIN, 51; CLINCH TITLE TIE
