description: Roberto Clemente and his Pittsburgh Pirate teammates both moved closer to their goals at Shea Stadium last night while the Buccaneers were trimming the Mets, 51.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) President Nixon flew to Camp David this afternoon for a mid week stay at his Maryland re treat.

title: STATE IS WARNED ON FUNDSHARING
description: New York State faces an ad verse impact on future state budgets from the revenue sharing bill now agreed on by Congressional conferees, al though the measure should per mit the state's current $7.8 billion budget to be balanced, according to an analysis made for Governor Rockefeller yes terday.

title: IGNATIUSNURKIEWICZ OF POLISH GROUP, 84
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 19 Ignatius Nurkiewicz, a former vice president of the Polish American Congress, died Satur day at his home. His age was 84.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19President Nixon is now fighting on about four fronts at the same time, so it is scarce ly surprising that what he says and does on one front sometimes gets in the way of what lie is trying to do on the others.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The National Education Associ ation vigorously protested Senator McGovern's statement today on tax credits for par ents of students in private and parochial schools.

title: McGovern For Tax Credit To Aid Parochial Schools
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 19Senator George McGovern endorsed to day a taxcredit system of pro viding Federal aid to parochial and other nonpublic schools.

title: 10 U.S. OFFICIALS SUED BY ELLSBERG
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Daniel Ellsberg, Anthony J. Russo Jr. and 17 of their at torneys and consultants in the Pentagon papers case sued 10 to Federal officials for dam ages today, accusing the Gov ernment of illegal wiretapping.

title: Revere Will Raise Prices Of Nickel and Tin Goods
description: Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., said yesterday that effec tive immediately it was in creasing base prices for all nickel bearings and tin bear ings mill products to reflect a new nickel cost of $1.54 a pound and a tin cost of $1.82 a pound. Scrap prices will be adjusted accordingly.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, Wednesday Sept. 20 (AP)John J. Droney, the Mid lesex District Attorney, won a threeway fight for the Demo cratic yesterday nomination for the United States Senate in the Massachusetts primary election.

title: Flier Becomes Top Ace Of War With Sixth MIG
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 19The United States Air Force announced today that Capt. Charles D. DeBelle vue of Lafayette, La., has been credited with shooting down six North Vietnamese MIG's, making him the leading ace of the war.

title: GOVERNOR SUPERSEDES D.A.'S HERE, NAMES SPECIAL AIDE ON CORRUPTION AND ORDERS A STAFF OF 200 HIRED
description: Governor Rockefeller named a special state prosecutor yes terday to take over from New York City's five District Attor neys all cases of corruption in cluding policemen, prosecutors and judges.

title: City Offers Tudor City Alternatives In an Effort to Preserve Parkland
description: In an effort to save some private, expensive parkland scheduled for development in Tudor City, the City Plan ning Commission announced yesterday that it had gone to the unusual length of preparing a list of alternative plans  including a 46story apartment tower spanning East 42d Street that would be put to a public hearing Oct. 4.

title: Blueprint for Parks
description: As the national park system goes into the second century of its existence, the crucial question is whether its priceless properties will remain the natural havens they were intended to be or deteriorate into manmade playgrounds against striking scenic backdrops. A gov ernmentsponsored panel, organized by the Conserva tion Foundation, has turned in a report that courage ously opts for natureand specifies ways to preserve it.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 19 (AP) Representative Shirley Chis holm, who unsuccessfully sought the Democratic Presi dential nomination, says she will not actively support Sena tor George McGovern's cam paign for the White House.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 19  Vice President Agnew's formal campaign began here today with a suggestion from him that the men indicted for the breakin at the Democratic headquarters in Washington last June were set up by someone attempting to embar rass the Republican party.

title: North Sea Most Tempting
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP)The North Sea is potentially the world's most tempting area for international petroleum invest ment, William I. Spencer, pres ident of the First National City Corporation and its principal subsidiary, the First National City Bank, said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Derek Sanderson's ability to  command a huge salary because he can shoot a puck 110 miles per hour through a sixfoot opening with con sistency  does not result, as Dr. Rutstein contends (letter Aug. 16) from the few gray areas in sports, i.e., either the puck is in or out. Gray areas fail to cloud many areas in our society, e.g., the corporate manager's profitability record, the professional investor's box score in the daily quotes, the trial lawyer's wins and losses and the surgeon's success ratio, yet the stars in these fields do not receive Sandersonesque compensa tion levels.

title: Business Briefs
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19 (UPI)With the takeover of another private bank, the Mexican Government has announced that it now controlled 50 per cent of all banking resources in the country. Treasury Secretary Hugo B. Margrain said the Government had acquired a majority interest in the Banco Internacional, S.A., with the payment of a debt of $37million incurred by the group of owners of the bank as a result of the bankruptcy of one of their other enterprises, a sugar mill.

title: Phoenix Salute Oct. 15 Will Star Its Alumni
description: Jack Cassidy, Rosemary Harris and Joel Grey will head the list of Phoenix Theater alumni taking part in Phoenix Rising, a musi cal and drama salute to the Phoenix as it enters its 20th season.

title: RED SOX, ORIOLES PLAY TWO TONIGHT
description: BOSTON, Sept. 19The Bos ton Red Sox and Baltimore Orioles, who did not need any new problems in the American League pennant race, got one tonight when their game was rained out and was rescheduled as part of a doubleheader to morrow night.

title: Credit Markets
description: Acting with unusual speed to avoid the risk of heavy losses, the underwriting group that won $50million of Balti more Gas & Electric Company bonds on Monday decided yes terday to give up trying to sell them at the price originally de cided upon and released the slowselling issue into the free market, where the yield rose substan tially. This deci sion by the Blyth Eastman Dillon led group to get out early enough reflected more deteroriation in the mar ket for corporate bonds. Out standing issues fell by another  or  point yesterday and there was an expectation that last week's $65million Ala bama Power deal, also moving slowly, would be released from syndicate price restrictions this morning.

title: Razing of 2 Old Townhouses Is Halted
description: A neighborhood association obtained a court order yester day halting demolition of two turn  of  the  century town houses opposite the Metro politan Museum of Art, after failing to persuade a Com munity Board committee, at a stormy session Monday night, to rescind approval of a 24story apartment build ing planned for the site.

title: Opening of Met Is Pervaded by Memories of Gentele
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened its 88th season last night and turned what was to have been the joyful debut of Goeran Gentele, its first new general manager in 22 years, into an emotional requiem for his death in an automobile ac cident on the island of Sardinia in July.

title: RUSSIANS' COACH EXPECTS TROUBLE
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 19  The Soviet hockey coach, whose team scored an upset over the Canadian professionals earlier this month, said today that the upcoming four games in Mos cow would be tougher for the Russians despite the advantage of playing on home ice.

title: Text of Rockefeller's Statement on Plans for Dealing With Corruption in the City
description: Following is the text of the statement by Governor Rock efeller:

title: Kampala Claims Victory
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 19 After a third day of fighting in the southern part of the country, a Uganda military spokesman said today that the invasion force from Tanzania had been completed routed and that scattered enemy troops still in Uganda had discarded their uniforms and were looting food and clothing.

title: INQUIRY ON GRAFT IN SUBURBS OPENS
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19  The State Commission of Investiga tion, opening public hearings here today on alleged munici pal corruption in New Jersey suburbs, received testimony of local officials' shakedowns and demands for bribes and kick backs in return for zoning and planning changes in Hillsbor ough, a sprawling Somerset County community.

title: SO.CALRATED NO.1 IN COACHES' POLL
description: Not very often does a team lose its No. 1 ranking after a 49.0 victory. Nonetheless, that was Oklahoma's fate yesterday as the United Press Interna tional board of coaches selected Southern California as the No. 1 major college football team in the nation.

title: Embry Elevated by Bucks
description: MILWAUKEE. Sept. 19 (AP) The parent firm of the Mil waukee Bucks today elected Wayne Embry as vice president and announced payment of its first cash dividend to share holders. Milwaukee Profession al Sports and Services, Inc., said Embry's new title would be vice presidentgeneral man ager. Embry had been general manager of the National Basketball Association team.

title: RooneyLowenstein Count Is Delayed by Contentions
description: Representative John J. Rooney jumped to an early lead last night in the first returns from the courtordered special primary election in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19The International Finance Corporation, a subsidiary of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, reported today a record volume of investment in private businesses in the less developed countries.

title: El Mundo Resumes Printing
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 19 (UPI)Puerto Rico's largest daily newspaper, El Mundo, re sumed publication today after a sevenmonth strike.

title: Concern Over Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  The Nixon Administration's latest increase in import quotas for homeheating oil was wel comed today by representatives of New England, but they re newed their criticism of the quota system.

title: GOLD PRICE ABROAD RECOVERS SLIGHTLY
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP)The price of gold recovered slightly on Europe's free markets today from yesterday's sharp decline.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
P.L. Grissom, 72, Owner Of Top Racehorses, Dead
description: DETROIT, Sept. 19 (AP) Perne Lewellyn (P.L.) Grissom, a colorful racehorse owner, died of a heart attack yesterday at the age of 72.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Not very often does a team lose its No. 1 ranking after a 490 victory. Nonetheless, that was Oklahoma's fate yesterday as the United Press. Interna tional board or coaches selected Southern California as the No. 1 major college football team in the nation.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 19 (UPI) The American party Presiden tial candidate, John G. Schmitz, said today that if elected he would refuse to enforce any courtordered, crosstown bus ing of public school students for racial balance. No Federal Court has the constitutional authority to issue such an or der, Mr. Schmitz said at a news conference.

title: Duane Thomas Reports To Chargers, Practices
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 19 (AP) Duane Thomas joined the San Diego Chargers today and worked out for the first time since he was traded by Dallas July 31.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 19 Delegates to the United Steel workers of America convention voted decisively today to sup port the decision of the union president I. W. Abel, and other steelworker leaders to refrain from endorsing either Presi dential candidate.

title: Devices Found in Paris
description: PARIS, Sept. 19Two large envelopes containing explosives were received in the mail today at the Israeli Embassy here. A security check of the mail spot ted the contents of the en velopes, which were then opened safely.

title: AGNEW SAYS NIXON BADE F.B.I. LOOK INTO MEAT SALES
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 19  Vice President Agnew said to day that the F.B.I. had been ordered to investigate the $750 million sale of American wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: Economic Analysis
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, Sept. 19Karl Klasen, president of the West German Bundesbank, breathes a sigh of relief as he contemplates the United States balance of pay ments and the dollar.

title: Drive to End Imbalance Law
description: BOSTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) Sponsors of an initiative peti tion to repeal Massachusetts' racial imbalance law began gathering signatures today, hoping to collect 56,038 by Dec. 6. The law forbids any school to have more than a 50 per cent enrollment of black stu dents.

title: 12.5Billion Investment
description: Investments in the new North Sea oilfields will total about $12.5billion by 1980, Michael J. K. Belmont, a partner in Caze nove & Co., a London brokerage and investment banking house founded in 1785, said yesterday.

title: IMPORTS TO JAPAN SET FOR WHIRLPOOL
description: The Sony Trading Corpor ation and the Whirlpool Cor poration announced yesterday that Whirlpool brand name products will be imported to Japan by Sony Trading, effec tive next Jan. 1.

title: HUNDREDS VISIT BIER OF REP. RYAN
description: Several hundred local and national political figures, con stituents and friends of Repre sentative William F. Ryan, who died of cancer Sunday night, paid last respects Monday night and yesterday at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madi son Avenue at 81st Street.

title: MRS. NIXON BRAVES STORM ON CAMPAIGN
description: IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Sept. 20Mrs. Richard M. Nixon continued her most extensive campaign swing of 1972 today after an outdoor performance that was pelted by rain, sleet, snow and hail.

title: Profits Rise at T.W.A. and American Airlines
Piano Movement Hits a High Note
description: SOUTH NYACK, N. Y., Sept. 20A rare grand piano was moved by helicopter to a sixthfloor apartment here this morning in what an ob server was quick to dub the rarest of piano movements.

title: Female Orgasmic Theory Challenged
description: A fiveyear study of the psy chological and social factors in fluencing the sexual responsive ness of women challenges many popular myths and professional theories and raises new thoughts on the treatment of women who fail to reach orgasm.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Controversy continues to smoulder over the refusal of Justice William Rehnquist to disqualify himself in three sensitive cases decided last term. Legislation on the general ques tion of judicial disqualification is sure to be introduced in the next Congress, yet there seems to be a curious pat tern to Justice Rehnquist's behavior that has received no attention.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  A Federal Judge ruled today that Maurice H. Stans, Pres ident Nixon's chief campaign fundraiser, who is also a former Secretary of Commerce, could be named by attorneys for Lawrence F. O'Brien as a defendant in a revised, $3.2 million suit arising from the breakin last June 17 at the Watergate office building.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 20  State, interstate and Federal officials laying the cornerstone of the $80million PATH Jour nal Square Transportation Cen ter here hailed the center today as practical evidence of their commitment to mass transpor tation.

title: Anniversaries
description: CAROL M.HAPPY ANNIVERSARY to the ocople from the dogs & the clowns. Love, DON M. (husband)

title: 2 WINNERS SEEN IN BEATTY VICTORY
description: Democratic Assemblyman Vander L. Beatty's victory over the incumbent State Senator, Waldaba Stewart, in Bedford Stuyvesant's 18th Senatorial District in Brooklyn, was also viewed as a victory for Repre sentative Shirley Chisholm, who yesterday called the result a warning from voters to other black officials to recognize her leadership.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Upjohn Company announced yesterday that, after five years of negotiation, it had signed a multimilliondollar agreement to supply the Soviet Union with urethane process technology. Urethane chemicals are used in producing such things as auto crash pads and transporta tionequipment insulation, the company said.

title: Chase Bank Asks S.E.C. To Exempt New Subsidiary
description: The Chase Manhattan Corpo ration, the parent company of the nation's thirdlargest bank, has quietly asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to exempt its new investment management subsidiary from S.E.C. regulation.

title: Panel Is Told of Family Court Problems
description: A rifletoting boy roaming the corridors of the Bronx County Courthouse and an in vasion of the court by a gang of teenagers were among the events described by witnesses at a public hearing yesterday at what the hearing's sponsors called a breakdown in the New York City Family Court system.

title: TV Review
description: Into every television season a little disaster must fall, and this season it seems to have fallen on the American Broad casting Company. It's called Jigsaw, part of a weekly rotating trilogy being pre sented under the umbrella title of The Men. The first episode, subsubtitled A Badge on Fire, can be seen tonight from 9 to 10 o'clock.

title: CHRYSLER CONFIRMS UNIVERSAL OIL PACT
description: The Chrysler Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Universal Oil Products Com pany under which Universal will provide a manufacturing facility to make some catalytic converter equipment for 1975 model Chrysler cars.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Truly excellent plans for creating working waterfowl decoys are available from the Sneak Box Studios, 44 Main Street, P.O. Box 55, Concord, Mass. 01742.

title: Connally Sees More Democrats Supporting Nixon
description: The former Secretary of the Treasury, John B. Connally, a Texas Democrat heading the national Democrats for Nixon campaign, said yester day that Democratic defections from the party's Presidential ticket were growing daily be cause voters are afraid of George McGovern.

title: Personal Finance: Investing Seminars Gain
description: If you can use a few extra pointers on investing, would like to mingle with people with money and, at the same time, get away from it all, you might be interested to know that you can do just that.

title: Personalities: Security Disputed
description: Clifford Buck, president of the United States Olympic Committee, charged yester day that the Munich Organ izing Committee failed to enforce the tight security measures it had planned for the Olympic Games. Speaking in Colorado Springs, Buck said. It is interesting that in all the advance information from the Munich Organizing Committee, they laid great stress upon the tight security they were going to impose at their Olympic Village.

title: Cleveland Policeman Jailed
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (UP1) A Cleveland policeman, charged with aiding and abetting in the theft of $316,500 from a Men tor, Ohio bank last week, was remanded today to the Cuya hoga County jail in lieu of $100,000 bond by a United States Magistrate. Patrolman Wallace E. Cowper, 31 years old, of Eastlake, did not enter a plea before Magistrate Her bert T. Maher. A preliminary hearing was sot for next Wednesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Robert Gottlieb's Sept. 12 letter is a gross misstatement of fact. Mr. Gott lieb faults Senator McGovern for say ing the North Vietnamese could be depended upon to release our prison ers as they did the French. He makes the statement that the North Viet namese released only 11,000 of the 37,000 French P.O.W.'s.

title: Capital Budget of $81.8Million Is Proposed for City Hospitals
description: The municipal hospital sys tem's proposed capital budget of $81.8million for the fiscal year 197374 came under pub lic scrutiny yesterday. This was the first of half a dozen steps the budget must undergo before it emerges in final form, which will represent a substan tially whittleddown version.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: SAPPHO WAS A RIGHTON WOMAN.The most rational analysts of ?? to emerge from the gay activist movement. Women's Wear ?? A ?? work. ?? ?? At your ?? ?? Stein and Day. Advt.

title: I.R.A. AIDE REPORTED SEIZED IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 20British troops report edly arrested a senior officer of the militant Provisional wing of the outlawed Irish Republi can Army here today.

title: IMPLIED WARRANTY ON HOUSE IS RULED
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 20 (UPI)Under a ruling issued yesterday by the Iowa Supreme Court, renters can sue their landlords if the houses or apartments they lease are un sanitary or unsafe.

title: WALTER FLETCHER, EXPERT ON TRUSTS
description: Walter D. Fletcher, a senior partner in what is now the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell and a longtime leader in edu cation and philanthropy, died yesterday in the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottes ville, Va. He was 76 years old and made his home in recent years at November Hill Farm in Charlottesville.

title: Ali Stops Patterson
description: Muhammad Ali stopped Floyd Patterson in seven rounds at Madison Square Garden last night in a bout between former heavyweight champions. Details, Page 59.

title: First $1MillionPlus Lottery Held
description: The threemember family of a 76yearold partly blind re tired mill worker in Little Falls, N. Y., was the apparent win ner yesterday of the $1million plus prize in the New York State lottery drawing, billed as the richest lottery ever played in America.

title: YANKS, BREWERS ARE RAINED OUT
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 20Two furious rainstorms, 20 minutes apart, saved the New York Yankees tonight from a defeat that would have all but snuffed out their flickering pennant hopes. They ended play with the Milwaukee Brewers leading, 20, and still at bat in the last half of the fourth inning.

title: LOSS OF CONCERNS IS STUDIED HERE
description: A new study indicates that the departure of corporations from New York City to the suburbs seems likely to con tinue.

title: M'KAY CHALLENGES GOVERNOR ON ATTICA
description: Robert McKay, chairman of the state's special commission on last year's disorders at At tica prison, challenged Govern or Rockefeller last night to pro duce evidence to support his belief that the insurrection was planned by revolutionaries.

title: Ali Deflects Quick Jab After Fight
description: It was, perhaps, paternal ism toward Floyd Patterson that described Muhammad Ali last night as he sat in the Madison Square Garden ro tunda after stopping the smaller, older Patterson after the seventh round.

title: Pennsylvania Ratifies Rights
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 20 (AP)Pennsylvania became the 21st state to ratify the proposed women's rights amendment to the Constitution on a 43to3 vote by the State Senate today. Approval by 38 states is needed for ratification of the amend ment, which bans sex discrim ination.

title: A Young Canadian Admits Setting Fire In Which 37 Died
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 20 (UPI) A young Canadian admitted today that he set a fire three weeks ago at the Blue Bird nightclub. He said he had tried to commit suicide after finding that the fire had killed 37 per sons.

title: PROFESSOR SLAIN IN MUGGING HERE
description: Dr. Wolfgang G. Friedmann, professor of international law and director of international legal research at Columbia Uni versity, was robbed and stabbed to death yesterday afternoon three blocks from the campus.

title: Paul  Henri Simon, Critic: Member of French Academy
description: PARIS, Sept 20 (UPI)Paul Henri Simon, writer, critic and political philosopher, died to day after surgery. He was 69 years old.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Plans A New Parent Company
description: The board of Dun & Brad street, Inc., is proposing the formation of a new parent com pany to be known as Dun & Bradstreet Companies, Inc. Ac cording to Hamilton B. Mitchell, president, the new name, which will be voted upon at the next meeting in March of 1973, is more indicative of the diversi fied activities of the organiza tion.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Art of DecoyCarving Continues
description: Truly excellent plans for creating working waterfowl decoys are available from the Sneak Box Studios, 44 Main Street, P.O. Box 55, Concord, Mass. 01742.

title: Ali Stops Patterson
description: Muhammad Ali knocked out Floyd Patterson in seven rounds at Madison Square Garden last night in a bout between former heavyweight champions. Details, Page 59.

title: Among Other Signers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  Among the signers of the letter were the Democratic Repre sentatives Morris K. Udall of Arizona, Benjamin S. Rosenthal of Long Island, Henry S. Reuss of Wisconsin, Frank Annunzio of Illinois and Donald M. Fra ser of Minnesota. Among the Republicans signers were Rep resentatives Pierre S. du Pont 4th of Delaware, Florence P. Dwyer of New Jersey, Barry Goldwater Jr. of California, and John Buchanan of Alabama.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: About 200 faculty mem bers at colleges and univer sities throughout the state hold bogus degrees from unaccredited institutions, the State Department of Educa tion said yesterday.

title: National Park Development
description: YELLOWSTONE PARK, Wyo., Sept. 20 (UPI)Interior Secre tary Rogers C. B. Morton said yesterday future national park development would be limited to necessary facilities compati ble with the natural environ ment. He said the area in a park preserved as wilderness must be overwhelmingly greater than the area selected for de velopment.

title: CONNECTICUT SALES OF SHELLFISH DOWN
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 20 (AP) Connecticut fish dealers com plained today that government bans on the sale of certain softshell clams or steamers had hurt sales of hardshell clams and other shellfish.

title: Bombs Mailed to Many Israeli Officials
description: Explosive devices concealed in envelopes have been mailed from Amsterdam to Israeli ofi ficials here and in at least six cities abroad.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 520 Military Mission Suspected
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20  The Soviet Union launched today an unmanned spacecraft, Cosmos 520, into a high eccentric orbit, believed to be that of a military communications satellite.

title: Shopping in Jersey
description: MAYWOOD, Sept. 20This prospering, small (1.2 square miles) borough is a fairly typical Bergen County com munity. Neither its geology nor its history is extraordi nary. Apparently Maywood has long been simply a nice place where nice people live.

title: Pastoral 'Dulcima' Opens
description: "Dulcima," based on a story by H. E. Bates, is a new English film about pastoral passions of the sort that I associate with D. H. Lawrence, perhaps because the story's catalytic agent is a dopey gamekeeper who doesn't look as if he'd spent much time outside.A stingy old farmer named Mr. Parker (John Mills), a widower with an attic-full of crumpled banknotes, falls in love with his young housekeeper Dulcima (Carol White), who comes to work for him because she feels sorry for him, and then stays on because she fancies both him and his money. Dulcima is earthy, a bit avaricious and essentially good. She doesn't mind a roll in the hayloft with Mr. Parker, but when she falls in love with the gamekeeper (Stuart Wilson), she decides to move out.Tragedy, as is its wont in this kind of fiction, strikes, rather like a bolt out of the ruddy old blue. And, as Dulcima has underestimated the depth of Mr. Parker's feelings, the movie is unequipped to support its melodramatic conclusion."Dulcima," which opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East, has been written and directed by Frank Nesbitt as if he were covering something with a sugar glaze. The settings are pretty and the performances picturesque. Mr. Mills and Miss White seem to be having a high time of it, what with all of their frowning, looking puzzled, acting sly, winking, sliding into fearful tempers and out again. It's not acting as much as it is a display of extremely busy behavior. Underneath the surface is the ham.

title: Policeman Wounds Self
description: Patrolman Ronald Raymundo, on foot patrol in Times Square, was wounded in the right leg early yesterday when he tried to untangle the leather strap on his nighstick from the trig ger of his service revolver and it fired, the police said.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)  George Meany decreed strong reprisals today against the Colorado Labor Council for its endorsement of George Mc Govern.

title: Lobbying Disclosure Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Public disclosure of lobbying activities to influence antitrust cases would be required by a bill proposed today by Sena tors John V. Tunney, Democrat of California, and Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida.

title: RECORDSETTERS LED BY ROMALIE HANOVER
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP)Romalie Hanover and Songcan scored impressive vic tories today in the third day of Grand Circuit harness racing, which produced six world re cords at the Delaware County Fairgrounds.

title: Covered Bridge Destroyed By Vandals, to Be Replaced
description: GREENFIELD, Mass., Sept. 20 (UPI)Two years ago, vandals destroyed a 99yearold covered wooden bridge spanning the Green River. It will be replaced this weekend.

title: BRAZIL RENEWS SALE OF COFFEE EXPORTS
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 20 (AP)The General Foods Cor poration of the United States, purchased 200,000 bags of Bra zilian green coffee, on the first day of the reopening of the reg istry of foreign sales, the Bra zilian Coffee Institute reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One point upon which we might all agree is that the conflict in Vietnam could not have continued without the active support of North Vietnam by both Russia and China. In this area we have been on a collision course with both countries yet, curiouser and curiouser, we have a companion paral lel course of accommodation on world trade between and among these very nations.

title: House Votes for a New Agency To Regulate Safety of Products
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The House swept aside objec tions of the Nixon Administra tion today to pass a bill to create an independent Federal commision with broad author ity to set mandatory safety standards for consumer prod ucts.

title: STOCKS CONTINUE TO SHOW DECLINE
description: Stocks continued their post Labor Day decline yesterday, drifting lower in slow trading. The market is dead, said one broker, who added, That's figu ratively speaking, of course.

title: Butz Predicts Small Profit
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 20 (AP)Secretary Butz estimated tonight that principal American wheat exporters would make only about 1 per cent profit on shipments to the Soviet Union.

title: Oritz Retires After Buchanan Stops Him in 6 Rounds
description: Ken Buchanan of Scotland was awarded a sixthround knockout over Carlos Ortiz last night at Madison Square Garden in a duel of former world lightweight champions when the 37yearold New Yorker surrendered on the stool in his corner, and later announced his retirement.

title: U.N. PANEL VOTES TO DEFER DEBATE ON KOREAN UNITY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20  An effort to place the question of reunification of Korea on the agenda of the General Assembly, which could have embarrassed the United States, was beaten back this evening by a narrow margin.

title: JUSTICE RITCHIE, 69, OF STATE HIGH COURT
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Sept. 20 D. Ormonde Ritchie, a State Supreme Court Justice in the 10th Judicial District from his appointment in August, 1952, to his retirement last February, died yesterday at his home, 434 Pine Acres Boulevard, Bright waters. He was 69 years old.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20  New Jersey restaurateurs voiced their opposition today to a state proposal that would re quire the posting of restaurant sanitary inspection reports and make the information on which reports are based available to the public.

title: Raids by Upstate Sheriffs Net 11 on Drug Charges
description: BATAVIA, N. Y., Sept. 20 (AP)  A force of 30 deputy sheriffs arrested 11 persons here and in other sections of Genesee County last night dur ing a series of narcotics raids.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: State Controller Arthur Lev itt and City Controller Abra ham D. Beame accused the Nixon Administration yester day of seriously considering a national sales tax and said it would be terribly regres sive.

title: At 70, Bing Begins New Career: Teaching About His Old One
description: Sir Rudolf Bing, for 22 of his 70 years the general man ager of the Metropolitan Opera, has just begun a new career as distinguished visit ing professor of music at Brooklyn College. Twice a week he teaches two classes, Humanities 801 (seminar in the performing arts) and Opera 20.3.

title: London Meeting Foreseen
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 With their reelection by a clear mar gin, Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling and his Progressive Liberal party have cleared the way for the Bahamas to declare independence from Britain next year.

title: Seaver Delays Pirates From Clinching Title, 41
description: The Mets, already eliminated from the pennant race, man aged to delay for at least one more day the titleclinching by the Pittsburgh Pirates as Tom Seaver stopped them on five hits last night in a 41 victory at Shea Stadium.

title: Bomb Scare in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) A bomb scare emptied the McGovernShriver headquarters in midtown Washington today. About 12:45 P.M., a man left a briefcase in the lobby of the eighthfloor headquarters and fled, according to Democratic party aides.

title: Lowenstein Assailed on His Campaign
description: Meade H. Esposiio, the Brook lyn Democratic leader, charged yesterday that former Repre sentative Allard K. Lowenstein had stooped to irresponsible charges and manufactured truths during his unsuccessful campaign for the Democratic nomination for the House in Brooklyn's 14th District.

title: All in One Spot: Kitchenware From the Very Old to the Modern
description: Underneath the skin, craftsmen and cooks are the same kind of people, people who like to do fine things with their hands. Indeed, many of the best craftsmen around are also talented cooks, and some of them make their own kitchenware.

title: Justices in Illinois Tell Court to Reset Sentence for Speck
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 20 The Illinois Supreme Court today ordered the Circuit Court at Peoria to conduct a hear ing and impose a new sen tence upon Richard Speck for the murders of eight nurses and student nurses in Chicago in 1966.

title: QUANGNGAI BASE IS UNDER ATTACK
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 21 (AP)North Vietnamese forces reportedly tightened their hold yesterday on Quangngai Province, south of Danang.

title: Lyndon B. Johnson
description: TEMPLE, Tex.With the ?? of September each year, we are ?? as the song says, that the days are dwindling down to a precious ?? By the calendar, we know that soon the green leaves of summer will begin to brown; the chill winds of winter will begin to blow; andbefore we are ready for the end to comethe year will be gone.

title: Arabs Said to Receive Bombs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20 Arab informants reported today that boobytrapped mailings had been sent to one or two leaders of Al Fatah earlier this year.

title: AMERICANS PUSH WIDER RED TRADE
description: WARSAW, Sept. 20Further evidence of the liberalization of the list of strategic items barred from sale to Communist countries has emerged here.

title: Bridge: New YorkJersey Regionals Open Today in Playboy Club
description: The New YorkNew Jer sey Regional Championships, heirs to a tournament tradi tion stretching to the nine teenthirties when the, coun try's top stars sought na tional titles ensconced in comfortable rocking chairs at Asbury Park, have a new home this year. Play begins today at the Playboy Club, McAfee, N.J., with the fol lowing schedule:

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS 6BILLION TAX RISE TO SPUR PENSIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The Senate Finance Committee voted today to increase Social Security taxes by about $6 billion to finance a vast array of new benefits for the nation's elderly and disabled.

title: Transit Breakthrough
description: The transportation problems of the cities and suburbs where most people live and work are frustrating as a traffic jam and inescapable as smog. Much as Americans love their private automobiles, and assiduous as highway engineers have been in building wider and better roads, it is now apparent that automobiles alone cannot solve those transportation problems. Subways, commuter rail roads, express buses and new experimental forms of rapid transit are all necessary.

title: Judge Dembitz Held Unfit by Bar Group For Appeals Court
description: Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz, who is seeking to be come the first woman elected to the State Court of Appeals, has been found not qualified at the present time by the State Bar Association for a seat on the state's highest tribunal.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ROBINSVILLE, N. J., Sept. 29The New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association has informed Camden High School that it is on probation in all sports for the current school year because its representatives walked out of a special hearing called by an association committee checking into behavior patterns of Camden athletes in the past.

title: SignCarrying Pickets Protest Curbs on Signs
description: About 500 sign industry workers demonstrated out side City Hall yesterday against a proposed regulation to prohibit the placement of signs near major highways.

title: Leader in Occupation Of Alcatraz Shot Dead
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., Sept. 20 (AP)Richard Oakes, a leader in an Indian occupa tion of Alcatraz Island in San Francisco Bay, was shot to death today, the District At torney reported.

title: Eastern College Football
description: Wesleyan got a twoweek jump on Amherst and Wil liams, its Little Three col leagues, when it opened its season last Saturday and lost to Southern Connecticut, 31 21. This proved to Bill Mac dermott, the Wesleyan coach, that our defense, which we thought was our strong point, has work to do. Each of the Little Three teams will play only eight games for the record, although Amherst is going to stage its second preseason scrimmage Saturday against Hamilton. This second practice game was arranged when Haver ford, scheduled to open the regular season with Hamilton on Saturday, dropped foot ball last week.

title: U.S. Official Sees No Shortage Of Oil for Heating This Winter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  An Interior Department official told Congress today that even with reasonably severe weather this winter, the nation would have a tight but work able supply of homeheating fuel oil.

title: Wright Posts a 70 to Lead State P.G.A. Tournament
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept. 20On a cold, gray, windy day Jimmy Wright equaled the course record today with a 70 to lead the $30,000 Marlboro New York State Professional Golfers Association champion ship.

title: British Study Urges Pornography Curbs
description: LONDON, Sept. 20A pri vate study urged Britain today to enact tougher laws against pornography. The study touched off a heated contro versy involving lawyers, civil liberties groups, Members of Parliament and broadcasters.

title: 3Run Ninth Decides
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (AP) Woody Fryman hurled a six hitter tonight and drove in two runs with a ninthinning single as the Detroit Tigers beat Cleveland, 41.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is ironic that the day after your [Sept. 4] editorial Back to Palestine appeared, the massacre at Munich took place. The Times was critical of Premier Golda Meir and her Cabinet for not allowing the former Palestinian residents of Berem and Ikrit to return to their villages, even though these villages are located near the Lebanese border, where most of the terrorist organizations make their home.

title: POSTEL TO MEET U.S. AIDES ON JOBS
description: City Councilman Robert I. Postel, who has charged that there are dozens of irregulari ties in the city's emergency employment program, is sched uled to meet today with Fed eral investigators.

title: NASA Chief May Resign After Final Apollo Mission
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 20 (UPI) Dr. James C. Fletcher said yesterday he might resign as director of the National Aeronautics and Space Admin istration after the final Apollo mission, scheduled for Decem ber.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (AP)It looks as if Joe Frazier will defend his world heavyweight boxing title against the undefeated contender, George Foreman, at Madi son Square Garden in November, Bruce Wright, director of the corporation sponsoring the champion, indicated today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Scores of paintings and sculp tures, many priced at more than $20,000, were put up for sale last night at two Manhat tan galleries in an effort to en large the financial coffers of Senator George McGovern's Presidential campaign.

title: 2 Synagogues Damaged By Bombs in Buenos Aires
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 20 (Reuters)  Two powerful bombs ripped through syna gogues here today, causing damage estimated at more than $16,000 but no casualties, the police said.

title: Bombs Mailed to Many Israeli Officials
description: Explosive devices concealed in envelopes and mailed from Amsterdam to Israeli officials were discovered yesterday in at least six cities abroad, and it was disclosed that they had also been found here.

title: Bank Sets Euroclear Stake
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company which is transferring its wholly  owned Eurobond settlement system to a new company to permit 117 other institutions to participate in its ownership, said today that it would retain a 3.25 per cent in terest in the new company, Euroclear Clearance System Ltd.

title: Three Americans Freed
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 20 (Reuters)Three of nine Amer icans detained in Uganda have been freed a State Depart ment spokesman said today. The others are to be released today, the spokesman. Charles W. Bray 3d, said.

title: Chess: Soviet Stars Are One, Two In Amsterdam Competition
description: The International Business Machines Chess Congress in Amsterdam attracted more than 300 participants, who were divided into groups. The grandmaster tournament the main eventdrew 16 players and was won by Lev Polugajevsky of the So viet Union, who finished with 12 points of a possible 15. Another Soviet star, Viktor Korchnoi, was second, with 11. Neither Polugajevsky nor Korchnoi was defeated.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Governor Cahill and more than 30 state legislators and county and court officials were among the mourners at funeral services in Hoboken for Assemblyman Sylvio J. Failla, who was slain in an apparent robbery attempt last Saturday. The officials gathered at the Failla memorial home, then went to St. Ann's Church for a funeral mass.

title: Governor Calls Step on D. A.'s His Most Important Act
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he regarded his decision to supersede New York City's District Attorneys on the handling of corruption among the police, prosecutors and judges as the single most important act of his 14 years as Governor.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20We are at another of those increasingly common place passes in current history when events have outstripped burlesque. Morning after morning, Page One reads like a lunatic's romp put together by the Marx brothers' script writers.

title: WILLARD E. FRASER
description: BILLINGS, Mont., Sept. 20 (AP)Mayor Willard E. Fraser died last night in his sleep at a motel in Yellowstone Na tional Park, apparently of a heart ailment. He was 65 years old.

title: TANNER CONQUERS GONZALES, 7.6, 76
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP) A 21yearold Stanford Uni versity senior, Roscoe Tanner, beat Pancho Gonzales, the de fending champion, in the second round of the Pacific Southwast tennis tournament today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The Watergate scandal, charges of Republican fundraising irregularities, and the possibility that some big deal ers made an illicit killing on the sale of $750 million in grains to the Soviet Union ought to revive interest in the pending appointment of a permanent director for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Texas Instruments Puts 3 Calculators on Market
description: Texas Instruments, Inc., made its debut yesterday in the electronic calculator market with three products made en tirely of American made com ponents.

title: Hammer' Depicts Black Boxer
description: If I say that it is a movie about a clean-cut young boxer on his way to the top, who is ordered by the syndicate to throw a fight, and doesn'tthen you will know, without too much elaboration, to what genus, class, species and set of clichs "Hammer," which opened yesterday at the DeMille Theater, belongs. There is only the difference that its young boxer (Fred Williamson) is both clean-cut and black, and therefore has certain problemsand, as everyone connected with it must be hoping, a certain appeal of his own.Neither passably good nor unspeakably awful, "Hammer" falls into the dullness that attends most routine movie projects these days, when the desire to make money remains, but nobody seems to remember how to do it gracefully. Sometimes the film looks like qualityespecially in the rhetoric of its fairly expert photography. And sometimes it looks like idiocyas in the plot device of the cop (Bernie Hamilton) who spends all his time hanging around with the crooks (except for Fred Williamson, virtually everybody else) telling them that they are doing wrong."Hammer" was made on location in Los Angeles, in and out of black neighborhoods, and its one potentially interesting aspect is an active and fairly intricate appreciation of lowlife types and stereotypes. Thus all my favorite people are very minor, like Mawama Davis, in a fine performance as a loudmouth whore who isn't good enough for Hammer. Or they are rats, like the stone-faced sadist (William Smith) who does all the syndicate's important murders. Or they are slobs, like the boss's girl, Rhoda (Elizabeth Harding), who serves as a reminder of white earthiness to set against the black gentility of the heroine (Vonetta McGee).Bruce Clark, who directed "Hammer," is a young New Zealander with a masters degree from U.C.L.A. and two exploitation films to his credit. With such a background I was hoping for lots of real-life passion. But the sex when we get it is all dissolved in smoky mirrors and softened focus, and in general it wouldn't shock the sensibilities of Radley Metzger's maiden aunt from Peoria.

title: Singer Co. and Hitachi, Ltd., Set BusinessMachines Deal
description: The Singer Company an nounced yesterday signing of a joint venture with Hitachi, Ltd., for marketing and eventual manufacturing of business ma chines presently made by the two companies.

title: 25 SEIZED UPSTATE IN DRUG CRACKDOWN
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 20 (UPI) At least 25 persons were ar rested today in coordinated raids on drug suppliers in Monroe County, the state police said.

title: Mr. Foreign Affairs
description: When 29yearold Hamilton Fish Armstrong, then a foreign correspondent for The New York Evening Post, was invited to help found the magazine Foreign Affairs, few Americans appreciatedas he passionately didthe role that the United States would inescapably have to play as a major power in a shrinking world. That was in 1922.

title: North Korean Is Said to Urge Japan to Open Diplomatic Ties
description: TOKYO, Sept. 20Premier Kim Il Sung of North Korea was quoted here today as urg ing Japan to establish diplo matic relations with his Gov ermnent on the same basis as those Tokyo maintains with South Korea.

title: Merger News
description: The FMC Corporation an nounced yesterday it had reached an agreement in prin ciple to acquire Raygo, Inc., for about $20million in FMC stock.

title: F.T.C. SEEKS DATA ON DETERGENT ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)  The Federal Trade Commission ordered 14 manu facturers and advertisers of soap and detergent products today to submit documentation for certain advertising claims within 60 days.

title: U.S. Reports Mining Waters Below DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 20  American planes have been mining the coastal rivers and canals of northern Quangtri Province, just below the demilitarized zone, to pre vent the North Vietnamese from moving supplies across the border by boat, a senior United States Air Force officer has disclosed.

title: TOWN FIXED CARS IT DID NOT OWN
description: ALBANY, Sept. 20 (AP)Last year, the Petersburg, N.Y., town government paid for repair and maintenance on police cars.

title: CONTINENTAL CAN FACES A NEW SUIT
description: LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 20 (AP)The European Common Market Commission intends in the next few weeks to take new antitrust action against the European packaging activi ties of the Continental Can Company, a commission law yer disclosed in court here to day.

title: Sports of The Times
description: For five rounds Cassius Muhammad Ali Clay showed off his big, beautiful body, his swift and accurate jab, his huge ego. Once he laid a glove on Floyd Patterson's haircut as though to cock Floyd's head exactly to his satisfaction, then shot the jab full into Patterson's earnest expression. At the start of the fourth round, Ali moved slowly about in midring, bent forward at the waist, hands folded in front of his lap, offering an unprotected head but weaving like a cobra to make every punch miss. Sometimes he seemed to let Floyd hit him on purpose, exposing the twotime heavyweight cham pion as a harmless puncher at the age of 37. Between rounds he lounged against the ropes, disdaining to sit down. Though he had professed no rancor toward his opponent and showed none, he still couldn't resist taunting him, swaggering, showing him up.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The lead editorial of Sept. 11 deemed the Israeli reprisal bombings of guer rilla centers in Syria and Lebanon understandable. However, whatever one's feelings about the bloodbath in Munich, to sympathize with these tac tics is equally reprehensible.

title: All 7thRound Victor Over Patterson
description: In an atmosphere more con ducive to pathos than a prize fight, Muhammad Ali was awarded a seventhround knock out over Floyd Patterson at Madison Square Garden last night when the 37yearold former twotime champion was adjudged unable to continue because of a severe cut over his left eye.

title: Maine Issues Foliage Report
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 20 (AP) The Maine Forestry Depart ment issued the first in its an nual series of weekly fall foliage reports today. For the weekend of Sept. 2324, northern Maine will have a 2025 per cent color change. The color change in central Maine will be 510 per cent and southern Maine will have a 1 to 2 per cent change.

title: MEDICAL AID BILL VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The Senate passed by 78 to 0 today an omnibus bill to extend several important health pro grams scheduled to expire next June 30.

title: Credit Markets
description: The bond market continued to back and fill yesterday with little evidence of any basic trend in interest rates.

title: Bahamians Celebrate Pindling Victory
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Sept. 20Bahamians celebrated with street dancing and singing to day after giving Prime Minister Lyndon O. Pindling a mandate to proceed with steps to make the Bahamas an independent nation.

title: Pocono Hanover Is First
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 20 (AP)Pocono Hanover won the $3,500 Farmingdale Pace today at Freehold Raceway, returning $26.60, $10.20 and $3.20 for $2 across the board. The winner paced the mile in 2:05 1/5.

title: Books of The Times
description: GLASS PEOPLE. By Gail Godwin. 208 pages. Knopf. $6.95.

title: Lefkowitz Seeks Federal Curbs On LandDeveloping Companies
description: The State Attorney Gener al, Louis J. Lefkowitz, called yesterday for Federal laws to bar all massselling programs by land development compa ing, restrict their advertis ing and eliminate boilerroom selling tactics.

title: MRS. SHOEMAKER, 63, MAGAZINE EDITOR
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 20Mrs. Vivien Bulloch Keatley Shoe maker, wife of Perry M. Shoe maker, retired railroad execu tive and former president of the Chamber of Commerce of New York State, died after a long illness at her home here on Monday. She was 63 years old.

title: City Acts to Rehire 31 Teachers Ousted In McCarthy Era
description: The Board of Education paved the way last night for the rein statement of 31 former city teachers who were dismissed during the early nineteenfifties as a result of investigations into alleged Communist influence in the school system.

title: Bank Opens London Office
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (Reuters) The Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit announced to day the opening of its London based European representative office. The bank, a founder shareholder of Atlantic Interna tional Bank, Ltd, the eight nation consortium bank, has total resources of about $2.3 billion.

description: WHAT DOES QUALITY LIFE INSURANCE COST? ?? Yearly Renew ?? Convert Term annual premium age 35, $662,30. Full details rates ?? age ?? ?? ?? ?? agent call North Atlantic ?? ?? N. Y. ?? 9356900.ADVT.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The Metropolitan Museum's new exhibition, Synagogues from Damascus to Newport, which opened yesterday and which consists of eight large models of historic synagogues accompanied by related Ju daica from New York collec tions, will have strong emo tional associations for the Jewish poition of its audi ence at this time of year. But its focus is less on Fifteen Centuries of Jewish History, which is the exhibition's sub title, than on architectural style in general. As such, it is an exhibition for every body.

title: 16 Die in Nepal Landslides
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 20 (UPI)Sixteen persons were killed in landslides last Satur day in Durgami village in west ern Nepal, officials said today, quoting delayed reports. Heavy rains caused the landslides, which damaged several houses, the officials said.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 20  Vic tories by Gov. Daniel J. Evans, a Republican, and former Gov. Albert D. Rosellini, a Democrat, in yesterday's gubernatorial primary in Washington will permit a rematch in November of the two candidates who bat tled for the Governorship in 1964.

title: Dorothy Wright Liebes Is Dead Noted Textile Designer Was 72
description: Dorothy Wright Liebes, a prizewinning textile designer whose fabrics were shown in museums and won recognition around the world, died yester day at her home at 131 East 66th Street here. She was 72 years old.

title: ' Hickey and Boggs,' a Tale of Chasing and Carnage
description: Although they've clicked as the supercool, funny and compatible black-white team of international sleuths in TV's "I Spy" series, Bill Cosby and Robert Culp are a good deal less convincing as the seedy titular private eyes of "Hickey and Boggs," which landed at the Victoria and other houses yesterday. And while Robert Culp, who is also making his directiorial debut with this caper, shows a flair for action and eye-catching composition in sordid and serene views of Los Angeles where all the shooting takes place, "Hickey and Boggs" is not involved in a story or with characters really worthy of a full theatrical treatment.Let's say, that Walter Hill, a newcomer to the screen, has written a script that's long on complexity and short on character definition as a seeming legion of bigshot mobsters, gunmen, cops, fences and our shamuses chase a cache of $400,000 stolen from a Pittsburgh bank and held by some harried Chicanos.As a detective thriller, "Hickey and Boggs" has the swift pace necessary for the genre. And, under Mr. Culp's guidance and the use of adept cross-cutting there are a few fairly exciting shots including some shootouts at the Los Angeles Coliseum and the Dodger Stadium and enough corpses to satisfy the bloodstirsty. And L.A.'s sleazy sidestreets and saloons get as much edifying attention as the scenic beach areas.As antiheroes, both Mr. Culp and Mr. Cosby are serious, sullen and extremely laconic. Terse passes at dialogue merely indicate their personal relationships and their concommittant, bloody, thankless mission. A viewer simply isn't given time or reason to be caught up with Rosalind Cash, as Mr. Cosby's estranged wife, who is killed by gunmen, or Mr. Culp's ex-wife, a go-go dancer who is driving him to drink.Understatement is obviously the keynote here but "Hickey and Boggs" still owes us a fuller explanation despite all the chasing and carnage.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 20A mem ber of the interim board operat ing Radio Station WNJR under a Federal Communications Com mission directive to provide service to the city's black com munity today broke with the two remaining board members over changes in publicservice programing.

title: Agrico Chemical of Expand
description: The Agrico Chemical Com pany, a subsidiary of the Wil liams Companies, announced yesterday a $50million expan sion program at its Donaldson ville, La., facilities. Engineering studies for the program are un aerway and construction is scheduled to be completed in mid1974, according to K. F. Lundberg, Agrico's chairman. Included in the program is the construction of a large phos phoric acid plant, increasing the capacity of the Fastina plant and additional docks on the Mississippi River.

title: Caracas Estimates Oil Gain
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 20 (UPI)Venezuelan Mines Minister Hugo Perez la Salvia es mated today Venezuela would get about 10 per cent of the more than 600,000 barrela dayincrease in United States imports of crude oil ordered Monday by President Nixon. He said Venezuela also ex pected to supply all of the 38,000 barrel  a  day  increase ordered by Mr. Nixon for fuel oil for home heating. The in crease would mean about 98,000 barrels a day for Venezuela.

title: Mrs. Sulzberger Gets Barnard Alumna Award
description: The Barnard College alumnae association honored Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger yesterday for excellence and service, intelli gence and oldfashioned hard work in helping her Alma Mater.

title: Market Place: Lack of Profits Closes Rafkind
description: The death knell sounded yesterday for Rafkind & Co., a small brokerage house that voluntarily gave up the ghost because of what it called a decline in its business and a lack of profits.

title: Business Briefs
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 20 (AP)E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. announced today that it planned to with draw from the business of manufacturing polyethylene film because company studies of the operations found the future to be economically unfavorable.

title: H.I.P. QUESTIONED ON BLUE CROSS TIE
description: The legality of a proposed joint financial or adminis trative venture between the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York and Blue Cross, the nonprofit hospital ization plan, was questioned yesterday by Dr. Leonard J. Raider, the president of Blue Shield, the nonprofit insurance policy for doctor's fees.

title: History Book Criticized
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 20 (UPI) A history book proposed for use in the fifth grade has a sen tence here and there about George Washington, but de votes 6 pages to Marilyn Monroe and therefore should be thrown out, state officials were told yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: Stepin Fetchit was a point of pride to the Negro people, said Lincoln Theo dore Perry, who became Hollywood's first black star by playing the role of the shuffling Stepin Fetchit in movies of the 1920's and 1930's. Mr. Perry, once the owner of 12 cars (including a pink Cadillac), and the employer of 16 Chinese serv ants, lost his riches in the early 1940's. In 1970 he filed a $3million suit against the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem, the Xerox Corporation, 20th CenturyFox and the Indiana Broadcasting Com pany, in connection with a 19,68 documentary film that characterized him, he said, as the white man's Negro, the traditional lazy, stupid crapshooter, chickenstealing idiot. Now that his suit has been blocked in Federal Court in Indianapolis, Mr. Perry who is 80 years old, has ap pealed at a news conference for public support. I opened the door to the black men of America, he said. If I let this [suit] go, the same thing can happen to Sammy Davis Jr., Bill Cosby and Sidney Poitier.

title: Plane Carrying Freed P.O.W.'s May Not Make Stopover in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 20 (AP)  Evidence mounted to day that a Soviet airliner ex pected to carry three released American prisoners of war out of North Vietnam Saturday might bypass Vietiane and make its first landing in Bur ma or India.

title: President Signs Measure Expanding Heart Research
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 20 (AP) President Nixon signed into law today a program authoriz ing up to $1.4billion for ex panded Federal research into heart, lung and blood diseases through the fiscal year 1975.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20A study commission on fluoridation heard opponents this morning challenge the impartiality of the commission and ask its members to fight mandatory fluoride treatment of the state's potable water supply.

title: New Republic Rejects Inference Against Nader
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The New Republic has pub lished what Ralph Nader calls a rejection of any inference that his position on nofault automobile insurance was in fluenced by a $10,000 auto safety grant by the American Trial Lawyers Association.

title: Peru Gets Dollar Credit
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 20 (Reuters)Peru has obtained a $30million, seven year credit from an interna tional banking consortium to help finance domestic develop ment projects, a member of the consortium, the Dresdner Bank said today. The bank added that the funds would be used mainly for preparatory work necessary to exploit crudeoil reserves in the Peruvian jungle east of the Andes Mountains.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Representative Les Aspin attempts to make election year capital out of developmental and financial problems of the Lockheed C5 logistics trans port. [OpEd Aug. 29.] He even asserts that two other contractors experienc ing difficulties on two unrelated pro grams were somehow encouraged by Lockheed's having received a U.S. guarantee of up to $250 million in bank loans about a year ago.

title: Advertising:
description: On the face of it, Goodrich passenger tires and ExLax have little in common, except that both have been showing strong sales gains and have decided to go to new ad agencies anyway.

title: Boston Leads by Game
description: BOSTON, Sept. 20The Bos ton Red Sox swept a double header from the Baltimore Orioles tonight, fastening their grip on first place in the Ameri can League's pennant sweeps takes and knocking the Orioles into third.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Having been down so long, fashion is pursuing the road back. Not only has it banned the loony look, but it's linking its respectable clothes with respectable causes. Alexander's opened its fall fashion collection yesterday with a benefit for the American Cancer Society and a Salute to Women of Achievement.

title: Administration Seeks Relaxation of Ban on CancerCausing Food Additives
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Nixon Administration pro posed to Congress today that it dilute the law that has forced such cancer  causing food additives as cyclamates off the market.

title: The Proceedings In the U. N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 20  Senator George McGovern engaged today in a sharp de bate about his policies on amnesty and the Vietnam war with two workers at the Western Electric Company plant here.

title: FUTURES IN GRAIN DROP AT CHICAGO
description: Speculators were buyers and commercial concerns were sell ers in a relatively quiet grain futures market yesterday. Prices dropped on the Chicago Board of Trade by several cents a bushel in the case of December and later deliveries and more than 6 cents a bushel in the case of the September contract that expired yester day.

title: Israeli Offices Here Stay Calm Despite Threats
description: All was calm yesterday at the offices of the Israeli Mis sion to the United Nations and the Israeli Consulate General despite the Post Office's inter ception of three explosive de vices addressed to the mission.

title: Resetting Priorities
description: It is impossible to divorce politics from the catand mouse game Congress and the White House are playing on Federal appropriations for health, education, welfare and labor. But, once that fact of Washington electionyear life is acknowledged, it must be recognized that the sounder priorities in these areas are now being followed on Capitol Hill.

title: Family, Friends and Colleagues Attend Simple Rites for Rep. Ryan
description: About 800 mournersfrom admiring constituents to one time political adversaries  crowded into a plain neighbor hood. Roman Catholic church yesterday morning to attend a funeral mass for Representa tive William F. Ryan, who died of cancer Sunday night.

title: Washington Teachers Resume Strike After Rejecting Accord
description: Teachers in Washington de cidedlast night to go back on strike today, while teachers in Philadelphia continued a rec ordlong walkout.

title: Barbers Ask Meskill To Provide Subsidies
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 20 (AP)  Barbers in and around this city have de cided to appeal to Gov. Thomas J. Meskill for state subsidies. They say their business is suffering because many men are wearing their hair long.

title: Soviet Reported to Agree To European Conferences
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Administration officials said to day that the Soviet Union had accepted in principle the West ern position that a separate EastWest conference on the re duction of military forces in Central Europe should be held next year at about the same time as broad political talks on European security problems.

title: $4.8Billion Poverty Bill Is Signed by President
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)  President Nixon signed into law today a $4.8billion anti poverty bill that continues the controversial Legal Services for the poor program without the shift of control fought for in Congress.

title: Thieu Sets Limit Line
description: HUE, South Vietnam, Sept. 20 (Reuters)  President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that South Vietnamese forces driv ing Communist troops back to ward North Vietnam would call a temporary halt 10 miles from the demilitarized zone.

title: Nixon Sets Grain Inquiry Step Laid to Agnew Error
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20A misstatement by Vice President Agnew apparently led President Nixon today to order an inves tigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the sale of 400 million bushels of wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: WORKERS SEIZED AT S.I. HOSPITAL
description: Four surgical operations were canceled and all but emergency and obstetrics admissions were refused yesterday at the Staten Island Hospital after 130 em ployes were arrested while pro testing delays in contract ne gotiations.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A secondary offering of 1,150,000 shares of Howard Johnson Company common at $24.625 a share was made yes terday by an underwriting group headed by Blyth East man Dillon, F.S. Moseley & Co., and Alex. Brown & Sons. The shares are being sold by cer tain selling shareholders. The company's stock was up  at 24 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Business Briefs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 (AP)The Bank of America, the nation's largest commercial bank, issued its economic forecast for 1973 today. The picture included reduced unemployment, increased inflation and continued strong general economic growth.

title: 2d Connecticut Law On Abortion Voided
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 20for the second time this year, a Federal district court declared Connecticut's abortion statutes unconstitutional, saying they abridged the rights of a woman to privacy and personal choice in matters of sex and family life.

title: 4 CASINO IN NEVADA ROBBED OF $183,000
description: STATELINE, Nev., Sept. 20 (UPI)A gunman took $183, 000 from Harrah's Tahoe Ca sino late yesterday, fled through the crowded gambling area to a spot near Lake Tahoe and escaped on a motorcycle tended by a waiting accom plice.

title: 41,000 in Drug Programs Seen in Job Market in '73
description: The city's Addiction Services Commissioner estimated yester day that 41,000 former addicts and drug abusers would be looking for jobs here next year as a result of treatment pro gramsand said they should get them as part of their re habilitation.

title: UGANDA FLIGHT SNAG IS TROUBLING BRITISH
description: LONDON, Sept. 20British officials said today that they feared that unless the departure rate of Uganda's Asians was sharply increased, thousands would be left in Uganda after the deadline for their expulsion, Nov. 7. About 50,000 are being forced to leave.

title: Tanaka to Begin Visit To China on Monday
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 21 (Agence France  Presse)  Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan will leave Tokyo next Monday for a sixday visit to China, the Government announced today. The visit is for the purpose of normal izing JapanChina relations.

title: News of Dogs
description: DORADO, Puerto Rico, Sept. 20  Armando Mir who left Cuba in 1960, is an artist. The medium he uses is acrylic and more than 1,000 works have been created in his Miami studio.

title: Boston Shorty Triumphs Over Jimmy the Cat
description: A threecushion billiard match between two of the best players in the country ended here last night with Larry (Boston Shorty) John son beating Jimmy (the Cat) Cattrano, 240 to 206.

title: Bonn's Early Election
description: Chancellor Brandt has bowed to the inevitable in taking steps to dissolve West Germany's Bundestag ten months before the expiration of its fouryear term. The inability of his coalition of Social and Free Democrats to govern effectively, after critical defections, had been demon strated as long ago as April, when it failed to get the 1972 budget passed. It was illustrated again yesterday, when the Government lost two important votes involving amendments to its pension reform package.

title: Forest Hills Project Compromise Scored at Hearing
description: An emotional, raucous hear ing marked by charges of rac ism was held at City Hall yes terday on the Forest Hills publichousing project as hun dreds of Queens residents turned out to denounce the compromise proposal endorsed by Mayor Lindsay.

title: NATURE RECYCLES CANS, BUT SLOWLY
description: Contrary to the impression created by some environ mentalists, an aluminum beer can tossed into the woods by a careless hiker will break down and return to natureeventu ally.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Despite a late recovery, prices again finished lower in dull trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: Subsidies Halted in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 20 (AP) Turbulence in world market prices for grain following heavy Soviet grain purchases has led the European Economic Community commission to sus pend temporarily grain export subsidies, a spokesman said to day.

title: 90 IN HOUSE SEND APPEAL TO SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20Ninety members of the United States House of Representatives have sent a letter to Leonid I. Brezh nev, the Communist party lead er, urging Soviet authorities to stop harassing Soviet Jews ap plying to emigrate to Israel.

title: Fed Postpones Action on 2 Regulations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Federal Reserve Board, act ing under a court restraining order, postponed today putting into effect two major new regu lations affecting sameday pay ment of checks and calling for a large net reduction in bank reserve requirements.

title: Ecological Science Corp. To Sue S.E.C. on Curb
description: The Ecological Science Cor proation announced yesterday that it planned to sue the Secu rities and Exchange Commis sion in an attempt to stop the suspension of trading of its stock on the American Stock Exchange.

title: PIKE RAISES ISSUE OF RAID PICTURES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Representative Otis G. Pike said today that he had reason to believe that reconnaissance photographs of most of Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle's unau thorized bombing missions over North Vietnam had been avail able to the military chain of command.

title: European Interest in U.S. Stocks Quickens
description: PARIS, Sept. 19  Wall Street is receiving closer scru tiny from the men who man age money on the Continent, and in some cases they have liked what they have seen and have nibbled at the better values, interviews showed to day.The interviews found a quick ening of interest from the Eu ropeans for a couple of potent reasons:

title: About Pro Football
description: Duane Thomas bolted the Chargers again yesterday after only one day with the San Diego team. He went home to Dallas without ex planation. But Thomas's ab sences from the Chargers are becoming shorter. He was gone only two weeks this time. The pressure on the great running back to return to football is strong. He needs the money and a district judge in Texas has told him that when he completes a solid year with the Chargers his fiveyear probated sentence for alleged possession of marijuana would be reduced.

title: Frankel Is Appointed Times Sunday Editor
description: Max Frankel was named yesterday as the next Sunday editor of The New York Times, and Clifton Daniel, an associate editor of the paper, was ap pointed to succeed Mr. Frankel as chief of The Times's Wash ington bureau.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Once again the telephone company is reducing a service to the user namely thirdparty billing, making a phone call (usually from a pay phone) and charging the call to your home or office. This is a great con venience to most and a necessity to many, particularly when longdistance calls are involved.

title: AMIN APPARENTLY VICTOR IN UGANDA
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 20 Uganda armed forces loyal to President Idi Amin appeared to day to have decisively defeated an invading force of exiles trying to overthrow him.

title: McGovern, in Jersey, Calls For $6Billion Aid to Aged
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J. Sept. 20 Senator George McGov ern proposed today a $6.1bil lion Federal program to aid the elderly.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Sir Rudolf Bing, for 22 of his 70 years the general man ager of the Metropolitan Opera, has just begun a new career as distinguished visit ing professor of music at Brobklyn College. Twice a week he teaches two classes, Humanities 801 (seminar in the performing arts) and Opera 20.3.

title: JOHN COPELAND, 87, EXPOLICE INSPECTOR
description: John Edward Copeland, a re tired New York City police in spector who spent 40 years on the force, much of it in the BedfordStuyvesant district of Brooklyn, died Monday in a nursing home at Sunbury, Pa. He was 87 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20The Soviet Union and Iraq have evidently reached a new agreement to increase Moscow's refining and marketing of Iraqi oil in the wake of Baghdad's expropriation of the Iraq Petroleum Company.

title: 2 Museums Here Named As Bicentennial Projects
description: The South Street Seaport Museum and the projected American Museum of the Met ropolitan Museum of Art were endorsed yesterday as the first official projects to be spon sored by the newly formed New York City Bicentennial Corporation.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS 6BILLION TAX RISE TO SPUR PENSIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The Senate Finance Committee voted today to increase Social Security taxes by about $6 billion to finance a vast array of new benefits for the nation's elderly and disabled.

title: Pianist, 24, at Crossroads of Career
description: When I was 12 I used to have a recurrent nightmare, Garrick Ohlsson was saying. I dreamed I was on the stage at Carnegie Hall in white tie and tails, before a packed house. I open the pro gram and find to my horror that I'm supposed to play the Chopin Impromptu in Gflat major, and I don't know it at all.

title: U.N. Unit Said to Report Greeks Violate Human Rights
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20  A United Nations panel, after examining hun dreds of letters, has reportedly concluded that a consistent pattern of gross violations of human rights appears to exist in Greece.

title: City Acts to Rehire 31 Teachers Ousted In McCarthy Era
description: The Board of Education paved the way last night for the rein statement of 31 former city teachers who were dismissed during the early nineteenfifties as a result of investigations into alleged Communist influence in the school system.

title: COMMANDOS SAID TO YIELD TO BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20 The Palestine Liberation Or ganization, under pressure from the Lebanese Army, has ac quiesced to new restrictions on Arab commando activity on Lebanese soil, highly placed Arab informants reported to day.

title: British Lords Approve Common Market Entry
description: LONDON, Sept. 20The great debate on Britain's entry into the Common Market ended tonight with approval by the House of Lords.

title: Advertising:
description: Angry murmuring was heard yesterday morning in the Terrace Room of the Plaza, where the Magazine Publishers Association was beginning a threeday stay. It seems that two agency men on a panel discussing Cre ativitythe Critical Varia ble chose to illustrate their remarks with television com mercials.

title: IMPORTS OF OVENS UNDER STUDY HERE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) The United tates began an in vestigation today to determine whether extra customs duties should be put on Japanese mic rowave ovens.

title: Narcotics Seized, 5 Held
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 20 (AP)The police say they have seized $127,000 worth of mari juana and hashish and $30,000 in cash in a raid on a Cambridge apartment. The police said four men and a woman were ar rested in the raid. A police spokesman said the seizure was the largest ever in the history of the city of Cambridge.
