title: 200 Degrees On Faculties Held Bogus
description: About 200 faculty mem bers at colleges and univer sities throughout the state hold bogus degrees from unaccredited institutions, the State Department of Educa tion said yesterday.

title: SCHOOL UNIT GIVES PLAN ON CROWDING
description: A $628.5million city school construction program for 1973 74, which would substantially eliminate all space shortages and end shorttime schooling in three years, was proposed yesterday by the Board of Ed ucation's division of school planning and research.

title: U.N. PROCLAIMS '74 POPULATION YEAR
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20  Secretary General Waldheim today proclaimed 1974 as World Population Year and announced plans for a major conference then on dem ographic problems.

title: Brandt Maneuvers to Get New Election
description: BONN, Sept. 20Chancellor Willy Brandt asked for a parlia mentary vote of confidence to day and made it plain that he intended to lose as a means of attaining a new Federal elec tion.

title: Mexican Agents Discover Vast Marijuana Plantation
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 20 (AP) Agents of the Justice De partment today found what was believed to be the largest marijuana plantation in Mexico in the town of Canoas, 500 miles west of the capital.

title: Lou's Hope Easy Victor In Yonkers Stakes Trot
Ford Prices Rise by $40, But Decrease Is Claimed
description: DETROIT, Sept. 20  The Ford Motor Company released the prices for its 1973 model today, but it contended that an average increase of $40 per model was actually a decrease.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Jersey Mayor Denies Accusation

title: First $1MillionPlus Lottery Held
description: The threemember family of a 76yearold partly blind re tired mill worker in Little Falls, N. Y., was the apparent win ner yesterday of the $1million plus prize in the New York State lottery drawing, billed as the richest lottery ever played in America.

title: Knapp, in Ceremony Here, Sworn In as Federal Judge
description: Whitman H. Knapp, chairman of the commission that investi gated police corruption in the city, was sworn in as a Federal judge here yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: About 500 sign industry workers demonstrated out side City Hall yesterday against a proposed regulation to prohibit the placement of signs near major highways.

title: House Votes for a New Agency To Regulate Safety of Products
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The House swept aside objec tions of the Nixon Administra tion today to pass a bill to create an independent Federal commission with broad author ity to set mandatory safety standards for consumer prod ucts.

title: REPORT ON MUNICH CLEARS OFFICIALS
description: BONN, Sept. 20An official West German report, issued to day on the killing of 11 mem bers of the Israeli Olympic team in Munich on Sept. 5, absolved the police and political authori ties of any blame in the tragedy.

title: ANTIWAR MARINE GIVEN YEAR TERM
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N. C., Sept. 20A jury of six officers of the United States Marines im posed the maximum sentence today on Pvt. Thomas P. Mi chaud, a Vietnam veteran who pleaded guilty yesterday to un authorized absence of nearly three years.

title: ERVING AWARDED TO BUCKS BY N.B.A.
description: Julius Erving, who played for the Virginia Squires last season and signed to play for the At lanta Hawks this season, was awarded to the Milwaukee Bucks yesterday.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 20 (AP)The Venezuelan AllStars won the first Kodak Baseball Classic last night by beating favored Albuquerque, champions of the Pacific Coast League, 62, in 12 innings.

title: Board Asks Fuentes to Return $15,527 He Got After Removal
description: The Board of Education has asked Luis Fuentes, the contro versial superintendent of Com munity School District 1, to return $15,527.41 that was paid to him after his services as a principal were terminated last October by his former employer, District 23.

title: Large Models of Historic Synagogues On Display at Metropolitan Museum
description: The Metropolitan Museum's new exhibition, Synagogues from Damascus to Newport, which opened yesterday and which consists of eight large models of historic synagogues accompanied by related Ju daica from New York collec tions, will have strong emo tional associations for the Jewish portion of its audi ence at this time of year. But its focus is less on Fifteen Centuries of Jewish History, which is the exhibition's sub title, than on architectural style in general. As such, it is an exhibition for every body.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: OSKALOOSA, Iowa, Sept. 20 (AP)William Penn Col lege's football Coach, Ron Randleman, said today that Pillsbury College of Owaton na, Minn., had notified him it would forfeit Saturday's scheduled football game be tween the schools.

title: El Tiempo Acquired
description: The Mirador Publishing Com pany, publishers of the Spanish language weekly, Mirado de Uueva York (Spectator of New York) has acquired the daily El Tiempo, it was announced yesterday. El Tiempo ceased publishing last July.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BRUSSELS, Spt. 20 (AP)Emiel Puttemans of Belgium set two world records today in winning the 5,000meter run in an international track and field meet.

title: 2d Connecticut Law On Abortion Voided
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 20for the second time this year, a Federal district court declared Connecticut's abortion statutes unconstitutional, saying they abridged the rights of a woman to privacy and personal choice in matters of sex and family life.

title: CAHILL IS ACCUSED OF SMEAR TACTICS
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20Mayor James Plosia of East Ruther ford, named today at a hear ing into alleged suburban cor ruption charged a few moments later that his implication had been engineered by Governor Cahill in retaliation for the Mayor's opposition to the new Meadowlands sports complex.

title: Cleric's Criticism Of Rainbow Order Gets Split Reaction
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 20 (AP)A minister who said the Order of Rainbow for Girls must be run by dowager big ots because of its racist mem bership policies said yester day he had caught a little flak from some people and agreement from others.

title: Violence on the Screen Scares Oil Reviewers
description: OSKALOOSA, Iowa, Sept. 20 (AP)William Penn Col lege's football Coach, Ron Randleman, said today that Pillsbury College of Owaton na, Minn., had notified him it would forfeit Saturday's scheduled football game be tween the schools.

title: Nixon Sets Grain Inquiry Step Laid to Agnew Error
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20A misstatement by Vice President Agnew apparently led President Nixon today to order an inves tigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the sale of 400 million bushels of wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: Soviet Reported to Agree To Twin European Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Administration officials said to day that the Soviet Union had accepted in principle the West ern position that a separate EastWest conference on the re duction of military forces in Central Europe should be held next year at about the same time as broad political talks on European security problems.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20Vice President Agnew today called national defense the over riding issue in the 1972 elec tion and accused Senator George McGovern of advocating positions that would reduce American military options to only one: nuclear retaliation.

title: Music: Philharmonic Opens 10th Year in New Hall
description: The Pension Fund concert of the New York Philhar monic, last night in Carnegie Hall, was also something of an additional celebration. It was nearly 10 years to the day when Philharmonic Hall was opened. On Sept. 23, 1962, the hall was officially inaugurated, amidst great ceremony and the greatest acoustic disaster in concert history.

title: Judge Who Jailed 2 Writers To Head Soviet's High Court
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (Reuters) The official who sent the writers Andrei D. Sinyaysky and Yuli M. Daniel to labor camps was named today chair man of the Soviet Union's Su preme Court.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 20 (UPI)The Republicans nomi nated J. M. Hewgley Jr. yester day to succeed 73yearold Representative Page Belcher in November. Mr. Belcher, a Re publican, is retiring.

title: A.T.&T. IN ACCORD ON MINORITY JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Government and the Amer ican Telephone and Telegraph Company today announced an agreement under which the company will employ more blacks, other minorities and women and will provide more opportunities for promotion for all these groups.

title: She Knew She Had to Help the Children
description: A little more than four years ago Chndace Jor dan saw a newsreel and it changed her life. What's more, through her, it has changed a good many other lives, mostly children's.

title: Study Finds Devaluation No Cure for U.S. Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20A privately sponsored study concluded today that last year's devaluation of the dollar would not solve the nation's balanceofpayments problem. The study, by the Interna tional Economic Policy Asso ciation, said that only further actions by the government, including a major new inter national agreement on sharing the balanceofpayments costs of troops abroad, could bring about equilibrium in the na tion's international payments.

title: Sporting With SoHo
description: The proposal to put up a sports center in lower Man hattan's SoHo district, like the London plan to put a con vention center in the Covent Garden district, has engen dered unusually vehement opposition. In each case, an area of smallscale structures of healthy mixed uses, in which historic buildings have become a center of light in dustry and the arts, is threatened by incompatible com mercial construction.

title: U.S. Panel Accuses Burma Of Obstructing Drug War
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20A Government narcotics commit tee accused Burma today of endangering efforts to stem the flow of heroin by refusing to cooperate either with the United States or the United Nations.

title: FRANCE TO SUPPORT A SCHWEITZER TERM
description: PARIS, Sept. 20 (Reuters) France will support Pierre Paul Schweitzer for a new term as head of the Inter national Monetary Fund de spite opposition from the United States, it was disclosed today.

title: Shorter Illinois Residency
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (UPI) A threejudge Federal panel ruled yesterday that a person need live in Illinois only 30 days before an election to be eligible to vote. The decision, which declared unconstitutional the state's sixmonth voting residency requirement, came on a case remanded from the United States Supreme Court. The ruling puts Illinois law in line with the Court's recent vot ing decision.

title: FORD AIDES TIED TO RIGGED TESTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The Environmental Protection Agency formally advised the Justice Department today that supervisory employes of the Ford Motor Company deliberate ly and illegally tampered with tests of federally required emission control devices.

title: MAO ASKED TO SEE ROOSEVELT IN 1945
description: Mao Tsetung and Chou En lai, the Chinese Communist leaders, offered to come to Washington in the last months of World War II to talk person ally with President Franklin D. Roosevelt but their message was never relayed directly to him, according to Barbara W. Tuch man, the Pulitzer Prize winning historian.

title: McGovern, in Jersey, Calls For $6Billion Aid to Aged
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J. Sept. 20 Senator George McGov ern proposed today a $6.1bil lion Federal program to aid the elderly.

title: Shooting Termed Necessary
description: BONN, Sept. 20 (AP)  The report on the Munich killings issued today was in three parts. The Bavarian government wrote the first part, about Olympics security before the raid, and the third part, about the airport shooting. The fed eral and Bavarian Governments jointly wrote the second part, about the unsuccessful negotia tions to free the hostages with out an exchange of fire.

title: DEANS. EDMONDS, 91 LED LARGE LAW FIRM
description: Dean S. Edmonds, a patent lawyer and senior member of Pennie, Edmonds, Morton, Tay lor and Adams here, died Mon day in Bridgeport (Conn.) Hos pital. He was 91 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Six FoodProcessing Concerns Cited on HealthCode Infractions
description: Four restaurants, a super market and a butcher shop were cited by the Health Department yesterday for serious violations of the city's Health Code.

title: Executive Changes
description: Rexford E. Tompkins, has been elected presi dent of the Dry Dock Savings Bank, an insti tution with assets in ex cess of $1.35billion. Mr. Tompkins, who is 56 years old, is currently president of Brown, Har ris, Stevens, Inc., a New York real estate concern, and will take over his new post on Dec. 1. The presidency of the bank has been vacant since the death of Robert Horsfield on July 4. Douglas C. Welton, chairman of the Dry Dock, was elected chief, executive officer last September during Mr. Horsfield's illness andwill retain that position. Mr. Tompkins, a graduate of Swarthmore College and the Columbia Univer sity Law School, was an Air Force officer during World War II. Prior to joining Brown Harris in 1968, he was president of the City and Suburban Homes Company for 15 years.

title: New Public TV Head Will Stress Programing
description: Henry W. Loomis, newly de signated president of the Cor poration for Public Broadcast ing, indicated yesterday that under his guidance the corpo ration would become active in programing and take full re sponsibility for programs dis tributed by the Public Broad casting Service.

title: MRS. ARTHUR V. FISHER
description: Mrs. Margot Hampton Shore Fisher, a former photo editor with Magnum Photos in Eu rope who had been a research er and assistant to Edward Steichen and the late Robert Capa, died Sept. 12 in San Francisco.

title: Saigon Paper Posts Bond And Resumes Publication
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Sept. 20Dien Tin, one of 14 daily newspapers closed last week as a result of a presi denial decree requiring pub lishers to post large bonds, has belatedly deposited its bond and resumed publication.

title: Amtrak Reports Losses
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)Amtrak, the govern ment operated passenger rail road corporation, reported to day that it lost $153million in its first business year but man aged to attract an increasing number of riders on its trains. In reports to Congress and shareholders, Amtrak said pas senger volume in May and June was up 13.7 per cent over the same two months last year, that June revenues rose 11 per cent from June, 1971, and that the figures indicated that the decline in railroad passenger ridership has been reversed.

title: Dance: Beryozka Company Returns
description: The Soviet Union's Bery ozka Dance Company re turned to New York at the City Center last night, but returned with a difference. When the company was last in town some years ago, it consisted entirely of women. Now men have been added to the ensemble, and they do munch to improve what was previously an elegant but de pressing monotony.

title: Sudan Holds Libyans
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Sept. 20 (Agence FrancePresse) The Sudan forced five Liby an military planes heading for Uganda over Sudanese terri tory to land today at the air port here, the Foreign Ministry announced.

title: U.N. PANEL VOTES TO DEFER DEBATE ON KOREAN UNITY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 An effort to place the question of reunification of Korea on the agenda of the General Assembly, which could have embarrassed the United States, was beaten back, this evening by a narrow margin.

title: Eisenhower Civic Center
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) A Dwight D. Eisenhower Bi centennial Civic Center has been approved for downtown Washington by the Senate. The center would cost about $65 million. It would be constructed by a private developer and be purchased by the city under a 3year lease plan. The Senate approved the project without opposition Tuesday and for warded the measure to the House.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, Sept. 20The re sults of yesterday's state and Congressional primary elec tions, coming less than two months before national elec tions in November, indicated a surprisingly conservative mood in Massachusetts.

title: More Mailed Bombs Found
description: More letters rigged with ex plosive devices and addressed to Israeli diplomats were found in several cities around the world yesterday.

title: Business Loan Rates Dip
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (Reuters) Interest rates for small short term noninstall ment loans to businesses de clined slightly in August to 7.32 per cent, compared with 7.34 per cent in July, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Mitsubishi of Japan Gives Million for Harvard Chair
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21 In what was said to be an unparalleled act of Japanese cor porate generosity, the Mitsu bishi group of industries of Japan donated $1million today to Harvard University to estab lish a chair in Japanese legal studies.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: CLINTON, Sept. 21  An tiques dealers from Maine to Delaware crammed their sta tion wagons this week with cigar store Indians and Art Deco clocks, weathervanes and whirligigs, Louis XVI consoles and Queen Anne tables and set out for the two shows that have, for years, proved to be the harbingers of the fall an tiques season around here.

title: personalities: Kennedy Balks
description: Pro basketball's owners can't live with many of these new amendments to a merger bill in the Senate, claimed Walter Kennedy in Houston yesterday. Kennedy, commissioner of the Nation al Basketball Association, is especially unhappy about gatereceipt sharing with vis iting teams, which the N.B.A. has never had.

title: 5 U.S. College Heads Protest Soviet Exit Fees for Scholars
description: The presidents of five lead ing Massachusetts institutions of higher learning have sent a letter to the Soviet Academy of Sciences to protest the im position of exit fees on schol ars who wish to emigrate.

title: 3 QUEENS MEN HELD IN NARCOTICS CASE
description: Three Queens men were ar rested yesterday after under cover policemen allegedly pur chased a total of 24 ounces of highquality cocaine from them in recent weeks.

title: RUMANIANS SEEK WORLD BANK ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Spokesmen for the World Bank and International Monetary Fund said today that Rumania had applied for membership in the two institutions.

title: Mrs. King, Miss Casals Gain
description: ALBANY, Calif., Sept. 21 (UPI)  Topseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King, Rosemary Casals, Kerry Melville, Mrs. Margaret Court and Lesley Hunt moved into the quarterfinal round of the $20,000 Golden Gate Pacific Coast Tennis Classic today.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The Kennecott Copper Cor poration said yesterday it would appeal the decision of the Federal Court of Appeals at Denver upholding the Fed eral Trade Commsion order to divest itself of the Peabody Coal Company. Kennecott bought Peabody for $600mil lion in March, 1968, and the F.T.C. issued a divestiture order shortly thereafter.

title: The Danger of Ideological Crusades
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.Those of us who were brought up between the two World Wars were taught to be isolationists. In our gradeschool his tory classes tremendous significance was given to the Monroe Doctrine. As sixthgraders we learned that Euro peans were forever squabbling among themselves and their wars did not concern Americans.

title: Amex and Counter Markets Drop Again in Slow Trading
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and overthecounter market continued to drift lower yesterday in slow trading.

title: Two Held in Murder of Man Before His Wedding
description: Two Brooklyn youths were arrested yesterday and charged with having robbed and mur dered a 27yearold Brooklyn maintenance worker three days before his wedding last June.

title: Backer Fears StripMine Bill May Be Buried in This Session
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Representative Ken Heckler said today that Congressional staff workers and the coal in dustry were working secretly to bury any effective stripmin ing control bill during this ses sion of Congress.

title: PERCY GRIFFITH DIES; SHIP'S ENGINEER, 79
description: Percy N. Griffith, an engineer on the Liberty ship Booker T. Washington, famous in World War II as the first American merchant ship to sail with a mixed crew under a Negro captain, died Wednesday at his home in Queens. He was 79 years old.

title: YOUTH, 16, IS FIELD INCOLUMBIA DEATH
description: A 16yearold Youth has been arrested and charged in the fatal stabbing of a Columbia University law professor, and the police issued a 13state alarm yesterday for two broth ers as accomplices.

title: FED REPORTS GAIN IN MONEY GROWTH
description: Monetary expansion acceler ated in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Re serve System reported yester day, while the dollar showed signs of renewed strength in the international money mar kets.

title: Court Lifts Ban on Razing Of 2 Houses on 5th Ave.
description: Wrecking crews returned to Fifth Avenue yesterday to the job of tearing down two turn ofthecentury townhouses op posite the Metropolitan Museum of Art after Justice Wilfred A. Waltemade of the State Su preme Court angrily dismissed a court restraining order.

title: PLATINUM GROUP HAS PRICE GAINS
description: Platinum and palladium futures yesterday rose sharply, the latter by the daily limit.

title: Cahill Weighs Laws to Bar Local Zoning Corruption
Nixon Names Commission On Aid to Higher Education
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) President Nixon appointed a National Commission on the Financing of PostSecondary Ed ucation today and designated Donald E. Leonard of Lincoln, Neb., a lawyer, to be chair man.

title: U.S. and Rumania Draw, 22, at Chess Olympics
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 21  The United States and Romania tied 22 in their third round match in the chess olympics here yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There is something grotesquely silly about the way in which Messrs. Mc Govern, Kennedy, O'Brien, et al., are placing virtually all their campaign thrust against the Watergate caper. At its worst Watergate was a childish attempt to spy on a political antagonist. Equating it with the Teapot Dome and Chappaquiddick scandals is making the McGovern campaign look pitifully weak at a moment when truly signifi cant problems are crying for discussion and solution.

title: GROUP IS SET TO BUY THE BARBIZONPLAZA
description: An agreement to sell the BarbizonPlaza Hotel at 106 Central Park South between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue has been reached. The purchase price has not been disclosed.

title: McGovern Aide Resigns
description: BISMARCK, N. D., Sept. 21 (AP)Charles Tighe resigned today as cochairman of the North Dakota McGovern for President Committee, saying he was not, consulted by the state organization on any matters of real importance to the Mc Govern campaign in North Da kota.

title: 43Foot Dubuffet Sculpture Rises at Chase Plaza
description: Scheduled for unveiling on Oct. 24, a 43foot sculpture called Group of Four Trees by the French artist, Jean Du buffet, is being erected at Chase Manhattan Plaza.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Although I have spent many sum mers, Including this one, in Aroostook County, Me., I fail to recognize the heartrending problem of child labor in the potato fields [Cassandra Stock burger's OpEd article, Sept. 4] based on the facts as I know them. The car toon with the article, straight out of Dickens, left me very dryeyed indeed.

title: Map Shows Vertical Movement of the Earth's Crust
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The National Geodetic Survey has compiled a map showing the trends of vertical move ment of the earth's crust throughout the 48 contiguous states.

title: Weekend Fishing Report for Nearby Waters
description: AREA A  Strong north eastern winds producing high seas effectively stopped fish ing in this area for the last three days, but fishermen are taking heart at weather bu reau predictions that the winds will blow out sometime tonight. The high winds end ed a good streak of catches of blues, albacore and bonito on Manasquan Ridge and the Klondike, six miles off Spring Lake, N.J. Fishermen using smelts and bunker backs were hauling in blues from 10 to 15 pounds. Bottom fishing was also good on Jer sey beaches with sea bass and fluke responding in abundance.

title: Merger News
description: The Coastal States Gas Pro ducing Company, which recent ly acquired about 47 per cent of the Colorado Interstate Cor poration's common stock, an nounced plans yesterday to ac quire the remainder. The orig inal acquisition, achieved by a tender offer for $40 a share, totaled almost $83million. Di rectors of both companies said they had approved a letter of intent calling for a com bination of the companies the company de clined to put a value on the planned acquisition because of its complexity.

title: Abortion in Connecticut
description: In striking down Connecticut's newly enacted anti abortion law purporting to protect human life from the moment of conception, a threejudge Federal court has again confirmed the right of women to end unwanted pregnancies. An older Connecticut law banning abortions had also been declared unconstitutional but the state is appealing the latest ruling to the United States Supreme Court.

title: Bridg: Long Team Matches Grow In Popularity in Region
description: Most duplicate enthusiasts agree that a long team match is the best test of skill. This accounts in part for the steadily increasing popularity of competitions organized in this form.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commis sion said today it would issue a complaint charging Korvettes department stores and its NAC credit subsidiary with sending out unsolicited credit cards.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)Howard Boyd, the chairman of the El Paso Natural Gas Company testified today that his company was willing to spend more than $100million in the next five years to search for gas for its market areas, provided it was able to preserve its inte grated pipeline system.

title: Air Rights on Transit Station
description: MILTON, Mass., Sept. 21 (AP)The Massachusetts Bay Transit Authority, for the first time in its history, has ap proved the leasing of air rights over its property. The author ity gave Hendrie's, Inc., an ice cream manufacturer, permis sion to expand its facilities over the Central Avenue station parking lot. Hendrie's will lease the air rights for 10 years with an additional 10year option.

title: STANLEY B. ERLANDSON
description: Stanley B. Erlandson, vice president for manufacturing of the United States Tobacco Com pany, died Saturday in Chicago, where he had returned this year after seven years at the company headquarters in New York and Greenwich, Conn. He was 62 years old.

title: Theater: Rumanian Troupe Does Pearl Necklace
description: The Jewish State Theater of Bucharest is a firmly established, honored com pany that performs plays by, among others, Gorky, Moliere, Schiller, Gogol and Ibsen. For its current American tour, it has chosen to present S. Ansky's somber The Dyb buk, and, in direct contrast, a musical revue called The Pearl Necklace, which opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  The United States is going to carry the fight against terrorism and anarchy in world communications to the United Nations in the next couple of weeks and try to make this a major test, not only of the world organization but of the basic principles signed by Presi dent Nixon and Chairman Brezhnev of the Soviet Union four months ago.

title: Sidewalk Jungle
description: The wanton murder of Dr. Wolfgang G. Friedmann by teenage hoodlums is an unspeakable outrage even in a city grown callously oblivious to brutality. Dr. Fried mann, a distinguished professor of international law, had courageously stood up to the lawlessness of Nazi thugs in his native Germany. Some years ago, he fought off another New York sidewalk attack by young crim inals. Now, 65 years of age, he has been fatally struck down in broad daylight, three blocks from Columbia University at the end of a day's teaching.

title: Deposit Growth Is Shown By Savings and Loan Units
description: Deposits at the nation's sav ings and loan associations in creased by $1.7billion last month, the United States Sav ings and Loan League estimated yesterday.

title: United Air Lines Moves Into Black for 8 Months
Ohlsson Gets, a Piano to Play Just
description: It could have been a case of they laughed when I sat down to play the piano because there was no piano. Garrick Ohlsson, who gave a recital in Tully Hall last night, had picked out a Stein way a few days ago, and it was duly delivered. Then, in an interview printed in yesterday's New York Times, he was quoted as say ing that the Bosendorfer was the RollsRoyce of pianos. The Steinway people turned paler than their white ivories, and ordered their instrument removed from Tully Hall. They could not be persuaded to relent, so Mr. Ohlsson's manager had to dig up an other piano fast, which turned out, coincidentally, to be a Bosendorfer that was next door at Philharmonic Hall.

title: Senate Backs Broad Curbs On Hijacking by 751 Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  The Senate passed a tough anti hijacking bill today that pro vides for a new airport security police force, screening of all airline passengers and the op tion of imposing the death penalty for skyjackers.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21At torney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that an elctronic bugging device found last week on the office tele phone of a Democratic party official had been put there after the June 17 breakin at the party's headquarters.

title: Grenade Death CourtMartial Unexpectedly Recessed on Coast
description: FORT ORD, Calif., Sept. 21 The courtmartial of Pvt. Billy Dean Smith, the young black draftee accused of killing two white Army officers in Vietnam, went into an un expected recess here today.

title: RYAN'S SUCCESSOR TO BE PICKED OCT. 1
description: New York and Bronx Demo cratic county committee mem bers from the 20th Congression al District will meet Oct. 1 at the Commodore Hotel to name a candidate to replace Repre sentative William F. Ryan, who died Sunday night.

title: State Sues to Close 4 Travel Agencies
description: The State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, filed suits yesterday against four Manhat tan travel agencies that he as serted had cheated hundreds of travelers who had paid for bargainrate charter flights to and from Europe.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Sept. 21Japan's gross national product in creased by 11.7 per cent in real terms in the second quarter, compared to the same quarter of 1971. The Government has forecast officially that growth for the full year will be 7.2 per cent.

title: Advertising:
description: While to many of you yesterday was merely Thurs day of the third week of Sep tember, to the gang in the Terrace Room of the Plaza it was Circulation Day of Magazine Week in New York. A week, incidentally, of only three days.

title: OTB's Newest Computer Is Rated Sleeper of the Field
description: Howard J. Samuels paraded a new horse out of his com puter barn yesterday, a late starter being touted as the pos sible big winner of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation's electronic sweepstakes.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 21  The State Department of Insurance announced today that it would distribute a consumers hand book to the public on the pit falls of buying hospital insur ance policies through the mails.

title: F.B.I. Agent Under Attack Being Allowed to Retire
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 The special agent in charge of the Los Angeles office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who has been under fire since May, has been allowed to re tire effective next week, it was announced today.

title: Man, 73, Survives Fall Beneath an IRT Train
description: A 73yearold man, taken to a hospital last night after five cars of an eightcar IRT subway train had passed over him, stepped down from a stretcher, brushed himself off, said he was un hurt and went home.

title: Joe Brooks
description: Joe Brooks, noted fisherman, author of many books on fishing and fishing editor of Outdoor Life magazine, died Wednesday of a heart ailment in Roch ester, Minn. He was 70 years old, lived in Richmond and spent his summers in Livings ton, Mont.

title: Assemblymen Graded on Ecology Votes
description: The Environmental Planning Lobby, a coalition of more than 50 organizations in the state, issued yesterday the first comprehensive environmental voting rating for state legisla tors.

title: West Side Parents Bar 2 Teachers In Dispute on City Assignment Policy
description: A group of parents blocked the way of two regularly li censed teachers who had been assigned to replace two substi tute teachers at a West Side school yesterday as a new dispute over teacher assign ments erupted in Manhattan's Community School District 3.

title: HADFIELD QUITS CANADIAN SEXTET
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 21 (AP) Vic Hadfield, star left wing for the New York Rangers, and two other players withdrew from Team Canada today on the eve of its resumption of the eight game hockey series with the Soviet national team.

title: There's Someone You Should Know:
description: All my friends at the beach this summer were, to a woman, reading women novelists, mostly Doris Less ing. Sylvia Plath, Joan Didion and Alix Shulman. One friend, a poet, com plains of the book she is reading, Well, this one lacks style. But then, perhaps we women have to think about getting ourselves, our struggles down on paper first, before we can attend to our art. I ask her whether she has ever read Kate Chopin and she says, Who? It troubles me.

title: U.S.SOVIET PACT SETS UP PROJECTS ON ENVIRONMENT
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 21  The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to under take 30 joint environmental projects to benefit and protect the cities, farms, rivers, lakes and air of both countries.

title: STRIKE OUT TAKES LITTLE BROWN JUG
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 21 (AP)  Strike Out erased the track record of his illustrious sire, Bret Hanover, and sped to impressive straight heat tri umphs today in the $104,916 Little Brown Jug.

title: Kennecott Planning Appeal
description: The Kennecott Copper Cor poration said yesterday it would appeal the decision of the Federal Court of Appeals at Denver upholding the Fed eral Trade Commission order to divest itself of the Peabody Coal Company. Kennecott bought Peabody for $600mil lion in March, 1968, and the F.T.C. issued a divestiture order shortly thereafter.

title: UGANDA'S CAPITAL IN AGITATED MOOD
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 21 Truckloads of heavily armed Uganda troops reportedly raced about the capital city of Kam pala today, apparently alarmed by the belief that some new treachery was being hatched against President Idi Amin.

title: Mrs. Nixon Names Building In Honor of MotherinLaw
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 Driving east from Los Angeles to the desert's edge, Mrs. Rich ard M. Nixon dedicated today a cornerstone to the President's late mother at a community for the elderly in Riverside, Calif.

title: LOCAL GOVERNMENTS GET WAGE CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  The Nixon Administration ruled today that employes of all local governments, no matter how small, will be subject to the Pay Board's restrictions on wage and salary increases.

title: Gold Drop Seen Embarrassing Soviet Bank
description: ZURICH, Sept. 21Last Monday the gold market went out of control. The price of gold plummeted 8 per cent from $66 to $61.25 an ounce, a considerable drop for any commodity, let alone a ?? that still represents some of the wealth of nations.

title: Pompidou Defends Government, Assails Opponents
description: PARIS, Sept. 21President Pompidou used his semiannual press conference today to make a dramatic defense of the crit icisms that have been piling up against his Government.

title: Valley Stream Hires Carters During Strike
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Sept. 21  Private carters guarded by more than 100 Nassau County policemen started today to pick up about 400 tons of garbage and refuse from in front of homes here while striking municipal sani tationmen jeered. There was one scuffle, but no arrests were made.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 8.1%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The Association of American Railroads reported that freight traffic on United States rail roads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.2 billion tonmiles, 8.1 per cent above the corresponding 1971 week. Carloadings totaled 543,655, up 4.8 per cent from last year. The American Truck Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 4.9 per cent above the 1971 level.

title: House Panel Backs Ban on Diverting Highway Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The House Public Works Com mittee voted today to continue to prohibit the use of Federal highway money to build mass transit systems.

title: SHOP TALK
description: A few months ago, the American Crafts Council Gal lery held the first of its re gional shows  the work of Southwestern craftsmen. Now it is the turn of the North east. And there are differ ences.

title: About Pro Football
description: Two key intradivisional contests, the Jets at Balti more and the Vikings at De troit, will be seen here on television Sunday. The New York team, displaying Joe Namath in Baltimore for the first time, is favored by 2 points (Channel 4, 2 P.M.), while the Vikings are the choice over the Lions (Channel 2, 4 P.M.). The Giants open here against the Cow boys. A preview of all games follows with wonlost records in paren theses:

title: Eban Arrives Here
description: Foreign Minister Abba Eban said on arrival in New York last night that terrorism was new obstacle to peace in the Middle East.

title: Executive Changes
description: David R. Clare has been elected chairman of the Johnson & Johnson Domestic Operating Company, Johnson & Johnson, Ltd., of Great Britain and the newlyformed Johnson & Johnson Baby Products Company, all units of Johnson and Johnson. In addition, the Johnson & Johnson Dental Products Company also reports to Mr. Clare.

title: Public Access to Data Said to Lag
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  A House subcommittee re ported today that footdrag ging by the Federal bureauc racy had impeded the effec tive operation of the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Dr. E. Gordon Bell Jr. 59; Headed Unit at St. Clare's
description: Dr. E. Gordon Bell Jr., chief of the ear, nose and throat division of St. Clare's Hospital, died Wednesday night at the hospital, after a brief illness. He was 59 years old and had offices at 30 East 60th Street.

title: Mrs. Parker, Mrs. Berman Card 72's to Tie for Cup
description: EAST NORWICH, L. I., Sept. 22Mrs. Sidney Parker of Old Westbury and Mrs. Robert Ber man of Glen Oaks were dead locked today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 33d Joseph J. Windle cup tour nament over the par72, 5,980 yard Pine Hollow course. Each carded a net 72. Mrs. Parker had a gross 91, two strokes fewer than Mrs. Berman. An 18 hole playoff will be held over the same course later this month.

title: A Preservative Linked to Disease At Senate Hearings on Additives
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 21 Attacks on Federal food addi tive protection laws and poli cies were stepped up today at Senate hearings with a charge that a commonly used meat preservative and coloring agent has been linked to blood dis ease in humans and cancer in animals.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21A panel of advisers to Senator George McGovern called today for a new philosophical frame work for national security policy and accused President Nixon of overextending Ameri ica abroad and shortchanging its citizens at home.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Through the day and into the early evening, guys asked other guys, What do you think about the fight? And four times out of five the answer was the same: I hope Floyd doesn't get hurt. Then it was 10:30 P.M. There were 17,378 in Madison Square Garden, 17,378 fight fans. Half a century ago, Irvin S. Cobb described the typical fight ?? He is the softfleshed, hardfaced person who keeps his own pelt safe from bruises, but whose eyes glisten and whose hackles lift at the prospect of seeing somebody else whipped to a souffl. These fans had paid $512,361 to see a strutting peacock named Muhammad Ali beat up a man about 30 pounds lighter, three inches shorter and seven long years older than he. When the fighters came into the ring it was the little old gentleman. Floyd Patterson, who got the warmer wel come, and in the voice of the crowd there was wordless entreaty:

title: 21 DIANN COLLINS WINS AT YONKERS
description: YONKERS, Sept. 21Diannl Collins, a soundly beaten fifth in her most recent appearance, When traffic problems wrecked Whatever chances she had in a stakes test at Syracuse, found smooth going in tonight's $43,018 New York Sires Stakes onemile race for 3yearold pacing fillies.

title: WRIGHT RETAINS LEAD BY STROKE
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept. 21  Bethpage State Park's Black course, one of five in the golfing complex here, was opened to the public in 1936. But on this gray drizzly day, Mal Galletta Jr., the 31year old Glen Cove professional, tal lied a 65, the lowest competi tive round ever scored over the course.

title: The School Aid Issue
description: The proposal by Senator George McGovern to grant tax credits to parents who pay private school tuition is virtually identical with a plan previously submitted by President Nixon's advisory panel on aid to parochial schools. Although this form of aid has not yet been tested in the courts, it appears to us a threat to the principle of the separation of church and state, no less real for being an indirect subsidy. Since tax credits would apply to all nonpublic school tuition, this form of Federal support moreover could easily become a wind fall for those private academies that have been estab lished to perpetuate segregation.

title: WARD FOODS NAMES HOWLETT CHAIRMAN
description: William P. Howlett has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Ward Foods, Inc., a diversified food company with sates of $500 million. He succeeds Charles W. Call Jr., who with five other directors resigned last week in what the company called a policy difference be tween two factions.

title: Harvester Plans Expansion
description: The International Harvester Company announced yesterday that it plans a $50million ad dition to its truck engine plant at Indianapolis. The 21 per cent increase in the manu facturing area will accommo date production of two new V8 gasoline engines. Con struction is to begin immedi ately and it is expected to be completed in late 1974. About 500 new jobs are to be added to the plant's employment which is now at 3,100.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TOMS RIVER, Sept. 21  A 20yearold Toms River man testified today that a state trooper had burned three tri angular brands on his buttocks with a hot wire during an in terrogation.

title: Redistricting Hearings Set
description: TRENTON, Sept. 21  The State Apportionment Commis sion, under orders by the State Supreme Court to reapportion, the Legislature in time for the 1973 election, announced today it would conduct a public hear ing Oct. 12. A commission spokesman said it would try for a plan that provided for an ideal district of 179,278, with a population deviation be tween the 40 legislative dis tricts of no greater than 2 per cent.

title: LETTERBOMBERS SOUGHT BY DUTCH
description: AMSTERDAM, The Nether lands, Sept. 21The chief of the Special Branch of the Amster dam police said today that he was not optimistic on the immediate chances of tracing the terrorists who mailed at least 35 letterbombs from here to Israeli diplomats and other officials in several countries.

title: News Privilege Law Held Unnecessary
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The Justice Department told Congress today that subpoena ing of newsmen by the Gov ernment was sharply reduced in the last two years, and that the Nixon Administration would therefore oppose as un necessary proposed laws that would shield journalists from subpoenas.

title: Opera: English Giovanni
description: When the New York City Opera's determinedly earthy and impious production of Don Giovanni opened last week in its Italian version, a bracing mixture of jeers and cheers greeted it. There had been, one understands, no dress rehearsal because of time pressures of the sort that seem to beset opera more than any other art form.

title: SHARE CASHINS IN FUNDS MOUNT
description: Investors in mutual funds, who had been buying more and cashing in less, reversed themselves last month, the in dustry's trade organization re ported yesterday.

title: 21st State for Amendment
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 21 (AP)After four months of lobbying by various women's groups, the Pennsylvania legis lature has become the 21st state to ratify the proposed equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution. The Senate voted 43 to 3 for the amendment yesterday.

title: Projects Involve Pressing U.S. Ecological Difficulties
description: The projects selected for joint AmericanSoviet scientific study in the United States en compass a broad spectrum of environmental problems that have plagued the North Ameri can Continent for many years.

title: Art: Native
description: The late Edith Gregor Hal pert, besides being one of the most successful dealers of her generation in promoting the work of living American artists, was also one of the first to take a serious inter est in American folk art. Be ginning in the 1920's, when the productions of such artists were generally regarded as esthetically insignificant curi osities, Mrs. Halpert was as siduous in searching out and acquiring important works in native folk art. The American Folk Art Gallery, an adjunct to her famous Downtown Gallery, thus became a key center for collectorsboth public and privatewho came to grasp both the artistic and historical importance of this socalled minor branch of American art history.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: New York (Madison Square Gar den)Muhammad Ali, 218 pounds, (Cherry Hill, N. J., knocked out Floyd Patterson, 188, New Paltz, N. Y., 7 rounds; Ken Buchanan, 134, Scotland, knocked out Car los Ortiz, 139, New York, 6.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DETROIT, Sept. 21Senator George McGovern said tonight that he planned to drop off the campaign trail next week to pre pare a series of fireside chats for national television.

title: Big Board and Amex Report a ShortInterest Drop
Letters to the Editor
description: A responsible debate on Senator McGovern's proposal to cut defense spending by $10 billion in each of three years should revolve around the issue of whether the United States could Indeed keep modernizing its weaponry and adequately defend the United States for $50 billion, instead of $80 billion now being spent.

title: FUND BILL FOR AID PASSED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  The House passed and sent to the Senate today a foreign aid appropriations bill that would provide $4.2billion in econom ic and military assistance dur ing the fiscal year that began July 1. The total is nearly $1 billion less than the Administra tion had requested.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: UNION CITY, Sept. 21A member of the Board of Edu cation here charged today that high school seniors and juniors and their teachers were forced to attend a rally held yester day in Schuetzen Park at which George McGovern, the Demo cratic Presidential nominee, ap peared.

title: Cahill Weighs Legislation To Bar Zoning Corruption
description: In a new move to break the alleged corruption surrounding local zoning and landuse laws in New Jersey, Governor Cahill disclosed yesterday that he was seriously considering legislation that would require everyone doing business with a com munity to make a full public financial report.

title: BETH B. SUTHERLAND, A GEM ENGRAVER, 74
description: Beth Benton Sutherland who spent more than half a century practicing the ancient craft of intaglio, or gem engraving, died Sunday of a heart attack at her summer home on Nantucket Island. She was 74 years old and lived in Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Arabs Bid U.N. Defer Terrorism Issue
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21The Arab bloc with the support of a group of Afri can nations, tonight mounted an effort to defer any discus sion of the terrorism issue for this session of the General Assembly.

title: PIRATES CLINCH EASTERN CROWN BY BEATING METS
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates won their third straight National League Eastern Division cham pionship at Shea Stadium last night when Steve Blass pitched a sevenhitter to defeat the Mets, 62.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 21Rutgers has sched uled Tampa, Tulane and Air Force as football opponents during the next four seasons. Scarlet recruiters have con vinced some outstanding basketball players in recent secondary school competition to attend Rutgers. A $5mil lion bond issue was approved by Jersey voters last year for construction of a new Rutgers field house.

title: The Lowenstein Loss
description: The victory of Representative John J. Rooney over Allard K. Lowenstein in this week's special Democratic primary in Brooklyn is a defeat for the public interest generally. But it is plainly the verdict of the electorate at least that part of it that turned out to vote. Mr. Rooney won by only 890 votes in the June primary thrown out by the courts for what Mr. Lowenstein rightly deicribed as massive irregularitiesbut he won this week's rerun by well over 2,000 votes. There were irregu larities this time, too; but not enough to have made a second court test tenable.

title: GILBERT H. WILLIAMS
description: Gilbert H. Williams, a former Brooklyn Eagle reporter who became copy director and vice president of the Federal Adver tising Agency here in the 1930's, died Saturday at his home in Grafton, Vt., where he had retired in 1963. He was 68 years old.

title: Lake Baikal Symbolizes Soviet Pollution Problems
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 21for the outside world as well as Soviet citizens themselves, Lake Baikal near the Siberian city of Irkutsk has become synony mous with pollution problems and the fight to save the en vironment in this vast nation. Today the lake became one of the sites designated for study by United States and Soviet ecologists.

title: Man Killed, 3 Others Hurt By Car Leaving Garage
description: A 46yearold Long Island man was killed and three others were injured when they were struck down last night by a car pulling out of a midtown nanhattan parking garage, the police reported.

title: Seismic Signals Recorded
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commis sion reported that seismic sig nals had been recorded in the United States today, presum ably from an underground nuclear explosion in the Soviet Union.

title: OFFICIALS SCORE LANDLORDS' AIDES
description: Alleged harassment by com panies hired by landlords to re locate tenants was criticized in a hearing at City Hall yester day by city, state and Federal elected officials, who declared that they intended to seek legis lation to curb the companies.

title: Nuclear Device Tested
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 21 (AP)A nuclear device was detonated 1,800 feet under the Nevada desert today as part of weaponsrelated tests, the Atomic Energy Commission an nounced. It was the fifth un derground test announced this year at the Nevada test site.

title: 11 Czech Parachutists Die in BusTrain Crash
description: VIENNA, Sept. 21 (Agency FrancePresse)Eleven mem bers of a Czechoslovak para chute team taking part in the Warsaw Pact parachute championships were killed in a driving accident in Bulgaria today, the Bulgarian Press Agency reported here.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)A net loss of $84,547, 000 for the first six months of 1972 was reported today by Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation. There was a loss of $153,470,000 for the fiscal year ended last June 30. But Amtrak said the number of railroad pas sengers was up in recent months.

title: American in Uganda Jail Found Brutality and an Unlikely Esprit
description: LONDON, Sept. 21Uganda soldiers pinned a man on the ground while a woman beat him with a rawhide whip10, 20, 50 times until he screamed and writhed and the whip drew blood.

title: Books of The Times
description: Paula Fox's previous novel, Desperate Characters, was a faultlessly crafted work and one that opened a new angle of vision on a familiar and much exploited scene. It extended the definition of urban poverty in a way that belied the statistics of in creasing affluence among the middle class and investigated areas of urban blight to which sociologists would never give a second glance. It proved, in a way at once subtle and overpowering, the truth of Donne's famous statement that no man is an island, that it is impossible to build an oasis of green ery in a sea of misery. The author did this without making a single rhetorical state ment, without ren dering one ab stract judgment. The incidents in the book and the involvement and recoil of her characters from them was enough. Her novel struck the reader as so true as to be selfevident, but one realized that this was so only after the author had framed the propositions in such a way that they required no further proof.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The Department of Commerce reported today that department, store sales last week were an estimated $864million, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $820million. Total retail store sales were an estimated $8.301 billion, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $7.89billion.

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED AFTER GUN MISHAP
description: A gang of seven persons linked to at least 20 midtown Manhattan robberies this sum mer was seized yesterday when one of the alleged gang mem bers was picked up a a hospital after he accidentally shot him self in the hand during a hold up, the police said.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Anniversaries

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21The motor launch cruised down the placid Monongahela River the other night, as the neon lights on the surrounding hills re flected in tile dark water.

title: Payne Must Stand Trial
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 21 (AP) An Atlanta psychiatrist testi fied today that Tom Payne of the Atlanta Hawks, facing three charges of rape, was mentally competent to stand trial in Su perior Court. Judge Sam Phil Lips McKenzie had ordered psy chiatric examinations for Payne at the request of the National Basketball Association player's attorneys.

title: No Change in Positions Seen at Session of Paris Talks
description: PARIS, Sept. 21  The 160th formal session of the Vietnam peace conference was held here today, with no visible sign that intensive American diplomatic activity last week had changed the position of any delegation.

title: The One & Only Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21When Richard Nixon ran for the Presidency four years ago, he benefited from the political equivalent of the statute of limitations.

title: The Talk of Kinsley
description: KINSLEY, Kan., Sept. 21 There is a saying out here in the wheat country that grow ing grain is riskier than gambling in Las Vegas. Some body once figured out that no fewer than 67 key factors ranging from weather to bug spray must mesh to pro duce a bountful harvest. One pelting, hailstorm sweeping across the flat, golden fields, one spring blitzkrieg by the hated Hessian fly and a man might as well plow everything under and start again.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 21UFO, a surefooted 8yearold chestnut gelding owned and ridden by Fred Bauer of Weston, Conn., won his second straight amateur owner jumper class at the Eastern States horse show to day.

title: FREDERIC HAHN, 76, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Sept. 21Frederic H. Hahn, invest ment banker and limited part ner in the New York broker age house of Goodbody & Co., died yesterday in Bethesda Memorial Hospital, Boynton Beach. He was 76 years old and lived here and in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: MET'S BUTTERFLY RUNS INTO A SNAG
description: On only its second night of the new season, Wednesday, the Metropolitan Opera had a problem of sorts. The work was Puccini's Madama Butter fly, which was to have been conducted by Alain Lombard for the first time with the com pany.

title: A Bill to Improve Benefits For G.I.'s Survivors Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)  President Nixon signed into law today a new benefit program for widows, widowers and children of retired mili tary personnel.

title: No G.I. Killed in Week In Indochina, U.S. Says
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 22for the first time since March, 1965, a week has passed without American combat deaths in Indochina, the United States command reported yesterday.

title: Audrey Meadows Joins Denver Bank's Board
description: During her acting career, the successes scored by Au drey Meadows included a stint as the wife of Jackie Gleason in The Honeymoon ers television program and the costar of Phil Silvers in the Broadway hit, Top Banana. For the last 11 years, she has been married to Robert F. Six, president of Continental Airlines, and has taken a part in the line's marketing programs.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: A registered secondary offer ing of 600,000 common shares of Smith Kline & French La boratories at $58.50 per share was made yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Smith Barney & Co. The selling shareholder is the estate of Francis Boyer, former chairman of the board of S.K.F. The company's stock closed at 58, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)  The commanding officer at Fort Dix, N. J., has denied per mission to Dr. Benjamin Spock and Linda Jenness to campaign for President on the base, the People's party said today. Dr. Spock is the People's party candidate and Mrs. Jenness is the candidate of the Socialist Workers party.

title: Nixon to Name Panel On Women in Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)President Nixon, who has been accused by George McGovern of neglecting the needs of women, announced today that he would appoint a 20member advisory com mittee on the economic role of women.

title: Vegetable Lover's Spaghetti
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: No G.I. Killed in Week
description: For the first time since March, 1965, a week has passed without American combat deaths in Indochina, the United States command reported. Details on Page 3.

title: ROBERT B. ZELENKO
description: Robert B. Zelenko, a senior international trade specialist for the United States Depart ment of Commerce, died Wed nesday of a heart attack in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 61 years old and lived at 150 Bennett Avenue and at Lake Copake, N.Y.

title: Business Briefs
description: Delta Air Lines and Braniff Airways, Inc., announced yesterday that they had purchased a total of 18 727200 jet aircraft from the Boeing Company.

title: MAIL TO ISRAELIS HERE IS SCREENED
description: Postal Inspectors imposed rigid surveillance yesterday over mail addressed to Israeli diplomats here, looking for ex plosive devices similar to three tiny bombs discovered Tues day night.

title: AGLIMMER FIRST ON BELMONT TURF
description: Aglimmer made things look easy at Belmont Park yester day. The 3yearold filly owned by John A. Bell took the lead at the start of the 1 116mile turf event that served as the feature on the card, and held it all the way, to win by five lengths.

title: DR. LEO A. WALL, 54, EXPERT ON PLASTICS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Dr. Leo A. Wall, an authority on the chemistry of plastics who had headed the polymer chemistry section of the Na tional Bureau of Standards since 1962, was found drowned in Chesapeake Bay yesterday. He had gone For a sail alone in his boat last Sunday. He was 54 years old and lived in Mc Lean, Va.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SWEDESBORO, Sept. 21 It looks dilapidated on the outside, Joseph Dibella said apologetically as he looked at the cinderblock shed that houses migrant workers on his farm on Davidson Road here. But it's all right in side.

title: Pollsters and Prophets
description: Faced with the beauty of seeming numerical precision, it is once again the season to spread the reminder that political polls are not elections.

title: Briggs Homers and Drives in 3 Runs
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 21Be cause of the way the other three contending teams are playing, the Yankees' ultimate exclusion from the pennant race is taking place in stages.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Mary Susino was in Peter Sergi's corner candy store at Court Street and treelined Loretto Place, Brooklyn, yes terday with her two little boys, Joseph and SantoSandy, ex cept in school; we American ized it.

title: At the Site of Slaying, Violence Is a Part of Life's Routine
description: Joe Trozzo, burly Italian American, is more or less the eyes of that small section of Amsterdam Avenue between 122d and 123d Streets where Columbia University professor was stabbed to death in a rob bery about 4 P.M. Wednesday.

title: RULES ON DISSENTS ADOPTED BY S. E. C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of new rules aimed at making clearer just what proposals dissenting stockhold ers may bring before annual stockholders' meetings.

title: Kenyatta Effort Is Hinted
description: NAIROBI, Sept. 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Secretary General of the Organization of African Unity, Nzo Ekangaki, met here today with President Jmo Kenyatta of Kenya in what was believed an effort to get Mr. Kenyatta to act as a medi ator in the current crisis be tween Uganda and Tanzania.

title: Raiders Kill Couple
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 21A parttime soldier and his wife were slain in their home in County Fermanagh to day a few hundred yards from the border with the Irish Re public. There were no witnesses but the killers are believed to belong to an assassination squad of the Irish Republican Army.

title: M'GOVERN BACKS LIMIT ON STATUS OF SOVIET TRADE
description: Senator George McGovern told the leaders of 25 major national Jewish organizations yesterday that he would vote in favor of a plan to withhold most favored nation trading status from the Soviet Union until it abolished its slave tax on Soviet Jewish emigrants and ceased its arming of Arab ter rorists.

title: Philadelphia Strike By Teachers Irks Parents and Pupils
description: The police had to rescue several Philadelphia Council men yesterday after they were confronted in their chambers by 700 angry parents and stu dents demanding an end to a threeweek teachers' strike that has closed the city's 200 pub lic schools.

title: Ronan Is Told to Produce Transit Records Levitt Says He Withheld From State Auditors
description: State Controller Arthur Lev itt invoked his rarely used sub poena powers yesterday and ordered Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, to bring to his office next week the records he said the Transit Authority had withheld from state auditors.

title: CROSBY FIELD, 83, INVENTOR, IS DEAD
description: Crosby Field, an engineer, in ventor and manufacturer, died Wednesday at his home, 8029 Harbor View Terrace, in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. He was 83 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Mayor Lindsay's crackdown on pornography (and your Sept. 5 editorial support of the crackdown) are totally illconceived, for at least four reasons:

title: Career Girls Turn Models for Seventh Avenue Fashion Show
description: Nan Nystrom, her blond hair flying, led the parade of mannequins down the long green runway set up in the street in front of the Manu facturers Hanover Trust Com pany branch bank in Madison Square Garden. She's 21 years old and not a manne quin at all; she's a super visor in the credit department at Gimbels. Still, she was very professional in describ ing the outfit she wore.

title: Tank Truck and Bus Collide on Turnpike; 1 Dies in Explosion
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Friday, Sept. 22A tank trailer carry ing liquid propane gas exploded in a fiery collision with a Grey hound bus and another truck on the New Jersey Turnpike near Interchange 8 last night.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A registered secondary offer ing of 600,000 common shares of Smith Kline & French La boratories at $58.50 per share was made yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Smith Barney & Co. The selling shareholder is the estate of Francis Boyer, former chairman of the board of S.K.F. The company's stock closed at 58, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: DayCare Aides Protest Proposed U.S.Fund Cuts
description: Hundreds of daycare workers, many of them wo men who sat down with chil dren in the middle of the street, tied up midtown traf fic on Madison Avenue for several hours yesterday as they took over President Nixon's campaign office near 52d Street to protest impend ing cutbacks in Federal fund ing.

title: After Death of Prof. Friedmann, What Can You Say? A Student Asks
description: Enrique Paguaga, who once met Dr. Wolfgang G. Friedmann at a debate on the Dominican revolution, stopped as he walked on Amsterdam Avenue at 123d Street yesterday to stare at the ?? on the pave ment, left from the day be fore, when Dr. Friedmann was stabbed to death.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: President Nixon will visit New York City next Tuesday to attend a Victory '72 Din ner at the Americana, Har ry J. O'Donnell, communica tions director of the New York Committee to Reelect the President, announced yes terday.

title: Screen: Hope Is Kept Busy in 'Cancel My Reservation'
description: Movies like "Cancel My Reservation," which opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall, aren't made; they are manufactured. They are processed, really, to a certain bland level of no taste and low expectationwhich they probably serve well enough, and make their money. If, like "Cancel My Reservation," they are comedies, their aim is not to produce laughter but rather to fabricate the conditions under which you are supposed to laugh. For some audiences that seems to be enough."Cancel My Reservation" is adventure comedyor, more accurately, murder comedy, in which Bob Hope, as a big-time Eastern TV personality, has to prove his innocence to a small-town Arizona sheriff (Keenan Wynn) and at the same time patch up his marriage (to Eva Marie Saint) and solve a mystery so as to save his own life. It is an exceptionally busy movie, with more action than insight, and a method of exposition that seems to consist mainly of voice-over wisecracks.Hope's comedy has always depended a good deal on its topicality, and "Cancel My Reservation" is not without its topics. These include Indian rights, which it favors; women's liberation, which it does not; and sex, about which it displays a fairly nervous ambivalence. Perhaps so as not to outpace even the dullest audience, or perhaps because there were no good writers present, the topics are all dreadfully safe and sadly predictable. It isn't that the gags fail. They don't even tryunless you consider yet another crack about Crosby's golf game to be trying.It is ungenerous to say so, but I think the real topicunexpressed  is how old everyone has gotten. At 68, Bob Hope lacks the youthful bloom of the 42-year-old he is supposed to play. And the inability of the Hope persona to accommodate an old man's range of comedy, which can be very funny and very beautiful, is a much more serious cause of failure than the silly plot or the uninspired jokes that clutter the film. Age keeps cropping up, mostly as a source of embarrassment, but there is no way of accepting it, or even openly recognizing itand for all its mild pretensions, "Cancel My Reservation" emerges as a kind of scandalous indulgence.

title: Connecticut Takes Ruling on Abortion To U.S. High Court
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 21Con necticut filed notice of appeal today directly to the United States Supreme Court against a Federal court ruling here yes terday that the state's new abortion law was unconstitu tional.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Jersey to Provide Christmas Tree

title: Film: Rough Magic' in Whitney American Series
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art yesterday in augurated its third series devoted to the work of new American filmmakers with the New York premiere of Rough Magic, a first fea ture by Timothy Knox, a New Englander in his early 30's who now teaches Eng lish at the Dalton School here.

title: Canadian Exports Increase, But Strikes Distort Figures
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 21 (Reuters) Canada's exports, seasonally adjusted, reached $1,584,000, 000 (Canadian) in August, par tially recovering from a sharp decline in July when the total was $1,482,000,000.

title: Chesapeake Bay Bridge Forced to Close After a Tug and a Barge Ram It
description: NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 21 (UPI)  A tug and a 235 foot barge, abandoned in heavy seas and galeforce winds, slammed into the Ches apeake Bay Bridge early to day, forcing its closing for up to a month.

title: Injury to Colts' Bulaich Makes One Jet Wince
description: Early reports out of Balti more say that Norm Bulaich is slightly injured again, but Paul Crane, the New York Jets' line backer, is one of those hoping the Colts' running back is fit for Sunday's game in Memorial Stadium.

title: Job Survey Finds Aged Work Well
description: PATCHOGUE, L. I., Sept. 21The State Commissioner of Human Rights announced today that a survey of more than 100,000 state employes had shown that workers over the age of 65 per formed their jobs about equal to and sometimes no ticeably better than younger workers.

title: Britain to End Internment Of Ulster I.R.A. Suspects
description: LONDON, Sept. 21Britain tonight ordered the end of the controversial policy of intern ing suspected terrorists in Northern Ireland without trial.

title: SHRIVER REPORTS $100,000 ASSETS
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21  Sar gent Shriver, the Democratic nominee for Vice President, dis closed today that his net worth was $100,000, most of it in bank accounts and life insurance.

title: Big Japanese Steel Maker Is Seeking U.S. Partners
description: Hitachi Metals, Ltd., Japan's leading specialty steels produc er, announced yesterday that it was negotiating with potential United States partners for a joint manufacturing venture to produce metals products in this country.

title: City Is Accused of Withholding $250,000 From Family Courts
description: A member of a State Select Committee on Child Abuse, in vestigating staff shortages in the city's Family Courts, said yesterday that the City Budget Director, David A. Grossman, would be subpoenaed to testify at a hearing next week re garding charges that the city is withholding $250,000 neces sary for successful operation of the courts.

title: AN EXTERRORIST IS HELD IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 21Amihai Paglin, a key strategist of the Jewish underground in the clos ing years of British rule in Pal estine, has been arrested here in connection with an attempt to form an antiArab terrorist campaign in Europe and America.

title: Notes on People
description: The first annual Reinhold Neibuhr award was presented to the Rev. Theodore M. Hes burgh at the Union Theologi cal Seminary here. Father Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame and chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, said at the award ceremony: America is the greatest melting pot in the world but there is one area where this melting pot has simply failed to function and that is the area of color. Father Hesburgh, who said the $5,000 award would be used to establish a Neibuhr prize at Notre Dame, added: There's no legitimate excuse for our politicians to fore close educational opportuni ties for generations of de prived blacks because it would be popular with the white majority. No one has the right any more to play games with human life in America.

title: Thieu Assails Colonialists
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 21  President Nguyen Van Thieu has rejected the latest Communist proposal for a threepart coalition Govern ment in South Vietnam, saying: Any political settlement in South Vietnam should be de termined by the South Viet namese people themselves with out foreign interference.

title: Appetizers Worth the Visit
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and d cor (four triangles to none).

title: BAY STATE RELAXES SHELLFISH SALE BAN
description: BOSTON, Sept. 21. (UPI) Massachusetts relaxed its ban on shellfish today allowing con sumers to buy available sea food from merchants.

title: Metropolitan Life to Sell Home and Car Coverage
description: The nation's secondlargest insurer, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, disclosed here yesterday that it would soon be selling insurance on homes and cars, thus making it the third leading life in surer to move into the busi ness in two years.

title: Will It Be Only Eight?
description: Ever since the signing of the Treaty of Brussels last January, the world has taken it for granted that the European Economic Community would expand from six to ten member states on next New Year's Day. Even when the legislation necessary for British membership of the Common Market was barely surviving critical tests in the House of Commons, it was habitual to refer to the Community of Ten as though it were almost an accomplished fact.

title: Pirate Bats Are Too Potent for Rivals
description: When they clinched the Eastern champion of the National League for the third straight year last night, the Pittsburgh ?? took a giant stride toward some thing that nobody else in the league had achieved for half a century  win two world titles in a row.

title: HELP FOR MINORITIES PLEDGED IN ACCORD
description: Officials of General Foods Corporation and People United to Save Humanity reached an agreement yesterday to improve the economic condition of blacks and other minority groups.

title: P.O.W.'s Relax in Hanoi as They Wait Next Step
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 21 (Agence France Presse)The bar of one of Hanoi's main hotels was the setting today for an unusual sight here: An American pilot casually drinking a beer.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
900,000 VEHICLES RECALLED BY FORD
description: DETROIT, Sept. 21  The Ford Motor Company today re called 900,000 of its 1972 cars and trucks and said that it would inspect 190,000 of the new 1973 models, seeking a de fect that could cause steering to fail.

title: Sudan Strains Ties With Libya By Barring Arms Aid to Uganda
description: CAIRO, Sept. 21The grow ing estrangement between the Sudan and her two Arab neighbors, Egypt and Libya, was carried a step further last night when the Sudanese Pres ident, Maj. Gen. Gaafar al Nimeiry, prevented five Libyan Air Force planes from flying Libyan troops and arms to Uganda. Today, the men and the planes were sent home and the arms were impounded.

title: SITSON MA, VIOLINIST PLAYS OWN WORKS
description: Sitson Ma, a Chinese violin ist and composer who has been living in this country for five years, appeared at Tully Hall Wednesday night. The program evenly balanced East and West by juxtaposing sonatas of Bach and Grieg with a collection of Mr. Ma's compositions.

title: Soviet to Provide Extensive Help for Indian Economy
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 21An agreement signed this week provides for extensive Soviet involvement in the economy of India.

title: GEN. J. R. CHAISSON OF MARINES DIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)Lieut. Gen. John R. Chaisson, former chief of staff of the Marine Corps, died of a heart attacks yesterday while playing badminton at the Of ficers Club at, the Pentagon. He was 53 years old and lived in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: After the Mylai massacre the big fish swam away and the little fish got caught. There is every reason to suspect that something similar may be happening in the Watergate affair. Although a representative of the Jus tice Department, which has had a sort of overlapping directorate with the Committee for the ReElection of the President since its inception, says that there is no evidence that any others should be charged. It is inconceivable that the initiative for the burglary should have come from the seven already indicted or that the stolen in formation should have been intended for their sole use.

title: Jimmy the Greek Puts Odds on Nixon at 8 to 1
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Jimmy the Greek Snyder, the Las Vegas oddsmaker, testi fied today that President Nixon was at least an 8to1 favorite to defeat Senator George McGovern Nov. 7 and said the odds would likely get higher.

title: Catch Rising Star At Americana Room Reflects New Trend
description: Along with the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel, the Royal Box of the Americana has for saken this fall the name per formers who have previously been the standard fare of both rooms, turning to lesser known, less expensive talent. The em phasis in the show that opened at the Royal Box this week is on quantity  eight singers, eight dancers and four princi pals in a 1hour program produced by Barry Ashton and Wolf Kochmann, whose usual milieu is Las Vegas, Nev., and Miami Beach.

title: SOBEL RESIGNS E.D.I. POSITION
description: Stuart Sobel, the personnel executive in the city's Housing and Development Administra tion who reviewed applicants for the controversial emergency employment program, has re signed following questioning by the city's Commissioner of In vestigation, Robert K. Ruskin.

title: STOCKS CONTINUE TO LOSE GROUND
description: The stock market took an other dip yesterday as Wall Street added a new worry to its long list of old worries.

title: Ladder Carrier Is Killed
description: HALIFAX, Vt., Sept. 21 (AP) Seymour O'Connor, 40 years old, of Halifax, was killed yes terday when a metal ladder he was carrying came in contact with electrical lines.

title: New Gouverneur Opens As the 19th City Hospital
description: New York's 19th municipal hospital, the new Gouverneur, was formally opened yesterday in a joyful polyglot dedication ceremony reflecting the institu tion's constituency.

title: Trust Suit Cites Cowboys
