description: DALLAS, Sept. 21 (UPI)A disgruntled fan filed a $50mil lion suit in Federal Court to day, charging the Dallas Cow boys with violating antitrust laws by requiring season ticketholders to buy preseason tickets. Richard E. Driskill, who filed the suit, also con tended ticketholders were il legally forced to buy preseason tickets to get season tickets for regular games.

title: Jean Shepherd Draws Agencies
description: Jean Shepherd fans who think they've spotted his voice on quite a few radio commercials lately are absolutely right. The humorist has indeed been discovered by advertising land and has a whole bunch of TV spots coming up as well.

title: Donald Walker of Upsala, Baseball Coach, Dies at 59
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 21 (AP)Donald B. Walker, baseball coach at Upsala Col lege here for 26 years, died yesterday at the Arnot Ogden Hospital in Elmira, N. Y. He was 59 years old.

title: Gas Exploration Planned
description: The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company announced yes terday that it has received Fed eral Power Commission appro val for a major new gas ex ploration program to be under taken through a new subsidi ary, Pan Eastern Exploration Company.

title: GOVERNOR SEEKS HOGAN'S SUPPORT FOR PROSECUTOR
description: Governor Rockefeller met with District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for two and a half hours yesterday in an effort to persuade the Manhattan prosecutor not to go to court to challenge the Governor's ap pointment of a special super seding prosecutor for cases of corruption among officials in the city.

title: Patterson Collects His Pay. Prepares to Resume Drills
description: Floyd Patterson, his left eye wrapped in gauze, returned to Madison Square Garden yester day to pick up a $125,000 check for fighting Muhammad Ali Wednesday night and then headedfor his New Paltz, N. Y., home to resume training.

title: Union Leader for Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  (UPI)  John F. Griner, pres ident of the American Federa tion of Government Employes today personally endorsed Pres ident Nixon for reelection.

title: Soviet Union Reported to Ship
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21 Highly placed procommando sources said today that the recent shipment of Soviet weapons to the Arab guerrilla organization Al Fatah con sisted only of conventional small arms and did not include terrorist devices or other ad vanced equipment.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: An agreement to sell the BarbizonPlaza Hotel at 106 Central Park South between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue has been reached, the purchase price has not been disclosed.

title: Miss Schumer Wed To Ronald Weiss
description: Miss Helen Schumer, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Schumer of Forest Hills, Queens, was married here yesterday afternoon to Ron ald Michael Weiss, son of Morton N. Weiss of East Hills, L. I., and the late Mrs. Bette Eckman. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony in Temple Israel.

title: M'GOVERN ACCUSED OF PARROTING HANOI
description: CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 21 (AP)  Vice President Agnew accused Senator George Mc Govern tonight of parroting the propaganda of the North Vietnamese and in helping to destroy the morale of thou sands of Americans who are not in possession of the facts about Communist brutality in Indochina.

title: 3 Theater Officials Seized in Midtown In Obscenity Cases
description: The chief corporate officers of three midtown movie houses were arrested yesterday on obscenity charges after war rants were issued by two Crim inal Court judges who viewed films shown at the theaters.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH, DRINK DEWAR'S William Lawson's 86.8 Proof Blended Scotch ?? Imported by Palmer & Lord. Ltd. Syosset, N. Y.Advt.

title: Israeli Says Peace Talks Must Wait End of Terror
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  An Israeli source reported to day that Israel was advising friendly governments that she would refuse to participate in further diplomatic negotiations for a Middle East peace settle ment until all Arab terrorism was eradicated.

title: Balasaraswati Dances in Classic Style
description: The greatest artists are the most exacting and cer tainly Balasaraswati, one of India's very greatest dancers, demanded no less of herself than she did of her audience and her musicians in her extraordinary concert Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Music: Boulez Streamlines Haydn
description: With the very first piece of the first concert of the sub scription season of the New York Philharmonic, last night in Philharmonic Hall, Pierre Boulez demonstrated how to make a 30minute symphony last 20 minutes. The work in question was Haydn's Sym phony No. 31, the Horn Signal, so named because of its opening horn calls.

title: Lowenstein Bars Third Election After Two Defeats by Rooney
description: Former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein, twice defeated by Representative John J. Rooney for the Democratic nomination in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District, said yesterday he would not ask the courts for another rerun.

title: StockList Consultant Is Named by Big Board
description: Herbert Morton Ball, who re cently retired as secretary and general counsel of the Johns Manville Corporation, has be come a consultant to the de partment of stock list of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: UFO AGAIN SCORES IN JUMPER CLASS
description: WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 21UFO, a surefooted 8yearold chestnut gelding owned and ridden by Fred Bauer of Weston, Conn., won his second straight amateur owner jumper class at the Eastern States horse show to day.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.4 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 122.8 from 122.4 last week.

title: Agnew Disputes Account Of Wheat Inquiry Origin
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 21Vice President Agnew today labeled as inaccurate a report that the White House, in an attempt to avoid embarrassing him, or dered a fourth official investi gation of American wheat sales to the Soviet Union.

title: Brewers Set Back Yanks, 64; Tigers Beat Boston, Close Gap
description: BOSTON, Sept. 21  The latest battle for first place in the American League's East opened here tonight with the Detroit Tigers mauling the Boston Red Sox, 103, and muscling their way into a vir tual tie for the top.

title: 5 BIRDIES IN ROW PUT JONES AHEAD
description: ROBINSON, Ill., Sept. 21 (AP)Grier Jones birdied five holes in a row en route to a 66 and the lead today in the rainsoaked firstround of the $100,000 Robinson Fall Golf Classic. Jones posted his five underpar score on the 6,556 yard Crawford Country Club course. He was one stroke in front of Hale Irwin, Larry Zieg ler and Dave Glenz, a rookie.

title: ASHE VANQUISHED IN PACIFIC TENNIS
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (UPI)  Robert Carmichael of Australia upset Arthur Ashe of Miami, 63, 46, 62, today in thirdround play of the $60,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament. Ashe was seeded second.

title: Credit Markets
description: Still displaying a lack of any overarching trend, the various segments of the bond market pursued their own courses again yesterday. On balance, interest rates tended to rise.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Dr. Seymour C. Post (letter Sept. 11) labors to revive those tired bicker ings of yesteryear when each specialist found it profitable to disparage com peting approaches to mental illness. Psychiatrists, with more conviction than proof, insisted that a degree in medicine was essential to the render ing of any form of therapy.

title: F. T. C. COMPLAINT SET ON KORVETTES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UNI) The Federal Trade Commis sion said today it would issue a complaint charging Korvettes department stores and its NAC credit subsidiary with sending out unsolicited credit cards.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Less than seven weeks before the election, the Republicans have moved to counter the ex panding television campaign of Senator George McGovern.

title: MONEY, EDUCATION HELD MARRIAGE AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) The more money a married couple makes and the more ed ucation they have, the greater the chances of the marriage surviving, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Credito Italiano Sets Deal
description: ROME, Sept. 21  Credito Italiano, one of Italy's three largest banks, has formally agreed to sell 31 per cent of its share capital to Britain's National Westminster Bank. Credito Italiano will retain the majority interest. The two banks are members of the Orion In ternational Finance Group, which also includes the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Royal Bank of Canada.

title: DONALD DICKSON, 61, EXBARITONE AT MET
description: Donald Dickson, Metropoli tan Opera baritone and concert singer who retired in 1961, died yesterday of a heart attack at Menorah Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 61 years old and lived at 317 West 83d Street.

title: COMMON CAUSE SETS A CONGRESS CANVASS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Common Cause said today that it would seek to learn the position of every Senate and House candidate on Congres sionalreform issues.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: S.I. Hospital Workers Return

title: Halloween Penalty Levied
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 (UPI) Richard Wright, 23 years old, of Baltimore, was sentenced in four years in prison yesterday on conviction of placing hits of glass in halloween candy given two young trickortreat ers.

title: 7 CONVICTS FLEE PRISON IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, Friday, Sept. 22  Seven prisoners sawed through window bars and es caped from the Vroom Building for incorrigibles of Trenton State Prison last night.

title: Books of The Times
description: It was a great crippled crosseyed one winged goony birdthe Federal Writers' Project. Or so it appears to be when Jerre Mangione introduces us to it as it was settling down on its deathbed in 1939. A great crippled bird getting its neck wrung by the Dies Committee because it appeared to be the most vulnerable animal in the New Deal menag erie  A cross eyed bird with its right claw hope lessly tangled in bureaucratic red tape and its left claw helplessly getting chewed off by New York City revolutionaries  A most unlikely bird to begin with simply because the Federal Gov ernment couldn't, on the one hand, pay writers to eschew their per sonal opinions and still expect them to be writers; and it couldn't, on the other hand, pay writers to say whatever they wanted to, and still survive as the Federal Government. (We believe that [the books produced by the Federal Writers' Project] contain far less personal bias than is usually found in books dealing with the American scene, wrote the project's di rector, Henry G. Alsberg, in defense of his pet in 1939as if a book's lack of per sonal bias were something to be proud of.)

title: ICB Seeking to Acquire An Insurance Company
description: The ICB Corporation, $162 million parent company of the International City Bank & Trust Company in New Orleans, is actively negotiating to acquire a fire and casualty insurance company, Eads Poitevent, chairman of the company, said yesterday in an interview. He did not identify the insurance concern.

title: R. IRA PENNOCK
description: R. Ira Pennock, who retired as a cashier for the New York Racing Association three years ago, died Wednesday in Roose velt Hospital after having been injured in a fall. He was 73 years old and lived at 244 West 74th Street.

title: TANAKA Will FLY TO PEKING MONDAY
description: TOKYO, Sept. 21Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan is scheduled to fly to Peking on Monday to extend diplomatic recognition to Communist China in Japan's most far reaching international initiative since the end of World War II.

title: Market Place: Tire Turnaround Still a Rut
description: In the eternal quest for turnaround situations much of Wall Street occasionally will focus on a single stock or a single industry all at once.

title: 3.5 MILLION ACRES URGED FOR WILDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  President Nixon asked Congress today to add 16 areas, com prising 3.5 million acres, to the nation's wilderness system.

title: AUGUST W. SCHELL
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 21Au gust W. Schell, who retired in 1965 as corporate secretary of the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad, died Tuesday at his home. He was 72 years old.

title: Police Are Near Bottom In Strength, Murphy Says
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy told a City Council committee yesterday that the Police Department was near the bottom line in precinct strength and would not be able to absorb the scheduled cut back of 1,200 more men in the next year without impairment of its functions.

title: RYDER PURCHASES 5,500 NEW TRUCKS
description: Ryder Truck Rental, a sub sidiary of the Ryder System, Inc., announced yesterday that it had purchased about $35 million worth of trucks. It said 5,500 vehicles had been pur chased from the International Harvester Company, General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company.

title: Infinity Wins at Freehold
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 21 (AP)Infinity won the $4,000 Garfield Pace today at Free hold Raceway. He covered the mile in 2:08 3/5 and paid $5.20 for $2 to win.

title: Dance: A Ballet Theater Innovation
description: TRENTONWhat do you do with young dancers? Or rather, what do you do if you are running a ballet company and need to give them ex perience of dancing leading roles? American Ballet The ater has come up with a bright, new answer, and I saw the results of it earlier this week at the War Me morial Auditorium here.

title: Wide Range of Movie Fare Coming Up
description: A look at the motionpic ture scene for the fall and winter seasons suggests the shape if not the symmetry of an encyclopedia running from Aabenraa (a town In Den mark) to Zygohyllaceae (a family of herbs).

title: Real Hunters and Gun Controls
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.I was a ten yearold kid raking walnut leaves on a crystal autumn morning when a pair of redcapped gunners walked up our lane and asked my father's permission to hunt our three acres. He cheerfully agreed. Until that morning, he always had.

title: MRS. HENRY L. WILLET
description: AMBLER, Pa., Sept. 22 Mrs. Muriel Crosby Willet, vice president and director of the Willet Stained Glass Studios of Phildelphia, died at her home here Tuesday. She was 70 years old and lived at Willow Wadi Farm, Meetinghouse Road. Her husband, Henry Lee Willett, is chairman of the studios.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Army opened its 1957 football season by trouncing Nebraska, 420. That was stand and operating procedure for the cadets, who won 16 opening games in the 18 years Earl Blaik was coach (19411958). Blaik's biggest problem for an opener in those days was to get his cadets concerned about it.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: MAYS LANDING, Sept. 22 (AP)The police were search ing for a 27yearold burglary suspect who escaped from the Atlantic County Jail here today.

title: U.A.W. Aide Suspended
description: DETROIT, Sept. 22 (UPI)A United Automobile Workers of ficer has been suspended as an insurance representative for a local because of charges of kickback and bribery. The Lo cal 47 offical, Ronald Smith, was accused of charging a member for filling out an in surance claim and expediting its payment. The allegations came from workers at the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Major Ulster Concession
description: By ending the practice of internment without trial, Britain has gone as far as Catholic leaders of Northern Ireland could reasonably expect in its effort to gain their participation in an allparty conference on Ulster's future. It is disheartening that, after this major British conces sion, the Social Democratic and Labor party, chief spokes man for 500,000 Catholics, is still threatening to boycott the talks, beginning Monday in the north of England.

title: JAMES HOGE DIES; LAWYER WAS 71
description: James F. Hoge, senior part ner in the law firm of Rog ers Hoge & Hills and an au thority in the law of trade marks, unfair competition and trade regulation, died yester day at New York Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 960 Park Avenue.

title: City Subways Given Four Top Places On List of Noises
description: New York City's subway sys tem has the world's noisiest stations, trains, highspeed ex press runs and screeching curves, according to a study announced yesterday.

title: Utah Power Expanding
description: The Utah Power & Light Company awarded yesterday the. StearnsRogers Corporation of Denver the engineering con tract for a new 430,000kilo watt generating unit scheduled for operation by 1977. The basic cost of the unit has been estimated at $100million but if built subject to more strin gent environmental regulations or at an alternate site its cost is expected to increase sub stantially, the utility said.

title: Norway Split on Eve of Market Vote
description: OSLO, Norway, Sept. 22On the eve of the referendum that will decide whether Norway joins the European Economic Community, the voters are bit terly divided and a mood of tense uncertainty has settled lover this far north country of fords and forests.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: EAST WINDSOR, Sept. 22 The police were still trying to learn the identity today of two persons killed late last night in a spectacular accident on the New Jersey Turnpike that also injured 32 other persons.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The Far Eastern bandwagon has been jumped on by still another store: Gimbels. But the leviathan on 32d Street is offering some interesting differences.

title: Gas Company Expected to File Late Appeal House Action Pending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22A House subcommittee concluded hearings today on a bill that would make legal an El Paso Natural Gas Company acquisi tion whose divestiture the Su preme Court has ordered.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: One would have thought the man ner in which the Uganda Government has handled the problem of reducing the influence of Asians in the coun try's economy was insult enough to civilized procedure. But President Idi Amin now offers an additional vulgar ity in his remark in support of Nazi barbarism against European Jewry. (News story Sept. 13.)

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 22An inflated rubber donkey fell over with a loud thud just as Sen ator George McGovern's wife, Eleanor, began quoting her husband's Come home, Amer ica speech, in the party room of a bowling alley here the other night.

title: Car Removal Starts For State Employes Lacking $5 Permits
description: ALBANY, Sept. 22 (UPI) The Rockefeller administration began towing away cars of state workers today that did not display the new $5 monthly parking permit.

title: Autumn Arrives
description: The autumnal equinox oc curred at 5:33 P.M. yesterday, signaling the first day of fall north of the Equator and the first day of spring south of it During the autumnal equinox, the sun crosses the Equator and day and night are every where of equal length.

title: Boston Regains Full Game on Detroit, 32
description: BOSTON, Sept. 22The De troit Tigers lost both Bill Free han and their halfshare in first place tonight when they dropped a 32 decision to the Boston Red Sox before the largest baseball crowd of the year at Fenway Park.

title: ARREST OF 3 FOILS $650,000 ROBBERY
description: The arrest of three men on narcotics charges prevented an attempt to carry out a robbery of $650,000 worth of cocaine that had been planned for yes terday, according to Thomas J. Mackell, District Attorney of Queens.

title: FINANCE CHIEFS STRESS REFORMS
description: LONDON, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Commonwealth Finance Min isters stressed tonight the im portance and urgency of re forming the international mone tary system.

title: PHILS BEAT METS IN 11 INNINGS, 54
description: Despite a threerun homer by Bill Sudakis in his first start as catcher for New York and onehit relief pitching for al most five innings by Tug Mc Graw last night, the Mets lost in 41 innings to the Philadel phia Phillies, 54, at Shea Sta dium.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: EUGENE, Ore., Sept. 22 (UPI)American athletes were victims of outright thievery at the Olympics, Bill Bowerman, coach of the United States men's track team, said today. He cited rulings in the shotput, pole vault and 1,600meter relay.

title: OZZARD FORESEES LOWER BUS DEFICIT
description: NEWARK, Sept. 22William E. Ozzard, president of the State, Public Utilities Commis sion, said yesterday he doubted Transport of New Jersey would lose as much as the $13million deficit it had projected for this year.

title: Teachers Approve 3Year Pact By an Overwhelming Margin
description: The city's teachers, as ex pected, have approved their new contract with the Board of Education by an overwhelm ing margin, the United Federa tion of Teachers announced Yesterday.

title: Spare Card Freehold Victor
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 22 (AP)Spare Card won the $4,000 Hackensack Pace at Freehold Raceway today, pacing the mile in 2:04 35. Spare Card, driven by Steve Inekai, paid $5.80, $3.80 and $2.80. Second was Scotch V.O. return ing $4.80 and $4, while the show horse, J. I. Lady, paid $7.40.

title: WHEAT FUTURES INCREASE IN PRICE
description: Wheat prices gained a few cents a bushel in futures trad ing on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. December wheat closed at $2.20 to $2.21 bushel, about 10 cents a bushel below its recent high under heavy speculative buy ing.

title: Spiritual Genocide
description: FLORENCE, ItalyTourists, visitors or observers of Czechoslovakia all agree in one respect: of all Eastern European countries, the deepest de pression, frustration and feeling of hopelessness prevails in Czechoslo vakia.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Scoffing at polls showing the Democratic Presidential ticket lagging far behind the Repub lican slate, Sargent Shriver yesterday campaigned in the streets of Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens, blaming the Nixon Administration for high unem ployment, soaring food costs and freezes on salary increases for the workingman.

title: Business Briefs
description: The pound dropped sharply yesterday in trading that some foreign dealers described as chaotic. The selling wave, the first significant disturbance in the international money markets in more than two months, carried the Brit ish currency down to $2.4342 by the end of the day here in New York. The pound closed here yesterday at $2.4435. In London, it reached $2.4360 at the close.

title: Labor Leader for Nixon
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (AP) Thomas W. Gleason, head of the International Longshore men's Association, said yester day that he would endorse President Nixon for reelection next week.

title: California Regents Reject Rehiring of Angela Davis
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (UPI)Angela Davis will not regain her old job as a philoso phy instructor, the University of California regents decided today.

title: Huge Social Security Rise Approved by Senate Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The Senate Finance Committee approved a vast, $14.6billion package of Social Security bene fits and welfare reforms today after 15 months of delays.

title: Replacing Ryan
description: With the holding of a special primary election ruled out by the restrictive provisions of state law, Democratic committee members from Manhattan and the Bronx will convene Oct. 1 to select a replacement for the late Repre sentative William F. Ryan. The high standard Mr. Ryan set in his twelve years in Congress puts an especially heavy responsibility on those who must now act for his constituency in making that choice.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: NORWOOD, Mass., Sept. 22 (AP)Ronald T. McDonald, an attorney who lost by 165 votes in his bid for the Ninth District Congressional seat in the Re publican primary Tuesday, said today he would seek a recount. Mr. McDonald lost to Howard M. Miller, 3,956 to 4,121.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TOMS RIVER, Sept. 22The principal witness against two state troopers accused of beat ing and branding him during an interrogation today had his bared buttock; examined by the trial jury in the courtroom here.

title: Senator Accuses Rival of Exploiting School Issue
description: DETROIT, Sept. 22Senator George McGovern walked into the thorniest thicket in Michi gan politics today  school busing for integration  and accused President Nixon of us ing the issue for cheap politi cal purposes in the most cyni cal and demagogic way possi ble.

title: WILLIAM P. McMULLAN
description: William Patrick McMullan, former chairman of the Deposit Guaranty Bank and Trust Com pany of Jackson, Miss., and former president of the Missis sippi Bankers Association, died Thursday in Jackson at the age of 70.

title: WAINWRIGHT BACK AT KANSAS CITY
description: One of the pleasures of re viewing pop music is hearing a performer pull everything together  especially if his skills have raised doubts in the past. Several months ago I heard singersongwriter Lou don Wainwright 3d working at a small club, liked his songs, disliked his singing and sug gested he should spend more time writing and less time performing.

title: A Saigon Paper Is Punished for Article Describing Extent of U.S. Air Support
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 22An issue of a Saigon daily newspaper was confiscat ed by the Government, its edi tors charge, for having pub lished a report extolling the air support the United States gave in the battles of Quang tri province.

title: Trend to Cuts in Traffic Patrols Seen in Closing of a Queens Unit
description: The Police Department's traffic division unit in Queens, created for the 1939 World's Fair, is closing Monday and its 125 men will be transferred to patrol work. It is the last of the department's traffic units outside of Manhattan.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 22 (UPI)Peter Butler, captain of the British Professional Golfers Association, crammed 10 birdies into a single round today to capture the lead in the $37,500 Wills open golf tournament. The 40yearold Ryder Cup player shot a nineunderpar 63 to clip two shots from the course record set earlier this week by South African Dale Hayes on the 6,639yard, par72 Dalmahoy course.

title: Social Troubles Deepen
description: MANILA, Sept. 5  This tropical republic was a trou bled land even before one of the worst natural disasters in history, the Central Luzon floods, devastated the richest part of the Philippines this summer.

title: President Says Leniency Harms Drive on Drugs
description: RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex., Sept. 22President Nixon, tour ing south Texas before large and friendly crowds, attacked today what he called permis sive judges whose leniency left a weak link in the coun try's efforts to rid the streets of pushers of hard drugs.

title: CARL J. RAUH DEAD; CINCINNATI LEADER
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 21Carl J. Rauh, president since 1966 of the Jewish Hospital here, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Houston, where he had undergone open heart sur gery Aug. 11. He was 67 years old.

title: Port Notes
description: A dispute over the number of deck officers to be as signed to each of eight new highspeed containerships halted nationwide operations of SeaLand Service, Inc., yesterday. Masters of Sea Land vessels in United States ports, acting on instructions of their union, the Interna tional Organiza tion of Masters, Mates and Pilots, stopped work yes terday morning on 12 ships in seven ports. The union had informed them by telegram Thursday that it had given the com pany 24 hours notice that the union was following its tradi tional policy of no contract, no work.

title: Ulster Catholics Critical Of Plan for Special Court
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 22The British Govern ment's decision to set up a special court to try internees in Northern Ireland was con demned today as another form of internment by Roman Catholic political leaders.

title: Defense Chief Unharmed
description: MANILA, Saturday, Sept. 23 Martial law was imposed throughout the Philippines at 2 A.M. today.

title: Blur on Capitol Hill
description: Calloused as most Americans have become to revela tions of undue influence by lobbyists, it is still shocking to learn of the intrigue that continues to surround Con gressional consideration of housing legislation despite the repeated scandals in that field.

title: WRIGHT, WITH 281, WINS BY 11 SHOTS
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept 22 Jimmy Wright, who led from start to finish, won the Marlboro New York State Pro fessional Golfers' Association championship today by the rec ord margin of 11 strokes.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.2% IN AUGUST AND 2.9% FOR YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  Consumer prices rose two tenths of 1 per cent in August, continuing the relatively mod erate rate of inflation that has prevailed for about a year, the Labor Department reported to day.

title: New NewspaperRecycling Test Slated for Brooklyn and Queens
description: Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Ad ministrator, announced yester day a new concentrated at tempt to collect old newspapers separately so they can be re ??

title: Another Commuter Knifed in Harlem
description: A 60yearold psychiatrist on his way home to White Plains was assaulted, robbed and stabbed Thursday night Clear an East 125th Stree't bar that had been raided last sum mer as a suspected hangout of drug sellers and users.

title: TV: C.B.S. Still Serious About Series Comedies
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System, stanchly retaining faith in situation comedy, has inserted three new halfhours into its schedule for Sunday evening. There's Anna and the King at 7:30, M*A*S*H at 8 and The Sandy Duncan Show at 8:30. And they lead into The New Dick Van Dyke Show, which wasn't particularly new even when it began last season.

title: F.D.A. CURBS USE OF GERMICIDE TIED TO INFANT DEATHS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  The Food and Drug Administra tion put under strict control to day the germ killer hexachloro phene. The germicide, which is commonly used in the home, has been linked to the deaths of 39 French babies this year.

title: Army Aim Is to Upset Nebraska
description: Army opened its 1957 football season by trouncing Nebraska, 420. That was stand ard operating procedure for the cadets, who won 16 opening games in the 18 years Earl Blaik was coach (19411958). Blaik's biggest problem for an opener in those days was to get his cadets concerned about it.

title: NATO War Games End in Victory, But Norway Defense Problem Stays
description: TROMSO, Norway, Sept. 22  The mud  stained infantry, the ships and the planes were redeploying today after the North Atlantic Treaty Organi zation's exercise Strong Ex press, the biggest military ex travaganza this bleak region has ever seen.

title: Art: Miniatures at the Japan House
description: The new exhibition at the Japan House Gallery, 333 East 47th Street, consists of 549 objectsthat's a whop ping numberranging from small to tiny, executed with craftsmanship that ranges from meticulous to excruci ating, in patterns where de tail is delicate at its boldest and next to invisible at its finest. Each object in the collection was meant to exist in intimate relationship to its owner, yielding its de lights over years of posses sionwhich makes anything like a full appreciation of The Magnificent Three: Lac quer, Netsuke, and Tsuba impossible even for anyone who already knows what netsuke and tsuba are. But even during a hopskipand jump introductory visit you cannot fail to land on a se ries of plesures.

title: Theater: Belgian Troupe at La Mama
description: The plays performed by Belgium's Theater Labora toire Vicinal have no mes sage, characters or plot. It is a theater of action. The basic content is actors and props. Beginning with a playwright's script, abetted by a director, the actors improvise, using objects and their own bodies in relation to the objects to create images and to con struct events. The work is not propelled by logic but by inspiration.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On Aug. 22, when the news first broke of Uganda's President, General Amin, deporting Asians from Uganda, I wrote you calling attention to the marked similarity between this action and Hitler's persecution of the Jews and the decision of the International Tribunal at Nuremberg with respect to these crimes against humanity.

title: Antiques: Alexander Hamilton's Chairs on Display
description: French influence is really obvious in the American made chairs originally owned by Alexander Hamilton that have just been put on exhi bition in the thirdfloor Fur niture Galleries of the Muse um of the City of New York.

title: Business Briefs
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 22 (UPI)A major steel company announced today that it had revived a practice of more than a century agousing raw coal as a blast furnace charge. A Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company vice president, Tom Cleary, said the concern began experi menting with raw bituminous coal as a substitute for coke in December, 1970. Now it is a regular practice to use 6 to 7 per cent coal in every charge, he said.

title: RALLY BY RUSSIANS BEATS CANADA, 54
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22  With a frantic fivegoal surge in the third period, the Soviet nation al hockey team came from be hind tonight for a 54 victory over the Canadian profession als, who had outclassed the Russians with a more aggres sive offense and tighter de fense for most of the first two periods.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ROANOKE, Va., Sept. 22 Vice President Agnew conclud ed his first swing through the South today with two speeches that denounced Senator George McGovern for consistent in consistency and proposals that Mr. Agnew said jeopardized national security.

title: Months Late, U.S. To Aid World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The United States, 15 months after its original deadline, fi nally notified the World Bank today that it would make its agreedupon contribution of $320million a year for three years to the International De velopment Association, the bank's easy loan subsidiary.

title: Executive Changes
description: J. S. Mitchell has been named a vice president of Amax Nickel Refining Company, Inc., a subsidiary of American Metal Climax, Inc.

title: Bridge: Success of Lead Often Hinges On Braving Wrath of Partner
description: Whether to lead your partner's suit against no trump or to prefer an attempt to establish your own suit is a psychological problem as well as a technical one. Partners tend to explode with rage if a failure to lead their suit has disastrous consequences, but they tend to be forgiving, or even oblivious, if the converse occurs.

title: BRAZZAVILLE TAKES ANTIFRENCH ACTION
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Re public, Sept. 22 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Govern ment of this former French colony today announced a series of antiFrench measures, including withdrawal from the organization of Frenchspeak ing African countries.

title: Art Group Gives City Great Walls of Its Own
description: A dozen youths were perched on a scaffolding at the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse on the Lower East Side, dabbing acrylic paint on a wall. They were creat ing a mural, nearly six stories high, depicting sur realistically the suffering and hopes of residents of low income areas.

title: 2d Suit Filed To Lift Curb On Drug Ads
description: A suit challenging the state's ban on the advertising of prescriptiondrug prices by pharmacies was filed in State Supreme Court here yester day by Representative Ben jamin S. Rosenthal, Queens DemocratLiberal; the Con sumer Assembly and Etta Ringle, a 68yearold Social Security recipient who spends about $17 a month on medicine.

title: Notes on People
description: Pablo Neruda, the 68year old Chilean poetturneddiplo mat, wants to leave his post as Santiago's man in Paris, according to Volodia Teitel boim, a Communist senator in Chile. He said that Ambas sador Neruda, who was sent to France two years ago, wanted to return to his writ ing, which won him the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1971.

title: TANNER TOPPLES ORANTES, 76, 64
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (UPI)Young Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., continued his giantkiller role today by upsetting seventh seeded Manuel Orantes of Spain, 76, 64, in the quarter finals of the $60,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tourna ment.

title: Merger News
description: The Atlantic Richfield Com pany announced yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent under which Pasco, Inc., would acquire its former Sinclair Oil Corporation gasoline marketing properties in 14 Rocky Moun tain and midcontinent states for about $160million, plus pay ment for working capital. Atlan tic Richfield agreed in 1970 to dispose of these properties as a condition of approval under a consent decree that settled Justice Department liti gation arising from its 1969 merger with Sinclair. The letter of intent agreement also in cludes the acquisition by Pasco of certain allied oil refining, production and pipeline prop erties from Atlantic Richfield.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DALLAS, Sept. 22 (AP)Jack Concannon, a quarter back for the Dallas Cowboys, suffered a broken left thumb yesterday while playing on the paddleball court provided by the National Football League club as a conditioning aid. Doctors said he would not be able to play for at least two weeks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: This reader is concerned about the editorial inconsistencies in The Times recently: Murder Made Easy (Sept. ??) laments the appalling number of needless deaths because of easy access to guns. Of 1,155 homicides in 1971, 635 were shootings.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 22Two of seven inmates who escaped last night from a maximum security unit for incorrigible prison in mates at the Trenton State Psychiatric Hospital were re captured this afternoon in a tenement here.

title: City Ballet Is Hailed in Kievas Tour Begins
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R., Sept. 22 The New York City Ballet has been given a warm but not overwhelming reception in this Ukrainian capital at the start of a monthlong tour of the Soviet Union.

title: Teachers in Capital Defy a Court Order; All Schools Closed
description: Striking teachers defied a backtowork court order yes terclay and forced the complete shutdown of schools in Wash ington, D.C.

title: McQueen Asks Jury Trial
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Sept. 22 (Reuters)Steve McQueen, who was arrested by the An chorage police June 28 for reckless driving has requested a trial by jury, now scheduled for Oct. 17.

title: Irish Aid Committee Wins Stay of Order on Records
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)  Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall stayed tem porarily today an Appeals Court ruling that the Irish Northern Aid Committee must turn over to the Federal Bureau of In vestigation all records, includ ing the names of contributors.

title: U.N. to Debate Terrorism Despite China and Arabs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22The issue of terror ism was put on the, General Assembly's agenda today after a debate in which China joined with the Arabs and some of the African states in an effort to block the move.

title: JUDGE SCORES PRESS ON INDICTMENT NEWS
description: BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP)  United States District Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. said yesterday that newspaper pub lication of the criminal records of some of 89 persons indicted last week on gambling charges was a course of conduct which no honorable citizen could doubt was prejudicial.

title: Pope Expresses a Willingness To Rewrite Treaty With Italy
description: ROME, Sept. 22Pope Paul VI said today that the Vatican was ready for a revision of its 43  year  old Concordat with Italy.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Sept. 19.

title: DOW CLIMBS 3.54, REVERSING TREND
description: Stock prices scored their first gain of the week yester day, buoyed somewhat by an encouraging report on the Gov ernment's consumer price index.

title: Allison Betters Record
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., Sept. 22 (UPI)  Bobby Allison of Hueytown, Ala., turned in the fastest lap run by a NASCAR Grand National car at Martins ville Speedway today and won the pole position for Sunday's $52,000 Old Dominion 500 stock car race. Allison, driving a Jun jor Johnson Chevrolet, roared around the track in just over 22 seconds, at a speed of 85.980 miles per hour to break the track record of 84.163 M.P.H.

title: No White House Comment
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 22A spokesman for the tray eling White House that he had no comment on the cable that had been received on Hanoi's terms for the release of the three American prisoners.

title: Huge Social Security Rise Approved by Senate Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The Senate Finance Committee approved a vast, $14.6billion package of Social Security bene fits and welfare reforms today after 15 months of delays.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 22 (AP) An Essex County grand jury has indicted a Newark man on charges of operating a still for the purpose of mak ing moonshine whisky.

title: MET BRINGS BACK GOUNOD'S ROMEO
description: Romo et Juliette, which the Metropolitan restored to the repertory several years ago after a long absence, is not going to stay there unless bet ter singing is provided in the roles than was heard in the season's first performance of the Gounod opera on Thursday night. The score is not good enough to overcome such medi ocrity.

title: UgandaTanzanian Accord on Peace Is Reported
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 22 (Reuters)  President Idi Amin of Uganda and President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania were re ported tonight to have agreed to a peaceful settlement of their differences.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: FLORESVILLE, Tex., Sept. 22 (AP)Sargent Shriver came to Texas tonight to eat tamales on a county courthouse lawn while President Nixon was dining with defecting Democrats at the John B. Connally ranch a few miles away.

title: News Analysis
description: Twelve years ago, a dis tinguished New York judge who once served as an assist ant district attorney under Thomas E. Dewey and Frank S. Hogan gave a speech in Chicago about controlling the abuses found in criminal law enforcement. Judge Charles D. Breitel, now one of the seven members of the highest court in the state, the New York Court of Appeals, argued then that the existing controls over the police and prosecutors were inadequate and that there was a need for statewide centralized administrative su pervision and control.

title: Farasopoulos Gaining Yards and Attention for Jets
description: Chris Farasopoulos is glad to be the National Football League's leading punt return specialist, but he realizes it could be a shortlived honor after the New York Jets take on the Colts tomorrow at Baltimore's Memorial Stadium (WNBCTV Channel 4, 2:05 P.M.)

title: Germicide Used in Cosmetics With Sales Set at $250Million
description: Hexachlorophene, first pat ented in 1941 and commonly used in hospital nurseries to prevent skin infections, has been an ingredient in about $250million worth of cosmetics in recent years. Among the products in which it is used are hygienic sprays, aerosol deo dorants, toothpastes and soaps.

title: Editor Is Convicted
description: SAIGON, Sept. 22 (AP)A Saigon newspaper editor who published excerpts from the Pentagon papers and a Cornell University study on United States bombing in Indochina was convicted by a military court today of confusing pub lic opinion and harming na tional security.

title: Scots' Fancy Wins Upstate
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Sept. 22 (AP)Scot's Fancy took an early lead and was never passed as the 7yearold tri umphed in Finger Lakes Race Track's feature race today. Scot's Fancy beat Early Judge by four lengths in the six fur long race and was timed in 1:13 45. The horse returned $6.60, $5.20, $3.40. Haunting Melody finished third.

title: Mrs. Abzug Gains in Bid for Congress
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug picked up support yesterday in her effort to replace the late Representative William F. Ryan as the Democratic candidate in the 20th Congressional District, but opposition to her also de veloped.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Staff workers in the clut tered offices of the late Rep resentative William F. Ryan in the Cannon House Office Building began putting the signature of W. Pat Jennings, clerk of the House, on their franked mail today. It was a minor matter, perhaps, but it signaled that the Congres sional offices of the 50year old Manhattan Democrat who died last Sunday would be continued until the end of the year. House officials ex plained that it was their pol icy to keep open the offices and retain the staff of a de ceased Representative until a successor took officeas a service to constituents who have problems with their So cial Security checks or some other Federal matter.

title: Beyond Rebellion
description: DETROITThe black movement has gone through a number of stages in the last 15 years. First, there was the civil rights movement which reached a critical stage with the Birmingham confrontations of 1963, and which fi nally collapsed with the assassination of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968. Then, there has been the black power movement which began to rise with Malcolm in 19634; and which mushroomed into a national movement following the Watts uprising of 1965 and the Newark and Detroit rebellions of 1967.

title: Teamwork for Ecology
description: The new SovietAmerican agreement on cooperation in environmental protection has a potential significance going far beyond its vast ecological benefits.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 22  The National Urban League an nounced here today the start of a program to recruit and aid black and Spanishspeaking people to join law enforcement agencies.

title: Snug Harbor Tract Bought By City as Center for Arts
description: The City of New York of ficially completed its acquisi tion of a section of Sailors' Snug Harbor on Staten Island yesterday morning, with the formal closing on 14.5 acres of land at a cost of $1.8million.

title: SCHOOL BUS SAFETY LAGS, PANEL SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The National Transportation Safety Board, citing a New York State crash in which five occupants of a school bus were killed and 45 injured, called today for the prompt elimina tion of structural weaknesses in school bus bodies.

title: Books of The Times
description: Now this is what I call workmanship. There is nothing on earth more ex quisite than a bonny book, with well placed columns of rich black writing in beautiful borders, and illuminated pic tures cunningly inset. But nowadays, instead of looking at books, people read them. A book might as well be one of those orders for bacon and bran that you are scribbling.The Earl of Warwick in George Bernard Shaw's St. Joan.

title: In Ireland, Market Entry Spurs Optimism
description: SHANNON, Ireland, Sept. 22It is the greatest thing that has happened to Ireland since Brian Born defeated the Vikings in 1014 said Bren ?? Swan, executive director of the Irish Industrial Devel opment Authority. He was talking about Ireland's entry into the European Common Market next January.

title: Surrealistic Theme Marks Solo Dance By William Dunas
description: There never was a Wild West quite like the one celebrated Thursday evening by William Dunas in To Love Us Is To Pay Us. Where the original was full of sweat, dust and clatter, Dunas's solo dance was a liquid and impeccably clean mood piece done to a smoothly plucked guitar and recitations.

title: Saigon's Foreign Minister Rejects Foe's Peace Plan
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 22Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam, like President Nguyen Van Thieu two days ago, said today that he rejected the latest Com munist peace proposal, for a tri partite coalition, as a plot of the Communists to take over South Vietnam.

title: Price Changes
description: The Engelhard Minerals & Chemicals Corporation has asked the Price Commission for permission to raise palla dium prices 31.93 per cent. A spokesman for the company said the request had been filed about two weeks ago.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Lodi school's were closed yesterday when more than 100 teachers failed to report for classes. Louis Ingenito, the Superintendent, said he closed the high school, five ele mentary schools and one specialeducation school before any of the system's 3,800 students arrived.

title: PRICEINDEX GAIN TIED TO RENT RISE
description: Higher housing costs and res taurant prices were major factors in a rise of 0.2 per cent in August in the Consumer Price Index for the New York northeastern New Jersey area, the United States Labor Depart ment's Bureau of Labor Statis tics reported yesterday.

title: Saigon Reports Enemy Attacks On Bases Near Quangngai City
description: HONG KONG, Sept 22Three Saturday, Sept. 23 (AP)  Fighting spread closer to the capital of Quangngai Province on the north central coast yes terday as enemy attacks were reported on Government cut posts around the city.

title: KENNEDY, WALLACE DISCUSS CAMPAIGN
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 22 (AP)Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts discussed the Presidential campaign with Gov. George C. Wallace of Ala bama tonight and said after ward that Mr. Wallace's sup port would be meaningful to any candidate.

title: HAROLD P. SEE DIES; RADIOTV PIONEER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (UPI)Harold P. See, a pioneer in radio and television and board chairman of the Chronicle Broadcasting Company, died yesterday of emphysema. He was 65 years old.

title: ROGERS AND EBAN DISCUSS MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 United States and Israeli offi cials agreed today that priority should be given to combating international terrorism al though options must be kept open for peace negotiations in the Middle East.

title: Personalities: Lockman Stays On
description: Carroll (Whitey) Lockman, who was an interim replace ment for Leo Durocher when the Chicago Cubs' fiery man ager was released in mid July, no longer is interim. Philip K. Wrigley, the presi dent of the National League baseball club, said he signed Lockman to a oneyear con tract yesterday.

title: Doubting Daughter Died, Father Offers a Reward
description: HAMBURG, N. Y., Sept. 22 (AP)A man who said he did not believe his daughter died in Lake Ontario after setting out on a raft posted a $2,500 reward today for information leading to her whereabouts.

title: DEBUT IN TRAVIAT A BY A SPANISH TENOR
description: When Jos Carreras walked on stage in the Act I party scene of La Traviata at the State Theater Thursday night, he looked young, timid and just a little frightened.

title: Manes Protests Memorial Here to Arab Terrorists
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens has asked the Board of Higher Education to investigate a silent memorial held for the Arab terrorists killed in Munich. The memorial took place Sept. 8 during an orientation meeting of about 1,000 incoming Manhattan Com munity College freshmen.

title: PRICES ON AMEX MIXED AT CLOSE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market were mixed yesterday in continued dull trading.

title: Metal Demand Aids South Africans
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Sept. 22Employment and higher income for thousands of South African blacks is expect ed as a result of United States automobile companies increas ing hunger for platinum and palladium for use in emission control devices.

title: Roundup: Reds Win Title With Victory Over Astros
description: The pennant race is over in the National League's Western Division.

title: Scotland Yard Will Coordinate Investigation of Bombs by Mail
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, Sept. 22The police here said today that all inter national inquiries into letter bomb terrorism would be cen tralized and coordinated in Lon don.

title: Railroad Requests Permission to Delay Paying 1973 Taxes
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Sept. 22 (AP)The Delaware & Hud son Railroad Company is ask ing municipal governments and, school districts throughout the state to allow the railroad to delay $1.7million in 1973 taxi payments that are due before December.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The British Government has sched uled for September a political confer ence on Northern Ireland's future. Re grettably, the British have restricted attendance at this conference to those parties that were represented in the Northern Ireland parliament which has long since been discredited by the minority in Northern Ireland and by the British Government itself. In ef fect, they have excluded the Govern ment of the Republic of Ireland and they have excluded both the official I.R.A. and the provisional I.R.A.

title: Suffolk Potato Crop One of Its Worst; Weather and Loss of Acreage Factors
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 22 Suffolk County, which pro duces more than half the total potato crop in New York State and is the second largest po tatogrowing county in the na tion, has had one of the worst potato years in a decade, Fed eral agricultural officials said today.

title: A FESTIVE WEEK IS PLANNED HERE
description: The bells in churches across the city will chime for two minutes starting at noon tomor row, and when the echoes have died away, thousands of men, women and children, gathered in parks and playgrounds and on street corners will join hands and observe three min utes of silence.

title: GERMFREE HOME SHIELDS BABY BOY
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22  A Baylor University medical pro fessor told today how a baby named David spent the first year of his life inside a steril ized plastic bubble, unable to come into contact with his parents or the outside world.

title: Explorer 47 Craft, Flying Physics Lab, Launched Into Orbit
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 22 (AP)Explorer 47, an 860 pound flying physics laboratory, was launched tonight toward an orbit extending more than halfway to the moon to probe the solar wind, radiation, mag netic fields and other inter planetary mysteries.

title: Biaggi Scores Lack of Foot Patrolmen
description: Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx, who once was a patrolman in the area of the fatal stabbing Wednesday of a Columbia University law pro fessor, aserted yesterday that the killing might have been prevented had there been a foot patrolman on the desig nated post just a few yards from the scene of the murder.

title: Lebanon Is Said to Have Set Up Liaison Unit With Commandos
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 22 Wellplaced Lebanese inform ants reported today that Arab commando leaders and Leba nese officials had formed a joint liaison committee to over see relations between civil and military authorities here and the 3,000 fulltime commandos estimated to be in Lebanon.

title: P.D.A. CURBS USE OF GERMICIDE TIED TO INFANT DEATHS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  The Food and Drug Administra tion put under strict control to day the germ killer hexachloro phene. The germicide, which is commonly used in the home, has been linked to the deaths of 39 French babies this year.The F.D.A. ordered the recall of products containing large amounts of the chemical.

title: LITTLE ME TAKES JUMPOFF CLEANLY
description: WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 22  Little Me, owned by Harmony Farms of Branch ville, N. J., turned in a per fect performance in the jump off to win the junior jumper stake today at the Eastern States Horse Show.

title: Defense Chief Unharmed
description: MANILA, Saturday, Sept, 23 Martial law was imposed throughout the Philippines at 2 A.M. today.

title: President Says Leniency Harms Drive on Drugs
description: RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex., Sept. 22President Nixon, tour ing south Texas before large and friendly crowds, attacked today what he called permis sive judges whose leniency left a weak link in the coun try's efforts to rid the streets of pushers of hard drugs.

title: Henry de Montherlant Is Dead; French Novelist and Playwright
description: PARIS, Sept. 22Henry de Montherlant, the novelist and playwright, took his life yes terday afternoon by shooting himself in the throat at his home on Quai Voltaire over looking the Seine. He was 76 years old.

title: DESTINATION TAKES FIRST LEG ON CRUISE
description: NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 22  Russell L. Hoyt's 43foot sloop, Destination, and J. M. Gore Friedrichs's 30foot sloop, Skipjack, were the International Offshore Rule Division winners on Long Island Sound last night on the first leg of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual cruise.

title: NEW ORDERS RISE IN DURABLE GOODS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 New orders for durable goods rose strongly in August to a record total of $35.7billion, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: RentaPresident
description: COLUMBUS, OhioNobody has ever asked me anything I've ever wanted to say about this 1972 Presidential election. Nobody. Not ABCTV, which is doing a weekly vivisection of vox populi in this allAmerican city, prompting scores of people who for merly considered themselves superior to try to outaverage each other. Not even The Columbus Dispatch (Ohio's Greatest Home Newspaper), which carries a portable strawvoting booth to county fairs and shopping centers, asking people if they prefer Richard Nixon or abortions on demand. And certainly not the pollsters, who are allegedly feeling pulses somewhere out there in the darkness of the great Gromboolian plains.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Wingtip vortices, the minia ture tornadoes that trail for long distances behind large aircraft, can tear light planes apart or hurl heavier ones to the ground. Prof. Shao W. Yuan of George Washington Univer sity here proposes to control the violent winds by instal ling little jets along the wing ends. Professor Yuan's equipment is protected by Patent 3,692,259, issued this week. It is to undergo wind tunnel tests later this year at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Lang ley Research Center with funds provided by the Air Force.

title: Ban on Hogs to Be Lifted
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 22 (UPI)The ban on shipments of hogs from Indiana to Ken ttucky will be lifted midnight Sunday, state veterinarian Dr. Tom Maddox announced today. Kentucky placed the embargo on importation of Indiana hogs Wednesday when it was dis covered that cholera, a disease fatal to hogs, was widespread in Indiana.

title: Indian Ace Gets 22d Victory Kline Loser
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 22As in the tune, September Song, the days are dwindling down for the Yankees in the pennant race they once were in. An other day dwindled away to night as Cleveland won, 41, behind the plucky pitching of Gaylord Perry.

title: MATRON FAVORITE IS LA PREVOYANTE
description: La Prevoyante, the unbeaten Canadianbred owned by a Montreal insurance executive, JeanLouis Levesque, makes the first appearance of her career in metropolitan New York to day when she competes in the Matron Stakes at Belmont. A $50,000 added sprint for 2 yearold fillies, the Matron's 66th running will be at seven furlongs, rather than six, for the first time.

title: Mrs. King Scores, 61, 61
description: ALBANY, Calif., Sept. 22 (UPI) Mrs. Billie Jean King out classed Julie Heldman today to advance to the semifinals of the $20,000 Golden Gate Pacific Coast tennis tournament.

title: U.N. to Debate Terrorism Despite China and Arabs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22The issue of terror ism was put on the General Assembly's agenda today after a debate in which China joined with the Arabs and some of the African states in an effort to block the move.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 22 (UPI)The Chicago Bulls of the National Basketball Association defeated the American Basketball Association's Utah Stars, 90.86, last night in the opener of a pro basketball tournament at Honolulu International Center Arena.

title: Murder by Mail
description: The new murderbymail technique initiated by Arab terrorists against Israeli diplomats adds a horrible new dimension to the excesses perpetrated by these fanatics. Now that the alarm has been given by the first fatal explosion of a letter bomb in London, the worldwide security measures being taken at Israeli missions make it improbable that more of these missiles will get through to their intended victims. Rather, postal clerks, local policemen and others totally, detached from the ArabIsraeli conflict are placed in jeopardy of death or injury through the movement and handling of this dead ly mail. That danger, coupled with the possibility that other deranged political factions or individuals will take up the same technique, represents another attack on the intricate web of transportation and communication on which the civilized world depends.

title: Senator Accuses Rival of Exploiting School Issue
description: DETROIT, Sept. 22Senator George McGovern walked into the thorniest thicket in Michi gan politics today  school busing for integration  and accused President Nixon of us ing the issue for cheap politi cal purposes in the most cyni cal and demagogic way possi ble.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: When a minor official of the Truman Administration was found to have taken a deep freeze from a favor seeker, or his wife a fur coat, the country rang with cries of scandal and corruption.

title: Business Briefs
description: GENEVA, Sept. 22 (AP)The world's leading cocoa producing and consuming countries have made no progress in the first two weeks of their negotiations to create an in ternational cocoa agreement. And prospects that the closed, monthlong conference would succeed before it ends Oct. 13 appeared highly uncertain today.

title: U.S. DROPS SUBSIDY ON EXPORT WHEAT
description: WASHINGTON. Sept, 22 The Agriculture Department an nounced today after the close of the commodity markets that it was eliminating the export subsidy on wheat.

title: Another Commuter Knifed in Harlem
description: A 60yearold psychiatrist on his way home to White Plains was assaulted, robbed and stabbed Thursday night near an East 125th Street bar that had been raided last sum mer as a suspected hangout of drug sellers and users.

title: U.S. MAPS OPTIONS ON HIJACKING LAW
description: If the antihijacking bill passed by the Senate Thursday be comes law, the Administration contemplates acting only in con junction with other nations to halt air services to countries re fusing to act against hijackers, State Department sources said yesterday.

title: WINTHROP BRUBAKER ADVERTISING AIDE, 60
description: NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 22 Winthrop Brubaker, who re tired last year as manager of advertising and public relations for RollsRoyce Aero Engines, Inc., and later became a con sultant in his field, died today in Norwalk Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in West port.

title: Chairman Resigns Post At Wolverine World Wide
description: Alfred L. Seeyle resigned yes terday as chairman of Wolver ine World Wide, Inc., but will continue as a director. Last month, he resigned as president and chief executive officer, fol lowing charges by dissident stockholders that he held too much Power.

title: CITY SAYS HAIL TO BOBBY FISCHER
description: New York hung a gold medal on Bobby Fischer yesterday.

title: Reed Returns as Knicks Set Back Bullets, 9794
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 22Seconds before the first quarter, ended, Willis Reed snapped the switch off a heat ing pad that he had on his left knce and Danny Whalen, the Knick trainer, put some eye wash into Reed's eyes. The Knick captain was being readied to enter the preseason game in which New York defeated the Baltimore Bullets, 9794, at Monmouth College.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 510,000 com mon shares of the Tesoro Petro leum Corporation reached the market yesterday at $39.50 a share through an underwriting group managed by E. F. Hutton & Co. Of the stock sold in the $20.14million offering 158, 115 shares were for the ac count of stockholders and 351, 885 were for the company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Attendance at Sunday mass in the Archdiocese of New York waned by 23 per cent between 1965 and 1970, accord ing to a study published yesterday by the pastoral research office of the archdiocese.

title: ROGERS AND EBAN DISCUSS MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 United States and Israeli offi cials agreed today that priority should be given to combating international terrorism al though options must be kept open for peace negotiations in the Middle East.

title: CITY FOUND TO LAG ON JOB PROGRAM
description: A yearlong study of the city's handling of the Federally financed emergency employ ment program has found the Lindsay administration making little effort to reach the chronically unemployed and Vietnam veterans, while favor ing teachers and other profes sionals with jobs.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TEANECK, N. J., Sept. 22Ed Donovan has never got sick to his stomach during a crosscountry meet be cause he never eats anything for five hours before a race. He has never been stopped by leg or stomach cramps that couldn't be kneaded out.

title: CITY SAYS HAIL TO BOBBY FISCHER
description: New York hung a gold medal on Bobby Fischer yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: During the last several weeks op position has developed among some residents of Westchester County to a proposal by the Urban Development Corporation to construct 100 low income housing units in nine towns in the county. The issue, however, has been obscured.

title: Mellon Bank's Prime Rite Will Float Up Next Week
description: The Mellon National Bank and Trust Company, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania's largest bank, announced yesterday that its floating prime ratewhich is geared to interest rates in the open market  would be 5 per cent for the week begin ning Monday, up from 5 per cent this week.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 22  Pas sengers hurried off the com muter trains onto platforms at Penn Station here today and walked through what Governor Cahill described as a hall of horrors.

title: NIXON SAID TO GET CABLE ON P.O.W.'S
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 22Three American servicemen who have been released from detention but so far kept in North Viet nam will be permitted to leave for home on the basis of an understanding that they will do nothing further to promote the American war effort in Indo china.

title: Social Troubles Deepen
description: MANILA, Sept. 5  This tropical republic was a trou bled land even before one of the worst natural disasters in history, the Central Luzon floods, devastated the richest part of the Philippines this summer.

title: Arts Big Business, At 23Million in '71, State Study Shows
description: The nonprofit arts are big business in New York State, channeling millions of dollars into local communities. This was disclosed in a study re leased Thursday by the Per forming Arts Association of New York State in cooperation with the New York State As sociation of Museums.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
NEW JERSEY
description: ROBINSON, Ill., Sept. 22 (AP) Bob Menne, who ranks 130th on the current moneywinning list, shot a fiveunderpar 66 today and took the second round lead by one stroke in the $100,000 Robinson fall golf classic.

title: 2 Killed as Plane Crashes On Newark Railroad Track
description: NEWARK, Saturday, Sept. 23 Two persons were killed early today when a cargo plane carrying United States mail crashed in a train yard after it had taken off from the Newark Airport about 500 yards away, the police reported.

title: Mrs. Loyce Butler Married to Thomas Milbank
description: Mrs. Loyce Butler and Thomas Powell Fowler Mil bank were married here on Thursday and are honey mooning in Paris at the bridegroom's apartment on the Place Vendome.

title: Controversial General Will Retire Early
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The Pentagon announced to day the retirement of Gen. Ralph E. Haines Jr., commander of the United States Conti nental Army Command, whose outspoken religious views had prompted controversy earlier this year.

title: Parking Rules Eased For Jewish Holiday
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will be suspended today in the ob servance of the Jewish holi day of Succoth, the Traffic Department announced yes terday.

title: WINE TALK
description: It seemed, for a year or so at least, that good French wines were about to disap pear from the popularpriced American market. Soaring prices were putting the best known bordeaux and burgun dies in a class where only the very rich could afford them, while wine lovers of moder ate means were left to pick among the unknowns from other lands, and the lower priced American bottles.

title: Market Place: Trading Costs And Little Guy
description: Few topics seem to inspire more comment in Wall Street than the role of the small in vestor in the stock market. Almost everyone has a theory on why the Little Guy is not as active as he was.

title: Artists Looking West
description: It is not unusual for our galleries to show the work of artists who live in areas outside the orbit of the New York scene, but such exhibi tions are generally organ ized as an effort to promote the interests of a specific group or tendency.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When the World Cup golf tournament is held in Australia in six weeks, the United States will be rep resented by Tom Weiskopf and Jim Jamieson.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 Mrs. Richard M. Nixon stood on the windswept aerospace base in Northern California, en circled by reporters and obvi ously eager to get back to the mother ship. Yards away loomed the awesome Presidential jet a Boeing 707, silver and pale blue, with United States of America leaping out in black capital letters the length of its fuselage.

title: Randy Johnson Gets His Job Back
description: Randy Johnson will be the quarterback for the New York Giants tomorrow against the Dallas Cowboys at Yankee Sta dium, Coach Alex Webster finally declared yesterday.

title: Relativity Theory Awaits Affirmation
description: Measurements of the delay ing effect of solar gravity on radio signals between Califor nia and a spacecraft orbiting Mars have been made with sufficient accuracy, the experi menters believe, to settle once and for all the nature of this aspect of Einstein's general relativity theory.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept  Jimmy Wright, who led from start to finish, won the Marlboro New York State Pro fessional Golfers' Association championship today by the rec ord margin of 11 strokes.

title: Green Thumb Proves a Boon to Elderly Rural Poor
description: COBLESKILL, N.Y., Sept. 22Harold A. Buckner sits in a little office on Main Street here, directing an op eration that is a boss's dream come true.

title: RISE IS PREDICTED FOR MONEY COSTS
description: The cost of money is likely to rise quite sharply in the next 12 months, an investment econo mist told the New York State Bankers Association here yes terday.

title: Auto Output at a High
description: DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP)  The nation's auto industry has scheduled overtime tomorrow at 14 assembly plants in what will be the highest level of pro duction this year, according to Automotive News.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I feel that it is time for an inquiry into and the public disclosure of the reasons Governor Rockefeller is at tempting to force lowcost public housing upon the unwilling residents of the area adjacent to Floyd Bennett Field.

title: Queens Woman Tied at Hearing To Concentration Camp Deaths
description: A Warsaw dentist, interned in the World War II concentra tion camp at Maidanek, Poland, from January, 1943, to April, 1944, said at a Federal hearing yesterday that she saw Hermine Braunsteiner, a former prison guard, help select Jew ish women to be sent to gas chambers in August, 1943.

title: Lowell Tech Names Head
description: LOWELL, Mass. Sept. 22 (AP)  Everett V. Olsen, act ing president of Lowell Tech nological Institute since Febru ary, was named president of the school last night by the board of trustees. He will take over his duties immediately on a contract that runs to July 31 1974.

title: MENNE, WITH 136, LEADS BY STROKE
description: ROBINSON, Ill., Sept. 22 (AP) Bob Menne, who ranks 130th on the current moneywinning list, shot a fiveunderpar 66 today and took the second round lead by one stroke in the $100,000 Robinson fall golf classic.

title: Metropolitan Museum to Auction Coins in Zurich
description: A huge collection of ancient gold and silver coins belonging to the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be auctioned in three stages in Zurich, Switzerland, beginning Nov. 10.

title: CHARLES R. McCLUSKY
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 22 Charles R. McClusky, an office manager for the Union Carbide Corporation in Man hattan, died here today in Law rence Hospital after a brief ill ness. He was 63 years old and lived at 50 Kingston Avenue, Yonkers.

title: Trading in Wheat: A Closer Look
description: Question: How does a farmer market his wheat?

title: LOCAL BOARD TOLD TO ASSIGN PUPILS
description: Deputy School Chancellor Irv ing Anker yesterday directed the community school board of District 18 in Brooklyn to im mediately place children from the largely black Tilden Houses project in Brownsville in junior high schools in the district where integrated education would be possible.

title: FOUR ARE ARRAIGNED IN TRADE OF A BABY
description: IMMOKALEE, Fla., Sept. 22 (AP)A couple accused of try ing to adopt a threemonth old baby boy in exchange for a used car, and two alleged wit nesses to the transaction, were arraigned today on felony charges in Criminal Court.

title: Drive for a U. N. Debate on Korea Is Reopened
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22Allies of North Korea tonight reopened their drive to have the reunification of Korea taken up by the 27th General Assembly.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.2% IN AUGUST AND 2.9% FOR YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  Consumer prices rose two tenths of 1 per cent in August, continuing the relatively mod erate rate of inflation that has prevailed for about a year, the Labor Department reported to day.

title: D.A. SILENT ON TALK WITH THE GOVERNOR
description: In the aftermath of the meet ing Thursday between Governor Rockefeller and District Attor ney Frank S. Hogan, city offi cials waited yesterday to see how, if at all, the Governor's special superseding prosecutor to fight corruption would be affected by their talk.

title: TACTIC BY BRANDY FORCES ELECTION
description: BONN, West Germany, Sept. 22As he had planned, Chan cellor Willy Brandt lost a par liamentary vote of confidence in the West German Lower House tonight.

title: Man Killed on L.I. Expressway As Parked Patrol Car Is Struck
description: One person was killed and at least eight others injured on the Long Island Expressway last night when a motorist hit a police car that had stopped to investigate a minor threecar accident; the result was a multi car collision that tied up traffic for miles.

title: Cooking Schools in City and Country
description: Cooking schools abound in the city and suburbs. Follow ing is a supplemental list to one provided earlier this month. The quality of in struction of the schools has not been evaluated and men tion of a course should not be considered an endorse ment.

title: BERNARD BERK
description: Dernard Berk, a manufac turers' representative in chil dren's sportswear, died Wednes day at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 45 years old and lived in Baldwin, L. I.

title: Union Will Be Neutral
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (UPI)  The 77,000  member Glass Bottle Blowers Associa tion today announced that it would not endorse a Presiden tial candidate this year.

title: Nickel Prices Are Raised
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 22 (UPI)Kaiser Nickel announced today that it was raising prices for ferronickel products. The company said it was increasing the prices of KFN3 12 2cents a pound to $1.42 a pound of nickel contained and of KFN4 by 9 centts a pound to $1.37.

title: A Compulsion for Living With Clutter
description: If Buddy Noro had a prob lem in the decorating of his Greenwich Village home, it was not where to start, but when to stop.

title: Savings and Loan Group Is Exuberant on Outlook
description: CORONADO, Calif., Sept. 22I've never seen people sock it away like this, said John J. Goodwin, executive vice president of the Gibraltar Savings and Loan Association.

title: Efficiency Yardstick
description: The heads of most city agencies are about to file with Mayor Lindsay reports designed to show for the first time in municipal history how much progressor retrogressionthey are making in meeting goals for increased employe efficiency.

title: R. H. MACY SHOWS RISE IN EARNINGS
Patricia Coyle Bride
description: Miss Patricia Maureen Coyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Coyle of New York and Southampton, L. I., was married yesterday morning to Daniel Francis Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Adams of Norwich, Conn. The Rev. Vincent M. Daly performed the ceremony in St. Mary Help of Christians Roman Catholic Church in Woodside, Queens.

title: L.S.U. Beats Texas A. and M.
description: BATON ROUGE, Sept. 23 (AP)Louisiana State, stymied by Texas A. and M. for a first half, rallied in the second half tonight to record a 4217 victory.

title: Marriage Held For Jill Harris
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 Miss Jill Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Miller Harris of Elkins Park, was married here this evening to Dr. John H. Herman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Herman of Hawthorne, N. J. Rabbi David H. Wice per formed the ceremony in Con gregation Rodeph Shalom.

title: So What Else Is New?
description: Re Stanley Hoffmann and his comment on Frances Fitz Gerald's Fire in the Lake.

title: EXPEDITION PLANNED IN SNOWMAN'S LAND
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 23 (Reuters)Six young American scientists are preparing for an extensive expedition into east ern Nepal that may establish once and for all if the Yeti, or abominable snowman, exists.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: The shallowness and the stupidity of Barnes's comment are epitomized in his closing paragraph. If George McGov ern is elected President, he writes, he could do worse than appoint [Colonel] King Secre tary of Defense.

title: TAIWAN IS BITTER AT TOKYO'S MOVES
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 23 As the military police were re storing order after student dem onstrators had threatened the mortorcade of Etsusaburo Shiina, the special envoy of Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan, at the Taipei airport ear lier this week, a young televi sion reporter approached a Western newsman of his ac quaintance.

title: Shea Named Recipient Of First Hodges Award
description: William A. (Bill) Shea will receive the first Gil Hodges memorial award. Thursday. Bishop Francis J.
