Mugavero of the Brooklyn Diocese will make the presentation at the award dinner in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel. The dinner is for the benefit of the Catholic Medical Center.

title: GERMICIDE LIMIT STIRS CONFUSION
description: Managers of retailoutlet stores selling a broad variety of household products contain. ing hexachlorophene expressed confusion yesterday over what to do following a Federal deci sion to limit the sale and use of the germ killer.

title: Treat this problem like a war effort
description: On the cover of Morton Hunt's recently published book, The Mugging, there is an illustration of a dark complexioned arm around the neck of a bald eagle holding a knife against the bird's throat. One possible interpre tation of this picture is that white America is being mugged by black America the symbolism is there. The cover of the same book tells us that mugging is America's most feared crime.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23It is now clear that Republican denials of re sponsibility for the sinister Watergate espionage case issued from the White House down have been a tissue of lies.

title: How to make the city safe again
description: How to reduce crime How to reduce police corruption How to make the city safe again

title: Met Stages HighPowered Un Ballo
description: The Metropolitan Opera's performance of Un Ballo in Maschera on Friday night was the the kind that justifies the com pany's existence. In part this might have been anticipated, because the cast was headed by three singers who are now at the top of their form: Mar tina Arroyo as Amelia, Placido Domingo as Gustav III (the production uses the Swedish locale) and Sherill Milnes as Anckarstrm. There was, how ever, a new conductor, Peter Herman Adler, who was mak his debut at the Met.

title: Holy Cross in Front
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 23 (AP)Steve Buchanan broke a tackle and rambled 35 yards for a fourthquarter touchdown to give Holy Cross a 3024 comeback victory over Brown today.

title: Tropical Storm in Atlantic
description: MIAMI, Sept. 23 (AP)  A tropical depression far out in the Atlantic, about midway be tween Africa and the Lesser Antilles, moved slowly north westward today, the National Hurricane Center said. Highest winds in the depression were estimated at 35 miles an hour and, there was no expectation of any rapid increase in strength today.

title: OKLAHOMA SINKS OREGON BY 683
description: NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 23 (AP)  Secondranked Okla homa racked up more than 700 yards in total offense and com pletely throttled Oregon's her alded passing attack as the Sooners routed the Webfoots, 68.3, today.

title: Training Ward
description: In 1929 during his last year at Sheppard and Enoch Pratt Hospital in Baltimore, Harry Stack Sullivan set up his famous special ward. It was in a new building and consisted of two rooms, each contain ing three beds. Sullivan had complete charge of the ward and admitted six male schizophrenic patients. He excluded nurses from the ward because he felt that for young men of such low self esteem as his patients, the presence of women with such comparatively high so cial status would tend to negate therapy. He also disputed the practice of putting patients of different age levels and diag noses together (manic or agitated patients had often been put in wards with regressed schizophrenics to liven them up).

title: A young Indian and a new father; Mom, The Wolf Man And Me
description: Motherhood is sacred. But only when it happens to married women.

title: Two old enemies sip tea together
description: In the millennium and a half of contact between China and Japan, the forthcoming meeting between the Chinese and Japanese Premiers will be the first encounter in which each side treats the other as a great power.

title: For Their Children, Life Began When Mother Was Past Forty
description: Mrs. Rafael Cabrera has learned to respond with good humor when people compliment her on her lovely grand child, for that grandchild is, in fact, her 14monthold son, Mrs. Cabrera, 47 years old, who hardly fits the grand motherly stereotype, belongs to that tiny group of women who had their first child after the age of 40.

title: A Flurry of Feathers, a Slash in the Air And Something Living Dies
description: THE land in California is changing so rapidly that if a speck gets in your eye you will miss some thing. Every week another or chard is gone, giving way not to rows of houses, as in the early sixties, but to a vineyard. America is to become a wine drinking nation, the laws of marketing decree. Cabernet grapes are selling for $750 a ton (up from $45 after World War II), and the breakeven groves of apples, prunes, pears and apricots are just space wasted now.

title: Color Film Shows Turnpike Widening
description: A 21minute color docu mentary film on the conver sion of the New Jersey Turn pike into the world's first dualdual highway has been assembled from more than 25,000 feet of film shot during three years of con struction.

title: Phillips and Abbot Merging Next Fall Into Coed Academy
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 23 Phillips Academy and Abbot Academy will be combined in a single, coeducational board ing school in Andover begin ning next fall, it was announced tonight by the two boards of trustees.

title: World
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Edward Heath of Britain sat under the glare of television lights in a crowded meeting room at the Imperial hotel here last Tuesday afternoon and told newsmen: I hope that no one will ?? that Europe has lost interest in this part of the world. Brit ain has not, especially in monetary and trading ar rangements.

title: BILL OF OLD AND NEW BY FARBER DANCERS
description: Viola Farber's dazzling dance company staged an event at Westbeth Friday night that combined elements of old and new works and was by turns engrossing and tiresome.

title: MISS DAVIS'S JOB REVIVED AS ISSUE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23  Another dispute involv ing Angela Davis, the contro versial black scholar, appeared in the making here this week.

title: College in South Carolina To Add Whites to Its Board
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 23 Allen University will inte grate its board of control and begin a $1million redemption campaign to liquidate its debts, Bishop D. Ward Nichols of The African Methodist Epis copal Church has announced.

title: You Like to Recognize the Tune? You Will
description: ROCK music drives you up the wall, right? It's too loud, too garbled, too lacking in familiar rhythms to make you do anything more than shudder every time you hear it, right? It roars out at you from every Broadway record shop, it's beginning to seep out of your television set and it's almost impossible to find a Broadway musical these days that doesn't have the word Rock as an antecedent to the title.

title: TANNER EXTENDS HIS UPSET STREAK
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP) Roscoe Tanner continued to cut down the favorites in the Pacific Southwest Open today with a 64, 76 semifinal victory over Tom Okker of the Nether lands.

title: Architecture
description: THERE is a very well intentioned and quite amiable little show at the New York Cultur al Center called Making New York Understandable, a theme close to this writ er's heart. It is a timeless and openended subject, and the questions it raises will last long after the closing date of Oct. 11.

title: OldTime L.I. to Go On View at Fair
description: STONY BROOK, L. I.  Thousands of visitors will converge this Saturday upon what was once a farmer's pasture here to savor life as it was on Long Island before 1840.

title: Paris Expected to Boycott Troop Talks
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 23France has made clear to NATO that she will boycott the EastWest conference on troop reductions in Europe, according to senior NATO and French sources.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The caper story, when well ?? is always good reading, ?? the British author, Lau ?? ence Henderson, has the style ?? pat. In CAGE UNTIL ?? (St. Martin's, $5.95) he ?? a group of professionals ?? off a big job in a very realistic manner. There are no heroics; the thieves sit around a table and painstakingly plan the operations, like business men working out a complicated merger.

title: A Crafts Fair Tied to Ecology
description: ORADELL  Craftsmen who feel that their arts are related to ecology will show what they mean on a three acre tract for 14 hours next Saturday and Sunday.

title: Gardens
description: THE continuing fall lectures schedule at the Queens Botanical Gar den includes an evening talk on Oct. 3, CoExisting With Plants by Frank Bow man at 7:30 P.M. and an aft ernoon talk on Oct. 4, a dahl ia clinic at 1:30 P.M. Both lectures will be given at the main building, 4350 Main Street, Flushing, N. Y.

title: Preps
description: Riverdale extended its win ning streak to 17 games by de feating New York Military Academy yesterday, 140. It was coach Frank Bertino's 174th victory in 29 years at Riverdale, which has not lost since 1969.

title: The Second Oldest Profession
description: All about moonshining. After a short history of distilling in America, Mr. Carr traces the illegal distiller back to the Mo lasses Act of 1733 but says that the business did not really get going until postRevo lutionary excise taxes. The Civil War was a further stimu lus, and to this day the hills are full of stills. An interesting bit of backwoods Americana.

title: Mass Arrests and Curfew Announced in Philippines
description: MANILA, Sept. 23President Ferdinand E. Marcos followed up his declaration of martial law in the Philippines today by announcing the mass arrest of what he said were Communist conspirators plotting to over throw the Government. He also announced plans for economic reforms.

title: John Hendee Roach Jr. Marries Miss Joan Hayden Muchmore
description: MADISON, N.J., Sept. 23 Miss Joan Hayden Muchmore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry George Muchmore of New Vernon, was married here this afternoon to John Hendee Roach Jr., son of John H. Roach of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Mrs. Roach.

title: Marion Davies
description: Once upon a time there lived in Brooklyn a lovely young maiden with a slight stutter whose mother must have been a student of Colette, for the first and most telling lesson she and her three older sisters learned at mother's knee was to go straight for the dough and the hell with all that nonsense about young men and romance. And because mother always knew best, they all followed this sim ple game plan, with the result that they all came to live lives well above the median standard of their day.

title: MISS SILLS BRINGS SPARKLE TO LUCIA
description: One of the directors at the New York City Opera over heard a customer at the box office a few days ago request ing tickets for The Beverly Sills show. Obviously the pop ular singer would be the first to disavow any such appraisal of her contribution to Lucia di Lammermoor, which was given for the first time this season Friday night.

title: Gali ffa Throws for 4 Touchdowns as West Va. Routs Virginia, 4810
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 23 (AP)Bernie Galiffa picked a porous Virginia sec ondary to pieces today with four touchdown passes as West Virginia's unbeaten Moun taineers overcame a sluggish start and rolled to a 4810 foot ball victory over the previously undefeated Cavaliers.

title: A young Indian and a new father
description: Give me 80 men and I will ride through the whole Sioux Nation, boasted young Captain William Fet terman. He did not live long enough to fulfill the pledge. On December 21, 1866, he and his entire command of 82 men, were killed in a battle known to whites as the Fetterman Massacre and to the Sioux as the Battle of the Hundred in the Hand.

title: Bid for U.A.W.Vote in Indiana
description: LOGANSPORT, Ind. Sept. 23 (AP)The United Auto Work ers president, Leonard wood cock, motored about northern Indiana in a persistent rain to day, urging union members to vote for the Democratic na tional and state tickets in November. You'll be serving your own best interests by sup porting the McGovernShriver cause of the negative record, particularly on economics as far as the workers are concerned, of the Nixon Administration.

title: Young Shoplifters' Penalty: Stay in Court
description: PARAMUSUpset by the number of young people who come before him during weekly court sessions, Judge Martin Burger uses the Param us courtroom itself to teach them a lesson. He hopes it sticks.

title: Mrs. Hillman Has Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Hillman of Flushing, Queens, on Sept. 16 at the Long Island Jewish Hospital. The child has been named Deborah Lisa. Mrs. Hillman, a school psycholo gist, is the former Miss Iris Durell. The child's father is manager of medical systems at the corporate headquar ters of International Business Machines in White Plains.

title: Actors Are Not the Only Ones Who Act
description: WHEN civilians (that's how we actors affectionately refer to those not in the profession) come backstage, why do they usually behave so unnaturally? They often do more acting than we've done all night. We seem to be very off putting to people and the further you get away from New York or Holly wood, the more so it becomes. So you practically feel like a different breed.

title: Dance
description: THE New York Dance Festival, which ended last Sunday, has be come a familiar aspect of New York's fall. In early September; after Shakespeare and his friends have finished at Central Park's Delacorte Theater, the New York Shake speare Festival stages this dance fiesta. For the past two seasons it has had as its Executive Producer Donald Saddler. At one time these free dance performances were substantially helpedif not completely paid forby Re bekah Harkness, but in recent years they have found a broader base of support, and this year both the New York State Council on the Arts and the National Endowment on the Arts helped pay the piper. The latter also seemed to want to call one of the tunes, but more of that later.

title: Employment Rise Reported
description: Employment in New York State in August was 7,815,000, an increase of 20,000 over July, Industrial Commissioner Louis L. Levine announced yesterday. However, the total was 60,000 less than in August, 1971. In New York City, there were 3,847,400 persons employed in August, 9,600 more than in July, but 77,200 less than in August, 1971.

title: Munich was the last Olympiad
description: MUNICH: Murder is an ancient Olympic tradition. In fact Pelops, the first champion, triumphed by kill ing his opponent as well as his own accomplice. Not withstanding, they named the Peloponnese in his honor. But perhaps this is irrelevant since Pelops, who took as his prize both a princess and a king dom, was clearly no amateur athlete.

title: 4 SEIZED IN ROBBERY OF CASINO IN NEVADA
description: RENO, Sept. 23 (AP)Four men were arrested today in connection with the $178,500 robbery of Harrah's Tahoe Ca sino at Lake Tahoe, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Preps
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 23Kingswood and Kent battled without scoring for three periods today until Mark Fisher, a Kingswood back, grabbed a short punt and re turned it 30 yards for the game's only touchdown and a 72 Kingswood victory. Fisher also kicked the conversion.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The new Agnew which is being used for this year's political campaign was built by Himmel & Hump of Houston, Texas, the same firm that built the first three new Nixons back in the mid1950's.

title: Home Improvement
description: EVERY list of socalled basic or starting tools should include one or two clamps of some kind. These versatile third hands are essential for many wood gluing and assembling jobs since they provide the only practical method for applying pressure to woodworking joints while the glue dries.

title: Stamps
description: The United States Postal Service has a gift for stamp collectorstheir very own postage stamp (but it will cost them eight cents.)

title: Three poets: physical, courteous, indispensable
description: I am here at home in South Carolina at the Olympic Games. Here is this TV vision, the Telstar vision, of the human body at its opti mum. It is diving beautifullyall these judged degrees of beauty, of mortal perfectabilityit is hurdling, it is running with incredible speed and endurance, it is swimming and leaping. The longdistance viewer cannot deny his own physicality in the presence of these fleeting, grace ful and muscular myths; he is proud of himself through the athletes. Though he realizes his own imper fection, he is part of the same breed as they, and that gives him hope. He watches the highjumper care fully as he hurls himself into space backwardwhat must it feel like to that Fosburyflopping guy? What trust is implied in such a high, blind gamble!and he brings a hand to his cheek in wonderment at the long jumper as he strides into the air, making, as Montherlant once said, a momentary and profound gesture of explanation.

title: Oehmig Senior Golf Victor Beating Pieper in 20 Holes
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 23 (AP) Lew Oehmig of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., won the Unit ed States Golf Association amateur golf tournament today with a 20thhole victory over a Californian, Ernest Pieper, at the Sharon Golf Club.

title: The Disenchanted Isles
description: A history of Hawaii from 1893 to the present. Mr. Wright takes Hawaii through several stages in its development, be ginning with the revolution that caused the last Hawaiian monarch to abdicate. Particular attention is paid to the varie gated ethnic groups that make up Hawaiian society, along with a racial explanation of why fears of a racial explosion in pre  Pearl Harbor days were groundless. Wright follows the overthrow of the family dynas ties that virtually ruled the islands and the rise of a re invigorated Democratic party under Jack Burns, who later became governor. A solid ac count of the progress of the 50th state.

title: ROWING TITLE WON BY NEW YORK A.C.
Thinking about lamb
description: A leg of lamb. Dot it with garlic. Tinge it with vinegar. Simmer it in a mush roomandsourcream sauce. Delicious! So what if the sauce does show signs of curdling. It doesn't affect the taste.

title: Love Bugs Swarm in Florida, Causing Problems for Drivers
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 23 Thousands of visitors to Disney World and other central Flor ida attractions are being intro duced to a comparatively new Florida phenomenon, the love bug.

title: TUNISIA QUESTIONS SCHOOL PROGRAMS
description: TUNIS, Sept. 13Tunisia, having undertaken one of the most comprehensive education programs in the Arab world, is wondering whether the effort was worthwhile.

title: 4 Small Earthquakes Jar Buildings in Salinas, Calif.
description: SALINAS, Calif., Sept. 23 (UPI)Four small earthquakes, three of them occurring within 11 minutes, cracked pavements and walls and swayed tall buildings early today in this farming community 65 miles south of San Francisco.

title: Delaware State Wins
description: MILLERSVILLE, Pa., Sept. 23 (AP)Despite a 210 half time lead, Delaware State had to score once more in the fourth period to hold off a surg ing Millersville State 2821 to day.

title: Hector J. Dowd, Banker, Dead; Was Top Policeman of S.E.C.
description: Hector J. Dowd, a retired banker and corporation execu tive, who was known as the No. 1 policeman of the Se curities and'Exchange Commis sion from 1934 to 1939, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 83 years old and lived at 500 East 85th Street.

title: Photography
description: EVEN with a onearmed Spencer Tracy thrown in for good measure, Bad Day at Black Rockone of our culture's few public acknowledgments of the virulence of antiJapa nese feeling here during World War II  can hardly be considered penanceinfull for the lapse of national conscience documented in Executive Order 9066, the traveling exhibit now at the Whitney Museum (through October 23). But that film is really the only moral restitu tion that has come unbidden to the JapaneseAmerican community; America does not readily forgive its victims.

title: Preps
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 23 A quarterback, Dennis Ohl, completed five consecutive passes in a 76yard drive to set Rick Skillings up for a success ful fieldgoal attempt from just inside the 8yard line today as Williamson Trade (Pa.) scored a dramatic 30 decision over Peddie. Ohl completed 12 of 23 passes.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 23 (AP) Eastern Air Lines has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for authority to operate the first nonstop flights between Atlanta and the Bahamas.

title: A Mall, in Downtown Newark?
description: NEWARKA young black entrepreneur is leading a group of smallbusinessmen on Halsey Street, a down town area of familyowned specialty shops in an attempt to revitalize tie street into a place able to compete with the suburbs for shoppers.

title: AN ARAB SUSPECTS ISRAELIS USED GAS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sunday, Sept. 24Lebanon's Health Minister said last night that there was suspicion that three Arabs who had been wounded in last weekend's Israeli raid were suffering from aftereffects of exposure to poison gas.

title: Haiti's Reputation For Primitive Art: From Best to Worst
description: PORTAUPRINCE, HaitiArt may only be Haiti's fourth biggest ex port (after coffee, bauxite and sugar) but hi terms of prestige and ubiquity it is surely No. 1. In the world market, for instance, Haitian coffee is to, say, Colombia's, as a spoon ful to a tanker. But mention primitive painters among collectors and what country can rival Haiti?

title: Jersey Honors Representative Dwyer
description: UNION, N. J., Sept. 23Rep resentative Florence P. Dwyer won a standing ovation today from an audience of 400 at a luncheon here paying tribute to her on retirement after 16 years in Congress.

title: Letters:
description: Ware, Mass., outlet capital of the world? Tsk, tsk to your article on out let stores in Massachusetts and Connec ticut (Travel section, Sept. 10). As any seasoned outlet shopper knows, Ware, with its seven stores, isn't even a close second to the outletrich Pennsylvania city of Reading. Reading has 33 factory outlet stores within its limits, and nearby communities host several dozen others. Within a 50mile radius of Read ing are more than 200 outlets, some of them just a twohour drive from New York City.

title: Movies
description: A GOOD snake nowadays is nerd to find, so what you have to do is find a good man and turn him into a good snake. At least, that's what Richard D. Zanuck and David Brown seem to think, since the first movie they'll make under their new Universal contract is Sssss, based on Hal Dresner's original script about a mad scientist who dashes about injecting snakemaking serum into sometimes pro testing specimens.

title: Pupils Pushing a Rock Record
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I. The seventh graders at the School of the Holy Child will be spending part of their time this fall on an activity that is not listed in the school curriculum: selling a rock LP record.

title: Hobart, Paced by Kowalski, Routsrochester Team,6013
description: GENEVA, N. Y., Sept. 23 Don Aleksiewicz gained 245 yards and Rich Kowalski, a freshman, picked up 145 while scoring five touchdowns today as Hobart College defeated Rochester Institute of Technol ogy, 6013.

title: CARL FRANK DIES; RADIOTV ACTOR
description: Carl Frank, a former radio and television actor and announcer, who had also appeared on stage and screen, died yesterday at his home at Cruz Bay in St. John, the Vir gin Islands. His age was 63.

title: Saigon Says Troops Sweep 2 Provinces to Hold Gains
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sun day, Sept. 24 (AP)Thousands of South Vietnamese troops were engaged in sweeps on the northern front yesterday in an effort to prevent North Viet namese forces from recapturing hardwon territory, the Saigon command reported.

title: Chimera
description: Some writers won't talk about their work because it's hard to find time enough, in the first place, to work. The problem is vitiated in John Barth's sixth book, Chimera, where talking about it becomes the work, and the more serious problem  verbal suicide  is copiously ac knowledged, along with a great deal else, and why not? The work con tains the writer's life; his life con tains Chimera, and it contains its writer, its shapeshifting hero, in side. Not John Barth. He's outside, photographed on the jacket back, looking witty and cool, wrapped in his own arms as if there's nothing more to say.

title: Whistle Blowing
description: Nader strikes again. He and his associates have been de pendent for many of their revelations on conscience stricken sources within the of fending companies. (Nader's tip on the faulty Corvair came from a GM engineer.) This book, which grew out of the Conference on Professional Re sponsibility, examines such questions as: When does a man owe more to his fellowcitizens than to his company or govern ment agency? Should informa tion be given anonymously? Should a man first resign and then expose? For whistleblow ers, whistleblowees and Na derwatchers.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  Who would write a 200page book with an absolute maxi mum sale of 468 copies and a probable period of usefulness of about 10 weeks?

title: France:
description: PARISThe preparations for Presi dent Georges Pompidou's semiannual press conference, in the sumptuously tapestried and chandeliered grand hall of the Elyse Palace, had been made well in advance. Questions of high policy had been accumulating, and the President strode purposefully to the dais to meet them.

title: 2 Policemen Shot at Creedmoor While Responding to an Alarm
description: Two policemen responding to a report of a man with a gun were shot early yesterday in an exchange of gunfire at an employes' party at the Creedmoor State Hospital Re habilitation Center in Queens Village.

title: Kosher Food Gets Boost From Zoning Action
description: Fiddler on the Roof was a hit on Broadway, but it has won no laurels in a new kosher butcher shop in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: UCONN IS 70 VICTOR ON LONG PASS PLAY
description: STORRS, Conn., Sept. 23 (AP)Greg Andrews, a split end, scored on an 81yard pass play from Ray Tellier in the third quarter today enabling Connecticut to post a 70 Yan kee Conference victory over Vermont. The game was the opener for both teams.

title: Dr. Catlin Weds Rosalie Hornblower
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 23Miss Rosalie Hornblower, a registered nurse formerly on the staff of the Ewing Pavilion at Memorial Hospital in New York, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Brian Catlin, who completed his residency in general sur gery at the Boston City Hos pital this summer and will practice here.

title: World
description: For a month Manila, the capital of the Philippines, had been a target for terror. Mys terious bombing incidents had damaged the city hall in Manila proper, and in nearby Quezon City. Public utility installations, the constitu tional convention hall de partment stores and schools were also damaged.

title: Music
description: WEST GERMANY'S 50odd theaters pour forth a seem ingly unending stream of new operas, but in the years since Henze turned his back on the pro scenium arch as an emblem of reaction, none of them has made as deep an im pression as Bernd Alois Zimmermann's Die Solda ten. Since its first produc tion in Cologne in 1965, this enormously complex and de manding work has also been mounted in Munich and Dus seldorf, whose Deutsche Oper am Rhein brought an admir able production by Georg Reinhardt and Heinrich Wendel to this year's Edin burgh Festival.

title: Cornelia Kittle Wed to Ensign
description: CISMONT, Va., Sept. 23 Miss Cornelia Lee Kittle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Wade Kittle of New York and Charlottesville, was married here this afternoon to Ens. Michael Chiles Gard ner Neer, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Casper Samuel Neer of Alexandria. The ceremony was performed in Grace Epis copal Church by the Rev. Allie W. Frazier.

title: Letters.
description: Last spring, as we sat sidebyside at an N.Y.U. writers' workshop, Laura Henning gaped with amaze ment as I extolled the joys of city living. I am not sur prised by her article, It's Great in the Suburbs, [Sept. 3] nor do I dispute it, but I do feel Mrs. Henning has shortchanged everyday life in New York.

title: BEIRUT'S STREETS ARE CLEAN AGAIN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 23 When the people of Beirut awoke today they found their city Beirut altered. The skyline was the same, of course, with its parade of spires and mina rets. The great hotels, the banks, the arabesque mansions were all unchanged.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 23 (AP) Bob Smith, a sopho more, set up two Maryland touchdowns with a 35 yard punt return and one of his three interceptions as the Terps over came stubborn Virginia Military Institute, 2816, today.

title: Helen Meyer Wed to Richard Murdock
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 23Miss Helen Justine Meyer, daughter of Mrs. W. Hayward Powers Jr. of Boca Raton, Fla., and Blakeman Quintard Meyer Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Richard Putnam Murdock of New York. The Rev. Dr. Charles Copenhaver, a Presbyterian minister and senior minister of the Re formed Church of Bronxville, performed the ceremony at the church.

title: 125th St. Block Is Commuters' Gantlet
description: The Penn Central station at 125th Street and Park Ave nue, all dark wood and massive stone, looks like a fortress.

title: Education
description: The Japanese have no great tra dition of private or corporate philos ophy. So there was some surprise last week when the Mitsubishi group of industries of Japan do nated $1million to Harvard Univer sity to establish a chair in Japanese legal studies. The company has never given any money to Japanese universities during the period of its tremendous postwar expansion in such fields as banking, shipping, steel and brewing.

title: Education
description: The perennial problem with teach ers' tenure is that it protects the in competent and freezes them into the system. The perennial problem with a lack of tenure is that it ex poses, teachers to such dangers as dismissal for holding unpopular political views.

title: Pop
description: LINDA HOPKINS: Linda Hopkins (RCA Victor LSP 4756). Linda Hopkins be came an overnight sensation in Broadway's illfated In ner City after singing gospel and blues in halls and clubs for years. Inner City fold ed but Ms. Hopkins won a 1972 Tony award and a con tract for her first solo rec ord album. Sadly, this album stifles Ms. Hopkins' great talent. Her glorious vibrant voice loses its impact in a lackluster collection of songs given uninspired arrange ments. The situation is not at all unlike Aretha Frank lin's floundering beginnings at Columbia Records. Not un til she arrived at Atlantic Records did Aretha's real soul shine an records.

title: Colby Tops St. Lawrence
description: WATERVILLE, Me., Sept. 23 (AP)Peter Gorniewicz picked up 166 yards rushing and scored two touchdowns today as Colby scored a 2815 victory over St. Lawrence.

title: Miss Susan Kress Is Planning Bridal
description: WILLOW STREET, Pa., Sept. 23Miss Susan Lynett Kress and Peter Thompson Hart mann plan to be married next June in Boston.

title: Tennessee Wallops Wake Forest, 456, for 10th in Row
Floyd Bennett Vote Near
description: WASHINGTON  Within the next couple of weeks the House of Representatives probably will have to resolve one of those Rockefeller Lindsay disputesthis one over whether 17,500 housing units for a population nearly as large as Levittown or Binghamton should be built on part of Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.

title: Housing Gains in. Southeast Brooklyn
description: New highrise construction in the Coney Island section accounted for the major part of the increase of 12,500 housing units between 1960 and 1970 in the three plan ning districts in the southeast corner of Brooklyn.

title: LOWERED LIMITS ON PRICES STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  The Price Commission is con sidering scaling down the price increases it will permit when it renews socalled term limit pricing agreements with big corporations.

title: Middies Prove Stubborn
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 23Penn State, a four touchdown favorite to have an easy time against Navy, never looked the part today as the Nittany Lions were forced to struggle and rallied in the sec ond half to defeat the middies, 2110.

title: New york
description: The phone number is 4321200. The office is situated on the 32d floor of the south tower of the World Trade Center. A husky male voice answers, Special Prosecutor's Office. Thus was launched last week what prom ises to be the single most extensive investigation of corruption among police, prosecutors and judges in New York City's long and investigation rich history.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, Sept. 23The three Croatians who hijacked a Scan dinavian Airlines System plane to Madrid on Sept. 16 will be put on trial in a military court, the Aviation Ministry said to day. They are members of a rightwing nationalist group opposed to President Tito's Yugoslav Government.

title: LETTERS
description: The suggestion by E. Spen cer Miller, the president of the Maine Central Railroad, for a unified national rail road system, privately owned and operated, led New Eng land's other prominent rail road executive, Frederick C. Dumaine, chief executive of licer of the Bangor & Aroo stock Railroad and president of the Amoskeag Company, to propose a merger of the northern New England rail roadshis own, Mr. Du., main's and the Boston & Maine (Letters, Sept. 17).

title: Preps
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Sept. 23 John Rufe ran for two touch downs and passed 16 yards to Scott Warmen for another as Pennington scrambled to a 30 14 victory over Morristown Beard. Rufe's 1yard plunge snapped an 88 tie in the third period. He followed with an 11yard sprint to open the fourthquarter scoring.

title: Assistant Harvard Dean Slain; Victim Was Former Newsman
description: BOSTON, Sept, 23Joseph Strickland, a 44yearold admin istrator at Harvard and a former Detroit newsman, was found shot to death last night in his Boston apartment.

title: Submarine Transfer Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)The submarine Andrew Jackson, now based at Charles ton, S.C., will be reassigned to Groton, Conn., for overhaul and conversion to the Poseidon missile system. Representative Robert H. Steele, Republican of Connecticut, who announced the shift Wednesday, said the Andrew Jackson with its 18 officers and 150 enlisted men would arrive for a 17month stay in March, 1973.

title: Leadership Crisis in Legislature
description: TRENTON  Republican and Democratic legislative leaders face a major leader ship crisis when both houses convene here in January for next year's session.

title: Music
description: AMERICA'S symphony orchestras, harassed by defi cits and by critics who call them musical dino saurs, persevere. They are, in fact, among this nation's glories, and many of them are expanding not contractingtheir activities. These are the days when they are tuning up for a new season, beginning to rehearse and perform the programs that were planned by their music directors as long as a year and a half ago.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE
description: A year of price controls, while probably helping to curb inflation, has proved a long, irksome trip for more than a few of the nation's largest retailers. Some of their executives feel that the next six months may be even more  difficult unless the rules are changed to allow some relief for a profit squeeze.

title: Louis Shaw, Tennis Umpire; ExAide of Realty Board
description: BAYONNE, N. J., Sept. 23 Louis W. Shaw, a prominent tennis umpire and former mem bership secretary of the Real Estate Board of New York, died yesterday in Bayonne Hospital. He lived at 15 West 39th Street here.

title: IRISH 370 VICTOR OVER N'WESTERN
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 23 Notre Dame's Fighting Irish opened their football season today by scoring the first five times they handled the ball and rolled to a chrushing 370 tri umph over Northwestern.

title: Union Tops Worcester,140; Westbrook Scores Twice
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 23A sophomore halfback, Ron Westbrook, ran for 107 yards and two touchdowns to day as Union defeated Worces ter Tech, 14.0, in the opening game for both teams.

title: Bus Terminal Will Start TaxiDispatching System on Tuesday
description: A system to dispatch taxi cabs for commuters who emerge from the Port Author ity's midtown bus terminal will be put into effect Tues day at 9 A.M.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Fanny Butcher, now in her 80's, looks back on a remark able career as reporter, music critic, society editor, booksel ler and, of course, book col umnist for The Chicago Trib une. She was born in Fredonia, Kan., was graduated from the University of Chicago and came of age at the time of the Chicago literary renaissance. Fascinated but not always im pressed by position and celeb rity, she writes with keen per ceptions about such middle American authors as Edna Ferber, Sinclair Lewis, H. L. Mencken, Willa Cather and such international figures (whom she got to know through International PEN) as Joyce, Maurois, Galsworthy. Her style in this memoir is easy, her man ner human, her subject matter always interesting.

title: Grouping Raised Few Problems For Renters
description: Last spring, because of a State Supreme Court ruling, many Long Island summer resort villages braced for a chaotic, general invasion of group renters, whom they feared would threaten they stability of community life.

title: Leith McLean, C. C. Adams 3d Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Miss Leith McLean, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gale McLean of Potomac, Md., was mar ried in the Universalist Na tional Memorial Church here this afternoon to Charles Closson Adams 3d, son of Charles C. Adams of. Wash ington and Mrs. Walter H. Bowes of Arlington, Va.

title: KINGS POINT VICTOR OVER NORWICH, 129
description: NORTHFIELD, Vt., Sept. 23 The United States Merchant Marine Academy defeated Nor wich University, 129, before 5,200 homecoming day fans on Sabine Field today.

title: Preps
description: SHEFFIELD, Mass., Sept. 23 Avon, led by Torn Aguda's two long touchdownsa 78 yard run and a 67yard return of an intercepted passrouted Berkshire, 296, today.

title: McGovern Seeks Moral Leader's Role
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 23Sen ator George McGovern came here today to tell the Ohio Democratic Convention that our principles are right for America, and Republican poli cies are wrong, and to assert that the outcome of the 1972 Presidential campaign could be determined by Ohioans on Nov. 7.

title: ZAPPA CREATES MUSICAL MAGIC
description: Frank Zappa proved again Friday night that he is a mas ter of musical sleightofhand. Dealing with a Felt Forum au dience that clearly expected to hear a medley of old Mothers of Invention hits like Son of Suzy Creamcheese, Are You Hung Up?, Nasal Retentive Calliope Music, Brown Shoes Don't Make It and other sim ilar provocatively titted tunes, Zappa gave them instead a tnixed bag of jazzrockclassi cal music from a 20musician ensemble. It is to his credit or perhaps to the persistence of memorythat the audience loved what it got.

title: Rural education Sea Islands style
description: In America, fads occur as frequently with our concern for social problems as they do with dress or music. A par ticular notion about some prob lem emerges, becomes fashion able and may almost achieve a realistic breakthrough and raise our social consciousness, but then it is deserted and we move on to some new area of concern. This pattern is clearly evident in publishing, particu larly as it relates to the pub lication of educational litera ture.

title: Views of the Review
description: In The Week in Review section of Sept. 10, John Hess echoed the claims of the moderate Arab gov ernments when he put the plight of the Palestinians at the root of the terrorist phenomena. He sees no solu tion at hand. In fact, a solution has been provided and the end may be in sight.

title: Red Tide in New England Costs Thousands of Jobs
description: The red tide, the infesta tion of poisonous algae that has invaded the New England coast from Cape Cod to upper Maine, has brought economic devasta tion to thousands of people who earn their livelihood from the ocean.

title: Art
description: FROM the ancien r gime to the Belle Epoque is a large slab of French history and an equally large slice of French art. Yet, two current exhibitionsa show of 18th century French prints and drawings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Oc tober 15), and an exhibition of 19thcentury French prints at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle (through October 8) man age to cover this vast canvas in a thoroughly admirable fashion.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: MIAMI. Sept. 23  Air Florida, a new state airline, plans to begin next week a lowcost air service between Miami and central Florida.

title: Mets Defeat Phils, 5 to 3, as Matlack Registers 14th Victory on FiveHitter
description: The Mets were full of lofty sacrifice yesterday afternoon at Shea Stadium as four of their runs in a 53 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies were driven home on long fly balls.

title: Rice Beats Clemson, 2910
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 23 (AP) Mark Williams kicked field goals of 25, 35 and 28 yards and Bruce Gadd tossed touch down passes of 29 and 28 yards to Edwin Collins tonight to lead Rice to a 2910 victory over Clemson.

title: After 3 Years Englewood Community House
description: ENGLEWOODDedication ceremonies this weekend at the new Community House here mark an important ex pansion of Englewood's so cial, recreational, and day care facilities. The new build ing replaces the 55yearold Memorial House, which was vacated in 1969 because it was too difficult and costly to maintain.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: I find myself dismayed by the reactions in this space to Joan Didion's recent essayre view (The Women's Move ment)  largely because your correspondents seemed to miss her principal argument.

title: Ann Durgee Fiancee of C. T. Lusk
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23 Miss Ann Christine Durgee, who teaches weaving and design on the home econom ics faculty of the University of Vermont, plans to be mar ried Oct. 21 to Charles Tif fany Lusk of Stowe, Vt., where the wedding will take place. Mr. Lusk, a tree sur geon and member of the Vermont Ski Patrol, is de scended from Charles Lewis Tiffany, founder of the jewel ry firm of Tiffany & Co.

title: The World
description: Suddenly last week there was a new type of terrorism: murder by mail. And with it came the realization of just how vulnerable we had all be came. The chances of our being at an airport, say, when terrorists strike is rather remote; few of us will ever be Olympic athletes. But we all receive mail.

title: Parade and Festivities Mark the Day
description: On the sort of sunny but cool day that seemed made for promenading and frolicking, city residents were treated yes terday to a multinational dis play of cultural eventsa Ger manAmerican parade up Fifth Avenue; a fiesta of Asian songs, dances and food in Central Park, and art exhibits in China town.

title: Reporter Gets Year in Jail
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (UPI)Ronald Ridenour, a re porter for The Los Angeles Free Press, has been sentenced to a year in jail for hitting a police man during a demonstration at local Nixon reelection head quarters. Mr. Ridenour, free on bond pending an appeal, was convicted Tuesday in a five day jury trial, and had been con victed last year of a similar of fense at another demonstration.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  It has just now been disclosed by the Times Literary Supplement (London) that George Orwell wrote a preface to Animal Farm on The Freedom of the Press, which has never been pub lished until this month.

title: Gardens
description: LNOW when the garden and field flowers are plentiful take time out to dry some of them for winter bouquets and arrangements. They can be as colorful and fresh look ing as arrangements made during the blooming season if the material is dried care fully.

title: Tips From Interpol Linked to French Seizure of Five Drug Plants
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 22  Interpol, the in ternational police organization that serves police units in 111 member countries as a central information exchange and data bank, stated here this week that its work had enabled French police officers to close five secret heroin laboratories in southern Prance last year.

title: LILCO Questioned on Rate Request
description: Officials of the Long Is land Lighting Company were crossexamined last week by attorneys for the State Public Service Commission concern ing the utility's calculations that it used to support its re quest for rate increases.

title: Coins
description: India's ninepiece proof set for 1972 will con tain a newly designed 10rupee coin made of .500 fine silver. Although in only the fourth year of issue, the crownlike specimen will represent the third distinct type produced thus far. The diam eter has been increased to 39 millimeters, making the coin approximately the size of a United States silver dollar.

title: Horse Show News
description: Entries for the National Horse Show closed last Mon day. Most horse show offi cials would breathe a sigh of relief and figure that the big job was behind them when the entry box was locked.

title: Tulane Upsets Georgia, 2413, on Ewing's Punt Return and Strong Defense
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 23 (AP)Tulane put together two 80yard scoring drives in the second period and George Ewing returned a punt 57 yards for a touchdown as the Green Wave upset Georgia, 2413, in football today.

title: Jane Champe, Dr. John Payne Are Wed Here
description: Miss Jane Champe was married here yesterday after noon to Dr. John Walter Payne of Baltimore, chair man of the medical board of the Eye Bank of Maryland. The Rev. James J. McNamee 3d performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany. A reception was held at the Cosmopolitan Club.

title: Marilyn Mainelli Wed to William Frank
description: NARRAGANSETT, R. I., Sept. 23  Miss Marilyn Carole Mainelli, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugo R. Mai nelli, was married here at noon today to William Pat rick Frank, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto H. Frank of Bronx yille, N. Y., in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Eugene J. O'Brien performed the ceremony, as sisted by Msgr. Walter F. Kenny and the Rev. Matlick J. Fitzpatrick.

title: Wheat Exporters Seeking Tax Benefit on Soviet Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  Grain exporters are pressing the Treasury Department for a ruling that would free them of Federal taxes on half of the profits made from the sale of wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: The Last Word
description: Michael Glenny's translation of Alex ander Solzhenitsyn's August 1914 has been severely criticized in the Book Re view. In an interview in New York the translator defended himself:

title: All Those Nights in Camelot, and They Didn't Write a Guidebook
description: THRONGS of American tourists in England stand around in Henry VIII's palace at Hampton Court, straining to hear the ghost of Catherine. Howard walk shrieking through the halls. Other throngs elbow for Instamatic room on the green at the Tower of London to snap a picture of the house where Elizabeth I lived while she was a prisoner. All very well, if you don't mind the crowds. But what of the quieter shrines of another British ruler, revered in history and romanti cized in legend for a millenium and a half? How about a sword's gentle tap on the shoulder for King Arthur?

title: New & Novel
description: Take an oldish river boat captain with a bilge full of treasure. Add a youngish, mis sionarytype lady as passenger. Set them both chugging down a hazardous stream on a vol canic island, and what have you got? Well, you may have an African Queen style adventure, except that everybody's moti vations are a bit underpowered.

title: The Meadowlands: How Open?
description: LYNDHURSTTwo years ago, the Hackensack Mea dowlands Development Com mission, in releasing its first master plan for the 21,000 acres of reedy marshes, gar bage heaps Wand jerrybuilt warehouses that sprawl five minutes west of the Lincoln Tunnel, said that its task would be to restore life to the Meadowlands.

title: The World
description: LONDON  Shortly before 4:30 A.M. on Aug. 9, 1971, hundreds of British soldiers swarmed into Roman Catholic districts of Northern Ireland and began seizing and interning sus pected terrorists of the outlawed Irish Republican Army. Days earlier, the British and Ulster Governments had made the secret decision to invoke emergency powers and hold the sus pects in confinement without charges against them, without trial and without fixed sentences. This intern ment policy has been a key issue in Ulster's recent troubles.

title: Paternity Leaves Offered In New City U. Contract
description: Prospective fathers would receive paternity leaves un der a pioneer contract pro posed by the City University of New York to its profes sional staff.

title: Stamps
description: AN AMERICAN healing art, osteopathic medi cine, devised by a Civil War physician unhappy with thencurrent medical practices, will be commemorated postally on Oct. 9 in Miami, Florida, when an 8c multicolored stamp will be released during the convention of the Amer ican Osteopathic Association. Later in the month, in Phila delphia, another type of doc tor will be honored for the 23d time on a United States postage stampon Oct. 20 a 7c Ben Franklin portrait stamp will have its debut. Designs are illustrated today.

title: Brown Scores Scott in 7th With TieBreaker Orioles 2 Back
Build another East Village in the Dakota Badlands
description: No one can fairly promise full relief from the crime that confronts New Yorkers but they might draw comfort from a common resolution if they followed a tripartite pol icy which I will call, for the sake of mnemonics, Deter rence, Disease and Direction.

title: Bishop Moore Is Enthroned in an 8Hour Celebration
description: The Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr. was enthroned as the 13th Episcopal Bishop of New York yesterday during a full day of ceremonies that combined the medieval pomp of a coronation with the restless festivity of a street fair.

title: Harold McGuire Jr. Weds Mrs. Horn
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Sept. 23Mrs. Iris Horn, a doctoral student in psycholo gy at the Graduate Center of City University in New York, was married here this after noon to Harold F. McGuire Jr., an assistant United States Attorney in New York.

title: About Motor Sports
description: About 130 sports cars of all designs, sizes and colors will gather at Bridgehampton Race Circuit next weekend for the 11th series of races in the North Atlantic Road Racing Championship compe tition. The drivers are not those who compete in the CanAm, TransAmerican or of the Sports Car Club of America. Perhaps a few of them will be someday, but they are the club racers who are out of pursuing their avo cations. The weekend races are being handled by the New York Region of the S.C.C.A., and it is the 11th in the series. Actually, it is a fillin program for one that region had to cancel earlier in the year and it is being run to complete the full set of 16 championship races for the season. One is being com pleted at Lime Rock this afternoon, and after next week there will be five more. They will give those down in the point standings chances to catch up with the leaders.

title: HOMOSEXUAL GAINS AUTHORITY TO TEACH
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 23 Joseph Acanfora 3d, whose admitted homosexuality once led to his suspension as a stu dent teacher, has been certi fied to teach in this state.

title: Police Official in Saigon Jailed for Illegal Arrests
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 23A Saigon police offi cial has been sentenced to two years in prison for illegal ar rests, the government news agency reported today.

title: Helen Fuller Dies at 58; ExNew Republic Editor
description: FRONT ROYAL. Va., Sept. 23  Helen M. Fuller, journalist, author and former managing editor of The New Republic, died here on Sept. 15. She was 58 years old.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONVice President Ag new ushered the Federal Bureau of Investigation into a strange new world last week when he announced, appar ently to the surprise of the White House as well as Congress and the bureau itself, that the crimefighting agency had been asked to investigate charges of profiteering and conflict of interest in the Soviet grain deal.

title: The O'Neill Conference: Was It Good for Writers?
description: I could name a dozen play wrights who'd hock their chil dren for the chance Kenneth Brown was given this sum mer. Because until you see it performed on a stage in front of an audience, a play is no more than chicken tracks on paper. That's why any pro duction opportunity a play wright gets is golden. And the topflight professional presentation the O'Neill af fords its playwrights is price less.

title: The O'Neill Conference: Was It Good for Writers?
description: Margaret Webster, in her interesting letter to Miss Worthington, says that thea ter audiences are reluctant to go to shows in New York be cause they are afraid to go out at night, and thus gives credence to a myth that has done much harm to this fas cinating city.

title: AROUND THE
description: September doesn't signal time to put the hose away. The ground is quite dry. Trees, shrubs and evergreens must have good soil moisture to winter through.

title: Tentam, $7.20 Captures 30,000 Boardwalk Handicap on Grass by 2 Lengths
General George Washington, Meet Little Betsy Smirch
description: WITH the approach of the bicentennial of American indepen dence, a great many communities will undoubted ly wish to conduct local ob servances, and almost cer tainly, a majority of these community observances will be centered around a histori cal pageant, one of the most difficult and demanding of all theatrical art forms. What follows, then, is intended as a public service to the scores upon scores of high school teachers of English, Music and Drama; regents of the Daughters of the. American Revolution; presidents of lo cal historical societies and Little Theater groups; the clergy, and others who may be called upon to lend their talent.

title: Legislature May Tackle the Perils in Amusement Rides
description: TRENTON  Amusement rides brought laughs and thrills to millions of visitors to New Jersey boardwalks and amusement parks this summerand death to at least three.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: It is a disappointment to find a reporter of the stature of Mar tin Nolan referring to Leonard Lurie's The Running of Rich ard Nixon as a hatchet job. This, in a review that calls the book skillful, witty, readable, often brilliantand with re deeming insights.

title: Son for Mrs. Roosevelt
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 23A son was kborn Thurs day to Mr. and Mrs. P. James Roosevelt of Oyster Bay. Cove at the Huntington Hospital. The child has been named Michael John. His mother, the former Miss Philippa B. Buss, is a daughter of Mrs. Patricia J. Buss of London, and Robert D. Buss of Edinburgh, Scot land. The child also is a grandson of Mrs. Philip J. Roosevelt of Oyster Bay, and the late Mr. Roosevelt. The child's father is an invest ment counselor.

title: Jane Foster Plans Bridal
description: MANCHESTER, Vt., Sept. 23The engagement of Miss Jane deMoret Foster of New York to David Martin Hall Barnes Lorber has been an nounced by Giraud Van Nest Foster, father of the future bride. Her fianc, who is with the Oriental department at Sotheby ParkeBernet in New York, is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin George Lorber of WinstonSalem, N. C.

title: New york
description: The primary election in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District that began at 3 P.M. last June 20 when the polls opened, ended three months later about 10 P.M. Tuesday with the crusty, 69 yearold Representative John J. Rooney finally defeating the energetic 43year old Allard K. Lowenstein. The Rooney victory margin was 2,415 votes, nearly triple his 890 vote plurality in the June 20 primary which was invali dated by the courts because of massive irregularities.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Both Presidential candidates have now endorsed tax credits as a means of giving substantial monetary aid to sectarian schools. Tax credits are the latest in a series of proposals designed to circumvent the Supreme Court's 8to1 ruling in June 1971 invalidating parochaid measures in Pennsylvania and Rhode Island.

title: MAINE BEATEN, 370, BY MASSACHUSETTS
description: AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 23 With Paul Metallo scoring three touchdowns and Pail Penning ton completing 14 of 25 passes for 228 yards, the University of Massachusetts downed the University of Maine, 370, today in a Yankee Conference game in Alumni Stadium.

title: Gap teaches us a lesson but it's over our heads
description: SAIGON: In the unending Communist war of revolution in Vietnam the tendency among American generals and civilian officials has been to see each phase as signaling, finally, an end to the fighting. To them, the light at the end of the tunnel has never been far away, and the straight line of progress has always canted upward. So it was not, perhaps, surprising that when the North Vietnamese began their offensive in late March, 1972, senior Administration officials described it as a last roll of the dice. Nor is it surprising that they are now describing it as a failure because it did not succeed in toppling the rgime of President Nguyen Van Thieu on the battlefield. Some of them have even predicted that the Com munists will therefore soften their terms for a peace, settlement, which they expect, happily, to come most likely about the time of the Presidential elections in November.

title: L.I. Lighthouse a Landmark
description: ASHAROKEN, L. I.  The Eatons Neck Light House, hidden from the public by a private estate and familiar primarily to boaters, will soon be designated a national historic landmark.

title: SHOP TALK
description: METUCHENThe brainy borough was Metuchen's nickname in the early 1900's, when many wellknow art ists, scientists, lawyers and writers moved here from New york In 1914, Essex County's Glen Ridge chal lenged Metticheri'S right to the title, and the two horoughs compared bignanie brains. Metuchen won.

title: Lama, of MitchellLama, Bitter About Election Loss
description: Last June, Alfred A Lama did something he had not done in 30 years  he lost an election.

title: The World
description: BEIRUTIn the flyInfested Rashi dieh refugee camp, a thickset Pales tinian guerrilla hitched up his grenade belt and declaimed: The Lebanese are our friends. Here in the capital, the courtly Lebanese Premier, Saeb Salam, intoned: Our ties with our brothers the Palestinians shall al ways be those of brotherhood.

title: Social Announcements
description: Weddings

title: Miss Kirsten Fenninger Wed To R.W.Ramage Jr., Bank Aide
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 23 Miss Kirsten Fenninger and Robert W. Ramage Jr. were married here this afternoon in the Episcopal Cathedral Church of the Nativity by the Rev. H. Lawrence Whitte more Jr., dean of the cathe dral. He was assisted by the Very Rev. J. Stuart Dooling, a Roman Catholic priest, who is president of Allentown College of St. Francis de Sales.

title: TEXAS CONQUERS MIAMI, 23 TO 10
description: AUSTIN, Tex, Sept. 23 (AP)  Alan Lowry picked up his own fumble and dashed 34 yards to set up the game clinching touchdown tonight as the 14thranked Texas Long horns won a 2310 victory over scrappy Miami.

title: 11 COMPANIES MAKE PRICE CUT OR REFUND
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) The Price Commission has announced that 11 concerns cited for violating price con trol or profit margin regula tions have dropped prices or made refunds to customers as compensation.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass.With proper Yankee cunning, the organizers of the Martha's Vineyard Striped Bass and Bluesfish Derby have devised a system where by the thousand of dollars set aside as prize money will be spent on the island and not carried off to the mainland.

title: WASHINGTON
description: Our greatest blessing, says Socrates in Plato's dialogue Phaedrus, comes to us by way of madnessmania. In this arresting statement, Plato does not mean mania as a disease but rather as a state during which man experiences a kind of selfrevelation occurring through the emergence of a powerful spirit from the depth of his being. Poetical words, tones and ges tures, and even prophecy, are the ex pression of enthusiasmthe god with in. Apparently certain drugs can help in generating this inspired state. But Plato traced inspiration to the primeval forces that Greek mythology symbol ized in the form of deities, especially Dionysos.

title: Italy and Greece:
description: ROME  Relations between Rome and Athens have often been strained since Sulla's legions sacked the Parth enon in 86 B.C., and Mussolini's ag gression on Greece 32 years ago didn't exactly foster amity in our time.

title: Cohasset Skippers Lose
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 23  The Western Long Island Sound team defeated Cohasset, Mass., skippers, 9 to 11, un der the lowpoint scoring sys tem off Larchmont Yacht Club today in the opening race of their annual interfleet match.

title: Level of Mercury Is Found Safe In Food Commonly Eaten in U.S.
description: The most commonly eaten foods in the United States, with the exception of certain fish, are free of significant quan tities of mercury contamina tion, Food and Drug Adminis tration scientists have found.

title: Mrs. Wendy Curll To Marry Nov. 25
description: MAPLE GLEN, Pa., Sept. 23Mrs. Wendy C. H. Curll of Lake Bluff, Ill., and Wil liam J. C. Surtees of Chicago plan to be married in Chi cago on Nov. 25. Announce ment of their engagement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Christopher J. Henry Jr., parents of the future bride. Mr. Surtees is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Conyers A. Surtees of Godalming, Sur rey, England.

title: Russell Etherington Marries Miss Dixon
description: ST. DAVIDS, Pa., Sept. 23 Miss E. Thayer Dixon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Henry Dixon of Rosemont, was married here this after noon to Russell L. Ethering ton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bur ton H. Etherington Jr. of Haverford. The Rev. Richard Hess performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. David's Chapel.

title: Northwest La. Harriers Win
description: LAKE CHARLES, La., Sept. 23 (AP)Northwest Louisiana won a fourmile crosscountry race among nine college teams today with 32 points. Houston, in 17 years the winner of 106 meets, was second with 39.

title: Villanova Wins, 2017
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 23 (AP)Villanova got two long secondhalf scoring passes from Mike Sunday and pulled out a 2017 victory today over Wil liam and Mary.

title: Preps
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 23 Ron McMahon returned the opening kickoff 93 yards today and Bridgeton Academy went on to defeat Worcester, 70.

title: Preps
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 23 Touchdown runs of 80 yards and 3 yards by Ted Berry offset two scoring receptions by Craig Jacobs as Loomis registered a 2414 victory over Hopkins today.

title: Miss Kempe Bride Of William Wolfe
description: In the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday, Miss Margaret Anne Kemp and William Allen Wolfe, former students at Syracuse University, were married by the Rev. Kenneth Jones.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 23  The Communist party newspaper Pravda reported today that the Chinese leadership has refused to accept a Soviet proposal for a ChineseSoviet pact on non aggression and avoidance of force.

title: The conversion of a square
description: Theodore Roszak's The Making of a Counter Culture (1969) was a revelation. It coined a phrase and disclosed new substance in familiar matters. It argued with much tentativeness and a conse quent plausibility that the activities of techno cracy's children, from the reading of dirty comics to the kidnapping of deans, from the quest for psychedelics to the casting of horoscopes to seques terings in the commune, amount to more than scat tered waste products dropped out from the official culture. These activities, Roszak argued, amount to a distinct and separate culture, whose dense con sistency is of an opposition to the culture of white, western masculinity, its idolatry of science, and the scurrilous, positivistic atheism of its Marxist sibling rivals. The counter culture, like any other, has its own history, heroes, values, villains, crafts, styles and rationales, all of which Roszak was able to fit more or less together as something un mistakably there, whether one liked it or not. Given the alternatives, found it hard not to like it.

title: Preps
description: MADISON, N. J., Sept. 23 Barry Robinson sprinted for touchdown runs of 63 and 61 yards as Madison swept to a 270 victory over Delbarton. Robinson sandwiched his two secondhalf scores around a 30 yard touchdown pass from Chris Natale to Mike DeAngelis.

title: SpanishSpeaking Justice
description: BOSTON, Sept. 23 (AP) An tonio Del Rios of Framingham took office this week as the state's first Spanishspeaking justice of the peace. He is di rector of the Office for the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico in Boston.

title: The mind and heart of a secessionist
description: I hereby declare my unmitigated hatred to Yankee ruleto all politi cal, social and business connections with the Yankees and to the Yankee race, Edmund Ruffin wrote in the final entry of his diary, two months after Appomattox. Then he picked up his shotgun and killed himself.

title: Headliners
description: When Nazi storm troopers invaded his court four decades ago, he ordered them to Get the hell out! When he was attacked by two youths in New York's Riverside Park 16 years ago, he beat them off. But last week, at the age of 65, set upon by three young robbers, he fought back and paid with his life.

title: Hadfield: Canada Six Unhappy
description: Vic Hadfield, the Rangers' all star left wing who quit Team Canada in Moscow, said yester day many members of the team were annoyed with the coach, the training camp routine and the booing by their Canadian countrymen.

title: McGovern Aide Counts on Registration
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  Senator George McGovern's strategists believe his campaign has been making striking prog ress on a largely unnoticed frontvoter registrationwhile, he has been lagging in more visible areas.

title: Repairs Due on Hazardous Parkway
description: A 3,700foot section of the Interborough Parkway, one of the most hazardous roads in the metropolitan area, will be modernized in an effort to make it safer.

title: LETTERS
description: E. Spencer Miller's idea in trigues me, but I cannot say that I support it at the pres ent timeI don't know enough about it. My immedi ate response would have to be a qualified no, based on the fact that I have no de tails.

title: BergenPassaic
description: Hackensack, which compiled an 81 wonlost record last sea con, received a superb twoway effort from Lee Larkins yester by and posted a 140 victory aver Wayne Valley at Wayne.

title: Director Asserts Marshals Averted 25 Air Hijackings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) United States marshals have prevented at least 25 attempts to hijack airplanes in the last three years, their directors said today.

title: INDIANS APPEAL ACADEMY CLOSING
description: ROSWELL, N.M., Sept. 23 Two leading Indian tribal offi cials have called for the con tinuation of the United States Indian Police Academy.

title: China and Japan Set Up Reciprocal Bank Deals
description: TOKYO, Sept. 13 (AP)The Bank of Tokyo said today it had opened a yen account with the Bank of China and the Chi nese bank has opened a Yuan account with the Japanese bank.

title: The Ripeness
description: This is the time of ripeness, in the fields, on the tree, the bush, the vine. The acorn and the grape achieve their purpose, to the satisfaction of squirrel and raccoon. The highbush cranberry and all the other viburnums are heavy with fruit, as they were white with blossom and loud with bees only a few months ago. The dog woods, large and small, are bright with berry, and al ready beginning to brighten in the leaf. The milkweed pods are ready to burst and strew the wind with autumn shimmer. The tang of windfalls scents the air where apple blossoms made May a delight to the eye.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 23  The 14yearold tuna war off the Pacific coast of Ec uador has subsided into an uneasy cease fire, with lit tle left to fight about.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: INTERNATIONAL economic relations are at a low ebb and in danger of further erosion. The happy rap prochement of the nineteensixties on trade and tariff issues is withering fast without, unfortunately, much recognition and concern. At a time when more than 100 nations were sending top economic officials to Washington for their annual conclave on monetary prob lems and hoping for progress on reforms to promote the expansion of world trade and investment, there was the ironic disclosure last week that a unit of Congress had taken a backward step on the issue of freer trade.

title: Eve Kanon Affianced
description: The engagement of Miss Eve R. Kanon to Michael Bruce Plan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Plan of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. D. Daniel Kanon of Forest Hills, Queens. Miss Kanon is a student at Hunter College and her fianc is attending New York University.

title: Grounding Skyjackers
description: The stern antihijacking bill adopted overwhelmingly by the Senate demonstrates to the world the determina tion of this country to get tough with aerial terrorists at home and abroad. Its timing was fortunate, coming as an extra prod to wavering delegations at the United Nations General Assembly in their heated debate this weekend. The coalition of Arab states, China and a few African governments seems to be losing ground in its obstruction to Secretary General Waldheim's courageous bid to focus the Assembly's attentions on the issues of global terrorism in all of its sordid expressions. Secretary of State Rogers intends to give this agenda proposal his strongest support when he addresses the United Nations tomorrow.

title: Undaunted by Injury He Passes Key Test
description: COLTS NECK TOWNSHIP  Sitting on his horse, Richard D. Farr smiled all the way into the future, his thoughts barely interrupted by the prize being handed to him.

title: Hollywood in interviews, memos, a memoir, pictures, a biography
description: Back in the thirties, my best friend at school shaved off her eyebrows so she could pencil in thin, arched lines like Dietrich's. Armed with lip stick brushes, we painted on big, juicy mouths like Joan Crawford's or we frizzed our hair and pouted, hoping somebody would catch the resemblance to Clara Bow. Only Garbo, so uniquely beautiful, de feated us.

title: Basque Activists Creating Tension in Spain
description: BILBAO, Spain, Sept. 20 Basque extremists are once again active in northern Spain in a resurgent effort to prove that the nationalist sentiment of one of Europe's most an cient races is still alive.

title: Virginia Cairns Wed to Albert S. Callan
description: HUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 23 Miss Virginia Ann Catherine Cairns, a member of Gover nor Rockefeller's staff and associate director of the Women's Unit of the State of New York, was married here this afternoon to Albert Stevens Callan, editor and publisher of The Chatham Courier.

title: 180 Learn in PublicService Project
description: TRENTON  One student spent the summer prepar ing defenses for inmates in dicted during the Rahway State Prison revolt last year. Another updating and re writing Camden's master plan, and a third determined waterpollution levels in Union County.

title: Preps
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Sept. 23  Lawrenceville used four goalline stands and the strong running of Corky Ellis and Scott Collidge to defeat Penn Charter today, 2216, in the opening game for both teams. Ellis and Collidge combined for 216 yards on the ground and three touch downs, Collidge's two scores coming after he had switched from defensive back.

title: 2 Tasty Ways to Cook Long Island Scallops
description: Here are two suggested ways to cook scallops:

title: Make sure every American is given the opportunities
description: Count me with the bleed ingheart liberals who be lieve that the most signifi cant action that can be taken against crime is action de signed to eliminate slums and ghettos, to improve educa tion, to provide jobs, to make sure that every American is given the opportunities and the freedoms that will enable him to assume his responsi bilities. In 1967 these were the words of the President's Commission on Law Enforce ment and Administration of Justice, which included Lewis F. Powell, President Nixon's recent Supreme Court ap pointment, Leon Jaworski and Ross Malone, past presi dents of the American Bar Association, William Rogers, Secretary of State, and others, none of whom are soft on crime.

title: MISS DAVIS'S JOB REVIVED AS ISSUE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23  Another dispute involv ing Angela Davis, the contro versial black scholar, appeared in the making here this week.

title: Busy Peddler Of Monetary Reform Abroad
description: WASHINGTON  One of the more soughtafter people at the annual fiveday clam bake and jamboree of finance ministers and central bank ers that opens here tomor row will be Paul A. Volcker.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 23 (AP)  The Democratic state chairman, J. C. Kennedy, an nounced today that he was re signing his party post because he could no longer actively support the Democratic nomi nee for the United States Sen ate, Representative Ed Edmond son.

title: Pistons Triumph, 109103
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (UPI) Dave Bing scored 18 points and Curtis Row added 16 to pace the Detroit Pistons to a 109103 victory over the Cleve land Cavaliers in a National Basketball Association exhibi tion game tonight.

title: MIAMI AREA GETS STATE UNIVERSITY
description: MIAMI, Sept. 23Florida In ternational University, the first state university in greater Miami, opened its classrooms this week to 5,500 students.

title: Art
description: LONDON, quite aside from being the last civilized metropolis in the world, offers right now a staggering richness of temporary art exhibitions for any visitor who can tear himself away from the inex haustible permanent attrac tions of the British Museum, the National Gallery, and half a dozen other institu tions bearing witness to man's greatness in spite of his foibles.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Senator George McGovern is plan ning some fireside chats for the near future, and well he might. He senses, probably correctly, that he is not making much of a personal impact on the voters, although the Democrats have been recently encouraged by the large crowds he is drawing and by daily evidences that the party and its traditional labor support are beginning to rally round the candidate.

title: Mary Liggett Bride of Richard Rinzler
description: SOMERSET, Pa., Sept. 23 Miss Mary Anne Liggett, a chemist, was married here this afternoon to Richard Rinzler of Willow, N. Y., an architect. The Rev. robe J. Carey of the Universal Life Church performed the cere mony at the Hidden Valley Farm Inn.

title: The World
description: UNITED NATIONS  For a while it looked as though the 27th Gen eral Assembly session would be just another tired rerun, but by the end of last week it was obvious there were a few things new.

title: Brel Is Back
description: IN the beginning there was Broadway, which con ceived, produced and popularized entertain ments, then sent them on the road. Now there is Off Broadway, which does the same job except that it sends its successes to the new roadBroadway. Under this dispensation, Jacques Brel is Alive and Well and Living in Paris has decided, after years and years of mak ing carousel music at the Vil lage Gate in the youknow where, to stop by on 45th Street for a projected six week stand, with the music box tinkle and the offtothe races orchestral swell as en ticing, as enveloping as ever.

title: Part Time Jobs Are Found for the Elderly
description: HACKENSACKA retired 67yearold salesman was able to use his longtime hobby  Commercial art as a source of income. A retired engineer found gain ful employment as a drafts man. More than a year ago, a job applicant was referred to a motherless home, and she has been there ever since  cooking, marketing, tend ing the childrento fulfull her role as a salaried mother substitute.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Times' editorial Roots of In equality (Sept. 10) correctly recog nized the false premise of the Jencks report on schooling. Equality of oppor tunity does not remove individual dif ferences in competence, aspirations and effort. Every knowledgeable psy chologist knows that improving the environment, especially educational opportunity, does not produce uni formity; rather, by removing the lid, it gives each individual a chance to maximize his or her potential.

title: College Here Names Dean
description: Dr. Margaret A. Green, who concentrated on student admin istration in her doctoral studies at Columbia University, has been, appointed dean of students at Manhattan Community Col lege. Prior to her appointment, Dr. Green served for three years as the dean of student af fairs at Butler County Commu nity College in Butler, Pa.

title: NATO WAR GAME IS TEST FOR NAVY
description: ABOARD U.S.S. INTREPID, in the North Atlantic, Sept. 21  The largest NATO war game ever held is an important anti submarine warfare exercise for the United States Navy.

title: MRS. BALLARDKANE
description: MILTON, Mass., Sept. 23 (UPI)Mrs. Anna M. Ballard Kane, a leader in Roman Catho lic relief and fundraising mis sions, died Thursday. She was 80 years old.

title: Jubilee and Pirate Victors On Indian Harbor Cruise
If You Go
description: to Haiti, here is a little an thology of things to do there: Skin dive.

title: Padres Stop Braves, 41
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 23 (AP) Steve Arlin won his first game in two months tonight, limiting the Atlanta Braves to seven hits in pitching the San Diego Padres to a 41 triumph.

title: Salt Marsh Is Studied For a Way to Save It
description: STONE HARBOROne of the world's most ambitious conservation projects, the preservation and evaluation of biologically essential marshlands, is under way in this tiny Cape May County municipality.

title: 3 That Start The Festival
description: Bunuel to Warhol, Brando to Burton, Jane Fonda to Leon Trotskythe 10th New York Film Festival will cover the international scene starting Friday night at Lincoln Cen ter's Alice Tully Hall.
