Twen tytwo films will be screened, the last of them Bernardo Ber tolucci's Last Tango in Paris on Oct. 14.

title: In a Nigerian Marketplace, Modern Doodads and Ancient Ritual
description: KANO, Nigeria, Sept. 6 I need money badly, ?? du Kano, a blanket ?? in the teeming Kurmi market, ?? out to a grimy Euro pean couple who had recently crossed the Sahara in a Land Rover.

title: PENALTY FOR BRIBERY STIFFENED BY ATHENS
description: ATHENS, Sept. 23The Gov ernment has adopted a law to curb corruption in the admin istration by doubling the min imum penalty for officials who solicit or accept bribes to a year in prison.

title: Toledo Group Raises Bond For Black Murder Suspect
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 23 Bond of $150,000 for the re lease of a 28yearold black man charged with the fatal shooting f a white patrolman was posted yesterday by a group of, 50 white and black Christians and Jews of the city.

title: Woodhaven Blvd. Rerouting
description: The northbound roadway of Woodhaven Boulevard between 61st Road and 63d Drive in Rego Park, Queens, will be made twoway for about four weeks beginning Monday, the Traffic Department said yester day. The southbound roadway is being closed at that area for repairs. Upon completion of this section further reroutings will be announced.

title: The World
description: This is by far the most comprehen sive agreement on environmental co operation ever entered into by any two nations.

title: REV. FRANCIS J. MARIEN
description: LOS ALTOS, Calif., Sept. 23 (UPI)The Rev. Francis J. Mar ien, a Jesuit scholar, writer and former head of the philoso phy department of the Univer sity of San Francisco, died of a heart attack yesterday at the age of 52.

title: Historical Park Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, in troduced legislation this week that would establish a historical park in Boston that would in clude Faneuil Hall, the Paul Re vere House, the old State House, Old North Church, Bunker Hill and the Old South Meeting House.

title: Hollywood in interviews, memos, a memoir, pictures, a biography
description: Gavin Lambert's On Cukor pro vides the perfect conjunction of au thor and subject. The author of The Slide Area and Inside Daisy Clover has interviewed the director of The Philadelphia Story and A Star Is Born, interspersing Cukor's own comments with shrewdly illu minating remarks of his own. The result is very far from being a con ventional movie interview book. It is an act of Boswellian dedication by a graceful and witty writer in honor of an equally graceful and witty filmmaker.

title: FOOTBALL INJURY RESULTS IN SUIT
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 23 Plays from a college football scrimmage held seven years, ago on a freshman practice field were replayed here this week on the floor of State Su preme Court, in the trial of a $3million lawsuit against Col gate University that may have implications for organized foot ball.

title: Black Studies Termed Not Practical for Jobs
description: PITTSBURGH, Sent. 23 (AP)  Arthur A. Fletcher, execu tive director of the United Negro College Fund, says courses in black studies are nice, but not very practical for black students who want to get a good job.

title: Local
description: Jefferson, which lost 21 of 22 starters from last year's Pub lic Schools Athletic League championship team, showed yesterday it had enough talent left over to challenge for an other title. The Jeffs over whelmed Tilden, 328, in a Brooklyn Division I game to run its winning streak to 10 straight.

title: Antoinette L. Roberts Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Alex ander Roberts of New York have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Antoinette Lewis Roberts, to Benjamin Brewster, son of Mrs. John G. Jones of New York and Charlottesville, Va., and Edward Cox Brewster of Easton, Md., and Upper St. Regis, N. Y.

title: Mirror Mirror On the Wall
description: Where Portnoy has led, oth ers must follow; and, as the Elizabethan expression goes, where it itches one needs must scratch. Stanley Ellin has had the itch, and he has scratched forth a novel. Its central char acter is not named Portnoy; that would be plagiarism, sort of. Instead he is named Peter Hibben and this is a crime novel, sort of.

title: STATEWIDE PACT ON TEACHERS EYED
description: Manly Fleischmann, who headed a commission that re cently completed a study of ed ucation in New York State, said last week that one of the body's upcoming proposals  that the contracts of all teach ers be negotiated on a state wide basis  would increase the possibility of a statewide teachers' strike.

title: Genevieve Bartlett Engaged to Richard Fricks, Poet
description: BRONXVILLE, N. AY., Sept. 23Mr. and Mrs. Aurelius T. Bartlett. 2d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Genevieve Wilson Bartlett, to Richard Park Fricks, poetinresidence in the Hamilton County School's of Chattanooga. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Park Fricks of Rising Fawn, Ga. The wed ding will take place here Oct. 14.

title: Carolina Official to Press for Burial of Immigrant
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 23 (UPI)  State Attorney General Robert Morgan has promised that his office would act to force the speedy burial of the body of an Italian immigrant carnival worker that has been displayed, until recently, at a funeral home at Laurinburg, N. C.

title: David S. Woodruff Marries Amy Nolan
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J., Sept. 23  Miss Amy Louise Nolan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Nolan of Mountainside and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married here this morning to David S. Woodruff, son of Prof. and Mrs. William Woodruff of Gainesville, Fla. The Rev. Raymond D. Aumack per formed the ceremony in Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church.

title: 8 TOWNS OPPOSE RECREATION PARK
description: DEEP RIVER, Conn., Sept. 23 A consensus has developed in the eight towns in the lower Connecticut River valley against any move to include recreation facilities in a proposed national park along the river.

title: SAN JOSE STATE BEATS CALIFORNIA
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP)  Dale Knott raced for the winning touchdown with 9 minutes 49 seconds to play to day as San Jose State upset California, 1710, in a noncon ference game.

title: Son Born to the Silvers
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. John Silver Jr. of New York and Carmel, N. Y., on Sept. 18 at Mount Sinai Hospital. The child has been named Lincoln Douglas. His mother is the former Miss Olwen Newsham of Lan caster, England, and his fa ther is a vice president of the City Investing Company.

title: Toy Library Helps in Teaching Preschoolers
description: MORRISTOWNNew Jer sey's preschool children are the focus of at least two na tionally tested educational projects currently being ex panded in the state.

title: Art
description: MAKING predictions is not, I believe, one of the functions of criticism. Yet there are times when certain signs and portents have to be ac knowledged, if the terms of criticism are to be fully understood. I think we are entering such a time as the new art season begins to un fold. We are in for some changes in what the art pub lic is going to be asked to consider appropriate objects of its concern.

title: MonmouthOcean
description: Middletown spotted powerful Bayonne two early touchdowns yesterday, then fought back in the second half for a 13.13 tie at Middletown.

title: GA. TECH TOPPLES MICH, STATE, 2116
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 23 (UPI)Georgia Tech's quar terback, Eddie McAshan, threw two touchdown passes and then the Yellow Jackets withstood a furious fourthquarter rush by Michigan State today to post a 2116 win.

title: Views of the Review
description: Your article on air travel in The Week in Review section of Sept. 3 uses words such as illegal, un derground and abuses without se riously examining the problems in volved in charter flights and their patrons.

title: Letters:
description: There was something fishy about the story, included in Torben Krogh's Wel come to New York (Travel section, Sept. 3), of the Scandinavian who had a smoked salmon confiscated by a customs official at Kennedy Airport. I travel to Europe four or five times a year and I regularly bring back smoked salmons, purchased either at Shannon Airport, Ireland, or Heathrow Airport, London. In. August I returned from London with two smoked salmons (see enclosed gold wrapper) without any trouble after declaring and showing them to the customs inspectors at Kennedy. The author reported that his acquaintance's smoked salmon was wrapped in newspaper, which would lead me to believe that it was home smoked and of dubious purity. In that case, the customs people were right in confiscating it. It is permissible to import smoked salmons that have been cured in regular commercial business establishments.

title: Nassau South
description: A dozen South Shore teams got the jump in league play on their counterparts in scattered activity yesterday, including Uniondale's 1916 decision over Calhoun, a South Shore Divi sion II rival.

title: Notes: Indian Resort
description: MOST American Indian reserva tions have become enclaves of depression and failure, with the only signs of economic activity shops selling authentic Indian arti facts made in Hong Kong or Japan. But there are an increasing number of ex ceptions, one of which is the reservation of the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, Ore., with about 2,000 enrolled members from the Warm Springs, Wasco and Paiute tribes. The Confederated Tribes recently opened KahNeeTa Lodge, a $5.1million resort and conven tion center 114 miles southeast of Port land. The bulk of the funds for the lodge came from a grant and a loan made by the Economic Development Ad ministration of the United States De partment of Commerce. The Tribal Coun cil put up $200,000 of its own money after two referendums conducted among the Indians authorized it to do so.

title: Pop
description: ROD STEWART: Never A Dull Moment (Mer cury SRM 1 646). When the mass media uses foresight instead of hindsight, we'll be seeing Rod Stewart's grinning face in every slick magazine instead of Mick Jagger's pouty kiss er. Jagger may be the big gest thing since Gelusil to sortie editors, but it seems to me that Rod Stewart has a lot more to do with 70's rock than do the Stones. Stewart has the wit to turn the whole superstar trip into a giggle. Wearing glittery, satiny suits, he prances around on stage with his tongue firmly in his cheek. Despite his gold records and SRO performances in gigan tic stadiums, Stewart's sense of humor will save him from all of those Truman's and Lee's and Zsa Zsa's who have begun to make rock stars their toys.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE PRICE OF GOLD in London plummeted to $61.25 an ounce last Monday on prospects of $50anounce South African gold, but by the weekend the price had recovered to $03.90.  Rumania has applied for mem bership in the World Rank and the International Mone tary Fund.  Japan's Hitachi Metals, Ltd., is negotiat ing with a potential American partner for a joint metal venture in this country.

title: The Films That Honor Dr. King
description: RIDGEWOOD For about 25 persons from this commu nity and surrounding areas, suburban Sunday nights were not inviolate this summer. Instead of enjoying backyard barbecues or swimming pools, Sunday nights they went to work by going to the movies.

title: Rome Intensifying Its Investigation of the Mafia
description: ROME, Sept. 23A parlia mentary commission that has been investigating the Sicilian Mafia for more than eight years is about to revamp its investigative machinery and broaden its scope in a climate of outrage over the continued power of organized crime.

title: 3 Are Seized in Brooklyn In Moonshine Trafficking
description: Brooklyn patrolmen arrested three suspected traffickers in moonshine yesterday after dis covering eight cases of the il licitly distilled liquor, labeled yams, in a truck bearing North Carolina license plates.

title: Still Too High
description: Housewives are less likely than the White House to take comfort from the news that higher living costs for the first full year of wage  price controls stayed just inside the upper edge of President Nixon's 2 to 3 per cent target.

title: Dalton Routs St. Paul's
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 23Dalton moved the ball at will after a slow first period and romped to a 347 victory over St. Paul's today. Roy Sam uelson, the Dalton quarterback, scored twice on runs and threw a 40yard touchdown pass to Orlando Wright. Dalton's clos ing score was a 70yard return of a kickoff by Jason Ekaireb.

title: An Urban State, It Is Full of Wildlife
description: TRENTONA black bear, 3 or 4 years old and 200 pounds, lured by some es pecially fragrant garbage, pads out of the woods and makes a raid in town. In Alaska?

title: Letters:
description: A traveler's elation on coming to New York after a long absence, as described in Welcome to New York, reminded me of the excitement and exhilaration of the country folk of America who come here for a visit. I have never seen the equal of such spontaneous and delightfully childlike exuberance in the many parts of the world I have visited. Nothing excels the enthusiasm of the visitor from Ohio or Indiana or even from Painted Post, N.Y., as he goes gleefully about the city, especially if it is a first visit.

title: Retiree's Hobby Works On
description: ENGLEWOOD From the time he was a Missouri schoolboy, Sam Cousley has collected everything from nickle and dime paperbacks to the autographs of Presi dents. Now his lifelong hobby has gone to work for him as a postretirement career that keeps his entire family on its toes.

title: Astros Defeat Reds, 71
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 23 (AP) Don Wilson retired the first 18 men in order en route to a fourhitter and Jim Wynn hit his 23d home run as the Houston Astros beat the Cin cinnati Reds, 71, tonight.

title: Conservatives: A Fading Star?
description: The Conservative party on Long Island is fighting for its life.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Any attempt to define the shape of the future relation ships between the business community and society would be a foolhardy effort at best. Tomorrow, we are assured, will be graced by such con cepts as social responsibility, redistributed wealth, a clean environment, affirmative ac tion and ombudsmanship.

title: Alimony for Martindale
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (UPI)A Superior Court judge has ordered Winston Martin dale, a television entertainer, to pay $1,400 a month alimony and $1,400 a month in child support to his former wife, Madelyn. The judge also granted Mrs. Martindale cus tody of their four children ranging in age from 11 ?? 17. He sued for divorce in August after 18 years of marriage.

title: Letters:
description: The articles recall tragedies that I have not witnessed but are nevertheless ingrained in the German conscience. I was born in Germany on Aug. 31, 1939, the last day of peace before the invasion of Poland. Germany is aware of its hor ror history and my generation is in volved in overcoming its blackness now and in coming years. But in printing those articles during the Olympics you pointed to the most evil times of Ger man history Just when Germany had the chance to show the world a better face. You have presented a denial to the younger generation that it is possible to strive and try for a better image. I am not the one to say, Let history alone, forget the past. I have to say, Know your history well but overcome it, re deem it if you can and learn not to repeat the mistakes. As a German liv ing in this country, I feel it seems almost impossible for a new generation to make its own image in the eyes of the world. Westhampton Beach, L. I.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Another in the growing num ber of books about airline safe ty procedures, only this is your captain speaking. Captain X criticizes the obsession of certain airline managements with speed in favor of safety and deplores the lack of sophisticated guid ance equipment at many air ports. He somewhat predictably defends his fellow pilots against what he claims is the alltoo frequent verdict of pilotfail ure. Captain X doesn't just complain but offers construc tive suggestions.

title: Baffin High in Elizabeth, the Only AllGirl Public School
description: ELIZABETH  With wom en having invaded Prince ton and Vassar a coed col lege, the days of the single sex school might seem to be over.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LONDON, Ky., Sept. 23 (AP)Campaigning in one of the nation's most strongly Republican areas, Vice Presi dent Agnew defended the United States bombing of North Vietnam today and re jected the contention of Sen ator George McGovern, the DemocraticPresidential can didate, that the Vietnam war is immoral and unpopular.

title: ANN ARBOR EASES MARIJUANA CURBS
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 23 Under the trees on the Uni versity of Michigan campus, in the back rows of movie theaterseven, it is said, in the public gallery of the City Council chamber itselfyoung people are increasingly light ing up marijuana in public these days.

title: Hanoi Aide Sees 4 More Years of War
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 23 (AP)A leading North Viet namese editor has said that his country is preparing for four more years of war if President Nixon, as he expects, is re elected.

title: The WinnersAnd Still Champions
description: YOU'D expect that seeing the same play twice in a period of a few monthseven a play as rock solid, bitterly funny, painfully shaming as Jason Miller's That Champ ionship Seasonwould take something away from it. After all, you've been told the playwright's secrets and can no longer be surprised. But director A. J. Antoon's superb management of five flawless actors remains so riveting, now that the play has moved from the down town Public to the uptown Booth, that the loss of surprise proves no loss at all. It is possible, this time around, to occupy yourself wholly with the orchestration.

title: 2 Rabbis Ask to Withdraw MailFraud Guilty Pleas
description: Two Orthodox rabbis, who in July had pleaded guilty in Federal Court to mailfraud charges arising from their hav ing enrolled students in a fic titious university, have asked to withdraw their pleas.

title: Forbidden No Longer
description: The Forbidden City has seldom seemed less forbid ding, on the eve of Japanese Premier Tanaka's arrival in the Chinese capital tomorrow. For Peking, this is the year's second great diplomatic extravaganza in honor of a visiting statesman from a once untouchable foreign power. For Tokyo, it marks Japan's grand entrance onto the world stage as an economic power pursuing an independent foreign policy.

title: Education
description: The choice for New York Univer sity, posed last May by an intensive examination of its dire financial condition, was stark: The state's largest private university could go down in the most spectacular fiscal crash in the history of American education, or it could pull itself out of the hole by its own bootstraps.

title: Nora Fleming Is Bride
description: NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 23 Miss Nora Lynn Fleming, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Fleming, was married here this afternoon to Frederick Stevens Wilson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Wilson of Roslyn, L. I. The Rev. Wendell Ligon per formed the ceremony in the Calvin Presbyterian Church.

title: FERTILITY LEVEL IN NATION CLOSE TO ZERO GROWTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 For the first time, fertility in the United States has dropped to the replacement levelthe threshold of zeropopulation growth.

title: 3 TeenAgers Are Seized In Attempt to Rob Market
description: The police arrested two teen agers and shot another after the three allegedly attempted to rob a A. & P. supermarket at 121st Street and Third Avenue in Harlem last night.

title: Exemptions From Civil Service Examinations for Some Lawyers in City Government Challenged in a Suit
description: Evelyn Junge went to work for the city's Law Department shortly after her graduation from New York University Law School in 1969. She was hired as a provisional (temporary) at torney in the Consumer Affairs Division, earning $11,400 a year.

title: Scheel China Trip Expected
description: BONN, Sept. 23Foreign Minister Walter Scheel will leave for Peking about Oct. 10 to make final arrangements for full diplomatic relations with China, sources close to the West German Government said here today.

title: Most people who met her disliked her
description: Surely no President's wife collect ed as many enemies as Mary Todd Lincoln did. John Hay, Lincoln's sec retary during the Civil War, re ferred to her apprehensively in his diary as the Hellcat. William Hern don, Lincoln's law partner, who had known Mrs. Lincoln before the war and who detested her then and later, called her the female wild cat of the age and, exhausting his jungle vocabulary, a tigress and a she wolf.

title: China Cotton Deal Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)  Representative John G. Schmitz, Republican of Cali fronia, who is the American party Presidential candidate, predicted today that a big cotton deal with mainland China will soon be announced similar to a $30million wheat sale announced last wee. Repre sentative Schmitz, who has urged stopping aid and trade with Communist nations as a theme of his campaign, asked that the Nixon Administration under no circumstances send cotton to China until two im prisoned American airmen were released.

title: Shopping Center For Postmasters
description: SOUTH SOMERVILLEA onestop shopping center, with no carts or checkout counters, is operated by the United States Postal Service in South Somerville, just out side of the Somerset County seat. However, shoppers are limited to United States post masters.

title: UGANDA FIGHTING IS SEEN NEAR END
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 23 Most of the Uganda exile guer rilla forces that invaded their homeland a week ago have re treated into Tanzania or have been killed or captured, wellin formed East African sources said today. If true, this would mean that the fighting in Ugan da was near an end.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: It is true that the O'Neill Playwrights Conference has its problems, but we must re member that this organiza tion is the only one in the country that gives play wrights the unusual oppor tunity to work on their plays with professionals. I wish we had more summer camps like the O'Neill.

title: DONALD J. MAVEETY
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 23  Donald J. Maveety, a retired chemical engineer who had been with the National Biscuit Com pany for 35 years, died yester day in Overlook Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 19 Brooklawn Drive, Short Hills.

title: Miss Roberts Is Bride of Lawyer
description: FENWICK, Conn., Sept. 23 The marriage of Miss Prudence Fenwick Roberts, an associate editor of Hard ware Age, published by the Chilton Company of Phila delphia, to Franklin L. Best Jr., a lawyer with the Phila delphia firm of MacCoy, Evans & Lewis, took place here this afternoon.

title: Who Is It That Makes A Movie Great?
description: IN 15 years of working the sound stages of Hollywood, of being em ployed by almost every major stu dio, I have never heard anyone connected with any film say, We've got a great screenplay and we're going to shoot it like it is.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The playing texts of five flops, with a general introduc tion and a postscript exegesis on each play by the drama critic of Cue. Look: We've Come Through by Hugh Wheeler, The Beauty Part by S. J. Perelman, The Last Anal ysis by Saul Bellow, Xmas in New York by Jack Richardson, Johnny NoTrump by Mary Mercier. Anyone sorting his memory on the nondramatic blind alleys of these plays will read with no change of mind. For the buffs who must have everything.

title: J.W.T. and the President
description: J. Walter Thompson has been one of the most prolific suppliers of manpower to the Nixon Administration, with three of its former executives now occupying sensitive White House posts, and at least seven others holding lesser jobs.

title: This Pool Player Stays Put
description: Jimmie Cattrano Jr., the 1971 American Billiard As sociation champion, dispels most of the myths cultivated about aimlessly wandering billiards players.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: There is no doubt that advertising of television news is today big business, said Christopher Ridley, director of advertising and press in formation of WCBSTV, New York.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  The Nixon Administration and the labor leaders who have formally adopted a neutral pos ition in the Presidential race are developing an increasingly cordial relationship  judging by recent words and actions from both sides.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 23  Prime Minister Heath's Conservative Government has dropped to a new low in public esteem, ac cording to a poll published to day in The Daily Mail.

title: Carl Linde a Photographer For Associated Press, Dies
description: DALLAS, Sept. 23 (AP)Carl E. Linde, a photographer who covered some of the world's big gest stories in his 47 years with The Associated Press, died today of complications follow ing surgery. He was 63 years old.

title: New & Novel
description: When you read that the au thor of this political novel has been PR director of the Liberal party and is currently press sec retary to the deputy mayor of New York (who's that?), you feel you can count on a puff piece. Far from it. In transmut ing into fiction (?) the wildand woolly New York State election of 1970, Irving Schiffer has made an expert and exhaustive search for warts. His findings are truly epidemic.

title: Jets Strive to Break Colts' Spell Today
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 23  Since the Baltimore Colts switched to the American Foot ball Conference of the merged and realigned National Football League two years ago, they have won four straight games against the New York Jets, their tormentors in the Super Bowl game of 1969.

title: A Shield for Newsmen
description: The Justice Department, in testimony before a House Judiciary subcommittee, has opposed legislation to shield reporters from subpoenas that might impair the confi dentiality of their sources. Assistant Attorney General Roger C. Cramton explained that the department does not oppose in principle the kind of protection demanded by the news media but it considers the Attorney General's personal supervision of the existing guidelines as suffi cient guarantee of a free press. He cited the sparing use of the subpoena during the last year as proof of respon sible exercise of power by the department.

title: Saving the spare
description: Intermediate players are sometimes ?? about the play of aceking ?? when the queen is miss ?? and a finesse may be indicated. ?? one of the top honors be cashed ?? Take these holdings:

title: BARRIER BEING BUILT ON GOETHALS BRIDGE
description: HOWLAND HOOK, Staten IslandWhile most motorists sleep, a median concrete bar rier is being installed on the Goethals Bridge that crosses the Arthur Kill from here to Elizabeth.

title: Judge to Rule on Legality of Importing Cane Cutters
description: MIAMI, Sept. 23A Federal judge here is expected to rule next week on the legality of importation of foreign workers to cut sugar cane in Florida.

title: Elizabeth Ann Wheeler Bride of Martin B. Iselin
description: Miss Elizabeth Ann Wheel er daughter of, Mr. and Mrs. Roy L. Wheeler Jr. of East Aurora, N.Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Martin Baxter Iselin, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Iselin of Shrewsbury, N. J. The Rev. Dr. Terance J. Fin lay performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episco pal Church.

title: It's HawkWatching Time on the Hills
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR  As trees begin to show fall colors, and roadside stands put out the first apples of the year, this is football or backtoschool time to some, or the start of the social sea son. But to a small flock of devoted birders, it means hawks.

title: Medicine
description: WASHINGTON  In prehistoric times the CroMagnon man learned to smear saltpeter on his mastodon steaks to help preserve their shelf life in his cool cave. Today, many of his de scendants are wondering if that first use of food additives was such a smart idea.

title: Stop countenancing selective obedience to the law
description: When I was asked to con tribute to this discussion of crime control in New York City, my reflex solution was pretty much the standard one: Hire more police, give them better training, get more of them out on foot patrol, pour in Federal funding for bigger guns, faster cars and louder radios, give the cops greater powers by repealing the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth and Four teenth Amendments, and then build bigger jails to hold the increased number of criminals the more efficient police would arrest.

title: 2 Are Arrested in Alleged Plot To Kill 2 Buffalo Police Officers
description: BUFFALO, Sept, 23Two men were arrested early today and charged with conspiracy to murder two detectives in the narcotics unit of the Erie County Sheriff's Department, and two other suspects were being sought in the alleged conspiracy.

title: SUCCOTH FESTIVAL IS BEGUN BY JEWS
description: The weeklong Jewish Festi val of Succoth, or Feast of the Tabernacles, began with synagogue services at sundown Friday as Jewish leaders em phasized the festival's theme of thanksgiving and happiness.

title: The Shape of Illusion
description: Ludwig Lorenson, owner of the Lorenson Galleries in Man hattan, invites four of his friends to see a 17th  century German painting. Rabbi Gerson Mahler arrives first, declares the painting antiSemitic, and leaves in anger. But the three others, Kirk Donner (a painter and the story's narrator), Neil Carlton, editor of a magazine like Christian Century, and a Jesuit priest, Joseph Graney, are in for a shocking exper ience. The painting shows Jesus in the courtyard of Pontius Pi late, surrounded by a mocking crowd. Each of the three sees his face in the crowdbut can the others'.

title: Missouri Lutherans Seek End To Controversy Over Seminary
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23\A tem porary respite in the bitter doc trinal controversy at Concordia Seminary was gained here this week through a series of appar ent peacemaking moves by the district presidents of the Lu theran ChurchMissouri Synod.

title: The World
description: LONDONOne of the best selling books in Britain last week was a 520 page paperback called Pornography, a title emblazoned on the cover in twoinch red letters. Its critics insist ed it was selling well because people thought it was dirty and even seedy shops stocked it. Its defenders at tributed the public interest to a seri ous and widespread concern about the rise in pornography.

title: GEM TAKES HONORS IN WINKLE CUP SAIL
Local
description: Lincoln, which cried foul last year when deprived of a spot in the Public Schools Athletic League championship playoff, suffered an early season jolt yesterday losing to Brooklyn Tech, 246, at Lincoln Field. The loss, in a Brooklyn Division I league game, ended Lincoln's 10game winning streak, going back to 1970.

title: CIVIL WAR LIBRARY IS PLANNED IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, Sept. 23 (AP) The Spanish Government is preparing to create a national library dedicated to the Spanish Civil War, making accessible thousands of books, documents and photographs from both sides. Officials say they expect the collection from the losing Republican side to outnumber nationalist papers by 2 to 1.

title: RHODESIA LEADER HINTS AT A SHIFT
description: BULAWAYO, Rhodesia, Sept. 23Prime Minister Ian D. Smith has quelled a revolt against his leadership and sig naled his intention at his party congress here to try again to reach a settlement with Britain of the dispute arising from Rhodesia's selfdeclared inde pendence.

title: Erving Defies Ruling And Plays for Hawks
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 23 (AP)Julius Erving, playing in defiance of a ruling by the National Basketball Associa tion, scored 28 points and pulled down 18 rebounds to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 112109 victory over the Kentucky Colonels in an ex hibition game.

title: Soaring Explorer 47 Called Good Bird in a Good Orbit
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla. Sept, 23 (AP)Explorer 47, a flying physics laboratory heading for an orbit extending more than halfway to the moon, was de scribed today by space officials as a good bird in a good orbit.

title: It's Boat Show Time Again
description: It's like an old joke with a new twist: if you laid all the outdoor, inthewater boat shows end to end, it would stretch the imagination. The funny thing is, it's no joke. They do stretch from Newport, R. I., to Annapolis, Md.five of them all within 16 days, conflicting on dates, vying for customers and exhorting deal ers to show their boats.

title: Jacksonville Road, an Area of FamilyOwned Farms
description: PEQUANNOCK  Only 30 miles northwest of New York City, Jacksonville Road here is a link between the fast fading familyownedandop erated farms, and the en croaching suburban villages.

title: the traveler's world
description: TRAVEL is, as the old saw puts it, broadening, as broadening and enlightening as the individual tour ist permits it to become, and some of the sometimes minorkey bits of in telligence picked up moving about America are fascinating. The following are the result of a month of motorized travel, first in New England and then, backtracking, into the Midwest.

title: Rhode Island Wins, 277
description: KINGSTON, R. I., Sept. 23 (AP)Kim Purcell passed for three touchdowns today as Rhode Island defeated North eastern, 277.

title: M'ANALLY OF EXPOS HALTS PIRATES, 30
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23. (AP) Ron Fairly's tworun homer and three double plays gave the Montreal Expos a 30 vic tory today over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Braving the Elements
description: The time eventually comes, in a good poet's career, when readers actively wait for his books: to know that someone out there is writing down your century, your generation, your language, your life  under whatever terms of difference makes you long for news of your self, for those authentic tidings of invisible things, as Wordsworth called them, that only come in the interpretation of life voiced by poet ry. With an impatience that picks up The New Yorker to see if there is a new poem, that goes to poetry readings to glean another sheaf, Merrill's readers have been assem bling this, his sixth book of poems, in their minds in order to possess it before it emerges between covers.

title: Letters:
description: The spoliation that was predicted In the article on Hagia Galene, Crete, Where Nothing Is All There Is to Do (Travel section, Aug. 27), as being many years away has already come. I was there a few weeks ago and witnessed one of the worst tourist scenes of my traveling experience. The little village was overrun by tourists, mostly back packers. The atmosphere was tacky (colored lights on the main street), English was heard everywhere on the mobbed streets and, worst of all, the few small restaurants were unable to feed the hordes of tourists. Fortunately, there are several villages in the south of Crete that still offer the solitude and type of charm described.

title: CHESS: Paul Morphy in 19th Century Devised Modern Principles
description: Paul Morphy, sometimes thought of as the only world chess champion America pro duced before Bobby Fischer, was born in New Orleans in 1837. He learned the game from his father, who was welloff financially and an ar dent chess fan. When he was 10 years old, Morphy de feated the best available players in his city. At 14, he began studying chess theory.

title: MOSCOW REBUKES CRITICS IN FRANCE
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 23As So viet relations with the United States are on the mend, Mos cow's normally smooth rela tions with France are suddenly showing some signs of strain.

title: In Search of Elusive Scallop Which Seems Scarce Again
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I.  For 51 weeks a year Russell Miller of Sag Harbor is a motor mechanic. Once a year, though, on his vaca tion, he puts aside the tools of his trade, gets out his dredges, and joins the pro fessional baymen to go scal loping.

title: A FossilHunt, ala GoldDgging
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS At the crack of dawn on a Sunday, a dozen persons were energetically digging a deep hole on a wooded slope along the south shore of Rar itan Bay. Their frenzied dig ging, their disheveled and worn denim clothes, the far away gleam in their eyes made them appear something like Klondike miners.

title: The Nation
description: CLEVELANDI think the polls are rubbish. In Columbus, Ohio, last week, Senator McGovern snapped at the sofamiliar question, Why are you 34 points behind? I don't know where they conduct these polls I think they make these things up in the back room some where.

title: Crowds Flock to Woodland Trail in Great Swamp
description: NEW VERNONSince its dedication last May, more than 75,000 people, have walked over the Woodland Swamp Trail in the Great Swamp.

title: New york
description: The guy was a saint. It was just one of hundreds of tributes paid to Manhattan Representative William F. Ryan following his death last Sunday. He died at 50, less than three months after his victory in a hardfought pri mary campaign.

title: Animals Believed Extinct Reappearing in Finland
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 23 (AP)Many types of wildlife previously considered extinct in Finland or limited to the north ern wilderness are beginning to reappear in the populated southern part of the country.

title: JOHN J. CATTERALL
description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., Sept. 23John J. Catterall, a retired partner in Arthur Young & Co., New York public accountants, died today at his home, 3 Circle Lane. His age was 60.

title: 450 in Java Die of Cholera
description: JAKARTA, Indonesa, Sept. 23 (UPI)Nearly 450 persons have died in a recent outbreak of cholera in West Java, medi cal officials here has an nounced.

title: SAMUEL MIKULANECZ
description: MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 23 Samuel M. Mikulanecz, former president of the Connecticut Conference of the International Typographical Union, died yes terday at St. Raphael's Hospi tal in New Haven. He was 52 years old and lived at 17 Grassy Lane here.

title: Rockland
description: A preseason favorite, Nyack, swarmed all over Pearl River in the first half and coasted to a 290 victory in the Public School Athletic League opener for both schools yesterday at Nyack. Clarence Evans, one of 21 returning lettermen, scored on runs of 2, 9 and 3 yards.

title: Researchers Complete Analysis of MakeUp of Gene
description: A Belgian research team has for the first time completely analyzed the chemical makeup of a gene that dictates the pro duction of a protein, an achievement that appears to bring closer the day when genes can be made to order and turned on and off at will.

title: MorrisSomerset
description: Watchung Hills brought an end to New Jersey's longest unbeaten string yesterday when it upset Bridgewater  Raritan East, 108, in Warren Township.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: American Telephone, the volume leader, was a star in last week's generally listless stock market. The nation's most widely held issue gained 2 points to finish 47 after reporting an increase in quarterly profits.

title: STANFORD VICTOR OVER DUKE, 106
description: DURHAM, N. C., Sept. 23 (UPI)Stanford's reserve quar terback, Mike Boryla, entered the game in the third quarter and fired the Cardinals to their lone touchdown today and a 106 victory over Duke.

title: Pop
description: MARK VOLMAN & HOW ARD KAYLAN: The Phlores cent Leech & Eddie (Reprise 2099). About 1967, the Tur tles, a particularly amiable singing group with an over grown sense of humor, emerged on the pop scene with a couple of very large hits and an image of cheerful naivet. When the Turtles disbanded, Volman and Kay Ian, who were the guiding spirits of the group, pro ceeded to give that image a devastating boot in the be hind by affiliating themselves with Frank Zappa's Mothers of Invention, a crew who have lovingly amassed for themselves the reputation of being the freakiest degener ate fungi in the business. (Images are the most fun.) From there the exTurtle duo went on to make themselves useful as background vocal ists for other particularly weird pop stars like T. Rex. Now they are on their own, sounding not at all like the Mothers and only as much like the Turtles as you would expect from two singers who haven't had larynx trans plants since their last group.

title: Nichols Routs New England
description: DUDLEY, Nlass., Sept. 23 (AP)Nichols routed New England College today, 486.

title: REVSON GETS POLE IN CANADIAN RACE
description: BOWMANVILLE, Ontario, Sept. 23Peter Revson, the only American regularly run ning the Grand Prix circuit, set a qualifying record for Formula One cars today and put his Mc LarenFord on the pole for to morrow's running of the Cana dian Grand Prix.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The idea, of course, was for the President to be the President the thoughtful states man diligently attending to the af fairs of state while those less bur dened took his candidacy into the noisy arena of the national campaign.

title: E.P.A. ACTSTOSAVE A MINNESOTA LAKE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Minnesota, the land of 10,000 lakes, hopes to have one of its dying lakes restored by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Miss Menis, Rumania, Sets DiscusMark:220Feet10
description: BUCHAREST, Sept. 23 (AP) Argentina Menis of Rumania set a women's world discus record today with a throw of 220 feet 101/2 inches during a track meet involving athletes from Finland, Sweden and Ru mania at Constanta.

title: WISCONSIN ROUTS SYRACUSE, 31 TO 7
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 23 (AP)  Wisconsin, sparked by the running of Rufus Ferguson and Rudy Steiner's two touch down passes to Jeff Mack, turned three recovered fumbles into scores and rolled to a 317 football victory over Syracuse toddy.

title: Maura F. O'Melia Wed To Timothy C. Bowen
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 28  Miss Maura Francis O'Melia, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. O'Melia of Westmoreland Hills, was mar ried here this afternoon to Timothy Casey Bowen, son of Mrs. George Edgar Bowen of Bethesda and the late Mr. Bowen. Msgr. Henry F. Grae benstein performed the cere mony in the Little Flower Roman Catholic Parish.

title: Nixon Opposes Amnesty and Urges Curbs on Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)President Nixon wound up a quick campaign swing through Texas and flew back to the White House today to tell a new group of labor backers that he still opposed amnesty for United States mili tary deserters and welfare for people who would not work.

title: LETTERS
description: I would like to say Amen to E. Spencer Mill er's article A Prescription for Railroad Recovery (Sept. 10).

title: Preps
description: CHESHIRE, Conn., Sept. 23 Paul Grillo tossed three touch down passes and two more for conversion to lead Cheshire to 2220 openioggame victory over BordentownLenox today.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: Barnes's over  opinionated, underinformed political review doesn't even attempt to ex amine the style or content of the book he is covering. He compounds his errors by pre senting a onesided picture of both the Army and the Point  then showing how popular his viewpoint is by citing the names of one general and numerous disgruntled colonels to support his propaganda points.

title: Some Interesting Social Events in the Weeks Ahead
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Show Spotlights Threatened Species
description: The American Museum of Natural History has opened a Never Say Die exhibition calling the public's attention to the threat of extinction facing the American alligator, timber wolf, Atlantic salmon, peregrine falcon and black footed ferret.

title: The Return of the HiFi Spectacular
description: CONSIDERING the fact that the football season has just begun its an nual season of trauma for wives, it may not come as a precisely joyful report that a high fidelity show is returning to New York this week after a fouryear hiatus. There are, I suspect, vast num bers of indulgent marital part ners who remember long, footweary hours of trudging from one earshattering dis play to another, eagerly seek ing out the latest in space age gadgetry for the high fidelity hobbyist.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: America's growing fondness for travel on two wheelson motorcycles, mini bikes and bicycleshas touched off another kind of boom that has safety experts worried: a steady rise in deaths and injuries from cycling accidents.

title: Swedish Weekly Is 100
description: The Swedishlanguage week ly, NordstjernanSvea, printed in New York City, celebrated its 100th anniversary last week. Since its first issue, Sept. 21, 1872, the paper, which has A circulation of 6,000, printed news of Sweden and the Swe dishAmerican community. It is circulated on the East Coast and in Sweden itself.

title: POLICE HOLD WOMAN IN BABYSWAPPING
description: UNION SPRINGS, Ala., Sept. 23 (AP)State troopers said they had seized a woman at a carnival in this south Alabama town today who is wanted by the authorities in Florida for allegedly exchanging her 3 monthold son for a used car.

title: Jewish Activist in Moscow Freed After 3 Days in Jail
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (AP) Gavriel I. Shapiro, a Russian Jew married to an American woman, has been freed after spending three days in a Mos cow prison, Jewish sources re ported today.

title: The productive years as a dramatist
description: At the beginning of the sec ond volume of the Collected Letters, Bernard Shaw, at 41 (look barely 55, he confesses to Charlotte PayneTownshend, soon to be Mrs. Shaw), was a successful journalist and critic, a celebrated public speaker, a practical politician, both as ves tryman in St. Pancras and as a member of the Executive Committee of the Fabian Socie ty. He was also a playwright, butso far as audiences were concernedhis plays, at the beginning of 1898, were pretty much private vices. Florence Farr had presented Arms and the Man for a brief run at the Avenue Theatre in 1894 (man ufactured into a London success at a net loss of about 4000 Shaw wrote an old friend), and A. E. Drinkwater had taken the play on a disastrous provincial tour; in America, Richard Mans field did beter for Shaw, first with Arms and the Man, then with The Devil's Dis ciple. For the most part, his first eight playsincluding Candidawere going begging and, although Shaw regularly recommended them to actors and managers, he was al most resigned to publication instead of performance. Plays Pleasant and Unpleasant was in the press.

title: Suffolk
description: Tim Allen's pass interception and 47yard run for a touch down early in the fourth quar ter gave Riverhead High a 146 triumph over Southampton in Suffolk County's oldest gridiron rivalry. It was the 57th renewal of the series between the two schoools, which dates back to 1908, and more than 2,500 fans were on hand.

title: Three poets: physical, courteous, indispensable
description: Auden was once brilliant but un comfortable at verse. His very bril liance seemed an effort to twist and elide his prosy materials into song. Now, by contrast, he is comfortable and wise. The inventive fever has died, he is swaying in the tree of his laurels.

title: The O'Neill Conference: Was It Good for Writers?
description: I've just seen an ad in The Times for the highly touted upcoming British play But ley, and now I can under stand why the Broadway theater is in trouble. Who can afford it?

title: Calder Dash to Opera Fan
description: MIAMI, Sept. 23 (AP)J. E. Suzyn's Opera Fan took advan tage of Clardenita's inability to run a straight course today and won the $10,000added Viscaya Stakes at Calder Race Course.

title: OPPOSITION PAPER FINED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, Sept. 23One of Saigon's two remaining opposi tion newspapers has been heavily fined and one of its executives sentenced to a year's imprisonment for having pub lished a report on a Cornell University study on American bombing in Indochina.

title: Views of the Review
description: Your allusion in The Week in Re view section of Sept. 10 to the Biblical dictum of an eye for an eye as the guiding principle of Israeli policy could lead to a serious misunderstanding of the humane, classical, historical Jew ish tradition. The text in Exodus XXI states a general principle com mon to many cultures, namely that the punishment shall fit the crime. The notion of measure for measure was intended to prohibit excessive punishment such as was common in Dickens's England and is still common in Greece and Russia. It related to damages inflicted by one individual upon another within the community and had no bearing whatever upon in ternational conflict. Most important, the binding rabbinic interpretation of the Biblical text is that in all cases monetary compensation is intended.

title: Haiti has put on many faces, and most of them have wound up on canvas. For a look at Haitian art past and present see Page 6.
description: THE flight to PortauPrince is filled, as usual, with odd visitors: the mildly Bohemian, the Franco philes, the lovers of primitive art, music and sex, those who crave a piece of strange. But now things are different. There is a nonstop jet from New York almost every day, and who is that sallow, sad, esthetic, wornout chap in the seat ahead of me? A French composer? An Italian poet? No, he's reading some legalsize papers in Eng lish; he's an American on his way to the new oneday divorce factory in PortauPrince.

title: The World
description: NAIROBI Uganda's slide toward chaos accelerated last week and in doing so it threatened the peace and economic wellbeing of the Central Af rican country's neighbors.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: The occasion was a fund raising dinner in Chicago, the kind of evening when the priest giving the invocation bluntly asks the Almighty for His help in electing a straight Demo cratic ticket.

title: Alabama Triumphs, 350
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 23 (AP)Jerry Davis capitalized on Kentucky mistakes for two quick Alabama touchdowns to start the Crimson Tide to a 350 football victory tonight.

title: Universities Flunk Investing
description: Universities are slow learn ers. Just over five years, ago, McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation, took a look at the way colleges administer their investment programs and leveled harsh criticisms of timidity and in eptitude.

title: Japan Bus Plunge Kills 15
description: TOKYO, Sept. 23 (AP)Fif teen persons were killed today and 63 injured, 12 seriously, when a crowded bus near Nagano, northwest of Tokyo, plunged from a mountain road 154 feet to a valley below.

title: S.M.U. CONQUERS FLORIDA BY 2114
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP) Alvin Maxson's flashing runs spurred Southern Methodist to its second straight victory of the season tonight, whipping a sluggish Florida team, 2114.

title: American Seeks to Reclaim Plane Lost in Web of Mexican Red Tape
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 20  An American millionaire busi nessman arrived in Mexico City last weekend and began a final effort to recover his $480,000 airplane, held by the Mexican Government for a year and a half despite two Mexican court decisions.

title: FREED PILOTS FAIL TO ARRIVE IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 23 The North Vietnamese Gov ernment, unaccountably, did not allow the three American prisoners of war that it re leased last week to leave Hanoi today as had been expected.

title: Guaranteed Income Urged By Spock for Neighborhoods
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) Dr. Benjamin Spock, Presi dential candidate of the Peo ple's party, proposed today the establishment of minimum in comes for neighborhoods.

title: News of Dogs
description: The dog show scene shifts to Long Island this week, with the Brookhaven Kennel Club event on Friday at Blue Point and Suffolk County on Saturday, at Lake Grove.

title: BOWLING GREEN WINS FROM MIAMI OF OHIO
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Sept. 23 (AP) Don Taylor, a freshman, booted a 27yard field goal and Joe Babics, the quarterback, plunged 1 yard for a touch down with one second left as Bowling Green defeated Miami of Ohio, 167, today.

title: Nicholas Ray: Still A Rebel With a Cause
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y. The screening room was leaking. During the night a wash basin on an upper floor had overflowed, leaving a large, drippy patch of ceiling about half way between the screen and the area where the members of the audience were standing and sitting, on the floor, on chairs and on tables, and sometimes on each other. Someone said there had been a beer party upstairs and no one had been paying attention. In the course of the screening itself, there was hardly a three or fourminute interval in which one of the five projectorsfour 16 mil limeters and one Super 8did not break down, each time prompting Nicholas Ray to call Cut. Cut, and to ask for a rewind. The showing was also meant to make use of a 35mm projector but one of the young technicians said that it certainly would blow a fuse.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: All the Raiders Need Are Some Professional Skaters
description: BRICKTOWN, N. J., Sept. 23  In a cheery, tidy rink called the Ocean Ice Palace, 70 miles from Broadway on the Jersey Shore, the New York Raiders are staging one of the more bizarre training camps pro hockey has wit nessed.

title: Social Announcements
description: Anniversaries

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I., Sept. 23 Senator George McGovern, in his first campaign foray into Nassau County, stressed today two sensitive issues in the sub urbs  reduction of property taxes and increased education aid.

title: Letters.
description: As a parttime Westchest er, parttime Manhattan dweller, I found Laura Hen ning's account of adjustment to the suburbs undeniably realistic, if not typical. How true that city dwellers such as Mrs. Henning may be burdened by myths about suburbia. This situation ap pears to make the voyage of adapting to the suburbs more satisfying, as myths are even tually destroyed and replaced by happy, realities.

title: Eyes Right, But Is the Spiel?
description: THE Wonderful AllDay Tour got under way one recent Fri day morning with the notso wonderful announcement that the airconditioning system on the Gray Line sightseeing bus wasn't working. The announcement, unfortunately, came after the 40 or so passengers had settled themselves on the bus with their purses and their cameras. It came, indeed, after the bus had pulled away from Gray Line headquarters, at Eighth Ave nue and 53d Street, by which time, of course, it was too late for anybody to demand a refund of his $13, or, if you think in terms of couples, $26.

title: Connecticut
description: West Hill of Stamford, play ing its first season in the S.C.I.A.C., threw a scare into Stamford High yesterday, but the defending state chmapions managed to come out on top, 136.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The Presidential contest may be providing precious little suspense these autumn days, but the political corridors and salons are full of speculation about the possi bility of a Republican takeover in the Congress.

title: A Man Is Stabbed by a Stranger In the Middle of Times Square
description: One man was stabbed and critically injured in the thick of a crowd of leisurely Satur day afternoon sightseers in Times Square yesterday, and later another man was stabbed after a dispute on a Times Square subway platform.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LAS. VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 23, (UPI)Sargent Shriver, wea ried by weeks of campaigning, was treated today for a sore throat and chest congestion.

title: Spearpoint
description: For years, when teachers be gan to talk to me vacuously, as they do, about language, imagination and children, I cut them short by asking: Have you read Teacher, Sylvia AshtonWarner's book. That book was about Miss Warner's experiences with Maori chil dren in New Zealand. She taught them to read and write by grounding their use of lan guage in their inner feelings and images, their dreams and imaginations. She seemed to understand the relation of lan guage to the soul, and their relation to collective reality. There was something magically simple but also magical in both her approach to teaching and her book; the homage she paid to the inner lives of the young restored not only their lives, but also the reader's, the read er's inner life.

title: Preps
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 23 A senior quarterback, Dave Hardin, scored all three of his team's touchdowns as Newark Academy rolled to a 196 vic tory over Hun.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: F.B.I. Chief L. Patrick Gray's recent series of proAdministration speeches raises a question which could never have been asked of his politically neu tral predecessor.

title: ANTIDRUG EFFORT IN CITY TO EXPAND
description: An expansion and refine ment of priorities in the city's antiaddiction program was an nounced yesterday following a threehour meeting between Mayor Lindsay and President Nixon's chief antidrug aide, Dr. Jerome Jaffe.

title: TV
description: SHE appears at the end of a long dark corri dor as in so many of her horror movies; a little dog is yapping at her heels. And then the light flares up behind her as she opens the apartment door wider and it's Joan Craw ford standing there in a print hostess gown saying in that familiar husky voice, Come on in, but don't mind me. I've got something the matter with my god damn eyes.

title: Elis Can Fail, but Yale Will Forget
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 23 A Yale undergraduate now can fail a course with a fair meas ure of impunity.

title: CITY AIDES' RIGHT TO GUNS AT ISSUE
description: City health inspectors had carried handguns as far back as they can remember, but legal experts are now search ing city and state administra tive codes to determine wheth er the inspectors actually have the right to.

title: Central Connecticut Wins
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. Sept. 23 (AP)Central Connecticut overwhelmed Springfield, 266, today. Dennis Schermerhorn ran for one touchdown and passed for another, and Jim Lally scored twice.

title: Prison Disturbance Quelled
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 23 (AP) Five prisoners were slightly in jured today when about 80 in mates were dispersed with tear gas during a disturbance at the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary, prison officials said. The inci dent began when three inmates locked doors to an inside visit ing area, preventing persons from visiting prisoners.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Tax Department plans to phase out a part of the bonus lottery system starting next month, Commis sioner Norman Gellman said yesterday. He explained that beginning with tickets sold for the Oct. 12 weekly lottery drawing, those persons holding tickets with the last two digits of the winning number sequence will no longer be eligible for the bonus drawing.

title: Old Mandolin Club Just Plinking Along
description: BASKING RIDGE  Back in 1932, a group of musi cians, mostly German immi grants, gathered at Mont gomery Hall in Irvington and formed the Newark Mando lin Club, which they expect ed to last as long as music existed.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: KENNETH H. BROWN'S article, The Average Was Lousy, on the Eugene O'Neill Play wrights Conference is a com plete betrayal of everything the O'Neill stands for.

title: The working writer emerges
description: Bernard Shaw never threw anything away. Ironically, the title suggests otherwise, but chuckerout is British for saloon bouncer, the title the nonagenarian Shaw suggested for a Chappelow photograph used on the jacket. Getting past the jacket, one has the impres sion of a large Shavian attic in which the editor has rummaged. Although many of Shaw's pa pers and effects were lifted by scavenging secretaries and self serving assistants to turn up eventually in American collec tions, the largest hoard remains in London, where the British Museum and the London School of Economics jointly comprise that spacious attic, the Museum being awarded by the terms of Shaw's will: Such letters and documents as might be worth preserving in a public collec tion. To the School of Eco nomics Shaw bequeathed Old diaries account books Bank passbooks paid cheques and their counterfoils expired agree ments box office returns and other records of my business operations and personal and domestic expenditure capable of being used by economic or legal historians or by biogra phers seeking documentary evi dence as to prices and practices during the period covered by my lifetime.

title: BROOKLYN PLAYER GOES FAR IN CHESS
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23The Australian team came a long way to the Chess Olympics in Yugoslavia. Five of the six members are of av erage strength for this presti gious gathering. The other is 24 year old Grandmaster Walter Browne.

title: Satisfaction Is Helping Strangers Who Have Problems
description: MONTVALE  Mrs. A., separated from her husband, had not yet returned home from work one night when a moving van pulled up to her home here.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: How many times have you seen wheat prices go up dur ing the harvest season? asked a North Dakota agri cultural expert last week.

title: Glenn Horan, Clarkson Alumnus, Marries Miss Linda Magnuson
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Sept. 23 Miss Linda Suzanne Mag nuson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy R. Magnuson, was married here this afternoon to Glenn Allan Horan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard N. Horan of Bedford Hills. The Rev. Thomas H. Hughart per formed the ceremony, in the Bedford Presbyterian Church.

title: An intellectual's fashion classics
description: Bonnie Cashin has a mind of her own. An artist and an outstand ing American designer, she is continually developing coura geous designs. But its not here today and gone tomorrow for her clothesshe is not afraid to hang on to an idea. Each season she evolves it until it reaches its simplest, most beautiful form. Then it becomes a Cashin clas sic. Some Cashin firsts: dress ing in layers, hardware closings, coats without linings and making leather high style. She pioneered accessories, too, with her leather boots, tote and shoulder bags. Next month she will receive the Coty American Fashion Critic's Award Hall of Fame.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A former President of the United States, then General George Washing ton in winter quarters with his army at Newburgh, read the riot act to his officers when he learned that some of them were in a cabal conspiring to overthrow the Congress and impose a military dictatorship upon this infant republic.

title: Miss McNally Wed in Suburb
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 23 Miss Catherine Berry Mc Nally and Calvin Edward Rafuse Jr. were married here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Sorrows by Msgr. Eugene A. Murtha.

title: Gardens
description: MORE than a dozen fresh vegetables can be grown all winter long if proper pro cedures are followed, Abun dant harvests are not likely not without a greenhouse or artificial lightbut a mod erate yield can be expected.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: At last a book on food ad ditives that steers a sensible course between the natural food fanatics and the food industry propagandists. Mr. Jacobson is not against chemi cals per se but is carefully look ing for those that are, or might be, harmful. He asks the ob vious question: why add bind ers, preservatives, etc., rather than improve foods naturally? The answer, of course, is that the former is cheaper. As a rule of thumb for additives: when in doubt throw it out.

title: Is Business Good for a Suburb?
description: Walter Carroll of Mont vale, chairman of the plan ning board and one of the prime movers in the success ful drive to woo business here, was flabbergasted at the meteoric spurt in con struction.

title: FORDHAM DOWNS ST. PETER'S, 227
description: Fordham registered its sec ond straight football victory, defeating St. Peter's, 227, yes terday at Jack Coffey Field.

title: Miss Falbo Wed to L. Rodman Page 3d
description: Miss Despina Georgia Fal bo and. L. Rodman Page 3d were married here yester day morning in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner) by the Rev. Alan W. Jones.

title: What's Great And Near Great In Musical Comedy
description: BEFORE Jack Kapp of Decca Records made the first original cast recording of a Broad way musicalOklahoma! in 1944  American theater music buffs had had to be content with such snippets as Victor's Gems from  series (Gems from The Pink Lady,  Gems from Robin Hood,  even a Selections from Show Boat by Paul Whiteman's orchestra with brief glimpses of Bix Beider becke's hot cornet and, on the reverse side, Paul Robe son singing Ol Man River) or occasional songs from a show sung by the original performerEdith Day sing ing Alice Blue Gown from Irene in 1920, for example, or Louise Groody and Charles King singing Sometimes I'm Happy from Hit the Deck in 1927 or Helen Morgan sing ing Why Was I Born? from Sweeet Adeline in 1929, all of them currently available on Originals/Musical Com edy/19091935, RCA Victor LPV 560

title: LILLIAN EICHMAN
description: Lillian Eichman, a lawyer here 45 years and former president of the Queens Wo men's Bar Association, died Fri day in Roosevelt Hospital at the age of 66. She lived at 242 East 19th Street and had her office at 51 Chambers Street.

title: New & Novel
description: The protagonist of this novel is something of a tall Holden Caulfield. Tall enough to be an ace basketball player in high school and collegebut incor rigibly sensitive and artless he has an average suburban up bringing: mother unstable, fa ther unfaithful, neighboring kids pretty bizarre. He slides into college and thence into a sum mer job at a warehouse where he pursues his unending quest to be well liked. Mr. Levitt strews his hero's progress to the brink of maturity with so cial caricatures. Some of them are too cute for comfort. Some are mighty funny.

title: Morgan Captures Title In Silver Star Sailing
description: TORONTO, Sept. 22Charles E. Morgan, known for his ef forts in building and sailing the America's Cup contender Her itaee, won the North American Silver Star championship today against 35 competitors.

title: Sagamore Toccoa, Cocker Spaniel, Scores at Ox Ridge for 32d Top Award
Is Rutgers U. Really Getting Its Money's Worth
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A ceasefire has gone into ef fect in an acrimonious pub lic exchange between the state's Chancellor of Higher Education, Ralph A. Dugan, and Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, president of Rutgers Univer sity, over how the 39,000 student statesupported insti tution should be run.

title: Florida State Triumphs
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP)Florida State scored early in each half today, on the passing of Gary Huff and the running of Hodges Mitchell, to defeat Virginia Tech's foot ball team, 2715.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 23Protestants and Ro man Catholics fought a gun battle today for 90 minutes before British soldiers broke it up.

title: New & Novel
description: This little horror tale has a split personality. The first half is devoted to the examination of a young American weirdo who spends his evenings in Rome spying on the apartment of his former love, Margaret, and her Italian boyfriend. Day time, Frank Wright paints un earthly flowersbut what he really lives for are those nights as a voyeur, when he feels that the lovers are in his power, as though he drew a magic circle around them, cast a spell, and confined them with in it.

title: NINE YEARS LATER, FEAR IN SKOPLJE
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 19  More than nine years after an earthquake collapsed most of this old Macedonian city, slamming people from their beds at 5:17 A.M. on July 26, 1963, some survivors of the disaster still tremble when they must enter a high building or a windowless room, climb a staircase or ascend in an ele vator.

title: It's the decent people vs. the ripoffs, in and out of uniform
description: All my life in one way or the other I've lived in the Ghetto and ever since I can remember there was always some sort of violence going on  fights, muggings, purse snatching, rapes, junkies and junkpimps, faggots and pros titutesand to enhance the ghetto world of violence around me, to help bring out its message of fear, hopeless ness and despair was the em bellishment of hot and cold running cockroaches and king size rats, of exploitation be yond compare, of pride and prejudice. But lest the people in the pretty Pleasantville sub urbs think that we of the ghetto dig violence and crime let it be known that the crimi nal element represents a com paratively small percentage of the total community. All the drugs that have been poured into our community by out side vested, organized inter ests have of course augmented the ripoffs by the junkies against the community via purse  snatching, burglaries, etc. But like, diggit, who brought hardcore drugs into our communities? It wasn't blacks or Puerto Ricans. It was another ethnic group that poured poison into our kids, and like I ought to know, hav ing been a junkie myself a mil lion years ago. I'd see the Lin coln Continentals cruise by and the bigtime pusher's face was stone white and like he didn't have no Puerto Rican or black accent.

title: Sharon McClane Bride of Glenn E. Sohm
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept. 23  Miss Sharon McClane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter D. McClane, was mar ried here this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. James of Jerusalem to Glenn E. Sohm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard T. Sohm of St. George, S.I. The Rev. Marlon Bowman performed the cere mony.

title: 5 Repertory Dramas Set At the McCarter Theater
description: PRINCETON  Princeton University's new profession al resident company will open its winter repertory season Oct. 26 with the world pre miere of an early work by William Alfred, the author of Hogan's Goat, the melo drama of life among the Brooklyn Irish that won the Drama Desk's Vernon Rice Award in 1965.

title: The boast of all possible worlds
description: On the flight to New York from West Falls, E. (arnest) F. (rank) Candid was restive. He examined his fellow passen gers with great care. Sup pose, he worried, one of them is a Marxist, Panther, Arab terrorist, I.R.A. gunman, or maybe just a parachutist with a screw loose.  His mind was put at rest only when he saw that the group flight consisted of nothing but bluehaired old ladies and 12 chiropodists heading East for a convention. Midway through the journey, just as Candid was closing his eyes to a George Peppard movie, a blue haired old lady and a chiropo dist leaped to their feet. The pair shouted as one: We are Mr. and Mrs. Elmer (Doc) Teasdale of Edgeworth, and we are neither Marxist, Pan thers, Arab terrorists, I.R.A. gunmen or parachutists with a screw loose. But we are sick of convenience foods, situ ationcomedy reruns; deterior ating cities; smug, sterile tract housing; soupy air; denatured airliners; shoddy railroads; in sincere government; barren political speeches; opportun ism parading as statesman ship. Why, even the dark nights of the soul are satur ated with talk shows peddling Henny Youngman's worst ma terial as if it were the Re vealed Word.

title: GREENLAND MOVES INTO MODERN ERA
description: GODTHAAB, Greenland, Sept. 16 (Reuters)Greenland, whose population 25 years ago was entirely dependent on hunting and fishing for a livelihood, still faces enormous problems in its transformation into a 20th century economy.

title: C. W. POST DOWNS WAGNER BY 170
description: GREENVALE, L. I., Sept. 23 Combining a stalwart defense with scrappy running, C. W. Post College over came its lack of a competent quarterback to defeat Wagner College, 170, before 2,185 fans at Hickox Field. Both teams are now 11.

title: WALL STREET
description: Most investors are thor oughly and painfully aware that the stock market in the United States has turned in a fairly unexciting perform ance so far this year.

title: Mrs. Harvey Wed to Bishop In the Suburbs
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 23  Mrs. Eleanor Janney Harvey of Brookville, widow of Walter Miles Har vey Jr., retired vice presi dent of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, was married here this afternoon to the Right Rev. Charles James Kinsolving 3d, retired Epis copal Bishop of New Mexico and Southwest Texas.

title: Photography
description: THE Photographic Tech nology Department of the. State University Agricultural and Tech nical College at Farmingdale, L. I., is offering four work shops in photography this fall: Small Format Photog raphy for the Professional, Color Workshop, Advanced Workshop for Photofinishers, and Introduction to Micro film Systems Technology.

title: Preps
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Sept. 23 The running of Bob Wallace and Jeff Levy led Woodmere over Englewood today, 80. Wallace scored the game's only touch down on a 12yard run and rushed for a total of 88 yards. Levy got the conversion and gaMed 107 yards.

title: The World
description: Chile's troubled political pot con tinued to boil last week, this time in the top ranks of the country's 60,000 man army.

title: BUILDING STRIKE ENTERS 12TH WEEK
description: A costly strike by construc tion workers that has halted work on some $2billion in new building here continued into the 12th week yesterday with pros pects for a settlement only slightly better as a result of a contract agreement reached last week that allowed the re sumption of mortar and brick hoisting.

title: CLEO LAINE SINGS LOCAL POP DEBUT
description: The British, who have been dropping one rock group after another on us for years, have meanwhile been hoarding what must be one of their national treasures. The treasure's name is Cleo Laine, a singer with a remarkable voice that ranges from an exotically dark, breathy quality to highnotetopping exclamations, as she covers sources from T. S. Eliot to Bessie Smith with a polished artistry rare in our own popular singers.

title: Air Force Routs Pitt, 41 to 13, With a Strong 2dHalf Attack
description: AM FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Sept. 23 (AP)Air Force, held to only 13 points in the first half, exploded in the third period today and went on to wallop a stagnant, fumble plagued Pittsburgh team, 4113.

title: INQUIRY IS PLANNED ON COAST TRANSIT
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 The fiscal affairs of the Southern California Rapid Transit Dis trict, serving Los Angeles and three other counties with a population of 10 million, will be investigated by the Joint Legis lative Audit Committee.

title: New & Novel
description: Simrit Raman is a divorce living in New Delhi with hordes of children and a tax problem the size of a python. She is also a sophisticated, cere bral, and delighted connoisseur of her native milieu. How, then, does it happen that so enlight ened a female has been hood winked by her exhusband as though she were a dimwitted slavey? The answer, relates Nayantara Sahgal in her cool epigrammatic style, lies in an environment that is sympathetic to the exploitation of women and encourages their passivity.

title: Auto Companies Queried
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)  The Price Commission has asked three foreign auto mobile companies to answer a series of questions about their pricing policies.

title: Music: More Pop and Rock Concerts at Princeton
description: PRINCETON  When the McCarter Theater, which had had a season of professional theater every year all through the sixties, decided last year to skip its theater series, Bill Lockwood, the McCarter's program director, decided to find out what the potential might be for expanded pro graming of pop and rock acts.

title: The World
description: BONNWas there anything like it in the practice of Western Parlia ments? Chancellor Willy Brandt de liberately provoked a vote of confi dence and then made certain that he would lose.

title: Mrs. Topkins Has Son
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 23A son was born Sept. 2 to Mr. and Mrs. Elliott S. Topkins in Richardson House in Boston. Mrs. Topkins is the former Miss Wendy Tarlow of Brockton.

title: Letters:
description: I was somewhat ambivalent in my response to your articles on a Jew's visit to Germany and about a concen tration camp in Poland (Travel section, Sept. 3), which presented vividly the horrors of World War II. No one with a remnant of intelligence would dispute the atrocities inflicted on the Jewish people. However, the articles seemed to indulge in a sense of moral superi ority which this country can hardly af ford or deserves. It would have been more germane to point out atrocities that this country directly or indirectly perpe trates, rather than subtly suggesting that the one and only moral catastropheof this century was committed by a foreign nation. If the Jewish disaster has any meaning, it should be the need to prevent abuses to human dignity and freedom.

title: Complicated Simple Things
description: Last time through the publishing haze, John Barth emerged with Lost in the Funhouse. With Chimera, four years later, his tale swirls through mythology. But this disap pearance is deceiving.

title: ARTHUR B. HAGUE
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 23  Arthur B. Hague, associate pro fessor emeritus of piano forte at the Yale School of Music, died Monday in the Veterans Administration Hospital at West Haven. He was 79 years old.

title: About 30 Tourists Die In Cafe Fire on Rhodes
description: RHODES, Greece, Sunday, Sept. 24 (Agence France Presse)About 30 foreign tourists were burned to death last night in a restau rant fire on this Greek sland.

title: Social Announcements
description: Births

title: Crucial Task Is Pressed By Hospital in Freeport
description: FREEPORT, L. I.On a quiet, treelined residential ?? in this South Shore vil lage is a hospital that be came this summer the first private treatment center for alcoholics and their families to be certified by New York State.

title: Miss Corker Bride Of Willard McCoy
description: Miss Elizabeth Corker, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. William F. Corker of New York and Quogue, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Willard Mason McCoy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond M. McCoy of Pleas ant Valley, N. Y.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In your editorial Civilian Control (Sept 17) you say in the third ?? graph: General Abrams' quality as an officer has not been in doubt. You are wrong. It is General Abrams' quality as an officer which is in seri ous question precisely in the context of your editorial.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: My play, Silverstein & Co., was an alternate at the O'Neill Playwrights Confer ence. One of the final twenty. There were letters promising that if there were time  There was no time. Not with the Jamaican Co., the Opera Co., the National Theater of the Deaf, and the Special Projects.
