So I asked Lloyd Richards, the artistic direc tor, if I could attend the con ference for a few days, inter view the playwrights, and perhaps write an article. He and George White, the direc tor, were receptive, and I ar rived during the final week of the conference.

title: Nuptials for Abbe Louise Parsells
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 23  Miss Abbe Louise Par sells, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman King Parsells, was married here this after noon to John Scott Welles Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Welles of Mount Kisco, N. Y.

title: Indian Civil Service Raise
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 23 (Reu ters)Some three million em ployes of the Indian Govern ment are to get an immediate monthly pay increase of 7 to 10 rupees (87 cents to $1.37) to offset rising costs, the Govern ment announced this week.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: DETROIT, Sept. 23  An auto seat belt that inflates like an air bag is being de veloped by the Allied, Chemi cal Corporation through its automotive products division in Mount Clement, Mich.

title: Center at Rutgers Testing Britain's Open University
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThere has been a flurry of activity at 5 Senior Street in recent weeks: the old house blos somed out in a bright new coat of paint, some furniture appeared and then people be gan to arrive emptyhanded, emerging a short time later laden with academiclooking materials.

title: Alice Cooper? David Bowie? Ugh! And Ugh Again!
description: UGH. Alice Cooper is ugly. His music is ugly. His boa constrictor is ugly. Why, then, is he the hottest rock act around? Because, my pets, ugly is in. Call it freak rock, transvestite rock or decadent rock, the uglies are the latest giggle on the pop music scene. Whether freak rock is just a momentary lapse in the development of popular taste or the harbinger of even greater excess remains to be seen, but the trend can't be ignored.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: How is one to explain the continu ing, enthusiastic use of massive air power in the destruction of Vietnam? Are the recordshattering air raids which are dropping tonnages greater than those dropped on all of Germany and Japan in World War II to be ac counted for by simply attributing them to the zealous carrying out of the President's order to protect our re treating soldiers and the evacuation of our troops? Or is there a more encom passing explanation?

title: Brigadier Gerard Takes Queen Elizabeth Stakes
description: ASCOT, England, Sept. 23 (Agence France Presse)  Brigadier Gerard, beaten for the first time in 16 races by Roberto last month, regained his winning form today by taking the Queen Elizabeth it Stakes.

title: MARIST SURPRISES MANHATTAN, 18 TO 0
description: Manhattan College, hoping to recover from last week's loss to Fordham, was surprised by the running of Neigoe Davis and lost, 180, to Marist Col lege at the winner's home field yesterday.

title: Coins
description: SPEAKERS for the edu cational forum to be held at the Great East ern Numismatic Asso ciation's convention in the Americana Hotel, Oct. 58; were announced last week by James McNeill of Phila delphia, first vice president. Val Pasvolsky, the American Numismatic Association's re gional field representative, will be the moderator.

title: The O'Neill Conference: Was It Good for Writers?
description: This is just to inform A. J. Antoon that his Cymbeline in Central Park last year was neither a flop nor anywhere near a flop. It was beautiful, lovely and wonderful. His concept of making it a child's nightmare (the child being, I presume, Cymbeline him self? His greatest contribution was to give the title character of that play a real character, which he totally lacks in the reading, and a very lovable one at that.) came across quite clearly, and one's laugh ter and enjoyment arose out of genuine affection for everybody, which in these cruel times is a very good place for it to arise.

title: BROOKLYN PLAYER GOES FAR IN CHESS
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23The Australian team came a long way to the Chess Olympics in Yugoslavia. Five of the six members are of av erage strength for this presti gious gathering. The other is 24 year old Grandmaster Walter Browne.

title: 2 Publishing Acquisitions
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 23 (UPI)The HarteHanks Publishing Company has an nounced the acquisition of publications in Yakima, Wash. and Orange County, Calif. These include The Yakima HeraldRepublic, a newspaper with a circulation of 40,000, and the VanDe Publishing Company, which produces a controlled distribution advertis ing publication with a circula tion of 600,000

title: MATRON IS TAKEN BY LA PREVOYANTE
description: La Prevoyante was just too good for her slim opposition in the $104,290 Matron Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A trip down memory lane for misspenclers of their youth ful Saturday afternoons watch ing all those improbable escapes. The authors, who have done excellent research and give accounts of most of the serials made, offer interesting asides on casting, production problems, technical effects. Su perman, for instance, had de ficient flight scenes. The his ory goes far back to The Perils of Pauline but omits foreign contributions to the genre, such the famous Fantomas.

title: The O'Neill Conference: Was It Good for Writers?
description: Cheers for Kenneth H. Brown! The playwright of The Brig has finally said some blunt and true words about the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center's milliondollar month for young playwrightsand also for old critics, aging Holly wood hacks and expensive importations of tripe.

title: Hairston, Unsigned, in Drill
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept 23 (UPI)  Happy Hairston, a Los Angeles Lakers holdout, prac ticed with the team for the first time today while negotia tions continued in his contract dispute. The Lakers said the 29yearold forward was in vio lation of his contract, which he was attempting to renegotiate for more money in an exten sion of its length.

title: Mrs. King, Mrs. Court in Final
description: ALBANY, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP) Decisive semifinal victories today moved Mrs. Billie Jean King and Mrs. Margaret Court into the final of the $20,000 Pacific Coast Tennis Classic.

title: Woodsy Owl Just Like Flag and Motherhood
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)The Senate was rou tinely passing minor bills yesterday when the clerk came to the last one.

title: About Pro Football
description: DETROIT, Sept. 23  Two important intradivisional games are on the National Football League's schedule tomorrow, the Lions playing the Minnesota Vikings here and Pittsburgh at Cincinnati. If the Lions can beat the Vikings, and they have not done so since 1967, they will have a twogame lead over the de fending cham pions of the Na tional Confer ence's Central Division. The game will be televised nationally, in New York on Channel 2 begin ning at 4 P.M.

title: DELAWARE SUBDUES GETTYSBURG, 647
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Sept. 23 (AP)Delaware, the nation's topranked small college foot ball team, converted two fum ble recoveries and a pass inter ception into touchdowns in the first 51/2 minutes today and went on to crush Gettysburg, 647.

title: Baylor, Despite 7 Fumbles, Rolls Over Missouri, 270
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 23 (AP)  A sophomore quarter back, Neal Jeffrey, ran for one touchdown and passed for an other today, leading Baylor to a 270 victory over Missouri in a game marked by 11 fumbles, seven by the winners.

title: Letters
description: I have read with deep cha grin Sheila K. Johnson's state ment that anthropology has never discriminated against women. I don't know what byway of anthropology Ms. Johnson has been wandering in, but studies by the Commit tee on the Status of Women of the American Anthropolog ical Association published in the Newsletter of the Associa tion have proven what most women in the mainstream of the profession have experi enced, that anthropology has discriminated against women and continues to do so.

title: Bill Withers: Just As I Am
description: OVER the years, American show business has managed to struc ture its own level of reality, its own behavior patterns for en tertainers who become, at the obvious instruction of managers, press agents and other guidance experts, the most absurdly unreal types imaginable. The Business generally creates personalities composed of equal parts of paranoia, childish insecurity and a fawning, plead ing oafishness that are all performance. Similarly, the new belligerence and icy toughness of the rock star are an act to hide all traces of human definition.

title: Carrolls Have Child
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., Sept. 23A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Merwyn A. Car roll of East Orange Sept. 7 in the St. Barnabas Medical Center.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 23 (UPI) An Israeli military source re ported today that an injunction was issued yesterday against Rabbi Meir Kahane and 19 other members of the militant Jewish Defense League ordering them to stay away from the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River and the Gaza Strip.

title: Flea Markets Grow in State
description: MAYWOOD  Flea mar kets are here to stay. These are the open marts in fields, schoolyards, town greens that are a hurlyburly of the used, the old and not so old.

title: GYPSYMOTH PERIL IS SEEN VANISHING
description: POUND RIDGE, N.Y., Sept. 23On the last days of sum mer, the 4,750 acres of trees within the Ward Pound Ridge reservation here are just be ginning to show hints of yellow and red. Most of the trees are still green. More important, al most all of them are still alive.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, dis closing that she had once voted Democratic, returned from a crosscountry campaign trip to day telling reporters her hus band is great and will win the election because people are better off than they were four years ago.

title: The World
description: Before the 1964 revolution that brought the military to power in Brazil, more than a dozen political parties were active in Latin America's largest nation. Within a year the Government abolished the old parties and created two new ones. One was the official Government party, ARENA; the other a token opposition group, MDB. Friday, MDB lost its leader, Rep resentative Oscar Pedroso Horta. He took a 90day leave of absence, pre sumably for health reasons.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ERIE, Pa.Stanley Franzcyk, an ethnic organizer for the Mc Govern  Shriver ticket, spoke passionately recently to a group of PolishAmericans here of their time for a day in the sun.

title: Fordham Beats Seton Hall In CrossCountry, 1550
description: Fordham won its first cross country meet of the season to day, defeating Seton Hall, 15 to 50, as Rams captured the first seven places. Mike Lisle, a freshman, finished first, cov ering the fivemile course in 26 minutes 42 seconds.

title: Dr. Haidak Is Fiance Of Deborah L. Walsh
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 23An nouncement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Walsh of this city and Wee kapaug, R. I., of the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Deborah Lesley Walsh, to Dr. Paul Michael Haidak, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Haidak of Pittsfield, Mass., and Block Island, R. I.

title: Sports of The Times
description: He's off ranch in Lewisville, Tex., not far from Dallas, where he grew up playing football and riding in rodeos He's still doing both. Walter Garrison is a unique National Football League player. There's no dolphin on the Dolphins, no eagle on the Eagles, but he's a cowboy on the Cow boys, the only one. Ask a Giants season ticketholder today at Yankee Stadium to identify the Dallas Cow boy and the answer will be, It's a midtown res taurant. Wrong, the Dal las Cowboy is Walter Garrison, running back. He's in his seventhseason now but the sophistication of pro football hasn't changed him. He's still all cowboy. Not long ago, he was in a telephone booth, lis tening for a telephone number he needed.

title: Patricia Heffernan Driggs Married to John Balassi
description: DEWITT, N. Y., Sept. 23  Miss Patricia Heffernan Driggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Paul Driggs of DeWitt and Point Lookimt, L. I., was married here this morning to John A. Balassi, son of Mr. and Mit. Augus tine G. Balassi of North Tarrytown, The Very, Rev. Raymond J. Swords, presi dent of Cranwell School in Lenox, Mass., performed the ceremony in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church: He was assisted by Msgr. Daniel O'Brien, the Rev. Williain Reilly, president of Le Moyne College, and the Rev. Thomas Flanagan, the bridegroom's cousin.

title: Schweitzer of I.M.F. Won't Quit His Post Despite U.S. Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 PierrePaul Schweitzer, opposed by the United States for anoth er term as managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today he had made no decision to resign and would accept the judgment of the whole membership of the fund.

title: Commissioner Aharon Sela, Israel's Top Policeman, 54
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 23Com missioner Aharon Sela died of a heart attack today, less than two months after his appoint ment as Inspector General, the country's top police post. He was 54 years old.

title: Portrait of a Swedish town
description: The Pantheon series on con temporary villages around the world has included some good books, not least because their authors took a broad view of what constitutes a village. This study of a Swedish town is singular, because its author re nounced a direct portrayal of the community. He gives us, instead, edited versions of what 12 of its inhabitants told him about their lives. We learn about their town, and about Sweden, by refraction. Perhaps there is a point to his method. Some social reporters, certain ly, schematize unduly. Com munity, after all, is what people experience. Or is it?

title: Two Men Found Murdered in Queens
description: Two men were found mur dered yesterday morning on a vacant street in a wooded area of South Ozone Park, Queens, near Aqueduct Race Track.

title: UnionMiddlesex
description: Westfield, New Jersey's best schoolboy football team in 1971, increased its unbeaten string to 34 yesterday with a 3314 vic tory over Clark in Clark Town ship. The game was in doubt, however, until a 205pound defensive tackle, Chris Vejno ska, suddenly scored for two touchdowns in the fourth quarter.

title: Suffolk Getting Race Track
description: YAPHANK, L.I.  Some time within the next year, on what is now 200 acres of vacant wooded land on the fringes of highly popu lated sections of Long Island, the first race track in Suf folk folk County will open its gates. It will be right next door to what has been called Long Island's largest planned community, the future home of 4,000 people.

title: Music
description: STANLEY WOODWARD, the sports editor of the Herald Tribune, once got into an argument with his superiors and left the paper for any number of years. Then there was a reconciliation and he returned. He started his first column with As I was saying.

title: Kent State Wins, 3714 Tinker Scores on Pass
description: KENT, Ohio, Sept. 23 (UPI) Kent State, paced by a 17 yearold freshman quarter back, Greg Kokal, and aided by an Olympic gold medalist, Gerald Tinker, exploded for 28 points in the second half today to whip Ohio Univer sity, 3714, in a MidAmeri can Conference game.

title: BLAIR TURNS BACK FARRA GUT, 32 TO 6
description: PINE BEACH, N. J., Sept. 23 Blair gained 225 yards rush ing today in a 326 rout of Admiral Farragut. Skip Wad dell led the way with two touchdowns on runs of 1 and 15 yards. Waddell also re turned punts for Blair, gaining good field position each time.

title: Flying Samaritans Are Widening Their Medical, and Dental Aid to the Needy
description: STANFORD, Calif., Sept. 23One month ago Francis ca Chiquival, 14 years old, was a social outcast in her tiny Maya Indian village in Central America.

title: Giants Run Into Streaking Dallas
description: In a game that is likely to set the direction of their season up, down or on a fairly even keelthe New York Giants will be 10point underdogs to the Dallas Cowboys at Yankee Sta dium today at 1 P.M.

title: Athens CabDrivers Say They May Bar American Riders
description: ATHENS, Sept. 23Athens ens, Sept. 23Athens taxi cab drivers warned today that for reasons of their own per sonal safety they might refuse to pick up Americans. The warning came after Greek au thorities waived prosecution of a United States airman charged with beating up a Greek taxi driver.

title: How Nucleotides Form Structure of Viral Gene
description: The viral gene whose chemical makeup has been analyzed by Dr. Walter Fiers and his colleagues is believed to exist in the structure at right when its genetic infor mation is not being trans lated.

title: An environmentalist's environment
description: Clean, open, airy spaces are just what ?? would expect of the home of New ?? City's Environmental Protection ??and the freshly reno ?? apartment of Jerome and ?? Kretchmer doesn't disappoint. ?? building, facing Central Park on ?? West Side, hadn't been updated ?? it was built in the nineteentwen ?? and the Kretchmers asked archi ?? Robert Stern and John Hagmann ?? a revamp that kept to a strict ??. The rooms of the Kretchmer ??, although large, lacked ?? and had little esthetic appeal. Glasswindowed doors, for instance, opened off a dark corridor to living room, library and dining room. The ar chitects ripped out oldfashioned doors and walls and installed new diagonal dividers (see plan) that changed the dreary foyer into a dramatic entrance that is also part of the living room. Jerry's over 6 feet tall, says Stern; the spaces and furnishings had to be scaled to him. The client and archi tects both liked the isolated zoning of the bedrooms and avoided all struc tural changes there. Instead, Stern de signed bedstorage combinations that sit in the center of each bedroom.

title: .0006 Separates Top 2 in Eastern Division Sox Get 6 Hits
To THE EDITOR:
description: Thank you for the two poignant ar ticles; you could not have known the added dimension they would gain as a result of the tragic events in Munich that followed their publication. The writers, Stephen Birnbaum and Thomas Glynn, have added measurably to our children's knowledge of their heritage, just as Tevye, the dairyman in Fiddler on the Roof, did when he admonished God, I know we are the chosen peo ple, but do you have to choose us so often?

description: CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 23 (AP)  Clark MacGregor, cam paign director for the Commit tee for the ReElection of the President, barnstormed through New Hampshire today, predict ing a large state victory for the President and attacking Democrats over Vietnam and the Watergate affair.

title: Movies
description: PAUL SHERMAN is a newsman at WINS. His voice is polished mahogany, his delivery flawless. Specializing in medical matters, he has done excellent indepth reports on TaySachs disease and sicklecell anemia. But I remember when Alan Freed was the hottest D. J. in America, the King of Rock and Roll, and Paul Sherman was his Crown Prince. Togeth er they played the music that kept us from falling asleep in the fifties, the music that loosened America's grip on itself, the music that has now returned.

title: The Death Of the Army

title: L.I. Colleges Are Drawing Wives and Mothers
description: Increasing numbers of women are entering colleges all over Long Island, and walking off with honors.

title: Good Me or Bad Me' The Sullivan approach to personality
description: The work of Harry Stack Sullivan, generally re garded as America's most original psychiatrist, is only now beginning to win widespread recognition. Sullivan died in 1949. Today interest in Sullivanian treatment and training methods is growing; more and more references to him are appearing in the professional literature, and his books are doing better than ever. At the heart of his contributions to contemporary psychiatric theory and practice and to social science lies his genius for understand ing interpersonal relations in all their manifold levels and communicating that understanding. What follows are an interpretation of his ideas and a brief sketch of his life.

title: Making Corporate Whoopee
description: MONTREALThere's noth ing unusual about whisky at an anniversary party, but here in Montreal this month they threw a threeday anni versary party at which whis ky was the guest of honor. The brand was Seagram's 7 Crown, the hosts were the Bronfmans who make it and the singing happy guests were the men who sell it.

title: Stumbling Ad Giant
description: When the name of J. Walter Thompson is nth up the flagpole these days, a lot of ad men across the coun try don't seem to be snap ping off salutes quite as briskly as they once, did.

title: The French Communists
description: France presents an ambigu ous double image: at once vola tile and stable. On the one hand, a history punctuated by revolution; on the other, pat terns of hierarchy and authority which Stanley Hoffmann and Michel Crozier have called stalemate or blocked so ciety.

title: If You Go
description: on an Arthurian trek and want to get the most out of it, do some preparatory reading. Plenty of books are available, among them The Evolution of Arthurian Romance by J. D. Bruce, Celtic Myth and Arthurian Romance by R. S. Loomis and, as mentioned in this article, The Quest for Arthur's Britain by Geoffrey Ashe. Glastonbury, which was a medieval center of learning and pilgrimage and lies about 130 miles west of London, would seem to be a natural base from which to explore King Arthur country. Besides being the reputed burial place of Arthur and Guine vere, it is close to South Cadbury (the site of the Camelot Research Committee's archeological digs), and about an hour's drive from Badbury Rings, Dorset, where Arthur is said to have defeated the barbarian invaders. Win chester, which also figures promi nently in the Knights of the Round Table mystique, is about 65 miles southeast of Glastonbury. From Glastonbury to Tintagel on the north Cornish coast, which some think was Arthur's birth place, is roughly 100 miles. And from Tintagel, which is situated in an area much favored by English tourists, drivers can cross the Cornish Peninsula to Fowey, a south coast resort, and the nearby Castle Dore, which is also associ ated with the Arthurian Age. You need at least a week and a rented car for such a tour; the area has plenty of B & B (bed and break fast) guesthouses.

title: New Black Culture, Quietly Evolving in All of the Arts Since the 1960's, Comes Into Focus at Exposition
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 During the midsixties, a num ber of gifted young blacks with drew, into the lofts and store fronts and church basements of their communities to work out new art forms that would reflect their social aid political ideas.

title: Snappers Aren't What They Used to Be
description: POINT LOOKOUT, L.I. I'm afraid I've got bobbitis again. Bobbitis, if you don't know, is an affliction of the snapper season. It comes from watching a bob bounc ing on the water all day long. When you try to go to sleep at night, all you can see behind your closed lids is that bouncing bob. That's bobbitis.

title: Son to Mrs. Cimmino
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 23A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Vincent M. Cimmino on Sept. 6 at the Women's Hospital. The child has been named Noel Aaron. Dr. Cim mino is a resident in surgery at University Hospital here.

title: Engineers Find Underground Nuclear Plants Feasible, but See Higher Costs
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 23 The construction of under ground nuclear power plants, possible answer to objections by environmentalists, has been deemed technically feasible, but at a priceabout 10 per cent more than the cost of a com parable plant above ground.

title: $100,000 Bail Is Cut For 5 Held in Texas In Gun Sale Inquiry
description: ABILENE, Tex., Sept. 23 (AP)  A Federal judge today ordered five New York Ameri cans of Irish descent freed on bonds ranging from $5,000 to $15,000 after lowering his orig inal order for $100,000 bail each.

description: NEWARK  Students in unprecedented numbers are crowding New Jersey's law schools this year.

title: Chicago Lyric Offers Foscari by Verdi
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23  The Chicago Lyric Opera was cer tainly not planning to dazzle the audience by choosing Verdi's sixth opera, I Due Foscari, as the opening pres entation of its 18th season last night. An unremitting gloom pervades the work, but it is, nonetheless, a powerfully ex pressive and dramatically con centrated score, Verdi's first to use the combined themes of political intrigue and family tragedy, which would lead ul timately to Don Carlo.

title: TV
description: ASSORTED outtakes: It may be that rather steady exposure to a television screen over the past 18 months has be gun to warp my judgment, but the new season does seem to be surprisingly bear able. Among the new regu lar series several, particular ly in the situationcomedy area, show encouraging signs of putting their assorted tal ents to slickly professional use. Don't knock slickness or professionalism when tur gid amateurism dominates the landscape, in and out side of television.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I would like to set the record straight on two points mentioned in your edi torial of Sept. 10, which criticized a report prepared by my colleagues and me on the causes of inequality in America.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Louis Bean, economic ad viser to three Secretaries of Agriculture and longtime analyst of voting habits, bases his forecasting technique on examination of twoparty voting trends, of key regions (such as downstate Illinois), economic changes and how they affect voter groups, and national polls. Wisely Bean labels his methods an art rather than a science, and in deed the technique is full of difficult variables. Still, for those who are statistically so phisticated there are enough charts and figures to keep them busy until November.

title: Monmouth Adding Homes
description: Fastgrowing Monmouth County his added more than 40,000 homes to its total housing stockas well as about 140,000 new residents in the 12 years since 1960.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It seems ironic that having been denied membership in the United Na tions for the last 22 years, the People's Republic of China saw fit in her great Confucian and Maoist wisdom to deny Bangladesh, a poor, ravaged country of 75 million people, membership in the U.N. by casting its first veto in the Security Council.

title: Letters
description: Mrs. Johnson believes that women in simpler societies do lighter work than men (A woman anthropologist offers a solution to the woman problem, by Sheila K. John son, Aug. 27). The cross cultural evidence runs heav ily, but not universally, to the contrary. In general, how ever, women do the heavy lift ing, moving, gathering, digging and similar chores. It is pre cisely because of this that some think of women as being the first exploited population.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  Looking toward trade, official credits and private investments that may run into billions of dollars in the next decade, American negotiators are deter mined to create an economic relationship with the Soviet Union capable of coping with every conceivable contingency.

description: SEATTLE, Sept. 24 (AP) Transportation Secretary John A. description: Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island, undefeated last year with a 100 wonlost record, extended its unbeaten streak to 41 games yesterday with a 166 comeback victory over St. Joseph's at West New York, N.J.

Allen Knit ting is wholly owned by the First Hartford Corporation, for merly the Wyandotte Industries Corporation. A successor to Mr. Goldman has not been named.

title: I.M.F. to Hear Nixon
description: President Nixon, in an un usual move, will address the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank at the opening session of their meet ing in Washington today. Ar ticles examining the issues and the people are on Page 59.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your Labor Day editorial Making Old Age Secure underlined the need for comprehensive planning about the future of our national retirement sys tem. The combination of personal sav ings, employer  or unions sponsored pension plans and the Federal Social Security system must adequately meet the income needs of our aging population without unduly burdening corporate shareholders and taxpayers, while neither underfunding the private plans nor unnecessarily accumulating assets in anticipation of future pen sion payments.

title: Arts Abroad
description: ROMECola di Rienzo, the 14thcentury populist, will soon stalk the piazzas of Rome again. The revived Roman repertory theater plans to make its debut in various parts of the city with an openair production of a new Life of Cola di Rienzo by Enzo Siciliani The protagonist, who is also the hero of Wagner's early opera, Ri enzi, was a re publican who called himself a tribune; was the scourge of the barons; dreamed of an empire of the common man; ruled for some time as the dictator of Rome and was eventually overthrown and killed in an uprising of the populace.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 When the international fi nancial world was rocked in August, 1971, by the United States decision to suspend the free convertibility of the dollar into gold, it would have been easy for Pierre Paul Schweitzer to silently wait to see what would happen.

description: ASHFORD, Ala., Sept. 24 (AP) The police and sheriff's depu ties were keeping watch today on a carnival in this southeast Alabama town as they con tinued the search for a young father accused of trading his in fant son for a used car.

title: Met's Giovanni Renews A Robust Heritage at 15
description: When the late Goeran Gen tele was discussing his plans for the Metropolitan Opera, he mentioned a possible new production of Mozart's Don Giovanni. The one designed by Eugene Berman and staged by Herbert Graf is 15 years old. But seeing it again Saturday night made one wonder why it should be re placed. No matter how often it turns up, it does not lose its remarkable unity and style. It is one of the finest legacies of the Bing regime.

description: YOSEMITE, Calif., Sept. 24 (UPI)A team of rescuers lowered a young rock climb er from a tiny ledge today 2,300 feet up the sheer face of El Capitan in Yosemite National Park.

title: Economic Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 This week's annual meeting of the World Bank and the Inter national Monetary Fund here will find the United States in the most unpopular, and often isolated, position in the quarter cen tury of the two in stitutions' exist ence. That is the view of diplomats, high officials of the bank and the fund, and many American officials, all expressed in pri vate until now.

title: Rev. Philip S. Watters Sr. Dies; ExWashington Sq. Minister, 82
description: HACKETTSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 24  The Rev, Dr. Philip S. Waiters Sr., Methodist clergy man and educator, died at his home here yesterday. He was 82 years old and lived in the Heath Village apartment com plex.

description: WALDPORT, Ore., Sept. 24 (UPI)A 15yearold boy was killed after being struck by lightning while carrying a box filled with 35 pieces of dyna mite yesterday at a logging operation 25 miles east of here.

title: NEW JERSEY

title: ISSUES 1972
description: We all know that in relation to Vietnam Richard Nixon is a war monger, a butcher and a monster more vile than Hitler, and that George McGovern is a defeatist, a quitter and a modern Benedict Arnold. But sup pose a visitor from Uganda, impressed by the ferocity of the dove vs. hawk rhetoric, asked us to explain just ex actly how the President's Vietnam policy differs from the rival candi date's.

title: 4 Flee Czechoslovakia by Bus
description: VIENNA, Sept. 24 (AP) Four Czechoslovaks, three men and a woman, defected to the West yesterday morning by strapping themselves to the rear axle of the daily Bratis lavatoVienna bus. All of a sudden, four people came crawling from under the bus and ran away fast, an official of the downtown bus terminal said today.

title: Marcos Plans Reorganization

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The most generous Democratic con tributor during the primary campaign gave $257,000 to President Nixon's reelection ef fort in three weeks last month, according to public financial disclosures required under the Federal Election Campaign Act.

description: I COME AS A THIEF. By Louis Auchincloss. 231 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $6.95.

title: Swiss Voters Turn Down Move To Ban All Armaments Exports
description: BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 24 (AP)Swiss voters defeated by a margin of fewer than 9,000 votes today a proposed consti tutional amendment that would have imposed a complete ban on arms exports and tightened state controls over the domes tic armament industry.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MATAWAN, N. J., Sept. 24They reached back over the last three decades at Diamond Jim's here tonight to pay tribute to seven fighters who have bragged as much about their New Jersey residency as they have about their accomplishments in the ring.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  A leading American economist offered a new proposal today for revising currency exchange rates in a reformed world mon etary system.

description: Governor Rockefeller has en dorsed the idea of replacing state Presidential primaries with a national primary because he believes the present system of selecting Presidential candidates is a bewildering hodgepodge that is unfair to the voters and candidates alike.

title: Laird Says Air Force Studies Possible Lavelle CourtMartial
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that court martial charges against Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle were pend ing and under current review by the Air Force in connection with unauthorized strikes he had ordered in North Vietnam.

title: Woman Dies of Snakebite
description: SOUTH CHARLESTON, W.Va. Sept. 24 (AP)Mrs. Beulah Bucklen died today, eight days after being bitten twice by a rattlesnake Sept. 16 at the Jesus Pentecostal Church in nearby Putnam County.

title: N.Y. BANK PLANS PALM BEACH UNIT
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the $11.7billion parent company of the Bankers Trust Company and numerous other banks in New York, said yesterday that it would estab lish a new investment manage ment subsidiary in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: ' The Emigrants,' a Swedish Film Epic, Lands Here
description: Jan Troell's "The Emigrants," a big, long, carefully detailed Swedish film about Swedish emigration to America in the middle of the 19th century, is an example of a type of drama much more common to the stage, especially to the regional stage, than to film. Although its characters are peasants rather than great personages, it is, at heart, a historical pageant of the sort you might expect to encounter at Colonial Williamsburg or Roanoke Island in midsummer.As such, it celebrates in deliberately simplified ways heroism, faith, fortitude, goals achieved and lives concluded that counted for something.Historical pageants can comprehend wars, earthquakes, tidal waves, famines, epidemics, reversals of fortune and even rotten luck. They aren't interested in failure, in the lot of the loser, in those who don't measure up, in lives forever in transit, in the contemplation of loss and futility.The pageant may not necessarily be a lesser form of theater or cinema, but because its purpose is so unequivocally affirmative, it tends, like socialist art, to be without surprise. It also tends to carry itself with a certain air of smugness, as do passengers disembarking from a capacity-stuffed 747 after an especially harrowing flight.All of these thoughts are inspired by "The Emigrants," which Mr. Troell, the young director, adapted from the novels of Vilhelm Moberg, with Bengt Forslund, the director's collaborator on the script of his first feature, "Here's Your Life," released here in 1968."The Emigrants" is a stately, pictorially romantic chronicle of the lives of a small group of peasants for whom existence at home becomes so tenuous that emigration seems the only solution.There are Karl Oskar (Max von Sydow), a tough, irreverent farmer, whose land will no longer support his family; Liv Ullmann, his loving, perpetually pregnant wife; Robert (Eddie Axberg), his younger brother, who rebels against being an indentured farmhand; Danjel (Allan Edwall), a fundamentalist minister who, with his followers, flees persecution at home, confident that God's grace will make itself apparent when they land in America by allowing them to speak fluent American; Ulrika (Monica Zetterlund), who plays Mary Magdalene to Danjel's image of himself as Jesus; Ulrika's daughter, Karl Oskar's children, friends, associates, people met en route and so on.The scope of the film is broad, and the running time seems even longer than it actually is (2 hours 31 minutes), probably because one is never unaware of the huge narrative task the film has set for itselfand is able to accomplish only through a succession of short, cryptic, high-point scenes (a birth, a death, a departure, an illness, an arrival), which have the effect of tableaus that evoke the look of events instead of the emotion."The Emigrants" is divided into three parts: the events leading up to the departure from Sweden; the voyage to the United States, and the journey by rail and steamboat from the East Coast to the wilds of Minnesota. (Mr. Troell has already completed a companion film, "The Settlers," about his characters as pioneers.)Although I have reservations about the film's form and intent, it's difficult not to be impressed by its conception, which called for extensive location shooting in Minnesota and Wisconsin as well as Sweden. To his credit, Mr. Troell tries to keep his melodrama small, thus avoiding the mistakes of "Hawaii," one of the last of the multimillion-dollar American epics.There is also about each of the performances, particularly those of Mr. von Sydow and Miss Ullmann, a kind of spontaneous truth, in look and gesture, that does a lot to relieve the otherwise programed nobility, truth and beauty. As he showed in "Here's Your Life," Mr. Troell, who is a fine cameraman, simply cannot resist the extra shot of sunlight-reflected-in-water that becomes just one too many, a thing of movie decoration."The Emigrants" opened yesterday at the Sutton Theater.

title: RALPH A. M'MULLAN, CONSERVATIONIST, 55
description: LANSING, Mich., Sept. 24 (UPI)Dr. Ralph A. MacMul lan, director of Michigan's De partment of Natural Resources, died here yesterday apparently of a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

title: Tanaka Arrives in China, Hoping to Establish Ties
description: PEKING, Monday, Sept. 25 Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Ja pan arrived in Peking today, hoping to end decades of un happy relations through the es tablishment of diplomatic ties between the two most power ful nations in Asia.

title: Uruguay Moves on Leftists
description: MONTEVIDEO. Uruguay, Sept. 24 (Reuters)Uruguayan officials said today that the armed forces have smashed a small, leftwing guerrilla organ ization called the 22d of De cember movement, which, they said, was linked with the Tupamaro urban guerullas.

title: Harvard Forms Cancer Unit
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP)Harvard President Derek C. Bok, citing a growing need for a universitywide approach to the study of cancer, an nounced tonight the formation of a President's Committee on Cancer to coordinate such work at the university.

title: No Link Seen in Garbage Strike and 2 Slayings
description: The police said yesterday that there seemed to be no connection between a strike by garbage men in Valley Stream, L. I., and the shooting deaths of two Nassau County men found Saturday in a wooded area of the Howard Beach sec tion of Queens.

title: A Federally Funded Bail Agency Is Speeding Up Pretrial Bond for Suspects in the Nation's Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Ellen Silberstein left her home in Bethesda, Md., at 7:30 o'clock on a recent morning, drove 40 minutes to the United States Superior Court building in downtown Washington, rushed to its basement cellblock and plunged into two hours of in terviewing men who had been arrested the night be fore on a variety of charges.

title: F.B.I. Recovers $126,280 In $178,500 Casino Theft
description: RENO, Sept 24 (AP)  The F.B.I. announced today that it had recovered $126,280 of the $178,500 stolen from Harrah's Casino at Lake Tahoe last Tuesday.

title: Advertising:
description: In the first case since its rules were changed to allow it, the National Advertising Review Board has disclosed a complaint and its disposi tion. The board found the complaint by a Massachu setts professor against Gen eral Motors, one of the country's major advertisers, without merit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Several recent letters have posed questions about trees along the streets and around some public buildings. Let me first say how pleased I am at this expression of the public's concern for these trees, which add so much to the pleasantness of the city.

title: Shultz Discusses Schweitzer
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (Reuters)  Secretary of the Treasury George Shultz said to day that the Nixon Administra tion held PierrePaul Schweitz er, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, in high regard, despite its recent moves to block his reelection.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As the election campaigns gain momentum, one turns to the announced policies of Senator McGovern and the Democratic platform to learn what ef fect they may have on a vital facet of American society which includes the several arts. The want of anything constructive is disturbing, the avowed elimination of significant private sources of support for the arts alarm ing.

title: Danger in the Streets
description: The fatal stabbing of Dr. Wolfgang G. Friedmann, a noted law professor at Columbia University, and the mugging of Dr. Selwyn Brody, a psychiatrist, on his way to the Penn Central station at 125th Street have put the spotlight on violent street crime. The public and the news media have responded by analyzing the circumstances of the assaults, the conditions of the neighborhoods in which they were committed and the background of the suspects.

title: City Aware Week Starts With Focus on Harmony
description: The bells of nearly 90 churches around the city rang in Aware Week at noon yester day.

title: Leon Russell Sings With Style and Ease In Nassau Coliseum
description: There's been a strong empha sis on theatricality in rock mu sic lately, with elaborate cos tuming, intricate lighting and staged tableaus becoming al most as common at pop con certs as the year in in a Las Vegas revue. Yet the two most theatrically effective perform ers I've seen this season have done little more than get up on stage and sing.

title: Saviet Fear Over Harvest Rises As Season's First Snow Falls
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24As the grain deal with the Soviet Union continued to stir politi cal controversy in the United States, a new urgency appeared to creep into frontpage har vest reports in the Soviet press today.

title: Screen: 'Sounder' Opens:Story of a Negro Boy in Louisiana of 1930's
description: It would be so comfortable to praise "Sounder." The story of a boy, David, and his dog, Sounder, and his family, black sharecroppers in Louisiana in the 1930's, it is a film that virtually announces nobility. And the pre-opening reviews quoted in the ads have responded as if on cue, treating "Sounder" not as a movie at all but rather as something unusually worthy, like the United Fund or a UNICEF Christmas card.It is about growing up, a subject with special appeal to the makers of distinguished motion pictures, and it is about growing up poor, black and dignified, and at a time just enough in the past to carry an aura of modern, but not quite contemporary, history. Even the plot  a kindly father caught stealing food for his hungry family, sentenced to a year at hard labor, a year in which his son comes to terms with himself and learns not to accept his lothas the feeling of historical demonstration.And if "Sounder," an inteligent enough movie, avoids all the major pitfalls of its type, it also lacks the excitement that may have come from plumbing greater depths and discovering a few tougher, less accessible insights."Sounder" was produced by Robert Radnitz, who specializes in children's films, and directed by Martin Ritt ("Hud," "The Molly Maguires," etc.) who poses something of a problem. An earnest, conscientious director, he seems to strive for classical plainness, but to succeed only in being ordinary. When David visits his father's labor camp, a long trip on foot and the centerpiece of the film, Ritt follows him through a series of shots dissolving into one another that are clearly meant to express the journey, but really promote a kind of decorative and oddly inexpressive picture-making.And the emotional life of the family is figured too often in scenes of fond greeting or of sad farewella requirement of the story partly but also, I think, a rather dull willingness to rely on conventional public views of what are essentially private relationships.Lonne Elder's screenplay, from the novel by William Armstrong, attempts a universality in its dialogue (e.g., "Where is it you went last night, Nathan?" "I did what I had to do, Rebecca.") that makes everyone sound as if he were reciting from a book. This can be very good where there is a style to match the solemnity, as in, say, the late films of Carl Dreyer, but it is merely unreal here.Among the performances, all rather expert, only the women are complicated enough to be interesting. These include Janet MacLachlan as the young black teacher who proves equal to David's sense of his own worth, and Cicely Tyson, as the mother who helped give him that sense in the first place.Miss Tyson seems to understand that part of screen acting is keeping secrets from the camera, and she does suggest a range of personality beneath and beyond the ambitions of this film."Sounder" opened yesterday at the Plaza and New Embassy theaters.

title: Taiwan Fears a Challenge In I.M.F. and World Bank
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 24 Nationalist China is following the proceedings at the Inter national Monetary Fund and World Bank meetings with con siderable anxiety.

title: Inmate Hangs Self At Rikers Island; 10th Suicide of '72
description: A 24yearold inmate hanged himself last night at the Correc tional Center for Men on Rikers Island moments after he had visited the facility's doctor, the Department of Corrections reported.

title: McRae Wins Championship In Continental 5000 Series
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP)Graham McRae of Wel lington, New Zealand, won the championship in the Continen tal Formula 5000 series today at Riverside International Race way.

title: Police Indicate Harvard Official Knew His Killer
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24  Joseph Strickland, the Harvard admin istrator who was shot last week in his apartment, may have known the killer, the police said today.

title: Headmaster Installed At Phillips Academy
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP)Theodore R. Sizer, for mer dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Educa tion, was installed today as the 12th headmaster of Phil lips Academy.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The 300 security officers now patrolling the city's high schools have received a positive response from teachers and principals, Eldridge Waith, the new director of school safety, said yesterday.

title: SMITH TOPS TANNER IN COAST NET FINAL
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP)Stan Smith, the Wimble don champion, defeated Roscoe Tanner, 64, 64, today to win the $60,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis championships.

title: PENSION REFORM CALLED STYMIED
description: The possibility of major re form of the nation's private, pension systems this year has been virtually eliminated, ac cording to Senator Abraham Ribicoff.

title: AIRLINE INDUSTRY IN PROFIT DECLINE
description: Knut Hammarskjold, director general of the International, Air Transport Association, said yes terday that the nonCommu nist world's airlines earned a $112million operating profit last year on revenues of $19.5 billion.

title: Namath Throws Six Touchdown Passes as Jets Win
description: Joe Namath threw six touchdown passes and ac counted for 496 yards in leading the New York Jets to a 4434 victory over the Colts yesterday at Baltimore. He came within a touchdown of matching the record of seven scoring passes with tosses of 65, 67, 28, 10, 79 and 80 yards.

title: Israel Denies Gas Charge
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)  An Israeli Army spokesman today denied a charge by Lebanon that Israel had used poison gas dur ing an attack on southern Lebanon last weekend.

title: Jazz Octet, in Busy Weekend, Excels in a Varied Repertory
description: It is not surprising to find that a group called the No Gap Generation Jazz Band should be a combination of young musi cians (two) and older musicians (six). But it is a relief to dis cover that this group has not come together simply to prove that the young musicians can play the standard Dixieland war horses with the same weary banality as their elders.

title: MRS. WALTER ROGERS
description: DOVER PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 24  Mrs. Natalie Bontecon Rogers, wife of the Rev. Walter Allyn Rogers, pastor of St. James Episcopal Church here, died today in Sharon, Conn., at the age of 76.

title: 2 Young Felons Plan to Testify In Riot Trial of Black Minister
description: BURGAW, N. C., Sept. 24 Two young convicted felons are expected to testify this week in the trial of the Rev. Ben Chavis, a black United Church of Christ minister, and several of his followers on charges of firebombing a whiteowned grocery store and plotting to attack, firemen dur ing a week of racial violence in Wilmington, N.C., last year.

title: Bridge : Younger New York Players Win Major Titles in Regional
description: The younger generation of New York experts collected the major titles in Friday's and Saturday's play in the New YorkNew Jersey re gional championships at the Playboy Club in McAfee, N. J.

title: Blaring Rock Leads to Monkey Fatigue
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 24 A loudspeaker blared Jimi Hendrix rock but a 2yearold rhesus monkey nicknamed Frankenstein stubbornly re fused to boogaloo or bop. Instead, Frankenstein, one of 16 rhesus monkeys recently involved in a series of noise pollution experiments at the University of Wisconsin, evinced fatigue.

title: Crash Kills 12 in Brazil
description: JEQUIE, Brazil, Sept. 24 (AP) A bus and a truck collided near this northern city yester day and the police reported 12 persons were killed.

title: U.S. WINS AT CHESS OVER VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 24The United States team to day completed a 40 sweep against the Virgin Islands team to take the lead in its section after five rounds of the Chess Olympics here.

title: Fashions Come to Life on Fifth Avenue
description: Everybody loved his com petitor at New York's first Fashion Fair, which started at noon Saturday in the middle of Fifth Avenue and lasted for four hours.

title: Parrot Allowed in U.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (UPI)Patpong, a Siamese par rot without a country, was finally allowed into the United States yesterday after a 235 day, 84,739mile ocean voyage. The bird was not allowed to come ashore last spring be cause of an outbreak of poultry disease in California and had to stay aboard the ship.

title: REV. HERBERT REDMOND
description: The Rev. Herbert P. Red mond, archivist of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn for four years and also chap lain of the Nursing Sisters of Sick Poor in Brooklyn for 28 years, died Friday in Southamp ton (L. I.) Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Pulitzer's Widow Burned In 5th Avenue Apartment
description: Margaret Leech Pulitzer, 78 yearold author and widow of Ralph Pulitzer, the journalist, was burned on the hands and feet in a fire early yesterday in her Fifth Avenue apartment.

title: HATCHERY SPEEDS LOBSTER GROWTH
description: Researchers at the Massachu setts Lobster Hatchery in Vine yard Haven have learned how to grow lobsters to eating size in onefourth the time it nor mally takes.

title: Foe BoobyTraps Hares, Cambodian Chief Warns
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 24 (AP)President Lon Nol has warned Cambodians against a Communist plot to use rabbits to kill them.

title: Fight Appears Certain in Effort to Revamp National Park Policies
description: JACKSON, Wyo., Sept. 24  Stormy weather in shaping management policies for the na tion's prime recreation areas is being presaged at the Second World Conference on National Parks.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: EDISON, Sept. 24A $4 million college center was dedicated at Middlesex County College here today, to serve the community as well as the 7,000 students attending the twoyear in stitution.

title: Allen Silberman Weds Leslie Landsman
description: Miss Leslie E. Landsman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour D. Landsman of New York and Brant Lake, N. Y., was married here yes terday afternoon to Allen J. Silberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Silberman of New York. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the cere mony at the Carlyle.

title: Mrs. Ayres Wed To Bank Officer
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 24Mrs. I. Christine Ayres of Cold Spring Harbor was married in the Brookville Re formed Church this afternoon to James J. Baechle, vice president and general coun sel of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, holding company for the Bankers Trust Company. The Rev. Donald McCabe performed the ceremony.

title: Shooting of 2 at Ali's Home Termed Accidental by Police
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Sept, 24 (UPI)The police today labeled accidental the shooting that wounded two persons in the home of Muhammad Ali, but said the investigation would continue this week.

title: Rumanian Sings Title Role in City Opera Rigoletto
description: Rigoletto is one of the sure fire roles in opera, but that in no way lessened the fine impact Vasile Martinoiu made in the part yesterday afternoon with the New York City Opera. The 38yearold Rumanian singer was making his debut here in the Verdi work.

title: Nicholas C. Christofilos Dies; Head of Thermonuclear Project
description: LIVERMORE, Calif., Sept 25 (AP)  Nicholas C. Christo Jilos, one of the nation's fore most nuclear scientists, died of an apparent heart attack today at nearby Hayward, where he lived alone. He was 56 years old.

title: Mobil Oil Reports A Find in Britain's North Sea Sector
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation reported yesterday that it may have a new discovery in a British sector of the North Sea.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: By the end of this week President Nixon will have presided over the Vietnam war for longer than it took the United States to fight and win World War II. From Pearl Harbor to Japan's surrender it was three years, eight months and one week.

title: Asians Arrive In Britain
description: STANSTED, England, Sept. 24 (AP) A special charter flight carried 180 expelled Ugandan Asians into this air port north of London today and disembarked them, shiver ing, into a bitterly cold wind.

title: Jane M. Pasachoff, Lawyer, Married
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Miss Jane Myra Pasachoff, a lawyer with the Appellate Court Section of the National Labor Relations Board here, was married this afternoon to Alan Norris Schlaifer, a lawyer with the Civil Frauds Division of the Justice De partment. Rabbi Bernard Mehlman performed the cere mony at the Madison Hotel.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 24An es caped murderer, one of seven convicts who fled last week from Trenton State Prison, was captured this morning as Gov ernor Cahill prepared for a meeting tomorrow with four of his top lawenforcement offi cials to discuss recent break outs.

title: Marcos Decrees a Military TakeOver Of Philippine Airlines and Main Utilities
description: MANILA, Sept. 24 Presi dent Ferdinand E. Marcos or dered a military takeover this weekend of three Philippine airlines and all major utilities to guard against any disruption of public services in the wake of the declaration of martial law.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Mayor Lindsay, making his first campaign rally appearance with Senator George McGovern went allout yesterday to boost the Democratic Presidential nominee he had fought in early primaries.

title: Mediation Begins Today in Contract Dispute Between City U. Staff and Higher Education Board
description: With the collapse of contract negotiations between the Board of Higher Education and the union representing its profes sional staff, the dispute goes today to a mediator, by agree ment of both sides.

title: BRUINRANGER GAME AT GARDEN TONIGHT
description: What is left of the Boston Bruins, the Stanley Cup cham pion wracked by defection, will be on display for the first time in New York tonight since they defeated the Rangers in the Na tional Hockey League cup fi nals last May.

title: Swamped With Work, Beset by Critics, The City's Election Board Perseveres
description: On one floor of the head quarters of the Board of Elec tions, thousands of registration cards were being checked and sorted by hand.

title: Yanks Top Indians Twice, Gain Half Game on Boston
Letters to the Editor
description: Legislation is currently being con sidered against the eyesore of graffiti which is plaguing the city. It is im portant that a strict interdiction against posters by political candidates be specifically included in any such legislation.

title: AMIN WELCOMES PEACE PROPOSAIS
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 24 Somalia, which is mediating the dispute between Uganda and Tanzania, has put forward a fivepoint peace plan, Presi dent Idi Amin of Uganda dis closed here today.

title: Voters in One Norwegian Town Find Market Entry a Vivid Issue
description: SKI, Norway, Sept. 24Bent Vale threw open the doors of the grammar school gymnasium promptly at 4 P.M. today and led inside more than 50 citizens of this semirural town 20 miles southeast of Oslo who were waiting, solemnfaced and si lent, in the pale autumn sun shine.

title: Two Scents, Not Plain
description: Perfume houses that had been resting on their laurels for decades have sent new scents wafting into the air. Rochas, which has done nicely with Femme and Madame Rochas, has brought out Audace, its first offering in 11 years. And Houbigant, which has been around for a century, is offering Indian Summer, its first new brew in 30 years.

title: Thieu's Rule Tighter Since Enemy's Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 24  President Nguyen Van Thieu has come out of the 1972 Communist offensive more powerfully in control of the machinery of Government here than ever before. But he seems to be less than sure of his own political strength and popular ity among the people of his country.

title: News Analysis
description: ROME, Sept. 24Pope Paul VI will be 75 years old on Tues day as many Roman Catholics, and others as well, are trying to assess the significance of his pontificate.

title: JONES WINS PLAYOFF IN ROBINSON GOLF
description: ROBINSON, Ill., Sept. 24 (AP) Grier Jones came from five strokes off the pace to force a suddendeath playoff today, then beat longshot Dave Marad on the second extra hole for the championship in the rain plagued Robinson Fall golf tournament.

title: Thompson Displays Range, Substance of Bassoonist
description: The bassoon player's lot is not a glamorous one. He sur faces once in a while for a Vi valdi or Mozart concerto, but usually makes the rest of his orchestral contributions from the anonymity of the back row.

title: COMMANDOS SAY BEIRUT EASES UP
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 24 The Lebanese authorities have quietly eased internal travel restrictions on Palestinian com mandos this weekend, sources close to the commando leader ship reported today.

title: Vikings Set Back Lions, 34 to 10, as Osborne Scores Three Touchdowns
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24Rather than assuming a posture of gritty determination, the De troit Lions stayed loose and easy as they prepared to play their nemesis, the Minnesota Vikings team, today. Loose equalled lose, however, as the Vikings beat the Lions, 3410, for the ninth straight time in a rivalry that has settled their, division title every year since, 1967.

title: Red Sox Set Back Tigers, 72, And Take 1Game Lead in East
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24The Bos ton Red Sox and Detroit Tigers broke off hostilities today aft er the Red Sox bounced back with a 72 victory for an even split of their fourgame series in Fenway Park.

title: Michael May, Pianist, Offers More Surprises
description: One of these days, Michael May is going to run out of im aginative surprises for his New York concerts, but meanwhile his programs here continue to be fascinating in their particu lars and highly entertaining overall.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TENAFLY, Sept. 24  Carl L. Marburger, the Commissioner of Education, called today for tax reform and full state financ ing of local schools as a means to improve the overall quality of education in the state.

title: Industrial Condominium Is Hailed as a Milestone
description: New York City is the home of about 200 of the country's 750 largest corporations and the site of 3,752 industrial con cerns with 100 or more em ployes each, including six with more than 10,000 employes each. But just as important are the city's small businesses, many of them growing ones.

title: Work Begins on 752 Subway Cars for New York
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 24Panel by panel, weld by weld and bolt by bolt, 752 new subway cars bound for New York are beginning to take shape on drawing boards in the heavily industrial South Side.

title: MARCOS DECREES AIRLINETAKEOVER
description: MANILA, Sept. 24Presi dent Ferdinand E. Marcos or dered a military takeover this weekend of three Philippine airlines and all major utilities to guard against any disruption of public services in the wake of the declaration of martial law.

title: China Restoring Exams in Her Schools
description: PEKING, Sept. 24Examina tions, condemned at the out break of the Cultural Revolu tion as an instrument for fool ing the people and for groom ing successors for the ruling classes, are to become a basic part of the Chinese educational system again.

title: Credit Markets
description: Shortterm interest rates, which frequently set the pace for the entire credit market, managed last week for the first time since early August to avoid being driven broadly higher.

title: Threat to SALT II
description: WASHINGTONDisturbing ques tions are raised by Administration support for Senator Henry Jackson in his successful effort to write stiff Senate guidelines for the next round of the strategic arms limitation talks (SALT II) with Moscow in November. But the chief threat to SALT II is the MIRV multiple warhead, an American invention that now could endanger American security.

title: Gallup Survey Finds Nixon Gains Among New Voters
description: In a survey, taken in late August for Newsweek by the Gallup Organization, and pub lished this week in the news magazine, President Nixon was depicted increasing his lead among new voters in the 18to24yearold age bracket from 50 to 52 per cent.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Senator George McGovern charged yesterday that Nixon administration politics might be delaying the release of three American pilots from North Vietnam.

title: Waiting for Washington
description: Finance ministers and central bank governors of 123 nations, in Washington for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund, now face their most serious challenge and opportunity in a quarter century.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island, undefeated last year with a 100 wonlost record, extended its unbeaten streak to 41 games yesterday with a 166 comeback victory over St. Joseph's at West New York, N.J.

title: Shifting Patterns of Immigration Add New Flavor to the City's Melting Pot
description: In subtle and in startling ways, the flavor of New York is changing.

title: Krebs Wages Uphill Fight To Unseat Senator Case
description: TRENTON, Sept 24Paul J. Krebs, the Democratic candi date for the United States Sen ate, is facing more than the usual problems in his bid to unseat the heavily favored Clif ford P. Case.

title: News Analysis
description: Representative William F. Ryan's death last week from the effects of cancer raises anew an issue that is becoming increasingly critical in political campaigns: Just how much is the public entitled to know about the status of a candi date's personal health? Two months ago, the nation was jolted when Sen ator Thomas F. Eagleton, then the Democratic Vice Presidential candi date, disclosed that he had been hospitalized three times since 1960 for depres sion.

title: Jet Hits Ice Cream Parlor, Killing 22 in Sacramento
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 24Twentytwo persons, in eluding at least 10 children, were killed today when a pri vately owned jeta former warplanecrashed into an ice cream parlor packed with par ents and children celebrating birthday parties. At least 26 persons were treated at three hospitals for injuries.

title: Personal Finance: Campaign Gifts
description: With the November elec tions approaching rapidly, thousands of political fund raisers are frantically beat ing the bushes all over Amer ica in an effort to pull in millions of dollars in con tributions to meet the al reedy staggering costs of presenting their candidates.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: A $250,000 fine has been levied against a Stanhope manufacturing concern found guilty of polluting the air on 360 days during the last year.

title: Parley Says Dental Schools Fail To Carry Out Reforms in Field
description: Despite broad changes in their curriculums, the nation's dental schools are failing to achieve the reforms the changes were designed to bring about, a weekend conference on the future of dental education seemed agreed.

title: Nixon Got QuarterMillion From a Democratic Donor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24The most generous Democratic con tributor during the primary campaign gave $257,000 to President Nixon's reelection ef fort in three weeks last month, according to public financial disclosures required under the Federal Election Campaign Act.

title: IBRAHIM HABASHNEH
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 24 A former Jordanian Minister of the Interior, Ibrahim Habash neh, died of a heart attack to day at the military hospital here, hospital officials said. He was 46 years old.

title: Robin Bernstein Weds Barry Roth
description: OTTSVILLE, Pa., Sept. 24 Miss Robin Joan Bernstein, administrative assistant to the secretary of personnel for Gov. Milton J. Schapp, was married here this afternoon to Barry Alan Roth, a state assistant attorney general who is serving as assistant to the general counsel of the state's Department of Wel fare.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: NEW SCHOOL NEWSLINE Call ?? 07117 24hr service for ?? of special events you'll want to attend ??

title: Ft. Worth 5 Back After Jail Release
description: The Fort Worth Five re turned to New York yester day after being held since last June in a Texas jail for refusing to tell a grand jury about the possible sale of arms intended for the Irish Republican Army.

title: CORRUPTION TIPS GIVEN TO NADJARI
description: The special state prosecutor appointed by Governor Rock efeller to investigate corrup tion in law enforcement in the city said yesterday that in his first five days in office he al ready had received hundreds of tips and complaints.

title: Bobby Unser Wins at Trenton; Leonard Takes U.S.A.C. Title
description: TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 24 Where do auto racing's gogo Indy drivers go after the In dianapolis 500?

title: Pearl Buck in Hospital
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 24 Pearl S. Buck, winner of the Nobel Prize for literature, was admitted to Medical Center Hospital here early today after suffering some abdominal dis comfort. Miss Buck, who re cently celebrated her 80th birthday, was accompanied here from her Danby home by her physician, who wanted further diagnostic tests. The author was hospitalized in Rutland in July with pleurisy. She was reported to be resting comfortably tonight.

title: White House Rerun
description: Once again the White House broadcasting czar, Clay T. Whitehead, has raised political implications in a state ment about what American TV viewers ought to be watching. Previously he had let it be known that the stations would be better off not putting on controversial subjects and also that public service activities ought to be localized, meaning that major documentaries on the issues of the day could be ignored. Now Mr. Whitehead is worried about the increased number of reruns in prime timethe second or umpteenth showing of the family, situation, medioel and similar halfhour or hour shows.

title: Theater: New Haven Bombed Again
description: The new production of Joseph Heller's We Bombed in New Haven, which opened last night at the Circle in the Square, is described in the first place as being a new interpretation, and in the second place as being con ceived and directed by Peter John Bailey. Mr. Heller did it better himself. This staging is a grievous insult to the play even though I understand that Mr. Heller himself ap proves of it.

title: King's College Wins, 216, From Pace
description: NANTICOKE, Pa., Sept. 24 (AP)John Jacobs scored two touchdowns on short runs as King's College beat Pace of New York, 216, in a college football game today.

title: KNICKS DEFEATED BY COUGARS, 10589
description: DURHAM, N. C., Sept. 24 Mack Calvin and Billy Cunning ham spoiled a secondhalf rally by the Knicks tonight as the Carolina Cougars defeated New York, 10589, before 4,398 at Duke University's Cameron Stadium.

title: Seymour Scores Antipollution Zealots
description: LAKE MINNEWASKA, N. Y., Sept. 24  Whitney North Seymour Jr., the United States Attorney for the Southern Dis trict of New York, whose of fice has been active in anti pollution efforts, made an un usually sharp attack today on some environmentalists who he said were actually hampering the cleanup effort.

title: Survivors of Maidanek Camp Honor Memory of Thousands of Fellow Jews
description: MAIDANEK, PolandOn Jan. 17, 1943, a train carrying 1,000 inmates arrived here from Pawiak prison in Warsaw. It was only one of thousands of such shipments needed to keep this concentration camp full during the war.

title: AMERICA SINGING PRELUDE TO 1976
description: By the calendar, it is only 1972, but that dull rumble you hear in the distance is the preliminary cannonading in what will be a long engage ment. Yesterday afternoon, an advance party marched into Alice Tully Hall and presented a program called America Singing: A Prelude to the Bi centennial. An 80  member chorus from the nation's capi tal, the Paul Hill Chorale, warmed us up for Independence Day, 1976, with lively perform ances of such things as Alice Hawthorne's Listen to the Mockingbird, Stephen Foster's We Are Coming, Father Abraam, 300,000 More and vocal excerpts from El Capi tan, one of John Philip Sousa's 15 operettas. (Did you know he wrote even one?)

title: Closing of Two Indian Training Programs Defended
description: ROSWELL, N.M., Sept. 24  The regional representative of the Bureau of Indian Affairs rebutted today Indian criticism of the decision to terminate two Indian employment training programs in this city.

title: 3 Killed on NATO Maneuver
description: MAALSELV, Norway, Sept. 24 (AP)Three Americans who were participating in NATO maneuvers were killed last night when their helicopter crashed on Groetoeya Island in the Vesteraalen group off the northwest coast of Norway, the maneuver information center announced today. A spokesman said that the names of the three Americans would be withheld until relatives were notified. The helicopter was taking part in a current largescale anti submarine operation code named Exercise Strong Express.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 24  Combining showmanship with a slashing attack on the Nixon Administration, Sargent Shri ver seems to, have discovered a new campaign style during his weekend swing through the Southwest.

title: Thieu's Rule Tighter Since Enemy's Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 24  President Nguyen Van Thieu has come out of the 1972 Communist offensive more powerfully in control of the machinery of Government here than ever before. But he seems to be less than sure of his own political strength and popular ity among the people of his country.

title: Advertising:
description: Christmas may be a busy time for Santa Claus, but in adland it's deadsville. News papers and magazines are skinny, and lots of time in broadcast is going unsold.

title: Democratic Senators Up Early To Criticize the Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Every morning last week, Sen ate Democrats conducted an early  morning fungo practice, trying to bat out what they be lieve should be the issues in the Presidential campaign to Senator George McGovern. If the Democrats have their way, the practice will probably con tinue every morning until the session ends.

title: Namath Throws Six Touchdown Passes as Jets Win
description: Joe Namath threw six touchdown passes and ac counted for 496 yards in leading the New York Jets to a 4434 victory over the Colts yesterday at Baltimore. He came within a touchdown of matching the record of seven scoring passes with tosses of 65, 67, 28, 10, 79 and 80 yards.

title: Case Is Heavy Favorite to Retain His Senate Seat
description: TRENTON, Sept. 24Paul J. Krebs, the Democratic candi date for the United States Sen ate, is facing more than the usual problems in his bid to unseat the heavily favored Clifford P. Case.

title: PARTY HEADS DEBATE WATERGATE IMPACT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The Democrats have failed to make a publicgripping issue of the Watergate affair, Sen ator Robert J. Dole of Kansas said today, but Lawrence F. O'Brien predicted that plenty of activity on Capitol Hill would keep alive the alleged political espionage aimed at Democratic headquarters.

title: Extension Sought
description: The Republic Corporationa diversified industrial company now $60million in debt to 25 banksdisclosed in Los An geles yesterday that it had reached tentative agreement on a new extension of credit that would give the company until 1980 to pay up.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Helen Bryant (letter Sept. 18) is wasting her energy objecting to S. J. Perelman's frivolous use of the ex pression The Old Centemptibles. Ascribed to the Kaiser by folklore, the phrase a contemptible little army is now known to have been the propa ganda invention of Sir Frederick Mau rice of the War Office, who imputed it to the Kaiser in hopes of angering and thus inspiriting the British troops falling back from Mons in the autumn of 1914.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Ira Glasser's Sept. 17 letter concern big the Work Relief Program ad ministered by the city stated: The city is, as a matter of policy, replacing regular civil service workers with cheap forced labor. Mr. Glasser is cate gorically incorrect in his interpretation of city policy.

title: Snead Rallies Club Houston Scores 2 on Long Passes
description: The New York Giants lost to the Dallas Cowboys by just about the predicted margin, 2314, at Yankee Stadium yes terday, but in the process they provided food for thought for those who like to look at the doughnut as well as those who like to look at the hole.

title: Israel Begins Celebrations Of Her 25th Anniversary
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 24 (Reu ters)A year of celebrations marking the 25th anniversary of Israel's independence began today with the kindling of 25 torches at a festive gathering on the grounds of President Zalman Shazar's residence here.

title: Whispin Takes Steeplechase
description: MERANO, Italy, Sept 24 (AP) Whispin, a 5yearold Italian horse, today won the $85,000 Gran Prix of Merano steeple chase race. Whispin, ridden by his owner, Andrea Donati, fin ished the 5,000meter race two lengths ahead of another Italian horse, Breuil, ridden by Gia como Colleo.

title: U.S. Considering Relaxation Of Trailer Lighting Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The Federal Highway Admini stration said today that it was considering a relaxation of lighting rules for current trail ers and semitrailers to conform with proposed rulse for new vehicles of this type.

title: CONSTANCE WARD
description: NEW HOPE, Pa., Sept. 24  Constance Allen Ward, painter and former owner of an art gallery here, died yesterday in a Doylestown nursing home after a long illness. She was 83 years old. Surviving are two sons, Allen of Philadelphia and Jasper D. of Louisville, Ky., and 13 grandchildren.

title: Study Shows Courts Lenient With Mafiosi
description: On Sept. 8, 1967, Paul Vario, who is listed by the Justice Department as a captain in the Mafia family of the late Thomas Luchese, pleaded guilty be fore Supreme Court Justice Do menic S. Rinaldi to commercial bribery of a police officer.

title: 7 JEWS IN MOSCOW SAID TO BE JAILED
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24Seven Moscow Jews who staged a sit down protest at Government offices against the new educa tion taxes on wouldbe emi grants have been tried secretly and sentenced to 15 days in prison, Jewish sources reported today.

title: RESTAURANT FIRE KILLS 31 IN RHODES
description: ATHENS, Sept. 24A fire gutted a tourist restaurant on the Aegean island of Rhodes last night, killing 31 persons and injuring 16most of them Scandinavian touristsin the worst fire disaster in recent Greek history.

title: Study Shows Courts Lenient With Mafiosi
description: On Sept. 8, 1967, Paul Vario, who is listed by the Justice Department as a captain in the Mafia family of the late Thomas Luchese, pleaded guilty be fore Supreme Court Justice Do menic S. Rinaldi to commercial bribery of a police officer.

title: Namath Throws for Six Touchdowns as Jets Top Colts, 4434
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 24Joe Namath and Johnny Unitas, two of pro football's storied passers, filled the air with foot balls before a capacity Crowd of 56,626 in Memorial Stadium today, and when the air had cleared, the New York Jets had a 4434 victory over the Balti more Colts.

title: Cambodia Reports Losses
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 24 (AP)The Cambodian com mand reported today that 16 Cambodian soldiers had been killed and 39 wounded in fight ing around the town of Cham bak on Route 2, about 20 miles from Pnompenh, where a battle continued for the third day in a row.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 24  About 400 employes of MercedesBenz of North America have stopped going to six different offices in the Fort Lee, N. J., area and are reporting to work at a $6 million new headquarters build ing in Montvale.

title: CORNELIUS M. BARNETT
