description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 24Cornelius M. Barnett, a deliverer for The New York Times from 1925 to 1969, died today at the age of 80. He lived at 34 Crestwood Drive.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Japanese history began again this month with Premier Tanaka's explana tion to President Nixon of Japan's new, independent China policy. For almost three decades Japan let America mis represent U.S. expansion in the Pacific as in large part the defense of Japan ese interests. Wouldbe American friends of Japan have particularly en joyed defending the separation of Tai wan from the rest of China as defer ence to the ambitions of Japan.

title: ST. BERNARD GETS TOP GOSHEN PRIZE
description: GOSHEN, Conn., Sept. 24  Five weeks ago, a St. Bernard, Ch. Alpine Acre Baron v. Shagg Bark, underwent surgery.

title: NEW SURVEY FINDS NIXON IS LEADING M'GOVERN 6223%
description: Voter preference for Presi dent Nixon grew so much in the last month of the summer that he took the lead over Senator George McGovern even among registered Democrats, according to a new 16state electoral vote survey.

title: Jet Hits Ice Cream Parlor, Killing 21 in Sacramento
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 24At least 21 persons were killed this afternoon when a privately owned former jet warplane crashed into an ice cream parlor packed with birth day partygoers.

title: Two Die in Car Crash
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Sept. 24 (AP)A man's car and a ve hicle containing his mother and brotherinlaw collided late yesterday killing the latter two several hundred feet away from their home.

title: Paysanne, San San Finish In Dead Heat at Longchamp
description: PARIS, Sept. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)Baron Guy de Rothschild's Paysanne, ridden by Henri Samani, and Countess Batthyany's San San, with Jean Cruguet aboard, finished in a dead heat for first place today in the $120,000 Prix Vermeilles at Longchamp.

title: Throwing New Light on the Subject
description: Behind the Let There Be Neon sign that spells out the name of SoHo's newest gallery, there's also a hope.

title: Bonn's Former Finance Chief Quits the Chancellor's Party
description: BONN, Sept. 24 (AP)West Germany's former Minister of Economics and Finance, Karl Schiller, announced his with drawal from the Social Demo cratic party in a letter to Chan cellor. Willy Brandt, a party spokesman said.

title: Job Market for the College Graduate Projected as Tighter Through 1970's
Steel Orders Lag
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24Or ders of the largest steel com panies lagged in early Septem ber after a promising surge in August.

title: MachineTool Orders Up, But Shipments Are Down
description: The machinetool industry continued to show gains in or ders through August, although the dollar value of shipments so far this year is running be hind yearago levels.

title: CITY SAYS IT GAINS ON PRODUCTIVITY
description: Budget Director David A. Grossman asserted yesterday that the Lindsay administra tion had been successful in its efforts to obtain improved pro ductivity from city employes.

title: Liner Hits Rock Off Cannes
description: CANNES, France, Sept. 24 (AP)The Italian liner Caribia hit a rock today while leaving this port on the French Riviera, and the 880 persons aboard had to be taken ashore quickly be cause of a leak in the hull. The liner had arrived late yesterday to anchor in the bay for a brief stopover during a Mediterra nean cruise.

title: BLACK ARTS GROUP TO HONOR 3 OCT. 8
description: Marian Anderson, Prof. Ster ling Brown of Howard Univer sity and Aaron Douglas, a painter, will be honored at the third annual awards banquet of the Black Academy of Arts and Letters.

title: BORIS N. LIVANOV, 68, OF MOSCOW THEATER
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24Boris N. Livanov, longtime actor with the Moscow Art Theater, died yesterday at the age of 68.

title: Vouchers Reshape a School District
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 24 The voucher financing system, being tried here for the first time in the nation, has caused a major restructuring of edu cation in the Alum Rock Union School District.

title: STEWART WINS CANADIAN PRIX
description: BOWMANVILLE, Ont., Sept. 24Jackie Stewart, Scotland's gift to international road rac ing, easily won the Canadian Grand Prix today in record time, finishing with a 48.2 second margin over Peter Rev son, the only American run ning regularly on the Grand Prix circuit.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Thirteen and a half minutes into the home season, some of the more discriminating sportsmen among the 62,725 assembled in Yankee Stadium stated their considered opinion of the 1972 Giants as a professional football team. B0000! they said. This was at 1:36 P.M. yesterday. The Dallas Cowboys had received the opening kickoff and gone 77 yards on what amounted to a Sunday afternoon stroll to take a 70 lead. They had held the Giants to 9 yards on four plays and, on the fifth, had creamed the New York quarterback, Norm Snead, for a 9yard loss. Boo! the connoisseurs said.

title: Car Kills L. I. Youth
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 24 A 17yearold boy was fatal ly injured here last night when he was struck by a car as he walked along Caledonia Road. The police said the youth, Rob ert Wrasa of 37 Clearview Drive, Wyandanch, died at Huntington Hospital at 2:45 A.M. today from injuries he received in the accident at 11 P.M. No charges were lodged against the driver.

title: Levitt Warns City DayCare Leases Pose Fiscal Risk
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that the city had committed itself unwisely to 138 leases for daycare cen ters with private developers, with no assurance of funding or need.

title: Goldman Partner Is Named Securities Association Chief
description: The Securities Industry Asso ciation, a trade group of the leaders in the securities busi ness, said yesterday that John C. Whitehead, a partner in Goldman Sachs & Co., had been nominated as chairman and chief executive of the 850 member group.

title: Countdown at the U.N.
description: The United States is on a collision course with the rest of the world at the newly convened session of the United Nations General Assembly. Unless there is some accommodation on both sides, the results could seriously injure both the world organization and the international standing of the United States.

title: Gloria Perkins, Violinist, Returns to Recital Stage
description: The last time Gloria Perkins gave a solo recital in New York, Franklin D. Roosevelt was in his second term as President, and the violinist was a 12year old prodigy. Sunday afternoon she was welcomed back by a cordial audience that nearly filled Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: NEW SURVEY FINDS NIXON IS LEADING M'GOVERN 6223%
description: Voter preference for Presi dent Nixon grew so much in the last month of the summer that he took the lead over Senator George McGovern even among registered Democrats, according to a new 16state electoral vote survey.

title: Russ Corey Gets 5 Goals As Meadow Brook Wins, 91
description: BETHPAGE, L.L, Sept. 24 Russell Corey scored five goals as he led the Meadow Brook poloists to a 91 victory over Brookville today in a Shaw W. Robinson memorial tournament match at Bethpage State Park.

title: ALLMON FORDYCE, ARCHITECT, DEAD
description: Allmon Grant Fordyce, found er and senior partner in the ar chitectural firm of Fordyce & Hamby Associates, died yester day of cancer at New York Hos pital. He was 72 years old and lived at 870 United Nations Plaza and had a home also in Little Compton, R. I.

title: It's Said, The Sun Never Sets on Cargill'
description: MINNEAPOLISIt is easy to drive past the modest green sign, no more than two feet square, announcing. Cargill Headquarters.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: TORONTOEach major failure in the conduct of postwar American for eign policy has led to the search for a new, more successful strategy which, in turn, has produced additional frus trations in a world ever less suscep tible to U.S. control. The Korean war and the irrelevance of containment evolved into Dulles' new look de pendence on strategic weapons, which the Kennedy Administration then modified to include a limited war doctrine whose main outcome was the Vietnam debacle. Today the Nixon Ad ministration has proclaimed the end of a bipolar diplomacy which it alleges is a new departureone promising future peace and stabilityin its larger foreign policy.

title: DR. VIOREL TILEA, RUMANIAN ENVOY
description: LONDON, Sept. 24  Dr. Viorel Virgil Tilea, Ruma nian Minister to Britain in 1938 who was recalled by Hitler's order but stayed in England and started the Pree Ruma nian Movement in 1940, died Wednesday at the age of 76.

title: Grim Sky Adds a Fine Pall to Poe Festival
description: The overcast sky yester day provided the proper mel ancholy atmosphere for the First Annual Edgar Allen Poe Festival and Block Party on West 84th Street.

title: SAIGON SAYS FOE RENEWS ATTACKS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 25 (AP)Enemy forces backed by tanks and heavy artillery were reported to have renewed their assaults yesterday along the northern coast below Danang and cre ated more hazards along the vital Route 1.

title: PETTY IS VICTOR IN 500MILE RACE
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., Sept. 24 (AP)Richard Petty cap italized on the laterace mis fortunes of Bobby Allison to day and won the Old Dominion 500 stockcar race at Martins ville Speedway.

title: Shoppers Here Stoical on Food Price Increases
description: We've all got to eat, so we really don't have much choice, do we? said Mrs. Ruth Sha piro, the mother of four chil dren, as she dropped a package of carrots into her shopping cart, noting that they cost 25 cents a pound, compared with 45 cents for two pounds the week before.

title: Mets Defeat Carlton Again, 21, As 41,644 Watch Home Finale
description: The baseball season at Shea Stadium ended yesterday with a duel between two of the Na tional League's best pitchers, and Tom Seaver delighted a crowd of 41,644 by beating Steve Carlton of the Phillies, 21.

title: Notes From Trenton
description: TRENTON, Sept. 24  Governor Cahill's running feud with some of New Jersey's leading Democratic women shows no sign of easing. In fact, there could be a showdown this Satur day if the Republican leader ignores their demand that he withdraw as a speaker at a statewide confer ence for women here. The trouble began last month when Mr. Cahill explained why there were not many women in New Jersey's delegation to the Republican National Con vention last month. Most women want to stay home and take care of their home and family, he said. To ask them to do more is to ask them to do more than they are able.

title: St. Francis Prep Wins, 437; Chaminade, Spellman Triumph
description: Zenon Szaro, a substitute halfback, scored 7 points yes terday in St. Francis Prep's 437 football victory over New Dorp on the loser's Staten Island field, and it brought back memories of when the Little terriers were one of New York's dominant teams.

title: Museum to Open In Statue's Base
description: A new museum in the pedestal of the Statue of Lib erty that memorializes the millions of American immi grants will be dedicated to morrow afternoon by Presi dent Nixon.

title: Roadrunner Shuffles for TwoBadger Touchdowns
description: Hours after Army' had suf fered that 777 loss to Nebraska Saturday afternoon, Michigan proved how topsyturvy a foot ball season can be by grinding out a 269 victory over the Uni versity of California, Los Angeles, the team that ended Nebraska's 23game winning streak two weeks ago.

title: Cabaret
description: New York may be losing some of its past distinction but this fall it has gained something that can be found in no other city in the world: two singers who represent the acme of sophisticated supper club performance. Bobby Short and Mabel Mer cer can both be heard here five nights a week, every week. Mr. Short is in his fifth season at the Cafe Carlyle, 76th Street at Madison Av enue, and Miss Mercer, after a trial run last spring in the St. Regis Room of the St. Re gis Sheraton Hotel, has set tled there as its resident en chantress.

title: A. T. & T. Weighs Rate Rises For Installation and Moving
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25 (AP) The American Telephone and Telegraph Cmpany is studying the possibility of raising rates for installing and moving tele phones to bring charges more in line with costs, Robert D. Lilley, president, told securities analysts here today.

title: Afghan Cabinet Resigns
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 25 (UPI)Premier Abdul Zhir and his Cabinet resigned their posts last night after 14 months in office. Official sources said today that Dr. Zbir had told King Mohammed Zhir Shah that his Government had faced many difficulties in develop ment programs. The sources said the resignation was mainly prompted by Government fail ure to overcome the effects of two years of drought.

title: PATTERSON DOWNS ANDERSON, 63, 75
description: ALBANY, Calif., Sept. 25 (AP)  Fourthseeded Andrew Patterson of Rhodesia fell be hind in his second set against Rich Anderson of nearby Red wood City but rallied today for a 63, 75 victory in the first round of Pacific Coast interna tional tennis championships.

title: Tanaka Tells Chou of Japan's Regret for Aggression
description: PEKING, Sept. 25Premier Kakuei Tanaka expressed Ja pan's regret and repentance to day for past aggression against China and joined Premier Chou Enlai in predicting complete agreement in their talks here to normalize longstrained re lations.

title: The P. B. A. Assails Murphy Idea to Base Assignment on Race
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of New York City sharply criticized yesterday a suggestion of Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy that the de partment consider recruiting by neighborhood and assign ing policemen by race.

title: Team of Craftsmen Who Try To Keep Their Income Low
description: WHITING, Vt.Ken May berger and his wife, Sal, could sell everything they weave and sculpt to New York's smartest shops, but they don't. They say they would rather keep their in come low enough to escape Federal taxation.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C.Mariannot her real namegraduated from high school about twenty years ago. A lively, alert girl, she, along with her class mates, heard the speeches about the promise of America and the glorious future that awaited her. Standing in cap and gown, she walled across the stage to receive her diploma.

title: New AntiPollution Process
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)  The Shell Oil Company said to day it had developed a process for removing virtually all the undesirable sulphur from crude oil and natural gas before it could become a pollutant. Tech nology now in use will remove from 94 to 96 per cent of the sulphur from the fuels, but the rest escapes into the atmos phere.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. President Nix on addressed the Inter national Monetary Fund World Bank meeting at the Sheraton Park Hotel. The President met with Thomas Gleason, president of the International Longshoreman's Association. Mr. Nixon also saw members of the Finance Committee of the committee for the Reelection of the President.

title: Warehouse and Terminal To Be Built at Hunts Point
description: A $37million refrigerated warehouse and pier, designed to maintain New York as the nation's leading meat import center, will be built on the East River shorefront of the Hunts Point Food Center.

title: $50,000 Flemish Art Stolen
description: HASSELT. Belgium, Sept. 25 (Reuters)  Twentyfour paint ings by Flemish masters were stolen from a converted church after their owner suggested that a roundtheclock watch on them was no longer needed, the police said today. The paintings were due to be sold at auction today and were valued at $50,000.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The recent hijacking by. Croatian terrorists must be viewed against the background of Belgrade's decision last December to eliminate the Croatian Communist party and government leaders. That purge gave a new im petus to the previously sidelined Croatian political extremists.

title: KNICKS TO OPPOSE BRAVES IN GARDEN
description: After an absence of little more than four months, the Knicks will be back in Madison Square Garden tonight. Coach Red Holzman's club, which lost in the National Basketball As sociation championship round last season to the Los Angeles Lakers, will oppose the Buffalo Braves in the second game of a preseason doubleheader.

title: Bridg: A MotherandSon Combination Takes a Major Regional Event
description: For a motherandson com bination to capture a major title is virtually unprece dented, at any rate in East Coast tournaments, but it happened Sunday when an unheralded foursome won the Swiss Team Champion ship in the New YorkNew Jersey Regional Champion ships at the Playboy Club, McAfee, N. J.

title: Evidence Shows a Nuclear Reaction Occurred Spontaneously Long Ago
description: A leading French scientist yesterday reported evidence that nature spontaneously ig nited a nuclear chain reaction in an African uranium mine millions of years ago. The re action, he said, apparently ran for a prolonged period.

title: Meadowlands Sports Complex Is Approved, With an If
description: LYNDHURST, N. J., Sept. 20 Two of New Jersey's state agencies today approved the Cahill administration's stillcon troversial plans to construct a vast sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands, pro vided the ecological integrity of the site is safeguarded.

title: SALINGER VOWS AID TO LOUISIANA ON OIL
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25  Pierre Salinger, cochairman of National Citizens for McGov ern said here today that Senator George. McGovern, if he became President, would work to give Louisiana a larger share of the tax revenues from oil found off its coast.

title: NoFault Rate Rise Sought
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25 (AP) Companies writing compulsory, nofault bodily injury automo bile insurance in Massachusetts have applied for a 6.5 per cent increase in passengercar rates for 1973, state insurance offi cials said today.

title: HOUSE FIGHT DUE ON GATEWAY BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  A bill that would create the Gateway National Urban Rec reation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor cleared the House Rules Committee to day and was sent to the House floor for a fight over whether housing should be constructed on part of what is now Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)The Government should provide more than the requested $15.5million for the 1976 Winter Olympic Games in Denver, a Congressman said today.

title: LEON J. KOERNER
description: Leon J. Koerner, a prominent retired lumber industrialist and philanthropist in Vancouver, British Columbia, died there yesterday after a long illness at the age of 80.

title: E Pluribus Unum
description: Nations and individuals, once grown successful and affluent, tend to forget their humble origins and the struggles of their ancestors. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in addressing the Daughters of the American Revolution as his fellow immigrants, intended more than a political wisecrack. There can be no meaningful belief in America as a nation without the acknowledgment of America as the creation of immigrant peoples and cultures.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 25  Gov ernor Cahill ordered steppedup security precautions today at the Vroom Building of the Trenton State Prison as offi cials pressed a nationwide man hunt for four of seven convicts who escaped last week.

title: Witness Relates How Colombo Gang Slew Gallo
description: The Mafia informant who has cooperated with lawenforce ment officials since soon after Joseph Gallo was murdered last April testified in State Supreme Court here yesterday that he and four other members of the rival Joseph A. Colombo family had plannetl and carried out the gangland leader's execu tion.

title: Lillian Hellman Is Among Nine Named to City University Chairs
description: The Board of Higher Educa tion last night approved the appointment of Lillian Hellman, the playwright, as distinguished professor in the Romance languages department of Hunter College, which includes part of that institution's pro gram in the arts.

title: Ulster Talks Open in England But Catholic Boycott Dims Hope
description: DARLINGTON, England, Sept. 25A threeday confer ence on the political future of Northern Ireland opened here today in a mood of gloom and anger.

title: RYAN WINS, GAINS 302D STRIKEOUT
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 25 (UPI)Nolan Ryan became the sixth man in American League history to post 300 strikeouts in a season and then scored the winning run tonight as the Cali fornia Angels beat the Texas Rangers, 21.

title: Notes on People
description: Israel's elder statesman, David BenGurion, celebrated his 86th birthday yesterday three weeks early by most calendars. But the white haired former Premier chose to receive friends at his home at Sde Boker in the Negev according to the Jewish calendar. He also marked the occasion by attending a garden dedication ceremony and speaking to a Bible study group that he organ ized in the kibbutz. Mr. Ben Gurion was born in Poland on Oct. 16, 1886, and emi grated to Israel in 1906.

title: McGovern Calls Nixon Ally of Business
description: BILLINGS, Mont., Sept. 25 Senator George McGovern charged here today that the Nixon Administration was dominated by special interests in environmental and regula tory agencies.

title: STOCKS RESUME RECENT DECLINE
description: The stock market yesterday resumed its recent downward pattern following Friday's mediocre advance. Prices closed sharply lower in slow trading.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Stanley M. Barkin's letter (Sept. 19) regarding the Geneva Accords and Vietnam repeats an error which needs correction, particularly since it has been uncritically accepted and pub lished in many articles and works dealing with the origin of American involvement in Vietnam.

title: Mechanical Failure Seen
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 25Spectrum Air, Inc., is a Cessna dealership owned by William Penn Patrick, who also owns Holiday Cosmetics.

title: Waldheim Picks Swiss Diplomat As Aide on SouthWest Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25Secretary General Waldheim today named a re tired Swiss diplomat as his representative to deal with matters relating to SouthWest Africa.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Sedco, Inc., yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Com mission in connection with a proposed public offering of 500,000 shares of common stock. The shares, to be offered through an underwriting group headed by Goldman Sachs, are being sold to assist in the fi nancing of four semisubmers ible drilling units. The com pany has about 9,570,000 shares outstanding. The com pany's stock was down ?? at 57 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Norwegians Bar Market; Government May Resign
description: OSLO, Norway, Tuesday, Sept. 26Norwegians voted de cisively in a twoday referen dum to reject membership in the European Economic Com munity.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Two new political polls re ported today that Senator George McGovern, the Demo cratic Presidential nominee, had narrowed the massive lead for President Nixon found in pre vious surveys.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 (UPI)John Matlack of the New York Mets was named as the National League player of the week today by the league president, Charles S. Feeney.

title: COLLEGES TO OPEN AT GARDEN DEC. 7
description: Highlighted by a rematch of last year's National Collegiate Eastern regional finalistsFlor ida State and North Carolina the 197273 Madison Square Garden intercollegiate basket ball program will offer 48 col leges in two tripleheaders, 15 regular season doubleheaders, and an expanded Eastern Col lege Athletic Conference Holi day Festival. The 38th college season at the Garden will be gin on Thursday, Dec. 7, and will conclude with the 36th an nual National Invitation Tour nament, March 1725.

title: Chess: Far Prom the Beaten Path, It's Too Easy to Get Lost
description: The Chess Club Argentina of Buenos Aires organized a roundrobin tournament re cently to celebrate its 67th anniversary. Twelve grand masters, international mas ters and masters participated and, to the surprise of the chess public, Hermann Pilnik topped the field by scoring 9 points out of a possible 11.

title: South Africa Is Selling About 2/3 of New Gold
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 South Africa's Finance Min ister disclosed today that his country had been selling about twothirds of its newly mined gold on the free mar ket since last spring, putting the rest into its monetary re serves.

title: Presidential Campaign Stirs the Arts Communities
description: Art and politicstradition ally the oil and water on the intellectual seascape  are being drawn this year into a real mix by the emotional realities of the Presidential campaign.

title: U.N. Bars Parcel Delivery To Employes Temporarily
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 (AP)The United Na tions has banned delivery of personal packages to employes inside its headquarters during the General Assembly session, which began last Tuesday and runs through Dec. 19.

title: Norwegians Bar Market; Government May Resign
description: OSLO, Norway, Tuesday, Sept. 26Norwegians voted de cisively in twoday referendum to reject membership in the European Economic Commu nity.

title: Lavelle Solely Instigated Strikes, Says Air Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)Air Force Chief of Staff John D. Ryan, in testimony before a Senate commitee, singled out Lieut. Gen. Jahn D. Lavelle as the sole instigator of unauthorized air attacks against North Vietnam.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ELEANOR GLUECK, EXPERT ON CRIME
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 25 Mrs. Eleanor Touroff Glueck, who with her husband, Sheldon Glueck, conducted pioneering studies at Harvard Law School on crime and delinquency, was found dead today in a bathtub at her home here. Her age was 74.

title: CAR SALES DOWN IN MIDSEPTEMBER
description: DETROIT, Sept. 25Carmak ers reported 150,910 retail auto mobile deliveries from Sept. 11 to 20, down from 194,366 sales of United States cars a year ago. There were nine sell ing days in midSeptember this year, compared with eight days a year ago, meaning that the average of 16,768 deliveries a day was down 31 per cent from a 24,296aday selling rate last year.

title: Nixon to Open Museum at the Statue of Liberty Today
description: A new museum built in a structural addition to the pedestal of the Statue of Liberty will be opened today by President Nixon and de dicated to the millions of im migrants who settled in this country.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES PRESIDENT POWER TO LIMIT SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to give President Nixon unlimited au thority to cut whatever Govern ment programs he chooses be tween now and next June 30 to keep total Government spend ing for the fiscal year at no more than $250billion.

title: HARYOU OFFICERS PROMISE REFORMS
description: A wide variety of reforms in HaryouAct, Central Harlem's often controversial eightyear old antipoverty agency, was promised yesterday by the new officers of the program, which is once again to channel $5, 119,385 in Federal and city funds into the area for the year starting Oct. 1.

title: 2 Handcuffed Bodies Found
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 25 (Reuters)Two men who had been handcufed and shot to death were found this morning in a field of a dirt road near Butler Hospital here.

title: R. AMORY THORNDIKE
description: BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 25  R. Armory Thorndike, an in vestment adviser, died of can cer yesterday at his home. He was 71 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Licensing massage parlors as part of a coordinated attack on one of this city's many ills is roughly analogous to treating the pallor of disseminated malignancy with a sunlamp: Not only does it fail to exert any discernible influence on the basic disease process, but it also runs the risk of conveying a false sense of security that some thing therapeutic has been done.

title: CANADA SIX GAINS REFEREES' OUSTER
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (AP) Coach Harry Sinden said to day that Team Canada had won its point and that the two West German referees who worked last night's hockey game against the Soviet Union will not be used for the rest of the series.

title: Hanoi Says Dam Was Hit
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  The North Vietnamese Foreign Min istry said today that the Nam dan Dam near Vinh was de stroyed by American bombs yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 25  Vice President Agnew began the second week of his campaign today by restating what has become its basic theme: an unrelenting attack on Senator George McGovern and his proposals for national defense.

title: EXAIDE TO SEYMOUR DENIES ACCUSATIONS
description: John M. Burns 3d denied yesterday charges by United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. implying that Mr. Burns had undermined anti pollution efforts by using the power of the office for what turned out to be personal political ambitions. Mr. Sey mour, speaking Sunday at an environmental conference, did not mention Mr. Burns by name, but his attack was clearly aimed at him.

title: Stage: Sleuth Retains Its Suave Wit
description: A character in Thomas Love Peacock's Headlong Hall comments that in lay ing out a garden he distin guishes three characteristics affording pleasurethe pic turesque, the beautiful and the unexpected. His compan ion in the novel rebukes him by asking how he would dis tinguish this last character istic on walking round the grounds for a second time. How indeed!

title: Some Areas in Massachusetts Are Open for Clam Harvesting
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) With the red tide no longer in evidence off the Massachusetts coast, the Department of Pub lic Health today opened spe cific sections of southeastern Massachusetts to the harvest ing of hardshell clams.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: A former assistant vice presi dent and branch manager of the First National City Bank was indicted yesterday on charges of embezzling more than $1million and falsifying bank records to conceal the scheme.

title: Hall to Stage Musical, Galactica, His First
description: In his cyclonic career the protean Peter Hall has di rected plays, operas and films. During, the last year he staged Albee's All Over at the Royal Shakespeare Company, Pinter's Alte Zeitung in Vienna and Monteverdi's The Return of Ulysses at Glyndebourne. He has also been a director of the Royal Shakespeare Company and the Royal Op era, Covent Garden, and in the spring of 1974 he be comes the director of Brit ain's National Theater, suc ceeding Lord Olivier.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, Sept. 25 (AP)British bookies made Bob Foster of Albuquerque, N. M., a 21 favorite to outpunch Britain's Chris Finnegan and retain his world lightheavy weight boxing title.

title: Music: Singer With Flair
description: Whether you chose to look or listen, the song recital by Lee Dougherty at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night was a striking event. The tall young soprano, who has been in residence as Affiliate Artist at Carthage College in Wisconsin for the last two years, looks like a Vogue model and sings with great flair, individuality and intel ligence.

title: Freed U.S. Fliers Leave Hanoi for China After Escorts Decide to Avoid Laos
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 25 (Agence FrancePresse) The three American pilots re leased by North Vietnam Sept. 17 left here for China today on the first leg of their journey back to the United States.

title: Graham and Lang Troupes Quit Dance Marathon
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company and the Pearl Lang Dance Company have canceled their performances in the City Center's American Dance Mara thon, which begins a sixweek season at the ANTA Theater on Monday.

title: Credit Markets
description: The money and capital mar kets were kept on the defensive again yesterday, but activity was extremely light and inter est rates did not climb by very much. Some rates, in fact; such as those on Treasury bills due from now until early next year, managed small declines. There was no significant new financings reach ing the market yesterday and no other reason ap peared to force in vestors to make decisions about portfolios or holdings of uninvested cash. The smart buyers are looking for values and they don't see it right now, one trader of corporate bonds suggested. Frankly, I can't say that I much blame them, he added.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE NEW CHASTITY AND OTHER ARGU MENTS AGAINST WOMEN'S LIBERATION.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TEANECK, N. J., Sept. 25Being a realist, Randy Newmann says he accepts his reputation and role as a white, Jewish heavyweight hope, even though he happens to be German.

title: FILM MAY PROVIDE CLUE IN JET CRASH
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 25 (AP)A bystander's home movies may help reveal why a rebuilt jet fighter plane faltered on takeoff yesterday and plunged into a crowded ice cream parlor here, Federal in vestigators said today. The death toll was 22.

title: Northwest Strike Talks Set
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 25 (AP) Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson today set up a meet ing between Northwest Airlines amt its striking 1,600 pilots. He said the meeting will be Wednesday in Minneapolis under the direction of W. J. Usery, an assistant Secretary of Labor.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WHAT DOES QUALITY LIFE INSURANCE

title: Judge Dembitz Acts To Have Bar Group Retract Criticism
description: Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz, who is seeking to be the first woman elected to the State Court of Appeals, an nounced yesterday that she had appealed to the State Bar Asso ciation to reconsider its finding that she was not qualified at the present time for a seat on the state's highest tribunal.

title: United Aircraft Names Top Officers
description: Harry J. Gray, president of the United Aircraft Corpo ration, was also named chief executive officer yesterday and Arthur E. Smith, chair man of the executive com mittee, was named chairman of the board.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Representative Ryan's untimely death on Sept. 17 deprives the Democratic left of one of its most capable and articulate spokesmen. For twelve years in the House of Representatives he embodied the best in American poli tics. Courageous and dedicated, he never compromised his principles, even when faced by illness and death. This great and honorable man was an example to all of us, and his passing leaves a vacuum in our lives and our affections.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass., Sept. 25 (AP)One of four men who escaped last week from a Cranton, R. I., prison has been found shot to death in a field here.

title: Nixon Says U. S. Will Lead MonetaryReform Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  President Nixon pledged to the world's finance ministers today that the United States would be in the forefront of ef forts to achieve a thorough going reform of the interna tional monetary system and said Secretary of the Treas ury George P. Shultz would make detailed proposals later this week.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., Sept. 25 Three New Jersey state po licemen took the witness stand today in the trial of two for mer fellow troopers and testi fied that they were not aware of the alleged branding of a lo cal youth last February during interrogation.

title: RABBI ROSENBERG OF KOSHER UNION
description: Rabbi Alexander S. Rosen berg rabbinic administrator of the Kosher Certification Serv ice of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of Amer ica since 1950, died in Jeru salem on Sunday. He was 69 years old and lived at 386 Park Hill Avenue, Yonkers.

title: Big Nixon Lead Indicated In Tristate Voter Survey
description: The Vietnam war, which was supposed to be Senator George McGovern's strong suit politi cally, is actually working to the advantage of President Nixon in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut where much of the antiwar movement has been centered, according to a voter survey released yesterday.

title: Nixon Has Key, Rival Says
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 5 (AP)  Senator George McGovern said today that President Nixon was the one man who holds the key to the release of United States prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

title: BRAZIL BATTLING REBELS IN JUNGLE
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 25 (AP)Brazil's armed forces have begun a combined drive to flush guerrillas out of a re mote Amazon jungle region. At least one soldier has been re ported killed in clashes between the rebels and 5,000 army, air force and navy troops.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  President Nixon won a political endorsement of his candidacy and pragmatic support for his new Soviet trade policy today from the International Long shoreman's Association.

title: Gypsy Cab Driver Slain; Third Killed Since Sept. 2
description: A 38yearold gypsy cab driver was shot and killed last night in northern Harlem when he apparently resisted three passengers who were trying to rob him, the police said.

title: LITHUANIAN TRIAL OF EIGHT STARTS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 25Eight Lithuanians went on trial today in Lithuania on charges of hooliganism presumed to arise from two days of nationalist inspired rioting in May after a youth had burned himself to death.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBIA, Md.So far, the big event in the seven week life of the Howard County headquarters of the Committee for the Re election of the President has been a brief visit by the President's soninlaw, Ed ward F. Cox, a couple of weeks ago.

title: A High Marcos Aide Says in Washington That Martial Law May Last 2 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25A Philippine official said here to day that martial law might be maintained in his country for as long as two years to allow the Government to control sub version and carry out social re forms.

title: Denmark Closing Exchange
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Tuesday, Sept. 26 (Reuters) Premier Jens Otto Krag an nounced last night that all for eignexchange dealings would be suspended until after the Danish referendum on Euro pean Common Market member ship on Oct. 2.

title: ZARETZKI HOLDING KEY TO RYAN SEAT
description: State Senate Minority Lead er Joseph Zaretzki loomed yes terday as a key figure in the struggle among West Side re form Democrats to succeed the late Representative William F. Ryan.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 25 (AP)Mrs. George McGovern honored a picket line at a television station today, can celing an appearance for a 90minute talk show.

title: Beatrice Foods Company Posts Record Sales and Earnings
EAST AFRICA PACT IS GAINING FAVOR
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 25 Uganda and Tanzania were re ported today to be giving most ly favorable consideration to a plan to restore more peaceful relations between them.

title: It's Time to Dust Off Those Old Saddle Shoes
description: They're back in the saddles again.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SANDY HOOK, Sept. 25  Governor Cahill reported today that the Federal Government had agreed to pay for the resto ration and stabilization of a stretch of beach here being eaten away by Atlantic storms.

title: Wallace to Get Checkup
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 25 (AP)Gov. George C1 Wallace checked back into the Spain Rehabilitation Center today for what his doctors termed a rou tine checkup. An aide, Elvin Stanton, said Governor Wallace would go back to Montgomery tomorrow afternoon it his checkup in the morning indi cated no complications in his condition.

title: HEATH BIDS AIRLINES ACT TO TRIM FARES
description: LONDON, Sept. 25, (Reuters) Prime Minister Heath warned executives of the world's air lines today they must bring down fares or lose their cus tomers to the cheapflight char ter companies.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Yields on United States Trea sury bills rose in the Govern ment's weekly competitive sale today of these short term securities.

title: INTERPOL URGES DRIVE ON TERROR
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25Interpol, the interna tional police organization, unanimously approved an Americansponsored resolution today urging its 110 member nations to intensify their ef forts to combat nonpolitical terrorism.

title: Bomb Wrecks Belfast Hotel
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland Sept. 25 (Reuters)  A large bomb shattered Belfast's new est luxury hotel today, causing damaged estimated at $2.5 million.

title: Uganda Ousts British Aide
description: LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 26 The Uganda Government has expelled the British consul in Kampala, George Hawkins, the Foreign Office announced last night.

title: Merger News
description: The Hawaii Corporation an nounced yesterday in Honolulu that the sale of its Pacific Trade Center for more than $26.5million had been ap proved by the boards and com mittees of the prospective buy ers. The Pacific Trade Center is an officeretailparking com plex in Honolulu's financial dis trict. The buyers were identified as the Northwestern Mutual Life Insur ance Company of Milwaukee and Western Properties, S. A., a consortium of five British fi nancil institutions. Final terms of the sale are to be negotiated, according to a Hawaii Corpora tion spokesman.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 25More than two dozen persons were injured today when an incom ing ErieLackawanna commuter train bumped a train that was starting to move out of Penn Station here.

title: Former Bank Official Charged With Embezzling $1.1Million
description: A former assistant vice presi dent and branch manager of the First National City Bank was indicted yesterday on charges of embezzling more than $1 million and falsifying bank rec ords to conceal the scheme.

title: Queens Policeman Bars Woman's Suicide Leap
description: A patrolman hanging from a safety belt 12 stories high made a daring rescue of 29yearold woman threaten ing suicide in Queens yester day morning.

title: Spiking Pension Reform
description: A wrecker's ball wielded by the Senate Finance Committee threatens to smash the most thoughtful measure ever devised on Capitol Hill for correcting defects in the private pension plans that cover more than thirty million workers.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In the dim light, Joe Namath swirled the ice in his glass. He was drinking vodka on the rocks with a splash of kahlua, a Black Russian, and he was grinning.

title: Text of Nixon Talk at Meeting of International Monetary Fund and World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Following is the text of Pres ident Nixon's address today before the meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank:

title: Meadowlands Sports Complex Approved With an Ecological If
description: LYNDHURST, N. J., Sept. 25 Two of New Jersey's state agencies today approved the Cahill administration's stillcon troversial plans to construct a vast sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands, pro vided the ecological integrity of the site is safeguarded.

title: White House Reported Working to Kill Part of Hijacking Bill
description: A Congressional storm ap pears to be building up over antihijacking legislation.

title: U.S. STEEL SIGNS A POLLUTION PACT
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (UPI) The United States Steel Cor poration signed a consent de cree today under which it will start immediately a major pro gram to eliminate massive pol lution by its coke works at Clairton, Pa., on the Mononga hela River 15 miles from here.

title: ROGERS ASKS U.N. TO SET '73 PARLEY ON WORLD TERROR
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25The United States asked the United Nations today to convene a meeting early next year to act on interna tional terrorism.

title: Pay Board Approves Raise for L.I.R.R.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The Pay Board approved to day a wage and fringe bene fit increase substantially high er than its own general stand ards for 1,433 trainmen and other employes of the Long Is land Rail Road.

title: Nixon Sets Veterans' Day
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) President Nixon today formally proclaimed Oct. 23 as Veterans' Day to pay homage to the millions of quiet, understand ing heroes who have served so that other generations might be spared war's anguish and de struction.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ENGLEWOOD, Sept. 25  About 150 worried and im patient parents turned out in force tonight at a meeting of the Board of Education to com plain about a series of violent incidents that began this fall at the Dwight Morrow High School.

title: INTERPLAY TO GET JOFFREY PREMIERE
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet will present Jerome Robbins's Interplay in addi tion to three announced new productions during its season at the City Center from Oct. 4 through Nov. 12.

title: ROGERS ASKS U.N. TO SET '73 PARLEY ON WORLD TERROR
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25The United States asked the United Nations today to convene a meeting early next year to act on interna tional terrorism.

title: MISSILE AGREEMENT APPROVED BY HOUSED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The House approved and sent to the White House today an interim United Slates  Soviet agreement to freeze a major part of their offensive nuclear arsenals for five years.

title: Nicholas C. Christofilos Dies; Head of Thermonuclear Project
description: LIVERMORE, Calif., Sept 25 (AP)  Nicholas C. Christo filos, one of the nation's fore most nuclear scientists, died of an apparent heart attack Mon day at nearby Hayward, where lived alone. He was 56 years years old.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Anthony L. DiLorenzo, the 44yearold reputed Mafia leader who disappeared on July 26 while on an unes corted furlough from Federal prison to his dentist on Long Island, was indicted yester day on charges of escape from Federal custody.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 25 (UPI)Lee Trevino shot a 69 today for a 54hole total of 206 and a sixstroke victory in the New Mexico open golf tournament. Trevino immedi ately donated his $1,500 win nings to charity and the New Mexico P.G.A.

title: Pavillon Closes Doors As a Dining Era Fades
description: Le Pavillon, at its peak the finest French restaurant in the United States has closed its doors. Truly, the era of the grand luxe restaurant in New York is over, Stuart Levin, the manager and one of the owners, said yester day.

title: Nixon Nominates Two Here for U.S. Judgeships
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  President Nixon today nomi nated Kevin Thomas Duffy, re gional administrator of the Securities and Exchange Com mission, and Robert J. Ward, a New York lawyer, to be Federal district judges for the Southern District of New York.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 25Sargent Shriver, support ing a coordinated Democratic campaign against the Republi can Administration, charged President Nixon today with fail ures in the field of health care.

title: General Huebner Is Dead; Led Big Red 1 in Invasion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Hueb ner, U.S.A., retired, who in World War II led the famous first Divisionthe Big Red 1 through its campaigns in Sicily, France and Germany, died Sat urday in Walter Reed General Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived here.

title: Jet Hijacker Gets 20 Years After 10Day Chicago Trial
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (UPI) William H. Greene was sen tenced today to 20 years in Federal prison for hijacking a Delta Airlines jet flight to Chi cago from West Palm Beach, Fla., April 17.

title: SUSPECT IN BRIBERY HELD SUICIDE VICTIM
description: EAST CHICAGO, Ind., Sept. 25 (AP)East Chicago police men said today that all the evidence points to suicide in the shooting death of City Controller George Lamb at his home.

title: Jones Climbs to 5th Spot On P.G.A. List of Earnings
description: Grier Jones's playoff victory over Dave Marad Sunday in the $100,000 Robinson, Ill., Fall golf tournament was worth $20,000 and put him in fifth place in the year's money winning race, the Professional Golfers Association Tourna ment Players Division an nounced yesterday.

title: Strike Injunction Denied
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (UPI) A Common Pleas judge re fused today to issue an in junction to halt a strike by 3,600 municipal workers. Judge Frank Celebrezze of Cuyahoga county denied the injunction request, made by the city, but did order that picketing around city facilities be limited.

title: Delegates to a World Conference Assert That the Use of National Parks Must Be Rationed
description: JACKSON, Wyo., Sept. 24 Public use of national parks in the United States and around the world is going to have to be rigorously ra tioned in the years ahead, parks officials believe, if the parks themselves are not to be destroyed.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPISenator William Prox mire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that Congress had vindicated Senator George Mc Govern, whose proposal to slash $4billion from the mili tary budget was defeated by the Senate last month.

title: Chattanooga Gasoline Blast Sets Off Vast Fire, Killing 1
description: CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 25 (AP)An early morning explo sion today in a gasoline storage yard set fire to five million gallons of petroleum products and left one man dead and at least six others injured.

title: PBW BEARING BID BARRED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today the request of the PBW Stock Ex change for a full evidentiary hearing on the commission's proposal banning institution al membership on stock ex changes.

title: Trade Deficit for August Was at an 8Month Low
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)The United States re corded its smallest trade deficit in eight months in August, but the nation's foreigntrade ledger still was in the red by $462.6million, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MANILA'S ACTIONS HELD CALCULATED
description: TOKYO, Sept. 25  The Speaker of the Philippine House of Representatives, Cornelio T. Villereal, asserted here today that President Ferdinand E. Marcos had decided to declare martial law long before it was announced as having gone into effect.

title: Buckley Drops Vidal Suit, Settles With Esquire
description: The legal battle between Wil liam F. Buckley Jr. and Gore Vidal, arising out of their pub lic exchange of affronts, appar ently came to an end yesterday with an announcement by Mr. Buckley of two acts: the drop ping of his suit against Mr. Vidal and an outofcourt set tlement of $115,000 with Es quire magazine.

title: Hanoi Reaffirms Policy
description: HANOI, Sept. 25 (AP)Pre mier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam has reiterated the po sition that the North Vietnam ese want to release all cap tured American pilots and will do so when there is agreement on ending the war.

title: 2 Factions of Zulus Fight In Center of Johannesburg
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Sept. 25Five persons were wounded, one seriously, when two rival groups of Zulu tribesmen fought in the central area of this city at dawn today.

title: Moose Invades Soo Locks
description: SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Sept. 25 (UPI)Traffic at the Soo Locks took on an unusual flair yesterday when a bull moose swam through behind three Great Lakes vessels. The authorities coaxed it ashore on Sugar Island, a vacation resort between Sault Ste. Marie and Ontario.

title: HOUSING DELAYED IN WESTCHESTER
description: Governor Rockefeller and Ed ward J. Logue, president of the State Urban Development Cor poration, have apparently de cided to defer the U.D.C.'s building plans in Westchesterl County for four months to give the nine towns involved a chance to come up with multi family housing plans of their own.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 25 (AP) Three witnesses who balked at testifying before the State Com mission of Investigation in a public hearing have evidence that could lead to indictments of public officials, the State Supreme Court was told today.

title: OPPOSITION CHIEF SEIZED BY MANILA
description: MANILA, Sept. 25  The Government said today that 49 Filipinos  among them six members of Congress, two provincial governors and sev eral newsmenwere being de tained under the state of mar tial law imposed over the weekend.

title: Competing Stock Quotes Proposed by Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it was proposing a system of compet ing quotations to foster com petition among the nation's ex change markets.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Francis A. Southard, a former employe of the Atlantic County Road Department, pleaded guilty yesterday Federal Court to charges of conspiring to commit bribery and extortion in the awarding of contracts in Atlantic County.

title: Business Briefs
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Sept. 25 (Reuters) West Germany's foreign trade surplus narrowed to 1,342, 000,000 marks in August from 1,623,000,000 in July, but was higher than the 1,333,000,000 of August last year, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The German mark is equivalent to about 31 cents.

title: Former Sanitation Official Charged In Attempt to Raise Funds for Mayor
description: A former deputy commis sioner of sanitation as arrest ed yesterday and charged with violating the state election law by attempting to induce city employes to buy tickets to a fundraising dinner for Mayor Lindsay.

title: Cooperative Competition
description: President Nixon's address to the International Mone tary Fund yesterday was most welcome, as it clarified what United States representatives should have made clear long ago: that this country will work for a major reform of the world monetary system; that it wants that system to be both equitable and open; and that it seeks, and will itself live by, a realistic code of economic con duct for nations, not only in the monetary area but also in foreign trade and investment.

title: RULE EASING SET ON SAVINGS UNITS
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board acted yesterday to lift the moratorium on conversions of savings and loan associations from mutual ownership to stock ownership at the discretion of the individual institutions.

title: Diebold Parent Feels Cash Pinch
description: John Diebold, 46yearold management consultant and venture capitalist, has long been a leading apostle of the computer as the key to a revolution in managerial technique.

title: U. S. BUSINESSES BIG IN PHILIPPINES
description: The number of United States companies with a stake in the Philippines, now being gov erned under a proclamation of martial law, has been estimated at 800 by the Philippine Secu rities and Exchange Commis sion.

title: G.E. Contract Addition
description: The General Electric Com pany received $38.4million in additions to existing Air Force contracts, it was announced yesterday. The company was awarded a $37.3million addi tion for the Minuteman Mark 12 reentry system, and a $1.1 million addition for automatic flightcontrol systems for aircraft.

title: Two Slain Girls in Chicago Identified by Their Parents
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (UPI) Two teenage girls found shot to death in a city park last weekend were positively, iden tifeld today by their parents, the police said.

title: Inkslinger Wins on the Flat, Too
description: A horse with a $100,000 stakes victory to his credit ran in a race for maidens (non winners) yesterday at Belmont Park  and won it as third choice in a field of nine.

title: Advertising: Dial and the Ban
description: Just about the only major deodorant toilet soap that will be affected by the Gov ernment's new ban on the nonprescription use of the germ killer hexachlorophene is the market's leader, Dial.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 25 Mrs. Andrew Sage of Piping Rock, rallying with a one underpar 36 after a fourover 41, posted a winning 77 in the qualifying round of the Wom en's Long Island matchplay golf championship today at Fresh Meadow Country Club.

title: Yankees Find 4th Is Just the Ticket
description: The Yankees could be elim inated from the Eastern Di vision title race as early as Thursday night. Then again, if they win all seven of their re maining games, they would fail to win the title only if Boston won at least six of its nine games, Detroit six of eight or Baltimore all seven of its games.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The Committee for the Reelec tion of the President opened the official Republican tele vision campaign tonight with lowkey fiveminute documen tary on President Nixon's visit to Russia.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION EDGES AHEAD 1.6%
description: Steel production for the week ended Sept. 23 edged ahead by 1.6 per cent to 2,536,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yester day.

title: Man in the News
description: Newspaper clippings about Julius Erving wallpaper the trophy case in the local high school in the village of Roosevelt, a predominantly black middleclass town on Long Island. His photograph is prominently displayed at the Theodore Roosevelt ele mentary school were he was the guest speaker at last June's graduation exer cises. The sign on the gate at Roose Park reads: This is where Julius Erving learned the game of basketball.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: All progressive citizens should mourn the tragic loss of Representative Wil liam F. Ryan, Congressman from the Twentieth District in Manhattan. Such a special breed of legislator is a rarity.

title: U. S. Population Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)The United States grew by an estimated 138,000 per sons last month bringing the nation's population to about 208,976,000 on Aug. 1, the Census Bureau reported today. This was about 1.8 million more Americans than a year earlier.

title: No Slipup for Gateway
description: For a project that has no serious opposition, the Gate way National Urban Recreation Area retains an air of suspense about it right down to the legislative wire. All that stands between the House bill and final enactment of this plan for a splendid series of parks along New York's harborfront is the inclusion of a provision, un fortunately forced into the measure at the insistent prompting of New York State Housing Commissioner Charles J. Urstadt, backed by Gov ernor Rockefeller. The contro versial clause, would reserve part of Floyd Bennett Field, otherwise included in the park, for a public housing de velopment. Few housing proj ects could have been more poorly conceived than this plan to subject people to the intolerable noise of jet planes to and from nearby Kennedy Airport; there were some 300 flights a day over this same area last year.

title: About Pro Football
description: In the Bills' first offensive huddle, O. J. Simpson asked, Does everyone here know everyone else? Walt Patul ski said, It seemed we were just introduced to each other before the game.

title: EDWARD S. LLOYD
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 25 Edward S. Lloyd, who retired recently as a partner in W. E. Burnet & Co., New York stock brokers, died today at his home here.

title: BRUINS SET BACK RANGERS, 4 TO 2
description: In a game important because, according to Ed Giacomin, it's a Boston team against a Ranger team, the Bruins last night captured a wideopen ex hibition contest, 42.

title: Chiefs Win on a Late Field Goal
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25 (AP)Jan Stenerud kicked a 22yard field goal with less than two minutes to play to lift the twotouchdown favorite, Kansas City, to a 2017 victory over the New Orleans Saints tonight in a nationally televised National Football League game.

title: Beer Can Collectors Hold BarterPest
description: LAKE GENEVA, Wis., Sept. 24 Doctors and mechanics and housewives and teen agersabout 600 persons in allgathered here this week end to share a common pas sion: empty beer cans.

title: V.A. Hospital Site
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) Senator Richard S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, urged Veterans Administra tion officials today to select Philadelphia as the site for a new V.A. hospital.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 25New Jersey secondary schools will begin moving this fall toward a new system of credits and grad uation requirements designed to increase curricular flexibility in local schools.

title: MUSICIANS' PACT AVERTS A STRIKE
description: A strike that would have darkened New York's theatrical district was averted yesterday morning when union musicians reached agreement with the League of New York Theaters on a new threeyear contract.

title: Vatican Makes Clear Pope Will Not Resign
description: ROME, Sept. 25The Vati can newspaper L'Osservatore Romano, in a frontpage edi torial on the 75th birthday tomorrow of Pope Paul VI, made it clear tonight that he would not resign.

title: Merrill Lynch Sets a Plan To Reacquire Own Shares
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith announced yesterday that it intends to acquire as many as 450,000 of its own shares over the next nine months. The concern said the reacquisition program was ap proved by its executive com mittee Friday.

title: Rhodes Restaurateur Faces Charges in Fire Fatal to 32
description: RHODES, Greece, Sept. 25 (AP)An owner of a restau rant that burned with a loss of 32 lives was charged tonight with involuntary manslaughter, physical harm and involuntary arson.

title: Tentative Accord Is Reached in Longest General Motors Strike
description: DETROIT, Sept. 25A tenta tive agreement to end the long est strike in the history of Gen eral Motors was reached today. The 172day strike cost the company over $100million in lost production and 4,000 mem bers of the United Automobile Workers about $20million in wages.

title: Diplomacy in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept 25The Swedish government was in volved in intense diplomatic discussion today in anticipation of what some diplomats said was a possible confrontation later this week at Stockholm's international airport between United States officials and the three former prisoners of war released by Hanoi.

title: Personalities: OTB vs. N.F.L.
description: Howard Samuels, president of New York's Offtrack Bet ting Corporation, said yester day that the National Foot ball League, in its alleged ban of OTB advertising dur ing New York Giant and Jet football games, was hypocritical, if not down right silly. Samuels said the league had forced WNEW, which broadcasts Giant games, to drop OTB as a sponsor and had ap plied pressure on WOR, which airs the Jets' games. He said that WOR had not yet decided whether to con tinue the OTB ads.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: DELLSLOW, W. Va.It's always been trouble for us. We've fought from day to day, fought worrying about where's the next meal coming from.

title: A Study Shows Leniency Is the Rule in City Courts
description: Sentencing in the city's courts has fallen into confusion, with judges by their own ac count regularly handing out sentences they consider either too lenient or too harsh.

title: Nixon Says U.S. Will Lead MonetaryReform Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  President Nixon pledged to the world's finance ministers today that the United States would be in the forefront of ef forts to achieve a thorough going reform of the interna tional monetary system and said Secretary of the Treas ury George P. Shultz would make detailed proposals.

title: Executive Changes
description: Harvey L. Schein has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Sony Corporation of America, the American subsidiary of the Sony Cor poration.

title: Texts of U.S. Resolution and Draft Convention on Terrorism
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25Following are the texts of a resolution on terrorism offered by the United States in the. General Assembly today, and of an American draft convention for the prevention and punishment of acts of terrorism:

title: GOV. BARRON EXAIDE GUILTY OF BRIBERY
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE. Va., Sept. 25 (UPI)Bonn Brown of Elkins, W. Va., was found guilty today of, conspiracy, bribery and influencing the jury in the 1968 trial of W. W. Barron former Governor of West Virginia.

title: Hurt Mother Whale Rescued on Beach With Newborn Calf
description: A badly cut and bruised 10 footlong pygmy sperm whale and her newborn calf, found washed ashore yesterday morning at a beach in Far Rockaway, Queens, were swaddled in wet blankets and rushed to the New York Aquar ium at Coney Island.

title: Matlack Is Player of Week
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 (UPI)John Matlack of the New York Mets was named as the National League player of the week today by the league president, Charles S. Feeney.

title: FRIEDMANN RITES HELD AT COLUMBIA
description: About 600 persons, led by Mayor Lindsay and Dr. William J. McGill, president of Colum bia University, attended a me morial service yesterday after noon at Columbia for Dr. Wolf gang G. Friedmann, the law professor who was mugged and stabbed to death Wednesday afternoon a few blocks from the campus.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Howard Samuels, president of New York's Offtrack Bet ting Corporation, said yester day that the National Foot ball League, in its alleged ban of OTB advertising dur ing New York Giant and Jet football games, was hypocritical, if not down right silly. Samuels said the league had forced WNEW, which broadcasts Giant games, to drop OTB as a sponsor and had ap plied pressure on WOR, which airs the Jets' games. He said that WOR had not yet decided whether to con tinue the OTB ads.

title: Brooklyn School Shut to Avoid BlackWhite Parent Showdown
description: A Brooklyn junior high school that has been involved in a ter zoning controversy was dered closed yesterday morning, about an hour before classes were to start, to avert a con frontation between parents from the East Flatbush and Brownsville sections.

title: Survey Finds War Issue Gains Votes for President
description: The Vietnam war, which was supposed to be Senator George McGovern's strong suit politi cally, is actually working to the advantage of President Nixon in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, where much of the antiwar movement has been centered, according to a voter survey released yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Denmark, Soviet Un ion, Mauritius, Ghana, Leb anon, France, Uruguay and Haiti are listed to speak in the general debate.

title: Riva Ridge Set to Compete In International at Laurel
description: LAUREL, Md., Sept. 25 (AP) The trainer, Lucien Lauren, announced today that Meadow Stable's Riva Ridge will run in the Washington D.C. Interna tional at Laurel Race Course Nov. 11.

title: Police Conference of State Backs Nixon for Reelection
description: The Police Conference of New York yesterday endorsed President Nixon for re election.

title: AMEX PRICES DROP AS TRADING SLOWS
description: Prices declined yesterday in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange and in over thecounter activity.

title: Allison Wins More Money; Petty Increases PointLead
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 25 (AP)Bobby Allison made an extra $5,000 yester day, but lost more ground in his bid for NASCAR's Winston Cup Grand National driving championship with Richard Petty in the Old Dominion 500 at Martinsville, Va.

title: Radioactive Water Released
description: ELK RIVER, Minn., Sept. 25 (AP)A discharge of 3,180 gallons of radioactive water into the Mississippi River at Elk River began as scheduled today. The release is the second in a series of several that are necessary to dismantle the re actor and are within standards allowed by the Atomic Energy Commission and the State Pol lution Control Agency.

title: NamathUnitas Duel Matter of Record
description: When the statisticians had finished searching the record books they found that Joe Namath and Johnny Unitas set five club records during the Jets' 4434 victory over the Colts in Baltimore on Sunday. Frankly, though, Namath couldn't have cared less about the records.

title: Seeing Is Not Believing For a Skeptical Unitas
description: Against the Baltimore Colts, Joe Namath did what John Unitas said no one can dothrow long and success ful passes against the zone defense. After Namath's six touchdown passes right in front of Unitas's eyes, the 39yearold quarterback re mained skeptical.

title: IN THE NATION
description: If President Nixon were leading Sen ator George McGovern by some con ventional margintive or eight or ten pointsprobably no one would be much concerned about the question of polls. But no Presidential candidate has ever been so far behind in a na tional poll as Mr. McGovern was on Labor Day, when he trailed by 34 points; and his showing was even worse in The New York Times Yan kelovich poll of sixteen major states published yesterday. It showed the President ahead, 62 to 23.

title: 8 MORE FOOD PLACES NAMED AS VIOLATORS
description: The Health Department yes terday released the names of eight restaurants and other food establishments charged with serious violations of the city's Health Code.

title: AWARDS TO BE MADE BY BOARD OF TRADE
description: The New York Board of Trade has named 12 companies and organizations to receive its Business Speaks Award for out standing contributions to the social and economic wellbeing of the city.

title: Crime in Capital Is Focus Of National Political Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The District of Columbia, designated by President Nixon as a na tional laboratory on crime con trol, has emerged in the politi cal campaigns as a center of controversy over the highly emotional issue of crime in the streets:

title: State Deputy Sheriffs Elect Officers at Annual Session
description: TONAWANDA, N. Y., Sept. 25 (UPI)George L. Osterberg of Easthampton has been re elected president of the New York State Sheriff's Deputies Association.

title: McGovern Calls Nixon Ally of Business
description: BILLINGS, Mont., Sept. 25 Senator George McGovern charged here today that the Nixon Administration was dominated by special interests in environmental and regula tory agencies.

title: PLATINUM PRICES SHOW A DECLINE
description: Platinum and palladium futures prices fell yesterday de spite an announcement by the General Motors Corporation over the weekend that it had developed an auto emission control system that would meet the Government's 197576 pol lution control standards. This system would utilize consider able amounts of platinum and palladium.

title: Market Place: Others to Gain By G.M. Device
description: When Charles E. Wilson, former chairman of the Gen eral Motors Corporation, was Secretary of Defense in the Eisenhower Administration, he was quoted as saying that what was good for General Motors was good for the United States, and vice versa.

title: Police Are Warned Of CarCheck Rules And to Avoid Chases
description: The police were issued re newed orders yesterday on how and when to stop cars and question their occupants.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES PRESIDENT POWER TO LIMIT SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to give President Nixon unlimited au thority to cut whatever Govern ment programs he chooses be tween now and next June 30 to keep total Government spend ing for the fiscal year at no more than $250billion.

title: HAYMAN E. MILLER
description: Hayman E. Miller, interna tional advertising manager of The New York Herald Tribune until 1967, died here early yes terday at Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old and for the last eight years had lived in Kingston, N. Y.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Sept. 26 (UPI) Joey Archer, South African boxer, was in serious condition today after being knocked out late last night by Michael Karpaney in a televised welterweight bout.

title: Rockefeller Is Firm on His Order Superseding D.A.'s
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he did not in tend to modify his executive order superseding New York's five District Attorneys on the handling of corruption cases among the police, prosecutors and judges.

title: Higher Magistrate Salaries
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) President Nixon signed a bill today raising the salary ceil ing for United States magis trates to $36,000 a year for fulltime work. The maximum for parttime work is $18,000. Under present law, magistrates cannot receive more than $22,500 for a year for fulltime work or $11,000 for parttime.

title: Caso, G.O.P. Split on Reapportioning
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 25 In an unusual split in Republi can ranks, County Executive Ralph G. Caso today vetoed a plan by the Republicancon trolled County Board of Super visors to implement a court order directing the board to reapportion on the basis of the oneman, onevote principle.

title: CourtMartial Is Recessed
description: FORT ORD, Calif., Sept. 25 (UPI)The fragging court martial of Army Pvt. Billy D. Smith was recessed today for an additional week while the prosecution seeks missing wit nesses. The trial judge, Col. Rawls H. Frazier, continued the case until Oct. 3 at the request of the prosecution. The prose cutor, Capt. Craig J. Casey would not say how many wit nesses were missing.

title: Padres Down Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 (AP) A pinchhitter, Randy Elliott, slammed a runscoring triple in the eighth inning to break a 33 tie and lead the Padres to a 5 to 3 victory over the Dodgers tonight, dimming Claude Osteen's hopes of be coming a 20game winner this season.

title: Marcus Welby Tops First Week's Nielsen TV Ratings
description: The first national Nielsen ratings for the new television season's first week, ending Sept. 17, were reported yes terday. They indicated that Marcus Welby, M.D. was still TV's most popular physician and that movies, at least on television, were doing better than ever.

title: American Troop Strength In Vietnam Down to 36,100
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25 (AP)American troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 400, to 36,100 last week, the United States command an nounced today.

title: and Welfare Reform
description: Sudden as was the Senate Finance Committee's decision to muscle in on private pension reform, it is no surprise at all to find it playing a similarly destruc tive role in seeking to torpedo Congressional action on welfare reform.

title: ProSchweitzer Feeling Strong
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 PierrePaul Schweitzer, manag ing director of the Interna tional Monetary Fund, received an ovation today when he rose to address the joint annual meeting of the fund and the World Bank.

title: Expert Says Human Organ Transplants Are at Level Below What Doctors Would Like
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 Success in human organ trans plantation has reached a plateau from which it can be expected to advance only with consider able effort, a major figure in that field told an international congress here today.

title: 2 Pygmy Whales, 1 Newborn, Beached; Survival Vigil On
description: A badly cut and bruised 10 footlong pygmy sperm whale and her newborn calf, found washed ashore yesterday morning at a beach in Far Rockaway, Queens, were swaddled in wet blankets and rushed to the New York Aquar ium at Coney Island.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Whenever we see people like Marcus Welby, Perry Mason, Matt Dillon and other comparably splendid professional men on television, we see them at their absolute best. This is only natural. Everybody smiles when he knows he is having his picture taken. Unfortu nately, this gives us a distorted im pression of the lives of these important men.

title: RUSSELL M. GROGAN
description: NORTH KINGSTON, R. I., Sept, 25Russell M. Grogan, who retired in 1966 as a vice president of the Long Island Lighting Company, died Satur day in Warwick. He was 66 years old and lived here.

title: Tanaka Tells Chou of Japan's Regret for Aggression
description: PEKING, Sept. 25Premier Kakuei Tanaka expressed Ja pan's regret and repentance to day for past aggression against China and joined Premier Chou Enlai in predicting complete agreement in their talks here to normalize longstrained re lations.

title: China Buying 2,100, Trucks From 2 Japanese Companies
description: TOKYO, Sept. 25 (UPI)Two Japanese automobile, companies today announced the sale of a total of 2,100 small and me diumsized trucks to China. The total value of the shipments is put at $6.7million.

title: LONG ISLAND MEDAL WON BY MRS. SAGE
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 25 Mrs. Andrew Sage of Piping Rock, rallying with a one underpar 36 after a fourover 41, posted a winning 77 in the qualifying round of the Wom en's Long Island matchplay golf championship today at Fresh Meadow Country Club.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company will drop trading stamps in its more than 200 A. & P. stores in four of the five counties of New York on Saturday, it was learned yesterday. The stores in Richmond stopped issuing the Plaid stamps some time ago.

title: Tax Court Judge Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Darrell D. Wiles of St. Louis for a 15year term as a judge of the United States Tax Court. He succeeds Judge Graydon G. Withey, who retired.

title: OPPOSITION CHIEF SEIZED BY MANILA
description: MANILA, Sept. 25 The Government said today that 49 Filipinos  among them six members of Congress, two provincial governors and sev eral newsmenwere being de tained under the state of mar tial law imposed over the weekend.

title: BRANDT SAYS RIVALS TRIED TO BUY VOTES
description: BONN, Sept. 25Chancellor Willy Brandt asserted today that West Germany's powerful conservative Opposition had of fered money to members of parliament to defect from his coalition and wipe out his par liamentary majority.

title: Snead Apparent Choice To Start Against Eagles
description: Two quarterbacks who didn't start Sunday afternoon prob ably earned the right to start against each other next Mon day night when the New York Giants visit the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: A Study Shows Leniency Is the Rule in City Courts
description: Sentencing in the city's courts has fallen into confusion, with judges by their own ac count regularly handing out sentences they consider either too lenient or too harsh.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Anthony L. DiLorenzo, the 44yearold reputed Mafia leader who disappeared on July 26 while on an unescorted furlough from Federal prison to his dentist on Long Island, was indicted yesterday on charges of escape from Federal custody.

title: Massachusetts Aide Named
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25 (AP)  Gov. Francis W. Sargent an nounced today the appointment of Dr. Harold Turner of New ton as chairman of the state Alcoholic Beverages Control Commission.

title: Pupils at Danbury to Get New Vaccine
