description: DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 25  About 1,000 first  graders here will become the first school children in the United States to receive a new vac cine against meningitis. It will be administered by a physi cians' team from the Univer sity of Connecticut School of Medicine.

title: Counterfeiting Law Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)President Nixon signed into law today a bill forbidding the forgery and counterfeiting of postal money orders and prohibiting the unauthorized use of money order validating machines. The law closes loop holes in the United States code, which previously did not spe cifically prohibit illicit traffick ing in possession of stolen blank postal money orders.

title: College Sports Notes
description: Bob Devaney, Nebraska's football coach, yesterday de nounced the Big Eight Con ference rule that limits trav eling squads to 50 players. Nebraska, a Big Eight team, took that many players to West Point last Saturday and trounced Army, 777. Saying that was one of the reasons the score got out of hand against Army, Devaney added: We could have used a lot of players if we'd had them available Saturday and it would have been good experience for them.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Delaney Kiphuth, athletic director at Yale, was elected president of two conferences yesterday in the opening session of the 36th annual convention of the Eastern Col lege Athletic Conference here.

title: Walter Kennedy, N.B.A. commissioner
description: In an internal dispute that threatens the structure of the pro basketball draft and the fouryear college rule, the Atlanta Hawks and Julius Er ving filed a $2million anti trust suit yesterday against the National Basketball As sociation.

title: Polish Port Cities Are Turbulent Again But This Time It's an Economic Boom
description: GDYNIA, Poland, Sept. 15 Nearly two years after riots in this port area forced a change in Polish leadership, the coast is again the scene of turbulencebut this time it is the result of an economic boom.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)Capital spending by Americanowned companies overseas will drop sharply this year and then pick up slightly in 1973, the Commerce Department said today.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Slimming. That's the word Irene Satz, Ohrbach's fashion director, used before more than 1,000 people yes terday to describe the brown and black striped Givenchy dress in the store's import fashion show. Not that the dress wasn't slimmingver tical striped styles usually are. And at $85, it wasn't a bad buy.

title: Queens Woman Called Second Cruelest at Camp
description: Dr. Danuta Czaykowska Medryk, who spent a year and four months during World War II at the Maidanek concentra tion camp in Poland, told a Federal hearing yesterday that, Hermine Braunsteiner was the second most cruel guard at the camp. The most cruel, she said, was a guard named Lotte.

title: Big Board Names Palamara As Executive Vice President
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that Francis J. Palamara, an executive vice president of the Pittston Company, had been named executive vice presi dent of the Big Board, effec tive next Monday.

title: Released Fort Worth Five Getting to Know Their Families Again
description: A bus driver, a carpenter, a house painter, a realestate salesman and a male nurse were enjoying reunions with their families yesterday after three months in a Texas jail.

title: Escaped Bay State Prisoner Is Found Shot to Death
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass., Sept. 25 (AP)One of four men who escaped last week from Cranton, R. I., prison has been found shot to death in a field here.

title: City Kills Tombs Addition, Priority Project After Riot
description: The Lindsay administration yesterday killed a proposed $70million addition to the Manhattan Men's House of De tention, which was a topprior ity project following the 1970 riots in the overcrowded Tombs.

title: PATRICIA TRECELLAS PLAYS ACCORDION
description: Patricia Tregellas, an accor dionist who has been in the pit orchestras of such hit mu sicals as Fiddler on the Roof and Cabaret, is also a firm believer in the concert potential of her instrument. Unfortu nately, she did not make a good case for it at her Carnegie Re cital Hall program late Sunday afternoon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The digging of the Second Avenue subway is about to begin. I assume this will mean the moving aside of all manner of pipes and electrical lines to clear the way. This is the moment to make some sense, to eliminate the incessant, recurrent, and uneconomic drilling that plagues the city.

title: Quota Memo Held Job Rights Retreat
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Officials of civil rights and women's rights organizations made public today a memoran dum that, they said, confirmed a retreat in equal employ ment by the Nixon Adminis tration.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 25 Fortyfour people who were un aware that they had high blood pressure, a factor underlying heart trouble, are now under medical care because of a pilot program started last summer by a group of 16 Bergen County dentists.

title: Saigon Reported in Drive To Open Key Coast Road
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 26 (AP)South Vietnamese troops reportedly began an attempt yesterday to clear Communistled forces from the coastal highway run ning through the northcentral province of Quangngai.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Dead and dying herring gulls near the town of Man chester on Massachusetts' north shore earlier this month provided the first warning to state officials that a socalled red tide invasion had be gun.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your recent editorial entitled Rustic Highways contained several serious misinterpretations of facts.

title: Rat in Movie Honored
description: VALENCIA, Calif., Sept. 25 (UPI)The Patsy, the equiva lent of an Oscar for the animals of show business, was awarded yesterday by the American Humane Association. The win ner was Ben, the rat who starred in the movie Willard.

title: Uruguay Devalues Peso
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 25 (Reuters)The Uruguayan central bank today devalued the peso on the commercial ex change market, increasing the rate of the dollar to 647641 pesos from the previous rate of 627621 pesos.

title: Business Briefs
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yester day it had agreed to sell three DC10 widecabin transport jets to Turkish Airlines, Inc., for about $62million, includ ing spare parts and support equipment.

title: It's a Livelier Fall Season
description: New York's fall season, which in recent years has been accused of having all the glamour of a soggy potato chip, apparently is going to be livelier this year. So cially, at least, the recession may be over.

title: Lebanese Premier Says the Guerrillas Accept Restrictions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 25 Premier Saab Salem of Lebanon said today that Pales tinian guerrillas in this country had agreed to avoid any harm to Lebanon in her relations with Israel.

title: Nixon Signs Bill Expanding Food Aid for School Needy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)President Nixon signed today a bill that will expand the program of Federal aid for school lunch, breakfast and summer school ground feeding programs.

title: World Monetary Reform
description: Secretary of the Treasury Shultz has made good on President Nixon's promise that the United States would offer the world a constructive plan for world monetary reform. The Shultz proposals to the International Mone tary Fund yesterday represent a major contribution to dispelling the disarray and easing the atmosphere of crisis and economic hostility in the nonCommunist world.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Want to look different when you go out at night, now that fashion's swung back to sheer silks and taffeta? Try leather, Jean Muir suggests. The English designer, whose New York outpost is the second floor at Henri Bendel, doesn't mean the tough sort of leather clothes that were fashionable a few years back. She means halters, smock dresses, silver edg ingssilver snakeskin edgings, that is.

title: Country Music: Quartet
description: Allan Block, a onetime Greenwich Village sandal maker and fiddler who now lives in New Hampshire, came back to New York Monday for an evening of string music and singing with sev eral friends at the Washing ton Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: 3 in J.D.L. Plead Guilty in Bombings
description: Three members of the Jewish Defense League pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to charges related to bombing incidents last year at two offices and property of the Soviet Union here.

title: KISSINGER MEETS WITH HANOI AIDES; TALKS GO ON TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Henry A. Kissinger met pri vately in Paris today with North Vietnamese representa tives, and the White House an nounced that the talks would be extended tomorrow into a second day.

title: Campaign Letter
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 One of the lingering myster ies in this Presidential cam paign has been the McGovern gap  the conflict in percep tion between the politicians, reporters and pollsters who judged the Democratic candi date to be hopelessly off the pace and those who saw him closing in at a steady gallop to ward an exciting finish. Almost any where away from George McGovern and his entourage, the signs have been of gloom and they prophecies of doom.

title: A Recanvass of Primary Set for Today in Brooklyn
description: The Board of Elections will begin a recanvass today of the Sept. 19 special primary in which Representative John J. Rooney defeated Allard K. Lowenstein in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District.

title: RACING STUDY UNIT GOES TO THE POST
description: Governor Rockefeller's special horseracing study group will listen terribly hard to everybody with something to say, its chairman promised yesterday.

title: CENTRISTS IN FRANCE PLAN A REFORM DRIVE
description: PARIS, Sept. 26Two French centrist parties announced a farreaching joint reform move ment today and offered to ne gotiate a coalition with the Gaullists after elections if their program was accepted.

title: A Suspect Is Seized In Slaying of Man At Midtown Church
description: A 21yearold unemployed dishwasher was arrested and charged yesterday with the murder and robbery two weeks ago of 83yearold Peter Brejwa in the basement of the rectory of St. Clemens Mary Roman Catholic Church at 406 West 40th Street.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Sept. 26 John L. Hurst of Deal shot a 36, 4177 to take the first round lead in the 50th New Jer sey Seniors Golf Association championship today at the Bal tusrol Golf Club.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose at Monthly Sale
Coping With Terror
description: Two necessary and complementary mechanisms for attacking the scourge of international terrorism have now been set in motion.

title: AliJones Bout Put Off
description: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)  The proposed heavyweight boxing bout between former world champion, Muhammad Ali, and Al Jones both of the United States, scheduled for Nov. 18 was postponed today until next year, according to the pro moters.

title: White Sox Bow to Royals And Fall 4 Games Back
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) Steve Busby, a 22yearold rookie righthander, and his batterymate, Ed Kirkpatrick, dealt Chicago's title hopes a severe blow tonight by leading the Kansas City Royals to a 21 victory over the White Sox.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)The State Department acknowledged today that it had supplied the White House with its Public Affairs Division's mailing list, which was ap parently used by the Demo crats for Nixon campaign or ganization.

title: Senior Citizen Is a Winner Before His First Wager
description: The New York Racing As sociation's senior citizens program, designed to reduce the admission price for fol lowers of form who are 65 years or older, was intro duced at Belmont Park yester day. It produced an immedi ate winner.

title: Norwegian Vote Termed Blow to European Unity
description: LONDON, Sept. 26Europe reacted with dismay and con cern today to Norway's rejec tion of entry into the European Economic Community.

title: Mountie to Head Interpol
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 26 (Agence FrancePresse) William L. Higgitt, Commis sioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, was elected president of Interpol today at the international police organ ization's 41st annual congress here.

title: 3 American P.O.W.;s Freed by Hanoi Leave Peking for Moscow
description: PEKING, Wednesday, Sept. 27 (Reuters)Three American pilots released by North Viet nam left Peking early today on their way home to the United States after an overnight stay here.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 26  Mid lantic Banks, Inc., has become the first New Jersey banking institution to attain $1.5billion in assets, Gustave E. Wieden mayer, chairman and chief ex ecutive officer, announced to day.

title: Bridge: Significance of Spot Cards Should Not Be Overlooked
description: The play to the first trick is often the key to the whole deal, especially in defense. A defender who is willing to think can some times discover an inner significance in the spot cards that land on the table. An example is the dia gramed deal, played Thurs day in the New YorkNew Jersey Regional Champion ships.

title: EUGENSPIRO,98,DIES; A PORTRAIT PAINTER
description: Eugen Spiro, a portrait painter whose subjects included Albert Einstein and Thomas Mann, died yesterday at his home, 15 West 67th Street. He was 98 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis has dismissed an other cook. Karle Jerome, the 19th chef to pass through the Onassis employ in four years, is a 23yearold sociologist with a reputation as a cool hand with coeur de la crme. He told tales of having to mix skim milk with the cot tage cheese and to prepare cucumber sandwiches for tea at the Onassis Fifth Avenue apartment. And then, as if life wasn't tough enough, he had to provide cinnamon sticks to sweeten the heat in the fireplace.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL ON GATEWAY AREA BUT KILLS HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The House today approved creation of a 26,172acre na tional recreation area at the entrance to New York harbor after killing a provision for a massive housing project that the Rockefeller administration wanted to build on part of Floyd Bennett Field in Brook lyn.

title: Bigger Role for the Hovercraft in World's Navies Is Forecast
description: LONDON, Sept. 26Increas ing use by the world's navies of hovercraft capable of up to 80 knots has been forecast by a leading authority on naval con struction.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Once again, Messrs. Gallup and Harris are becoming an issue in a na tional campaign. How reliable are their polls? How meaningful? Do they become selffulfilling prophecies?

title: House Panel Votes Aid to Grain Farms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The House Agriculture Com mittee approved today a bill that would partly compen sate farmers in Texas, Okla homa and Kansas who sold their early wheat at low prices while unaware of the magni tude of Soviet wheat purchases that ultimately sent prices soar ing.

title: Nader Welcomes Pension Setback; Sees a Better Bill
description: Ralph Nader said yesterday he was pleased that major pen sion reform had been side tracked by the Senate Finance Committee, but only because the legislation it was consider ing did not go far enough.

title: Mundine Stops Aguilar
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 (UPI)Tony Mundine, the Aus tralian Commonwealth middle weight champion, stopped An tonio Aguilar of Argentina in the third round today of a scheduled 10round fight.

title: Advertising: New Hop at C. & W.
description: B. Bunny, known to his friends as Bugs, has joined the advertising sales fortes of Yellow Pages, according to an announcement by Cun ningham & Walsh.

title: 4 SEASONS ACTION BY HOLDERS GAINS
description: Ira Jay Sands, an attorney for some of the plaintiffs in the stockholders' class action suit involving the Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., expressed satisfaction yes terday at a conditionally ap proved multimilliondollar set tlement, but said that other legal hurdles must be cleared before final ajudication.

title: Rising Complaints Shake Film Truce With Blacks
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 26 (AP) A truce between Hollywood and minority groupssoothed by lucrative allblack movies and heightened minority em ploymentis being shaken by angry complaints, demands and charges of bias.

title: A STRONG DEFENSE STRESSED BY NIXON
description: Calling for the maintenance of a strong defense establish ment, President Nixon urged Americans last night to never send the President of the United States to the conference table with anybody as head of the second strongest nation in the world.

title: F.H.A. AIDES SAID TO TAKE BRIBES
description: Six persons, including five employes of the Federal Housing. Administration's office in Hempstead, L. I., were in dicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy and accepting bribes from the president of a mort gage corporation to influence their official acts.

title: Boycott Closes P.S. 75 As Dispute Continues
description: A oneday boycott by parents kept virtually all pupils out of Public School 75 on the upper West Side yesterday in a con tinuing dispute over the City Board of Education's teacher assignment policy.

title: Immigration Aides Raid A Catskill Farm at Dawn
description: Immigration investigators moved in on a Catskill chicken farm at dawn yesterday, taking into custody eight startled workers who the investigators said were illegal aliens from Latin America.

title: Revenue Sharing Upsets Urban Renewal Officials
description: WHITEFACE, N. Y., Sept. 26 Here on the edge of Lake Placid, where the only things that tower are the trees and the Adirondack Mountains, ur ban renewal officials from all over the state are sharing their concern about how many more alterations to their skylines they are going to be permitted to make.

title: Potato Trading Ban Killed By House Rules Conimittee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The House Rules Committee today killed a bill that would have banned potato trading for future delivery on commodity markets.

title: 4 VETERANS FREED IN PROTEST PLOT
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 26 (AP)  A Federal appeals court has dismissed contempt charges against four antiwar veterans who were twice jailed in Tallahassee, Fla., for refus ing to testify before a grand jury investigating protest plans for the Democratic and Repub lican national conventions.

title: GARBAGE CRISIS FEARED IN BRONX
description: The Bronx has a continuing crisis of refuse disposal that will culminate in two years when the city Ma longer can use the Pelham Bay landfill site, the City Planning Commission was told yesterday.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: IF YOURE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH, DRINK DEWAR'S William Lawson's ?? Proof Blended Scotch ?? ?? by Palmer & Lord ?? ?? ?? N.Y.Advt.

title: Collector of Banks Is Going Public
description: LONDON. Sept. 26Edmond J. Safra is a Lebaneseborn banker with Brazilian citizen ship and a home in Geneva.

title: GROUND FIGHTING AT A 6MONTH LOW
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 27 (AP)  American officials said yester day that overall ground fight ing in South Vietnam had ta pered off to its lowest level since the North Vietnamese be gan their offensive March 30.

title: American League East Sets OneGame Playoff
description: If the New York Yankees and Boston Red Sox finish the season tied for first place in the American League East (and they are the only two teams that can tie), a onegame playoff will be held on Thursday, Oct. 5, at a site to be determined by a flip of the coin.

title: Attempt to Weaken Bill for Consumers Rejected by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Proponents of an independent Federal consumer protection agency won what they called a key test today as the Sen ate handily defeated an effort to weaken the agency's authori zing legislation.

title: Revenue Sharing: A Major Event
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass Two years ago, on the second day of the OpEd page, I spoke on behalf of a mildly optimistic view of events. This was a political statement made for the purpose of arguing that the opposite contention was equally political. I desired to as sault the complacency of those who all about them saw naught but decline and fall.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SOUTH ORANGE, Sept. 26 A Seton Hall sophomore was robbed at knifepoint in his dor mitory room early this morning in the second robbery on his campus in two weeks.

title: State and Local Taxes up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) The Commerce Department says that state and local taxes paid throughout the United States increased $14.3billion during the fiscal year ending in June, to $108.6billion.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Tickets for the New York Nets' first 10 games of the regular season, covering October and November, have been put on sale at the Nassau Coliseum. The price scale is $7.50, $6.50 and $5.50

title: Hurst Shoots 77 for Lead In New Jersey Senior Golf
description: SPRINGFIELD, N. J. Sept. 26 John L. Hurst of Deal shot a 36, 4177 to take the first round lead in the 50th New Jer sey Seniors Golf Association championship today at the Bal tusrol Golf Club.

title: Market Place: Mobile Homes: Who Is Right?
description: Wall Street has been down  in  the  pocketbook about the mobilehome mak ers for some time. The neg ative attitude was appar ently sparked last May by a critical analysis of the group, particularly the priceearn ings multiples of the leaders.

title: Indian Head's Earnings and Sales Up 13% in Its Third Fiscal Quarter
Key Gains Hinted as ChouTanaka Talks Go On
description: PEKING, Sept. 26 (Reuters) Talks between Chinese and Japanese leaders continued here today amid indications that the most important problems block ing the establishment of diplo matic relations between the two Asian powers had been settled.

title: New Post Filled in Boston
description: BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) David S. Liederman of Malden was appointed today as director of the recently created State Office for Children by Gov. Francis W. Sargent. Mr. Lied erman immediately withdrew from the race for reelection to his seat in the State House of Representatives.

title: Personalities: Littler Sets Up Golf Comeback
description: Gene Littler, making a come back after undergoing sur gery for cancer, will com pete in the $300,000 Pacific Club Masters golf tournament in Tokyo, starting Oct 5. This will be the first major tournament for the 1961 United States Open champion since February. Littler, of La Jolla, Calif., underwent oper ations last March after a malignancy was discovered in his left armpit.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Diplomatic. The President accepted the resignation of Fred J. Russell as Ambassa dor to Denmark. Mr. Russell, who has been Ambassador to Denmark since November, 1971, will return to private life.

title: Fashion Fete Ends a la 7th Ave1
description: Proudly displaying their Sev enth Avenue labels on sleeves, lapels and backs, the moguls and workers of New York's clothing and fashion industry celebrated last night the end of the city's first Fall Fashion Fes tival with a gala party in Shu bert Alley.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 26 Mrs. Andrew Sage of Piping Rock, the medalist, upset Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks, the defending titleholder 2 and 1, today in the opening round of the Women's Long Island match play golf champi onship over the par74, 5,976 yard Fresh Meadow Country Club course.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Meskill Scores Bus Management And Opposes a Subsidy by State
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 26Gov. Thomas J. Meskill today ques tioned the quality of the man agement of Connecticut's bus companies and warned that he would veto any attempt by the General Assembly to force the state to subsidize the com panies to keep the buses run ning.

title: GANG FIGURE GOES ON WITNESS STAND
description: Peter Diapoulos, a close friend and associate of the Gallo family for 33 years, took the witness stand yesterday in his own defense in State Su preme Court in Manhattan.

title: ROLES ASSIGNED FOR NIGHT MUSIC
description: Glynis Johns, Len Cariou and Hermione Gingold have been signed for costarring roles in A Little Night Music, a new musical comedy suggested by Ingmar Bergman's 1957 movie, Smiles of a Summer Night, opening on Broadway Feb. 25.

title: STOCKS DISPLAY A MIXED PATTERN
description: The stock market did nothing spectacular yesterday but it did manage to finish mixed in steppedup trading which some analysts termed mildly bullish.

title: Pentagon Position
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)An official said that the Pentagon regards the three for mer war prisoners as active duty military officers responsi ble for turning themselves over to United States authorities at the first opportunity.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Mayor Lindsay has announced with much pride and fanfare the approval of $11.2 million worth of contracts for 273 new airconditioned buses for the city. This is an unconscionable waste of the taxpayers' money.

title: Saga Planning Acquisition
description: The Saga Administrative Corporation and Harry M. Ste vens, Inc. announced last night that negotiations were under way concerning the possible acquisition by Saga of all of the outstanding stock of the Stevens company and a num ber of related companies under common management. Stevens operates concession units at racetracks, sports stadiums, arenas and convention halls while Saga is an institutional food management service com pany.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Word comes by moccasin telegraph across the tall Tehachapis that Walter Alston may retire as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers after this season. If he does. Maury Wills hopes to succeed him. If this should come to pass, then the club that broke baseball's color line by bring ing Jackie Robinson to Brooklyn 25 years ago would become the first in the major leagues to employ a black manager. When the stewardship of Walter F. O'Malley came up for a final reckoning, it would have to be recorded on the credit side that he was involved as a minor partner when Branch Rickey signed Robin son, and was presiding as chairman of the board at the elevation of Wills. Can't be all bad as the saying goes.

title: Handlin Named by Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26 (AP)Oscar Handlin. a Pulitzer prize  winning historian, has been appointed to a professor ship at Harvard. Mr. Handlin, a specialist on immigrant life, has been named Carl H. Pfor zheimer University Professor. The chair is one of six not tied to particular departments and established for distin guished scholars.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The Pentagon today disputed testimony that Secretary Laird opposed letting Congress know why General Lavelle was re lieved as the ranking Air Force officer in Vietnam.

title: Tanner Gets New Contract
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (UPI)  Chuck Tanner's contract as manager of the Chica en White Sox, which ran through they 1974 season, today was ex tened for another year.

title: Danes Sharpen Fight Over Market Entry
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 26  Spurred by Nor wegian voters' rejection of the Common Market, both support ers and opponents of Danish entry increased their efforts to day to win the 18 per cent of the electorate that opinion polls say are still undecided.

title: Times Appoints a Medical Director
description: The New York Times has appointed Dr. Howard R. Brown, an assistant professor of clinical medicine at the New York University School of Medicine, as the news paper'S medical director.

title: Fire Hits Newspaper Plant
description: CHICOPEE, Mass., Sept. 26 (AP)A new $3million office complex and printing plant of The Wall Street Journal, due to be completed in three weeks, suffered smoke damage yester day when a twoalarm fire broke out. No estimate of damage was available immediately.

title: 2 at Plaza Hotel Beaten and Robbed By 3 Holdup Men
description: New York's fall Fashion Fair proved expensive yesterday for two outoftown customers who were beaten, handcuffed and robbed in their room at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Judge Bars Eniwetok Tests
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 26 (UPI) Federal Judge Martin Pence yesterday issued a temporary restraining order blocking any further explosive testing on Eniwetok atoll in the Marshall Islands until a court hearing Oct. 5. Judge Pence found that the Government officials con ducting the experiments had not filed the proper environ mental impact statement as re quired by Federal Law.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ENGLEWOOD, Sept. 26 When the Board of Education hired Dr. Mildred W. Abramo witz away from her job as prin cipal of a South Bronx school to become head of the Dwight Morrow High School here, she was given a mandate to tighten discipline on a campus that has had its share of random acts of violence over the last several years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Trooper Says He Was Taught to Scare
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., Sept. 26A suspended state police man accused of branding a youth during interrogation tes tified today that he had learned at the State Police Academy that fear and intimidation were acceptable methods for gain ing information.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL ON GATEWAY AREA BUT KILLS HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The House today approved creation of a 26,172acre na tional recreation area at the entrance to New York harbor after killing a provision for massive housing project that the Rockefeller administration wanted to build on part of Floyd Bennett Field in Brook lyn.

title: Senate Backs Tighter Rules On the Use of Pesticides
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 26 (AP)The Senate passed, 71 to 0, today a compromise bill to give the Government in creased powers over the test ing, marketing and use of pes ticides.

title: A STRONG DEFENSE STRESSED BY NIXON
description: Calling for the maintenance of a strong defense establish ment, President Nixon urged Americans last night to never send the President of the United States to the conference table with anybody as head of the second strongest nation in the world.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: GREENWICH, Conn. Sept. 26 The Metropolitan open golf championship, a competition that began in 1905, will be played for the 57th time begin ning tomorrow at the Stanwich Club.

title: Colosseum, in Danger, Is Completely Closed
description: ROME, Sept. 26The Col osseum was completely closed to the public today after an examination of the most famous ancient Roman monument by a municipal commission.

title: Charles Correll, 82, Andy of Radio, Dies
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 26Charles J. Correll, the Andy of the Amos n Andy radio show for more than 30 years, from. 1928 to 1960, died today of a heart attack in Wesley Memorial Hos pital. He was 82 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Can George McGovern win?

title: U.S. RESERVE ASSETS ADVANCED IN AUGUST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  (Reuters)Total reserve assets of the United States rose by $34million in August to $13.12 billion after a $240million de cline in July, the Treasury De partment reported today.

title: I.B.M. and Macy Realign Top Posts
description: In two unexpected moves, the International Business ?? chines Corporation and R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., yesterday an nounced top management changes. I.B.M. also established a new mandatory retirement age of 60.

title: COLISEUM ICE SET FOR N.H.L TONIGHT
About Pro Football
description: Cheers and jeers have al ways been a part of football in tidy balance, like offense and defense. But the booing in this young season emanat ing from several stadiums of the National Football League has taken a psychotic twist. Many fans, who are paying up to $12 a ticket for the privilege of ex pressing them selves, seem to be making two demands, Win but also entertain me. Or else. Joe Namath and the Jets can oblige, but George Mien and the Red skins are finding the request impossible. The Patriots, who in a year have tripled their home audience, play before downright hostile fans, even in victory. They boo in Philadelphia, but that has al ways been true. However, one hears unfamiliar catcalls now in such places as Cleve land and Green Bay, where years of success had satiated the customers.

title: ROBERT E. THOMPSON
description: YONKERS, Sept. 26Robert E. Thompson, retired industrial, personnel and labor relations director of the John Wanamak er store chain, died at his home here on Monday. He was 80 years old.

title: U.S. CHESS TEAM WINS ITS SECTION
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 26The United States team has scored 21 points out of a possible 28 to win its section in the chess Olympics.

title: G.M. Seeks Aid of Fuel Industry and U.S. on Pollution
description: DETROIT, Sept. 26  The General Motors Corporation, disclosing today for the first time details on emission control equipment for 197576 cars that it plans to produce, in ef fect, challenged the petroleum industry and the Government to take the next steps that the company feels are required to make the systems work.

title: KISSINGER MEETS WITH HANOI AIDES; TALKS GOON TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Henry A. Kissinger met pri vately in Paris today with North Vietnamese representa tives, and the White House an nounced that the talks would be extended tomorrow into a second day.

title: Veteran Pension Rise Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The Senate Veterans Affairs Committee approved a bill to day to provide for a 10 per cent increase in pensions for World War I veterans and their wid ows. It also approved a bill to increase the annual income limitations for all veterans on pensions by $400, so that the recently voted 20 per cent in crease in Social Security bene fits would not mean a cut in II veterans' pensions.

title: Tanaka Writes a Poem On New Link to China
description: PEKING. Sept. 26 (AP) Premier Kakuel Tanaka of Japan wrote a poem today celebrating imminent diplo matic relations between, Ja pan and China.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Stride Rite corporation yesterday said it may purchase up to 50,000 of its common shares on the open market. The stock would be held in its treasury for general corporate purposes. The stock closed at 18, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Holiday Inn Near Kennedy Library Fought
description: CAMBRIDGE. Mass., Sept. 26A real estate developer has broken ground for a 19 story Holiday Inn that will tower over the planned John F. Kennedy Memorial Library on the banks of the Charles River here.

title: 25th Year of Israel as a Nation Is Celebrated by Jews in City
description: Candles glowed yesterday on the 25branch candelabra in the International Synagogue at Kennedy International Air port yesterday as Jews here began a yearlong celebration of Israel's silver anniversary as a nation.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The first of a series of ex hibitions of the work of con temporary New Jersey artists will open Saturday at the New Jersey State Museum on West State Street in Trenton.

title: C.B.S. to Return Music Rights for TV to Composers
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System argeed yesterday to return to the composers the rights to all music written for its TV programs in the past, and to negotiate all such fu ture contracts in a way that will leave the rights to the music in the hands of the com poser.

title: Exchange May Study Rule's On Offerings of New Issues
description: The New York Stock Ex change said yesterday that it was considering forming a committee to study whether to establish rules governing the offering of and trading in new issues by its member firms.

title: F.C.C. Ruling Is Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals upheld yesterday a ruling by the Federal Communi cations Commission refusing to renew the license of radio sta tions WXUR and WXURFM of Media, Pa., which are associ ated with the Rev. Carl D. Mc Intire, the New Jersey funda mentalist radio preacher. The commission ruled in 1970 that the stations failed to provide reasonable opportunity for the presentation of contrasting views on controversial issues of public importance.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Vince Matthews said yes terday he had no regrets about his behavior at the 20th Olympic Games and probably would continue his track and field career be cause it feels better to be in shape instead of out of shape.

title: Text of Shultz Talk Before International Monetary Fund and World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz today at the annual meeting of the International Mone tary Fund and the World Bank:

title: CANADIANS BEAT SOVIET SIX, 43, AND EVEN SERIES
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 26Can ada's top hockey professionals squeezed out a roughandtum ble 43 victory tonight over the Soviet Union to pull even with their hosts and set up a win nertakeall showdown in the final encounter of their eight game series Thursday.

title: Auxiliary Police Patrolling Broadway
description: The city's auxiliary police in augurated their own version of the mobile Tactical Patrol Force last night with a special 40member foot patrol on Broadway from 66th to 86th Street.

title: Marcos Outlines Policies; Land Reform Is Stressed
description: MANILA, Sept. 26President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he planned to exercise broad legislative and judicial powers under the martial law announced over the weekend.

title: M'GOVERN OFFERS A MONETARY PLAN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 (UPI)Senator George S. Mc Govern today proposed new rules for international finan cial dealings, rules aimed at stopping sudden, sharp changes in the price of money which have left Americans with less to spend in many foreign coun tries.

title: STRIP MINING BILL DYING IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The first major effort at pass ing legislation to regulate the nation's coal strip mines is near death in the Congress.

title: Merger News
description: The Bowater Corporation, Ltd., a paper and buildingma terials producer, and Ralli International, Ltd., an in vestmentholding company, announced yesterday an agree ment to merge. The transaction is valued at about $196million based on current stock market prices. Bowater, formerly known as the Bowater Paper Corporation, stated it would is sue 11 of its ordi nary shares for each 10 Ralli ordi nary shares. Bowater traded yesterday at 4 on the London exchange.

title: ExWelfare Officer Pleads Guilty to Diverting Checks
description: A former welfare police of ficer, accused of stealing 34 checks worth $3,292.70 and in tended for welfare recipients, pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court, the Bronx, to a charge of criminal possession of stolen property.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 (UPI)Tony Mundine, the Aus tralian Commonwealth middle weight champion, stopped An tonio Aguilar of Argentina in the third round today of a scheduled 10round fight.

title: Poorer Lands Militant On Monetary Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The lessdeveloped countries, which traditionally have con centrated on lining up more economic aid at the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, are asserting themselves in the monetaryreform arena with unusual emphasis.

title: Mother Whale Dies in Aquarium
description: A pygmy sperm whale that was washed ashore Monday at Far Rockaway Beach, Queens, died shortly before dawn yesterday.

title: Jobs for ExAddicts
description: It is a measure of success, however limited so far, that the struggle against spreading drug abuse must now assume a new dimension. Need is growing for employ ment opportunities for exaddicts who have completed drugfree therapy or who have become established a methadone maintenance program. The head of the city's Addiction Services Agency, Graham Finney, esti mates this need at more than 40,000 jobs in the com ing year.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: WE INTEND TO PRESIDE, OVER THE LIQUIDATION OF THE DEADLY 2020 VISION ADVERTISING DESION PACKAGING. 9144280133Advt.

title: Cambodia Blast Kills 2 But U.S. Aide Is Unhurt
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, Sept. 27 (UPI) Deputy United States Ambas sador Thomas O. Enders barely escaped death early today when the embassy limousine he was riding in set off a booby trapped plas tic bomb in Pnompenh's Inde pendence Monument Square.

title: Price Board Cuts Revenue Of Concern by $3.5Million
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)  The Price Commission said today that a Los Angeles based food wholesaler had re duced its revenues by an esti mated $3.5 million under com mission order the largest reduction so far under price control.

title: Sclerosis Bill Advances
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill to estab lish a National Commission on Multiple Sclerosis to study how best to conquer the crippling disease. The 11member com mission, appointed by President Nixon, would be directed to recommend within a year the most productive avenues for finding causes, cures and treat ment.

title: TROTTING WORLD TOASTS AVERY, 78
description: YONKERS, Sept. 26In the 54th and final year of his ca reer as a harness racing driver, 78yearold Earle Avery was feted tonight at Yonkers Race way, the site of many of his successes.

title: Currency Market Closed
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark Sept. 26 (UPI)The National Bank today suspended the foreigncurrency market for a week after an emergency ses sion with the Government.

title: L. I. Oystermen Turn to Aquafarming
description: EATONS NECK, L. L., Sept. 24Big money and big busi ness are causing the biggest resurgence of the oyster in dustry on Long Island in more than two decades, but they are also ending an old way of life.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: A narcotics raid in Middlesex County yesterday re sulted in the arrests of 24 persons, including two 15year old boys.

title: VALERIE ZIEGENFUSS IS UPSET AT PHOENIX
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 26 (AP)Laura DuPont of Char lotte, N. C., the former Na tional Collegiate champion, upset eighthseeded Valerie Ziegenfuss of San Diego, 62, 64, today in the opening round of the Virginia Slims Phoenix Thunderbird tournament.

title: MRS. SAGE ADVANCES IN GREAT NECK GOLF
Norway's Problems Grow; Premier to Quit Next Week
description: OSLO, Norway, Sept. 26  Norwegians today faced a range of critical problems  political, economic and military  as a result of their decision to reject membership in the European Economic Community.

title: ADM. L C. RAMSEY, LED HAWAII STAFF
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 (UPI)Rear Adm. Logan C. Ramsey, the Navy flier who was the first to radio news of the Japanese attack on Pearl Her ber on Dec. 7, 1941, died last evening at the Philadelphia Naval Hospital, He was 74 years old.

title: Poseidon Rocket Fired
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 26 (AP)  A Poseidon rocket was fired from the nuclear submarine George Bancroft last night while the submarine was cruising submerged about 30 miles off the shore here.

title: EndtheWar Amendment Killed in Senate, 45 to 42
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26The Senate reversed ed itself today and rejected, by a vote of 45 to 42, an endthewar proposal that it had adopted two months ago. The vote was widely regarded here as marking the collapse of the antiwar movement in the Sen ate for this session, leaving the Administration firmly in control of the war issue in Congress.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Sept. 26 Sargent Shriver, the Demo cratic VicePresidential nomi nee, said today that any con sideration of amnesty for those who fled the country to avoid military service should await the conclusion of a national program to take care of the veterans of the Vietnam war.

title: Lynde Selden, Former Official Of American Express, 80, Dies
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 26Lynde Selden, a retired executive of the American Ex press Company, died today in Greenwich Hospital. He had broken a hip 10 days ago. He was 80 years old and lived at 30 Field Point Park.

title: Issues in Nadjari Dispute Detailed by Aide of Hogan
description: A requirement that cases in volving criminal justice corrup tion be conducted in the name of the state's special prose cutor was reported yesterday to be a key issue in the con tinuing dispute between Dis trict Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan and Governor Rockefeller over the creation of the anticorruption post.

title: Jewish Theater of Rumania Thriving After Ordeal
description: Jewish theater in Rumania, once a flourishing arena of competing traveling compa nies, has survived an anti Semitic dictatorship and the Nazi occupation and is to day a thriving testament to ethnic perserverance and the providence of national sub sidies.

title: Mayor Names Queens Aide
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday named Richard A. Brown, the city's legislative representative, to be chairman of the Forest HillsRego Park Urban Action Task Force.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The tragic escalation of violence in Munich and the Middle East in the last several weeks must be set in its proper perspective. It is only the most recent in a chain of violent acts which began more than 24 years ago with the Zionist seizure of Palestine and the eviction of the majority of its in digenous inhabitants through the manipulation of terror and fear.

title: Foster Stops Finnegan and Retains Title
description: LONDON, Sept. 26 (AP) Bob Foster knocked out Chris Finnegan with a smashing left and right to the head in the 14th round tonight and re tamed his world lightheavy weight championship.

title: 51 AWARDS MADE BY DRAMA DESK
description: Fiftyone members of the theatrical profession were cited yesterday at the Drama Desk's annual awards luncheon for outstanding contributions to New York's 197172 season. Fourteen winners in the most promising categories each re ceived $100 checks from Theo dore W. Helweg, president of Ticketron, Inc., the electronic boxoffice system.

title: New Jersey Utility in Deal On Offshore Nuclear Plant
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company confirmed reports yesterday that it planned to share ownership of its proposed $1billion offshore nuclear generating plant. The New Jersey utility said it would retain 80 per cent ownership of the plant with 10 per cent each held by the Atlantic City Elec tric Company and the Jersey Central Power & Light Com pany, a subsidiary of the Gen eral Public Utilities Corpora tion.

title: Nixon Daughter Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON; Sept. 26 (UPI)Mrs. David Eisenhower left today on a fiveday, six state tour, her longest yet in behalf of the reelection cam paign of her father, President Nixon. She will stop in Kansas City, Kan.; Kansas City, Mo.; and in New Mexico before she flies back to Washington late Saturday night.

title: House Panel Votes Aid to Grain Farms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The House Agriculture Com mittee approved today a bill that would partly compen sate farmers in Texas, Okla homa and Kansas who sold their early wheat at low prices while unaware of the magni tude of Soviet wheat purchases that ultimately sent prices soar ing.

title: PENNCO SETS PAYOUT ON PREFERRED STOCK
description: The Pennsylvania Company voted yesterday to pay the Oct. 15 dividend on its 4 per cent cumulative preferred stock to holders of record Oct. 6.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: This does look a little bit like Ontario, said Camille Henry, the diminutive coach of the New York Raiders.

title: 23 Burt in Belfast Blast
description: BELFAST. Sept. 26 (Reuters) Twentythree people were injured when a bomb estimated to contain 100 pounds of ex plosives blew up outside a social club near the center of Belfast tonight.

title: Specialist Reports Legally Blind Aided By Plastic Surgery
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 26 A University of Florida eye doctor reported today that he and a team of research ophthal mologists had improved the vi sion of 10 persons legally blind in one or both eyes by means of a new kind of plastic surgery that requires less than one minute to perform.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 26 Vice President Agnew offered a paean of praise for President Nixon and his foreign policies at a gathering of wealthy sup porters today.

title: JOSEPH GROSS, HEAD OF JERSEY HOSPITAL
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 26  Joseph Gross, president of the Jewish Hospital and Rehabili tation Center of New Jersey here, died today in the institu tion's Gross Pavilion, named for him. He was 79 years old and lived at 2520 Kennedy Boulevard.

title: An Appraisal
description: PRINCETON, N. J. The air is a bit more rarefied at the Institute for Advanced Study than in the rest of Princeton, and the new ar chitecture, generally, is bet ter. The institute, the pres tigious center of advanced research in the fields of mathematics, historical stud ies and natural and social sci ences, is the country's sacro sanct temple of pure learning at ionosphere levels. From those wonderful people who gave you Einstein and relativity, now comes a distinguished complex of new buildings. And for once, there is a tie between standards of schol arly endeavor and the setting where it takes place.

title: Hormone Made by the Thymus Reported Found
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 Discovery of a longsought hormone produced by the thy mus gland was reported here today by a team of ?? from Paris.

title: Access Sought in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 26 (Reuters) United States officials said tonight that American diplo mats would try to meet the three pilots freed by North Vietnam when they arrive here tomorrow.

title: Humphrey Stumps Coast For Old Rival, McGovern
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who warned Democrats away from Senator George McGov ern here in June, returned to day to urge them to come home to the McGovern candi dacy for President.

title: A '73 Ford Engine Is Unable to Meet Pollution Standard
description: DETROIT, Sept. 26  The Ford Motor Company an nounced today that sales and production of one of the basic engines used in the 1973 Mav ericks and Comets would be held up because it had not met Federal air pollution standards.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CHARLIE'S SHORTS The Charlie Chaplin revival (was he ever really moribund?) reels on. You can see Chap lin features in commercial houses and on TV (from time to time) and in film muse ums.

title: Chalmers Is Named Head Of Chicago's Art Institute
description: E. Laurence Chalmers Jr., former chancellor of the Uni versity of Kansas, has been named director of the Art In stitute of Chicago.

title: Nuclear Test in Nevada
description: YUCCA FLATS, Nev., Sept. 26 (AP)A nuclear device with a yield of less than 20 kilotons was exploded beneath the Ne vada desert today, the Atomic Energy Commission announced It was the second underground nuclear test at the Nevada sit in less than a week.

title: Hearing Judge Dembitz
description: The Court of Appeals race is clouded by the rather surprising ad hominem (or is it ad feminam?) observa tion of the New York State Bar Association that Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz is the only one of seven contenders not qualified. Before the Democratic primary last June, in which she placed second in a field of four despite the lack of official party endorsement, Judge Dembitz was found qualified by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, a state Democratic party commis sion headed by a former chief judge of the Court of Appeals, and a group of Columbia University law school professors.

title: Burns, ExAide, Calls Seymour Political Hatchet Man for Nixon
description: United States Attorney Whit ney North Seymour Jr. was ac cused yesterday by a man he had dismissed as his executive assistant of serving as a politi cal hatchet man for the Nixon Administration.

title: City BaseRent Program Is Criticized at Hearing
description: The city's maximumbase rent program for rentcon trolled apartments was sharply attacked yesterday by tenants, the real estate industry and the state's Rent Administrator.

title: 48 F111'S GOING TO VIETNAM AREA
description: The Air Force announced yesterday that it was tempo rarily sending 48 of its F111A attack bombers to Southeast Asia to bolster its lowlevel and allweather capabilities for the approaching monsoon sea son.

title: Norwegian Vote Termed Blow to European Unity
description: LONDON, Sept. 26Europe reacted with dismay and con cern today to Norway's rejec tion of entry into the European Economic Community.

title: EASY ACCESS SET ON CAR INSURANCE
description: Twentyfour leading insur ance companies committed themselves formally here yes terday to make automobile in surance more readily available almost everywhere in the coun try and to almost anyone who wanted to buy it.

title: AIR TRAVEL CREDIT LOST BY DEMOCRATS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)  American Airlines has cut off air travel credit to the Democratic National Commit tee for failure to pay more than $6,000 in overdue bills.

title: 16 Seized Here as Members of Major Heroin Ring
description: Federal and local narcotics agents arrested 14 persons in the metropolitan area yester day who were said to be part of a major heroin ring supply ing central Harlem and the South Bronx. Nine other per sons were being sought.

title: CITY WANTS WASTE DUMPED IN OCEAN
description: Dumping garbage in the ocean, a practice outlawed by the United States Supreme Court in 1933, was suggested by the Lindsay administration yesterday as a means of solving the growing problem of where to put the city's waste.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Thomas Grabowski, a New Jersey state trooper sus pended after being accused of branding a youth during an interrogation, said at his trial in Toms River, N. J. yesterday that he had been taught ae the State Police Academy that it was sometimes necessary to instill fear in suspects.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: MAHWAH, Sept. 26Sister Elizabeth McAlister, convicted of a lettersmuggling charge in the Harrisburg Seven conspir acy case, is teaching at Ram apo College here this fall while awaiting the outcome of an appeal from her conviction.

title: SHEA CONVERTED INTO JETS' FIELD
description: While the New York Jets ran through a patandgo sweatsuit drill yesterday in right field, the Shea Stadium groundskeepers were convert ing the cityowned sports facil ity into a gridiron, leaving the New York Mets homeless until next year.

title: Cary to Be New Chief at I.B.M.
description: For the second time in its history, the giant Interna tional Business Machines Corporation has reached out side of the Thomas J. Watson family for a chief executive.

title: Billings Is Named to Post In Department of Parks
description: David J. Billings 3d, who for three years was chairman of the city's policymaking Coun cil Against Poverty, was named yesterday as the assistant ad ministrator for community projects in the Parks, Recrea tion and Cultural Affairs Ad ministration.

title: McGovern and Stevenson
description: Twenty years ago this autumn Adlai Stevenson of Illinois, like George Mc Govern today? was fighting a losing battle for the Presidency against Gen eral Eisenhower, but there was at least one fundamental difference.

title: Gromyko, in U.N., Assails Terrorism; Cites Palestinians
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26Foreign Minister An drei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said today that his Gov ernment opposed acts of ter rorism and acts of violence that serve no positive ends and cause loss of human life.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Anaconda Company announced yesterday that hid signed an agreement to give technical assistance to the Sat Cheshmeh Copper Mining Company of Kerman in developing its $400million copper mine about 800 kilo meters south of Teheran.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ENGLEWOOD, Sept. 26 A fundraising gathering here and a tour of an undergar ment factory in Bayonne were highlights of a day of campaigning for Mrs. George McGovern, wife of the Dem ocratic Presidential nominee.

title: A.C.L.U. Sues Press Club
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 (UPI)  The American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California filed suit in Superior Court today, seeking to force the San Francisco Press Club to admit women to full mem bership.

title: Curtis to Aid Ticket
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 26 (AP) Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis left Maine today for a oneday trip to Buffalo, where he will cam paign for Senator George McGovern. The trip is Mr. Curtis's first on behalf of the Democratic Presidential candi date.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am amazed by Milan Radovich's letter (Sept. 4) pleading for human rights to be extended to Czechoslova kian chess grandmaster Ludek Pach man.

title: Wide Disparities Mark Sentences Here
description: Jack Greenberg took $15 from a post office; last May in Federal Court in Manhattan he drew six months in jail. How ard Lazeil misapplied $150, 000 from a bank; in the same month in the same courthouse he drew probation.

title: FISHOIL EXPORTS HALTED BY PERU
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 26The Peruvian Government today de creed an indefinite halt to all exports of fish meal and fish oil beginning Oct. 1, thereby offi cially recognizing the worst fishing crisis in the history of the nation that has become the world's largest producer of fish products during the last decade.

title: Population Rises 138,000
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)  A Census Bureau report showed today that the popula tion of the United States grew by 138,000 persons in August to 208,976,000.

title: It's Just Work as Usual For Pope Paul VI at 75
description: ROME, Sept. 26  Pope Paul VI worked as usual and made no public appearance on his 75th birthday today.

title: Fugitive Monkey Dies After Flight in Woods
description: ELDRED, N. Y., Sept. 26 (AP) Two Alaskan huskies and a tranquilizer gun put an end to the adventures of a 30pound escaped monkey tonight, and authorities saidsheer ex haustion later killed the animal.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The current emphasis on polls of voters' preferences suggests that our present election practices should be changed. In the old days it was cus tomary for voters to cast their votes openly, by voice, so that everyone could know how each of his neighbors voted.

title: 23 Missing off South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 26 (AP)Twentythree persons were reported missing after their cargo ship capsized and sank off Kunsan, 110 miles south of Seoul, last night, po lice officials reported. The ves sel was carrying workers and construction material to an iso lated island to build a school.

title: MRS. RYAN TO SEEK HUSBAND'S SEAT
description: The widow of William F. Ryan has decided to seek the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives from the 20th District in the Bronx and Manhattan, which her hus band held before his death on Sept. 17.

title: Dispute in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 26  What amounted to a dispute among antiwar groups became evident here today over the publicly announced travel plans of the American peace delega tion escorting the three prison ers from Hanoi.

title: More Arrests Reported
description: MANILA, Sept. 26 (AP)  New arrests were reported to day, bringing to 96 the an nounced total of those picked since martial law was pro claimed on Saturday. Four have reportedly been released.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland, Sept. 26 (UPI)Tom Weiskopf of Columbus, Ohio, posted a warning to his rivals today on the eve of Europe's richest golf tournament, the $150,000 John Player Classic. He tamed the 7,060yard, par71 course with a 65 that included seven birdies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: May one not a far distance from what is rarely these days called old age raise a protest against that chastely repulsive phrase senior citizens? Its obvious and overhearty euphemism is not the only element of its repul siveness. These two forceyoked words are cumbersome and they have about them an air of redundancythe latter point perhaps suggesting an alternative usage.

title: NIXON ADDRESSES A YOUNG AUDIENCE
description: In parochialschool uniforms, European peasant garb, yar mulkes and plain, everyday school clothes, children by the thousands turned out yester day to hear President Nixon dedicate the American Museum of Immigration in an addition to the pedestal of the Statue of Liberty.

title: Marcos' Medicine
description: The imposition of martial law in the Philippines is dubious medicine for the fundamental ills that have been sapping the strength and unity of this island repub lic in the Pacific. The Communistled rural insurrection and urban terror cited by President Marcos as justifica tion for the suspension of civil liberties and a roundup of opposition leaders are outgrowths of such underlying problems as widespread poverty and social injustice. The impact of governmental corruption and inefficiency, unemployment, and cultural and political antagonisms between Muslims and Christians in the southern islands has now been aggravated by recent disastrous floods on Luzon.

title: Pilot in Jet Crash Used Short Runway To Conserve Fuel
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 26 (UPI)The pilot of a re built jet fighter plane that crashed into an ice cream par lor Sunday, killing 22 persons, was offered a longer, safer runway but chose the shorter one to save fuel, a Federal investigator said today.

title: Former Pastor Sentenced
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) A former Baptist pastor and two other men have been sen tenced to prison for conspiracy to defraud in the selling of church bonds. The Rev. Charles H. Palmer, 46 years old of Eagle Pass, Tex., former pastor of the Melrose Park Baptist Church, was sentenced to two years in prison. Joseph E. Melody, 40, also received a twoyear sen tence and Douglas Jack White, 38, of Austin, received a three year term.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The presidents of nine build ing and construction unions representing 1.7 million work ers endorsed President Nixon for reelection today, saying that they found the positions and policies of the candidate of the Democratic party wholly unacceptable.

title: Saks Chairman to Head Boy Scouts' Campaign
description: The appointment of Allan R. Johnson, chairman of the board of Saks Fifth Ave nue, as general campaign chairman of the 197273 Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America Fi nance Campaign, was an nounced yesterday by David L. Yunich, vice chairman of R. H. Macy & Co. and presi dent of the New York Coun cils.

title: LAIRD ACTION CITED IN LAVELLE'S CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (Reuters)The Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. John D. Ryan, has testified that Melvin R. Laird, the Secretary of Defense, turned down his recommendation that key members of Congress be told why Gen. John D. Lavelle was relieved in April.

title: NEW U.S. MONETARY PLAN ASKS WIDER FLUCTUATION IN WORLD EXCHANGE RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The United States made pro posals today for a new world monetary system  a system that would include a lot more movement up and down in cur rency exchange rates than the world has been accustomed to in the quartercentury of the old system.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 26 (UPI)British European Airways today signed a contract worth $150million for the purchase of Tristar airliners from the Lockheed Aircraft Corpora tion a company the United States Government bailed out of bankruptcy with ah emergency loan.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)Giving an even higher shine to an already bright farmincome picture, the Agri culture Department today predicted 1972 net farm income might climb to a record of about $18.6billion.

title: Humphrey Stumps Coast For Old Rival, McGovern
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who warned Democrats away from Senator George McGov ern here in June, returned to day to urge them to come home to the McGovern candi dacy for President.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 26 (AP)Jimmie Dean Hand of Moutain Home, Idaho, goes to trial Jan. 10 on a charge of asking illegally for investment money from professional athletes. The 35yearold Hand has pleaded innocent to grand theft and violation of the California Securities Code. He was released on $3,000 bond.

title: FUTURES PRICES FOR HOGS SLUMP
description: Most live hog futures prices declined the limit yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Ex change following a report Fri day by the Department of Agriculture that more pigs would be brought to market this year than had been ex pected.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PRINCETON, Sept. 26The New Jersey wing of Common Cause, the national citizens' lobby, announced yesterday a series of efforts aimed at mak ing the New Jersey State Gov ernment more responsitive to the people.

title: 121 Tee Off Today at Stanwich In 57th Metropolitan Title Golf
description: GREENWICH, Conn. Sept. 26 The Metropolitan open golf championship, a competition that began in 1905, will be played for the 57th time begin ning tomorrow at the Stanwich Club.

title: Yanks in Detroit Tonight To Resume Bid for Title
IGOR PANTUHOFF
description: Igor Pantuhoff, a portrait artist whose subjects had in cluded Princess Grace of Mon aco, Mrs. James V. Forrestal, Laurance S. Rockefeller and Anthony Drexel Duke, died Monday evening in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Some progress has been made in recent talks aimed at secur ing a new contract for the state's law enforcement offi cers, according to Thomas Sav age, lawyer for the 10 Patrol men's Benevolent Association locals saekinz the pact. Sal aries are stillthe big key, Mr. Savage said.

title: CONFEREES SPLIT ON ULSTER RULE
description: DARLINGTON, England, Sept. 26Northern Ireland poli ticians sharply disagreed today on proposals for a new parlia ment to govern their stricken province.

title: Australia Curbing Foreign Controls Over Industries
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26Prime Minister William McMahon announced tonight strong new measures to re strict foreign control of Aus tralian industries.

title: Books of The Times
description: TIME OF NEED: Forms of imagination in the twentieth century. By William Barrett. 401 pages. Harper & Row. $10.

title: Economic Analysis
description: VIENNA, Sept. 25An area of the world with 350 million people and a gross national product of $725million  the Soviet Union and the countries of Eastern Europeis not rep resented in the international monetary talks in Washington this week.

title: DAMON VAN UTT, 55, A MANAGEMENT AIDE
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Sept 26Damon Van Utt, a management consultant, died Friday apparently of a heart at tack. He was 55 years old and lived on Ragged Rock Road.

title: Guard Is Beaten on Head By Convict at Rahway
description: RAHWAY, N.J., Sept. 26 (AP) A guard at Rahway State Prison was beaten by a prisoner tonight, according to a prison spokesman.

title: Cancer Survey Finds Big Gain In Survival Rates Since 1940's
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The Government reported to day that important increases in survival rates from more than a dozen major forms of can cer have been achieved among white American patients since the nineteenforties.

title: Matthews Tired of Answering That Question
description: Vince Matthews said yes terday he had no regrets about his behavior at the 20th Olympic Games and probably would continue his track and field career be cause it feels better to be in shape instead of out of shape.

title: Hearings on Mrs. Ryan Halted
description: The Immigration and Natural ization Service yesterday su spended indefinitely hearings on whether to deport Mrs. Russell Ryan, the former Her mine Braunsteiner, a guard at the World War II concentra tion camp at Maidanek, Poland. The proceedings were halted after Mrs. Ryan's lawyer, John Barry, suffered an attack of bleeding ulcers Monday night. The government is seeking the deportation of Mrs. Ryan on the ground that she is an un desirable alien.

title: Amex Stocks Retreat in Price As Trading Shows an Advance
ACCORD ON QUAKES MAY YIELD A BONUS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Almost inadvertently, the Unit ed States, by agreeing with the Soviet Union to cooperate on protecting the environment, may have opened the back door to cooperative research on detecting underground nu clear explosions.

title: State Plans to Shut Dobbs Ferry Clinic Over Its Abortions
description: DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Sept. 26The State Attorney Gen eral's office, armed with a new court order, prepared today to close the Dobbs Ferry Medical Pavilion, Inc., on the ground that it was an unlicensed abortion clinic.

title: Rival Blames Nixon for Delay
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 (AP)Senator George McGov ern, the Democratic Presiden tial candidate, blamed what he described as interference by the Nixon Administration for the delay of a week in the de parture of the prisoners from Hanoi.

title: With Kindergarten Ahead, They're Getting Ready
description: To the ethnicallymixed group of 3 and 4yearolds, it all seemed like play: build ing things out of blocks and cubes; baking birthday cakes; watching a guinea pig have a baby; learn ing numbers and letters and words; singing, dancing, woodworkingor just run ning like crazy around the open, curving spaces of the big schoolroom.

title: Executive Changes
description: John W. Prieslitg has been named a group vice president of Phelps Dodge Industries, an arm of the Phelps Dodge Corporation.

title: Wallace Leaves Birmingham
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 26 (AP)A spokesman said today that Gov. George C. Wallace left Birmingham today for Montgomery after undergoing a physical examination at Spain Rehabilitation Center.

title: Gromyko, in U.N., Assails Terrorism; Cites Palestinians
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26Foreign Minister An drei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said today that his Gov ernment opposed acts of ter rorism and acts of violence that serve no positive ends and cause loss of human life.

title: ABORTION FORCES PREPARE FOR FOES
description: A panel including Mrs. John V. Lindsay and Gloria Steinem announced yesterday a fall mobilization by the Women's National Abortion Action Coa lition against what it termed the fanaticism of groups committed to restrictive abor tion laws in New York State and elsewhere.

title: TV: Effecting Changes in Children's Programing
description: It has been argued that the best way to effect changes in children's programs on tele vision might be to force par ents to sit and watch most of the fare that goes down the tube to the, kids. After forcing my childless self through several hours of kidvid last Saturday morning, I have nothing but increased respect for the ar gument.

title: Israelis Say Arms Were Sent Abroad for AntiArab Terror
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 26The Is raeli police confirmed here to day that arms shipments air freighted abroad for a terror ist campaign against Arabs had reached their destinations.

title: Yunich to Retire at 55 From R. H. Macy
description: David L. Yunich, former president of Macy's New York and currently one of the two vice chairmen of the parent company, R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., will retire at the age of 55 next February after 33 years with the department store chain.

title: Belfast Man Shot Dead
description: BELFAST. Northern Ireland, Sept. 26 (UPI)Gunmen shot and killed a man in a Belfast street today in what appeared to he the latest in a series of reciprocal sectarian assassina tions that have terroized North ern Ireland.

title: Heath Proposes Voluntary WagePrice Restraints and Calls UnionIndustry Response Heartening
description: LONDON, Sept. 26The British Government, struggling to improve the country's lag ging productivity and curb its persistent inflation, proposed a program of voluntary wage and price restraints today.

title: Traffic Engineers Say They Oppose Right Turn on Red
description: A proposed national rule that would allow motorists to turn right on red lights encountered stiff opposition yesterday at the annual meeting of the In stitute of Traffic Engineers.

title: U. S. Asked to Ease Standards On Noise and Approve Project
description: A group of residents of the Two Bridges section on the Lower East Side urged the Fed eral Government yesterday to waive noise pollution limits so that a lowincome housing pro ject can be built in the area, where industrial and traffic noise has been found excessive.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The artificial distinctions between the way young criminals and older criminals are processed by the author ities and punished, if found guilty, have long stood in the way of the suppression of juvenile crime.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 26 (AP)  Kentucky State Univer sity's track team was suspend ed for one year today by the National Association of Inter collegiate Athletics because of unsportsmanlike conduct last April at an N.A.I.A. district championship meet at Nash ville.

title: Old Synagogues in Jerusalem Opened
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 26A major link in the history of the Jewish presence in the walled Old City of Jerusalem was re stored yesterday with the for mal opening of four old Sephar dic synagogues in the recon structed Jewish quarter.

title: A Prayer for America
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26A recent bulletin published by the Christophers contained this informal prayer:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Will Rogers Jr. has heard a political slogan he doesn't like.

title: Books of The Times
description: LUCE AND HIS EMPIRE. By W. A. Swanberg. 529 pages. Illustrated. Scribner's. $12.50.

title: Notes on People
description: The next Israeli Ambassa dor to the United States, ac cording to diplomatic sources in Washington, is likely to be either Simcha Dinitz, political secretary to Premier Golda Meir, or Mordechai Gazit, di rector general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry. With the present Ambassador, Yitzhak Rabin, expected to leave Washington early next year, the sources noted that Mr. Dinitz is Mrs. Meir's chief aide and political adviser, while Mr. Gazit was former Minister of the Israeli Em bassy in Washington.

title: Eximbank Grants a Loan To El Al for an Airplane
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)  The ExportImport Bank said today it had author ized a loan of more than $13 million to El Al Israel Airlines for the purchase of a Boeing 747 jet aircraft. The total cost of the plane and related spare parts and services is $30.5 million.

title: Opposition Party in South Korea Split
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 27The opposition New Dem ocratic party was virtually split today as a result of factional strife. Two separate conven tions have been held and two party chiefs chosen by rival groups.

title: Business Briefs
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 27 (Canadian Press)Canada's deficit in international payments for goods and services grew by $73million in April, May and June to $543million at midyear, Statistics Canada reported today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The United States Government did not arrange for the release of the three prisoners of war now on their way home from Hanoi. Nor, so far as can be ascertained, was it any policy or action of Washington's or any words of the Nixon Administration that prompted the North Vietnamese Government to turn these men loose. Why then should the Pentagon and officials abroad be so determined to get control of these men before they even return to this country, and why should Pentagon officials including Secretary Laird be raising the threat ening possibility of courtmartialing them?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Times decries the murder of Dr. Friedmann as an unspeakable outrage, which it certainly is, and goes on to say that justicethough it cannot return to life a humane and respected scholarshould be equally swift.

title: BALLOON BUILDER TEACHES COURSE
description: TOLLAND, Conn., Sept. 27 (AP)Charles E. MacArthur of Tolland says the adult educa tion course in balloon building that he teaches is practical for the 19th century.

title: Heavy Air Attacks Continue Against North Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 28The United States command reported yes terday that its planes had at tacked targets in an arc around Hanoi during the previous 24 hours, with the closest mission 14 miles from the North Viet namese capital.

title: Saigon's Big Bureaucracy Is Criticized by Premier
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 27Premier Tran Thien Khiem has charged his nation's gigantic Government bureauc racy with clockwatching, moonlighting and failing to work hard.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: PEKING, Sept: 27 (Reuters) Chairman Map Tsetung today received Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan in a meeting that apparently sets the seal on the new relationship be tween the former Asian foes.

title: DR. RUSSELL BEATTY, A COLLEGE FOUNDER
description: BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP)Dr. H. Russell Beatty, founder and retired president of Wentworth College of Technology here, died last evening at University Hos pital. He was 66 years old.

title: Longest Strike at G.M. Is Ended At Plant in Ohio After 174 Days
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 (AP) The longest strike ever mounted against General Motors ended tonight after 174 days with ratification of a new contract by members of The United Automobile Workers from the General Motors Assembly Divi sion plant in suburban Nor wood, Ohio.

title: Iran's Empress in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 27 (AP) A Chinese airliner carrying Empress Farah Pahlevi of Iran made an unprecedented flight from the Chinese mainland into Hong Kong today. It was the first Chinese airliner carrying passengers to fly to Hong Kong since the Communists came to power 23 years ago.

title: Elements Help Out As Sailboat Show Opens at Newport
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 27 When Senator Erich A. Taylor of Rhode Island snipped the ribbon today to open the second Newport In ternational Sailboat Show, people applauded, breezes sprang up from nowhere, dormant pennants flapped and the sun came out for the first time.

title: C.A.B. Eases Rule So Almost Anyone Can Fly by Charter
