description: The Civil Aeronautics Board approved yesterday a new charter flight regulation that, for the first time, will allow virtually anybody  not just members of clubs, unions, pro fessional societies and other or ganized groupsto fly on low cost charter flights to Europe and elsewhere.

title: ECONOMIC GAUGE ROSE FOR AUGUST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)The Government's index of leading economic indicators jumped sharply in August after two sluggish months, the Com merce Department reported today.

title: Advertising: Cosmo Goes Abroad
description: Cosmo is going interna tional, said Richard E. Deems, president of Hearst Magazines, showing once again a willingness of Ameri can business to share its cul tural gems with less fortu nate nations.

title: Suspect Surrenders in Slaying Of Columbia Law Professor
description: A 16yearold suspect in the slaying of a Columbia Univer sity professor turned himself in last night, the police report ed.

title: BEACON TEACHERS RATIFY CONTRACT
description: BEACON, N.Y., Sept. 27The 176 teachers of the Beacon School District voted today to accept a new threeyear con tract. The teachers have been on strike since Sept. 7, delaying the opening of school in this Dutchess County community.

title: Times's Publisher Honored By Society of Journalists
description: The Society of Silurians, an organization of past and present New York newspapermen and women honored Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, yesterday for his contributions to journalism.

title: Personal Finance: Loan Rates on Cars
description: Where can a newcar buy er get a better dealfrom a bank or a finance com pany?

title: Bowater Plans London Unit
description: The Bowater Corporation and the Natural Resources group of W. R. Grace & Co. announced yesterday that they planned to form a jointly owned subsidiary to be known as Bowater/Grace Newsprint Process, Ltd. The new unit, which will have its head quarters in London, will pro mote the construction of mills for the manufacture of news print from bagasse, a byprod uct of sugar cane.

title: Judge Orders State to Release $52Million Boston School Aid
description: BOSTON, Sept. 27A Su perior Court Judge ordered the state's Board to Education to day to release nearly $52mil lion in school aid it had been withholding from Boston for year because of the city School Committee's alleged failure to comply with the state racial imbalance law.

title: New School Protest on Lower East Side Keeps Most Pupils Away
description: A new protest by parents kept children out of Public School on the Lower East Side yesterday while disputes over pupil and teacherassignments continued in other parts of the city.

title: Panel in Rochester Scores Both Sides In Antiwar Protest
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 27 (AP) A grand jury that investigated clashes between the police and antiwar demonstrators criti cized both factions and recom mended that complaints against policemen be handled by the district attorney instead of police administrators.

title: Police Seize Father of Boy Allegedly Traded for Auto
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 27 (AP) The father of an infant boy allegedly traded for a used car last week In Immokalee, Fla., was arrested today by sheriff's deputies and charged with rape, a police spokesman said.

title: OCCIDENTAL SEEKS SOVIET GAS VENTURE
description: Dr. Armand Hammer, chair man of the Occidental Petrole um Corporation, said yesterday that he had discussed with Hiroshi Anzai, spokesman for the Japanese gas industry, a proposal to be made to the Soviet Union that natural gas deposits in Siberia be devel oped jointly by the United States, Japan and Soviet Union.

title: Gains Noted on Auto Warranties
description: Until recently, new  car warranties and servicing contracts were labyrinths of small print, which could be counted on to ensnarl an owner in timeconsuming ar guments and frustrations.

title: Butler Capital Abandons BrokerageBusiness Role
description: The Butler Capital Corpora tion has become the second member organization of the York Stock Exchange within a week to abandon the broker age business because of ad verse conditions in the securi ties industry.

title: Hortense Calisher Talks About Writing and Herself
description: When the writing is going well, Hortense Calisher will spring up from her desk and do a silent dance of delight.

title: Study of Marijuana Draws Crowd of Hopeful Subjects
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 (Reu ters)A report that free and legal marijuana was available in a Governmentsanctioned psychological study brought a flood of phone calls this week at the Maryland Psychiatric Re search Center near here.

title: C.A.B. Eases Rule So Almost Anyone Can Fly by Charter
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board approved yesterday a new charter flight regulation that, for the first time, will allow virtually anybody  not just members of clubs, unions, pro fessional societies and other or ganized groupsto fly on low cost charter flights to Europe and elsewhere.

title: TwoRun Rally in Ninth Defeats Lyle of Yankees
Letellier's 70 Leads Metropolitan by a Shot
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 27 While scores generally soared well above par, Ron Letellier began the defense of his Metro politan open golf title with a twounderpar 70 today at the Stanwich Club.

title: An Expanded Men's Store Opened by Bloomingdale's
description: Bloomingdale's last night opened an expanded and re modeled Men's Store at its Manhattan store at Lexington Avenue and 59th Street at a benefit reception for Odyssey House, Inc., the drugrehabili tation center.

title: KENNEDY ASSURES DOCTORS ON PLAN
description: In an apparently conciliatory move toward organized med icine, Senator Edward M. Ken nedy said yesterday that he did not want to see American med icine socialized and asserted that the health care reform he had proposed could be achieved within the existing free enter prise system.

title: Merola Is Designated to Seek Post as Bronx District Attorney
description: City Councilman Mario Me rola was formally designated yesterday as the Democratic nominee to succeed Burton B. Roberts as the Bronx County District Attorney.

title: Spaniard Retains Crown; Challenger Gives Up in 6th
description: LA SPEZIA, Italy, Sept. 27 (AP)Agustin Senin of Spain retained his European bantam weight title tonight when the Italian challenger, Antonio Sas sarini, quit 10 seconds before the end of the sixth round.

title: MRS. KANE, WITH 78, LEADS SENIORS GOLF
description: ORELAND, Pa., Sept. 27 Mrs. John B. Kane Jr. of White marsh, Pa., gained a onestroke lead in the 11th annual 54hole United States senior amateur women's golf championship by scoring a fouroverpar 37, 4178 today at the Manu facturers Golf and. Country Club.

title: City StudiesProposal to Grade Meat and Fowl for Consumers
description: The City Department of Con sumer Affairs said yesterday that city legislation requiring the grading of meat and poultry for the consumers would be considered after a legal review of possible conflict with Federal law.

title: Chess: Interzonals Are Under Way To Pick World Challenger
description: In the first stage of de terming who will challenge Bobby Fischer for the world chess championship in 1975, the zonal tournaments began this year. From each of the 10 zones in the world, one or more playersdepending on the number of chess play ers in the zoneare selected to enter two interzonal tour naments in 1973.

title: KISSINGER'S TALKS SPUR PEACE RUMOR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Henry A. Kissinger arrived here from Paris tonight amid ru mors, which were strongly de nied by the White House, that there had been a breakthrough in Vietnam peace negotiations.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Graham S. Finney resigned suddenly yesterday as Com missioner of the city's Addic tion Services Agency.

title: TALKS ON ULSTER ENDED IN ENGLAND
description: DARLINGTON, England, Sept. 27 William Whitelaw, British administrator for North ern Ireland, and Ulster politi cians discussed today the cru cial issue of the control of security in the province.

title: News of Dogs
description: Old English sheepdogs were out in force at the Ox Ridge Kennel Club's show last Saturday, with 92 bob tails lumbering across the turf. They were there be cause Old English owners wanted Mrs. Jean Gould, a British authority on the breed, to see their dogs and get her opin ion of them.

title: Many Look On as 3 Youths Here Mug and Rob Prominent Lawyer
description: In daylight, with scores of people looking on, a prominent lawyer and civic worker was mugged and robbed yesterday afternoon on 109th Street be tween Fifth and Madison Ave nues.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PRINCETON, Sept. 27Deep Throat, an Xrated sex film whose showing in Manhattan once led to a raid on the ground that it considered hardcore por nography, opened tonight at a firstrun theater on Route 1 near this affluent university community.

title: Red Sox Beat Brewers; Tigers Top Yanks, 65
description: BOSTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)  Reggie Smith doubled home two runs in the fifth inning and Luis Aparicio tripled for two more in the sixth today to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 75 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Operation PUSH Opens a Black Expo in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 27  This year's Black Expo, which opened here today, was to have been the fourth annual event sponsored by the South ern Christian Leadership Con ference. Instead, it is the first annual black business and cul tural trade exposition under the auspices of Operation PUSH.

title: The former commander of all U.S. forces in the Pacific, just retired, sees Vietnamization as a success and holds it absolutely essential to remain a power in the Pacific
description: HONOLULU  Viewing my tenure as commander in chief of Pacific forces, I am struck by the realization that there have been tremendous changes in this vast area within these four years. The United States has made great strides in attaining the goals of the Nixon Doctrine, which call for continued United States lead ership in the Pacificbut with re duced American forces.

title: F.H.A. RESHUFFLES INDICTED L.I. STAFF
description: New executives from vari ous parts of the United States took over the regional office of the Federal Housing Adminis tration in Hempstead, L. I., yesterday, replacing officials whose indictments were an nounced the previous day.

title: ANACONDA CO. SUES ON CLEANAIR RULING
description: DENVER, Sept. 27 (AP)The Anaconda Company of Montana filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court, asking that en forcement of federally imposed air pollution standards for the company's Montana copper smelter be stopped.

title: Business Briefs
description: A steel mill in upstate New York is to be restarted next month, while two aluminum potlines in Alabama will be closed down and two in Oregon will be started up again. The moves reflect the unsettled condition of the metals industry.

title: Maine Foliage Change
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept 27 (AP) Northern Maine will have 50 to 75 per cent foliage change this weekend, with the peak expected next week, the State Forestry Department said to day.

title: More Bombings in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 27 (AP)More bombs ex ploded in Northern Ireland today as sectarian violence claimed two more lives.

title: RecklessHomicide Term
description: ALFRED, Me., Sept. 27 (AP) David L. Woods of Plaistow, N.H., was sentenced today to 1 to 3 years in prison for reck less homicide in the auto death of a college student who was working as a toll collector on the Maine Turnpike. Superior Court Justice Harry P. Glass man suspended all but 60 days of the 25yearold's sentence and placed him on probation for two years.

title: Canada Bans Firecrackers
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 27 (UPI) The Minister of Energy. Donald Macdonald, announced today that the Government was ban ning immediately the sale of firecrackers to the general public.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 27 The Nebraska A.F.L.C.I.O. leadership, after considerable maneuvering, adopted a resolu tion here today condemning the antilabor tactics of the Nixon Administration and applauding the prolabor record of Gedrge McGovern.

title: Wallace Back Home
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 27 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wal lace returned to the executive mansion yesterday from Spain Rehabilitation Center in Bir mingham where doctors gave him a routine checkup. Mr. Wallace has been paralyzed from the waist down since be ing shot May 15.

title: Continued Economic Growth Is Predicted for 1973
description: Continued economic expan sion next year in the United States was widely predicted yesterday by economists partici pating in a 1973 business out look conference.

title: MRS. SAGE REACHES L.I. GOLF SEMIFINALS
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 27 Mrs. Andrew Sage of Piping Rock, the medalist, advanced today to the semifinals of the Long Island women's match play golf championship at the Fresh Meadow Country Club. Mrs. Sage covered the par74, 5,980yard course in 78 as she turned back a clubmate, Mrs. Gordon McGrath, 5 and 4.

title: City Unveils Police Cars In Disguise
description: The Police Department ad mitted yesterday that its un marked detective cars  the lowpriced, lackluster civilian models that can be seen lurking in trafficwere about as subtle as a siren for un dercover work.

title: Filmways Elects President
description: Richard L. Bloch has been elected president of Filmways, Inc. He will continue as chair man and chief executive officer.

title: OBJECTIVITY URGED FOR ABORTION FOES
description: ALBANY, Sept. 27 (AP)As sembly member Constance E. Cook, Republican of Ithaca, urged opponents of New York State's abortion law today to avoid hysteria and fear in ex pressing their views.

title: Canonero ll Withdrawn From Woodward
description: On a day on which 17,147 fans at Belmont Park saw a big turnout of 19 thoroughbreds compete in two divisions of the Manhattan Handicap  worth a combined $93,450  a damper was put on Saturday's $100,000added Woodward by the loss of one starter.

title: Mortgage Loans Climb 17 Per Cent to Set Record
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)  The amount of new mortgage loans outstanding at federally insured savings and loan associations jumped 17 per cent in August to $5.2billion, a new high, the Federal Home Loan Bank board said today.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 27 (AP) Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell, head of the United States Na tional Guard Association from 1963 until 1970, was ordered today to stand trial Oct. 10 whether or not his lawyer is ready.

title: Philadelphia Strike By Teachers Ends; Classes to Resume
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP)  Philadelphia's striking school teachers voted by near ly a 3to1 margin tonight to return to their classrooms to morrow while contract negotia tions continue.

title: Screen: Peerce's Version of 'A Separate Peace':Story of Friendships at School at Cinema II Exeter Locale Adds to Emphasis on Details
description: Larry Peerce's film version of "A Separate Peace" is so good and true in small, subsidiary details of costume, music, weather and such that the ultimate banality of what it's all about is just that much more apparent, and just that much more difficult to accept without seeming unnecessarily ill-tempered. Which is pretty much the way I feel about John Knowles's novel, originally published in 1960 and now, I'm told, something of a cult classic with the crowd that a decade earlier would have worshiped J. D. Salinger.The time is 1942-1943 and the setting is the posh Devon School for boys in Devon, N.H., a school long on tradition, well-born alumni and fancy bequests. It's a place much like Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N. H., where Mr. Knowles went to school and where Mr. Peerce shot his film, paying more attention to the beauty of the season than to the sense of the screenplay that Fred Segal adapted from the novel."A Separate Peace" is the story of a quintessential friendship between two 16-year-old boys who are roommates, a mutual admiration society of two, rivals and, finally, an assassin and his victim. The narrator is Gene (Parker Stevenson), a bright young man whose bookishness is balanced by an exuberance fondly encouraged by his best friend, Finny (John Heyl), the most popular boy in the class, a born leader and the school's best athlete. Finny is a natural man (boy), the kind of innocent favored in romantic literature, incapable of viciousness and simply puzzled when he recognizes it in others.The separate peace of the tilte is actually a series of accommodations that repeat the film's theme as if the movie were a gigantic echo chamber. The school itself has made a separate, if temporary, peace to allow its seniors one last, normal season before they go into World War II. The first student to enlist cannot take the discipline of the service and finds his peace by going completely crackers.However, the most awesome accommodation is that between Gene and Finny after Gene knowingly or unknowingly (he is never sure which) is responsible for an accident that effectively ends all competition with Finny.Like the book, the film is compelling as long as it sticks to the more or less realistic details of upper-class American life, particularly of its school life, and of a friendship that embraces murderous hatred as well as love. But the movie, like the book, insists on drawing oversimplified, rather dumb parallels between the nature of the beast in Gene, which causes him to lash out against the innocent Finny, and the nature of war. "Just some ignorance inside of me," says a mopey Gene, as if that explained anything.For the first 30 minutes, the movie looks and sounds absolutely right, but as the melodrama piles up, everything goes slightly awry, including the Knowles-Segal dialogue that has teen-agers talking what I assume is meant to be wisdom, but could only be taken as such in the lower forms."If war can drive somebody crazy," says Finny when he hears of another student's nervous breakdown, "then it's real, all right." The admittedly nutty student describes sunlight coming through trees in "millions of rays, like golden machine-gun fire." I suspect that the book's popularity may be ascribed to the fact that a lot of people really wish they could talk this way.Peerce is very good with his almost completely nonprofessional cast, especially with John Heyl, a stocky, handsome young man whose face reflects the profound cheerfulness of someone who' will never grow old. Parker Stevenson has the more difficult role (perhaps an impossible one) and I'm not sure I'd have had much idea of what was going on in his mind had I not ready the book.As he displayed in "Goodbye, Columbus," Peerce has a positive talent not only for period detail, but also for knowing when and how to cut around and away from the performances of non-actors so that Heyl, Stevenson and a large proportion of the Exeter student body manage to come up trumps."A Separate Peace" opened yesterday at the Cinema II.

title: Levitt Bids U.S. Pay Taxes Penn Central Owes the City
description: ALBANY, Sept. 27 (UPI)  Comptroller Arthur Levitt said today that, during the Penn Central's reorganization, the Federal Government should pay the estimated total of $10mil lion annually in property taxes, the company owes New York local governments.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: One of the most tragic aspects of the mailabomb campaign against Is raeli diplomats, so far overlooked by most observers, is the fact that the bombs used in the campaign are Americanmade gravel mines, and were first used by American forces in Indochina. The use of gravel mines in Indochina was first proposed by the Jason study group (a group of civilian scientists who regularly advise the military on new applications of tech nology) after a meeting at the Dana Hall School at Wellesley. They sug gested that gravel mines would be useful for both harassment and areadenial.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 27A legislative commssion studying gambling today heard a series of witnesses, including Jersey City's Police Director and an Assemblyman, advocate legal ized gambling because they said it would eliminate a major source of corruption of police men and other public officials.

title: Big Bands
description: Although nostalgia for one thing or another is always with it is usually as evanescent as a morning fog. Nostalgia for the big bands of the thirties and forties, however, has turned out to be something elsea memory that clings on and on for some of those who lived through the period.

title: U.S. Steel Officer Outlines Program To Aid U.S. Trade
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 (AP) R. Heath Larry, vice chair man of the United States Steel Corporation, said today that improvement in the nation's foreign trade position depends upon realignments in exchange rates, better operation of the domestic economy, and either the removal of artificial traed barriers in other countries or a United States move to counter balance them.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW GOOD GAIN
COACHES DEFEND DEFENSE OF JETS
description: The questions people are ask ing about the success of the New York Jets football team, now sporting a 20 wonlost record, usually begin some thing like this:

title: Murphy Warns Top Aides Fight on Corruption Lags
description: Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy told his commanders during two private meetings this week that despite some progress they still had failed to combat adequately cor ruption among their men.

title: Spying Laid to Pentagon
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (UPI) Antiwar activists accompany ing the three American pilots released by North Vietnam charged today that the Penta gon was attempting to convert other captured fliers into es pionage agents.

title: L.I. MURDER TRIAL ENDS IN ACQUITTAL
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 27 John O. Hughes of Smithtown, the suspended lawyer who de fended himself against murder and conspiracy charges in the death of George Bilodeau, a Lin denhurst, L. I., electronics exec utive, was acquitted here today of both charges.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: John Donne wrote, in 1623: No man is an island  any man's death diminishes me, because I am involved in mankind. Any man's death does diminish each one of us, yet the death of a man of the stature of Wolfgang Friedmann, and especially the manner in which he died, does more than diminish mankind. For a man who spent much of his life in the field of law, and who escaped the lawlessness of Hitler's Germany, to die at the lawless hands of three muggers is tragic commentary on life, and death, in too many of our cities today.

title: KAHANE UNIT TO RUN FOR OFFICE IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 27Rabbi ?? Kahane announced here today that the militant Jewish Defense League, which he heads, would form a political party and enter the Israeli par liamentary elections next year.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS BY 64 IN AN EXHIBITION
Lindsay Aides Assailed by Councilmen Over Appointments to Civil Service Jobs
description: The Lindsay administration was sharply attacked yesterday by a committee of the City Council for allegedly undermin ing the Civil Service system by making widespread political ap pointments and by swelling the ranks with provisional em ployes who do not take ex aminations.

title: Bridge: Goren, the Master Bidder, Could Also Play Brilliantly
description: Tournament players are only the visible tip of a very large iceberg. Nobody knows how many rubberbridge players there are hidden be neath the surface, but some optimistic estimates have placed the number above 35 million. A vast majority of this multitude of rubber bridge enthusiasts play pri vately rather than in clubs, but an attempt is now being made to remedy that situa tion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I violently object to the editorial Sidewalk Jungle which appeared on Sept. 22. It is obvious the writer neither was near the location where Dr. Friedmann was inhumanly mur dered nor does he know anything about the neighborhood.

title: Executive Changes
description: Herbert G. Stolzer has been named president of the Johnson & Johnson Operating Company.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The killing of Professor Friedmann raises an issue which will probably not be noticed in the press. The issue is whether Professor Friedmann, who tried to defend himself, ought not to have been allowed to possess the means to do so.

title: No Nobel Peace Prize Will Be Given This Year
description: OSLO, Norway, Sept. 27 (AP)The Nobel Peace Prize will not be awarded this year, it was announced here today.

title: General to Retire Jan. 31
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 27 (AP) Gen. John L. Throckmorton, commander  in  chief of the United States, Readiness Com mand at MacDill Air Force Base, announced today plans to retire Jan. 31. President Nixon has nominated Gen. Bruce Palmer Jr., acting chief of staff of the Army, to succeed him Feb. 1.

title: Burton E. Vaughan, ExDirector Of B B. D. 0. Agency, Dies at 70
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 Burton E. Vaughan, a re tired director of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, Inc., ad vertising agency, died yester day in Presbyterian Hospital after a twomonth illness. He was 70 years old.

title: REV. EARL DOUGLASS, AUTHOR, DEAD AT 84
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 27 The Rev. Dr. Earl L. Douglass, an author, syndicated feature writer and a Presbyterian min ister, died at his home here last night of a heart attack. His age was 84.

title: Personalities: Blass Indifferent
description: Steve Blass doesn't seem concerned about winning his 20th game for the Pirates. Either I do or I don't, Blass said after beating the Phillies for No. 19 on Tuesday night. The Pirate righthander add ed, I certainly want 20, but I'm not going to worry about it. Blass has one more start against the New York Mets, whom he beat last weekthen he will rest until the National League playoffs begin against Cincinnati. If Blass wins No. 20, he will be the first Pittsburgh pitcher to reach that figure since Ver non Law in 1960.  Ted Williams, manager of the Texas Rangers  which has the worst record in the major leaguesmay be in his final year as manager. Joe Burke, the club's general manager, says, Williams has a five year contract with one year left on it. If he chooses to stay, Bob Short, the owner, will honor the contract. There'll be no firing or any thing like that. Short says, Williams hasn't told us any thing yet. We have talked about it, but there has been nothing definite from him at this point.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 President Nixon's former chief economic adviser believes that there is less than an even chance that the Nixon Admin istration will keep its promise to ask for no tax increases dur ing the next four years.

title: What's in a Name? A Suit For $100,000 in Damages
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 27 (UPI) A $100,000 damage suit has been filed by a Woodbridge physician against the Southern New England Telephone Com pany, accusing it of Improper ly listing his specialty in the Yellow Pages as osteopath instead of obstetrician.

title: NATO to Check Soviet Position On ForceReduction Discussions
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 27The North Atlantic Treaty Organ ization agreed today to press the Soviet Union for satisfac tory assurances that it is pre pared for substantive explora tory discussions on reducing forces in Central Europe.

title: 2 Sentenced in Smuggling
description: BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP)Two men who pleaded guilty to smuggling into the country of 600 pounds of hashish valued by the United States Attorney's office at $1million have been given sixyear sentences in Fed eral court. They are Stephen Kurwood, 24 years old, of Cambridge, and Norman B. Casas, 24, of Coopers Mills, Me.

title: Paris Blaze Destroys Le Drug Store
description: PARIS, Thursday, Sept. 28 (Reuters)A spectacular fire on the Champs Elysees last night gutted the sevenstory building that houses Le Drug Store, a popular luxury bou tiquerestaurant. Le Drug Store was a total loss and two ad joining buildings were virtually destroyed.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland, Sept. 27 (AP)Laurie Hammer of Delray Dunes, Fla., shot a 70 today for a tworound total of 135 and a fivestroke lead in the International proamateur golf tournament. Hammer's nearest rivals were Allan Mc Clay of Summit, N. J., Willard School of Gulf Mills, Pa., and Dick Stranahan of Longmeadow, Mass., who were tied at 140.

title: U.S. NOW REQUIRES VISAS FOR TRANSIT BY MOST VISITORS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept: 27  The United States today im posed visa requirerments for for eigners in transit through this country.

title: B52's Attack in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, Thursday, Sept. 28 (AP)For the second succes sive day, United States B52 bombing raids across South ?? were reported curtailed yesterday to fewer than half of the normal 100 strikes.

title: DRIVE IS CATCHING MANY FUGITIVES
description: New police and court pro cedures were reported yester day to have achieved a dra matic increase in catching up with criminal and other de fendants who fail to show up in court and against whom bench warrants are then issued.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: TOKYO, Sept. 27 (UPI)George Knudson of Canada and J. C. Snead of the United States are expected to be strong contenders to win the Japan open golf title in the fourday tournament starting tomorrow.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: A Newark policeman was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Newark on charges of distributing and attempting to distribute heroin. United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern said the policeman, Alton Smith, 30 years old, of 69 North Munn Avenue, was arrested by Federal narcotics officers on July 29.

title: COURT BACKS LAW ON HOLDING TANKS
description: New York pleasureboat owners received a setback yesterday in their efforts to void a state law requiring hold ing tanks (for the disposal of polluting waste) as part of standard equipment aboard yachts.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: New top executives took over the regional office of the Federal Housing Author ity in Hempstead, L.I. The new officials replaced the di rector, the deputy director and three other former offi cials in the office who were suspended after being in dicted on charges of bribery. The former director has al ready pleaded guilty to the charges.

title: NISSANAUDI ACCORD ON ENGINE IS REVISED
description: TOKYO, Sept. 27 (AP)The Nissan Motor Company of Ja pan said it had reached an agreement to revise its present contract with Audi NSU Auto Union, A.G. of West Germany to allow Nissan to export ve hicles equipped with rotary en gines.

title: City AddictionAid Chief Quits; Decries Reliance on Methadone
description: Graham S. Finney resigned suddenly yesterday as Com missioner of the city's Addic tion Services Agency.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: LANDER, Wyo.Recently, a trio of Eastern outdoor writereditors came here de termined to demonstrate to their Western hosts that ex cellent markmanship is not confined to the men of Marl boro Country.

title: Fines and Jail in D.C. Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)  A judge today fined the striking Washington Teachers Union $50,000 and ordered its president, William Sinons, and executive committee jailed.

title: Antidrug Success Noted
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 27 (UPI)Attorney General Rich ard G. Kleindienst said today that, for the first time, Govern ment efforts had succeeded in keeping narcotics out of the hands of addicts and wouldbe addicts. Mr. Kleindienst, speak ing at the annual youth banquet of the Pasadena Junior Cham ber of Commerce, said that Federal agents made more than 16,000 narcotics arrests in the fiscal year 1972, nearly double the number of fiscal 1969. He credited a major part of the increase to the use of author ized wiretaps of drug dealers.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 27Pete Gogolak got some of the extra attention he had been begging for today when the New York Giants coach, Alex Webster, had the team put on a simulated rush at the place kicker, who missed fieldgoal attempts of 45 and 24 yards in Sunday's 2314 defeat by the Dallas Cowboys.

title: CALIFORNIA LAWYERS BACK NOFAULT PLAN
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Sept. 27 (AP)The State Bar Associa tion's Conference of Delegates has voted to back a statewide compulsory nofault auto insur ance plan that differs from one backed by the bar's board of governors.

title: SENATE WOULD LET PENSIONERS EARN $3,000 EACH YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Senate voted today to al low the older worker to earn up to $3,000 a year without forfeiting any Social Security cash benefits.

title: Giscard d'Estaing Backs Schweitzer in I.M.F. Talk
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  France proposed today a three stage program for world mone tary reform, with the rules gov erning currency exchange rates to be agreed upon within a year from now.

title: Norway Says No
description: In rejecting the European Economic Community, Nor wegian voters have done much more than derail the welladvanced program for enlarging the Common Market from six to ten members Jan. 1. They have dealt a heavy blow at the whole concept of Western European integra tion and Atlantic cooperation, thus turning back toward a position of isolation which their postwar leaders, with out exception, have warned that Norway cannot afford.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Consumers of alcoholic beverages can expect to pay another 4 to 7 cents a fifth at retail liquor stores starting Nov. 1 following the State Liquor Authority's approval last week of a 1 per cent rise in wholesale prices. The authority chairman, Bertram D. Sarafan, said the approval was based on increased labor and operating costs and higher warehouse rentals.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M. on Rho desia

title: Britain Asks U.N. Assembly Seek to Delay Expulsion of Asians by Uganda
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27  The British For eign Secretary, Sir Alec Doug lasHome, today asked the General Assembly to give ur gent consideration to the ex pulsion of Asians from Ugan da  an outrage against standards of human decen cy, in the face of which this Assembly cannot remain si lent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: When Smith Simpson, in his Sept. 17 letter, cites the memoirs of Paul Henri Speak to establish the charge that the U.N. bombed hospitals in the Congo, he is stretching the term documented much too far.

title: PERJURY IS CHARGED IN U.S. BUILDING CASE
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 27 (AP)A Dunkirk man was under arrest today, accused of lying to a Federal grand jury investigat ing possible extortion during construction of a new Federal office building here.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 27The State Department of Environ mental Protection collected $465,550 in air pollution fines in the first eight months of this year, it was announced today.

title: BOARD SUPPORTED AT GREAT WESTERN
description: Shareholders of the Great Western United Corporation have voted to support manage ment's slate of directors, the company announced yesterday. Of a total of 1,473,100 votes counted at the annual meeting last week, 1,216,100 were cast in favor of management.

title: SLOW PACE IS URGED ON A NEWSMAN LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) The president of the Ameri can Newspaper Publishers As sociation urged Congress today to go slow in trying to write a law that would protect news men's sources of information.

title: A Leftover '72 May Be a Buy
description: Will you save money by buying a leftover new 1972 car instead of a 1973 model?

title: Text of Fuld's Statement
description: Following is the text of Judge Stanley H. Fuld's statement on articles in The New York Times on criminal sentencing:

title: MARTIN MATHESON OF JOHN WILEY, 77
description: Martin Matheson, retired se nior vice president of John Wiley & Sons, Inc., publishing house, died in New York Hos pital on Tuesday. He was 77 years old and lived in Brook field Center, Conn.

title: Fuld Suggests Sentencing By an Agency, Not Judges
description: The chief judge of the state suggested yesterday that it might be desirable to take the job of sentencing away from judges and give it to correc tion authorities or some other agency.

title: Alleged Slayings Near Mylai In '67 Under Study by the Army
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Army has been actively investigating allegations that another infantry company com mitted War crimes one year earlier in the same area where the mass slayings at Mylai oc curred in 1968.

title: District Attorney Acquitted Of TaxEvasion Charges
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 27The District Attorney of Oswego County was acquitted here last night of charges that he wil fully failed to file Federal in come tax returns for 1968 and 1969.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In the greenandwhite King Ranch barn at Belmont Park yesterday, under a gloomy gray sky, Alberto Quin tanilla, a stable foreman, was unwrapping heavy white bandages to show the injury on Canonero Il's right foreleg. When a camera clicked, the horse's head snapped toward it, as if he were posing.

title: 3 P.O. W.'s Land in Soviet, Reject U.S. Aid
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 27Three American pilots freed by North Vietnam arrived here today and turned down an official Ameri can offer of assistance in their journey to the United States.

title: Samuels Defends Hiring Of Key Campaign Aides
description: The suggestion raised yester day at a City Council hearing, that the Offtrack Betting Cor poration is susceptible to pa tronage is freely acknowledged, by its president, Howard J. Samuels.

title: Uganda Reports Tanzanians Are Moving Toward Border
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Sept. 27 (Reuters)A Uganda military spokesman said here that Tan zanian troops were reported moving overland to the Ugan daTanzania border and by boat across Lake Victoria toward eastern Uganda.

title: Postal Nominee Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)The Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee approved today the nomina tion of Robert Earl Holding of Cheyenne, Wyo., as a member of the board of governors of the United States Postal Serv ice. Confirmation by the Sen ate is expected this week.

title: JOSEPH VIELAND
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 Joseph Vieland, who played the viola in the New York Philhar monic Orchestra from 1930 un til he retired 30 years later, died of a heart attack today in Women's Medical Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: U.A.W. AIDE URGES AN EXTRA VACATIC
description: DETROIT, Sept. 27  A week's vacation five times a year, in addition to normal va cation time, was suggested to day by Ken Bannon, a leader of the United Automobile Workers.

title: LAW CURBING GUNS IS CALLED UNLIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)  Congress appears cer tain to end its session without passing any new gun control legislation.

title: Perry Blanks Orioles, 30
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 (AP) Gaylord Perry of Cleveland notched his 23d victory, a 30 decision over Baltimore in a raindelayed game tonight, the Orioles moved closer to ward elimination in the Amer ican League East race.

title: MRS, RYAN ENTERS RACE IN THE 20TH
description: Mrs. William F. Ryan de clared yesterday that she was seeking the Democratic nomi nation for the House of Repre sentatives because she wanted to continue the kind of repre sentation her late husband gave his district.

title: Major's Family Explains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Reached by phone at a hotel here, Barney Elias, the father of Major Elias, said today that members of his family had de cided not to accept an invi tation to go to Hanoi after hear ing press reports that the State and Defense Departments re garded such visits as contrary to the best interests of the pris oners and of the United States.

title: Unions Reject Heath's Proposal For Voluntary WagePrice Curb
description: LONDON, Sept. 27 Trade union leaders, in a sharp re buff to Prime Minister Heath, today rejected the Govern ment's proposals for a program of voluntary wage and price restraints.

title: Aaron Hits No. 672; Bench Continues Spree
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 (AP) Dank Aaron and Bob Did ier combined for six hits and five runs batted in and Phil Niekro notched his 16th vic tory as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Cincinnati Reds 85 tonight.

title: JOHN M. FLAGLER OF LOOK DIES AT 50
description: John M. Flagler, former hu mor editor of Look magazine, died on Tuesday at his home after it long illness. He was 50 years old and lived at 36 West 12th Street.

title: SILVER FUTURES SHOW A BIG GAIN
description: Silver futures prices, which had opened lower, rallied sharply yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange, and closed 3.5 to 3.8 cents an ounce higher than in the pre ceding session.

title: Tokyo Official Says Japan Will Cut Ties With Taiwan
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 28 Acting Premier Takeo Miki said today that Japan would announce tomorrow that she was severing diplomatic rela tions with the Nationalist Chi nese Government on Taiwan.

title: Starting at Right Tackle: Ms. Jones
description: The Eastern College Ath letic Conference yesterday declared undergraduate wo men eligible for all varsity intercollegiate sports played by its 214 member colleges and universities.

title: Does It Really Matter Which Stove You Buy?
description: Picking a stove, all things considered, is as hard as choosing a mate. There are far too many models available to check out more than a few. Advance testing is discouraged, and a sure sense of what the longterm future will be once installation in the home has oc curred is difficult to achieve. But, as with marriage, it helps to have an ideal in mind, and to remember that beauty is only skin deep.

title: Dial ME 71212 to Get State Lottery Number
description: New York Telephone's re corded time announcement service will begin carrying the winning state lottery number today.

title: Bank Loot BoobyTrapped
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP)A bank robber's getaway was foiled today when a canis ter of tear gas hidden in his bag of loot by a teller exploded outside the bank. The canister was activated by an electronic device at the door of the build ing.

title: DR. EDWIN C. BRAYNARD
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 27 Dr. Edwin C. Braynard, a gen eral practitioner who began practice in nearby Seacliff in 1913, died today at his home, 47 Highland Road, at the age of 88.

title: The Next Four Years
description: In less than six weeks, we, the American people, will be choosing the President and Vice President of the United States for the next four years. But we will be doing more than that; we will be determining whether we want this country to continue along the course it has been taking during the past four years, or whether we want to restore to American political life its tradi tional values of democratic liberalism and social concern.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Today is the final day to register to vote for candi dates for state and local of fice whose names will appear on the Nov. 7 general elec tion ballot in New Jersey. Clerks at town halls and at special registration points in parks, stores and shopping malls will be taking registra tions until 9 P.M. in many areas.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TOMS RIVER, Sept. 27 An Ocean County jury heard today how a rape suspect was tracked from the scene and finally identified by a bloodhound.

title: MRS. COURT GAINS IN PHOENIX TENNIS
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 27 (AP)Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia and Rosemary Casals of San Francisco advanced to day to the quarterfinals of the Virginia SlimsPhoenix Thun derbird women's tennis tourna ment.

title: BRITON POSTS 64, TAKES GOLF LEAD
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland, Sept. 27 (AP)Britain's Brian Hug gett carded a recordbreaking sevenunderpar 64 today for the firstround lead in the $134,750 John Player golf tour nament.

title: Olin in Real Estate Deal
description: The Housing Group of the Olin Corporation and the YoungAmerican Companies of Dallas have agreed in principle to form a new real estate de velopment and residential con struction concern to be known as OlinAmerican, Inc. Olin Corporation will own more than 90 per cent of the stock in the new company.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 5 million com mon shares of the Virginia Electric and Power Company at $18 per share was made yester day by an underwriting group managed by Merrill Lynch. Pro ceeds will be used to retire shortterm indebtedness. The company's stock was un changed on the New York Stock Exchange at 18.

title: Thieu and Bunker Hold EarlyMorning Meeting
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 28 (Agence France Presse)  President Nguyen Van Thieu and the United States Ambassador, Ellsworth Bunker, met for 45 minutes early this morning At the Doclap Palace.

title: Marcos Lengthens List Of Those to Be Arrested
description: MANILA, Sept. 27President Ferdinand E. Marcos today broadened the scope of arrests to be made under the martial law he imposed in the Philip pines last week.

title: Credit Markets
description: News reports on the Vietnam peace talks in Paris shook the bond market out of the dol drums yesterday afternoon and pushed most longterm interest rates down sharply.

title: Norway Cabinet Quit Oct. 6
description: OSLO, Norway, Sept. 27, (Reuters)  Premier Trygve Bratteli announced today that his Labor Cabinet would resign on Oct. 6 as a result of the de feat of his bid to take Norway into the European Common Market.

title: The Times Names 3 New Vice Presidents
description: The New York Times Com pany named three new vice presidents yesterday. They are John D. Pomfret, who is assist ant to the publisher; Charles B. Brakefield, president and general manager of WRECTV in Memphis, and John R. Harri son, who heads a group of nine Florida newspapers owned by The Times and is president of The Lakeland Ledger.

title: 4 Teachers Face Jail
description: BURLINGTON, MASS., Sept. 27 (AP)Four officers of the Burlington Teachers Asso ciation were, sentenced today to seven days in the Middlesex County Jail after being found guilty of contempt of court for ignoring a strike ban.

title: Many Look On as 3 Youths Here Mug and Rob Prominent Lawyer
description: In daylight, with scores of people looking on, a prominent lawyer and civic worker was mugged and robbed yesterday afternoon on 109th Street be tween Fifth and Madison Ave nues.

title: Woman in the News
description: I'm sorry, I'm very new at this, the slender, simply dressed woman said yester day after a raspy voice, ema nating from the smoky gloom, interrupted the begin ning of her news conference with: Can you wait till all the cameras are on? Priscilla Marbury Ryan waited until the last TV cam era was poised in a room at the Biltmore Ho tel and then an nounced that she was a candidate for the seat in the House of Representa tives held by her late hus band, William F. Ryan.

title: AGNEW AND BUTZ STUMP IN ILLINOIS
description: PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 27Vice President Agnew was joined today by Dr. Earl L. Butz, the Secretary of Agriculture, and the two took the Republican campaign deep into the heart of the American farm belt.

title: $5.5MILLION ASKED IN A CONTRACT SUIT
description: Richard Rosenthal, former chief executive of the Utilities & Industries Corporation, has filed a $5.5million breachof contract suit against the com pany, it was disclosed yester day.

title: MAN SHOT ON L. I.; $350,000 FOUND
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L. I., Sept. 27  A 30yearold man was found critically wounded in the kitchen of a home here today with a suitcase contain ing $350,000 in currency on a nearby table.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: NEW SCHOOL NEW8LINE  Call 741 0707. 24hr service for listing of special evente you'll want to attend. Advt.

title: Price Changes
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it planned to increase its prices on low density polyethylene film, beginning Oct. 16. The products are widely used in packaging.

title: Israeli Military Aide Says That Lebanon Is Not Ready to Stop Guerrillas' Operation in South
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 27Israeli intelligence has concluded that Lebanon and the Palestinian guerrilla organizations have reached a mutually acceptable agreement that will permit the guerrillas to continue their op erations against Israel from southern Lebanon.

title: Hockey Draws Record Crowd
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 27 (AP) The largest crowd ever to witness indoor sports events in Connecticut, 8,114, saw the New Haven Nighthawks of the American Hockey League tie the National Hockey League's Minnesota North Stars, 11, to night in the first event to be held in New Haven's new Vet erans Memorial Coliseum.

title: Mosaic Workers Agree On $2.10 Hourly Increase
description: Striking mosaic and terrazzo workers have agreed on a threeyear pact with contrac tors and are scheduled to re turn to work today, a spokes man for the contractors said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A press photograph of the murdered Prof. Wolfgang G. Friedmann lying in front of Public School 36 reveals a policeman looking at the graffiti on its wall. How ironic and significant, for it is the leniency (having the young sters wash the walls) of judges and the city administrationand leniency is permissivenessthat permits this desecration and crime against property that may have contributed to the shocking killing and other crimes. If children and young adults think they can get away with defacing property, perhaps in their fragile minds they feel they, can get away with more. Boys will be boysand boys will be murderers.

title: Judicial Nominees Supported
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)Mayor Frank ??. Freed man of Springfield and United States Attorney Joseph L. Tauro Won quick approval of a Senate Judiciary subcommit tee today as nominees to he United States district judges for Massachusetts.

title: LAG IN JOB SAFETY IS CHARGED TO U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  Organized labor charged the Labor Department today with responsibility for a highly suc cessful scare campaign by thousands of smallbusiness operators to discredit the Oc cupational Safety and Health Act and the protection it af fords the working man.

title: U.S. Puts 72 Soviet Grain Crop At About 75% of Harvest in '71
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 27  The Soviet Union's winter wheat crop, plagued by severe weather, was down this year to about half of 1971 levels, according to latest estimates by the Department of Agriculture.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)A proposed Federal Financing Bank would neither create new Government lending programs nor end any existing ones, Under Secre tary of the Treasury Paul A. Volcker promised today.

title: Cold Front Due Today, Ending Humid Weather
description: A mild cold front out of Canada is expected to bring relief today from the humid, sticky weather that the met ropolitan area has experi enced since Monday, the Na tional Weather Service re ported.

title: 3 P.O.W.'s Land in Soviet, Reject U.S. Aid
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 27Three American pilots freed by North Vietnam arrived here today and turned down an official Ameri can offer of assistance in their journey to the United States.

title: MARCOS BROADENS SCOPE OF ARRESTS
description: MANILA, Sept. 27President Ferdinand E. Marcos today broadened the scope of arrests to be made under the martial law he imposed in the Philip pines last week.

title: Black Panthers in Algiers Name Deserter as Chief
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 27 (Reuters)  The Black Panthers in Al giers announced today that Wil liam Roger Holder, an Ameri can Army deserter who hi jacked a United States plane here last June with his girl friend had been appointed their new leader.

title: HARTFORD PASSES BUS LINES' SUBSIDY
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 27With Connecticut's major bus com panies faced with imminent strike and ruin unless there is a break in the political deadlock in the state, the Legislature to day approved a subsidy for the companies. The Governor, who has said he did not want the subsidy, had promised to veto the measure.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, Sept. 27 (AP)The Man chester United soccer club agreed today to pay $490,000 for Ted MacDougall, an English Third Division player for Bournemouth.

title: Male Chauvinist Textbook
description: BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 27 (UPI)The local chapter of the National Organization for Women says textbooks being used in the Boulder school sys tem promote male chauvinism. A psychologist told the Boulder Valley School Board yesterday that one textbook series cur rently in use showed more in terest in animals than females.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TOMS RIVER, Sept. 27A state police sergeant who taught at the State Police Academy for 14 years told an Ocean County jury today that no trooper candidate had ever been instructed at the school to use violence, intimidation or fear against citizens.

title: SYDNEY L. SOLOMON
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 27Sydney L. Solomon, a cofounder of the Wholesale Electrical Distributors Corpora tion of New York, died after a brief illness today at the home of a daughter in Woodbridge, Conn. He was 59 years old and lived at 94 Ward Drive here.

title: Coast Parley Is Told That Organ Transplants Are Successful and Will Go On
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 The way to give a heart transplant patient the best chance of prolonged life is to treat him as though he were likely to develop heart disease, doctors from Stanford Univer sity reported today.

title: Quiet, Please
description: The sooner Mayor Lindsay signs the noisecontrol code passed by the City Council, the sooner New Yorkers can hope for eventual relief from the city's maddening racket. The legislation would do more than impose strict decibel limits on such ubiquitous offenders as air compressors, paving drills, sirens and motor vehicles, especially gar bage trucks. It would establish varying overall noise limits for specific areas of the city, depending on their character, curb the blaring of amplifiers and completely ban that least excusable of all intrusions, the playing of radios and recorders on public conveyances.

title: University of the State, in a First, Awards Associate Degrees to 77 Who Did Not Have to Attend Any Classes
description: ALBANY, Sept. 27Seventy seven men and women who were not required to attend classes, listen to a teacher or pay tuition received college de grees today from a university without campus, buildings or professors.

title: G. O. P. AIRS SHRIVER ON DIALAPOLITICIAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Both the Democrats and the Republicans have special tele phone numbers here that auto matically provide callers with recorded excerpts from state ments by candidates and other luminaries.

title: Pentagon Denies Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) A Pentagon spokesman said today the allegations made by the antiwar activists were too ridiculous to dignify with a re ply.

title: 6 Die in Texas Truck Crash
description: ZAPATA, Tex., Sept. 27 (UPI) Six persons died today when a pickup truck ran off U.S. Highway 83 into a rainswollen creek seven miles south of Zapata. The Zapata County sheriff's department said that Maria Lucia Villarreal, 25 years old, was driving the truck, hound from California to the lower Rio Grande Valley, and apparently went to sleep.

title: BUILDING WORKERS WALK OUT IN ITALY
description: ROME, Sept. 27Some 1.5 million workers in the building trades went out on a 24hour work stoppage today.

title: Police Identify Man Slain In Gang Style in Queens
description: The body of a man found slain in gangland style in South Jamaica, Queens, has been iden tified by the police as that of Petros Zoumbouldis, 40 years old, with no known address.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 27  For the McGovern campaign's star organizer, Chicago has been a humbling experience, but then Gene Pokorny al ways thrived on the humble work of grass roots cam paigning.

title: Youth Residency Perils College Funds
description: State colleges and universi ties could lose between $250 million and $300million in an nual income if laws granting adult status and voting rights to 18yearolds allow students coming from out of state to claim lower tuition rates as resident students, according to a recent survey.

title: Confidential Data on Hospitals In Jersey to Be Released Today
description: TRENTON, Sept. 27Com missioner James R. Cowan of the State Department of Health announced tonight that confi dential state inspection reports on hospitals, nursing homes and other health facilities in New Jersey would be open to the public beginning tomorrow.

title: Brazil Opens a Section Of TransAmazon Road
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 27 The first stretch of the TransAmazon Highway, cut ting westward through one of the world's greatest jun gles, was opened to traffic today.

title: India Is Given $158Million In Two Credits From I.D.A.
description: The International Develop ment Association, the World Bank's softloan affiliate, an nounced yesterday two credits to India totaling $158million.

title: G.I. Pension Rise Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) Veterans of World War I and their widows would receive a 10 per cent increase in their pensions under a bill approved yesterday by the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee. Also approved was a bill to transfer jurisdiction over most national cemeteries to the Veterans Administration.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 President Nixon carried to Cal ifornia today his quest for a clear majority in the Presi dential election, portraying his opponent as one whose domes tic policies would lead to confiscation of wealth and whose defense proposals would be a move toward war.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: OneShot Hunters Zero In
description: LANDER, Wyo.Recently, a trio of Eastern outdoor writereditors came here de termined to demonstrate to their Western hosts that ex cellent markmanship is not confined lb the men of Marl boro Country.

title: Board of Beatrice Foods Votes 2for1 Stock Split
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) The board of directors of the Beatrice Foods Company ap proved today a twoforone stock split.

title: Never Tried Pot, Spock Says
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 27 (UPI) Dr. Benjamin Spock, the People's party Presidential can didate, advocates legalized ma rijuana but said today that he had never smoked it. Frankly, it's a little embarrassing, he said. If offered the chance, I wouldn't even know what to do. He spoke at Memphis State University.

title: KISSINGER'S TALKS SPUR PEACE RUMOR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Henry A. Kissinger arrived here from Paris tonight amid ru mors, which were strongly de nied by the White House, that there had been a breakthrough in Vietnam peace negotiations.

title: Reports of Progress at Paris Peace Talks Spark Advance
GENES ARE LINKED TO CANCER STUDY
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27  A Minneapolis scientist report ed here today that the genes from a frog cancer cell could be reprogramed to act like normal noncancerous genes and could be induced to differenti ate into a tadpole.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Whether they're period or modern in inspiration, the model rooms devised by Bar bara D'Arcy are still the most dramatic stage sets in town.

title: American Party Candidates Ruled Off Ballot in Illinois
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (UPI) The American party will nor have candidates on the Nov. 7 Illinois ballot.

title: Chicago Police Stage A Ticket Job Action
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (UPI) Yellow traffic tickets were handed out in force today as Chicago policemen fol lowed strict enforcement of traffic laws.

title: SENATE WOULD LET PENSIONERS EARN $3,000 EACH YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Senate voted today to al low the older worker to earn up to $3,000 a year without forfeiting any Social Security cash benefits.

title: U.S. NOW REQUIRES VISAS FOR TRANSIT BY MOST VISITORS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  The United States today im posed visa requirements for for eigners in transit through this country.

title: DANIEL E. GARDNER
description: DALLAS, Sept. 27Daniel Earl Gardner, who had been principal of the Riverdale Coun try Schools in New York City, died at his home here yester day. He was 82 years old.

title: Merger News
description: The Rank Organisation, Ltd., is planning to acquire for about $100.5million the 102.6 million remaining shares of Butlin's, Ltd., in which Rank already owns about 6.4 million shares of Britain's largest resort op erator.

title: Musicians at Radio City To Continue Wage Talks
description: Negotiators for Radio City Music Hall and its orchestra have agreed to continue bar gaining talks another week, sources close to the negotia tions said yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Nearly 200 labor leaders here from the building trades, the uniformed services, the long shoremen and the teamsters joined yesterday in forming a committee to reelect President Nixon, praising his handling of labor's problems and his efforts to achieve peace with honor in Vietnam.

title: Jews Ask Nixon to Bar Credits To Soviet Until Exit Taxes End
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The National Conference on Soviet Jewry, representing the major Jewish organizations in the United States, today de manded that the United States deny credits and trade conces sions to the Soviet Union so long as Soviet Jews were sub ject to extortionate emigra tion taxes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: While it is true that the candidacies of Richard Nixon and George McGov ern offer the voter a clear choice be, tween two disparate political and philosophical views, it is growing more evident that the choice is at best a melancholy one indeed.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 27Half an hour after the New York Giants depart for the day, Coach John Hooper leads his playforfun Vikings onto the practice field here at Upsala College.

title: Economic Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27In the midst of the technical com plexity involved in reforming the world monetary system, ordinary citizens may find it hard to understand the political struggle here at the Interna tional Monetary Fund. urious ly enough, what seems to be a sentimental and emotional sideshowthe is sue of whether Pi errePaul Schweitz er will be reap pointed managing director of the fund when his fiveyear term expires next yearsymbolizes the larger conflict.

title: Telephone Rate Rise Denied
description: BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP) The state's Department of Pub ?? Utilities today turned down the New England Telephone Company's request for an emer gency $61million rate increase. The decision announced by the department's chairman, John R. Verani, came suddenly fol lowing a daylong hearing. He said that the company had failed to show that an emer gency existed to justify the in crease.

title: Smithsonian Portrays History of Fight for Ballot
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) The long struggle of the land less, blacks, women, Indians and others to win their right to vote is portrayed in a new exhibition at the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Market Place: Executive Shuns Forecast on Net
Letters to the Editor
description: I am sitting at my desk listening to the music of bands of the first of this season's many parades. Ac companying the music is the screech ing of brakes and yells of drivers of cars caught in the snarl of traffic caused by the parade. Scores of New York's Finest are stationed at street corners and along the parade route.

title: Reducing Devices Called Ineffective
description: Eleanor Morello's right thigh was wrapped in a beige bandage yesterday. She was helping out at a press confer ence called by the Better Business Bureau of Metropol itan New York to blow the cover off socalled fraudu lent reducing devices.

title: LAID DISCUSSES RELEASED P.O.W.'S
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird refused today to rule out the possibility of courtmartial proceedings against any of the three American prisoners of war just released by North Vietnamese authorities.

title: BOMB SCARE DELAYS IND TRAIN IN QUEENS
description: Thousands of subway riders in Queens were delayed for more than an hour last night when power on the IND line was shut off between Roose velt Avenue and Continental Avenue in Forest Hills because of what the Transit Authority police described as an un founded bomb scare.

title: Cabaret: Lisa Kirk Stages a Comeback
description: Lisa Kirk has capped a long, painful fouryear strug gle back from an automobile accident that threatened to end her career with an en gagement at the Maisonette of the St. Regis Sheraton Hotel. She'll be there through Oct. 7 and she is dancing and singing as though nothing had ever happened.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27Carruth ersto give him a pseudonymis one of the richest men in America. It was, therefore, startling to discover him on Pennsylvania Avenue near the end of a long line waiting to be admitted to Republican campaign headquarters the other day.

title: Holiday on Ice Opens Its 28th Season at the Garden
description: The Program

title: AID FUNDS APPROVED BY A SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, (AP)  The Senate Appropriations Commit tee approved today a $2.8bil lion foreign aid appropriation for nonmilitary assistance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Times, on one and the same day (Sept. 22) published news and articles on the murder of a bridegroom in Brooklyn on June 22, details of the recent murder of Professor Wolf gang Friedmann, a declaration by Police Commissioner Murphy warning that the police are near bottom strength,

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Since only 5 per cent of the Soviet debt for lendlease will be repaid in cash, the balance should be used to pay the exit fees for educated Rus sians who wish to emigrate. At the currently establiShed rates this would ransom one to two million people and represent our best response to a noxious policy.

title: U.S. IS DROPPING ACTION ON SEALE
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP)  The Government announced to day that it would ask the United States District Court to dismiss contempt charges against Bobby Seale, the Black Panther leader who was an original defendant in the Chi cago Seven conspiracy trial.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept 27  Mrs. George McGovern campaigned in two states to day and managed to meet elderly citizens and pre schoolers and attend a private political luncheon as well as an outdoor rally in a lowkey series of appearances.

title: Murphy Warns Top Aides Fight on Corruption Lags
description: Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy told his commanders during two private meetings this week that despite some progress they still had failed to combat adequately cor ruption among their men.

title: ROBERT DOLAN, 64, COMPOSER, IS DEAD
description: WESTWOOD, Calif., Sept. 27 Robert Emmett Dolan, the stage, screen and television composer, conductor and pro ducer, died in his sleep ap parently of a heart attack last evening. He was 64 years old and had been living at the Cav alier Motel.

title: Taiwan Avoids Role Seen Protecting Status in Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 27 Stopping just short of deserting their table on the floor, the representatives of Taiwan have sought to make themselves in conspicuous at the meeting there this week of the World Bank and the Interna tional Monetary Fund.

title: 2 World Pace Marks Eclipsed at Red Mile
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 27 (AP)Ricci Reenie Time set two world records for 2 yearold pacers on a mile track today while winning the Meadow Land Pace on opening day at the Red Mile.

title: MAJOR WORKS BILL PASSED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)The Senate voted today to authorize more than $560 million in public work projects, almost all of it for flood control.

title: U.S. Monetary Ideas Prompt Heavy Dollar Selling in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Sept. 27  Heavy selling of dollars broke out in the Tokyo foreignexchange market today on fears of an other upward revaluation of the yen.

title: Port Notes
description: After nearly a century of guarding the port's health from an installation on a grassy waterside slope on Staten Island, the New York Quarantine Station has moved inland.

title: Film Festival Hopes To Survive Success
description: Success is the mother of troubles this year for the New York Film Festival, with tickets to all programs sold out more than a week in advance and emptyhanded fans clamoring for seats that do not exist or sending poisonpen notes to the fes tival's staff.

title: Shriver Advocates a New Department of Justice
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 27 Sargent Shriver today ac cused President Nixon of a de structive politicization of the concept of justice and proposed a new department of justice that would include a division to confront injustice wherever it is found.

title: Westchester Police Use Phone Hookup To Find 2 Saspects
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 27 (UPI)  Fast police work on the telephone last night led to the arrest of two men 10 minutes after they had allegedly robbed a local man of $20 and his car keys, the police said.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)  A bill designed to increase United States fortunes in future Olympic Games was introduced in the Senate today.

title: Won't Interfere, U.S. Says
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 27 (UPI) The United States Embassy here said today that it would not interfere with the expected stopover here to morrow morning of three re leased American prisoners of war.

title: $10.6Billion Housing Bill Killed by House Rules Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The $10.6billion omnibus housing bill was killed today by a vote of 9 to 5 in the House Rules Committee, and Congressional sources said its demise probably marked the end of an era in housing legis lation.

title: 7 Food Concerns Found in Violation Of the Health Code
3Way Plan Announced To Build New Housing
description: The First National City Bank, the New York Urban Coalition and the Tishman Realty Com pany have signed an agree ment to construct low and middleincome housing on a large scale in the city.

title: 9 HERE ACCUSED OF RELIEF FRAUD
description: Nine welfare recipients were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of having defrauded the Department of Social Serv ices of $35,000 by failing to disclose hidden financial assets.

title: Disaster Area Proclaimed
description: BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP)The Farmers Home Administration of the Department of Agricul ture has declared Massachu setts a natural disaster area because the wet, cool spring caused a loss of 35 per cent of the crops in the state. It is esti mated that farmers lost $80 million.

title: LAVELLE INQUIRY WIDENED TO NAVY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  The Senate Armed Services Committee, which has been in vestigating charges of unau thorized bombing of North Vietnam by the Air Force, has widened its inquiry to include allegations of illegal activities by the Navy.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: EWING TOWNSHIP, Sept. 27 The Federal Government is taking a second look at $400,000 grant for a community center awarded to this middle class suburb following dis closures that it may not qual ify for the money.

title: City Planning Drive To Get Street Holes Repaired Properly
description: The city's Transportation Administrator, Constantine SidamonEristoff, announced plans yesterday to crack down on companies that cut holes in the city's streets for repair work and do not fill them properly, when the work is done.

title: Fuld Suggests Sentencing By an Agency, Not Judges
description: The chief judge of the state suggested yesterday that it might be desirable to take the job of sentencing away from judges and give it to correc tion authorities or some other agency.

title: News Analysis
description: PARIS, Sept. 27The news of Norway's rejection of the Common Market hit Brussels while ministers of the bloc were deadlocked in another dreary allnight meeting and while technocrats were trying to explain the almost unex plainablewhat the deadlock was about. What was happen ing in Norway's rejection, and the possibility of a similar move by Denmark in a ref erendum next Monday, is a crisis of confi dence in a European Economic Community that has cemented peace and doubtless raised liv ing standards on this continent but has utterly failed to capture the imagination or even the in terest of most Europeans.

title: AFRICANS AT U.N. CRITICIZE BRITAIN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27  Representatives of African nations called today for Britain to involve black Rhodesians in planning for their country's independence.

title: Islander Coach Foresees a Long Season
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 27 Phil Goyette sat at the edge of his chair in the lobby of a nearby hotel this afternoon, a mainspring on the edge of be ing overwound. In just a few hours the team he coaches, the New York Islanders, were go ing to introduce the $28million Nassau Coliseum to hockey in an exhibition game against Goyette's former teammates, the New York Rangers.

title: Business Briefs
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 27 (UPI)  Australia's Wheat Board chairman, John Cass, announced today the sale of one million tons of wheat valued at $78million to China. The announcement followed the arrival in Hong Kong of a fourman Wheat Board delegation headed by Mr. Cass, which spent 10 days in China.

title: Mrs. Florence T. Taylor, 81, Of Child Labor Committee
description: Mrs. Florence Taylor, former director of publications for the National Child Labor Commit tee and former staff member of the National Association of Social Work, died of a heart attack Monday at her home, 171 West 12th Street. Her age was 81.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 27 (UPI)Mayor Richard G. Lugar of Indianapolis, a Republican, predicted today that President Nixon's present lead in the polls over Senator George McGovern would be reduced by Election Day, diminishing the chances of Republican control of the Senate.

title: $1 0.6Billion Housing Bill Killed by House Rules Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The $10.6billion omnibus housing bill was killed today by a vote of 9 to 5 in the House Rules Committee, and Congressional sources said its demise probably marked the end of an era in housing legis lation.

title: Midget Who Did Tours As Buster Brown Dies
description: HUGO, Okla., Sept. 27 (AP) Edmond Ansley, who trav eled the country for 27 years in the costume of the comic strip character Buster Brown to promote Buster Brown shoes for children, died last night in a Gainesville (Tex.) hospital, apparently of a heart attack. He was 84 years old.

title: Brazil Denies Military Drive Against Guerrillas in Jungle
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 27 (UPI)  A Brazilian Army spokesman today denied reports of a large military operation against a guerrilla band in the jungles of the Amazon River basin.

title: How to Decide When to Trade the Car
description: With the 1973 cars arriv ing in showrooms, many po tential buyers are trying, to decide whether this is the year to trade in their old cars. A recent study by the Federal Highway Administra tion has shed new light on how to calculate the best tradein time.

title: Iraq to Note Jewish Holidays
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Sept. 27 (AP)Iraq's Ruling Revolution ary Command Council has de clared Jewish religious holidays official, meaning that Govern ment offices and schools will close, the Baghdad radio said today. The station broadcast a message of thanks that it said Nour Basri, head of the 1,100 member Iraqi Jewish commu nity sent to the council.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The first of a projected series of nine halfhour television broadcasts, through which Sen ator George McGovern hopes to persuade the public of his fitness for the Presidency, will be seen on a national network at 8:30 P.M. Sunday.

title: LATE RALLY LIFTS PRICES ON AMEX
THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: FLORESVILLE, Tex., Sept. 28 (AP)Former Treasury Sec retary John B. Connally has canceled a speech in Bartles ville, Okla., tomorrow because of illness, it was reported to day. He has a terrible cold, said Beth Coleman, an aide.

title: QUAD CITIES OPEN HALTED BY STORM
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa, Sept. 28 (AP)  Jack Lewis and Don Iverson matched fourunderpar 67's for the firstround lead be fore a violent thunderstorm and a threat of a tornado forced suspension of play today in the first round of the $100,000 Quad Cities open tournament.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.7 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index for foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 123 from 122.3 last week.

title: REED IS THE MAN JETS MUST STOP
description: The Houston Oilers, an old foe in the former American Football League, occupied the attention of the New York Jets during their Shea Stadium workout yesterday.

title: Brazil Finds and Disarms Explosives Sent to Israelis
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 28 The Brazilian police said today that they intercepted two let ters rigged with explosive de vices mailed from Amsterdam to the Israeli consulates here and in Silo Paulo.

title: ROBBED CABBIES LEERY OF POLICE
description: The holdup murders of three drivers of gypsy cabs here in the last four weeks have come as no great surprise to the industry or the police, who say that gypsy drivers are the vic tims of many more crimes than are ever reported.

title: LETELLIER, ON 142, LEADS BY 2 SHOTS
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 28 Ron Letellier borrowed a put ter from a rival and used it so effectively today in the Metro polian open golf championship that he led by two strokes with a 36hole aggregate of 142.

title: JAILING DELAYED FOR D.C. TEACHERS
description: Hours before they were to be jailed, union leaders got a fourday reprieve yesterday from a Federal judge to give negotiators more time to end a teachers strike that forced the closing of all District of Columbia schools through at least Monday.

title: Amax Applies for Validation
description: American Metal Climax, Inc. (Amax), applied yesterday in Tokyo with the Japanese Gov ernment for validation for the Amax Japan Company, Ltd. The Japanese subsidiary would provide closer liaison and com munications with Japanese in dustries. Eiji Honda, president of Nichibei Boeki Company, Ltd., will be president of the new company with Takeshi Sakurauchi, former general manager of the Americas de partment in the Tokyo office of Mitsui & Company, Ltd., as executive vice president.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 28  State health inspection reports dis closed here tonight indicate that conditions in a number of New Jersey hospitals and nurs ing homes are extremely bad and that in at least one ma jor urban hospital there are dangerous violations of accept ed medical practices.
