title: ONE AIR INDUSTRY URGED FOR EUROPE
description: TULOUSE, France, Sept. 28  Britain today proposed the creation of a fully integrated European aircraft industry as the only way to compete with the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Baker's 152 Wins by Shot In Jersey Seniors' Golf
18 Injured as Tornado Hits Northern Illinois
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) Eighteen persons were in jured, none of them seriously, tonight when a tornado touch ed down in a residential area north of Chicago.

title: Freeport Takes Tuna Title
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Sept., 28 (AP)  The Freeport, L.I., Tuna Club captured the team championship yesterday on the third and final day of the president's invitation tuna tourney of this port. Twenty boats took part and Babylon, L.I., finished second.

title: Paintings Lost in Paris Drugstore Fire
description: PARIS, Sept. 28 A fire that burned out the building housing Le Drugstore on the Champs Elysees last night destroyed a collection of Eisenhower mem orabilia and five paintings by 20th century masters.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Although New York is one of the most liberal states in the union, twothirds of the New Yorkers interviewed in the latest Presidential campaign survey for The New York Times classified themselves as con servative or moderate.

title: KENYA, IN U.N., ASKS ACTION ON RHODESIA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28  Kenya's Foreign Minister asked the Security Council today for stronger economic sanctions against the whiteminority government at Rhodesia.

title: Egypt Reported to Have Received SwingWing Plane From Soviet and to Have Been Disappointed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Shortly before President An war elSadat ordered Russian pilots and military advisers to leave his country, Government analysts say, a swingwing fighterbomber never before seen outside the Soviet Union was delivered to Egypt.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 President Nixon ended a brief campaign trip today with a strong defense of his economic and foreign policies, then flew back to Washington.

title: A Children's Play Area With Some New Ideas Is Started in Central Park
description: A group of West Side parents will begin to see their dream of an innovative playground in Central Park take form today when work men start renovating the play area at 100th Street and Central Park West.

title: EINAR W. ANDERSEN
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. ?? Einar W. Andersen, chairman of the board of the Westport Bank and Trust Company, died today at his home here. He was 78 years old and lived at 72 Ludlow Road.

title: L.I. Case Brings an F.H.A.Reform Call
description: Recent indictments of em ployes of the Federal Housing. Administration in the regional office at Hempstead, L. I., were deplored yesterday by Rep resentative John S. Monagan, Democrat of Connecticut, as additional evidence of sicken ing manipulation of F.H.A. em ployes by builders and mort gage lenders.

title: Substantial Civilian Hiring On Police Force Expected
description: Mayor Lindsay is expected to announce today that he will increase substantially the number of civilians working for the Police Department in nonpolice jobs.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: WHAT DOES QUALITY LIFE INSURANCE COST? $100,000 Yearly Renew & Convert Term, annual Premium, age 40, ?? ?? Full details, ?? your age. ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? N. Y. ?? ??ADVT.

title: BRITON IS ELECTED TO KEY I.M.F. POST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28The new Committee of 20 that will negotiate reform of the world monetary system held its first meeting today and, despite United States opposition, elect ed a Briton, Jeremy Morse, an executive director of the Bank of England, to the key post of chairman of the deputies who will do the hard negoti ating.

title: AMERICAN PLACE WILL OPEN ROY. 2
description: The American Place Theater will open its season Nov. 2 with The Kid, a first play by Robert Coover. Jack Gel ber will direct. The author de scribes his work as a liturgi cal western with magic and music. Stanley Walden has composed the music.

title: Sadat Rejects Rogers Suggestion of Interim Suez Canal Accord
description: CAIRO, Sept. 28President Anwar elSadat today scorn fully. rejected the idea of an interim agreement to open the Suez Canal that was revived by Secretary of State William P. Rogers at the United Nations Monday.

title: Scribner Defends Board on Fuentes Appointment
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner said last night that he had found that Community School Board 1 on the Lower East Side had not acted illeg ally or improperly in appoint ing Luis Fuentes as district superintendent.

title: Thompson Makes a Giant Splash Now
description: Rocky Thompson was catching his share of passes in the New York Giants' workout at Upsala yester day, although his main job is returning kickoffs. But. there's no doubt that Rocky catches getter than he did a year ago.And that's no accident. He worked hard at his weakness as soon as he showed up at training camp in 1971, slated to become a wide receiver, sight unseen. That experi ment was abandoned quick ly, but he kept getting hours and hours of practice, and after the season he went at it in his own way.

title: POWELL PROPOSED BUSINESS DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Lewis F. Powell Jr., in a con fidential memorandum written two months before his nomina tion to the Supreme Court, urged the United States Cham ber of Commerce to mount a campaign to counter criticism of the free enterprise system in the schools and the news mediaparticularly television.

title: LEWIS A. DREYER. 57, A COPYRIGHT LAWYER
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 28 Lewis A. Dreyer, a leading copyright lawyer, who formerly served as executive vice presi dent and general counsel of Hill and Range Songs, Inc., died Tuesday in Huntington Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in Huntington Station.

title: Chicago Police Chief Vows Punishment for Job Action
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28Police Superintendent James B. Con lisk Jr. promised disciplinary action today against those Chi cago policemen engaged in a traffic ticket job action in sup port of demands including one that they be granted collective bargaining.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 28New Jersey, which has more peo ple per acre and probably more decibels to bombard them than any other state, took anther step today to ward quieting things down when Governor Cahill named nine members to the Noise Control Council.

title: EXPILOT CHARGES NAVY ORDERED HIM TO BOMB IN NORTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 A former Navy, pilot told the Senate Armed Services Com mittee today that pilots aboard his aircarft carrier off Vietnam in late 1971 and early 1972 had been instructed to bomb tar gets in North Vietnam regard less of whether they were fired upon first.

title: Nets Top Squires, 108102, In First Preseason Victory
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Sept. 28Bill Melchionni and John Roche scored 23 points each and Jim Chones scored 18 as the New York Nets defeated the Virginia Squires, 108102, for their first preseason victory. The Nets had lost to the Dallas Chapar rals in their only other pre season test.

title: DIAPOULOS GUILTY OF A GUN CHARGE
description: Peter Diapoulos, alleged bodyguard of the late Joseph Gallo, was convicted last night in State Supreme Court in Man hattan of having possessed an unloaded gun, a misdemeanor, after Gallo was murdered last April.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $864,000,000, up 4 per cent from the yearearlier level of $827,000,000. Total re tail store sales were about $8, 639,000,000, up 8 per cent from the yearearlier $8,030,000000.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On behalf of our respective organiza tions, we wish to commend your edi torial Pollsters and Prophets (Sept. 22). All responsible practitioners would agree with your reminder that polls reflect public attitudes at the given moment and are not to be taken as forecasts.

title: 3 Freed P.O.W.'s Return; Dispute Flares Over Leave
description: The three American pilots freed by North Vietnam and their escort of antiwar leaders arrived from Copenhagen last night at Kennedy International Airport, and the three  after a 25minute shouting match aboard the parked Scandina vian Airlines System plane were taken by Defense Depart ment officials to military hos pitals.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 28 (AP)Authorities in Uru guay announced today that they had intercepted letter bombs addressed to local Jews.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 16.2 billion tonmiles, 8.9 per cent above the 1961 level. Carloadings were 554,500, up 6 per cent. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., re ported intercity truck tonnage was 5.9 per cent above last year.

title: Cambodian Election Won By ProGovernment Party
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 28 (AP)The proGovernment Social Republican party won an expected clean sweep of 32 seats in the upper house of Parliament, according to offi cial figures for the Sept. 17 election, published here today.

title: McGovern Wins a Poll
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (UPI) A straw poll taken yesterdar at the 15th annual Illinois states convention of the American Federation of Labor and Con gress of Industrial Organiza tions showed that Senator George McGovern was favored over President Nixon, 864 to 90.

title: Teamsters Get New Offer From Building Contractor
description: Building contractors here hav made a new proposal to ?? members of Local 282 ?? the teamsters union, it was re ported yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ?? paper clip fashioned into a tri angle. The official emblem of the New Jersey State Police is a triangle.

title: Personalities: Fete for a Feat
description: Cheryl Toussaint was given a surprise party by friends and presented with a special citation by Dr. James M. Hester, the president of New York University, last night. Who is Cheryl Toussaint? She was a silvermedal winner at the recent Olympic Games in Munich, West Germany, where she ran the third leg on the women's 1,600meter relay team. Miss Toussaint, a mathematics major, is a junior at N.Y.U.'s Washing ton Square Arts and Science campus.

title: HIGH CITY OFFICIAL IN ETHICS INQUIRY
description: A high official in the Lindsay administration is also a top offi cer and major shareholder of a small, familyowned company that has sold the city $654,000 worth of equipment, mostly during his tenure in office, it was learned yesterday.

title: BOMB SCARE DELAYS EL AL PLANE IN PARIS
description: TEL AVIV, Sept 28 (AP)  El Al officials and French police officers said a false bomb alarm delayed an El Al jumbo jet at Paris for about an hour today. They denied a report here that a bomb had been found aboard the plane.

title: Schools Springing From Old Factories
description: Next month, when tenants and pupils start moving into a new 33story building on East 87th Street, between Park and Lexington, it will mark one more advance in the national movement that is altering longheld no tions of what a school build ing is supposed to be.

title: Cleveland Averts Walkout By Sewer and Power Union
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (AP) Tentative agreement was re ported late tonight, heading off a strike that could have crippled Cleveland's sewage treatment, water purification and Munici pal Light Plant opeartions.

title: Both Mrs. Ryan and Mrs. Abzug Pick Up Backing in 20th District
description: As more Democrats chose sides, both Representative Bella S. Abzug and Mrs. Priscilla Marbury Ryan picked up sup port yesterday in their contest for the Democratic nomination for the House of Representa tives from the 20th Congres sional District.

title: CHINA AND JAPAN AGREE TO RESUME DIPLOMATIC TIES
description: PEKING, Friday, Sept. 29 Japan and China today ended an era of conflict dating from 1937 with the signing of a joint communiqu establishing diplo matic relations.

title: 4 Britons Crowd Top After 36 Holes Of $134,000 Golf
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland, Sept. 28 (UPI)  Four Britons moved clear of overseas challengers today as Europe's richest golf tournament, the $134,000 John Player Classic, reached the halfway stage.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STATELINE, Nev., Sept. 28 (AP)The junior middle weight title fight scheduled for tonight between Denny Moyer and Ernie (Indian Red) Lopez, Was postponed.

title: 7 Are Indicted Here In Drug Operation In South America
description: NEWARK, Sept. 28  Seven persons from the New York area were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to establish a co caine factory in Colombia and smuggle the drug into the Unit ed States.

title: CHINA AND JAPAN AGREE TO RESUME DIPLOMATIC TIES
description: PEKING, Friday, Sept. 29 Japan and China today ended an era of conflict dating from 1937 with the signing of a joint communique establishing diplo matic relations.

title: City Seeks MiniTerminal for Buses
description: The City Transportation Administration yesterday dis closed a plan to build a mini terminal on Second Avenue between 58th and 60th Streets for express buses to and from Queens.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It was billed as a symposium on gambling jointly sponsored by the National District Attorneys Association and the celestial hierarchy of professional baseball, foot ball, basketball and hockey, which translates simply as Czars Against Sin. Lined up in a forbidding phalanx of rectitude were, from the left: William Cahn, the Nassau County D.A. who is past president of the NDAA and chair man of its gambling committee; Bob Carlson, commissioner of the American Basketball Association; Pete Rozalle; pontiff of the National Football League; Carol S. Vance, current president of the NDAA from Houston; Bowie Kuhn, supreme being of baseball; J. Walter Kennedy, archdeacon of the National Basketball Association, and Don Ruck, vicar of Clarence Campbell, the high priest of hockey. They sat shoulder to shoulder at a long table and the shoulders were faultlessly tailored. There was a slightly abandoned splash of scarlet in Walter Kennedy's necktie, but rags are royal raiment when worn for virtue's sake, and nowhere this side of the College of Cardinals could you encounter more solid righteousness yesterday than in the gathering in the Plaza.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I.You're not an economist, you're no expert, you have no degree, you're no big wheel, but you have some pretty strong feelings about the economy. You have no cre dentials, so why would anyone be interested in your views about the economy? Does it matter that you've been shopping for thirty years? Prob ably not. Some women have been shop ping for fifty years, and are even more frustrated.

title: PANEL RESUBMITS VETOED H.E.W. BILE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  The Senate Appropriations Com mittee, in the political battle over a vetoed appropriations bill for health, education and wel fare, sought today to shift back to President Nixon the burden of deciding which social pro grams should be given budget. ary cuts.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  The Government official respon sible for the decision to grant a bank charter to a Minnesota group that included major con tributors to the Nixon cam paign denied today that that decision had been taken with unusual speed.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS WAIL ST. REFORMS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) A House Commerce subcom mittee reached unanimous agreement today on terms of a sweeping reform bill intended to resolve a securitiesindustry paperwork problem by elimi nating stock certificates.

title: More Politicians Are Arrested in the Philippines
description: MANILA, Sept. 28  More prominent politicians were ar rested today in President Ferdi nand E. Marcos's drive to rid the Philippines of corrupt of ficials and their guns, suppress crime and combat subversion against his Government.

title: Court Confusion Decried
description: A prominent Brooklyn judge called upon the State Legisla ture yesterday to cut markedly into the power of judges to sentence defendants, saying that the whole bench agrees.

title: EXAGENT COMMENTS ON WATERGATE CASE
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 28  Al fred C. Baldwin 3d, who al legedly provided information to the Federal grand jury that indicted seven men in the Watergate bugging case, was interviewed yesterday for the first time since the indictments were issued, but he refused to discuss specifics of the case.

title: SOVIET GRAIN DEAL IS CALLED A COUP
description: The Soviet Union's recent purchase of more than $1bil lion worth of American wheat, feed grains and soybeans, the biggest grain deal in history, appears to have been a remark able coup for the buyers from Moscow.

title: F.T.C. AIDE UPHOLDS COCACOLA ON CLAM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)A Federal Trade Com mission judge has dismissed a complaint that the CocaCola Company, and its advertising agency made false claims, about the nutritive value of HiC fruit drink, it was announced today.

title: BUS DRIVER HELD IN I.R.A. GUN PLOT
description: A New York City bus driver who was linked to the Irish Republican Army was arrested early yesterday and charged with the illegal purchase of more than four dozen rifles and carbines.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)A bill to centralize the borrowing operations of various Federal agencies through a Federal financing bank was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee. At present, such agencies independently issue bonds and similar securities and sell them in the general financial markets.

title: GALBREATH CLOSES DEAL FOR HIALEAH
description: MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 28 (UPI) The longrumored sale of Hia leah Race Track to financier and sportsman John W. Gal breath was consummated to day.

title: William H. Hillmann Dies; Parks Department Designer
description: William H. Hillmann, a mas ter craftsman of the Parks De partment who helped design and reproduce rustic shelters as part of the restoration pro gram of Central Park Lake, died Tuesday of a heart attack at the Eastern Long Island Hos pital, Greenport. He was 63 years old and lived at 150 Grant Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am writing as a Vietnam veteran in response to the Sept. 15 OpEd article by John O'Neill. Mr. O'Neill writes of Senator McGovern's plan to deprive the South Vietnamese people of their freedom.

title: Airline Court Fight Develops on Rule Allowing Everyone to Fly by Charter
description: A bitter legal battle began to develop yesterday between scheduled and nonscheduled airlines over a new Civil Aero nautics Board regulation that will permit all Americans to fly on lowcost charter flights.

title: Metropolitan to Auction 12 Paintings
description: The Metropolitan Museum will sell 12 paintings from its collections on Oct. 25, it was announced Wednesday by Sotheby Parke Bernet, the auc tion gallery that will handle the sale. Thomas P. F. Roving, di rector of the museum, said yes terday that the paintings, 11 from the impressionist collec tion and one by Odilon Redon, are the first of 135 paintings slated for sale in the near fu ture. Arrangements for the dis posal of the remaining 123 have not been completed.

title: U.S. Finds Increase in FarmerConsumer Price Gap
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) A Government report showed today that supermarkets wid ened the beef price gap between farmers and consumers to a record margin in August, thus failing to pass along to house wives recent declines in cattle prices.

title: Mrs. Sage and Mrs. Cici Gain L. I. Title Golf Final
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 28 Mrs. Andrew Sage of Piping Rock, the medalist, and Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook, the 1959 Metropoliton hampion advanced to the final of the women's Long Island match play golf championship today at Fresh Meadow.

title: Putting Down the Brush And Painting on a Loom
description: What do Garry Moore, the television personality; Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank; Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the David, Winthrop and Nelson Rocke fellers have in common?

title: The Restaurant's Expensive, But Lacks a Soul
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and d cor (four triangles to none).

title: Clerk of Cook County Is Indicted in Bribery
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28Ed ward J. Barrett, who is Cook County Clerk and has been a power in Illinois Democratic politics for more than 40 years, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of income tax eva sion, mail fraud and bribery in connection with the county government's purchase of voting machines.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
Elliott Perry, a Leading Expert On 19thCentury Stamps, Dead
description: Elliott Perry, a foremost researcher of facets of 19th century United States stamps, died Wednesday night at Muh enberg Hospital, Plainfield, N.J., where he had long been a pa tient. He lived in Westfield, N.J., and was 87 years old.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Harold John Adonis Sr., a key figure in a gambling investigation more than 20 years ago, was indicted on charges of fraudulently selling unregistered securities for PolyCraft, Inc., of Morris Plains. Thomas Light, a neighbor of Adonis in Roxbury Township, and the company were named in similar charges. Adonis was executive clerk to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll from 1947 to 1949. In 1950, Willie Moretti, an underworld leader, was quoted as saying that he had paid Adonis $12,000 a month to protect gamblers.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: Las Vegas, Nev.Freddie Jones, 144 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Pepper Romero, 144, Anaconda, Mont., 5 rounds.

title: Vicinal Troupe From Belgium Offers Lunapark
description: The title of the Theatre Laboratoire Vicinal play Tramp could mean both tramp steamer and hobo. Lunapark, which the Bel gian company is performing this week at La Moma, could refer to an amusement park, the moon and, if you like, an asylum. The work is nonin sistent on levels of interpre tation.

title: McGovern Pledges Increase in Funds To Help the Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Senator George McGovern, de claring that the 1972 Presi dential election was a referen dum on the future of our cities, pledged today to re verse the priorities of the Nixon Administration.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Is it possible, now that there no longer are American combat deaths in Vietnam to report, to concern our selves with human combat deaths in Vietnam caused by Americans?

title: About Pro Football
description: The Giants and Jets are favorites against Philadelphia and Houston teams searching for their first victories. The Jets' game will be televised from the Astrodome begin ning at 2 P.M., Sunday, on Channel 4. The Giants meet the Eagles on Monday night, Channel 7, 9 P.M. Other games on tele vision Sunday are Miami at Minne sota, Channel 4, 4 P.M., and Washington at New England, Channel 2 at 1.

title: Insurance Woman Elected
description: The Women Leaders Round Table, an organization of women who have sold at least $250,000 of life insurance a year, an nounced yesterday that Mrs. Mary E. Fort had been named president. She is an agent in Chevy Chase, Md., for the Amer ican National Life Insurance Company.

title: Souffle for Dessert Served in Oranges
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: A Palestinian Leader Promises More Terrorism
description: BEIRUT, Sept. 28  An im portant Palestinian commando leader told a cheering audience of Arabs today that terrorist actions against Israel were go ing to continue all over the world.

title: BOAT SHOW OPENS TODAY ON SOUND
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 28  The North Atlantic Boat Show doesn't open to the pub lic until 1 P.M. tomorrow, but the producers are so confident of its success that they have announced the dates for the next three years.

title: Team Canada Wins
description: Team Canada won the hockey series with the Soviet Union, taking the final game, 65, yesterday in Moscow. The decisive goal was scored by Paul Henderson Canada won four of eight and one was tied. Details on Page 49.

title: PAUL L. BRANDES
description: HENDERSONVILLE, N. C., Sept. 28Paul L. Brandes, re tired assistant vice president of the First National City Bank of New York, died here yesterday at Pardee Memorial Hospital aster a brief illness while on vacation. He was 72 years old and lived in Deerfield Beach, Ha.

title: TV: N.B.C.'s Friday Schedule of Varied Offerings
description: Apart from Sanford and Son at 8 o'clock, the rest is new this season on the Friday evening schedule of the Na tional Broadcasting Company. At 8:30 there's The Little People, at I) Ghost Story and at 10 Banyon.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH, DRINK DEWAR'S William Lawson's 86.8 Proof BIended Scotch Whiskies. Imported by Palmer & Lord Ltd. ??, N. Y.Advt.

title: Eban Tells U.N. Israel Is Flexible Regarding Mideast Boundaries
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28  Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel reiterated before the General Assembly today that Israel did not seek to perpetuate the present cease fire line in the Middle East or to freeze the situation as it now stands.

title: NORBERT BROWN, AIDE IN HOUSING
description: Norbert H. Brown, a retired public relations executive who specialized in housing, died yes terday in Columbus Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 521 East 14th Street.

title: Canada Beats Soviet Six, Wins Series
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28  With 34 seconds to go the Cana dian professional ice hockey team scored a dramatic goal tonight and won the deciding game in the series against the Soviet Union, 65.

title: Cards Keep Schoendienst
description: ST. LOUIS. Sept. 28 (UPI) Red Schoendienst, signed to day a oneyear contract for the 1973 season with the St. Louis Cardinals. It will be his ninth season as manager.

title: Pacific Group Attack Tests
description: APIA, Western Samoa, Sept. 27Pacific island leaders meet ing here have accused France of polluting the sea and en dangering vital fish resources at Mururoa Atoll in French Polynesia.

title: BREMER TERM CUT BY 10 YEARS TO 53
description: UPPER MARLBORO, Md., Sept. 28 (Reuters)Ten years were dropped today from the 63year sentence imposed on Arthur Herman Bremer, who was convicted of shooting Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama and three other persons at a political rally in Maryland in May.

title: U.S. Reports One Killed In War Action in Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 28 (UPI)One Ameri can was killed in war action in Indochina last week, United States military spokes men said today.

title: Yamaha Is Issued Rights To Wankel Rotary Engine
description: NECKARSULM, West Ger many, Sept. 28 (AP)Yamaha, the Japanese maker of motor cycles, has obtained license rights to build Wankel rotary engines, Audi NSU Auto Union, AG, and Wankel, G.m.b.H., re ported today.

title: Inquiry on Mafia Cases
description: The New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime will hold hearings next month on the lenient treatment of or ganizedcrime figures in state courts, Senator John H. Hughes, the committee's chairman, said yesterday.

title: Stock Tables to Carry PriceEarnings Ratio
description: Starting Monday, the stock market tables that provide the annual price range of securities will also include one of Wall Street's favorite investment guidesthe price earnings ratio.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 28Odyssey House, long regarded as one of the state's most successful drugrehabilitation centers, may be forced to stop operations this week because it has run out of money.

title: Weekend Fishing Picture in Area
description: AREA AFishermen were generally kept ashore yester day because of 25milean hour winds. Earlier in the week blues were running in good numbers and quality around Barnegat Light and the Klondike. Weakfish, re sponding to squid and dia mond jigs, are plentiful off the beach at Barnegat, as are fluke. Sea bass and porgies are reported in good numbers about six miles off Brielle, N. J., crabbing is excellent in Barnegat Bay.

title: Chapter XI Arrangement Is Sought by MillerWohl
description: The MillerWohl Company, Inc., a leading operator of ap parel specialty stores and dis count stores, yesterday filed a petition for an arrangement un der the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Books of The Times
description: The distinctive wrinkles in W. H. Auden's face are almost as famous as those of his poetry. Though he is only 64, his physiog nomy is like a map of our century, tracing in its folds and convolutions the ironies of our history. Here you can see the imprint of the winces, grimaces and the occasional grins of the man of sensibility who has been forced to live through sixanda half decades of rude reversal, who refused to run away from them and instead pre pared a face to meet the faces that he'll meet. His face, like his poetry, bears tes timony to the wear and tear of the 20th century. In his recent book on Igor Stravin sky, Robert Craft reports the com poser as remark ing, on greeting Auden one day, that soon we'll have to smooth him out to see who it is.

title: Why a OnceIndulgent Judge Now Demands Mandatory Jail Terms
description: I didn't want to be a hang ing judge.

title: Maine Inmates to Vote
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 28 (AP) Secretary of State Joseph T. Edgar today ordered the print ing of special ballots extending voting rights in the upcoming Presidential election to incar cerated persons, He said he was responding to a complaint from an attorney with Pine Tree Legal Assistance, Inc., who un successfully tried to register five inmates at the Maine State Prison who previously resided in Portland.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Peter Iselin pleads for the real estate owners' right to be relieved of taxes on capital gain on sales, because they are the result of inflation. In the case he mentioned, a $10,000 investment has increased to $27,325 in thirty years due to inflation. [Letter Sept. 15.]

title: U.S. Water Official Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton accepted today the resignation of H. Garland Hershey, 66 years old, director of the Office of Water Resources Research. No succes sor has been named.

title: Topper Estimates Loss
description: The Topper Corporation, a toy company, said yesterday that preliminary figures showed that its deficit net worth was substantially more than pre viously indicated. Earlier the company said it expected to show a 1971 loss of between $10million and $15million.

title: Notes on People
description: Former Gov. Raymond P. Shafer of Pennsylvania was named winner of the New York City Council of Churches' 1972 Family of Man award. Mr. Shafer, chairman of the National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse, is being honored especially for his leadership in the world's ef fort to better understand and combat drug abuse. He will receive the award at a din ner here Nov. 2.

title: Mass Killings Laid to Foe
description: SAIGON, Sept. 28  The Saigon Government charged to day that Communist troops killed hundreds of inhabi tants of the villages of Nangan and Ducquang in the embattled province of Quangngai last Fri day.

title: U.S. Team at Chess Olympics Defeats Sweden as Finals Begin
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28The United States team has defeated Sweden 2 to 1 in the opening match of the finals in the chess Olym pies here.

title: U.N. STUDY CITES ATEST EFFECTS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28A scientific commit tee on atomic radiation has found a significant increase in the radioiodine levels in milk in the Southern Hemisphere since France's 1970 and 1971 nuclear tests in the Pacific.

title: Theater: City Center Company Makes Debut With The School for Scandal
description: The City Center Acting Company is the newest con stituent of the New York City Center, and it opened its first season of plays in repertory at the Good Shep herdFaith Church at Lincoln Center last night. It is wel come but to some will seem a strangely familiar new comer. For this season's City Center Acting Company is last seasons Juilliard Acting Ensemble.

title: Spectacular Navajo Blanket Opens
description: The exhibition called The Navajo Blanket, which opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum, is an event of enormous interest and appeal. Seventyfour works of the most breath taking design have been brought together in a show that is at once a revelation of something unexpected and a confirmation of something familiar.

title: Tokyo Says Taiwan Treaty Is Ended
description: TOKYO, Sept. 29 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira said today that Japan's 1952 peace treaty with Nation alist China had lost the reason for its existence and has been terminated.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There are some very strange things happening in this energyshortage pic ture that need explaining to the Amer ican public.

title: Shareholders Approve Hayden Stone Inc. Name
description: Shareholders of C.B.W.L. Hayden. Stone, Inc., voted at the annual meeting yesterday to change the firm's name to Hayden Stone Inc. The firm was created by the merger two years ago of Cogan, Berlind Weill & Levitt with Hayden, Stone & Co.

title: Laotian Officials Voice Optimism Over the Prospects for Peace
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 28 Laotian Government officials have begun expressing opti mism over the prospects for a negotiated settlement of the Laotian war following the lat est exchange of messages with the leader of the proCommu nist Pathet Lao, Prince Sou phanouvong.

title: Retreat on Hijacking
description: American efforts to promote strong international action against terrorism, including aerial hijacking, could be seriously compromised if Congress settles for the emas culated antihijacking bill that was approved by the House Commerce Committee this week.

title: Washington Supreme Court Ends Death Penalty in State
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Sept. 28 (AP)  The Washington State Supreme Court struck down today state laws allowing capi tal punishment, saying they are unconstitutional under a recent United States Supreme Court ruling.

title: Substantial Civilian Hiring On Police Force Expected
description: Mayor Lindsay is expected to announce today that he will increase substantially the number of civilians working for the Police Department in nonpolice jobs.

title: WILLIAM MADDOX, CAREER DIPLOMAT
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 28 Dr. William P. Maddox, a for mer State Department official and Foreign Service Officer, died yesterday in Princeton Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 20 Merritt Lane in Rocky Hill.

title: NO LETUP IN RAIDS ON FOE REPORTED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Sept. 29 (AP)American fighterbombers attacked North Vietnam's transportation system and military depots Wednesday with more than 300 raids for the third successive day, the United States command re ported yesterday.

title: Ungracious Welcome
description: With every passing day, it becomes more unmistak ably evident that the American prisoners of war have become the pawns of the rival propaganda machines in Hanoi and in Washington. The act of releasing some captives, and particularly of giving credit for the trans action to the American antiwar movement, is obviously a calculated political move by North Vietnam.

title: Wall St. Hiring Policy Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The Securities and Exchange Commission and the private organizations that regulate stockbrokers were asked to day to force all brokerage firms to adopt nondiscrimi natory employment policies.

title: WESTINGHOUSE GETS A CONTRACT AWARD
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday receipt of a contract valued at about $200million to supply the major equipment for a new nuclear power plant to be built by the Commonwealth Edison Company.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your criticism of the wisdom of Senator McGovern's articulating his position on aid to nonpublic schools and on the right of teachers to strike before assemblies of parochial school students and teachers' unions seems to me to be very apt indeed. Signifi cantly your editorial appeared on the very day that your news columns recorded that Senator McGovern had taken the occasion of his meeting with the leaders of various Jewish organizations to announce that he would vote against a measure in the Senate to grant mostfavoredna tion trading status to the Soviet Union because of its inhumane treat ment of Soviet Jews wishing to emi grate to Israel.

title: ExGraft Unit Head Held Guilty of Lying About a Bribe Offer
description: Capt. Philip J. Foran, former head of the police unit assigned to the City Department of In vestigation, was found guilty yesterday of falsely denying that a policeman had informed him about a $300 bribe offer from a gambler.

title: SUPPORT OF LABOR SOUGHT BY SHRIVER
description: DETROIT, Sept. 28Sargent Shriver urged a national meet ing of automobile union lead ers today to remember labor's needs in the upcoming election when they return to their plants around the country.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 28  Two Union City commissioners who were part of a reform ticket that beat an entrenched Democratic organization in city elections in 1970 were indicted today by a special Hudson County grand jury on charges of misconduct and conspiracy.

title: State Ballot Law's Legality Challenged by Third Party
description: The American Independence party challenged yesterday the constitutionality of New York State's election law requiring at least 20,000 signatures to get a nominee on the ballot.

title: FRANCOISE DURR GAINS AT PHOENIX
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 28 (AP)The field for the quarter final round in the Virginia Slims  Phoenix Thunderbirds women's tennis tournament was completed today withvic tories by Mrs. Nancy Gunter of San Angelo, Tex., Franoise Durr of France and Wendy Overton of Ormond Beach, Fla.

title: China Lets Westerners Enter Imperial Palace and Tombs
description: Access to the Imperial quarters in Peking's Forbidden City and to the sealed Ming Tombs has been granted a TV team from the National Broad casting Company, filming a documen tary produced by Lucy Jarvis. It is the first time the Communist Govern ment has granted western newsmen permission to film these interiors.

title: Hanoi Denies a Paris Accord Is Nearing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Hanoi charged today that an American propaganda machine is trying to give the impres sion that the United States and North Vietnam are getting closer in peace talks held in Paris.

title: HIGH CITY OFFICIAL IN ETHICS INQUIRY
description: A high official in the Lindsay administration is also a top offi cer and major shareholder of a small, familyowned company that has sold the city $654,000 worth of equipment, mostly during his tenure in office, it was learned yesterday.

title: LATE SPURT SENDS MARKET UP AGAIN
description: A late rally in the last half hour of trading enabled the stock market to post a good gain yesterday for the second consecutive session in slightly steppedup trading.

title: No Progress at Paris
description: PARIS, Sept. 28The 161st session of the Vietnam peace talks was held here today, with no progress reported.

title: Talks Set on Size Of Hotel Near Site Of Kennedy Library
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 28  The developer of a Holiday Inn that is to rise next to the planned John F. Kennedy Memorial Library here is expected to meet next week with the City Manager, John H. Corcoran, in an effort to resolve a dispute over the projected 19story hotel.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert L. Stone has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Hertz Corporation, effective Oct. 9. He succeeds the late Ronald J. Perman, who died this month.

title: CARLTON FANS NO.303 IN PHILS 21 VICTORY
A City Strike Ends
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Sept. 28 (UPI)City employes, including policemen, went on strike for 10 hours yesterday, returning to work because the City Council promised to try to find funds for the workers' increased pay demands. The strike was called after voters rejected a 1cent sales tax that would have fi ?? the pay raises.

title: 5 Suspects Plead Not Guilty In Virgin Islands Murders
description: ST. CROIX, V. I. Sept. 28 (AP)  Five men pleaded not guilty today to charges of mur der and armed robbery in con nection with the slaying of eight persons three weeks ago at the Fountain Valley Golf Club here.

title: Market Place:
description: If you think the current bull market suffers from tired blood, your thinking squares with that of a bril liant friend of ours in Wall Street.

title: A Law on Bootleg Cigarettes Is Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Legislation sought by New York State to make the bootlegging of cigarettes a Federal crime was rejected today as pre mature by the Justice Depart ment.

title: WASHINGTON
description: The Communist leaders in Hanoi keep on misjudging American public opinion. They seem to believe that if they release three U.S. prisoners to antiwar and antiNixon propagandists, while holding on to the other pris oners, the American people will be impressed by their generosity and turn to George McGovern in the election as a way to end the war and bring all the American prisoners home.

title: Evidence of Increasing Confidence in Dollar Appears in Report
description: The pace of monetary expan sion slowed slightly last week, the Federal Reserve System re ported yesterday, while at the same time there were contin ued signs of strength of the dollar on world financial mar kets.

title: WHITE SNAPS TIE WITH A HOME RUN
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Factory Workers' Earnings Drop

title: STEWART OPPOSED AS JETPORT SITE
description: An environmentalists' group and the Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority exchanged charges yesterday over the scope of the. M.T.A.'s plans for future expansion of Stewart Air Force Base near Newburgh.

title: China Seeks Japan Steel
description: TOKYO, Sept. 28 (Reuters) A Chinese steel buying mission will visit Japan early next month to negotiate for an ad ditional 500,000 tons of steel products, the Japan Interna tional Trade Promotion Asso ciation announced today.

title: Senate Votes Funds For Economic Aid; Total $2.8Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)  The Senate passed a $2.8billion appropriation bill for foreign economic aid today by a vote of 44 to 31.

title: Commerce Group Campaigns for Use Of Recycled Paper
description: To help solve the staggering solidwaste problem, the New York Chamber of Commerce has opened a campaign aimed to get more corporations to make larger use of recycled paper.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Conference Board said yesterday that its latest attitude survey, taken in July and August, showed that there was a pickup of optimism among consumers that was reflected in their opinions about the economy and in their plans for purchasing cars, homes and major appliances.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP)  Britain's staterun coal industry today announced its worst results since it came under Government control 26 years ago. The National Coal Board's annual report recorded a loss for the year ended last March of $384.7million. Derek Ezra, the board's chair man, said the industry expected to have another $245 million loss by the end of the current financial year.

title: BOMBING IN BELFAST DESTROYS 3 STORES
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 28Three men carried a sofa stuffed with 200 pounds of explosives into a furniture shop in the center of Belfast today while posing as moving men.

title: SHOP TALK
description: I don't go by designers, but this Givenchy fits me well, said Mrs. Felix Doppelt. She was examining the front and back views of the sandwichboard dresssleeves and sides black, front and back panels whitein the mirrors of her fitting room. The dress is $48.

title: Bridge:
description: The semifinal stage of the playoff matches to determine the 1973 North American in ternational team begins to night in Memphis with New York strong represented.The Old Guard of American tournament expertise is rep resented by George Rapee, Bill Grieve and Edgar Kap lan, all of New York; Norman Kay of Philadelphia and Lew Mathe and Don Krauss of Los Angeles. Their opponents are the Young Guard, the Preci sion team including Steve Altman, Gene Neiger, Alan Sontag, Joel Stuart and Peter Weichsel, all of New York, and Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President addressed the National Can cer Conference in Los An geles and returned to Wash ington in the evening.

title: Black Group Cancels March
description: CHICAGO, Sept 28 (AP) Leaders of Operation PUSH, a black organization, canceled plans today for a march through Mayor Richard J. Daley's neigh borhood to dramatize demands that Voter registration booths be set up at the group's expo sition. They feared the march might divert attention from the exposition's theme, which is education.

title: LEWIS IN LEAD DEBUT AS THE MET'S ROMEO
description: It has been a venerable rule of thumb at the Metropolitan Opera that comprimario and supporting singers do not grad uate to starring roles. Perhaps this, too, will change with the new regime: the Romeo in Gou nod's Romeo et Juliette Wednesday night was William Lewis, the Tulsaborn tenor who made his debut at the house nearly 15 years ago, but had yet to land a lead.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 28 (AP)  Guerrillas tossed a powerful bomb into the Dungannon home of the sister of Bernadette Devlin last night, the police said today.

title: Higher Plane Loans Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) A Senatepassed bill provid ing a $20million rise in the limit on federally guaranteed loans for aircraft companies was approved by the House Commerce Committee today. The legislation, accepted on voice vote, would raise the current $10million ceiling to $30million.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Sept. 28If Rutgers accumulates three rolls of film against Princeton Saturday, it will probably come out on top. That's the way it was last week when the Scarlet beat Lehigh and filled three rolls that got rave reviews from the coaching staff.

title: CHARTER IS OPPOSED ON ITS L.I. BANK PLAN
description: The Charter New York Cor poration, the $6.2billion parent company of the Irving Trust Company and numerous other banks in New York, has run in to sharp local opposition to its plan to take over the $52mil lion First National Bank of Glen Head, L. I.

title: Making It a Contest
description: While state electoral law unfortunately precludes the holding of a special primary in which rankandfile Democrats might choose a successor to the late Repre sentative William F. Ryan, there is no legal bar to the holding of formal debates among the several candidates now seeking to take his place.

title: SOVIET GRAIN DEAL IS CALLED A COUP
description: The Soviet Union's recent purchase of more than $1bil lion worth of American wheat, feed grains and soybeans, the biggest grain deal in history, appears to have been a remark able coup for the buyers from Moscow.

title: Ajax Amsterdam Victor
description: AMSTERDAM, Sept. 28 (Reu ters)Ajax Amsterdam of the Netherlands won the world club soccer tournament tonight by defeating Argentina's lode pendiente, 30. The victory gave Ajax the twogame final series, 41.

title: Triumph Keeps Boston Ahead in East Race
The City's ItalianAmerican Needy: Too Proud to Take Aid They Earned
description: Return to the time when they came here from Sicily and Naples, of peasant stock mostly, to be masons and bricklayers, hod carriers and excavators, venders of fruits and vegetables and oldcoun try icesarmed only with ambition and persistence.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 28 The executive board of the State American Federation of Labor and Congress of Indus trial Organizations recommend ed tonight the endorsement of Republican Senator Clifford P. Case for reelection to a fourth term.

title: WHITE HOUSE BARS COMPROMISE PLAN ON RELIEF REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  A move to rescue welfare re form legislation appeared doomed today as the Nixon Administration renounced sup port of a compromise offered by Senator Abraham A. Ribi coff, Democrat of Connecticut.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 28 (AP)Despite what it called frequent and severe differ ences with the Nixon Adminis tration, the Ripon Society en dorsed President Nixon today for reelection.

title: BUCKLEY BACKS MARCHI'S ELECTION
description: Siding against a Conserva tive party candidate, Senator James L. Buckley yesterday en dorsed State Senator John J. Marchi, a Staten Island Repub lican for reelection.

title: A's Defeat Twins in Ninth And Retain Crown in West
Budget Cynicism
description: No one likes to be the bearer of bad news. The finan cial bad news is that for the fourth straight year the Nixon Administration is piling up an enormous budget deficit. In the next year or two there will have to be a substantial increase in Federal taxes or a difficult reduc tion in Federal expenditures or some combination of the two.

title: Overton Is Challenging Efforts To Oust Him From Union Post
description: L. Joseph Overton, the con troversial Harlem union official who three months ago was con victed by a Federal court for conflict of interest, is chal lenging a move by his union's leadership to oust him as busi ness agent.

title: SCRIBER PLANS HARLEM INQUIRY
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner said that he would look into school conditions in East Harlem after 300 parents from the area demonstrated yesterday outside Board of Ed ucation headquarters in Brook lyn.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TOMS RIVER, Sept. 28  A defendant was convicted today in the first trial in New Jersey in which evidence developed by a bloodhound was allowed.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP)Avery Brundage, retired president of the International Olympic Committee, cele brated his 85th birthday today and expressed confidence that the Olympics would continue to flourish despite the recent and illfated Munich Games.

title: Chase Study Finds Economic Growth Slowing in Quarter
description: The pace of economic expan sion slowed markedly in the third quarter but should pick up again toward the end of the year, Michael K. Evans, presi dent of Chase Econometric Associates, said yesterday.

title: WHITE HOUSE BARS COMPROMISE PLAN ON RELIEF REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  A move to rescue welfare re form legislation appeared doomed today as the Nixon Administration renounced sup port of a compromise offered by Senator Abraham A. Ribi coff, Democrat of Connecticut.

title: Saigon Restates Stand
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 28South Vietnam re iterated today its rejection of a Communist proposal for a three way coalition government here.

title: Chile Criticizes World Bank Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Chile bitterly criticized today the World Bank and its presi dent, Robert S. McNamara, for cutting off all loans, al legedly under pressure from the United States, on the ground of Chile's nationaliza tion of coppermining prop erties.

title: Premier Sees Danish Yes on Market
description: LYNGBY, Denmark, Sept. 28  Premier Jens Otto Krag of Denmark said today he was confident his countrymen would vote yes Monday in theirs referendum on Joining they European Economic Com munity.

title: NEW HEAD NAMED AT MARTIN MARIETTA
description: Directors of the Martin Mari ettaCorporation yesterday des ignated J. Donald Rauth, 54, who became the company's president last April, as chief executive officer. He succeeds George M. Bunker, 62, who is chairman.

title: Joint Venture Is Planned
description: The WarnerLambert Com pany and the National Patent Development Corporation an nounced yesterday that they had agreed to form a joint venture company to research, develop, manufacture and mar ket products containing GK 101 for dental and oral use. GK 101 is an experimental compound which attacks dead protein. It was developed by dental scien tists at Tufts University.

title: Southern Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  As Negroes have moved north in the last thirty years, they have unwittingly. brought with them the politics of the South.

title: Hewitt Advances
description: ALBANY, Calif., Sept. 28 (AP) South Africa's Bob Hewitt and Frew McMillan led seven topseeded players into the quarterfinals of the Pacific Coast tennis tournament at Golden Gate Field today. Top seeded Hewitt easily beat Aus tralia's Ross Case, 61, 61. Mc Millan defeated New Zealand's Onny Parun, 46, 75, 76.

title: McGovern Pledges Increase in Funds To Help the Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Senator George McGovern, de claring that the 1972 Presi dential election was a referen dum on the future of our cities, pledged today to re verse the priorities of the Nixon Administration.

title: Mrs. Cox Visits Alabama
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 28 (UPI)Tricia Nixon Cox spoke today about the elderly and with the young in a twocity Alabama campaign swing for her father and other Republi can candidates. Mrs. Cox, after breaking ground for a Social Security building and visiting a child development center, was to fly to Selma.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The controversy over the mam moth sale of wheat to the So viet Union intensified on Capi tol Hill today.

title: STEINGUT TO SEEK CONSUMER AGENCY
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 28 (AP) Assemblyman Stanley Stein gut of Brooklyn outlined a Democratic program today that he said would provide new consumer protection in the state.

title: Court Confusion Decried
description: A prominent Brooklyn judge called upon the State Legisla ture yesterday to cut markedly into the power of judges to sentence defendants, saying that the whole bench agrees.

title: COMMODITIES UP ON CHICAGO BOARD
description: Government reports of crop prospects and inclement weath er in the growing areas set off a flurry of purchasing that sent commodity futures higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Brooklyn Bridge Lanes To Be Shut for Repairs
description: Roadrepair work will re quire closing of the Manhat tanbound lanes of the Brook lyn Bridge for four succes sive nights, beginning Mon day, from 9 P.M. until 5:30 A.M., the Transportation Ad ministrator, Constantine Sida monEristoff announced last night.

title: Scant Ulster Progress
description: The conference on the political future of Northern Ire land, held this week in England, was badly handicapped from the outset by the refusal of four of Ulster's seven parties to participate. British Minister William Whitelaw, who presided, insists that the sessions produced a thor oughly constructive dialogue and exchange of views, but his task of devising even a modest next step toward an Ulster solution appears as difficult as ever.

title: Team Canada Wins
description: Team Canada won the hockey series with the Soviet Union, taking the final game, 65, yesterday in Moscow. The decisive goal was scored by Paul Henderson. Canada won four of eight and one was tied. Details on Page 49.

title: David Robinson under arrest at the 24th Pre cinct yesterday.
description: Cruising a Harlem street early yesterday morning, two Housing Authority detectives spotted a tall man in a wind breaker and arrested him as the third and final suspect in the fatal stabbing a week ago of a Columbia University law pro fessor, Dr. Wolfgang G. Fried mann.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 (Reuters)Craig Breedlove said today that he had the financial backing to start build ing a supersonic landrocket to race against the Soviet Union and Australia.

title: China Lets Westerners Enter Imperial Palace and Tombs
description: Access to the Imperial quarters in Peking's Forbidden City and to the sealed Ming Tombs has been granted a TV team from the National Broad casting Company, filming a documen tary produced by Lucy Jarvis. It is the first time the Communist Govern ment has granted western newsmen permission to film these interiors.

title: Snake Bite Kills Man
description: NASHVILLE, Ga., Sept. 28 (UPI)A zealous member of a snakehandling cult in south Georgia was bitten and later died from a rattlesnake bite, the authorities said today. Sheriff Walter Gaskins identified the man as Alfred Leon Parsons, 32 years old, who died after he was bitten by a rattlesnake Sunday night during a snake handling ceremony at a rural church.

title: SUPER BOWL BIDS FOR TRIPLE CROWN
description: YONKERS, Sept. 28Super Bowl, with a twoheat record smashing triumph in the Ham bletonian behind him, will be aiming for the second leg of the triple Drown of trotting when he races four opponents in the Yonkers Futurity at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night. Stan ley Dancer will be his driver.

title: EXPILOT CHARGES NAVY ORDERED HIM TO BOMB IN NORTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  A former Navy pilot told the Senate Armed Services Com mittee today that pilots aboard his aircarft carrier off Vietnam in late 1971 and early 1972 had been instructed to bomb tar gets in North Vietnam regard less of whether they were fired upon first.

title: Merger News
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 28 (UPI) Federal Judge Martin Pence has ordered officials of the General Telephone and Electronics Cor poration to prepare to cut back its size to the 1950 level.

title: China Presents Japan With 2 Giant Pandas
description: TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 29 (Agance FrancePresse)  China today presented Japan with two giant pandas to mark the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries.

title: 3 Freed P.O.W.'s Return; Dispute Flares Over Leave
description: The three American pilots freed by North Vietnam and their escort of antiwar leaders arrived from Copenhagen last night at Kennedy International Airport, and the three  after a 25minute shouting match aboard the parked Scandina vian Airlines System plane were taken by Defense Depart ment officials to military hos pitals.

title: Mrs. Andrew Cordier Dies at 72; Wife of 15th Columbia President
description: Mrs. Dorothy Butterbaugh Cordier, wife of Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, president emeritus of Columbia University, died of cancer yesterday at their home, 6 Merrivale Road, Great Neck, L.I. She was 72 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Vladimir Katin's Sept. 16 OpEd article defended reimbursement by Soviet citizens taking up permanent residence abroad, of state expenses on their education.

title: Army Clears 167 Black Soldiers Disciplined in a Shooting in 1906
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The Army announced today that after 66 years it had cleared the records of 167 black soldiers who were dis honorably discharged for a frontier shooting incident in Brownsville, Tex.

title: BOAT SHOW OPENS TODAY ON SOUND
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 28  The North Atlantic Boat Show doesn't open to the pub lic until 1 P.M. tomorrow, but the producers are so confident of its success that they have announced the dates for the next three years.

title: Dietary Factors Linked to Cancer of Digestive Tract
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 Worldwide changes in the in cidence of cancers of the diges tive tract are pointing to meats, alcohol and a deficiency of the trace element molybdenum in the diet as possible causes of these major cancer killers.

title: Tonnages by Company In Soviet Wheat Sales
description: Following are the tonnages of wheat purchased from American companies during two recent visits of a Soviet grainbuying team:

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)Legislation to make socalled pyramidsales operations a Federal crime was introaucea today by Senator Walter F. Mondale. The Minnesota Democrat said such getrichquick schemes were perhaps the most serious pending consumer fraud prob lem across the country, cheating gullible investors out of millions of dollars monthly.

title: MRS. CUDONE CARDS 158 TO SHARE LEAD
Rogers Sees Hopes for a Peaceful Settlement in the Middle East Despite Recent Setbacks
description: Secretary of State William P. Rogers said last night that de spite recent setbacks the forces favoring a peaceful set tlement in the Middle East still have the upper hand.

title: Celler Declines to Seek Reelection to the House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn, nearing the end of a halfcentury in the House of Representatives, announced today that he would not seek reelection this fall as a Liberal party candidate.

title: New Tennessee Hog Cholera
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 28 (AP) Hog cholera spread today to a fourth Tennessee county. A ban on public auctions closed 13 auction markets in the state. The state agriculture depart ment said that Fentress County became the latest in the state where cholera was confirmed. Cholera had previously been reported near Shelbyville in middle Tennessee, near Knox ville in east Tennessee and on the Cumberland plateau.

title: LEVITZ FURNITURE SEES A PROFIT LAG
description: Profits of the Levitz Furni ture Corporation thus far in the third fiscal quarter ending Oct. 31 have been disappointing and will increase at a considerbly slower pace than they have in the year's prior quarters, Ralph Levitz, chairman and chief executive officer, said yesterday in Miami.

title: Successes With Bone Marrow Transplants Cited
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 Medical scientists described cases today in which transplan tation of bone marrow has evi dently produced strikingly long survivals in some patients who had been near death from usu ally fatal blood diseases.

title: S.E.C. Action to Close Waddell Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Waddell & Reed, Inc., the big mutual fund complex, has agreed to let the Securities and Exchange Commission put out of business an offshore mutual fund subsidiary charged with misrepresentation and other offenses.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Vladimir Katin [OpEd Sept. 16] justified the Soviet Government in their demands for ransom from Jews who want to leave the U.S.S.R. for Israel. They, should pay for their edu cation, he Writes.

title: Manila Imposes Strict Censorship on News Media
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28 The Philippine Government has imposed drastic curbs on the news media and the ac tivities of newsmen under mar tial law declared last week.

title: Army Clears 167 Black Soldiers Disciplined in a Shooting in 1906
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The Army announced today that after 66 years it had cleared the records of 167 black soldiers who were dis honorably discharged for a frontier shooting incident in Brownsville, Tex.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Crime statistics became the center of a political debate today when the Government re leased Federal Bureau of In vestigation figures showing what was said to be the lowest crime rise in a dozen years, and the Democrats cited the same figures as proof that crime had become worse.

title: D.A.'s, With Hogan The Host, Discuss Ties With Nadjari
description: New York's five District At torneys held a luncheon meet ing yesterday to discuss their future relations with the city's new special deputy attorney general, Maurice H. Nadjari.

title: Immediate Changes Are Urged In Election Procedures in City
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday pro posed some immediate changes in election procedures here aimed at eliminating confusion among voters over whether they are registered.

title: U.S. AIDES OPPOSE SOVIET TRADE BAR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  The State Department said to day that the Administration op posed any legislative action in tended to block economic con cessions to the Soviet Union be cause of its restrictions on the emigration of Jews.

title: Casey Proposes Rule Halt On Realty Tax Shelters
description: William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, recommended yes terday that a moratorium be imposed on new regulations governing realestate tax shelt ers.

title: Advertising: News of Promotion
description: There are two men in new jobs and both announcements could come under the general title of promotion news.

title: Radio City Unions Warned on Closing If Musicians Strike
description: Radio City Music Hall noti fied its unionized employes yes terday that it might have to discontinue operations next Wednesday if musicians in the orchestra went on strike.

title: Israel Declines Response
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 28The Israeli Government declined immediate response tonight to President Sadat's proposal for the establishment of a Pales tinian government in exile, but Government officials said pri vately that Israel would re fuse to negotiate with a govern ment formed by Palestinian guerrillas just as they had in regard to the guerrillas them selves.

title: OTTO J. HARTWIG
description: Otto J. Hartwig a retired executive in the home building field for more than 30 years, died Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Jacksonville, Fla., after a long illness. He was 72 years old and formerly lived in Hempstead and Mineola. L.I.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor

title: ISSUES 1972
description: WASHINGTON  The truth about food prices can be summarized in three propositions:

title: SUPER BOWL BIDS FOR TRIPLE CROWN
description: YONKERS, Sept. 28Super Bowl, with a twoheat record smashing triumph in the Ham bletonian behind him, will be aiming for the second leg of the triple crown of trotting when he races four opponents in the Yonkers Futurity at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night. Stan ley Dancer will be his driver.

title: News Analysis
description: LONDON, Sept. 28Within the next few days, William Whitelaw, Northern Ireland's administrator, and his advisers in Belfast and London will set out to deal with the precarious political options that Ulster faces.

title: Campaign Letter
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 The nation's most populous state appears to be staging the nearest thing to a close contest for the Presidency so far and both President Nixon and Sen ator George McGovern passed through here in the last 48 hours to rake in some money and to keep the contest astir.

title: Inquiry on Mafia Cases
description: The New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime will hold hearings next month on the lenient treatment of or ganizedcrime figures in state courts, Senator John H. Hughes, the committee's chairman, said yesterday.

title: DR. CHARLES N. FREY, A BIOCHEMIST, DEAD
description: Dr. Charles N. Frey, a bio chemist who specialized in food research, died Wednesday in New York Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 15 Cambridge Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Investigators Begin Confidential Inquiry On Complaints of Civil Service Abuses
description: City Council investigators yesterday began what was ex pected to be a long series of confidential interviews with city workers who have com plained about Civil Service abuses in the Lindsay admin istration.

title: U.S. Tour to Stress 4 Areas of Health For Chinese Group
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  The 10 Chinese doctors and three aides who will tour the United States next month plan to concentrate on cancer con trol, heart disease, public health and birth control, the Institute of Medicine announced today.

title: Books of The Times
description: John Berger, in his new novel G., ob serves that There is an historical equiv alent to the psychological process of re pression into the unconscious. Certain experiences cannot be formulated because they have occurred too soon. This is a surprising admission from a noted British art critic whose books have often been highly praised for their vigorously contempo rary questions, then damned for their simplistic Marxist answers. Nevertheless, Mr. Berger here re turns to his themes of political and sexual revolution, this time analyz ing that historical process of repres sion in a pro foundly arresting and intelligent fic tion. G. makes a perfect comple ment to two recent films set in the same period, Luigi Visconti's version of Thomas Mann's Death in Venice and Joseph Losey's ver sion of L. P. Hartley's The GoBetween. Both films were vivid observations of fin desiecle class war, and both suggested the subversive potential of sexual liberation.

title: WINE TALK
description: There are no records to in dicate that Charles VI of France had a Ralph Nader around to badger him, or even that he had a Bess My erson at court.

title: Council Gets a Bill To Assist in Buying Of AirConditioners
description: Legislation proposed by the Lindsay administration requir ing airconditioner dealers to in form customers of the operating costs and the cooling capacity of every model they sell was introduced yesterday in the City Council.

title: One U.S. Agency Challenges Another On Antibias Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  The antidiscrimination agree ment that the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company has signed with a major Gov ernment agency was challenged as possibly inadequate today by another Federal agency.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: ALBANY, Sept. 29 (AP)The New York State Council of Harness Tracks said today that Saratoga Harness and Roosevelt Raceway had filed suit in State Supreme Court seeking to have the 1970 state law allowing quarterhorse racing declared unconstitutional.

title: Carl Holty Touches Many Bases in Art
description: The career of the Ameri can painter Carl Holly, who is now 72 years old, has touched so many important bases in the art of the 20th century that it has sometimes been difficult to isolate the salient characteristics of his own work. We recognize him easily enough as a confirmed modernist who handles his chosen medium with remark able intelligence, authority and ease, yet no single pic ture one has encountered over the years has seemed sufficient to represent his manysided interests and de velopment.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Never let it be said the furriers aren't in tune with the rest of the fashion world. In a season when the big news is pastels, there arc palecolored furs of every description to carry out the look: palomino mink, almond fox, white badger, white broadtail, pinkdyed mink and shadow blue fox (which looks white).

title: MRS. KING EARNS $100,000 2D YEAR
description: PHOENIX, Sept. 29 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King of Palm Aire, Fla., the first woman ath lete to earn $100,000 in a year in 1971, did it again today with a victory in the quarter finals of the Virginia Slims Phoenix Thunderbirds women's tennis tournament.

title: HUCH C. WILLIAMS
description: Hugh Cobbett Williams, for mer chief designer for the Tif fany Studios, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 233 East 72d Street and in Bridgewater, Conn.

title: Britain, Citing an African Initiative, Suspends U. N. Bidfor Uganda Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29Britain today sus pended her request for immedi ate General Assembly debate on the expulsion of some 50, 000 to 60,000 Asians from Uganda.

title: U.C.L.A. 6510 Victor
description: LOS, ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP) The University of California, Los Angeles, wishbone attack, with Mark Harmon, Rob Scrib ner and John Sciarra at the con trols, crushed Oregon, 6510, to night in a Pacific Eight Confer ence game.

title: Ax for Welfare Reform
description: The rejection by President Nixon of the sound com promise plan on welfare reform worked out by his own aides and Senator Ribicoff all but dooms the most con structive social innovation advanced by this Admin istration.

title: South Africa Warns U.N. of Double View on Terror
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29Hilgard Muller, Min ister of Foreign Affairs of South Africa, said today that his country remained ready to enter into a dialogue with any country that wishes to nego tiate with South Africa.

title: Notes on People
description: Guam, where the Amer ican day begins, is the ex pected honeymoon site of Shoichi Yokoi, a former Jap anese Army sergeant, and Miss Mthoko Hatashin, who are scheduled to be married. If anyone knows the attrac tions of the small Pacific isle, it should be the 57yearold Mr. Yokoi. In January, he was the last Japanese sol dier, to date, to surrender, after World War II. He was discovered after hiding for 28 years in the Guam jungles, defeated but uninformed. After their first three dates, the 44yearold Miss Hata shin said, We can now com municate with each other by eyes, though we don't talk to each other much.

title: Escapee to Be Extradited
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 29 (UPI) One of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10 most want ed criminals, a 27yearold Alabama man, is to be extra dited to North Carolina to face charges of prison escape, kid napping and bank robbery. Har ry Lee Green was turned over to Federal marshals yesterday and placed under $100,000 bond by United States Magistrate Aaron Brown Jr.

title: 5 Added to Musical
description: Amelia Haas, Gene Kelton, Philip MacKenzie, Ty McConnell and Patti Perkins are recent ad ditions to the musical version of The Contrast, the Royall Tyler play, opening off Broad way this fall. The work will be presented at the New Theater in Cambridge, Mass., next Wednesday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Still alive mathematically, the New York Yankees open a twogame series with the Cleveland Indians at Yankee Stadium today at 2 P.M.

title: WILLIAM P. ADAMS, ACTOR HERE, WAS 85
description: William Perry Adams, a dramatic actor who performed on stage, radio and television, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. His age was 85 and he lived at 155 West 81st Street.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 29 The Middlesex County Pro secutor's office said today that it had begun an investigation of the National Football Found ation, which, after years of fundraising, recently dropped plans to build a college foot ball hall of fame in the county.

title: Gen. Le Van Vien, 70, Dies ExVietnamese Warlord
description: PARIS, Sept. 29 (UPI)Gen. Le Van Vien, a wellknown warlord in South Vietnam dur ing the French colonial era, died in exile in Paris Wednes day at the age of 70.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)A net inflow of $727million of corporate capital from foreign subsidiaries of United States companies occurred during the second quarter of this year, for the first time in five years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ??The HoHoKus Inn, East Franklin Turnpike and Sheridan Avenue, HoHoKos, (201) 4454115.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 28 The computer letter may have replaced the television commercial as the preemi nent political tool of 1972, but you can't prove it by Senator Walter F. Mondale.

title: Freed Pilots Begin Tests and Are Visited by Families
description: The three American pilots freed by North Vietnam began intensive medical checkups and debriefings yesterday while the mother of one of the men com plained that the military's reac tion to his return really didn't seem like a hero's welcome.

title: OutwardBound Asians Tell of Maltreatment by Uganda Soldiers
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 29  Two trainloads of Asian refugees from Uganda passed through Kenya today and some of those aboard said that as they left Uganda, soldiers of that East African nation had beaten a few of the refugees and robbed many others.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: When a winner of the Nobel Prize for Economic Science expresses his views of Senator McGovern's eco nomics (OpEd Sept. 8), I am naturally hesitant about replying critically.

title: SENATE VOTE BARS CUTS IN WELFARE AS PENSIONS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Senate voted today to in sure the aged, blind and disabled against cuts in welfare pay ments due to the recent 20 per cent increase in Social Security benefits, to be mailed out next week.

title: SENTENCE REVIEW BACKED BY BOTEIN
description: The demand for a new sys tem of reviewing and correcting the sentences meted out by the state's judges continued to mount yesterday, as yet an other prominent juristformer Presiding Justice Bernard Bo tein of the Appellate Division joined in the call for the cre ation of a sentencing review board.

title: Sign Language Offers Clues to Primeval Gift of Gab
description: LA JOLLA, Calif.  To most people the sign lan guage of the deaf is little more than excited gesturing. To Dr. Ursula Bellugi, how ever, it is full of poetry, wit, irony andmost important to her as a linguistsome tantalizing clues to the fun damental nature of all lan guages and how they are ac quired by children.

title: Newsmen Protest Curbs
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 29Lieu tenant (jg.) Norris A. Charles, back home from nearly nine months of imprisonment in North Vietnam, today occupied a suite normally reserved for captains and admirals at Balboa Naval Hospital here.

title: U.S. Planned More Gradual Homecoming for P.O.W.'s
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 29  North Vietnam's release of selected United States prisoners of war into the custody of American antiwar activists has complicated and possibly frus trated a Pentagon plan for the gradual and cautious return of the captives to their families.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In an Aug. 20 news story by Paul Delaney, headed S.C.L.C. Says It Is Broke but Proud, the following' ap pears after the report of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference's of ficial opposition to the reelection of President Nixon:

title: Mugged Lawyer Regrets Calling the City a Jungle
description: Herman B. Glaser, the lawyer who described New York City as a jungle after he was mugged Wednesday afternoon, took it back yesterday morning at a City Hall news conference, calling the city the greatest town in the world.

title: Play Street for Tonight
description: The Park Avenue sitdown play street was canceled last night. Performances will be held tonight and tomorrow night at 9 on Park Avenue between 52d and 53d Streets.

title: HANOI AIDE DENIES RUMOR ON PEACE
description: PARIS, Sept. 29North Viet nam's spokesman said today that negotiations here were at a complete deadlock and no progress had been made.

title: Henry A. Strohmeyer Jr. Dies Livestock Photographer Was 81
