description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 28 Henry A. Strohmeyer Jr., a specialist in livestock photog raphy, died Tuesday night in White Plains Hospital after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Sludge Dumping On Land Urged To Spare Oceans
description: A Presidential advisory board recommended here yesterday that Federal or state lands of relatively low value be used for experimental sewage sludge disposal to avoid using the ocean as a dump.

title: 5 Missing in Ship Fire
description: LORIENT, France, Sept. 29 (AP) Rescue ships saved 17 crew members from the flam ing Cypriote freighter Kekenis early today. Five men were re ported missing. The bodies of two crew members were recov ered. Distress messages were heard from the 5,000ton ship late last night and several ships in the vicinity changed course and went to the rescue in the Bay of Biscay, the Atlantic inlet bordering on France and Spain.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 29A handful of protesters and a handful of partisans lifted Vice President Agnew to his oratori cal best today as the Republi can campaign dipped deep into the Old South, seeking the Wallace vote.

title: Palestinians Weigh Offer By Cairo on Government
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29 The Palestinian Liberation Or ganization's executive commit tee held an emergency session on the offer of President Ammar elSaclat of Egypt to recognize a Palestinian government in exile to be based in Cairo.

title: Meskill Delays Subsidizing Buses, Urges Talks
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 29Gov. Thomas J. Meskill delayed ac tion today on legislation to sub sidize bus services in Connecti cut's biggest towns and called for continued labor negotiations to solve the immediate problem.

title: Perfidious, Taiwan Says
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 29 The Nationalist Government bitterly announced tonight that it was severing relations with Japan because of that nation's perfidious action in establish ing relations with mainland China.

title: Merger News
description: EMI, Ltd., the British holding company, announced yesterday in London that it had made a bid for the shares of Golden Egg Group, Ltd. that was slightly higher than one made last week by the Ralston Pu rina Company. Ralston's bid amounted to $29.7million.

title: Kennedy and Mills Assail Administration on Health
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, said to day that the Nixon Administra tion had granted huge premium rises for the healthinsurance industry while opposing efforts to return the nation's health care system from the brink of collapse.

title: MISS HAYNIE TIES 3 RIVALS WITH A 71
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 29 (UPI)  Sandra Haynie, Mary Mills, Betty Burfeindt and Mrs. Judy Rankin carded twounder par 71's today to share the firstround lead in the first Portland Classic on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour. They hold a onestroke lead.

title: Metropolitan Sells Two Modern Masterpieces in an Unusual Move
description: The Metropolitan Museum, in an unusual action, has sold two of its modern mas terpieces, Vincent Van Gogh's The Olive Pickers and Douanier Rousseau's Mon keys in the Jungle.

title: Business Failures Mount For U.S. Food Industry
description: The food industry, essential to the life of the economy, is one of the most hazardous of all businesses.

title: CHARLES H. SAGE
description: NEENAH, Wis., Sept 29 Charles H. Sage, a retired vice president and director of the KimberlyClark Corporation and former president of its Ca nadian associate, the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Com pany, Ltd., died today. He was 81 years old.

title: Sports of The Times
description: At one time in his National Hockey League career, wore a surgical mask in practice because the cold air from the ice aggravated his asthma. It's not surprising. Paul Henderson was born in cold air, on a sled in the snow of Ontario nearly 30 years ago somewhere between the small towns of Kincardine and Lucknow across Lake Huron from the Michigan woods. His stature as an established, although not extraordinary, left wing, perhaps the N.H.L.'s swiftest skater, prompted each town to claim him on its birth rolls. But now all Canada claims him. With only 34 seconds remaining, he scored the goal for Team Canada that produced victory over Russia in the decisive final game of their international series. He also had scored the winning goals in the two previous games. Virtually by himself, he had preserved Canada's pride.

title: Marcos Steps Up His Purge Of Government Employes
description: MANILA, Sept. 29President Ferdinand E. Marcos stepped up his purge of government em ployes considered corrupt, sur plus or incompetent by drop ping 452 persons today from state employment.

title: Personalities: Golf Pros on Pan
description: Gary Player, the United States Professional Golfers' Association champion, had harsh words for some Amer ican pro golfers. Some of those making $100,000 a year could hardly burst a grape if they stepped outside their own country, the 35yearold South African said yesterday. lie added, A great golfer is a man who can win any where in the world.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Herman B. Glaser, the lawyer who described New York City as a jungle after he was mugged Wednesday afternoon, took it back yesterday morning at a City Hall news conference, calling the city the greatest town in the world.

title: de Montherlant Cremated
description: PARIS, Sept. 29 (AP)Henry de Montherlant, one of France's leading contemporary plar wrights, who committed suicide at the age of 76 last Friday, was cremated yesterday with an absence of ceremony, accord ing to his wishes. There were no speeches or religious serv ice of any kind in the crema torium of the Pere Lachaise Cemetery.

title: POLICY RING TIED TO LANSKY RAIDED
description: The smashing of probably the largest policy gambling empire in New York City was reported yesterday with the ar rest of 23 people, including key figures linked to its reputed organizer, Meyer Lansky.

title: Premiers Celebrate Pact On ChinaJapan Relations
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 29The Premiers of China and Japan celebrated at a joyous banquet here tonight the agreement to establish diplomatic relations that they had signed in the morning in a solemn cere mony in Peking.

title: SUPER BOWL WINS TROT AT YONKERS
Hofstra Is 150 Victor
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 29  Continuing to display the tough defense that has allowed only 16 points in the last three games, Hofstra University evened its wonlost record at 22 tonight by blanking Trenton State College, 150.

title: Quake in Ocean Off Coast
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP)A mild earthquake shook the ocean floor 25 miles west of San Diego at 7:14 A.M. To day, the California Institute of Technology said. The tremor was felt slightly in the San Diego area, but there were no reports of damage.

title: Major Undergoes Tests
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 29Maj. Edward Elias, 34, one of the three American prisoners released by North Vietnam, spent his first day back on an American military base under going routine medical exam inations and intelligence de briefings.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: COMMERCIAL, N. J., Sept. 29  There will be no ghosties or ghoulies and nothing will go bump here on Halloween. Halloween  or at least one way of cele brating it  has been voted out of existence.

title: British Panel Asks Reform Of Old Official Secrets Act
description: LONDON, Sept. 29  An official committee proposed to day that the controversial law protecting government docu ments be reformed to permit an easier flow of information.

title: AMEX AND 0TC SCORE ADVANCES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market ended higher yesterday in moderate trading.

title: RIVA RIDGE PICK IN BELMONT RACE
description: Attendance slumped to 14, 266 at Belmont Park yesterday, but the situation is expected to improve dramatically today when Riva Ridge shoots for Horse of the Year honors in the $116,000 Woodward Stakes.

title: Earlier Results
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 29  The United States team tied 22 with Switzerland today to maintain a slight plus score after two rounds of the finals. in the Chess Olympics here.

title: 3 Policemen Are Indicted in the Bronx
description: Three narcotics policemen have been indicted on various charges, including robbery and perjury, as a result of a con tinuing investigation of police corruption, District Attorney Burton B. Roberts of the Bronx announced yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: Interest rates on con ventional home mortgage loans inched upward dur ing August for the fourth month in a row, the Fed eral Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: Canadian Production Off
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 29 (Reuters) Canada's index of industrial production fell in July by 0.1 per cent to 193.9, Statistics Canada reported today. The index is based on 1961 equals 100.

title: Nuclear Reactions on Surface Of Sun Reported by a Scientist
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)  A spacecraft has ob tained the first direct evidence that nuclear reactions oc casionally occur on the surface of the sun as well as in its deep interior.

title: ROMNEY IN WARNING ON MORTGAGE DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)  Housing Secretary George Romney notified his agency's field offices and many financial institutions today that Congress had not renewed the Federal Housing Administration's au thority to insure new home mortgages and homeimprove ment loans.

title: Art: Two Shows South of Houston St.
description: Anyone not yet familiar with the cluster of galleries just south of Houston Street can get a favorable impres sion of what goes on down there by visiting a couple of current exhibitions, Pat Steir's, which opens today at Paley & Lowe to run until Oct. 18, and a doubleheader of paintings by Tony King and Bruce Everett at O.K. Harris, closing next Satur day.

title: MRS. CUDONE WINS SENIOR GOLF TITLE
description: ORELAND, Pa., Sept. 29 Mrs. Philip Cudone of Myrtle Beach, S.C., shot a competitive course record, a oneunderpar 36, 3773, today and won the 54hole United States women's senior amateur golf champion. ship for the fifth straight year. She finished with a 231 total in murky, drizzly weather at the Manufacturers Golf and Coun try Club.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Nutley School Aide Assails Writers

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 29 John J. McKeithen, the former Democratic Governor, a tough and colorful campaigner, filed yesterday as an independent candidate for the United States Senate seat left vacant by the death of Senator Allen J. Ellen der in July.

title: WHEAT EXPORTERS LOSE PLEA ON TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Treasury Department, in a proposed ruling announced to day, has decided unexpectedly that export companies getting a subsidy on sales of wheat abroad should not also be freed of taxes on half their profits from such sales.

title: Educators Split on Pleas For Increased School Aid
description: TRENTON, Sept. 29  Faced with growing financial and oth er problems they said they could not solve alone, private and parochial school spokesmen called today for increased state and Federal aid, but a public school advocate sharply chal lenged their view.

title: Theater: Baraka Plays
description: The five oneact plays in the Imamu Amiri Baraka (LeRoi Jones) festival at the AfroAmerican Studio may not entirely work as drama, but each has a certain suc cess as exhortation. The final two plays, which opened Thursday, are filled with out rage and hostility at that favorite Baraka targetthe emulation by blacks of whites.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reu ters)  George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nomi nee, starting an attack on President Nixon's policy on health care, named a special blueribbon advisory panel to day to plan a new national health program.

title: Hospital Election. Resolves UnionRepresentation Issue
description: Two hospital unions contest ing the right to represent em ployes of the French Polyclinic School and Health Center each won in two of four worker categories as a result of an election held Thursday, the State Labor Relations Board announced yesterday.

title: JOBSON CAPTURES 3 SAILING EVENTS
description: BARRINGTON, R. I., Sept. 29 Garry Jobson of the New York Maritime Academy and Robbie Doyle of Marblehead, Mass., took turns in winning all five races today in the first North American Inter Class Solo sail ing championship on Narragan sett Bay.

title: Bridge: Bid of 5 in Intended Trump Can Be an Invitation to Slam
description: A player who is heading for a slam in a major suit can sometimes bid five in the intended trump suit as a simple invitation. By do ing so he asks partner to evaluate his hand for slam purposes, bearing in mind that other possible meth ods of approaching a slam have been rejected.

title: Business Briefs
description: The First National City Bank, the Irving Trust Com pany and the Bank of New York acted yesterday to in crease their prime lending rates of 5 per cent, effective Monday. First National City had been posting 5 per cent, while the other two banks were charging 5 per cent for loans to their most creditworthy borrowers.

title: Kissinger's Deputy Is Sent to Saigon for Three Days to Confer With Thieu
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  President Nixon today sent one of his principal foreign policy advisers to Saigon to confer with President Nguyen Van Thieu and make a general as sessment of the situation there.

title: Thieves Hit Bookstore
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 29 (UPI) The student operated bookstore at the University of California reported yesterday that it lost $117,000 because of thieves last year.

title: Mrs. Meyner an Underdog in Jersey Race
description: BOONTON, N. J., Sept. 28 An old pro with 15 years in the Legislature and a politically knowledgeable newcomer with a wellknown name are vying, for election to Congress in the newly carved 13th District in north western New Jersey.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Veeco Instruments Inc. yes terday said it had acquired 35, 400 of its own common shares and added that such acquisi tions are continuing. The com pany's board has authorized acquisition of up to 100,000 shares. The company's stock was unchanged at 16 on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: We were deeply distressed to note in your Aug. 20 news story on the Southern Christian Leadership Con ference an erroneous implication about the National Urban League. The story reported that the S.C.L.C., which does not receive any Federal funds, is the first major civil rights organization to oppose reelection of President Nixon.

title: Board of R. H. Macy Confirms Seegal's Election as President
description: The post of president of R.H. Macy & Co., Inc., vacant since August of 1971, was filled yes terday at a special meeting of Macy's board of directors.

title: H.D.A. Aide Is Suspended, 2d Ousted in Hiring Inquiry
description: One city official was dis charged and another suspended yesterday for allegedly urging job applicants at the Housing and Development Administra tion to lie about their addresses in order to take advantage of an emergency hiring program for residents of poverty areas.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: One city official was dis charged and another suspended yesterday for allegedly urging job applicants at the Housing and Development Administra tion to lie about their addresses lin order to take advantage of an emergency hiring program for residents of poverty areas.

title: Hetty King Is Dead at 89 British Music Hall Star
description: LONDON, Sept. 29Hetty King, a leading name of the music hall in its golden Ed wardian era, died recently in a Wimbledon hospital at the age of 89.

title: SCHEUER IN RACE FOR RYAN'S SEAT
description: Representative James H. Scheuer announced yesterday that he was available as a candidate for the Democratic nomination in the 20th Con gressional District if there was a deadlock between the two chief contenders.

title: Beef Price Gap Narrows
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) Mr. Rumsfeld said today that the beef price gap between farmers and consumers was narrowing.

title: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn Art for Man's Sake: I
description: Like that bewildered savage who picks up a strange and wondrous object  perhaps something thrown up by the sea, perhaps disinterred from the sand or dropped from the heavens  an object intricate in its convolutions, now shin ing with a dull glow, now with a bright shaft of light  who turns it over and over in his hands, trying to find some way of putting it to use, trying to find in it some humble function and never conceiving of a higher purpose

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Sept. 29 (AP)A 93to1 shot figured in a $15,005 daily double payoff last night at Lincoln Downs, believed to be the largest daily double return the history of racing.

title: Industrial Graveyard
description: In passing an amended health and labor appropriations act after President Nixon's veto of the first bill, the House has missed an opportunity to rectify a gross injustice contained in the original measure.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: SEA GIRT, Sept. 29The New Jersey State Police Acad emy, which returned to its original home at the ocean front National Guard camp here two years ago, ranks as one of New Jersey's most im portant and unusual institu tions of learning.

title: Film Festival: Eric Rohmer's 'Chloe in the Afternoon'
description: Frdric (Bernard Verley), the hero of "Chlo in the Afternoon," the last in Eric Rohmer's marvelous cycle of comedies, which he calls his Six Moral Tales, is happily married, but he is stumped: he's no longer capable of flirting with other women.That's what he says, but he is not always trustworthy when he talks about himself. Never before in his life has he been so conscious of desirable womenon the train as he commutes from Saint-Cloud, in his Paris office, in the cafs. When he crosses a street, he attends to the passing women like a naturalist studying life in a rain forest. For a minute or two, he even falls in love with an unspectacular young saleswoman, apparently because she is so seriously insistent that he buy a shirt he doesn't want."I feel marriage closes me in, cloisters me, and I want to escape," he tells us on the soundtrack. "The prospect of happiness opening indefinitely before me sobers me. I find myself missing that time, not too long ago, when I could experience the pangs of anticipation. I dream of a life made of first loves, lasting loves."Like Adrien in "La Collectionneuse," Jean-Louis in "My Night at Maud's" and Jrome in "Claire's Knee," Frderic must choose between love and desire, which Mr. Rohmer sometimes calls love-in-idleness. In "Chlo in the Afternoon," desire takes the fairly ample shape of Chlo (Zouzou), a none too stable, not immediately prepossessing young woman out of his past Chlo, who was once a successful model and the mistress of an artist with whom she went to America, has returned to Paris with boredom in her heart and a man named Serge she doesn't love.Because Frdric feels so secure in his marriage, because Chlo's interest flatters him and because he is so incapable of flirting, he begins to see Chlo in the afternoons, just to talk, sometimes to advise her, on her muddled affairs. He tells himself that because they have no commitments to each other, he can feel a freedom and excitment with her that he can't allow in his, marriage. Quite surprisingly (at least to Frdric), he finds himself wanting to go to bed with her."Chlo in the Afternoon," which opened the 10th New York Film Festival last night and begins its commercial engagement today at the 68th Street Playhouse, is the perfect coda to those three of the Six Moral Tales that have already been released here ("Collectionneuse," "Maud's" and "Claire," whose heroines are recollected in a comic reverie in the new film).In "Chlo" Mr. Rohmer examines monogamous marriage as if it were the sum total of contemporary civilization: the thought of destroying it is natural but also to be resisted for the time being, at least until something better, more practical, comes along. It's a comedy of very funny, complex contradictions, between action and word, between image and sound.Unfortunately, because American audiences must spend a great deal of their time reading the English subtitles that translate the French dialogue, "Chlo," like the earlier Rohmer films, will probably be too easily classified as literate.Much of the wit is verbal, and Mr. Rohmer's screenplay contains absolutely lovely passages, such as the one in which Frdric describes his love of Paris and its crowds as being like his love for the sea. He says he is not engulfed or lost in the city. Instead, he rides its crest like a solitary surfer following the rhythm of a wave.These passages are impressive, but the reading of them tends to distract the eye from seing what's really happening onscreen: including Mr. Rohmer's way with actors. He seldom photographs them in close-up so that we must make our own choices about what sort of people they are, about what they're thinking and whether or not we can trust them.Although Mr. Rohmer's heroes inevitably opt for the comparatively celibate choice, his films succeed in being immensely erotic. When Nestor Almendros, Mr. Rohmer's superb cameraman, shows us a few square inches of Chlo flesh, it has the suddenly tactile effect of a realnot an imaginedembrace. Most important, just because Mr. Rohmer keeps his focus short, clear and precise, one sees deeply into the lives of his characters without the sort of pretentious distortions of most movies that deal in metapsors. Because Chro is about what it says it is, it works on more profound levels.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Sept. 29This suburban com munity of 35,000 people bordering on the Watchung Mountains has an impressive high school football team.

title: CLOSURE DEFEATED ON CONSUMER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The Senate today defeated a move to stop debate on a bill to establish an agency to rep resent consumers in govern ment and court proceedings.

title: CHESTER A. SMITH, 87, LAW GRADUATE AT 75
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 29 Chester A. Smith, a court stenographer for 47 years, died this morning in a nursing home at the age of 87.

title: NEW JERSY
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 28 (AP)  Pearl Buck underwent surgery today for removal of her gall bladder, a spokesman at Medical Center Hospital re ported.

title: Yastrzemski's Homer in 10th Is Decisive
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 29The Boston Red Sox ended the threeyear reign of the Balti more Orioles as champions of the American League tonight with a 42 victory in 10 innings that also kept the Red Sox in the Eastern Division lead with five games to play.

title: Justice John A. Mullen Dies Served on State Supreme Court
description: John A. Mullen, a formers State Supreme Court justice who played a key role in mak ing Frank S. Hogan the Man batten District Attorney, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hos pital. He was 82 years old.

title: LEVITZ DECLINES IN EVEN MARKET
description: Plunging prices for Levitz Furnituredown 13 points to 33 as the most active issue took the spotlight in a general ly even stock market yesterday in the final session of the September quarter.

title: U.S. AND CZECHS TIE, 22, IN CHESS
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 29 (AP)  The United States split the third round of the men's Olympic chess finals to night, 2 to 2, with Czechoslo vakia.

title: Market Place: 2 Levitz Views Confuse Street
description: Ralph Levitz, the chairman and chief executive of the Levitz Furniture, Corpora tion, disclosed Thursday after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange that his company's profits for the third quarter would be disappointing.

title: 3 City Units Told to Shift More Men to Street Duty
description: Mayor Lindsay directed the heads of the Police, Fire and Sanitation Departments yester day to develop plans immedi ately to put additional uni formed men on the streets and replace them with civilian employes.

title: 2 Attempt to Rob a Bank With 11 F.B.I. Men Inside
description: Two men made the error yes terday of trying to rob an Upper East Side bank that has more than 300 agents of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation as customers.

title: CHARLES KRIGER, 71, EXGOVERNMENT AIDE
description: Charles H. Kriger, former area administrator here for the Small Business Administration, died of a heart attack in Newark on Wednesday. He was 71 years old and lived at 72 Orange Street, Brooklyn.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  The frustration bursts from Senator George McGovern quite often; it is a variation of the old schoolboy taunt: Why won't he come out and fight like a man? Last week, the South Dakotan made several derisive references to President Nixon's habit of dropping down from the skies in his helicopter once in a while to mingle with the people. This week in Ta coma, Wash., he spoke bitterly about the Presi dent's surrogate campaigners he called them lackeys and secondrate bureaucratsget ting so much attention from the press and television.

title: Willamette Unit to Expand
description: Willamette Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that its Western Kraft Corporation sub sidiary had been authorized to construct an unbleached kraft linerboard mill on the Red River, near Campti, south of Shreveport, La. Cost of the project is estimated at $30 million.

title: POLICEMAN SLAYS MAN IN UNIONDALE
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Saturday, Sept. 30A Nassau County policeman shot and killed a man in the parking lot of the Nas sau County Coliseum late last night, the police said.

title: Angkor Fight Abandoned
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 29 (UPI)The Cambodian com mand announced that it had abandoned its efforts to recap ture the 1,000yearold temples at Angkor. The operation, be gun on Jan. 29, was abandoned Sept. 19, a spokesman an nounced. It had been almost at a standstill since early August. Enemy units have occupied Angkor since June, 1970.

title: Britain, in U.N., Bars Rhodesia Plan
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29  Britain today vetoed an Africansponsored resolu tion on Rhodesia after three days of Security Council dis cussion on that country.

title: Prosecution Opens the Corona Case
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Sept. 29 The state reluctantly opened today its case against Juan V. Corona, the husky Mexican na tional who is accused of the largest mass murder in Ameri can history.

title: 10th Film Festival Opens To a Capacity Tully Hall
description: The New York Film Festival, the 10th annual feast for film buffs, opened a 16day series of performances last night to a full and festive house in Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There is a stern political lesson for reformers in the RooneyLowenstein saga. It is perhaps a lesson that applies to the McGovern campaign as well. Empathy is not sufficient in attempting to win the votes of those whose lot we wish to better. Empathy must be joined with an ability to identify with those whom we consider politically, econom ically or intellectually deprived.

title: Nippon Airways Buys 727's
description: The Boeing Company an nounced yesterday that All Nippon Airways of Japan had purchased five Boeing advanced 727 jets for delivery in mid 1973 at a price of about $40 million. Boeing said two of the planes would be delivered in July and three in August.

title: Thieu Is Adamant
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 29President Thieu said today that during the last four years he had lost hope of peace, and he reiterated his Government's implacable re jection of a Communist pro posal for a coalition govern ment.

title: McGovern Sleeps Late, Then Drafts Chats
description: ST. MICHAEL's, Md., Sept. 29 (AP)  Senator George McGovern slept late today and then worked on what will be one of several crucial speeches in the last stage of his Presidential campaign.

title: 100 Die in South Africa Train Crash
description: MALMESBURY, South Af rica, Saturday, Sept. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)  At least 100 people were report ed killed last night when a passenger train was derailed near Malmesbury, in Cape Province, in what appears to be South Afria's worst train disaster.

title: Nixon Unit Fights Naming Of Campaign Contributors
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  Lawyers representing President Nixon's campaign finance com mittees contended in court here today that the key provisions of the new Federal Election Campaign Act  public disclo sure of contributors  is an un constitutional invasion of Re publican donors' privacy and their fundamental right to anonymous freedom of political association.

title: Soviet Is Said to Arrest A CivilRights Advocate
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (Reuters) Usually reliable sources said tonight that Soviet security police had arrested a Moscow teacher on a charge of anti Soviet activity in the fourth such more this year against members of an unofficial Civil Rights group.

title: Shipyard Workers of 1940's Told of Cancer Peril
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29An expert on environmental medi cine warned here today that the millions of men and women who were directly or indirectly exposed to asbestos while they worked in shipyards in World War II faced the possibility of an imminent epidemic of a oncerare cancer.

title: Ford Sets Guarantee
description: DEARBORN, MICH., Sept, 29 (UPI)  The Ford Motor Com pany announced today it was guaranteeing the present retail prices of all Ford cars through Oct. 31, regardless of whether the Federal Price Commission grants Ford an increase.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29 Officers of the Industrial Union Council, an affiliation of the State A.F.L.C.I.O., recommend ed today the endorsement of Paul J. Krebs, the Democratic nominee for Senator, and also offered a resolution in con demnation of President Nixon that urged members to cam paign for Senator George Mc Govern.

title: Executive Changes
description: Don Smith, chairman of WolverinePentronix, Inc., has also been elected president.

title: Willowbrook Physician Doubts Report About Severe Injury as Result of Fall
description: A physician at the Willow brook State School on Staten Island testified yesterday that a mentally retarded 22year old woman under his care had been so seriously injured early this year that he could not be lieve the official report that she had simply fallen during an epileptic seizure.

title: EGYPT SAYS SUDAN WITHDRAWS TROOPS
description: CAIRO, Sept. 29Egypt an nounced today that at least some of the Sudanese troops stationed on the Suez Canal front since the sixday war of 1967 had recently been with drawn from Egypt.

title: PRICES OF WHEAT AT 9YEAR RECORD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) Farm prices of wheat, hoisted by massive sales to the Soviet Union, jumped 22 cents a bushel in September and av eraged the most for the month since 1963, the Agriculture De partment reported today.

title: U.S. Sends F111's Over North For the First Time Since 1968
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, Sept. 30 (AP)The Unit ed States has sent the contro versial F111A fighterbomber back into the air war over North Vietnam for the first time in four and a half years.

title: Japan's Payments Surplus Shrinks After Strike Ends
description: TOKYO, Sept. 29 (Reuters)  Japan's balanceofpayments surplus in August shrank to $557million with a revival of imports following the end of the Japanese seamen's strike, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Carroll Equals Save Mark
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 29 (AP) Clay Carroll tied the major league record for saves with 35 tonight as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 41. Sparky Lyle of the New York Yankees and Wayne Gran ger of the 1970 Reds share the record on saves.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 29 (AP)The Middlesex County prosecutor's office announced today it was con ducting a fullscale investigation of the National Football Foundation, which was supposed to build its college Hall of Fame in the county.

title: S.E.C. Suspends Trading In the First Leisure Corp.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced that it has suspended until Oct. 7 overthecounter trading and securities of the First Leisure Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Robert Finch's Sept. 8 OpEd piece is distinguished by the avoidance of issues that has always characterized Richard Nixon.

title: Southern Yemen Charges Tank Invasion by Yemen
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29 (AP)Troops and tanks from Yemen have overrun four vil lages in Southern Yemen, kill ing 25 civilians and an army officer in the threeday attack the Southern Yemen Embassy here stated today.

title: One U.S. Agency Challenges Another On Antibias Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The antidiscrimination agree ment that the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company has signed with a major Gov ernment agency was challenged as possibly inadequate today by another Federal agency.

title: Nixon Unit Fights Naming Of Campaign Contributors
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  Lawyers representing President Nixon's campaign finance com mittees contended in court here today that the key provisions of the new Federal Election Campaign Act  public disclo sure of contributors  is an un constitutional invasion of Re publican donors' privacy and their fundamental right to anonymous freedom of political association.

title: Baron Lambert Creates a Giant
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 29Baron Leon Lambert, 44yearold cousin of the French Roths childs, has just put together Belgium's second largest hold ing company in a develop ment that not only revamps the structure of Belgian in dustry but also brings closer togetherperhaps eventually into some form of merger two of the nation's leading banks.

title: U.S. ACTS TO HELP ELDERLY ON RENT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  The Cost of Living Council, following a meeting with Presi dent Nixon, announced today a nationwide rent watch aimed at preventing excessive rent increases for elderly ten ants who will soon be receiving larger Social Security checks.

title: News Analysis
description: It is now more than three months since the international pilots pulled off their startling, if far from universal, 24hour airline stoppage to support de mands for sterner measures against skyjacking, sabotage and other aviation crimes. What, if any, solid progress do they have to show for it? Therehas been a start  disappointingly timidon a treaty that would open the way for airline boycotts or other sanctions against nations aid ing air pirates. Congress is wrestling with Senate and House versions of an antihijack ing bill authorizing the Presi dent to cut off air service with countries refusing to extradite or punish air terrorists.

title: Scout Spends Summer Finding Books for Prisoners on Rikers I.
description: On a muggy day last June a 17yearold Puerto Rican youth wearing a Boy Scout uniform and an earnest expression walked into Correction Com missioner Benjamin Malcolm's office and offered to plant trees on Rilcers Island. His offer was refused.

title: Text of the ChineseJapanese Accord Signed by Chou and Tanaka
description: PEKING, Sept. 29 (Reuters] Following is the official English language translation of the joint ChineseJapanese communiqu signed in Peking today:

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 29 (UPI)Thailand's chal lenger, Venice Borkorsor, captured the World Boxing Coun cil flyweight championship from Betulio Gonzalez on technical knockout in the 10th round tonight when the Venezuelan refused to continue to fight.

title: OLD TOWN CORP. SETS A SUIT AGAINST 3M
description: The Old Town Corporation filed yesterday a $30million damage suit against the Min nesota Mining and Manufactur ing Company in the Supreme Court of the State of New York.

title: MOORER SAYS NAVY DID NOT VIOLATE RULES ON BOMBING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chair man of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that the Navy had not conducted unauthorized bombing strikes against North Vietnam.

title: Tokyo Informs Envoy
description: TOKYO, Sept. 29  The Na tionalist Chinese Ambassador to Japan, Peng Mengchi, was in formed at the Japanese Foreign Ministry this morning that dip lomatic relations between Tokyo and Taipei cease to exist.

title: Dance: Utah Repertory Opens Series
description: The idea of the Utah Rep ertory Dance Theater, which opened a series of perfor mances at Hunter College on Thursday night is mildly pre posterous. It is, after all, one of the few fully professional moderndance groups to ex ist away from New York City. There are plenty of profes sional ballet companies, but moderndance troupes are al together rarer birds.

title: THE 1972 COMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) A secret Republican fund used to pay for attempts at gathering information about Democrats was personally con trolled by John N. Mitchell while he was Attorney General, The Washington Post reported today.

title: 2 Attempt to Rob a Bank With 11 F.B.I. Men Inside
description: Two men made the error yes terday of trying to rob an Upper East Side bank that has more than 300 agents of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation as customers.

title: $5 MARIJUANA FINE IS UPSET BY COURT
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich. Sept. 29 (AP)Ann Arbor's controver sial marijuana ordinanceit allows violators to get off with a $5 fine that they can send in by mailwas ruled unconstitu tional today by District Court Judge S. J. Elden.

title: Massengale Ties for Open Lead
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 29In the rain and heavy fog, Don Massengale scored a fourthround fourunderpar 68 today to close an eightstroke gap and tie Ron Letellier at 288 for first place in the Metro politan open golf champion ship.

title: MOORER SAYS NAVY DID NOT VIOLATE RULES ON BOMBING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chair man of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that the Navy had not conducted unauthorized bombing strikes against North Vietnam.

title: Ivy Teams Go Into Action Today
description: Columbia will open its football season against Fordham today because Buffalo University decided it could no longer af ford the luxury of a varsity football team.

title: THE 1972 COMPAIGN
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 29 (UPI)  An arsonset fire caused $100,000 damage to Republican campaign head quarters here early today, just six hours after President Nixon's daughter, Mrs. David Eisenhower, dedicated a new Phoenix convention center.

title: BID BY TIME INC. ON PRICES BARRED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)  The Price Commission today turned down a request by Time Inc. to raise its maga zine advertising and circulation prices and ordered price roll backs for a large clothing store and a farm machinery company.

title: A Ruling on Income Data For MitchellLama Urged
description: Muriel Stromberg, a Demo crat member of the City Coun cil from the Bronx, demanded yesterday that Mayor Lindsay rule on whether tenants of Mitchell  Lama middle  income housing projects were required to permit the city to check their incomes with city tax records.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The letter by Earl G. Graves (Sept. 23) accusing opponents of the Urban Development Corporation's proposal to build 100 lowincome housing units in each of nine Westchester towns of being motivated by bigotry and racism reflects the success which the Urban Development Corporation has had in turning a multifaceted issue into a racial one, polarizing communities and fostering racial animosity. This is be cause the U.D.C., faced with strong countywide opposition to its program not, as Mr. Graves suggests in his letter, simply during the last several weeks but from the moment the plan was announced in Junehas chosen to ignore all substantive criticism by treating it as racist.

title: Premiers Celebrate Pact On ChinaJapan Relations
description: SHANGHAI, Saturday, Sept. 30The Premiers of China and Japan celebrated at a joyous banquet here last night the agreement to establish diplomatic relations they had signed earlier in Peking, and this morning the Chinese gave the Japanese leader a warm farewell.

title: Music: Boulez Conducts Mahler's 6th
description: Even during this Mahler renaissance of the last half dozen years the Sixth Sym phony, in A minor, is seldom played. Thus there was spe cial interest in the program of the New York Philharmonic in Philharmonic Hall on Thurs day, when Pierre Boulez con ducted the work.

title: Hope for the Mongoloid: Places to Live and Work Together
description: Whenever Mrs. Harry Schmidt gets down on hands and knees to scrub the floor of her North Bergen, N. J., home, her 6yearold daughter, Patty, has a favorite ritual.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Meskill Holds Up BusSubsidy Bill

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 29Vice President Agnew described the secret fund, report today as unattributed and counter productive.

title: SCHWEITZER SEES GAINS ON REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  The managing director of the International Monetary Fund said today at the conclusion of the fund's annual meeting that conditions for a concerted at tack on the issues of interna tional monetary reform are now much more proprtlous than they looked a week ago.

title: Man in the News
description: Christopher Jeremy Morse, the Briton who won honors at school for his study of Greek and Latin classics, may need every bit of Socrat ic reasoning and Ciceronian eloquence he can muster in the job he has just under taken.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As an independent Democrat who first voted in the last Presidential election, I am one of many who may respond to Joseph Heller's letter (Aug. 29) on leaving the party this fall:

title: F.B.I. SHIFTS POLICY TO ROTATE OFFICIALS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)L. Patrick Gray 3d, act ing director of the Federal Bureau of Investigations an nounced today a major person nel policy change wheby top officials at headquarters would be sent back to the field and field commanders sent here to replace them.

title: 3 City Units Told to Shift More Men to Street Duty
description: Mayor Lindsay directed the heads of the Police, Fire and Sanitation Departments yester day to develop plans immedi ately to put additional uni formed men on the streets and replace them with civilian employes.

title: Pernn Wins Home Opener Under New Lights, 5512
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29  Something new was introduced at ivycovered Franklin Field tonight. The University of Pennsylvania played host to Lafayette in the first intercol legiate football game played here under the lights since the Quakers' big cement stadium was unveailed in 1895.

title: PISTONS TRIUMPH OVER KNICKS, 9586
description: DETROIT, Sept. 29Willie Norwood scored 15 points in the fourth quarter to lead the Detroit Pistons to a 9586 vic tory over the New York Knicks at the University of Detroit Memorial Building tonight.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: BOONTON, Sept. 28  An old pro with 15 years in the Legislature and a politically knowledgeable newcomer with a wellknown name are vying for election to Congress in the newly carved 13th District in northwestern New Jersey.

title: GREAT PYRENEES GAINS TOP AWARD
description: BLUE POINT, L.I., Sept. 29 It was Ch. Karolaska Glacier's weather today. The turf of the Suffolk County Republican Club was drenched from intermittent showers that fell throughout most of the Brookhaven Kennel Club show and a heavy mist was drifting in from Great South Bay as Mrs. Nancy Lind say judged the final.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 A consulling engineer was granted a patent this week for a mechanical hand that is to be part of a whole mechanical man. James F. Mullen of Mount Vernon, N. Y., who received Patent 3,694,021, plans to arrange for production of robot men to perform manual work under remote control in space, in deep water or in other ditficult environments. To promote the project, he has formed a company known as Auto mated Man, Inc. The inven tor has built a model of his mechanical man, which is described as looking like a human skeleton.

title: General Electric Workers To End Bay State Strike
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 29 (UPI)Welders at the General Electric Company plant here have voted to return to work after a strike of nearly two weeks that made 1,000 workers idle.

title: SENTENCE REVIEW BACKED BY BOTEIN
description: The demand for a new sys tem of reviewing and correcting the sentences meted out by the state's judges continued to mount yesterday, as yet an other prominent juristformer Presiding Justice Bernard Bo tein of the Appellate Division joined in the call for the cre ation of a sentencing review board.

title: Israel Gives Lansky a Travel Document
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 29Meyer Lansky, the reputed American underworld figure, this week received an Israeli travel docu ment that is valid for one year and will enable him to go to any country that will receive him.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Heckscher Views Boardwalk Project

title: Dr. Benjamin Kramer Is Dead Led Pediatric Unit in Brooklyn
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Sept. 29 Dr. Benjamin Kramer, emeritus chief of the pediatric service of the Jewish Hospital and director emeritus of the department of pediatrics at Maimonides Hospital, both in Brooklyn, died today at a nurs ing home here. He was 84 years old.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29Outside of the small circle officially involved, none of us can really be informed on the state of the talks between Henry Kissinger and Le Duc Tho. But among some peo ple who have thought about Vietnam for years there is now a feeling a tingling sensation, as one put itthat something just could happen in Paris.

title: BONN TO ESTABLISH PEKING RELATIONS
description: BONN, Sept. 29 (AP)West Germany announced today that it would establish diplomatic relations with China.

title: SOYBEANS CLIMB AND THEN FALTER
description: Prices on the Chicago Board of Trade rose sharply at the opening yesterday, with soy bean futures leading. Profit taking later took much of the steam out of the rise, however, and prices closed mixed.

title: Suit Names Indiana Prison
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 29 (UPI)Filing of a Federal court case charging unconstitutional deprivation of necessary medi cal care to prisoners at the In diana state prison was an nounced today by the Legal Services Organization of Indi anapolis.

title: MATHEW BEECHER
description: YONKERS, Sept. 29Mathew Beecher, who retired as an ad vertising agency art director five years ago, died today at the Yonkers Professional Hos pital. He was 80 years old and lived at 182 North Broadway.

title: Tanner, Connors Advance
description: ALBANY, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP)  Roscoe Tanner and Jimmy Connors, two of Amer ica's top young tennis players, won matches today in the $34,000 Pacific Coast tourna ment and will face each other in tomorrow's semifinals.

title: JOHN BURRELL, 62, OF OLD VIC BOARD
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 29 John Burrell, former chair man of the board of directors of the Old Vic Theater Com pany, who staged plays in Lon don and on Broadway, died yes terday of a heart attack in Urbana. He was 62 years old.

title: IRA, BUDGET PUT AT $23.8MILLION
description: After two years of caution and delay because of local op position, the Human Resources Administration said yesterday that it planned to build a cot tagetype institution on Staten Island to house the residue among the city's most neglected youths.

title: Valdes Outpoints Duncan
description: Rodrigo Valdes, a highrank ing middleweight from Colom bia, was awarded a unanimous' 10round decision over Lloyd Duncan of London at Sunnyside Garden last night. Valdes weighed 165 pounds, Duncan 166. Valdes had scored 11 straight knockouts.

title: Antiques: Boston Silver
description: Boston's Museum of Fine Arts is the place to see a splendid instructive exhibi tion of American silver, cele brating the publication of catalogue of the museum's American silver collection by the undisputed master con noisseur of the subject, Kath ryn Buhler, a research fel low at the museum.

title: John Robinson, 65, Dies Won '52 Photography Prize
description: DES MOINES, Sept. 29 (AP)  John R. Robinson, a Pulitzer Prize photographer for The Des Moines Register and Tribune, died of leukemia yesterday. He was 65 years old.

title: SIR LINTON ANDREWS OF PRESS COUNCIL
description: LONDON, Sept. 29 (UPI) Sir Linton Andrews, onetime chairman of the British Press Council and editor emeritus of The Yorkshire Post, died today. He was 86 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE NATURAL MIND A New Way of Looking at Drugs and the Higher Consciousness. By Andrew Weil. Houghton Mifflin. 229 pp. $5.95.

title: CHARLES IN FRONT IN SCOTTISH GOLF
description: TURNBEBRY, Scotland, Sept. 29 (UPI)Bob Charles of New Zealand shot a par 71 for a total of 209 today and took the thirdround lead by a stroke in the $134,000 John Player Golf Classic.

title: U.S.Soviet Effort to Expand
description: WASHINGTON, Sept,29 (AP) The United States and the So viet Union have agreed to ex pand their cooperative efforts to try to harness the fusion reaction, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

title: Independent Bahamas
description: The Commonwealth of the Bahamas, a 750milelong island chain with a population of only 180,000, is now headed for independence from Britain, probably by next July. That was the clear verdict of Bahamian voters in giving decisive victory last week to Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling's Progressive Liberal party. A Nassau hotel waiter undoubtedly spoke for many Bahamians when he said: I'm a little scared, but this is what we want.

title: Misdirected Aid
description: The Senate's rejection this week of an endthewar amendment to a military aid authorization bill has cleared the way for early enactment of comprehensive foreign assistance legislation.

title: Yankees Home Today For Game With Indians
description: Still alive mathematically, the New York Yankees open a twogame series with the Cleveland Indians at Yankee Stadium today at 2 P.M.

title: A Rebuff to Pompidou on Engine
description: President Pompidou of France made a direct appeal to Presi dent Nixon last summer urging authorization for the General Electric Company to export its latest jetengine technology to France.

title: Three Hurt in Jerusalem Blast Arab Workers Nearby Are Held
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 29  A bomb exploded among racks of wine and whisky bottles in Jerusalem's largest supermar ket this morning, sending shards of broken glass in every direction.

title: SEAVER SUBDUES PIRATES ON 2 HITS
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29  On a night when 24,193 fans turned out hopeful of watching Roberto Clemente get his 3,000th major league hit, Tom Seaver ruined their party by shutting out the Pirates, 10, for his 20th victory. It was the third time in six years and the second season in a row that the ace of the Mets registered 20 victories.

title: Dollar Is Rising Abroad On Monetary Progress
description: PARIS, Sept. 29  The muchbattered dollar is staging a major recovery in Western Europe's foreign exchange markets, trading at the highest levels since last spring, and one of the key reasons is the improved outlook for monetary reform.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: BLUE POINT, L.I., Sept. 29 It was Ch. Karolaska Glacier's weather today. The turf of the Suffolk County Republican Club was drenched from intermittent showers that fell throughout most of the Brookhaven Kennel Club show and a heavy mist was drifting in from Great South Bay as Mrs. Nancy Lind say judged the final.

title: WHEAT EXPORTERS LOSE PLEA ON TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Treasury Department, in a proposed ruling announced to day, has decided unexpectedly that export companies getting a subsidy on sales of wheat abroad should not also be freed of taxes on half their profits from such sales.

title: U.S. DENIES HANOI SET TERMS FOR RELEASE
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 29 The Pentagon's chief specialist on prisoner affairs denied to day that North Vietnam im posed travel conditions on the release last week of three American pilots.

title: Beyond the Tombs
description: Last night some 1,300 men slept in the Tombsthe Manhattan Men's House of Detention, built to house 902. So it has been month upon month. Despite fervent promises to improve prisoners' living conditions after the Tombs riot of 1970, inhumane overcrowding still plagues this city's jails. And now, after ten months of cerebration, the city has decided against building a $70 million annex to the Tombs to provide modern accommo dation for 1,000 prisoners.

title: JAMES PIERCE DIES A WOOLWORTH AIDE
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Sept. 29 James E. Pierce, a formet vice president for real estate and construction and a direc tor of the F. W. Woolworth Company, died last Thursday. He was 58 years old.

title: CAR OUTPUT OFF 2,000 FOR WEEK
description: DETROIT, Sept. 29 (AP) The cancellation of overtime last Saturday by the Ford Motor Company and the Gen eral Motors Corporation re sulted in a 2,000unit drop in the week's domestic auto pro duction, Automotive News said today.

title: RECORD CONTRACT FOR SHIPS SIGNED
description: The largest peacetime ship building contract in this coun trya $268.7million agreement for construction of the nation's first large liquified natural gas tankerswas signed in Wash ington yesterday.

title: The Screen: 'Asylum,' a Documentary
description: "Asylum, I think, is to say, a safe place to be when you're frightened and alone." It is in such disarmingly basic terms that the British psychiatrist, R. D. Laing, defines his therapeutic community in London, the subject of Peter Robinson's documentary, "Asylum." The community, which occupies very unpretentious quarters and houses fewer than 20 patients (probably not the right word) along with some Laingian therapists, was filmed by Mr. Robinson and his two-man crew during what must have been for them six very trying weeks early in 1971.The effort was surely worth it for "Asylum." unlike so many documentaries, actually has some value as a document. And as a film it passes the fairly basic testagain, unlike so many documentariesof letting its subject essentially define and express itself.It is not a course in R. D. Laing's theories. It is a record of the daily lives of some very disturbed people living in close contact with one another, and not usually putting the best face on it. Unavoidably there are some tense moments, and they are explored but not exploited by this enterprising but humanly decent film.Nobody in the therapeutic community is destitute (patients pay their own way), and nobody, except an irascible older man named David, seems inaccessible to the therapists' rather unassertive suggestions. One clever young girl, Wendy, regresses to a state of near infantile dependency, and then seems to get hold of herself and becomes in a sense the heroine of the movie.But I was most impressed by an outsider, a young male patient's businesslike father, who, in paying his son's bills and announcing that he has hired a girl for the boy to date so as to build up his ego, suggests just enough about the world at large to make "Asylum" seem a not unreasonable place to be."Asylum" opened yesterday at Film Forum, an unusual and very valuable little Upper West Side theater that shows its movies only on weekends.

title: IVERSON CARDS 71 FOR 2SHOT LEAD
description: BETTENDORF. I owa, Sept. 29 (AP)A tour sophomore, Don Iverson, matched par 71 in cold, blustery weather to day and established a two stroke lead after the second round of the $100,000 Quad Cities open tournament.

title: Election Assistant Named In Alleged VoteFraud Plot
description: An administrative assistant at the city's Board of Elections headquarters who is also a Democratic coleader in Man hattan with Hulan E. Jack was arrested and accused yesterday of conspiring to insert the names of persons who were not legally registered into voter registration files.

title: Four Northrup Hits Pace Rout of Brewers
description: DETROIT, Sept. 29  Billy Martin, a favorite target of secondguessers of both his strategic moves and nonmoves, had to do only one thing right tonightmake out his lineup card.

title: OUSTED INDIANS QUIT SAIGON, GO TO HANOI
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 29Expelled by the Sai gon Government, the Indian delegation to the International Control Commission left here today to establish headquarters in Hanoi.

title: LowKey Moves on 3 Fliers Ordered
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The White House has quietly passed the word to the rest of the Nixon Administrationin cluding Melvin It Laird, the Secretary of Defenseto take a lowkey approach to the three prisoners of war who returned to the United States last night.

title: Russian, Canadian Hockey Players Offer Vivid Contrasts
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29  Be hind the headlines of the unexpectedly hard  fought hockey series between the top professionals from Can ada and the Olympic cham pions from the Soviet Union, which ended yesterday in a narrow victory for the Ca nadians, there is a remark able study in cultural con trasts that points up the vastly different treatment of sports in East and West.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Sept. 29 (UPI)The Tokyo stock market hit a record high today with the signing of the agreement to establish JapaneseChinese diplomatic relations.

title: Baby Whale at Aquarium Shows Signs of Improving
description: An ailing baby whale showed signs of improving yesterday by leaping like a porpoise in a pool at the New York Aquarium, but officials still believe the chances of the whale's surviv ing are slim.

title: 3,000 ATTEND PARTY FOR BLOOMINGDALE'S
description: Three thousand people waltz ed and polkaed to an old fashioned German band last night at an indoor block party in honor of the 100th anniver sary of Bloomingdale's depart ment store.

title: Kentucky Derby Purse For '68 Redistributed
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30 (AP)Dancer's Image, the big colt who streaked to victory in the 1968 Kentucky Derby, officially lost his purse today to the runnerup, Forward Pass.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Democratic Representatives from New York City ex tracted a promise this week for the appointment of an ombudsman in the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare's office for civil rights to hear complaints of abuses in the Government's program for equal job opportunities in the nation's colleges and uni versities. It was an effort by the New York members of Con gress, who do not often agree on too many things, to wade into the sensitive problem of alleged quotas and reverse discrimination in the admin istration of the Government's socalled affirmative action program on nondiscrimina tion in hiring, promotion and dismissals required of nearly all Federal contractors.

title: SENATE VOTE BARS CUTS IN WELFARE AS PENSIONS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Senate voted today to in sure the aged, blind and disabled against cuts in welfare pay ments due to the recent 20 per cent increase in Social Security benefits, to be mailed out next week.
